I cut my earliest political and social teeth during the latter Vietnam and Watergate years.
column2: Wrestling with those reliable old Russians - and arguing with the North Vietnamese - was Henry Kissinger.&nbsp
column3: He cut an amazingly long shadow for a guy the size of Golem and his occasional commentaries today are still run in major publications.

column1: But I was taken aback recently to realize that Henry was secretly giving me lessons in disciplining future children during all those years.
column2: Henry pursued diplomatic strategies that are actually usable with the kids, especially when they're being particularly recalcitrant.&nbsp
column3: I now ask myself, <em>what would Henry do?&nbsp
column4: Here are three of his favorites that I regularly employ.

column2: This trite little phrase was used by Henry to highlight his plan for dealing with the Soviet Union about missile reduction.
column3: It's also effective in teaching little kids about truth-telling.

column1: Women and society say that families need engaged fathers who actively participate in their family life.
column2: But men are apparently caught in the trap of&nbsp
column3: trying to make that happen with few, if any, guides on how to how to pull it off.&nbsp

column1: A recent study released by the Council on Contemporary Families finds that the amount of family-oriented work (housework/childcare) performed by men increased significantly over the past 40 years.
column2: Men doubled their housework contribution from 15 to 30% - not where most wives want it, but a significant change - and tripled their time spent on actual childcare.&nbsp

column1: Despite the positive results shown in the study, fathers are hamstrung by a public perception as a borderline idiot.
column2: This is even demonstrated in the AP article about the study:
&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column12: ""The average dad has gradually been getting better about picking himself up off the sofa and pitching in, according to a new report in which a psychologist suggests the payoff for doing more chores could be more sex.""

column1: And nowhere in the AP article is sex even mentioned.
Granted, most guys don't frequent the family section of your neighborhood bookstore, but there is a huge imbalance between resources available for mothers and those available for fathers.
column2: A brief review of the Barnes/Noble magazine rack showed&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: magazines for mothers with none for fathers.&nbsp
column7: And a like inspection of the family section shows an imbalance as well.

column1: The public image of the father has also taken a drastic hit in the preceding 30 years.
column2: &nbsp
column3: Starting with Archie Bunker, the typical media father is a loudmouthed, (c)rude, boor who doesn't know how to relate to his family, even if he is a closet sentimentalist.&nbsp
column4: There is the occasional Reverend Camden from 7th Heaven, but he's offset by Al Bundy, Homer Simpson and Peter Griffin.

column1: If you want men to take an even greater role in their family's life, try giving them the resources and public support that they need.
column2:
Please, throw them a frickin' bone, huh?

Food, this is Junior.&nbsp
column3: Knock yourself out, kid.&nbsp

column1: Introducing your baby to solid foods involves more thought and planning than just tossing a diced Italian sub on the high chair.
column2: It is a months-long process in which the child learns how to eat solid foods and you learn what foods he can't tolerate.&nbsp
column3: Surprisingly, one of your best tools here is a pencil and notebook or calendar as you monitor what he eats and how he responds to it.&nbsp
column4: You are, in a sense, controlling the variables in something akin to a science project.&nbsp

column1: Why Do I Have to Do This?
The body can be allergic to certain types of food and react in a number of unpleasant ways to them.
column2: The reaction severity can range from mild skin rashes to diarrhea to breathing problems requiring a full-blown 911 call, although this last is a rare possibility.&nbsp
column3: Foods which most commonly cause allergic reactions are milk (lactose intolerance), peanuts, wheat products (gluten intolerance) and shellfish.
column4: Physicians will advise you to hold off on those items until later.

column1: You introduce one particular food at a time so that you can monitor the effect of each on your child and if there is a reaction, note that food as allergenic.
How Do I Know that He's Ready for Solid Foods?
From birth, Junior will be taking either breast milk or formula and he will continue to do so even after even starting solid foods.
column2: It is a weaning process which commences when:
&nbsp

column4: &nbsp

column6: &nbsp

column2: &nbsp

column2: &nbsp

column7: He wants the pretzel that you're munching while you're reading this.

column1: â€¨This can occur anywhere from 4 to 6 months of age and when these happen, you can take it as a sign that he's ready to go.
An allergic reaction to a particular food is typically noticeable within several seconds to several minutes, although it could occur within several hours afterwards.
column2: Here are symptoms that might appear:
&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: Reddened or flushed skin, hives or itching

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Diarrhea, upset stomach/vomiting

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Sniffles/running nose (aka the Green Elevens), congestion, sneezing or difficulty breathing

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Anaphylaxis, a condition in which the throat and airways start swelling and lead to breathing problems.&nbsp
column8: If you suspect anaphylaxis, immediately contact your physician or 911.

column1: There are some foods that physicians and dietitians advise you to stay away from until the child is older.
column2: These are:
&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: Milk and dairy products until about one year of age

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Eggs and egg products until about two years of age

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Peanuts, other nuts, fish/shellfish and honey until about three years of age.

column1: Ask yourself and your mate if there is any family history of food allergies and if so, share that with your physician.
column2: She will recommend that these particular foods not be introduced until late in the hopes of keeping your child from developing sensitivity to that food.

column1: When he has reached the solids threshold, start with a single helping of rice cereal one a day.
column2: The rice cereal is free of gluten, a protein found in wheat and a potentially allergenic substance.&nbsp
column3: Mix the dry cereal, available in the grocery's Baby Food section, with a small amount of formula, breast milk or warm water.&nbsp
column4: Then feed it with a rubber tipped spoon to protect your child's gums.&nbsp
column5: Continue the feeding until he lets you know he's done by turning his head away or pushing on the spoon.&nbsp
column6: One of my children was notable for a particular ""get that crap out of my face"" look.&nbsp
column7: You'll increase the number of feedings - up to three - each day as the weeks continue until he is taking cereal with every feeding
column8: once regular food is established, you can stop the cereal.

column1: After several days of cereal, you can start with a highly strained vegetable.
column2: Again, try it for about three to five days to see if there is any allergic reaction and if none is found, note it as okay and move onto another food.&nbsp
column3: After each new food has been tried and found to be okay, it can become one of the stable of acceptable foods for meals so that there are additional choices for meals.&nbsp
column4: If there is a problem, you can link it to the new food being tried.

column1: There is no set way of determining what food to introduce when but you might want to consider starting with some green vegetables instead of fruits and sweet potato.
column2: Some kids get hooked on the sweet flavor early and then snub the plainer foods.&nbsp
column3: Since your memory can suffer from the pace and confusion of caring for a baby, be sure to use the calendar or pad for brief notes so that you can keep things straight.

column1: As the first year passes, you can start shifting from strained to solid foods.
column2: You
column3: >must cut the solid foods into very small pieces so that the child doesn't choke as he eats.
column4: His esophagus is very small and there is a choking hazard.
column5: By the end of the first year, he can be off of breast milk/formula at meals as well as the rice cereal.&nbsp
column6: A typical lunch for my kids at this point consisted of finely diced meat (hot dog, for instance), grapes sliced into quarters and carrots microwaved for softness (but then cooled before serving).

column1: Remember that even as he takes in more solid foods, he may still need breast milk or formula until he's about one year of age.
column2: The general format of a meal in the latter part of his first year would be a small amount of formula or breast milk, followed by cereal and topped off with the food.&nbsp
column3: As a practical note for Dads, check with the new Mom before you introduce a new type of solid food since it can be a memorable event.&nbsp
column4: I was frankly ticked off to return from a restroom to the restaurant table to find that eldest had had her first bite of solid food while I was away.

column1: Even if science wasn't your best subject, keeping things consistent is the key.
column2:
Remember that and you should have no problem.

column1: You experience abject fear and relentless guilt.
The former grabs you when you realize that your kid has swallowed or drunk something potentially dangerous.
column2: What is it?&nbsp
column3: When did this happen?&nbsp
column4: Could she die?

column2: How could I be such a god-forsaken, ignorant, lazy fool for letting this happen?
Who do I call?&nbsp
column3: 911?&nbsp
column4: Not necessarily, because the people that they'll call are at a regional Poison Control Center.

column1: As a parent, your first introduction to them is probably through the bright green ""Mr. Yuk"" stickers that came from your pediatrician or maternity ward.
column2: And if you're paying attention - and fortunate - that will be your last

column1: Created to provide toxicology information for medical emergencies, there are more than 60 Poison Control Centers in the country and each is responsible for a particular region.
column2: Each is staffed by trained specialists, frequently nurses or pharmacists, and has access to a computerized database of natural and toxicological substances.&nbsp
column3: It is surprising that there is no automatic government funding for these Centers.&nbsp
column4: Each must obtain its individual funding separately through applications for federal and state grants, medical center affiliations and individual donations.

column1: What You Need to Know About Poisons and Your Child
Trust me, a poisoning event - either through chemical or natural substances - can happen to your child.
column2: It's happened to my family twice in 13 years.

column1: First, there is only one phone number for all the Centers and it isn't 911.
column2: Mark this:
&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column1: Several years ago, the Centers adopted phone technology which reads the incoming area code and automatically routes the call to the appropriate Poison Control Center.
column2: While all have the same toxicology information available, each has a better grasp of what local hospitals and resources are available in their particular region.

column1: According to Dr. Allison Muller, Clinical Director of the Poison Control Center at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, her center alone averages 80,000 exposure calls annually for the region of Delaware and Eastern Pennsylvania.
column2: In her experience at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, there are three key things for parents to understand.

column1: First, do not underestimate the speed and resourcefulness of your small child.
column2: A toddler is eminently able to reach high places and enter remote cabinets when he puts his mind to it.&nbsp
column3: Having all of the prescriptions and other medications in a separate cabinet simply isn't sufficient.

column1: Second, even a child-proof/resistant cap can be beaten and might only provide a few minutes of difficulty before your child is into it.
column2: Knowing these facts, Dr. Muller keeps her home medicines stored in a locked toolbox.

column1: Third, keep all liquids in their original marked containers and don't store excess of refills in other containers.
column2: Dr. Muller cited a call in which a toddler was unwittingly served dilute windshield washer fluid as a snack drink when it was stored in a juice bottle and inadvertently placed in the refrigerator.&nbsp
column3: The child fortunately survived.

column1: So What Should You Expect When You Call Poison Control?
Most bottle warnings tell you to either contact your physician or Poison Control if the contents are ingested.
column2: According to Dr. Muller, a Doctor of Pharmacy and toxicologist, the first call should be to the Poison Control Center as time is essential and you're already there with the bottle or material.&nbsp
column3: If however, you believe that immediate medical attention is required, call 911.

column1: You can expect such questions as your child's age and condition at the moment, what was ingested, when it was ingested and how much was ingested.
column2: Dr. Muller outlined a scenario for a child who drank from an adult formula Dimetapp bottle.
How much did she drink?
I don't know.
Okay, what's the size of the bottle?&nbsp
column3: How much does it contain at purchase?

column2: The label says 4 ounces.
How much is in the bottle now?
Umm, maybe a third?
Alright then, how much was in it to begin with?
I don't know.&nbsp
column3: I'm not sure.

column2: I want you to add a teaspoon of water to the bottle - count the number that it takes - to bring the level back to where you thought it was.
(After a pause) Five teaspoons.

column1: With this, the specialist can estimate how much the child drank and outline whatever course of action is appropriate.
column2: If you're directed to a physician or hospital, be sure to take along the bottle for the staff to review.

column1: Practical Home Tips for Kids and Poison Safety

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Keep all medications secured in a locked place.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp

column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Keep all liquids in their original containers.

column12: If you move into a new home and have small children, identify what's planted in your yard.&nbsp
column13: I removed a vine plant growing from under a corner bush after a neighbor identified it as Nightshade.

column9: your kids only use paints marked as non-toxic and keep them separate from adult paints.&nbsp
column10: Keep model-kit paints (oil-based) and supplies in a separate box from other children's art supplies.

column7: If you're using cleaning supplies and are called away to the door or phone, take your child with you or gate them away from the supplies.&nbsp

What Do You Do With a Crying Baby?
Probably the greatest dread of a new Dad is - dah dah duh - the crying baby.
column2: Remember that this is equally daunting to Mom at first, but she's expected to know what to do about it and has plenty of resources available to her.&nbsp
column3: So here are some things that you should know about crying babies and what you can do for them.

column1: Understand first that a baby will pretty much cry about everything because that is the only way that they have to communicate with you.
column2: Whatever the reason, they can't tap you on the leg and say ""Yo Dad"", so they'll cry instead.&nbsp
column3: Think of it as a jarring, frustrating translation game.&nbsp
column4: Not all cries are necessarily the same and if you pay attention, you'll start to recognize what each one means to her.

column2: Start by developing a checklist of possible complaints to consider.&nbsp

column3: &nbsp

column8: She wants fed and if she's having a growth spurt, her typical schedule will be thrown off.
column9: If she was just fed, then move to the next item on your checklist but if it's been awhile, then consider this one.&nbsp
column10: What is an indicator that she's hungry?&nbsp
column11: Gently rub the clean tip of your finger against her lower lip and see how she responds
column12: if she opens her mouth and moves to latch onto it as though it's a nipple, then it's probably hunger.&nbsp
column13: If she doesn't respond to that, then it's time to move on.

column1: A baby who cries a lot doesn't necessarily have colic.
column2: A ""colicky"" baby is one which cries for several hours each day, several days a week and the crying will generally happen at the same time - typically late afternoon or early evening.&nbsp
column3: It can start as early as four weeks of age and last until the child is about 16 weeks, which makes for the longest three months of your natural life.&nbsp
column4: There are multiple reasons for colic, including chronic gas and abdominal distension, and any one of these can wreak havoc.

I know that it can make you nuts since there were nights that I didn't think that I would ever sleep again.

Okay guys, you now have sole custody of the kid while your other half takes some time to run errands or kibbitz with her friends.

column1: What on God's green earth am I going to do with this little kid for that long?
column2: This is my chance to show that I do have a clue so just tossing him in the crib or in front of the TV isn't really an option here.
Babies and small children won't need things done at precisely the exact moment, but they really do best if kept on a fairly predictable routine.&nbsp
column3: Creating a simple thumbnail schedule is a place to start.&nbsp
column4: Does Junior take naps, and is your timeframe with Junior in that nap period?&nbsp

column9: If so, jot it onto the schedule and then determine what Junior's going to eat and how long it might take to prepare.&nbsp
column10: By the way, I have kids of both genders but I'm using&quot

column2: Here are a few basic rules before getting on with the good stuff.
Remember that perhaps the most important thing that your child needs is interaction.
column3: He will have to learn to occupy himself at times, but his needs - cognitive, emotional and physical - and his ability to cope with the world are dramatically improved by regular interaction with you and Mom.&nbsp
column4: Yes, love is absolutely a given here but let's be honest, there are a lot of folks around who love their kids but don't spend enough time with them.

column1: This is your time, take advantage of it.

column2: A little TV is okay, but only in limited doses and only certain programs.&nbsp
column3: TV might be an option while you fix a snack/meal, or tend to a few quick chores
column4: but it cannot and must not become a staple.&nbsp
column5: Spending the afternoon in the woodshop while Junior watches the idiot box is not the right idea.

column2: You have a little leeway if Junior isn't crawling yet, but you are still going to have to pay attention to where he is and especially what is withing his reach.
column3: If he can reach it, it's going in his mouth faster than a cop with a doughnut.

column2: Now what can I do with Junior?
column3: Try these for size.

column2: Even if he's a baby, hearing the use of language will give him a leg up on his own verbal skills.&nbsp
column3: When we lived in DC some years ago, the only way to get my regular dose of Michael Wilbon and Tony Kornheiser was to read aloud to the baby while she lay next to me on the floor.&nbsp
column4: If he's older, cardboard page books are great: they are written for the youngest levels and he can work on his motor skills by helping to turn pages without the worry of tearing them.

column3: It isn't the melody and God knows not the singing, but the voice, language and rhythm that are important for the kid.

column1: Get down on the floor with him.
column2: Play Peek-a-boo and lift him over your head.&nbsp
column3: Wrestle.&nbsp
column4: If he can sit up, spend time rolling a ball back and forth.&nbsp
column5: Give him piggyback or bear rides.&nbsp
column6: Build block towers and let him knock them down, but don't get invested in creating masterpieces that you won't allow to be destroyed.&nbsp
column7: It might get monotonous, but it matters to him and believe it or not, this is part of your job as a parent.&nbsp
column8: And not all jobs are exciting.

column2: If the weather isn't bad, toss him into a backpack, stroller or wagon and go for a walk.
This doesn't have to be rocket science and God knows I'm not Martha Stewart.&nbsp
column3: Use your imagination.&nbsp
column4: One neighbor spent an afternoon making more than a dozen light sabers out of rolled-up newspapers, water bottles and duct tape.&nbsp
column5: Make a space helmet from construction paper and a 24 pack soda case.&nbsp
column6: Sometimes the simplest and goofiest looking stuff is the most memorable.

column2: You can use them to practice counting, teach him the difference between colors and shapes, or if he's older, teach basic math skills by playing War.

column1: Build a fort. If you have boxes, pull them out and let Junior climb in and through. Or just throw a blanket over the dining room/kitchen table to create a clubhouse.

column1: Teach cause-and-effect. If your child touches you, move something else. Touching a left cheek means a lifted left eyebrow or poking a lower lip rewards him with a wink. Have fun with it.
No matter what you do here, remember that the key is interaction. This benefits him immensely, as well as you with stronger bonds.
And one other note. If you have to leave the room for any period of time - regardless of the length - make sure that he is back in his crib or playpen. This requirement will diminish as he grows, but

It's finally time to start brushing your daughter's teeth.
column2: You've been using a damp gauzepad to wipe her teeth and gums and she now has enough teeth to justify using a small, soft-bristled brush.

column1: And if you're like me, the question is...now what?
column2: How long until she can brush for herself?&nbsp
column3: When can she start doing it without my being there?&nbsp
column4: Just how long should each brushing session be?&nbsp
column5: When can we start flossing?

column1: How long until she can brush for herself?
There's no hard and fast answer for this question, unfortunately, and depends upon the parents' judgment.
column2: It can depend upon how well she can hold a brush and how thorough - and her thorough differs from your thorough - she appears to be in brushing.
column3: You might consider doing it simultaneously and then letting her finish, or vice versa.&nbsp
column4: It will simply depend upon your comfort level.&nbsp
column5: But this leads to the next question.

column1: How long do I have to be there while she brushes?
This is going to be for a long time.
column2: My dentist's hygienists asked me if I was there for my kids' brushing, even when they were five years of age.&nbsp
column3: It's only by being there that you can determine how she's doing and correct anything that she might be doing wrong.&nbsp
column4: And it's only by being there that you can develop that comfort level.

column1: When we brush, how long should we brush?
A simple way to track how long you should brush is to hum "
column2: The Birthday Song&quot
column3: twice through.&nbsp
column4: Make it a standing tradition to hum the tune and then when she's old enough to hum it, have her do it for you since you love to hear her hum it sooooo much.&nbsp
column5: It consequently becomes an ingrained habit.&nbsp
column6: Others have simply used an egg-timer set to two minutes.&nbsp
column7: Enterprising toothpaste manufacturers even now have a musical cap that plays a melody once the cap opens and the child brushes while the music plays.&nbsp
column8: Just bear in mind that with this method, your daughter should be old enough to swish and spit.&nbsp
column9: Or simply create your own song to accompany the act.&nbsp

column1: Flossing can also start very early, but you'll have to do it at first.
column2: To ease the job, your dentist can provide a small flossing device that resembles a tiny bow - as in arrow.&nbsp
column3: The floss is strung between two ends of bent plastic and it can easily be held and manipulated by small fingers.&nbsp
column4: There is no difference between when a child and an adult should floss.

What else can you do with a very small child? If nothing else appeals, just talk. You're doing far more good than you might expect.

According to a childhood language study from UNC's FPG Child Development Institute, the language skills of three year-olds were examined. This study measured their verbal abilities in light of parent education, child care quality and finally, how the parents verbally interacted with them. The surprising finding was the impact of the father's vocabulary on their language skills
column2: two year-olds with fathers using a wider vocabulary scored significantly higher on tests given when they were three. This impact even outweighed the vocabulary of the mothers, who were found on tape to talk with them more frequently than the dads.

column1: So what does this mean? Even at the earliest ages, talk to your child. Let her hear the rhythm of your speech and tone of your voice, and as she ages, expand the vocabulary. Describe things to her and talk to her about what she's holding. Read to her - a lot - and even if she can't yet speak, ask if she can point things out in the book. When she's started speaking, ask specific and simple questions (what's floating in the sky?) and then ask more open-ended, general questions as she progresses (what does that cloud remind you of?). Just keep talking and working with her.

But remember, the key to the kingdom is a wider vocabulary. Save the different meanings of ""dude"" for your buddies.

While most guys are only unfamiliar with the medical development and needs of their kid, they are utterly lost about their kid's mouth.
column2: This is the child's business end since the dollar cost of not caring for it properly can be huge.&nbsp
column3: Dollars aside, the child can become very insecure and embarrassed by their mouth's condition as they age.

column1: Over the next 20 or so years, your child - who we'll call Ramona - will first gain a full set of 20 baby (also called primary) teeth.
column2: These will last until they are finally replaced by the adult complement of 32 teeth.&nbsp
column3: You will probably start to see the first tooth &quot
column4: erupt&quot
column5: at several months of age in the front of the mouth.&nbsp
column6: These are the incisors and they will later be flanked by the canines.&nbsp
column7: This process continues until all 20 teeth have arrived at about two years of age.&nbsp
column8: They will then remain intact until the first adult teeth start arriving at roughly six years of age.&nbsp
column9: Something which confuses most parents is the arrival of the six year molars, located immediately behind the primary molars.&nbsp
column11: replace the original primary molars, so their arrival isn't preceded by the loss of any primary teeth.

column1: You can expect that the first teeth lost will be the lower incisors (front teeth) at age six, followed by the upper incisors.
column2: Molars and canine teeth are generally not lost until 10 - 12 years of age.&nbsp
column3: From the loss of the incisors, you then have several years in which to arrange financing for the coming orthodontia.

column1: What is Teething, and How Many Buckets Will I Need?
Teething is the time when Ramona gains a new tooth and covers the period from its approach to the gum from below to its final arrival.
column2: You'll hear the term erupt to describe when the gum is breached
column3: this is a misnomer penned by some sadist to induce you to hold out hope for some uninterrupted sleep.&nbsp
column4: You'll know Ramona's teething by:

column1: <li>increasing amounts of drool, as though this were possible
<li>a marked desire to chew and gnaw

column2: Welcome to Extreme Nursing.

column1: If you suspect that she has started teething, look in her mouth and you'll find the gums inflamed.
column2: An arriving tooth will also physically appear to be pushing through the gum as though a finger were pushing through a balloon.

column1: You can help relieve Ramona's pain - and it does hurt - by giving her a cold teething ring, available at any grocery or pharmacy.
column2: You can give her a cold, damp washcloth to suck on, or even your <u>clean</u> finger.&nbsp
column3: Only consider using any form of pain reliever, like infant acetaminophen, after speaking with your doctor.&nbsp
column4: Oh, and remember to wipe the drool from her face or you'll add insult to injury by allowing a rash to develop on her face.

column1: How Do I Care for My Child's Teeth?
Start mouthcare long before the first teeth arrive.
column2: After feeding, whether breastmilk or formula, use a clean and damp gauzepad or cloth to wipe the gums.&nbsp
column3: This removes bacteria from the food and also gets Ramona used to the practice of doing something to keep her mouth healthy.

column1: Because a toothbrush might cause undue distress to the baby with only a few teeth, continue to use a clean, damp washcloth to wipe the teeth.
column2: When you do decide to move to a toothbrush, get one with soft bristles on a small head so as not to irritate the gums and create even more unnecessary problems.&nbsp
column3: Replace the brush every four months and also after any time that Ramona's been sick.&nbsp
column4: Even after you start brushing her teeth, toothpaste shouldn't be introduced until the third birthday when she has a clue about how to spit.&nbsp
column5: Even then, use a non-flouridated training toothpaste
column6: she's still going to swallow a fair amount of paste and the flouride can upset her stomach as well as potentially cause flourosis.&nbsp
column7: This condition will eventually show itself by a discoloration to the permanent teeth.&nbsp
column8: The training toothpaste&nbsp
column9: is available in the baby section of any grocery or pharmacy and be sure that it's approved by the American Dental Association.

column2: Now you have a reason to teach your little girl to spit.

column1: When Should My Child See the Dentist?
Today's rule of thumb is that Ramona should see the dentist at about her first birthday, something endorsed by both the ADA and the American Academy of Pediatric Dentistry.
column2: It might seem overprotective, but the dentist can advise on how you're doing with mouthcare and see if the mouth and teeth provide insights into future problems.

column1: These early visits would encompass an examination of her mouth and teeth, as well as what to expect with the sequence of eruptions.
column2: The dentist can also advise you on childhood habits such as thumbsucking and pacifiers, as well as the use of sippy cups and bottles.&nbsp
column3: Excessive use of these cups with juice has led to a major rise in early childhood cavities, which is not something that you want.&nbsp
column4: Because not all water sources are created equal, you can also consider whether to supplement the flouride available to Ramona to forestall later teeth problems.

column1: For additional information, visit the website of the American Academy of Pediatric Dentistry at www.aapd.org
Many Thanks to Dr. Maria Meliton for her review and comments to this article.
column2: You can visit Dr. Meliton's website at www.pediatricdentist.com

When you have a cavity, you go to the dentist and have it filled - some novacaine, an hour and around $160.
column2: Then you leave&nbsp
column3: knowing there's another appointment in six months.&nbsp
column4: For a small child, cavities aren't that simple.&nbsp
column5: Let's examine why in a&nbsp
column6: not too far-fetched&nbsp
column7: scenario.

column1: Ralphie is four years old and an exam with the family dentist finds three cavities, two on the upper level on either side of the mouth and one down below.
column2: Because she doesn't feel comfortable doing significant repair in a small child's mouth, she refers you to a pediatric dentist.&nbsp
column3: A pediatric dentist specializes in children and understands that a scary experience can have huge repercussions later on.

column1: The pediatric dentist's judgment is to remove the teeth due to the severity of the cavities.
column2: These aren't little pinhole cavities, but large and discolored pits that crater the center of each tooth.&nbsp
column3: Since Ralphie could wind up traumatized from the stress of having multiple shots and devices in his mouth, she suggests that it be done on an outpatient basis and under a light anesthesia.&nbsp
column4: She also suggests&nbsp
column5: coating the teeth with a thin veneer to help prevent further decay.&nbsp
column6: You've now gone to two dentists and are looking at outpatient surgery.

column1: After the teeth are removed and the veneer applied, you're going to spend the better part of that day and the next with a groggy and
column2: sore preschooler.&nbsp
column3: Ralphie is utterly miserable, which means that you'll be too.&nbsp
column4: You've missed that time from work and incurred outpatient surgery charges&nbsp
column5: dwarfing your adult dental costs.

column2: Ralphie now has gaps in&nbsp
column3: his mouth from three missing teeth.&nbsp
column4: A small child's mouth is not immobile.&nbsp
column5: It is dynamic and the teeth can shift like the North&nbsp
column6: American tectonic plate.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: Like a teenager that expands to occupy any free space on a couch, Ralphie's teeth will start to move to&nbsp
column9: allow themselves more room in this newly vacant area.&nbsp
column10: Because Ralphie's mouth will be gradulally increasing from 20 baby teeth to 32 adult teeth, there are other teeth coming that might not be able to grow into Ralphie's mouth because they are blocked by those free-loading baby teeth.&nbsp
column12: Then you have to consider additional surgery down&nbsp
column14: The pediatric dentist wants to forestall that chance by now referring you to an orthodontist.

column1: If a parent isn't scared by the thought of an orthodontist, it's only because he is one.
The orthodontist can handle this particular problem by inserting little devices into the gaps called
column2: spacers.
column3: These are metal bands - fortunately not heavy - that wrap around&nbsp
column4: the teeth adjoining each space in order to maintain the empty&nbsp
column5: space.&nbsp
column6: Because the bands are attached to the teeth, they&nbsp
column7: will remain there until&nbsp
column8: those teeth come out.
column9: And by the way, Ralphie can&nbsp
column10: no longer have chewy candies like Tootsie Rolls, licorice or gum due to the risk of displacing&nbsp
column13: case you're back to the orthodontist.

column2: may read like a&nbsp
column3: worst-case scenario and other&nbsp
column4: cases aren't so severe.&nbsp
column5: Yet it highlights that the&nbsp
column6: changing space needs of the mouth, and the effect on the child's psyche&nbsp
column7: will involve more than would occur with&nbsp
column8: you or Mom.&nbsp

column2: the next&nbsp
column3: dental visit&nbsp
column4: isn't an experience this side of hell, then it's a testament to the manner and&nbsp
column5: care of the pediatric dentist.

column1: Be sure to let her know it.

column1: Will your trip cause your credit card usage to vary from its norm?
Card issuers have fraud units that will suspend the card if it encounters usage that is different from the norm.
column2: Several years ago, my issuer contacted me about a purchase to my account in Australia when I was nowhere near that hemisphere, preventing a bigger problem.&nbsp
column3: Consequently, I advised them of a recent upcoming trip to Canada so that their system wouldn't start bouncing back any charges that I might be making.&nbsp
column4: I also gave them my cell phone number if they noted other problems.

column1: Do you need to pack the full load of disposable baby supplies or can you restock at the nearest store?

column2: kind of crib does the hotel have for use?

column1: Not all cribs are created equal and some otherwise fine facilities will present you with a crib that hasn't seen a baby since it held Little Ricky Ricardo in a 1952 episode of I Love Lucy.
column2: It might be worth your while to just tote along the Pack-and-Play but why do that if the hotel already has one for you to use?&nbsp
column3: Save that car space for something else.

column1: Have you left a contact number with family or friends in the event of a problem?
Cell phone coverage isn't universal and cell phone batteries die, or the phones are lost.
column2: You'd hate to come back from Wallyworld to find that they'd planted your mother-in-law in your absence.

column1: If you're travelling with school-age children, is this trip causing them to miss school?
column2: If so, what paperwork must be completed for the school system prior to departure?

column1: With the passage of the No Child Left Behind legislation, schools are sensitive about kids missing for family vacations
column2: one of the criteria for successfully meeting the requirements is cumulative attendance of 90%.&nbsp
column3: Consequently, almost all schools have guidelines about requirements before and after the trip for it to be counted as an approved absence.&nbsp
column4: On top of the obligatory homework, there might be age-appropriate extra work, such as a journal that asks questions of the student:&nbsp
column5: <em>What kind of clouds did you see on the airplane?&nbsp
column6: What was your favorite activity of the trip?&nbsp
column7: How many hours of Cartoon Network did you see each morning?

column1: What identification/safety measures do you have in the event of a missing child?
column2: How do you keep tabs on the kid(s)?

column1: Companies that do student pictures will now include an identification card with the photos.
column2: A copy of this in your wallet is invaluable when you travel.&nbsp
column3: You can also get child fingerprint identification kits and keep the cards in the dash or suitcase - and pray you don't need those.

column2: uniforms&quot
column3: , or outfits that all the children wear when travelling or for visiting a park or museum.&nbsp
column4: Nothing fancy, but simple bright cotton shirts of the same color so that they are easy to distinguish in a&nbsp
column5: crowd.&nbsp
column6: Likewise, it's helpful to wear something that your child can easily spot.&nbsp
column7: More than one child has come up to hug my leg to discover that I'm the wrong daddy, so I usually travel with a brightly colored baseball cap when at the airport or in crowded areas.

column1: It might seem to be a lot to cover, but remember that you're now thinking for three.
column2: And a little preparation can help keep it a vacation and not an ordeal.

If you've taken small children on airline flights, you understand that one of the constant complaints is the nagging ear pain from the changes in pressure.
column2: Our early solutions used the obligatory movement of the jaw and pretend yawning.&nbsp
column3: We met folks who would magically produce juice boxes early in the flight so that the sucking on the straw and swallowing would help alleviate the discomfort.&nbsp
column4: This was made moot with the banning of liquids on flights.

column1: While on a flight with a bothered toddler, the flight attendant directed me off of the plane during a layover.
column2: She sent me on a run to a candy kiosk for a unique solution.&nbsp
column3: She &quot
column4: suggested&quot
column5: that I purchase a bag of sour fruit-flavored gummy worms and bring them for the child.&nbsp
column6: According to the attendant, the sour flavor promotes salivation&nbsp
column7: - and swallowing - while the chewing helps clear the child's Eustachian Tube.&nbsp
column8: It's this tube which links the back of the throat/nose and the middle ear, and clearing it equalizes the middle ear pressure with the ambient pressure.&nbsp
column9: This approach worked brilliantly and the subsequent flights have been problem-free.

column2:
I wonder if a Snickers bar quells air-sickness?

to have children bickering is the family car.&nbsp
column3: You're stuck behind the wheel as the kids whine, accuse, pick, poke and annoy one&nbsp
column4: another - and you.&nbsp
column5: In many instances, this is caused by the kids feuding over who gets to sit in what spot.&nbsp
column6: It might be who gets to sit shotgun or in our case, who gets to sit by the automatically-closing minivan door.

column1: You could hit a storefront for the distraction it causes, so you have to figure out some workable, consistent and verifiable solution for the problem.
My favorite was created by a Practical Dad for his quarreling kids.
He ran an older vehicle without front passenger airbags, so the kids could sit shotgun.
column2: But who's turn was it?&nbsp

column4: And you forgot that I didn't get to sit there last week when we went to the mall, didn't you?&nbsp
column5: Huh?&nbsp
column6: Huh?&nbsp
column7: Dintja???

column1: Bill's a precise guy with an affinity for building and creating.
column2: He stole a page from Isosceles and created a triangle from thick cardboard, reinforced along the edges by heavy tape.&nbsp
column3: Each corner was then labeled with the name of one of his three children.&nbsp
column4: He kept the device inserted into an easily visible seam on his dashboard and when he had the children in his vehicle, he shifted the triangle so that the name of the shotgun child was on top, towards the ceiling.&nbsp
column5: He kept it in that position and when the next trip came along, shifted it to show the next child's turn in the seat.&nbsp
column6: He used this device faithfully until he was able to retire it.

column1:
But kids being kids, it might still come in handy.

column4: Years before our first child, we visited with friends who were new parents.&nbsp

column6: nah, he just eats and mostly sleeps.&nbsp

column1: Remember that these are averages and yours just might be different.
column2: One of my kids only napped for an hour at a time during the first year, while an acquaintance's&nbsp
column3: son would sleep for three hours at a pop.

column1: Near the end of each age level, the shift will begin to occur.
column2: The morning nap will naturally shorten until she stays awake
column3: the next day, she might again act as though she's ready to conk out and the day afterwards, not conk out.&nbsp
column4: This is a natural transition until you're clear the next level has been reached.&nbsp
column5: There is no absolutely certain sign that she's dropping a nap or changing her sleep schedule.&nbsp
column6: The real adjustment that you need to make during this period is to be ready to feed her earlier so as to move up the afternoon nap.

column1: Why does a child need to nap?
Your daughter is growing at a phenomenal rate and her body is consuming energy and fuel at a massive clip, kind of like Mainland China.
column2: Even with a decent night's sleep and a solid diet, her body's capacity to cope will diminish unless she can get more rest.&nbsp
column3: The naps will lessen as she develops a better nighttime sleep pattern, but growth spurts and illness will place added burdens on her body and increase the need for a good nap.

column2: The Witching Hour&quot

column1: If you ask most homemaker parents about their least favorite time of the day, the response would probably be late afternoon, aka The Witching Hour.
column2: Even with naps, the kid's energy levels are waning as she wears out after the day and she'll likely need more attention just as you're trying to get dinner ready.&nbsp
column3: It is a good test of your ability to multi-task, even with a nap.&nbsp
column4: So how would it be if there were no nap at all?

column1: How do I know when my kid needs a nap?
Obvious signs of needing a nap are:
How do I put my kid down for a nap?

column2: There is no 100% Guaranteed way to successfully put a child down for a nap, so be patient until you get the hang of it.

column1: Kids do better with a routine as they find the familiarity comforting, so unless she utterly collapses on the floor from exhaustion - which occasionally happens - be prepared to spend some time in a daily ritual.
column2: This involves a period of quiet time to wind down from activity
column3: you can try a short book, perhaps followed by a hummed or sung lullaby.

column1: You ideally want her to fall asleep by herself instead of in your arms, so make it a practice of getting her to the crib - on her back - before she conks out.
column2: Whether or not she cries, be prepared to check on her every several minutes until she does sleep and don't panic if she does cry.&nbsp
column3: In that event, reassure her and step out again
column4: recognize though that persistent crying might be indicative of other problems and you should check for other issues.

Uphold your kid's mother.&nbsp
column3: Even when you're on the outs, uphold her to the kids.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: Although it's lesson #2, it's actually the hardest to put into practice, and especially if the marriage is over.&nbsp
column6: But it has to happen.

column1: Likewise, you should expect the same from the mother.
column2: Hear that, ladies?

column1: First, young kids aren't stupid and they'll see that marriages founder and families break up.
column2: Even if your marriage&nbsp
column3: is solid, snide remarks or complaints about your other half will cause concerns.&nbsp
column4: When my wife and I called the two eldest kids together to tell them of pregnancy #3, our daughter's first question on coming in was whether we were going to get a divorce.&nbsp
column5: Why?&nbsp
column6: A friend's parents had called her in similarly to tell her of their plan to end their marriage.&nbsp
column7: Growing up can be hard enough, don't make it unnecessarily harder.

column2: - deserve to be given respect by the other.&nbsp
column3: Kids will realize soon enough that the 'rents aren't perfect, and there's no need to hasten that along or magnify the existing imperfections.

column1: Third, and this feeds off of the second, kids are remarkably calculating.
column2: They inhabit a world of egocentrism that only later gives way to a larger view - if it does at all.&nbsp
column3: To denigrate Mom - especially if she's home with the kids - will only give them additional means to exploit any parental cracks for their own ends.&nbsp
column4: And this can only foster more problems for you, too.

column1: Finally, adulthood can exist in remarkable shades of gray.
column2: Unfortunately, children see in stark black and white.&nbsp
column3: They cannot comprehend the stresses and tensions that inhabit adult relationships and to expose them to such in any casual way is to potentially overwhelm them.&nbsp
column4: There's a difference between a careful, planned explanation and an impromptu remark or slam.

column1: There are difficult periods in any relationship, even if your mate is your best friend.
column2:
Don't create additional problems by losing your cool in a momentary pique.

It's a sunny and hot July morning in DC, when you understand why the English used to consider the British Embassy posting as a tropical assignment.
column2: The spouse has gone to work for the first time after her maternity leave and I'm&nbsp
column3: on my own after a weekend of cramming and preparation for my first time with the infant girl.&nbsp
column4: I've managed to feed and change her without dropping her on her head or setting fire to the crib.&nbsp
column5: She's been successfully tucked in for a nap - I hate the phrase &quot
column6: putting her down&quot
column7: as it sounds sinister - and when I descend the stairs, the swelling confidence is overcome by the clutter in the sink and the pile of laundry on the sofa.&nbsp
column8: And it's the first of many times that I'll ask myself:

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: What the hell do I do now?

column1: What can prepare a former corporate rat, a business/economics-degreed suit, for a life at home raising children?
column2: It's not like I took Home Economics - excuse me, it's Family and Consumer Science now, thank you - or even paid close attention when we visited with friends and their newborns.

column1: Fourteen years later, I understand that the business/economics curriculum is perhaps the best education for being a stay-at-home parent.
With the first child, you spend your time focusing on the concepts learned in Human Resource Management.
column2: As Maslow described it in his Hierarchy of Needs, you want your little prodigy to go beyond what you'll ever accomplish and attain the highest level of the hierarchy:&nbsp
column3: <em>self-actualization.&nbsp
column4: Even after an 'A' in the class, I'm still not certain what it means
column5: I do know that it sounds suspiciously like what some old-line Catholics consider a sin.

column1: Get out of there right now, Aloysius!
column2: Are you self-actualizing again?&nbsp
column3: Father Tim preached against that last month!

column1: Regardless, you work to assure that Junior can reach his full potential and astound the world.
column2: Who knows doing what.

column1: That perspective changes when the second child arrives and in a short period, you've begun to spend more time utilizing your Business Law background.
column2: Especially property rights.&nbsp
column3: And labor relations/negotiations.&nbsp
column4: Don't get me started on justice and fairness.

column1: Sharing and altruism might be innate in some children, but they require effort to cultivate.
column2: Even when you've convinced little Vincent that he has old toys that can go to &quot
column3: Sister Mary Margaret's Home for Destitute and Wayward Children&quot
column4: , if he sees little sister caressing a disemboweled, scabrous Teddy Bear, it will become the most beloved friend that he ever had.&nbsp
column5: And then there's:&nbsp

column2: You can't take that toy away from Hortense after letting her play with it for two weeks.&nbsp
column3: That's not sharing.&nbsp
column4: It's wrong and you're estopped from doing that.

column2: Highway Household&quot
column3: - so long as your feet are under my table, it's my way or the highway - so it's still grating to have children try to negotiate with you.&nbsp
column4: I understand that it's how they learn and test their limits, but cleaning your room is just something that you do.&nbsp

column1: Daddy, if I put away ALL of my toys, can I have a cookie?
column2: And if I really put them where they belong, can I have a 50% COLA in my allowance?
Clean your room before I put a 50% increase in your donation to Sister Mary Margaret's.&nbsp
column3: Got me?

column2: =3

column1: By now, you've moved onto the Operations Management portion of the curriculum.
column2: The daily schedule - especially with older children - becomes an exercise worthy of the &quot
column3: Traveling Salesman&quot
column4: problem.

column1: Hortense has a 3:45 Tuesday basketball practice at St Matilda's while Vincent has a 4:15 guitar practice across town at Mrs. Shyster's studio.
column2: Vincent will be done in a half-hour while Hortense has Brownies at 5:15 until 6:00, at which time Vincent has his soccer practice at the Fieldhouse.&nbsp
column3: Remember that the bus wouldn't even arrive at their stop until 3:40, so you're picking them up at school.&nbsp
column4: Being children, meaning that they sometimes can't find their tushies with both hands, you're obligated to pack the van with two sets of gym clothing, a guitar and sufficient books and toys for little Abner, who's begun to grow roots into the carseat.&nbsp
column5: Given the above, what's for dinner?&nbsp
column6: Extra credit is identifying what vegetables will be part of the meal.

column1: The flip side to Operations is Inventory Control.
column2: Cost Accounting teaches that there are various approaches to the control of a firm's inventory.

column1: FIFO (First In, First Out) - the kids' clothes are used regularly and the drawer contents are rotated to assure that Vincent and Hortense routinely wear all of their clothing.
LIFO (Last In, First Out) - the kids' clothes are managed such that the last items in the drawer are used first by Vincent and Hortense.
column2: The consequence is that some clothes are worn more than others and that really lovely outfit from Aunt Florence will see the light of day just when it gets dontated to Sister Mary Margaret's.

column1: JIT (Just In Time) - the inventory mechanism in which the daily wardrobe consists solely of what's available in the dryer that morning.
column2: It would&nbsp
column3: be easier to just move the dryer into Vincent's bedroom, but that would entail upgrading the outlet to 220.

column1: But although the focus changes with each new addition, you still make the effort to come back again and again to Maslow.
column2: And one more extra-credit question:&nbsp
column3:
Was Maslow Catholic?

A truly fun - and nervewracking - experience is watching your small child participate in a team sport for the first time.
column2: They've wanted to try it - hopefully - and you watch to see how they do.&nbsp
column3: The outdoor games, like soccer, are especially interesting since the budding star can get waylaid by low-flying planes, clouds and a particularly beautiful patch of dandelions.

column1: Unlike soccer however, in which the junior Beckham
column2: chases the speckled round ball, tee-ball is more challenging.&nbsp
column3: The player not only is trying to figure out how to catch and throw a ball, he must also try to remember where to stand while in the field.&nbsp
column4: Players routinely shift from 3rd to 2nd base as they meet to look for worms or congregate at the pitchers mound to see who can kick dirt the farthest.&nbsp
column5: Or they just don't remember where to stand.

column1: One Dad on my son's team solved the problem nicely.
column2: Junior kept veering away from first base or played in the basepath, oblivious to any runner.&nbsp
column3: Instead of constantly having to yell to gain his attention and then communicating the right position, Dad just walked over to 1st base between innings and scuffed a big circle in the dirt with the instructions to &quot
column4: remember your circle&quot
column5: .&nbsp
column6: And when Junior started to stray, Dad would yell &quot
column7: circle&quot
column8: and Junior returned like a faithful retriever.

column1: By the last game of the season, all of the players did a creditable job knowing where they had to be.
column2: And as we walked across the diamond after my son's last game, I looked down and noted a circle at every position.&nbsp
column3: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column2: forest for the trees&quot
column3: experience, especially when you have more than one child.&nbsp
column4: You are so caught up with the everyday minutiae of schoolwork, errands, activities - and squabbling - that you don't always see that longer view.&nbsp
column5: And suddenly, it's as though there's a break in the tree-line and you realize that you're on a ridge affording you a view of miles.

column2: Youngest's Tee-ball team met at a minor-league game to close out their season and the boys spent seven of nine innings tossing toy balls, wrestling, chasing and begging food.&nbsp
column3: They were typical early elementary boys:&nbsp
column4: wired and spastic.&nbsp
column5: Along for the ride was eldest, a daughter with a foot in the teen years and an ear in the iPod.&nbsp
column6: Middle was absent on his first non-family trip to go white-water rafting with his scout troop.&nbsp

column1: So down below was the route of childhood as I've known it thus far.
column2: Gradually starting to recede in the distance is the monitored playground romping and chase-tag of early childhood.&nbsp
column3: Adjacent to me are the first experiences of breaking away as the kids begin to expand and explore.&nbsp
column4: And ahead is the hilly and twisting passage into adulthood as they develop into the people that they'll become.

column1: As breathtaking a view as any overlook, whether in rural Virginia or British Columbia.
And suddenly, you're again enveloped in trees as the next round of stuff happens.
column2: And you keep that moment as long as possible until the next one arrives.

Be Prepared.

column1: You didn't know that these lexicons of daily life also pertain to your new ball-and-chain, the diaper bag.
And that's your mood when you find that it's not properly stocked.
column2: You'll break a hip kicking yourself in the butt for when you don't have what you need.

column1: Let's face it, you're stuck with it so here's how to make the best of it.
Congratulations and welcome to the new world.
column2: Since your other half is probably working and you're doing your doody, that's going to include taking Philo to the store and other spots.&nbsp
column3: Don't be afraid to negotiate for a bag that, while obviously for babies, isn't embarrassing.&nbsp
column4: When I started this gig 14 years ago - geez, I'm old - all of the bags that we saw in the store had cute, cuddly themes printed all over them.
column5: Ideal, since I'm as far from cute as you get.&nbsp
column6: My wife understood that there was a difference between looking like a parent and the village idiot.&nbsp
column7: Consequently, our bag was a stolid navy blue and sturdy enough to last through three children.

column1: I wore out before the bag did.
Since then, the number of actively involved men - Stay-at-home Dads and otherwise - has burgeoned.
column2: And a few fathers, who also tired of looking like village idiots, came up with design lines of diaper bags and vests for the well-appointed father.&nbsp
column3: New bags, from DadGear (www.dadgear.com) and DiaperDude (www.diaperdude.com), sport updated designs and motifs to compartments for your mp3 and Blackberry.

column1: First, regardless of the design and motif, you need something with a shoulder strap that allows you to keep your hands free for Philo.
Next, there should be a portable changing pad on which you can lay him while he's being changed.
column2: Clean it regularly and even in a designated changing area, don't expect it to be particularly sanitary.

column1: Third, a large enough compartment for the spare wipes and diapers.
Fourth, consider a separate compartment to hold any bottles or liquids that you bring along for a meal or snack.
column2: Some are equipped with insulated compartments for cold-storage.

column1: Finally, you need sufficient smaller compartments to handle personal effects, like pens and keys.
column2: Oh yeah, an mp3 player, too.&nbsp

column1: Diapers and wipes are obviously first on the list.
column2: Carry enough diapers to last you through nasty situations, like a diarrhetic kid in a traffic jam.&nbsp
column3: Okay, that scenario requires a carton, but you get the drift.
column4: I typically kept four in a bag at one time and would restock as needed.&nbsp
column5: What else?

column2: Wipe manufacturers provide a small box in which to carry wipes, but I replaced it with a ziplock bag after the clasp broke and I was left with stiff, semi-dry wipes.

column1: <li>A full set of spare clothes, including an extra &quot
column2: onesie&quot
column3: for Philo after his customary blowouts.

column1: <li>A tube of ointment for chafing and redness
column2: one with zinc oxide is preferable.

column1: • A plastic grocery bag to hold particularly nasty diapers when there are no receptacles available.
• A small plastic container to hold Philo's snack.
• After he was weaned, a sippy cup for thirsty moments.
• A small jar of Vicks Vap-o-rub for a nose dab during a particularly nasty mess.

column2: Take a few moments to check out the bag and restock it with needed - and clean - items.&nbsp
column3: You can always stop at a local store if you're desperate, but when you need the bag isn't conducive for a Walmart run.&nbsp
column4: Finally, make it a point to regularly clean out the bag and wipe it thoroughly with a disinfectant wipe.&nbsp
column5: Philo's bottom is nasty enough, don't make it worse.

column1: There are moments when the pressure to go along can be overwhelming.
column2: And it's those moments that the parent has to be willing to be &quot
column3: the bad guy&quot
column4: in order to protect the kid.&nbsp
column5: It's neither the manager's nor the photographer's job since they have a financial interest in letting this occur.&nbsp
column6: Whether it's another parent, an employer or even a school system that's trying to jam your kid, you have to be willing to enter unpleasant situations and stand for the best interests of your child.&nbsp
column7: Voices might be raised and threats rendered, but it's your job to stand your ground.

column1: When I was in middle school, I was badgered by other kids and several music faculty to take up the string bass.
column2: I repeatedly said &quot
column3: no&quot
column4: to both groups and spoke to my father about it.&nbsp
column5: His response?&nbsp
column6: You have to learn to deal with the kids yourself, but the teachers should leave you alone when you refuse.&nbsp
column7: After a teacher called my father directly to enlist his support, I never heard of the issue again.&nbsp
column8: When I later asked what had happened, he simply said that it was part of his job as a father to stand up for his child.&nbsp
column10: a kid can't be an SOB with an adult.&nbsp
column13: It was a relief to know that I was supported and it taught me a great deal about standing up to my peers when the need arose.

column1: Yes, there's a different world out there as mothers take to the workplace and fathers take to the home.
column2: But that doesn't mean that fathers are emasculated and can't do right by their children.&nbsp
column3: You have to protect your young.

Bringing our first baby home was turning out to be a disaster.
Despite hospital guidance during the maternity stay, my wife had continuing difficulty nursing our new daughter.
column2: The infant was chronically hungry from not being able to nurse properly, my wife was physically sore from the increasing milk supply, and we watched as our baby developed jaundice.&nbsp
column3: For a woman, being unable to feed her hungry baby is about as stressful and low as one can go.

column2: It's a condition marked by a notable change in the color of the skin and eyes to a bilious yellow-orange.&nbsp
column3: It almost appears as though your newborn is becoming a traffic cone.&nbsp
column4: The red blood cells in the human body regularly breakdown into a substance called bilirubin
column5: this is in turn normally excreted via human waste.&nbsp
column6: It's no problem for an adult, but when a newborn is having difficulty nursing, the lack of food slows the bowels and leads to an increase in the baby's bilirubin levels - hence jaundice.

column1: I can honestly say that at 4 AM on a Sunday morning, formula cannot be had in the nation's capital region.
column2: My male hunter-gatherer instincts were as useless as tits on a bull and the home stress levels worsened markedly.&nbsp
column3: Fortunately, our pediatrician saw us that same Sunday morning and immediately set us up for a session with a lactation consultant.&nbsp
column4: As a corporate rat, consultants ranked on my need-to-know list somewhere between a sales rep and a pretzel vendor so I was going solely on faith in the doctor.&nbsp
column5: And during that interim day, we gave our first-born formula.

column1: As we drove to the appointment in the region's outer limits, I envisioned a trip to the greater DC area's sole ashram, ensconced near an orchard nestled on an organic granola farm.
column2: And when the directions terminated in a neighborhood way better than my own, I began to&nbsp
column3: realize the depth of my misconception.

column1: The lactation consultant was a pleasant middle-aged woman who worked out of an office in her basement.
column2: The result, inside of two hours, was a newly fed infant and a spouse who was no longer in pain and stress mode.&nbsp
column3: Better nursing techniques were taught and new Mom was on the road to becoming a pro.&nbsp
column4: I don't recall if insurance paid for the visit,&nbsp
column5: but it didn't matter as that bill was as worthwhile as an ER visit for an amputated limb.

column1: These folks are expert in teaching women how to nurse and helping correct any difficulties that might arise in nursing your child.
column2: And just like a person can work as an accountant while preparing for their CPA exam, a lactation consultant can be working while they prepare for their own board certification, IBCLC (International Board Certified Lactation Consultant).&nbsp
column3: The course work includes medical background courses such as anatomy/physiology, child development and nutrition, followed by an additional 45 hours of specific lactation education.&nbsp
column4: To top it off, they have to have documented a minimum of 900 hours counseling before they can even sit for their exams.

column1: If you don't meet a lactation consultant at prenatal classes, you - and certainly your mate if you're not there - will meet one during the maternity stay.

column2: The medical research shows that there are much greater benefits from nursing, so much so that the CDC hs made it a goal to have 75% of all mothers nurse, at least initially.&nbsp
column3: Impressive, but the numbers haven't always been so good.

column1: My father would share Western Pennsylvania Depression stories, and one of them involved going to town to shop and seeing the long benches outside the local Woolworth lined with nursing mothers.
column2: As Madison Avenue took over in the 1950s, the use of formula became prevalent.&nbsp
column3: <em>Why nurse when you can get better from a can?&nbsp
column4: Today's modern, affluent American mother can provide the best that American scientific know-how can devise for her young proteges!&nbsp
column5: Available from your friendly Safeway Grocer!&nbsp
column6: The reaction from American doctors of the period, as they lit up their Winstons, was that "
column7: sure, you can try to nurse, but if it doesn't work, just buy some formula and it'll be fine.&quot

column1: By 1971, according to the CDC, only about one quarter of American mothers nursed their babies.
column2: The upshot is that because about two generations of American mothers didn't nurse - and more babies were born in hospitals instead of through midwives - the knowledge and guidance that would've been passed along disappeared instead.
Generations of mothers who largely stayed at home used formula while their descendants, over half of whom are working, are strongly encouraged to nurse their children instead.&nbsp
column3: And thus the need for a specialty to help replace what was lost.

column1:
And y'know, they're worth every bit the cost.

There are a few things that your child will have to master on his own, like learning how to make a tight seal around Mom's nipple to better nurse.
column2: Or learning how to hold his head steady when he's about a month old.&nbsp
column3: And figuring out how to grasp objects in his tiny hands.

column1: But almost everything else will be learned from you, Mom and others, and you have to be careful not to fall into the trap of thinking that he naturally understands how to do the simplest things.
column2: To your child, events and activities are akin to individual photos that they've placed on the vellum board inside their head.&nbsp
column3: One of your primary jobs is to help him learn to connect the photos so that they develop coherency, a context in which to grow and learn to think.&nbsp

column2: And as they grow and develop you'll have to learn to use those different ways of teaching.&nbsp
column3: First, just doing the basic things time and again so that they learn as they watch - and they will watch.&nbsp
column4: Later, helping them and explaining as you demonstrate.&nbsp
column5: Later still, letting them do something as you stand nearby.&nbsp
column6: There are no hard and fast rules as to which is best for a particular child or situation, so be patient with him.&nbsp
column7: And yourself.

column1: One of the adjustments that I had to make was to learn to build additional time into the schedule of daily life.
column2: Time to account for the childhood stuff that comes up - squabbles, bumps and cuts, questions, fears and play.&nbsp
column3: Several years ago, I built concrete steps and a walkway out front.&nbsp
column4: Obviously, there was a schedule but I didn't account for the fact that one of my children wanted to help, and in a very material way.&nbsp
column5: It is one of my great regrets that in the effort to accomplish the job, I did a poor job of allowing him to contribute and was at times unnecessarily brusque.&nbsp

column1: And I've had to learn to routinely ask them, especially after a new situation:
column2: <em>What did you notice?&nbsp
column3: What happened?&nbsp
column4: Do you understand what occurred?&nbsp
column5: And even if they say that they do, I ask them to explain what they saw just to make sure.
column6: It's not uncommon to find that while they can describe what they saw, they don't understand the meaning.

column1: And finally, understand that they learn simply by watching you.
column2: Which means that if you do a good job of biting your tongue and maintaining your temper, they'll never notice
column3: but they will notice the times that things slip.&nbsp
column4: So when your preschooler turns the corner into the next supermarket aisle and exclaims &quot
column5: <em>what the hell is that?&quot
column6: , then you need to be careful when you ask where he learned the language.

column2: Because unlike an Etch-a-Sketch, there's no erasing this slate.

column1: All of these variables will have an impact on the delicate balance on the trip.
column2: Some are uncontrollable, since you can't start a trip having left a child behind, while others can be controlled.&nbsp
column3: If you have more than two children, don't try to take them across the Southeast US in a subcompact, rent a U-Haul.

column1: However, you can make sure that you get sufficient rest and plan ahead so that the departure is easier than it has to be.
column2: This might even entail starting days in advance so that all of the bases are covered.&nbsp

Perhaps one of the touchiest areas about being a father is when you have to correct the playmates and friends of your child.
column2: Not only are you handling issues of behavior and discipline that keep the household in decent order, but you are cognizant that you might have no idea what the non-family kids are hearing and being taught as well as not wanting to embarrass your own kid.

column1: Situation in point is the repetitive phone calls that arise from kids who are exploring independence via the telephone.
column2: On one occasion, a school friend fell into the habit of repeatedly calling our house, several times each day.&nbsp
column3: As we sat to a late dinner, the phone rang and we let it go to the answering machine, which elicited no message.&nbsp
column4: This immediately occurred again and on the third series of rings, I answered it, intent upon wringing an elementary age neck.&nbsp
column5: Fortunately, my response was much more muted - but instructive - when I spoke.&nbsp
column6: I found that this kid had indeed called immediately before both times and was intent on speaking with my son.&nbsp
column7: My following comment was to the effect that if there's no answer and it goes to a machine, feel free to leave a message.&nbsp
column8: But it was unaccepable to repeatedly call.&nbsp

column1: My concerns that led to the muted response?
column2: First, who's monitoring the kid that is repeatedly calling?&nbsp
column3: Is there a phone in the child's room?&nbsp
column4: Second, what has the child learned about phone manners - quaint idea that it is - and is it just that the adult has assumed that the kid understands?&nbsp
column5: That can happen, since it's easy to assume&nbsp
column6: something as&nbsp
column7: obviously simple as&nbsp
column8: if there's no answer, leave a message and call back later.
column9: Finally, while blowing a gasket is immediately gratifying, the ultimate effect is counter-productive.&nbsp

column1: I generally take the following tack in such situations.
First, unless there's obvious malice - kicking, purposeful disobedience - accept it as an instructional situation.
column2: State your case in very clear and simple language.&nbsp

column1: Second, if at all possible, make sure such comments are in earshot of another adult.
column2: As a stay-home parent, that's not always practicable, but there are moments when I've made sure that my wife could hear the commentary.&nbsp
column3: The greater clarity, the better.

column1: Third, repeat conversations are accompanied by clearly stated consequences.
column2: Consequences that you would enforce with your own children, excluding corporal punishment.&nbsp
column3: And then follow through with them.

column1: Fourth, be sure to tell the kid's parent or guardian when you've had to have such a conversation.
column2: In the large majority of cases, they're glad to know of what's going on so that they can handle things.&nbsp
column3: Because kids tend to be drama queens/kings and overstate things, it also precludes the surprise dinnertable announcement that Mr. PracticalDad yelled at me today when the reality is closer to you told Junior that if he kept running and trying to slide on wax floors, you'd make him sit down for a short timeout.

column1: And unfortunately, it's a sad reality that your comment might be one of the rare times that the child has heard corrective comments.
column2: And in a play environment where the tendency is to &quot
column3: rev up&quot
column4: , the need for keeping a rein on things is key.

column3: Or just say that no boy will be in the girl's room and vice-versa.&nbsp

column1: • Make sure that when any child is over, you keep yourself available and in the open at all times.

Apart from provider and caretaker, the largest fatherhood job is role-model
column2: demonstrating how a man should act and behave.
column3: One of the keystones to being a good role-model is credibility and the groundwork for that arises out of keeping your word.
column4: And while it flows through all aspects of fatherhood, this reputation for follow-through will be especially important when it comes to maintaining discipline.

column1: This reputation starts with the simplest things from your kid's youngest age.
column2: Following through on a simple request.&nbsp
column3: <em>Can we go to the park?&nbsp
column4: Will you read to me?&nbsp
column5: Can we play a game?&nbsp
column6: Will you help me build a fort?&nbsp
column7: The request's timing is frequently poor, balanced against the press of the daily "
column8: to-do&quot
column9: list and the demands/requests of others.&nbsp
column10: But you must gain this reputation.

column2: in a little while&quot
column3: since there's a disconnect between what a child and an adult consider &quot
column4: a little while&quot
column5: .&nbsp
column6: A child has a short attention span and when you come to her a bit later to fulfill your promise, you're liable to find that she's gone on to the next thing
column7: and while it's unfair, in her mind, you haven't followed through.&nbsp
column8: Enough instances of this and a pattern is set, even if they're too young to remember individual events.&nbsp
column9: Yet if you do what they ask when they ask, you'll have problems finishing those things that really have to be done.

column1: While the sheer frequency of requests diminishes as they age, the requests grow more intricate and time-intensive.
column2: <em>Will you take me around to sell for a fundraiser?&nbsp
column3: Can you help me build a Pinewood Derby car?&nbsp
column4: Can you help me learn how to drive?&nbsp
column5: Will you look over this essay that I wrote?&nbsp
column6: You want these requests to come your way
column7: but they won't if there's no reliance on you keeping your word.

column1: So what can you do to help yourself follow-through, and still get things done?

column2: in a bit&quot
column3: or &quot
column4: in a while&quot
column5: .&nbsp
column6: Since small children don't tell time, tie it to something definite and definable like &quot
column7: when I'm done raking&quot
column8: or &quot
column9: after we've cleaned up after dinner&quot

column1: • Learn to build kid-time into what you're doing.
column2: Expect interruptions and allow time for them or even better, allow time to include them in what you're doing right then if possible.&nbsp
column3: If time is short, make arrangements to have the kids kept busy
column4: I've hired a sitter for the occasions that I have to do something without interruption.

column2: wish&quot
column3: list and for longer term projects, schedule them on the daily calendar.&nbsp
column4: I once built a cigar-box banjo for one of m children and explicitly set aside time for gathering the materials and then assembling it.

column1: • Don't be afraid to say no if you have to.
column2: If there's no way to get to something, say no to that&nbsp
column3: request and put it on the schedule.&nbsp
column4: If he request is simply beyond your capability or time, it's better to say no instead of starting something that engenders more heartache than it's worth.

column2: this is a long-term balancing act and even the best gymnast falls.&nbsp

He still has it in his closet eight years later.
