Helping Your Child Nap

column1: Her body might be crying out for a nap but she's too excited or overwrought to be able to actually get to sleep.
column2: It's certainly possible to let her scream herself down but if she starts to equate naptime with turmoil, then all naptimes will become more difficult.&nbsp
column3: You can help her get to sleep - without a dose of Benedryl - with the investment of a little time and a bit of patience.

column1: Children have almost nil control of their emotions and her screaming isn't because you're a rotten father for wanting her to have to stop and nap
column2: it's exhaustion ripped through with frustration.&nbsp
column3: She'd be screaming at her mother, Santa and the Easter Bunny if they were there.

column1: Lie down with her and talk with her quietly until she can regain some form of calm
column2: I've sung at times as well.&nbsp
column3: Once she's slowed down a bit, wrap her in your arms and begin a steady pattern of long and slow deep breathing.&nbsp
column4: If she's fidgeting - typically in an attempt to stay awake - then gently hold her hands in your own.&nbsp
column5: Continue this process and you'll likely find that her breathing pattern begins to match your own and she'll nod off to sleep in several minutes.

column1: For those instances when she can't calm herself, consign yourself to taking the time to actually wrap her in your arms and hugging her until she stops.
column2: While doing this, follow a deep and steady breathing pattern
column3: not only does it provide a pattern for her to mimic, but it will also serve to help you remain calm as well.&nbsp
column4: Again, you'll likely find that she's asleep within a few minutes.

column1: The real key to this is your own self-control.
column2: Even if she can't adequately express or understand, seeing you control yourself in the face of outbursts will provide a model for her future behavior.&nbsp
column3: <strong><em>If, at any time, you note your own self-control flagging, then it's time to simply leave the room and let her have at it.&nbsp

column1: On most occasions, this technique has worked for me.
column2:
But there have been times when I've been best served to walk out and let the child go - there's no sense compounding her misery with my own.

column1:
55,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Lice and Tigers and Bears, Oh My!
You'll get used to the various gross things of childhood - vomit, stool, blood and snot - but nothing will get to you like headlice.
column2: Even if you don't get it from the kids, you'll be scratching your head and it won't be in surprise.
Charlie's got cooties! is a common memory from elementary school and Charlie hated it as much as the next kid.
column3: In today's world, when a school gets wind of a child with lice, the administration will send home a note apprising other families that there's a problem.&nbsp
column4: A necessary part of this letter is the reminder that having lice is not emblematic of a poor household or social problems.&nbsp
column5: Headlice are a nasty insect that can be passed from one person to another through physical contact and a kid's homelife is not an indicator.&nbsp
column6: Despite being highly egocentric creatures, kids will share the most amazing things - hats, combs, pencils and even already-chewed gum - and it's this thoughtlessness that can create the problem.

column1: Headlice are insects that survive and thrive by living on the blood of a human host.
column2: They live in the hair of the host, where they lay their eggs - called &quot
column3: nits&quot
column4: - attached to the individual strands of hair.&nbsp
column5: They prefer a moister environment so that they'll typically be found near the ears.

column1: Lice don't jump or fly and it doesn't take long for them to move
column2: a louse can move almost nine inches in the course of a minute.&nbsp
column3: They are passed physically from one person to another, typically via the sharing of personal items like hats, scarves and combs.&nbsp
column4: As an example, Johnny can get a lice transfer by wearing Bob's hat but won't have a problem sitting next to Bob on the school bus.&nbsp
column5: The louse isn't going to walk across the bus seat to Johnny since that would entail leaving his preferred habitat.&nbsp
column6: He is a smart and lazy little bugger.

column1: The typical louse is damned near indestructible, able to survive underwater for hours as well as away from a human host for up to a full 24 hours.
column2: This is why simply taking a hot shower is inadequate for the problem.&nbsp
column3: They're difficult to find unless you're looking for them since an adult louse, eating all it's Wheaties, can grow to a&nbsp
column4: whopping 1/8&quot
column5: in length.&nbsp
column6: The nit itself is tiny, perhaps 2 mm long, and can only be found with a focused search of the scalp.

column1: Your child won't notice one louse and will only start to scratch after fully infested, typically in a month's time.
column2: Let's do the math.&nbsp
column3: An adult louse has a lifespan of about 30 days.&nbsp
column4: It can lay eggs after reaching maturity in about 8 days and will lay an average of 6 eggs each day until it dies.&nbsp
column5: No, there's no menopause here.&nbsp
column6: After eight days, the louse lays its first six eggs with another six eggs each day thereafter.&nbsp
column7: By the time Johnny has reached the 14 day mark, 42 eggs have been laid and at 16 days, the first days hatch to begin a new lifecycle in which those six now-mature lice hatch about 36 eggs each day.&nbsp
column8: I'll spare you the math since I can't count that high, but you get the picture.&nbsp

column2: &nbsp

column1: Apart from a barber/stylist finding an infestation - which happens - the best sign of lice is when you note the child persistently scratching their heads.
column2: They'll even do it in their sleep without awakening.&nbsp
column3: The problem is also found by school nurses in class examinations performed periodically.&nbsp
column4: This isn't necessarily a foolproof method since the staff are moving quickly to cover a large number of children in a short period of time.

column1: The first thing to remember is that you, the adult, have to remain calm and measured
column2: you might want to start scratching your own head and make remarks - or worse - but you cannot. the reason for the calm is that the child must remain relatively still.&nbsp
column3: If you have a conniption fit, the kid probably will, too.

column1: The first question is whether you should just shave the child's head.
column2: Not really an option if it's your daughter, but it is a possibility if it's a boy and the weather's warm.&nbsp
column3: Barbers and stylists will not want this job since it raises the risk of their shop becoming infested, so shaving&nbsp
column4: the head would be up to you.&nbsp
column5: Electric clippers are available at most pharmacies and box stores.&nbsp
column6: Here are some things to remember if you opt to shave the head:

column1: <li>Do the job outside or in a garage so that the hair and lice are out of the house
<li>Shaving the head will remove nits - attached to the strands of the hair - but not necessarily the lice, which will have to removed by hand
• Even after the hair is removed and your child's lice removed, you should still make it a priority to recheck them for several days.
Treatment of headlice takes a two-prong approach.
column2: The first is treatment with a shampoo to help kill the nits and lice and involves chemical based products such as Rid and Nix (including the chemical pyrethrin) or Kwell (including the chemical lindane).
column3: The second - and most important - prong is to physically examine the scalp and hair.&nbsp

column1: Yes, this is where the term nitpicking comes from.
column2: And the need for this, despite living in a quick-fix society, is that lice are&nbsp
column3: increasingly&nbsp
column4: resistant to both pyrethrin an lindane.&nbsp
column5: You can use the shampoos but if the lice are resistant, then the shampoo is useless.&nbsp
column6: So resign yourself to nitpicking and doing it scrupulously.

column1: Before you start the process of examining the head,
column2: get organized.

column1: <li>Find a well-lit spot in which you can work.&nbsp
column2: Since this is a time-consuming process, move lights in front of the TV and find something that can keep your child relatively still and occupied while you work.

column1: • Have a vacuum cleaner at hand so that you can vacuum the floor immediately upon finishing, catching up any lice that might have fallen off the scalp.
<li>Keep a bowl filled with rubbing alcohol handy to take the lice/nits that you remove.&nbsp
column2: Remember that lice can survive in water for about half a day so you want them dead and immobile immediately.

column1: <li>Have the appropriate comb for use in checking.&nbsp
column2: The teeth of the standard comb are not close enough together to catch the nits on the hair
column3: lice-shampoo can be purchased in kits which have an appropriate comb enclosed.&nbsp
column4: Wash the comb in rubbing alcohol or boil in water when you're finished.

column1: • For longer hair, have hair clips to clip together those segments of hair that have already been checked.
When you start, find a section of the scalp to examine and run the comb through the hair, pulling the comb upward towards you.
column2: As you find lice, remove them immediately from the scalp and place them in the nearby bowl and then return to the section being searched.

column1: In this process, you'll find nits typically attached to ahri strands about 1/2"
column2: from the scalp.&nbsp
column3: The nit can be distinguished from dandruff&nbsp
column4: by the readiness with which it comes off of the strand since the nits are literally glued on when laid.&nbsp
column5: Remember that the nit is oval and can vary from white to tan , depending on whether it's an old egg sac or a live, unhatched egg.&nbsp
column6: When you encounter a nit, remove it and place it immediatley in the bowl, returning to the same segment.

column1: Being methodical and persistent if essential in this process.
column2: Be ready to repeat this process again and again
column3: you'll only know you're finished when you find nothing on a thorough examination.

column1: When you're finished, immediately send the child for a bath or shower and vacuum the surrounding area.
What also makes a lice-problem so nerve-wracking is that it takes over your life and household.
• Since lice are mobile and can live a day without a human host, consign yourself to changing the bedding daily.
• Put the pillows through the dryer on a high heat setting before use.
<li>Vacuum the mattresses, furniture and carpets daily.&nbsp
column2: If you aren't going to change the bag any more frequently, keep the vacuum cleaner in the garage or basement and out of the family living area.

column1: • Stuffed animals and non-essential pillows should be bagged and placed away for about two weeks.
• Fortunately, you don't have to worry about pets since the lice only feed on a human host.
You and your family will survive this problem
column2: there are worse and you can take small comfort in that.&nbsp
column3: But it will require a degree of self-discipline and self-control that goes beyond the typical, so be sure to get rest and prepare for a long haul.

column1: In my family, with two kids simultaneously infested, it was three weeks.
Photo of Adult Louse courtesy of Rahul Goyal

Stuff is expensive and while I support the kids trying new and different things, I have usually drawn a line.
For sporting equipment, shoes and shinguards get passed down one to another
column2: I refuse to buy soccer cleats in a girls model and even shorts can be passed from one gender to another.&nbsp
column3: If there's team equipment, then they can share with other members of the squad.

column1: And I continued that line until watching one of my kids playing baseball the other night and put on a batting helmet laid down by another boy.
column2: My wife nudged me and suggested that in light of the headlice article, it might be worthwhile to just invest in a helmet all of his own.

column1: And for all of the heartache from handling a past lice infestation, I agreed.
column2: Tomorrow we go shopping.

column1:
There are some things that just make sense despite the philosophy and cost.

If you have a kid with headlice, I can't stress enough that there is no way to get around nitpicking, or manually examining the hair and scalp.
While you certainly treat with chemically laden shampoos like Rid and Nix, there is no guarantee that the lice won't have a tolerance to the chemicals.
While we were in the process of treating two of our children, I received a call from a friend whose daughter was also infested.
column2: She'd done the examinations for a full week and then stopped, trusting in the efficacy of the shampoo treatments.&nbsp
column3: After three weeks of living with that assumption, her stylist had found the daughter's head again infested and had immediately stopped cutting the hair.&nbsp
column4: A few of the eggs had survived the treatments and after birth, had matured and started the process once again.&nbsp
column5: This led to another three weeks of head checks for the daughter as well as the siblings
column6: avoidable had she kept up the examinations.

column1:
It will make your scalp crawl, but suck it up and handle it.

One of the things that I've had to learn is to consistently ask the question, where's this coming from?
column2: It has become a mantra as I deal with the daily workings of the child/teen mind.&nbsp
column3: You will see and hear - and occasionally smell - things that will make your sensory organs bleed, and that mantra has to be close to you since it has a distinct bearing on how you respond and address them.

column1: The key to successfully finding the answer to that question is to work at remaining calm even when your organs want to bleed.
column2: Even small children aren't stupid and if Junior realizes that he's stepped in a steaming hot pile, then your access to accurate, truthful answers shuts down fast.&nbsp
column3: It doesn't mean that you can't show surprise or shock, but the initial responses need to be as matter-of-fact as possible.

column1: For example, as I walked out the back door, I witnessed one of my children trying to perform a stunt worthy of Johnny Knoxville.
column2: The immediate response was to grab the child before he could hurt himself and remove him from the situation.&nbsp
column3: It's in the minutes afterwards, when I'm recovering from the shock, that I consider the question where did this come from?
column4: Not surprisingly, I found that Rupert at school was boasting of doing this.&nbsp
column5: Mind you, there are moments when I wonder how Rupert will survive long enough to contribute to the gene pool.&nbsp
column6: This led to a conversation over physical safety, common sense, gravity and believing everything being spouted by a third-grader with a death wish.

column1: Another time, I'm driving in the car and the preschooler in the back asks Daddy, what does M*&
column3: &amp
column4: k&nbsp
column5: mean?&nbsp
column6: Does this require a later conversation with an older sibling or child, or did Junior see or hear something on cable?
column7: In this particular instance, I pulled the car over and after talking with him, found that it had been dropped by another preschooler when her block tower fell over.

column1: And sometimes, the answer is that there was no particular reason for doing something, like using permanent marker
column2: to doodle on the hardwood floor.&nbsp
column3: In that case, all you can do is shake your head and have the child get their toothbrush.

59,"1","1",,"xhtml","

A friend related that her employer had a seminar on generational diversity.
column2: Huh?
column3: Simply put, it is explaining to the present staff how it should understand and adapt to the new generation of young employees coming into the hospital.&nbsp
column4: This comes on the heels of a newspaper article about &quot
column5: helicopter parents&quot
column6: now involved in their adult child's workplace.

column2: that the article was reporting incidents in major urban areas and was surprised to find a local example in a small city in flyover country.&nbsp
column3: The flipside question is, are the younger employees given similar training in how to adapt to the older, more experienced adults who have been performing their job for years?

column1: And I ask myself, is this how I want my children to go through the world, unable to adapt to the rigors of life and unable to fight their own battles?
column2: I recall conversations with my late father in which I griped about some adult's personality
column3: his response typically that as a person aged, they were increasingly unable or unwilling to change or be flexible.&nbsp
column4: <em>Get over it, you have to adapt and figure out how to make it work.&nbsp
column5: And then, he'd help me with strategies on making it work.

column1: Yet now, the older generations are being asked to adapt to the vagaries of the Y Generation.
column2: We've decided that the children and teens have to be protected not just from the real threats, but also from the things that just come along in life.&nbsp
column3: Odd working hours.&nbsp
column4: Unpleasant job situations and performance standards.&nbsp
column5: Performance reviews.&nbsp
column6: When does that generation learn to stand on its own two feet and adapt to what happens in the world?&nbsp
column7: When does the child finally and fully become an adult?

column1: How do I teach my own children to adapt - and thrive - in the world and handle what comes at them?

column2:
won't always be there.

61,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of a father's primary jobs is as teacher, and successful teaching sometimes requires preparation.
column2: Even for something as simple as tying a shoe since breaking it down into teachable component parts is daunting.

column1: Even after several kids, I had to sit down and think about what wold work for teaching a child to tie shoes.
column2: What I recalled most was that it's like teaching other tasks, you have to set them up to succeed.
The task for a child can be harder than it appears and too much at one time can be self-defeating.

column1: • Break the process into smaller parts so that even if the shoe isn't tied, he can be praised for what he did accomplish.
<li>Don't try to teach when you know that you have to leave.&nbsp
column2: He probably won't get it immediately and if you have to tie the shoe prior to departure, then it creates a sense of failure.&nbsp
column3: Find a few moments to spend at other times.

column1: • Avoid shoes with velcro straps that can get in the way.
• Let them practice with the shoes in their laps and off of their feet, then let them work on it after they've mastered the mechanics.
• Plan for a date for him to do the job himself before leaving and make sure that he has some extra time.
And then praise the bejeezus out of him.
column2:
For a job well done, he deserves it.

60,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Parents have always been faced with the question, how much do I protect my child from current events?
This came home to us on 9/11 when we scrambled to pick up our children from schools which had early dismissals due to the attacks.
column2: My own child, then in elementary school, stated in the car that they were being sent home because planes were coming to bomb our homes.&nbsp
column3: It was a chilling moment and my exact thought was of the parents in Poland in September, 1939.&nbsp
column4: What's happening and what do I tell my child?

column1: My immediate response then was that there was no one coming to bomb us and that there was no physical danger
column2: she would be alright.&nbsp
column3: And in the coming days, we explained what many others did, that there are bad people who didn't like our country and wanted to hurt our country.&nbsp
column4: We avoided the immediate use of the first person plural, we.
column5: And as time progressed, we continued to fill them in as we thought appropriate.

column1: My general philosophy is that children do best when they have some preparation.
column2: When we know that there's a new experience on their horizon, we talk to them in advance and revisit the conversation several times.&nbsp
column3: What's the event?&nbsp
column4: What can you expect and how should you behave?&nbsp
column5: Do you - or we - have to prepare?&nbsp
column6: If it's a social, macro-level event, is there a way to describe it in terms that are more immediate to them?

column1: My other philosophy is that children do need to be aware of what's going on.
column2: Small children are attuned to their parents' sense of calm and can tell when something is amiss.&nbsp
column3: In his terrific oral history of the Great Depression, Hard Times, Studs Terkel interviews a women who was a small child during the time of the Crash.
column4: She recounts that she heard her parents' frantic whisperings after the children were in bed and the sense of fear feeding off their fear even when she couldn't hear the words of their conversations.&nbsp
column5: They know that something's up, so don't just gloss over it.&nbsp
column6: That said, Bill Cosby was correct.&nbsp
column7: Kids just want an answer.&nbsp
column8: Cosby responds to his child's question, <em>why is there air?&nbsp
column9: He realized that kids don't want the full science answer, just something to assure that you've got it covered.
column12: And you expand as they age.&nbsp
column13: By the time they're in upper elementary/middle school, they should be able to handle the larger details.

column1: And that includes how it affects their daily lives.
column2: Is the economy in turbulent times and are you cutting back?&nbsp
column3: Then share that with them
column4: that everyone has to economize in order to better prepare for uncertainty.&nbsp
column5: Will something happen to them?&nbsp
column6: Probably not, but that's why you prepare.&nbsp
column7: And as you progress, you share that with them.

column1: And then you really do make sure your bases are covered.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
62,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Developing a good daily routine for managing kids after daycare or school is crucial.
column2: Life is chaotic enough with children, and when you toss in the occasional financial/banking crisis, the lack of a routine makes life far more difficult.

column1: I have to admit that having cable and the internet makes for ringside seats at the 2008 Financial Crises, and the stunning speed with which events have passed has been attention-absorbing.
column2: Goldman and Morgan Stanley are morphing into bank-holding companies?&nbsp
column3: The Lehman bankruptcy is a straw horse for bailing out JP Morgan Chase?&nbsp
column4: What's this mean and how does it affect me?&nbsp

column1: It also means that dinner is thrown together on the fly and the necessary post-school items have been knocked aside.
column2: And that can't happen.

column1: Children and teens do better when they know that there's a standard routine to the day when everybody gets home.
column2: Dinner is made and hopefully the family can spend a little time together catching up on the day's events
column3: and the schoolwork can be checked.&nbsp

column1: As the school year starts, the flow won't become discernible until the second week as the studies gear up.
column2: At that time, you can determine who needs to do what.&nbsp
column3: Does the elementary schooler need to do a certain amount of reading or are you to read to her?&nbsp
column4: Are you supposed to sign the student's planner to assure that you've seen what's hanging out there?&nbsp
column5: Are they supposed to practice for music lessons and if so, on what days?&nbsp
column6: What activities are there and when do they meet?

column1: I've found that a general routine helps keep things on track.
column2: What can help with this routine?
a regular and visible place&nbsp
column3: for each child to place their backpack when they arrive home.

column1: <li>Spend a few minutes with them over a kitchen snack to let them share what happened that day.&nbsp
column2: Some days are minimal information while others lead to in-depth conversation or bull sessions.

column1: <li>Check the school planners to see what homework or test is awaiting.&nbsp
• Help the younger children plan how they should tackle the afternoon/evening activities.
• Use the available time to read to the younger ones and monitor homework/studies for the older ones.
• Assure that all of the necessary items are done before they settle down for any electronic time, i.e. time spent with an electronic device of any kind.
Once you settle on a general format, the flow of the routine will take over and make life more manageable.
column2:
And that's part of what it's about, isn't it?

My father was an artist with language, and obscenity was his medium.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column1: Fathers need to understand that their language skills will be absorbed by their children, especially the words they choose.
column2: I always identified with Ralphie Parker since my father was a Korean Veteran who closed out his army career as a Drill instructor.&nbsp
column3: Consequently, I heard obscenities - scatological and otherwise - which I didn't learn until adulthood were physically impossible.&nbsp
column4: And yes, my father didn't react terribly well when he heard me use some of this language.&nbsp
column5: <em>You're a kid and I'm an adult so you can't use that language.&nbsp
column6: Dammit.

column1: First and foremost, understand that today's general society isn't your friend when it comes to language.
column2: Or to a lot of other things, but that's another article.&nbsp
column3: You can feel like an utter idiot on some days, but that doesn't alter the fact that when they are small, your children will truly look up to you and strive to emulate you.&nbsp
column4: On a general time frame, they'll suspect idiocy in elementary school and positively believe it in their teens.&nbsp
column5: You have to make a conscious effort to monitor your language and it's this effort that will largely set the stage for their own use of language.&nbsp

column1: After cracking down on your own profanity, remember to always ask the question, where is this coming from?
column2: Knowing this can help you define a context on how you address the foul language.&nbsp
column3: The smallest children can simply stumble across a word as they play with sounds.&nbsp
column4: One of my children, then a small toddler, happened upon the word f*** while we were with a large group of people at a Relay-for-life event.
column5: He wandered around experimenting with sounds ending in -ck when he blurted out that one.
column6: Prophetically, that's the one that he came back to repeatedly until we redirected him to a different sound.&nbsp
column7: The where is this coming from question is essential
column8: once the child recognizes that a line's been crossed it frequently becomes more difficult to ascertain the source.&nbsp
column9: Seeing something on cable or hearing raw lyrics?&nbsp
column11: Your own mouth coming back to bite you?&nbsp

column1: As the children age, they'll start to bring words to you for explanation.
column2: My approach has been to first define the word and then place it in context, followed&nbsp
column3: by a warning about usage.&nbsp
column4: My sense of this approach is that while it can be uncomfortable, to shunt the question aside or refuse it runs a greater risk of closing down the communication avenue between you and your child.&nbsp
column5: Nah, don't take it to Dad 'cuz he'll just turn red and find something else to do.&nbsp
column6: The kid is better served getting any information from you and your mate than some middle school reprobate.&nbsp

column1: For example, one of my children, a sixth grader, asked me about the term douchebag.
column2: Where'd you hear that word?&nbsp
column3: Bocephus was using it to describe another boy during a playground basketball game.&nbsp
column4: I explained the technical definition - uncomfortable to have to tell a daughter - and then placed it in its appropriate context.&nbsp
column5: This was topped off by the warning that this language isn't used by Dad and any further usage will have consequences.

column1: There are other things to remember and consider with your - and your child's - language.
<li>As stated before, very small children will often stumble across the word inadvertantly and the best option is to redirect them to something else.&nbsp
column2: It's likely that they won't even know that they've hit the mother lode.

column1: <li>If you do drop a major word, don't necessarily bring attention to it since it's liable to have totally escaped them.&nbsp
column2: If they ask how you know the mother of the man in the car ahead of you, then you need to make things right.&nbsp
column3: Otherwise, keep rolling and listening.

column1: <li>Work to respond calmly when you hear your child use foul language.&nbsp
column2: If they're hearing it at school or in the media, they probably have little understanding of the meaning.&nbsp
column3: Dropping the hammer on an unsuspecting child is poor form and will make it more difficult to find the source.&nbsp

column1: • That said, feel free to drop the hammer if they've been warned on more than one occasion or are certainly old enough to know better.
<li>The response that you can use that language since you're an adult really has no merit.&nbsp
column2: Like it or not, you're an example.&nbsp
column3: Be one.

column1: Unless you're Amish or a mute, expect to screw up and drop language bombs as you spend time with your kids.
column2: But also expect to have to explain and even apologize for poor language when you get caught.&nbsp
column3: It's best to handle it on the spot then in front of the folks at the store, the PTA or church.

column1: As my brother-in-law related, the pastor at a children's sermon complimented a little girl on her dress.
column2: Her response was:&nbsp
column3: thank you, but Mommy says it's a bitch to iron.

As seemingly mundane and academic as it may appear, Economics has taken on a new perspective and importance in the past several weeks.
column2: What is occurring now in our economic system - financial and otherwise - will have huge repercussions for how we live and how we raise and teach our children.

column1: This website is a new experience and for me, a vertical learning curve.
column2: My intent was to post a new article daily and I was starting to get into the swing when the children returned to school.&nbsp
column3: And then the Wall Street firms went to hell - Lehman Brothers, AIG, et al - and my life was fully taken over by this ability to witness the unprecedented destruction of credit and the financial sector via the internet and CNBC.&nbsp
column4: Yes, it's exciting in a morbid way and certainly historic.&nbsp
column5: But my focus on that led me away from here.

column1: That doesn't mean that I've been playing or slacking, however.
column2: My questions are always, in this order:
What are the real facts of the situation, i.e. how do I parse out the signal from the surrounding noise?

column1: • What are effects for me and my family?
<li>What measures do I take to protect them and is some way to turn it to my advantage?&nbsp
column2: That sounds cynical perhaps, but as my father once said:&nbsp
column3: cynicism can make you feel dirty, but it can also buy a lot of soap.

column1: There are huge and real changes happening here.
column2: It is, to use the academic term, a paradigm shift in which the old teachings are shown to be outmoded and in need of replacement.&nbsp
column3: And there are philosophies and practices that need immediate replacement.&nbsp
column4: More of my time is going to be spent addressing these changes in my own home, and consequently, discussing them here.

column2:
How do I figure out what's going on?

column1:
65,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The speed of the financial and economic changes in the past decade reached a crescendo this week when the credit system came to a startling and terrifying halt.
column2: The Federal Government, in its infinite wisdom and hope for a miracle,&nbsp
column3: has approved a massive bailout with no clear idea as to whether it will even work.&nbsp
column4: What exactly has happened and what does it mean?

column1: Let's start by looking at what the credit market is.
column2: The typical person looks at the Stock Market/Dow Jones Industrial Average as an indicator for the health of the economy.&nbsp
column3: That's natural since the large majority of the 401k retirement options pertain to stocks
column4: there might be a single bond option in addition to a money market fund, and these are both members of the credit market.&nbsp
column5: It's this credit market - with huge daily flows of money siphoning through the system - that provides the daily operating funds for financial and non-financial firms to operate.&nbsp
column6: Simply put, firms borrow the everyday/short-term funds for their daily operations - paying vendors, taxes, employees...and it's this particular item that has everybody spooked.
column7: Firms will have cash on hand, but it's simply never going to be enough to meet all of the obligations.&nbsp
column8: Consequently, you could think of credit as the oil that keeps the gears of the grand economic engine&nbsp
column9: turning smoothly, pistons pumping on all cylinders.

column1: And what happens when you don't check the oil?
column2: Geez, how can the economic pistons wind up thoroughly jammed?
Debt in and of itself isn't a bad thing.&nbsp
column3: The average person would never be able to afford a home without borrowing the principal, and the same goes for cars, and so on.&nbsp
column4: But in the course of the past several decades, debt has gone from being a useful financial tool to a mechanism to satisfy every consumer's wildest fantasy.&nbsp
column5: It has become acceptable and even encouraged - think all those rebate credit cards - to use credit to pay for anything you might want, let alone need.&nbsp
column6: Mortgage programs were made available that encouraged people to buy beyond what they could reasonably afford by the use of teaser introductory rates
column7: some were even allowed to&nbsp
column8: borrow large sums based solely on what they said they earned.&nbsp
column10: NINJA - No Income No Job/Assets - loans.

column1: And at the same time, genius financial engineers with mathematics degrees were learning to create financial instruments for sale, and these instruments were packages of those same mortgages bundled together.
column2: The cumulative payments from the homeowners were the cash flow on which the value of the instrument was based.&nbsp
column3: These instruments were called MBS for Mortgage Based Securities.
column4: This appeared to work so well at first that other asset classes were constructed on the same premise - credit card payments, auto notes, you name it.&nbsp
column5: And the collective group was named CDO, for Collateralized Debt Obligations.
column6: These became so popular that they were sold throughout the global economy.&nbsp
column7: A Chinese bank can conceivably own a bond backed by an apartment building in Poughkeepsie, New York.&nbsp
column8: It is a&nbsp

column1: So they combined a very loose lending policy with a vehicle for spreading this loose policy throughout the global financial system.
column2: This sounds suspiciously like a communicable disease with a virus encapsulated in a vehicle for faster spread.&nbsp
column3: And this is the point at which people remember that geniuses frequently have a very poor grasp of the real world.

column1: Lax lending, overfed consumerism and a virus-like financial package meant that this chinese bank owned a bond back by an apartment complex that simply didn't have the cash flow to support the mortgage payments.
column2: Now multiply this by hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of like products.&nbsp
column3: And in the course of a decade, there isn't a country which hasn't had these products flood throughout their system.

column1: So how does this get to a credit crunch?
column2: Remember that all of these banks lend to other banks and also non-financial companies.&nbsp
column3: The notes of the non-financial firms are the basis for something called commercial paper, or very short-term debt
column4: it is this debt that serves as the bulk of the assets held by the deemed-safe money market funds.&nbsp
column5: Well known disasters like Bear Stearns, Lehman and AIG simply exposed that many institutions are supported by financial instruments backed by failing assets, like house values.&nbsp
column6: And with firms not willing to divulge what they have in their books, trust amongst the firms and banks has collapsed.&nbsp
column7: Over the last week, this was demonstrated by the increasingly higher rates that firms and banks had to pay one another for the commercial paper.&nbsp
column8: As of yesterday, October 2, the rates were meaningless as banks simply refused to lend to anyone else as they hoarded the money to rebuild their own MBS-depleted books.

column2: Simply put, that if this continues for several more days, businesses of all sizes will be unable to obtain the money necessary to meet their obligations.&nbsp
column3: Vendors aren't paid and this ripples through the economic fabric, and ultimately, employees are laid off for lack of funds to pay them.&nbsp
column4: It amounts to a replay of the Depression of 1929.

column1: The Paulson Plan is simple and akin to a plague city worker.
column2: The intent is to remove the dead or dying assets from sick institutions via purchase and replacing them with healthy capital, think Treasury Notes.&nbsp
column3: If the government purchases the bad assets for more than Fair market value, then the institution can use the excess proceeds to rebuild their assets and hopefully spur lending again.
column4: Will it work?&nbsp
column5: The scarily interesting part is that no one knows.&nbsp
column6: There's simply no guarantee that impaired banks will resume lending instead of just taking the assets onto their books and hunkering down for the duration.

column2: And like the old maps said, &quot
column3: here there be monsters.&quot

column1: Next...how does this affect me as a father?

66,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Children certainly grow and their tastes certainly change, and don't be surprised when the daughter asks the question how does this look?

column2: you have to get away from your memories of little girls in cute outfits and consider reality.&nbsp
column3: First, do you like it as a fashionable look for a young woman?&nbsp
column4: Do the colors match and flatter her hair, complexion and eyes?&nbsp
column5: Is it the right match for her body type?&nbsp
column6: Would you rather see a girlfriend in that outfit instead of your own daughter?&nbsp
column7: If that's the case, prepare for a fight.

column1: Second, even if the look is not what you'd like, is it clean and at least well put together?
column2: We've reached an understanding in this household that while we will not dress the children in such a fashion that they'll become targets, we will not permit them to wear clothing that's suggestive, decrepid or promoting a prison lifestyle.&nbsp
column3: Read that as low slung pants and the whole bling thing.

column1: Finally, consider how to deliver the message.
column2: While you feel caught in a sling between your daughter in the outside world and your daughter as your little girl, she's equally torn between wanting to look fashionable and still meeting the code.&nbsp
column3: And in many instances, she does want your approval.&nbsp
column4: Mine has come to expect that her PracticalDad will actually look for several seconds and that prolonged silence means that he's trying out how to gently provide the phrase it doesn't work.

column1: And as I write this, I'm actually glad that she's still asking me what I think.
column2:
Because the time will come when she'll be asking another instead of me.

I apologize that this article was posted&nbsp
column3: half-finished.&nbsp
column4: Life intruded...and the article is now complete)

column1: What's happened in the financial sector of the Economy
column2: is a tangled knot of various issues that have come together in what some refer to as a Perfect Storm.&nbsp
column3: It can appear mind-numbing to the average person who's looking at it for the first as he or she sifts through the rubble of the 401k statement.&nbsp
column4: Since much of it arises from the quantitative mathematics of Ph.D mathematicians, mind-numbing is about right.

column2: a college degree in Administration and a minor in Economics, I started digging in 2005 when basic economic principles no longer seemed to match the reality that I had learned and with which I'd grown up.&nbsp
column3: With the internet, I encountered dozens of sites - literally hundreds are there - and sifted through them to come to the ones that I go&nbsp
column4: to regularly.&nbsp
column5: Some are on the wonkish side and others are more visceral in terms of tone.&nbsp
column6: But the key is to find a few good ones and then not only link the referenced articles, but also read the comments and start to pull your understanding together.

column1: I'll take a few moments to note my top choices.

column2: general outline of the Economics/Personal Finance arena, then I would recommend www.kiplingers.com.
column3: It is the digital equivalent of the old Kiplinger Newsletter but the articles are straightforward and written towards the layman.&nbsp
column4: If you find yourself getting further into investing, then I suggest that you try www.morningstar.com for a wider variety and analysis of investment opportunities.
column5: They even go so far as to provide their own criteria for selection of mutual funds.

column2: the finance and investment&nbsp
column3: developments can be found at www.nakedcapitalism.com and
column4: is penned daily by Yves Smith.&nbsp
column5: She is a retired investment banker who started&nbsp
column6: the site after noting the disconnect between what she was reading in the Main&nbsp
column7: Street Media (hereafter&nbsp
column8: MSM) and what she knew was actually happening.
column9: She explains developments well and remains&nbsp
column10: connected to peers within her former profession.

column1: My personal favorite, and source of great insight, remains www.calculatedrisk.blogspot.com,
column2: hosted by CR and Tanta.&nbsp
column3: CR is apparently an independently wealthy investor who also started the site in 2005 when he noted the growing disconnect between&nbsp
column4: reality and economics/finance.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: He was subsequently joined by Tanta, the pseudonym for&nbsp
column7: a retired mortgage banker who posts wonkish&nbsp
column8: or scathing articles, depending&nbsp
column9: upon her ability to suffer fools gladly.&nbsp
column13: apart from CR's well thought out and executed &quot
column15: , is the collection of individuals who&nbsp
column17: The commentary is pithy, intelligent and depending upon the subject matter and poster, exceptionally&nbsp
column21: to post - and I lurked for close to a year before&nbsp

column1: www.londonbanker.blogspot.com is a new and increasingly favorite blog from an English central banker.
column2: His posts are infrequent as yet but they are beautifully written and provide incisive behind-the-scenes&nbsp
column3: glimpses of the workings of the macro-level economic landscape.&nbsp
column4: It does presume a certain level of understanding, but even if you have&nbsp
column5: a thin knowledge base, the use of the English language is excellent.

column1: A good look at general economic trends and developments is www.econbrowser.com.
column2: It was created by two Economics professors, James Hamilton of UCSD and Menzie Chinn of University of Wisconsin/Madison.&nbsp
column3: Their content is topical and provides a grounded overview of the Economics developments.&nbsp
column4: And while their &quot
column5: chart porn&quot
column6: isn't always up to CR's standards, they will readily correct and adapt them if it's appropriate.

column1: Finally, I tend to wander regularly to www.maxedoutmama.com
column2: for a ground level view of the situation.&nbsp
column3: It's penned by a woman with an interest in Economics and has a &quot
column4: boots on the ground&quot
column5: feel to what's occurring.&nbsp
column6: It's thoughtful and if some nowadays consider her too political, then I simply acknowledge that everything happening now has political overtones.&nbsp
column7: Bear that in mind as you read and you'll still find useful information.

column1: Finally, am I a proponent of Jim Cramer?
column2: Uh, no.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: His schtick is good for everyday trading, but the present circumstances are far from everyday and make his approach simply too dangerous.

column1:
Next up...so how does a PracticalDad approach today's environment?

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

68,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With all of the sound and fury in the credit and financial markets, what's the immediate effect on the PracticalDad Family?

column2: new&quot
column3: paradigm:&nbsp
column4: Pay As You Go.

column1: The effect of the credit crunch, and as of this writing the credit markets are getting smashed, is that credit will be greatly curtailed to the American family.
column2: If you have any unused lines of credit, they will likely be cut or eliminated by the banks and other credit providers.&nbsp
column3: This destruction of credit, faster than the ability of the governmental authorities to replace it, is referred to as deflation.
column4: And in a deflationary environment like today's, the general rule of thumb is that &quot
column5: cash is king&quot

column1: The PracticalDad family has long taken a stand-off attitude towards credit.
column2: Mortgage?&nbsp
column3: Yep, but a vanilla fixed rate note.&nbsp
column4: Credit cards?&nbsp
column5: Only one major card offering a college&nbsp
column6: plan rebate, paid off monthly.&nbsp
column7: The preferred operation for service providers - mechanics, etc. - is to go to&nbsp
column8: those offering 90 days &quot
column10: financing so that the purchase can be paid off in 90 days without interest.&nbsp

column1: And I sometimes leave the house without money in my wallet.
column2: That way, when the kids start bemoaning their lack of a soda/snack/goody, I can honestly say that I don't have any money.&nbsp
column3: There's plenty at the house and they'll survive until then.&nbsp
column4: If there is an emergency, that's what the credit card is for.

column1: For several years, the typical family has had no savings whatever as they've used the house as a savings vehicle.
column2: The expectation was that the housing value would go up and they would be able to tap into it for cash, replacing the borrowed money with the profits when they sold it.&nbsp
column3: Families will simply have to walk through their spending habits and decide what can stay and what has to go as they adjust their spending to the new reality.&nbsp
column4: This could promise to be a searing experience but has to happen as the cash reserves are rebuilt.

column1:
And cash will be necessary as the credit is adjusted downwards.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

69,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The economic events of the past year have caused the PracticalDad and spouse to not only rethink the uses of credit, but also the targeted use of spending when we do choose to spend.
column2: In a nutshell, spending your economic stimulus check for a new TV is meaningless for the country since the money ultimately flows to Korea or Japan.&nbsp
column3: If you do spend, try to assure that it goes to your neighbors or countrymen first.

column1: One of my wife's comments challenges the view that Walmart is good for America.
column2: How can it be really good for America if all of the manufacturing profits on goods sold flows overseas?
column3: How does that help my own countrymen?

column2: I can't say it better myself.

column1: The PracticalDad family has long tried to control credit use, and is adapting to the new reality of Pay-as-you-go.
column2: But we moved to a newer home in the past year and have consistently planned to finish the basement, paying it with cash.&nbsp
column3: The day that we signed the contractor's contract was during the week of Wall Street hell and stroking a deposit check required a serious gut-check.&nbsp
column4: As we discussed the project later that night, we found that&nbsp
column5: we'd had similar thoughts regarding the project.&nbsp
column6: One of those was that in this environment, if we had money to spend, we wanted to assure that it went to local people who would benefit from the money.&nbsp
column7: It wouldn't go to improve the living standards of someone in another country.&nbsp
column8: And if we have to purchase bathroom fixtures, we'd like to purchase the products of American companies providing wages to American employees.&nbsp
column9: So we'll be looking at American manufacturers.

column2: Not really.&nbsp
column3: We've purchased foreign products when they were a compelling buy, but as we age, we begin to understand that we are, in a sense, neighbors who have to support one another when the opportunity arises.&nbsp
column4: We understand that domestic products are liable to be more expensive than some imports, but it's our responsiblity to look beyond our immediate checkbook to the support of our larger society.&nbsp
column5: And if the quality isn't there, then we will elsewhere.

column1: So our cash burn in the next two months will skyrocket as we move forward with the project.
column2: But local electricians, plumbers and contractors will also benefit.

column1: And if Walmart is so great about saving Americans money, it's only to make up for the fact that the typical American is poorer for all of the manufacturing sent overseas.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
70,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As I said in an earlier article (Career Training for a PracticalDad), when you move to more than one child, your most critical skill is time and logistics management.
Almost every parent wants to see their child experience new things and find their niche.
column2: And while this is entirely understandable, it gets dicey when more than one child is introduced into the scheduling mix.&nbsp
column3: It's at that moment that the parent has to consider overload for both the child and the family.&nbsp
column4: Does the child really need another activity?&nbsp
column5: What's the impact on the other members of the family, especially younger siblings?&nbsp
column6: Does it ruin the ability of the family to have a regular mealtime, one of the true necessities for a successful family?

column1: While we live in a digital and wireless age, the most crucial element is the old-fashioned family calendar clearly displayed in a prominent place.
column2: The PracticalDad preference is the 18x24&nbsp
column3: inch wall variety available in any office supply store and hung on the kitchen wall.&nbsp
column4: This is clearly&nbsp
column5: an analog method in a digital age, but it serves several purposes.

column2: read a calendar.

column1: <li>When they're older, it relieves you of having to constantly open the daytimer or Blackberry/Palm when they ask whether they can go to the mall, game, friend's house, etc.&nbsp
column2: They can at least see if something else is happening before even coming to you.

column1: <li>It visibly displays for them that there are others in the family and that these others also have lives, an important lesson in the typically self-obsessed child and teen.&nbsp
column2: They might not appreciate it, but at least they can see it.

column1: • It introduces them into the world of scheduling and learning how to make use of blocks of time.
When it comes to calendars, the PracticalDad has come to prefer the calendar based upon the academic year - September through August - since the kids' activities usually revolve around school.
<li>Starting in July, purchase an academic year calendar at an office supply store and then begin to review the months.&nbsp
column2: When is Christmas?&nbsp
column3: When is Easter?&nbsp
column4: Even if you aren't religious, many school systems base their Winter and Spring vacation periods around these holidays.

column1: <li>When the school district or preschool sends home a calendar at the beginning of the year, start the first review by getting the in-service days and holidays marked on the family calendar.&nbsp
<li>If kids are in different schools, i.e. elementary vs middle/high school, then use the child's initial after the family calendar entry.&nbsp
column2: Different levels can have different in-service dates and dismissals.

column1: • When the child starts to involve himself in various activities, obtain the appropriate sport/activity calendar and make those entries on the calendar as well.
• Keep a separate folder in the kitchen or office in which to hold all of the various activity calendars, and refer to it if there are discrepancies.

<li>Some PracticalDads might prefer to use a different color pen or marker for each child or activity, but this PracticalDad found that his markers developed legs and marched off to various coloring and school projects.&nbsp
column2: Some things aren't worth the fight.

column1: <li>If you find that a child has too many competing activites for a particular night, then you have to consider whether the child is overscheduled.&nbsp
column2: Kids do have a purpose in &quot
column3: goofing off&quot
column4: or &quot
column5: vegging out&quot
column6: and minimizing this time can be detrimental.&nbsp
column7: It also highly complicates your life and doesn't teach the philosophy of fully committing to an activity.

column1: <li>Plan your upcoming week each Saturday or Sunday and consider meal planning, travel logistics and arrangements for other children if necessary.&nbsp
column2: Nothing ticks this PracticalDad more than to have a phone call requesting last minute babysitting services from the PracticalDad's daughter.

column1: <li>When a child asks if he can do something, then take him to the calendar to look at it.&nbsp
column2: As he ages, you can simply ask what's on the calendar and let him then come back to you.

column1: This PracticalDad has found it helpful to keep calendars for a year after it's out of date.
column2: There are instances in which it's helpful to review it in order to determine how something has changed or when an activity occurred.&nbsp

column1: And if there are other reasons than schedule to prevent a child from doing something, then you can take up that discussion.
column2: And you know, it's actually alright if you simply tell the kid not today, I need a break from the running.
column3:
They'll appreciate it eventually.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
71,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Apart from the daily routine of who has to be where, a PracticalDad has to pay attention to specific seasonal activities and get ahead of the curve in scheduling.
column2: If you don't, then life will be more chaotic as deadlines approach.

column1: These events typically occur in the late summer and fall and the demand amongst families is such that it pays to act ahead of time.
column2: What are these events?
The advertising for these begins in late July and into August and if you delay, then much of the mercandise - school supplies and clothing - will be largely picked over and unavailable.
The Centers for Disease Control now recommend that all children under the age of five receive flu vaccine, although it doesn't have to be a shot anymore.&nbsp
column3: Most pediatricians have a nasal vaccine available, called Flumist, which is simply sprayed up both of the nostrils.
column4: The vaccines are typically available from September through December
column5: since the flu &quot
column6: season&quot
column7: commences in January and it takes several weeks for the antibodies to develop after vaccination.&nbsp
column8: It pays to contact your family physician starting early September to see what their particular schedule is.

column2: Again, it pays to have the photos done early enough so that you can enclose them with the Christmas cards if that is your habit.&nbsp
column3: Since it takes several weeks for them to be developed and returned, having them done in December makes the card deadline difficult.&nbsp
column4: It pays to contact your photography studio starting in September, especially if the children are in school and have to have after-school or weekend appointments, which are more in demand that daytime, middle of the week.

column1: These are the types of appointments that you have to consider when you first start reviewing the new calendar
column2:
this PracticalDad's experience is that it even pays to note the appointment calls for a specific date.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
72,"1","1",,"xhtml","

When you do schedule, it's helpful to look at the other commitments around whatever appointment that you make.
With multiple children at the November/December timeframe, life takes on a frenetic pace.
column2: After making the Christmas photo appointment the other day, the PracticalDad was reminded that with family or children photos, additional cushion time must be allowed.&nbsp
column3: Children and babies don't cooperate or the parent doesn't get the photo poses that are wanted, or outfits have to be changed which leads to a longer studio time than is typically expected.&nbsp

column1: Since we're a month ahead of time, the appointment has been changed to later in the day so that other appointments aren't missed.
column2:
It pays to check and check again.
