column1:
73,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Although I love my family dearly and do appreciate the opportunity to be at home, it has created awkward and confusing situations.
column2: &nbsp
column3: After 14 years of being the Stay-at-home Dad/primary caregiver/Mister Mom/whatever, I can now officially declare myself a writer.&nbsp
column4: If nothing else, it's certainly easier than any of the other titles in the past.&nbsp

column1: Women can identify themselves in any number of ways:
column2: mother/wife/careerist/hobbyist/whatever.&nbsp
column3: Unfortunately, men identify themselves by what they do.&nbsp
column4: A guy could introduce himself as a circus carnie and other men would nod approvingly, thinking <em>man, all the fries he wants and he doesn't have to shave.&nbsp
column5: Suh-weet.&nbsp
column6: There have been points in the past 14 years when I've truly wondered what an appropriate title would someone in my position would be, acceptable to both society and me.
column7: Unfortunately, the two haven't routinely intersected.

column1: Shortly after starting this experience, I went to the hospital for a routine pre-operative visit.
column2: The clerk taking the necessary background information was&nbsp
column3: a blue-haired older woman who resembled Mary Worth and the interview proceeded apace until she asked my occupation.&nbsp
column4: When I replied &quot
column5: homemaker&quot
column6: , she refused to enter the answer and stated &quot
column7: oh, we can't do that.&quot
column8: &nbsp
column9: She refused to acknowledge that answer and we ended up compromising on student since I'd also gone back to school for a teaching certificate.
column10: After that, I ran into any number of other situations in which&nbsp
column11: the title of my occupation was debatable.&nbsp
column12: So what other titles have gone past?

column1: • A pastor once introduced as my wife's wife, for which he immediately apologized.
<li>A housefather, to which I immediately thought:&nbsp
column2: great, and my children are members of a group home.

column1: • A Superdad, which just made me uncomfortable.
• Mister Mom, which I resent since I look lousy in make-up and sweats.

column2: I'm uncomfortable with that sole word as occupation since every guy with a child is a Dad.&nbsp
column3: The fact that I'm home with the kids a lot more doesn't give me the right to use that word, as though I'm somehow more qualified than all of the other guys.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: So I adopted the socially acceptable Stay-at-home Dad and stayed with it.

column1: And now, I'm like the other guys who have a title to go with the occupation.
column2: And I've also formalized the title PracticalDad.
column3:
It by no means makes me a better father, but one who's a lot more experienced with the daily stuff than most.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
74,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Many people nowadays poke fun at the old model of fatherhood, with Dad ensconced on the sofa watching television.
column2: Al Bundy brought it to high art as he inserted his hand into his pants.

column1: And I even bought into it, not watching television as I believed that there was always something else to be done.
column2: And there always will be.&nbsp
column3: But as the children have aged, it has become the occasional treat to sit with them as they watch something.&nbsp
column4: Part of being a father is sometimes just having a presence and enjoying the moment with the kids.&nbsp
column5: In this instance, we're watching a rerun of Goldfinger.

column1: And after I put down the laptop, I'll sit here without my hand in my pants.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
75,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With fathers stepping up more and mothers in the workforce, expect to also spend time managing the family activities while mom's away.
column2: And with sufficient planning and preparation, there's no reason that it should be a terrible experience.&nbsp
column3: It can frankly be liberating to realize that you can also manage it successfully.

column1: Again, the key is to know the calendar, schedule and routine and then plan accordingly.
The situation is easiest when the children are young and not involved in activities.
column2: Remember that kids do best when they have a routine to follow and knowing that routine is important since the kids are liable to miss Mom, which can throw them off.&nbsp
column3: If you have your own activities apart from work, then you should consider just foregoing them during the absence in order to lessen the stress.&nbsp
column4: When you get home with the kids, get dinner ready and then after feeding them, start the bathing process.&nbsp
column5: Understand that small children shouldn't be left alone in a bathtub, so don't expect to do other things while that process is ongoing.&nbsp
column6: After bathing, then pull together clothing for the next day and make any other preparations requiring light in the child's room.&nbsp
column7: When you finish tucking in the kids, then you move to preparations for the next day - making lunches, cleaning up, whatever necessary.&nbsp
column8: And then top it off by looking at the next day's schedule again.

column1: If the kids are old enough to have activities, then what happens is akin to choreography.
column2: Activities implies school, which means that one of the first things that happens on your arrival is a review of the backpack.&nbsp
column3: What homework is there and when is it due?&nbsp
column4: Are there forms to return or announcements that require an update of the family calendar?&nbsp
column5: In the PracticalDad household, all good things flow from the schoolwork.&nbsp
column6: When that doesn't happen, other things don't happen.&nbsp

column1: Where do they have to be and when, and how does dinner happen?
column2: Is there the opportunity to sit for a brief meal together or will it happen on the road?&nbsp
column3: While I do sometimes spring for fast food in a pinch, I try to avoid it if possible and have even packed sandwiches for the car ride.&nbsp
column4: The backpack is everpresent and those not involved in the activity can finish schoolwork while the other(s) do their thing.&nbsp
column5: Along with the backpack should also be other activities for after the schoolwork, including books, toys and electronic devices.

column1: If you've looked ahead, you have the time to arrange other transportation if possible.
column2: Can other parents split driving?&nbsp
column3: Can you call in a favor from a trusted friend?&nbsp
column4: These do make life easier.

column1: When the activities are done, then the bath/shower/bedtime prep can occur.
column2: Part of this preparation is seeing what the next day's clothing will be.&nbsp
column3: Your kids might be old enough to complain that they can dress themselves without your help and why do you always insist on treating them like children? Thank you!
column4: However, they are young enough to complain the next morning if they don't have clean underwear and how can you be <em>such a slackard for not making sure that I have clean underwear at least?&nbsp
column5: Thanks alot!
column6: If your kids pack, this would also be the opportunity to have lunches made, whether by you or them.

column1: When they are finally almost ready for bed - or in bed - then you can move on preparing for tomorrow and again, checking the calendar and planning accordingly.
These days will wear you out and these are clearly the times when you simply have to suck it up and make it happen.
column2: But the satisfaction from making it happen is worth the wear.&nbsp
","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
76,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With the mate away for a week on business and three active kids, making the activities happen will require some choreography.
column2: Actually, it's more akin to a linear programming exercise in Operations Management.

column1: <li>there will be a family meal together in some manner
<li>money won't be spent on fast food, which is being held in reserve for an otherwise unmanageable night
<li>child A has a play practice commencing at 4:15 through 5:30 and since it's a professional stage production, absence is not an option
<li>child B has a school play practice commencing at 6:30 in the evening with a 10 minute drive time, including a stop for another kid pick-up to the practice
<li>child C has a cub scout meeting, for which PracticalDad is the Den Leader, so absence is&nbsp
column2: not an option

column1: <li>children A and C attend a different level of school and are dismissed later than child B

column2: checking the schedule and working through the other obligations, I'll handle it in the following manner:

column1: <li>Child A will be picked up from school and dropped off at the practice, with the PracticalDad coming home to handle other issues

column2: home on the bus and be supervised by child B, who is certainly old enough to babysit until my return

column1: <li>Leftover soup will be put on the stove to heat up and sandwiches pre-made until returning to get child A
<li>Child B is old enough to monitor soup and is even now preparing the occasional family meal when she chooses - or is asked
<li>Child C is old enough to set the table under my supervision, so the table and food will be ready on return with child A
<li>The family will sit to eat at about 5:50 in the evening and can have a twenty minute meal together before the next set of departures
<li>Child C can throw on his scout uniform before leaving - or even take it with him - to pick up the child&nbsp
column2: B friend and make the school play drop-off

column1: <li>Child C and I will do scouts and return home to child B, who can be alone for 75 minutes to do homework and take care of the dishes
<li>On returning, I can check out completed homework and check on dishes while child C takes a bath and prepares for bed
• Child B will be brought home by the parents of the friend that we picked up for the evening play practice.
By this point, two of them should be about ready for bed when the last child arrives home.
column2: Then we assure that the regular daily tasks&nbsp
column3: - clothing and lunches - are ready for the following morning.&nbsp
column4: Those things don't just go away amidst the bedlam.

column1: It sounds crazy - and it really is - but the reality is that we don't permit the children to take on too many activities.
column2: We have&nbsp
column3: said no to requests for more activities and have forced them to finish activities that they'd started and found they didn't enjoy
column4: at the expense of trying something else.&nbsp
column5: This is simply what can happen on an evening when the varied interests of three children&nbsp
column6: collide.

column1:
And the climax to the evening will be a well-deserved beer while planning the next day's forays as a single parent.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

77,"1","1",,"xhtml","

And even when you plan your work, as I had to do for yesterday, things don't quite happen as you'd like and you have to improvise and amend accordingly.
column2: Which is why it's called management.

column1: Kids appeared where they were expected and most work happened as outlined with a few bumps.
<li>Child B was required to turn in grade paperwork to allow her to continue with the school play, but didn't bother to make a print-out until time to walk out the door.&nbsp
column2: At which time, the printer broke.

column1: <li>This delay caused a detour to the scout meeting place to at least open up for the other cub scouts and parents.&nbsp
column2: Then the school play delivery occurred.

column1: • The dishes weren't finished upon return home since the dishwasher wasn't emptied of clean dishes and child A can't safely reach the uppermost shelves.
So my notes for the future would have to include making a reminder to remind child B to get the paperwork out in a more timely fashion.
column2: And then to either get a stool for child A or make sure it's emptied myself.

Not the most pretty thing perhaps, but it worked.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
78,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Seven years of college, down the drain.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column1: I went away to college and when I came to, I was on the six year plan.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column10: - High School Friend of the PracticalDad

column1: There was a time when college was more affordable and financing was easier to come by.
column2: The new - and lasting - realities from the recent financial turmoil&nbsp
column3: are that further education is a necessity for economic advantage and that the student must find the most cost-effective means of obtaining it.&nbsp
column4: Viewing college as an opportunity to &quot
column5: grow&quot
column6: are long, long gone.&nbsp
column7: This awareness of cost and benefit is foreign to the large majority of most teenagers, so one of the jobs of a PracticalDad is to help frame the decision's parameters for the teen.&nbsp
column8: They still might not make the best decision, but at least they've had the opportunity to do so.

column1: So just what are the segments of the new realities?
First, no one can disagree that a typical high school graduate will outearn a high school graduate.
column2: &nbsp
column3: CNNMoney
column4: estimates are that a college graduate will make $20,000 more annually than a high school graduate of similar age.&nbsp
column5: With the shifts in the economy to a greater knowledge-based need, that will probably widen further.

column1: But this information is incomplete without further examination.
column2: The present circumstances now require even greater educational requirements in order to stay ahead of the economic curve.&nbsp
column3: According to statistics in CNNMoney, the average bachelor degree holder lost 4.2% in earnings from 2001 to 2006.
column4: A graduate degree holder earned 4.6% more over the same period while the holder of a doctorate gained greater than 9% in average earnings.&nbsp
column5: So if your child is going to get ahead of the economic curve as an adult, they will have to prepare, if they are of that bent, to obtain even more than a Bachelor's degree.&nbsp
column6: Not everyone is cut out for graduate education and not all graduate degrees are created equal, but an advanced degree is increasingly a necessity to get and stay ahead.&nbsp
column7: So why load up on the debt for the bachelor degree?

column1: Second, the cost of obtaining a college degree has and will continue to expand greater than the rate of standard inflation.
column2: www.finaid.org provides statistics that show the historic tuition inflation rate at almost twice the CPI general rate.
column3: And the simple truth is colleges have little incentive to control their costs
column4: the supply of colleges is largely set and they don't just spring up or go out of business.&nbsp
column5: Demand for a college degree is rising however, as everyone jumps on the bandwagon.&nbsp
column6: And any basic economics professor will sketch out how price rises with demand when the supply curve is fixed.&nbsp
column7: A shining contrast to this trend is Harvard, which actually dropped it's tuition cost in 2008 in response to the pressing financial demands on families and students.&nbsp
column8: Of course, Harvard has a $35 Billion endowment so whether this leads the way with other institutions remains to be seen.

column1: Providers of higher education state that financing is certainly available for any college whether through scholarships, student and private loans, grants and work study opportunities.
column2: This is true.&nbsp
column3: But the mix available has changed dramatically in the past decades.&nbsp
column4: Government grants have been overtaken by government loan programs and even these loan programs are now in trouble.&nbsp
column5: In March of 2008, the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency (PHEAA) ran into the credit mess and found that it was&nbsp
column6: unable to float a sufficient number of bonds necessary to support student lending.&nbsp
column7: Six months later, this PracticalDad knew of two local students forced to make changes in their plans to account for this financing failure.&nbsp
column8: Scholarship programs will also be affected since their investment returns will suffer along with everybody else's returns.

column1: So the cost of further education is rising and the financing options are narrowing.
column2: What can a PracticalDad do?

column1: <li>Early in the child's life, decide what financing mechanism is best for your needs.&nbsp
column2: There are a variety of savings mechanisms available, ranging from UGMA (Uniform Gifts to Minors Act) accounts to various state 529 plans.&nbsp
column3: Then, as much as possible, utilize some of the college cost sites mentioned above to help plan what should be deposited regularly.&nbsp
column4: If that's possible.

column1: <li>After deciding on the mechanism, monitor it regularly and make the appropriate changes as the need arises or the environment changes.&nbsp
column2: Like your retirement savings, the plan has to be regularly checked and updated.

column1: <li>Spend time figuring out what the generic college costs might be for your child at both a public and private college.&nbsp
column2: My recommendation would be www.bankrate.com, which is an excellent site for all manner of hands-on financial tools.
column3: You can specify the length of time until college and also the estimated inflation rate.

column1: <li>Start talking with the children early - and I measure early in terms of years - about what college is and isn't.&nbsp
column2: What they see in the media doesn't necessarily jibe with reality and for most anymore, it's not an opportunity for self-exploration.

column1: <li>When they reach high school, meet the guidance counselors and learn what materials the guidance group offers.&nbsp
column2: What's available in terms of scholarship resources and what other programs are offered that would be of benefit.

column1: <li>Utilize the other publicly available reading materials.&nbsp
column2: This PracticalDad recommends What Colleges Don't Tell You by Elizabeth Wissner-Gross and How to Go to College for Almost Free by Ben Kaplan.
column3: The former is a large collection of tips and &quot
column4: secrets&quot
column5: for successful admission provided by the author, who's advised students and families on admission for more than a decade.&nbsp
column6: The latter is a &quot
column7: how-to&quot
column8: guide to maximizing scholarships written by a Harvard graduate who's become one of the leading experts on working the scholarship system.

column1: <li>And constantly reiterate to the kids about the need to keep up with the studies.&nbsp
column2: And then reiterate it again.

column1: If you have a newborn, it might appear that you have an almost infinite time until she is ready for taking that step and from a financial standpoint, there is a lot of time.
column2:
But like anything else, it will pass faster than you know so use your time wisely.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
79,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Colleges and universities are non-profit entities and paint themselves as caring for the best interest of your child.
column2: But let's be honest, they are a huge business and it's good to remember that.&nbsp

column1: My local school district found itself in a controversy last year when they sponsored a seminar by a for-profit specialist in college financial planning.
column2: This person made the comment that colleges were a big business and you had to bear that in mind when speaking with them and reviewing their material.&nbsp
column3: The word leaked out and the next thing anybody knew, the local colleges - state and private - were sending angry letters to the editor decrying this viewpoint and steadfastly maintaining their care for the welfare and best interest of the student.&nbsp
column4: From what I understand, that session won't be happening again.

column2: The cost of tuition has gone up significantly faster than the rate of general inflation and no one can provide an adequate rationale for justifying this.&nbsp
column3: Indeed, is this a big business?&nbsp
column4: It might be not-for-profit, but it acts like any major corporation.&nbsp
column5: Consider the state of Pennsylvania.&nbsp
column6: The state financing agency is the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Authority, hereafter referred to lovingly as PHEAA.&nbsp
column7: This group has gained recent notoriety for a lack of accounting controls on spending&nbsp
column8: with executives making paid trips to the California wine country and the corollary perks of cigars and wine excursions.&nbsp
column9: Even when the information was divulged by a local newspaper using the Freedom of Information Act, PHEAA turned around and spent almost $100,000 to take their employees and families for a day at the local amusement park.&nbsp
column10: Indeed, the head of PHEAA makes an annual salary of $285,000, which is more than the governor of Pennsylvania.

column1: And the Chancellor of the state university system, comprising fourteen universities, is pulling down $325,000 annually.
There is an institutional bias toward keeping the gravy train rolling, at least for the powers that be.
Likewise, many colleges and universities are competing not only for faculty, but also in terms of the plushness of the facilities.
column2: One local private college even offers a Mongolian Grill for the students.&nbsp
column3: And this is generally matched by the upgraded student commons facilities.&nbsp
column4: These institutions have a vested interest in assuring that the steady flow of students and funding come through their ivied portals.

column1: So when you read the materials and meet with the Admissions and Financial Aid people, be prepared to negotiate as hard as you can and be prepared to walk if you must.
column2: There are other institutions available and&nbsp
column3: they need your child and money more than you&nbsp
column4:
need them.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
80,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As the teens age, one of the tricky parts for the PracticalDad is how much to involve himself in deciding what happens after high school.
column2: I want to raise the kids to be able to think and survive in the great wide world so while there may be times that they require some help, my intent isn't to have them moving home for an indefinite period.&nbsp
column3: I'm not Amish and I won't be adding onto the house.

column1: So the period around the end of high school is problematic.
column2: How do I measure my involvement in such a way as to ensure that they make the best decision that they can - whether I agree with it or not - versus just assuring that they make a decision at all?&nbsp
column3: Parents can become frustrated with the kid if they perceive no activity or movement in the post-high school process and assume laziness.&nbsp
column4: But it's just as likely that their child is overwhelmed by the situation.&nbsp
column5: For some, frankly, it akin to being a deer caught in the spotlight of adulthood.

column1: For this PracticalDad, I have to remember that part o the tuition for whatever comes next will be on the back of my offspring via scholarships and work study.
column2: They absolutely must take responsibility for whatever decision is made.&nbsp
column3: But most haven't the experience or knowledge base to adequately evaluate the choices and opportunities.&nbsp
column4: This means that the parents must take an active hand.&nbsp
column5: So part of my job is to provide a framework in which they can make the best decision possible.

column1: And how in God's name does that happen?
column2: As usual, it isn't a process into which you just jump one morning.

column1: First, start early to help determine whether or not they even are the kind of person who would benefit from a college education.
column2: There is a growing and increasingly critical need for people with the skills to actually do and make things.
column3: In our future environment, those who can actually provide something of value will in all likelihoood prosper more than most.&nbsp
column4: If this is the case, then there are absolutely valid alternatives in technical education and the guidance department can provide the resources to determine what they might be.

column1: Second, ascertain what the Guidance Department offers to help your kid with career exploration and possible educational matches.
column2: When I was in high school, the Guidance Counselors were largely silent on career exploration and existed to help counsel the student if there were problems and to assist in the college selection process.&nbsp
column3: I've been pleasantly surprised to find that they now plug incoming freshmen into software packages and websites to help identify their strengths, weaknesses, likes and dislikes.&nbsp
column4: These packages then link the results to potential career paths across the employment spectrum.

column1: Third, early in the high school years, determine what the general timeframe for specific milestones are.
column2: When are the college tests, i.e. the SAT and ACT?&nbsp
column3: When should the student start considering what the school alternatives are out there?&nbsp
column4: When should they be expected to have a realistic idea of what their college major might be?&nbsp
column5: When should they start exploring schools and do those schools have programs that match the prospective major?

column1: Then work with your kid to set up a schedule that satisfies all of these general timeframes.
column2: Some will take to it readily and others will struggle, but at least you have&nbsp
column3: a sense of what has to happen and can adapt accordingly to help move things along.

column1:
And you might be pleasantly surprised at how they handle it.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

81,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Like other parents, I'm frequently frustrated when the kids don't listen when told something.
column2: The word &quot
column3: no&quot
column4: means no and "
column5: stop&quot
column6: means stop.
column7: Why don't they always listen?

column1: And tonight I realized one contributing factor to the problem.
While middle kid was at an activity, youngest went with me to a bookstore to read some books and have a hot chocolate treat.
column2: As we waited there for the drinks, I gently rubbed his neck while I thought about something else.&nbsp
column3: And it didn't even register when he - actually - politely asked me to stop.&nbsp
column4: I was caught up in my mental world and enjoyed the sensation of being affectionate with my son.&nbsp
column5: And then he used the phrase that struck me:

column2: Dad, you tell me that I have to stop when someone tells me to!&quot

column1: I had to apologize for doing that, agreeing that he was absolutely correct.
So that's something to remember when the kids are listening when someone tells them to stop.
column2: They're frequently in their own world of thought and imagination, and if they do hear it, they don't always have the self-discipline to stop doing something that they enjoy.&nbsp
column3:
This doesn't mean that I won't keep following up with them to remind to honor the word no, but I will try to use tonight's experience to keep some perspective.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
82,"1","1",,"xhtml","

How does a Dad handle the altered sleep schedule and survive?
column2: After you have children, your sleep habits will change dramatically and a full night's sleep will become much more dear.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: I write this before dawn after spending part of the night curled up with a first grader to help him sleep.&nbsp

column1: Having a child is a tiring thing and part of this will result of sheer lack of sleep.
column2: When they are babies, it's only fair that you take turns handling the night time duties
column3: this isn't just Mom's job and she needs rest, too.&nbsp
column4: And as they age, you'll continue to lose sleep because of child fear, nightmares, bedwetting and illness.&nbsp
column5: Once you think that they're beyond that, you'll be staying up late to wait for them as they proceed into the world.&nbsp
column6: This PracticalDad found out last night that he's going to be a chaperone until 2 AM for a high school cast party.&nbsp
column7: I've found that as I've aged, I've had to rethink what is acceptable for my own sleep.

column1: So how can a Dad cope with an interrupted sleep schedule?
column2: Here are some possibilities.

column1: <li>Take turns with the mother on being &quot
column2: on call&quot
column3: on alternating nights so that you can get a decent night's sleep.

column1: • When it's not your call night, retire earlier to catch up on what you've missed.

column2: I've historically felt guilty taking a nap since there's always &quot
column3: other stuff&quot
column4: but I've come to accept that a nap is an acceptable way to compensate for the lost sleep since it helps me continue to function.

column1: <li>Keep a favorite kid's video handy to occupy the kids when you need a rest.&nbsp
column2: One of our children slept horribly at night for about a year and I had to contend with an older child as well.&nbsp
column3: When the younger one went to sleep and the older one was awake, I'd pull the video out and let older child watch it as she curled up in my lap - while I napped.

column1: <li>Synchronize your nap with the child's nap and even curl up with the child for a period.&nbsp
column2: I found that a half-hour snooze at the start of the child's two hour nap left me 90 minutes - refreshed - to get work done.

column1: Raising children is a marathon and when you have several of them, it's akin to an Ironman competition.
column2:
Take care of yourself so that you can take care of them.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
83,"1","1",,"xhtml","

A major concern for a PracticalDad during the Fall season is setting up Flu vaccinations for the kids before the official flu season "
column2: kicks off&quot
column3: around January.&nbsp
column4: Anyone with a child in (pre-)school knows that these rooms are incredibly efficient germ incubators, even with stringent hand-washing follow-up by teachers.&nbsp
column5: There are cases in which the flu virus can wipe out a third of a classroom at any one time.&nbsp
column6: Consequently, it's important to make sure that both you, your mate and your children receive the flu vaccine.&nbsp
column7: Fortunately, most kids can now receive the vaccine via a nasal inhaler.

column1: More serious than a common cold, influenza - the flu - is a highly contagious virus spread through infected droplets from coughing and sneezing, or left on surfaces.
column2: That means that any classroom with small children will be inundated with the germs when the flu season really takes off in January.&nbsp
column3: Any child with a true case of influenza can suffer from regular cold symptoms as well as fever, and can also have to deal with nausea/vomiting and diarrhea.&nbsp
column4: The flu's duration will typicall last for several days with a resulting cough lasting up to two weeks.&nbsp
column5: Even before your child shows symptoms of the flu, he can be contagious and that contagion stage can last to five days after becoming sick.

column1: Worse cases of the flu can develop into pneumonia and dehydration, requiring some hospitalization for further treatment.
In February, 2008 the Centers for Disease Control changed the recommended ages for children to receive the vaccine.
column2: The previous suggested age range was for any child from six months to five years of age, but studies were finding that the illness rates for all children was up to three times that of adults.&nbsp
column3: The consequent change is for all children from six months to 19 years of age.

column1: The start of the vaccination period is usually in September/October adn the vaccines are available through late December.
column2: It would be better however, to have the vaccines given earlier since it generally takes several weeks for the immunity to build.&nbsp
column3: Additionally, a child receiving the vaccine for the first time will have to have two shots, one several weeks before the other in order to help prepare the body for the full effect of the vaccination.&nbsp
column4: After that, any further flu vaccinations will only have to occur once annually.

column1: To find out about flu vaccine availability, contact your family doctor or pediatrician in early September and they should be able to tell you when vaccine clinics are scheduled
column2: these will be run to improve the efficiency of vaccinating a large number of children at one time.&nbsp
column3: If you don't have a physician, then contact your local health department and they can direct you.

column1: How do the kids receive the vaccine?
column2: Any child over the age of two - except for those with asthma or other chronic health problems - can receive the vaccine via a nasal inhaler, called Flumist.
column3: Those younger than two, or with these problems, will receive a shot so expect a nasty but short interval of crying.&nbsp
column4: The Flumist vaccine is administered via the nostrils with a burst up each nostril, followed by a quick inhalation by the child.&nbsp
column5: The vaccine does not guarantee that your child will avoid the flu, but it can at least lessen the impact as the body has had an opportunity to develop some immunity to the virus.

column1: What is your child is less than six months old?
column2: In that case, the child should not have the vaccination
column3: however, YOU should.&nbsp
column4: That way, you are protected and don't have to take all of the extra precautions to ensure that the baby doesn't catch it from you.

column1: Yes, there is the possibility of a slight reaction to the vaccine, usually with the onset of minor cold symptoms, nausea or diarrhea
column2: within about 24 hours.&nbsp
column3: One of my children responded to the vaccine with nausea the following day, but my wife and I deem that an acceptable risk versus the much higher likelihood of flu should there be no vaccination.&nbsp
column4: That same child has had to be admitted to the hospital for treatment of dehydration after becoming dangerously dehydrated.&nbsp
column5: There is a very small risk of a serious reaction to the vaccine, but these incidents are exceedingly rare.&nbsp
column6: If you do have such a concern, please speak to your family doctor or pediatrician for a better understanding of the risk.

column1: I understand that parents have concerns about the long-term effects of vaccinating their children but our family's practice has been to have the vaccinations since we have lived with the effects and after-effects of childhood flu.
column2:
If you do have such concerns, please contact your physician in order to address your concerns.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
84,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Having a sick child is a difficult experience, but things can really augur into the ground if the sickness is passed amongst the family and one child to another.
column2: Effective germ control is an imperative to at least give you&nbsp
column3: a fighting chance in the sick period.

column1: Almost every parent with whom I've spoken over the years acknowledges that their child tended to get more cold and viruses after they entered an environment with other children.
column2: Any classroom or daycare facility will facilitate more disease spread and only the most rigorous&nbsp
column3: handwashing regimen there can combat it.&nbsp
column4: And let's face it, kids don't want to waste their valuable play time washing their hands.&nbsp
column5: And once they get something, it's going to come home and become your problem.

column1: So how can you at least maintain some control in your house and mitigate the spread of germs amongst the family?
column2: You can try some of these ideas but be ready to have to adhere to things rigorously.&nbsp
column3: And guys aren't known for being rigorous about hygiene.

column1: <li>Wash your hands rigorously - both in terms of time spent washing and the number of times you wash.&nbsp
column2: Antibacterial soap is ideal but any soap will work if done properly.&nbsp
column3: This means for about 20 seconds of solid lathering and rubbing, including between all the fingers and up to the wrist.&nbsp
column4: In warm water.

column1: <li>Keep some hand lotion available since your hands will probably crack and dry from all of the washing.&nbsp
column2: This PracticalDad prefers something with aloe to help the skin.

column1: <li>Monitor the children closely for clean hands and stay on them.&nbsp
column2: After using the toilet and before any meal or snack.&nbsp
column3: After you notice them wiping their nose or coughing in their hands.&nbsp
column4: Make them wash and if they can't count to 20, then they can sing the Birthday song as a general guide for time spent.&nbsp
column5: I clocked my rendition at fifteen seconds, so they may want to go for two rounds of the Birthday song.&nbsp
column6: When the kids get sick, there isn't much rest and you simply have to suck it up and watch them carefully.

column1: <li>Work to keep all utensils and plates/glasses from being shared.&nbsp
column2: If there's a common bathroom cup - and frankly, there should never be one - give each child their own cup for use.&nbsp
column3: A disposable cup is best, since you can mark a particular child's with a favorite sticker as an identifier for that child and that child only.

column1: <li>Stay on top of any and all surfaces and disinfect them frequently.&nbsp
column2: This PracticalDad will stock up on disposable disinfectant wipes and wander the house when able to wipe down common surfaces.&nbsp
column3: These surfaces can be bathroom and kitchen counters, doorknobs, bath and sink faucets, surfaces of remote controls and electronic devices, toilet seats and rims and the floors around the toilets, sink surfaces, appliance handles - particularly refrigerators.&nbsp

column1: • Commonly shared toys should be removed and later wiped down.
• Sick children should be relegated to their rooms for as long as practicable, but this shouldn't be to the point of their feeling as though they're being punished.
• Sick children should never be allowed to rifle the fridge or bread drawers for food.
Naturally, this means that you and Mom will have to ride herd on this process so fully expect that the regular daily stuff of life
column2: is going to take a hit due to lack of time and pure exhaustion.&nbsp
column3: This especially will get worse if there's one or more vomiting and nothing brings more joy than a family pukefest.

column2: When you do use any cleaner or disinfectant wipes,&nbsp
column3: be sure to keep them out of the way of your children.&nbsp
column4: Small children are used to being cleaned by baby wipes and a non-reader could get hurt if trying to wipe themselves with a disinfectant wipe.

column1: For further information, check out the Centers for Disease Control site at www.cdc.gov/germstopper/home_work_school.htm

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
85,"1","1",,"xhtml","

If you want to really see what daily life is like for your kids, follow the examples of Patrick and John, and have lunch with the kids at school.
Both are fathers of elementary school students and take the opportunity to periodically join their kids for school lunch.
column2: They then join them on the playground for games of soccer and football with the other kids.&nbsp
column3: As Patrick stated, if you really want to get the kids united, score a goal from across the field and they'll mob you.

column1: It's not a practice that the overwhelming majority of parents use, let alone fathers.
column2: But it does serve several purposes.

column1: • It allows you to meet the teacher on more than just the periodic parent/teacher conference and see how he or she handles the class.
• It allows you to meet some of the other kids and put faces to names that you're hearing repeatedly.
<li>It allows you to see how your child interacts with the other kids, and how they interact with him.&nbsp
column2: Your kid will most likely become so involved in play that he'll forget that you're watching - or even playing - and you can see the real kid come out.&nbsp
column3: It can be eye-opening.

column2: show you off&quot
column3: as a father.&nbsp
column4: There are children out there with little, if any, knowledge of what's it like to have a father so any modeling that you can offer - even as minimal an amount as this - is beneficial.

column1: It really isn't difficult to do this and greatly worth the time.
column2: Contact your local school and inquire about the procedures, which will probably involve registering at the office and using a clip-on pass.&nbsp
column3: Also let the teacher know ahead of time so that they have a &quot
column4: heads up&quot

column1:
86,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With fathers having a greater role in raising the kids, they'll be there for more of the "
column2: first&quot
column3: moments than in the past and Mom might be missing them instead.&nbsp
column4: Some of these things are unavoidable but it pays to think about those &quot
column5: firsts&quot
column6: than can be scheduled.&nbsp
column7: I believe that most mothers do miss the ability to be there for these instances and it can soothe a relationship if you pay attention.

column1: It was fourteen years ago this Thanksgiving that my eldest had her first bite of solid food.
column2: I remember this date as we were in a Naval Officer's Club with relatives for a Thanksgiving meal with our first-born baby.&nbsp
column3: She'd been making headway in readiness for solid food but it didn't occur to me that it was that soon
column4: I excused myself to the restroom and returned to find Mom and Mother-in-law had decided to make the leap and the baby was happily finishing up her first green bean.&nbsp
column5: It wasn't that she had taken the first bite, but the fact that the decision for this situation was made in my absence, that bothered me.&nbsp
column6: You can't exercise great control over rolling over and the first steps, but the baby didn't put the food in her own mouth.&nbsp
column7: Since then, I've tried to bear this experience in mind as we've moved forward with other firsts and other children.

column1: A little forethought can make absence a bit more bearable for Mom.

87,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Some important life skills come about through learning to manage schoolwork and homework - time management, self-discipline, consequences - and this PracticalDad fully supports the role of said work.
column2: But it's a bit of a trial-and-error process in the household since no kids are alike and the one might not be handling it as well as another.&nbsp
column3: So I have a quiet internal controversy about my role in managing schoolwork and how much I might be helping versus hindering in the long-term.

column1: Technology has permitted parents much greater latitude than our own folks probably ever had.
column2: School systems offer online programs that not only list the current student grades, but also offer teacher comments and daily updated homework assignments.&nbsp
column3: The message to parents is <em>take advantage of the technology to keep tabs on how your child is doing.&nbsp
column4: Keep up with the homework and see if he/she's missing or failing anything.&nbsp
column5: Stay on top of them since grades matter!

column2: But how far do I take it?

column1: At the upper elementary level, the students are given weekly planners for listing all assignments and upcoming tests and it's my responsibility to review it daily and sign off to verify that it's been seen.
column2: Starting at the middle school level, I can visit the daily school district website to remotely ascertain what's required for homework and tests.
Do I require my child to continue to bring me all of the pertinent work for my review after it's done?&nbsp
column3: If so, then I'm assured that everything is being done and can be corrected so that the maximum grades are obtained.&nbsp
column4: I can also see what the teacher is covering and how material is being approached.&nbsp
column5: If I know this and think that some remedial work is necessary, then I know how to approach it as well.

column1: But if I don't review all of the work, then problems might be missed and assignments scotched with resulting poorer grades.
column2: However, my child will learn the lesson of consequences better than if I review everything with him.&nbsp
column3: The simple reality is that I won't always be there and there has to be a level of self-sufficiency.

column2: As usual, it depends upon the age of the child.

column1: <li>Younger children, through elementary school, have their materials checked daily and the homework is handled before other non-scheduled events occur.&nbsp
column2: This will include reviewing everything for correctness and completeness.&nbsp
column3: The thought is that as the child ages and is raised in a particular routine, that routine will hopefully be imprinted on the kid for the future.

column1: <li>When they get to upper elementary and middle school, I've taken to checking the planner as usual, but no longer review the assignments for completeness and correctness.&nbsp
column2: They should, by now, have some sense of what's involved in reviewing their work and will suffer the consequent dings for not following through.

column1: <li>With one now in high school, and apparently in control of the coursework, I no longer look at things daily but will go to the system every week or so.&nbsp
column2: By now, we've thoroughly explained that the costs of college will also be met by her own efforts in addition to what we've been able to save.&nbsp
column3: We began this discussion when middle school commenced.&nbsp
column4: We've also continued our insistence that other activities and sports are entirely dependent upon good grades.

column1: And I'm finding that I have to re-evaluate and adjust as needed.
column2: Children are not alike in their skill sets and personalities and I'm having to blur the line as things continue.

column1: Like the rest of fatherhood, this is a highly inexact science and I won't really know how things went for quite some time.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
88,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's evening and you're home from work, or weekend and there's a full allotment of chores and jobs to be done.
column2: And your child asks that you play a game with him.&nbsp
column3: You might think that <em>I'm busy and there's too much to do.&nbsp
column4: I can't spend the time here so he'll have to play video games/in his room/ etc.&nbsp
column5: Bear in mind that as a parent, playing with your child is one of your most important tasks.
column6: Apart from the creation of emotional bonds and spending of &quot
column7: quality time&quot
column8: , there are practical benefits for both of you.

column1: First, you get an opportunity to see how he's developing in a number of ways.
column2: How well does he learn the rules and flow of play?&nbsp
column3: How does he handle early forms of adversity when the game doesn't go the way that he'd like?&nbsp
column4: Does he cheat - and trust me, most do after a certain age - and how does he respond to your handling of the consequences of cheating?&nbsp
column5: Is he picking up habits or phrases from other children as they play games at school?&nbsp
column6: If it's a&nbsp
column7: game that he knows but you don't, how well does he teach you?

column1: Consequently, he gets some practical insights into life.
column2: What happens when someone catches you cheating?&nbsp
column3: For that matter, does he even know that it's wrong to change the rules in the course of the game?&nbsp
column4: That sounds simplistic, but if the children are only learning from playing with other children and not adults who might hold them accountable, then do they really learn honesty and accountability?&nbsp
column5: Does he have someone help him with some higher level thought processes, such as choosing between competing alternatives?

column1: This was brought home to me this weekend by my first grader, who found a box of Old Maid cards in a Santa stocking from a tree lighting ceremony.
column2: It was a cheap deck and would've cost no more than $1.50.&nbsp
column3: As I glanced at the paper with my coffee and considered the list of chores, he asked if we could play a round of this new game.&nbsp
column4: I demurred and then reconsidered and wound up playing four hands with him.&nbsp
column5: What did we get to work on in Old Maid?

column1: <li>Each set of cards was labelel with the names of characters.&nbsp
column2: We practiced putting the dealt cards in alphabetic order to assure ease of matching as the game progressed.

column1: • What happens when he has the Old Maid card and tries to foist it off on Dad?
column2: His attempts to shift the cards around so that I chose that particular card only doomed him.<em>&nbsp
column3: Watch what people do and that will give you clues as to where things really are.&nbsp
column4: Match that against what they really say.
column5: He even learned a poker term, &quot
column6: the tell&quot

column1: • Pay attention to detail, because it's good to know where the Old Maid card was placed if your opponent took it and you don't want to get it back.
<li>Sometimes you win and sometimes you lose.&nbsp
column2: Unfortunate, but true.

column1: <li>What are the consequences when you decide to unilaterally change the rules?&nbsp
column2: Life isn't a round of Calvinball and others will object.

column1: After four rounds of this, I closed up that activity and moved on to the chores.
column2: But the activity was invaluable and gave each of us new insights and information that we didn't have before.

column1:
And the chores still managed to get done.

89,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Your child is in preschool and you're starting to play simple card and board games with her.
column2: &nbsp
column3: Not all games are created equal and not all kids are ready for the more competitive games that require basic strategic thinking.&nbsp
column4: What might you keep in mind?

column1: • The earliest games that you choose should give the child the opportunity to win without being allowed to win.
column2: Children want to do well and show what they can do, so winning does matter to them.&nbsp
column3: On the other hand, letting them win games for which they are unprepared sets up a bad precedent for a future life.&nbsp
column4: Games such as Candyland are great since the chance of winning is random and the child has the chance to win without any strategic thought.
column5: You can instead concentrate on more basic skills like taking turns and color recognition.&nbsp
column6: Checkers is a lousy choice except for the rarest of cases.

column1: <li>Not all games accomplish the same thing.&nbsp
column2: Assemble a variety of games that teach different things in a fun way.

column1: <li>How many bells and whistles are there?&nbsp
column2: Having to constantly install batteries is a nuisance and some games are rendered useless if too many parts are missing.

column1: <li>If you have children of different age levels, is this a game that can be enjoyed by everybody?&nbsp
column2: I was surprised to find that when I had high schoolers to my house for a youth group event, they all took turns playing Candyland.

column1: <li>What's the general time frame on length of play?&nbsp
column2: If you have limited time, then it's fair to opt for a game that has a short time frame.

column1: Over the next series of articles, we'll explore some of the games that are available and what they offer.

91,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's important to keep the communication lines open with your kids and easy to let them get jammed.
column2: That jamming can be a function of both time and interest as they grow and branch out and you suddenly look at your teen and wonder when did that happen?

column1: It's easy to find time together with the smaller children.
column2: There aren't so many activites and they still enjoy playing ball or games with Dad.&nbsp
column3: And I've wondered how to carve out time with the teen
column4: while some think that the teens don't care to spend time with the old man, I was surprised to get a stray comment from mine about getting together.&nbsp
column5: She's involved in sports and other activities and when I've the opportunity to do something, she's been gone.&nbsp
column6: And vice-versa.&nbsp
column7: And with the younger ones still about, it's easier to make&nbsp
column8: their moments&nbsp

column1: And I remembered what the friend of a friend did with his teens.
column2: He made it a point to have regular &quot
column3: dates&quot
column4: with his kids, without any other siblings or adults around.&nbsp
column5: It was their regular &quot
column6: time&quot
column7: and he scheduled it as though it were a meeting or sport practice.&nbsp
column8: So when my teen was coming home from school earlier than her siblings, I took her to lunch and without the PC or TV, we had a wide-ranging conversation full of the laughter that seems to be lacking in the press of life.

column2: It gave us the chance to renew our ties and see her in yet another light as she matures.&nbsp
column3: It isn't the Candyland gameboard or the backyard, but it works just as well and it will take it's place in the monthly calendar.

92,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Fathers with children know that while the mother might be responsible for the Christmas purchases and preparation, what happens with gifts after Christmas is often up to Dad.
column2: Toys need assembled and electronics connected and kids being kids, they each want their own thing done first.&nbsp
column3: So after some years of experience, I have a &quot
column4: toolkit&quot
column5: of things that I make sure are available for Christmas Day and the day after.

column1: • Phillips head screwdrivers in regular size - think bicycles and outside toys - and also smaller versions to unscrew the backs of electronic games.
• A wrench set for whatever outside toys come along - again think bicycles or basketball nets.
<li>Several sets of AA, AAA, C and D batteries for the electronic devices.&nbsp
column2: A good rule of thumb is to count in advance what gifts require batteries and then get approximately four times the numbers of batteries.&nbsp
column3: For example, if there are three handheld games not requiring a power cord, then purchase 12 AA batteries for use.

column1: <li>Several rolls of tape of all varieties.&nbsp
column2: This not only includes scotch tape, but also duct tape and painters tape.&nbsp
column3: The painters tape is especially helpful in marking electronic cords that might have to be removed and then reinstalled&nbsp
column4: with the new TV or other component.&nbsp
column5: My eldest didn't take it well when she wanted to just yank the cords from the back of the TV prior to moving it
column6: I explained that systems with multiple components and cables can be truly messed up if the cords aren't properly placed.&nbsp
column7: Despite her protest, I'm still waiting for her to do it.

column1: <li>Pen and notepaper for keeping a list of what has to be assembled.&nbsp
column2: The children aren't usually forgiving when they think that they're being replaced in the assembly loop and you may actually want to let the kids choose a random number to help decide whose toy is completed first.&nbsp
column3: This eliminates tne grousing about how &quot
column4: Dad loves Johnny more than me.&quot

column1: • A supply of zip-lock bags in sandwich and storage sizes to hold gamepieces, action figure parts and trading/playing cards.
<li>An envelope for each child to hold money and gift cards.&nbsp
column2: The contents can be labelled on the named envelope and it can be kept in a central location&nbsp
column3: so that the contents aren't thrown out with the trash.&nbsp
column4: Been there, done that...

column2: You're going to multitask and being kids, they'll think that the world turns on their ability to play with the presents.&nbsp
column3: This will also include mouthy, occasionally disrespectful commentary.

column1: As a side-note, it's helpful to share notes with your mate before Christmas Day's arrival so that you can have a sense of what's coming and how to best make things work - scheduling wise, that is.
You're likely to be tired afterwards, but it's worth the time and headache and the kids will wonder how Dad is able to manage to put the stuff together so effortlessly.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"
reality&quot
column3: television and routinely pass on watching it.&nbsp
column4: This is partially a result of available time, but also a belief that the presence of a camera kills real spontaneity and personality.&nbsp
column5: It breeds artificiality.&nbsp
column6: That said, I find the presence of a three year old child as part of a package deal to be both fascinating and extremely disturbing.&nbsp
column7: The fact that four of the 25 available bachelorettes are also single mothers only raises both the fascination and disturbance.&nbsp

column1: From the clips viewed on both the internet and regular commercials, the child is apparently chipper, cute and sweet and the scenes with Dad are heartwarming.
column2: There are hugs, shoulder rides and curling up for naps and a lot of talk about finding a&nbsp
column3: stepmother for the boy.&nbsp
column4: Unfortunately, they don't reveal that Dad Jason is actually divorced and the tike already has a mother, living and breathing and agreeing to this for reasons that only God seems to understand.

column1: On the positive side of the ledger, it does serve to showcase affectionate and positive paternal behavior and could serve as
column2: a decent model of how a guy can interact with his son (or daughter).&nbsp
column3: This is a welcome change from the frequent depictions of television fathers as boorish, rude and out-of-touch
column4: Stephen Collins' portrayal of Reverend Camden on Seventh Heaven stands out as an exception to this trend.

column1: On the negative side of the ledger, it could represent an unrealistic portrayal of fatherhood.
column2: A three year-old child is at a great age and they can be a much more wonderful experience than a two year-old or fourteen year-old
column3: they are eager and innocent and haven't yet learned to think of their parent as an idiot-savant.&nbsp
column4: But the simple reality is that a child also requires a great deal of patience, energy and discipline.&nbsp
column5: Will they show the Bachelor having to contend with the whinies because the socks don't feel right or he's cranky from too much activity and lack of sleep?&nbsp
column6: Will they show the Bachelor having to oversee a time-out or carry the recalcitrant kid out of the grocery store like a sack of BOGO potatoes?&nbsp
column7: Real fathers, like real mothers, can and do get testy and exasperated and there's nothing abnormal about that.

column1: Likewise, I do question whether having a three year-old shown in such a situation is healthy for the kid.
column2: What's he learning about real courtship and building a real relationship with a woman.&nbsp
column3: Women being courted do take special care in how they present themselves and want to look their best, but seeing Dad with 25 women who look like beauty queens isn't a good basis for reality.&nbsp
column4: Especially when the physically hot-and-heavy moments hit the airwaves.&nbsp
column5: And how is this being explained to the boy?&nbsp
column6: That 25 women are competing to be Dad's new wife - and your stepmother?&nbsp
column7: <em>Daddy, if you became a polygamist and moved to Utah,&nbsp
column8: you could have 'em all!&nbsp
column9: This sets the future stage for a budding-narcissistic personality who expects people to fall all over themselves to be with him.

column1: Honestly, if any woman that I ever dated saw me in that kind of romantic situation with another woman, I'd have been shot.
So when it comes on, I'll check it out with a great deal of curiosity but not much hope.

94,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Major holidays are a wonderful respite and in this household are marked by visits from out-of-town family and gatherings with nearby friends.
column2: &nbsp
column3: The corresponding school break means no need for the kids to rise early and their activities are largely on hold.&nbsp
column4: So speaking plainly, all routine and schedule goes straight to hell.&nbsp
column5: And this is always followed by the need to get them back on schedule and when we haven't handled it well, the resulting attitudes and behaviors from the disrupted sleep schedule and routine have been unpleasant.&nbsp
column6: Face it, we all need our sleep and kids need it even more than the adults.

column1: The return to a typical schedule is easier this year since the large majority of schools are returning on a Monday after a Thursday (New Years) holiday.
column2: This provides an opportunity to ease the transition to routine by working it in over several extra days.&nbsp
column3: In other years, the New Year's Eve event is followed next day by a standard bedtime the next evening with school the following morning.&nbsp
column4: Since the kids are more revved than a '70 GTO, this typically leads to cranky and befuddled mornings that take several days to remedy.

column1: In the PracticalDad household, the long weekend after the holiday permits us to:
<li>Review backpacks (for younger kids) for any work that needs completed before Monday's return
<li>Start a general clean-up of the house so that the household isn't still a wreck for days afterwards
<li>Return to the general chores that each child has to do, including making beds and picking up toys that were left while everyone was caught up in the melee
<li>Return to the academic drills that were put aside for the holidays, which might include mandatory reading times, spelling lists and various kinds of math drills
<li>Return to the music practices that were put aside

<li>Work our way back into a normal sleep schedule with the difference between standard and holiday bedtimes shortened each evening so that the night before school is akin to a regular bedtime and Little Johnny doesn't spend hours in bed staring at the ceiling
• Work our way back to standard wake-up times so that the child is hopefully back in the swing of arising at the required time.

Bear in mind that with older kids, it's helpful to look at schoolwork before the break begins since they're at a level that might require even more work over the holidays than can safely be done in two or three days.
While parents see a return to normality as positive and kids really do thrive with routine and structure, they love chaos and most are anarchists at heart.
column2: So be ready for squawking and whining and some unpleasantries in the household over these several days.&nbsp
column3:
Still take the time to play the Christmas gift games and enjoy the little time left, but this effort will make the return to routine more manageable and much less stressful.

With the Christmas break ending and a return to "
column2: normal&quot
column3: in three days, there's a need to get the kids back into the swing of regular life as painlessly as possible.&nbsp
column4: By painless, I refer to the kids' eyes sprained by rolling them so much at Dad.&nbsp
column5: So today was the first day in a several-day effort to bring normality back to the household.&nbsp
column6: This is a cumulative process as just throwing them into bed on Sunday night after so much hoopla invites disaster.&nbsp

column1: <li>For the most part, they awoke at reasonable hours although not at school time.&nbsp
column2: The exception was the feverish one who slept through until mid-morning, and I'll live with that one.

column1: • Each kid had their own to-do list with the caveat that upon successful completion and approval by Dad, they could have time on the new Wii system.
column2: With such incentive, each took some care to assure that things were completed, although some items fell through as is the wont of all teenagers.

column1: • We were back to the usual sniping and grousing that comes from the younger children.
<li>Dinner was held at a reasonable time, altough the meal didn't come off as I expected.&nbsp
column2: Newly discovered leftovers left the new dish in the dust.
family fun&quot
column3: night as we broke in the new Wii system and this is where the wheels fell off of the wagon.&nbsp
column4: Bedtime for each was exceptionally late and if they arise at a regular time tomorrow, then there will be hell to pay on account of attitude and integrity.

column1: So the catch-up tomorrow will be to assure that they at least get some sleep in the morning and a recurrent grinding of parental teeth as they
column2: bounce off one another like so many marbles.&nbsp
column3: And tomorrow evening is also the crunch time for getting to bed at a reasonable hour since a late bedtime tomorrow would definitely affect the bedtime on Sunday night, the last night before school.&nbsp
column4: If that goes, then the first several days of school will be unpleasant while they get the routine back down pat again.

Early on in fatherhood experience, I decided that if I wanted the kids to believe that they could come to me with questions or problems, I would have to learn to control my responses when the questions and comments got uncomfortable.
column2: In today's smartass age, it's too easy to be sarcastic and kids are looking for answers instead of sarcasm.&nbsp
column3: And as they age, they'll shy away from conversation and question if they believe that Dad's going to overreact.&nbsp
column4: I haven't fully mastered it even now, but it's a damned sight better than it ever used to be.

column1: <li>When your four year-old pipes up in the backseat and asks &quot
column2: what's a mother*&amp
column3: ^%$@?&quot

column1: • When your fourth-grader makes a caustic, off-color remark (ignoring the paternal pride that it's a really funny and on-target remark).
• When one of your children makes the first reference to a sexual act, not involving intercourse.
When these things happen - and believe me, they have - what do I try to remember?
• Keep things calm and don't blow a gasket.
• Where is this coming from and what's the source?
• Oops, if that's from me, how do I fix this?
• Is this something requiring immediate action or can I address it at a more opportune time?
<li>How much do they really understand what they just said?&nbsp
column2: If they're asking,&nbsp
column3: it's safe to&nbsp
column4: assume that they don't understand.

column1: • My response(s) need to be straight-forward and honest, regardless of how uncomfortable that might be.
<li>After providing the simple fact, provide a bit&nbsp
column2: of&nbsp
column3: morality to put it in context.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: For example,&nbsp
column6: <em>that's not something that&nbsp
column7: we ever say, even Daddy.

column1: <li>Don't make it a joke afterwards or followup with some sarcastic remark.&nbsp
column2: For&nbsp
column3: example,&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: <em>we don't say that someone is &quot
column6: on the rag&quot
column7: , even if Mrs. Ferkley could be a spokesperson for Tampax.

column1: This is an ongoing exercise and even now, I have moments where the comment or situation is so outrageous that my reaction overwhelms my practice.
column2: But it's worked often enough that I continue to hear them.&nbsp
column3:
Which is what I want.

column1: If you give a young boy a Pinewood Derby race car kit, he's going to want to build it.
And despite being before school in the morning, it's a snow delay so you say okay.
You ask him to get pencil and paper to draw some ideas of what he wants the car to look like while you pull out the peanut butter and jelly.
He can't find a pencil, so you put the jelly jar on the counter while you help him find one and the elder sibling decides to open the race car kit box, causing a fight between the two kids.
You separate the kids and get the other child settled doing something else, and finish helping the cub scout find a pencil.
The pencil is brand new so you send the cub scout to sharpen it while you return to packing lunches.
He can't get the sharpener to work so you go over to find it overflowing with shavings, needing to be emptied.
You give the shavings tray to the cub scout to empty as you return to the kitchen and you hear a crash of glass as the elder sibling - who's decided to help - drops the jelly jar on the floor.
As you enter to see what's happened, the boys start scuffling again as the older sibling squawks at and pushes the cub scout for walking across the spilled jelly.
When you separate the boys, you step in jelly as the tray of pencil shavings is knocked from the cub scout's hands and across the kitchen floor.
The elder child then steps in the mound of jelly spewed across the linoleum.
You thank God that both are wearing shoes but have to keep them on amidst the shards of sticky jelly glass.
column2: You have to have them walk out of the spill zone, spreading the mess like grape-flavored ebola virus.

column1: You help each kid get their shoes off since they don't want to get their hands dirty and toss the shoes into the garage, then quickly return to separate them in separate parts of the living room.

As you wipe off the shoes in the garage and return to start clearing the debris from the kitchen floor, the scout retrieves the kit box and returns to open it in the living room, then spilling four nail axles across the light colored carpet.
You respond to the yelling and insist that they not move while you run upstairs to don another pair of shoes so that you can carry them out of the living room.
The elder child sees the clock and insists that the bus will be coming shortly, so you carry them to the garage to put on their sticky shoes, then run inside to get their coats and backpacks.
column2: En route, you look at the only-started sandwiches and tell them that they're buying as you shove them out through the garage.

column1: And once you've found the nails and finished mopping the kitchen floor, it dawns on you that one of them doesn't have enough on the lunch ticket for lunch.
column2: So you have to get the keys to take lunch money for a meal.

column1:
And the kids wonder why you're cranky when the Pinewood Derby kit is brought to you that evening, because if you give a cub scout a Pinewood Derby kit...

101,"1","2",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml","http://www.cpyu.org","none","The site for a non-profit organization devoted to clarifying the constant changes in today's youth culture.  It's a great resource for helping to keep up with your 'tween and teen.","xhtml"

column2: raising children, especially in terms of exposure to sex.&nbsp
column3: It's one thing to be able to monitor what's on the television - and even that gets difficult at times - but another thing entirely when it comes to music.&nbsp
column4: The rise of the iPod/mp3 player, downloadable music and burnable disc has made parental surveillance far more difficult because of the lack of labels and also much more important than it was.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: What are some things to consider?&nbsp

column1: First, be clear and explicit that if it's in the house, it's a privilege and not a right.
column2: Two of my own have their own personal players - one an iPod and the other an mp3 player - and even though the elder bought the iPod herself, it was with parental consent and an explicit understanding that there could be unexpected inspections of&nbsp
column3: the contents.&nbsp
column4: And gross failure would result in confiscation.&nbsp

column1: Kids will trade CDs amongst themselves and even if you can monitor what they purchase, you can't monitor their friends' buys.
column2: So I do take the opportunity to keep an eye on what's laying around and have on occasion required that a CD be returned to the owner because of contents.&nbsp
column3: It wasn't liked, but with the expectation made clear, it happened.&nbsp
column4: What if the CDs are kept in drawers?&nbsp
column5: Again, the kids are clear that while they deserve some respect of their privacy, we have the right to toss their rooms if we deem it necessary.&nbsp

column1: Besides, that's one of the reasons that I'm still willing to help them put away clothing.

column2: The simplest way to follow what's happening in the culture is to simply sit with the kids and watch music videos with them or periodically listen to their favorite stations.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, some station websites will have lists of the most popular and requested songs in a specific period of time.&nbsp
column4: Listen to a few at random and hear what it says.&nbsp
column5: Likewise, purchase your own mp3 player - I'm too cheap to buy an iPod - and load your own favorite music.&nbsp
column6: Offer to share it with the kids and you'd probably be surprised to find that they're really curious about your taste in music and much more willing to share the contents of theirs as well.&nbsp
column7: I was surprised that my eldest had Queen and Styx on her iPod.

column1: If you can't understand what's said, and it hasn't improved since we were teens, then you can visit a lyrics
column2: site.&nbsp
column3: There are any number available and most are up to date on current lyrics.&nbsp
column4: Most lyrics are still fairly innocuous in terms of sexual content, but others are more explicit
column5: even the innocuous lyrics can be surprising given the constantly changing slang.&nbsp

column1: If you run across phrases that don't make sense, then the best alternative is to then explore the phrases themselves.
column2: And for that exercise, you&nbsp
column3: should visit urban dictionary, a site dedicated to the recording of the most scatological and sexual slang.
column4: It is educational, appalling and sometimes even hilarious.&nbsp
column5: I've made it a point to visit the site on multiple occasions because of things that I hear from teens and this is from teens in a church and Christian venue.

column1: An Exercise (and the links are explicit, so get ready)
I spent an evening with some teens and the conversation turned to Crank Dat, a then-popular song
column2: by Soulja Boy.&nbsp
column3: Some were laughing at the lyrics and others were confused at the &quot
column4: Superman&quot
column5: reference.&nbsp
column6: I was aware of the slang usage of superman
column7: so I was able to finally manage the discussion into male/female relationships - and the session would have been a lot worse had I not been aware.&nbsp
column8: I still returned home that night to double check the lyrics of the song and after cross-referencing, was astonished to find that no one had picked up on the &quot

column1: This is a practice that you can try with songs chosen at random, so that you have a sense of what's coming through the ear-buds.
And in today's world, what's through the ear-buds can be corrosive so it's worth the time and effort.

One of our end-of-the-year tasks in the PracticalDad household is culling the closets for items to donate to charity.
column2: While we periodically donate throughout the year, there are plenty of instances where growing children find that&nbsp
column3: what fit three weeks ago no longer does
column4: those items are typically pulled but never actually seem to make it out of their bedrooms.&nbsp
column5: Hence, a mess.

column1: The youngest had multiple too-small items folded on the closet shelf, and the eldest was collecting items for several months in the floor of her own closet.
column2: Simply put, there were too many things in too many different places and it was becoming confusing.&nbsp
column3: What to do?

column1: We resurrected a solution that had fallen through the cracks after a move the previous year.
column2: There is now a large cardboard box in the corner of the garage to hold those items that should be sent to various charities.&nbsp
column3: I no longer have to roam from room to room and root through closets and shelves and after checking, the children can simply take their items to the box.&nbsp
column4: When the box is full, I can sort, itemize and get the items where they need to go.

column2: bedtime routines&quot
column3: and while they continue for years, they naturally change as the kids age.

column1: When I was a kid, probably in third or fourth grade, the routine changed to one of teethbrushing followed by a goodnight kiss from the folks and then off to bed.
column2: Mom might enter to give me a kiss, but it was brief and there were no longer any prayers.&nbsp
column3: Dad was always downstairs ensconced in the favorite chair and almost never participated in the ritual.

column1: This kind of change has also taken root here as the kids grow and are less willing to have the usual routine.
column2: Or are they?&nbsp
column3: I'm finding that even the eldest - a high-schooler - still wants me to join her for a short cuddle before going to sleep.&nbsp
column4: The biggest change is that they wish to do a silent prayer instead of spoken, but the cuddling and quiet conversation is what they still want.&nbsp
column5: If I miss more than two nights of that, then one of them asks for some time before they nod off to sleep.&nbsp
column6: I admit that it might appear a little odd for a middle-aged man to curl up with a teen-age girl and I have found the concept disquieting as she's aged.&nbsp
column7: But I've balanced that by lying on top of the bedcovers while she's curled up beneath.&nbsp
column8: I believe that a father can and should be able to be affectionate with his daughter without having to worry about questions of impropriety.&nbsp

column1: These private moments continue to be important even as they age.
column2: It's a chance to share daily events and affections, or just talk about life for a few moments.&nbsp
column3: So I'll continue to miss the evening television programs and follow-through on the bedtime routines&nbsp
column4: as long as they last.

column1:
And I'll throw that missed season finale on the list of shows to rent on DVD.
