The New Year is a good time to make changes - it's easy to remember and when the change involves a topic in which time is involved, it's easy to remember the starting date.
And one of the family changes pertains to the kids' allowances.
column2: We're like many families in that we pay weekly allowances to the kids and unfortunately, we're also like others I know in which we're frequently in arrears on paying the kids.&nbsp
column3: <em>When were you last paid?&nbsp
column4: No, it couldn't be...you got it just a few weeks ago!&nbsp
column5: That's right, few is an irregular number akin to Pi and Phi, the biological constant.
column6: It's been the source of some argument with the kids and sore feelings with some concern that Dad's either an idiot or a cheat.

column1: This situation is a result of two things:
<li>The amount that we give each child is not necessarily a nice, round number
• We expect them to split the allowance into three components of spending money, savings money and charity money.
Simply put, I never have the right change for the kids to make it work and I keep forgeting to get to the store or bank to get it.
So it's becoming part of the family calendar along with piano lessons and sport practices.
column2: Family allowances.
column3: And then I'm making sure that I have twenty one dollar bills and rolls of coins in the desk drawer so that when that day comes, I can be the good Dad instead of the deadbeat.

We expect that our children will break away from us and that's what we want
column2: we want them to be able to survive in this world.&nbsp
column3: There are two things to remember:&nbsp
column4: First, not all steps are &quot
column5: big&quot
column6: steps noted by trumpets and choirs
column7: second, the early steps are gradual and a step in one area doesn't mean everything else changes as well.

column1: One of these steps occurred the other evening when I left the movies with my two sons and the elder son's friend.
column2: The two older boys were walking ahead of me and I reached down for the younger boy's hand as we were stepping into the parking lot.&nbsp
column3: He took it for no more than four seconds and then removed it and placed it in his coat pocket like the elder boys.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, he pulled his hood over his head and moved ahead to join them.&nbsp
column5: My immediate response was to again take his hand but I reconsidered.&nbsp
column6: I simply reminded him to continue to watch for cars and moved a little more quickly to keep a watchful pace several feet behind them.

column1: The older boys moved apart just enough for the younger to take a place between them and just behind, accepting them into their small world.
column2: This episode was only a powerfully short ten seconds, a span in which Dad was replaced by a willingness to venture with the other guys across the dark lot.&nbsp
column3: And a moment in which the middle-schoolers silently and willingly took in a first-grader into their world.

column1: What if I had insisted that he continue to hold my hand?
column2: Embarrassment before the older boys?&nbsp
column3: A reinforced sense that the only safe place in a normal environment was with his father, heightening a sense of uneasiness about the world around him?&nbsp
column4: The world does require vigilance and watching out for them is one of my primary jobs as a father.&nbsp
column5: But it's a disservice&nbsp
column6: to insist that the only safe place is by my side.&nbsp
column7: If I don't allow these small steps now, then the later larger steps will be more daunting than they need to be.

column1:
Later that night, the youngest asked me to cuddle with him after he went to bed and I happily obliged.

107,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Everybody reads how ill-informed our children are about history and current events.
column2: With all of the surrounding electronic noise to distract them, it's not surprising.&nbsp
column3: But do I require them to follow events and if so, to what extent?

column1: I believe that children can't become fully productive adults if they have no clue of what the surrounding world is like.
column2: National history, politics, current and economic events don't have the cachet of Britney or the excitement of American Idol.
column3: Not to mention that it's frequently disquieting.&nbsp
column4: In this household, I don't expect them to follow the daily news but I do discuss the news at the dinner table and around the house.&nbsp
column5: Last evening, we sat at the dinner table and I asked if they knew what would happen the following day
column6: fortunately, they knew that Barack Obama was being inaugurated and the significance of the event.&nbsp
column7: They weren't certain that they would see any of it in school but I was pleased to find that TV sets were available and on for the event.

column1: They were also told last night that they shouldn't expect to see anything on television after school except for the inauguration and the subsequent hoopla.
That's the exception to the rule, however.
column2: I don't require them to read the paper or follow the news unless we know of some special or extraordinary event.&nbsp
column3: The drumbeat of the media bearing bad news is discouraging even for adults, so I take the tack that it's my job to follow current events and then pass that along to them until they show readiness&nbsp
column4: and awareness.&nbsp
column5: The positive to this approach is that we can cushion the bad news and provide assurance to rattled kids.&nbsp
column6: The flip side is that they are unfamiliar with various news sources and &quot
column7: how&quot
column8: to read and listen.&nbsp
column9: It sounds over-protective - especially coming from me - but I'd prefer that they go through news with me to gain some perspective.&nbsp
column10:
And the first is old enough to start lessons on following the news, much to that child's chagrin.

109,"1","1",,"xhtml","

In the PracticalDad household, my spouse brings home the paycheck and I'm responsible for the household, money and kids.
column2: &nbsp
column3: Our joke is that she plays offense and I play defense.&nbsp
column4: And part of playing defense is to be aware of the larger environment and anticipate what's both on and over the horizon.&nbsp
column5: While some fathers might consider themselves to be wolves and lions guarding the pack and pride,&nbsp
column6: I've come to think of myself as a prairie dog, jutting his head out of the hole and sniffing for everything that I'm worth.

column1: What are some of the near-term things to watch for?

column2: When do the snowboots go on sale and does it make sense to buy them immediately when the kids are growing like weeds?&nbsp
column3: If I wait too long, will the inventory be sold out?&nbsp
column4: When do the school outfits and bathing suits come into stock and when do they go on post-season sale?

column2: Grocery stores usually run canned good sales in the Winter.&nbsp
column3: And holiday foods are usually sold out or seriously depleted by the time that the particular holiday arrives.

column2: When they reach high-school, the courses available widen and there has to be thought into what the kid takes.&nbsp
column3: Does the course work for that child and does it meet their need?&nbsp
column4: Not all kids are created equal in terms of talent and interest.

column1: What are some of the long-term things to consider?

column2: I have kids at different ages and they constitute the spectrum of time for planning purposes.&nbsp
column3: How do I save for college and how do I shift that money around as they age?&nbsp
column4: What do I have to do now to avoid a major problem later?

column2: How do I start preparing the kids to drive the car?&nbsp
column3: Are they sufficiently mature to even handle a vehicle when they reach driving age?&nbsp
column4: What do we do for vehicles, buy another or just learn to share?

column2: Believe me, this is the overarching concern into which everything else factors.&nbsp
column3: If I do this now, what is the effect on retirement savings?

column1: That means that I spend a great deal of time paying attention to the news and talking with other parents.
column2: It also means that things that I might enjoy are put aside until later and that is&nbsp
column3: itself part of being a father and parent.&nbsp
column4: Teaching the kids that gratification sometimes has to wait.

column1: So I have a mental list of books that I wish to read and movies to watch when - and assuming - there is more time.
And that list is very, very long.

We're now into January and even though everyone has had their shots and Flumist, the official flu season is now open.
column2: As I put cleaning supplies in the laundry closet, I realized that I'm out of the one thing that I really use at this time of year:&nbsp
column3: disinfectant wipes.

column1: Remember that the flu vaccine doesn't cover all flu variants.
column2: Instead, the government experts estimate which variant or two are most likely to strike and the contract goes to the pharmaceutical firms for production.&nbsp
column3: So there's no given that the vaccines will be fully effective and there have been some years&nbsp
column4: when the vaccines haven't been as effective.&nbsp
column5: So it's imperative to try to keep ahead of household germs, especially during flu season.&nbsp
column6: Instead of walking around with a spray bottle and paper towels or tissues, I've come to rely on disinfectant wipes.&nbsp
column7: They're easy to carry and are effective on most bacteria and germs.

column1: • Door handles, knobs and door frames at the height at which your kid would place her hands.
• Drawer knobs and pulls, especially in the kitchen and bath.
Literally, anyplace that you think your kid is going to lay their mitts.
This isn't a commercial for any particular brand of wipe, but do take the time to check the label ingredients.
And one other reminder is to make sure to keep them out of the reach of very small children who might mistake them for regular baby wipes.
column2: The idea is to keep the kids from&nbsp
column3:
the doctor.

A dad's view about life usually differs from a mom's view, and it's no different in this household.
column2: &nbsp
column3: I will typically defer to my wife about girl issues while she defers to me about boy situations.&nbsp
column4: After all, I've never experienced life as a girl and my wife has never had a jockstrap placed over her face in a junior high locker room (aka the japanese gasmask).

column1: This valley was displayed in our response to eldest son's return from a boy scout camping trip to northern Pennsylvania.
column2: His troop went to a scout's cabin and property near the New York state line and the group dispersed to the appropriate rooms for changing and sleep arrangements.&nbsp
column3: In this case, the male and female leaders got their own separate rooms while the cabin owners took another, leaving the last bedroom and it's beds for the scouts.&nbsp
column4: My son and the younger scouts were the first to the room to claim bunks with their bags and were surprised to find that the older scouts arrived and tossed said bags in the hallway.&nbsp
column5: The younger scouts then had to claim sofas and floor space in the living room for the duration of the trip.

column1: As our son explained the situation, my wife was taken aback that the older scouts could and did do this.
column2: What right do they have to just displace these boys?
column3: I could only smile and explain to my son that this was a part of life and that &quot
column4: rank did have it's privileges&quot
column5: .&nbsp
column6: The reality is that upon arrival, the younger scouts disappeared to lay claim while the older boys were delayed by staying to&nbsp
column7: help unload the vehicles.&nbsp
column8: This was simply a group of guys' silent way of teaching upstart youngsters that they couldn't benefit from not helping.&nbsp
column9: No complaints or arguments, just a simple action to prove a point.&nbsp
column10: And while it may sound sexist, I expect that the result would have been vastly different had it been a group of girl scouts.

112,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The different perspectives of Dad and Mom keep cropping up, this time in talking about the family transportation.
The PracticalMom asked me when I anticipated
column2: buying another car and I responded that it would probably occur in 2010.&nbsp
column3: With the eldest approaching driving age, my thought process was that I'd purchase a good used vehicle for my wife, take her still-good car and let the teen use my mini-van.&nbsp
column4: A win-win since my wife would get a decent vehicle, I'd get her Toyota for hauling kids and my well-used Chevy would become the fall-back.&nbsp

column1: I was surprised that she disagreed with me.
column2: <em>Why? Why would the teen get the newer Toyota while I'm left with the older Chevy mini-van?&nbsp
column3: Where's the justice in this picture?&nbsp
column4: Her response was that the Toyota has air-bags along the sides as well as in the front seats, a much safer arrangement for the new driver.

column2: Yet there is such a thing as the pecking order and the belief that children should wait their turn.
column3: What does it teach them that they automatically get to drive the newer, better vehicle while the parent drives the older one?&nbsp
column4: Having learned on a 1967 Volkswagen Beetle, I was grateful that I at least had a car to get around in and the nicer cars were left to the parents.&nbsp
column5: You want a different car, said my father, then get a job and buy one yourself.
column6: I frankly believe that my teen would be perfectly happy driving the Chevy and it is a solid vehicle with dual front airbags.&nbsp
column7: So the problem is mine to own.&nbsp

column1: Do I concern myself with feeding a teen's sense of entitlement or my own?
column2:
I'm curious...

column1: From the first time that your infant sees the pediatrician, there'll be a growth chart in the medical file and it will stay with that file until adulthood.
column2: The chart, an example shown&nbsp
column3: above, was developed by the Centers for Disease Control to display weight and height data for your child in comparison to other children of the same age.&nbsp
column4: It shows the information graphically on a percentile basis so that the medical staff can gain a quick&nbsp
column5: understanding of where Junior in relation to all the other kids of his particular age.

column1: It's certainly helpful to know where Junior is relation to the rest of the boys his age.
column2: Should you start thinking of a basketball scholarship or is that not too likely?&nbsp
column3: Apart from that, your child's growth rate is a possible indicator of whether there might be lurking difficulties.&nbsp
column4: For example, if he's been persistently in the 85th percentile for height but suddenly drops to the 35th percentile around his eighth birthday, the doctor might consider whether there are other health issues at play.&nbsp
column5: That's not necessarily the case, but it is a consideration.&nbsp

column1: It can also indicate whether Junior is getting off his diet and thus affecting his weight.
column2: There are significant risks associated with poor diet, principal of which is Diabetes.

column1: On a more practical level, it's helpful when buying clothes to know whether he runs shorter or taller than the typical boy of his size.
column2: If he's in the 95th percentile for height, then you should look a size upwards.

column1: The sample chart is for boys from two to twenty years of age and shows the age in years on both upper and lower horizontal axes.
column2: The left and right vertical axes list stature (height) and weight in both the English and Metric systems.&nbsp
column3: There are two range-bound curves, upper and lower.&nbsp
column4: The upper range pertains to the child's height for the 18 year duration and is bounded at the 5th percentile and the 95th percentile.&nbsp
column5: The lower range pertains to the child's weight and is also bounded at the 5th and 95th percentile.&nbsp
column6: Remember that the percentile is a measure of about where he is in relation to any 100 randomly chosen boys of his age.&nbsp
column7: The 50th percentile means that he's smack dab in the middle while the 90th percentile shows that he's bigger than 89 of the 100 boys.

column1: The nurse or physician will measure your child at each physical and then mark the appropriate height and weight on the chart.
column2: For example, Junior is in for his pre-kindergarten physical at the age of five.&nbsp
column3: His height is 3'5&quot
column4: (41&quot
column5: ) and his weight is 44 lbs.&nbsp
column6: He might seem perfectly proportional given the closeness of the numbers, but entries on the chart at the fifth year mark would reveal that he's at roughly the 15th percentile for height but the 75th percentile for weight.&nbsp
column7: Clearly, he's built like a fireplug - for what that's worth.

column1: You can download a copy of a chart for both your baby and child, split out by the gender, from the Centers for Disease Control website.
Birth to 36 Months/Boys Length-for-age and Weight-for-age
Birth to 36 Months/Girls Length-for-age and Weight-for-age
Children 2 - 20 Years/Boys Stature-for-age and Weight-for-age
Children 2 - 20 Years/Girls Stature-for-age and Weight-for-age

Can you help me figure out what size clothing to get for my son?
The guy at the register was embarrassed to ask and the clerk said that she'd help him after she finished with other customers.
column2: I was standing nearby and walked over and together, we figured out what he could do.&nbsp
column3: Granted, it's most helpful to have the child there but even then, small children don't have the patience to try things on repeatedly.&nbsp
column4: So what do you do?

column1: The obvious and easiest thing to do is to first find out what size Junior's wearing at the moment.
column2: That first comment isn't meant to be offensive
column3: I've been in the position of finding out that he needs something and not knowing what the&nbsp
column4: current size&nbsp
column5: is.&nbsp
column6: It happens and especially so if he's bigger or smaller than the norm for his age.&nbsp
column7: And those are the keys if you don't have the size in front of you.&nbsp
column8: How old is he and how big is he in relation to others his age?&nbsp

column1: The thing to know is that for children's clothing, the sizes reflect the normal size for a child of that age.
column2: For example, a five year-old would wear a size 5 shirt and pants and a four year-old would wear a 4 or 4T(oddler).&nbsp
column3: This practice is standard for sizes up to 8.&nbsp
column4: After that, they range in two size/year increments such as 10 - 12 and 14 - 16 and beyond the 14 -16 size, then you're into adult size clothing.&nbsp
column5: If you have a daughter, all bets are off since she's not going to want you anywhere near getting her clothing when she's old enough to care.

column1: Once you've settled on the general size, think whether Junior's bigger or smaller than the typical kid that age.
column2: If you've paid attention, The CDC Growth Chart
column3: for your child will show you whether he's in the average size range&nbsp
column4: or&nbsp
column5: on either end of the curve.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp

column1: The final early question is why you need
column2: the clothing.&nbsp
column3: If it's replacing something relatively new because&nbsp
column4: of ruin, then go to that size.&nbsp
column5: If it's&nbsp
column6: been awhile since the&nbsp
column7: old clothing was bought, then&nbsp
column8: Junior&nbsp

column1: Is it necessary to try it on?

column2: I know some people who just grab a bunch, buy it and take it home for the child to try on
column3: they then return the non-fitting items.&nbsp
column4: The problem is that you then have to return with the non-fitting items and you have to have the receipt to get full credit.&nbsp
column5: Lose your receipt and ...

column1: But there are some things to remember that will help make it easier.
• Choose clothing items or consecutive sizes and have Junior try the smallest size first.
• If the smallest is too small, then try the next size.
• Keep the too-small clothing however, for comparison with that made by other manufacturers, since some make a larger size 8 than others.
<li>When you have clothing that fits, then lay it out flat and use that as a standard for measuring other clothes that you've picked.&nbsp
column2: It beats having first grader Junior having a loud spasm in the dressing area.

column1: • Junior may still have to try something on, but the number of clothing articles is minimized and you can avoid bloodshed in the aisles.

column2: you get home, Junior can try on the clothing at a slower and less stressful pace or just as it's pulled out of the closet and drawer for that particular day.&nbsp

column1: If Junior tries on the clothing as it's pulled from the closet, then you have to be sure to:
<li><strong>keep the receipt where you can find it
• keep the sales tags on until you're certain that it fits.
Buying clothing is stressful enough when you know what you're doing.
column2: Keep your head about you and it can be much easier than the horror stories that you hear about.

116,"1","1",,"xhtml","

If there's been a source of tension between my wife and I over the years, it's been about getting the housework done.
column2: What needs to be done and when?&nbsp
column3: What should be done and when?
column4: And those are two very different things, believe me.&nbsp
column5: Taking an active role in the household means that there has to be a balance struck between the children and the housework.&nbsp
column6: The children's health and safety can depend upon having the housework and clutter under control, yet kids&nbsp
column7: require frequent and significant interaction for them to develop and housework can take a backseat.

column1: It's not easy to strike that balance and there are going to be times when
column2: it might appear almost impossible to do.&nbsp

column1: So what might help avoid some of the headaches that this causes?
<li>Decide with your mate where your focus should be.&nbsp
column2: My earliest belief was that I should be spending the large majority of the time with the children and I did so
column3: but it became apparent that the sloppy household would create issues.&nbsp
column4: Is your mate a neat freak?&nbsp
column5: Then that might create problems since the clutter and dirt that children create is significant and the interaction with them suffers.

column1: <li>Decide with your mate about what should be done.&nbsp
column2: Create a list of what those chores and items are, as well as a general schedule of how often they need done.

column1: <li>Be clear about both your and her expectations of the satisfaction level for the chores.&nbsp
column2: Does vacuuming mean that you just run the vacuum or does that also include an attachment for use along the edge of the baseboard?&nbsp
column3: Do you use a polish for the furniture when you dust or just run a rag along it?&nbsp
column4: Does it make more sense to vacuum and then dust, or vice-versa?

column1: • Knowing these things, who's going to be responsible for the items?
<li>Be honest about what you actually know how to do.&nbsp
column2: The truth is that most women were raised to pay attention to the household and picked up more information than guys did.&nbsp
column3: If it bothers you, flip the situation - would you want your mate to ask how something is done before she dismantles part of the engine or takes something apart?&nbsp
column4: Sorry if that appears sexist, but it's the truth.

column1: <li>Take a lesson in how to do something before damage is done.&nbsp
column2: I never bleached laundry until I was home with the kids and managed to ruin multiple pieces of clothing
column3: and the replacement cost came at a time when the funds weren't really available.

column1: <li>Learn what things you can do while you interact with the children.&nbsp
column2: Can Princess play with clay at the table while you clean the kitchen and talk to her?&nbsp
column3: Can Junior play with toys in his room while you're in hanging up the clothing?

column1:
There's no hard/fast answer to this question and it works out differently for each family, but with some effort, honesty and patience - on both parts, ladies - there can be some reasonable balance found.

It's almost Valentine's Day and the process of gettiing the kids to fill out their valentine cards is
column2: commencing.&nbsp
column3: But the preparation for the holiday actually continues for up to a week afterwards, and that's restocking for the next year.&nbsp
column4: While boxes of cards aren't terribly expensive, getting them at 40% off for the next year is a help.

column1: So what to consider before you do this?

column2: How many kids do you have and about how many will each probably give?&nbsp

column1: <li>Look at the your kids' genders and ages.&nbsp
column2: When the kids are young - toddler and preschool - then it usually won't matter.&nbsp
column3: But it will start to matter when they get a bit older
column4: your kindergartner is going to have a fit when he finds that he's giving Disney Princess cards to his buddies.

column1: <li>Where can you keep the cards for the coming year so that you know where to find them?&nbsp
column2: The ideal is to have a place to keep all of the holiday paper items together.&nbsp
column3: In our house, we have drawers in the garage to hold all of the Valentine and Christmas cards and stickers.

column1: <li>Have a sense of what's current amongst the kids and likely to stay that way.&nbsp
column2: Disney Princess or Marvel Superhero cards are pretty timeless and it won't make a difference if they're carried over for two or even three years.&nbsp
column3: But cards based upon fads or Japanese Anime - think DragonBall Z - can pass quickly and are likely not to be popular the following year.

column1: • Does it make more sense for your household to just purchase a simple card software package that will permit you and the kids to make your own cards for whatever holiday you choose?
The truth is that despite the economic conditions, parents will do whatever possible to provide some sense of normalcy for our children.
column2:
And with a bit of thought and planning, that can be done for a lot less.

122,"1","1",,"xhtml","

No, that doesn't mean that you have no authority and have to check everything with your mate.
column2: But with fathers taking a greater role in the house and family, it's more likely that something's going to occur when your mate isn't there and that's liable to create some hard feelings.&nbsp

column1: Some things are uncontrollable, such as first steps or first words and if you miss it, that's life.
column2: Other things however, are controllable and some consideration is advisable.&nbsp
column3: My gold standard was my eldest's first bite of solid food, which occurred while I was in the restaurant bathroom
column4: I returned to find that she'd been given green beans in my absence, so that I was unable to enjoy the sight of a six month old munching on a bean.&nbsp
column5: It wasn't a big deal in the great scheme of things, but it was irritating and it sticks in my craw more than a decade later.

column1: This particular case in point is this morning's invitation for the youngest's first sleepover at a friend's house.
column2: I personally have no objection and will permit it, but am going to run it past the mother to assure that she has no concerns and at least has had the courtesy of a check.&nbsp
column3: And to be on the safe side, I won't mention anything to my youngest until the matter is settled.

Having the family eat together is one of the few things on which I'm adamant.
column2: Unfortunately, that becomes more difficult as the children age and move on to activities
column3: there are nights on which it's impossible.&nbsp
column4: So if we can't all eat together, we can all at least have a hot meal in our respective shifts.

column1: The key to making this work anymore is planning, and using the family calendar
column2: is crucial.&nbsp
column3: What's&nbsp
column4: coming this evening and for the next several nights?&nbsp
column5: While I'm not religious about it - and it would probably help - I sometimes sit down and plan the meals for a week in advance so that we don't spend our time eating sandwiches.

column2: One child has a play practice from 6 to 9 pm and another has an activity starting at 6:30, requiring us to leave at 6:00 as well.&nbsp
column3: There's also a piano lesson at 4:30.&nbsp
column4: The kicker is that we have to meet with somebody at the house at 5:15.&nbsp
column5: The youngest is home with nothing planned and can stay with my mate while I run the other two.&nbsp
column6: How do I handle this?

column1: <li>First, understand that this will not be the evening for a full family meal.&nbsp
column2: That said, I can eat earlier with the children before the visitor.
won't permit me to spend much time on food preparation.&nbsp
column3: If there's a hot meal, it's made ahead of time.

column1: • My available time is in the morning, so any meal preparation has to happen early.
The best option today winds up as a crock-pot chili that can cook through the course of the day with minimal work ahead of time.
column2: With a larger crock-pot, I'll be able to make enough that tomorrow's meal is already made since that evening is booked as well.

column1: But at least tomorrow, we can eat together.

124,"1","1",,"xhtml","

While listening to the radio today, I heard an interview with a recently laid-off man who stated that he was now "
column2: a daddy at home.&nbsp
column3: I babysit the kids and take them to school.&quot

column2: sounded like he was&nbsp
column3: in shock.&nbsp
column4: He's been laid off and has a family.&nbsp
column5: His household income has been blown to hell and God knows if there's a mortgage - hopefully not since he could probably rent more cheaply.&nbsp
column6: But I was struck that he considered himself a babysitter.&nbsp
column7: He might not be providing an income right now, but he still has far more to offer than just babysitting.&nbsp

column1: Fathers have to understand that in the new economic and social world - partially wrought by the demand by women for greater economic and professional gain - they have a corresponding responsibility and right to step up.
column2: They should see themselves as equally able to care for and raise the children, without having to seek approval and permission from Mom for everything.&nbsp
column3: Men are hampered by the fact that they've never paid attention to the details that help run the household.&nbsp
column4: But that doesn't mean that they can't learn.&nbsp
column5: Men are hampered by the belief that they are incapable of providing the love and attention that children require, but that doesn't mean that small children can only thrive under a feminine influence.

column2: Attention.&nbsp
column3: Interaction.&nbsp
column4: Discipline.&nbsp
column5: Kindness.

column1: There's nothing I know of that states that these things are solely the realm of women.
So my hope is that this guy - once he gets his feet back under him - will start to recognize that his role for his kids is not to just keep them safe until Mom gets home.
column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"
highway&quot
column3: household - it's my way or the highway - I've&nbsp
column4: sometimes&nbsp
column5: had difficulty with argumentative&nbsp
column6: children.&nbsp
column7: And while I don't want children to question everything that I say, I'm coming to the conclusion that I'm doing them a disservice if I don't permit some argument.&nbsp
column8: If it's a question of safety, absolutely no movement.&nbsp
column10: This isn't because I've suddenly gotten soft in the head and want to raise disrespectful little brats.&nbsp
column11: It's because their futures are going to be vastly different than ours
column12: credit and money flowed to such an extent that people were willing to pay whatever the demanded cost and would only attempt to save money when something was on sale.&nbsp
column13: People only saved money when the other party said that it was okay to do so.

column1: In a sense, we've lost the ability to negotiate with one another and that's going to be a needed skill in the future.
Some children are naturally more at ease with pushing boundaries and questioning authority than others.
column2: It's natural that they do so and the ability to question is a future skill that they'll need.&nbsp
column3: But the trick that they have to learn, and it only comes with a lot of practice and maturity, is how to make their point in a way that can be best be described as advocacy instead of argument.
column4: The difference between them lies in tone and physical conduct.&nbsp
column5: How do I help them learn to stand for themselves without whining and petulance so that they don't alienate others?&nbsp
column6: How do I help them to develop their skills?

column1: • Don't automatically insert yourself when they're amongst themselves.
column2: If you pay attention, you'll hear even the youngest children deal amongst themselves.&nbsp
column3: Don't make the mistake of thinking that if you deem something you overhear unreasonable, that you have to step in and act as the judge making a final disposition.&nbsp
column4: Ask yourself whether this is an egregious case of taking advantage of someone.&nbsp
column5: If it's not, then let it stand since they themselves might be satisfied with the outcome.

column1: <li><strong><em>If you know that a deal's been struck and it passes the (relatively) equitable test, take a moment to talk with the kids and go over the deal with them.&nbsp
column2: Is that what you wanted?
column3: If not, what's different?

column1: • While it's frustrating when they argue with you, be patient and ask whether it's the issue or the way in which they're handling it.
column2: Is this a safety issue?&nbsp
column3: If not, see what they might have to say.&nbsp
column4: When our kids have resorted to whining, we make them stop for several minutes until they can speak without a whine.&nbsp
column5: The time lapse allows you to also repair your own frayed nerves.&nbsp
column6: Then come back to it and if it then works, great.&nbsp
column7: If not, then move on to something else but follow-up with the child later.&nbsp
column8: They do listen and with reminders, they at least make an effort to improve.

column1: • Remember that this is yet another of those things that requires repetition and patience.
column2: And then even more repetition.

column1: • Feel free to replay the situation again and help them with figuring out their options.
column2: Kids don't know what to say or how to approach situations, so role-playing with them gives them a little needed experience.&nbsp
column3: Even create a new scenario and play through it with them
column4: joke around and keep it light and short.&nbsp

column1: • Don't be afraid to go back to an issue.
column2: I can be stubborn and there have been occasions when I've said &quot
column3: no&quot
column4: and then had to reconsider.&nbsp
column5: The result was in my raising the issue again with the child and with further discussion, reaching a good compromise.&nbsp
column6: But only on occasion.

column1: Negotiating is an important skill and with some practice, even those who are uncomfortable with it can improve.
column2:
So the next time, one of the kids starts to disagree, I'm going to grit my teeth and remind myself that it does make a difference.

So your child complains about the shoes and that they're too tight.
column2: And after checking to assure that there is sufficient room for the toes, you have to get another pair.&nbsp

column1: But what exactly are you supposed to know about buying shoes?&nbsp
column2: What are you supposed to do?

column1: There are some basic facts that you have to remember when you go out to buy shoes.

• Children need solid support through the arch of the feet as they grow, so buying the cheapie sneaker off of the rack can be ultimately self-defeating as a constant practice of this can lead to problems in the future. Stride Rite has been considered to be the gold standard for small childrens' shoes.
• You might consider buying them a small pair before they start to walk so that they're at least used to the feeling of shoes when they actually take the first steps.

column2: that for children, there are two sizing scales.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: You have to be&nbsp
column5: careful in discussing sizes whether&nbsp
column6: you're referring to the scale for toddlers or the one for children who are in elementary school&nbsp
column7: and beyond.

column1: <li>The sizing decision can be different depending upon the type of shoe.&nbsp
column2: You want to move up a half size on dress shoes and a full size on winter boots.

column1: When you take your child to the shoe store, you're going to need to use what most people refer to as "
column2: that flat, long foot measuring thingy.&quot
column3: &nbsp
column4: At least that's what I always called it.&nbsp
column5: That piece of equipment is actually called a Brannock Device
column6: and was invented in the 1920s to ease the process.&nbsp
column7: I could try to explain the process of using it, but it's better done by simply going to the actual directions.
column8: With children, it's important to always measure the foot for several reasons.&nbsp
column9: First, not all children grow at the same rate and a kid could easily have gone two sizes since the last pair without complaint.&nbsp
column10: Second, if a child is hypersensitive about the feel of something on their feet - one of mine is fanatical about socks - then you can physically point to the number on the device and reassure them that that should be the correct size.

column1: When considering which scale to use, use this as a starting point.
column2: The sizing for Toddler shoes runs from 1 to 13 and when the child outgrows a size 13, they revert back to size 1 on the&nbsp
column3: scale used by everybody else.&nbsp
column4: A good rule of thumb is that a child will move to the upper scale at about four years of age.&nbsp
column5: If they're higher on the growth chart
column6: than the typical kid their age, then consider the upper scale size earlier.

column1: You should consider bringing a pair of thinner - think dress - socks when trying on the shoes.
column2: Thicker athletic socks are fine for trying on sneakers, but if you're looking for dress shoes, then you do want to have the kid in appropriate socks.&nbsp
column3: Because of health concerns about people trying on new shoes while barefoot, shoe stores are supposed to have disposable hose socks available
column4: I have been in stores however, in which the boxes were empty so it's worth extra effort to have a pair of socks in&nbsp
column5: your pocket or diaper bag.

column1: If you're like me, you might find the foot width confusing.
column2: The sizes on shoe boxes are listed as either M(edium) or W(ide), yet the width on the Brannock Device is alphabet based (A through E).&nbsp
column3: There is a general translation in that the 'E' is considered Wide and the 'C' is a Medium.&nbsp

column1: A reasonable approach for finding a pair would be this.
• Measure your child's foot - and she needs to stand - in the Brannock Device and then find one or more potential pairs of shoes.
<li>Put one or both shoes on her feet, tying them securely, and then take check her toes for room.&nbsp
column2: Ask her to stand and then lift her big toe as high as possible.&nbsp
column3: You should simultaneously be pressing your thumb on the very end of the shoe to see about where the raised toe is in relation to the end of the shoe.&nbsp
column4: The ideal is to have a thumb-width between the big toe and the very end of the shoe.

column1: <li>Take her for a walk around the store.&nbsp
column2: You can send them for a walk around when older, but the little ones are difficult to see in crowded stores and are more likely to forget where you are.

column1: <li>Pay attention as she walks to how she's doing in them.&nbsp
column2: Limping?&nbsp
column3: Constantly reaching down to readjust or rub them?&nbsp
column4: Crying her lungs out?&nbsp
column5: When she walks, does the heel come out of the back of the shoe?

column2: she removes her shoes, take a look at her heels below the ankle.&nbsp
column3: Is there redness from the heel rubbing against the back of the shoe?

column1: If everything checks out, then it's looking good for buying the shoes.
column2: Don't be surprised if your child complains or whines about the shoes in the next several days.&nbsp
column3: Examine her feet to see if it appears to be a legitimate issue, but some kids don't do well with change and that even carries over to the new sneakers.

column1: Petunia is a five year-old with a history of chronic complaints about uncomfortable shoes and clothing, and her normal mode is to shuck off her clothing and don baggy sweat pants and a Barney Sweatshirt as soon as she's home.
column2: When you see her actually rubbing her toes one night, you decide that perhaps it is time to swing by the shoe store.

column1: Petunia stands and has her foot measured on the Brannock Device and it comes in at 3 for length and D for width.
column2: You have her look down and see how it says 3 - D for future reference.&nbsp
column3: You find a reasonable pair of size 3 sneakers in Wide (3 W) and since you decide to kill two birds with one stone, you also find a pair of 3 1/2 W Dress shoes.

column1: Have Petunia try each pair on and with each, walk around the store - specifying that she isn't supposed to actually leave the store.
column2: Also check the location of her big toe and when she takes the shoe off, check her heel for rubbing/redness.&nbsp
column3: If you're satisfied that further complaints are really Petunia's head and not her feet, then they're good to go.&nbsp
column4: If there are legitimate issues, then go back and find one or more other pairs to try.&nbsp

column1: Sorry, but you can't just walk in and be done with it.
column2: But a little time spent here is worth a world of upset later.

• You startle a co-worker at lunch by sticking your finger in your mouth and reaching over to wipe a dab of ketchup off of his chin.
• You get sucked into a heated debate whether Marvel is better than DC and all the reasons that Aquaman is a loser.
• You're in public and state that you have to go to the potty.
• Your kid is in public and excuses herself to go to the restroom.
• You have kid tunes in your head and find yourself searching for Roger Day's Mosquito Burrito for your iPod.
• You can name the characters on iCarly and any other Nick/Disney live-action show.
• You rue the day that your kid refers to Barney as a giant purple cash-cow.
• You can look at your kid and notice whether something's going to fit before he even puts it on.
• You can visualize how something happened between the kids without even being there.
• Your kids come over to spontaneously hug you and try to pick you up.
• You tell them you love them too, now put me down.

Some kids are pretty good at negotiating, since they spend a fair portion of life doing so campaigning for later bedtimes, increased allowance and being allowed to watch what they shouldn't.
column2: But that's between you and them, and it still doesn't prepare them for determining what makes decent financial sense.&nbsp
column3: And it's part of our jobs as fathers - and mothers, too - to teach them instead of just assuming that they know what to do.

column1: In my simple opinion, the bulk of the negotiation work occurs even before an offer or counter-offer is made.
column2: It occurs with the evaluation of the situation, whether buying something, trading for something or negotiating a slip-and-fall.&nbsp
column3: To just toss numbers back and forth is a waste of time.&nbsp
column4: But toss a number that is meaningful to the other person, and you're much closer to making a deal.

column1: One of the kids told me tonight that a friend was moving up to an iPod Touch and would be getting rid of the old iPod
column2: my kid wanted to buy it from her.&nbsp
column3: Suppressing my first inclination to say no, I asked why the desire when the kid already owned an iPod.
column4: The answer was that this one was 8 GB - up to a thousand songs, exclusive of any pictures.&nbsp
column5: And how much money do you have available to spend?&nbsp
column6: And what other expenses are on the horizon?&nbsp
column7: And what other funds are incoming to make up for what you spend?

column1: When these were sufficiently answered - not that I liked the answers but that there at least were answers - the next question was the original cost and age of the desired used iPod.
column2: These answers were also satisfactorily available.&nbsp
column3: And then came the biggies.&nbsp
column4: What do you plan to offer?&nbsp
column5: And why?&nbsp
column6: An amount was being considered, but there was no reason for why.
column7: And that's where the work begins with the teen.&nbsp
column8: How do we walk through the situation to find a legitimate offer?

column2: Fortunately, there's a little time available and I can go back to the teen with an idea for evaluating what the used iPod is actually worth.&nbsp
column3: And we'll see how the teen is doing with critical thinking.&nbsp
column4: Who knows?&nbsp
column5:
Maybe I can also learn something about iPods that I didn't know before.

As children age, they obviously become aware of the world around them, which means that they will reach a point at which they can become embarrassed when corrected.
column2: Each will differ in the degree to which they care, but they all care.&nbsp
column3: Your life will be easier if - when they're old enough to understand signals - you arrange a signal that indicates that it's time to stop.

column1: One of my children is a budding comedian and the stuff in his head is far beyond his years.
column2: This means that he can be screamingly funny, but he will also push the boundaries when it's neither the time nor the place.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: There are moments when, in the interest of stopping a train proceeding down the wrong track, I directly and openly intercede.&nbsp
column5: The train is stopped, but the child is embarrassed and it can lead to hurt feelings and further issues.

column1: So what can you and I do?
<li>Arrange a pre-set signal between you that is understood to mean &quot
column2: knock it off&quot
column3: .&nbsp
column4: A highly raised eyebrow or a brief slash of the finger across the throat would be examples.

column1: <li>Since children are generally lousy at watching others when the spotlight is on them, assure that they understand that you'll do things to get their attention before even delivering the signal.&nbsp
column2: Cough repeatedly, clear your throat, whatever you mutually decide is okay.

column1: <li>If you do have to interrupt, try to do so in a lighter manner.&nbsp
column2: I recently warned this child off by moving my right hand - first two fingers extended - in a mock Jedi wave while intoning this is not the joke you want to be telling.
column3: I had to do it a second time to drive it home, but it went down easier.

column1: <li>Before taking your children into places or situations, give them a &quot
column2: heads up&quot
column3: about what it is appropriate language and behavior.&nbsp
column4: Also remind them of whatever signals you agree upon.&nbsp
column5: This is frequently enough to forestall any situations.

column1: There are bunches of adults who are lousy at controlling their mouths and actions, so don't be surprised if the kids goof.
column2:
But with sufficient follow-up, you'll raise kids to be adults that can control their mouths and actions.

Spend enough time around them and you'll be amazed at what they've concocted to deal with life and language.
column2: To wit:
A means of discouraging the kid on the playground who chases you or constantly follows you.&nbsp
column3: As soon as you realize that the kid is approaching, either lick or spit into your hand and suddenly thrust it towards their face.&nbsp
column4: They typically recoil and you can further drive them back without contact by slowly advancing on them.&nbsp
column5: Simple, and it beats going to the teacher and earning the reputation of a tattle-tale.

column2: A phrase meaning that you failed in a huge way.&nbsp
column3: I'd seen it on the internet, but was surprised to hear from a teenager.

column2: Shared by the daughter of an acquaintance, this is a failure of such epic proportions that it should be counted and considered as a win.

Early pubescence is a truly challenging time for all parents and kids.
column2: Many families have tried to shelter kids from the problems of the outside world but the parents are noticing an increased curiosity about their larger world.&nbsp
column3: At the same time, the kids are starting to experience more independence at the same time that they're&nbsp
column4: typically weak in the common sense/judgment department.&nbsp
column5: How can these disparate threads be pulled together in a decent marriage?

column1: Perhaps the best way is to find a way for the kid to volunteer in the community.
column2: How is this&nbsp
column3: a good solution?

column1: • It provides a structured opportunity to introduce the youth to the lives and issues of others who can be in extremely different economic and life situations.
• It provides an outlet for some of the free summer time that would be otherwise wide-open.
<li>It gives the youth a chance to experience some responsibility for having a schedule with responsibility to others.&nbsp
column2: This isn't just a class or camp for their benefit, but their failure to show will have an impact on someone else.

column1: Don't be surprised however, at finding some resistance to this.
column2: The kids are growing and there is the sense that the larger world is starting to eat into their free time.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, this world can place them in situations outside their comfort zone and that's difficult even for adults at times.&nbsp
column4: There are several routes that you can take to handle this.<strong><em>&nbsp
column5: Understand that this is going to require an investment on your part.&nbsp
column6: Just throwing them the situation is setting them up for failure.

column2: A good starting point is the Volunteer Coordinator at your local United Way agency.
column3: The United Way is an umbrella for many disparate non-profit groups and will typically ascertain the needs of the various groups
column4: it will also help these groups better understand how to structure the experience for the youth so that bad situations are avoided.&nbsp
column5: In our area, the United Way will provide an updated list of groups, listing their age requirements and job outlines.

column2: Because there are only a certain number of volunteer positions for different groups, start in the mid-winter so that your youth has a decent shot at finding the best match.&nbsp
column3: If there are various scheduling spots, the earlier you can get things rolling the better it can be for your own family/transportation situation.

column1: <li>Talk with your youth and help them define what they want to do.&nbsp
column2: Some kids know up front while others need to talk through things to find a reasonable match.&nbsp
column3: If your kid has a natural aversion to something, don't place them in a situation that sets them up for failure.

column1: <li>Walk them through the process of contacting the potential choices.&nbsp
column2: While the organizations are actively looking for volunteers, they don't want just a body and you don't want your kid in a mess.&nbsp
column3: You can turn it into a practice for future job interviews by helping them frame their own questions, answering questions in turn and teaching them about presenting themselves.

column2: this investment on their part is also going to be an investment on your part.&nbsp
column3: Transportation is on you - whether you take them yourself or help arrange it - and keeping track of the calendar and schedule will rest with you until they improve.

column1: <li>Keep talking with them about what they're doing there.&nbsp
column2: Is it in keeping with what's offered?&nbsp
column3: My eldest spent last summer working with the local WIC (Women and Infant Children) program and I suddenly realized that she was now helping in the lab area.&nbsp
column4: Since the lab area deals with drawing blood for samples, what would be the exposure to used needles?&nbsp
column5: A quiet phone call to the director allayed my concerns and things moved along.

column1: Volunteering is not a panacea for all situations, but it's a good start on meeting the various needs of a youth, family and community.
column2:
The resources are there and some forethought and planning will make it a win/win/win.

While I chose to stay home with our first child - and her siblings - this article, More Laid-off Men Equals More Mommy Breadwinners, brought back
column2: vivid memories of the first days at home.&nbsp

column1: The most pointed was the dogging worry about money.
column2: We gave up almost 60% of our income to have me at home and in Washington, DC that meant something.&nbsp
column3: We also knew that it would be almost two years before my spouse's fellowship ended and she could look forward to an income that previously approached&nbsp
column4: our combined salaries.&nbsp
column5: Dinners out?&nbsp
column6: Largely gone.&nbsp
column7: Movies?&nbsp
column8: Gone.&nbsp
column13: And make that transportation last since a newer vehicle - we'd never bought a new car - would be out of the question.

column1: Hunting and gathering took on a new meaning as I started truly shopping for the best deal on everything from bread to diapers.
column2: Hit the newspaper coupons and sales flyers, but only after first determining what was actually needed.&nbsp
column3: I found that it was easy to confuse an impulse for a need - yeah, those bookcases could really come in handy for the toys - when I hadn't really even previously considered whether a bookcase was necessary.
column4: After working with my mate to find the best buys, it then shifted to the &quot
column5: Traveling Salesman&quot
column6: scenario to find the best combination of stops for particular errands in a set timeframe.&nbsp
column7: With a baby and small children, I was constrained by the need for consistent feeding times and naps.&nbsp
column8: And the realization that I wasn't home so that the kid could spend all her time in a carseat.

column2: deciding what needed to be done versus what could be done.&nbsp
column3: When did it make the most sense to do dishes versus laundry?&nbsp
column4: How often should the vacuum be run or the bathroom cleaned?&nbsp
column5: Believe me, with small children, the bathroom needs done a whole lot more than I ever thought necessary.&nbsp
column6: Since I was up frequently with the children as they grew, should I grab a nap with them or put&nbsp
column7: the time&nbsp
column8: to other use?&nbsp
column9: And how much time is optimal for interacting with my child?&nbsp
column11: I wasn't staying home to do housework but to raise the children, and plunking them in front of the television was defeating our intent.

column1: Perhaps the biggest question dealt just with me.
column2: Was I actually letting my family down by not bringing in a paycheck?&nbsp
column3: Did that lack of a paycheck make me less of a man?&nbsp
column4: Was it wrong to look forward to time alone and away from the little one?&nbsp
column5: It took time to recognize that childcare - being the househusband - was actually far more difficult than I ever understood
column6: balancing the needs of the household, the child and the mate was and is sometimes an antic juggling act.

column1: Finally, the simple fact of having to answer the question what the hell do I do now? was tiring.
column2: There are tons of resources out there for women but very little oriented towards a guy who's having to decide between managing a fussy baby and cleaning Gerbers off of the walls.&nbsp
column3: It would be easy to just call my mate but pride prevented that.&nbsp
column4: After all, I'm a self-reliant guy who should know how to figure this out.&nbsp
column5: The flip side was the humility of what I was doing.&nbsp
column6: No income meant that what I did was less important than her and I should avoid bothering her since I only took care of the kids.

column1: These concerns largely resolve with time - learning to live on less, making best use of your time, and even coming to grips with your manhood.
column2: But there are still challenges even after years and these will never resolve until the children are making their own way in the world.&nbsp
column3: And then they're back just in time for the grandkids...

I try not to let the kids spend too much time, but there are moments when I feel Amish.
Through the years, I've tried to rein in the household electronics so that the kids don't spend all - or even most - of their time staring at a screen.
column2: Having grown up with a TV and the early cable, I firmly believe that the majority of stuff on any kind of screens is simply a waste of pixels.&nbsp
column3: There are good programs and also good websites, but most is dreck.&nbsp
column4: But the past year has forced us to reconsider what is an acceptable accomodation.

column1: As a practical guy, I never put much faith in psychology/self-help literature and I've rarely found one that actually made me change how I operate.
column2: One of the few exceptions is <a title=""The Shelter of Each Other"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/Shelter-Each-Other-Mary-Pipher/dp/1594483728/ref=pd_bbs_1?ie=UTF8&amp
column3: s=books&amp
column5: sr=8-1"">The Shelter of Each Other
column6: by Mary Pipher, an experienced family therapist.&nbsp
column7: This book is based upon observations drawn from a long career as a therapist
column8: her premise is that the modern American family is harmed by a combination of factors.&nbsp
column9: The first is the consumerist belief that bigger is better, especially when it comes to housing.
column10: The typical house's square footage grew so much over the decades from the 1950s that a parent could be in the kitchen - where I practically live - while never being able to hear what was going on in the far corners of the house where the offspring would spend their time.&nbsp
column11: A second factor is the rising ubiquity of consumer electronics, to the point that many children have computers and television sets in their own rooms.&nbsp
column12: Consequently, there is no appreciable reason for them to gather with the rest of the family
column13: especially during the teen years when they might consider the 'rents as trainable idiot savants.&nbsp
column14: The third reason is the attention of the 'rents to those things in the outer world, like work and outside activities.&nbsp
column15: That isn't meant to denigrate parents who have to work, but the first two factors make connecting with the kids all the more difficult.

column1: The book made such an impact on both of us that several things occurred.
<li>We moved our sole computer from the guest room/office to the family room so that the screen would be in a common area.&nbsp
column2: This was pre-emptive&nbsp
column3: in order to avoid any possible&nbsp
column4: hurt feelings when moving it after she started using it.&nbsp

column1: <li>We decided to assure that the size of our house would never be larger than it was at that moment.&nbsp
column2: We've since moved into a smaller house, willingly giving up the space to assure more intimacy.&nbsp
column3: To clarify, we moved from a home of about 2600 square feet to 2200 square feet so it's not as if we moved into the storage shed.

column1: <li>We agreed to not allow the kids to have computers or televisions in their rooms.&nbsp
column2: We've compromised on personal music devices - CD player/radio and mp3 - when they reached a specific age.

column1: • Cell phones would not happen until we were very comfortable that there was a real need, i.e. obtaining a driver's license.
And here is where the situation rests.
column2: Over the years, both my wife and I have acquired laptops for use in work.&nbsp
column3: Hers is purely work while I use mine for this website and financial matters.&nbsp
column4: My laptop has aged along with my eldest child, to the point that mine is frankly clunky and she requires more time on the computer for classwork.&nbsp
column5: If and when I replace this, is giving her this particular device violating what we agreed upon?&nbsp
column6: And if not, what restrictions do we place on it's use?

column1: My mate is more comfortable with this than I am.
column2: From my perspective, questions to be answered would include:

column1: • About how much would it be used in her bedroom versus the common areas?
<li>Since she is still a minor - not even driving - do we have access to her passwords?&nbsp
• Do we reserve the right to inspect the contents?
• What are the consequences of not meeting the guidelines?
• Indeed, am I setting a better example by just using this until it dies and making her continue to use the family PC?
The situation will play out in the next several weeks as my wife and I discuss our concerns.
column2:
And while I refer to myself as an electronic Nazi, I'd hate to be referred to as Amish.

One of the first signs of Spring in our household is managing the clothing inventory.
column2: With multiple children and a network of friends with children, there's a constant flow of clothing through the house and it takes periodic time and attention to keep everything in some order.&nbsp
column3: Early Spring - and early Fall - is a good time&nbsp
column4: to check what fits, what's needed&nbsp
column5: and what needs to go away.

column1: If you have multiple recipients for the outdated clothing - whether charity or another family - the first question is whether you want to sort by recipient or just toss everything going into one pile to be sorted later.
column2: If you have time issues, you probably want to have one larger pile in an out-of-the-way&nbsp
column3: area that you can go back to later.&nbsp
column4: In our case, we have a charity box
column5: in the garage to hold what's leaving the household.&nbsp
column6: I can always go back to sort out later when the kids aren't around.

column1: The next step is deciding where to start.
column2: I've made the mistake of starting with an older child whose clothing goes to a younger one.&nbsp
column3: The end result is a clothing pile bottleneck until I can clear out the old clothing from the younger one
column4: that bottleneck is presently residing in the upstairs hallway.

column1: Unfortunately, there's no way to avoid doing it without the kids to try things on.
column2: A couple tips?

column1: • Pay attention to the weather and shoot for a poor-weather weekend so they can't argue about missing nicer weather outside.
<li>Choose one set of jeans, slacks, pullover shirt and dress shirt to use as a pattern.&nbsp
column2: After finding one of each that fits, you can lay it on the bed and use it as a benchmark by laying others over it for sizing.&nbsp
column3: That way, the kids don't have to try everything on and you can pull them in for only those questionable items.

column1: <li>Yeah, there are moments when a bribe helps and this is one of those times.&nbsp
column2: You can talk until blue in the face about how they gain from this, but it's not going to work.

column1: After the clothing is sorted and on to the next location, take the moments to clean out the drawers and refold what's needed.
column2: When the kids are a little older, it's also a good opportunity to teach them and let them practice&nbsp
column3: folding and hanging things up.

column1: As the clothing shifts through the house like a rat in a python, you can then disperse it to its destination(s) from the garage.
column2: One final question is whether the outgoing clothing should be washed before leaving the house
column3: I generally look at everything as it comes through and wash what actually needs it - grass stains on knee, food stains on shirts.&nbsp
column4:
Honestly though, since kids usually toss things in the hamper after wearing once, things are typically clean when I go through them.

As kids grow, they still need to be reassured but might not want to come out and show that there's anything that requires reassurance.
column2: This is especially the case for boys who will go through a lengthy period of false machismo matched only by a stunning lack of common sense.

column1: Eldest son knows that I've gotten larger in the waist and the doctor has suggested the Flat Belly Diet
column2: to get my waist back below size 40.&nbsp
column3: As we shot basketball this afternoon, he remarked that if I would&nbsp
column4: get back to the gym - to which I hadn't returned since an illness last year - I could take him in wrestling without being winded.&nbsp
column5: The subject changed and then he came back to exercise again.&nbsp

column1: As we talked, I asked whether he was worried about my having a heart attack.

column2: Well, maybe a little...

column1: I told him that having a heart attack wasn't on my calendar - not that it couldn't happen - and his response was direct and pointed:
column2: So get to the frickin' gym!

column1: So my history with boys is that if an issue comes up another time, it's best for me to put it on the table.
column2: That way, the boy can concentrate on the issue without having to appear as though he's worried or even scared.&nbsp
column3: When he's older and more secure with himself, then he can learn the direct approach.

column1:
And I'll save the choice of language for another time.

I was really stung by the words from my middle-schooler, who's someways down the road to being a full-blown cynic.
column2: They came in response to a conversation about the ways that the new Geithner Private-Public Investment Program could be abused - and for the&nbsp
column3: record, our personal conversations can appear to the average reader as seriously bent.&nbsp
column4: He and his older sibling are aware that I'm worried about the economy and the country and I've shared a fair amount with them both.&nbsp
column5: I laid out the general idea of the plan and then stated that theoretically, I could wind up legally owning our own home for about $15,000.&nbsp
column6: Our credit would be ruined, but the mortgage money&nbsp
column7: could eliminate the need for credit.

column2: Lots of others are doing it, why shouldn't we?
has a point.&nbsp
column3: Do I honestly believe that the bastards at Citi, BlackRock and the rest are stepping back for fear that what they're doing is wrong?&nbsp
column4: That they're not actively figuring out new and innovative ways to enrich themselves at the public trough?&nbsp
column5: I'd be a fool since it's become abundantly clear that the controls stopping such action - both internal and external - are slipping away into a kleptocratic&nbsp
column6: nightmare.&nbsp
column7: How do I respond to this, Messrs. Geithner, Bernanke and Frank?

column2: That's all that I could muster in the moment and it's only been in the last while since I started this that I can give better words to it.
When we allow ourselves to start down that road, then we eventually come to a point and which we willingly betray our own neighbors, friends and family.&nbsp
column3: And then we can no longer continue without wondering whether they are playing us for fools as well.&nbsp
column4: It's called being a moral person and it has to be a conscious choice.&nbsp
column5: In other times and places, it's pretty easy to make the moral choice but in today's society, it will require effort.&nbsp
column6: If everyone fails the effort test, then it really will be a bleak and dangerous world.

column1: Thank you for letting me puzzle this out in print.
column2: Tonight will be a revisited conversation about the original &quot
column3: honesty&quot
column4:
comment.

column2: Clothing comes into the house via your own purchases, grandparents and extended family, and hand-me-downs from other families. On top of that, the kids will start buying some of their own things as they grow older. But with everything coming in, clothing should also exit the house and especially in today's economics, you should&nbsp

column14: I've learned that our local Goodwill won't accept shoes or baby toys/equipment for fear of liability issues.&nbsp
column15: Likewise, our local rescue mission will take shoes but not toys and I can never find anybody at the local Boys &amp
column16: Girls Club to actually accept the toys.&nbsp

column1: So I've changed how things are distributed and adopted the following guidelines.
<li>Neighborhood schools and families who respond that they need and are willing to accept the clothing.&nbsp
column2: Yes, some school districts are sponsoring events where families can bring in unneeded clothing for use by those who might need it.

<li>Rescue missions and other entities who serve under-privileged populations.&nbsp
column2: And yes, I still send some things to Goodwill.

column1: While you might look at the stuff and feel a need to just get it out of the house, remember that the best use and greatest need in today's world isn't necessarily miles and time-zones away.

The general PracticalDad philosophy is that so long as your feet are under the table, then there will be rules by which you will abide
column2: according to my father, it's been a philosophy that he knows for certain was handed down over the past four PracticalDad generations.&nbsp
column3: And this certainly applies to the Electronics as well as everything else.

column1: Before you react, bear in mind that we also believe that there is an appropriate time for introducing things and that we do allow leeway as the kids age.
One of the ongoing questions has been when can I have a cellphone?
column2: Our standard response has been when you actually have a need for one.
column3: Thus far, that takes us to about driver's age for a teenager.&nbsp

column1: When we were told that alot of friends had them, we also learned that part of having the phone was the understanding that numbers of parents told their kids that they were liable to be called randomly and the kid needed to respond with where they were, who they were with and what they were doing.
column2: Eldest seemed to think that this was a selling point in the drive to obtain one.&nbsp
column3: My response - and that of my mate - was the opposite.&nbsp
column4: I recall that part of the joy of growing up was the time and freedom that came with friends away from parental intrusion.&nbsp
column5: I had clear expectations and rules, but my parents let me have that time with only those expectations to provide constraint.&nbsp
column6: And yes, there were moments of pubescent nonsense that were within the expectation boundaries but I still wouldn't want to have to divulge them at any particular moment to the 'rents.&nbsp
column7: My honest take is that this kind of tie to possession of a cellphone only tends to encourage dishonesty.&nbsp

column1: But we reviewed things last week when our eldest went on a school choral trip to Disney World.
column2: Eldest is a year away from driving and we understand that most of the peers also have cellphones, so it's not as though there would be no way to communicate.&nbsp
column3: But I permitted eldest to take mine just in case.&nbsp
column4: There were no requirements about nightly bedtime calls, apart from the request to contact us about an hour before returning to the pick-up point so that I could retrieve her.&nbsp
column5: Eldest also understands from a previous experience that I'm not on a text plan and that any text message costs $.50 each
column6: because the need for her to know never occurred to me, I paid for that one but informed her that she'd be paying any future bills.&nbsp
column7: What's been nice is that she's chosen to call from different points in the trip to let us know what she's been doing on her first real trip away from the family.

column1: I have truly missed Eldest and I pick her up this evening.
column2: I will have dinner with her and listen to the stories of doing what with whom and how the performance went.&nbsp

column1: And in several weeks, I'll review my phone bill to see the usage.
column2:
The results will help form our final decision on whether the phone actually comes before the driver's license.

I'm not a physician and I don't play one on TV.&nbsp
column3: But that doesn't mean that I can't pass along some tips on handling a sick kid at home.

column1: Yep, Middle is home for the second day with a recurrent fever after violent nausea two nights ago.
column2: Some comments.

column1: <li>After a kid's been sick in bed with a fever, it will feel good to have fresh sheets to replace those dampened by sweat.&nbsp
column2: Having to change the sheets is more work but the kid will appreciate it.&nbsp
column3: Even if they don't mention it.

column1: <li>Keep the paper towels and disinfectant solution handy for the bathroom, light switches and doorknobs.&nbsp
column2: You may also want to wipe down electronic devices - phones, remotes - with a disinfectant dampened towel or wipe.

column1: <li>A kid with a fever is more prone to be sensitive to violent or scary imagery.&nbsp
column2: My new rule of thumb is that a kid with a fever will never again watch NCIS prior to bedtime.&nbsp
column3: Or any other &quot
column4: alphabet&quot
column5: show (SVU, CSI, etc.).

column2: sick supply&quot
column3: of carbonated non-cola available in the case of upset stomach.&nbsp
column4: In our case, we try to keep a bottle of Sprite or 7-Up available&nbsp
column5: since it's easier on the stomach and can help keep a kid hydrated.&nbsp
column6: Always a good thing.&nbsp
column7: In today's case however, I had to make a quick run to the store since our supply had been used and not restocked.

column1: <li>Go to bed earlier since there's a higher likelihood of middle-of-the-night disruptions.&nbsp
column2: You can fold the laundry or watch TV later.

column1: <li>Clear your schedule for several days later if possible since you're likely to get sick as well.&nbsp
column2: In my case, a three day lag is pretty routine.

column1: The workload with a sick child is heavier, especially if there's stomach or bowels involved.
column2: But it doesn't have to be unbearable.&nbsp
column3:
So good luck and stay healthy.

People want their kids to have a broad array of activities from which to choose, but the unfortunate reality is that the broad array takes manpower to happen.
And there usually aren't enough paid professionals to make it happen.
So be ready to step up and take a role, whether you have a clue about the activity or not.
It's fairly straightforward if you spent your youth learning a sport or activity, like soccer through high school or camping with your family.
column2: But the kids might want to try something different and that's fine.&nbsp
column3: So don't let lack of knowledge stop you
column4: there are any number of ways to participate.&nbsp
column5: The simple reality is that when your kids are little, they' won't see the tentativeness if you're unfamiliar and will honestly appreciate the time spent with them.&nbsp
column6: Since my first child came along, I've learned how to:

column1: <li>measure the correct dimensions for a soccer field
<li>fill in as soccer and basketball coach
<li>cook a foil dinner on an open fire
<li>build a kayak (okay, it's a work in progress)
<li>managed a Brownie Troop cookie program (my wife, the &quot
column2: cookie mom&quot
column3: gave birth the week before product delivery).

column2: Each activity or organization is akin to a raft in time's river.&nbsp
column3: As the raft travels, it periodically puts to shore with the parents of older children exiting and being replaced by the parents of younger ones.&nbsp
column4: And the traditions and lessons are passed along over time, improved or changed as needed.&nbsp
column5: But if there are no new members, then the raft fails.

column2: You can spend time with the kids to create a&nbsp
column3: wealth of memories and experiences that can be shared in the future.&nbsp
column4: The prospect exists that the activity will continue and develop into a shared interest to carry over into the teen years and beyond.&nbsp
column5: And those are the years when you're going to need it.

And sometimes you don't even see it coming.

column2: have a typical modus operandi with exhaustion and the droops, fever, nausea/vomiting and perhaps some intestinal stuff.&nbsp
column3: But then you have the occasional critter that sneaks in and works it's way through the entire family.&nbsp
column4: No sense of being tired or fever, just some onset of nausea and then family members are greeting the commode.

column1: Middle started it yesterday after a busy day and we chalked it up to extended car travel - middle tends to motion sickness - and exhaustion after an overnight scout event.
column2: Plenty of fluid and a long night sleep - and no fever whatsover - and he was back to school this morning.&nbsp
column3: And then Eldest came home midday with the same, and no fever.&nbsp
column4: So we're again working with a virus that is going to relay around the house until everyone's suffered, including me.

We try to keep some basic food items in the house for when a kid comes down with a virus.
column2: Note try since the shortsighted little beggars will pilfer through supplies despite your best efforts, in which case you have to replenish quickly.
column3: Despite that, what can you keep around for those days when a child is sick?

column1: <li>Apple juice (note that some acidic juices like orange or grapefruit juice will further upset the stomach)
<li>unopened packs of plain crackers, like Saltines
<li>Bouillion cubes for mixing with hot water
• cans of simple soup, like chicken/noodle or chicken/rice.
Remember that the idea for a child with a stomach virus is to keep them hydrated while they're sick and then provide them with mild items as they recover.
column2: This morning, I'm bringing Eldest - who's recovering from a stomach virus - along with a juice/Sprite mix.&nbsp
column3: When she deals with that successfully, then we'll move up the ladder to dry foods, followed by soup and soft foods.&nbsp
column4: After she's successfully handled these items without further nausea/vomiting or intestinal problems, then we'll get back to the regular foods.

column1: Note this is not intended to be medical advice, but an insight into what can be used for kids with a mild virus.
column2:
If you have any questions or problems, immediately contact your family physician or pediatrician.
