Fatherhood lesson #5 is a family corollary to Newton's Law of Gravity.
column2: Inelegantly put, stuff flows downhill.

column1: It's one that regularly grabs my ear and kicks my butt.
column2: The more time that you spend with the kids, the more attuned they'll be to your moods and concerns and while you might tell kids otherwise, they are pretty perceptive.&nbsp
column3: You help set the tone in the house and it does have an impact.&nbsp

column1: In this particular instance, I've found that if I respond harshly - whether it's deserved or not - to a child, that child will pass the love onto a younger sibling.
column2: And if you have more than two children, you can watch it pass in a linear and chronological fashion through the children.&nbsp
column3: So I've had to really work at trying to temper the response to the situation.&nbsp
column4: Honestly, if I'm in a really bad mood then I can tell the kids to go to their rooms for a period so that I can come to grips with myself.&nbsp
column5: When they were younger, there was confusion as to what they might have done but continued conversation with them can help understand that there are moments when Dad needs a break as much as any of them.&nbsp
column6: They now understand that there are moments when I just tell them to go to their rooms while I regain control and that it's nothing that they might have necessarily done themselves.

column1:
All told, it beats the stink caused by spreading the toxicity through the household.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

144,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Kids are no different from adults when it comes to leisure time
column2: they resent the intrusion of work upon their free time and especially when it comes to holiday school breaks.&nbsp
column3: I know a lot of adults who will procrastinate on the work until the last minute, but spending panicked time trying to accomplish something under a tight deadline isn't a way to live a life and it isn't something that I want for my children.&nbsp
column4: And the kids aren't going to learn a proper way to do things if I don't at least sit down with them and work on how to manage time and work properly.&nbsp

column1: And in the last several days, I haven't served them well.
This particular break, the family had multiple activities planned - including a weekend visit to distant relatives - and we hit the ground running for getting into the Spring Break spirit.
column2: Note that my kids are all still in elementary and secondary school and none are in college.&nbsp
column3: Kids came in the door and backpacks hit the floor
column4: I did review the items that came home but didn't press on exactly what homework was due on what particular day.&nbsp
column5: And the party commenced.

column2: with school in session tomorrow, we returned late this afternoon to find that there was actually a fair amount of homework still to be done.&nbsp
column3: Younger and Middle were able to get things done in a timely fashion but Eldest is still sitting next to me as I write, and will probably stay here until after midnight.

column1: So what do I take from this screw-up?
• I have to remember that time management is largely a learned skill and not something that's going to come naturally to any youngster.

• While there's sufficient time available, it's up to me to walk through the scheduled work with the kid and help them to figure out how to plan their work so that the late night extravaganzas are minimized.
<li>I can't just lay back and grouse at the kids when a fair part of the responsibility lays on my shoulders.&nbsp
column2: Kids learn discipline and it takes a large investment of time and repetition to get that concept across.

145,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Your kids actually would like to spend time with you, even if they don't readily admit it as when they were younger.
column2: The problem that I'm running into sometimes is that what the kids want to do involves going out and spending more money.&nbsp
column3: So how do I try to handle things?

column1: First, if the time involves going to a bookstore or other retail spot, I try to set up the parameters ahead of time.
column2: Drink?&nbsp
column3: <em>Yes/No/Maybe&nbsp
column4: Snack?
column5: <em>Yes/No/Maybe&nbsp
column6: Purchase?
column7: Yes/No/Maybe
column8: Even if they later badger me, I can fall back on the original parameters.&nbsp

column1: Second, I try to be consistent about the personal rules.
column2: No credit card to pay for food and snacks.&nbsp
column3: Pay only with cash and not with change (all my change goes into a money jar at the end of the day).&nbsp

column1: Third, I sometimes remove the credit card so that I can fall back
column2: on its absence if the badgering reaches the point that even I have a problem with the pressure.&nbsp
column3: And yeah, they can really make it difficult to keep saying no.

column1:
Which leaves us with the prospect of being able to learn how to enjoy simple browsing, a valuable skill to know.

146,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Let me share a secret with you and it's one that many who promote hands-on fathering don't share.
column2: Children are really hard work.
column3: Frustrating, irritating work that only changes in the manner of challenge over the years.&nbsp
column4: And don't be surprised if you find yourself responding in ways that might be condemned on Doctor Phil or Supernanny.

column2: Because you're dealing with growing, changing individuals who are lacking common sense, self-discipline and the understanding that the world doesn't revolve around them.&nbsp
column3: Your world might, but the larger world largely doesn't give a rat's butt whether Junior gets to stay up for fifteen minutes past bedtime.&nbsp
column4: And it's not really politically correct to show individuals reacting out of frustration when their buttons have been pushed multiple times.

column2: You can't go smacking kids, calling them names or behaving like a bigger kid than they are.&nbsp
column3: But don't spend your time measuring yourself against an idealized image of a father portrayed in the media either.&nbsp
column4: Because their secret is that there really is no ideal father out there.&nbsp
column5: We're living on a cusp of a new social structure in which fathers are taking more and more of a hands-on role in the family and household, whether due to choice or economic reality, and the old models are no longer operative or relevant.&nbsp

column1: If you want a better indication of what involved, time-intensive, hands-on parenting is like for the parent,
column2: think of&nbsp
column3: Bill Cosby's routine on giving the kids chocolate cake for breakfast.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: The wife's reaction to seeing the kids spend their breakfast noshing on dad-permitted chocolate cake is more typical for any parent responsible for the lion's share of child-rearing.&nbsp
column6: Either mother or father.&nbsp
column7: So understand that we're in the process of watching the father's image move from that of Bill Cosby to that of his wife, who's thoroughly out of patience with the nonsense that she's witnessing on the part of the adult and the kids.

column1: That's what I've been thinking about after this morning's foray into absurdity by two elementary school boys.
column2: One won't make a decision on what pants to wear yet refuses to don what I've pulled out.&nbsp
column3: The other first asks what the temperature is going to be and after being told a typical wet and chilly early Spring day, walks out of his room in sockless sneakers, Bermuda shorts and a cotton Polo shirt.&nbsp
column4: As I stand at the top of the steps counting the minutes to departure, bouncing back and forth between the duellling arguments, my voice rises and the one accuses me of taking my anger out on him because of the other.&nbsp
column5: My response is that I wouldn't be yelling if he'd not argue with what is sheer common sense.

column1: It's taken years to accept that being a hands-on parent doesn't entail saint-like patience and that a raised voice isn't the mark of bad parenting.
column2: It's not how I choose or try to spend my time, but it doesn't make me bad either.

Sometimes you read something in the national news that strikes a nerve, and
column2: page=1"">Madlyn Primoff
column3: did that with millions of parents since it goes to the heart of disciplining children.&nbsp
column4: What is discipline and its purpose?&nbsp
column5: How can you handle it effectively?&nbsp

column1: Disciplining the kids is one of the most vexing issues a parent handles.
column2: Always has been and always will be.&nbsp
column3: I started notes on this article even before the website came online and wrestled with it until a friend asked if I'd be writing about discipline as it should be or how it actually is.&nbsp
column4: And that's a great starting point.

column1: At it's heart, the idea of discipline involves teaching and learning.
column2: Discipline's root word is the latin disciplina just as the latin word for pupil is discupulus.
column3: Christ had his disciples, who referred to him as Rabbi (teacher) as they followed him about.&nbsp
column4: While the root pertains to learning however, it has become synonymous with punishment and that's where problems arise.

column1: • To help learn the difference between right and wrong.
• To help learn the concept of recognizing good and bad behaviors.
• To help learn that there are consequences to those bad behaviors.
• To help learn - through lots of repetition - the concept of self-control.
• To help learn that they live in a world with many others, so they have to harness the egocentrism.
In its most basic form, learning involves communication.
column2: No communication and I guarantee there'll be no learning.&nbsp
column3: So communication is key in effective discipline.

column1: That's lovely theory and there are times when it works.
column2: But it assumes that the base nature of the typical kid allows that.&nbsp
column3: The unfortunate reality is that your typical child lives in a world of wild egocentrism and natural selfishness, and those attitudes and resulting behaviors don't usually just yield to talk.

column1: So how about the practical side of discipine?
column2: The fictional Klingon aphorism is that revenge is a dish best served cold.
column3: That's probably a bad place to put that comment since revenge and discipline cannot be the same thing - ever.&nbsp
column4: But good discipline should be served with ICE.

column2: Consistent.&nbsp
column3:
Enforceable.

column1:

When you're bouncing back and forth amongst kids, it's easy to set aside school and activity paperwork and lose track of it.
column2: Unfortunately, this paperwork - showing schedules/contact names, field trip information, registrations, and all many of stuff - is just as important as the tax receipts.&nbsp
column3: So I keep a folder at the kitchen desk to hold specifically and only that information.&nbsp
column4: And I've come to live by it.

column1: Today was one of the days where the system broke down.
column2: Middle had a choral concert this evening, and a form was sent home weeks ago by the music teacher with all of the pertinent information including the all-important what-to-wear.
column3: This form unfortunately didn't make it to the folder after being noted on the family calendar.&nbsp
column4: Consequently, this morning found all manner of angst about what would be appropriate attire since what a sixth grader finds appropriate doesn't match PracticalDad's definition.&nbsp
column5: This chart exemplifies the conflict:

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp

column1: Making the situation even more difficult was that the students were being bused to the high school immediately after school and wouldn't be home to change, so what they put on that morning was it for the concert.
Now here are a few comments about what you'll hear from kids who want their way.

column3: And you'll note that there's no mustard on your lunch sandwich.

Sometimes things go smoothly and sometimes they fall apart.
With a two story house, I keep a disinfectant spray bottle - containing bleach - on each level so that I can minimize the steps.
column2: And on the main level, that bottle hangs by the trigger from the wire shelf above the washer/dryer.&nbsp
column3: Also above the washer/dryer hangs a bottle of stain treatment spray.

column1: You see where I'm going with this.
In the process of loading the washer, I found that one of my dark shirts needed a quick treatment and reached for the white bottle to spray the stain.
column2: It was after the shirt came out of the dryer that I realized that the item was ruined
column3: I can't even wear it and make it appear as though it's some weird tie-die design.&nbsp
column4: It's fortunate that nothing else was ruined.

column1: So, what do I take from this exercise?
• I could say pay attention to what you're doing or
• I can find a different high location on which to store the disinfectant.

column2:
Rats.

On a sunny and warm Spring day, it's the perfect time for handling the Spring clean-up yardwork.
column2: Trimming bushes, clearing underbrush, setting up the patio table and chairs and cleaning the pond.

column1: And it's a day on which I kicked myself as I did it with the wife and kids.
column2: Now that I have three kids, I wish that I had done some things differently with the older two.&nbsp
column3: Clearly, the kids need(ed) to help in order to learn what has to be done to keep a household going
column4: but I could have handled it both differently and better.

column1: With multiple small children and a working wife, I felt pressed to get the job done as expediently as possible so that we could move on with the other activities that make weekends fun.
column2: And being a former operations guy, I figured that the best way to make that work was to divide the work so that the kids who were old enough could do something productive while I tackled the power engine applications - mowing grass, weed whacking and such.
column3: The one who was less than about seven years of age wasn't expected to do much and could run and play so long as they stayed within sight.&nbsp
column4: Once a child turned seven, then there was an expectation that he or she could do something to assist.&nbsp

column1: But my goof was believing that just giving an easy task was sufficient while I took care of the other jobs.
column2: Yes, a first or second grader can do some minimal sweeping.&nbsp
column3: But what looks manageable to a 40-something guy isn't the same for a kid, even if it really isn't much.&nbsp
column4: So the kids would complain about how much they had to do and the situation would deteriorate.&nbsp
column5: And today, I heard one of the older kids channeling my years-ago grousing to Youngest who complained about the work.&nbsp
column6: And when I went over to help Youngest pick up yard waste, the complaints ceased.&nbsp
column7: It wasn't the work that created the issue, but rather the sense of being alone in a job that looks unmanageable to a kid.

column1: So how would I do it differently?
• Scale back my expectations of work to be done and the appropriate time-frame in which to do it.
• Understand that the complaints might be laziness, but entertain the real notion that perhaps the child just wants to do the job with his/her dad.
• Recognize that I need to do a better job of multi-tasking as I shuttle between the power-equipment work and the childrens' tasks.
Kids need to see the work necessary to keep the daily life running.
column2: And they need to have some jobs to teach responsibility.&nbsp
column3: But making it an unpleasant situation through crankiness only defeats the purpose and does a disservice.

column1: And I have to think about I'm going to have a conversation with the grousing child and
column2:
re-visit some old issues.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"
Practice
Immediate.&nbsp
column3: Consistent.&nbsp
column4: Enforceable.

column1: There are different methods of disciplining kids, but any decent and effective discipline should have these three aspects.
When a small child does something that requires correction, that correction has to occur immediately or the kid will have difficulty processing why there he even needs the correction.
column2: If you're in a store and the child misbehaves by repeatedly grabbing something, you have to address it immediately in whatever way you choose.&nbsp
column3: To do nothing and then wait until after you've returned to the car creates a sense that you're acting arbitrarily, even if you remind them why they're being corrected.&nbsp
column4: A friend of mine refers to kids as early members of the Twelve Step Program
column5: &nbsp
column6: you tell them something and they've forgotten what it was withing twelve steps of their original position.

column1: As they age and the memory improves, the definition of immediate can lenghten so long as the misbehavior stops in the moment..
column2: For example, if a child is injured and requires immediate attention, you can attend to the kid and then go back and deal with the behavior that caused the injury.&nbsp
column3: If there's anything that kids remember, it's blood.&nbsp
column4: But you still have to be reasonable and remember that their sense of time is poor at best.

column1: Probably the toughest of all three is consistency since any number of factors - annoyance/anger levels, tiredness, desire to win, attention to other matters - can render you horribly inconsistent.

column2: Simply that the kid understands that the consequences for any misbehavior will be real and pertinent each time he misbehaves.&nbsp
column3: It doesn't necessarily mean that the consequences&nbsp
column4: are precisely alike
column5: repeated behaviors demand that the consequences increase in severity until you have the kid's attention.&nbsp
column6: Nor does it mean that there are identical consequences amongst different children since not all children are affected by the same consequence.&nbsp
column7: But there should be some proportionality about the various consequences.&nbsp
column8: Making one child sit on the steps for eight minutes isn't proportional to making another kid scrub the kitchen floor for a similar offense.

column1: Likewise, you have to assure that there are no mixed messages about kinds of behavior.
column2: If something is unacceptable, then it's unacceptable and not subject to whether you feel like dealing with the situation.

column1: Giving a kid warnings about consequences is important if they're going to learn self-control.
column2: Hey, I've got to remember to not do that or the 'rents will have the iPod.
column3: But the warnings have to be about consequences that are both reasonable and pertinent to the child, and enforceable.&nbsp
column4: Because follow-through is one of the core tenets of parental discipline and if your noted consequence isn't enforceable, then you'll more likely to lose control of discipline.

column1: Not all kids are alike - DUH - so no consequences will have the same effect.
column2: Some kids are sensitive about privacy while a sibling happily uses the bathroom with the door open.&nbsp
column3: Others prize their electronics.&nbsp
column4: Others have favorite activities that they hate to miss.&nbsp
column5: So the first part is to know the child well enough to find that leverage.

column1: The consequence also has to be reasonable and commensurate with the situation at hand.
column2: Is it overkill to ground a child for a week for writing on the floor or walls?&nbsp
column3: Trust me, such behavior isn't localized to toddlers.&nbsp
column4: Or does it make more sense to have the child help clean such writing?&nbsp
column5: Or even do it themselves&nbsp
column6: if old enough?&nbsp
column7: There's no perfect answer here, so you have to trust the common sense test.

column1: Finally, the consequence has to be enforceable.
column2: If your kid thinks that there's no follow-through, then there's nothing to make them even consider the idea of consequences.&nbsp
column3: I'm not known for my memory so I've occasionally made notes about what consequences were promised if certain situations arise again.&nbsp
column4: I'm serious enough about it that I even know where the notes are kept.&nbsp
column5: (Note to the kids:&nbsp
column6: If you're reading this, don't even ask where they are.)&nbsp
column7: It pays to take a few seconds or moments to run the proposed consequence past the common sense test, but not so long that you lose the immediacy of responding to the circumstances.

column1: There's one other vital piece to good discipline and that's the follow-up.
column2: Some call it the talk and my father referred to it as the post-mortem.
column3: This is especially important when the kids are younger as they might not grasp exactly what it was that earned them what they got.&nbsp
column4: I've been known to sit on the bed and point-blank ask them to tell me why they're in th eroom and the ensuing conversation pointed out other issues that required attention.&nbsp
column5: Failing this follow-up can lead to a repeat with even greater issues.

column1: Good discipline is kind of like a power turbine that's installed early and then runs through the years.
column2: And the talk and conversation is the oil and maintenance that keeps it running smoothly.

When the kids age, they at least pay a bit of attention to the news.
column2: And unfortunately, that news today is all about a possible pandemic of the swine flu.&nbsp
column3: And naturally, they'll ask the magic question are we gonna die?

column1: My first response to these questions is no, we're not going to die.
column2: And they usually then go outside to shoot some hoops or pester another sibling.&nbsp

column1: My second response is to then take a deep breath and start a mental review of what we might need in the event that things do get ugly.
column2: But how do I define &quot
column3: ugly&quot
column4: ?&nbsp
column5: My assumption is that things will not follow the Mad Max/Road Warrior scenario, so I'm not going to spend my time stocking up on Pez Dispensers for use as trading goods.&nbsp
column6: I assume that in the worst case, schools might be closed and public will slow to a crawl for awhile.

column1: So what do I plan to keep on hand?
column2: Remember that the idea is not to have to leave the house while one or more of the kids is sick.

column1: • Several bottles of disinfectant cleaner, fully stocked, since the germ-control activities will rise significantly.
• Several bottles of antibacterial hand cleaner, enough for each sink plus a spare.
• Disinfectant wipes for wiping down all common hand surfaces - think remotes and handles.
• Some rubber/latex gloves in the event that I have to clean up vomit or other bodily messes.
• Several bottles of carbonated non-colas - Sprite, Ginger Ale - for queasy stomachs as well as several bottles of apple juice to mix with it.
• Some Pedialyte for the smaller child to help the body recoup.
• Some cans of mild/bland soup for recovering stomachs.
• Adequate supply of paper towels and toilet paper since the usage will probably rise.
• Adequate supply of child's ibuprofen and acetaminophen to help with any fever control.
And if I have to go to the store, I'll handle it one of two ways.
column2: First, I'll either go at night so that the kids aren't alarmed or else I'll take the eldest with me and work these items into a larger list.&nbsp
column3: If I take Eldest, we'll have some conversations on preparation for emergencies.

column1:
And then I'll fall back on the default you're going to be alright.

As I wrote about in the practical side to discipline, any form of discipline has to be handled as swiftly as possible.
column2: As the child ages and gains a better perspective on time and memory, the definition of &quot
column3: immediate&quot
column4: will lengthen, but failure to handle issues in a timely fashion is simply going to confuse the kid.&nbsp
column5: After all, if something is really important, then it should be handled immediately, right?

column1: That even pertains to public locations and special events at which any misbehavior is highlighted in neon green.
column2: Kids do better when they have some notice or warning about what's coming, so we've made it a habit to talk with the kids in advance and give them some idea of what they can expect and what's expected of them.&nbsp
column3: That said, it took me time to accept that even well-behaved kids have their moments and I've had to learn that paying full attention at any public event is liable to not happen.&nbsp
column4: I've simply had to adjust my own expectations of what's doable with children.

column1: And if you're worried about what people will think, most adults are appreciative that parents are willing to ride herd on their children.
column2:
The key is to maintain control of your own temper, so again, adjust your expectations accordingly.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
155,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Handling discipline consistently is probably the most difficult aspect of disciplining children.
column2: Because you need to be consistent in multiple ways:

column1: <li>Consistent over time with that particular child
<li>Consistent when having to shift between disciplining one child and another
• Consistent in conjunction with the mother so that the kids don't receive competing messages.
At heart, kids are creatures of habit and routine.
column2: They can handle a bit of change, but they'll do best when they know what they can expect and what's expected of them.&nbsp
column3: In addition, not all kids respond to the same forms of discipline - even in the same family - so it's easier for you if you stick to what you know works.&nbsp
column4: Having to constantly &quot
column5: reinvent the wheel&quot
column6: for correcting behavior can be self-defeating, especially if you're having to do so while thoroughly torqued with them.

column1: This is probably the most difficult aspect of all.
Even when they're a bit older, they are egocentric.
column2: So don't expect any immediate rational conversation or sympathy for the fact that you're contending with another recalcitrant pre-schooler.&nbsp
column3: And frankly, kids will start spinning out of control if they perceive that the little miscreant who presently has your attention is getting it because of poor behavior
column4: let's face it, egocentrism means that they want attention, sometimes in whatever form they can get it.

column1: I've found that when there are issues with more than one at a time, my best response is to separate each to their room immediately.
column2: The child is physically safe, has an opportunity to calm down and it gives me a brief opportunity to regain my sanity/composure as I move from one child's situation to the next.&nbsp
column3: Unfortunately, I wish that I had understood this when they were younger since some of my worst moments as a father came when having to contend with dueling meltdowns amongst squabbling children.&nbsp

column1: Believe me, there is absolutely nothing wrong with briefly isolating them while you work to regain your own self-control so that you can handle each child's discipline that is best for that particular child.
column2: Some children are highly sensitive and respond well to nothing more than some conversation while others look at conversation as a joke and require more serious measures for effective discipline to occur.&nbsp
column3: And yes, each of mine respond best to different measures.

column1: I'm convinced that all of the great generals of history were - at heart - children since they all understand divide and conquer so well.

column2: in handling discipline with the kid's mother doesn't mean that a father must handle discipline exactly as a mother.&nbsp
column3: But each of you has to understand that while there are different styles of handling kids in a stressful moment, the measures used should be consistent.&nbsp
column4: Time outs, counting, loss of privileges - each parent can use whatever works consistently even if one parent is more emotive in the moment than the other.

column1: If two parents aren't consistent in their approach to discipline, then the natural inclination of the kid will be to shift to that parent who's "
column2: easier&quot
column3: with the child
column4: the end result will be that the one parent is pitted against the other with the heartache that's going to ensue.

column1: And the cardinal rule of two parents is this:
column2: Never challenge the disciplinary measure taken in the moment by the other parent, excepting abuse.
column3: If you disagree with a disciplinary measure, you can privately intercede with the other, but never overtly break ranks with the other parent.&nbsp
column4: Both my wife and I have interceded with the other when we thought things were handled poorly, but we've tried to never break ranks in front of the kids.

column1: And that's perhaps one of the hardest things of all.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
156,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Regardless of what types of discipline you choose, remember that effective discipline is handled immediately, consistently, and is enforceable.

column2: It seems odd at first since the first inclination of many dads is to just impose the punishment and be done with it.&nbsp

column1: But remember that discipline is more than just punishment, it's also teaching, and this is where enforcement comes into play along with the others.
Remember that part of discipline is to help teach a kid to distinguish right/wrong, make good choices and also understand the concept of consequences.
To help the kids understand and grasp consequences, many parents - me included - will give a child a "
column2: choice&quot
column3: of outcomes
column4: let's be frank, it's usually a threat.&nbsp
column5: You can either choose to toe the line or you can expect a specific outcome.&nbsp
column6: Many will phrase it in a negative light - act badly and deal with a bad outcome.&nbsp
column7: But it can be phrased in a positive light as well - act well and expect a good outcome.&nbsp
column8: Regardless of the phrasing, it is important that it be sometime that can actually be backed up.&nbsp
column9: Failing to enforce or deliver the outcome will create even more disciplinary problems since the kid will lose any sense that there is any real consequence.&nbsp

column1: Frankly, it helps to spend some time thinking through what consequences are most appropriate for that child.
column2: A father can be utterly torqued with the child - been there, done that - and it's frequently in that mindset that you have to handle Junior's issues.
column3: And in the heat of the moment, a father can come up with some totally unsatisfiable consequences and that is the kiss of death to the child having expectations of discipline.

column1: What can you consider to help find something appropriate?
• Is there a particular task that they have to do?
• Is there a special event or activity planned?
All of the above take a negative approach to discipline.
The flip side is that effective discipline can be positive as well without resorting to bribery.
column2: Close friends of ours are masters of tying activities to desired behaviors - <em>you can play with the neighbor's kid after your room is picked up to my satisfaction/practiced the piano/taken out the trash.&nbsp
column3: This however, does entail some thinking about time.
column4: Is there sufficient time for the kid to meet the expectation and then enjoy the consequence?&nbsp
column5: Kids have no sense of time and playing with little Mikey isn't an enforceable consequence if your child has met the behavior but doesn't have the time to enjoy it.&nbsp
column6: If this happens often enough, the kid's going to fail since there's no expectation of consequence.

column1: Bearing these things in mind, I have a rule of thumb about what makes an appropriate enforceable discipline.
<li>Is this illegal or going to land me in the news?&nbsp
column2: No, you can't threaten to leave them at the airport since that's abandonment.&nbsp
column3: And yes, I've heard a father threaten to leave his recalcitrant kid at the airport while the rest of the family went to Florida.

column1: <li>Is this tailored to the kid or is it going to impact other kids or the rest of the family?&nbsp
column2: You might want to threaten to cancel a trip to the movies, but will that entail a punishment to the other kids?

column1: • Does it touch them where it'll have an impact?
<li>Is it too cumbersome to pull off?&nbsp
column2: You can threaten to remove all of the child's toys, but where do you put them and how long will it take to do?
While it seems intuitive, enforceable discipline is still easy to goof in the heat of the moment.&nbsp
column3: And it's as important as consistency and immediacy&nbsp
column4:
to good discipline.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
157,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Anyone who's going to deal with kids will find the "
column2: time out&quot
column3: useful as a disciplinary tool.&nbsp
column4: But what exactly is it and what should you remember when you utilize it?

column1: It is literally what it sounds like - a time out and away from a problem
column2: activity or behavior.&nbsp
column3: Kids will frequently get into a cycle or pattern of behavior and this removal from that activity can sometimes be enough to keep that from continuing when the time out is over.&nbsp
column4: It also serves to reinforce the idea that there are consequences for poor behavior and for a child, not being able to play is a significant consequence.&nbsp

column1: Time outs can be used after the child reaches the toddler stage
column2: this would typically be about 18 months of age.&nbsp
column3: To be honest however, I began using the practice several months earlier with one of my children.&nbsp
column4: This particular child found it fun to pop me hard in the nose when I reached into the crib for her
column5: when simple corrections - don't do that, that's bad - didn't work, I started to simply put her back in the crib when she popped my nose.
column6: I'd connect this with the verbal correction and leave her in the crib for less than half a minute and repeat it each time I got smacked.&nbsp
column7: Yes, she cried but soon got the message that beating on Dad wasn't the best choice.&nbsp

column1: They are an effective tool - when used appropriately - for the toddler years and beyond but start to lose their usefulness when the kid reaches about 10 years of age.
column2: At that point, there are other, more effective, means of discipline.

column1: • The rule of thumb for a time out's length is about one minute for each year of age.
<li>When you put a very small child in time out, find a spot that is free of any entertaining activities whatever - toys, music, TV, whatever.&nbsp
column2: A corner or at the foot of the steps are both options.

column1: <li>Be prepared to stay nearby to ensure that the child stays there.&nbsp
column2: Depending upon the kid's willfulness - or stubbornness if you prefer - you should be prepared to simply lose that time for anything that you were doing at the moment.&nbsp
column3: If Junior decides to move, make him return
column4: when mine were younger, I would simply tell them to return and if they refused, I'd physically return them.&nbsp
column5: And yes, I'd tell them clearly that the more they refused, the longer they'd stay in time out.&nbsp
column6: While some parents believe that it shouldn't be a contest of wills, the simple reality is that it is.
column7: If you cannot get them to understand that the discipline is going to be enforced, then you're going to have major issues later.

column1: <li>When you start a time out, be sure to clearly say why they're going into time out.&nbsp
column2: And be sure to have a brief follow up to assure that they get why they were corrected.&nbsp
column3: It might be perfectly clear to you, but don't assume that it's perfectly clear to them.&nbsp
column4: Full disclosure:&nbsp
column5: Been there, done that.

column1: <li>Unless you're comfortable that your child will actually not do anything - and some are dependable for that - then giving a time out in the bedroom is asking for violation of the time out.&nbsp
column2: Full disclosure:&nbsp
column3: Been there, done that.

column1: <li>If you do leave the immediate vicinity to attend to something else - cooking dinner, for example - then set a timer to remind you that the time out's over.&nbsp
column2: Some kids will continue to sit.&nbsp
column3: Full disclosure:&nbsp
column4: Been there, done that.

column1: <li>If you're engaged in cooking and hear problem behavior - and yes, that's possible - that requires a time out, make sure that you use the right name for the child who gets the time out.&nbsp
column2: Multi-tasking can lead to mistakes so&nbsp
column3: don't be afraid to apologize the kid who wrongfully got the time out.&nbsp
column4: This goes&nbsp
column5: back to the need&nbsp
column6: to stay nearby.&nbsp
column7: Full disclosure:&nbsp
column8: Been there, done that.

column1: Finally, remember that while the time out is a good tool, it's not a panacea and should only be one of several in the father's toolbox.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
158,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Take to any parent and you hear that have to pick your battles.
column2: Every child is a unique creation and they'll start developing their own tastes during the toddler years, which is good since the world can't take a clone of me.&nbsp
column3: But that also means that as they grow, they'll bump into what you find acceptable and will naturally push the envelope.&nbsp
column4: Which is why parents are big on picking battles.

column1: • You realize that as members of a new generation with its own tastes and subculture, they'll take an interest in what has little appeal to you.
• You realize that there's going to be some bumping as these interests suddenly appear in your home.
• You remember that you yourself went through a similar experience and in the interest of family harmony, you have to make peace with some of this.
• You have to actually pay attention to what's out there and decide in advance whether you can accept it in the house.
• You have to be willing to actually examine what they want and then explain why something is unacceptable.
• You have to be willing to listen to their rationale for why something should be allowed and then willing to move if they actually make sense.
You're right if the last statement indicates that a particular issue might be revisited multiple times over weeks or months.
column2: But if you do bend in that particular instance, then you need to explicitly acknowledge why you're doing so or the kid will start thinking that they can wear you down.

column1: <li>You have to just accept something - in the interest of family harmony - just because the kid is acting like an ass.&nbsp
column2: And yes, when they enter the teen years, they can do that.

column1: <li>You use it as an excuse because you're too tired after a day or week at work.&nbsp
column2: If you've taken a legitimate stand on a particular behavior or mode of dress, then be ready to stand the ground as the campaign grinds onwards.&nbsp
column3: It will be unpleasant for everyone, but there are legitimate reasons for certain expectations and the kid is just going to have to adjust.

column2: My mother sometimes dressed me funny and my own father wouldn't tell her to knock the hell off.&nbsp
column3: White patent leather shoes are especially snappy, but not when you're a seventh-grader required to wear them to school.&nbsp
column4: I'd done as well if I'd just worn a sign on my back reading go ahead, abuse me.
column5: So I do have some sensitivity to the tween and teen need for fashion acceptance.&nbsp
column6: That said, my mate and I have had to develop some general parameters within which the kids can work with their clothing.

column1: They know my history and I've explicitly told them that I'll never make them dress in such a manner as to attract ridicule.
column2: But we do insist that:

column1: <li>pants must be kept at an appropriate level since low slung pants started as a means of copying prison dress
<li>shirts not have any foul language on them
<li>the kids dress better for certain occasions since dressing well is a sign of respect for the situation at hand
<li>they learn that there are a few kids who'll poke fun just because they're idiots and that's what idiots do, so suck it up
• common sense is used so that clothing is appropriate for the weather at hand.
In that last statement, I don't give a tinker's dam what the other kids are saying since a
column2: high of 50 degrees isn't appropriate for flip-flops and shorts.

column1: Whether the kids find you cool is irrelevant here.
column2:
But what is relevant to the ongoing tension and debate is that you might actually be turned onto something that is itself cool.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
159,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's human nature that people who don't like what they hear will somehow turn it around so that it's not what you originally meant.
column2: And if it's human nature that affects adults, you can be sure that it's operative with the kids.&nbsp
column3: So I take great pains to be frank with them, almost to the point of bluntness.

column2: They will not focus on what you say as well as most adults.
If they doan like what they hear, they'll try to minimize it or manuever around it.
They sometimes just doan get what you're saying.
Some are&nbsp
column3: concerned that their child not hear something unpleasant lest that&nbsp
column4: child's self-esteem&nbsp
column5: be damaged.

column1: Fortunately, children are about as resilient as weeds.
Most children are very concrete in their thinking and haven't yet developed abstract thinking skills
column2: their listening skills are also not up to speed.&nbsp
column3: For example, I caught one of my children in a major lie and consequently told that child - then in second grade - to write <em>I will not tell a lie, 110 times.&nbsp
column4: Within a minute, the child was out of the room playing and when I interceded, showed me the paper.
column5: Correctly written - from a kid's point of view.&nbsp
column6: The paper simply said I will not tell a lie 110 times.

column1: And after a quiet discussion, the child wrote the correct phrase another 109 times.
column2: And I learned a lesson.
But handled properly with kids, you can be very clear without being rude.&nbsp
column3: Being frank means that you are as clear as possible with the kid, even asking them to repeat back to you what you said.&nbsp
column4: Being frank also means that you use language that clearly identifies a behavior or comment with a&nbsp
column5: specific label.&nbsp
column6: This is where many trip up since they apply the label to the kid and not the action.

column1: For example, L'il Fred sees someone sitting down and thinks it would be cool to watch them land their scrawny butt on the floor.
column2: So L'il Fred removes the chair and Gertrude lands both her butt and her head on the floor - along with a pint of blood.&nbsp
column3: Some parents will tell Fred that he's a bad kid for what he did.&nbsp
column4: Repeated enough times, Fred hears &quot
column5: bad kid&quot
column6: but tunes out the remainder of the phrase until he's convinced himself that he really is a bad kid.&nbsp

column1: A better way to talk to Fred?
column2: You can ask him why did you do that? but honestly, Fred was in the moment and awaiting the sound of a bony butt on the concrete floor.
column3: He was probably even wondering whether it would sound like so many dice landing on a Candyland Board.&nbsp
column4: After you correct Fred in whatever manner is best for Fred, talk to him but distinguish between him and the action.<em>&nbsp
column5: Fred, you're a really smart guy, but that was a dumb/bad thing to do.
column6: Fred will probably be embarrassed and over time, will learn that he is a smart guy capable of making a good decision - or stopping a bad one - with some thought.

column1: Also feel free to be clear and specific with your language.
column2: Don't be afraid to use labels that have a moral component.&nbsp
column3: Some actions aren't only stupid, they are bad and they are wrong.&nbsp
column4: And if the child doesn't hear those labels attached to the behavior, they won't get the moral aspect of their behavior.&nbsp
column5: If you spend your time using phrases like stupid and dumb, then the child will only learn that their actions serve to reflect
column6: on their image&nbsp
column7: and not whether those actions&nbsp
column8: are good&nbsp
column9: or right in and of themselves.

column2: Not nice is a particular dislike of mine.
column3: If L'il Fred dropped Gertrude on her bony butt, it was bad.&nbsp
column4: If L'il Fred used the dinner fork for his salad or farted at the table, it wasn't nice.&nbsp
column5: There's a distinct difference between the two and the kids won't learn it if they don't hear it.

column1: Being concrete, kids don't get open-ended and vague threats of consequences in case of misbehavior.
column2: In the moment, I've also used vague warnings of impending apocalypse should something occur but I try hard to assure that the child is aware of potential consequences.&nbsp
column3: I've found with mine that the resulting ill-will of discipline is lessened if they had a clue of what was coming.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: The seriousness of an action is reflected in the consequences that adults assign to that action and a child who screws up is less likely to feel wronged if they&nbsp
column6: understood the magnitude of the action.

column1: • Be plain in your language and don't be afraid to ask them to repeat what you've said back to you.
• Be sure to verbally distinguish between the child and the action when using descriptive phrases or words.
<li>Be sure to use words that convey a moral component to the action.&nbsp
column2: Regardless of your religious belief, your home is the principal place for the kid to learn basic tenets of morality.
Use clear, strong words that are unmistakeable to a young mind.

column1: • When you discuss consequences should something occur, be clear, direct and specific as possible.
And since we're human, we're going to make mistakes.
column2: I've made plenty and will continue to do so.&nbsp
column3: But don't let a fear of erring with the kid keep you from communicating clearly.&nbsp
column4:
The more clear that you are, the less likely the mistake.

One of the big challenges to being involved with the kids and household is balancing children and housework.
column2: The kids need your attention - they thrive on it - but the house isn't going to run itself.&nbsp
column3: And it continues to be a challenge with changes and tweaks as activities multiply, kids grow and more critters enter the house.&nbsp
column4: It can become a point of contention between you, your mate and the kids as well.

column1: Despite the changes that occur, there are some constants however.

column2: It simply continues to a new cycle of the same tasks to be done.&nbsp
column3: If you feel like it's never done, that's because it isn't.

column2: It accumulates fast and in no particular order and you'll have a constant battle of what to keep versus discard.

column1: • Even when you ask nicely, even including please, a child can respond in an unpleasant fashion.
column2: Until they're old enough to learn that things don't just happen, unpleasantries like chores will interfere with the important job of play.

column1: <li>Even as chores remain the same, the age of your children will dictate how the frequency of the chore.&nbsp
column2: Everything happens more often with younger children.

column1: With the constants out of the way, here's a basic chore roster of the PracticalDad household.
column2: Remember that it might not work in every household, but it's a point of departure for building a schedule.

column1: Remember that this chart assumes that the kids are old enough to be in elementary school.
column2: When they're young, the frequency of what's done will increase.

column1: This last is just a starting point and doesn't cover all of the other aspects of cleaning house.
column2: Other&nbsp
column3: tasks might include cleaning windows and woodwork, animal care, grocery shopping and cleaning the refrigerator.

column1: In the next series of articles, we'll cover some of the ins and outs of the items on the PracticalDad chore chart.

As mundane and mind-numbing as they are, dusting and vacuuming are two of the cornerstones of keeping the house in livable shape.
column2: So wrap your head around the idea that these tasks will be regular parts of the the routine that keeps the household in decent order and diminishes the likelilhood of respiratory problems.

column1: Yeah, the old stereotype is that the housewife did these jobs in order to keep the house spic and span and presentable for the Ladies Book Club.
column2: But she was also doing it to keep the dust levels and animal hair under control.&nbsp
column3: And let's face it, if you have kids, you probably have a dog, cat, hamster, mouse, rat or ferret.&nbsp
column4: The PracticalDad household has the first three and I'm standing pat on the remainder.

column2: It's not just one particular thing, but a mess of multiple components gathered together.

column1: • Tiny bits of human skin that is constantly being sloughed off as it dies and is replaced by new skin cells.
• Tiny bits of hair and follicular materials.

column2: and desiccated feces of those same microscopic creatures.

column1: There has been a marked rise in the incidence rate of asthma among children between the ages of five and seventeen, reaching a level of
column2: b=22782"">106 cases per 1000 kids in that age range.
column3: This is spurred by a number of causes.

column1: • The more enclosed nature of modern homes with central air and less frequently opened windows.
• Children spending more time inside than before.
• A greater exposure to vermin in the home.
While children can grow out of this condition as they age, it does create major issues for them and keeping the house clean is a large part of helping protect the kids.
There are also respiratory problems for adults in the form of allergies and a greater prevalence of respiratory illness.
On one level, it's simple - you dust and vacuum.
column2: But if you have to do these mind-numbing activities, then you should consider some things to make sure that it's really worth the time and effort.

column1: <li>Dust first and use a cloth with a dust spray (Endust, for instance) in order to capture the dust particles in the cloth.&nbsp
column2: By dusting first, you assure that any particles that land on the floor are then caught by the vacuum.

column1: <li>Avoid a featherduster since it only kicks the dust particules into the air, where they'll then settle back on the furniture.&nbsp
column2: There's no sense doing things twice.

column1: <li>A furniture wax should be used to keep the furniture wood moisturized but that should only be done on a more infrequent basis, perhaps once every several months.&nbsp
column2: Do it too often and the furniture will develop a perceptible wax build-up.

column1: <li>On furniture where the wood is in close proximity to fabric - the arms or legs of chairs for instance - spray the cloth instead of the furniture itself.&nbsp
column2: The spray then is kept off of the fabric.

column1: • While there are innumerable models of vacuum cleaners, make sure that you're using one that has a HEPA filter
column2: to help remove the tiny particles not caught in the vacuum.

column1: <li>Check the bag before vacuuming to make sure that there's sufficient room for the dirt.&nbsp
column2: A too-full bag can create a strain on the motor and burn it out.&nbsp
column3: <em>Full disclosure:&nbsp
column4: Been there, done that.

column1: <li>Use an extension on the hose to periodically clean along the baseboard, where it meets the carpet.&nbsp
column2: This is especially important if you have animals that shed.&nbsp
column3: And what's the point of having animals if they can't shed and create more work?

column2: the manufacturer didn't include them just to get lost.&nbsp
column3: The brush attachment can be used on blinds and wood surfaces.&nbsp
column4: The broad attachment&nbsp
column5: can be used for furniture fabric, drapes and carpeted steps.

column1: • Move chairs aside in order to get underneath them and periodically move the sofa as well.
<li>When vacuuming on a hard surface, you might have better luck first sweeping the floor with a broom and then vacuuming up the pile.&nbsp
column2: The broom allows you to reach into corners and under counters that the vacuum might not be able to reach.

column1: It might seem silly to consider these things, but there have been any number of times that I've wanted to bang my head into the wall because of a poor job or goof.
column2: So think of it as saving yourself the job of scrubbing blood off the wall.

The kids know that I'm a closet economics geek.
column2: But being an economics geek doesn't help me since personal finance can be a world away from economics and that's especially true for kids with minimal experience.&nbsp
column3: So I grab the opportunities to bring a point about savings and shopping home to them.

column2: We're in a different state attending a family wedding when my wife asked that I somehow find her some decaffeinated Diet Coke.&nbsp
column3: Because we have a room refrigerator and are here for more than one night, it made more sense to go out for it.&nbsp
column4: Middle went along with me to a nearby Walmart for a twelve pack and asked why we didn't just go to the vending machine instead?&nbsp
column5: This led to a conversation about the cost of a soda from a vending machine versus the per soda cost from a twelve pack.&nbsp
column6: In the hotel vending machine, a single soda is $1.25 while the cost per can in the twelve pack - not on sale - came to about $.33.

column2: How much more expensive is it?&nbsp
column3: With twelve cans at that difference, how much would that be?&nbsp
column4: Most importantly, what else could you do with the money?&nbsp
column5: In Middle's case, it's about several comic books.

column1: Much of being a father - parent, actually - revolves around talking and finding ways to shrink the wider world down to a kid's viewpoint.
column2: There are days that it seems that all I do is talk, and there are days when I tell the kids that I'll get back to them once I figure out how to answer the question or discuss the issue.&nbsp
column3: And then, I have to make sure that I get back to it.

column1: But look for the moments and grab them when you can.
column2:
What they learn most about money and finances is going to come from you.

There's nothing exciting or sexy about it, but changing the bedsheets is one of the things that simply has to happen.
column2: And even though the kids are only sleeping, their bodies continue to slough off skin and sweat so that the bedding can become disgusting in short order.

column1: Understand first that there are different sizes of sheets depending on the size of the mattress.
column2: Since most households are a mix of bed sizes, one of the tasks is going to be keeping the various combinations separate so that you don't waste time putting the sheets on, just to find that&nbsp
column3: they don't&nbsp
column4: fit and have to be refolded.

column1: • Some families might opt to go with color coding, i.e. Junior gets the red shaded bedclothing and Juniorette gets the green shaded sheets.
<li>Some families - this included - have the sheets folded in the linen closet by size.&nbsp
column2: The twin bed clothing is always on the far right for example.
twin&quot
column3: size is the same as &quot
column4: single&quot
column5: .&nbsp
column6: The rest - Double, Queen, King - are straight forward.

column1: • If you're stuck, you can find the size on the tag attached to the sheet.
How Many Should I Keep and How Often Should I Change Them?
Most households have at least two sets of sheets per each bed, but for the younger kids, you might want to consider having a third set available in the event of illness.
column2: When a smaller child has a stomach virus or flu, you can easily blow through two sets of sheets in an evening
column3: they're going to be vomiting in the bed before they can make it to a bowl, even if you're at their side.&nbsp
column4: After cleaning the child, you have to get the sheets changed and you probably aren't going to have the 60+ minutes required to wash and dry a load of sheets.

column1: In our household, we had three cribsheets.
column2: It first appeared as overkill, but there were moments when we were grateful for them.

column1: As to changing, both my wife and I grew up in households where the bedsheets were changed weekly and we've stayed with that.
column2: With kids however, I do keep a closer eye on how things look and have changed them more often if necessary.&nbsp
column3: With toddlers, you have to contend with bed-wetting events and even when they go through&nbsp
column4: puberty, there&nbsp
column5: are more instances of pre-menstrual and menstrual spotting, excessive perspiration and nocturnal emissions.&nbsp
column6: Don't expect the kids to say anything - they might be embarrassed or simply don't care.

column1: Because kids are a stewpot of bodily juices - sometimes with the lid missing - you have to have a mattress pad under the sheets to help protect the mattress.
column2: You can wash sheets, but you can't wash a mattress, so you do what you can to protect it.&nbsp
column3: They're thicker and heavier, so you might find yourself taking it to the laundromat to throw into a larger machine if your machine isn't large enough.&nbsp
column4: How often you wash the mattress pads are open to debate, but again, I take the age of the kids into account and have also applied the smell test to see if they require washing.

column2: What you can do however, is periodically leave the bedclothing off so that it airs out
column3: some will also choose to spray it with a disinfectant spray to kill any germs.&nbsp
column4: If you do that however, leave the other bedclothing off for a short while to let it continue to air out.

One of the kids was incredibly recalcitrant this morning - argumentative, disrespectful and manipulative.
column2: &nbsp
column3: So I handled things.&nbsp
column4: But did I do enough and should I lay on further this evening?

column1: The child didn't like the clothing options since his favorites weren't yet washed.
column2: The poor behavior blossomed until he'd missed his opportunity for breakfast and I refused to take him to school
column3: he'd have to catch the bus like any other morning.&nbsp
column4: For those moments when he'd refuse to do something - put on left sock, put on right sock, put on left shoe, put on right shoe - I'd have to force the appropriate action by warning of the consequence if I had to count three on him.&nbsp
column5: I'd then count and each time I hit three, the consequence would go into effect.&nbsp
column6: In this case, the consequence was an additional fifteen minutes earlier bedtime.&nbsp
column7: As of this moment, he'll be lights out 75 minutes earlier than another typical night.

column1: The earlier bedtime is effective with this case since he enjoys the family time/sibling interaction.
column2: The days are warmer and longer and there's more opportunity for fun - tossing ball, riding scooter, the typical little kid stuff.&nbsp
column3: But this behavior has been ongoing for several weeks and I can't always tell what's going to trigger it.&nbsp
column4: Yes, if I know that something is a trigger for a child, I do try to avoid it since kids are not rational creatures and I don't believe in provocation.&nbsp

column2: One of the prime behavioral criteria in this house is that there are consequences for actions.&nbsp
column3: If this pattern of behavior has been on-going and I really want to drive a point home, do I purposefully suggest to Mom that she take the other kids for a treat while I stay home with the kid?&nbsp
column4: Taking the kids for a treat didn't occur to me until a few minutes after the bus left and honestly, the scenario arose as I was pondering how to really drive the point of consequences home.&nbsp
column5: But is it fair to hit the kid with a consequence that wasn't mentioned in the course of the original correction?&nbsp
column6: I wouldn't say that because he was bad, I was rewarding the other two while withholding
column7: instead, the approach would simply be that the others are going for a treat and since that would interfere with the earlier bedtime, he's home.

column1: Yes, it would be a pointed example.
column2:
But would it be fair?

Having a kid means having to change
column2: your expectations of what a family activity means.&nbsp
column3: A family activity will usually hark back to what you enjoyed before kids, but their presence will create more work for you and less enjoyment for the activity
column4: it can still be a good time but you have to alter your expectations of the event.

column1: My wife and I have lived in cities with minor league baseball teams - Richmond, Virginia (Braves), Winston-Salem, North Carolina (then Cubs) and Central Pennsylvania (Harrisburg Senators and Reading Phillies).
column2: Our experience is that the games are affordable and fun, and the beer is relatively cheap.&nbsp
column3: Or at least was cheap.
column4: And we began going again when our hometown gained a franchise four years ago.&nbsp
column5: But going to a game with small children isn't the same as without them.&nbsp
column6: Our first game with the kids was mixed.&nbsp
column7: We had great seats behind the visiting team dugout, but I spent most of my time with the younger ones in the play area.&nbsp
column8: The area sat in a raised portion of the venue so that you could overlook the field, but the presence of numbers of children meant that I spent almost of that time monitoring their location and behavior.&nbsp
column9: I left the game frustrated and annoyed, thinking that it was a waste of money and time, promising myself not to return.

column1: But we did return for several other games that season.
column2: More importantly, we returned with the kids and the experience improved.&nbsp
column3: As I chatted with my spouse, several things became clear about shared family activities.

column1: <li>The activity is how we teach the kids to behave and carry themselves in public settings with a wide variety of people.&nbsp
column2: If they spend all of their time at Chuck E. Cheese, they'll never know another level of behavior.

column1: • The activity is how we pass along our own interests and values, and provides a common ground for those later times when the relationship is strained.
• The activity provides you the opportunity to see how your child behaves in a public setting and provides some insight on what topics or issues you have to cover with them.
<li>The activity provides the child with an opportunity to see a part of you that they won't see in the home.&nbsp
column2: <em>Gee, Dad can explain how a knuckler is thrown?&nbsp
column3: He's not a complete idiot, after all.

column1: My wife and I spent the evening at a minor league game with six first grade boys and four teenagers.
column2: I monitored the playground, fetched food and drinks and maintained control of a few disciplinary issues.&nbsp
column3: And I even managed to see one of the home team's five runs being scored.&nbsp
column4: And all things considered, I enjoyed myself far more than sitting home nursing an attitude.&nbsp
column5: I just changed my expectations.

column1:
Now I have to adjust my expectation of what constitutes a cheap beer.

167,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Earlier in the week, I noted that one of the kids had major behavioral issues in the morning and I posed the question of whether I should apply an unexpected consequence that evening.
He'd been through significant corrections in the morning and would be in bed more than an hour earlier that evening.
column2: But I wondered whether I should take the other kids out for a treat after his early bedtime
column3: it wasn't planned before the behavioral collapse but would serve to highlight that he'd really missed something with his actions.

column1: So, did I apply the extra consequence that night?

column2: Had we already planned the treat before things fell apart, I would've happily taken the other kids.&nbsp
column3: But it seemed to be &quot
column4: piling on&quot
column5: the kid by making him sit out a good event when it was only planned to tweak his figurative nose.&nbsp
column6: Good discipline happens when you can help the child see the connection between behavior and consequence.&nbsp
column7: Kids are concrete and literal and many aren't good at extrapolating their actions into unseen consequences.&nbsp
column8: Indeed, my concern is that if I were to blindside the offending child, he would develop a fearful attitude about his actions.&nbsp
column9: If I don't do something exactly right, then God knows what will happen next.

column1: At 7:45, the offending child was safely in his bed and crying himself to sleep for missing family time.
column2:
I think that that was quite enough, thank you.

When you have kids, you begin to understand that your life really is no longer your own.
column2: You can still have some favorite activities or hobbies, but they have to be more tightly scheduled and some of them have to be curtailed.&nbsp
column3: Especially in terms of media - music, movies and television.&nbsp
column4: Kids are affected to one degree or another by what and how often they see something and you simply have to closely monitor what you enjoy.&nbsp
column5: An example would be my use of the mp3 player.

column1: I have a real fondness for the Pogues, especially their raucous Bottle of Smoke
column2: another favorite is Meat Loaf's Paradise by the Dashboard Lights.
column3: When I finally got an mp3 player, I was delighted that I could finally hear my own music and not have to worry what kids were in the vicinity.&nbsp
column4: But it's sunk in that even with the mp3, I have to curtail the music since the earbuds prevent me from hearing what else is going on in the household.&nbsp
column5: When you become more familiar with the kids and their habits and routines, you learn that the household has a tone and rhythm as alive as any music itself.&nbsp
column6: The kids have their own give-and-take and you can start to determine when things are moving out of sync.&nbsp
column7: The term &quot
column8: mother's intuition&quot
column9: is frequently used for knowing when something is amiss, but it can also be attributed to an increased awareness of how the kids act and interact.

column1: This was brought home the other day as I worked in the kitchen while the three were upstairs.
column2: I put the buds in but then removed them when I remembered that my spouse was gone.&nbsp
column3: And within a few minutes, I began to note a shriller tone to the play, one that I wouldn't have heard using the buds.&nbsp
column4: And yes, within a short while I was upstairs to intercede with the squabbling ones.

column1: So I now have another device that I'll use intermittently until the kids are gone.
column2:
And by then, I'll have to learn to use another platform and hope that I can still get Meat Loaf and the Pogues.

Kids are spending an average of six hours daily in front of the an electronic screen - PC, TV or game console.
column2: A timespan so long that&nbsp
column3: even I was surprised.

column1: And I don't surprise easily when it comes to kids.

In a June 2, 2009 JAMA news release, Dr. Victor Strasburger reported that the typical American kid spends an average of six hours daily in front of an electronic screen - either TV, PC or game console.
column2: It's at the point that two-thirds of all kids have their own television
column3: which gives credence to my kids' claims that they're in the minority when they have no TV sets in their rooms.

column1: Most are aware of the long-term concerns.
column2: Desensitivization towards violence, increasingly casual attitudes towards sex, greater obesity rates.&nbsp

column1: But are they aware of how hard it is to control the electronics?
column2: We have purposefully tried to limit the electronic exposure - no bedroom television sets, one family PC in family room, one DVD player in the basement - for the kids.&nbsp
column3: And even though I'm home, it's a constant struggle to keep tabs on who's doing which media and how long they've been doing it.&nbsp
column4: It's seductive and seemingly addictive.

column1: <li>With the summer months, there are no electronics before noon.&nbsp
column2: No television, no computer games and no handheld games.&nbsp
column3: And yes, I have to periodically prowl the house to verify that it's being upheld since children tend to &quot
column4: forget&quot

column1: <li>Try to enforce a two hour electronics limit in the course of a day.&nbsp
column2: That means that I have to sometimes appear like a member of the Gestapo, forcing the kids off the device when that time limit is up.

column1: • Actually kick the kids out of the house so that they're in the outdoors or simply tell them to read or go listen to music.
<li>Sitting down with the kids and the television section each morning to teach them how to use the schedule.&nbsp
column2: The oldest two know, but are simply used to flipping on the box and switching around.

column1: <li>Helping the kids work out how they want to divide their screen time.&nbsp
column2: All TV for a good movie?&nbsp
column3: Nothing on the box, so a Wii tournament?&nbsp
column4: Even if it sounds overly controlling to an adult, the large majority of kids do not instinctively know how to make these distinctions so the process has to modelled for them.

column1: • Perhaps create a grid showing the date and each kid's name with the start and end time for each electronic activity?
That last proposal is probably too impractical, but the real nut is probably in the second proposal.
column2: The kids get their cues from us, and if they see us come home and collapse after a meal in front of the television, they'll take it to heart that that's how things happen.&nbsp
column3: You take to the brain candy to escape from the daily grind of living.

column1:
So perhaps while I sit with the kids to review the schedule, I can also demonstrate that I'm likewise planning the time available to its best electronic use.

Kids love a good vacation or special event as much as anyone else, but most don't have the capacity to handle the pace and change unless they know what coming.
column2: So that means that you have to spend time in advance - sometimes weeks in advance - telling them what's coming up.&nbsp
column3: What complicates things tremendously is that children typically have a limited attention span or don't really understand unless it's presented very clearly and plainly.

column1: I Should Start How Long In Advance?
Yeah, give them as much notice - weeks or months - as you possibly can.
column2: Special events aren't the same as grocery shopping, and there's no real reason - apart from a purposeful surprise - to keep it from them.&nbsp
column3: This is especially important when the event is one that an unprepared child can seriously disrupt.&nbsp
column4: So take the available window to work with them and help them build the foundation for a successful outing.&nbsp
column5: Since kids deal best with information presented in smaller bites, you can expect to have to use that time to go back to the same well again and again.

column1: Preparing the Kids Is Like Building A House
Knowing that you have a window of time to prepare them -
column2: and that they don't usually handle large information doses well at one time - handle&nbsp
column3: it like building a house.&nbsp
column4: The foundation is the most basic and broad information presented over several days and when they show that they've got it down, move onwards to more specific items presented on multiple occasions.

column1: For example, let's say that Uncle Dirk is getting married.
column2: Start with the most basic items, like <em>do you remember your Uncle Dirk?&nbsp
column3: When Junior demonstrates that he has a clue of Uncle Dirk's identity, then you can move on to other items:

column1: <li>What does it mean when a man and woman are married?&nbsp
<li>What if Uncle Dirk is marrying another man?&nbsp
column2: This isn't meant as a joke remark since small children are seeing this.&nbsp
column3: I've already had to explain the situation to a young child and it can truly complicate your previous conversations with the child.

column1: <li>Where will it be and will we have to travel?&nbsp
column2: Will we stay in a hotel?

column1: <li>Who else is going to be there?&nbsp
column2: Will there be any other kids there?
How will you deal with misbehavior?

column1: And kids will have all manner of other questions about the situation.
Another aspect to new situations is that kids tend to be concrete thinkers.
column2: If a kid thinks that he's going someplace fun, he probably won't handle it well if other twists are thrown into the events of the day.&nbsp
column3: <em>Dammit, Daddy, you said we were going to the beach - why are we at the Kmart now?&nbsp
column4: He isn't going to register that you're buying water wings for him and the resulting snit will only create some resentment at the outset of what should be a fun event.

column2: People can wonder why the kids don't want to participate in after-dinner conversations, but if the kids haven't had the opportunity to participate in those talks when they were younger, then they won't care to when they're older.&nbsp
column3: And when they are younger, the conversations will be short or might veer into talk about Barney the Purple Dinosaur, but they are cumulative.&nbsp
column4: Be patient.

column1: So when you learn of something new on the horizon, think about how to present it and what you can do to make it a good event for the child as well as the other adults in contact.
column2: He really does want to please you.

column1: Almost any parent with a child, especially a pubescent 'tweener, can relate to the comment from an acquaintance many years ago.
column2: This woman had two kids, one of whom was in middle school while the other was in fifth grade, and they could seriously tick her off through any number of means.&nbsp
column3: She related that she'd try to speak with one of them and would be met with enough disrespect and argument that her hand would just reach over and slap the child.

column1: If you really believe that you don't want to do this, what are your options when you're seriously torqued with the kid?
column2: Because believe me, you will get to that point.
I'm fairly old-fashioned in that there are moments when I'm the father and I don't have to provide a reason.&nbsp
column3: Yes, I believe deeply in communicating with the kids, but there have been times when they don't deserve a reason apart from my approach to the PsychoDad realm.&nbsp
column4: You should later speak to them and follow-up on the situation, but the moment doesn't necessarily require an answer since they aren't your equals.

column1: <li>Simply put your hands in your pockets when you have to speak with them.&nbsp
column2: My kids have come to understand that when I speak with them in a certain tone and my hands are in my pockets, then I'm really fighting the urge to give them a &quot
column3: dope slap&quot
column4: across the back of the head.

column2: for a few minutes, assuming that the kids are old enough to manage themselves without self-immolation.&nbsp
column3: Take that time to get yourself together and then head back to the combat zone.

column2: Understand that these are strategies to handle your own anger and to minimize hitting.&nbsp
column3: But this shouldn't be confused with corporal punishment since corporal punishment - if to be used properly - is not done on the spur of the moment but only with sufficient detachment.&nbsp

So how can you maintain discipline with the kids while you're on vacation?
You're typically going to feel constrained because you're in a public area and the usual measures - loss of toys or privileges, room confinement, corporal punishment, whatever - aren't available.
column2: What can you do to maintain order?

column1: First, remember that while you're on vacation, you probably need to exercise even greater patience than at home.
column2: If you're travelling, the bedtimes are probably shot to hell and the activity has the motors revved to the point of burnout
column3: the kids are going to be more tired than usual and their ability to control themselves is going to suffer.&nbsp

column1: Bearing that in mind, you might consider a three count warning with the punishment being a one minute timeout - or longer if the kid's older - at the front of the park on arrival.

column2: Simply put, you're putting the kid on notice and providing them with an opportunity to control themselves before the third count causes the correction.&nbsp
column3: How does it work?&nbsp
column4: When you go somewhere, tell the child up front that when you find them misbehaving, you'll start to count to three.&nbsp
column5: When the child hears 'one', it's the signal that he needs to stop.&nbsp
column6: If he doesn't, then you'll count 'two'.&nbsp
column7: If the child hasn't stopped after the 'two' count, then you'll count 'three' and the correction will occur.&nbsp

column1: We've used the count system for years and it does work.
column2: The beauty with the timeout on entering the vacation spot is that the first several minutes there are typically spent orienting yourselves
column3: the child can sit in a timeout at a specified spot while you figure things out, and then you can move on to the first activity with the correction out of the way.&nbsp
column4: And the kid has learned that there is a consequence without realizing that he'd probably be hanging out at the same spot anyway.

column1: So the correction is immediate, consistent and enforceable.
column2: It might not work on all occasions&nbsp
column3:
but it can take care of a number of them.
