When you take the kids out for summer vacations, they'll look for the fun stuff but you have to pay attention to them.
column2: The combination of heat, humidity and activity can be a major problem for children.

column1: We recently took the first trip to Orlando with the three kids and this became apparent as we waited in a slow line for a Universal Theme park ride.
column2: Further ahead, a teenage girl leaned against a wall and then proceeded to slowly go limp.&nbsp
column3: Her father began talking to her as he supported her by the shoulder but her head suddenly lapsed into her chest and the support became an urgent effort to control the fall as she went into a heap.&nbsp
column4: Someone produced a cold bottle of Gatorade and the parents finally managed to induce her to sip the liquid
column5: after several minutes - during which&nbsp
column6: no park personnel were present - she was able to stand and leave the line, hopefully for an air-conditioned spot.&nbsp
column7: My mate is a physician who assisted and I could only feel for the father as I watched my own three.

column1: And I already pay considerable attention to how they're doing.
Children - especially smaller ones - are more susceptible to heat-related problems than
column2: adults.&nbsp
column3: This is partially due to differences between the child's and the adult's body.&nbsp
column4: Another part, however, is that kids are simply too caught up in the activity to pay attention to their body's needs.&nbsp
column5: They don't think in&nbsp
column6: terms of rehydration
column7: they think in terms of a sudden awareness of thirst or nausea arising from dehydration.&nbsp
column8: And by then, it's already on the verge of too late.

column1: So what should you consider as you prepare to take the kids for those summer days of family outings?

column2: Not soda, juice or milk - water.&nbsp
column3: While the others contain water, the body does best with clear and colorless liquid that contain no additives to process.&nbsp
column4: If you have a baby less than nine months,&nbsp
column5: you&nbsp
column6: can even consider whether&nbsp
column7: to give&nbsp
column8: it water in&nbsp
column12: But seriously ask yourself if it's in the best interests of the infant to be out in mid-day heat.

column1: <li>If you aren't certain when to give the child water, use yourself as a guide.&nbsp
column2: Remember that thirst is a sign that you're already becoming dehydrated, so make it a point of pacing yourself with regular water intake.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: And when you do drink, be sure that your child also drinks
column5: kids are notoriously proud and drinking with you will go over better than Know-it-all Dad forcing the kid to do something utterly uncool as drinking because they need it.&nbsp
column6: The typical kid under twelve years of age should have an average of six cups of water daily so be sure to use that as a baseline and increase it with the heat and activity.&nbsp

column1: <li>When you change a diaper - or take&nbsp
column2: a smaller child to the bathroom - pay attention to the color of the urine.&nbsp
column3: A lighter color urine is preferred since darker urine indicates that the urine is more concentrated and thus demonstrating dehydration.

column1: <li>Like everybody else, kids should wear lighter-weight and -colored clothing to reflect the heat.&nbsp
column2: It should also be looser fitting, so those pretty tights on your little girl&nbsp
column3: are a bad idea.

column1: <li>Take an additional set of clothing to replace the sweaty clothing later in the day.&nbsp
column2: Children are more susceptible than adults to heat changes and a child wearing a sweaty/damp outfit will feel the chill more as the day's temperature decreases later on.

column1: • Kids should also wear hats to provide some protection from UV rays on the nose and forehead.
<li>Any stroller should have a shade to protect the child.&nbsp
column2: If you think that your kid needs something additional, I've known some parents to carry a collapsible umbrella in the tote bag should the kid need additional protection.

column1: <li>Hot, humid weather wouldn't be the best time to use a snuggli or other close body device.&nbsp
column2: The nearness of the small body is uncomfortable for both of you and could even drive up the child's body temperature further.

column1: • Keep a good supply of diapers and wipes for more frequent changes, to forestall an increased risk of diaper rash and discomfort.
<li>Be liberal in using a diaper rash ointment - A&amp
column2: D for example - to protect the child's bottom from chafing or rash.

column1: <li>A child's skin is more sensitive than an adult's toughened skin.&nbsp
column2: This means that before you depart for the day, apply a base coat of sunscreen and then reapply as the day progresses.&nbsp
column3: The back of any bottle will provide guidance on how often to reapply.

column1: <li>The peak of the sun's effects on skin are from 10 AM to 2 PM.&nbsp
column2: If possible, plan to spend some of that time inside.&nbsp
column3: For example, we planned to spend the bulk of that time in Orlando&nbsp
column4: inside, in&nbsp
column5: covered shows or eating lunch.

column1: <li>Understand that your child is more likely to crap out earlier than he would otherwise and will later require more and/or longer naps.&nbsp
column2: This is typically accompanied by a cranky tantrum as the kid melts through the last of the energy reserves.&nbsp
column3: It isn't because he chooses to be nasty, but is instead finally overwhelmed and is no longer capable of providing self-control.&nbsp

column1: If this seems like a lot to
column2: remember, then understand that one of your primary jobs as a father is to protect them so that they can enjoy these things.&nbsp
column3:
And as they age, you can teach them so that they can pass it along to their own children.

As the kids age and take a larger role in the world, they're going to come across things called contracts.
column2: And it's crucial that you take a few moments to review the contracts with the kids so that they learn to do it in the future.&nbsp

column1: I'm a purist by nature and professional training.
column2: I've written contracts, reviewed them, altered them and signed them.&nbsp
column3: My previous career was in the insurance industry and I memorized the quote what the big print giveth, the small print taketh away.
column4: So I read every contract that I sign and I admit to amusement when a clerk doesn't know what to say when I alter a standard contract.&nbsp
column5: Trust me, the typical place will cave when you walk to the door with your money.

column2: And while we don't expect minors to understand business law, they should have a basic enough understanding to know that they have to read them.&nbsp
column3: We live in a period of economic mayhem, when thousands are losing their homes because they were locked into mortgage products that made no sense.&nbsp
column4: And some have proffered the response that they couldn't be expected to read the documentation.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: Unfortunately, that response isn't forestalling the loss of their homes.

column1: Eldest is working as a volunteer this summer and part of the preliminary packet was a confidentiality agreement.
column2: I became aware of it when she asked me to sign it as the parent witness.&nbsp
column3: Before finalizing it, I asked her to explain her understanding of what it meant and was pleased that she covered the bases well.&nbsp
column4: I also impressed upon her the fact that as a minor, her screw-up wouldn't lead to civil litigation against her, but me instead.&nbsp

column1: Parents will have different takes on handling the situation, but here's what I do:
• Assure that both you and they have read the contract.
<li>Ask them for their understanding of what the contract means.&nbsp
column2: Don't assume that you've both understood it the same way.
what if&quot
column3: situation question, or just provide some examples of a situation that might arise under the contract.

column1: <li>Not only give them a situation or two, but help them frame an appropriate response.&nbsp
column2: In our situation, don't assume that someone has a right to know by virtue of being in the office, but refer the person to an adult employee that you know.&nbsp
column3: Then dummy up.

column1: • Discuss the consequences of failing to honor the contract.
And remember that when they're with you and you are presented with a contract, you take the time necessary to read it.
column2: They'll learn to&nbsp
column3:
do that when they see you do it as well.

Next week is the fifteenth anniversary of my resignation from work to stay home with the kids.
column2: And I've been asking myself the question, what do I wish that I'd known then?
column3: And the first answer is:&nbsp
column4: time.

column1: Adults live in a world that is typically regimented in terms of time.
column2: There are work deadlines and due dates for bills.&nbsp
column3: Many usually have one or more favorite activities that fill in the unused blocks.&nbsp
column4: We fit in a trip to the gym for&nbsp
column5: a workout before work or between work and dinner.&nbsp
column6: We arrange for a weekend away with the mate or schedule a regular poker night with the buddies.&nbsp
column7: And there are constant complaints about the lack of time and the constant rush to be somewhere or do something.

column1: But kids are born with no innate sense of time.
column2: Their awareness of time is something that is absorbed from the parents&nbsp
column3: and they will frequently later take on the habits and attitudes of their folks.&nbsp
column4: But when they're first born, they have no need to be somewhere and the only activities are the ones that the parents schedule for them.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp

column1: What kids are born with is an extreme egocentrism.
column2: Initially, it's necessary since a baby simply cannot take care of itself, but as the child grows and becomes aware, the egocentrism reigns supreme until he or she learns to consider others.&nbsp
column3: And until this starts to develop, you have to understand that your life is no longer your own.
column4: You do need to find time for yourself to maintain some sanity, but your child isn't going to care whether you were able to make the gym or have the poker night.&nbsp
column5: And the reality is that with the new requirements of parent- and fatherhood, you aren't going to have time available for them.&nbsp

column1: One of my major challenges over the years has been to find a balance between schedule and flexibility, especially when the kids are very young.
column2: I have to make the doctor and dentist appointments work within the construct of their daily needs - feedings and naps - but what can be jettisoned if they're in a growth spurt and need the additional sleep?&nbsp
column3: How do I&nbsp
column4: reapportion the daily task load when she's teething and especially needs hands-on attention while I should be making dinner?&nbsp
column5: What has to go away to make time for coaching the soccer team or leading the scout den?&nbsp
column6: How do I function when I've gotten four hours sleep from caring for a kid with a g-i virus?

column1: The irony is that while kids have no concept of time, time is what they require most.
column2: You don't have to give them a new toy a week to maintain their interest and you don't have to sit them in front of the television or computer to occupy them.&nbsp
column3: What you do need to do is spend concentrated time with them.&nbsp
column4: Take them for walks or to the park, play games with them and read to them, and talk to them.
column5: The child isn't going to be terribly aware of what he doesn't have until he's taking in more television and spending more time with other kids.&nbsp
column6: And if you give him the time that he requires for his development - and no, there's not a hard and fast number - then he really isn't going to give a damn that somebody has more Bakugon cards.

column1: So don't get terribly frustrated when it seems like there's no time.
column2: There is time and God willing, there will be time again when they're older.&nbsp
column3: But accept that what you considered to be timely - in terms of activity and time spent - is going to change for the next number of years.&nbsp
column4: And try to enjoy them.&nbsp
column5:
As someone once wrote to me, I miss those days.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column2: With fifteen years of full-time caregiving under my belt, I've learned that I've had to alter my concept of time and timeliness.&nbsp
column3: But I also wish that I'd understood that patience really is critically important.
column4: Patience with my&nbsp
column5: kids, my mate and myself.&nbsp

column1: I've always been categorized as an easy-going person.
column2: Before my marriage, my father-in-law asked his daughter whether I really was this laidback or if was just a display for the family.&nbsp
column3: Nope, he's usually like that was her response.
column4: And this continued through years of marriage and moving, despite some occasional lapses.&nbsp
column5: It even continued through the years with only one child.&nbsp

column1: But there came a point with the arrival of Middle - Eldest was a toddler - that the patience started to break.
column2: The baby took all of the attention that babies take, especially when they don't sleep at night.&nbsp
column3: And there were nights that I swore that I'd never sleep again.&nbsp
column4: And Eldest the Toddler had her own set of needs as she processed the change in her life.&nbsp
column5: Middle cried and got the attention, and when Middle napped in the afternoon, Dad grabbed naps in the La-Z-Boy while she watched Disney to a soundtrack of paternal snoring.&nbsp

column1: Eldest really was - and still is - a wonderful kid, but she had her own set of toddler issues.
column2: Reaches for independence versus the need to feel protected.&nbsp
column3: Processing the usual new sibling feelings of love and competition.&nbsp
column4: And the almost universal egocentrism that afflicts all children until they hopefully outgrow it.&nbsp
column5: Or at least learn how to bring it under control.&nbsp
column6: And with the arrival of youngest, the circus took on a whole new dimension as Middle experienced the same general feelings for the first time and Eldest experienced them again&nbsp
column7: from a different age with it's own perspective.&nbsp

column1: Change requires adjustment and sometimes adjustment is a bit difficult, even if it's good.
And in the midst of it, I sometimes forgot that little kids can't always control these things because they're kids.
column2: They aren't &quot
column3: little people&quot
column4: with the implication that they're just smaller versions of adults.&nbsp
column5: They are children having to grapple with issues that are far newer to them than to a thirty or forty-something adult, but without the ability to express themselves.&nbsp
column6: So when they encounter new situations, they respond with what they know.&nbsp
column7: Children are wonderful and deserve protection, good families and good parents but you have to understand that they are still children.&nbsp
column8: And that means that when they're little, they frequently can't control what they do.&nbsp

column1: More men are taking a larger role in the family life - by choice or necessity - and this really is a break from previous American generations.
column2: But this is new territory for the mothers as well as the fathers.&nbsp
now have to work to help support the family as much as the men.&nbsp
column3: And before this, they were sold the idea that they could successfully manage both a career and motherhood.&nbsp
column4: But they weren't shown the cost that comes with such juggling.&nbsp
column5: Employers that expect loyalty yet frequently don't return it.&nbsp
column6: A grudging acquiescence to the demands of parenthood when kids get sick or encounter difficulties.&nbsp
column7: The need to produce in order to compete with other families trying to support themselves.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column10: My brother-in-law once remarked that women are starting to realize there's perhaps a reason that American men die years earlier their spouses.&nbsp

column1: So women are now finding that they aren't there for the special moments that their mothers and grandmothers experienced.
column2: Instead, these moments are seen by the fathers or others and they must get the news later.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: The arena that they usually learned would be their purview - the home - would instead be managed by the father.&nbsp
column5: This last is probably most frustrating since the reality is that the really, really large number of guys never grow up learning what it takes to run a household.
column6: She's left trying to teach the right way and at the same time, un-do the wrong way that something's been done.&nbsp

column2: When my mate was fifteen, she was reaching under the bed to clean.&nbsp
column3: When I was fifteen, I was reaching under the bed to reach the stash of Playboy magazines.

column1: So this process of ceding the control of the household isn't easy for the women.
column2: Change and adjustment.

column1: Most men don't ever think that they're going to be spending a huge amount of time with the kids.
column2: And like me, they're unprepared for what's coming at them.
Kids don't think.&nbsp
column3: Kids are walking, breathing blank slates that you can never assume actually know how to do anything on their own.
column4: Some can figure things out on their own, but it's not safe to think that they actually will.&nbsp
column5: And a child can, in almost an instant, shift from screaming banshee to the child that you once again would die for.&nbsp

column1: And an increasing number of children isn't additive, it's exponential.
column2: They will react to their surroundings and one another and do so in ways that make perfect sense to a child.&nbsp
column3: But it's been at least two decades since I was a child, so forgive me if I forgot the thought process.

column1: The result is that I felt for years as though I was living in a real-life pinball game and because nobody ever really told me about the reality, I didn't understand that these things were part and parcel of heavy involvement with children.

column2: You are probably doing more with your kid than your old man did with you and in the great majority of cases, the fact that you're doing it will mean all of the difference in the world to your kid.&nbsp
column3: With a divorce rate of about 50% for the past twenty years, a fair number of men have no real experience of hands-on fathers and are doing their damnedest by feel, thought and intuition.

column1: You will get frustrated and you will get angry.
column2: You will probably wonder whether they're ever going to pull things together or whether you're a failure as a father.&nbsp
column3: Kids&nbsp
column4: will pull themselves together and your constant conversations will register with them and crop up later at the most unlikely moments.
column5: And you will find those moments when everything comes together and renews you for the next round of childishness.

column1: But one of the differences between you and your child is what you remember to do with the anger and frustration.
column2: You're the adult.

177,"1","1",,"xhtml","

At what point do the kids learn to do something as requested - without having to have you ride herd on them?

column2: A close friend was impressed when her mid-teen son began replacing the toilet paper rolls when he found them empty.&nbsp
column3: But what can be done to help the process along without spending all of your time yelling?&nbsp
column4: Because failing to listen is one of the key factors in causing parents to lose their temper.

column1: It continues to be a struggle in this household, although there are lights at the end of one of the tunnels.
column2: There are several things that I routinely do and something new that's being tried.

column1: <li>Have the child turn off and put down any handheld devices, as well as turn away from the television.&nbsp
column2: Depending on the circumstances, I'll sometimes stand so that the kid has to fully turn away from the TV and is unable to gain a side-glance.

column1: <li>With a smaller child, get directly within about a foot of his face and speak slowly and clearly.&nbsp
column2: We have a finger-to-nose signal that means focus on me.

column1: <li>Have the child repeat the directions so that anything misunderstood can be corrected.&nbsp
column2: And even then, it can be hit-or-miss.

column1: • Have the child come to a separate room that is free of games/electronics/toys in order to get the instructions.
<li>I've begun putting the burden of carrying out the correct instructions back onto the kid.&nbsp
column2: This means that when I find that something's been done totally half-assed, I'll call the kid in and have them do it again.&nbsp
column3: When kids get to be older, they resent having you looking over their shoulder
column4: the resulting attitude creates even more issues and there have been moments when I'm so out of patience that I simply correct the situation myself.&nbsp
column5: Now, the kid will be called back and have the directions reiterated.&nbsp
column6: I then leave the kid to their job and will return to check it.&nbsp
column7: The kid should learn that if he wants to be left alone, he had better pay attention and get it right the first time.

column2: This approach obviously won't work on brand new chores or situations with which they have no&nbsp
column3: experience, but it should work and cut down on the I'll just do something close so that I'm done and can move on without the old man nagging.

column2: And until then, I'll keep with the other approaches and try not to blow a gasket.

column1:
178,"1","1",,"xhtml","

After illness, family guests and then an out-of-town trip with the eldest and other teens, I'm back.
column2: I regret if anyone has come here looking for new articles and I'll have to take to heart the mantra of publish, publish, publish.

column1: A large part of being a father is teaching.
column2: Not esoteric stuff, but the daily minutiae that keeps you out of trouble.&nbsp
column3: And a trip with kids is loaded with opportunities to teach if you pay attention.

column1: • Why you hold your credit card face down when transacting business.
• Determining an appropriate level of tipping for a service rendered.
• Checking the store receipt when using a credit card to assure that the number and termination date isn't on the slip.
• Watching how people respond to new and/or frustrating situations.
<li>Why an education truly matters - in this instance, walking with your daughter&nbsp
column2: past&nbsp
column3: the Hustler&nbsp
column4: Club on New Orleans' Bourbon Street.&nbsp

column1: • How to hail a cab and how to make small-talk.
• How to respond to people who are trying to make polite conversation with you.
• How to register a complaint and have a charge removed for poor service.
The opportunities are there and my kids fully expect that I'll call them over at any time to show them something.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1:
179,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Kids love birthday parties. Usually. But if there's an invitation and the child doesn't want to attend, should I push the issue and require attendance?

On the one hand, nobody likes the idea of a child's birthday party with everybody skipping. The thought of a heartbroken child with no friends drives an impulse to require attendance as parents think there but for the grace of God, goes my child.
column2: There are children who are simply unpopular for no particular reason and it shows in the order in which they're picked for sports teams, or by the chronic name-calling that accompanies their schooldays.&nbsp
column3: Kids are cruel.&nbsp
column4: It's this same impulse that drives well-meaning parents to press the kids to befriend someone who appears to not have any friends.&nbsp
column5: We talk to the invited kids and try to get them to see the other viewpoint:&nbsp
column6: how would you feel if...

column1: But if the cruel kid is the one extending the invitation, then it's entirely reasonable that your child is resisting.
column2: And the trick is in figuring out why the child doesn't want to go.

column1: We've been burned by the willingness to extend sympathy.
column2: One of our children came home from the first day of second grade and as we talked about who was in his class, he spoke about how everybody disliked one child whom he described as a &quot
column3: chunky chinese bully&quot
column4: .&nbsp
column5: Both my wife and I talked to our son about this comment, reminding him that perhaps the boy&nbsp
column6: was acting out because&nbsp
column7: of the weight and also being the only Asian child in the class.&nbsp
column8: To his credit, he took our advice to try and be a friend
column9: the unfortunate reality was that our son was correct and in the rush to extend sympathy, we found that the descriptive term bully was entirely correct.
column10: This child took over a large part of our son's school year and my wife and I had multiple conversations with his parents as well as the teacher and principal.&nbsp
column11: Yes, my son was entirely correct in his assessment.

column2: So when Youngest received an invitation earlier this year and resisted attending, I had a better clue of how to approach it.&nbsp
column3: This particular child had a reputation of anger management issues and when I pressed my son, found that he had on multiple occasions taken swings at Youngest.&nbsp
column4: He had frankly taken swings at just about everybody in the class.&nbsp
column5: And when I looked again at the invitation from the boy's parents, my heart dropped at what they'd written.&nbsp
column6: They were aware that there was liable to be no one attending and had pushed the presence of pizza, games and ice cream as added incentive to attend.&nbsp
column7: Mind that these are typical fare at birthday parties and I've never before seen them touted.

column1: So if there's resistance to the invitation, consider these factors.
<li>Is this a name that you've heard before and if so, in what context?&nbsp
column2: That means when you talk with your child about school, ask who they played with and take note of what names are cropping up.&nbsp
column3: If the kid has raked your child's face with a stapler, then you don't want anything to do with it.

column1: <li>Simply ask why she doesn't want to attend.&nbsp
column2: Vague descriptive terms like weird, nerd or geek with no other rationale can be the jumping off point for discussions about sympathy and extending a friendly hand.
column3: Terms like bully, rough, cheater are words that have clear meanings even for small children and are worth some respect.

column2: If it appears to be overkill - as happened in my case - then the parents are unwittingly signalling their worries.

column1: <li>Listen to what your child is saying to other kids in your presence.&nbsp
column2: That's why I love driving kids places:&nbsp
column3: I become wallpaper and absorb everything that they say as they forget I'm there.

column1: And remember that when you get answers to your questions, you'll probably have to dig further and deeper.
column2: But the digging is worth it if it helps you understand the rationale behind the resistance.

If there's ever a key month for families, it's August.
column2: The summer vacation is in its last legs and there are any number of things to consider besides the newspaper ads touting the latest back-to-school sales.

column1: For a PracticalDad, there are a variety of things to do in the remaining weeks before school.
• Inventory the kids' clothing to see what's now outgrown and what's in the pipeline from other kids and families.
• Inventory the school supplies in-house to ascertain what sales aren't only great, but needed.
• Start to create a master family calendar for the upcoming year, comprising important dates and known activities.
• Begin working with the younger kids on reviewing academic skills that have rusted - to be kind - since the end of school.
• Begin preparing the kids for new classes and teachers, especially if they're just entering school or entering a new school, such as middle school.
• Note the time requirements for older kids who are involved in activities that commence practices in August, such as sports and band.
<li>Schedule doctor and dental appointments so that school forms are completed and ready to be turned in.&nbsp
column2: Also schedule teeth cleanings so that you don't have to pull the kids from classes.
Even if that appears to be a long list, it's still an opportunity to enjoy some time before things really start moving in September.

When your child first goes away for any period of time - overnight, a weekend or a week - you can expect the I'm homesick, I really miss you call.
column2: It's wonderful if you don't, but it's also okay if you do.&nbsp
column3: The fact that your kid is homesick and misses her environment and family is entirely natural.

column1: But how can you handle it if you do receive such a call?
column2: Here are some things to bear in mind.

column1: <li>Keep tabs on your patience and level of annoyance.&nbsp
column2: Even if it's a simple overnight at a friend's house, the feelings of fear and anxiety can be disproportionate and letting your impatience get the better of you can be damaging.

column1: <li>To what extent is your child homesick?&nbsp
column2: Ask about how she's feeling physically
column3: homesickness can cover a range of responses from crying jags to withdrawal to legitimate physical symptoms such as headache and nausea.&nbsp
column4: If you can't get a solid answer then ask to speak with her counselor or adult chaperone for answers.

column2: Is this the first night away or have you finally been called because this has gone on persistently and isn't abating?&nbsp
column3: While you want your child to work through it - and most do - there is a point of diminishing return and you do have to consider whether greater harm is being done by her staying there.

column1: <li>Some kids, especially if they're older, can be embarrassed by their reaction.&nbsp
column2: Reassure them that it's natural and that it will pass.&nbsp
column3: When my middle child called while homesick, I shared stories about how I'd been in similar straits and what the end results were.

column2: Kids deal in feelings and emotions and the reasoning side typically doesn't come until later.&nbsp
column3: Ask what she's done and then see what comes out, and you'll probably hear something positive that can encourage her to see that the time away isn't a complete disaster.

column1: <li>If the child is persistent in wanting to come home, speak with her and then ask to speak with her counselor or adult leader.&nbsp
column2: There are options available, such as pairing the child with another counselor
column3: in this case, the counselor might make progress by enlisting her help with duties and even leading some simple activities.&nbsp
column4: Make sure that the counselor knows to contact you separately to update you on the situation and whether it really is in the best interests to terminate the stay.

column1: <li>Let both the child and counselor and child know that it's alright to contact you if necessary, but don't volunteer to call the child regularly.&nbsp
column2: Let the staff or other chaperones do their job.

column1: <li>If the situation continues and you do have to take your child home, keep rein on yourself and don't berate or embarrass her.&nbsp
column2: She'll be embarrassed enough and your response will only make a volatile situation worse.&nbsp
column3: Perhaps take the tack that if it didn't work out this time, there are other times in the future.&nbsp
column4: If it's a persistent situation, then you might want to consider speaking with a counselor about what can be done to help her adjust.

column1: Most kids suffer homesickness to some extent - I certainly did - and will pull through.
column2:
Just be sure to thank those adults or counselors who helped since they earned their money.

One of the key times for clothing inventory is August, when the Fall wear comes in and hits the racks.
column2: And with money tight, this is the time to work through the clothing to see what's really needed.
column3: This includes what's in the closet and drawers, as well as any clothing that is tucked away from friends and older siblings.

column2: How do you handle the job, especially if you have more than one kid in the mix?

column1: <li>Start the process with the youngest child.&nbsp
column2: As clothing is shifted down the range from old-to-young/large-to-small, starting with the eldest means that hand-me-downs will sit at the next level until those drawers are cleared.&nbsp
column3: Starting with the youngest means that that space is already cleared for the additions.

column1: <li>When you begin with each child, make sure that as much of the clothing is out of the hamper and away as possible.&nbsp
column2: This assures that the inventory is complete as possible and that you don't wind up buying three more pairs of jeans because three were in the washer when you did the job.

column1: <li>Verify what size clothing the kid is presently wearing.&nbsp
column2: While different brands of clothing can vary when they're supposedly the same size, it's unlikely that if Junior is solidly in size 8, he's going to fit into a size 6 from another manufacturer.&nbsp
column3: Knowing that, you can start by removing the now-small sizes.&nbsp
column4: That&nbsp
column5: clothing can go into whatever pile is necessary, whether for another family&nbsp
column6: or charity.

column1: <li>Sort types of clothing - long-sleeve shirts, pants, etc. -&nbsp
column2: into separate piles.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: Junior doesn't have to&nbsp
column5: try everything on, but select one or two from each pile for a try-on and then use these as&nbsp
column6: templates for sizing up the remaining items.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp

column2: Junior has tried the&nbsp
column3: sizing clothes on, you can lay them&nbsp
column4: out on the bed and use them as a&nbsp
column5: template for the other items.&nbsp
column6: This can&nbsp
column7: account for most&nbsp
column8: of the clothing except for the items that might require&nbsp
column9: Junior's efforts, particularly in regards to the waist size.

column1: <li>Remember that this is not going to be an exact process.&nbsp
column2: Kids don't grow at constant rates and you can't know when something is suddenly necessary.&nbsp
column3: Consequently, don't bag things that are a little big, such as pants that are longer than would be acceptable on a thirty year-old Dad.&nbsp
column4: Junior's liable to fill it faster than you expect.&nbsp
column5: I know of kids who grew two inches in the course of a month.

column2: sized and sorted, the old&nbsp
column3: clothing can be moved to the next spot and the&nbsp
column4: usable clothing can be stored away&nbsp
column5: until it's time for use.&nbsp
column6: Then you&nbsp
column7: note what you&nbsp
column8: actually need and&nbsp
column9: take care of procuring what's necessary.&nbsp

column1: <li>You want to consider where you're going to keep the usable fall/winter clothing until it's needed.&nbsp
column2: You might not have the closet or drawer space with the summer clothing in use, but make sure that the box or bag is clearly labeled and accessible when the time comes.

column1: This process continues up the age range until the work is process is complete.
column2: You can then maximize your time by shopping for several kids instead of wasting gas, time and money by making multiple trips for individual kids.

column1:
It can appear daunting - especially with multiple kids - but the time spent now is more than worth the time and money later.

The more time that you spend around kids, the more time that you'll spend around other people's kids.
column2: I typically refer to this brand of child as Opie K (OPK), or just Opie.
column3: This raises the issue of how you'll respond when&nbsp
column4: Opie states that in his house, he's allowed to:

column1: <li>play Grand Theft Auto at the age of seven
• raise holy hell until the cows come home.
And the first three are not theoretical examples, but have happened to me within the past nine months.
Do you want to be the nice guy who wants his child to get along with the other kids?
column2: Or do you want to maintain some standards in the face of child protest?

column1: I've persistently chosen the latter, and for the following reasons.

column2: When many younger kids find out that something they want is verboten, they'll flat out lie in the hope that you'll back down when you see that everybody does it and you're really out of touch, so if you don't want to mess with my daddy, you'll let me continue.
column3: The problems with this are that first, the other Daddy might completely agree with you and second, it's not that kid's house.&nbsp
column4: It's yours.&nbsp
column5: And constantly bending rules to different kids leads to confusion and mixed messages.

column2: They'll knowingly say things to see how you respond and measure the distance they can take.

column1: <li>It provides your own child with a sense of certainty about what is and isn't acceptable.&nbsp
column2: There's no question as to whether something is okay when the friend, Billy, says it is (but really isn't).&nbsp
column3: The litmus test becomes simply, would Dad allow this?

column1: <li>If their houses really are that permissive, then it also provides a glimpse of a household with expected behaviors.&nbsp
column2: They might not realize when they're younger, but they perhaps will when they're older.

column1: Over the years, the various friends find that this PracticalDad tries to be consistent in acceptable behavior.
column2: And that excuses about levels of acceptable behavior don't fly but are instead met with resistance that can include banishment from the house.

column1: For the record, Opie had to return
column2: the Mountain Dew to the store cooler and get something&nbsp
column3: else.&nbsp

While it won't be finished in August - it's actually never completely finished - the family calendar will receive a new batch of attention starting in August as the kids gear up for a new school year.
column2: And don't think that it's not important just because your little ones are only in a three year-old preschool class.&nbsp
column3: The scheduling starts that young and the earlier the kids get a basic handle on time-management, the more adept they'll be later on.

column1: Because time-management is an acquired skill, not an inborn one.

column2: Get a monthly planning calendar from an office supply store, large enough to be readable and with enough space to handle multiple entries.&nbsp
column3: The wall-mounting simply means that it has a permanent home
column4: kids have a stunning ability to make movable objects disappear and anything left on a flat horizontal surface will acquire enough stains to remind you of a Jackson Pollock painting.

column1: Once you have the calendar, start listing all of the information that you know.
Since most activities for younger kids don't commence until after the start of the school year, the logical starting point is the general school calendar.
column2: These dates - showing vacation, early-dismissals and in-services - are typically available on the school or district website starting in July.&nbsp
column3: The great majority of school districts then supplement these bare-bone efforts with a complete calendar that's delivered several weeks before the start of school.&nbsp
column4: Use this calendar as the starting spot for the planning.

column1: You have the option of just keeping everything together and putting it the family calendar at one time, but you're better served by building the family calendar in a layered fashion.
column2: This means that you're continuing to build upon the basic structure as the information becomes available
column3: you have a better grasp of how activities and events interplay so that as new things crop up, you can mentally compare the times with what you know is already there.&nbsp
column4: It also lets you begin to work through the logistical requirements of how to get meals served and children One and Two to activities A and B.&nbsp
column5: And even decide when the particular activity has to be discarded because of excessive strains upon the kid and family time.

column1: Once you've got the information on the family calendar, be sure to keep the original calendar - and subsequent activity schedules - in the schedule folder
column2: as backup when disputes and questions arise.&nbsp

column1: As each new activity schedule comes home, make certain to add it to the schedule and then move it to the schedule folder.
As kids are added, aged and involved, the family calendar will have to be adapted to meet the family needs.
column2: What can you do to keep it working for you?

column1: <li>Use pencil so that any changes don't make the calendar ultimately unusable.&nbsp
column2: If it helps - or you're just that retentive - assign each child a color and make the additions in the appropriate colored pencil.

column1: <li>Get in the habit of a uniform response when the kid asks about being able to do something or go somewhere.&nbsp
column2: What's on the calendar?
column3: The kid can get into the habit of reviewing it and learn to actually make it a valuable tool.

column1: • Make it a routine to update the calendar or at least thoroughly review it on a regular basis.
<li>Use the calendar as a guide for menu preparations.&nbsp
column2: Some nights are crockpot nights because of kids eating at different times, while other nights cry out for pizza because there's simply no way to even prepare food.

column1: <li>Make it a practice to keep the old calendar for a period in order&nbsp
column2: to refer back to it as the need arises.&nbsp

column1: Don't get flustered if the kid occasionally misses a practice or appointment.
column2: The calendar is a constant work-in-progress but consistent use will allow you to add at least one more ball to the daily juggle.&nbsp
column3:
And even the greatest jugglers occasionally drop one.

A life raising kids is full of trials and tribulations.
column2: One of the unexpected tribulations of kids is the stress to the household plumbing and you'll be amazed at what is going to go into the pipes.&nbsp
column3: Excess wads of toilet papers, paper and cloth towels, clothing and toys - <em>Daddy, he threw&nbsp
column4: my bunny in the potty! - will gum up the works.

column1: So what helps in the plumbing department?
column2: Surprisingly, just&nbsp
column3: two plungers.

column1: Wrap your head around the fact that as a father, you're going to experience about every bodily fluid and will develop a stomach for most of what comes your way.
column2: But any other kids you have will freak when they see the same plunger used for the toilet used in the sink.&nbsp
column3: So take the opportunity to purchase a separate plunger solely for non-toilet uses.&nbsp
column4: You can label it with a sharpie to distinguish it, but you should consider getting one of a separate color
column5: smaller kids might not understand the lettering and bigger kids will simply not pay attention to lettering.&nbsp
column6: That way, there'll be minimal fuss over using the sink/bathtub after it's been plunged.&nbsp
column7: You should still clean the sink or tub after plunging, but the kids' squawking will be largely eliminated.

A large part of a father's job is teaching, but much of what has to be taught can't be done in a sit-down, teaching style.
column2: And much of this teaching will happen over a lengthy span, by example, correction and a lot of conversation.

column1: A case in point is teaching your kids about basic time management skills.
column2: Time management is, to an extent, a skill set that you either have or you don't and I know plenty of adults who are terrible at managing time and commitments.&nbsp
column3: But because it's something that I had to struggle with while some younger peers handled it easily, I concluded that it's something that I have to explain and model for the kids.

column2: clearly displayed and&nbsp
column3: make it a habit of referring back to it when a child wants to know if&nbsp
column4: Philo can come play.

column1: • Talk with the kids early in the day about what has to happen and when it has to happen.
<li>Keep an openly accessible to-do list and update it in front of the kids.&nbsp
column2: Let them see you doing it so that they learn by osmosis and example.

column1: <li>When the kids are old enough, make sure that they have timepieces so they aren't depending on others to know the time.&nbsp
column2: When Middle went to scout camp last month, I made certain that he had a decent - not expensive, just decent - watch in order to keep track of time.

column1: • When I goof, I openly talk about what went wrong and what I could have done differently.
• When the kids bring home a planner issued by the school, make sure that I sit with them after school to go through it and see what's on the horizon.
Some things will come quickly, like how to use a screwdriver.
column2: But others will take a long time, so be patient and prepare yourself for the long haul.&nbsp
column3:
This is one of those things.

column2: use signal language
column3: with the kids as a way to surreptiously know that they're crossing a behavioral line, but a speaker at a middle school orientation keyed us into another use of language:&nbsp
column4: codewords to signal for help from Mom and Dad.

column1: Nobody likes to take grief from others, and kids are especially susceptible to peer pressure.
column2: The idea is to provide a ready reason for refusing to go along with whatever dubious idea that some kids have concocted and letting the folks be the bad guys in the entire affair.&nbsp
column3: Your kid is removed from a bad situation and manages to save face in the process.&nbsp
column4: A win/win.

column1: Most kids now have cellphones, or at least access to one.
column2: Work it out with Junior that if he has a situation that makes him uncomfortable, he should get you on the phone on the pretext of letting you know about a change in schedule because of the idea.&nbsp
column3: Once you're on the phone, he can use the predetermined codeword as he lets you know of the assumed schedule change.&nbsp
column4: When you hear the word - and you have to train yourself to actually respond when you hear it - you put on&nbsp
column5: a huge fuss, chewing him out for something and ordering him home that instant.&nbsp
column6: Junior can then bow out of the situation on grounds that he's dead meat at home and has saved face in front of the other kids.

column2: one that I've now put in place.&nbsp
column3:
Because your kid might be concerned about what others think, but that's the least of your issues as a father.

Education matters, and don't be surprised to find yourself working with the kids on spelling, science, history and math.
column2: Especially math.

column1: For many younger elementary kids, it isn't necessarily the actual addition or subtraction that gets them, but the constant inability to keep digits in the proper columns.
column2: It's something that made me crazy for awhile until a teacher shared an idea that I still use years later.&nbsp
column3: Math problems on graph paper.

column1: This gentleman suggested that when the kids are doing math problems, they do so on graph paper.
column2: Each numeric digit gets a single grid on the graph paper and the next number goes into the grid immediately below it, so the kids can see that all digits in the ones place line up, as well as those in the tens and hundreds place.&nbsp
column3: The result should be a decline in errors made by carelessness and haste.

column1:
And it was, which is why I keep a pad or two of graph paper available.

What makes me most crazy about raising children is the issue with estimating the timeframe
column2: on completing tasks.&nbsp
column3: Having one children is akin to playing &quot
column4: If you give a mouse a cookie&quot
column5: , but the presence of three makes it damn nigh impossible.&nbsp
column6: The constant back and forth amongst kids adds considerable time to any particular task, especially if you've curtailed the electronics.

column1: Chores are delayed in order to play taxi for Grandma, who's having her eyeballs dilated.
column2: After toting, hauling and having lunch with her and Youngest, I get home to find that Eldest is just returning from a babysitting gig and Middle is back from the pool.&nbsp
column3: Meanwhile, the rest of the yard needs mowing, the bathrooms cleaned, dinner cooked, Youngest must review flash cards and Middle needs to start a for-pay household project before eating and being delivered to a work session for an Eagle Scout project.

column1: The scene commences with Eldest and Middle commencing to their tasks while I start cleaning the master bath.
column2: With one ear-bud dangling
column3: to keep tabs on the activity, I get to the commode when I hear squawking from Youngest.&nbsp
column4: He's responding to tart language from cleaning gloved Middle, who's reacting to Youngest's repeated play with a stuffed monkey that emits a&nbsp
column5: nails-on-blackboard recorded screech.&nbsp
column6: Middle has repeatedly asked him to stop, but it's a challenge to see if Middle can be delayed in his task.&nbsp
column7: That's about three minutes of eavesdropping, quizzing, and separating the irksome brothers.&nbsp
column8: Since this isn't the monkey's first offense, he's sent to the high-shelf hoosgow for a five day sentence.&nbsp
column9: I return to my meeting with the toilet.

column1: Right after getting back, Eldest interrupts with the news that the mower and gas can are parched and have been since Middle didn't tell me yesterday that they were suffering when he finished the front part of the yard.
column2: Because of days of rain and growth, the yard needs done today lest I then have to adjust the mower height upwards and move up the next week's cut.&nbsp
column3: So it's off for a twenty minute jaunt to the convenience store pumps so that the lawn can be done.&nbsp
column4: I again return to my friend and then move on to the bathroom counters.

column1: Now I hear the sound of a brewing riot downstairs as Middle and Younger bicker.
column2: My policy now is to ignore it until the tenor reaches the level of incipient violence, at which point I descend downstairs again.&nbsp
column3: Charge and counter-charge are leveled until a comment is made about an earlier situation that requires additional investigation.&nbsp
column4: I'm moving from attempted assault to Conspiracy and more time with Eldest reveals further behaviors that require correction.&nbsp
column5: The child in question requires discipline but since it can't wait any longer, more time passes as I handle the offenses.

column1: Unfortunately, since part of the discipline requires writing apology notes to the offended siblings, I now need to help him spell what needs to be said.
Damn, another five minutes shot and the clock 'til dinner is running.
column2: Note to self:&nbsp
column3: no more apology notes until they can operate Spellcheck.

column1: I manage to finish the counters and move onto the shower when the phone rings and it's my mate with the need to talk.
column2: Some things can't wait and I settle into the dining room chair to discuss things when she blurts out Oh God, Middle has the Scout session right now.
column3: <em>And I won't be making it home for dinner.&nbsp
column4: I hang up and run upstairs to find that Middle is happily cleaning off in the shower and has to be chased out.
column5: After several more minutes - with no dinner on the horizon - I grab the other two and we proceed with Middle to the meeting site.&nbsp
column6: Because this locale is much further away than the usual place, Eldest and Youngest fetch the ball and some gloves from the van - every well-stocked minivan now carries a ball and multiple gloves - to toss for an hour until Middle is finished.&nbsp

column1: After which, we scoot to a nearby McDonalds for fast food and to hell with the home-cooking.
column2: We arrive home near dark to find my mate - their mother - on the phone for business and fixing a quick meal, which I finish preparing for her.&nbsp
column3: Now the evening routine has to play out with bath, catch-up conversation and dogwalk.

column1: And tomorrow, I plan to actually finish the bathroom.
column2: And feel as though I've accomplished something.
","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"
I'm going to have a drink.

column1: - Mother overheard by PracticalDad on the first day of school
You'll love them and you're willing to die for them.
column2: But understand that the more time spent with them, the more likely that you'll need a break from them.&nbsp

column1: Children are many things, but you don't often hear the reality about them either.
column2: The large majority&nbsp
column3: are born as egocentric narcissists and you&nbsp
column4: are charged with the task of helping them grow into something better.&nbsp
column5: It&nbsp
column6: isn't easy and it's only been in the past several years that TV shows like&nbsp
column7: <em>Supernanny&nbsp
column8: and
column10: brought the lowlights of screaming, misbehaving children to the screen.&nbsp
column11: Granted, these are culled from the worst for&nbsp
column14: truth in there that sitcoms and other shows don't discuss.&nbsp
column18: petulant and random, testing their boundaries on a daily basis - and even the best parents can lose their temper.&nbsp

column1: Which is why you should have a place of your own, a mancave.
column2: Even Superman had a Fortress of Solitude, a place to go when he tired of having to deal with another falling airplane or Lex Luthor for the umpteenth time.&nbsp
column3: And it occasionally appears as though the kids are trying to push your buttons as frequently as Luthor did with Superman.

column1: There was an article several years ago about the decline and coming demise of the average guy's den.
column2: There were fewer and fewer guys with their own retreat rooms, places where they could go to get away from the noise and fracas.&nbsp
column3: These places might look cruddy and dingy, but they reflected the inner guy.&nbsp
column4: My father's retreat was a dank basement workbench that smelled of smoke and discouraged childhood attendance.&nbsp
column5: But with more men stepping up and pitching in, these retreats are fading as the guy sticks more closely to the main living area, decorated by the mate and strewn with the debris of childhood run amok.&nbsp
column6: One of the few exceptions is Brian, the father of Youngest's friend, who tells his son that he'll be in the mancave watching sports on the big screen.

column1: And with the slow demise of the den, the need for another refuge rises.
So what can you do when the kids have pressed you to the limit?
column2: How do you get a break?

column1: <li>Banish them to their individual rooms for a period of time.&nbsp
column2: Letting them stay together only asks for further trouble as they pick and annoy one another, further driving you to the breaking point.&nbsp
column3: And don't guilty about it since a temporary Dad's time-out is infinitely better than the alternatives.

column1: <li>Pop in a DVD acceptable to the kids and head to your room or some other place in the house.&nbsp
column2: Electronics will usually keep them in thrall to the Pixel God long enough that you get the break you need.

column1: <li>Schedule a regular time for a get-away from the kids.&nbsp
column2: It can be a night that the mate or a sitter takes the kids while you pursue what interests you.&nbsp
column3: Poker, pool, bowling or a good book.

column1: <li>It's counter-intuitive, but let them invite other kids over to play.&nbsp
column2: Children don't want to cannibalize playmates as much as siblings, so having someone else to hold their attention can buy you the time you need.&nbsp
column3: Understand however, that you are now binding yourself to maintain control of your emotions and actions.

column2: a regular time into the kids' schedule for quiet, whether it's listening to music, quiet play or reading/looking at stories.&nbsp
column3: That's why I truly miss the naps that the kids took daily.

column1: So there are alternatives when you don't have a mancave available like Brian.
column2: But I still gotta get me one of those.

There are few things as intimidating for a father as clothes shopping
column2: with the kids.&nbsp
column3: Minding antsy children, assessing appropriateness and checking what fits can scare most guys.&nbsp
column4: That doesn't even touch the fear about crippling your kid's lifetime self-worth with&nbsp
column5: a poor choice of fashion.&nbsp
column6: But there are some things to remember - and do - that can make it more manageable and less fearful.

column1: Shopping for clothing doesn't begin when you walk into the store.
<li>Before you leave the house, know what you need to buy.&nbsp
column2: That means reviewing the clothing that they have
column3: so that you aren't spending hard-earned money on yet another pair of jeans or hoodie.&nbsp
column4: That also means knowing where you want to shop and how much time you have to reasonably accomplish what you want.&nbsp
column5: If it's too long, be prepared to go on multiple trips.

column1: <li>If the kids are older, set groundrules on what's acceptable school clothing and what's not acceptable.&nbsp
column2: If you're not certain about a school's policy, check the district website for their clothing standards and if necessary, take a copy in your hip pocket.&nbsp
column3: Then go over your own family's standards.&nbsp
column4: In the PracticalDad family, that means no low-slung pants, no shirts with messages, no ripped clothing - no, if ripped jeans are cool, we'll stop at Goodwill and I'll slash them myself, thank you - and no skulls.
column5: I can live with black jeans or a stylish black shirt, but goth is as much a mindset as a fashion.

column1: <li>Do the kids even need to come along at all?&nbsp
column2: Some families I've known with very small children practice &quot
column3: hit and run&quot
column4: shopping with the parents swooping in to buy what looks like it will fit, then returning the non-fits after trying things on at home.&nbsp
column5: There are two disadvantages to this:&nbsp
column6: first, a child who is sensitive to how things feel - I hate this collar, my shoes are too tight, I don't like how these socks feel - should come along so that you can determine whether something is going to create problems.
column7: Donating never-worn clothing to charity is a frustrating waste of money.&nbsp
column8: Second, you have to really maintain control of the receipts and know which stores provided which items.

column1: • Like Dirty Harry said, a man's gotta know his limitations.
column2: It's one thing to go for the daily wear, but if you have a limited sense of fashion-sense, then let your mate worry about the high fashions.&nbsp
column3: If my eldest went with me, she'd be perpetually dressed in a habit and wimple.

column2: The first rule is that there's no hide-and-seek at all.

column1: <li>Then make sure that they know the consequences of misbehavior.&nbsp
column2: Loss of promised rewards - if I don't have a problem at Kmart, then we'll stop at the toy section - is better than the hoopla and public angst of having to remove a favorite toy.

column1: • Let the kids choose favorite toys or books to take along so that they can be occupied while there.
<li>If you have multiple children, consider the age-order in which you shop.&nbsp
column2: Smaller children have a shorter attention-span - and fuse - and won't last as long as older kids.&nbsp
column3: Additionally, the older kids can even chip in with finding clothing.&nbsp
column4: <strong>Understand that you're going to be interrupted and feel like a pinball but this is just another of the ways that you're teaching the kids.&nbsp

column6: and if it fits within the school and family parameters, then why not let the kids be fashionable?&nbsp
column7: By the time that kids are in middle elementary school, even the boys are starting to pay attention to what's in.&nbsp
column8: <em>Please Dad, can I&nbsp

column1: • When you've finished shopping for the younger ones, they can read or play with their toys while you attend to the older kids.
<li>Find a spot in which you can keep an eye on the kids while you attend to the clothing.&nbsp
column2: &nbsp
column3: They'll simply have to move&nbsp
column4: with you to an extent as you can't afford to let them to wander.&nbsp
column5: A missing child is absolutely&nbsp
column6: terrifying, trust me.&nbsp

column1: <li>Follow through on the pre-set guidelines about behavior and consequences.&nbsp
column2: Warnings and reminders about consequences can help keep kids in line, if they believe that you will follow through.

column1: <li>If the kids are old enough to follow and remember, take the opportunity to teach them about clothing and determining what fits.&nbsp
column2: <em>What are pleats?&nbsp
column3: How do you tell if a pair of pants fit?&nbsp
column4: How do you find what shoebox goes with the cool sneakers on display?

column2: Many large malls have play areas and a trip there during the shopping is a decent break for the kids and the parents, even if you have to monitor the behavior of the other kids there.

column1: <li>Don't be afraid to cut the expedition short.&nbsp
column2: It's better to have to come back than create a dread of something that just has to happen.

column1: <li>Take the opportunity to have a quick economics lesson at the checkout.&nbsp
column2: <em>A credit card doesn't mean that we don't pay.&nbsp
column3: See how much we were able to save by doing this?

And remember that you're going to feel like a pinball, but it's a manageable feeling.

It's important to keep the household well-stocked for emergencies, but what do you stock up on to address any household incidence of Swine Flu?
There are certain items to keep in event of sickness, but this is especially important with this flu season.
column2: Swine Flu - H1N1 - is expected to make inroads into the Northern Hemisphere starting in the next several weeks after a&nbsp
column3: jaunt through the Southern Hemisphere, which is ending its fall/winter cycle.&nbsp
column4: This is in addition to the flu variants with which many already have some immunity, so some authorities anticipate that in the event of a worser case scenario, hospitals will be busy, if not completely full.&nbsp
column5: By itself, having Swine Flu doesn't mean that&nbsp
column6: you have to have a special set of supplies but it does mean that there could be greater stress on the family and society.

column1: The saddest part to H1N1, which thankfully so far hasn't been as deadly as some have feared, is that it predominantly strikes children and younger people.
column2: And this means that school districts across the country are preparing contingency measures to close schools in the event of flu outbreaks.

column1: While this doesn't mean that martial law is going to be declared and tumbleweeds will roll through the streets, it does mean that you need to be ready to take care of some very sick children.
column2: &nbsp
column3: So you may not have the latitude to get to the nearest grocery should you run out of something.

column2: cleaning supplies, basic medicine and certain foods/drinks.
You'll have to take greater care to assure that little Milo washes his hands after sneezing, coughing, wiping a runny nose or using the bathroom.&nbsp
column3: Don't expect a seven year old to remember since it's a royal pain in the neck, so it's your job to do so.

column2: They aren't a panacea, but they are a much easier way to wipe down common surfaces than lugging around a spray bottle and paper towels.
column3: Keep the spray bottle and use, but it doesn't have to be on everything.

column2: Wipes are great for smaller areas but won't touch a larger pile of vomit or excrement.&nbsp
column3: For that matter, kitchen sinks and wide area countertops are better served by the paper towels.&nbsp
column4: Just remember to read the disinfectant label to determine how long the cleanser has to sit on the surface to truly disinfect it.

column2: These can be used to clean up the truly nasty messes.&nbsp
column3: While having a sick child increases the likelihood that you'll catch it, there's no reason to guarantee it by snorkeling in contaminated body fluids.

column2: They're more durable than toilet paper and won't aggravate the skin of the nose as readily as paper towels.
Many kids grab a drink in the bathroom, so letting the kids throw them out to stop the germ spread makes sense.

column1: <li>Extra supply of childrens' ibuprofen and childrens' acetaminophen (childrens' Tylenol).&nbsp
column2: These help to control higher fevers and limit discomfort, but they don't actually cure the virus.&nbsp
column3: That said, if you have one or more kids sicker for a longer period, then you can kill a bottle faster than you can kill the virus.

column2: Children with flu might have to be hospitalized for no other reason than to address dehydration, so working to avoid this is imperative.&nbsp
column3: And while additional amounts of water at home might provide hydration, the water doesn't replenish the electrolytes and minerals lost to volume vomiting and diarrhea.

column2: Even if nausea has relented, the wrong kinds of foods can aggravate the stomach and cause a recurrence.&nbsp
column3: Cream based soups&nbsp
column4: - those with dairy content - and those with lots of solid ingredients could create problems, so it's best to stay with bouillion and weak soups.

column2: It's not a thick or highly acidic fruit juice that could exacerbate nausea and vomiting and is helpful to mix with Pedialyte, which some kids find to have an unpleasant taste.
It's easy to run out of bread, but a package of crackers can last among sick kids for much longer.

column1: <li>Clear carbonated drinks, such as ginger ale and Sprite.&nbsp
This isn't a comprehensive list and doesn't address every last contingency.
column2: But it can provide a basic level and a departure point for families to consider.

What do you do when the kids are coming home with dirty jokes?
column2: This is especially a question that arises with pubescent boys, but it can also crop up more frequently with the girls, and one that my wife and I wrestled with before reaching a compromise.

column1: With the prevalence of electronic media, things today are definitely more raw than when I was a kid.
column2: Jokes are cruder and the ability to see questionable sights and actions on Youtube means that the exposure is wider than two decades ago.&nbsp
column3: So what do you do with that?

column1: My wife grew up in a family that taught the value of good manners and raised the kids to appreciate finer things.
column2: I grew up in a family that laughed at fart jokes at the dinner table.&nbsp
column3: And as our kids have grown and come home from school, we've not always agreed on how to handle things.&nbsp

column1: • Highlight the concept of time and place with the kids.
column2: I can't control what Middle says to his friends in the locker room, but I can control what's said in the house and at public venues.&nbsp
column3: There are appropriate times and places to pass along dirty jokes but at the table or in front of the grandparents is neither and is unacceptable.&nbsp
column4: It's proven to be a long. long conversation but one that is sinking in as he's learned the value of self-censorship and has actively refrained from off-color comments.

column1: <li>Assure that the kids know that I'm the guy that wants to hear the jokes.&nbsp
column2: Yes, I like adult humor - within reason - and I appreciate a joke as much as anybody.&nbsp
column3: And kids do want to share these with their parents, whether the parents realize it or not.&nbsp
column4: They might understand that Mom and Dad might kill them, but they do want to share.&nbsp
column5: In our household, Mom isn't the person for that.

column1: <li>Hearing it also gives me the opportunity to see where they're at in terms of understanding the human body, sexuality and topical events.&nbsp
column2: I can laugh, but they know that I'll sometimes ask questions to gauge their understanding of what's really been said and will even explain or correct misinformation and misunderstandings.&nbsp

column1: <li>I frequently use these jokes as an opportunity to discuss morality and treatment of one another.&nbsp
column2: <em>So that's what the joke's referring to.&nbsp
column3: Is that a way that you'd want to be treated?&nbsp
column4: Or see a member of your family treated?
column5: You might think that they're tuning you out, but they really are listening and you have to grab every opportunity you can.

column1: • Hearing it also helps to push the idea of time and place.
column2: There have been jokes that I've had to explain and then make sure that they understand why certain jokes can't ever see the light of day again.&nbsp
column3: And frankly, there have been jokes and comments that they're horrified that they've made once they understand the full meaning.

column1: You have to accept certain premises to make this work, however.
column2: You have to be able to control your reaction so that the kid isn't terrified of your response.&nbsp
column3: And you have to be willing to speak frankly about sex and the body, especially in proper terminology.&nbsp
column4: Using slang in this situation runs the risk of shifting you from the father/parent role to that of a buddy or someone on the&nbsp
column5: kid's level, which isn't what you want in this situation.

column1: So enjoy a good laugh when the kids brings home a dirty joke.
column2:
But be sure to monitor your reaction and be ready to talk about it further.

Our kids learn a huge amount from us and sometimes the best lessons are ones in which we wind up looking like complete idiots.
column2: A case in point is what happens when you don't pay attention to the cleaning - or any other - equipment that we use around the house.&nbsp
column3: Specifically, a vacuum cleaner.

column1: For years, we owned and used a Hoover upright vacuum cleaner.
column2: I was familiar with the sound of the motor as an indication that the bag was filling, and I periodically checked regardless even if it sounded alright.&nbsp
column3: With a shaggy dog and multiple cats, it was necessary.&nbsp
column4: But as the kids started to use the vacuum to help with the cleaning, I paid less attention.&nbsp
column5: I mentioned - although they'll deny that I did - that you have to listen to the motor, but earbuds interfered or the radio was turned up or they just weren't familiar with the sound of&nbsp
column6: a straining motor.&nbsp
column7: And the bag filled with my assuming that it was being checked.

column1: Until a few months ago when I found that the vacuum literally wasn't even picking up a wad of doghair.
column2: I pulled the cover and found the bag was full.&nbsp
column3: And then pulled the bag out to discover the hoses were clogged with hair and debris, so much so that even with dismantling the vacuum, I was unable to reach debris pockets that continued to clog the device.&nbsp
column4: The result was a discarded Hoover and a new Bissell.&nbsp
column5: What pulled me to this new vacuum wasn't the manufacturer but that it had a clear tank in which you could see the dirt and debris so that&nbsp
column6: you knew when it needed to be emptied.&nbsp
column7: So now the kids were able to clearly tell that the vacuum canister was full and could empty it.

column1: But as miffed as I was at having to buy a new appliance for a bad reason, I had to stifle myself since this one was on me.
column2: Why?

column1: <li>I've routinely done the vacuuming - and other cleaning - when they're not around and they haven't had the visual osmosis of seeing Dad follow the routine.&nbsp
column2: Kids learn a lot by observation and they'll form the habit of doing things from just growing up watching you.

column1: <li>I forgot that kids need to be constantly reminded and aren't always dependable.&nbsp
column2: I assumed that because I mentioned it, that it was done.&nbsp
column3: <em>Don't forget to check the bag when you're done.&nbsp
column4: Did you check the bag when you were finished?&nbsp
column5: Expect them to squawk and roll their eyes in exasperation, but keep it up or else you live with the results.

column1: <li>I wasn't the adult and simply didn't even check the damned thing myself and assumed that it was in decent shape.&nbsp
column2: Attention to detail is a learned trait and one that they have to pick up from the adults in their lives.&nbsp
column3: In this case, it wasn't me.

column1: So I've had a good kick in the mental butt about my responsibilities.
column2: There are some other areas in which I've had to check myself to counter parental laziness and pick up the slack.

column1: Now I have to remind them to actually look at the clear tank canister on the vacuum cleaner.

When I'm answering one of my kid's questions about sex, should I include something moral in the answer?
Stunned is too strong, but I was truly surprised to hear the question from a female friend some time ago.
column2: One of her elementary-age children asked a question about sex and she was curious as to whether I thought that it was appropriate to include some moral commentary.&nbsp
column3: Absolutely, every chance you get was my response.

column1: Kids are going to ask questions about the human body and sex and that's exactly what you want to happen.
column2: When the kids are younger, the questions will pertain to the human body and its parts.&nbsp
column3: And as they age and are exposed to other kids and media, the questions will shift to sex.&nbsp
column4: The body questions are easy and the best response is a simple straightforward answer using the proper terminology.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: Because you don't want kids to view the body as something evil or sinful, you might want to consider the question before inserting any moral statements.&nbsp
column7: A breast is a breast as far as a six-year old is concerned.

column1: Sex questions however, are more uncomfortable for
column2: the parent and there can be a&nbsp
column3: burning desire to give a quick answer&nbsp
column4: with a move onwards&nbsp
column5: to other topics.&nbsp
column6: Like cooking shows.&nbsp
column7: But it's vital to answer the questions in as straightforward language as possible and since you might never discover&nbsp
column8: the&nbsp
column19: giving the answer - a platonic friend who extends sexual activity - let your&nbsp
column24: Be clear and most importantly, be calm, even if your head is ready to explode.&nbsp
column26: They're listening and this is a key opportunity to counter whatever is being said by their peers in the locker room or hallway.&nbsp
column28:
I doubt that a testosterone-addled teen is concerned with the feelings or reputation of another teen so you have to take the opportunity presented to get your message across.
