After all of the hoopla about the positives and negatives of President Obama's speech to schoolkids today, I took the opportunity to read the president's transcript.
And I'm actually going to discuss it with them this evening at dinner and reinforce his remarks.
column2: Frankly, the content of the speech is refreshing in that it places some of the responsibility of learning on students themselves instead of focusing solely on teacher ratios or education spending.&nbsp
column3: Enough - too much - has been said about the failings of the educational system with the root causes being ascribed to:

column1: <li>inadequate resources, despite per capita spending among the highest in the world
• other factors, depending on your political bent.
But it's been in the past 18 months that I've begun to hear of the need for parents to become more involved and push the value of education.
column2: And now the kids are being reminded that, like life, much of what they get from education is what they make of it themselves.&nbsp

column1: It's also a generational wake-up call for them, even if they don't realize it.
column2: Our nation is past the point of being able to support all of the promises that have been made to the citizenry and I believe that the generational groundwork is now being sown so that the kids understand there won't be the financial support that was promised to the Baby Boomers and other adults.&nbsp
column3: Today's kids are going to have to be able to compete globally and won't be able to depend upon the government for its largesse.

column1: For those who argue that this speech is a veiled attempt at political indocrination, I would point out the following.
column2: Children and teens are, by nature, optimists and willing to trust those whom their parents distrust, especially someone who occupies the Oval Office.&nbsp
column3: And this is a generation noted for it's unawareness of the greater social/political debate
column4: many are unable to even name their Congressmen and Senators.&nbsp
column5: So are they really going to be able to read between lines like an experienced politics watcher?&nbsp

column1: This is language that actually reinforces what I've been telling the older kids for a few years now.
column2: And I'm glad to&nbsp
column3: have someone with some fame and power support me so I'm going to take this big, fat ball and run with it as far as I possibly can.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column1: Your kids will ask searingly direct questions and you're liable to be placed on an uncomfortable seat, as I was tonight.
For the record, I've got a bad leg subsequent to a long-ago battle with cancer.
column2: The good new is you'll survive but the bad news...

column1: This question was in response to my having to take a cane along for a scouting event.
column2: I've used it on very rare occasions, but today was a bad one for that particular limb so I took it just in case.&nbsp
column3: As we talked on the way home, I was initially struck since I've never thought of myself in that light.&nbsp
column4: I stumbled on a response and decided to walk with him through the question and what it meant.&nbsp
column5: No, I can rarely wrestle with the kids anymore because of frequent cramping.&nbsp
column6: No, I can't run anymore either.&nbsp
column7: He knows that when he wants to sit on my lap that he has to approach from a particular side.&nbsp
column8: And depending on how it feels on a particular day, I might have a pronounced limp.&nbsp
column9: While my initial impulse was to deny it, I had to finally acknowledge that in some ways, I was crippled.&nbsp

column1: Young children can't discern the vagaries of political correctness.
column2: They&nbsp
column3: deal directly in the here and now.&nbsp
column4: Since the examples that he can comprehend clearly show a physical inability because of a specific problem, then what's the real value in muddying the waters while protecting my pride?&nbsp
column5: What it also means however, is that I'll have further conversations with him about all of the things that I can do in spite of the leg.&nbsp
column6: And while I have the issues, it doesn't mean that I'm incapable of doing anything.&nbsp
column7:
In other words, I'll make an effort to merge direct language with the good intent of political correctness.

Men don't appreciate that their voice - tone and inflection - can have a real use in helping maintain control of the kids.
I somehow realized when the eldest was a toddler that how I used my voice
column2: made a real difference in how she responded to my authority.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: Understand that as kids grow, they'll seek ways to assert their independence and challenge authority.&nbsp
column5: It's expected and actually healthy and that's one of those things that you learn to handle.&nbsp
column6: But there are moments when you have to immediately reassert yourself before further problems arise.&nbsp
column7: Like when?

column1: • When the child is going to place themselves in immediate danger, as running pell-mell towards a busy road.

column2: a group of children and misbehavior threatens to ruin the setting for everyone.

column1: <li>When a child is starting to ignore warnings or corrections.&nbsp
Because it's best described as hard and/or brusque, it's a tone that only sees use when I have to make a point.
column2: If children don't think that they're going to like what's said, they'll learn to ignore it and later claim that they didn't hear you.&nbsp
column3: I try to take care to insure that it's&nbsp
column4: tucked away from daily usage so that they can't claim that and the&nbsp
column5: effect isn't lessened.&nbsp
column6: Sometimes it happens and sometimes it doesn't, but I try.

column1: The tone isn't yelling, but a frank and controlled one that even the youngest can't mistake.
column2: There is no rise in inflection at the end, as though a question is being asked, and it goes hand-in-glove with the child's belief that what's said will be enforced
column3: if not followed.&nbsp
column4: So a history of follow-through is helpful to the process.

column1: What are some situations in which I've used it, either with my own or another child?
<li>When Eldest was playing with a group of preschoolers and started to run after a ball towards a crowded street.&nbsp
column2: Stop now! was in a deep, harsh tone that cut through the ambient noise and all three of the kids froze several feet before the roadway while the ball went into traffic.

column1: <li>Helping a nanny at a playground control a child - her ward - who was tossing rocks at kids sliding down a slide.&nbsp
column2: The child ignored the nanny until one of the rocks almost clocked Middle and then I had a brief conversation with him.&nbsp
column3: No yelling, but a kneel to the kid's level and a look directly into his face while stating that the behavior would stop immediately.&nbsp
column4: Surprisingly, the nanny thanked me.

column1: <li>Stopping a young ballplayer from breaking the coach's rule about swinging a bat behind the backstop.&nbsp
column2: The boy started swinging the bat and another father asked what did the coach say about swinging the bat?
column3: The kid then simply moved further away and continued to swing the bat.&nbsp
column4: My response was to walk over and tell him - in a hard tone - to leave the bat and reassume his place in line.&nbsp

column1: And there are plenty of other situations out there.
The point is to assure that they understand you offer no options, as the other father did.
column2: The would-be batter was left with an option that satisfied the father's comment while continuing to violate the coach's rule and continuing the behavior that could injure someone else.

column1: It's not a tone that I enjoy using but with some practice and follow-through, it can offer a better alternative to having to yell or let a child ruin a situation by poor behavior.

I'm talking about the one on the bottle, not the other one.
Now that I have your attention, pay the same attention to the bottle nipple as you pay to changing the oil in your car.
column2: Because an overly-used nipple creates issues for Junior just like dirty oil does for the mini-van.

column1: When the baby suckles from the bottle nipple, the milk flows through a tiny hole in the nipple into the baby's mouth.
column2: And it's small size means that only a certain amount can enter at a time.&nbsp
column3: This&nbsp
column4: is good for your child&nbsp
column5: since it prevents too much into the mouth - and stomach -&nbsp
column6: at one time.&nbsp
column7: But over time, the constant suckling and pressure of the milk flow&nbsp
column8: increases the size of the hole so that more milk flows into the baby and creates the potential for a stomachache.&nbsp
column9: And if a baby drinks too much too quickly, more air will also flow into the stomach with all of the discomfort - and crying - that that entails.

column1: What's a good indicator that the nipple is ready for replacement?
column2: When you turn the bottle over to test whether the liquid is too warm, watch&nbsp
column3: how it flows from&nbsp
column4: the&nbsp
column5: bottle.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: The nipple should be fine if the milk comes out&nbsp
column8: in drops.&nbsp
column11: comes out in a small, constant flow, then it's time to replace the nipple.&nbsp
column13: best results, the milk comes at a rate determined by the baby's suckling, not&nbsp
column14: one akin to a beer can&nbsp

I've learned in the past several days that I need to go back and take another first aid course.
column2: Because I've forgotten&nbsp
column3: some of what I used to know.

column1: The range of injuries for most children is consistent with a bell curve.
column2: Scrapes, cuts and bruises comprise the large majority of &quot
column3: boo-boos&quot
column4: but&nbsp
column5: there are the occasional things that remind&nbsp
column6: me what I don't know.&nbsp
column7: And what must I refresh?

column1: • The difference in clearing an obstacle from a small child's throat versus performing a Heimlich Manuever on an adult.
• Discerning how much pressure to apply for CPR on a small chest.
• How to handle immediate treatment for burns.
• How to handle first aid for broken bones.

column2: It's pretty easy to discern when it's for the ED instead of the pediatrician's office.&nbsp
column3: But there's still the initial work on the situation&nbsp
column4: before contacting the doctors and that's where I got caught the other day
column5: because what I had Middle do for his injury wasn't going to help him, even if it didn't hurt him (fortunately).

column1: So in the several days, I'll make the time to contact the American Red Cross to see what's available in First Aid courses.

And Middle's going to be fine, thank God.

At what point do we say that the kids are overscheduled and it's time to cut back?
column2: &nbsp
column3: Even when the family meal is shot to hell and the transportation is problematic, it isn't always an easy call.

column1: Today was one of the typical Fall school-is-back-in-session days.
column2: Each child had somewhere to be and the timing was peccable.&nbsp

column1: • Middle had a theatre practice with pick-up at 5 pm and a fifteen minute commute places him home at 5:15.
• Youngest had baseball practice at a remote field at 6 pm and a twenty minute commute in the opposite direction means that he leaves at 5:40.
• Eldest was babysitting down the street at 6:30 and won't be home until late.
This means that if we want to have any kind of family meal, then we have an event window of about twenty-five minutes and that assumes that everybody is washed up and at the table immediately.

column2: And are we bad parents if we refuse to let our kids participate in an activity?

column1: The reality is that kids today have far more options than we had when we were younger.
column2: There are more scholastic female sports and there are more non-sport activities for guys as well.&nbsp
column3: We want the kids to have the opportunity to try different activities and that means a commitment on our part.&nbsp
column4: Even if we limit them to a maximum of two activities through the course of a calendar year, then multiple kids means that the parents and family are going to stretch farther than would've happened in the past.&nbsp

column1: In the PracticalDad household, we try to hold each child to two concurrent activities at one time.
column2: Because a sport schedule involves multiple practice nights in addition to games, we limit each child to one sport per season.&nbsp
column3: Each of the kids was, or still is, a scout which means that it's a year-long commitment in addition to the sport that they select.&nbsp
column4: And even with these restrictions, the typical weekly schedule can border on the insane.

column1: I don't believe that refusing to let a child join an activity is bad parenting.
column2: In previous conversations with our kids, my wife and I have pressed home the following lessons.

column1: <li>Life is a matter of choices and as an adult, you won't be able to do everything that you would like.&nbsp
column2: So these are important lessons in making decisions.

column1: <li>There are more in the family so you have to look beyond yourself and consider others.&nbsp
column2: Would you like to spend as much time in the carseat as your little brother will have to spend in his?

column1: <li>What's the practical impact of an activity on other aspects of your life?&nbsp
column2: Will it interfere with schoolwork - from whence all benefits flow in the PracticalDad household - or will it mean that you'll be splitting time with another activity?&nbsp
column3: Is it fair to your teammates to only show for half of the practices and not be fully prepared for the game or activity?&nbsp

column1: <li>It isn't the end of the world for a child or teen to stop a sport or activity and then go back to it later.&nbsp
column2: These years are&nbsp
column3: important for kids as they try to find their likes and skills and a season or year out typically won't make a major impact.

column1: We've used all of these talking points with the various kids as we manage the individual and family affairs.
column2: The response hasn't always been&nbsp
column3: what we wanted but with some thought, each child has responded decently.

column1: And we've had to reconcile ourselves to the notion that multiple children simply means a busy life during the school year.
column2:
So each side sucks it up and makes the best of the situation.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp

column1: Managing the household - with multiple children and activities - is frequently a case of establishing a routine that is both wide-reaching and monitored.
column2: &quot
column3: Monitored"
column4: means that you follow up to assure that what has to happen actually happens.
column5: Expect things to go wrong, but a decent calendar and schedule will minimize the BOOMS.
column6: Unfortunately, that means that you have to actually go back to the calendar and be sure to carry things forward.

column1: This includes treating the animals for fleas.
column2: Prior to our move to another house, we gave our dog/cat pets monthly flea treatments and routinely carried the date forward to the following month so that it was handled and we kept the fleas out of the house.&nbsp
column3: But after the move, that particular item never made it back to the calendar and subsequently dropped out of the routine.&nbsp
column4: And now we find that each of the three cats has at least one flea.&nbsp
column5: We've found one on each but live by the assumption that there's plenty more where that came from.

column1: So my life is now more complicated over the next several days.
column2: What has to happen?

column1: • Obtain the medication necessary to treat each animal and re-establish that routine.
• Vacuuming the entire house with multiple dumpings of the canister to assure that the suction stays strong and that they don't congregate in the bag after being swept in.
• Changing multiple bedlinens so that they don't infest the kids' beds and bite them.
<li>Continuing this vacuuming daily so that the fleas don't&nbsp
column2: linger.
flea bomb&quot
column3: powder for the house, which means that animals must be removed from the house for the day, as well as all other lifeforms.

column2: My failure to get that item back on the routine has now doomed me to additional drudgery that could've easily been avoided.&nbsp
column3:
And the lesson is to make certain that the family calendar is complete and current.

On my first day running the household, the pile of laundry on the
column2: basement sofa was one of the two things that led&nbsp
column3: me to ask the question&nbsp
column4: <em>what in the hell do I do&nbsp
column5: now?
column6: &nbsp
column7: The laundry&nbsp
column8: has to be cleaned, but what do you need to know to assure that the laundry gets done, and done right?&nbsp
column12: you before college is great for a steady diet of hoodies and jeans, but fails when applied to womens' and baby clothing.

column1: Let's just spend this segment talking about washing baby clothing.
Remember first that your infant has soft skin and absolutely no exposure to the fragrances and scents of many detergents.
column2: The various scents are the product of chemical additives to the detergents and are known to create itchy, uncomfortable rashes on the baby's skin
column3: this is even after the rinse cycle removes the soap from the clothing.&nbsp
column4: So you're going to have to use a detergent that is has no such additives.&nbsp
column5: While I don't want to shill for any particular product, Dreft was the detergent of choice for years.
column6: There are now other products available for baby/toddler laundry.

column1: Even Before Your Infant Puts On Clothing
Now that you've settled on a detergent, let me ask you
column2: some questions.&nbsp

column1: Think of that cute onesie that just came out of the packaging.
column2: Do you know where it was&nbsp
column3: before it got into the packaging?
column4: Or that little dress that your mate rescued from the rack before another mother nabbed it.&nbsp
column5: Do you know where it was laying before it was placed on the rack?&nbsp
column6: Or even before it was placed in the shipping box in the Dominican Republic?&nbsp
column7: Just how clean are most factories?

column2: the answers are less than appetizing, then you probably want to wash new clothing before it hits Junior's body.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: I didn't always wash the clothing before first use, but fell into the habit as I gained some control in the whole laundry process.&nbsp
column5: So make it a point to do a wash of new clothing before putting it on the baby.

column2: Clothing Survives the&nbsp
column3: Wash

column1: Great, so you're going to use an appropriate detergent and wash the new stuff.
column2: Now you have to make sure that it survives the laundry routine in decent enough shape for the kid to wear it.&nbsp
column3: What do you need to know?

column1: <li>Obviously, dark colors are washed separately from bright colors and whites.&nbsp
column2: Even if brights and darks can go in cold water, don't mix them if you don't have to.&nbsp
column3: Neither of them go in with the new white onesies.

column1: <li>Check the tags to see what the material is since high-content cotton items will shrink in the dryer.&nbsp
column2: Go to Wally Mart and invest a few bucks in a drying rack and you'll recover the investment when you get to actually dress Junior in the cotton outfits.

column1: <li>Check the tags to discover what the drying cycle should be.&nbsp
column2: Dryers have different temperature settings and tags specifying a low setting - Tumble Dry Low - mean that the item will probably shrink in the standard drying cycle.

column1: <li>That precious frilly outfit that your Mother-in-law bought for your daughter should be washed separately from the denim and heavy fabrics.&nbsp
column2: These heavier fabrics will batter the delicates and I've lost clothing to metal zippers/buttons tearing into lace and other delicate items.

column1: <li>Keep an eye on the amount of clean clothing in the drawers/closet so that you can have things moving in a standard process.&nbsp
column2: It actually is embarrassing to take the kid somewhere in clothing that's obviously dirty.&nbsp
column3: What kind of parent are you anyway?

column1: <li>If you're comfortable with the process, you can even get Junior into larger clothing by washing it first and then running it through a dryer so that it shrinks.&nbsp
column2: I've done it successfully - and not - so it's only done if you have a sense of what to do.

column1: <li>I'll bet you didn't know that there's an alarm buzzer on your dryer.&nbsp
column2: If you can get the clothes out shortly after the buzzer notes the end of the drying cycle, you can elliminate many of the wrinkles in the clothing.&nbsp

column1: • Of course, you have to actually fold or hang up the clothing after getting it out of the dryer.
• Consider using a mesh bag to hold tiny socks so that they don't get stuck under the washer's agitator and add to the legend of the Missing Sock Zone.
If you think that it's more than you expected, you're right.
column2: What brought it home for me was the money lost on unwearable clothing and the look on my mate's face when her baby wouldn't wear that outfit that she adored.

column1: So pay attention and work the process.

Even if you aren't overscheduled, you're going to spend a decent amount of time in the family vehicle.
column2: And that means that you should consider keeping it stocked with some items for contingencies that come with kids of any age.&nbsp
column3: What do I keep in my minivan, even if the kids aren't aware of it?

column1: • A first aid kit stocked with plenty of wipes, bandaids and antibacterial cream.
• When the kids were younger, a supply of clean diapers/training pants and wipes tucked into a pocket behind the driver's seat in case the diaper bag was forgotten.
• A ready supply of pens and paper for drawing to pass the time.
• Snacks, separate from what can be found between the seats.

column2: Older kids can opt to bring their own selection.
At this writing, it's Steven Pressfield's The Afghan Campaign.
And even if you try to cover all contingencies, you're going to come up short on occasions.&nbsp
column3:
That's why God created Walmart...

So you're looking at a full hamper of dirty clothing in the hallway or bath and perhaps another in one or more of the kids' bedrooms.
column2: What do you do now with all of this dirty laundry?&nbsp

column1: Understand first that a pile of dirty laundry is one of the two exceptions to that physics law which states that matter is neither created nor destroyed.
column2: As you start to work through the pile, you'll think that each item removed is replaced by another mysteriously appearing under the pile.
column3: But you have to start somewhere.

column1: Work through by creating a separate for each category of clothing.
<li>Denim and other heavy material pants, including cargo and khaki pants and shorts.&nbsp
column2: Because the denim (jeans) will be probably be dark colored, this pile should be washed in cold water to keep the color from bleeding.&nbsp
column3: And you want to keep the heavier material separate from other clothing so that it doesn't wear or damage the lighter fabrics.

column1: • Lighter fabric darks, including dark delicates, in cold water wash.
• Bright colors - reds, blues, yellows - in cold water wash.
• Whites and grays, including boys/men underwear and socks, to be washed in warm water.
Several factors can help you determine where to start.
column2: First, any laundry that's dried on a clothesline or rack should go early in order to give it time to fully dry.&nbsp
column3: As the day progresses into evening, the laundry on the line will dry more slowly and even absorb dew to become damp.&nbsp
column4: Second, consider what's coming up on the calendar.&nbsp
column5: If a kid has an event or activity requiring clean clothing, be sure to get that done earlier than later.&nbsp
column6: If none of these come into play, then just find a pile and start.

column2: Here are some things to remember when you handle the laundry
column3: just tossing items in the washer invites a mess.

column1: <li>Check the pockets on all pants and shirts.&nbsp
column2: Pens will leak and stain multiple items if they break, money will be ruined or keys will rip holes in pockets.

column1: <li>You can't use bleach on any items that have color of any kind.&nbsp
column2: Bleach is solely for whites.

column1: <li>You have to check the exterior of all items for stains.&nbsp
column2: Use stain products and scrub the heavier stains with a toothbrush before putting it in.

column1: <li>Likewise, check the stained clothing when you remove it.&nbsp
column2: If the stain remains, don't put it in the dryer since the dryer heat will set the stain permanently.&nbsp
column3: If you think that there's still a chance to remove the stain, do the item the next opportunity you have but don't dry it in the dryer until then.

column2: labels on questionable items, especially womens' tops and blouses.&nbsp
column3: Especially be sure to do so when you remove them from the washer.&nbsp
column4: Putting a Tumble Dry, Low Heat item in a regular setting dryer will shrink it until it's unwearable.
column5: And hell hath no fury like a woman who's dress blouse is unwearable.

column1: • Make sure that dry clean only isn't in the piles.
• Womens' hosiery and bras are dried on a rack, not in a dryer.
• And remember that baby clothing is done separately, especially if you're using a baby detergent like Dreft.
And despite all of the attention to detail, you'll still find items are ruined.
column2: But it will get better.

You sometimes come across an article that resonates with what's happening in your own life and household.
column2: In this particular instance, a timely parenting article - Age-old kids' query in a text message: Wuz4dina? - by Beth Harpaz.

column1: We held off on purchasing a cellphone for our eldest until we saw a certifiable need, in this case, a youth trip to a city 1000 miles away.
column2: And along with that purchase came a debate that I hadn't anticipated:&nbsp
column3: text messaging in the phone plan.&nbsp
column4: Understand that my wife and eldest child are technophiles and infinitely better versed in modern electronics of all kinds.&nbsp
column5: I was the one who worked in the corporate headquarters of a Fortune 500 company and&nbsp
column6: walked down the hall to talk to someone instead of emailing them.&nbsp
column7: But after discussion - them versus me - we came to a reasonable compromise.&nbsp
column8: She got the texting package and contributes to a portion of her cellphone bill.&nbsp

column1: But while understanding the slang and acronyms are a real concern - I long ago learned that I had to keep up with youth culture
column2: - my qualms simply go to having one more thing that I have to monitor and place on the parental radar.&nbsp
column3: Are the number of messages within the plan parameters?&nbsp
column4: Who's being texted?&nbsp
column5: And unless something goes radically amiss, are things being kept appropriate?&nbsp
column6: And if you're reading this, Eldest, I do believe that they are
column7: it's simply a parental concern.

column1: Giving her access has also proven to be the departure point for any number of other issues.

column2: speak properly with people despite being able to text with your buds.&nbsp
column3: There are moments when texting is appropriate and moments when it's not, like when I'm sitting in the next room.

column1: <li>Understanding that these services come at a financial cost and that you can't always text if it's going to cost you for texting those outside of your plan.&nbsp
column2: It's an elementary resource allocation exercise for young minds.

column1: • Learning how to read a bill and about the affiliated service and regulatory fees.

column2: contract and billing errors, and that speaking frankly isn't the same as &quot
column3: yelling&quot
column4: or being rude.

column1: So I'm grabbing the opportunities as they come.
column2: She'll learn about these things and I'll get additional glimpses into her world.

column1:
But I'll keep the texts with her to a minimum since I don't have texting as part of my plan.

When you contact the kid's physician to arrange a flu vaccination appointment, you'll likely be asked whether you want her to receive a flu shot or Flumist.
column2: My first reaction on being asked:&nbsp
column3: What's that and what's the difference?

column1: Flumist is a flu vaccine designed to help provide immunity against the expected flu variants.
column2: In that regard, it's like the standard flu injection in that it covers the exact same flu variants expected for that particular season.&nbsp
column3: It&nbsp
column4: principally differs in these ways:

column2: a brief squirt up each nostril so that antibodies develop in the bloodstream and the nose, which is the most likely entry point for the flu virus.

column1: • Flumist is made from a weakened live virus while standard flu injections are derived from a dead virus.
Because small kids are usually terrified of needles, it's a parental godsend.
column2: She might still be squeamish at having to endure a squirt from some strange tube stuck up her nose but a little conversation and encouragement will help her through the process.
A Brief Comparison

column1: * If this is the first time that your child is receiving a flu vaccination, there has to be a second administration to assure that the antibodies develop.
column2: This follow-up won't be necessary in subsequent years.

How often have you heard a co-worker, neighbor or friend use the term quality time to describe time spent with their kids?
column2: It's a term that connotes play and recreation with the child with no sense of shared responsibility or work, and even I've used it as such in the past.&nbsp
column3: But&nbsp
column4: there's merit in re-examining what it means&nbsp
column5: as the kids grow and responsibilities multiply.

column1: As kids grow, they need to learn how to perform the daily tasks that keep their world running.
column2: This includes fixing meals, cleaning their immediate areas and even handling outside chores.&nbsp
column3: Yet they truly do want to spend time with you
column4: these moments provide&nbsp
column5: significant opportunities to pass along the &quot
column6: tribal knowledge&quot
column7: that is often&nbsp
column8: lost in the transition from one generation to another.&nbsp
column9: What can you expect from the opposite sex?&nbsp
column10: What's it mean to be a good sport?&nbsp
column11: What are the hidden messages behind the events they witness in their daily lives?&nbsp
column12: Play with the kids is important as well as fun, but it doesn't promote the environment of togetherness - frequently in close proximity and shared effort - that engenders serious conversation.&nbsp
column13: Understand that it isn't something that is easily done with&nbsp
column14: young children, even if they are willing to shift back and forth from play to time with you.&nbsp
column15: But as the kids age, they can participate in the work.&nbsp
column16: And that participation can lead to:

column1: <li>a greater understanding of what's involved in seemingly mundane tasks
<li>understanding of family and personal values that comes from one-on-one conversation

column2: &nbsp
column3: Many fathers - myself&nbsp
column4: included - will shunt the&nbsp
column5: kids to their own&nbsp
column6: activities as they find respite from daily life in the&nbsp
column7: things that need to be done.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column10: then set aside specific periods of time&nbsp
column15: But this habit is too limiting for the needs of your child, who won't gain the true education that can come from their fathers.

column1: The next time that you have a set of chores or a project, consider how to include your kids.
column2: It can be a better time than you expect.

It was frightening enough to have to provide the primary care for the infant, but doing so on a 55% paycut made it almost terrifying.
Prior to the arrival of Eldest, we were the prototypical DINKs - Double Income No Kids - living the urban lifestyle.
column2: We frequently dined out with Thai cuisine being the preferred.&nbsp
column3: Movies and trips were standard and it meant little to routinely&nbsp
column4: shop at&nbsp
column5: the Barnes and Nobel Superstore.&nbsp
column6: And because my mate was in a federal government fellowship, her earnings were lower than mine as a corporate staffer.

column1: My decision to stay home only came about five weeks before my mate had to return from maternity leave.
column2: It wasn't simple and the knowledge that our combined salaries would be cut by 55% made it problematic.&nbsp
column3: How did we handle it and how would we do it differently now?

column1: A baby means that you have new and unexpected costs for staples.
column2: What costs can you anticipate?

column1: <li>Certainly diapers and remember that not all brands are created equal.&nbsp
column2: Do you need all of the special touches, such as diapers that let you know they're wet by artwork that appears when it becomes wet?&nbsp
column3: These are items that drive up the cost.&nbsp
column4: In our case, we went with the Toys 'R Us store brand.

column1: • Co-pays for doctor visits, assuming that you have such insurance.
<li>Formula, if that's what you use to feed your baby.&nbsp
column2: One neighbor referred to it as &quot
column3: liquid gold&quot

column2: You might find that the extended family will provide the special clothing or play clothing but the staples are likely to be on you.&nbsp
column3: You will also find that such items will typically not be found at second-hand stores although friends with other small children might be a source.

column1: <li>Other staples such as bottles, nipples, and other safety devices and equipment.&nbsp
column2: Larger items - strollers, carseats and the like - were either purchased prior to the baby's arrival, when we had available cash, or were gifts from friends.&nbsp
column3: Don't expect that you can purchase such items at thrift stores since liability concerns prevent them from carrying any baby furniture.&nbsp
column4: In this case, yard sales can serve as a source for reasonably priced equipment.

column1: • We set aside money for life insurance, a first for us.
We re-examined what the spending habits and made changes.
• We were fortunate to rent at the time so we didn't have the corollary homeownership costs or worries about a mortgage.
• Cable was paid, but because we knew that we'd be spending more time at home.
<li>We continued to occasionally eat out, but the demands of the baby and costs meant that I did much more cooking.&nbsp
column2: The Thai cuisine went away.

column1: <li>We continued to drive older vehicles, although we did carry a note on one of the two autos.&nbsp
column2: This was paid off early.

column1: • Insurance was re-bid to assure that our costs were the lowest we could get.
• We paid extremely close attention to grocery sales and heavily utilized coupons, membercard savings and sales to cut the cost of some weekly groceries by 35 - 40%.
Despite these measures, we still found ourselves running a credit card balance.
When I reconsider those early days, there are certain additional things that I would consider.
<li>Shopping at second-hand/consignment stores for everyday adult clothing.&nbsp
column2: I've found that the children's rack at such stores is sparse as children's clothing is either picked over before I get there or clothing is traded among close family friends.

column1: • Paying off the credit card in entirety, as we typically do today.

When you're responsible for the family cooking, you begin to understand that there are changes in the family lifecycle.
column2: Timing and menus aren't the same when you have an infant as when you have teenagers.

column1: Yesterday was one of those changes that took me by surprise.
The media periodically run articles about the need for families to dine together, and I wholeheartedly agree that it matters.
column2: But&nbsp
column3: there are still weeks when coordinating family meals with competing schedules is difficult and I'm happy to get four family meals together out of seven.&nbsp
column4: As we moved from yesterday morning's&nbsp
column5: Fall baseball to afternoon housework and errands, I mentally planned out the evening meal with the understanding that Eldest would&nbsp
column6: attend the Homecoming Dance.&nbsp
column7: <em>Let's see:&nbsp
column8: that amount of&nbsp
column9: leftover chili takes an hour on the stove to heat up in that particular size pot and I have to also cut up apples for the microwave.&nbsp
column10: Another fifteen minutes in there for the tea to brew and it would be good to eat about one to two hours ahead of departure for the dance at 6:50.&nbsp

column1: As 5:45 rolled around and I called children and the spouse to the table, Eldest yelled back that she couldn't come because of having to curl her hair
column2: I'd have to wait about fifteen or twenty minutes longer.&nbsp
column3: It might not seem like much, but it is frustrating to watch hot food on the table start to cool in that period.

column1: So I now have to factor the personal preparation needs of teens into the dining mix.
column2: When the kids are younger, they aren't concerned with their appearance and there are moments when you want to at least wear something even moderately appropriate for the table.&nbsp
column3: But I have forgotten that teens on the cusp on a major seasonal social event will extend their times significantly.&nbsp
column4: So the upshot will be that when I plan the evening meal on the day of an event, I'll have to speak with the child in advance to learn what she'll be doing and then factor that information into the planning.

column1: Because I really do want to preserve the family meals as much as possible.
column2: And if that takes some additional effort, then so be it.

Keeping up with regular flea treatments is a necessity for animals and my dropping the notes from the family calendar has led to a flea infestation
column2: that has taken over my life.&nbsp
column3: Because it's been years since we've had issues with vermin of any kind, I've had to remind myself that treating any kind of infestation requires disciplined persistence.

column1: Fleas have a lifespan of about 90 days and the typical female flea can lay upwards of twenty eggs each day.
column2: However, most fleas aren't on the animals
column3: they'll be found in the household surroundings such as carpets, bedding and furniture.&nbsp
column4: What's stunning to see is the jumping ability of the adult flea.&nbsp
column5: During a vacuum session last week, I noted that one leaped ahead of the vacuum and it appeared to reach a height of a foot about the floor.&nbsp
column6: This would be akin to watching LeBron James leap over Madison Square Garden.

column1: Understand that it will require assiduous effort to get rid of the problem.
column2: There are several steps that I've taken to remedy things.
Ours were each given a single tablet of a flea killer called Capstar, which will have a rapid effect on the fleas as it spreads through the animal's system and poisons the fleas.
column3: This kills off the fleas that can lay eggs and the medication lasts long enough that any newly hatched fleas will be killed as they bite the animal.

column1: <li>Removal of any and all stuffed animals.&nbsp
column2: In this instance, I've bagged them for a month so that any hatching fleas will starve.

column1: <li>Daily vacuuming of the carpets and rugs.&nbsp
column2: That includes moving furniture since cats and small dogs can move&nbsp
column3: almost everywhere and the flea can wind up&nbsp
column4: almost anywhere in the carpet.

column2: vacuum from the house so that the fleas don't&nbsp
column3: crawl out of the bag and back into the carpets.&nbsp
column4: Seriously.&nbsp
column5: It was&nbsp
column6: recommended by&nbsp
column7: our vet that we toss every vacuum bag, but&nbsp
column8: the cost is prohibitive so we keep the vacuum in the garage unless we are using it.

column2: Siphotrol, available at the vets and reapplied in two
column3: weeks.&nbsp
column4: Note that the animals&nbsp
column5: have to be placed in separate areas and the house vacated for several hours due to the odor.

column1: <li>Renewing the schedule for the flea medication on&nbsp
column2: each animal so that the&nbsp
column3: issue doesn't happen again.

column2:
And with the kids always watching, when they're old enough, they'll learn that the responsibility for an animal extends beyond feeding them and playing with them.

As kids age and grow, you want to help them move from naive innocence to a more measured awareness of the world around them.
column2: And especially about the people that inhabit it.&nbsp
column3: Which is why I persistently try to develop their common sense by asking:&nbsp
column4: <em>Now think, does that pass the common sense test?&nbsp
column5: Does that make sense?

column2: My definition has been that it's the ability to think through situations and examine problems in a manner that is both rational and realistic.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: Bear in mind that my own youth was spent talking office politics at the dinnertable with a&nbsp
column6: father who a co-worker later described as having &quot
column7: the ability to slit a guy's throat two weeks before he even knew that it was&nbsp
column8: slit.&quot
column10: So I'm aware that I am a skeptic and need to protect my kids from veering into full-blown cynicism.&nbsp
column11: Yet they also need to learn how to consider what they&nbsp

column1: When do the common sense questions apply?
column2: Surprisingly, more often than you might think.

column1: <li>In reviewing the answers to math problems.&nbsp
column2: <em>Okay, you have that answer.&nbsp
column3: But does it make sense that the answer to that addition problem is less than one of the two addends?

column1: <li>In considering the answers to history and social studies questions.&nbsp
column2: <em>If you heard a recording of one of FDR's Fireside Chats in class,&nbsp
column3: does it make sense that he delivered the Gettysburg Address?

column1: <li>As occurred in my house this morning, <em>if using gasoline engines less helps the environment,&nbsp
column2: does it make sense that&nbsp
column3: riding a dirtbike falls into the same transportation alternative as walking?

column1: <li>So Kelly was bragging of her family's money and that she owns a pair of $725 shoes.&nbsp
column2: &nbsp
column3: <em>Think about what your shoes cost, does it make sense that&nbsp
column4: a parent
column5: does it&nbsp
column6: make sense that a parent would spend that much money on shoes for an adolescent girl who's still growing?&nbsp
column7: &nbsp

column2: Swine Flu (H1N1)?&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: <em>Who&nbsp
column5: told you this?&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Before&nbsp
column8: you panic, was George tested to be positive or could this be the&nbsp
column10: Does it make sense that a classmate would know this firsthand?

column1: The upshot of this is that you have to pay attention to the kids' comments and conversations.
column2: As much as I would love to walk into the mancave, the reality is that a large part of parenting and fatherhood means that I have to listen to what the kids are saying, reading, listening to, watching and doing.
column3: And I then have to apply my own common sense test to determine whether I need to address it further.&nbsp
column4: The next question is how much time I have to spend on the issue and whether to handle it in the moment or set aside time later.

column1: I then have to work to assure that I am consistent in how I ask the question.
column2: Kids learn much through repetition and hearing the question in the same format will help cement it into their thinking.

column1: It's a time-consuming process and often frustrating.
column2:
But without the time spent in pushing the common sense questions, they'll be at a disadvantage in critical thinking at a time when it's more desperately needed than ever.

Kids grow faster than you realize and before you know it, they've gone from watching the Hannah Montana show to asking to see R rated movies.
column2: And while I normally toe the line on ratings - no, you can't see that since it's rated R and you're thirteen - tonight was the occasion that I crossed that threshold with Eldest.

column1: Eldest is closer to seventeen than thirteen and was asking to go see Paranormal Activity.
column2: She honestly didn't expect to go but I surprised her by purchasing two adult tickets on Fandango to assure that we had seats for that showing
column3: a good thing since the show was sold out.&nbsp
column4: I started to write that there were multiple reasons for taking her, but the simple reality is that we both like horror movies and I wanted to enjoy her company for the evening.&nbsp

column1: Besides that however, is the understanding that some things are first time events - the first glass of wine with dinner at home and
column2: the first driving lesson,&nbsp
column3: for example - and it's a bit more special if you can share those moments.&nbsp
column4: In my world, taking a child to their first R rated movie is a threshold.&nbsp
column5: But before doing that however, I did the research so that our evening together wouldn't be uncomfortable.&nbsp
column6: My criteria was that there would be no sexual scenes and no drug glorification, <em>a la Cheech and Chong.&nbsp
column7: The research is worth the effort if you can have a memorable evening together, tailored to your common interests.

column1: And besides, it was a great Halloween flick that she'll talk about for years.

So consider those first-time moments to share with the kids, but only after doing the research first.

216,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Like most families, I'm the partner responsible for the typical Autumn duties, such as covering the air conditioning unit and winterizing the house.
column2: But I'm also responsible for other duties that most fathers typically don't cover.&nbsp
column3: You could call these &quot
column4: winterizing the kids&quot
column5: since they pertain to clothing and other issues and they're as common in our household as checking the smoke detector batteries when the clocks change.

column1: <li>Pull all of the winter coats and assure that each child has a winter coat - with hood if possible.&nbsp
column2: I wait on this until October since coats tend to be more expensive and my concern is that a sudden Autumn growth spurt will render a coat unwearable if it's bought too early.

column1: <li>Pull the winter boots and assure that each child has a pair that fits.&nbsp
column2: Because most stores only buy a set amount of boots, you don't want to wait too long into the season
column3: waiting too long might mean a harder time trying to find a decent pair later on.&nbsp
column4: If you do buy boots for one or more of the kids, be sure to make it a bit larger than the actual shoe size, by perhaps half of a size.

column1: <li>Pull the hat and glove bin to assure that they have what they need and whether too-small items can go to Goodwill.&nbsp
column2: I'll also&nbsp
column3: wash the items&nbsp
column4: for the season.

column1: <li>Think about the Christmas pictures, if you have them taken.&nbsp
column2: Most studios are starting to fill the appointment books and you should be prepared.&nbsp
column3: Making the appointment also means that you have to arrange for haircuts in advance of the photos and assure that the kids have appropriate clothing to wear.&nbsp
column4: In our case, I'll be making the hair appointments for a week in advance of the photos and will ascertain whether I need to get clothing.

column1: <li>Pay attention to the summer clothing since some stores will have clearance sales on remaining summer clothing.&nbsp
column2: Consider whether you can get a good deal on summer clothing in the next size up and store it for the winter.

column1: • If you haven't done so, pursue the flu vaccinations for the kids so that their bodies have had an opportunity to build immunity when the seasonal flu arrives in December and January.
And after all of that is finished, sit down with a hot cider and enjoy the change of seasons.

My three major concerns in enforcing discipline are immediate response, enforceability, and consistency.
column2: But another question that occurs is whether clemency is ever advisable.&nbsp
column3: Does giving a reprieve create more issues?

column1: Another child - a friend of my own kid -
column2: returned home after dark after having a mechanical problem with his bike.&nbsp
column3: He erred in assuming that his elder sibling would pass his whereabouts to the parents, who were briefly away.&nbsp
column4: The father's response was to ground him as a reminder that it's&nbsp
column5: <em>his&nbsp
column6: responsibility to inform them of his plan and then obtain permission.
column7: I've done the same thing when one or more of my own have failed to inform or show up late.

column1: But Murphy's Law can crop up when the grounding occurs within a short time of an event that is particularly important to the child.
column2: In this instance, my son had invited this boy and others to a Halloween Scary Movie night.&nbsp
column3: What might Dad do?&nbsp
column4: Should he grant clemency?

column1: What are some of the considerations on whether to provide clemency?
<li><em>What did the child do to deserve discipline?&nbsp
column2: Is it recurring?&nbsp
column3: This occurrence was a failure to think and not being "
column4: bad&quot
column5: , and is a rarity for the child.&nbsp
column6: Dad's discipline wasn't meant to be punitive as much as to force the child to understand that there are consequences for (in)actions
column7: and not keeping Dad apprised of his whereabouts is meaningful.

column1: • How is the child handling the discipline?
column2: If the kid whines and creates an issue about the discipline, do you want to grant clemency?&nbsp
column3: Or will doing so encourage future whining and general nastiness?&nbsp
column4: Kids have to learn that they will encounter unpleasant situations in life and that whining can make it worse.&nbsp
column5: As one father said, his pastor referred to it as learning to &quot
column6: suffer well&quot
column7: .&nbsp
column8: I agree, although we refer to it as &quot

column1: <li><em>Does the child ask for the reprieve and if so, how does he handle it?&nbsp
column2: Kids have to learn how to speak without whining and if he can manage to actually carry on a conversation, then there's possible merit in rewarding that effort.
column3: Frustration and emotion are difficult to control and the effort should at least be noted, even if you deny the request.

column1: <li><em>What's the nature of the upcoming occasion?&nbsp
column2: Does it involve other kids or people with whom he should associate?
column3: You don't have to say I don't approve of this guy, but allowing him to attend after finding out who else is involved sends a powerful message.
column4: Is it a one-time occasion that won't come again?&nbsp
column5: My father gave me a reprieve to attend my junior year homecoming dance.&nbsp
column6: And then it was back into the doghouse.

column2: Will he use this as a reminder or excuse to demand further clemencies?
column3: Not everyone will use this occasion as a tool for future demands and some kids will respect the deal.
column4: You might want to consider if it's going to haunt you in the future.

column1: Kids and situations can be so variable that there isn't always going to be a right decision.
column2:
But asking these questions can help with the thought process as you consider the situation.

I believe that children want - more than anything - to spend time with their parents.
column2: And since Dad is typically involved with play, they want time with you.&nbsp
column3: Stuff is nice, but they'd rather have your undivided attention.

column1: When each of my children was born, I made a promise to that infant that I wouldn't buy her or him a lot of stuff.
column2: Requests for things would largely be met with No.
column3: However, I would give unstintingly of my time, since that is what is what I - as a cancer survivor - find most precious.&nbsp
column4: I have managed to live up to that promise for years but I now find that the press of life with three children and schedules leaves little time for what we took for granted in earlier years.&nbsp
column5: Requests by Youngest for gametime, wrestling or reading a book are increasingly met by refusal because of other commitments.&nbsp
column6: And last night I considered what I'd read with the older kids, and played with them, that I haven't done with Youngest.

column1: So I'm considering something different for a Christmas gift this year.
Instead of figuring out all of the presents that a kid should get, I would make my time my primary gift to each.
column2: Each would&nbsp
column3: receive a printed coupon book with each coupon claiming time for a different activity - movie nights, reading hours, wrestling matches and the like.&nbsp
column4: It won't be as cheap as you might expect since some of the activities will require tickets or evening &quot
column5: dates&quot
column6: for dinner out.&nbsp
column7: Yes, there will still be wrapped presents under the tree but each will reclaim time from me that has become lost in the shuffle of daily life.

Even after dealing with the illnesses and injuries of three kids over fifteen years, I'm never certain if a cut of any kind requires only a simple bandaid/gauze pad or actual stitches.
column2: And Youngest today cemented his family title of Stitch King with an injury that initially scared the hell out of me:
column3: an inch long laceration under the left eye.&nbsp
column4: And it begged the question of whether or not he needed stitches or just some antibiotic cream and a gauze pad over the eye.

column1: Stitches, also called sutures, are simply used to assure that the edges of open wounds are held together long enough to permit the skin to heal itself.
column2: The principle is the same as stitching fabric together, except that in time, skin can heal over an open wound.&nbsp
column3: With the edges held together closely enough, the wound is also provided further protection again an infection and scarring is&nbsp
column4: minimized.

column1: In this instance, Youngest was in the side yard tossing a piece of PVC pipe in the air like a baton when an end landed on his face.
column2: Because the pipe had been cut, the striking edge of the pipe was rough and caused a laceration of about one inch below the left eye.&nbsp
column3: Most specifically, the crease where the cheek meets the pouch of skin beneath the eye.&nbsp
column4: He came around to where I was cutting bushes with his hand covering the eye and my stomach turned when I saw the wound.

column1: Physicians use several criteria for deciding whether to use stitches or not.
<li>The amount of blood emanating from the wound isn't necessarily an indicator of stitches.&nbsp
column2: In this instance, Youngest had very little blood loss, especially since many wounds around the face and head can bleed heavily.

column1: <li>Are the skin edges of the wound so far apart that they can't be easily pinched together?&nbsp
column2: Youngest's wound looked like a typical laceration in that there was an obvious cut but the wound wasn't gaping.

column1: <li>Can you see the deeper layers of flesh - called subcutaneous - beneath the top layer of the skin itself?&nbsp
column2: When I dabbed the wound with a clean, wet washcloth, I saw that the top edges of skin were peeled slightly back so that I could see deeper layers of tissue despite the narrowness of the wound.

column1: <li>Is the location of the wound such that scarring&nbsp
column2: might be an issue?&nbsp
column3: A physician might be&nbsp
column4: more likely to suture a wound in&nbsp
column5: the face or&nbsp
column6: other visible area&nbsp
column7: to minimize scarring.&nbsp
column8: Youngest&nbsp
column9: can't avoid the coming shiner and sutures, but&nbsp

column2: wound located where there's a lot of body movement?&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: A&nbsp
column6: similar gash on the knee would certainly require stitches simply because the constant stress of skin movement&nbsp
column7: at the injury site would&nbsp
column8: delay healing because of&nbsp
column9: persistent stress on the wound edges.&nbsp

column2: visibility of the&nbsp
column3: subcutaneous tissue and&nbsp
column4: our desire to minimize facial scarring led the ED physician to use six stitches to close the wound.&nbsp

Schools have grasped technology and enabled today's parents to keep far better tabs on school progress than any previous generation.
column2: But does using these tools&nbsp
column3: mean that I am a helicopter parent?&nbsp
column4: It's an issue with which I wrestle since I'm aware that Dad isn't always going to be there when they're adults.&nbsp
column5: And&nbsp
column6: this morning I opened the paper to a column by Betsy Hart, who's thinking about how much she should follow the schoolwork.
column7: On one level, I agree with her opinion that we should let the kids learn from their mistakes.&nbsp
column8: But&nbsp
column10: doesn't necessarily help a kid learn&nbsp

column1: Her situation was different in that her child is in the third grade and the principal was discussing upcoming advance placement tests, which I find amazing for the elementary school level.
column2: Parents were advised so that they could assist the kids in preparing.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: My elementary equivalent has been a reminder that standardized testing is approaching so be sure that Junior gets good food and plenty of sleep.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: But starting at the middle school level, any parent or guardian can both obtain the child's homework assignments and follow the grade progression on a daily basis.&nbsp
column7: I've used it intermittently through the years but now follow it more closely.

column1: Kids do need to learn from mistakes and some of my best lessons were from time management screw-ups.
column2: But these were lessons gained in a generation that was less scheduled and with more parents at home.

column1: Children are born with no framework for anything in life and part of our job as parents is to help them build those different structures.
column2: This is no different for time management and organization than any other skill set.&nbsp
column3: But not all children are created equal in talents and some require greater attention than their siblings or other peers.&nbsp
column4: This is compounded by the growing brain's re-wiring itself as it moves towards adulthood.&nbsp
column5: Attention will wander and assignments will repeatedly be copied wrong in planners.&nbsp
column6: Failing to&nbsp
column7: monitor schoolwork&nbsp
column8: can lead to greater heartache for the kid who's foundering because intelligence is hampered by a lack of organizational skills
column9: the reality is that a trait of some gifted and creative kids is a fundamental tendency towards disorganization.

column1: With each of our kids, we started in early elementary school to walk through the backpack and take-home folders to see what had to be done.
column2: The repeated routine of doing so helps create the structure that enables them to handle their responsibilities as they age and permits us to step back.&nbsp
column3: And our continued surveillance - yes, that's the appropriate word - of schoolwork lets us assess how they're doing and whether there are indicators of other issues.&nbsp
column4: But since all children aren't equal in these skills, we've adapted the level of involvement to each child.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: This ranges from what's the homework look like tonight? to let's sit down with the planner and the site.

column1: But as I write this, perhaps the best route is to continue going through the planner but keep the school website information
column2: to myself.&nbsp
column3: And let the kid take the occasional hit&nbsp
column4: when&nbsp
column5: the two&nbsp
column6: don't jibe.&nbsp
column7: Experience isn't always the best teacher, but it is some of the time.

221,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Why start a Fatherhood website with any number of excellent Fatherhood websites - Fatherville, MrDad, RebelDad
column2: - are already out there?&nbsp
column3: What can possibly be added to the conversation?&nbsp
column4: And why call it PracticalDad?

column1: The articles on PracticalDad are generally a hands-on approach to the situations and circumstances that confront many fathers who take an active role in childrearing and the household.
column2: This focus is deliberate because I believe that the American family structure, as well as our society, is in the midst of significant change.&nbsp
column3: And much of that change will both involve and affect the American father.

column1: Although much of this change is economy-driven, there was prior evidence that the father's role in the family was changing.
column2: A 2008 study by <a title=""Oriel Sullivan and Scott Coltrane"" href=""http://www.contemporaryfamilies.org/subtemplate.php?t=briefingPapers&amp
column3: ext=menshousework"">Oriel Sullivan and Scott Coltrane
column4: noted that fathers were spending double the time on housework and triple the time on childcare as they were in 1965.&nbsp
column5: Women still spend more time on these functions than their mates, but the levels had dropped with the slack taken up by the men.&nbsp
column6: More men, some of whom were from divorced families, were stepping up to assure that their own children and families had the presence that they had missed.

column1: Now comes the economic downturn that some wags are referring to as a mancession.
column2: The term emanates from the startling statistic that in multiple months of layoffs, fully 70% of job losses were suffered by men
column3: the recession had a much larger impact on the male-dominated construction and industrial sectors than on the predominantly female health and service sectors.&nbsp
column4: So hundreds of thousands of men - many of whom are fathers - are back home while their mates become full-time breadwinners.&nbsp
column5: A further upshot of the recession is that the woman's average income has risen at a rate disproportionate to that of the average man.&nbsp
column6: While the man's income is still higher, the woman is catching up and will reach parity at some point.&nbsp
column7: This isn't a whining complaint, just acknowledging reality.

column1: The simple truth is that the American economy is in a decline and will not return in any form that resembles what we've known in our time.
column2: The persistent transfer of our manufacturing jobs to lower-cost nations coupled with massive overbuilding in residential and commercial structures have eliminated any significant near-term recovery in these areas.&nbsp
column3: Mass higher-paying jobs for men - akin to the auto plants and steel mills of our industrial glory days -&nbsp
column4: are only a dream in the coming America.

column2: So where does that leave the American father?&nbsp
column3: In training for another job, a period that could last several years.&nbsp
column4: Hitting the road in search of employment to support the family at home.&nbsp
column5: Or back at home with the kids until the economic ship&nbsp
column6: somehow finally rights itself.&nbsp
column7: In any case, the typical father&nbsp
column8: is - like I was - probably unprepared and asking the eternal question:&nbsp
column9: What in the hell do I do now?

column1: PracticalDad describes the viewpoint of someone who cares more about what works and makes sense in today's world than any particular parenting philosophy.
column2: A PracticalDad only knows that the kids are the first priority.&nbsp
column3: They have to be cared for, loved and raised and&nbsp
column4: the old fatherhood models for doing so really don't apply to his situation anymore.&nbsp
column5: So he'll observe and adapt, understanding that so long as the kids are properly covered, there can be any number of ways to make it happen.

Even when your kids follow through on all of the right precautions, a virus can make it through and this morning, Middle awoke complaining of feeling feverish.
column2: So what to do?&nbsp

column1: <li>Obviously, take his temperature and sure enough, he has a fever high enough to call for ibuprofen to help control it.&nbsp
column2: Bear in mind that for most people, their body temperature is lowest when they arise and if sick, will rise appreciably throughout the day.

column1: <li>Because taking ibuprofen on an empty stomach can cause nausea, assure first that he isn't nauseated.&nbsp
column2: Then prepare dry toast and make sure that it's eaten so that there's some bland food in the stomach before the ibuprofen is given.

column1: <li>Provide a large cup of apple juice/water mix for him to drink and keep it filled through the morning.&nbsp
column2: Keeping him hydrated is essential.

column1: <li>Immediately pull the disinfectant wipes and start wiping down all of the bathroom handles and surfaces before the other kids arise.&nbsp
column2: Wiping down with disinfectant might seem like closing the barn door after the horse is out, but I may as well make the effort.

column1: • Then take the disinfectant wipes to other household surfaces, especially electronic remotes, telephones and door and faucet handles.
• Banish him to his room to sleep and periodically check on him.
Now I have to settle in for the long haul as these cases can last for days.
column2: That also suggests that I have to start looking at the calendar and if necessary, make changes in what's scheduled.

column1: Please note that this is not intended as medical advice.
column2: If you have concerns or questions, contact your pediatrician or family physician.

223,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There are any number of factors in the increasing number of obese children:
column2: lack of exercise
column3: excessive snacking
column4: poor choice of foods for meals.&nbsp
column5: But large food portions are a large portion of the problem.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Experts and writers point to&nbsp
column8: fast-food restaurants but the reality is that the issue also occurs in the home.&nbsp
column9: And fathers, still new to the family management role, tend to overdo the food portions fed to the kids.

column2: have to be taught just about everything and much of that learning is absorbed through watching and repetition.&nbsp
column3: You won't be able to lecture them on finding the right sizes - God knows I've tried that - but you can teach them by making sure that they repeatedly see the right thing being done.&nbsp
column4: If kids consistently note roughly the same amounts on their plate, then they'll be set to take the appropriate amounts as they age.&nbsp
column5: They might still overdo it, but they'll at least understand that what's presently on the plate really is too much when you remind them.

column1: First, remember that they aren't adults and
column2: don't&nbsp
column3: require&nbsp
column4: the same amount as you.&nbsp
column5: Their plate might appear sparse to you, but it's fine for their age and size and they aren't going to go hungry.

column1: The portion sizes for children will vary by their ages, which means that you may have to do some additional mental gymnastics when feeding kids of different ages.
column2: In the PracticalDad household, that means feeding two teenagers and an elementary schooler, so be prepared for grousing when the younger ones have less on their plate.&nbsp
column3: The following chart is adapted from one provided by Kaiser Permanente.

column2: Kids are sick or have colic, schedules change and activities intrude, and there are meals that won't come close to what's recommended for nutritional requirements.
column3: But the goal is assure that the kids have the necessary foods for the large majority of meals.

column1: It's simple to get the right portion size for children who are still on baby foods and cereal but that changes when they start to eat the same things that are on your plate.
column2: So how can you find the right portion size?

column1: <li>Use a small scale or measuring cups to measure appropriate amounts.&nbsp
column2: This can continue until you are comfortable that you can reasonably estimate the right amount visually.&nbsp
column3: That said, you should consider occasionally still using them just to check yourself.

column2: For instance, an adult serving of meat is four ounces which is comparable to a piece of meat about the size of your palm.&nbsp
column3: A one ounce piece of meat would consequently be a quarter of the size of your palm.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, a serving of peanut butter (a protein) is about one level tablespoon.&nbsp
column5: A good reference article for portion sizes can be found at Meals Matter.

column1: <li>If things are too chaotic in the moment, just consider what you would find appropriate and then cut it by one-half to two-thirds.&nbsp
column2: Trust me, it's not a perfect approach but there will be meals like that.

column1: The upshot of all of this is that meals require planning and forethought that goes beyond deciding what foods to serve.
column2: You have to leave yourself sufficient time to prepare and then be ready to leave your own food while you tend to the kids.

column1: And don't let them load you with guilt because you or older sibling has more on the plate.

column2: www.permanente.net/kaiser/pdf/40863.pdf

Sitting here and making a mess of multi-tasking, mixing up food preparation and notes on upcoming articles, I wandered to the pantry.
column2: Like many other households, ours is filled and we prefer to keep it that way.&nbsp
column3: But why do so many of us prefer it that way?

column1: The fully stocked pantry for many families is a learned behavior that was picked up from parents, who in turn got it from their parents and their grandparents.
column2: And where did that generation learn that behavior?&nbsp
column3: From the Great Depression.

column1: Supermarkets are a product of the 1920s, pioneered by firms such as the Great Atlantic &
column2: Pacific Company (A&amp
column3: P).&nbsp
column4: With a rising middle class and the start of sprawl away from the cities, supermarkets were a successor to the corner grocery that had served generations of Americans.&nbsp
column5: Buying habits began to change during this period as improvements in food storage and household appliances meant that food could be stored longer with fewer trips to the grocery that had marked the lives of those previous generations.&nbsp
column6: But the major change occurred after the onset of the Depression.

column1: Job losses ripped through the economy and income dropped disastrously.
column2: Those without jobs rapidly spent their savings and those still with jobs - only 75% of the wage-earning public - shut down spending to everything but the absolute necessities.&nbsp
column3: And the parents began to contend with the concept that their jobs could be next.
column4: Adults saw that their jobless friends were running out of food and with kids and a roof to provide, began to stock up on the food necessities to carry them as far as possible should they lose their jobs.&nbsp
column5: Note that in some cities, existing charities estimated that fully more than 70% of the schoolchildren were malnourished.

column1: These children - our grandparents - remembered the hunger and poverty.
column2: If they didn't suffer, they certainly knew someone who did and when they became adults, they changed their shopping habits to assure that there y would be food in the event of a lost job.&nbsp

column1: That behavior was passed along to our parents, who've in turn passed it along to us.
column2: But without the lessons of the Great Depression, what foods are in our pantries should we lose our jobs?

Junior wants that Goosebumps book that Freddy Merkle brought on the bus.
column3: But Freddy's in fourth grade and Junior's in second, so how can&nbsp
column4: I tell if he's ready for&nbsp
column5: <em>Goosebumps:&nbsp
column6: Welcome to Dead House?
column7: &nbsp
column8: I don't have to guess, since there are several ways to determine if a book is at his reading level.

column1: Once kids get into school, it can be more difficult to find an appropriate level book since they can
column2: develop reading skills&nbsp
column3: faster than you expect.&nbsp
column4: The first place to start is to simply nose through the book bag and see what&nbsp
column5: he's bringing home from the school library.&nbsp
column6: Teachers and school librarians do keep an eye on how the child is doing and will nudge him to something that's at or near their reading level.&nbsp
column7: I once encountered a school librarian who permitted my then-first grader to check out an adult dictionary, but that one&nbsp
column8: was an outlier on the&nbsp

column2: I'm not clear from the backpack, I can check with the teacher on the current grade reading level.&nbsp
column3: Autumn is a great time as many schools are scheduling the Parent-Teacher Conferences and one of the items discussed will be the assessment of Junior's reading level.&nbsp
column4: Is he at grade level or above or below it?&nbsp
column5: And about where on the grade level does he reside?&nbsp
column6: The baseline for a child at the start of the&nbsp
column7: second grade&nbsp
column8: year is that he's reading at grade level 2.0 or 20.
column9: As Junior grows in his skills, his level is expected to grow to levels such as 2.4 and 2.8 so that he's at Reading Level 2.9 by the end of the school year.

column1: After you know his Reading Level, you can actually consider the book.
column2: &nbsp
column3: Unless I'm already familiar with the author, I prefer physically getting a book&nbsp
column4: from a library or bookstore so that I can quickly peruse it.&nbsp
column5: Since Junior asked for Welcome to Dead House, I pick up a copy and
column6: turn to the back cover.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: Children's publishers will place&nbsp
column14: Reading Level (RL) and an age range for prospective readers.&nbsp
column23: The publisher is telling me that this book is on a fourth grade entry level
column24: since kids don't always read at grade level, most kids from ages eight through twelve years would appreciate it.&nbsp
column25: Since Junior's at a reading level of 2.4, the book would most likely end up collecting dust for a year until Junior could handle it.

column1: But what if there's no information on the back cover?
column2: Then the best alternative - Christmas secrecy aside - is to select a random paragraph from the book and ask Junior to read it aloud.&nbsp
column3: If he has difficulty with five or more words, then&nbsp
column4: I need&nbsp
column5: to steer him to something at a lower level.&nbsp

column1: Remember that there's a difference between the Reading Level and the scary content.
column2: &nbsp
column3:
I'd rather wait and not contend with any nightmares.
