column1: To a father of three, the word is as frightening as orthodontist.
Like many parents, my wife and I wonder how we're going to help our children cover the cost.
column2: We're aware that the economic reality is that the college sheepskin is worth more than the high school diploma.&nbsp
column3: We see the marketing push for our impressionable teen:&nbsp
column4: <em>Eldest, you're the kind of student that we're looking for!&nbsp
column5: Did you see our rankings in Barrons/US News/Princeton Review?&nbsp
column6: Don't you deserve to be here for all of your hard work?&nbsp
column7: Our graduates routinely earn entry salaries of $X, move onwards to advanced degrees and are positioned as the nation's leaders of tomorrow!&nbsp
column8: We want the best for them and see them live a full and productive life and a good education is key to that.

column1: We also question the current model, especially when we read that more than 20 private college presidents earned an annual salary of $1 million.
column2: Many of these institutions have an annual cost in the mid five figures.&nbsp
column3: We understand the opposing reality in that there's no pension and our goal is not to spend our dotage in Eldest's basement.&nbsp
column4: So there's real guilt when I have to buck the prevailing wisdom and fight the college marketing machine to talk frankly to the kids.

column1: This morning was another chapter in the ongoing conversation about reality versus the college machine.
column2: What points did we cover?

column1: <li>I've spent considerable time discussing money and economics with the kids and this conversation was about bankruptcy.&nbsp
column2: Eldest is familiar since we've discussed the concept and procedure before and she understands that debt can be mitigated or cleared in the process.&nbsp
column3: We talked about the fact that <strong><em>student loans from the government - the principal source of college financing - were not forgiven or affected by a person's bankruptcy.&nbsp
column4: In fact, they'll follow the borrower like stink on a skunk until paid in full or the borrower dies.

column1: <li>Does the institution have to be top-tiered and have a name?&nbsp
column2: Indeed, do the first years even have to be at the institution at which you graduate?&nbsp
column3: Hell, I graduated from one of the nation's top liberal arts universities and look what I'm doing.&nbsp
column4: If the name matters, perhaps a better route is to save the money and transfer in for the remaining two years.

column1: <li>Does the degree justify the post-college debt load?&nbsp
column2: Suppose two people are attending similarly priced private universities.&nbsp
column3: One plans to be a chemical engineer and the other a historian.&nbsp
column4: They graduate with similar debt loads.&nbsp
column5: Are the job/income prospects of the two able to support the respective debt payments?&nbsp
column6: Remember that what doesn't go to the debt could instead go to&nbsp
column7: caring for your own family or retirement.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: Because I was talking to a teenager, I also mentioned better wheels, nicer apartment and upscale electronics.

column1: This is as far as time and attention allowed, but it will be repeated.
column2: And then repeated again.&nbsp
column3: I hate to have the conversation, but the cost of not doing so is too high.

column2: For a good extended handling of real-life college financing and college options, I would suggest The Truth About Money
column3: by Ric Edelman.&nbsp
column4: When I first read his book, my eldest was a toddler and I read it with intellectual interest.&nbsp
column5: Now that she's a teen, I've reread it and found it&nbsp
column6: worth the time, even&nbsp
column7: twelve years later.&nbsp

column2:
twelve years later.

I have a friend - a mother - who runs marathons.
column2: And throughout the course, there are water stations so that she can get a quick refresher for the next leg.&nbsp
column3: This is a great metaphor for raising a family.

column1: Raising children is a marathon and each child is a slightly different course.
column2: Most have a mix of up- and downhills
column3: a few are strictly uphill and a rare number are downhill.&nbsp
column4: And that's why you have to grab the watercup whenever and wherever you can since you have to be able to finish the race.

column1: Hobbies are helpful, or some activity that takes you away for a short while.
column2: But you have to stay on that course for the duration even when you're worn down by the constant questions, occasional idiocy and sometimes raging egocentrism of the typical kid.

column1: <li>Carried a screaming child like a sack of potatoes from a grocery store?&nbsp
column2: Check.

column1: <li>Walked into my room and punched out the dresser?&nbsp
column2: Check.

column1: <li>Said goodbye to my wife as she pulled into the driveway while I pulled out?&nbsp
column2: Check.

column1: <li>Announced to the family that I was resigning?&nbsp
column2: Check.

column1: <li>Yelled at one or more children, rightfully?&nbsp
column2: Check.
Check.

column1: You'll have paternal side-stitches and parental shin-splints from the run.
column2: But after your water, you have to stay on the course.&nbsp

column1: The absolute greatest gift that you can give your child is your time, and I believe that most children would rather have time with their father than any thing.
column2: So you're going to have to understand that the egocentrism is part of their young nature and must be balanced by your own selflessness
column3: your rules will be tested because that's what they do
column4: you'll be questioned continuously, and be glad if they do because you can be relatively certain that the answer's correct.&nbsp

column2: So have the hobby but don't let it have you.&nbsp
column3: You can always take classes later, read that bestseller or catch that movie on DVD.&nbsp
column4: Remember that you cannot regain the time lost with that child.&nbsp
column5: There is only this one opportunity to raise this child well and there are no mulligans or do-overs.&nbsp
column6: You cannot turn the clock back to when they were toddlers or primary graders.&nbsp
column7: This is the marathon, so grab the cup but stay in the race.&nbsp
column8:
You cannot run this course again.

How much should a parent make the child follow the news?
column2: I typically don't, but tonight will be the exception as I discuss the stunning 32% University of California tuition hikes at the dinner table.

column1: California is in the throes of near-bankruptcy and a projected 2010 deficit of $21 billion is leading to both draconian cuts and unsustainable cost hikes.
column2: Given the situation, the University of California Board of Regents today announced that starting next year, there will be a 32% tuition hike for the approximately 175,000 students scattered at campuses across the state.&nbsp
column3: The response?&nbsp
column4: After what I can only surmise as stunned amazement, a number of students rioted.

column1: California might be described as being at the far end of the Bell Curve in terms of budgetary woes, but there are many other states in a similar situation.
column2: Virginia, South Carolina, Michigan, and the list goes on.&nbsp
column3: They are just experiencing now what I anticipate other states will have to endure although their tuition hikes will probably not be as bad.&nbsp
column4: The problem is simply that there isn't enough real wealth to support all of the promised programs - education, law enforcement, social service network, transportation - that states manage.
column5: There's a great deal of paper wealth, but not enough productive assets to support the structure.

column1: From news sources and bloggers, I'm aware that the UC system has dramatically cut back on services and construction, and eliminated staff via layoff and furlough.
column2: But the cost structure to support a system constructed during times of plenty is too great to be controlled solely by contracting services.&nbsp
column3: So the students will take a substantial hit and I don't expect that it will be the last.&nbsp
column4: The system will contract painfully until it can reach a new equilibrium where the services provided can be supported by the state and its students.&nbsp

column1: So Eldest - and Middle, who's more aware of news than his elder sibling - will hear about the California college riot.
column2: And the point of this is that colleges have to pay for the classes and services that they offer and they will do what they must to survive.&nbsp
column3: So the questions once again:&nbsp
column4: <em>How much will college cost?&nbsp
column5: What's the final debt load?&nbsp
column6: Is this supportable?

column1: We refer to our colleges and schools as alma maters.
column2: The crucial difference is that real mothers love you back.

One of the first ways that families cut back on discretionary spending is by cutting the restaurant fare and cooking more at home.
column2: Indeed, restaurants have taken taken major hits in this recession
column3: with almost two full years of declining patron traffic.

column2: Meal preparation gets easier and cheaper when cooking for a larger number of people, but fixing meals for a family with children is complicated by a mix of factors.&nbsp
column3: Some are a function of kids and others are outside the family, but all have to be taken into account to make the dollar stretch as far as possible.

column1: • Obviously, the number and age of your children.
• Family food preferences, such as my Eldest being a vegetarian.

column2: family meal&quot

column1:
Over the next several days, I'll explore these aspects further, starting as always with the kids.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

230,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Of the multiple factors that affect feeding the family, the kids rank up there with money in terms of impact.
column2: Both how many kids you have and their ages.

column1: There's no difficulty whatsoever when the child is an infant and not yet graduated to real food.
column2: It's when that happens that the challenge starts.&nbsp
column3: The earliest eaters are learning to eat solid foods
column4: that are limited in variety to ascertain if food allergies exist, so they're generally easy to fix.&nbsp
column5: At the same time, the small children are near the end of their days and hence more prone to being cranky and needing additional attention - and grace.&nbsp
column6: If you are pressed for time, consider shortening the preparation time by having their meals pre-made on microwaveable dishes and ready to go immediately.&nbsp
column7: Be certain that the food is warm instead of hot before you serve it out of the microwave as small children are more sensitive to food temperature.

column1: Having a family meal is not innate to children as they'll frequently want to bolt to play and television afterwards
column2: it's&nbsp
column3: an experience that children learn from their parents through countless repetition.&nbsp
column4: If you are feeding the kids before you yourself eat, try to take the time to sit with them while they eat and engage them.&nbsp
column5: Talk to them about their day and listen to what the say, even if only for a brief period so that they learn the experience.

column1: As kids age and move beyond the toddler stage, it does become easier as you're no longer fixing multiple simultaneous meals and the bedtimes are pushed farther back, allowing a greater meal window.
column2: The kids are&nbsp
column3: also not as worn out as when they were toddlers.&nbsp
column4: That said, you then have to work out the routine of checking the backpacks to ascertain what homework has to happen.

column1: So what can you do to ease the situation, especially if you work?
• Have the kids preset the table for the next meal after it's been cleaned from the evening meal, which cuts the next day's work considerably.
<li>Choose to fix meals that are largely premade and ready to eat when you arrive home.&nbsp
column2: This would include crockpot cooking that occurs before you leave in the morning.

column1: • Cook in bulk during the weekend and refrigerate portion-sized servings to place in the microwave upon return in the evening.
The unfortunate reality is that there's no simple - and inexpensive - way to prepare family meals without taking enough time to make it work.
column2:
But the time spent can make the evening family meal something that helps cement the family despite the rush and rigors of everyday life.

231,"1","1",,"xhtml","

If you pay attention to what the teens - and tweens - are saying, you can learn some interesting games that they play amongst themselves.
column2: They're a fascinating and sometimes disturbing example of the teen mind, adrift somewhere between childhood and adulthood.&nbsp
column3: And before you react, just take the time to ask and engage them before rendering a value judgment.&nbsp
column4: These three particular games range from goofy to existential to simply base, a distressing concept when you realize that your kids are playing along with everybody else.

column2: Yellow Car&quot

column1: This goofy game requires observation and is great for passing time while traveling.
column2: The first person to call out &quot
column3: yellow car&quot
column4: when they see one receives one point.&nbsp
column5: Likewise, calling out for a boat lands a point.&nbsp
column6: But calling out for a cemetary is the big win:&nbsp
column7: the caller gets ten points and everyone else loses ten points.&nbsp
column8: If you listen, the arguments pertain to such questions as whether a jet-ski constitutes a boat or is a taxi disqualified from the competition?&nbsp

column2: yellow car!&quot
column3: while alone.

column2: The Game&quot
This game is the oddest one yet.&nbsp
column3: There is but one rule and that is that you can't think of the game.&nbsp
column4: When you think of it, you lose.&nbsp
column5: It's puzzling to walk around near teens and see one of them suddenly smack himself in the forehead with the palm of his hand and mutter dammit, I lost!
column6: Eldest has exclaimed that she's lost the game on multiple occasions and each is noted by a comment exclaiming her loss.

column2: Marry, Dump or Bang&quot

column1: A group game, this is one in which a participant has the floor and has to answer others' questions about whether he or she would
column2: marry, bang or dump a particular person called out by the group.
column3: This can include people within the playing group or not present.&nbsp

column1: As a father, it's distressing to find that your own kids have been present at playtime amongst their peers.
column2: Forbidding their participation is as useful as baying at the moon so I have to content myself with using it as a departure point for further conversation
column3: and that it's important to&nbsp
column4: add a moral element
column5: to the game.&nbsp
column6: <em>Did it bother you that this kid viewed you in such a manner?&nbsp
column7: How would you feel if someone made it clear that she wanted only to dump you?&nbsp
column8: Forbidding participation won't work since I've found that this game has occurred amongst teens - and tweens - by themselves even during church-sponsored events.

column2: what's going on around you.&nbsp
column3: And&nbsp
column4:
if you hear something odd, just ask what it is they're saying and prepare for an experience.

You can always save money by cooking at home, but the best results come from taking the time to plan what you'll prepare.
column2: And as the kids grow, you'll have to account for the multiple activities that consume the afternoons and evenings.&nbsp
column3: This is especially important if you want to preserve some time for a family meal where everyone can connect and recount the day.

column2: As always, with the family calendar.
column3: Make it a habit to review it routinely when you plan the meals so that you have a handle on an evening's window of opportunity for eating
column4: as you accumulate children, you also accumulate the activities that come with them.&nbsp
column5: You might want to consider choosing a Friday evening/Saturday morning if you prepare and refrigerate meals over the weekend so that you can get to the store for the food that you'll require for the cooking.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp

column1: Another factor to consider when you plan
column2: is the length of time required to pull the meal together on any particular night.&nbsp
column3: Even if there are no activities that evening, the demand of small children after a long day&nbsp
column4: will cut into your available time.&nbsp
column5: Is this something that is microwaveable in a few minutes or will it take a bit longer in the oven for reheating?&nbsp
column6: If you truly only have twenty minutes - and with three kids, we've had as little as fifteen minutes on the rare night - then consider using the crockpot so that you can just ladle the contents quickly and move on.&nbsp
column7: The crockpot is&nbsp
column8: advantageous in that larger sizes can hold sufficient contents for further nights
column9: and experienced cooks will attest to the improved flavor as the various ingredients further meld together over the ensuing night.&nbsp
column10: Crockpot meals - are you seeing a trend here? - also allow the freedom to prepare the ingredients an evening ahead so they can simply be added the following morning.&nbsp
column11: The dirty preparation dishes and utensils can be put into the dishwasher before you walk out the door.

column1: The important things about a family meal aren't the quantity or presentation on the table.
column2: What's important are&nbsp
column3: the discussions with the children, the teaching of the table manners necessary for the larger world and the food's nutrition.&nbsp
column4: The differences between&nbsp
column5: the PracticalDad&nbsp
column6: evening dinner table and that of Happy Days' Cunningham family are that mine isn't typically as elaborate and I look lousy in a skirt.
column7:
It's okay to serve soup and a sandwich with vegetables if that's what is necessary to make things work in the alloted time.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column2: Several years ago, I was talking to another parent whose three kids were several years older than mine and I remarked that it must be nice to have kids that were older and didn't require the supervision needed by younger children.&nbsp
column3: Her response?&nbsp
column4: That pressure's gone but it's been replaced by a different kind of pressure now.

column1: The teenage years are ones in which the teen body resembles Dick Van Dyke playing a one-man band in Mary Poppins.
column2: There's frenetic activity galore as the drums boom, cymbals crash, horns toot,&nbsp
column3: elbows and knees plunge in random directions and the brain rewires itself.&nbsp
column4: And estrogen and testosterone bubble&nbsp
column5: as frothily as a recently tapped keg.&nbsp
column6: With such a panoply of random energy and activity, the result is sometimes brutal as kids knock into one anothers' bodies and emotions, eliciting sarcastic, catty and nasty remarks.&nbsp
column7: And when I speak up, the sarcasm and attitude are pointed in my direction.&nbsp
column8: So I respond.&nbsp
column9: Because for me, gritting the teeth simply means that I don't bite them, not that I don't call them for the mouth.

column1:
Then I remember that I have as many teen years ahead of me as I had toddler years.

A large part of saving money by cooking at home comes from controlling the food costs, and that is largely a function of smart grocery shopping.
column2: Walking into the store with a list and good intentions isn't smart shopping.

column1: <li>Remembering that the food menu on which you decide drives the shopping choices and not vice-versa.&nbsp
column2: Many families develop a stable of proven recipes, supplemented by the periodic I thought that I'd try something different, so here goes meal.
column3: This stable is based upon the food preferences, dietary requirements and ease of preparation.&nbsp
column4: You might think that it's cheaper to purchase only the sales items, but this is more likely to lead to impulse sales and the need for repeated visits to obtain the supplemental items that you might not have when it's time to prepare the meal.

column2: stores aren't created equal and different stores have&nbsp
column3: their own&nbsp
column4: strengths and specialties.&nbsp
column5: One store might be great for meats but have a poor selection of produce.&nbsp
column6: Others are affiliated with a generic store brand that you find superior to other store brands.&nbsp
column7: You have to decide if the trade-off between money saved and shopping time is worth the additional activity.

column1: <li>Know the various stores' hours and whether&nbsp
column2: their sales cycles run during the same period of time.&nbsp
column3: For example, two of the major local grocery stores run sales from Sunday to Saturday while two other decent stores run their sales from Wednesday to Tuesday.&nbsp
column4: If you really want to maximize the cost savings and are willing to go to different stores, you need to look at all of the sales circulars when they're in effect.&nbsp
column5: In my case, I have to review them when they're all effective, which would be Wednesday.&nbsp
column6: If time is an issue, then you have to decide whether the potential savings are worth the time invested.

column1: • Review the circulars against the coupons that you have available.

column2: &nbsp
column3: Remember that the&nbsp
column4: product placement in a grocery store is a work of&nbsp
column5: marketing art designed to separate you from&nbsp
column6: your dollar.&nbsp
column7: They will&nbsp
column8: push for the impulse dollar and you have to steel yourself to stick with the shopping list, developed from the&nbsp

column1: Much of this finally comes down to preparation, both in planning and in cooking.
column2: The savings are out there but they aren't just going to happen.

235,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Most fathers understand that they have to have behavioral boundaries with the children.
column2: We understand that the kids will mimic us and learn the cues for what is and isn't appropriate behavior.&nbsp
column3: It's simpler when they're young:&nbsp
column4: No cussing or sexual humor
column5: minimal or no violence on television
column6: decent treatment of other people
column7: good self-control, especially in terms of tobacco and alcohol, and absolutely no drugs.&nbsp
column8: But as they age, the lines blur and I have to reconsider what's appropriate versus still inappropriate.

column1: This weekend was a case in point.
column2: I've watched Saturday Night Live since it's inception, although I can go for long periods without if the cast is poor.
column3: The cast for the past several seasons has been decent so I watch regularly.&nbsp
column4: Now that Eldest is in high school, she's beginning to watch with me and it can provoke decent conversation.&nbsp
column5: But&nbsp
column6: I have to reconsider what's appropriate when the skit pertains to an ESPN women's sporting event sponsored by Vagisil.&nbsp
column7: So, do I turn it off or let it play through to the next skit and Weekend Update?
column8: What is my criteria for appropriateness in the future?

column1: <li>Is it a behavior or activity that in any way causes a sense of emotional or mental discomfort?&nbsp
column2: I'll still wrestle with the boys, but ceased doing so years ago with my daughter because it made me distinctly uncomfortable as her body was developing.&nbsp
column3: That also means that I have to listen and look for such signs from the kids, who might be uncomfortable saying something.

column1: <li>Does it promote an activity or lifestyle that I find unwholesome, unhealthy or immoral?&nbsp
column2: Wholesome is a word that's nowadays derided as hypocritical or, at best, incredibly naive.
column3: But the definition connotes something that helps to complete - or makes whole - a person.&nbsp
column4: Old Cheech and Chong skits were funny when I was younger but I can't bring myself to watch them now.

column1: <li>Does it blur the parental line so that I'm not so much&nbsp
column2: father as&nbsp
column3: peer?&nbsp
column4: My children need to remember that I'm still their father and my concern is that behaving too much as a peer undermines&nbsp
column5: that authority.&nbsp
column6: Kids are good at playing&nbsp
column7: Moral Battleship and blowing holes in the ships by pointing out inconsistencies in your own words and behavior.
column8: Why make it easier for them?

column2: Things are illegal for a reason and I've been frank that I won't permit them to own games such as Grand Theft Auto as it makes such a life appear acceptable and exciting.
column3: This is also why I made Middle turn off a youtube video of A Bag of Weed from Family Guy.
column4: My statement to his argument was that it promotes what is a gateway drug
column5: he doesn't know that I knew people who made more effort scoring a bag than a job.

column2: This is precisely why I won't watch many reality shows, which place people in situations that cause them to have to lower themselves to win.

column1: Every circumstance isn't always clear and will require conscious evaluation.
column2: But perhaps now I understand why my own father&nbsp
column3: opted to go to bed instead of&nbsp
column4:
watching SNL with me when I was a teenager.

","none",,"xhtml",,"none",,"xhtml"

column2: 'Tell me why?'

column1: 'I wear the chain I forged in life,' replied the Ghost.
column2: 'I made it link by link, and yard by yard
column3: I girded it on of my own free will, and of my own free will I wore it.&nbsp
column4: Is its pattern strange to you?'

column1: It's ironic and sad that, in this Christmas season, many Americans are bound by the legal chains of a mortgage.
column2: They girded it on of their own free will, before their house's equity fell to a level less than the loan's value or before they lost the income that paid for said loan.

column1: A common thread of many cases is that people believed the advertising which touted that you can buy your own home, implying that a residence can't be a home unless it's purchased.
column2: Even though the average American lives for six years in a&nbsp
column3: residence that they bought, purchase implies permanence, adulthood and financial success.
column4: Commercials created for the National Association of Realtors in this housing downturn state that it's never been a better time to buy your own home.
column5: Go to any residential builders' website - Ryan, Keystone, Lennar, Gemcraft, Ryland
column6: - and you'll find multiple references to the word home, but almost never the word house.

column1: While there are good reasons to own a house, thinking that purchase automatically makes it a home isn't one of them.
column2: In a society that prizes time management and quick gratification, we've forgotten that a home isn't a physical thing or place.&nbsp
column3: A home is a sense, a belief and a feeling.&nbsp
column4: It arises from our cumulative actions and attitudes instead of the workmanship of the carpenters and plumbers that completed the structure.&nbsp
column5: They simply provide the physical&nbsp
column6: structure from the elements but we take that structure and create a home in which to raise our children.&nbsp
column7: Homes are made, not built.

column1: Our country prizes property ownership, and rightfully so.
column2: But we've now staked our economy on how many own houses and the collective value of those houses.&nbsp
column3: The government and FIRE industries - Finance, Insurance, Real Estate - are promoting sales in order to keep the collective value of housing from falling further.&nbsp
column4: Further drops mean larger holes in the balance sheets of financial institutions that need to be plugged.&nbsp
column5: This recession and credit crisis are directly linked to the value of housing and programs such as the First Time Home Buyer Tax Credit are a clear effort to support the value of housing and save the financial system.&nbsp
column6: Their concern is the system and not the family
column7: the family is your concern.

column2: If you're a father and you and your mate are looking to buy a house, make sure that you think and aren't manipulated by the media.&nbsp
column3: Consider neighborhoods and schools.&nbsp
column4: Evaluate commuting distance and whatever other factors matter to you.&nbsp
column5: But all else being equal, don't think that a purchase agreement is automatically superior to a lease.&nbsp
column6: There are landlords who love a good tenant - we've had them - and will work with them as situations change and you only have to ask.&nbsp
column7: And if it doesn't work out, the costs are far less than having to contend with trying to sell a house and being stuck with the mortgage.

column1:
Because being chained to a house can destroy the home that you're trying to create.

For a guy who lives and dies by the calendar, December has been a mess.
The next year is approaching and I have to start listing the 2010 events on it, but the problem is dropping the December events.
column2: With all of the Christmas hoopla, I've not kept up with it and have been burned twice due to non-listing of events.&nbsp
column3: Damage?&nbsp
column4: Just some embarrassment.&nbsp
column5: So the job tomorrow is to get the 2010 calendar and then cull through December notes and get the present calendar updated.

column1:
The upshot is that I have to get back to weekly reviews of the calendar to assure that this doesn't happen again.

238,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Raising kids becomes more interesting as they age since they want to assert their independence with decisions and actions that can border on the insane.
column2: The question is, when to permit their efforts at independence and when to pick your battle
column3: and reassert your authority?

column1: Adolescence is that period between childhood and adulthood when the body undergoes puberty and grows, changing dramatically.
column2: Even after the body has ceased growing however, the brain is continuing to change and won't stop until later.&nbsp
column3: Several years ago, scientists revised the upper bound age of adolescence to twenty-five years&nbsp
column4: to reflect that&nbsp
column5: there are portions of the brain that are continuing to change until then.&nbsp
column6: Unfortunately, the last part of the brain to develop into maturity is that segment that controls&nbsp
column7: risk assessment and judgment.

column1: The choice is simple when they're young.
column2: Your working assumption is that they haven't got a clue and are going to have to do as you say.&nbsp
column3: But they grow and you have to decide when you think that they do have a clue and that alters the assumption accordingly.&nbsp
column4: You'd think after several years of school that they'd understand the meaning of cold weather or the danger of trying to learn unicycle-riding on a brick retaining wall.&nbsp
column5: But they don't.

column1: So what are my guidelines on deciding when to let them learn on their own, versus gearing up for an argument?
<li>Is there a reasonable chance of injury to themselves or others, such as tossing a lead pipe as a baton or riding on said retaining wall?&nbsp
column2: And by this, I mean significant injury beyond a cut or scrape.&nbsp
column3: There's a reason that kids aren't supposed to jump off at the swing's apogee or playing with fireworks.

column1: <li>Is the child going to do something that goes beyond embarrassing and make a royal ass of&nbsp
column2: himself - or you?&nbsp
column3: A little embarrassment can be a good objective lesson, but humiliation is something different and it's your responsibility to try to ascertain the difference.

column1: • Is there a risk of causing property damage, such as chucking rocks at a spot next to the car parked next door.
It's with these criteria that I entered the pre-Christmas weekend.
column2: After purchasing the past two trees from a local fire company, we traveled with friends to a Christmas Tree Farm to cut our own again.&nbsp
column3: It was snowing when we left and while the kids made good decisions on footwear - I now&nbsp
column4: know that Youngest had a spurt and needs another size snowboot - they argued on coats.&nbsp
column5: Tony Hawk jackets and hoodies are now cool for kids and despite having heavier coats that could be worn, one opted not to wear it.
column6: This was the time that we found that another had lost the heavy winter coat.&nbsp
column7: We decided not to force the coat issue and let the child wear the Autumn weight Hawk jacket to the farm as we chose and cut the Frasier Fir.
column8: The one who lost the coat would have to deal with it until it could be replaced.

column2: There was no likelihood that wearing a too-light jacket would violate any of the above criteria.&nbsp
column3: Yes, the kids could become cold but they had the option of getting back in the minivan if that happened.&nbsp
column4: And this was supposed to be a family event that they'd remember and carry with them.&nbsp
column5: And with two inches down and more falling, it was memorable
column6: why ruin that because they were making a bad choice?&nbsp
column7: As it was, they all stayed outside for the selection and cutting of the tree but at least one remarked that next year, they'd have to wear a heavier coat.

As they've grown, Eldest and Middle have learned that I've got a particularly dark sense of humor.
column2: I don't trot it out often, and certainly not in front of Youngest.&nbsp
an opportuntiy came about several months ago as Eldest was looking at a college scholarship website.&nbsp
column3: These sites are designed as databases for the thousands&nbsp
column4: of scholarships available and&nbsp
column5: the questionaire asks a wide variety to elicit enough information to best match the student to the available scholarships.&nbsp
column6: The questions however, are not only about the children but also about the parents.&nbsp
column7: <em>Did either parent serve in the Armed Services?&nbsp
column8: Does either belong to the Masons/Lions/Professional Circus Geeks?&nbsp
column9: Then the questions take a darker turn.
column11: Has either of the parents suffered a job loss?&nbsp
column13: These are valuable and understandable questions, helping to allocate a finite pool of funds to young people who might be in a tighter spot because of personal family difficulty.

column2: not proud to admit it, but reading the list of various questions led to the dark side.&nbsp
column3: I remarked to Eldest that perhaps one of the hopes would be that I&nbsp
column4: have a recurrence of cancer within the next year or that the best would be a tragedy trifecta of being hit by a bus while crossing the street with my seeing eye dog enroute to my chemo treatments.&nbsp
column5: It did generate a solid laugh but it's not one that I try for very often.

column2: First, concerns about how to meet the college funding challenge can cause a more emotional response than you expect.&nbsp
column3: These are your children and the hunt is on for a piece of the large - but still finite - scholarship pie.&nbsp
column4: Second, the criteria go beyond mere grades and merit.&nbsp
column5: Don't be surprised at the nature of the questions and try to keep perspective on the rationale behind them.

column1: And for the record, I really, really, really don't want to hit the trifecta.

Guys, be sure to thank your mate for everything they're doing to prepare for the Christmas holiday.
column2: If you're taking a major role, good for you since you have a good idea of what's involved in making things happen.

column1: Because of job constraints - a major increase in patient care responsibilities - my wife has had minimal time to do what she would like to do and PracticalDad has picked up the slack.
column2: That means that there have been no posts for over a week and a full day is planned here, consisting of:

column1: <li>Preparing a Chili dinner for pre-Christmas Eve services (done)
<li>Making a final grocery run for the forgotten celery for stuffing (done)
<li>Making a final run for a restaurant gift certificate (to do)
<li>Pre-cutting celery and onion for tomorrow's braising for stuffing (to do)
<li>Grating sweet potatoes for tomorrow's casserole (to do, and gee, do I have enough butter?)
• Having a beer as the kids spend the day with the grandparents.
If you've ever noticed your mother or mate getting a bit high-strung the day before, this stuff is the reason why.
column2: But the kids frequently don't notice the angst and what they'll remember as they age is the sense of home, family and whatever traditions that you've chosen to make part of the family life.&nbsp

column1: I hope that you have a wonderful Holiday season and despite the hoopla, remember that it really is about family.

I was watching television the other day and noted a Public Service Announcement from the President.
column2: His brief point was that it was imperative that fathers spend a few minutes with their kids each day in order to obtain almost incalculable benefits.&nbsp

column1: I absolutely agree that raising your kids is your most important job.
column2: But to be honest, I don't know what to make of this.

column1: Does he mean that fathers simply are ignoring the kids completely and losing themselves in their own activities?
column2: Or that there has to be concentrated one-on-one or one-on-several sessions in addition to the everyday household time?&nbsp
column3: Or is this some push for quality time
column4: to help cement paternal and family relationships?

column1: The simple truth is that raising your children to survive as productive and decent members of society is the greatest responsibility of any parent, father or mother.
column2: This doesn't come from trips or special occasions and celebrations, but from the everyday interactions that pass on values and beliefs.&nbsp
column3: Even if you're sharing custody, the time spent doesn't have to include trips to the park or movies.&nbsp
column4: It can simply be working in the kitchen or the yard, or chatting in the evening.&nbsp
column5: When you adopt this approach, then it no longer becomes a question of how much time was spent with them or trying to figure out how to stuff that additional few minutes into what appears to be a packed day.

column1: Trips to Disney or the beach are a wonderful time for a family.
column2: But those things are the icing on the cake.&nbsp
column3:
What goes into that cake are the simple ingredients that gather no special attention but really do make it a memorable thing.

The more time that you spend around kids, the more you learn.
column2: When the kids were younger, I realized that you can quantify the backseat nonsense on a trip.
column3: Now that my kids comprise the gamut from elementary to high school, I better understand the concept of the Space-Time Continuum.&nbsp

column1: According to the theory, we exist in dimensions that comprise not only the physical dimensions of space - height, width, depth - but also time.
column2: But I've realized that&nbsp
column3: this only applies to adults since&nbsp
column4: children and teens don't exist in the two until&nbsp
column5: they're&nbsp
column6: actually&nbsp
column7: adults.&nbsp
column8: Like with&nbsp

column2: exist first solely in the&nbsp
column3: dimension of time.&nbsp
column4: They&nbsp
column5: actually take up almost no space - you can easily fit eight children into a double closet - but require a considerable investment in time.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: <em>Can you tie my shoe?&nbsp
column8: No, the other way 'cuz the laces are&nbsp
column10: Will you watch a movie with me for the thirteenth time?&nbsp
column15: Daddy, he threw my bunny in the potty!&nbsp
column23: But I really need Wally NOW!
column24: Children will expand to occupy the time continuum and that is exponential to the number of children in the household.

column1: But that changes somewhere around the age of thirteen.
column2: It's as though the onset of puberty causes a mysterious shift as the structure of the time continuum collapses upon itself and the space demands blossom like an ebola virus in a closed monkey colony.&nbsp
column3: Teens have absolutely no concept of time.&nbsp
column4: They can pass hours engaged in electronic conversations filled with acronyms or watch the entire Hannah Montana weekend marathon without voluntarily shifting from the sofa.
column5: Oh, it's really Sunday night and there's school tomorrow?
column6: I've got a whole 'nother day so no problem on the Science Fair project, I'll get on it real soon.
column7: <em>Hey!&nbsp
column8: Why do I have to empty a trash can that's overflowing?&nbsp
column11: The space continuum not only pertains to their corporeal selves, but the items that they generate.
column13: Waste tissues with dried blood, mucus and/or acne residue.&nbsp
column14: Clothing that blooms from the fertile soil of the recently emptied hamper even though it appears already clean.&nbsp

column1: I prefer to work in the time continuum with the smaller ones and I really do miss that element.
column2: But the teens represent a greater challenge and I'll just have to risk a warp breech as I impose the time continuum on the spatial requirements of the elder siblings.&nbsp
column3: The results are sometimes a bit destructive.

We're not Amish.
&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column1: For those who try to control the household electronics, monitoring what's used and for how long presents the greatest struggle.
column2: This is especially the case with new electronic devices that enter the household.&nbsp
column3: In our case, an iPod Touch and a Nintendo DS, gifts that were given when Eldest and Middle reached a certain age in their teens.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: But when does it become&nbsp
column6: too much and how do I control it?&nbsp
column7: And yes, I consider it entirely appropriate to control the usage.

column1: I have never believed that it's alright to give
column2: kids unfettered access to electronics, whether it's computer, television or game system.&nbsp
column3: Apart from the typical concerns - desensitization to violence and lack of exercise - my&nbsp
column4: real worries&nbsp
column5: are the stifling of their creativity&nbsp
column6: and&nbsp
column7: critical thinking skills.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: It's these gifts and skills that will most enable them to survive as adults.&nbsp
column10: Middle would argue with me about how his friends all had this or that particular system, a TV in the room or their own laptop by the third grade.&nbsp
column11: This began to slack off after I laid out my concerns by asking if all of your friends spend the bulk of their time playing games, who's going to make the best living - the game user or the guy who spent the time learning how to think and develop the game?
column12: I was surprised when this particular point paid dividends.

column1: But still, we're not Amish and the kids should be able to play or experience the technology.
column2: So how much is too much and what can I do?&nbsp

column1: First, understand that there is no data that says that X hours on electronics is optimal and Y hours is harmful.
column2: You'll have to use your best judgment and choose a time.&nbsp
column3: Since most kids are spending about five hours on electronics outside of school, we decided that each child having two hours of screen time - whether television, computer or game system - should be sufficient.
column4: This ration increases on weekends.&nbsp
column5: And there are still individual variances.&nbsp
column6: Eldest spends more time than that on homework some days, so we give some allowance for free time since much of her homework is on the computer.&nbsp
column7: Likewise, another of the children gets snarly when told to turn off a game and we've had to learn that this child shouldn't have such unfettered time on a screen.

column1: Second, understand that there are some steps you can take to help control things.
column2: The most important is that screens stay in public areas so that use can be monitored and times controlled.&nbsp
column3: This becomes more difficult with the arrival of the portable devices such as the Touch or the DS, which can move from room to room.&nbsp
column4: This means that I have to be willing to check on things like a housebound Shore Patrol.&nbsp
column5: If you think that you should be able to keep the devices in a central location and to be used with your approval, then that would work as well.&nbsp
column6: Establish ground rules.&nbsp
column7: I've now told kids that there will be no electronics at any dinner table, ours or friends whose own kids text at the table.&nbsp
column8: Likewise, if you're talking to me, expect to put the device away for the duration of the conversation.&nbsp

column1: Third, it's alright to consider that you call the shots since it's your house.
column2: Kids will throw their friends in your face to provoke guilt, but there's nothing wrong with laying down clear rules and&nbsp
column3: sticking to them.&nbsp
column4: Your house isn't a democracy.

column1: Fourth - and this is my Achilles Heel - remember that kids have almost no sense of time.
column2: They probably aren't trying to push the envelope on screentime but have actually lost track of time.&nbsp
column3: Again, a timer would be a worthwhile tool.&nbsp
column4: And even if you have a timer, expect to wander the house to still close down screens.

column1: Fifth, take the time to ask about the device and even play with it to an extent.
column2: Many parents shy away from new technology, but this only lays the groundwork for further problems down the road.&nbsp
column3: I'm fortunate in that my mate is a bigger technophile than Eldest, so she can ride herd in that regard.&nbsp
column4: Still, the game cartridge and the Playlist provide some good information about the kids' interests and activities.&nbsp
column5: And that kind of information is what you'll need as they age and establish themselves outside of the house.

column2: one-off&quot
column3: issue that easily resolves.&nbsp
column4: It's going to require ongoing attention and considerable patience to make things stick.&nbsp
column5: Besides, it's a hoot when you can beat a kid at&nbsp
column6: his own game.

The more involved that you are with your kids, the more involved you'll be with their friends, the Opies.
column2: What are some things to remember when they're over to play?
Opie is short for Other Peoples' Kids, any child that isn't actually my own.
column3: I know their names and use them, but Opie is the generic term that I've come to use over the years.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, my own kids are someone else's Opies.

column1: Your child's earliest years will revolve around you and your mate but once they hit preschool, they'll meet other kids and want to play.
column2: This is natural and needs to be encouraged
column3: playing with their peers and developing friendships is critical for them.&nbsp
column4: This also means that there are going to be playtimes at your house and you need to be prepared because not all Opies are created equal.

column1: <li>How long is Opie going to stay?&nbsp
column2: Knowing this lets you know what else is going to be entailed:&nbsp
column3: nap?&nbsp
column4: snack?&nbsp
column5: electronic entertainment/play?&nbsp
column6: It may seem simple, but I had an early experience when the other parent didn't come back for hours because we misunderstood one another.

column2: While not widespread, some children have allergies to peanuts, milk or other foods.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, find out if there any allergies to any pets that you have or any fears of animals and be ready to lock them away for the duration.

column2: Opie is a toddler, is he still in training pants or&nbsp
column3: diapers?&nbsp
column4: For over a year after my kids were out of training pants, I&nbsp
column5: kept a stash of clean training pants in case a visiting&nbsp
column6: Opie needed one.

column2: very young, stay close&nbsp
column3: in order to keep an&nbsp
column4: eye on what's happening.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: When you get to know Opie and are more comfortable with her, then you can&nbsp
column7: give the kids some space out of sight.&nbsp
column8: I still kept it a&nbsp
column9: habit to check in on things as the&nbsp
column12: As a matter of fact, I&nbsp
column16: kids when they're in the basement with friends.

column2: &nbsp
column3: Some Opies, regardless of their age, will press the boundaries to see what's&nbsp
column4: acceptable and&nbsp
column5: what they can&nbsp
column6: frankly get away with.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: Apply the same rules that you have with your own kids and feel free to issue&nbsp
column14: get that bad, call the parent to pick Opie up.&nbsp
column17: not handling the issue only teaches the Opie that it's Open Season at your place and sends a strong negative message to your own kid.

column1: <li>Try to keep the electronics under control.&nbsp
column2: Just sitting in front of a screen isn't helping either child learn how to play and interact with one another.&nbsp
column3: My usual rule has been that any screen time happens later in the visit
column4: the kids have played together and perhaps they're needing a break from one another sooner than Opie's parent has planned to arrive.

column1: <li>When Opie's leaving, share any events or news with Opie's folks.&nbsp
column2: This is especially important when the kids are younger because parents do have to keep track of things like snacks and bowel movements.&nbsp
cautious as a father about informing the other parent if I've had to help Opie with wiping the bottom or cleaning up after an accident.&nbsp
column3: By cautious, I mean that I make it a point to tell the other parent so that they don't scratch their heads when Opie later makes some weird remark about PracticalDad seeing private parts or helping wipe.&nbsp
column4: This is a judgment call based upon several factors:&nbsp
column5: How well do I know the family?&nbsp
column6: How old is the child?&nbsp
column7: I've had the situation of watching a Kindergarten Opie for several hours and found that the child needed help wiping himself.&nbsp
column8: Because I didn't know the family very well and the age was older than what I would've expected, I told Opie's Dad at pickup about helping the boy.

column1: <li>Make it a point to chat with your own child afterwards.&nbsp
column2: The more your child is used to just chatting with you, the more likely they'll tell you things and you'll be amazed at what you learn.&nbsp
column3: This will diminish somewhat in the future, but what smaller children reveal is a goldmine for later items to discuss with them.

column1: Things will change as they age and by necessity, the ground rules.
column2:
But it'll be easier for you later if you become used to it earlier.

247,"1","1",,"xhtml","

You have to take care of the kids and
column2: you also have to shop for groceries.&nbsp
column3: And having to combine the two is unavoidable.&nbsp
column4: So what are some things to remember when you have to shop with small children?

column1: First, the experience starts before you even leave the house.
<li>Know when your kids are going to tire and when they take a nap.&nbsp
column2: Is this a trip that you can make in the time available or can it wait?&nbsp
column3: There's no sense in setting yourself and your child to publicly fail because Junior's going to hitting the nap-time wall in the canned vegetables section.&nbsp
column4: If you simply need some milk to carry you through until dinner, then you can stop at a convenience store and do the major shopping later.

column1: <li>Know what you're going to get and work from a list.&nbsp
column2: Children simply require a lot of attention and you're liable to become cranky having to bounce back and forth between Junior's questions and trying to figure out the label data.&nbsp
column3: Again, those issues can be handled at another time so just get what you need on the list.&nbsp

column1: <li>What can you take along in your pocket or bag to help distract or entertain Junior?&nbsp
column2: When she's starting to get antsy and spastic simply because she's three, you've got a better shot at managing the situation through distraction than correction and warning.&nbsp
column3: I kept a cheap toy cell phone in my pocket and would pull it out for Eldest and Middle when they started to fuss.&nbsp
column4: When that didn't work, I produced a ring of toy keys and sometimes managed to alternate them with the child throughout the store.&nbsp
column5: Remember, distraction is a great tool.

column1: Then things continue before you enter the store.
<li>Spend time talking with them en route and if they're old enough, remind them of some simple ground rules in the car.&nbsp
column2: Most small kids really do want to please you and will need to be reminded of the rules.

column1: • Remind them of the rules one last time before you enter the store.
<li>Try to remember to have some fun and keep your voice light.&nbsp
column2: I generally found that if I kept an upbeat manner, I was setting the tone for the excursion
column3: if I was irritable, I was more prone to have issues in the store.&nbsp
column4: Frankly, there were some days that I killed the shopping trip because I was in a foul mood and knew that things would spiral out of control.

column1: Keep things moving inside of the store.
<li>Talk to your child as you go throughout the store.&nbsp
column2: Actually, talk to your child a lot no matter where you are, but especially as you shop.&nbsp
column3: What colors do you see?&nbsp
column4: Can you help me find a can with the funny little Green Giant on it?&nbsp
column5: It does create more of a pinball effect as you're bouncing between shopping and childcare, but an engaged kid is far less likely to develop issues on the outing than one who's just hanging out in, on or near the cart.

column1: • I generally kept my distraction items away until Junior began to really fret and only produced them to distract and keep things under control.
<li>Sometimes, distraction simply isn't going to work and you'll have to act accordingly.&nbsp
column2: Remind your child of the rules periodically and if you have to remove a problem child for a period of time, do so.&nbsp
column3: People would much rather see a child removed than have to listen to a pissing contest between a misbehaving child and an irritable parent.&nbsp
column4: My rule of thumb was to remove the child for a timeout in the car instead of doing so in the store and inflicting the angst on everybody else.&nbsp
column5: As for the cart, I found that a brief word to an employee on the way out meant that the cart would still be there in a short while.&nbsp

column1: • That said, hit the frozen foods last so that items don't melt in the cart while you're disciplining Junior.
It doesn't end even after you leave the store.
<li>Praise Junior if he's done a decent job of behaving.&nbsp
column2: Note that a decent job of behaving isn't perfection, because he's a kid and he's going to be loud and occasionally rambunctious.&nbsp
column3: But decent behavior to me meant that he responded to correction and didn't create situations that required more extensive actions, like removing him from the store for a timeout.

column2: <em>What did you like best in there?&nbsp
column3: What did you see?&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: Many kids - if they're not too tired - enjoy getting out to see someplace that's bright and full of different things.
column6: Use the opportunity to teach and play with them.

column1: There is no perfect way to manage kids and I've had to haul kids out of the store like a sack of potatoes, but some preparation and understanding can keep it from becoming a routine nightmare.

248,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Even if you're a techno-saur, it's important to try to keep tabs on what the kids are finding popular on the web.
column2: In this particular case, Eldest shared a new iPod app for a site that she finds hilarious.&nbsp
column3: www.textsfromlastnight.com is an ongoing compendium of very recent text messages submitted by people who find them particularly humorous or interesting.
column4: It's popularity is noted by the banner promoting their new iPod app as well as the announcement that their new book will be issued next week.

column1: www.highDEAS.com is a site devoted to real-time entries made by those who are stoned.
column2: I came of age in the late 1970s/early 1980s and have too vivid recollections of stoner humor and commentary, so I find it tiresome and banal
column3: per Eldest, her friends find it humorous.

column1: So why do I try to keep tabs on these things?
• It gives me a snapshot of what's going on with the Youth Culture and what my own child, now a teen, is seeing and what she knows.
<li>It presents me with the opportunity to evaluate what I need to speak about.&nbsp
column2: When the kids become teenagers, your authority is still existant on some issues, but much of it derives from moral authority.&nbsp
column3: If we want to raise children who can handle the world, then&nbsp
column4: we have to accept that there are things with which they will come into contact and&nbsp
column5: the best hope comes from knowing what's out there and speaking to it.&nbsp
column6: Talking without sermonising is a difficult thing, but the attempts have to be made.

column1: <li>If my child wants to share this with me, I will try to accept the experience and not create barriers to future offerings.&nbsp
column2: There are certainly exceptions, as with vulgarities and violence, but I otherwise try to keep my surprise in check.

column1: What will I try to use as talking points with Eldest in the next several days?
<li>That unlike conversation, electronic texting is permanent and is liable to end up in the unlikeliest and most uncomfortable places.&nbsp
column2: Be thoughtful with your posts.

column1: <li>That there is nothing glamorous or especially hilarious about stoner humor, and that marijuana is indeed a gateway drug for many people.&nbsp
column2: In keeping with the first point, do you want posterity - or your parents - to read you when you're stoned?

column1: We will come back to these conversations in the next several days and I'll make every effort to remember the difference between injecting a moral tone
column2: and sermonizing.

249,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The U.S. Census Bureau recently reported that the number of women who are primary breadwinners is rising, thanks in large part to the recession.
column2: The recently ended recession so badly whacked the manufacturing and construction sectors - providing predominantly male-oriented jobs - that one economist dubbed it a mancession, a term that's taken root.
column3: But is this purely an economic change or one driven by sociology?

column2: Because if it's economics-driven, then the figures should drop as the recovery takes hold and men return to the labor force.&nbsp
column3: If it's a sociologic change, then the trend will continue albeit at a lesser pace.&nbsp

column2: There's been a discernible shift in the past fifteen years, the time that I've been home with the kids.&nbsp
column3: A 2008 study found that fathers were spending more time on childcare and housework than in the past, regardless of whether they were at home full-time or working.
column4: I can also anecdotally note this simply in the manner in which I - and my choice as a stay-at-home father - have been accepted over the years.&nbsp
column5: When I first stayed home, most mothers tended to avoid my children and I at the park when they realized that I was the one at home.&nbsp
column6: I was isolated for some time until developing a network of friends - mothers and fathers - through our church and preschool.&nbsp
column7: Until then. there were moments comical in retrospect
column8: situations reminiscent of Animal House's Larry Kroger and Kent Dorfman journey to the primo Omega House during Rush Week and being steered through to join the likes of Mohammed, Jagdish, Sidney and Clayton.
column9: There's still a very occasional kidding - <em>do you macrame? -&nbsp
column10: but people appear to be far more comfortable than they were before and the isolation is long gone.

column1: But the economics reinforce the sociologic aspect and will probably continue to do so.
column2: Like the 2001 recession, I anticipate that this is going to be a jobless recovery especially in regards to the manufacturing and construction sectors.&nbsp
column3: The US is still a manufacturing leader, but we've shipped millions of jobs overseas to much cheaper locales and these won't be returning unless our own labor costs drop significantly or multinational corporations remember their civic loyalties.&nbsp
column4: The former is a long-term likelihood and the latter is...well, don't hold your breath.&nbsp
column5: The construction sector is hampered by an inventory glut of residential and commercial properties as well as a debt-burdened consumer.&nbsp
column6: Neither is set for a comeback in the foreseeable future and if things stall further, then the fathers and the families are in for a real sea-change.

column1: Regardless of the cause, more men will continue to take a greater role in the family's life, caring for children and managing the household.
column2: Some will do this because they were forced home and others simply because they see their mate working longer and harder.&nbsp
column3: Both groups will come through with a greater understanding of what's involved than what they might have&nbsp
column4: had otherwise.&nbsp
column5: And as the economic factors play out in the distant future, there will be what University of Michigan sociologist Pamela Smock refers to as a move in the &quot
column6: ...direction of egalitarian roles.&quot

The more involved you are in something, the more that your perspective changes.
column2: Especially in regards to what you find important.&nbsp
column3: In this instance, what's important is keeping the housework that's generated by three kids, a dog and three cats to a minimum.&nbsp

column1: Case in point is my returning home from an errand and noting a toy jutting out from under the family room sofa.
column2: There's no material that obscures the area under the sofa so that I could see another toy further back when I reached down to get the first item.&nbsp
column3: I put my hand further under the furniture and as I moved it towards the back, felt a jagged pain as a protruding spring gashed my right hand open.&nbsp
column4: The laceration was like a bible school song - deep and wide - and it bled freely.

column1: And my first thought was, blood's gonna ruin this carpet!
column2: So to save the carpet while getting up and running to the kitchen sink, I raised my arm in a symbolic oath of loyalty to the carpet and let the blood flow down my arm and into my leather jacket sleeve.
column3: It's easier to clean a leather jacket than to have to try to remove copious blood stains from carpet
column4: and the blood only stained the inside of the sleeve so that it really doesn't show anyway.

column1:
And that's one less thing to worry about with a stitched and bandaged hand.

There's no doubt that your child benefits from reading with you.
column2: Her vocabulary improves.&nbsp
column3: Her speech improves as she takes in tone, cadence and pronounciation.&nbsp
column4: She's better able to focus and follow extended thought processes.&nbsp
column5: Her memory improves, especially if you periodically ask questions about what was just read.

column1: She looks forward to spending time with you in a shared activity that strengthens the father-child bond.

column2: But when?

column1: I don't know that I've ever seen a final answer on the age at which to stop reading together.
column2: But my sense is that the transition to fully self-reading from read-to occurs in the second or third grade.&nbsp
column3: At this point, most of the books are chapter books and have the story and plot line that lead onwards to adult reading.&nbsp
column4: And some kids use this as an independence step, demonstrating that it's something that they can do just like the parents.&nbsp
column5: But others will want to continue reading a common book together even as they read their own books and that's something that should be encouraged, even if it does happen because the school requires a certain amount of free reading each night.

column1: I continued reading with Middle through the fourth grade and we polished off books like The Hobbit and Treasure Island.
column2: When he was in third grade and Eldest was in sixth, we spent the Thanksgiving/Christmas evenings walking through Dickens' <em>Christmas Carol.&nbsp
column3: He's now moved onwards to F. Paul Wilson and Ian Fleming while Eldest is cruising through Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy.
column4: Where I believe that I've slipped&nbsp
column5: is with Youngest, who's caught amid the hustle of a busy household and elder siblings.&nbsp
column6: He happily reads to himself and is working through a Whitman's child edition of The Invisible Man, but our reading together has lapsed because of the demands of the household.

column1: And that's something that I believe has to change.
column2: He's the youngest and the days that he'll be willing to do that instead of Nintendo and Baseball are numbered.

Sometimes you can find instruction in the oddest places and I've noted that Tony Soprano provides some valuable insights for fathers.
column2: Not in regards to the physical side since what he's got to offer is unacceptable.&nbsp
column3: However, he does have something beneficial ot say about getting someone's attention and compliance.

column1: Tony - and others like Don Vito Corleone - understand the value of leverage.
column2: Like the physics principle, leverage is used to multiply an existing force to provide the maximum output.&nbsp
column3: It's a tool that's used to overcome inertia and cause a motionless object to move
column4: the lever can be a simple block of wood or it can be far more sophisticated.

column1: My wife and I have occasionally disagreed about whether there are moments in child-rearing when it simply comes down to a contest of wills.
column2: I believe that while a parent shouldn't have to go head-to-head with the&nbsp
column3: youngster, there are moments when the child is simply going to have to knuckle under and do what he's been told.&nbsp
column4: And in these moments, when other means fail, it's helpful to know what leverage is available to insure that the child obeys.&nbsp
column5: It's not pleasant, but it is necessary.

column1: What is it that matters to the child?
column2: Is it a toy or an activity?&nbsp
column3: When you realize what it is and decide that you have to use it as a lever, there are several things to consider.

column1: <li>Is there another alternative to the situation?&nbsp
column2: If the item is a toy that provides quiet entertainment and you're looking at an event at which the kid's liable to be bored, are you creating later problems by removing what will help occupy him?

column1: • Has there been sufficient warning of what could be lost if he doesn't comply?
<li>Does the child truly understand what's at stake if he doesn't comply?&nbsp
column2: It does no good to make an offer he can't refuse if it's one that he can't understand.

column1: <li>Is the consequence commensurate with the situation?&nbsp
column2: If it's a privilege or toy, is it going to come back again or is it gone forever?

column1: <li>Will the child have the opportunity to earn it back afterwards?&nbsp
column2: Depending on the situation, we've sometimes allowed the possibility of earning it back.&nbsp
column3: Frankly however, it also depends on how torqued I am.

column1: Leverage isn't the be-all and end-all of disciplinary methods and it's not one that has to see the light of day every time the kids are out of control.
column2: But it is another tool that can go into your pocket for use when you deem it necessary.

Guys love action flicks with lots of blood and gore and taking care of kids will provide you with lots of that, so you have to be prepared.
column2: This doesn't mean that you have to garb for Level IV decontamination, but you should take a few basic precautions&nbsp
column3: if your kid is sick.

column1: One of your foremost defenses against catching what the kids bring home is to thoroughly wash your hands.
column2: After you leave the child's room, take a moment to wash your hands with soap and water or use hand sanitizer.&nbsp
column3: This will help prevent the spread of germs and cut down on your taking ill.&nbsp
column4: But something that you should also have available are disposable pairs of latex gloves.

column1: I'm prone to dry and cracked skin in the winter, which leaves my hands a mess
column2: pile on the typical scrapes and cuts and my hands are a waiting recepticle for infection.&nbsp
column3: When your child is sick with a stomach or intestinal virus, you're likely going to have to clean up body fluids in quantity and the mess is laden with germs and bacteria.&nbsp
column4: So I've taken to keeping disposable gloves in the house for those times that I am cleaning up such messes.&nbsp
column5: I pull out the gloves to address the situation at hand and then dispose of them in plastic grocery bags which I tie up and deposit in the trash.&nbsp
column6: I'll also use them when I clean the child's bathroom, wiping down the surfaces that I've had to disinfect.

column1: But remember that the gloves only come out when you're cleaning up because a sick child will be sick enough without feeling like a leper.
column2: So take care of the child and then break them out.

As more people strive to enter college in an effort to further their economic interests, the pressure is on for good grades.
column2: Good grades for better schools and good grades for more scholarship money.&nbsp
column3: But how far do we, as parents, go to foster the drive for good grades?&nbsp
column4: Do we go as far as paying for performance?

column1: My wife and I have opted to not pay for good grades.
column2: Our stance has been good grades are expected because that's just part of what they're supposed to do.&nbsp
column3: Their job is their schoolwork before anything else - activities, part-time job, volunteerism - and that's what has to take precedence.&nbsp

column1: We know others however, who've installed a pay-for-performance system, starting at the middle-school level.
column2: Their belief is that if good grades really do matter, then the student can best understand that by being rewarded for the extra work that is typically required to obtain the higher grade.&nbsp
column3: In this view, the prime motivator is financial, which translates into greater savings or buying power.&nbsp
column4: The additional argument is that this is a foretaste of the real world in which good performance is rewarded with greater income.&nbsp
column5: Additionally, it is positive reinforcement

column1: While I understand this rationale, I disagree with it.
column2: There are things that we have to do simply because they are what's required
column3: that includes doing our best in all facets, including grades and studies.&nbsp
column4: It is like the definition of character
column5: doing your best regardless of whether someone is watching or not.&nbsp
column6: It is also one of the hallmarks of parenting:&nbsp
column7: you can look at all of the arguments and pros/cons of a particular situation and adopt a stance that might appear to be outweighed by the other positions.&nbsp
column8: Simply because that's not who you are.

column1: So we'll continue to stress good grades and good effort.
column2: And the money for grades will wait.

I've been, and continue to be, an Electronics Nazi.
column2: Yet I still have to constantly fight and re-evaluate the use of electronics in the household.
column3: This isn't going to change but I've become aware of an additional problem with the electronics:&nbsp
column4: multi-tasking.&nbsp
column5: I admire people who can multi-task.&nbsp
column6: My wife and her best friend are queens of the skill, but does that carryover to the use of electronics?

column1: We have one family computer that remains in the family room, open to viewing by all.
column2: Both my wife and I have laptops for ourselves, but we only permit the kids to utilize them if the family PC isn't working.&nbsp
column3: If it's working, then the kids just have to share and wait their turn and they generally do well with that situation.&nbsp
column4: But what happens when the kid spends time multi-tasking the electronics?&nbsp
column5: Does the television need to be run while the kid listens to iTunes, texts their friends while sending IM messages to another batch?&nbsp
column6: How much is too much?&nbsp
column7: That's the source of my present concern.

column1: Certainly, I've tossed the kid off of the computer while multi-tasking.
column2: If there's homework, turn off the IM and cellphone and get the job done so that the PC is available to others.&nbsp
column3: If there's no homework and you're just messing around, then get off of the PC and let someone else use it while you content yourself with texting and music.&nbsp
column4: But what if there's no other demand for the machine?

column1: I have two concerns about this, even though I have nothing to substantiate them.
column2: The first is that the multi-tasking will have an impact upon the critical thinking skills.&nbsp
column3: Yes, the child can handle two simultaneous conversations amongst multiple persons, but what's the quality of those conversations?&nbsp
column4: It's akin to saying that I can juggle and ride a unicycle simultaneously, but I can't handle more than two balls.&nbsp
column5: Will the children develop thinking skills that permit them to penetrate to deeper understanding of an issue or situation?&nbsp

column2: I was raised to be able to speak well, but with the notion that good manners required that I actually pay attention to someone with whom I was conversing.&nbsp
column3: Flitting back and forth amongst two different conversations was actually rude and indicated to the other person that he wasn't really worth my time.&nbsp
column4: Indeed, I once walked out of a date when the woman refused to turn off her television and contended that she was perfectly capable of paying attention to our conversation while simultaneously watching The Dukes of Hazzard.
column5: Sorry, but I'm not coming over to share you with John Schneider, Tom Wopat and Boss Hogg.&nbsp
column6: If the kids believe that they can skip blithely back and forth on the screen, why can't they do it in real-time?&nbsp

column2:
Yet.
