While fewer are eating at restaurants, it's still a nice change from the kitchen table.
column2: But it isn't so nice when the little ones are carrying on and drawing nasty glances from other diners and the restaurant staff.&nbsp
column3: But what can you do to teach good restaurant behavior so that it again becomes a pleasure worthy of the money being spent?

column2: understand that it&nbsp
column3: - like almost everything else with a small child - is a learned behavior.&nbsp
column4: The typical child is utterly egocentric and wants to run roughshod while having fun and having to behave at a table while waiting for food is simply a bore.&nbsp
column5: So she is going to have to learn and that's going to take time, effort and consistency.&nbsp
column6: That being the case, be sure that the training takes place at a restaurant that is neither fast-food nor haute cuisine.&nbsp
column7: The child needs to learn to use even a rudimentary menu and also wait for service.

column1: Second, be clear about what you're trying to teach.
column2: Most kids are finicky eaters and the intent isn't to expose them to different foods.&nbsp
column3: Your intent is to teach and reinforce a series of behaviors that will later permit trying different foods without the stress.&nbsp
column4: If Mac and cheese makes her&nbsp
column5: happy now, that's fine.&nbsp
column6: Also know that good behavior isn't going to be perfect behavior.

column1: Third, remember that this is going to be a process.
column2: Expect that you're going to have to step out of the restaurant to correct repetitive misbehaviors until she learns.

column1: <li>Set your child up for success by thinking ahead.&nbsp
column2: Most people go out for dinner during what is the witching hour
column3: for children, that time of day when they're wearing out even if they've had a nap.&nbsp
column4: If she's appearing overly tired, then consider shelving the dinner for another night.&nbsp

column1: <li>Think about what restaurant serves the purpose.&nbsp
column2: Consider a local family restaurant or a chain restaurant&nbsp
column3: with decent lighting and a children's menu.

column1: <li>Throw some crayons and notepaper in your pocket to occupy her in the event that the restaurant doesn't have diversions of their own to offer.&nbsp
column2: Learning to sit and wait doesn't mean that she can't be quietly occupied.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, you have to be ready to spend time interacting with her and not just ignoring her.

column1: <li>Clearly talk about what you expect before you enter the restaurant and also talk about what happens if there are problems.&nbsp
<li>Be prepared to routinely take her out of the restaurant for brief walks if things drag on.&nbsp
column2: This isn't the same as disciplining her, but just giving her a brief break from the wait.&nbsp
column3: She needs to learn how to be patient and wait, but you&nbsp
column4: have to also remember that she's a small child with a finite capacity.&nbsp
column5: I routinely took the kids for brief strolls outside when they&nbsp
column6: began to appear near their limit and these brief breaks helped control their behavior.

column2: she becomes disruptive, warn her&nbsp
column3: clearly about the consequences.&nbsp
column4: Once, twice or three times is entirely at your discretion but remember that warnings without enforcement
column5: can lead to a sense that you aren't serious.

column2: doesn't heed the warnings, remove her from the restaurant.&nbsp
column3: I'd take my kids to the car where I'd strap them in the carseat for several minutes while I waited outside the car.&nbsp
column4: They could scream, cry or sulk but they spent the time out of the restaurant and in the car.&nbsp
column5: After that interval, I'd talk to them, calm them and reinforce the rules before returning inside.&nbsp
column6: If necessary, I'd repeat the process although that rarely happened because they learned that if it did, there was no returning to the restaurant.

column1: <li>When the meal is finished, talk about the experience.&nbsp
column2: How was the food?&nbsp
column3: What did she&nbsp
column4: like best?&nbsp
column5: Would she&nbsp
column6: like to return there?&nbsp
column7: And part of the talk has to be praise for how well she
column8: did, provided that she&nbsp
column11: had to be removed, find a way to praise&nbsp
column12: her for how she did afterwards.&nbsp
column13: The more that she enjoys the experience, the likelier that she'll behave the next time around.

column1: It is a process and it does require work, because a child isn't an adult.
column2: But the effort and persistence are worth the effort when you find that you can take them to the nicer restaurants and actually enjoy the food, experience and&nbsp
column3: company.

I'm a firm believer - along with many others -
column2: that children gain much from having the family gather together regularly to sit down for family meals.&nbsp
column3: It's a topic that's been seriously researched and covered by&nbsp
column4: the mainstream media
column5: and multiple family advocate organizations.&nbsp
column6: Both my wife and I remember growing up in families that had family meals that could last for two hours as we hashed around school, family and societal issues.&nbsp
column7: But while everybody discusses the benefits and joys, what about the process that it takes to get to those benefits?

column1: Most of our memories are from a time that we can reliably and consistently recall, which is typically from the primary grades onwards.
column2: We have no recollection of the years before then and I doubt that many of us ask our own parents about those years.&nbsp
column3: The result is a repetitive cycle of frustration as each generation doubts and is forced to rediscover what their preceding generations learned.

column1: So what have I had to (re)learn about family meal times?
• Understand that family meals are learned events since children have to be taught almost everything.
column2: Those memories of family meals are the culmination of considerable effort and work to get you to the point that you knew rudimentary table manners, knew how to&nbsp
column3: sit for more than a few minutes, and could carry a reasonable conversation.

column1: <li>There are far more activities available to children today than when we were children, so our childhood family mealtimes weren't competing against sports, dance and theatre practices.&nbsp
column2: When we were teens perhaps, but not at as young an age as today.

column1: <li>Preparing a family meal requires some forethought when you have two or more small children.&nbsp
column2: It then becomes a function of when parents are able to make it&nbsp
column3: home from work as well as the body clocks of infants and toddlers, which aren't always the same.&nbsp
column4: On more than one occasion, the family meal didn't happen because one or more children was simply too tired to hold off until waiting until their mother made it home.&nbsp
column5: In that case, I had to eat with the child(ren).

column1: <li>Most small children don't have an innate ability to sit still, let alone carry a conversation.&nbsp
column2: Because of this, some of our meals - and conversation - &nbsp
column3: simply focused on the rudiments of eating:&nbsp
column4: working with the utensils and learning basic table manners.&nbsp

column2: mealtime shorter if&nbsp
column3: an adult's&nbsp
column4: frustration level is growing so that the kids don't come to view family meals as something to be endured or&nbsp
column5: feared.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Kids are perfectly capable of torquing you - by accident or on purpose - into all manner of unique and entertaining shapes.&nbsp
column8: It's sometimes the old &quot
column9: how far can I push him?&quot

column1: <li>As they grow, conversations have to be kid-friendly.&nbsp
column2: Many of our family discussions stem from just asking&nbsp
column3: what they did in school that day.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: Don't expect&nbsp
column6: younger kids to be able to engage in wide-ranging conversations since&nbsp
column7: all of them think that Plato comes in a small yellow can available&nbsp
column8: in the toy section at Walmart.&nbsp
column9: The discussions will change as the kids grow and are exposed to more.

column2: Even when we're in family mealtime hell with competing activities - Eldest has soccer, Middle has dance and Youngest has baseball - I try to take the opportunity to sit with them, singly or any combination.&nbsp
column3: The conversation might be minimal but the opportunity to talk has to be present.

column1: <li>Family meals are a family event, which means that while the parents have to bend to the necessities of childhood,&nbsp
column2: the kids should likewise&nbsp
column3: be expected&nbsp
column4: to rise to our level as they grow.&nbsp
column5: On more than one occasion, we've made one or more kids sit back down and at least listen as&nbsp
column6: another child or adult talks about their day.&nbsp
column7: The child doesn't have to like it but the message has to be clear that this is a shared event.&nbsp
column8: And there are&nbsp
column10: have to be discussed for the child to learn.

column1: The point to remember is that like everything else with raising children, this is a process and a marathon.
column2: When the children are very young, there may not even appear to be a light at the end of the tunnel.&nbsp
column3: But they will learn and there will be an increasing&nbsp
column4: number of&nbsp
column5: meals that&nbsp
column6: you can plug&nbsp
column7: into&nbsp
column8: your memory banks for future reference.

column1:
And still, there will be meals that you won't.

If I want to hear how wonderfully I've done, I take my essay to my mom.
column2: &nbsp
column3: But to&nbsp
column4: really know how it is and how to improve it, I take it to my dad.

column1: Kids thrive with praise as it helps them learn to believe in themselves and their capabilities.
column2: Praise to a child is akin to fertilizer to a plant.&nbsp
column3: But there has to be common sense applied or the praise goes from fertilizer to just another load of manure.&nbsp

column1: I'm cognizant, both anecdotally and from dealing with kids, that there is a
column2: gap between what young people actually can do and what they think they can do.
column3: My wish for my own kids is that they have a good sense of self-worth without thinking that every stroke of pen to paper is another Shakespearean Sonnet.&nbsp
column4: But that won't happen if I simply offer blind, blanket praise.&nbsp
column5: So what are some things to consider on rendering praise?

column1: <li>When praising a small child for something that they've done, try to be specific and concrete on what you're praising.&nbsp
column2: Show your child that you've paid attention because rendering blanket compliments teaches that nobody is paying attention.&nbsp
column3: With that comes a greater willingness to attempt to slip something past you when they've grown older.&nbsp

column1: <li>As your child ages, praise can be accompanied by constructive criticism but that's purely a judgment call as to when to start.&nbsp
column2: Instead of offering constructive criticism however, one possibility is to sit with your child and then explore other ways of doing something.&nbsp
column3: <em>How would it look if you did this?&nbsp
column4: How else might you do this?&nbsp
column5: This way, your kid starts to look at different alternatives without feeling as though he hasn't done a good job.

column1: <li>Once your child is in school, you can praise but you have to consider whether this is indeed what&nbsp
column2: the teacher&nbsp
column3: is seeking.&nbsp
column4: Kids don't listen well and they can do great work that simply isn't what's required.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: So&nbsp
column7: ask&nbsp
column8: if there's a rubric to guide the child.

column2: not praise the child if it's not deserved.
column3: This will typically happen with schoolwork and&nbsp
column4: continuing to praise when it's not warranted is a disservice.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: Constructive criticism is&nbsp
column7: a good place to start, mixing the critical comments with legitimately worthwhile remarks.&nbsp
column8: And if there's an obvious lack of effort, call it that.&nbsp
column10: I once told one of my assignment-resistant kids that what was shown to me was <em>crap.&nbsp
column11: However, this child was in the sixth grade at the time and not in preschool.

column1: <li>As your child grows, be sure to determine whether you're being asked on a matter of&nbsp
column2: style or a matter of fact.
column3: There's no bending if something is factually or technically wrong.&nbsp
column4: But kids will grow to develop different tastes and I try to be careful with the commentary if it pertains to the writing style.

column1: <li>Kids are not equal to one another in talent and skill
column2: don't make it a point to go overboard on praise if there are others who are clearly superior in that particular arena.&nbsp
column3: Praise for what they've done but don't lay on the stuff about best on the field if they're clearly not.&nbsp
column4: Temper yourself.&nbsp

column1: Kids love to know that someone is behind them and paying attention to what they're doing.
column2:
But as they age, they'll be like Leah and appreciate that paying attention also means helping to teach them to be their best.

One of the children awakens in the morning complaining of an upset stomach, a condition of which he complained before bedtime last night.
column2: Does he go to school or not?
objective findings&quot
column3: , things that can be readily observed or verified.&nbsp
column4: In this particular case, there's been no vomiting despite the upset stomach.&nbsp
column5: There's no fever, no clammy skin and no appearing to be pale.&nbsp
column6: Kids have discernible energy levels and through familiarity with the child, you can tell if the energy level is off
column7: this is what is meant by the term &quot
column8: listless&quot
column10: In this household, each child has a different morning level - one is bouncy, one calm/level, one quiet/slow.&nbsp
column11: How is he moving in relation to other mornings?&nbsp
column13: Kids are notoriously poor with blowing their nose - Blow! - and drainage through the night will wind up in the stomach as it's swallowed, contributing to or causing queasiness.

column2: If he doesn't get something in his system, he won't last until lunch since a child's body burns through a lot of energy.&nbsp
column3: Options for food are dry toast or dry cereal
column4: if the stomach is sensitive, it won't tolerate heavier foods such as dairy (butter/milk) or bananas.&nbsp
column5: I'm also ruling out citrus fruits because of the acidity.&nbsp
column6: The only fruit that I'd consider would be apple slices but even that's taking a chance.&nbsp
column7: For a drink, I'm giving a mix of apple juice and clear carbonated, such as ginger ale or Sprite.&nbsp
column8: Then give the kid a chance to eat and see how his body responds to the food.&nbsp

column1: This is probably a morning that I don't want to put him on a bus.
column2: If there's sufficient time to see how he handles food, let him rest quietly and then prepare to take him to school.&nbsp
column3: If things are proceeding well, then I'd probably let him go.&nbsp

column2: activity.&nbsp
column3: The reality is that when kids are engaged and among friends/classmates, they simply don't pay attention like they do when things are quiet and nothing's occurring, allowing them to focus on their discomfort.

column1: There are no clear answers in this situation.
column2: &nbsp
column3: Kids can recover&nbsp
column4: well and have no further problems, or they&nbsp
column5: wind up coming home and I've had both&nbsp
column6: outcomes occur.&nbsp
column7: What it does mean is that&nbsp
column8: I&nbsp
column11: schedule for the remainder of the day in the event that I have to&nbsp
column12: return to school and bring a child home.

column2: This is a discussion about what I'm considering in my own situation and not medical advice.&nbsp
column3: If you have questions or concerns, contact your pediatrician or family physician to discuss them.

You have kids and as they age, they want to try new things -
column2: sports, scouts, music.&nbsp
column3: And in the great majority of instances, you'll fill out the registration and come upon the dreaded section asking what duties you'd be willing to fill.&nbsp
column4: And these positions are typically things that you've never done before in your life.&nbsp
column5: Do you really have to sign up for something?

column2: But you should.

column1: There simply isn't enough money to go around and provide all of the opportunities that parents want their kids to have.
column2: So the best way to stretch the dollar is to support the myriad voluntary organizations and clubs that provide the opportunities.&nbsp
column3: Many of these organizations have been around for a long time so stepping up isn't like creating the wheel, although there are moments when you have to help change a few tires.&nbsp
column4: What are some of the things that you should know and remember about volunteering?

column1: <li>Experience isn't a prerequisite for getting involved in the activity.&nbsp
column2: There are three salient points about volunteering.&nbsp
column3: First, the large majority of coaches, advisors and den leaders are the parents of the kids involved in the activity.&nbsp
column4: Second, many of these other adults also have no real experience but want to assure that their kids have a good time so you're all in the same situation.&nbsp
column5: And third, the kids are young enough that&nbsp
column6: they'll have no clue that you're a neophyte.&nbsp
column7: They honestly like having Dad involved in the activity.

column1: <li>Because the kids are coached by the parents, they move up and gain experience together.&nbsp
column2: The coaches and advisors will learn as they go along, attend offered clinics if they're interested, and generally better themselves as the kids do the same.&nbsp
column3: So it isn't as though you're stepping into coaching at a semi-pro level or taking scouts to Philmont Scout Ranch.

column2: akin to the&nbsp
column3: See One, Do One, Teach One school of experience.
column4: There are no Discovery&nbsp
column5: Channel experts to&nbsp
column6: direct you in how to properly lay out a soccer field or&nbsp
column7: keep a basketball scorebook while simultaneously running the scoreboard and clock.&nbsp
column8: You pitch in and pay attention&nbsp
column9: and by the third season, you're the guy with the clipboard and calculator&nbsp
column10: who's laying out the initial soccer lines.&nbsp

column2: skill levels for the youngsters.&nbsp
column3: The Rec League level&nbsp
column4: is for the kids who&nbsp
column5: just want&nbsp
column6: to play without the stress of competing&nbsp
column7: against&nbsp
column8: better/more intense&nbsp
column13: the better players frequently have parents who played when younger&nbsp
column14: and so taught their kids, these folks will tend to wind up coaching at the upper level.&nbsp
column15: Think about where you're most interested and handle it accordingly.&nbsp

column1: <li>You don't have to be a coach or scout leader to volunteer since there are any number of tasks that need to be done
column2: you can tailor the involvement to the time available for commitment.&nbsp
column3: In my case, I supplemented being a scout leader with lining soccer fields.

column1: It can be unnerving to take on an activity with which you aren't familiar.
column2: What will everybody else think?&nbsp
column3: Will my kid be embarrassed?&nbsp
column4: The reality is that most are in the same boat and you won't embarrass the kids until they're teenagers.

column2: Don't try to run a scoreboard/clock while keeping the coach's scorebook.&nbsp
column3: The data suffers horribly.

There are many good parts to a day with kids, the truth is that I find bedtime to be the best part of all.
column2: Spend more time with kids and they'll wear you down
column3: they also are crankier in the late afternoon and early evening as their energy levels diminish.&nbsp
column4: So by their bedtime, they're done and I'm done as well.

column1: But kids thrive on routine and a key daily routine is the bedtime routine.
column2: You decide what works for you - in our house, it's a round of reading before getting them into bed and a nighttime prayer.&nbsp
column3: Then the parent who didn't participate in the routine comes for a quick goodnight kiss and hug.&nbsp
column4: With all of the bases covered, the child can finally close her eyes and go to sleep.

column1: But what happens when you vary from the routine?
column2: If a parent is out for the evening, the child can say goodnight before Mom or Dad departs.&nbsp
column3: And if that parent is away on business, a quick goodnight phone call can work.&nbsp
column4: But you have to be prepared to find a way to stick to the routine.&nbsp
column5: The result of messing it up is the greater likelihood of a crankier child in&nbsp
column6: the morning.&nbsp
column7: And that puts a whole new spin on what you've got planned for&nbsp
column8: the next day as&nbsp
column9: you have to manage a cranky, sleep-deprived child.&nbsp

column1: If you don't find a way to work through it, then you're liable to encounter what happened again tonight.
column2: In our case, it was late night for Eldest's play and we didn't arrive home until a full 90 minutes past Youngest's bedtime.&nbsp
column3: We got him upstairs to his bed and then the routine fell apart.&nbsp
column4: Neither of us made it in for the routine - at least the prayer and goodnights - and realized a full half-hour later that he was upstairs waiting for us.&nbsp

column1: Any tomorrow is never set in stone.
column2:
But we've managed to make this particular tomorrow a greater likelihood and you can be sure that I won't be deviating from the bedtime routine tomorrow night.

It's the middle of the night and you're as sound asleep as a parent can be but you awaken to hear your kindergartener cry out.
column2: The crying continues so you conclude that it's more than an isolated nightmare and you rise to check on him.&nbsp
column3: You enter the room and find him in tears, reaching down to grasp his leg.&nbsp
column4: Daddy, he says, it hurts.
column5: You shake your head awake and proceed to try and figure out what's wrong.
column6: There are no visible marks - no blood, no scrapes, scratches or cuts from loose items in the bed, and no scratches or marks from a family pet that crawled under the bedclothes and startled - and you wonder whether it could be simple growing pains.&nbsp
column7: But isn't that just an old wives' tale?

column1: What are Growing Pains and are they real?
Yes, Dad, growing pains are indeed real and if your child is anywhere from preschool to upper-elementary age (3 - 12 years), then growing pains are a possibility.
column2: Despite the moniker, physicians and researchers actually don't attribute the pain to growth at all
column3: while there is no identifiable cause, the consensus is that the pain is emanating in muscles that have been heavily used through the course of the&nbsp
column4: preceding day.

column1: Growing pains typically occur in one or both legs and will start in the late evening or sometime during the night.
column2: By morning, the pain is resolved and there'll be no reoccurrence through the coming day.&nbsp
column3: Because it's difficult to get a good description from any small child - and it's nigh impossible at 3:00 AM - you might conclude that it's akin to a cramp or deep muscle ache.&nbsp
column4: Growing pains have no skeletal or joint components and sometimes the pain is resolved by helping stretch out the limb or massaging it until it feels better.&nbsp
column5: If those actions don't help, applying heat and giving children's ibuprofen can help relieve the pain.

column1: When should I consider another possible cause?
It's always helpful to keep a close eye on the frequency of occurrences.
column2: You might want to make a quick note on the family calendar and follow this for a period to see if they're relatively isolated or happening with frequent regularity.&nbsp
column3: If the pain is occurring several times weekly, then you might consider consulting your family physician.&nbsp
column4: What else might cause you to see the doctor?

column1: • The pain occurs not only at night, but also during the day.
• There are other objective findings, such as skin redness or areas that are warmer to the touch than others, inflammation or swelling.
• Pain that's routinely isolated to only one spot instead.
• Pain that's occurring in areas other than the legs.
One of our children has had intermittent growing pain for years.
column2: It's sporadic and only occurs in the feet and legs and even&nbsp
column3: happened last evening.&nbsp
column4: We were out later than usual to see another child's play and as we were leaving, the first started complaining of pain in his legs and feet.&nbsp
column5: He's learned to massage his own limbs and on arriving home, we gave him children's ibuprofen to alleviate the pain that would interfere with his sleep.

column1: And as usual, there were no problems come this morning.
This article is for information purposes only and not meant as medical advice.
column2: If you have concerns or questions, please contact your family physician or pediatrician.

column1: For more information on Growing Pains, you can visit Probing Question: Are Children's Growing Pains Real?

helicopter parents&quot
column3: who involve themselves in their kids' lives to the extent that some even contact the offsprings' bosses when something arises.&nbsp
column4: Last year, a local hospital even had a program for staff about how to interact with the newest and youngest employees, as though they might be more easily damaged than previous generations.
column5: But the best advocate for a child is the parent.&nbsp
column6: So what makes an involved parent different from a helicopter parent?

column1: What do I try to bear in mind?
<li>What's the severity of the situation and how frequently does it happen?&nbsp
column2: An isolated pushing incident typically doesn't require a parental response but a chronic pushing situation might if it involves more and/or larger kids.&nbsp
column3: But try to get as many details first as possible.

column1: <li>Does it involve another child or is your child having to deal with someone who's on a different authority level?&nbsp
column2: For example, one of my kids was accused of theft by another and his college-age brother, who further threatened him.&nbsp
column3: In that instance, I went to the playground directly to address the situation since there's a world of difference between a sixth grader and a guy who's old enough to vote.

column1: <li>Remember that when you speak with a child, you're only getting one side of the story and with younger kids, that side is sometimes tangential at best.&nbsp
column2: They get facts and details wrong or omit them entirely.&nbsp
column3: Children also lie if they believe that it will help them or if they're embarrassed.&nbsp
column4: Take the time to parse through the details and if that means contacting other parents or the school for other information, then do so.

column2: information gathering&quot
column3: mode when speaking with others.&nbsp
column4: People - even experienced educators - are nervous talking in a negative light about someone else's kid and approaching them with any emotionally charged statement will only make&nbsp
column5: it harder to get a clear picture.

column2: &nbsp
column3: A&nbsp
column4: first grader will have to learn how to deal with&nbsp
column5: trash talk on a bus but having his lunch money stolen by sixth&nbsp
column6: graders is a different&nbsp
column7: issue.

column2: the child be coached on how to handle the issue?&nbsp
column3: Many situations are brand new to younger children and with some coaching, they can handle it themselves.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: Instead of calling the teacher about a bad grade yourself, help your kid with the language they can use and have them do it.&nbsp
column6: They learn how to speak with people in authority and gain self-confidence.&nbsp
column7: But remember to follow-up to assure that it's been done.&nbsp

column1: <li>This leads to the next point, which is that your first follow-up on grades should be with the kid instead of the school.&nbsp
column2: When one of my kids called me a helicopter parent&nbsp
column3: as I followed up on a grade issue, my response was that I couldn't be since my first response on poor grades was to kick his instead of the school's butt.

column1: The line between involved parent and helicopter parent is real but it can be fuzzy at times and yes, you might be accused of being the latter - at least by your kids.
column2: There are still moments, however, when taking up the banner on behalf of the child is necessary.

column1:
And for the record, the kid on the playground found his wallet with the money intact.

Part of the daily routine - at least for the younger kids - is checking the homework that's been returned.
column2: It might seem a waste as the work's already been turned in and recorded, but there's value in seeing what's been done.

column1: In my case, I'm concerned not with the work itself but instead the process of how the work was done since it's never safe to assume that kids just know how to do something.
column2: There's a process in taking any test or homework and failure to follow it can render all of the hard work moot.&nbsp
column3: Did you go back and check all of your work?&nbsp
column4: Did you answer the questions sequentially or did you jump around the page?&nbsp
column5: Did you have a test-race with Lily in the seat next to you?&nbsp
column6: If you didn't understand the question, did you ask the teacher to make it clear?

column1: Assume nothing since all of these instances have occurred in this household, and I guarantee that the landscape is littered with other instances.
As the kids age, they'll squawk but learn until there comes a time that you don't have to perform the post-mortems.
column2:
They'll really stand or fall on the knowledge base alone and that's the point of the whole exam.

Little ones, big ones and the occasional goose egg that resembles another shoulder growing out of the forehead.&nbsp
column3: Icepacks are a reliable treatment especially for the whoppers since they keep the swelling under control.&nbsp
column4: But when Junior's wailing in the moment, creating an icepack out of ice cubes and a plastic baggy and tie is a cumbersome and nerve-wracking effort.&nbsp
column5: It's better if you have something available quickly.

column1: We learned early on that the best alternative was to use a readily available bag of frozen food.
column2: Why?

column1: <li>A screaming child requires immediate attention and the steps involved in creating the ice pack can lead to spilled cubes and angst as the child wails.&nbsp
column2: Grab the bag and run.

column1: <li>A frozen food bag is typically larger than the baggy with ice and will cover&nbsp
column2: a larger area.

column1: • If the bag is filled with a larger number of smaller items - peas or blueberries - it will more readily mold to the form being covered and distribute that cold more evenly.
<li>I found that it created more opportunity for distracting conversation
column2: <em>gee, does that feel like a blueberry bruise or more of a green bean bruise?&nbsp
column3: When they were a little older, the kids would even label the bruise as
column4: fruit or veggie and I took to keeping a bag of each sealed in separate freezer bags, lying flat in the freezer.

column1: <li>The plastic bag is sealed and does a better job of not leaking than a baggy.&nbsp
column2: That said, we keep ours in ziploc freezer bags since a blueberry leak will lead to stains.

column2: complete all of the housework, powerwalk and volunteer six days weekly at the elementary school?&nbsp
column3: So do I.&nbsp
column4: But there are some things that I can pass along that make things quicker and simpler.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: And it starts with a different mindset about the household.

column1: It helps to think in terms of operations management - what can I do to streamline the processes so that the output is maximized in terms of time?
<li>Before you start, think ahead about what has to happen and set up a working plan.&nbsp
column2: While I no longer put it in writing, I still have a mental to-do list that I compile in the evening.&nbsp
column3: What has to happen and who needs to be where?&nbsp
column4: And nowadays, what article do I need to write and what kind of research needs to be done?&nbsp
column5: Then lay it all out.&nbsp
column6: Frankly, there are instances in which I have to arrange things days ahead of time.

column1: <li>Is there something relatively mindless that I can do while I interact with the kids?&nbsp
column2: Folding laundry is a great possibility since there's no loud noise to interfere.

column1: <li>Is there anything that I can have the kids do to help?&nbsp
column2: If I'm cooking, the kids can fetch and carry items or ingredients.&nbsp
column3: If there's laundry, the kids can carry clean stuff upstairs or dirty stuff downstairs.

column1: <li>Remember to carry things with you as it arises.&nbsp
column2: Housework is a process and there is no point at which things are 'done.'&nbsp
column3: It's continual and you just try to have things in a decent state at any time.&nbsp
column4: So if you have to go upstairs and there's something nearby to go up, take it with you and deposit it
column5: save yourself a needless trip.

column1: <li>What can be done while you're gone?&nbsp
column2: Washers, dryers and dishwashers are terrific labor saving devices if you utilize them properly.&nbsp
column3: So if you know that you're going to be leaving for some time, build a few extra minutes into the schedule to load any of the machines so that the job can be done while you're out.

column1: <li>Keep tabs on the schedule of family members so that you're on top of the clothing needs.&nbsp
column2: Is there a concert or event requiring decent and clean clothing?&nbsp
column3: Is there a gym class requiring clean uniforms?&nbsp
column4: If I know that there's a need for a clean and pressed white shirt in two days, I'll do with a full load of like clothing so that there's no water or electricity wasted.

column1: <li>Keep tabs on the schedule of family members so that you're on top of the meal needs.&nbsp
column2: Starting next week, I'll have three kids in three sports at three different levels and the crock pot will be used heavily as kids are shuttled.&nbsp
column3: When the kids were in preschool, I generally had them play quietly while I prepared the food or they could join me in the kitchen and play or draw at the kitchen table.&nbsp
column4: Their favorite programs were in the late morning and I used that time to fix lunch, so I had things laid out at the table in advance.

column1: There are no magic tricks to getting this accomplished, just trying a different mindset and sticking to it.
column2: &nbsp
column3: It doesn't eliminate the&nbsp
column4: chaos that kids breed but it does make it more&nbsp
column5: manageable.&nbsp

Many were surprised - me included - to find that the recently passed
column2: Health Care Reform Bill also contained legislation that made significant changes to the Federal Student Loan Program.&nbsp
column3: And the healthcare uproar has carried over to the college funding program as well.&nbsp
column4: So why was it even done, what is in it and what does it mean for my family?

column1: What Are the Demands and How Are They Being Addressed?
Like any major overhaul legislation, Congress is trying to meet multiple demands with one piece of legislation.
column2: What are the driving forces behind this?

column1: First, people are learning that college is America's new default educational requirement.
column2: The problem, from a public policy/society level, is how to best help the largest number gain a degree with the money available.

column1: <li>More money will be directed to the neediest students via the Pell Grant Program.&nbsp
column2: Pell Grants are federal grants for students that demonstrate financial need and do not have to be repaid if the student meets certain completion requirements.&nbsp
column3: These grants will be increased starting in 2013-2014 for five years and the increase will be linked to the Consumer Price Index.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp

column1: <li>Those institutions that typically admit students from needier households are receiving more support.&nbsp
column2: More money is being directed to Community Colleges ($2 Billion) and historically African-American Institutions ($750 Million).&nbsp

column1: • Removing the Financial Services Industry and SallieMae from creating
column2: and &nbsp
column3: servicing&nbsp
column4: federally backed loans saves tens of billions in costs.&nbsp

column1: Second, this is actually a pre-emptive response to the moral hazard created by the government bailout of Fannie Mae and the housing industry.
column2: Sallie Mae is a fully privatized lender that began as a Government Sponsored Entity is 1972.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: It was created to serve a single purpose - facilitate student lending - and was finally fully spun off from the government in 2004.&nbsp
column5: This is exactly the same&nbsp
column6: scenario as the&nbsp
column7: now-bailed Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.&nbsp
column8: Likewise, the default rate on student debt is rising significantly just as the default rate on mortgages.&nbsp

column2: learned from the mortgage debacle&nbsp
column3: what happens when&nbsp
column4: banks are able to&nbsp
column5: originate&nbsp
column6: loans&nbsp
column7: for which they have&nbsp
column8: no final exposure
column10: kept and the risk is passed along to the taxpayer.&nbsp

column2: has no real system to penalize&nbsp
column3: the financial industry for&nbsp
column4: originating loans&nbsp
column5: that will ultimately&nbsp
column6: default.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp

column1: <li>The administration of a large portion of the federal student loan program will be passed along to the colleges themselves.&nbsp
column2: The government does have a mechanism - the Cohort Default Rates
column3: - to penalize colleges and universities that do a poor job of assessing the credit risk of a prospective student.

column1: <li>The government has effectively made the program administrators somebody with &quot
column2: skin in the game&quot

column1: Third, legislators are hearing the complaints of burdensome student debt - debt that can't be discharged via bankruptcy in the worst case scenario.
• The interest rate on the PLUS loans from the federal government will drop from 8.5% to 7.9%.
• The maximum monthly repayment amount for these loans will drop from 15% of income to 10% of income.
<li>Loan amounts outstanding after twenty years will be forgiven, a decrease of five years from the previous forgiveness period of twenty-five years.&nbsp
column2: I do not know the tax consequences of this loan forgiveness.

column1: So What Does This Mean For Me?
Here's what I suspect will be the upshot of the changes, apart from the continuing shift of students to the community college model.
The federal loan money will still be there but the problem will be gaining access to it.
column2: Colleges and universities are not in the business of&nbsp
column3: personal lending, which is what this really is.&nbsp
column4: As they&nbsp
column5: assume and learn the responsibilities, they'll err on the cautious side to protect themselves&nbsp
column6: from the Cohort Default Rate&nbsp
column7: mechanism.&nbsp
column8: The result will be that students and families with marginal credit histories will be frozen out.&nbsp
column9: The institutions will probably also ask&nbsp
column20: Are your plans defined enough to merit the money paid for the degree?

column1: The funding will dry up and more students
column2: will&nbsp
column3: shift to local colleges and community colleges.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: The timespan required to earn a degree will lengthen accordingly.&nbsp
column6:
And we are all in for a cultural shock.

The final information is now in and the results are painful as three kids play three different sports.
column2: If I'm going to manage affordable and well-cooked meals - family meals are&nbsp
column3: now no longer a given - then I have to work with the calendar and plan ahead of time.

column1: We're a family that actually tries not to have everybody going in different directions, but kids need some activities and that means chaos when they get older.
column2: So what's the schedule look like?

column1: So for any given week, I've got three meals on the fly.
column2: How do I manage that?
If possible, I want to make&nbsp
column3: the meals made&nbsp
column4: to minimize cost and maximize nutrition.&nbsp
column5: Second, even if everybody is eating earlier, I want us together as much as possible.&nbsp
column6: Third, I want to only have to prepare one time instead of cooking the same thing multiple times.&nbsp

column1: My parameters favor crockpot and soup recipes.
column2: These are meals that can be prepared in bulk and eaten over several nights.&nbsp
column3: They can also stay warm for the others if one has to eat earlier.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: Additionally, I can use the evening hours to prepare the next day's ingredients - cutting vegetables, mixing spices into a small holding bowl and assuring that everything is clean for the next day.&nbsp
column6: The leftovers are easily stored and reheated the following night.&nbsp
column7: And frankly, these kinds of foods usually taste better after sitting and letting the flavors of the various ingredients blend further.

column1: So a sample calendar for next week's meals would be:

column2: Beans provide ample protein for the kids doing the sports.

column1: Tuesday - Chili leftovers with broiled cheese toast.

column2: The activity doesn't start until early evening so nobody's running around dinnertime.

column1: Friday - Grill night with burgers and grilled vegetables, such as peppers, onions and squash.
There are two benefits to planning ahead.
column2: The first is that you can control your cost by creating a decent shopping list.&nbsp
column3: When you shop, you aren't wandering aisles like an itinerant nomad and falling prey to the marketing techniques.&nbsp
column4: The second is that you can gauge how to best use the available time to prepare the meal.&nbsp
column5: Even when you're using the calendar and planning ahead, kids breed chaos and it doesn't stop just because they're no longer toddlers.

column1: Just because the schedule is nuts - and there are requests that my wife and I have denied - doesn't mean that life has to feel chaotic.

Two of my kids are preparing in class for the upcoming state standards assessment, the one mandated by the Federal No Child Left Behind Act.
column2: And as I watch them and their grades, I repeatedly run into the media flogging the newest bad boy for our national educational difficulties.&nbsp
column3: The newest group of floggees, freshly proclaimed by Newsweek, appears to be the teachers.
column4: There are bad teachers in the schools - agreed - and it's well nigh impossible to get rid of those bad ones - also agreed.&nbsp
column5: But blaming the teachers and their unions is simplistic and wrong.

column1: I'm not a fan of unions in their current form as most are recalcitrant and prickly when confronted with any change to the status quo.
column2: Let me use Pennsylvania for a brief example.&nbsp
column3: In 2001, the Pennsylvania legislature passed legislation mandating that teacher pension funds must be kept fully funded.&nbsp
column4: It was&nbsp
column5: a worthy gesture, given that those in the rest of the workforce who still have a pension find theirs underfunded.&nbsp
column6: Of course, it also provided cover for the legislature, which was in the process of updating&nbsp
column7: and improving its own pension system but they'll never admit that.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column13: large group of teachers retiring simultaneously and about 1.5 working union members supporting each retiree.&nbsp
column14: The fund has also been shellacked by the just finished recession&nbsp
column15: and per law, has to be brought up to date by the state and the 501 state school districts.&nbsp
column17: many districts will find their pension contributions doubling&nbsp
column22: board voted unanimously to ask the state for help&nbsp
column23: or relief in addressing this, the local union representative asked that they not send the letter at all.&nbsp
column24: Great, don't move out from under the falling piano because&nbsp

column1: As much as that instance galls me, it's simplistic to lay it all on the teachers.
column2: The solution is as interconnected as the problem.&nbsp
column3: Poor teaching methods?&nbsp
column4: Yes.&nbsp
column5: Staff that can't be removed?&nbsp
column6: Yes.&nbsp
column7: Outmoded equipment?&nbsp
column8: Yes.&nbsp
column9: But the missing key is, like the President says, the parent.&nbsp
column11: Do you practice the addition, subtraction and multiplication tables with them?&nbsp
column12: Do you hold your children accountable for their grades?&nbsp
column13: Do you have requirements on homework and studying for tests?&nbsp
column15: you contact the teachers to find out what's happening when there's a problem, academic or otherwise?&nbsp

column1: The principal reason that private and charter schools do so well, often with less resources, is that the parents are making the decision to send their kids there and that decision implies commitment.
column2: <em>This is important enough that we'll spend the extra money and if we're going to do without to educate you, you're going to make it worth the money spent.&nbsp
column3: This should be the operative philosophy for all parents, regardless where the kids go to school.

column1: There are any number of reasons that parents stand-off from the schoolwork.
column2: Guilt for having to work away from the home, societal experts advising not to stress the kids, tired of the hassle from recalcitrant kids.&nbsp
column3: But whatever the reason, they - you - have the responsibility to push them.&nbsp
column4: It's actually okay to tell them that they can do better if you believe that's the case.&nbsp
column5: It's okay to withhold privileges if they don't measure up to their potential and yes, you can tell if that's the case.&nbsp
column6: It's okay to use guilt on occasion - I work hard to provide and it's not right that you spend the time on the DS instead of getting the homework done - because that's a way that they see that there's someone else besides just themselves.
column7: If the effort is clearly substandard, it's even okay to describe that piece of work as crap.&nbsp
column8: Yes, I've done that and in the circumstance, it was entirely appropriate.

column1: This matters because you aren't always going to be around to pull their chestnuts from the fire and they'll have to compete against people named Helmut, Sanjay and Addaya.
column2: So hold the teachers accountable but be comfortable with the knowledge that you're also holding yourself accountable as well.

Involved parenting means that there are certain things with which you have to become accustomed.
column2: And mothers, who are well aware of the true nature of kids, have learned that you have to look ahead to see what new situations are coming and how the child can be prepared for them.&nbsp
column3: In this instance, knowing that the child's going to an activity that requires wearing a new form of clothing that they haven't worn before.

column1: Kids are creatures of habit and while some don't care about what they wear, others will roar their terrible roar over having to wear something that's beyond their experience.
column2: Kids want to try sports but it doesn't occur to them, especially with sports that don't require football pads, that there are necessary protective items that aren't seen.&nbsp
column3: More than one child has fretted and whined about having to wear shinguards for soccer.&nbsp
column4: They aren't visible under the long socks - which are also outside the norm - and trying to get a whiny, recalcitrant child moving for the first practice is setting things up for failure.&nbsp
column5: <em>The socks are too long.&nbsp
column6: They itch.&nbsp
column7: This plastic guard thingy on my leg doesn't feel good.&nbsp
column8: Why do I hafta wear it?&nbsp
column9: The coach won't see it, so she won't know!&nbsp
column11: It's fruitless to blame the child, who in most instances is
column13: They don't have the experience base with which to make comparisons - hey, it's not as bad as this or that event - nor do they possess the patience.&nbsp
column14: And they don't have the attention span and ability to focus so that they can concentrate on the coach and learning.&nbsp
column15: Instead, they put on a show for the crowd by doing some snazzy Bossa Nova moves trying to relieve the itch from the sock.

column1: The frustration level ratchets upwards until the stage is set for a repeat performance of PsychoDad.
column2: And yes, I've been PsychoDad.

column1: So what do I do differently to avoid this and set up the child for success?
column2: This season, youngest will be playing soccer like his elder siblings and have to wear shin guards.&nbsp
column3: But several days before the first practice, I'll have him running around outside with the shinguards on for the first time in order to get used to the&nbsp
column4: sensation of the device.&nbsp
column5: He'll also wear the long socks and we'll play so that he's used to the feeling come that first practice next week.&nbsp
column6: It will be, in a sense, like taming a wild colt until it's broken and ready to accept the bridle or saddle.&nbsp
column7: Except that through this period, if the whining continues, I'll keep talking with the child and emphasizing the need for the guards.&nbsp
column8: And while I don't think that it's going to be an issue in this case, I'd rather take the time now than lose it a half-hour before the practice starts.

column1:
So think ahead to what new experiences face your child and what you can do to set things up for success.

Kids do well when there's a standard routine for them to follow.
column2: It provides a sense of comfort, especially when things are tense or rocky, and&nbsp
column3: an anchor to which they can cling.&nbsp
column4: But a good routine has certain elements in common regardless of the child and his or her personality and age.

column1: The rationale of the bedtime routine is that it provides the child an opportunity to calm down and relax after the course of a day.
column2: They're usually tired and the energy levels are lower after a busy day, but they can still become hyper and overly stimulated if the situation isn't managed properly.&nbsp
column3: And an overly stimulated, tired child is a classic recipe for an evening meltdown.&nbsp
column4: So what should you remember?

column1: <li>Active play of any kind will tend to stimulate a child.&nbsp
column2: This includes chase/tag, wrestling and even playing in the bathtub.

column1: <li>Kids need to learn to remember things and a quiet talk about their day helps train their memory to what occurred.&nbsp
column2: It's common to ask a small child what he - or she - did in a day and get a thousand yard stare.&nbsp
column3: It's not being disobedient as much as simply not remembering and walking them through the day's events will help train their memory for when they're older.&nbsp

column1: <li>Early evening is not the time for additional snacks that contain sugar or any other kind of stimulants.&nbsp
column2: Any snack should be relatively bland or naturally sweet and devoid of sweeteners.&nbsp
column3: This ban also includes fruit juices, which typically contain significant amounts of high fructose corn syrup or sugar.

column1: <li>Most video games, especially action games, will stimulate the child so that the bedtime is damaged.&nbsp
column2: The child won't want to stop the game and when they do, it will take additional time to relax and then fall asleep.

column1: The key is to provide a calm environment.
So what might a bedtime routine look like?
<li>After finishing dinner, the child can have a bath.&nbsp
column2: Smaller kids get messier at dinner and an earlier bath simply avoids any additional mess.&nbsp
column3: The child also has an opportunity for wet hair to dry before bedtime - avoiding the morning bedhead - and if the bath gets boisterous, there's still an opportunity to calm down before hitting the sheets.&nbsp
column4: And yes, bathtime was a rambunctious affair in my house.

column1: <li>After the bath, you - and the child when older - can quickly pick up their room after putting on the pajamas.&nbsp
column2: This way, the day doesn't actually end with a chore.

column1: <li>When the pajamas are on and the room is picked up, he can watch some quiet television or play a game with you.&nbsp
column2: As much as I enjoyed Sesame Street, I found that the pace was just a little too quick for the time just before bedtime.
column3: Again, this is an opportunity to play an easy card or board game.

column1: <li>Take your child up to bed and curl up for a story or for some easy conversation.&nbsp
<li>Finish the routine with whatever customs you deem appropriate.&nbsp
column2: Prayer or final thoughts for the day can be done before the lights are out.
They'll someday grow up and avoid the little affections that they love when little.&nbsp
column3: It's also important if there's some anger or tension at bedtime, and yes, that's liable to happen.&nbsp
column4: Even if you're ticked off or frustrated, try to find it within yourself to provide that affection so that they don't think that they aren't loved because of something that they did.&nbsp
column5: I was surprised to find that children will believe that&nbsp
column6: Daddy doesn't love them anymore&nbsp
column7: because of their behavior.&nbsp
column8: I also felt tremendously guilty.

column1: <li>After they're in bed, take a few minutes to hang around upstairs to assure that they're settled.&nbsp
column2: A child who gets out of bed and walks into a lit area is prone to a bit of additional stimulation, so hanging around can avoid that situation.

column1: You're liable to find that the early evening television is ruined because of the bedtime ritual and I've found that some shows were almost off of the air before I was able to even see them.
column2: But you can always catch the shows on cable, which is something that you'll never be able to do with a child's bedtime.&nbsp

When you have a child, you think back on how things might, or might not be, different.
column2: And when it comes to giving your child milk, it's something that is both the same and different.
column3: How can that be?

column2: Things haven't changed in the years since you were a child in that children under the age of one year should not be given cow's milk, or soy milk for that matter.&nbsp
column3: Babies, those under one year of age, require the nutrients that are found in breast milk or formula, if the child isn't nursing.&nbsp
column4: Not only that, but the child's stomach and intestines aren't sufficiently developed to handle the digestion of these products and it can lead to significant distress for the infant.&nbsp
column5: The rule of thumb is that a child should be able to drink and digest regular milk after reaching the first birthday.&nbsp
column6: Remember&nbsp
column7: however, that you have to still take care and monitor how your child does with the new food
column8: to assure that there's no allergy.

column2: First, there are now alternatives to regular cow's milk, specifically soymilk and almond milk.&nbsp
column3: Neither soy nor almond milks have lactose, which is a&nbsp
column4: sugar in cow's milk that can cause real intestinal distress for a child, let alone an adult.&nbsp
column5: Each of these alternatives has its own nutritional profile and some might decide that it's better than cow's milk.&nbsp
column6: The flip side is that soy and almond milks don't have the calcium content of regular milk and calcium is important for a growing child.

column1: If you do decide to feed your child regular milk, the second difference is the question of whole milk versus lowfat or skim milk.
column2: Most are unaware that toddlers do need the extra fat content of whole milk until two or three years of age in order to assist with additional development of the body and brain
column3: this need diminishes after that time and it can be replaced with a lower fat content milk.&nbsp
column4: The reality is that many children receive a high fat diet and the whole milk fat content then only adds calories from fat with no added benefit to the older toddler.

column1: If you take anything away from this, it's the simple notion that your infant doesn't get regular milk.
column2:
Because it's a mistake that you don't want to make.

Fatherhood is a juggling act with one ball consisting of job responsibilities, another consisting of household duties and the third consisting of spending time with the kids.
column2: But sometimes one ball&nbsp
column3: has to be&nbsp
column4: substantially larger than the others and you have to take greater care to assure that the children's ball isn't the one being dropped.&nbsp
column5: There's not always much that can be done with the job, but there are things that you can do to keep the kids in the loop when you're contending with the household projects.

column1: What should you remember about kids and household projects?
<li>Children have no sense of time and schedule, so plan your work and be realistic about what you can accomplish.&nbsp
column2: Expect questions and constant interruptions, even if your mate is there to help keep things under control while you work.&nbsp
column3: The speed with which you might have accomplished a particular project or task is lessened with kids around.

column1: <li>Children have no sense of risk or danger and you have to be aware for them.&nbsp
column2: Are power tools unplugged when you walk away?&nbsp
column3: Should&nbsp
column4: you actually remove the drill bit lest the kid plug in the drill?&nbsp
column5: This not only tacks on additional time but also means that you might not be concentrating entirely on the project at hand.&nbsp
column6: If you really do need to pay close attention to the task - or if the hazards are potentially fatal - then arrange for the kids to be gone while you work.&nbsp
column7: Setting studs to a concrete&nbsp
column8: floor with a nail gun?&nbsp
column10: consider removing the second-grader from the house.

column2: help, what are your expectations and can&nbsp
column3: he&nbsp
column4: meet those expectations?&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: There are no absolute&nbsp
column7: correct responses in this judgment call and if necessary, check with your mate to see if they make sense.&nbsp
column8: Smaller kids&nbsp
column9: usually don't have the attention span, let alone skill level,&nbsp
column10: to seriously participate but they will&nbsp
column11: check in and out and if there's something that they can do to help, then they do have a sense of accomplishment.&nbsp
column12: Even if you've done 98% of the work.

column1: <li>Be prepared to talk alot more than if you were working with another adult.&nbsp
column2: &nbsp
column3: Safety is crucial and you're going to have to talk as you explain what you're&nbsp
column4: doing, or how the girl should handle&nbsp
column5: some&nbsp
column6: equipment, or where the boy should stand while a task is being accomplished.&nbsp
column7: Bear in mind that&nbsp
column8: even teens&nbsp
column9: will tune out as they think about&nbsp
column10: other things - mostly involving sex - and you're going to have to repeat yourself.&nbsp

column2: you're under a microscope&nbsp
column3: and they'll&nbsp
column4: learn from you do as well as what&nbsp
column5: you say.&nbsp
column6: Cut yourself?&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: Do the requisite first aid, even if you&nbsp
column12: Teens usually lack good judgment and if Dad ignores&nbsp
column13: first aid, then he'll probably do the same&nbsp
column14: when it's actually critical that the wound be cleaned and treated.&nbsp

column2: talk about the plans with them and&nbsp
column3: especially talk about the safety concerns of working with particular tools.&nbsp
column4: One of the last things to develop with the adolescent brain is risk assessment and if&nbsp
column5: they actually hear you talking&nbsp
column6: through hazards and safety, they'll&nbsp
column7: at least hear that things can go wrong.&nbsp

column1: • Understand that you're going to have to repeat yourself, or did I mention that already?
<li>Even if a kid takes on a project as their own, expect to have to stay involved so that the project is finished.&nbsp
column2: Attention spans wander and they can lose interest if someone isn't there to keep them on task.&nbsp
column3: In this household, Eldest took on the project of reclaiming a 9' X 15' fish pond late last summer.&nbsp
column4: The project was 85% finished before Autumn - with school and activities - forced a suspension and although I've mentioned it several times in the past two weeks, the reality is that I'll have to help put things back on track for the project's completion.&nbsp
column5: It isn't that she can't do it or doesn't care, but larger and longer projects require some planning and maturity that most teens haven't mastered yet.

column2: It's stressful enough having a major project hanging over your head, but some forethought can help keep the balls airborne.&nbsp
column3:
And the kids will actually get something out of it.

Being a father is a full-time endeavor, one that never ceases and always changes as the kids grow.
column2: There will be occasions when you simply don't do well and feel real guilt about how you acted or responded to a situation.&nbsp
column3: Nobody talks about those moments and they do stay with you.&nbsp
column4: While making notes for Tackling Major Projects With Kids Around, I had to consider what I believe to be my worst moment and greatest regret as a father.

column1: The front yard of our old house was very plain and sloped considerably in two different directions.
column2: The only path from the sidewalk to the front porch consisted of some broken, partially covered flagstones that had been thrown in the grass by the previous owner and it was apparent that the whole front needed work.&nbsp
column3: My wife wanted a concrete walkway, with steps, that ran from porch to sidewalk in a way that best utilized the yard's topography.&nbsp
column4: Because I spent several summers in college pouring concrete for a construction company, I took on the project myself.&nbsp
column5: I reacquainted myself with the work involved, took the necessary measurements and laid out the plans accordingly.&nbsp
column6: What I didn't do was account for the fact that I was a stay-at-home father with three children and a hard-working spouse.&nbsp
column7: I was an idiot.

column1: Let me tell you a little something about concrete.
column2: It responds badly to hot weather.&nbsp
column3: You can add all of the water you want in the mixer and as soon as it's poured, it will be as though there's a giant invisible straw sucking out the moisture and making it impossible with which to work.&nbsp
column4: That means that the most difficult time is in the height of summer, which is about when my own project was ready to pour.

column1: My idiocy was compounded by failing to start early enough to beat that stretch and it meant that I drove myself to get the job done, even bringing in a teenager to help with the heavy digging and pouring.
column2: But that need to see the job done meant that I was a bastard when it came to letting the kids help and my eldest son - then a third grader - desperately wanted to help his father.

column1: I was curt with his questions and impatient with his efforts when he tried to help.
column2: I never verbally berated him but my looks and demeanor were clear when I thought that he was in the way and I now recall how his face looked when I brusquely ordered him to move and then complained about what had to happen to get this project moving.&nbsp
column3: The project was successfully completed but I was a true bastard in doing it.

column1: Both my sister and I were at our father's side when he died from lung cancer.
column2: In the hours before his death, he was conscious and coherent while he leaned against us and labored to breathe before his body finally succumbed to the effort.&nbsp
column3: He managed to speak and I was dumbfounded when he apologized to us for his failings as a father.&nbsp
column4: His comment was, <em>I'm sorry that I was a royal horse's ass sometimes.&nbsp
column5: Both of us loved him dearly and considered him to be an excellent father.
column6: Yet in his last moments, he could only reflect on those occasions when he had fallen short.

column2: We're going to have some bad instances but that shouldn't define us as failures.&nbsp
column3: What makes us failures are not acknowledging our mistakes and learning from them, and ultimately, walking away from our responsibilities as fathers.

column1: I learned from my father's example yet again.
column2: But instead of waiting for my deathbed, I apologized to my now-older son last night.

She's not as playful as before the kids' arrival.
column2: Perhaps she's more curt and distracted and it seems harder to engage in the same conversations that you had when it was just the two of you.&nbsp
column3: You look at her and wonder, what's going on inside her head?&nbsp
column4: If you want to understand, think of her brain as the dependable family PC.&nbsp
column5: The game processing speed is diminishing as more practical work packages are added to the hard drive to handle the increasing family demands.

column1: Dads today are doing more with kids than previous generations.
column2: A 2008 study
column3: found that today's fathers are managing twice the housework and triple the childcare as our grandfathers.&nbsp
column4: But that doubling still only takes it to 30% of the housework.&nbsp
column5: Working and managing family obligations are filling the maternal hard drive.

column1: You can separate these obligations into two categories - relationships and operations management.
column2: Running these two areas means that she's had to further develop multi-tasking subroutines.

column1: It's the women who usually take care of the relationship aspects of the family.
column2: What's happening with the kids?&nbsp
column3: Who are their friends and&nbsp
column4: how are they developing socially?&nbsp
column5: The mothers arrange the playdates and are more sensitive to the kids' issues.&nbsp
column6: There's also maintaining extended family relationships as well, arranging gatherings, passing important news and remembering important dates.&nbsp
column7: We are also sandwiched between two generations who are on opposing ends of the self-care Bell Curve.&nbsp
column8: Kids absolutely require time and attention.&nbsp
column9: Grandparents can still be very competent but the physical and mental cracks begin to appear as they age.&nbsp
column10: Unlike the Chinese, who prize their sons for eldercare, the care of aging American parents normally falls&nbsp
column12: your wife is probably more aware of her father's prostate than you are of your own.

column1: Managing the household operations occupy a significant portion of the drive.
column2: Kids prosper when they have a routine and general schedule in their daily lives.&nbsp
column3: But the reality is that kids leave confusion in their wake
column4: they sicken, forget things, get cranky and demanding.&nbsp
column5: So the mothers, as primary caregivers, are trying to reconcile flexibility with maintaining some kind of daily routine.

column1: It can be maddening and even infuriating when others who aren't aware of the competing demands question why more wasn't accomplished in the course of a day.
column2: The kids' chronic interruptions also mean that she's being constantly diverted from the original task and getting back on track requires additional time and mental effort.

column1: There's a cycle to maintaining even a relatively clean house - cleaning, cooking and laundry - and these require additional subroutines that add more multi-tasking layers.
column2: Toss a load of laundry in the washer and return to the kitchen to load&nbsp
column3: the dishwasher.

column1: While these run, cut up food for the crockpot and then help Junior find the prized possession that he's mislaid for the twelfth time.
column2: Then it's back to shift laundry to the dryer and onwards to something else that needs to be done.&nbsp
column3: Weave that into the mix of work and childcare and you have a woman who's maintaining a high level of efficiency at the expense of game speed.

column1: Don't make the mistake of thinking that distance automatically equals a lack of love.
column2: It's likely that she still loves you and wants those moments to play the games.&nbsp
column3: But the games are best enjoyed when more of the computing processes and subroutines are removed from her hard drive.&nbsp
column4:
Just remember that the family family needs these subroutines to survive, so they have to move to a different hard drive.

column2: about whether we should pay our children for good grades and our consensus was that the kids would have to do without the money.&nbsp
column3: But now Time Magazine
column4: weighs in with the research put forward by Dr. Roland Fryer of Harvard about the effects of financially rewarding - paying - schoolkids for good grades.&nbsp
column5: And after reading the article and understanding that there are good points, I still have to disagree and not solely for intellectual reasons.

column1: The trials in question were run in four urban areas - DC, New York City, Chicago and Dallas - and to his credit, appear to be well-designed studies.
column2: Each group in each of the target cities are inner-city students and the reality, politically correct or not, is that most are mostly underprivileged from homes that are not intact.&nbsp
column3: Each city was also tested based upon different criteria so that the results could be compared against one another as well as against the control groups.&nbsp
column4: The results were that in two cities, Dallas and DC, the results were positive with reading comprehension scores rising significantly in Dallas and multiple factors being positively affected in DC.&nbsp
column5: The results in NYC and Chicago were either mixed or to no effect.

column1: There is one key element in the article that bears some exploration.
column2: A common retort of critics - me included - is that kids should be taught that learning is important in and of itself and should be taught that it's so.&nbsp
column3: But here's the paragraph in question:

column2: We tend to assume that kids (and adults) know how to achieve success.&nbsp
column3: If they don't get there, it's for lack of effort - or talent.&nbsp
column4: Sometimes that's true.&nbsp
column5: But a lot of the time, people are just flying blind.&nbsp
column6: John List, an economist at the University of Chicago, has noticed the disconnect in his own educational experiments.&nbsp
column7: He explains the problem to me in this way:&nbsp
column8: &quot
column9: I could ask you to solve a third-order linear partial differential equation,&quot
column16: A third-order linear partial differential equation,&quot
column19: I could offer you a million dollars to solve it.&nbsp
column22: ...For some kids, doing better on a geometry test is like solving a third-order linear partial differential equation, no matter the incentive.&quot

column1: The simple reality is that in most inner cities, the welfare society created a situation in which multiple succeeding generations were raised without a real regard for the value of education and then didn't pass it along to their own children.
column2: One of my laws of fatherhood is the understanding that your child is a blank slate
column3: and is going to have to be taught everything
column4: to expect them to simply figure things out is unrealistic.&nbsp
column5: The simple skills that create a successful learning environment - reading, math drills, checking homework, accountability - are absent and without these in the homes, the kids don't have the tools necessary to pull themselves along.&nbsp
column6: Unless there's an additional incentive that prompts them to the extra effort necessary to overcome the circumstances.

column1: I have two other concerns about the question.
column2: The practical question is one of sheer resources.&nbsp
column3: If this is to work, then the financial resources have to be in place to cover the costs and the fiscal reality is that the money just isn't available to pay kids for decent grades.&nbsp
column4: Some can argue that the available money should be put towards the underprivileged kids since they don't have the family structure and opportunities in place like those who are in suburban or rural areas.&nbsp
column5: But this leads to the other concern, which is the corrosive social message that's sent by the government to the families who do&nbsp
column6: work with their children and push for education and good grades.&nbsp
column7: Your kids won't get the money that goes to the underprivileged kids from homes whose families don't value what you do.&nbsp
column8: That might seem extreme and childish, but consider the catastrophic law of unintended consequences that struck after the Great Society programs of the 1960s.&nbsp
column9: Within thirty-five years, the number of fatherless inner-city children rose dramatically and the two-parent model within the inner city was literally destroyed.&nbsp
column10: Over the next several decades, how many other parents will simply say to hell with it as did so many from the Great Society years?

column1: Which was in large part what led to this predicament.

column2: It frustrates me, as I'm sure that it does many other parents, that&nbsp
column3: those parents who don't place the value upon education are seemingly rewarded at our expense.&nbsp
column4: So I'm in favor of further exploring the research and perhaps some other reward mechanism can be found that can be universally applied without bankrupting us further.

column1:
But otherwise, remember the Great Society debacle and just forget the whole thing.

Discipline is too often equated with punishment since most fathers only remember to apply it when something has gone wrong.
column2: But the&nbsp
column3: purpose of discipline is about teaching
column4: the child right from wrong and that's also something that can be done in a positive way as well.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: It's important to remember that positive reinforcement can be an important disciplinary tool with your child.

column1: One of my greatest tasks as a father is teaching
column2: my child about the world, what it means and ultimately how to survive in it.&nbsp
column3: If Junior begins to think that I only notice her when things are going wrong, then the result will be defensiveness whenever I open my mouth and the necessary lesson isn't going to be learned.&nbsp
column4: And frankly, it naturally gets tougher as the kids age and begin to think that they know more than they do.

column1: So what do I try to remember about positive reinforcement and praise?
• Remember first and foremost that kids want your attention and time more than stuff.
<li>Praise is a more general term and is a feedback that you can provide in non-specific circumstances.&nbsp
column2: For instance, if I'm chatting with one of the kids and tell her that she's really smart - and Eldest actually is - then that's providing feedback for a generalized trait regardless of any specific instance.

column1: <li>Positive reinforcement is more specific and refers to a particular instance or series of instances.&nbsp
column2: Telling Eldest that she's smart is praise, telling her that she really earned her A through persistence and a smart study plan is positive reinforcement.&nbsp
column3: My attention to the situation reinforces the behaviors and habits&nbsp
column4: that led to the good result.

column1: <li>When I provide either, but especially positive reinforcement, I&nbsp
column2: try to have&nbsp
column3: one or more concrete examples to bolster&nbsp
column4: the commentary.&nbsp
column5: If I don't, then&nbsp
column6: Junior's going to view it as overpraise
column7: and will both get a swelled ego and begin to ignore the commentary that actually accompanies it.

column1: <li>I try to tailor the reinforcement to&nbsp
column2: Junior's age level and experience.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: If Junior's three years of age, then positive reinforcement on good table manners is important.&nbsp
column5: When she's fifteen, then good table manners are simply an expectation of standard behavior and&nbsp
column6: usually not to be&nbsp
column7: commented on.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column10: said, I have on occasion issued a blanket compliment to the three kids when&nbsp

column2: is especially important when it's a new&nbsp
column3: circumstance with which Junior's had no experience.&nbsp
column4: It's also important on those&nbsp
column5: occasions to talk to her&nbsp
column6: in advance and&nbsp
column7: give her some understanding of what's&nbsp
column8: going to happen so she's not blindsided
column9: the reinforcement at the end brings the experience home and lets her know how she did and&nbsp

column2: These aren't magic in and of themselves, but they are valuable additions to the fatherhood toolbox.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: And a good and well-used toolbox is filled with implements that are regularly used.
