Kids grow, age and change and we expect that.
column2: One of the great challenges of being a parent is adapting&nbsp
column3: while still being consistent within the adaptation, just like a parent trying to be flexible within the daily schedule while still maintaining a sense of structure.&nbsp
column4: It's no different for discipline&nbsp
column5: than it is for anything else and in fact, it's probably more difficult for discipline since the heart of discipline is teaching the child and that child is going to push more and more of your buttons as she ages.

column1: When the kids are smaller, you're around them more and the environments are much more controlled.
column2: You can keep an eye on them and their activities and things are much more of a known quantity.&nbsp
column3: You have a decent sense of the risks, hazards and temptations.&nbsp
column4: They'll still come up with new twists that catch you off-guard but if you think like a kid, you start to anticipate what can happen.

column1: Temptations and situations develop when they enter a larger environment.
column2: More kids from other families - each family with its own values and priorities - and new surroundings mean that the parents must stretch their attention span
column3: what new challenges can arise and what should the response be when they do?

column1: But discipline becomes a real challenge when the kids reach the point that they're more aware and think that they're
column2: smarter than &quot
column3: the 'rents&quot
column4: .&nbsp
column5: Rules will be questioned - sometimes rightfully - and the opportunity is now there to pursue actions and behaviors that are potentially self-destructive.&nbsp
column6: Now discipline can almost reach the point of being akin to a military campaign.&nbsp
column7: You have to observe and question, demand details and parse through commentary that appears straightforward to the addled teen brain but is actually short of real information.&nbsp
column8: You then have to work to channel them to the options that are in their best interests and that can involve maintaining a considerable and extended period of pressure to assure their compliance.&nbsp
column9: It can be unpleasant and lead to&nbsp
column11: the child is unhappy having to comply with a semi-senile old coot and you're unhappy too.&nbsp
column14: and equally unpleasant enforcing accountability, especially if it means that something in which the child excels is being withheld to assure compliance.

column1: Over the long term, it's easy to become discouraged and doubt yourself.
column2: Expect mistakes, by both you and the child, and correct them accordingly.&nbsp
column3: But remember that you're the parent and have a much larger knowledge base as well as the responsibility to help this kid reach a productive adulthood.&nbsp
column4:
And then gear up for a potentially protracted campaign.

I've always spent considerable time trying to keep tabs on the media environment that's surrounding the kids.
column2: I can try to limit the television and computer time, but there are still other screens and devices to focus their attention and I generally take the random sampling approach.&nbsp
column3: That's simple when the media in question is in a public area, such as the television and the family computer.

column2: do I not appear heavy-handed when approaching the personal devices, such as the iPod and the mp3 player?&nbsp
column3: Some of the lyrics are short-term harmless but long-term corrosive to the 'tween/teen attitude and psyche.

column1: <li>Make your own mp3 or iPod available for sharing with the kids.&nbsp
column2: <em>Hey, you wanna hear some real music, try this!&nbsp
column3: Then swap devices and take a little cruise.
column4: It has been effective in giving me a glimpse of what they're listening to and whether I should be concerned.&nbsp
column5: I was truly surprised to find that Eldest had a selection of Etta James pieces from the 1950s on her iPod.

column1: <li>Pay attention to what you see them playing on Youtube or the various websites, then take some moments to visit some of the other offerings by that group.&nbsp
column2: The upshot is that you do have to act on it if seems extreme.&nbsp
column3: In one instance here, Killer Clown Posse has been banned, inasmuch as I can do so.
column4: The discussion with one of the teens pertained to the question of how cool something could be when the video acts out sniper attacks on innocents.&nbsp
column5: I was frank in evoking the Columbine massacre as well as the more recent Amish School Nickel Mines shooting and the teen in question has acknowledged the point.

column1: <li>Visit the websites for favorite stations and view the playlists for most requested songs.&nbsp
column2: Then check a sample against the on-line lyrics from sites such as Lyrics.com
column3: and read them.&nbsp
column4: There are opportunities - if you're willing to make them - to discuss the songs with the kids and if things are bad enough, then you have to be willing to force the issue.&nbsp
column5: It's unpleasant to confront a teen about burning highly objectionable discs but the reality is that it has to happen.&nbsp

column1: <li>Use technology to turn the private media into public media.&nbsp
column2: A friend recently told me that there are devices that be used to hook the mp3 or iPod up to the car radio and I'll investigate that this weekend.&nbsp
column3: I believe that the kids do want to hear things on the air versus having to wear earbuds and I'm willing to invest in such technology.&nbsp

column1: When the average kid is spending hours each day saturated by the electronic media, then something unpleasant - photo, lyric or otherwise - is going to leech through to the kids.
column2: But casting a wide net into the electronic sea at least gives you an insight into the waters in which they swim.

column1:
And whether you also need to jump in as well.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

287,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of the great lessons that I had to learn as a new father was that my life was no longer my own, and that pertained to all of its facets.
column2: This especially included sleep, which became far more dear than I ever realized it could.&nbsp
column3: So what can you expect from the typical child as she moves through life's pipeline?

column1: While no child is alike, their bodies have similar needs and the following chart summarizes what the typical child/teen needs in terms of hours of daily sleep.

column2: height: 183px"" border=""1"" cellspacing=""1"" cellpadding=""1"" width=""685"">
<span style=""font-size: xx-small"">Data:&nbsp
column3: www.webmd.com
column4: and www.practicaldad.com

column1: Bear in mind that the first several months will appear chaotic as the child will sleep intermittently and wake regularly through the night for feeding.
column2: It's your job - both Mom and Dad - through these months to help your infant adapt to a regular schedule that includes sleeping through the night without feeding and obtaining sufficient and routine naps.
column3: But the upshot for many is that during that first year, the night-time feedings will disappear and the child will begin to nap regularly - you might not believe it while in the midst of the chaos, but it will happen.

column1: After about three years of age, the naps will disappear and your child will still need significantly more sleep than you but this will diminish as well.

column2: matter.&nbsp
column3: They help the child's body learn to prepare for sleep and your child will usually look forward to the wind-down from the day.&nbsp
column4: My youngest is still in elementary school and one of the best parts of that pre-teen age is that the bedtimes are earlier, which permits me some of my own quiet time after a full day of work and the normalized chaos that comes from children.

column1: That changes however, when the kids reach the teen years.
column2:
Then the needs change, as well as the surrounding environment.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
288,"1","1",,"xhtml","

From the time that your child is born through the later elementary school years, she'll need a little less sleep each year until she bottoms out at about 8 - 9 hours each night.
column2: Bedtimes will be mid-evening and she'll be up and moving at a relatively early hour each morning.&nbsp
column3: But that amount of nightly sleep required will rise as her body - and his if you have a boy - runs aground on the shoals of puberty.

column1: Kids need more sleep as they enter the teen years with the optimal amount being about 9.5 hours each
column2: night.&nbsp
column3: Most are unaware that many of the key body chemicals and hormones for growth and development are released by the body during sleep.&nbsp
column4: Unfortunately, the combination of technology/environment and the teen's body itself works against most teens getting that amount of sleep on a routine basis.&nbsp
column5: Most teens' bedrooms are a technological cocoon with the presence of television, stereo, radio, phone and computer.&nbsp
column6: They've become used to the technological 'noise' and don't want to separate themselves from the electronic presence of friends available via the media sources or don't wish to turn off the 'noise' with which they're now comfortable.&nbsp
column7: Faced with an early school day, the typical teen is operating on a sleep deficit as the bedtime isn't until much later than a 9.5 hour optimal sleep amount would account for.&nbsp
column8: Assuming that a teen has to rise at about 6:30 in order to prepare and arrive at school on time, the ideal teen bedtime would be about 9:00 the previous evening.

column1: Life with a teen tends to be an emotional rollercoaster fraught with churlish turns and attitudinal drops.
column2: Honestly, it becomes a bit more difficult for some parents because the evening break that came with an earlier bedtime is now gone and there's no longer a perceived&nbsp
column3: relief.&nbsp
column4: It can be easier to blame the desire to stay up later on rebellion and resistance but their late night habits do have a scientific basis.&nbsp
column5: Humans have a &quot
column6: darkness hormone&quot
column7: called melatonin that the body begins to produce in the evening to relax itself and prepare itself for sleep.&nbsp
column8: Studies have found that this hormone starts production in the typical adult at about 10:00 in the evening.&nbsp
column9: The typical teen body however, doesn't begin production of this hormone until almost 1:00 am, a full three hours later.&nbsp
column10: So the teen's body isn't close to being ready to shut down until much later while still facing an early morning wakeup for school.&nbsp
column13: Is it due to the hormonal chaos of puberty or instead environmentally delayed by the ambient light produced by the various screens within the teens' bedrooms?&nbsp

column2: We try to walk the middle ground and not enforce an &quot
column3: early&quot
column4: bedtime that ensures the full 9.5 hours nightly since there's going to be enough potential conflict without it.&nbsp
column5: However, the teens are expected - and required when we catch them - to have&nbsp
column6: the interactive&nbsp
column7: electronics(texting in our case)&nbsp
column8: off at a certain hour before bed so that their bodies have a chance to relax.&nbsp
column9: We're helped by the fact that we've never allowed televisions or computers in their rooms but they do have music available as we did when we were teens.&nbsp
column10: The principle is the same but the only difference is the technology platform.&nbsp
column12: we check on them around bedtime and occasionally afterwards to assure that they're sans electronics.&nbsp
column14: know of other parents who've routinely confiscated cell phones at a certain hour&nbsp
column15: each evening to assure that the texting is done or who've removed the televisions if they're found in use after hours.&nbsp
column16: It ensures that there's going to be conflict, but some is to be expected as the teens test their limits.&nbsp
column17: Frankly, refusing to abide by parental rules is always grounds for a worthwhile conflict since parents should expect to be obeyed if the rules are reasonable and fairly enforced.&nbsp

column1: Teens are able to absorb information and knowledge at an amazing rate and I'm routinely surprised by what my kids know.
column2: But knowledge isn't the same as judgment.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
last&nbsp
column3: evening to answer a question that I asked myself almost exactly sixteen years ago.&nbsp
column4: Today is her birthday and on the morning that she was born, I looked at this infant - graced with more hair than I had and&nbsp
column5: a clear resemblance to her mother - and&nbsp
column6: wondered what she might look like when it came time for that milestone, her driver's license.&nbsp

column2: exactly 5840 days ago and at that moment, it really seemed like forever.&nbsp
column3: There were so many things to work through and learn such as feeding and changing this child, and managing to get her down for sleep without having to depend upon her mother.&nbsp
column4: But with time and persistence, I learned and the process still continues albeit with a different bent.&nbsp
column5: Should I rebid the auto insurance now that I'm going to have a teen driver on the policy and what discounts can I get for driving lessons?&nbsp
column6: What are the household driving rules, which are in addition to the road rules?

column1: The point is that time does indeed pass and your child will reach adulthood, with or without you.
column2: But the quality of that adulthood is also however, largely dependent upon your efforts and imputs.&nbsp
column3: I guarantee that there will be mistakes and that you'll have regrets but children have a wonderful ability to forgive, one that many of us have lost.&nbsp
column4: Learn from the mistakes and rectify them but by all means, stay involved and engage the kids in all aspects of their lives.&nbsp
column5: Regardless whether you're a father or a mother, raising kids is like one long golfer's Mulligan.&nbsp
column6: There will be mistakes but there will be opportunities to make them right if you pay attention and stay with it.

column1: As I finish this note, I'm wondering what she'll look like on her wedding day.
column2: But there's still a great deal to do until we get to that point.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
291,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Several months ago I wrote about the difference between praising your child and overpraising him.
column2: But in reviewing a recent article in Scouting Magazine, I came across a different perspective from psychologist Carol Dweck.

column1: In her research on the effects of praise, she believed that there was a qualitative difference in the form of praise.
column2: The first form was &quot
column3: person praise&quot
column4: , in which a child is praised for their own traits (you're really smart or you're beautiful) while the second form was "
column5: process praise&quot
column6: , in which a child was praised for the process in which they did something well (you did a great job studying for that test).
column7: Her research revealed that there was a quantifiable difference in how the two groups - each receiving its own form, personal or process - did on similar tests.&nbsp

column1: In a two part experiment, students who were provided with identical IQ tests on which they all scored well.
column2: But afterward, one half of the group received person praise while the second half received process praise.&nbsp
column3: In a subsequent part, the students were allowed to choose which of two tests they wanted to take - and there was a discernible difference between the difficulty levels of the tests.&nbsp
column4: The majority of the person praise group chose the easier test while an overwhelming majority - think 90% - of the process praise group chose the harder exam.&nbsp
column5: Subsequent interviews found that the person praise group feared that the test would negatively affect their image, i.e. they wouldn't appear as smart.&nbsp
column6: Finally, each group was given an identical test and the person praise group did discernibly worse than the process praise group.&nbsp
column7: In this instance, the person praise group scored 20% worse than the first test while the process group scored 30% better than the first test.&nbsp
column8: With a testing group of 400 kids, this appears to be significant.

column2: First, you simply must pay attention to what the kids are doing and share with them that you're paying attention.&nbsp
column3: Kids aren't stupid and can tell a line of bull from the truth.&nbsp
column4: Second, offer praise that focuses on what they've done.&nbsp
column5: You can still tell them that they're smart but if they understand that the success comes from the combination of smarts and applying themselves, it will help them build the drive to succeed and overcome obstacles later in their lives.&nbsp
column6: Focusing on the process also helps them understand where things did - or did not - work well in the particular circumstance.

column1: As the psychologist notes in the article, "
column2: We cannot hand children self-esteem on a silver platter, which is what we're trying to do with person praise.&nbsp
column3: What you can do is give them the tools to manage their own self-esteem, to take on challenges and see them through, to build and maintain their own self-esteem.&quot

column1: Which is probably far better said than I could say myself.
column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
292,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Kids are egocentric and so far as they're concerned, your old life died with their birth
column2: but as they age, they can become more curious.&nbsp
column3: They want to hear stories about the family and knowing family history strengthens their sense of self and being a part of something larger.&nbsp
column4: But just&nbsp
column5: how much, especially with this parental generation's use of recreational drugs and casual sex, should you actually reveal about yourself?&nbsp
column6: Because somewhere in that adolescent brain, your past activity will be viewed as a tacit approval for dangerous or unacceptable behavior.

column1: This was brought home by one of my kid's questions last week:
column2: Dad, were you a playah?
column3: When I'm surprised - and I really was at this one - I always try to determine what's prompting the question.&nbsp
column4: <em>Why would you think that I was?&nbsp
column5: The subsequent exchange revealed that it was rooted in an earlier conversation between my boy and his best friend, who's akin to an adoptive son as well.
column6: In the course of family conversations about dating, I've been frank that I was raised with the attitude of &quot
column7: date 'em all&quot
column8: .&nbsp
column9: I've also been clear as they aged that dating isn't synonymous with sleeping with said dates.&nbsp
column10: But this part has been selectively forgotten and now I had to go back and clarify things again.

column1: I'm fortunate that my past is pretty clear.
column2: I was the guy who got more than one woman out of trouble in college by assuring that she was removed from a situation before there were even greater regrets and I was typically &quot
column3: the brother figure&quot
column4: to many women.&nbsp
column5: I reiterated this to the teen but he kept hammering on the question of being a &quot
column6: playah&quot
column7: and it occurred to me that the other part of the question pertained to virginity.&nbsp
column8: I resisted the question further but as we went back and forth, I began to fear that failure to respond in this age of &quot
column10: would be tantamount to confirming that I was sexually active as an early teen.&nbsp
column12: <em>Because you won't stop, all I'll say is that I was much older than you are.&nbsp
column13: His response was dramatic, demanding to know why I'd tell him that and that he didn't want to know.
column14: I'd cracked the box and given him a glimpse of a father as a man before his children came into the world.

column1: How you answer questions about your past is your choice.
column2: I know people who have lied to their children about their past and I even have a family history of forebears lying about an out-of-wedlock birth.&nbsp
column3: I also know those who have been open about their experiences and accepted the discomfort that comes with acknowledging past behaviors.&nbsp
column4: Whichever route you select, remember certain things.

column1: <li>Kids want to look up to their fathers and respect them, unlike what's depicted on television and in the media, so always consider what you choose to reveal about your past behaviors and habits.&nbsp
column2: I didn't know until I was an adult that if my own father were my son, I'd have had him shot.

column1: <li>Expect to spend time out of your comfort zone when talking with the kids about issues, especially when it pertains to sexual behavior.&nbsp
column2: This is conversation that you must have since they won't receive any moral perspective discussing it amongst their peers.

column1: <li>Always offer a moral perspective to any conversation that you have with the kids.&nbsp
column2: It isn't just about being religious, it's helping them build a framework through which they can make the value judgments which are part of life.

column1: <li>Always offer a practical assessment of the risks that can arise from situations.&nbsp
column2: Teens have a notoriously bad ability to assess risk and considering potential consequences with them can be instructive for both of you.

column1: Since then, I've reiterated with my son that I won't provide answers to specific questions since it's none of his business.
column2:
And he's learned that if you don't think that you're going to like the answer, perhaps you shouldn't ask the question.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
293,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With three kids and three separate sports - soccer, volleyball/dance, and baseball respectively by age - the spring season is simply chaos.
column2: So how to manage getting everybody fed in a decent manner, especially if Eldest is a serious vegetarian?

column1: Yes, there are nights when fast food is simply the only alternative, but there are times when the wallet and body need a break from that alternative.
column2: So yesterday was a rummage through the fridge to see what was available and the following plan ensued.
Yesterday:&nbsp
column3: Thaw and cook a frozen turkey breast, cutting the meat off and freezing the majority while reserving some for sandwiches and soup.&nbsp
column4: The turkey carcass was wrapped in plastic and saved until this morning.&nbsp
column5: I also noted that there are 8&quot
column6: tortillas and cheese slices in the fridge along with lettuce.

column2: Today:&nbsp
column3: Using an easy recipe found online, toss the carcass in a large pot with a quartered onion and garlic salt and boil/simmer for about 90 minutes.&nbsp
column4: Then precut all of the remaining vegetables and add the spices in a small bowl for later addition to the soup after the carcass is removed.&nbsp
column5: As for vegetarian eldest, save some chopped vegetables and add to the lettuce so that the mix can be used with the cheese and tortilla to make a vegetarian wrap.

column1: So as the various parties come and go, the food is ready for easy eating before everybody hits the door for where they have to go.
column2: It's not pretty and the traditional sit-down family meal is blown to hell and back, but it's cheaper and healthier than a constant diet of fries and burgers - and fish sandwiches for the vegetarian.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
294,"1","1",,"xhtml","

By the time the kids are in preschool, they're starting different activities and sports and it's a no-brainer to take the other kids along.
column2: They're also young and they have no choice in the matter.&nbsp
column3: But as they age and finally reach a point at which they can reliably be left home alone - and trust me, I've heard some hilarious stories of teens at home - they'll assume that they don't have to go along.&nbsp
column4: And you'll hear the ageless query do I have to go? when you suggest that they go too.

column1: What are some guidelines on whether to take the older kids?
column2: Here's what we do.

column1: <li>If the child is old enough to be alone and it's a practice, then we let them stay home.&nbsp
column2: The proviso is that any homework must be done (and checked) and if there's a chore to do, get it done.&nbsp
column3: If you have to stay - which happens with the baseball practice due to distance - then you'll just be reading or doing paperwork anyways.

column1: <li>If the event is an actual game or concert, then we overlook the rolled eyes and have the kids come along.&nbsp
column2: They might not actually pay attention during the event, especially if it's an outside sport with room to run, but they'll usually check in to ascertain how sibling's doing before returning to play.&nbsp
column3: If it's a concert, then it's another opportunity to learn how to sit quietly and learn the art of patience.&nbsp
column4: The idea is that they at least become used to the idea as a way to show support, even if they initially - and realistically - aren't.&nbsp
column5: But as the habit sinks in and they age, they'll spend more time watching and actually cheering for one another.&nbsp

column1: <li>When the child is older and it pertains to a younger sibling, I've even provided a rationale that was hard to resist.&nbsp
column2: <em>There's years between the two of you and as he ages, you won't be here to see and cheer.&nbsp
column3: He'll miss you and you're going to miss everything that he'll do through that time.&nbsp
column4: But every time that we come to see what&nbsp
column5: you're doing, he'll be along so take advantage of these events now.
column6: In both cases of elder siblings, they've nodded and acquiesced to coming
column7: they even cheered.

column1: It's irritating to have to contend with the deep sighs and rolled eyes.
column2: But it's important to hold the family line because kids need to know that they indeed matter.&nbsp
column3: Like many things with children, these practices take considerable time and attention before they actually take root into a deeper&nbsp
column4:
sense that holds a family together as it grows and ages.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
295,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As kids grow and the schedule tightens, it's easy to say 'no' to a child who wants to play.
column2: There is a long list of items to be checked in a finite period of time and that leaves little room for play.&nbsp
column3: But the reality is that playing with your child might be play for him - or her - but it's actually an important part of a father's responsibilities.&nbsp
column4: Well, mothers as well but it seems to fall more into the realm of fathers.

column1: That was the case this past Saturday morning as I sat at the laptop and tried to write for the site.
column2: We have guidelines on when the Saturday morning television can be turned on and I came downstairs to find Youngest ensconced in front of Cartoon Network.&nbsp
column3: After I said something, Youngest turned off the television and approached, asking if I wanted to play Fiki Football with him.&nbsp
column4: My initial response was a firm no but as I looked at his face and considered that I was sitting in front of a laptop on a Saturday morning, I changed my mind and cleared the kitchen table for the game.
column5: It lasted for the better part of a half-hour and the accompanying conversation veered to school and classmates as well as the best technique for kicking the football.

column1: Making sure that you play with the kids is actually important for multiple reasons.
• It reinforces the sense that they do matter and are important, which is crucial in these days of harried schedules and blown-to-hell family meals.
<li>It builds a bond that can help move beyond the communications problems that often develop as they age and push their limits.&nbsp
column2: On more than one occasion, I've found myself playing Horse at the driveway hoop with Eldest after undergoing several hours of parent/teen tension.

column1: <li>The conversation that results from shooting hoops or playing a board game can be revealing to what's inside their heads and lives at the moment.&nbsp
column2: In Peter Pan, J.M. Barrie writes in the first chapter about the typical mother's habit of tidying up the child's mind after bedtime and removing or placing the clutter.
column3: The point is that this provides you the opportunity to see what's on their mind.

column1: <li>A regular habit of playing with the kids creates an opportunity for them to unburden because they feel more relaxed with your presence.&nbsp
column2: More than one conversation about sex and behavior has arisen from just playing some game with the kids.

column1: <li>It helps you teach good manners and honesty when they're young.&nbsp
column2: You can address cheating and sportsmanship issues early so that it doesn't become ingrained.&nbsp
column3: I realized that if I was called away to the phone during a game of Candyland, one of my kids would reshuffle the card deck so that the next card that I drew was Plumpy while her card was Queen Frostine.&nbsp
column4: I became suspicious after two occurrences and finally confronted her when I was comfortable that that was the situation.

column1: <li>It helps you determine what areas of development need addressed.&nbsp
column2: How are the fine motor skills - drawing and using scissors - versus the gross motor skills?&nbsp
column3: Is there an issue with vision or balance?

column2: Spending time with a board game or basketball helps them learn to pass the time without having to spend money or involve themselves even further with electronics which are sometimes both violent and/or noisy.

column1: It's important to keep a roof over the head and food on the table.
column2: But raising the kids well is vitally important and&nbsp
column3: play is an often neglected part of that job.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
296,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Sometimes it takes tripping over one small tree to make you notice the forest around you.
column2: In this particular instance, a game of Fiki football
column3: was the catalyst to realizing just how many small activities and&nbsp
column4: skills are being lost due to the failure of fathers to pass them along to the kids.&nbsp
column5: And believe me, business has noticed as they've taken up the slack and made money in the process.&nbsp
column6: We're outsourcing fatherhood.

column1: Fiki - Flick It Kick It - football is a cheap little game available at Five-Below, a glorified dollar store that caters to tweens and teens with individually minimal amounts to spend.
column2: Along with a thinly stuffed leather triangle is a plastic football goalpost attached to a base.&nbsp
column3: The point is to take turns flicking the triangle across the table and if the triangle stops with any part of it extending over the opposite edge - your opponent's goalline - then you score a touchdown.&nbsp
column4: Then kick it through the uprights and you score the extra point.&nbsp
column5: What struck me was that this is the exact game that we played on the cafeteria table after lunch thirty plus years ago.&nbsp
column6: Almost any of us could make a triangle out of notebook paper, with the ends tucked into folds, and proceed with play.&nbsp
column7: The goalpost was made by touching the opposing index fingers then holding the thumbs upwards.&nbsp
column8: But this never made it to the next generation and now some enterprising nebbish is profiting from it.

column1: Other companies are profiting from this loss of institutional fatherhood knowledge.
column2: Home Depot and Lowes regularly have Saturday morning classes for kids, showing them how to do basic woodcrafts like birdhouses and pinewood derby cars.&nbsp
column3: Things are nicely arranged and laid out in the workarea, typically located near the tools that the farsighted marketers hope to eventually sell to the 3 - 5% of kids who take up this type of hobby.&nbsp
column4: Kids might be there with a parent or they might be left in the charge of the employee while the parent shops.&nbsp
column5: If the kid has a parent there, it's probably a parent - father or mother - who has minimal access to tools and/or little knowledge of what to do.&nbsp
column6: Likewise, there was recently a <a title=""Amazon:  Dangerous Book For Boys"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_i_1_12?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&amp
column7: field-keywords=daring+book+for+boys&amp
column8: sprefix=daring+book+"">series of books for boys and girls with activities that were fun, cheap and popular in previous generations.
column9: Authors and publishers have realized that there's money to be made here and are pursuing it.

column1: Not all of this loss can be pegged to fatherhood alone.
column2: There was a time <a title=""I Don't Know - I Was Just A Kid"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/Dont-Know-Was-Just-Kid/dp/1932864032/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&amp
column3: s=books&amp
column5: sr=1-1"">when kids were together enough that they passed childhood's institutional knowledge to one another, and that amounted to the imagination and games.
column6: But other knowledge isn't being passed along by fathers, either due to not having learned it during their own youth, fear or self-absorption.&nbsp

column1: This is why we're outsourcing fatherhood and turning it over to those who largely have no interest apart from profit.
column2: The divorce rate in the past several decades, climaxing at nearly 50% of marriages in the early 1990s, has left many men without the fatherhood model upon which to draw in their own experience as a father.&nbsp
column3: Their lack of a father to share this knowledge has deprived them of that same knowledge to pass to their own children.&nbsp
column4: This is compounded by the fear that their own failed efforts will lead to embarrassment in front of the kids and the self-absorption of many men in their own activities.

column1: Fathers have to do more with the kids.
column2: This doesn't mean that they should pick up tools with which they have no familiarity and have at it, but instead focus on what they do know and work on sharing that.&nbsp
column3: Sports, hunting, tinkering, whatever it takes - just utilize it and pass it along to the kids.&nbsp
column4: And as to fear, follow the old adage that if you don't mention you're unfamiliar, they won't notice unless you say something.&nbsp

column1: Then go out and improve as you go.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
297,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Some people say that common sense - which I define as the ability to think critically
column2: -&nbsp
column3: can't be taught and to an extent, that's true.&nbsp
column4: But while some are more blessed with a healthy dose of common sense than others, fathers can help the kids learn to exercise critical thinking skills throughout their youth.&nbsp
column5: Part of my job is to help the child develop their own native crap-o-meter, or what my own father delicately referred to as the Bullshit Detector.

column1: I marvelled at my own father's ability to dissect an issue, idea or advertisement and never found myself able to reach his level.
column2: &nbsp
column3: My mother was also blessed with a broad streak of common sense but didn't express it as analytically as he did.&nbsp
column4: But after years as a commercial multi-line claims adjuster - an adjuster who specializes in property, liability and worker's compensation losses - I realized that listening to enough truth-bending and outright lying developed my own detector to a level that approached my father's.&nbsp
column5: You might say that it's just an unhealthy skepticism and disbelief but to get at the heart of a matter, you have to move past skepticism and ask whether something actually makes sense
column6: if not, where's the failure?

column1: I started when they were at an early age by messing with them when we talked and making outrageously non-sensical comments.
column2: <em>Gee, Elmo's looking rather green today.&nbsp
column3: He's not?&nbsp
column4: How can you tell and what makes you right?
column5: This has progressed through the years so that the kids are usually able to tell when I'm bluffing even if they aren't sure why.&nbsp
column6: Well, two of the three but even that one's making progress.&nbsp
column7: And occasionally, I'll come across something that makes me scratch my head and decide to bring it up for educational purposes.

column1: Tonight's foray into PracticalDad's Crap-o-meter is a Yahoo article about Sears/Kmart's new offering of a cash-for-gold service.
column2: In an effort to make their products continually affordable to cash-strapped consumers, Sears Holdings is offering a service in which spare gold jewelry and items can be sent to a vendor in return for cash.&nbsp
column3: They've thoughtfully provided pre-printed envelopes for the items as well as a tracking mechanism to assure that&nbsp
column4: the transaction doesn't get lost.&nbsp
column5: But my questions and the resulting conversation will hopefully touch upon certain points.

column1: <li>Why would Sears/Kmart offer such a service and why does the cash delivery have to occur within the confines of that particular store?&nbsp
column2: <em>Because they want to provide money for folks who need it.&nbsp
column3: And some of&nbsp
column4: those needs can be met within their store.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: If not, impulse buying will hopefully occur because that's why there's target marketing.

column1: • What else does Sears/Kmart get out of it besides oodles of goodwill and maybe some sales?
column2: <em>Well, how does the gold vendor make money?&nbsp
column3: And if they make money on a percentage cut from the transaction, will they have to share some of the cut with Sears/Kmart for the privilege of making it available within the store?&nbsp
column4: And how much bigger does that cut have to be to make it worthwhile for both parties involved?

column1: <li>For that matter, is all gold even created equal?&nbsp
column2: <em>Gee, do you know that the amount you'd get for the 10k bracelet is less than I'd get for the 14k wedding ring purchased from a high-end Virginia jeweler?&nbsp
<em>It's increasing in value or what it might be buy if it were dollars?&nbsp
column3: If that's so, why would you trade it in to purchase items at a Kmart?

column1: My goal is to actually make them answer the questions, even if there's silence for a bit.
column2: I might have to explain some things but the great effort is to have them talk and not just sit listening while Dad carries on a monologue.

column1: The larger idea of picking apart and reviewing an idea or program isn't likely to take root immediately.
column2:
But with time and persistence, they'll get the hang of it and hopefully avoid some of the mistakes that snag so many others.

As a matter of course, I try to stay on-topic and focus on the message that fathers should do more - and can do more - with the kids and household.
column2: I might throw in some family/personal economics and the occasional general economic article but my focus is kids and family.&nbsp
column3: But today is the occasion where I'll cross that line and touch upon something important but only peripherally related to family and kids.

column1: Despite the absense of greasy smoke and widespread destruction reminiscent of the Second World War, there's a massive battle being fought in Europe.
column2: It's a battle waged with electronic bytes and digitized currency transactions but it's a massive battle nonetheless, waged between the financial elites and the European governments.&nbsp
column3: It's a battle over who possesses real control of society, the sovereign governments or what some refer to as the Plutocrats, as engendered by the financial elites of Wall Street hedge funds and global
column4: investment banks.&nbsp
column5: At stake presently is the European currency, the Euro.&nbsp
column6: While much of the damage to the Euro still results from the issues that were never resolved at its creation, the fact remains that the currency is under attack by the plutocracy and their&nbsp
column7: various financial instruments.

column1: Why should you care and be aware?

column2: corporate executives, Wall Street executives and global bankers - believe that they have gained control of significant levers of power within our own government and are able to manipulate our own currency and regulations.&nbsp
column3: The weakness of the SEC and Congress' agreeing to TARP despite the huge opposition of the American people gives weight to their belief.

column1: <li>The Plutocracy is greedy and seeks to gain wealth at the expense of the people.&nbsp
column2: Removing the Euro removes a currency that threatens the status of the dollar and hence, the power of these Plutocrats.

column1: <li>If European governments cave in to the Plutocracy, they will be emboldened to finish their project of gaining full and effective control of the currency and economy&nbsp
column2: in this country.&nbsp

column1: • This means that the great mass of our children will become nothing more than the financial equivalents of modern-day serfs, working at low-wage jobs to support a credit-driven society that ultimately enriches the few who control the banks and funds that govern the country through their paid-for representatives.
If you had told me two years ago that I'd be writing this, I would have honestly said that you were nuts.
column2: But my children - our children - deserve better than what is promised by such a future.&nbsp
column3: And there is precedence for such a struggle in our own history.&nbsp
column4: The Depression of 1837 - notably remembered by the song Hard Times, written by Stephen Foster to describe the suffering -
column5: was a result of the conflict between President Andrew Jackson and a banker named Nicholas Biddle, who controlled the Bank of the United States.&nbsp
column6: The Sherman Anti-Trust Act was later wielded by President Theodore Roosevelt to assault the Robber Barons, who controlled railroads and industry instead of banks.

column1: So start to pay attention and exercise your right to speak and vote as you see fit.
column2: Understand that there's going to be real economic hardship ahead and that it will be our responsibility to bring our families through it.&nbsp

column1:
But this isn't the first time this has occurred and if we're fortunate, it won't be the last either.

I recall asking my own father that question one night before bedtime.
column2: My world was scary even without the constant news of inflation and threats of nuclear war with the now-dead Soviet Union.&nbsp
column3: I had a test for which I really hadn't studied and there was some neo-neanderthal who made my life miserable in the hallways.&nbsp
column4: My gut was twisted and I dreaded bedtime because I knew that immediately afterwards I awoke to a&nbsp
column5: stressful new day.&nbsp

column1: My own father seemed to be made of an iron core that nothing shook.
column2: He took surprise with great steadiness and simply acknowledged the ongoing mantra of doom with equanimity.&nbsp
column3: I might even see him jump on the bed to Motown - a truly surreal moment - but I never once saw him scared.&nbsp
column4: Concerned, perhaps, with his face in a neutral mask when something really big happened.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: But I never saw him scared.&nbsp
column7: I was surprised to hear him answer that question with&nbsp
column8: Yes, at times I am.
column9: <em>Everybody gets scared, but I think that things are going to be alright.&nbsp
column10: He talked about fear as being something that everybody - everybody - had but he then added that if you stepped back and considered, the fear was generally overstated.
column11: It was one of those conversations upon which you later look back and consider as special.&nbsp

column1: You had to really be there in the mid 1970s to appreciate it.
column2: Rising prices and job losses that struck repeatedly.&nbsp
column3: School thermostats turned low enough that I routinely wore my coat in class and even occasionally my gloves.&nbsp
column4: And in the midst of all of this, I asked my father if we would be alright or if we were going to lose our home.&nbsp
column5: His response was that we would be fine and come through this, so you take care of school and let me worry about this.
column6: I actually did go upstairs to bed feeling relieved and reassured that things would be alright.

column1: It wasn't until my adulthood that I learned and understood more of my father.
column2: Of the nightmares that routinely awoke him, a chinese infantryman charging him with a bayonet aimed at his stomach
column3: of wrapping himself around a scotch bottle when his full set of teeth were later removed by an army dentist
column4: of having to move in with his grandmother when his own father had a heart attack and lost his house in the midst of the Great Depression.&nbsp

column2: stressful times like&nbsp
column3: this that I miss the old man and what he taught me.&nbsp
column4: It's fine to be scared and it's okay to even admit it to our own kids.&nbsp
column5: But it's our job to master ourselves and reassure our own children because they both need and deserve to feel secure.&nbsp
column6: Part of that is because they're our children and we love them and part is because what we teach them by our behavior, our response to adversity, will be passed along to their children.

column1: After our eldest child was born, we took her to visit my folks at our old house.
column2: Dad excused himself from the kitchen and several minutes later, returned with a bundle wrapped in a blanket that actually went clank when he put it on the table.
column3: He unwrapped the parcel to show three 100 ounce silver bars that he'd purchased in the mid 1970s and kept stored away as insurance in case the economy went to hell.&nbsp
column4: It never did and the bars sat in the attic until he figured that there was a good need for his own grandchild.&nbsp
column5: And that was the final part of the lesson:&nbsp
column6: after admitting the fear and reassuring the kids, work to offset the problem as best you can.

Global Reserve Currency.&nbsp
column3: Gold Standard.

column1: You've heard terms like these on the news and in the paper, but what exactly do they mean?
column2: How does the mess in Greece and Europe relate to what's happening here and why should I even care?&nbsp
column3: We're going to spend some bytes in the next several articles laying out the basics of the ongoing financial crisis - no, it never actually went away - and what it means to us.

column1: But first, let me share a true story.
My father once bought a third car because his eldest child, my sister, was now driving.
column2: Since he was having what I now recognize as fully blossomed mid-life crisis, he pulled into the driveway one evening in a sporty, low-slung, forest green convertible, proud that he thought he'd bagged a two-fer.&nbsp
column3: This car was a 1973 Fiat Spyder and it looked fabulous, the best that he could afford with the money available.

column1: We soon learned the joke that Fiat was an acronym for "
column2: Fix It Again, Tony&quot
column3: and it was a car that demanded unrelenting vigilance and discipline, more than any other vehicle we'd owned.&nbsp
column4: It was a mechanically unforgiving auto and if it wasn't assiduously maintained it would wind up at the shop.&nbsp
column5: There were still times that it was in the shop despite my father's best efforts.&nbsp
column6: Because the engine didn't like the Pennsylvania climate, he kept it in the garage and covered the engine itself with a canvas tarp in cold weather.&nbsp
column7: so the morning routine was the enter the garage, lift the hood and remove the tarp, recite a Hail Mary and then turn the ignition.

column1: This car remained in the family until one winter morning when Mom needed to drive it.
column2: She was running late, so she drove the Spyder for a quick run to the local bank.&nbsp
column3: She sat waiting in the drive-thru lane when she noticed the window teller banging on the glass and yelling at her while pointing furiously at the hood.&nbsp
column4: Mom glanced ahead to see that smoke was billowing out from under the hood where the tarp - which she hadn't removed - was burning.&nbsp
column5: After the tarp caught fire, the engine soon followed and in a quick few minutes, there was a toasted Fiat blocking the bank's drive-thru lane.

column2: A Currency As Well As A Car

column1: The dollar, as are all of the world's currencies, are fiat currencies
column2: &nbsp
column3: it isn't an acronym, but actually the Latin term for &quot
column4: faith&quot
column5: .&nbsp
column6: Each is considered a fiat currency because it is backed by the globe's faith and confidence in the ability and will of that particular country to support it in terms of competitive ability, resources and capacity to service its debt.&nbsp
column7: That faith is demonstrated in the daily global transactions involving the buying and selling of the various currencies.&nbsp
column8: All manner of entities engage in currency transactions - companies, banks, hedge funds, individuals and central banks - and it's the number at which buyers are willing to pay versus what sellers will accept that the valuation occurs.&nbsp
column9: And with world-wide networked computers, valutation occurs quickly and globally.&nbsp
column10: Because the Norwegian Krone is used by a country with solid governmental finances and an oil exporting economy, the world demonstrates its respect by valuing that currency higher than the Argentina's, whose government burned international investors by defaulting on its debt.&nbsp
column11: It takes far more Argentinian Pesos to buy one Krone now than it did ten years ago.

column1: And that's the key to my father's Fiat and today's currencies.
column2: Fiat currency is based, to a significant degree, upon the perception and faith of others.&nbsp
column3: Maintaining that faith and supporting that perception requires self-discipline and vigilance on the part of the owner to assure that it continues to be deemed worthwhile by others.&nbsp
column4: If a country's currency gets a poor reputation, like the Italian car, then the global economies vote against it&nbsp
column5: by valuing it less than other currencies.

column1: How Did We Get To a Fiat Currency?
For most of our history, the dollar - like all of the other currencies - was backed by gold and silver and its control was mandated in our Constitution.
column2: What that literally meant, after paper notes were issued, was that somebody who held a dollar was able to go into a&nbsp
column3: bank and trade that paper dollar for a fixed amount of metal, either silver or gold.&nbsp
column4: People learned to accept the dollars because the amount of the metal was fixed and also because it was simply easier to carry paper bills than deal in gold.&nbsp
column5: Because the dollar bill was backed by the metal for which it could be exchanged, it had a steady store of value that buoyed the people's confidence in it as a currency.

column1: This gold standard was a staunch enforcer of discipline upon the international markets.
column2: For instance, if America purchased more from England in 1866 than England purchased from America, then England could take all of the dollars that it had received and return them to the US Treasury for an equivalent amount of gold from the American government's vaults.&nbsp
column3: Consequently, the US government would have less gold than could support the number of its own dollars in circulation, running the risk of default should enough citizens trade paper for bullion.&nbsp
column4: Dollars would have to be withdrawn from circulation and the result would be less money around for the citizenry.&nbsp
column5: So countries had to live within their means or develop new ways to garner wealth.

column1: We're not finished with the gold standard yet, but we need to cover something else first that makes the final days of the gold standard understandable.
Many live by the rule that simpler is better and that runs to international financial transactions as well.
column2: To keep from having to constantly recalculate the value of one currency to another in these transactions, banks and merchants long ago opted to assure that international transactions were usually handled in one currency only.&nbsp
column3: This is referred to as the Global Reserve Currency (GRC) and it's a role presently held by the dollar because it serves as the medium of exchange for almost all international business transactions.

column1: The status of GRC is bestowed by the world upon that currency which, it is view, is the steadiest and best able to weather the various storms - political, economic, natural - that occur.
column2: The dollar became the GRC at the end of the Second World War after a meeting of allied financial ministers at Bretton Woods, after which the subsequent agreement was named.&nbsp
column3: At that time, the US was literally the last country standing after a second global war which devastated dozens of nations and exhausted the country with the existing GRC, Great Britain.&nbsp
column4: It was agreed that going forward, all international transactions would be handled in dollars.

column2: The dollar was now the GRC but it was still backed by gold.&nbsp
column3: The dollar's status as the &quot
column4: anointed one&quot
column5: was only peripherally related to its backing and it had not yet become a fiat currency.&nbsp
column6: At that time, the US had roughly 20000 tons of gold in the government's vaults.

column1: This system lasted for almost thirty years.
column2: And in that time, the country began to persistently run trade and government deficits so that we were sending more dollars overseas than we were bringing in from elsewhere.&nbsp
column3: Our standard of living rose dramatically and we dreamed big dreams and tackled big projects but that meant that periodically, our gold flowed out of Fort Knox.&nbsp
column4: Financing the Vietnam War, the Great Society and Apollo took huge sums of money and those dollars printed were returned by foreigners for gold.&nbsp

column1: And this was where the gold standard ran into problems.
Somewhere around 1969, the government acknowledged that the US was going to run out of gold if things weren't brought under control.
column2: There was yet another meeting of international finance ministers and they hashed out what's now referred to as Bretton Woods II.&nbsp
column3: The dollar - still the biggest kid on the block - continued as the GRC but it was agreed that all of the currencies would &quot
column4: float&quot
column5: in valuation against one another.&nbsp
column6: Gold would no longer be used to back the store of value as it once had.&nbsp
column7: Those valuations would be set by tracking transactions within the global markets and&nbsp
column8: updated by computer, which now made this possible.&nbsp
column9: The dollar's value now floated against other currencies, which was good because we'd lost over half of our gold reserves in the preceding thirty-odd years.&nbsp

column1: The flip side was that if our country didn't pay attention, exercise discipline and maintain our fiat, it would eventually become toast as others punished it in the global marketplace.
So What Do You Need To Remember Going Forward?
<li>The dollar is a fiat currency with a value based solely upon the willingness of people to accept it.&nbsp
column2: That means that perceptions, beliefs and biases play a major role in how well it holds value - especially to pay for things like oil.

column1: <li>The dollar is the Global Reserve Currency, which means that almost all of the world's business transactions occur in the dollar.&nbsp
column2: It also means that the dollar's value is determined not just by folks in this country, but by others throughout the world.

column1: <li>Financial systems can change and if there's a pressing enough reason, change relatively quickly.&nbsp
column2: We went through two major changes - Bretton Woods I and II - within a thirty year period.&nbsp
column3: It might seem like a long time personally, but it's a blink of history's eye.

column1: • Covering a Fiat with a tarp is ultimately bad for the Fiat.

I don't know any parents who enjoy saying no to their child.
column2: The reality however, is that children need to hear the word as it helps them understand that they can't have everything that they want and that the world doesn't revolve around them.&nbsp
column3: In reality, parents with small children have to pretty much revolve around them but the kids don't have to know that.&nbsp
column4: So&nbsp
column5: here are some things to remember about telling your child no.

column1: <li>Be clear and firm with your voice when you say it.&nbsp
column2: Kids aren't stupid and will note any indecision as much as sharks smell blood in the water.
to think about things before saying it and be ready to have a simple and legitimate&nbsp
column3: reason.&nbsp
column4: With multiple kids and multiple activities, I'm prone to reflexively saying no in the moment and then have to go back and reconsider if the child responds with a good point.
column5: That few seconds of thought can save you from the reputation of going back on a decision.&nbsp

column1: • One parent taught me that if you're saying something to stop a child from engaging in a potentially dangerous activity, use stop instead of no.
column2: Some kids do understand that the word stop has safety issues involved while the word no has the automatic impression of Dad just saying it because that's what he says.
column3: I've tried it and it actually does make a difference.

column1: <li>Don't take it personally if the kids respond with attitude or appear not to like you.&nbsp
column2: Part of being a father is remembering that you're a grown-up and it's your job to look at the larger picture.&nbsp
column3: It's irritating, but I can go for days without being liked&nbsp
column4: - C'est la vie.

column1: <li>Be prepared to repeat yourself and don't be afraid to apply consequences if the nagging doesn't stop.&nbsp
column2: If you have a legitimate reason, stick with it.

column1: <li>That said, as the kids have aged, I've tried to offer alternatives when the situation allows.&nbsp
column2: It teaches the kids - over time - that there are other possibilities that can be explored and found acceptable.&nbsp
column3: <em>No, Johnny can't spend the night because we leave for Grandma's early tomorrow morning.&nbsp
column4: But he can come by for a while this evening and I'll take him home.

column2: want what they want and that's the nature of children.&nbsp
column3: But it's our jobs as fathers to temper their wants with the reality of daily life around us.&nbsp

column2: Supernanny&quot
column3: but find myself conflicted while watching it.&nbsp
column4: On the one hand, it does a good job of introducing important tools and points that bring the particular family from train wreck to functional.&nbsp
column5: But even assuming that everybody's not on absolute best behavior for the camera, the one hour limit doesn't show the maddening, frustrating efforts at getting to that desired point.

column1: Being an involved father - or mother for that matter - isn't always easy.
column2: The end of the show displays an engaged family playing in the yard and smiling happily.&nbsp
column3: But the reality is that while those moments certainly exist, there are plenty of other moments where you're trying to ride herd on and teach kids that sometimes aren't going to cooperate.&nbsp
column4: The non-cooperation can be limited to one child but if there are more kids involved, it's likely to spread as kids start to veer off the track for various reasons.&nbsp
column5: They might find it fun to drive Dad over the edge or they start to misbehave to gain attention like the repreobate sibling.&nbsp
column6: Or they join in solidarity of teen rebellion.

column2: Time-outs are a good disciplinary tool when the kids are younger and a TV show will demonstrate it being done by a parent in a several minute segment.&nbsp
column3: You might see the Dad returning the kid to the spot when&nbsp
column4: he tires of it, but that only takes a few times before the kid knuckles under - and that's exactly what it is - and remains there.&nbsp
column5: And again, at the end of the show, things are infinitely improved.&nbsp
column6: But the reality is that the process by which a child learns that you're serious can take far longer.&nbsp
column7: I've had early time-outs take longer than an hour as the child repeatedly gets up to leave without permission and the mutual frustration level is high.&nbsp
column8: But you can't quit because that only teaches the child that further disobedience is permissible.&nbsp
column9: So don't be surprised if you find that your voice and blood pressure are raised and an out-of-body view shows you to appear to be on your last shred of patience.

column1: • Tag-team the situation with your mate so that you can get a short breather before re-entering and taking your turn.

column2: I've enforced time-outs with a recalcitrant child by using a three-count with loss of favored toys/privileges for refusal to cooperate.

column1: • Then be sure to enforce that measure.
<li>Send the child to bed for the night.&nbsp
column2: They'll scream and carry on but will eventually wear out and you'll get some quiet.&nbsp
column3: If that means it's as early as 5 PM, so be it.&nbsp
column4: There are times when the child is legitimately at the end of his tether due to exhaustion and simply cannot control himself.

column1: <li>If you're alone and have to take a breather to keep from snapping, take that break and remove yourself.&nbsp
column2: Then go back and resume.

column1: • When the situation is finally resolved, remember to go back and follow up with some conversation about behavior and consequences.
There are times that you will become angry and some of those times are entirely appropriate.
column2: Being angry doesn't make you a bad parent.&nbsp
column3:
The difference is what you do with the anger and how you channel it.

• Practicing for a four minute school presentation the next day.
• Monitoring deadlines for school activities and projects.
<li>Estimating costs and laying out the steps for a summer&nbsp
column2: fishpond project.

kids aren't going to automatically figure things out by themselves and you can't assume that they just &quot

The toxic college debt meme is spreading and if you want a glimpse of what's liable to happen here, consider the situation in the UK.
column2: As you may be aware, the UK is one of multiple European countries that are looking at grim economic times in the next several decades and the new coalition government is taking steps to lay out new austerity measures.&nbsp
column3: While the figures are still nebulous, the prospect is that the size of the UK national debt will require up to 20% cuts in many programs, if not all of them.&nbsp
column4: And financing of higher education is one of the programs on the table.

column1: A few words about the UK university system.
column2: The universities there are largely under the purview of a Universities Minister within the government, who in this case is David Willetts.&nbsp
column3: Like the US, many of the students will borrow to finance their education and the average English University graduate will leave with a debt owed of about 22,000 Pounds (almost $32,000 at an exchange rate of $1.45).&nbsp
column4: Much of the money comes from public funding and unlike the US, repayment isn't required until the graduate is employed and has an annual&nbsp
column5: income of at least 15,000 Pounds (almost $22,000 at the same exchange rate).&nbsp
column6: With job prospects amongst young people much poorer than their older countrymen, that means that a significant amount of debt is simply being carried without repayment until the student is several years older and no cash flow back to a starving national treasury.

column1: The upshot is a series of moves - and corresponding comments - from the UK Universities Minister that are best likened to a bushwhacking of unaware students unprepared for the real world about to be unleashed on them.
column2: The first and obvious move is discussion of a rise in annual university fees.&nbsp
column3: Yes, being essentially part of European society, there is an English National Union of Students which opposes the increase
column4: and being English and students, they'll probably find their voice in a series of riots.&nbsp

column2: is a&nbsp
column3: structural changes that are really more daunting.&nbsp
column4: First is the suggestion that English teenagers place a greater emphasis upon entry into an apprenticeship program with practical training.&nbsp
column5: If they continue and do well, then an actual degree could be considered.&nbsp
column6: The article provides the example of entry into an apprentice position with British Telecom followed later by a possible degree in Electrical Engineering.&nbsp
column7: The problem with that is the question of just how many hands-on positions there are in the English economy to support the masses of young people who would want such a position.&nbsp
column8: What exactly does England do and make anymore?

column2: another major institutional change.&nbsp
column3: As Willetts first&nbsp
column4: stated, public funding of student higher education is a &quot
column5: burden on the taxpayer that had to be tackled.&quot
column6: &nbsp
column7: The common view for years has been that the public should help pay for a youngster's education, akin to it takes a village to raise a child on a larger scale.
column8: But in the new austerity, the government and culture will shift its view to one that again places the bulk of the educational onus back onto the family.&nbsp
column9: This paradigm shift back to the individual is reinforced by Willetts' other comment that &quot
column10: the so-called debt (students) have is more like an obligation to pay a higher income tax.&quot
column12: So we'll no longer call it debt but instead consider it as something to be paid for the added benefit of an education.&nbsp
column13: Regardless of whether or not that value-added education actually leads to higher income.&nbsp
column14: The response of the young president-elect&nbsp
column15: of the National Union of Students, Aaron Porter, was that it &quot
column16: very much felt like debt to them.&quot

column1: The situation is a microcosm of the coming debates on the role of higher education and how to pay for it.
column2: The comments section contained a succinct summation of the position in which English teens and young adults find themselves.&nbsp
column3: &quot
column4: Kibblesworth&quot
column5: writes:

column1: And it's all very well urging everyone to go into apprenticeship now - but the fact is that schools, for the last 13 years, have pretty much based their goals on getting their students to pass exams to get into uni.
column2: No real skills are taught...We were constantly told that uni was the only way we were ever going to get a decent job.&nbsp
column3: Many of us have applied - and many more have taken out student loans already.

column1: The reality is that this view has been promulgated for more than 13 years, but it's been about that long to the young Kibblesworth.
Our job is to prepare our children for their adulthood and our real influence should last greater than the years that we are their legal guardians.
column2:
Times are changing and we have an obligation to both understand the present circumstances and speak frankly and honestly to them about what they should expect and how to enter their adult world prepared to survive and prosper.

column1:
306,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Shopping for kids clothing gets a little dicier when the kids reach the teen years.
column2: The occasionally wild swings in the growth rate makes purchases a hit/miss proposition and my response is to keep things simple.&nbsp
column3: The everyday wear is cheap enough at Kmart that I'll hit there for jeans and shirts, supplemented by hand-me-downs from friends with boys older than my own.&nbsp
column4: But one of the things for which I'm responsible is teaching the boys how to dress appropriately and that means that they have some basic and decent items for events such as church, school concerts and more formal occasions.&nbsp
column5: That also means that I have to show them how to pay attention to the details so that they don't come off looking like Jethro Bodeen.&nbsp
column6: Unfortunately, I don't believe that any quality dresswear is available at Kmart.&nbsp
column7: So how do I match decent clothing that's also inexpensive for a boy who's going to last in it for a maximum of 6 months, if that?

column1: After our end-of-school lunch with Mom and the kids, we split up in the mall
column2: my wife and Eldest went to look at bathing suits while the boys and I browsed in a music store.&nbsp
column3: After we finished, we went to the department store bathing suit area to pick up the ladies.&nbsp
column4: Middle, who's now 13, and I wandered to the Men's Department and after eyeballing him, asked him to try on a plain men's blazer.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: My appraising&nbsp
column7: eye is still decent and he went into a 36 jacket, although the sleeves were too short so I moved him up to a 36 Regular.&nbsp
column8: As he tried on the blazers, I asked him to do certain things to ascertain if it fit properly and I also made it a point to explain why he was doing these things.&nbsp

column1: <li>Lift your arms in front of you like Frankenstein.&nbsp
column2: How far up along the wrist do the sleeves ride?&nbsp
column3: Let you arms hang naturally at your side.&nbsp
column4: Does the sleeve come about halfway between the bottom thumb joint and the wrist?

column1: <li>Button the top button of the jacket - you typically don't button both - and look in the mirror.&nbsp
column2: Does the material lay naturally around your midsection or does it appear to be tight?

column1: <li>Turn around and keep the jacket buttoned.&nbsp
column2: Does it appear to be tight and stretch (&quot
column3: span&quot
column4: ) across the back?

column1: <li>How far down along the torso does the jacket hang?&nbsp
column2: Teens are notable for some call the colt stage since they can grow disproportionately.
column3: In Middle's case, he's got a long torso and disproportionately long arms that grew ahead of the rest of his body.

column2: How do I reconcile my belief that he, like all teens, needs to have some truly decent clothing and the recognition that this blazer was on sale for $90 and he'll be out of it in months?

column1: The plan is to make one or more visits to Goodwill in the next week.
column2: In my experience - and some of my own clothing comes from there - the dress clothing tends to be gently used and in decent condition.&nbsp
column3: The men's clothing typically comes from guys who have outgrown it themselves but has been cared for in its previous use.&nbsp
column4: We'll drop by several times and search for a 36 Regular jacket that has held up well and pick it up for about $7.50.&nbsp
column5: If I can keep on top of Middle so that the jacket continues to be in decent shape, it might go to Youngest when he's older.

column1: That assumes that their the same torso/arm proportions.
column2: If they aren't, then it's back to Goodwill again.

column1: When the guys have finished growing, then we'll take them out for some new, high quality menswear.
