column1:
307,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Any shift from one aspect to another is typically bumpy and that's no different from going from the school year to summer vacation.
column2: The change is noted by a flurry of activity as kids have end-of-school family nights/parties, tournaments, playoffs/championships and recitals.&nbsp
column3: In this household, we've survived the tournaments and playoffs - and championship win - and are awaiting the final recital and the corollary practices.&nbsp
column4: It creates greater stress as the practices and events sometimes overlap and it's difficult to manage the usual household activities as well.

column1: There are certain things that I stay on top of during these stretches, even as I've learned that some of the daily stuff has to wait.

column2: Kids will tend to shed equipment entering the house as a snake sheds its skin.&nbsp
column3: Unchecked, the cleats will be left in one location and the socks can be found under the family room sofa while the shin guards have been tossed across the room and landed behind the television set.&nbsp
column4: Make certain that the child properly disposes of equipment upon entering the house so that when called upon for the next use before the upcoming game, it can be easily found and the frantic agitation avoided.

column1: <li>Assure that the uniforms and outfits are cleaned in time for the next game.&nbsp
column2: It's tempting to think that the shirt doesn't look dirty or might not smell, but the reality is that the kids do get dirty and you're setting an example by how you handle it.&nbsp
column3: Besides, would you really want to wear a jockstrap that's been through a seven inning or sixty minute game?

column1: <li>The water bottles are cleaned and ready to go.&nbsp
column2: One of us will also frequently toss one or more bottles in the fridge the morning of a game so that the water's relatively cold at gametime.&nbsp
column3: If the weather's hot, we'll even throw a water bottle in the freezer for several hours so that the ice will melt in the heat and keep the water cold.&nbsp

column2: Some smaller kids teams will have post-game treats and parents take responsibility for individual weeks.&nbsp
column3: Even as the kids age, some parents will provide half-time snacks - oranges and grapes - for a quick energy boost at the half.&nbsp
column4: So what are you responsible for and what has to be done to make it happen?

column1: <li>At the end of the season, is anybody taking responsibility for getting the coach(es) a thank you gift or card?&nbsp
column2: In most instances, these activities happen because different parents are stepping up and volunteering their time and some gesture is only reasonable and appropriate.&nbsp
column3: In the case of the baseball coaches - all of whom are fathers - each received a gift card and the head coach got a ball signed by all of the players.&nbsp
column4: The soccer coaches - both mothers - likewise got gift cards accompanied by a card signed by the team.

column1: <li>Even if family meals themselves are blown out of the water, the kids still have to eat decently.&nbsp
column2: Are they getting the proteins, fruits and vegetables that their bodies require?&nbsp
column3: In our case, we've learned to stock up on eggs since they're easy to fix and are a great source of protein prior to&nbsp
column4: a game.&nbsp
column5: Likewise, is the food prepared in time for them before departure?&nbsp
column6: Eating a meal and then immediately running 70 minutes in a soccer game is a recipe for disaster, so quick and decent meals are prepared for eating about 90 minutes before the event - if possible.

column1: Much of the daily stuff will wait until the evening or weekend for completion.
column2:
And then when everything's done, I'll take a deep breath and get ready for the summer break.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
you spend any time talking with other fathers, you can expect to hear the same concerns and irritations about the kids.&nbsp
column3: They're disorganized, late, unmindful of the time.&nbsp
column4: The difficulty is that most of us forget what it's like to have been kids but if you think about it, you'll find that you probably weren't that much different in those regards.&nbsp
column5: And if you think about it further, you'll sometimes run across ways to help your kid so that the irritating moments are fewer.&nbsp
column6: It was the situation that another father - who I'll call Bill - considered and came across a simple answer for his son's situation.

column1: Bill is the father of Jacob, a rising second grader playing for a little league team that's composed of many older boys.
column2: He's on the lowest cusp of the age grouping for that level but his level of play is such that he'd be wasting his time at the lower level of coach-pitch baseball.&nbsp
column3: When those situations occur, you expect that the younger player will struggle a bit as he (or she) plays up to the level of boys who might be three years older.&nbsp
column4: But&nbsp
column5: Jacob is truly a gifted, gritty little guy whose play typically matched that of even the oldest boys.&nbsp
column6: When I first saw Jacob at practice, I was surprised by&nbsp
column7: his skill level both with the glove as well as the bat.&nbsp
column8: As the boys were messing around at the end-of-season team picnic, Bill and I chatted and the topic turned to the pre-game household rituals, especially in regards to trying to get out of the door on time.&nbsp
column9: Bill's expectations were simple and he understood that laundry meant that the clothing was sometimes out of the boy's control, but he did expect that the boy would know where his hat was.&nbsp
column11: but many young boys frequently can't find their own heads.&nbsp
column12: After several instances of not knowing the hat's location - and it is a nice hat with a stitched league logo, by the way - Bill settled on the uniform hook.

column1: The uniform hook is a standard metal coat hook that can be mounted on a wall.
column2: There are two protruding hooks attached to the same base, the upper hook being larger and extending farther than the smaller lower hook.&nbsp
column3: Bill mounted one of these hooks in the bedroom with simple instructions:&nbsp
column4: your uniform and hat stay on the hook.&nbsp
column5: <em>We won't fold the clean uniform and put it in the drawer with the other clothes, we'll just hang it on the hook.&nbsp
column6: And you will keep your hat on the hook, ready for when you have to go play ball.&nbsp
column7: Yeah, there's now a hook with clothing mounted on the wall but I think that that's acceptable given all of the other nonsense that's in a boy's room.

column1: It's a simple and effective solution that keeps things easy for the kids and the parents.
column2: Dad doesn't have to go upstairs to find the game shirt that's in the drawer where it belongs.&nbsp
column3: Junior knows that he's got a special spot for something that he probably prizes and that even serves as a visual reminder of something that he loves.&nbsp
column4: And the only words that usually have to be spoken are a reminder upon return from the game to put the hat on the hook.

column1: Kids want to please their parents if given the chance and they especially want to show how they're progressing as they grow.
column2:
Sometimes it only takes a little thought to come up with a workable plan to minimize the angst and help the child show what he can do.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
Scott at an auction recently, also a father with three young adult children, and I unfortunately put my foot in my mouth - a not uncommon occurrence for me.&nbsp
column3: He was relating that they were gathering furniture in the garage for their youngest's move to a new apartment with his college friend and his wife commented that they'd have to probably &quot
column4: move that s*** for him as well.&quot
column5: &nbsp
column6: When he asked if I could believe that she would say that something like, my response was that I really could believe that.

column1: He was visibly annoyed, especially since his wife is a quiet and capable woman
column2: who&nbsp
column3: never uses profanity.&nbsp

column1: Kids will act -or not act - in a way that's guaranteed to irritate you and one of the ways that this will show is your language.
column2: My late father was a former Korean War-era army drill instructor and I grew up in a household that wasn't obscene but certainly profane at times.&nbsp
column3: If I had to characterize him as a television father, he was closest&nbsp
column4: to Red Forman of&nbsp
column5: <em>That 70s&nbsp
column6: Show.&nbsp
column8: He was capable of stringing together expletives and&nbsp
column9: phrases that alternated between colorful, vulgar, scatological and physically impossible - which made them especially hilarious to a boy in his middle-teens.&nbsp
column10: That's carried over to my own household although I do try to monitor what comes out of my mouth and can honestly say that much of what I heard as a kid and teen has never made it to my own kids.&nbsp
column11: Tell my kids that however, and they simply won't believe it.

column1: The upshot is that I can't just haul off and yell when they in turn use a poor choice of words.
column2: I can say that I'm an adult and they're not, but that will only carry over to behavior within the presence of adults and&nbsp
column3: not to language used around their peers.&nbsp
column4: I have to set an example and try to actively monitor what I say.&nbsp
column5: There are certain guidelines that I've adopted over the years and to which I try to adhere.

column2: to&nbsp
column3: describe&nbsp
column4: other people.&nbsp
column5: I'll use terms such as cretin, moron, idiot or the family favorite, bonehead.&nbsp
column6: As they've grown, we've had conversations about judging people based upon their behavior instead of their gender and race - even religion - and I'm adamant that you have to make value judgments but they have to be based on the actions of a person.&nbsp
column7: It's not an easy conversation with a young child but it's easier after they hit elementary school.

column1: • Certain words have simply vanished from my vocabulary, including the F-bomb.
<li>Don't chastise a child who's used an expletive immediately after a physical injury.&nbsp
column2: When Youngest took a baseball in the mouth and bled from a gashed lip, I let the immediate expletive sonuvabitch pass.
column3: We'll worry about the lip and blood first and if the language continues, then we'll deal with it.&nbsp
column4: Besides, when he beaned me in the kidney with a pitch last week, I said the exact same thing.&nbsp
column5: Like son, like father.

column1: <li>Never use a derogatory term to refer to your child, even when they've done something that qualifies as certifiably stupid.&nbsp
column2: I grew up with dumbass and never liked the term.
column3: It's better to condemn the behavior and I'll try to say something akin to you're smarter than that, so why'd you do something so idiotic/stupid/dumb?
column4: Full disclosure:&nbsp
column5: Even I've been appalled enough in the moment to&nbsp
column6: refer to more than one child as idiots.&nbsp
column7: But I try hard to avoid those instances and have apologized in the follow-up conversation.&nbsp
column8: Except once and I'll never apologize for that one since they were old enough to know better.

column1: • There is such a thing as guy talk and I've used it in small amounts around the elder son after he reached middle school.
column2: I adhere to the rules as listed above and am clear with the boy that this conversation is strictly between father and son and has no place amongst the remainder of the family or outside.&nbsp
column3: And when I've heard him violate those rules - and you'll know when you hear it - then the result has been that the guy talk has gone away for a period of time.

column1: • The flip side of guy talk is that I refuse to comment on another woman's appearance.
column2: He's the one with addled testosterone and I expect to hear some comments about being hot, but I refuse to comment.
column3: Frankly, it would be wildly inappropriate and borderline perverse to comment on a child his age and I don't want him thinking that I'm looking at anyone other than his mother.&nbsp
column4: Kids need stability and the thought that Dad is looking outside the house is destabilizing.

column1: The language is an ongoing work in progress and I really am much better than I was as a young adult, not that they'll believe it.
column2:
And now I have to figure out what I'll say to Scott when I next see him.

column1:
310,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's natural that kids are going to press limits and defy parents.
column2: They're growing and testing limits and the results when the limits are enforced aren't always pretty.&nbsp
column3: But what do you do with a kid who ignores you in the moment and proceeds with whatever it is that they want?&nbsp
column4: That's the situation that I learned about this morning when a father banned television for his middle-school son and the boy then took the remote and sat down and flipped on the set.&nbsp
column5: What are the options available?

column1: Let me start by saying that I'm a firm believer in parental/paternal authority, what some now consider to be a quaint notion.
column2: I'm legally responsible for their safety and behavior&nbsp
column3: and&nbsp
column4: I believe that they simply don't have the experience and judgment to&nbsp
column5: handle whatever&nbsp
column6: comes their way.&nbsp
column7: So if&nbsp
column8: I expect them to listen when those crunch times&nbsp
column10: able to depend on them to listen - and obey - when the stakes aren't so high.&nbsp
column11: That means that they don't have the option of picking and choosing when to listen
column12: they can question me if they want and&nbsp
column14: and there have been moments when&nbsp
column15: I'll even change my mind if&nbsp
column16: the objection both makes sense and is properly presented.&nbsp
column18: - and that includes teen - is expected to toe the line when required.&nbsp
column19: And that's where it gets dicey.

column2: Junior takes the remote and clicks on the television despite the ban, what are the options?
or do nothing and continue to talk/lecture/argue with the boy.&nbsp
column3: The reality is that the advantage now lays with the boy.&nbsp
column4: He's ensconced on the sofa and watching television while&nbsp
column5: Dad's the one who is standing there talking.&nbsp
column6: The thought probably running through&nbsp
column7: his head is that if he continues on the same path, then Dad will tire and&nbsp
column8: eventually leave and he can continue on with the show.&nbsp
column10: obvious problem with this approach is that&nbsp
column11: the kid's learned that he'll win and the situations will continue and worsen through the years until the situation is untenable.

column1: <li>Physically go after the remote and remove it&nbsp
column2: from the boy's hands.&nbsp
column3: Adolescent boys are particularly difficult with&nbsp
column4: testosterone and growing masculinity and the risk is that there's going to be a full-blown brawl.&nbsp
column5: Worse than that, if the kid is hurt then you have to consider the prospect of being charged with abuse.&nbsp
column6: If that doesn't happen, you're still faced with the roiled emotions and damaged pride that can created further damage.

column1: • Know what the boy truly values and then use leverage
column2: to regain the remote.&nbsp
column3: If the kid has a cellphone, use that to regain the remote.&nbsp
column4: Threaten to take the cellphone and if he physically has it, then promise to call the carrier and cancel the contract.&nbsp
column5: The key is that if you're going to use leverage, you&nbsp
column6: have to&nbsp
column7: follow through with whatever's&nbsp
column8: promised.&nbsp
column10: then to have a history of following through with what's promised
column11: and that's something that comes from paying attention and following through from the youngest ages.&nbsp
column12: You can still do it if it's new to the boy, but the situation will still be a mess.&nbsp
column14: I have a track record of following through on unpleasant consequences and have used leverage successfully on&nbsp
column15: a number of occasions with all three of the kids.

column1: That's the reality that you often won't see on the parenting shows, a reality of tension and unpleasantness that simply has to be waded through.
column2: There's liable to be yelling and while I don't spend my time bellowing, there are actually moments when it serves a purpose.&nbsp
column3:
But the important thing is to make sure that Junior toes the line because if he doesn't, then the unpleasantries will spill outside the house into other, more public, venues.

column1:
311,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Throughout my wife's first pregnancy and the first several months of Eldest's life, I had difficulty believing that I was a father.
column2: The guy in the mirror was the same one that I'd known throughout my life and it didn't register that now I was going to be someone akin to my own father and all of his peers.
column3: What precisely should a father look like?&nbsp
column4: Certainly not the guy who several years before was partying in a club.&nbsp
column5: The idea of fatherhood has settled with time and I now suspect that I appear to my own kids as my dad appeared to me.&nbsp
column6: But the big secret is that there is no father &quot
column7: look&quot
column8: that makes one stand out as an identifiable dad.

column1: If you want to examine this, spend time watching the men who are with their kids at events.
column2: The event to which I'm referring now was the weekend cub scout resident camp attended by about 150 boys and their accompanying parents - a few moms but mostly dads.&nbsp
column3: What do I notice about the guys?

column1: • Most fathers favor beaten and semi-ratty baseball caps, the bills comfortably bent and the headband stained with sweat.
• The large majority of us have short haircuts that are easy to clean and maintain and a fairly sizeable minority is bald.
<li>Many of the fathers are at least in their mid-thirties and some of us are significantly older than that.&nbsp
column2: There are very few fathers who are discernibly less than thirty years of age.

column1: <li>Many of the fathers carry a corresponding paunch varying from mild love handles to beer kegs.&nbsp
column2: The arms might be thick and muscular but the midsection is as well.

column1: • Many of the fathers thrived on the morning cup of coffee and are capable of making it last until the early afternoon.
• Many of the fathers looked at their sons with a varying mix of love, exasperation and wonderment, realizing that they too were once as spastic and wild as their boys.

• This father at least wished that there could be a similar event to share with the daughter, but is aware that Girl Scout guidelines forbid close distances between men and girls at campsites and that the sense is that men are discouraged from attending due to liability guidelines.
<li>All of the fathers were walking billboards,&nbsp
column2: carrying ads&nbsp
column3: and insignia on the caps and&nbsp
column4: shirts.&nbsp
column5: These range from favorite fishing and boating businesses to NASCAR&nbsp
column6: sponsors and even the Israeli Defense Force.

column2: concept of pacing oneself&nbsp
column3: as the boys run ahead, saving themselves for when they have to carry the boys&nbsp
column4: before Taps sounds in the&nbsp
column5: mid-evening.&nbsp
column6: The kids can&nbsp
column7: run, but the&nbsp
column8: Dads will find a spot&nbsp

column1: • Despite the regulations about all medications being handled at the camp first-aid cabin, more than a few of us kept a small bottle of Advil in our kit.
• Many of the fathers kept a running dialogue with their sons about the location of towels, trunks and toothbrushes.
<li>More than one father was heard to say <em>of course there are flies out here, you're camping.&nbsp
column2: What do you expect?

column1: • Many fathers looked uncomfortable singing at the first night's campfire but by the third night, were shouting at the top of their lungs during the songs.
<li>While some mothers were concerned with the boys' appearance - and I have heard more than one talk through the years about staying clean and neat - the fathers' attitude was indifference.&nbsp
column2: You're camping, what do you expect?

column1: There is no look to fatherhood and there is no image.
column2: We're all different but strikingly similar in the desire to see our kids grow well into productive adults who can handle whatever comes along.&nbsp
column3: And if that means that we're dirty, sweaty and unkempt, so be it.

column2:
What do you expect?

column1:
312,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Not all kids develop their skills at the same rate and that runs the gamut of activities.
column2: Some are poor at hand-eye coordination while those who excel at that are lousy at gross motor skills.&nbsp
column3: That's the case with all three of the kids here and notably the case with Youngest's bicycle skills.&nbsp
column4: That's normally something that doesn't worry me but when other kids are riding on the neighborhood streets and he's still uncertain with his balance and skills, then I have to pay particular attention.

column1: Youngest is far and away a big boy, head-and-shoulder above his classmates and is wearing hand-me-down clothing that his older brother wore when he was three years older than Youngest is now.
column2: Judging from the commentary of a physical therapist friend - who specializes in balance issues - that growth has impacted the balance skills which simply haven't caught up and compensated for the larger body.&nbsp
column3: I haven't pressed the issue and have let him set the pace for the past two&nbsp
column4: years
column5: we'd go to the local playground and ride around while he slowly learned his skills and it's been in the last three weeks that he's finally mastered the skills.

column1: The issue that arose last week was his wish to ride back to his friend's house and then ride with the friend and family to a neighborhood playground.
column2: I've done no practical road skills with him apart from talking about road rules and that doesn't qualify as prepared.&nbsp
column3: He desperately wanted to go, especially since this child will sometimes taunt if someone's skills don't measure his, but I refused and dropped him off at the friend's house with his Razor Scooter.&nbsp
column4: That's not so far-fetched I figured, since there are any number of neighborhood teens who ride their Razors and do stunts with them.&nbsp
column5: It worked on that occasion but the occasion will arise again and he needs to be prepared.&nbsp
column6: The other aspect is that road safety and skills are my responsibility and not that of some other parent
column7: taking a child on the road involves issues of legal liability and that's my problem.

column1: So tonight began the road rules practicum.
column2: We started with the rules discussion before we even left the driveway:&nbsp

column1: <li>Ride on the right side with the traffic
<li>Stop at every stop sign and look both ways AND behind
<li>Know the hand signs for right, left and stop
<li>Know the surrounding traffic and don't think that they know you
• Ride single file but stay in front of me where I can see you.
After discussing the rules, we talked about the route and what we'd do, then we left.
On one level, this shouldn't be about "
column2: keeping up with the developmentally advanced Joneses&quot
column3: .&nbsp
column4: Over the next week, we'll take progressively longer road trips and will continue until I'm comfortable that he's mastered the road skills.&nbsp
column5: But on the other hand, when he's got the balance and riding issues down pat, then it's my responsibility to help take him over the final hump and that might mean that I have to take extra time to assure that it's done properly.&nbsp
column6: When I'm comfortable that he's there, then I'll turn him loose with the friend and family.&nbsp
column7: And if he's still not there, I can at least honestly say that he needs some additional work but has the basics down pat.

column1:
I won't push the skills faster than they seem to be capable of going, but once they're there, I have to be ready to make the time to finish the job.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

313,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Doing things and having fun comes naturally to kids, but other areas like time management and thinking things through don't come so naturally.
column2: This is precisely why I've draftedand instituted the Details Sheet.

column1: Kids are generally self-absorbed and egocentric, so not only do they NOT think through their own details, they won't consider anybody else's details either.
column2: This is what drove me over the edge the other evening as plans were formulated and reformulated with no realization that the lack of drivers' licenses meant that Dad would have to be formally involved.&nbsp
column3: When I required that these&nbsp
column4: carefully - at least what two teens consider carefully - laid plans be re-laid with some foot in reality, the sparks flew.

column1: The basis for time management in the PracticalDad household is the family calendar, which I assiduously maintain during the school year.
column2: With the summer schedule, I haven't been as attentive and have mistakenly thought that they'd be old enough to update some of their own activities.&nbsp
column3: Eldest will circle a date in crayon and list the time for a babysitting gig but there's no info as to where and for whom and the rest is merely white space.&nbsp
column4: I realized this after the blow-up, which means that I bear some responsibility for the situation and can't just peg it on a couple of teenagers.

column1: The intent of the Details Sheet is simple and isn't meant to automatically say no to a kid's request although there's going to be some thought that that is indeed the case.
column2: The intent is to simply force the kids to examine the details and how their request fits into the greater scheme of the family activities - to make them think beyond themselves so to speak.&nbsp
column3: The questions are journalistically straightforward - what, where, when, with whom, transported how - and are supplemented by the question about what else is on the family calendar.&nbsp
column4: Going forward, any request that I receive will be met with another question as to whether the sheet's questions have been answered.&nbsp
column5: When all of the questions are answered and everything makes sense, then I'll probably say yes to the request and make certain that it makes the calendar, preferably following up that they did it.

column1: The reality of any family system is that its effectiveness hinges
column2: upon the ability of the parents to uphold and maintain the system.&nbsp
column3: That means several things:

column1: <li>When the system is rolled out, I can't appear torqued - even though that's what prompted the response - or it will be viewed as punitive and resisted
<li>I have to consider what questions they'll pose when they learn of the system and digest it
<li>I have to be consistent in referring everything back to the sheet
<li>It's my responsibility to assure that the calendar is still updated even though I want the kids to do it

• I have to realize that the calendar's going to be messier as the older kids get used to updating it and will have to stay calm enough to handle things as educational when we discuss correcting the calendar.

column2: If the intent is to have the kids working in tandem and considering others, then it's my responsibility to follow through for as long as it takes.&nbsp
column3: And how long is that?&nbsp
column4:
As long as necessary until my wife and I are comfortable that they've got the basics down and can routinely bring us the necessary information on which to make a decision.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
314,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of the purposes of discipline is to teach a child self-control
column2: that good things can come from mastering oneself.&nbsp
column3: Folks who are older - some of us anyway - can grasp the intellectual concept of delayed gratification but that's difficult for a child who lives in a world of the physical here and now.&nbsp
column4: One way of helping them grasp the concept of self-control is to pay them for good behavior with spending money when the goal is reached.

column1: I was reminded of the technique while talking with the mother of two boys, one of whom is in middle school and the other in upper-elementary.
column2: The premise of the 25 cent solution is each child is promised a set amount of money at the end of a defined time period and any violation of the rules is met by a 25 cent reduction in the promised amount.&nbsp
column3: In the case of the mother's boys, each would receive $5 at the end of the day if they didn't get called on an infraction.&nbsp
column4: In her case, the infraction pertained to either one smacking the other which is a common complaint for those of us with boys.&nbsp
column5: <em>He looked at me funny so I smacked him!&nbsp
column6: He called me a name so I smacked him!&nbsp
column7: I am not adopted (smack)!&nbsp
column8: You are too (smack)!

column1: It's a technique that we've used on a few occasions as well, but only on longer car trips when the kids are in close proximity that invite border incursions akin to those practiced by the North Korean Army.
column2: It's honestly not something that I would use as a disciplinary technique on a daily basis for several reasons.&nbsp

column1: • First, the kids have to learn that decent behavior is something that is expected of them - and everybody else - if we're to have a functioning civil society.
<li>Second, rewards should really be for something exceptional and not commonplace.&nbsp
column2: <em>Yeah, I shaved this morning!&nbsp
column3: I deserve a beer.

column1: <li>Third, there simply isn't enough money to meet the growing expectations of aging kids who become more jaded with each passing year.&nbsp
column2: The first grader might be happy with some post cards and a souvenir pencil, but the eighth grader is holding out for an iPod.&nbsp
column3: The last time that I checked, the Federal Reserve was only providing liquidity to large banks and not to parents of kids with champagne tastes.&nbsp

column1: There are instances however, when it's a valuable tool.
column2: In our case, we&nbsp
column3: used it on long car trips when keeping hands to one's self really was a feat of self-control.&nbsp
column4: Additionally, the kid knew that the money would be earned and could be spent as he or she deemed fit with no input from us unless it was wholly inappropriate.&nbsp
column5: This meant that we wouldn't have to listen to constant begging for souvenir money and allowed the kids to allocate their resources as they saw fit.

column1: Here are some guidelines for using the 25 cent solution if you want to consider it.
<li>Decide in advance what rules are to be followed and explain them clearly.&nbsp
column2: These might include don't hit (or even touch one another in our car), no bad language, no throwing objects, no teasing/namecallling and whatever else you deem important.

column1: • If one of the kids is an instigator, the second complaint about the instigator (Dad, I smacked him because he keeps poking me with his foot!) means that the instigator also gets dinged with the 25 cent solution.
• It's helpful to have a small pad/pen with which to keep a tally each time the child gets dinged for a quarter.
• Specific situations - having to pull the car over - lead to double penalties for all children.
• Expect arguments during the early stages but things will improve as kids and parents learn the intricacies of the solution.
It's another tool in the disciplinary toolbox and an effective one at that.
column2:
It can help maintain some order for a period in the family's life until the kids are old enough to truly control themselves and trips are enjoyable just because, well, they are.

column1:
315,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Projects take time and that's especially the case when the kid wants to head the project.
column2: It's not just that the project will take longer because the kids want to &quot
column3: help&quot
column4: , but also in the sense that the kid may actually want to ramrod the project when he or she becomes older.&nbsp
column5: That means that&nbsp
column6: you've got to make a concerted effort to stay with the project and push it ahead lest the kid - usually a teen in this situation - starts to lose interest or heart in the sometimes lengthy project.

column1: Any guy with some experience understands that do-it-yourself projects can be lengthy and occasionally frustrating affairs.
column2: Things go wrong or there's a situation that requires an additional step (or more) that simply wasn't foreseen and it can be frustrating.&nbsp
column3: But if the teen hasn't done anything like this before, she'll have to lean heavily upon you for advice, encouragement and drive.&nbsp
column4: And if you don't or can't provide the time that's necessary to make it happen, then there's a fair possibility that the project will fail.

column1: Eldest and I have a significant project that's in danger of failing now and as much as I hate to admit it, a significant part of any responsibility for failure will rest with me.
column2: In 2007, we purchased a house - a logistical move, not a &quot
column3: gee, we gotta have this house&quot
column4: move - and the kids noted when we first went through it that there was a DIY fish pond right next to the deck.&nbsp
column5: The kids' response was &quot
column6: Daddy, it's got a pond!&quot
column7: and my unspoken response was &quot
column8: Oh S*&amp
column11: The pond survived decently until last summer (2009) when we encountered a full fish die-off and algae explosion.&nbsp
column12: The liner then proceeded to hole, meaning that the problem was now structural.&nbsp
column13: My thought was that this was the perfect opportunity to fill it in and lay out a small patio with fire pit while Eldest argued forcefully for another pond and with her younger siblings pushing the issue, my wife and I relented.&nbsp
column14: My caveat was that this would be a project that we did ourselves and that Eldest would be responsible for the redesign plans and cost estimates.&nbsp
column15: To her credit, she did these and actually did them well.

column1: The problem was that we started in late July and proceeded to encounter technical problems, like when the dirt side of the pond wall collapsed in a major rain storm.
column2: This led to a lengthy side project involving a wire and stone retaining wall that now undergirds the newly replaced liner.&nbsp
column3: The upshot was that the season ended before we could finish with the waterfall segment, which is where we came to understand the previous owner's Rube Goldberg approach to things.

column1: We're now in another summer and the pond's waterfall is as yet unfinished.
column2: Eldest has agreed with her mother that it would instead be really cool to have a pondless waterfall and her interest in finishing the other has flagged considerably.&nbsp
column3: My stance now is that we'll take another crack at the waterfall and if that doesn't work, then we'll seriously consider the pondless waterfall option.&nbsp
column4: With the proviso that we again do the project ourselves since I don't want to spend hard money on something as frivolous as that.

column1: So what do I take from this exercise on the eve of the last crack on the fishpond?
• I was unrealistic to believe that a teen would have the ability to drive through a long-term project without greater support and drive from me.

• I still want to do projects like this on a DIY basis in order for the kids to see that you don't have to constantly hire people to do things for you (which is why I refuse to pay someone to do my lawn since I have child labor).
• I have to be willing to commit the time to make this happen much more quickly than it did so that it doesn't lose steam.
So that's one more additional item on the to-do list, along with the relandscaping of the backyard, another gift of the previous owner.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
316,"1","1",,"xhtml","

If there's anything that I despise more - apart from the New England Patriots - it's having to do housework.
column2: Even with the labor-saving devices, and they really are labor-saving when you consider the old ways, it's dull work and full of drudgery.&nbsp
column3: The presence of children only makes it more frustrating since everything just gets dirtier that much quicker.&nbsp
column4: So if I hate it so much, why should I actually bother doing housework?

column1: <li>The reality is that a dirty house really is a breeding ground for health problems, especially for small children who still haven't fully developed their immune systems yet.&nbsp
column2: Kids exposed to higher amounts of dust and dirt are likelier to develop difficulty with asthma than kids who reside in a more dust-free house.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, kids are always bringing in new germ variants and will wander through the place leaving colonies like England in the 1600s.&nbsp
column4: These will be picked up by you or the other family members and next thing you know, WHO and CDC are quarantining your place and foreign embassies are issuing travel warnings to your neighborhood.

column1: <li>It honestly becomes embarrassing to invite people to your home when the carpet is obviously coated with animal hair and the bathrooms haven't been touched in weeks.&nbsp
column2: This is coming from a guy who isn't really concerned about appearances.&nbsp
column3: When the kids get older and become aware, they'll also become embarrassed and unwilling to invite their friends over.

column1: <li>A relatively neat house - vacuumed, dusted and with most things properly placed/stored - does give a sense of order and stability to the home and by extension, the kids.&nbsp
column2: There's going to be clutter with children and more cihldren generally produces more clutter, but keeping it under control provides a sense that things aren't out-of-control.

column1: <li>Kids learn a huge amount by simply watching their parents and if they see that the parents are responsible and able to manage the household, they'll have a sense of what to do when they're older.&nbsp
column2: When they are older, you can teach them how to handle some of the chores by themselves and just provide some oversight to assure that things are done properly.&nbsp
column3: Seeing Dad demonstrate some discipline will help set the tone of exercising their own self-discipline when they're older.

column1: I truly do dislike housework and several thousand loads of laundry have taken the blossom off of the rose, but it's important that it continue to happen.
column2: So tomorrow, I'll clean my bedroom and bathroom before heading off to take care of other responsibilities.&nbsp
column3:
And I'm going to crank up the classic rock when I do.

column1:
317,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of the perks of summer is the greater availability of fresh fruits and vegetables, of which I try to take great advantage.
column2: The kids love picking the fruit from trees and it's become an annual highlight
column3: the family record of picked fruit was 2005 when we picked more than 300 pounds of varying fruits and vegetables.&nbsp
column4: But I've had to learn to pace myself in purchases so that I don't waste and have to throw out spoiled food.

column1: We live in a semi-rural area with a large number of farmer's stands and pick-your-own orchards.
column2: It's&nbsp
column3: easy to drop by and become overwhelmed by the variety and amount of fresh food available and on more than one occasion, I've engaged in impulse buying that has been a waste of food and money.&nbsp
column4: So what do I try to do when I'm shopping for summer foods?

column1: <li>Farmer's stands and orchards are no longer &quot
column2: hey, I'm here so I might as well stop&quot
column3: occasions.&nbsp
column4: They are purposeful stops.

column1: <li>I have to have a good idea of what's on the calendar for the next several days, and even weeks, before I make larger purchases.&nbsp
column2: This is especially the case if purchasing larger quantities of fruit which have to be cut up and frozen or preserved before going bad.&nbsp
column3: If we're going out of town in the height of the peach season - late July/early August - then I simply forego the peach preserves until the next season because I won't be able to get all of the fruit handled before it spoils.

column1: <li>Some fruits will simply be ignored because they're too time intensive when there are children around.&nbsp
column2: Case in point was 2005 when I took my three and three other kids to a local orchard and gave them a half-hour in which to pick fresh Queen Anne cherries.&nbsp
column3: The kids had a blast but I simply didn't think that they'd manage to pull in 30 pounds of cherries, all of which had to be subsequently pitted before they could be cooked down.&nbsp
column4: That evening, five of us sat at the kitchen table and manually pitted the cherries -&nbsp
column5: a monotonous task only made bearable by great conversation and good beer.

column1: <li>Not only do I try to know what's on the calendar for the next several days/weeks, I try to have a reasonable menu that varies from evening to evening.&nbsp
column2: This evening will be grilled eggplant and green pepper along with corn on the cob and chicken.

column1: <li>Remember to keep cash handy since most, if not all, of these places won't take check or credit.&nbsp
column2: &nbsp
is not only healthier but also cheaper and can be both fun and educational for the little ones with you.

column1: Now if you'll excuse me, I have to mix some olive oil and balsamic vinegar for the grilled vegetables.
column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
318,"1","1",,"xhtml","

When you have kids, expect to have the ends played against the middle and at some point, expect to hear the phrase "
column2: But Mom said!&quot

column1: How do you handle this phrase when it's tossed on the ground at your feet like a dare to be picked up?
column2: In my case, it depends, plain and simple.&nbsp
column3: It depends on whether it's an area in which I defer to my wife because of better skills.&nbsp
column4: It also depends on whether I expect that she really has a clue as to the reality of the situation.&nbsp
column5: And finally, it simply depends on whether or not I'm torqued at the child, period.

column1: In tonight's case, one of the kids wanted to ride back around the neighborhood in the failing light of a 9 PM evening.
column2: The initial exchange as I returned home was whether or not the child mounting his bike had actually finished doing the dinner dishes.&nbsp
column3: When I had to dig, it became apparent that he hadn't finished the dishes but instead, only &quot
column4: the dishes&quot
column6: in his logic, all of the dishes were rinsed and in the dishwasher but none of the pots and pans had been touched.&nbsp
column7: The argument started with the demand to return inside and finish the job and the phrase &quot
column8: But Mom said!&quot
column11: That you could ride because you'd finished your narrowly defined segment of the chores?&nbsp
column12: That you could ride in the failing light and risk a serious accident on the street?&nbsp
column13: In this particular instance, my response was a simple &quot
column14: I don't care what your mother says, go back inside and finish!&quot
column16: Chagrined and surly, he returned to the house to finish the job.

column1: So how do I typically handle the phrase?

column2: excuse without further questions.&nbsp
column3: Precisely what did Mom say?
column4: What did you ask her permission for?&nbsp
column5: What information did you give her?

column1: <li>Second, God made cellphones for a reason and my response if things are still unclear is to pick up and call her to verify.&nbsp
column2: The reality is that kids will give incomplete information, whether inadvertant or by design, and it's helpful to check.

column1: <li>Third, if it pertains to something about which I clearly disagree - like riding a bike with no headlight at night - I'll simply refuse.&nbsp
column2: And Mom has come back to me on several occasions to determine why I refused, but she's always honored my refusal.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, if she has real reservations, then I'll honor them if they make sense.

column1: In tonight's case, the bike stayed in the garage as even the teen realized that it was simply too dark to ride after finishing his chores.
column2:
And boy, am I torqued.

319,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Sometimes when you're carried away doing something fun with your child, you - or worse yet, your child - is struck by the Law of Unintended Consequences.
column2: And I mean that literally.&nbsp
column3: This was vividly and viscerally brought home while watching some poor father with his toddler daughter at the amusement park recently.

column1: We took the kids and some of their friends to a local amusement park for the day.
column2: This particular park has a large &quot
column3: Boardwalk&quot
column4: section composed of multiple water rides that range from high and long water slides to a&nbsp
column5: &quot
column6: Lazy River&quot
column7: ride in which the rider is gently propelled via inner tube along a long, circular concrete river.&nbsp
column8: There's also a large wave tank for older folks and in this particular situation, a smaller wave tank for children.

column1: There were any number of component water toys and fountains as part of this kiddie wave pool and with the brilliant colors, it resembled something brought to life out of Dr. Seuss' imagination.
column2: As kids and parents entered the&nbsp
column3: wave area, they passed by and under daisy-yellow pipes that rose out of the ground to a height of seven feet&nbsp
column4: before re-entering the ground several feet away.&nbsp
column5: Suspended from the pipes were large cone-shaped buckets which swung back and forth&nbsp
column6: and into which water streamed from the pipes overhead.&nbsp
column7: When the buckets filled with&nbsp
column8: water, they tipped over and would spill water onto the people who walked underneath on the way to the wave pool.&nbsp
column11: about thirty yards away, held his little girl in his arms and wanted to get her a little wet before&nbsp
column13: He stood under a bucket as it slowly filled with water and chatted with his little girl awaiting the tip-over.&nbsp
column14: He unfortunately misjudged the amount of water the bucket could hold and when it finally tipped, his baby girl took a large volume directly on her head.&nbsp
column17: pitied the guy as I watched emotions flash across his face that ranged frrom sheepishness to horror and finally, to disgust.&nbsp
column20: away and sat down to console her and apologize profusely.

column1: I felt for the guy because I've been there.
column2: &nbsp
column3: Fathers throw their kids, wrestle and swing them and&nbsp
column4: create all manner of mayhem that the kids love.&nbsp
column5: But the downside is that there will be accidents and mishaps and while you want to die, it doesn't make you a bad father.&nbsp
column6: It does however, make you take a longer and harder look at what can go wrong so&nbsp
column7: that you better appreciate the risksof playing with the kids.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column1: One of my hardest lessons was dislocating my preschool daughter's elbow while swinging her like an airplane in the backyard.
column2: The&nbsp
column3: game was to simply hold her hands while swinging her in a circle so that her feet were&nbsp
column4: off of the ground and&nbsp
column5: in this, I was wonderfully successful until&nbsp
column6: she&nbsp
column7: cried out that her elbow hurt.&nbsp
column8: After icing the elbow and still finding her in pain, my wife contacted the pediatrician who saw her within the hour.&nbsp
column11: and was intimately familiar with it since he'd had to reset his&nbsp
column12: own children's elbows after similar play in his&nbsp
column14: Unlike this physician however, I never played the game again.&nbsp

column1: The guilt of inadvertantly hurting your child is severe.
column2: Bur&nbsp
column3: the point&nbsp
column4: is to learn&nbsp
column5: to assess the risks and then adapt so that you either minimize them or avoid them entirely.&nbsp
column6: But don't let the fear keep you from playing with them because they both&nbsp
column7: love and need it.&nbsp
column8: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
320,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There are parts of fatherhood that I love and parts that...well, not so much.
column2: One of the latter is having to take the daughter into the public men's room because (a) there are men there, and (b) it's often a germophobe's living hell.&nbsp

column1: So about when should you be able to stop taking her into the men's room and what did I consider when mine was very young?
There is no magic number as with a driver's license - Happy 5th Birthday to the Big Girl Birthday Princess!
column2: You can go the women's restroom now! - and multiple factors come into
column3: play.&nbsp
column4: How they intersect is completely up the parent and what one father finds acceptable another might find repugnant.

column1: <li>Naturally, what's your assessment of your daughter's ability to tend to her personal needs?&nbsp
column2: Can she clean herself adequately and do a decent job of washing her hands afterwards?&nbsp
column3: So long as she's still in any kind of training pants or unable to tend to cleaning/wiping herself, then it's a non-starter and she's with you.

column1: <li>What's the condition of the men's restroom?&nbsp
column2: There's been more than one occasion that I've walked into the men's room with her just to take a quick look at the cleanliness.&nbsp
column3: There's likewise been more than one occasion that I've left with her to go elsewhere to find an acceptably clean restroom.&nbsp
column4: In those years, we lived in suburban Washington, DC and I could tell&nbsp
column5: you any number of acceptable men's rooms on Rockville Pike, Georgia Avenue and the vicinity of downtown Silver Spring.&nbsp
column6: I also learned to keep a clean change of clothes packed in the car in case there was a resulting accident.

column1: <li>If there's a large women's restroom, such as in some airports, how many entry/exit points are there to the facility?&nbsp
column2: I've been in the position of simultaneously caring for daughter and son in major airports where there were two access points into the women's room.&nbsp
column3: My fear was that she might exit the other access point while I was preoccupied with the boy.&nbsp
column4: In that instance, I took her into the men's room even though she could care for her needs.

column2: I've actually seen a child pick a lollipop off of the toilet stall floor and stick it in his mouth.&nbsp
column3: I suspect that a girl's marquee won't be missing so many bulbs, but you have to consider judgment.

column1: • If there are multiple children with which to contend and only one small restroom, I'd consider sending her in the women's room by herself while I managed the other children outside.
• At no time if your child is in a restroom alone do you leave your place outside the door.
The point and trick in each situation is to assure that the child is either within view or in a place from which there's no exit without your knowledge.
column2: It can be a real test of your multitasking ability if you have more than one child at hand, and there will be moments of real stress as you manage the kids.

column1:
And at those moments, I tried to remember to thank God that I didn't have to change a diaper in an airplane lavatory.

321,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Like everybody else, we're cutting back and deleveraging, which is financial-speak for paying down debt.
column2: We're acutely aware that on top of the mortgage, there are three kids to educate and each of our vans has racked up more than 95,000 miles.&nbsp
column3: I regularly talk to the kids about money and they know that we're ratcheting down the spending.&nbsp
column4: But does that mean that they have to feel poor?

column1: What are some of the things that I've recently done with one or more kids to pass the time?
• Travel several miles to a small river bridge and explore the circa 1830 canal locks, and then explain what a canal is in the first place.
• Throw a baseball, followed by a football.
• Throw a baseball that's been recovered from plant beds that we're tearing out to relandscape.

• Watch a lightning storm from the safety of the front porch and debate whether thunder is caused by the lightning itself or the clash of warm and cold air (it's the latter per my wife, the rocket scientist),

column2: more kids to the community pool.&nbsp
column3: While membership isn't free, it costs $200/year for a family of four and if three kids spend 30 days at the pool, then the cost of entertaining each child drops to an average of $2.22 per day.&nbsp
column4: The more that you go, the cheaper is the average daily cost&nbsp
column5: and if you throw in some snacks from Costco, you've got a cheap day of entertainment.

column1: <li>Spend an evening just reading, either each within his or her own book or aloud to one another.&nbsp
column2: Tonight, we started with Treasure Island.

column1: • Let the kids invite friends over to spend the evening watching DVDs and eating snacks.
<li>Teach the kids how to make a favorite food.&nbsp
column2: My wife spent time this evening teaching Middle how to make egg salad from start to finish.&nbsp
column3: The other day, Eldest made brownies while I cut up fruit.

column2: one or more kids on a bike ride around the neighborhood to familiarize them with&nbsp
column3: road rules for bicycles.

column2: different TV shows on different nights.&nbsp
column3: I've come to enjoy&nbsp
column4: <em>Pawn Stars&nbsp
column5: and
column6: American Pickers
column7: while my wife and several of the kids gather around&nbsp
column8: any&nbsp

column1: <li>Explain where babies come from and how women don't have&nbsp
column2: to sit on their eggs after they're fertilized.

column1: • Give a probie slap to the child who told Youngest that women have to sit on their fertilized eggs in order for the babies to hatch.

column2: family and dog, not forgetting the plastic&nbsp
column3: grocery bag for dog poop.

column1: <li>Give a probie slap to the child&nbsp
column2: who told Youngest that&nbsp
column3: when people recycle their plastic grocery bags, they're all filled with dog&nbsp
column4: poop.

column1: We're not going cold turkey with spending since we still got
column2: a few books from Borders and took a recent trip, but we are emphasizing that things don't have to have a price tag attached to be enjoyable.&nbsp
column3: And we'll continue to deleverage despite what the economists and officials say.

column1: And I'll also continue to pass the time
column2:
probie-slapping a certain child who thrives on disinformation.

column1:
322,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There are any number of sports opportunities available for kids to choose, far more than were available than when I was a kid.
column2: Baseball, football and basketball are now joined by soccer, lacrosse, volleyball, field hockey.&nbsp
column3: This is further complicated by the option to play at various levels that range from rec league to travel and premier for the most committed players.&nbsp
column4: The question that my wife and I ask ourselves is at what point we finally tell the kids that they have to finally concentrate on one sport instead of just letting them play a number of them?

column1: It's a family decision and the answer will vary accordingly.
column2: Frankly, some will read this and probably think that I'm full of crap and that's fine.&nbsp
column3: But what are some of the things that we consider when talking about kids and sports?

column1: <li>First, if the kid wants to play multiple sports, are they in the same season?&nbsp
column2: Soccer in our area is played both Fall and Spring, so it's concurrent with both Football and Baseball.&nbsp
column3: Our philosophy has been that if the sport options play and practice simultaneously, the child will have to make a choice.&nbsp
column4: When the kid splits sports in one season, there's a real possibility that practices and/or games will overlap and the kid won't be able to make a full commitment to either sport.&nbsp
column5: There are multiple reasons to compete in a sport and frankly, one of them is to win.&nbsp
column6: It's important to learn teamwork and cooperation and it's especially important to have fun.&nbsp
column7: But most kids do want to be on a winning team and it's simply not fair to the rest if a team member isn't making all of the practices but still expects to play.

column1: <li>Second, at what level does the kid want to compete?&nbsp
column2: Eldest played for a season at a travel team level and decided that rec league's more to her liking
column3: if she's happy playing multiple sports at a more relaxed level, then we're fine with that.

column2: The demands of some sports and coaches are rigorous and it can frankly burn out a child.&nbsp
column3: It's a shame to see a child grow to hate a sport because of the demands on a child not yet ready to accept them.

column1: <li>Fourth, what's the impact on the remainder of the family?&nbsp
column2: Middle asked on multiple occasions - which is one of my criteria to ascertain the seriousness of a kid's idea - to take up Fencing.&nbsp
column3: To give fair due, he's a wiry teen with physical grace, flexibility and quick reflexes.&nbsp
column4: There's even a local instructor who competed with the national Soviet team in the 1970s/1980s.&nbsp
column5: However, the competitions will frequently be out of the area and we're unwilling to commit that kind of time to competitions in other states.

column2: Youngest has been clear that he wants to play baseball for the local high school team, which has a history of winning seasons and championships.&nbsp
column3: If he persists in this desire, we'll support him
column4:
but at his young age, we're going to let him play other sports until he's old enough to better understand the demands that serious competition makes.

There's a recent saying that you don't write a blog, but rather, the blog writes you.
column2: My goal has been to post regularly, if not daily, and not turn out anything resembling dreck and I've been successful - in production at least - for the past two years.&nbsp
column3: But three kids make you busy and it's been that.

column1: I apologize for the recent inactivity - nobody's died, although I've been tempted on two occasions recently - and when things quiet down, will get back to writing as expeditiously as possible.
column2: &nbsp
column3: I plan however, to resume my regular articles&nbsp
column4: in about a week.&nbsp
column5: Until then, keep the electronics under control and say no to your kids regularly.

Family vacations change with the family as it ages and changes.
column2: There's less obvious work for the parent as kids no longer need to be diapered or constantly watched, but the stress doesn't completely depart.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: The kids now have some of their own interests that compete for family time but still haven't fully developed the sense that their interest isn't necessarily the most important.&nbsp
column5: And there's some friction as they think that they're ready for more than a father thinks that they can handle.&nbsp
column6: The family vacation is a work in progress, evolving with the kids and their growing bodies and interests.

column1: So what are some notes that I made during the past 10 days?

column2: skuId=9412619&amp

column5: lp=8"">Auto FM Transmitter that connects an iPod or mp3 to the car stereo for everyone to hear.
column6: Kids have the capacity - especially as they reach the teens - to download an enormous amount of material and many are actually willing to play it for you.&nbsp
column7: In our case, Eldest, Middle and I each played two selections from our respective devices with the caveat that they had to be appropriate for younger ears and middle-aged sensibilities.&nbsp
column8: We consequently heard everything from Don McLean's Miss American Pie
column9: to Psychostick's This Is Not A Song, It's A Sandwich and Glee's cover of Queen's Somebody to Love.
column13: shown up and that's surprised in a mostly good way.

column4: fortunate&nbsp

column6: That said, we try&nbsp
column7: to give the&nbsp
column8: elder kids some freedom without the responsibility of monitoring a youngster and set aside concentrated time to keep Youngest occupied.&nbsp
column9: When Youngest does move with the older kids, we are explicit with them that he's with them and&nbsp

column14: several minutes at Monticello when the older kids split up and didn't verify who had the boy, leading to a PracticalDad wandering the Dependencies at Monticello and working the cellphone furiously.

column3: what I consider to&nbsp

column5: know.&nbsp

column1: <li>Surprisingly, you still have to monitor discipline and that's&nbsp
column2: especially the case with teenage boys.&nbsp

column4: paying attention to others around them.&nbsp
column5: Texting will occur in inappropriate places and horseplay will erupt around Senior Citizens who can't afford to get knocked over and it will continue to be an ongoing responsibility for a parent.

column3: I frankly enjoy them now more than before and that's perhaps because I realize that the family vacations with all of the kids present are now numbered.&nbsp

Your approach to them will help set the tone for the category that the kids choose.

325,"1","1",,"xhtml","

All fathers have and must contend with fear
column2: and it varies from one to another.&nbsp
column3: Will my child be assaulted or kidnapped?&nbsp
column4: Will her current crop of friends lead to trouble down the road?&nbsp
column5: How am I going to afford college and still have some money set aside for my own old age?&nbsp
column6: What do I owe my children versus myself?

column1: I've considered all of these questions at one time or another, but the fear that truly haunts me doesn't pertain to my children's present, but actually their future.
column2: Anybody with half a lick of sense knows that things with America simply aren't right at the moment.&nbsp
column3: Yet&nbsp
column4: I know enough of national and family history to know that bad times come but then are replaced with better times.&nbsp
column5: I know that my maternal great-great-great grandfather survived the entire Civil War - and Gettysburg - without a scratch.&nbsp
column6: I know that two great uncles survived the trenches of the First World War and their mother died of sepsis from a hand cut in the kitchen.&nbsp
column7: My own parents were both children of the Great Depression and both my uncle and father served in - and were actively shot at - in two separate wars.

column2: Bad times go.&nbsp
column3: There was usually a sense during those days and years of fear that there would again be something of value and hope if things could be seen through to their conclusion.&nbsp
column4: Peace, prosperity, real hope and not the faux kind peddled by various politicians - of both parties.

column1: But I fear that my children face a future in which bad times come, and then stay.
column2: That if decisions aren't made and appropriate policies followed, that they will have no opportunity to live with the possibility of betterment and advancement for themselves and their children.&nbsp
column3: And the data of the past two or more decades shows that the income disparities between folks have become so marked that there is the real risk of a permanent underclass and a gutted middle-class at the mercy of an oligarchy that rules for itself.&nbsp

column1: This was brought forcefully home in an article entitled Who Rules America?
column2: The article is lengthy, detailed and the numbers and charts leave little room for doubt.&nbsp
column3: While there has been much written about income disparity, the synopsis presented shows that the wealth in the past two decades has shifted markedly to the wealthy so that the top 1% of the wage-earners possess a vastly disproportionate amount of the wealth.&nbsp
column4: I'm not a conspiracy theorist that believes that a secret cabal planned all of this in 1977, but I do believe that there are some exceptionally astute people who realized the implications of certain policies and then hi-jacked these to their own ends.&nbsp
column5: Changes in lobbying standards?&nbsp
column6: Let's exploit them.&nbsp
column7: Changes in financial regulations?&nbsp
column8: Let's exploit them.&nbsp
column9: The failure of the government to actively monitor and pursue those who broke or manipulated the law led to a period of laissez-faire on steroids in which anything has occurred and will continue to do so.

column1: And the super-wealthy, who aren't stupid and are able to employ even smarter consultants, understand this and will advance themselves at the expense of the common wealth.
So what do I do apart from rail at the television and listen to Glenn Beck?
<li>Spend more time examining the internet and exploring alternative information sources.&nbsp
column2: Lurk and watch and determine what is legitimate versus on-the-fringe and then pass this information along to your neighbors.

column1: <li>Ask whether a proposed policy or solution benefits all or really only a few?&nbsp
column2: For instance, who truly benefits from an extension of the Bush tax cuts?&nbsp
column3: Is their extension going to set the stage for a stable economic future?

column1: <li>Actually call or write your Congressman, as simplistic as that sounds.&nbsp
column2: They do pay attention to numbers and respond to the varying windspeeds because that's what politicians do, unfortunately.

column1: <li>Make sure that you talk to your kids about the world around them and fill them in, even if in small doses.&nbsp
column2: If that means that you have to physically have to turn off the various electronic devices, then do so and talk.&nbsp
column3: Some of my best moments are in the car or at the dinner table when there's no screen to distract them.

column1: <li>Spend time discussing money with your kids and help them learn good habits.&nbsp
column2: There are some things that we do poorly here and some other things that we do extraordinarily well.&nbsp

column1: <li>Re-examine your own personal and family views on consumerism/materialism.&nbsp
column2: Do you really need to purchase something that was in all probability made in China?&nbsp
column3: Do you really need to have the newest car?&nbsp
column4: Can you get by happily with less?&nbsp
column5: Don't buy the lie that spending money will help America if most of that money goes to high-end items that are simply made by foreign workers.

column2: kids on their grades and make that a fight if necessary.&nbsp
column3: With three kids, I understand that not everybody wants to study
column4: but that is a fight in which I will routinely engage just because it has to happen.

column1: <li>Stop accepting things at face value just because Limbaugh, Beck and Franken say that it's so.&nbsp
column2: Understand that these outlets thrive on debate and conflict and will continue to encourage it because it's profitable.

column1: • In short, question and examine and then press.
column2: Press the politicians and the economists.&nbsp
column3: Press the children and above all else, press yourselves.

column1: There is unfortunately no easy way out of what's upon us.
column2: There will be painful sacrifices and considerable angst and economic pain before things are finally settled and I suspect that there will be civil turmoil.&nbsp
column3: Long-held economic/financial strategies will be overturned.&nbsp
column4: But I take heart in recognizing that my forefathers have been in the same position and so far, nobody's shooting at me.

column1: For the record, I think that Glenn Beck is a truly funny guy and I even agree with him sometimes.
column2: But I'm not planning my future based upon his musings and rallies and I no longer listen on a regular basis.&nbsp
column3:
There's too much else to do.

326,"1","1",,"xhtml","

You've got a full slate of things to do and many of them are outside
column2: when one of the kids suddenly becomes ill.&nbsp
column3: He lies down in bed, but do you still go outside to work in the yard?

column1: That's the situation facing me now and frankly, I'll chuck the outside work and leave it go until later.
column2: Yes, there's always the baby monitor if the child is smaller and God knows that I used it.&nbsp
column3: But when the child is sick - even if only sleeping - I'd rather forego the&nbsp
column4: monitor and just stay close.&nbsp
column5: Kids will come to physically need you less and less as they age, and this sick one is a young teen, but there's still the child's sense of knowing that he's not alone.&nbsp
column6: Additionally, if there's nausea and vomiting involved, I believe that kids do feel better knowing that someone's there to help.&nbsp
column7: And in the worst case scenario, I'm nearby in the event of a real emergency and can respond immediately.&nbsp
column8: The other aspect is my own peace of mind knowing that I wasn't unattentive in the event of trouble.

column1:
So instead, I'll take some moments to write and put off the outdoor work until later.
