327,"1","1",,"xhtml","

When people discuss puberty, it might come across as almost an overnight event - girls have their first period and develop breasts while boys have two days of cracked voices and then spend the next two years in the bathroom.
column2: But the reality is that puberty is a lengthy process that comes on gradually and lasts for years.&nbsp
column3: While it generally starts full bore in the early teens, there is no definitive time that it begins for any particular person and some will begin much earlier while a few start at an older age.&nbsp
column4: However, one of the common precursors to puberty is the onset of body odor and that should serve as notice as your child's body is starting the road to Puberty.

column1: Children can sweat when they're very little, but body odor is a result of activation and increase in the sweat glands as the child's body chemistry starts to morph.
column2: You might finally note a discernible body odor after active play or at the end of the day and if it is, then it's likely that your child is near time for a deodorant.&nbsp
column3: If you want to verify whether there's actual body odor, simply take a quick sniff of the dirty shirts in the laundry
column4: it might sound rude but that's all part of parenthood.&nbsp
column5: It isn't necessary to sniff their pits and not the least bit helpful to make smartmouth remarks about it
column6: kids are exquisitely concerned with their social status and anything that indicates that they'll be unpopular or the potential butt of jokes is more frightening than a Wes Craven film.

column1: If you think that body odor is now going to become an issue, then there are several things to consider.
<li>Is your child unaware of it and regardless, how do you wish to broach the issue?&nbsp
column2: Kids can fear anything that threatens their social status and when you discuss it, play up the fact that this is all part of the process of changing from child to adult.&nbsp
column3: You can also reassure them that there are things that can be done to manage things so that it isn't an issue.

column1: <li>If there are other concerns, such as a very early onset of odor, certainly contact your family physician and schedule a&nbsp
column2: checkup.&nbsp
column3: While it's not common, there are occasionally other circumstances that are the catalyst for body odor.

column1: <li>Can the issue be addressed simply by more&nbsp
column2: thorough bathing or have you moved into the realm of products that mask or control the odor?

column1: <li>If your child is going to need a personal hygiene product, do you want it to be an antiperspirant or a deodorant?&nbsp
column2: The two aren't the same as each approaches the issue of body odor from a different perspective.&nbsp
column3: An antiperspirant actually contains chemicals in the formulary that serve to block the pores through which sweat comes so that if there is no sweating, there isn't any odor.&nbsp
column4: A deodorant serves to control the odor by having antiseptic compounds in the formulary that kill the bacteria that can cause the odor
column5: a deodorant doesn't actually block the pores.

column1: <li>A child's body can have the same allergic reaction to an unfamiliar&nbsp
column2: deodorant or antiperspirant as a new food
column3: for an infant or toddler.&nbsp
column4: Be aware of complaints about itching or pain after it's first used and consider taking some looks for visible skin changes at or&nbsp
column5: around the areas being treated.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Start the process first&nbsp
column8: by using&nbsp
column9: a product that doesn't have any fragrance, whether it's a mass market product that's unscented or a product that is touted as natural or organic.&nbsp
column12: problems and your child wants it&nbsp
column14: you can move on to the scented products.&nbsp

column1: <li>If your child is using a scented product, expect to have to educate the kid about the appropriate amount of deodorant to use.&nbsp
column2: Kids typically have no calibration for anything and things are either all or none, so your house is liable to smell like Axe until things are brought under control.&nbsp
column3: In our case, my wife entered our house through the front door and immediately walked out same door because of the reek of Axe deodorant wafting from Middle's bedroom.&nbsp
column4: Our son decided to treat all of his clothing by spraying his drawers and closet with the Axe body spray and it took days for his room to clear the smell.

column2: with body odor is like any other&nbsp
column3: bodily function issue.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: It's neither gross nor is it a magical precursor to be celebrated as a marker to adulthood.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: But it is an&nbsp
column8: early indicator that your child is developing and a clue to start looking for other signs of pubescence.&nbsp

column1:
328,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As a father, I've been concerned with how schools manage the issue of bullying.
column2: The school system and I agree that bullying is wrong and we likewise agree that it shouldn't be tolerated.&nbsp
column3: We even agree that the first response of a child being bullied shouldn't just be to haul off and smack the problem child.&nbsp
column4: But where we disagree iswhether a child has any right to self-defense.
column5: Is there a point at which achild can actually stand up for himself when the other avenues have failed?

column1: We've taught our three children that they're to do three things if they feel they're being bullied.
column2: First, tell the kid to stop doing whatever's creating the problem.&nbsp
column3: Second, simply walk away.&nbsp
column4: If the first two steps fail, then find and tell someone in authority.&nbsp
column5: Many of these instances occur in places where there is adult control and it's the adults' responsibility to prevent these problems.&nbsp
column6: Schools are particularly sensitive to the issue and will actively take measures to monitor, control and discipline kids who bully.

column1: I was raised with the understanding that you might have to fight back.
column2: We've taught our kids that if the three avoidance steps fail, they should defend themselves.&nbsp
column3: So I was surprised some years ago to hear that the elementary school guidance counselor had asked my son's class this question:&nbsp
column4: <em>How many of your parents have said that it's okay to fight back if you're being bullied?&nbsp
column5: My son and several classmates raised their hands.
column6: <em>Your parents are wrong.&nbsp
column7: If anybody is caught throwing punches or kicking somebody, even a bully, they'll be punished the same as the person they say&nbsp
column8: is bullying them.&nbsp
column9: One of the kids asked what would happen if they were outnumbered with their backs to the wall and had no choice?
column11: The counselor did provide the class with strategies that could be used if they were being bullied but the kids were left scratching their heads.&nbsp
column12: This, along with a comment that was wildly misconstrued by my son, led to a phone call to determine what was said and in this instance, the counselor's original question was indeed correct.

column1: I understand the situation in which schools find themselves.
column2: Society's violence level has spilled into schools and what we settled with fists is now handled with weapons.&nbsp
column3: If a child denies being a bully to the parents, today's parents are more likely to support them even at the threat of litigation.&nbsp
column4: Combine these factors and school systems simply find it easier to adopt a zero-tolerance policy that punishes all equally, regardless of guilt or circumstances.&nbsp
column5: It's the juvenile equivalent of the&nbsp
column6: Second Amendment argument that when all guns are outlawed, only outlaws will have guns.

column2: A bully will take over a child's life and the bully must be handled one way or another.&nbsp
column3: Our kids have had to contend with multiple bullies, including a troubled first-grader who actually contracted with a fourth-grader to attack and beat up my first grade son.&nbsp
column4: In that instance, our son immediately went to the playground aide and all three wound up in the principal's office to settle the matter.

column1: <li>First, pay attention and decide whether or not there is a bullying problem.&nbsp
column2: Some kids will share it but others will hide the situation. Learn the signs of bullying.
column3: Likewise, listen to the names that get thrown around by the kids and the context in which you're hearing them and then take an opportunity to visit the school, even if it means taking time out of work.

column1: <li>Second, find out your school system's policy on bullying.&nbsp
column2: How do they address cases of bullying?

column1: <li>Third, if you think that your child has a problem, contact the school and speak with the teacher and principal.&nbsp
column2: To their credit, they will take it seriously and listen.&nbsp
column3: Tell them what you're hearing and ask what they know.&nbsp
column4: What about the suspected child or children?&nbsp
column5: Any other issues?&nbsp
column6: Ask them to investigate and give them an opportunity to respond.&nbsp
column7: When the teacher knows that there's a problem, you'll generally have a respite window as greater attention is paid.&nbsp

column1: <li>Fourth, follow up quickly and work out an action plan.&nbsp
column2: Then share it with your child and pay attention.&nbsp
column3: If the bullying continues, follow up with the school again.&nbsp
column4: Delegate upwards if the problem persists.

column1: <li>If the situation does continue, decide what your response is.&nbsp
column2: In our case, a bully took over our other son's second grade year and despite multiple conversations with the teacher and the bully's mother - Dad wasn't around - the problems continued.&nbsp
column3: After our son was bullied again, I simply told the principal that my son would defend himself accordingly.&nbsp
column4: The bullying did decrease afterwards and I then made it a point to share with other teachers and principals - when the need arose - that my kids had the option to defend themselves if the adults didn't resolve the problem.&nbsp
column5: My wife and I made a conscious decision - and shared it with the kids - that if all other approaches failed, we'd back them if they got in trouble for fighting.

column1: There might be consequences at school, but we'd work with it and they'd have no consequences with us.
column2: Because when the kids are adults,they will have to manage these issues themselves.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
329,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There was an office supply store commercial several years ago that showed glum children shopping for school supplies while their father rode on the shopping cart with the Xmas tune It's The Most Wonderful Time Of The Year playing on the soundtrack.
column2: Spend significant amounts of time with kids in the summer and you're liable to agree with this assessment.&nbsp
column3: But before you can get to that point, you have to perform some true drudgery in getting ready for that first day.&nbsp
column4: You can walk into the store and start spending, or you can actually save some money by planning ahead on what you need and that's the drudgery.

column2: consists of two parts&nbsp
column3: - the paper and school supplies themselves, and then the dreaded clothing.&nbsp
column4: The school supplies are relatively easy since the materials generally don't change from one year to the next and you can actually stock up on really good sales, keeping the materials stored for years while you slowly exhaust them.&nbsp
column5: But the tricky part is outfitting your child's clothing because of growth, and in the case of many girls, fashion changes.&nbsp

column1: Various stores will start rolling out the back-to-school sales in the first week of August and there will be all manner of stuff available.
column2: Some will even run super specials with items for the dime during a specified period and it's tempting to run in and then pat yourself on the back for all of your savings.&nbsp
column3: But there are several things to consider.

column1: <li>Just because school supplies are for sale doesn't mean that your child(ren) will necessarily need those particular school supplies.&nbsp
column2: You might see all manner of items in the Sunday circulars and some office supply stores will even have generic lists available of what items are required for different grades in a particular school district.&nbsp
column3: But the reality is that there can be variances within school districts and even amongst teachers.&nbsp
column4: We've been burned on several occasions and at the elementary school level, now wait for the introductory letter from the teacher to see what he or she wants our child to bring.&nbsp
column5: Some things are a given, such as backpacks and crayons, but there can be differences.

column1: <li>If there's a great sale on truly utilitarian items - yellow high-lighters and lined notebook paper, for instance - then consider buying in quantity and then storing them until they're finally exhausted.&nbsp
column2: We've got reams of notebook paper, two pocket folders and highlighters in the basement and just feed off of them.&nbsp
column3: But be sure to take stock of what's in storage before spending money needlessly.

column1: • When you get the items home, sequester them so that excitable kids don't disperse them all over hell and half of Georgia.
<li>Pay attention to the receipts, especially if there's an item on it that can be rebated.&nbsp
column2: This is where women have it over on men since they're able to get away with purses
column3: I'm able to bend gender roles in multiple shapes as the need arises but I'm not going to spend my time correcting people that I'm carrying a satchel and not a man-purse.
column4: Thank you very much.

column1: <li>Before you even worry about shopping, ascertain what clothing you already have and that's especially the case if you're using hand-me-down clothing from others.&nbsp
column2: With two boys, we have plenty of clothing from friends flowing through the house and it's made a significant dent in the clothes spending.&nbsp
column3: That means that you'll have to physically cull through the clothing articles and dispose of obviously small items while setting aside others to be tried on.&nbsp
column4: Once that's done, then you know what you'll need.

column1: <li>Have a sense of what the school's clothing policy is so that you can eliminate needless argument from the child or teen.&nbsp
column2: If your kid attends a school with a uniform policy, you're golden in that regards.&nbsp

column1: <li>Be prepared to spend the better part of a day in shopping for clothing.&nbsp
column2: If your kids are younger, be prepared to break the shopping into several separate increments.&nbsp
column3: In our case, we wrap the shopping into other events that keep it tolerable for the kids - lunch at the food court, browsing at the book store or a stop at the music/video store.

column1: <li>If time is an issue - as we were shopping for Youngest's blue jeans while Eldest was at soccer - then simply purchase clothing of the size needed and then try it on at home.&nbsp
column2: In Youngest's case, he knows that he'll try on jeans after school and I'll return it tomorrow night for a refund.&nbsp
column3: Stores are willing to let people take things home to try on and return provided the tags and receipt are presented at return.&nbsp
column4: <strong><em><u>Again, keep the receipt.&nbsp
column5: If your mate can keep a grocery receipt in her purse for nine months, then you can keep the thing for a few days.&nbsp
column6: And DO NOT remove any of the labels or the items will be unreturnable.

column1: <li>Be ready for commentary from the kids as they age.&nbsp
column2: I was surprised to find that kids in elementary school are concerned about whether they're perceived as wearing tighty-whities
column3: and <em>granny pants.&nbsp
column4: It makes things stressful but it can be entertaining as they age and you see where their tastes lie.

column1: Preparing for school isn't a spur-of-the-moment thing but if you consider what you're doing, that time spent doesn't have to be miserable either.

And for Pete's sake, don't lose the receipt.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

330,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With my eldest child just a few years away from college and two more in the pipeline at intervals behind, I wonder how we're going to help the kids pay for higher education.
column2: Just how much do I/should I pay for their higher education?

column1: Though all of my thinking however, it never occurred to me to use my home's equity to pay for the education.
column2: I know others who've done it and they now find themselves in their fifties with two mortgages on their home, but that option simply never entered my calculations.&nbsp
column3: The extent to which it's been done - and the effect that it's&nbsp
column4: had on education rates - was surprisingly brought home in a recent Wall Street Journal article, Housing Bust Makes Paying For College Harder.

column1: The article's gist is that a significant portion of the tuition payments are being made by parents who are borrowing against the equity in their home and unfortunately, the decline in housing values means that that financing mechanism is being shut down.
column2: This is especially the case in which lower wealth families - those with income less than $65,000 and what they define as &quot
column3: housing wealth&quot
column4: less than $125,000 - have used the home ATM for education.&nbsp
column5: A study noted that for each $10K rise in &quot
column6: housing wealth&quot
column7: , which I assume to mean equity, in the four years prior to the child's college age for a family in this stratum meant that there was more than a 6% likelihood of that child attending college.&nbsp
column8: With housing values declining and mortgage lenders cutting back on second mortgages, the fear of the study's authors is that this will create a significant loss of higher-trained, college educated workers for the labor force.

column1: This is one of the reasons that I don't particularly care for social scientists since they focus on the academic, ignore the human side of the equation and help perpetuate a con.
column2: The verbal sleight of hand is that companies want a labor force that's competitive with the global population and there's truth that many of our students are behind the curve.&nbsp
column3: But when I follow the business news and announcements, the real value-added jobs are being sent overseas because the cost of labor is significantly cheaper and rarely do&nbsp
column4: I see that it's because Frank can't add as well as Rashid and Jagdish.&nbsp

column1: The expectation of the past several generations is that the parents pay to educate the children, and my guilt exists because that's what my own parents did for me.
column2: But the economic environment has changed dramatically.&nbsp
column3: Our parents and grandparents&nbsp
column4: owned their home free-and-clear for their dotage, our generation faces the senior years with the prospect of having to continue paying for housing with far less money to pay for that housing.&nbsp
column5: And with stagnant or declining incomes, the burden on our own children will be increased.&nbsp
column6: Yes, their student debt - a toxic debt if ever there was one - will be minimized while I can deduct the interest payments, but I truly don't want to spend my senior years being financially dependent on my children.&nbsp
column7: It does hearken back to past generations in our history when families were multi-generational with kids tended to by grandparents, but it's not something that we necessarily want to pursue.

column1: I can't speak for my wife but I'm truly uncertain about how far to take the financing aspect.
column2: My sense is that it will be a possibility but one contingent upon the child/student
column3: if we haven't seen you put out to get the grades necessary to compete, then we won't put out the money for more than the standard college degree.&nbsp
column4: But regardless of the decision, it will be weighted down with emotional baggage that will linger long after they're out.

column1:
331,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Sometimes you see something and you know that it's going to coming to your house like something from a bad horror story.
column2: The bobblehead will likely be coming to mine.

column1: My wife works for a non-profit hospice which holds a fund-raising auction each Labor Day weekend.
column2: This event started more than 25 years ago as a one-day event which raised a few thousand dollars and has grown into a two day affair which last year grossed more than $335,000.&nbsp
column3: There are multiple buildings and tents for the different venues - sports collectibles, hand-made furniture, plants, new items/quilts, and the used stuff - and dozens of volunteers and staff will work for a week to get the fairground site ready for the day.&nbsp
column4: Our kids have been literally raised with the event and all of us, except for Youngest, now volunteer in some way to help pull this off.&nbsp

column1: The kids' favorite destination is the used tent, full of thousands of donated items from attics, basements and bedrooms of long-departed teens and it was from the latter that came the Bobblehead.
column2: I spent two shifts in the used building, sorting the incoming items into various lots under the direction of an auctioneer and seasoned volunteer when I came across the Bobblehead.&nbsp
column3: It was from the band, Iron Maiden, and was a deformed oversized zombie's head on a skeletal mummified body that leaned forward to attack the owner.&nbsp
column4: The bobblehead apparently so scared the owner that it had never been removed from it's dusty, grimy clear plastic prison and it sat on the table bearing the original price tag, awaiting it's next owner before finally being consigned to the local landfill.&nbsp
column5: Woody, Buzz Lightyear and the Toy Story crew were never meant for the landfill but this guy was born for it.&nbsp

column1: I looked at this thing and kiddingly asked - well, almost kiddingly - if I could trash the thing because it was so grotesque and odd.
column2: Carol, the lead volunteer, laughed and reminded me that only if it was irreparably broken would we&nbsp
column3: toss it and that somebody somewhere would probably be willing to buy it.&nbsp
column4: Unfortunately, I thought, that somebody will be my middle kid.
column5: Middle is 13 and has discovered the joys of rock music and has managed to explore the realms of Rock
column6: ranging from mainstream Pop to the fringes of Punk Ska and the crevices of Swedish Death Metal.&nbsp
column7: Like his peers, he thinks that heavy metal bands who sing of rebellion and sticking it to the man are on the fringe of mind-altering revolution but it hasn't sunk in that they're now guys older than me who are hocking their guitars on Pawn Star and worried about their IRAs and fiber content.
column8: I nodded in resigned agreement and placed it&nbsp
column9: in a box with a few other items for the lot, one of which was a remote-controlled car without the remote because hey, they're innocuous enough that somebody somewhere probably has a remote.
column10: My only hedge was to assure that the height of the containing box was taller than the bobblehead so that it didn't stand out like the pimple on the Prom Queen's forehead.

column1: Yesterday, Middle went with me to drop off a friend's kitchen table for the auction and after we'd unloaded and placed it, Middle took a quick cruise through the used building.
column2: I suddenly heard his voice from the distance yelling that <em>This is cool!&nbsp
column3: I love Iron Maiden!&nbsp
column4: Dad, can I get this?&nbsp
column5: This thing is awesome, dude!
column6: I strolled over and found the Bobblehead in his hands, reaching for Middle as a baby reaches for Daddy to be picked up.&nbsp
column7: I looked at the thing and then my son and responded that he could bid on it but that it would be his coin on this one.&nbsp
column8: He nodded and asked that if he was working when it went on the block if I'd bid for it for him.&nbsp

column2: But then again, neither did the poster on the wall of childhood room or the Aurora model of the Frankenstein on my shelf.

column1:
332,"1","1",,"xhtml","

I typically keep about four books going simultaneously and shift back and forth depending up my mood on any particular late night.
column2: But I've put them aside as I work through <a title=""Amazon:  Debt-Free U"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/Debt-Free-Outstanding-Education-Scholarships-orMooching/dp/1591842980/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp
column3: ie=UTF8&amp
column5: sr=1-1"">Debt-Free U by Zac Bissonnette.
column6: The author, who is actually only about 21 years of age and working his way through the University of Massachusetts, writes knowingly of what he's learned about the college financing game and pushes the philosophy that what matters is the degree instead of the institution.

column1: Bissonnette is a youth from a financially struggling family who decided to take his financial future into his own hands.
column2: He's had hard lessons that many young people haven't encountered and has developed a hard-won ability to think critically, especially examining a higher education system that encourages debt assumption by youth and families who can't absorb that debtload.&nbsp
column3: Early in the book, he discusses the frequent practice of including with the college's financial aid package letter a suggestion that the student's parents can easily cover the funding shortfall by taking on additional debt for that amount.&nbsp
column4: The problem is that the letter is to the youth and leaves the parent in the position of being the bad guy.&nbsp
column5: As Bissonnette writes:

column1: Who wants to be that guy?
column2: No one, and the financial aid office knows that.&nbsp
column3: So they send a letter to the student suggesting that his parents borrow $24,000 with no collateral.&nbsp
column4: In 2004, the parents of 15.3 percent of graduating college seniors took out federal PLUS loans, carrying an average debt load of $17,709.

column1: Of all the dirty tricks that financial aid offices play, this one irks me more than just about any other.
column2: If you are going to suggest that someone borrow $24,000 per year for four years, you should send a letter to that person.&nbsp
column3: It is sneaky and unethical to send someone a letter suggesting that she try to convince another person to borrow up to $24,000 per year for four years.

column1: The author writes with an easy authority that belies his youth and a viewpoint that many of my middle-aged peers lack.
column2: But instead of simply bemoaning how terrible things are, he lays out straightforward financial illustrations that bolster his contention that the key to a successful future isn't an Ivy League degree but rather, a fresh start with a new degree and the freedom of no debt.&nbsp
column3: It challenges long-held assumptions about the value of public versus private institutions as well as the myths of community colleges - which will&nbsp
column4: certainly be winners under the recently passed changes in the Federal Student Loan Program.&nbsp
column5: It also demonstrates a grasp of practical economic principles such as &quot
column6: opportunity costs&quot
column7: , which consider how resources can alternatively be used
column8: the accumulated debt after college could instead be used for travel, a new car, a more satisfactory albeit lower-paying job.&nbsp
column9: Above all, it demands that parents look honestly at&nbsp
column12: for whom they desperately want to provide and still shelter from the realities of adulthood.

column1: I've spoken at length with my oldest child about the need for higher education as well as the cost that it will bear.
column2: As&nbsp
column3: she's looked at the amount in her 529&nbsp
column4: plan and compared that to the cost of&nbsp
column5: the institutions&nbsp
column6: already soliciting her attendance, the&nbsp
column7: financial discrepancy has dawned and she's&nbsp
column8: become aware of the financing&nbsp
column10: She still has her dream school and truthfully, she's enough of a rocket scientist - like her mother - to potentially pull one of the&nbsp
column11: dozen full scholarships that that institution offers.&nbsp
column14: dream course, I've already told her that she'll read&nbsp
column15: Bissonnette's book so that we can develop plans&nbsp

column1: Bissonnette's book is truly worth the money spent and if you and your child make any changes in your plans, it will be a huge and lifetime return on the education investment.

column1:
333,"1","1",,"xhtml","

If you check on one of your kids before bed, you're liable to be told that they don't have any underwear for tomorrow.
If you ask whether they put it in the hamper, because you just did laundry and saw very little of it, you're liable to be told that they threw it away.
If you ask why in the hell they threw away their underwear, they're liable to say that it didn't fit anymore.
If you ask why in the hell didn't they tell you at a time when you could actually do something about it, they're liable to say that they forgot.

If you ask them to wear something small for tomorrow until you get replacements, they're liable to complain that it'll be uncomfortable and whine about why can't you go out to the 24 hour Walmart NOW to get it for them?
If you turn out the lights on them and proceed to say goodnight to another child, the other is liable to say that they overheard and by the way, his underwear is tight as well.

If you go the store the next day you realize that the two boys are similar enough in size that Medium is going to closely resemble Large and that if one of them gets the wrong size by mistake, he's liable to refuse to wear it.
If you return the wrongly stored underwear to the original owner, he's liable to complain that he won't wear underwear touched by his brother and will pitch a minor fit.
If you tell him to suck it up since it wasn't worn, he's liable to complain and whine about why can't you go to the 24 hour Walmart NOW to get a new pair?
If this continues, you decide to let them go to bed without any night-time goodnights and checks and they're liable to complain about how uncaring you are.

column2: checking on the kids before bedtime,&nbsp
column3: you're liable to be told that they don't have any underwear for tomorrow.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
334,"1","1",,"xhtml","

In any family, playing with the kids is something that generally goes to the father.
column2: But do I ever let them win and if not, how competitive should I be?

column1: Playing games is actually important for kids' growth and development.
column2: What are the rules and how do you follow them?&nbsp
column3: What happens when you don't follow the rules?&nbsp
column4: Can I really do this and win?&nbsp
column5: <em>Hey, I really can do this!&nbsp
column6: Now what else can I do?
column7: That is all part and parcel of exploration and maturing and it's part of my job as a father.&nbsp
column8: That fact that it's fun is simply icing on the cake.

column1: I've had a few guidelines on what and how I play with the kids.
column2: First, make sure that it's an activity which provides them the opportunity to win if they play well.&nbsp
column3: For the smallest children, games of chance - Candyland was a favorite - gives the child an even chance to win even though he doesn't understand that there's no real game skill involved.
column4: Second, if Junior wants to play something that requires skill - think basketball - then avoid actually playing for points and just work on the shooting and the other stuff.&nbsp
column5: Third, never throw a game so that Junior can actually feel some pride for having won on his own effort and talent.&nbsp
column6: While it sounds immensely old-fashioned, knowing both that you can lose and how to lose really is character-building.

column1: But with the kids getting bigger and older, am I ever in a situation in which I purposefully turn up the heat to the point of embarrassing them?
column2: That's the question I have now, especially in regards to one of the kids who made it a point of trash-talking me while kicking the soccer ball around.&nbsp
column3: I've had a chronic leg problem for many years and it has affected my ability to physically play with the kids.
column4: When I took Eldest to her soccer practice, Youngest came along and we kicked the ball since he's back in soccer after a baseball hiatus.&nbsp
column5: Because Youngest wants - for some unfathomable reason - to play goalie and have the ball aimed straight for his head, he took up a position and I began to shoot on him.&nbsp
column6: He did a creditable job and I began to shift the shots to either side so that he'd have to dive.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: If he bobbled the ball, I'd rush in to finish the goal and force him to scramble to cover.&nbsp
column9: As he did well however, he grew cocky and began to talk smack and it was then that he shot off his mouth about my age and inability to &quot
column13: That was when I ignored his age and ratcheted up the power of the kicks, but to his credit he still did a decent job and stopped almost all of them.&nbsp
column14: As I reminded him when he shot off his mouth, he had better be able to &quot
column16: that he was spewing on the field and in this case, he did.

column1: What I'm questioning now is whether to take the boy onto the basketball court to teach him some manners.
column2: He's routinely beaten there in games like &quot
column3: Horse&quot
column4: and &quot
column5: Make it, Take it&quot
column6: by his elder siblings and I can outshoot the lad handily.&nbsp

column1: But as I write this, I'm deciding not to do that.
column2: This is a kid who's found something that he can legitimately beat the old man at and if he shoots off his mouth, it's because he's starting to see himself in a position to compete more equally with elder siblings and a father who don't just let him win because he's the youngest.&nbsp
column3: Taking him onto the court to purposefully beat him would be simply wrong of me.&nbsp
column4: My initial response on the soccer field - if you're gonna talk smack, you'd better be able to back it - was the best course and it'll be incumbent upon me to simply remind him of this before other games and practices.
column5: I'm the adult, even when my own buttons are pushed.

column1: And yes, I really didn't know what I'd do when I sat down to write this article.
column2: Thanks for listening.

column1:
335,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Most kids are tangential storytellers and getting the full, coherent story is sometimes akin to trying to untangle the lines from three separate fishing rods.
column2: When they're younger, it's a result of simple inability to keep their facts and timelines straight but when they're a bit older, it's more likely shading, omission or outright lying to avoid consequences.&nbsp
column3: My general practice is to find out everything that I can, make the decision and then move on.&nbsp
column4: But is anything truly closed?

column1: The particulars are unimportant to this article, but it's sufficient to know that I thought that the matter was closed.
column2: But at a recent&nbsp
column3: event, I came to learn additional facts that put the incident in another light
column4: certain information was omitted by the child in the course of the interrogation.&nbsp
column5: I was going to say &quot
column6: investigation&quot
column7: but interrogation is really closer to the truth of the moment.&nbsp
column8: The new facts were unbidden and came pouring from another person's mouth and they were honestly horrified that they'd spilled beans.&nbsp
column9: This person was correct in their realization that this was damning information.&nbsp
column10: So, do I reopen the matter and a probable can of worms?&nbsp
column11: Or do I let it go and remember to dig a bit deeper the next time?&nbsp
column12: Fortunately, the incident didn't involve any illegal activity or injury and in the great scheme, isn't actually that big of a deal.&nbsp

column1: My expectation is that when this child returns from a trip with Mom, there'll be further discussion.
column2: If for no other reason, I want the child to realize that there is no such thing as complete silence and that in the end, the parents will generally find out if they pay attention and follow-up.&nbsp
column3: I also anticipate that there will actually be discipline involved - the previous response was a discussion based upon the premise of a new situation with no real consequences - just to reinforce that it's better to get the truth out there instead of covering it up.&nbsp
column4:
We'll also have a discussion about omission being as damaging as commission.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
336,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of my great memories of growing up is the family meal and when I reached my teens, when all of us were gathered together again, a meal could last for hours as we told stories, discussed and debated.
column2: I'm a major proponent of the need for the family to gather at the table several times each week.&nbsp
column3: If anything depresses me, it's the loss of that shared experience.&nbsp
column4: But activities, sports and simple growing up are making me rethink some things.

column1: The value of the family meal rests in the ability to keep tabs on what's going on in one another's lives.
column2: As the kids move into the daily world with school, they need the opportunity to share and it's sometimes through simple storytelling that other indicators and issues are revealed.&nbsp
column3: But I've had to realize that Eldest is growing up and spending more time at sport practices and activities and she needs to eat something before her mother is home from work
column4: the meal then becomes something rushed and eaten standing up as Youngest plays outside with a friend or watches television.&nbsp
column5: After she leaves, the routine has fallen apart and we've all found ourselves eating away from the table.&nbsp
column6: I fear that the unspoken message being sent to the younger siblings is that the family traditions don't carry over for them, that Eldest has more inherent value than them and that we aren't a family unit without Eldest's presence.&nbsp

column1: As I've considered the situation, I recalled a comment that my father once made to my mother as my older sister prepared to leave for college.
column2: Actually, it gives us the opportunity to spend more time concentrating on him.
column3: Bearing that in mind, I think that several things will come into place.

column1: • Even in the rush of the moment, there will no longer be any meals eaten while standing up or in front of the television.
• No child of any age will eat alone at a table but will be joined by either me or my wife.
• The table will be cleared of the crap and set appropriately so that none of the kids might think that they are an afterthought.
We have had some memorable meals of our own and I think that we will again.
column2:
But the tradition has to hold as the kids come and go.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
337,"1","1",,"xhtml","

You repeat yourself so often that you'd like a recorder attached to the hip that would say the phrases so you can save your voice.
column2: <em>Hang up the towel.&nbsp
column3: Put your cleats and shinguards in the garage.&nbsp
column4: Put your dishes in the sink, I'm not the butler.&nbsp
column5: Are they even listening?
column6: With three kids in three different levels of school and typically surrounded by constant media, I wonder whether they even listen to what I'm saying.&nbsp
column7: But there are occasional moments that reveal that they are indeed listening to you.

column1: A case in point is the other evening's interaction with Eldest.
column2: Eldest is faced with the upcoming SAT and we were in the process of registering her online for the month-away exam.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: Each registrant is allowed to have the results released - free of charge - to four colleges or universities for recruiting and information purposes and additional ones are for a fee.&nbsp
column5: This actually serves to focus the youngster's mind on the prospect that college is no longer some far-off dream but something with real implications, and that the college literature that's coming daily really has meaning.&nbsp
column6: And now Eldest actually had to sit and make some choices as to her preferences out of the dozens that have contacted her.

column1: As we've talked over the past two years, my concern has been that an education is imperative to survive and prosper in the world.
column2: My other concern however, is that the education must occur without the addition of such levels of student debt that her future after college is crippled with student loan payments.&nbsp
column3: There might have to be some debt, but it should be minimized as much as possible.&nbsp

column1: Eldest is like most other kids and looks forward to leaving home for the experience.
column2: The house rules are so restrictive for someone who's obviously old enough to handle herself and there are so many friends with whom to spend time and activities to enjoy.&nbsp
column3: Let's face it, we're raising our children to make their way in the world and become productive adults
column4: we won't turn them away if they have to come home but it's not what either parent or child necessarily wants.&nbsp

column1: This is why I was truly surprised when Eldest added the name of the local state university that sits three blocks away from our home.
column2: It's a good school in it's own right and has even received national kudos for some of the programs but it isn't really what she wants.&nbsp
column3: At that moment, I became the child focused on dreams and she became the adult who looked at reality and I inquired why she was adding it to the list.&nbsp
column4: <em>Because I want them to have my results in case I have to go there because of money.&nbsp
column5: That's when I knew that she understood what I've been saying for the past several years
column6: part of her experience will depend upon her ability to attract scholarship money and the competition is fierce enough that enough of that money won't come to her.

column1: We have two years left of high school and she has the intellectual firepower to pull it off - God knows she didn't get the book smarts from me.
column2: But she's also demonstrating an ability to look beyond and understand that dreams have to be tempered by resources and choices.&nbsp
had to remind her the other night to put her cleats and shinguards in the garage and the towel is still wadded up on the bed.&nbsp
column3: But it's encouraging to know that she's listening to what I'm saying and processing it, so I'll just keep talking.

column1:
338,"1","1",,"xhtml","

A recent Today Show Parenting article
column2: discussed the situation of an infuriated father who got onto a middle school bus to confront the bullies who were tormenting his daughter.&nbsp
column3: The question is whether he went too far and by the time I found the article, more than 2400 comments were in the thread.&nbsp
column4: I've been on the phone with my own child's principal about bus bullying and can understand this father's upset, but some comments and questions are in order.

column1: <li>First, let's be frank and not confuse these youth as children.&nbsp
column2: The bullies - thugs, actually - were physically assaulting a young teen and humiliating her by placing condoms on her head.&nbsp
column3: At least some of the bullies were young teen males with access to prophylactics and there are frankly sexual overtones to this kind of activity.&nbsp
column4: I'd be furious, too.

column1: <li>Second, the article leaves silent the question of whether the school district and administrators were aware of this behavior.&nbsp
column2: Given the father knew enough to be out there, I can surmise that he'd heard of previous problems and that this was not the first incident.&nbsp
column3: But were the school authorities aware of the situation, either from the family or more especially, the bus driver?

column1: <li>Third, did the father enter the bus immediately after&nbsp
column2: the incident or was&nbsp
column3: his daughter out of immediate danger?&nbsp
column4: &nbsp

column1: <li>What precisely was the driver doing about the behaviors?&nbsp
column2: The bus driver is an extension of the school and does have a responsibility to maintain order.&nbsp
column3: I understand that some children can be vicious little bastards and can literally make a busride an excursion into Lord Of The Flies, but that doesn't absolve the driver of any responsibility.
column4: In the past, I've known drivers to actually quit the route and immediately return the full load of children to the school for management by the principal
column5: what was this driver doing?

column1: Should he have climbed aboard the bus?
column2: It depends upon the timing
column3: if she was out of immediate danger, then he was - as much as I want to agree with him - wrong.&nbsp
column4: The immediate concern is the physical safety and the short term fixes are to simply remove her from the bus until the situation is resolved.&nbsp
column5: The later concern is the handling of the violence so that it's stopped.&nbsp
column6: In this regard, the Sheriff's office was correct in that they could also have been contacted since the nature of the harassment/bullying was so overtly sexual that it surpassed the school's usual scope.

column1: I suspect that the guy will be exonerated or given a very light sentence and given the fear of God.
column2: I sympathize with him and in the heat of the moment might have even responded similarly were condoms involved.&nbsp
column3:
And I hope that the actions move beyond just the father and extend to the thugs who would treat a teenage girl in such a way.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
339,"1","1",,"xhtml","

While reading a recent news article regarding the neophyte Republican Senate candidate from Delaware, Christine O'Donnell, I was struck by the comment from the writer (unfortunately, I can't find the link).
column2: Regardless, the writer commented on multiple questions and controversies, one of which was the fact that it took her about fifteen years to obtain her college degree from Fairleigh Dickinson.&nbsp
column3: The article also noted her comment that it took her about ten years to pay off her student loans.

column1: Is this really a controversy as much as a commentary on the hurdles facing young people trying to obtain their degree?
column2: Let's parse the facts.&nbsp
column3: She obtained her college degree this year and is about 41 years of age.&nbsp
column4: If it took her fifteen years, that means that she would have started college while in her mid-twenties.&nbsp
column5: If it took her about ten years to pay off her loans, which implies that she's now debt free of student loans, then she probably took on considerable debt but was then unable to complete college due, at least in part, to a lack of funding.&nbsp
column6: It took years to pay off the debt and bring some order to her finances before she could finally complete the degree.

column1: What does this mean for an average person completing this degree at this stage in life?
column2: While my father taught me not to make assumptions - it makes an ass out of you and me - there are moments when it's instructive.
column3: Assume that the data is correct and a person really does make significantly more - almost $1 million - over their life with a degree than without.&nbsp
column4: Assume that the average age of a woman giving birth for the first time is twenty-five, which according to the National Center on Health Statistics, it is.&nbsp
column5: A person who has to take additional time to complete their degree without ending up in debt afterwards will finally have the opportunity to make the higher salary only when they're finally in their &quot
column6: green years&quot
column7: and if there's a child, it's a teen starting to look at college.&nbsp
column8: The income flows that are necessary to help them care for their families and prepare for their own retirements are postponed with the result that the person is facing a working retirement well past sixty-five years of age.&nbsp
column9: If the person held off on children during that period and still wants a family, then the family's financial situation will be that the kid's education will be kicking in when a worker would be actively considering retirement about two generations ago.

column1: Whether you agree with the assumptions or not, the reality is that the cost of today's higher education have a major impact on young people.
column2: Some choose to postpone forming their own families until their debts are paid off or reduced and they can afford a house in which to raise the kids.&nbsp
column3: Some choose to purchase older cars with the resulting loss of car sales and employment at the dealer and on the line.&nbsp
column4: Some simply give up and default, accepting that they'll be haunted forever by the debt around their neck.&nbsp
column5: These kinds of scenarios can only be avoided if:

column1: <li>the youth has clear guidance and an understanding of the process in obtaining and financing a degree
• the youth is willing to explore and accept alternatives to the model of goin' off for four years
• College costs are somehow brought under control so that it's once again relatively affordable.
Since #3 won't happen without significant public pressure, governmental intervention or a certifiable miracle, then it's up to us to involve ourselves and keep talking to the kids.
I'm thoroughly unfamiliar with Christine O'Donnell and hadn't heard of her until the Delaware republican primary.
column2: But the willingness to stick to a plan for fifteen years and finish it without debt is actually something of which to be proud.&nbsp
column3: It's the fact that some find this mindset controversial is what should really be controversial.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
340,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of the things that people might be hearing from the economics blogs is the question of whether - and to what extent - the Federal Reserve System is gaming the system.
column2: What is meant by quantitative easing and what does it mean to say the Fed is Monetizing the Debt ?
above link is to an article in a business/economics site entitled Zerohedge.&nbsp
column3: The site is like many other economics sites in which the writer (here the pseudonymous Tyler Durden) has a particular point of view as to how things will turn out in the world of money.
column4: In this case, Durden espouses the case of monetary&nbsp
column5: collapse and hyperinflation, which is a particularly scary outcome arising from our economic difficulties.&nbsp

column1: The reality is that times are truly tough and no one knows what's going to happen as a result of these policies and actions.
column2: But the article does a decent job of explaining what it means when you hear talk of monetizing the debt and walking through the essential pathways of how it happens, so I thought it might be of some benefit to folks.&nbsp
column3: As an additional treat, follow the comments thread for an eye-opening look at what some others believe and the opinions and arguments that they make.&nbsp
column4: It makes for fascinating, eye-opening and occasionally hilarious reading.

column1: I have no final idea of what's going to result from the policies and actions of our leaders and central bankers.
column2:
But follow enough and you'll learn that neither does anybody else, so we're all even.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
341,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The past several decades have been a parental anomaly.
column2: Parents have been concerned with their child's self-esteem and image, and have often wished to be considered as much friend as parent.&nbsp
column3: That means that there's generally less discipline and control and&nbsp
column4: techniques that&nbsp
column5: our grandparents used have gone by the wayside.&nbsp
column6: Two tools that have fallen out of use are embarrassment and old-fashioned guilt.&nbsp
column7: Is it ever appropriate to embarrass the child or make him feel guilty?

column1: Actually, yes and I've used them both on occasion
column2: as they're tools to be used to maintain discipline and teach, as much as groundings, time-outs, privilege-loss and old-fashioned jawboning.&nbsp
column3: This doesn't mean that they're used on every occasion - and they should actually be used sparingly - but neither are they to be avoided.

column1: Embarrassment and guilt are powerfully negative feelings and kids are like everybody in that they'll act to avoid the sense
column2: that these feelings bring.&nbsp
column3: But these are actually learned sensations and if a child doesn't know to be embarrassed or feel guilty, then she simply won't.&nbsp
column4: I think that there's actually some value in these negatives
column5: each reflects an awareness of other people and indicates that the child understands that there are other beings in the world apart from themselves.&nbsp

column1: Embarrassment's value is in helping the child to learn to control impulses and exercise some thought process instead of just doing something without any consideration as to the consequences.
column2: When there's an obvious and glaring outcome, there might even be no need on my part to embarrass the child since the action speaks solely for itself.&nbsp
column3: For example, if&nbsp
column4: Junior is playing a sport and his goofing off on the field leads to a goal for the other team, there's no need for me to highlight anything since his teammates will swiftly and certainly bring it to his attention.&nbsp
column5: In those instances in which Junior has been embarrassed by his actions, I've had to do nothing more than just acknowledge quietly that he had reason to be embarrassed.&nbsp
column6: <em>Yeah, son.&nbsp
column7: You should have been embarrassed - so what do you take away from this?&nbsp
column8: A kid's parents might not want to embarrass the child but his peers will certainly think nothing of it and a few will take to it like a pig to slop.
column9: Where I've come to really utilize embarrassment is when my child is absolutely old enough to know better and the behavior is so glaringly stupid that it borders on or crosses into dangerous territory.&nbsp
column10: Teens are notorious for lacking the ability to assess risk, let along simply judgment in many cases and even when presented with the possible negative outcomes, will simply think <em>that can't happen to me.&nbsp
column11: This is especially the case when there are multiple kids together and absolutely none of them is thinking clearly, in which a cold dose of embarrassment will quickly bring things to a halt.
column12: For example, finding three teenage boys playing tag in the rafter of a picnic pavilion more than ten feet above a concrete slab floor brought a vividly phrased condemnation to bring the point home.&nbsp
column13: <em>Maybe you won't fall, but you can be damned sure that you'll get your self-esteem mangled if not your ribcage.&nbsp
column14: Likewise, misbehavior with a vehicle stands as ground for embarrassment and outright humiliation if the need arises.
column15: Kids and teens might not remember reason, but they will acutely remember embarrassment before their peers.&nbsp
column16: Like many disciplinary situations however, there has to be a calmer follow-up conversation to bring the point home.&nbsp
column17: Pairing the immediate embarrassment with a later conversation can have a positive outcome.

column1: Guilt differs from embarrassment in that the concern arises out of the consequences involving another instead of oneself.
column2: &nbsp
column3: It doesn't have to have such a public cause and few, if any, need to be aware of the sense of guilt.&nbsp
column4: Most kids and teens with any conscience will experience the pangs of guilt and it usually isn't necessary to inflict that sense on the child.&nbsp
column5: Where I have had to inflict a sense of guilt on one of my children has been when there's been no realization that the behavior involves another person
column6: the child will spin in his or her own little world unaware of how the behavior or attitude affects someone else.&nbsp
column7: In those rare instances, I've mentioned the concept of shame and the shock of the language and tone has usually been enough to bring the point home.&nbsp
column8: Again, it's imperative that you talk with your child soon afterward so as to wade through the morass of upset and conflicting emotions until the other side has been reached.

column1: Having to contend with a child who's out of control requires some quick judgment on your part and it's not my intent to provide wholesale endorsement of these two measures.
column2: However, they do have their place and value and if you find yourself in the heat of the moment utilizing them, don't necessarily condemn yourself as a poor parent or incompetent.&nbsp
column3: You're actually doing the kid a favor.

When the San Jose cop "
column2: arrested&quot
column3: his stepdaughter's boyfriend for sleeping with her, the story raised all manner of questions.
column4: Most pertain to whether the officer was appropriate in using his station to scare the boy and others pertain to whether the daughter should have been busted instead of the son.&nbsp
column5: A more basic question is how much latitude a parent has in dealing with Opie (Other Peoples kid).
column6: Just how far can and should you go?

column1: Let's put the immediate question of the San Jose stepfather/cop to bed - I doubt that there'd be any issue at all if he's simply punched the teen while out of uniform.
column2: But utilizing an official process to &quot
column3: scare&quot
column4: a kid, especially in the boy's home, was simply unacceptable.&nbsp
column5: Now let's move on.

column1: There are multiple factors coming into play with Opies.
<li>Are the other parents even around to help supervise or are you the sole adult in charge?&nbsp
column2: It's likely that if you've got a toddler playdate at a neighbor's house that you'll have to take much action apart from monitoring your own.&nbsp
column3: The other parent is there to keep tabs on their own child and at the younger ages, simple redirection is often the only thing necessary to keep things in check.&nbsp
column4: That said, it's not uncommon to &quot
column5: talk shop&quot
column6: , which for parents often relates to common disciplinary measures so that you get a measure of the other parent's views and preferences.&nbsp
column7: And if things do spiral out of control, then you should immediately let the other parent contend with the kid.

column1: <li>Are you a parent or are you fulfilling another role, such as leader at an event in which you have some legal responsibility?&nbsp
column2: I've found - and others have confirmed - that if you're in charge, then the other parents are generally happy to let you handle the discipline short of corporal punishment.&nbsp
column3: On multiple occasions in scouting, I've noted that some parents' attitude is akin to he's your issue, have at it and good luck as Junior runs amok in the room.
column4: Fortunately, there have been few issues when I've assigned time-outs or even pulled a boy aside for a chat.&nbsp

column2: You might think that you have to be more &quot
column3: in the face&quot
column4: with smaller children who are out of control, but the younger more routinely only require quiet correction of some kind
column5: it's the teens who've been caught up in the cycle of group thoughtlessness who require a stronger hand.&nbsp
column6: Teens will tend to get caught up in the moment and group dynamics as they feed off of one another
column7: there are also other issues such as saving face amongst the peers when confronted with an adult who's trying to maintain or regain control.&nbsp
column8: Honestly, my moments of truly yelling have been with groups of 'tweeners and teens who've gone totally around the bend.&nbsp
column9: Younger kids can still be intimidated and awed by the size of the upset adult and are more likely to be physically scared (which might or might not be a good thing) while the larger teens might feel the need to prove something.

column2: If I find teens - for whom I'm responsible - driving around with other teens on the hood of the car, then I have no qualms about going ballistic on them
column3: the chance of injury or death justifies yelling so that the shock breaks through their event barrier and grabs their undivided attention.&nbsp
column4: Yelling because the television is too loud in the basement is overkill.

column1: <li>Do I want to embarrass my own child?&nbsp
column2: Actually, if my own kid is there and I feel obliged to yell or become unpleasant, then embarrassment is the least of his or her problems.

column1: It's actually rare to have to become unpleasant with opies and many will take listen once you have their attention.
column2: Only once have I had to actually get physical with teens and that was to protect my own kids, then toddlers.&nbsp
column3: The regional park to which I took&nbsp
column4: my own kids had an elevated playground in a copse of trees - seriously cool - and unsupervised teens were running through it repeatedly with the risk of a small child being knocked off.&nbsp
column5: One parent said something to no effect and when one group ran past, I shoulder-blocked the leading boy and knocked him askew.&nbsp
column6: <em>Gee, sorry about that.&nbsp
column7: Guess you'd better watch where you're going.&nbsp
column8: My point was taken and the group moved on.

column1: But if I ever find a boy with my daughter...

A large part of my paternal job is to keep tabs on the world and how it affects my family.
column2: What's happening and what must I do to adapt?&nbsp
column3: More importantly, how do I help prepare my children for the world in which they're going to live?

column1: Parental roles are slowly blending and blurring as fathers take on childcare and mothers expand into the workforce.
column2: But each still has a certain impact upon the kids and for dads, it's how the child perceives and interacts with the outside world.&nbsp
column3: Research has shown that it's a father's input that helps spur vocabulary and language skills in small children.
column4: When fathers were actively involved, the language skills of a three year-old were higher at a statistically significant level.&nbsp
column5: More recent research finds that a dad's horseplay and interaction with the kids encourages exploration and self-confidence
column6: this helps them meet and cope with the larger outside world.&nbsp
column7: It's simply part of our job to prepare our children to survive and be productive in the world.

column1: But our times are significantly different than our own parents' and the economic challenges facing our children will make ours pale in comparison.
column2: If we're going to prepare them, we have to first get a handle on what they'll be facing in the future.

column1: Stroll through the internet's economics offerings and you'll find the full gamut of opinions on what's going to happen and unless you live in Chile or Norway, little of it is good.
column2: Views are offered by economists, investment strategists and advisers, pundits and even the odd economic astrologer.&nbsp
column3: This opinion spectrum ranges from stagflation and economic depression to Japan-style deflation and hyperinflation
column4: to paraphrase one economics blogger,&nbsp
column5: we really have no idea what will happen.

column1: The short-term future is fuzzy at best but statistics and anecdotal evidence make the long-term outcome pretty certain.
• The quoted unemployment rate (U-3) is stuck persistently at 9.5%+ but the more realistic rate of U-6 is closer to 17%.
• The gap between the wealthiest Americans - the top 1% of wage-earners - and the rest of the country has widened to a level not seen since the days just prior to the Great Depression.
<li>We remain an oil-based economy with an oil-based infrastructure, reliant upon foreign suppliers&nbsp
column2: who often don't like us and only tolerate us for our military and our currency
column3: unfortunately, you can't field a military without a viable currency.

column2: prices - an indicator of fear and instability - are at global 30 year highs as individuals and institutions purchase them to counter the continuing devaluation of the dollar and other fiat currencies.

column1: <li>Within the past several weeks, 25 nations have piled into what the <a title=""Brazilian Finance Minister openly calls a &quot
column2: currency war&quot
column3: href=""http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/33ff9624-ca48-11of-a860-00144feab49a.html"">Brazilian Finance Minister openly calls a &quot
column4: currency war&quot
column5: .
column6: Even Peru bought $12M in order to drive up the dollar versus whatever they call their currency.

column1: • The US Federal Reserve System will again engage
column2: in further <a title=""quantitative easing"" href=""http://www.google.com/search?q=define:Quantitative+easing&amp
column3: aq=0&amp
column4: oq=what%20is%20quantitative%20eas&amp
column5: aqi=l1q1&amp
column6: psj=1"">quantitative easing, effectively flooding the economy with even more cash and liquidity.

column1: • The financial markets are largely broken.
column2: The pervasive use of High Frequency Trading
column3: has led to a market-wide &quot
column4: flash crash&quot
column5: with multiple smaller flash crashes amongst individual stocks, most notably Apple Computer.

column1: <li>Through unfettered lobbying and campaign contributions, the financial system has corrupted the legal/political system to a degree unmatched in our nation's history.&nbsp
column2: In 2009, Senator Richard Durbin (IL) told an interviewer that on Capitol Hill, banks <a title=""&quot
column3: own the place&quot
column4: href=""http://progressillinois.com/2009/4/29/durbin-banks-own-the-place"">&quot
column5: own the place&quot
column6: .
column7: The attitude of lenders has become so cavalier regarding such bedrock legal principles of title and property-ownership that in 23 states, large mortgage lenders have suspended foreclosure proceedings
column8: when the courts found that cases brought didn't adhere to basic principles and in some cases, the bank had no actual financial interest in the property.&nbsp
column9: Additionally, mortgage servicers hired by lenders have been caught presenting counterfeit court summons
column10: attesting that foreclosure notices were delivered when they really were not.&nbsp
column11: Most disturbingly, Reuters news recently reported that advance notes of the Federal Reserve Open Markets Committee meetings are being provided to paying clients by a former Federal Reserve System governor in advance of their release to the general public.

column1: • Our elected representatives are failing in their most basic duties as they leave for a pre-election recess without having yet passed an actual budget.
Viewing even only this partial statistical and anecdotal evidence, our nation really does sit on the cusp of huge structural challenges that haven't been faced in generations.
Whether it happens hard or easy in the near-term, the long-term outcome for our children is difficult.
column2: There is real risk that the American Middle Class will be largely eliminated as the political and financial elites sacrifice the common good for their own personal power and benefit.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: Our children will be marginalized to an underclass forced to subsist in lower-wage jobs with little hope of real prosperity, their earnings spent meeting the debt payments on a societal-wide model based upon the company town model of the 19th/20th century coal fields.&nbsp
column5: Their freedoms will be likewise jeopardized as those in positions of power continue to consolidate and maintain their grasp on the levers of government, twisting the screws even further as they bleed the future underclass.

column1: So what can any typical father do?
column2: There are no magic tricks to suddenly undo what's been in the making for decades and it's doubtful that there will be any call for great acts of heroism or civil disobedience.&nbsp
column3: The great changes will have to be made at the family level and it's our job as fathers to expose them to the wider world as we do with our words, language and horseplay.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1: When the children are very young, they are self-absorbed and generally clueless but one holds out hope that they'll grow out of it when they hit their teens.
column2: But once they hit their teens, you understand that the self-absorption is still there and the nature of the cluelessness changes.&nbsp
column3: They can handle multiple electronics simultaneously and perform academic/intellectual functions that are actually quite impressive.&nbsp
column4: But they still can't remember to give you the details on where they want to go with their friends.&nbsp
column5: They are convinced of their invincibility - as I was when I was that age - and are generally unaware of the dangers that can surround them, unless they're forced to adapt due to living in a dangerous neighborhood.&nbsp
column6: When you try to talk to them, the response is akin to the dog in the Far Side cartoon:
column7: &nbsp
column8: Blah blah blah blah Fido blah blah blah.

column1: If I had to find a television father who most temperamentally resembled my own father, it would have to be Red Forman of
column2: That '70s Show.&nbsp
column3: For all of his wonderful qualities, he was cranky and generally intolerant of teenage boneheadedness
column4: being called a dumbass was a familiar experience.&nbsp
column5: I promised myself with Eldest's birth that I wouldn't continue that experience with them and for the very large part I've been successful but it has really gotten much harder as the years pass.&nbsp
column6: My father, and other men that I've met through the years with teenagers, have commonly used the term &quot
column7: half-assed&quot
column8: &nbsp
column11: It's one that I've tried to avoid but&nbsp
column12: there are now moments when I quietly offer it up as I consider something that's been said or done.&nbsp
column15: Like many other fathers through the course of generations.

column1: I wonder if scientists have finally figured out what most fathers know.
column2: The last step in the maturation of the teen body into adulthood is that the kid finally develops a second buttock, qualifying him or her as no longer being half-assed.

column1: And until then, I just have to hang on.

I was taken aback the other day when Eldest complained that I was a sexist.
column2: <em>HUH?&nbsp
column3: You're complaining to a guy who's bent gender issues in all manner of shapes and angles.
column4: Her comment was prompted by a safety situation that occurred the previous evening in which she believed that she'd been wronged.

column1: We live in a small suburban community in an agricultural area and there's no crime the likes of which you read about in the larger communities.
column2: I was preoccupied when she said that she'd be taking a jog and didn't notice that it was already dark in the early evening.&nbsp
column3: She's an athletic, strong teen who likes to jog on non-sport practice days to keep in shape.&nbsp
column4: Within ten minutes, Middle asked if he could also take a jog and I permitted it, again not noticing that it was dark outside - bad on me.&nbsp
column5: Middle is a few years younger but already taller than his elder sibling and immeasurably stronger due to consistent exercise through the years
column6: this is a kid who announced in the kitchen at the age of six that he wanted a six-pack and had one by the age of eleven.&nbsp

column1: He returned a few minutes after his sister and caught us in the midst of discussion
column2: because I'd since realized that it was actually dark outside.&nbsp
column3: My stance was that while I appreciated that she wanted to stay in shape, I no longer would permit her to run after dark unless she ran with another person
column4: otherwise, she'd only be running alone when there was still daylight.&nbsp
column5: We disagreed but she respected my reasoning that running alone after dark was simply inviting problems.&nbsp
column6: While she was still in the room, Middle asked whether the same rule applied to him and after looking at the kid, I stated that yes, he could continue to run alone after dark, but only in the early evening.&nbsp
column7: My thinking was that he was strong enough&nbsp
column8: and fast&nbsp

column1: It was at lunch the next day that the previous evening's conversation came up and Eldest asked why the rule applied only to her instead of him.
column2: Again,&nbsp
column3: she's female and the reality is that it's likelier that lone females are prey&nbsp
column4: to attackers&nbsp
column5: than lone males.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Predatory&nbsp
column8: males are cueing on lone females instead of lone males and such predators are typically armed in some manner.&nbsp
column10: Additionally, her younger brother was still younger and stronger than she was.&nbsp
column14: called me a sexist and truly pulled me up&nbsp

column1: I stewed on the comment through the remainder of lunch and afterwards pulled both elder kids aside.
column2: <em>Here's the deal then.&nbsp
column3: You might consider this rule sexist, but you'll still only run at night with a buddy.&nbsp
column4: However, bad things can also happen to a lone male so that your brother will be bound by the same rule
column5: he's not a full-grown adult and the prospect for problems exists as well.&nbsp
column6: If you want to run at night, then you'll have to run together.&nbsp
column7: I believe that I'm correct in not permitting Eldest to run alone after dark.
column8: But I was wrong to think that Middle's gender would be fool-proof protection against attack or mugging.&nbsp

column1: Kids often live in a world that's devoid of external dangers, at least that's for kids living in low-crime or rural areas.
column2: Safety consciousness is a learned skill and it will take much continued talk and effort to get the kids to think about the threats of the outside.&nbsp
column3:
Threats that are larger than a father that you find quaintly overprotective.
