Abraham Lincoln remarked that you can fool some of the people all of the time and all of the people some of the time, but you can't fool all of the people all of the time. Some time ago, I read that a strong majority of American adults
column2: now believe that the opportunities for our offspring will be less than the opportunities that we had when we became adults and this group falls into the third category of Lincoln's comment.
column3: If we truly are in trouble, what must I do to help prepare my kids for such a future?

column1: The first lesson of preparing the kids for the new economic world is to be purposefully countercultural.
When economists and the bobbleheads on CNBC talk about deflation, they're not necessarily talking about a decrease in prices, they're actually talking about a drop in the amount of liquidity
column2: and credit available in the financial system.&nbsp
column3: One of the notable items since the bailouts of late 2008 is that large banks are given huge amounts of credit but the credit for consumers contracted and only recently began to increase again.&nbsp
column4: We're still being pushed to spend but with flat or declining incomes and food inflation, more and more of us are finally being pushed to the wall and most will only change when there is neither time nor option.&nbsp
column5: When you've been raised and taught a certain way, the trauma to the perceptions and psyche can be exquisitely painful.

column1: Our forebears taught their kids that one of the crucial financial skills was to practice savings.
column2: The future was uncertain and you had to take responsibility for your financial health.&nbsp
column3: On an aggregate basis, that meant that there was also sufficient capital available for investing in projects and products that actually helped to create national wealth.&nbsp
column4: Today, that's turned around as the corporate culture punishes those who save and rewards those who learn to consume, especially on credit.&nbsp
column5: Sitting on the kitchen island as I write this is a mailer from American Express for their prepaid AmEx card for teens, touting that it's neither debit nor credit but with all kinds of online tools to help them track their spending and manage their budgeting.&nbsp
column6: Next to the mailer is Eldest's savings account statement, showing an annualized interest rate yield of .1%.

column1: Why save when we can help you learn how to spend in the adult world?
There are no magic answers or pop-psychology techniques to confronting the prevailing culture.
column2: If you don't want to go Amish and completely ban all external electronic tethers to your kids, the you have to be prepared to monitor and control them.&nbsp
column3: It's both time-consuming and frustrating to have to keep tabs on what and how long they've been immersed in the electronic culture but it's necessary.&nbsp
column4: The entire electronic culture is saturated with spending messages and cross-marketing techniques and the first line of defense is simply to control it as much as possible.&nbsp
column5: How pervasive is it?&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: One dark night several months ago, Youngest was taking cans to the recycling bin when he sang out Red Robin! and a stranger walking his dog down the
column8: block called back YUMMMMM!

column1: Along with limiting electronics, you have to have a sense of what's out there.
<li>Keep the screen electronics - computers and televisions - in a public area so that you can keep an eye on what's being seen.&nbsp
column2: I understand that there's no way that I'll see everything but I view it as a parental quality control device, a visual random sampling.

column1: <li>Use the parental control tools available onthe family computer to limit the time spent or the hours that it can be viewed so that if you're not around, it can't be used.&nbsp
• Review the browser history and visit some of the sites that the kids are at to see what they're viewing.
<li>Take some time to visit MTV and view some of their offering.&nbsp
column2: I've also spent time viewing Cartoon Network's Adult Swim.

column1: When moving beyond the household walls, be purposeful in how
column2: you spend your own money.&nbsp
column3: I've ratcheted down my own spending significantly and have cut my personal expenses for the coffee and muffins, choosing instead to brew my own and work through a pot in about two days.&nbsp
column4: When you're shopping with the kids, audibly ask yourself whether you actually need that item that you've been eyeing or whether it'sactually only something that you want.&nbsp
column5: discuss it aloud when you're with the kids and opt to keep the wallet in the pocket instead
column6: while you might not think so, they really are listening and taking in what you say.&nbsp
column7: If you have to go to the mall for something, take the kids along but tell them in advance that the purchases made will be only for the needed items.&nbsp
column8: Show them that it's possible to walk out with having spent unnecessarily.

column1: Talking is crucial, especially when the kids are saturated in a media world that specializes in promoting consumption by blurring the lines between need and want.
column2: Why do you buy a car - to get from one place to another or to make a statement about your tastes and values?&nbsp
column3: Is the need to have a new car worth the amount of money that's going to be lost to depreciation in the car's first three years of ownership?

column1: Pay attention to where and when you shop.
column2: While my wife is in a position in which she has to dress well, I'm not and I frankly buy the everyday wear at Goodwill.&nbsp
column3: We've passed this along to the kids and now the older two prefer to shop there in lieu of going to chain stores that provide cheaper clothing made in China and the Pacific Rim.&nbsp
column4: My comments have been frank in that I'd rather provide business to an entity that employs the locally disabled than an entity that's paying a pittance to some poor foreign 'tweener and pocketing the rest.&nbsp
column5: Likewise, instead of shopping&nbsp
column6: at the major supermarket that's owned by a Dutch conglomerate, we now do most of our food purchases at the locally owned grocery as well as at local farmers markets.

column1: Buying food locally and eschewing the culture might sound like a hippie thing, but it is important.
column2:
Our children will have to think outside the current economic model's box and seeing money flowing to those who don't fit the model will be instructive.

column1:
347,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Almost every parent wants their kid to do well - I say almost since I've met a few who honestly couldn't give a tinker's dam about their kid - and that leeches over to the schoolwork.
column2: How far do you go in helping before taking over the process in its entirety?&nbsp
column3: When is it too much?

column1: I'm facing that question now as Eldest is involved in an A(dvanced)P(lacement) US History course.
column2: Part of her assignment for the year is to write an original paper on some topic of interest.&nbsp
column3: She came home last week with three tomes on US Economic History from the school library and when I inquired as to why she'd have a 400+ page history of American economic development, she told me that her topic was the history and development of the dollar and the controversy between a fiat dollar and a gold-backed dollar.&nbsp
column4: I was honestly stunned as she stood near me in the kitchen
column5: it's a topic of which few are aware but one that I find of exceptional pertinence in this day.&nbsp
column6: This PracticalDad econogeek has shared concerns over the economic future of the country since it's her generation that stands on the precipice of an economic cliff and while I talked about it, I was never entirely sure that she or her brother was listening.

column1: Yes, she was listening - even with one earbud dangling from her left ear.

Further discussion revealed that she needed at least a half-dozen primary and more secondary sources and as I also looked at the AP Physics textbook on the kitchen counter, I actually pitied the kid for the amount of work that she's taken upon herself.
column2: It also dawned on me that she'd decided upon the topic because she understood that dear ol' PracticalDad had a clue of the subject, even if he's not an expert.&nbsp
column3: Further, It was&nbsp
column4: a means by which I could&nbsp
column5: maintain a common bond with a teen who's a&nbsp
column6: social butterfly and actively in the college decision process.&nbsp
column7: So it behooves&nbsp
column8: each of us to work together.&nbsp

column1: But how far do I take it?
column2: Both her mother and&nbsp
column3: I have stressed the academics -&nbsp
column4: <em>everything flows from the schoolwork -&nbsp
column5: but we
column6: have actively demurred from doing the homework as some other parents do.&nbsp
column7: I've even gone so far&nbsp
column8: as to&nbsp
column12: assisted on isolated questions but have refused to do more than&nbsp
column17: not always going to be there, that's&nbsp
column19: Now use what we've done as a model.
column22: to write it for her and I&nbsp
column23: can't explain everything since she can't use&nbsp
column25: as either a primary or secondary source, but I can at least whittle down the amount of reading that she&nbsp
column28: The result is that I've taken the liberty of&nbsp
column29: pointing out what chapters in the three tomes are pertinent to her topic so that she doesn't waste time reading about American Agricultural Economics in the mid-19th century.&nbsp
column30: Likewise, I've pointed her to multiple other sources that provide what she'll need to gain an understanding of the topic.&nbsp
column31: The final part of my task will be to&nbsp
column33: basic reading list so that she can read on the topic chronologically and thus keep some sense of order.&nbsp
column34: After that, she's on her own and I'll limit any further involvement to explaining what I can.

column1: It's easy for parents to think that the kids don't care about being around them anymore.
column2: There are friends and activities and they never seem to have enough time in the day for what they want to do, and the parents wonder what happened to that little kid who wanted to spend so much time around them.&nbsp
column3: But there are still moments when the kids will come to you and you have to put things aside and grab the opportunity when it presents itself because it's often as much the teen wanting to stay connected as it is the question or issue itself.&nbsp
column4: The venue or activity will change as they age, but the desire to stay connected is still there.&nbsp

column1: I had no intention of spending considerable time perusing economics and historical texts for information on the gold standard and the several decade change to the fiat currency.
column2: But it is something that I can do to help the kid as she prepares for the AP paper.&nbsp
column3: And I'll stay available to discuss the questions that she has as the year progresses, because that time is not long for this stage of our lives together.

column1:
348,"1","1",,"xhtml","

If you're fortunate, you'll tie in with a network
column2: of folks who are able to pass along outgrown clothing, thus helping to keep those costs under control.&nbsp
column3: That also means that there's going to be clothing that's stored away and has to be periodically sorted both by size and seasonality and that task is something that I do twice each year when the weather starts turning cold or warm.&nbsp
column4: It does raise the occasional question of whether there's actually too much clothing to keep in the house.

column1: We're fortunate in that we have two boys and are physically/emotionally close to another family with two boys and there's been a flow of clothing through the years.
column2: They also have a daughter, but she and our daughter are similar enough in size and age that we really haven't been able to process hand-me-downs for the girl.&nbsp
column3: So what's the logistical process for sorting and&nbsp
column4: handling the flow of clothing?

column1: <li>Start with the youngest child and cull through the clothing, either throwing out or passing along what he or she can clearly no longer wear.&nbsp
column2: It took me a while to finally visualize a pipeline between one kid and the next one and realizing that if there wasn't room for the clothing being passed down, I'd wind up with a stack - or pile - of clothes with no room for storage.

column1: <li>You can visually size up what's obviously too small and move that to a separate pile&nbsp
column2: for later processing.&nbsp
column3: What's obviously wearable for the colder or warmer weather is separated and yet another stack is composed of what the child actually has to try on.&nbsp
column4: My experience has been that it's best to just pull the child for one stack of try-ons instead of constantly asking him or her to come away from the activity and creating resentment.

column2: attention to the condition of the clothing.&nbsp
column3: I've kept and patched jeans that are ripped but I then have to be careful that those are the pants that are worn for Saturday play instead of making it to school.&nbsp

column1: <li>Since kids don't grow at a constant rate, expect that not everything is going to be the exactly right length.&nbsp
column2: Pants might be a bit short or long and depending on how much and what is available, might have to be worn until they are either unacceptably short or are finally the right length.&nbsp
column3: The same goes for shirts.&nbsp

column1: <li>In dealing with shirts, this process gives you the opportunity to cull what's acceptable in terms of language.&nbsp
column2: Many 'tweeners and teens today wear shirts with messages and there are many parents who simply say nothing about the message.&nbsp
column3: Our stance has been that shirts with messages are fine for play but not school and even then, the message can contain no offensive language.&nbsp
column4: A case in point is the farting dog shirt that simply wound up in the trash.

column1: <li>You might have to decide how much is too much.&nbsp
column2: A year ago, our eldest boy had eight pairs of jeans that fit simultaneously, but does a boy need eight pair of jeans?&nbsp
column3: In our case, I held several pair back for the younger boy.

column1: <li>The offsetting question is whether the child has any other clothing besides jeans and play clothing?&nbsp
column2: I don't know of any families where the girls don't have some dresses or more formal clothing, but boys can be so rough and tumble that it's easy to forget that they do need to have more formal clothing, even if it's simply khakis and one or two dress shirts.&nbsp
column3: In our case, each of the boys has one or two pair of dress pants and a pair of khakis, along with some ties and decent sweaters.

column1: <li>The final question is where you want the old clothing to go.&nbsp
column2: Is there another family that can use the clothing?&nbsp
column3: Do you have a favorite charity?&nbsp
column4: In our case, there's a bag of kids and adult clothing that will go to the school district, which is organizing a free clothing give-away within the next several days.

column1:
349,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's 9:15 in the evening and I've donned my down vest and cap to take the dog for an evening stroll.
column2: Even better, I've pulled out my mp3 and earbuds so that I can enjoy some of my own music as we saunter around the block.

column1: Hey Dad, I just got out of the shower but can I walk the dog with you?
No, Son, your hair's still wet so I'll just go.
Really, Dad, I'll only be a minute.
My wife cuts me a glance and I already know what she's going to say and I nod my head.
column2: Sure enough, she says it:&nbsp
column3: <em>Your son wants to take a walk with you.&nbsp
column4: And she's right, my son wants to take a walk with me.

column1: In that brief fifteen minute excursion, I catch further glimpses of life amongst the teen tribe.
column2: How Scream-o isn't the same as Punk and it really - supposedly - takes considerable talent to master the Death Metal growl.&nbsp
column3: How kids in middle school really don't listen when you tell them to stop the bean-dips - reaching up and grabbing another's nipples - and you just have to punch them in the face to make them quit.
column4: How I was apparently right in that even our town isn't as safe as he previously thought, and that truly grabbed my attention.&nbsp
column5: He and some friends were walking home from&nbsp
column6: the high school football game when they were challenged from behind by some older teens and if he's not exaggerating, had to bluff their way out of the situation.&nbsp
column7: And with each of these snippets, I asked further questions or in the case of the bean-dips and football game incident, offered some suggestions such as not walking home at night in an alley.

column1: As a father, my life really isn't my own anymore and it's been that way for years.
column2: I miss quiet moments and the latitude to do what I want, when I want to do it.&nbsp
column3: And God knows I miss my favorite musical pieces.&nbsp
column4: But the reality is that I have to take advantage of every opportunity to spend time with them even if I'm not in the mood.&nbsp
column5: It's their attempt to maintain the lines of communication and as they age, those lines can fray or become brittle with age so it's my responsibility and obligation to put away the mp3 and honor the attempt.&nbsp
column6: I'm actually counting myself fortunate that my young teen still wants to walk the dog with me and share those insights and moments because I hear plenty from people who feel as though they've been completely shut out.

column1: Perhaps however, they really haven't been shut out but simply haven't realized that they've been approached.
column2: The time spent together doesn't have to be earth-shattering and when teens come, it's frequently when it suits them instead of on the parents' schedule.&nbsp
column3: Dad might be tired, sore or just craving some privacy and quiet but it's still the first rule of fatherhood in effect, that a father's life is no longer his own.&nbsp
column4: So pay attention when the teen comes up and says something to you.&nbsp
column5: It isn't the dog or the other stuff, it's you that he or she wants.

column1:
Better yet, pretend that my wife is looking at you and then put away whatever it is that you're doing.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

350,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Most fathers understand that it's fun to mess with the kids and rile them up, but yea verily, for everything there is a season and right before a school concert isn't the season.
It took me awhile to realize it when the kids were much smaller and it wasn't until my wife made the connection between their
column2: pre-bedtime wrestling and post-bedtime insomnia that I grasped the concept of riling time.
column3: Unlike adults, most of whom can control themselves at a moment's notice when the need arises, kids are unable to simply control themselves as readily.&nbsp
column4: Riling time is fun and since kids recognize that most fun is good, they're unwilling - or unable - to regain control.&nbsp
column5: Control is for adults and it's stunningly dull.&nbsp
column6: So after multiple mornings of hard-to-rouse, cranky children, I learned to pay more attention to the clock.

column1: But tonight was an occasion in which both a mother and grandmother royally goofed.
column2: We were attending an informal high school fund-raising concert and the two women plopped next to us with two toddlers.&nbsp
column3: As the chorale gatherered to the stage and found their respective spots, the two adult proceeded to break into raucous peals of bird-like chittering.&nbsp
column4: The toddlers kicked in and soon, most eyes were on the foursome as they created a cacophony of jungle bird noises.&nbsp
column5: The high schoolers raised themselves to attention as the director took her place and the women began to try to control the kids.&nbsp
column6: They gathered the two into their laps and gently shushed them, they placed their index fingers over the kids' lips and spoke several times into their ears, asking and then admonishing them to be quiet.&nbsp
column7: It was an honestly weird situation since I wouldn't expect two grown women to act in such a manner at such a time.

column1: As the group began to sing, the kids occasionally yelped out a bird-like call and the women became increasingly insistent that the kids control themselves.
column2: But the women were in no position to expect immediate obedience since they'd started the ruckus in the first place.&nbsp
column3: The women simply forgot - or didn't care - that kids take their cues from the adults closely surrounding them and I doubt that it occurred to them that the kids wouldn't be able to control themselves.&nbsp
column4: Kids also have almost no sense of time and if the parents can get away with something quickly, the kids will think that it's still occurring and they have free rein.

column1: So what have I had to learn?
• That I can't rile up the kids at certain times because of soon-to-be-occurring events, such as meals or situations in which they need to be able to sit still for a period of time.
<li>That in the case of my own kids, I need to have some time after riling time for the kids to decompress.&nbsp
column2: Once they've been riled up, the kids won't just be able to stop but will instead requirement an adjustment period.

column1: <li>If the kids can't regain control and make a scene, then I have nobody but myself to blame.&nbsp
column2: I'm the adult and they're the children.

column1: • If they're a little older, I can remind them of other obligations so that they can remember - or try to, at least - and help themselves maintain control.
The kids tonight actually did a better job of reining themselves in that I anticipated when the entire incident occurred.
column2: &nbsp
column3: The toddlers finally listened and settled down and the high schoolers recovered from the hoopla of the previous song, and I can only hope that the two women understood that they were the issue instead of the kids.

351,"1","1",,"xhtml","

People that have their own websites can be caught up in numbers.
column2: How many hits?&nbsp
column3: How many unique visitors?&nbsp
column4: From where are they accessing the site - via search engine or link to somebody else?&nbsp
column5: Honestly, I've never paid a great deal of attention to the data which is why PracticalDad is a relatively stripped down, no-frills site.&nbsp
column6: Parents - fathers and mothers - aren't going to read this site because I toss in an article about which is the best family minivan
column7: there are other and better sites for that and I'm not going to spend my time playing <em>Can You Top This?&nbsp
column8: But what has become my focus is the RSS Feed and it was this weekend that the RSS feed clicked over the 10k mark.

column2: Honestly, thank you very much for giving enough of a damn to put this site on your RSS feed.&nbsp

column1: But now I'm going to ask for some input from you, if you could kindly spare me a few moments.
Should I just keep plugging as I've been or are there some changes that you'd like to see?
column2: More importantly, are there areas on which I need to provide greater - or lesser - focus?&nbsp
column3: I'm not hiring a market research firm to handle data collection since this is effectively a kitchen table endeavor, but I'd appreciate knowing, and if I don't get 10,000 responses, then I'll try to respond to as many as I can.&nbsp
column4: If you don't want to respond or have nothing to add, then that's fine, too.

column1: And in the meantime, I'll continue to roll on as I have, writing for the site in between hauling the kids and managing the family affairs.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
352,"1","1",,"xhtml","

I just posted an article about the RSS feed having topped 10,000.
Again, thank you for being one of those who subscribed via RSS.
And you're now witnessing what happens when one tries to multitask with a young one at the table doing homework, since I goofed and omitted my contact address:
If you do want to drop me a brief note with some suggestions as to what to see or delete in the future, I can be reached at don@practicaldad.com.

column2: When they're young, you spend your time cleaning up the personal messes and keeping them on track.&nbsp
column3: When they're older, they can handle their own bodily functions but they still generate messes and dirty laundry like the Dallas Cowboys generate hatred in Philly.&nbsp
column4: Couple that with the various activities and there are weeks when the household work takes a back seat.&nbsp
column5: This weekend culminated in a spate of soccer tournaments, scouting and youth activities and I awoke this morning to a household that's adrift with debris.&nbsp
column6: Throw in a website that's behind on posts and a spouse who's work has taken her out for the better half of the month and things really are in chaos.&nbsp
column7: What can I do to effectively bring things back under control?

column1: There are certain things that I've had to learn.
<li>Take a few moments to lay out a plan on what has to be done.&nbsp
column2: On this particular day, I know that I need to pay attention to the website as well as do laundry and prepare a family dinner for about 5:30 this afternoon.&nbsp
column3: While the laundry is going, what else can I do?&nbsp

column2: Women really are better at multi-tasking than men but one can learn through time.&nbsp
column3: Devices such as washing machines and dishwashers are labor-saving after they're loaded, so take the time to get them moving first and then move onto other tasks while they're going.&nbsp
column4: Sorting laundry is time-consuming but once a load is going, I can move onto other items.

column1: <li>Understand that multi-tasking will generate chaos as piles of clothes await their turn.&nbsp
column2: Also understand that I'm not going to be able to handle any task to completion before moving on to the next item, as most men like to do.

column1: <li>Take a moment to think after shifting to a new task.&nbsp
column2: In my case, this is my second effort at this article.&nbsp
column3: I've already done several loads of laundry and cleaned the kitchen while returning to the laptop to write new bullet points and I didn't take the time to remember that the posting software won't&nbsp
column4: hold the work for more than an hour&nbsp
column5: unless I remember to periodically save the writing.&nbsp
column6: So an article that was more than three quarters complete was lost and I'm now on the second take.

column1: <li>Think about what tasks can be passed off to the children.&nbsp
column2: Part of growing up is learning to care for things and that includes such household tasks as bathrooms, dusting and vacuuming.&nbsp
column3: The trade-off is that I might not have it done exactly the way that I'd do it, but it's still done and they've contributed.

column1: <li>Look for little things to physically carry with me as I move from one part of the house to another.&nbsp
column2: I'm presently sitting at the dining room table and noting that Youngest's toys are clustered on the living room sofa instead of the family room while Eldest's shoes are at the base of the steps.&nbsp
column3: When I leave this spot, I'll take the toys to the family room - which adjoins the laundry - and then take the shoes upstairs when I next go upstairs.&nbsp
column4: I could wait for the kids to come home, but the reality is that kids and teens have wildly short attention spans and it's immensely frustrating to constantly remind them to take this or carry that.
column5: This is definitely a case of picking the battles since I'd rather have them spend the time handling the bathroom and dusting.

column1: <li>Re-evaluate the plan through the course of the day.&nbsp
column2: Kids get sick or other issues arise that require time and attention and it's frustrating to get to the end of the day and not have accomplished what you wanted.&nbsp

column1: Finally, I've had to learn that these tasks and chores are a process instead of singular tasks or projects that can be completed, like a wood project or car repair.
column2:
That change in mindset will make the work infinitely more acceptable.

column1:
354,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Today's election day across the country and I'm faced with the choice of not only the candidates for the various offices - and trust me, I'm not thrilled about the various options - but which kid goes with me to vote.
It was easier when the kids were very little since my wife and I would trade off.
column2: She'd vote in the morning or after work and I'd go in the evening after she'd returned to watch the kids.&nbsp
column3: But they're older now and while Eldest could watch Youngest, Eldest and Middle also need to see the process in action.&nbsp
column4: The problem is that under our voting laws, I'm only allowed to take one minor into the voting booth with me while the other stands around outside and twiddles the proverbial thumb.&nbsp
column5: Each is old enough to understand not only the process but also some of the issues in varying degree and I expect that it will ultimately come down to a coin toss.

column1: The other issue that I have with voting in this election, far more than in previous elections, is that I'm frankly disgusted both with the slates of candidates offered by both parties as well as the campaign system in general.
column2: I recall my parents bitching about the various politicians when I was younger, but they at least perceived that there were other choices and there really was a better candidate.&nbsp
column3: The message that I got was that the system worked and if one did sufficient research, one could actually find the best candidate for the post.&nbsp
column4: But today, I look at the candidates and I see political hacks of all stripes whose sole preoccupation upon entering office is to hang onto the gravy train.&nbsp
column5: Likewise, much of the political power in the country has shifted to the corporations and financial sector.&nbsp
column6: I might never get my congressman to personally take my call but a multinational corporation with sufficient resources will have his attention in a New York minute.&nbsp

column1: That means that I have to monitor my disgust and try to keep some kind of balance when I'm talking about the political process with the kids.
column2: While I'm jaded at the moment, a part of me believes that it is a civic duty and hopes that there will be time that the pendulum has swung back and there really are alternatives.&nbsp
column3: I consequently have to try not to ruin youthful optimism for fear that when the moment arrives, they'll have opted out of the political process in despair.&nbsp
column4: While I can recall my father excoriate a particular candidate, I never heard him excoriate the entire group of candidates as I'm wont to do inside my head.

column1: So when I enter the voting booth with one of the kids, I'll try to make sure that I refer to a particular candidate as a lying sack of @#$% instead of all of them as lying sacks of @#$%.

And I promise not to hold my nose while I vote, either.

355,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Several decades ago, a family cruise on the QE2 was an event to be remembered and cherished.
column2: Passage was booked well in advance in order to secure a cabin and it was sufficiently expensive that only the wealthier families could afford the trip.&nbsp
column3: But now, millions of American families - the great majority of whom wouldn't go because the expense -&nbsp
column4: will most likely be&nbsp
column5: peremptorily booked on a new QE2 adventure courtesy of the Federal Reserve System.&nbsp
column6: The excursion's cost will be ruinously expensive and for most families, savings will be wiped out long before the cruise is finished.&nbsp
column7: The only question is whether the soon-to-be-destitute will be jettisoned before the cruise ends.

column1: Most older Americans identify QE2 as the famous Queen Elizabeth 2, symbol of a slower, more gracious age.
column2: But the liner is now long out of service and the QE2 being referenced is what economists and business pundits call Quantitative Easing.
column3: Because it's a repeat of what the Federal Reserve System did two years&nbsp
column4: ago&nbsp
column5: with massive infusions of cash to the financial sector, it's referred to as QE2.&nbsp
column6: With an economy loaded past the gunwales with debt, more than can be adequately serviced, the value of various asset classes have been dropping steadily for more than two years with a resultant wipeout of trillions of dollars in wealth - paper though it may be.&nbsp
column7: The intent of the experts at the Fed is to actually purchase huge amounts of various kinds of assets from holding banks and institutions, with the institutions and banks subsequently creating additional credit as the funds ripple from the financial sector throughout the economy.&nbsp
column8: These assets will go beyond just the debt to be issued by our Federal government - the government actually only needs a fraction of what's expected to come - and leech into other areas as well
column9: this would possibly include corporate and municipal bonds and if they emulate Japan's central bank, could even include ETFs and Real Estate Investment Trusts.&nbsp

column1: That's the intent and as the maxim goes, the road to hell is paved with good intentions.
column2: The reality is different.&nbsp
column3: Since that time and despite all of the money pushed to the banks, credit available to the average consumer and small business has dropped, while the reserves held by the banking system has risen multi-fold.
column4: Since short-term consumer debt rates - think credit cards - have never been decreased to Joe Six-Pack and credit limits for many have actually been slashed, the response has been to steadily pay off debt as much as possible so that the family debt load is lessened.&nbsp
column5: What has surprised financial authorities is that people in general have made greater efforts to stay current on the credit cards while letting the house payments fall behind
column6: given that many now depend upon the credit card for essentials, this isn't surprising.&nbsp
column7: And this is where Joe Six-Pack's actions contribute to the Fed decision to launch the QE2 since many of the deteriorating financial assets are bonds backed by the mortgages that Joe's letting slip away.

column1: That's hopefully a nice explanation, but what does it mean for me and my family?
column2: How will it impact my kids?&nbsp
If the banking system is getting all of these funds - and stands to get hundreds of billions more commencing shortly - but isn't passing them through to everyone else,&nbsp
column3: where is the money going?&nbsp
column4: Banks exist first and foremost as for-profit enterprises with the intent of making money.&nbsp
column5: If they can gain money by selling dodgy assets to or borrowing from the Fed at almost 0% rates, then they can take the almost free money and literally throw it at various investments
column6: if everyone is throwing money at the same assets, the result is that the price is bid up and the asset becomes more expensive.&nbsp
column7: In this instance, the assets at which they're throwing the money are commodities and natural resources, assets that have a hard, tangible output and value.&nbsp
column8: Remember that ours is a fiat currency
column9: backed solely by the tax receipts of our country.&nbsp
column10: Bankers fully understand the concept of debt service and asset valuation and sense that&nbsp
column11: our country has entered a phase in which the ability to cover our debt is seriously questionable.&nbsp
column12: In a grotesquely perverse act of selfishness, they're taking the money that flows from the increased debt and using it to profit by pushing up the prices of the resources of families and children need to survive - wheat for flour, sugar, corn for food and animal feed, cotton, oil.&nbsp
column13: The prices of these items will continue to rise out of proportion as the money released by QE2 flows further into commodities.

column1: The result will be what the Federal Reserve wishes, inflation.
column2: Inflation which not only profits the financial institutions via commodity investment, but also inflation which&nbsp
column3: supposedly makes the country more competitive internationally&nbsp
column4: as the dollar is devalued and the cost of American labor decreases.&nbsp
column5: Joe Six-Pack will be making less, when he's employed, but will have to stretch the dollars to cover the cost of everyday items needed for his family's survival.&nbsp
column6: So what might we expect to see for the American family?

column1: <li>First, the birth rate will drop as fewer couples feel secure enough to take on the cost of raising a child.&nbsp
column2: Already, the US marriage rate is dropping
column3: as couples forego marriage until employment prospects improve and while marriage is no longer an automatic precursor to parenthood, many will avoid purposefully having children.

column1: <li>Second, there will be a continuing swell of the food support programs such as SNAP and WIC.&nbsp
<li>Third, school attendance rates will continue strong and lunch program participation will&nbsp
column2: rise.&nbsp
column3: Children who haven't enough to eat at home will be sent by parents in order to take advantage of subsidized and free meals and more of the three squares a day will come from the school districts.&nbsp
column4: God knows where that money will come from when the Federal Government is eventually forced to pare down spending.

column1: • Fourth, more men will take to the road for employment opportunities a la the Great Depression, further removing fathers from a frayed family structure and placing more stress on the family.
<li>Fifth, the American retailing model will take a hit as a devalued dollar leads to higher finished goods prices.&nbsp
column2: Even the made-in-China clothing of Wal-mart will become more expensive and out of the reach of stretched families.&nbsp
column3: Clothing will increasingly be purchased or obtained via alternative sources as parents scramble to clothe growing children at church thrift shops, second-hand/consignment shops or even clothing distribution events.&nbsp
column4: In my small town, a reasonably prosperous school district sponsored a free clothing give-away for all ages on a recent Saturday morning.&nbsp
column5: In the longer term, expect handy skills such as sewing to make a comeback.

column1: <li>Sixth, expect families to take a greater hand in their own food growing, storage and preparation.&nbsp
column2: If food prices rise, more will return to gardening and the subsequent canning/drying.&nbsp
column3: In my own case, I've begun the process of turning a manicured hillside ornamental garden into a terraced vegetable garden.&nbsp
column4: I was also surprised to find that a daily chore performed by one of the third-graders in my cub scout den is to feed the chickens.&nbsp
column5: This child leaves in a classic suburban housing development built in the 1970s and the parents, both employed, built a chicken coop in the backyard to cut down on food costs.

column1: <li>Seventh, anticipate an uptick in juvenile crime and violence.&nbsp
column2: We've raised our children permissively and tended to spoil them and the resulting cut-off of the various goodies will probably lead to some level of increased thefts and violence as they steal from one another as well as others.

column1: <li>Eighth, expect that the standard housing arrangements will change as families move in&nbsp
column2: with one another to keep costs down and still provide housing for the chlldren.&nbsp
column3: Children might also be&nbsp
column4: more likely to share bedrooms as well as electronic devices within the household.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp

column1: <li>Ninth, expect that in the longer-term, today's children become far more practical and&nbsp
column2: hardnosed than we - their&nbsp
column3: parents - &nbsp
column4: ever had to be.&nbsp
column5: I glimpsed this one day while talking with one of my&nbsp
column6: son's friends, who was then in sixth grade.&nbsp
column7: His parents were delighted to be going on a&nbsp
column8: trip to the Bahamas and when&nbsp
column9: I asked about it, he responded&nbsp
column16: Likewise, I spoke with a teenager&nbsp
column17: who was being raised by his older sister.&nbsp
column18: We were discussing money with a group of teens and&nbsp
column19: the question was what would each do with a windfall of $100,000.&nbsp
column22: said that he wanted to purchase health insurance and&nbsp
column23: set aside the rest for a place of his own.

column1: There's no guarantee that any of these will come true,
column2: but I wouldn't be surprised if some of them didn't.&nbsp
column3: Some of them are already&nbsp
column4: happening and&nbsp
column5: doing so&nbsp
column6: before my eyes.

column1: We parents are going to be stretched in ways that we never considered
column2: before.&nbsp
column3: Our priorities will change and we'll be forced to make choices and decisions that are new and painful to our generation.&nbsp
column4: The key will be to absorb the blows in such a&nbsp
column5: way that even while our children have to&nbsp
column6: adapt to a new&nbsp
column7: reality, they don't find it as painful as we&nbsp
column8: will.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
356,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Now that we're cruising aboard the QE2, everybody wonders whether we'll reach the promised destination of a return to economic normality.
column2: The cost of this return however, is the value of the dollar and whether we'll be able to afford anything at all after we're done.&nbsp
column3: There's been growing concern about the validity of the economic data coming from the Federal Government, especially in terms of consumer prices.&nbsp
column4: The Federal Reserve has kept interest rates at all-time lows under the mantra that the Consumer Price Index is .1%, exclusive of food and energy.&nbsp
column5: Apparently the Fed believes that the rest of us don't eat and don't have to buy gas, so we can stay home on our extreme diets.&nbsp
column6: I've heard people say that food prices are rising, and I believe that they will if they aren't already, but nobody can seem to say how much.

column1: So we're going to put it to the test and track the prices of commonly used household items in the PracticalDad BOG (Boots on the Ground) Index.
column2: The BOG Index will measure, monthly, the prices of selected grocery items in a&nbsp
column3: simple, straightforward format.&nbsp
column4: What do we actually buy and what's happening to the price?&nbsp
column5: It's actually not difficult to do provided that you have some rules in place at the outset and then follow them scrupulously
column6: the key is to keep it simple and consistent.

column1: <li>The Index will be calculated by following prices on a monthly basis at three different grocery stores in my vicinity.&nbsp
column2: These stores comprise a mix:&nbsp
column3: a locally owned grocery
column4: an American owned Grocery chain store
column5: an internationally owned grocery chain store.&nbsp
column6: I don't pretend that there aren't regional differences but we're looking at the price changes in totality, not pricing by region.

column1: <li>The items are those that would be purchased by a family with children.&nbsp
column2: The item list will not change and the items will be consistent from store to store in package size and comparability.&nbsp
column3: A five pound package of ground round (80% lean) will be the same item priced at each of the three stores.&nbsp
column4: If an item is no longer available at one of the stores, then the best-fit alternative will be used.

column1: <li>Because one of the concerns about pricing is &quot
column2: stealth inflation&quot
column3: , in which prices remain the same but package size changes, the package size of each item will be consistent.&nbsp
column4: In the event that the package size of an item changes, I will adjust the price recorded to reflect the change by recalculating the item on a per ounce basis.&nbsp
column5: This will then be carried forward as we move along.

column1: • If the stores do not have identically sized packaging for the item in question, the price for the item will be calculated at the base unit price (per ounce, per count, etc.) and equalized amongst the three in a common size.
<li>Pricing will not allow for BOGO or other such specials&nbsp
column2: so that price movements aren't distorted.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: Likewise, there will be no allowance for coupons.

column1: <li>As much as practicable, the BOG Index will concentrate on generic&nbsp
column2: items.&nbsp
column3: If generic items aren't available, such as diapers, then&nbsp
column4: a brand name will be used.

column2: during the first week of&nbsp
column3: each month and the prices as of&nbsp
column4: November 2010 will constitute the base level of 100.&nbsp

column1: It's going to be a work in progress but with a little time, the question of whether there's price inflation - and the extent to which it exists - will become apparent.

The results of this month will be posted next week.
