357,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Because there are questions as to whether inflation is really going to accelerate, I began a simple price index - the
column2: PracticalDad Index - &nbsp
column3: with the market basket priced at three local and unrelated grocery stores.&nbsp
column4: The basket consisted of 47 items covering basic food categories such as dairy, meat, produce, staples, baby items and health/beauty products.&nbsp
column5: The pricing will occur during the first several days of each month and the results posted during the second week.

column1: Listed below are the items, with store and average prices, that compose the market basket.
column2: The average cost of the basket is $178.39 with a basket range from $174.37 to $181.42 and whenever possible, the items sampled were store brand.
Price Index - November 2010
OS, store brand (fl oz)

column1: As time progresses, the November 2010 average will serve as the basis index level of 100.

column2: Why did you open the door?

column1: This came from one the kids who arrived home from school to find the bedroom door open.
column2: And it begs the question, just whose room is it, really?

column1: Teens are acutely aware of their privacy, especially as their bodies change and they become more aware of their privacy.
column2: I get that and recall the days of walking in my bedroom, shutting the door, turning on the music and turning off the world.&nbsp
column3: While it appears to be lazy - especially as I wander through carrying laundry or stuff - it does serve a purpose.&nbsp
column4: That however, is a different article for a different day.

column1: The question arises because of what occurs behind the doors, at least in terms of unacceptable behavior.
column2: Yes, I also know about self-stimulation and unless it appears to take center stage in life, my view is that it's normal sexual development for teens.&nbsp
column3: But unacceptable behavior in this instance pertains to actions which damage the property.&nbsp
column4: I know one family whose son had an Air-Soft gun, a high-pressure air gun that can shoot plastic pellets at a high rate of speed, and he'd periodically load up the gun and shoot the walls of the room.&nbsp
column5: Did it knock holes in the walls?&nbsp
column6: No, but it did leave the walls with an interesting dimpled effect from the high-pressure impact.&nbsp
column7: It's a conversation that I've had on multiple occasions with one of the kids as I've had to (re)explain my stance.

column2: to open up the room when the child's not around to permit air to flow and stuffiness to dissipate.&nbsp
column3: Teenagers' rooms can get rank in a New York minute if permitted.&nbsp
column4: When the kid gets home and chooses to shut the door, I'll honor that.

column1: <li>If damage occurs within the room - and I mean the damage that arise from brain-dead anarchy - then the door will stay open as the child has shown himself incapable of behaving in such a way as to deserve privacy.&nbsp
column2: Sorry, but the Justices don't live under my roof.&nbsp
column3: It might be your room, but it exists inside of my house and will revert back to me when you've grown and moved on.

column2: privilege that can be removed in the event of outside misbehavior so egregious that it warrants it.&nbsp
column3: And there have been instances in our household when the bedroom doors have been removed because of major-league issues.&nbsp
column4: While we sometimes permit the kids to earn back removed privileges - note that I didn't say<em>&nbsp
column5: rights - the loss
column6: of privacy is something that we've let run the full course.

column1: <li>I periodically make the statement that I reserve the right to search a room if I deem necessary.&nbsp
column2: I don't know that that will occur but I don't want the kids to claim that they were ever unaware that it could occur.

column1: <li>To the extent that it's possible, any damage within the room will be fixed or cleaned up by the offending child.&nbsp
column2: That includes scrubbing the floor and spackling and painting damaged walls.&nbsp
column3: I can talk until I'm blue in the face but having to sand a recently spackled wall will send a memorable message - and teach the kid another life skill.

column1: The last point that I've occasionally had to make, especially as the kid ages and matures, is whether they'd like someone to treat their property as they might have treated mine.
column2: Some kids will never quite understand the point, but others will and amend their ways accordingly.

column1:
And to finally prove the point, not only do I open the door to the bedroom but I even open the window.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

359,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Each Veterans Day, I think of my deceased father and the stories that I later learned of his service in the Korean War.
column2: But this Veterans Day, I've been thinking more about my grandfather, the man who watched his son march off to Korea.&nbsp
column3: How must it have felt knowing that your son was enlisting with the prospect of combat and then knowing that he was engaged in combat?

column1: Children grow up and we expect them to talk about the future and what they plan to do.
column2: But as I walked the dog with my eldest son the other evening, the discussion turned to life after high school.&nbsp
column3: He's not yet in high school but watches Eldest with the typical high school decisions - where do I want to attend and what do I wish to study?&nbsp
column4: My son - whom I refer to as&nbsp
column5: Middle - struck me with a serious comment about serving his country and&nbsp
column6: his thought of enlisting after graduation.&nbsp
column7: This wasn't the tone of the kid saying that he wanted to&nbsp
column8: be a soldier when he grew up, but the tone of someone who's actually giving it consideration.&nbsp
column15: Because I want to make a difference and know that what I did meant something besides just a job.

column1: I honestly felt as though one half of my heart was being torn from the other.
column2: This is what I want from my children, the willingness and ability to lead productive and fulfilling lives.&nbsp
column3: I can't give them happiness since that's something that they must find for themselves, from within.&nbsp
column4: But the other half was the fear that I suddenly realized, in an intense fashion, is felt by millions of other fathers as they worry about their sons and daughters.&nbsp
column5: Before this moment, it had occurred to me as an intellectual awareness that maybe my child would become a soldier but now it struck me viscerally.&nbsp
column6: We talked and he then asked me what I thought of that prospect.&nbsp
column7: Both of our families - maternal and paternal - are shot through with veterans, although my wife's tends to the Navy while mine tends to the Army - and the kids know at least some of the stories that have been handed down.&nbsp
column8: God knows that awareness shot through me as we walked.

column1: I struggled with my thoughts and responded simply.
column2: I told him that it was an honorable wish and certainly an honorable way to gain that wish, and God knows we need solid, dependable people in the Army.&nbsp
column3: But the reality of what truly bothered me quickly became clear.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: <em><span style=""display: none"" id=""1289532408884S"">&nbsp
column6: It's not that the Army or Air Force isn't worthwhile, because it is.
column7: What's bothering me is that you might have to risk your life and I want - need - to be sure that the people making the decisions about going to war are truly able to make a good decision that's worth the sacrifice.&nbsp
column8: And I'm no longer certain that they're either competent or honest enough to make a solid decision.

column1: That's why I've been thinking of my grandfather the past two days.
column2: None of us wish to see our children in danger but the large majority understand that there's a real need for those able and willing to serve.&nbsp
column3: My grandfather however, had Truman as a president and a Congress that believed that division ended at the water's edge.&nbsp
column4: I'm honestly not the least bit confident in the political leaders, either in their decisions or their loyalties.&nbsp
column5: Who do they serve?&nbsp
column6: The people that elected them, or a corporation that's purchased their vote for an issue that's unfriendly to the common man?&nbsp
column7: If my son and his friends are someday&nbsp
column8: in Harm's Way, I need to know that they're there for the reasons that idealistic young join - serve, protect and make a difference.

column1: I hope that I haven't offended anyone reading this and I mean no disrespect to those who served.
column2: Now that it's off of my chest, I'm going to have a drink and have a few thoughts of my own father, the veteran.

column1: Good night and thank you for your service.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1: The hope and aim of the Fed Chairman, Ben Bernanke, is that all of the liquidity that's being injected into the system will cause prices to rise as inflation takes hold.
column2: The fear of many is that he'll succeed and the general public is now catching up with the econophiles as they try to determine if this is going to happen.&nbsp
column3: After hearing friends comment about how this or that went up in price, I went ahead and started the PracticalDad Price Index
column4: to publicly follow the course of prices amongst a market basket of 47 items.

column1: It seems that Walmart has been keeping its own internal survey of about 86 items and the Walmart purchasers are expecting prices to rise in the coming months.
column2: Apart from the intellectual exercise of trying to stretch the family dollar even further, people should be concerned because these prices will be concentrated amongst the major producers of items that are composed of commodities such as wheat and sugar.&nbsp
column3: These are precisely the commodity items that have been the recipients of a significant portion of the funds that the Fed has injected into the economy via the financial system.&nbsp
column4: As quantitative easing
column5: kicks in over the coming months, more funds will be funneled by the financial sector to commodities that in turn sends the price up further.&nbsp

column1: If I read the article correctly, the prices haven't actually hit the shelves yet so shoppers are safe.
column2: But they're coming and we'll be following them publicly on a monthly basis.

column1:
361,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Listen to AM talk radio nowadays and you'll hear hosts rave on about the value of gold in your portfolio.
column2: <em>I buy it and you should too.&nbsp
column3: Protection in the face of a declining dollar.&nbsp
column4: Buy now and don't be priced out.
column5: Most people can see the value to purchasing precious metals in today's financial environment but now pundits are tossing around &quot
column6: gold standard&quot
column7: like a football and you have to question, what is a gold standard and what does it mean?

column1: To understand the gold standard, you first have to understand that we live with a fiat currency
column2: monetary system.&nbsp
column3: Excepting those countries who tie their currency to the value of another's currency - think China and the United States - currencies &quot
column4: float&quot
column5: in value versus one another and it's the collective global concensus that evaluates which countries have stronger currencies.&nbsp
column6: There is nothing backing any currency except for the economic policies and tax revenues of that nation.&nbsp
column7: The Norwegian Kroner - remember that Norway is not a part of the Euro - represents a nation that's the #3 oil producer in the world, started the world's first Sovereign Wealth Fund to cushion against the day that the North Sea oil runs out, and keeps it's public debt under control.&nbsp
column8: Now consider the Mexican Peso.&nbsp
column9: The country is in year three of a vicious fight against drug lords, has a depleting oil supply and never fully recovered from the currency crisis of the 1990s.&nbsp
column10: When the global currency market considers these factors, it values the Kroner higher against the peso so that it takes far more pesos to purchase one kroner.&nbsp
column11: If the Mexicans could magically deport the drug lords to Norway, find another huge oil field and the Norwegians shot through five years of oil revenues on a month-long binge of hookers and blow, then the world will re-evaluate the peso as worth far more than the kroner.&nbsp
column12: Not that the typical Norwegian male would be in any condition to care.

column1: Cut through the mustard and that's about where it comes down.

Countries compete against each other in multiple ways but one of the long-term keys is via national interest rates, as set by both the particular central bank and the assessment of the global investment community.
column2: In the ideal world, interest rates supposedly act as a crude governor to the economic engine so when things start to heat up, the national rates are raised, credit demand declines and things slow down.&nbsp
column3: When things are slow, rates are dropped and credit is more available so that things pick up.&nbsp
column4: The market also has an impact on rates however via a risk premium on top of the set national rate.&nbsp
column5: When things are copacetic and the investment assessment actually matches reality, the risk premium is small and other factors are allowed to help set a country's course.&nbsp
column6: When things aren't copacetic however, then the risk premium rises so that a country has to pay far more for capital than others.&nbsp

column1: In today's world, we're awash with debt at all levels - personal, municipal, state, national (sovereign).
column2: Because we're a fiat currency, the only way to handle governmental debt is to either raise taxes on a strapped citizenry or else cut spending.&nbsp
column3: The reality is that our political leaders haven't been willing or able to cut spending and raising taxes isn't seen as an option.&nbsp
column4: Our monetary authorities - the Federal Reserve System - have opted to address the debt by devaluing the currency.&nbsp
column5: This has been done by keeping interest rates at historic lows for long periods of time and also by purchasing lousy assets from the banks at rates that are far better than the underlying asset is worth. The end result is that huge amounts of liquidity have been injected into the system and at this moment, there's no evidence that that's going to be brought under control.&nbsp
column6: The long and short is that the political and financial classes appear to have lost the will to do what's in the best interest of the country, assuming that we could all agree on the definition of &quot
column7: best interest&quot
column8: .&nbsp

column1: It's this sense that certain members of the financial and political community - both in and out of the US - can't be counted on to control themselves that's led to the rising talk of a return to the gold standard.
column2: When countries agreed to operate on a gold standard - whose best days were from about 1880 to 1914 - the operation was almost mechanical.&nbsp
column3: In a sense, each country's bank vault was akin to a giant bucket and international trade was the liquid that flowed between the various buckets.&nbsp
column4: When a bucket became too full, the country took the currencies filling it to the various currency owners and turned them in for gold to fill the national bullion vault.&nbsp
column5: Because the amount of a country's money circulating was a function of the amount of gold in the vaults, more gold led to easier credit and more money circulating.&nbsp
column6: Those with less gold had tighter credit and higher interest rates until such a time as they adjusted their policies enough to balance the system so that increased trade brought gold back to their own vaults.&nbsp

column1: In a way, the system was self-regulating amongst the countries and eliminated the vagaries that arose from the decisions of individuals regarding their particular currencies.
column2: It was consequently a mechanism that imposed discipline among the member nations so that no one country could run chronic trade and budget deficits or debase their currency.&nbsp

column1: That's the theory behind the argument on behalf of a gold standard and the reason that more voices, domestically and internationally, are being raised.
column2: Just bear in mind that there's no such thing as a hands-off mechanism that's flawless when it comes to the interactions and foibles of people.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
362,"1","1",,"xhtml","

I recently had a series of conversations and the gist was the question of whether fathers had a serious role in raising smaller children or whether small kids are the mother's purview.
column2: The sense of one person was that the father should let the mother be primarily responsible for the younger kids until they're older, at which point the father steps in.&nbsp
column3: Others disagreed and to be honest, I was surprised.&nbsp
column4: Why shouldn't the father be involved from the earliest days?

column1: Mothers historically are viewed as the nurturing parent and that's partially the result of the physical act of having to nurse the child.
column2: Both nurture and nurse are from the latin nutrire, of which one definition is to nourish.
column3: Prior to formula, and followed later by the breast pump, women had to stay home since they were the only ones capable of actually feeding an infant that wasn't yet able to take in solid food.&nbsp
column4: And historically, the fathers were out working in order to put the bread on the table and the roof over the head.&nbsp
column5: With these clear job delineations, men looked askance at women as they entered the workplace.&nbsp
column6: I can attest from firsthand experience that when men started to take up the household and childcare duties, more than a few women likewise looked askance as well.

column1: But is that parental job division still valid?
column2: Are kids better off with mothers when they're younger or are men equally as capable?

column1: I'll have to be honest and acknowledge that at some level, there will be some gender generalizations made.
column2: In my experience, women seem naturally more capable of multi-tasking than men and I can't determine if that's hard-wired into their brains or just a skill acquired from watching their own mothers as they grew up.&nbsp
column3: Multiple men have commented that their wives are better at handling several things simultaneously but I can attest that there are some learned skills that make the juggling of various tasks at the same time.&nbsp
column4: The more that you handle housework, the more you learn about how to accomplish various tasks while the dishwasher or dryer is running.&nbsp
column5: Most women have also had the opportunity to watch their mothers work with the children and combined with the plethora of additional resources available and are less surprised by the various ways that a child can throw a monkey wrench into the workings of the average day.&nbsp
column6: Men haven't had the benefit of seeing their fathers in this role before and couple this with the lack of resources and many men are far more unprepared than their mates for the task.&nbsp
column7: Likewise, women tend to be far more detail oriented than men and one of the female's standard complaints is that the male just isn't paying attention.

column2: But the flip side is that it's hard to keep track of details when you've got no clue what the details even are.&nbsp
column3: Birthday parties, vaccinations and clothing shopping&nbsp
column4: are generally off of the father's radar but once he's aware, he can also learn to make sure that they're covered.

column1: But apart from the inexperience and unfamiliarity factors, fathers are also capable of taking over the childcare and household responsibilities.
column2: It's liable to be a bumpy ride at first, but men can learn the tips, tricks and routines that go into the daily life of the child.&nbsp
column3: What are the child's sleep and nutritional requirements?&nbsp
column4: Why are they acting as they are and if it's a problem, what can I do about it?&nbsp
column5: These are issues that don't lend themselves to any particular gender and with some experience and attention, fathers should be able to handle them as well.&nbsp

column1: There are some areas of childrearing in which fathers do have an advantage over the women.
column2: The communication skills of children with active fathers is significantly higher than those without an active father.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, kids with active fathers are more self-confident in their dealings with new situations and are more willing to explore than if the father isn't involved or present.&nbsp
column4: It's the men who interact in the world and take the time to model that behavior for their children that really are watching what they do.&nbsp

column1: There's another aspect to fathers in the home that deals less with the child's well-being than the father's.
column2: Perhaps because so many now grow up in fatherless homes that those men who had no active fathers want to take a strong role in the household and childrearing so that their children don't experience what they did.&nbsp
column3: I've had multiple conversations with men over the years and the common thread of these fatherless guys is that they want the kids to not experience their own difficulties.&nbsp
column4: They also want to enjoy their time with the kids, far more than their predecessors did.&nbsp
column5: Solid parent-child relationships are built on more than just weekend trips to the zoo or other activities and it's in the day-to-day life that many lessons are passed along.

column1: But for all intents and purposes, it's become a more academic question than it was one or two decades ago.
column2: The old gender lines are blurring and as they continue, because of economics and choice, it will be less of a concern to the simple question of who's making sure that the kids are cared for and raised.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
363,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Those who have been reading me awhile know that I'm a closet economics geek.
column2: The Chinese aphorism is may you live in interesting times and if they didn't get so damned scary, it would be utterly fascinating.
column3: But the periodic conversation over the past several months has been the game of economic dominoes played first in Greece and most recently in Ireland.&nbsp
column4: Just what is going on in Ireland?&nbsp
column5: What does it mean to my family?

column1: One of the better layman's explanations of the Irish predicament comes from Gonzalo Lira.
column2: I recommend the article in it's relatively brief entirety as it lays out the core of the problems that now face the Irish.&nbsp

column1: But what does it mean for my family?
column2: The gist is that the Irish backed their failing major banks in their entirety without knowing that the banks had blown such gaping holes in their hulls that they saddled the Irish taxpayer with a ghastly debt burden.&nbsp
column3: What it means for my family is the concept of austerity, in which the national economy goes into literal lifesupport as desperately needed capital is transferred from the taxpayer to support the banks.
column4: As the Irish did with their Anglo-Irish Bank, we've thrown life support to the TBTF entities so that the typical American family will carry huge tax burdens to cover the cost of that debt.&nbsp
column5: The result will be higher taxation of the general public and greatly constrained public spending as the debt assumed from the financial system crowds out the debt that would be used for real public expenditures, and that was already too high to begin with.

column1: What is frightening is that it truly is a game of economic dominoes.
column2: If the poorer European Union nations - the infamous PIIGS - are permitted to flounder and collapse the Euro, then the stronger core European banks holding the PIIGS sovereign debt will fold.&nbsp
column3: If these banks fold or collapse in any way, the interconnectedness with the US TBTF institutions will create stunning pressure on the US financial system with the&nbsp
column4: growing prospect of collapse.

column1: I'm actually sorry that the Irish government caved in and took the IMF/European Central Bank rescue proposal since it ostensibly saves the bank bondholders at the expense of the Irish taxpayers for the next generation (that isn't an exaggeration, either).
column2: It's once again the bondholder and corporations - one group relatively few in number and the other legally fictitious - that will prosper at the expense of the mass of the taxpayers.&nbsp
column3:
That's a continuing thread that poses a true threat to my children's future.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
364,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There are milestones in a family's life and one of them in our family has been the shotgun seat - aka the front passenger seat for the uninformed.
column2: With the presence of airbags, kids have had to wait until they were sufficiently old and large enough to withstand the impact of deployment and it was a rite of passage amongst the older ones when they could graduate from the backseat to the shotgun seat.&nbsp
column3: But what do we do when there's a gray area?

column1: Different states have differing guidelines on when a child is legally allowed to ride shotgun with a front airbag.
column2: While the consensus of many is that the child has to be twelve years of age, it does vary.&nbsp
column3: In my instance, our state laws mandate that a child must be at least eight years of age with a minimum height of 4'9&quot
column4: and a weight of 80 lbs.&nbsp
column5: We had previously based our decision with the other two kids on the recommendation of the American Academy of Pediatrics, which suggested that it's simply wiser to wait until the child is twelve years of age so that any question of size and weight is moot by that point.&nbsp
column6: That was fine when the two older kids were well within the size guidelines, but Youngest is the Bell Curve outlier in terms of size and weight.&nbsp
column7: He wears clothing sizes that are typically worn by kids in middle school and is far past the front seat parameters set by state law.&nbsp

column1: When Youngest and I were doing some Christmas shopping on Saturday morning, he asked if he could sit shotgun.
column2: Given his size - and the fact that having a kid sit shotgun happily changes the occupant dynamics - I agreed and he jumped into the front at the next stop, with the understanding that I'd check on the requirements when we got home.&nbsp
column3: While he's well past the state requirements, he doesn't meet the AAP guidelines of being twelve years of age.&nbsp
column4: But the opposition came from his older siblings who protested based upon the premise that they had to wait and it was only fair that he should as well.&nbsp
column5: The logic that he's far bigger at his age than they were doesn't wash with the siblings and I suppose that I can understand why.&nbsp
column6: But as I pointed out to them, it's not a matter that they weren't as mature at that age or that I might love him more - it's the simple reality that he's simply much, much bigger than they were.

column1: For the record, we've decided to follow the AAP guidelines and have him wait until he's older for the shotgun seat.
column2: We've made it clear to all three kids that it's not due to their protest or their apparent - to Youngest, at least - status as most favored children.&nbsp
column3: It's simply the sense that the pediatricians have more thoroughly studied the issue and find it to be more than simply a matter of size.&nbsp
column4:
But I've also warned that the next milestone will soon be upon them - when Youngest physically dominates his elder siblings.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
365,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As kids grow and are able to take on more responsibility, parents frequently turn to chore charts to help keep things on track.
column2: They have multiple advantages. not least of which is helping a frazzled parent keep tabs on what's been done and who's responsible for what
column3:
I can't emphasize enough how chaotic things with multiple children can become.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
366,"1","1",,"xhtml","

My wife and I go particularly out of our way on two items, making sure that the kids feel comfortable enough to have their friends over regularly and also monitoring the electronics.
column2: While they seem different enough, last night was a case where they intersected and we had to decide whether the electronic control would damage the kids' willingness to have friends over.&nbsp
column3: Can we be so controlling that the kids will cease having the friends over?

column1: The situation was a gathering last night after the town's Christmas Tree lighting ceremony, when multiple families and kids descended on a friends home for real hot chocolate and Christmas cookies.
column2: Afterwards, five teenage boys - ages 14 through 18 - and a third grader came back to our house for multiple activities.&nbsp
column3: The youngster was spending the night with Youngest while the boys wanted to watch a movie and eat like locusts.&nbsp
column4: The typical chaos reigned as the group entered, settled in and began to pillage the pantry and refrigerator like Vikings at a nobleman's castle.&nbsp
column5: As we got the younger kids settled, the older ones switched on the television and went to the On-Demand section to peruse and make a selection.&nbsp
column6: When I returned to the kitchen, they had already started The Expendables with Stallone, Willis, Schwarzenegger, etc.
column7: The opening sequence of the film was the shoot-'em-up violence of any PG-13 film and I moved on to other tasks, thinking nothing of it until my wife called my attention to a scene in which someone was being waterboarded, to my wife's horror.&nbsp
column8: One or two questions yielded the information that the film indeed had an R rating, earned for gratuitous violence.&nbsp

column1: We've not only monitored and controlled electronic usage, but we've always been strict with the movie rating system and have on any number of occasions shot down a movie request because of the proposed movie's rating.
column2: My wife left the decision on handling it to me and after a short while to think, I left the movie run but joined the kids so that there was indeed parental supervision.&nbsp
column3: The gist of the thought process was that this kind of movie would be seen by any of the others and the concern that if I were to embarass them, the willingness to bring others into the house would falter.&nbsp
column4: It wasn't a movie that I would've permitted them to attend and the boys did get one over on me.&nbsp
column5: After the movie, I spoke to my kids and told them bluntly that any future movies would have to be cleared with me first or else I would end it at that moment, regardless of the embarasssment.

column1: In retrospect, I wish that I had just ended the film then and there.
column2: While this wasn't a situation that demanded immediate action - like drinking, partying or fighting - I should have made the boys toe the line so that they don't begin to believe that I can be rolled.&nbsp
column3:
The kids will sometimes get one over me but it doesn't mean that I have to accede to the con.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
367,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Are prices - specifically grocery prices that affect the typical family - rising?
column2: Prices for those 46&nbsp
column3: items that comprise the PracticalDad Price Index food basket have been collected for December 2010 and are presented below.&nbsp
column4: There are some comments:

column1: <li>The final cost of the market basket is based upon the average taken for items from three separate and unrelated grocery stores.&nbsp
<li>In the majority of cases, the item size is consistent across all stores.&nbsp
column2: For a very few items however - a box of kitchen trash bags for example - there are three different box sizes and I have recalculated the price to be equivalent to the same size across all three stores.&nbsp
column3: In the case of the trash bags, two stores had their prices recalculated from box sizes of 22 and 20 bags to equivalent costs per box of 26 bags.&nbsp
column4: This methodology was used last month and will used consistently going forward.

column1: <li>The cost of December's basket was $179.79 versus November's basket cost of $178.39 for an increase of $1.40.&nbsp
column2: This is a cumulative monthly price rise of 0.78%, annualized to a rate of 9.42%.

column1: • Using the November basket figures as the baseline of 100, the December results raise the PracticalDad Price Index to 100.78.
• One grocery store provided an example of phantom inflation as the coffee price remained the same ($3.19) but the can size decreased from 13 to 11 oz.
column2: I recalculated the price to an equivalent price at 13 oz, which would reflect a price of $3.77
column3: this was an increased coffee price of 18% at that particular store.

column1: <li>While I expect statistical noise on a monthly basis, I was surprised at the extent of a monthly price rise in two commodity-based items, coffee and aluminum foil.&nbsp
column2: While aluminum foil only rose $.07/75 sq ft roll, this is still an increase of 2.4%, annualized to almost 29%.&nbsp
column3: Both the coffee and the foil are household examples of the effects of excess liquidity sloshing into raw materials and driving up prices for the end consumer.

368,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With kids spending so much time engaged with one form of electronic media or another, I'm honestly concerned about my kids' critical thinking skills.
column2: For me, a large part of critical thinking is determining the difference between what's real and what's&nbsp
column3: crap and from what I observe, much of what's presented in the media today is mostly crap.&nbsp
column4: I want my kids to view things with a skeptical eye, asking themselves whether what they're hearing, viewing and reading makes sense or if it really is nonsense.&nbsp
column5: I want them to question and in light of today's current events - political figures calling for someone's assassination and the confluence between business and government - skepticism and critical thought&nbsp
column6: are&nbsp
column7: essential.

column1: This isn't a new goal since I've made it a lifetime habit of pulling their legs with nonsense so that they can start to learn to determine the difference between truth and fiction.
column2: But the drive is taking on a new impetus as I no longer have any faith in the traditional Main Stream Media (MSM).&nbsp
column3: The good thing is the presence of the internet, which allows a person to dig further.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, the bad thing is the presence of the internet which allows a person to dig further. The key&nbsp
column5: however, is the ability to ascertain&nbsp
column6: whether what's being presented can stand on its own logic or if it requires further examination and debunking.

column1: Unlike other articles, this one has taken further examination and the language used has changed from the original draft.
column2: My initial impetus was to raise kids that willingly question authority, which is radically different coming from a status-quo conservative
column3: both my wife and I were raised in autocratic households and to an extent, ours has been the same.&nbsp
column4: But I know that we have reasons to do things a certain way and it's frankly sometimes a nuisance&nbsp
column5: to raise kids who start in the&nbsp
column6: home and automatically question&nbsp
column7: everything we do.&nbsp
column8: Learn how to ask properly and I'll explain it, perhaps even more than once.&nbsp
column9: It occurred to me however, that the key is to raise kids who will think through things first and ascertain whether something indeed needs to be questioned.

column1: So how do I manage to raise skeptics?
<li>Starting at a young age, pull their legs frequently and then take the opportunity when they bite to examine the information.&nbsp
column2: Can you really milk an alpaca?&nbsp
column3: Let's go find out and verify that.&nbsp
column4: Is Morocco really just to the east of Las Vegas?&nbsp
column5: Pull out the atlas and find Las Vegas, and then look to the east.

column1: <li>Establish some guidelines about the use of electronics and then work to enforce them.&nbsp
column2: Make the kids turn off the screens and spend time in the real world instead of the virtual one.&nbsp
column3: It creates more work for you, but educating the kids is one of a father's primary functions.

column1: <li>Take time to discuss issues with them, even if they're younger.&nbsp
column2: It's certainly a judgment call as to the issues for which they're ready and expect to draw the occasional blank stare, but you'd be surprised to find out how much&nbsp
column3: the kids are taking in and if they're taking things in, it's best that you have a handle on what those things are.

column1: <li>Try the Socratic Method and ask questions to walk them through an issue.&nbsp
column2: My own father was a master at the Socratic Method and more often than not, my questions only raised other questions back to me.&nbsp
column3: It was a tremendous nuisance - does the old man know anything? - but it did help me learn how to frame questions and give me some sense of how to approach an issue.

column1: <li>This goes to the next point, which is to be prepared to spend the time to explore their questions with them.&nbsp
column2: Turn off the damned electronics yourself and spend the moments - hell, hours if necessary - to help them gain a grip on the issue.&nbsp
column3: Again, this cuts into your own time but remember Fatherhood's First Law - your life is no longer your own.

column1: <li>Avoid overly political labels and try to stick to the salient facts at hand.&nbsp
column2: Is Julian Assange a terrorist and Sarah Palin a fascist? Who says so, and why would they say it?&nbsp
column3: What did these people do anyway?&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: What exactly is a fascist in the first place?

column1: <li>Walk with them through the various sources available and critique these sources.&nbsp
column2: I remember learning a dictum in elementary school:&nbsp
column3: the educated person doesn't know everything, but they know where to go for the information.&nbsp
column4: Help&nbsp
column5: your kids learn the various sources available to them.

column1: This is an ongoing work in progress and I don't profess to know the answers.
column2: But these are all items that I try to keep in mind as the kids grow and raise questions and while it sometimes feels as though I'm beating my head against the wall, there are other moments when I can see the lights starting to turn on.&nbsp
column3: Those are moments that I live for.

As busy as people get, we've gone a long way to subcontracting and outsourcing many family functions.
column2: Cleaning house, yardwork, food preparation and even aspects of childrearing - apart from daycare, think Gymboree in lieu of the old-fashioned playgroup - have all been privatized as parents seek ways to keep the kids covered while they either work or, in extreme cases, just don't bother.&nbsp
column3: But there activities that thrive only with the input of volunteers and it's here that fathers can and must step up, especially scouting and sports.

column1: Through our history, almost everything having to do with the children has been the purview of mothers.
column2: But as they're stretched further with work, other areas have to necessarily suffer and some of the obvious areas, like housework and childcare, have seen fathers step up accordingly.&nbsp
column3: But one of the areas that hasn't seen as much is volunteering.&nbsp
column4: Men simply aren't as gifted at multitasking as women, and there's still considerable fear amongst many guys that they aren't as good with the kids as women.&nbsp
column5: Men are obviously becoming more comfortable with their own children but that hasn't always carried over to working with and managing Opies - Other People's Kids.
column6: But the reality is two-fold:

column1: <li>Many worthwhile activities and organizations simply cannot survive without an active volunteer cadre to carry the load
• With as many broken families and absentee fathers, there's a true need for fathers to serve as role models for kids.
The obvious start is to stick with what you know.
column2: What sports did you play when you were younger?&nbsp
column3: What were your activities apart from sports, such as scouting or hunting and camping?&nbsp
column4: These kinds of things in and of themselves give you a leg up as a volunteer with kids.&nbsp
column5: My youngest has taken to baseball and it's fascinating to watch the fathers involved with the teams.&nbsp
column6: While the head coach of his most recent team never played as a kid, he's&nbsp
column7: comfortable with kids and a number of other fathers - all of whom played - stepped in to assist with the position drills and practices.&nbsp
column8: This goes with whether the sports are for boys or girls as the key is to provide a steady, stable and authoritative presence for the kids.

column1: If you don't have any particular sporting experience, you can still step up.
column2: As I mentioned, Youngest's baseball coach had no experience as a kid but stepped in when his child was a beginner and learned over the years with his son.&nbsp
column3: It's likewise been the case with my daughter's soccer teams, many of whom were coached by adults with no real experience.&nbsp
column4: The case of soccer will probably change as time passes as the game becomes&nbsp
column5: more popular and played in this country.&nbsp
column6: Regardless, these are all individuals who started when the kids were little and learned along with them and as is often the case, if you don't announce that you have no experience, the kids will never know the difference.&nbsp
column7: If the adults can tell the difference and complain, then screw 'em - they should be out there doing it instead of grousing about you.

column1: There is one area which makes men uncomfortable - me included - and that pertains to girl scouting.
column2: The only time that I've declined to become involved is when a desperate scout leader asked if I would be willling to lead a Brownie Troop, and my refusal was on grounds that many parents would be uncomfortable with a man working with little girls.&nbsp
column3: This was borne out by subsequent conversations with female friends whose comments confirmed my suspicions.&nbsp
column4: Both Girl Scouting and Boy Scouting are organizations that have taken the concern for predatory behavior to heart, but there's still a cultural bias against men taking such an overt role with girls and the Girl Scouting organization itself has established guidelines that highly curtail the interaction of men and girls, such as on camping trips in which any fathers who might choose to come along have to remain a certain distance from the girls' campsite.

column1: This is another aspect that I believe concerns many men, and that's the worry about whether they'll be perceived as predators or face accusations of predatory behavior.
column2: It's a legitimate concern but one that's easily handled if you exercise some common sense.&nbsp
column3: The Boy Scouts of America require that all leaders take training in their Child Safety Policy and the cornerstone - apart from a mandatory criminal background check - is the practice of the &quot
column4: two deep rule&quot
column5: , where no adult leader can be alone with any youth apart from their child.&nbsp
column6: Any meetings or activities require the presence of at least one other adult at all times and that policy carries through to such simple tasks as picking up a child for a meeting or taking the kid home.&nbsp
column7: On multiple occasions, I've demurred from taking another kid to an event as it would violate the rule and the other parents have learned to work around that.

column2: There's a chronic need and it's not just for volunteers, but fathers to step in and take a role.&nbsp
column3: Like I said, if you don't tell the kids, they'll never know.&nbsp
column4: They'll just be glad that you're there.

Earlier today, a live BBC news feed showed an English student dressed as Santa being arrested.
column2: The arrest arose from the student protest against the UK Parliament's vote to triple the higher education tuition fees to 9000 Pounds annually, an amount that many students cannot afford.&nbsp
column3: The English youth are rioting because they've been taught for decades that the best preparation for a prosperous economic adulthood comes via a college degree, and now their hopes of actually obtaining a degree are moving inversely to their tuition costs.&nbsp
column4: They're not stupid and see the writing on the wall.&nbsp
column5: Precisely what does England make?&nbsp
column6: What do they produce, apart from good soccer teams, BBC America and fearsome hooligans?&nbsp
column7: There will always be a need for good plumbers and craftsman, but not in the scale that would be required to absorb that kind of labor surplus.

column1: This is also a portent of what's to come as more American states raise their in-state tuitions and higher education is effectively removed from a larger and larger segment of our children.

To be honest, I'm inclined to go ahead and riot with them since some of what ails England ails us as well.

371,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Why must I explain such a simple thing to a kid?
column2: He - or she&nbsp
column3: - is no longer a preschooler and some things are simply so self-evident that explanation beggars the imagination.&nbsp
column4: But thanks to the presence of the MRI, which demonstrates how the teen brain is literally rewiring itself during that decade of growth, I can at least convince myself that there's a legitimate reason to have to explain what is abundantly clear to 98.9% of adults.&nbsp
column5: Our parents simply would shake their heads and weep for America.&nbsp
column6: I now have a greater appreciation for Red Forman of That '70s Show.

column1: What are some of the questions that make me want to honestly plant a foot in someone's butt?

column2: Why must I use a topsheet when I put clean sheets on my bed?&nbsp
column3: (I'm really okay without them).&nbsp
column4: So that we only have to wash thin sheets made dirty by your body oils and sweat instead of the comforter/quilt/bedspread that can only be done at the laundromat in the commercial washer.

column2: Why can't I learn to ride a unicycle while riding on a brick retaining wall?&nbsp
column3: <strong>So that you don't really hurt yourself when you fall.&nbsp
column4: But Dad, I won't fall/get hurt on this unicycle.
column5: <strong>And that's why it's called an accident.&nbsp
column6: Now get off of the wall.

column2: Why do you care if I go in my bedroom and draw my name on the hardwood floor with permanent marker/shoot Airsoft pellets at the wall/use the wall for knifethrowing target practice/repeatedly throw myself on my old bed when I'm having a tantrum?&nbsp
column3: <strong>A, because I said so.&nbsp
column4: B, because you'll someday move on and I'll have to fix/repair/paint/clean it to sell this place.&nbsp
column5: C, because I said so.&nbsp
column6: And if you aren't certain, D, because I can remove everything to prove that it's really mine.&nbsp
column7: And did I mention because I said so?

column2: It's this preceding question that elicits a Red Formanesque mutterance.
Why can't my buddy and I stand on opposite sides of the house and shoot arrows over the rooftop at each other?&nbsp
column3: (Silence)

column2: Why can't I ride the skateboard while hanging onto a moving car?&nbsp
column3: Michael J. Fox did it.&nbsp
column4: Yeah, and unfortunately, Michael J Fox now has Parkinson's.

column2: Why can't I play two story bowling with the pins at the bottom of the steps?&nbsp
column3: <strong>Just because, son.&nbsp
column4: Just because.

column1: If it appears that these are mostly male-oriented questions, you're right.
column2: Teenage boys are wildly poor at assessing risk but even the teenage girls are notable in their ability to skewer rationality and common sense.
Hey Dad,&nbsp
column3: Junior managed to handcuff himself to the chair without checking to see if there were handcuff keys.&nbsp
column4: Why can't we tie bows in his hair and put makeup on him?&nbsp
column5: He did it to himself.&nbsp
column6: (Silence)

column1: Many have read the mass email talking about the destructive qualities of small boys and what they can accomplish.
column2: It doesn't go away as they age, but it does change considerably.&nbsp
column3: And for the record, each of these situations that I've referenced has really happened although not necessarily with my own kids.&nbsp
column4: But if the incidents aren't firsthand, they are secondhand - none of them are thirdhand.

charset=utf-8"" http-equiv=""Content-Type"" />

column1: Scrooge started back, appalled. Having them shown to him in this way, he tried to say they were fine children, but the words choked themselves, rather than be parties to a lie of such enormous magnitude.

column2: Spirit! are they yours?&rdquo
column3: Scrooge could say no more.

column2: They are Man&rsquo
column3: s,&rdquo
column4: said the Spirit, looking down upon them. &ldquo
column5: And they cling to me, appealing from their fathers. This boy is Ignorance. This girl is Want. Beware them both, and all of their degree, but most of all beware this boy, for on his brow I see that written which is Doom, unless the writing be erased.&nbsp
column6: -&nbsp
column7: A Christmas Carol, by Charles Dickens

column1: These are frightening economic times and the fact that it's the Christmas season doesn't make it any less so
column2: in some ways, it makes it even worse.&nbsp
column3: This is the time when kids are supposed to get the gifts for which they ask and when they can tell that things aren't good - and they aren't stupid, they know - most parents feel even more pressure to keep Christmas alive for the kids.&nbsp
column4: It hasn't helped that in the past fifty years, Madison Avenue has had a heyday blurring the lines between wants and needs.&nbsp
column5: Many parents will tilt further giving the kids what they want thinking that that's what they need to allay the fear of things spiraling out of control.

column1: But Dickens had it correct as the greatest concern is the ignorance of our children.
column2: Many parents work to satisfy the wants of the child and some are recognizing the economic necessity and shifting to providing for the needs instead. Many families are caught in the economic bind however as some are un- or underemployed while others are working longer hours to just keep up the status quo.
column3: Coming home to a brisk routine of homework/childcare, chores and bedtime leaves many parents perpetually harried and looking for ways to gain a little rest.&nbsp
column4: Understanding that children do create additional time demands and some mayhem, parents let the kids entertain themselves with all manner of electronic devices.
column5: We permit them to anesthetize themselves so that we can in turn be anesthetized from the daily grind of life.&nbsp

column1: So the kids get what they want, but the downside to the barrage of electronics is ignorance.
column2: The kids can multitask, download and interact electronically in ways that even many young parents find unimaginable yet they are profoundly ignorant of the actual world around them.&nbsp
column3: They see YouTube videos of accidents that, while funny, inflict injury and aren't touched or concerned when something happens in front of them.&nbsp
column4: They don't learn the everyday mechanisms and procedures of how the world around them works and often with profound effects. While I don't expect kids to understand the role of a notary public in land records, the ghastly lapses in the Florida and New York foreclosure cases are an adult version of what happens when techno-savants are permitted to monkey with centuries-old systems and policies.
column5: Simply put, kids have no clue of how to function in the daily world because the adults aren't teaching them.

column1: This ignorance - how and why things are the way that they are, how they work and what things really mean - is a profound handicap for a child when he becomes an adult.
column2: The reality is that it can only be remedied through intentional and significant time with the parents and away from a screen.&nbsp
column3: A videogame won't explain why somebody acted in a certain way or why it's important to know to follow rules or even to be able to lose gracefully.&nbsp
column4: It won't explain the difference between a playmate and a friend, literally the difference between someone who'll toss a ball with you and then stab you in the back before the teacher or spread gossip about you.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: A computer screen won't teach the physical skills of how to hold a knife or reinforce the need for consistently good manners at the table.&nbsp
column7: All of these things will only come from the parent who is willing to spend the time necessary to bring the child along in the world.&nbsp

column1: One of a father's greatest - and most important - jobs is to teach.
column2: Yes, the dishes need to be washed and the yard needs to be mowed, but our children need our time and attention even more.&nbsp
column3: Our sons and daughters are our primary responsibility and our greatest gift to them is our time, a phenomenally priceless yet cheap commodity that satisfies both their needs and wants.&nbsp
column4: Take the time to read to them and play with them, incorporate their presence into your activities as much as possible and turn off your own devices when they come to you.&nbsp
column5: You may feel guilty for taking the time to &quot
column6: play&quot
column7: with them, but it's really your job and an activity that can lead to wildly unimaginable opportunities to teach about any number of topics.&nbsp
column8: The dishes will always need to be washed and the grass will continue to grow, but we only have what is really a very brief time to combat the ignorance that might otherwise dog them later.&nbsp
column9: Likewise, they can't learn when they spend their time ensconced in front of a screen so make them turn it off.&nbsp

column1:
They might not realize it yet, but it really is what they want.

Think of the faces of OWS and the Tea Party and you have two seemingly very different groups.
column2: OWS is young, and if you read the more recent media accounts, slovenly and prone to the goofy, odd behavior exemplified by the younger generation.&nbsp
column3: On the other hand, those who identified themselves as Tea Partiers are typically middle-aged or older and notable for their self-control and law-abiding approach.&nbsp
column4: I suspect that if you were to randomly pluck two hundred individuals from each group and ask them to gather in an open area, the OWS group's outline would resemble a pulsing amoeba while the Tea Partiers would assume a shape with defined corners.&nbsp
column5: As different as they are however, these two groups are akin to a coin.&nbsp
column6: Each side of the coin has a different image and label.&nbsp
column7: But each is minted from the same material so that beneath the disparate images&nbsp
column8: facing in seemingly opposite directions, the core substance is the same.&nbsp
column9: In this matter, the substance is composed of disagreement with, and opposition to, a power structure that is now functionally fascist.

column1: Fascist is a term that's been bandied around for decades as protestors proclaim one person or another as a fascist, akin to a
column2: jackbooted thug who's happier with a trudgeon than a pen.&nbsp
column3: But fascism is actually a political structure in which the interests of big business - controlled by a small group of individuals - are allied closely with big government, also controlled by a small coterie of people.&nbsp
column4: Each element provides the other with the wherewithal to prosper and that prosperity generally comes at the expense of the large majority of the society.&nbsp
column5: Any democratic nation is predicated upon the notion that the various elements are able to compromise in such a fashion that the setting exists for the majority to prosper.&nbsp
column6: In the fascist state however, the two minorities are so self-absorbed that they wish only to further themselves and the remainder be damned
column7: in the extreme cases, if it takes a jackbooted thug to cow and subdue the remainder for the benefit of the minority, so be it.&nbsp

column1: America's present power structure is ostensibly democratic, but the interconnectedness of the corporations and government as shown by their actions is functionally fascist.
column2: At the end of his second term, then-President Dwight Eisenhower <a title=""Papers of the Presidents"" href=""http://www.h-net.org/~hst306/documents/indust.html"">warned of the potential dangers of what is referred to as the &quot
column3: military/industrial complex&quot
column4: .
column5: His concern was predicated on the idea that the rewards of power and money would corrupt the political system to the benefit of these two groups alone.&nbsp
column6: We've outsourced much of our manufacturing, but the industrial faction has since been joined by the financiers, who've demonstrated their willingness to spend huge amounts lobbying to curry the favor and votes needed to build their parasitic fiefdoms.&nbsp
column7: The end result is that corporations, benefitting only a few shareholders and senior executives, retain outsized profits&nbsp
column8: while&nbsp
column9: the control of our currency has been effectively turned over to a private entity that enables and defends the foolish, short-term actions of its banking wards.

column1: Here's where the two nascent political groups are both alike and differ.
column2: Each opposes a separate head of this two-headed creature, Orthrus, which exists in a body that cannot prosper and function outside of its present form.
column3: Think of the prototypical Tea-Partier and what comes to mind is a middle-aged middle class causcasian, who is aghast at the out-of-control spending of an intrusive government that exists simply to grow.&nbsp
column4: If the average American reaches some form of political consciousness during their late teens and early twenties, then these folks awoke to Ronald Reagan, who famously stated that <em>government isn't the solution, it's the problem.&nbsp
column5: Reagan's ability to effectively communicate and encapsulate ideas laid the cornerstone of today's Tea Party and fostered their antipathy to Orthrus' governmental head.
column6: OWS is comprised of the Tea-Party's children, who awakened to find that their hopes for a decent, prosperous future had been outsourced by Orthrus' corporate head.&nbsp
column7: They'd bought into the premise that there were jobs available to help pay off the permanent debt that they accepted for the ticket that gave entrance to the middle-class life.&nbsp
column8: Frankly, if I'd hocked my next decade of earnings for a World Series ticket and found myself watching sandlot ball, I'd be upset, too.&nbsp
column9: But don't be fooled by the photos of the group members
column10: in the instances in which I've gone past the OWS encampment in my local city, the graybeards (and graybeardlesses as well) have been present.

column1: Each of these groups has arisen - regardless of who's purportedly funding it - because the citizenry is looking around and finding that Orthrus' foes are either broken or co-opted.
column2: The unions that arose to challenge the industrial order in the early 20th century are broken, a shadow of their former selves.&nbsp
column3: Even the public unions are on the retreat as the populace wonders why they should continue to receive top-tier benefits while they, the taxpayers, take it in the teeth.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, the media that portrays the OWS members as unkempt, lazy kids is principally controlled by a handful of major corporations who are part of the group being protested by OWS.&nbsp
column5: Consider the verbiage coming from FoxNews, controlled by one Rupert Murdoch, whose minions were turned out in England when it was found that they were actually hacking the phones of public figures.&nbsp
column6: Even if this - hopefully - isn't occurring here, do you believe that similar beyond-the-reach attitudes aren't occurring here just because we're across the pond?&nbsp
column7: So why are they separated, despite their similarities?&nbsp
column8: They're separated because the image is manipulated into the classic left/right standoff, when the reality is that it really is an upper/lower conflict in the offing.&nbsp
column9: When you hear the commentary about the youngsters, ask yourself who's talking and more importantly, who's paying the speaker's salary?

column1: While we're functionally fascist, this isn't the first time in our history that we've been in this situation and I'm not certain that the jackboots will march down Main Street and Constitution Avenue.
column2: But the recent passage of the National Defense Authorization Act, which throws open the prospect of the open-ended confinement of American citizens, does show that Orthrus is aware of its enemies and is willing to act to defend itself accordingly.&nbsp
column3: In that case, we'll all be better off if we're not isolated in our own small encampments wishing the plague upon one another.

373,"1","1",,"xhtml","

My wife considers me the family prairie dog, spending his time out of the hole and persistently sniffing the air and surveying the horizon.
column2: I spend time surveying the on-going slo-mo changes in our economy and try to adjust accordingly depending on what I suspect might happen, and so far, I've been right more often than not.&nbsp
column3: That said, I took my drubbing on a Double-Short Treasury ETF (TBT) manfully and resolved to never again walk in that segment of town.&nbsp
column4: Otherwise, I keep my eye on what's happening and despite that, there are still moments when I really don't know what to answer when my wife looks at me and asks so what does all of this mean for our family?

column1: That's a damned fine question and I honestly wish that I had a clear answer.
column2: But I will - finally - lay out when I anticipate might happen and what I'm doing otherwise but don't worry, I'm not going to shill for weapons/ammo/clean water filters and GoldLine.&nbsp
column3: I work hard to not wear a tin-foil hat and refuse to put one on now.&nbsp
column4: Let me start by saying that I try to look at events beyond the 24 hour CNN newscycle and in the context of a longer timeframe.<em><strong>&nbsp
column5: Americans have notoriously short attention spans, made shorter by the CNN newscycle.
column6: Unlike here, there are countries well versed in their past and so much so that they still hold grudges, such as the Serbians who took apart Sarajevo in the early 1990s.&nbsp
column7: If you have to remember who the Serbians are and what happened in Sarajevo during the early 1990s, then you need to start thinking beyond the newscycle span.&nbsp
column8: My second reference frame is the idea that life and systems are entropic.&nbsp
column10: My kids aren't completely the same as they were six years ago nor am I completely the same man that I was 30 years ago.&nbsp
column11: This holds true as well for systems of governance and currency as new pressures and dynamics alter or overwhelm the existing structure.&nbsp

column1: I couple these two points because there's no reason in the world that we are so special as to not be alive during a time of major societal or economic change.
column2: When the Soviet Union fell in 1990, some yahoo wrote a book entitled <em>The End of History.&nbsp
column3: Even then, I found it offensive as it presupposed that now that capitalism had vanquished communism, there were no other conflicts in the offing and we could trot merrily on our way into an Ayn Rand Utopia.
column4: So long as there are teenage boys and a video recorder, there is potential for something spectacular to occur.&nbsp
column5: If it involves a skateboard, a roof and a firepot, it could even be historic.

column2: The end of the dollar as the reserve currency.&nbsp
column3: On the one hand, there are as many currencies out there as countries and none of them are the reserve currency, so how bad can that be, right?
column4: Technically, that's correct and there's some long-term good that could come out of it but the problem will be the short and intermediate before the long-term.&nbsp
column5: Resets can be a bitch.

column1: Listen to an auctioneer at the outset of the bidding for any piece just being offered and you'll hear him asking to start the bidding at a specific point.
column2: If there are no bids at that suggested price, then he'll continually drop the opening bid to a point at which someone finally thinks there's value.&nbsp
column3: Substitute the dollar for the item being auctioned and it's the same. Our fiat currency is accepted primarily because the world believes that the full faith and credit of the US Government stands behind the buck.
column4: But with our 2010 end of year debt at about $14 trillion, and more on the way, the world seriously doubts that the debts can be repaid.
column5: Likewise, the Federal Reserve system is happy to trade cash for various forms of US treasury notes, effectively monetizing the debt - which is econobabble for printing money.

column1: At some point in the future, the rest of the world will move from the dollar to something else and the rest of the world includes the oil producers who sell us more than half of our oil supply. The rest of the world will shift out of dollars into something else, so the dollar is less valuable and worth less, and they'll want paid in something else besides dollars.
column2: If the dollar is then worth less compared to everything else, then it will take more dollars to buy oil and that will ripple through the system creating inflation as it goes.

A nation with both political and economic power concentrated amongst a small minority, aka an oligarchy. When even USA Today writes openly about the size of the income gap between poor and wealthy Americans, then it's now both mainstream and noticeable.
column3: There's always been a gap in the US, but it's reaching a point that's honestly frightening as the nation sets records for food stamp participation - 43 million and rising.&nbsp
column4: Couple this with the frustrated efforts to control the money flowing into the coffers of our elected politicians and the cards are increasingly stacked against the growing majority of our children.

column2: A system of higher education that is increasingly affordable only if the student and family incur significant debt, some of which simply can't be repaid in today's economic environment.&nbsp
column3: When a young person comes out of college with tens of thousands of dollars in debt, that's money that they can't spend on setting up their own lives and families.
column4: They defer decisions that are ultimately important to our greater society, such as becoming full-fledged adults capable of supporting themselves and starting their own families. Unless and until this country gets back to producing what the rest of the world wants and needs, then the employment will continue to be largely service/government oriented which is akin simply to rearranging the deckchairs on the Titanic.

column1: So what does that mean for me and my family?
<li>We've planned and saved for a large trip in 2011 and we'll continue to do so.&nbsp
column2: That said, the other spending will be ratcheted downwards and multiple requests for different things have been shot down peremptorily with the word Europe.

column1: • Starting on January 1, restaurant meals will be finished.
• We'll continue to speak purposefully about spending as well as the appropriate use of credit.
• Grades will continue to be pushed and as the kids age, we'll overtly talk about scholarships and other forms of low-cost higher ed alternatives.

• As Eldest toys with a hard science versus a soft science college, we'll make sure that she's aware of the advantages of a hard science (think biology) over a soft science (think psychology) in the workplace.
<li>Political conversations have already taken on a harder tone with a harder edge.&nbsp
column2: There is clearly a system in place that immediately places young people at a disadvantage at a time when they are financially disadvantaged enough already and to ignore it's existence is simply foolish.&nbsp
column3: For example, when Senator Bernie Sanders (I - VT) gave his eight hour filibuster last week, I made certain that the two kids at home heard at least a few minutes of it and what it meant.&nbsp
column4: Simply put, we're passing the point at which it's best to appear balanced and are better suited now to clear political advocacy.

column1: <li>I'll contine to spend time explaining the &quot
column2: real world&quot
column3: examples in finance and economics.&nbsp
column4: It's been surprising to understand that despite the rolled eyes, they really are listening to what's being said.

column1: What's happening and what's coming are not single events but rather whole changes in the way that we handle our economic lives.
column2: It's necessary for me to set aside the desire to protect them and educate them instead.
