column1:
374,"1","1",,"xhtml","

I was pleased to find out today that a young friend is now officially a father for the first time.
column2: I've known that it was coming and had the mother's present ready but didn't really know what to give the new father.&nbsp
column3: What is a good gift for a new father?

column1: Depending upon their circumstances, new parents can find themselves utterly awash in goods and items.
column2: There will be showers and various other gifting opportunities and a young couple can really stock up, but these are generally items for the family situation - blankets, towels, devices, supplies.&nbsp
column3: Women will always be able to figure out something that's for the new mother since many of them have either been through the pain of childbirth or have actually paid attention when their friends went through it.&nbsp
column4: But what do you get for a guy?&nbsp

column1: Many products for guys are recreation oriented and while that's nice, the reality is that such gifts help to draw the guy's attention out of the household and away from the family.
column2: Golf clubs?&nbsp
column3: They're a great gift but that guarantees several hours at a time away from the home and family.&nbsp
column4: Tools?&nbsp
column5: Better, since they can serve a purpose that at least keeps the guy around the house.&nbsp
column6: But some men just aren't all that handy or into tools for the sake of tools.&nbsp
column7: Except Bill, but he's an exception.&nbsp
column8: Today's reality is that women are stretched between work and home and the kids desperately need love and attention more than anything so gifts that pull a father's focus from the household is actually counterproductive.&nbsp
column9: At the same time, men simply don't have the same sensibilities as women and would look askance at the great majority of items that might please the mother.

column1: As I ran errands the other weekend, the choice occurred to me as I passed a Tobaccionist's shop and I stopped and purchased both a Cohiba and an Arturo Fuente for the new father.
column2: While I only occasionally smoke a cigar, it is true that a really good cigar is a different taste and experience
column3: as the old saying goes a woman is a woman, but a good cigar is a smoke.
column4: But I've had to wonder, what it is about cigars that has made them a time-tested fatherhood gift?&nbsp
column5: Some psychologist somewhere might make a comment about phalluses and fatherhood but I do think that it's different than that.&nbsp
column6: Smoking a cigar is truly an aqcuired taste and one that requires a certain amount of practice and time to truly appreciate.&nbsp
column7: It's a truism that in previous times, fathers who wanted to break their kids of smoking would start them on a cigar. Certainly there are women who appreciate a good cigar but I simply think that a cigar is best appreciated by men and giving such an item is a nod to a guy's finally taking that final step to the fullest aspect of manhood, being a father.

column1: Come to think of it, perhaps I'll send the Fuente and smoke the Cohiba myself.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
375,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Like Jethro Gibbs, I believe that there are certain rules that one needs to follow to make it through life and that includes fatherhood.
column2: One of the first articles that I wrote pertained to PracticalDad's First Rule of Fatherhood and given some situations I've encountered in the past several weeks, I'd like to revisit that rule again.
column3: <em>Until your child is grown, your life is no longer your own.&nbsp
column4: Now repeat that three times and please do so loud enough for everyone else to hear.

column2: really do civilize men and perhaps the final part of the civilizing process is getting men to stand and be responsible for their families.&nbsp
column3: This bundle presently sleeping/suckling/resting in your arms is now wholly and fully your responsibility and will be so until they are old enough to make their own way in the world.&nbsp
column4: That phrase - make their own way in the world - is incredibly vague and there really aren't any hard and fast rules as circumstances and offspring abilities vary from one family to another.
column5: But there are some things that don't vary.&nbsp
column6: Your child needs and desperately wants your support as they grow - in school, in sports, in activities, in whatever is happening.&nbsp
column7: There are moments when you might not be able to make an event and kids are both smart and forgiving enough to deal with that.&nbsp
column8: But if your child is going to really thrive and prosper, then she needs to know that Dad is fully behind her in her efforts.&nbsp
column9: For the purposes of what I've been witnessing, it's not just Dads but Moms who are also screwing the pooch on this rule.

column2: Do I have to become a soccer dad or someone who only finds fulfillment living vicariously through my child?&nbsp
column3: No, but it does mean that you have specific basic responsibilities such as providing food and shelter, and assuring that the child is educated.&nbsp
column4: Those are simply the bare-bones rudiments as kids, in order to really flourish and grow, require constant interaction. The more that they're around you and really interacting with you, the more that they'll start to blossom.&nbsp
column5: With work and any other responsibilities that you have, you will wonder when you get time to yourself and there's nothing wrong with a little &quot
column6: you&quot
column7: time, but that time is - and has to be - drastically scaled back from when you were single or didn't yet have children.

column1: The reason for reviewing this first rule of fatherhood - even parenthood, actually - is because of multiple situations that I've seen in which the kids are being simply ignored.
column2: Some parents are thinking that since the kids are now teens, they ought to be able to fend for themselves as the folks head out.&nbsp
column3: My wife recently forwarded me an email with a Facebook posting for a teen whose parents were taking a January cruise and had told the teen to find herself a place to live for the week that they'd be gone.&nbsp
column4: Staying at home was out of the question since the house was heated by woodstove and they didn't trust her to not set an accidental fire, yet they were perfectly happy to let the kid find herself a place to stay. So let me get this straight:&nbsp
column5: you haven't taught the teen the rudiments of how to keep the house warm with a wood stove and don't trust her to not set the house ablaze but you're alright with leaving for a week and telling the teen to find another place to live for that week.

column1: Another teen has no parental support and attendance for something like National Honor Society Inductions and Regional Science Competitions.
column2: There's a recent razor commercial in which boys look into the stands and audiences full of people and the only person that they note is Dad
column3: these kids want their fathers - and mothers - there and they want them there desperately.&nbsp
column4: If you're going to have a kid, bloody well make sure that you understand that your evenings and weekends are going to be spent on the basics with the kids, even if there are no sports or activities.&nbsp

column1: The responsibility continues even as they age.
column2: Teens are not adults despite their quaint notion that they are and leaving them without any supervision is simply asking for a disaster.&nbsp
column3: It's at this point that a father has to pick and choose the battles and stand the ground against the some of the utterly insane ideas that these cranially challenged teens have.&nbsp
column4: There are days that I live in a state of perpetual annoyance and there are moments when I'll decide that the kid has to learn a lesson the hard way.&nbsp
column5: But there are also days that I have to bear down and stick to the rules despite the commentary, arguments and actions of the teens.&nbsp
column6: I don't look forward to it but that's simply part of my job and whether they're too damned dumb to realize it or not, my contrariness really is about them and not my desire to force someone to stick to rules for the rules' sake.

column1:
Fatherhood - parenthood - is the endurance race and to make it, you have to look to the goal ahead and ignore the various complaints that you have because it's not about you.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

376,"1","1",,"xhtml","

...Yes, but they're holding off on price increases until they see whether and how the economy's improving.
column2: This little tidbit, along with information gleaned from other restaurant executives, is presented in an article on Agweb, a commodities business site.

column1: The question of whether the economy is suffering from inflation or deflation - or even what I refer to as hyperstagdisindeflation - has been the debate for months and it's only now that further information is becoming available to clarify the picture.
column2: The gist of the article is that restaurant chains have been seeing commodity price increases but have been successful thus far in mitigating the rises via contract lock-ins, addition of new producers and old-fashioned sucking up the prices and taking the bottom line hit.&nbsp
column3: However, they're watching the economy's general performance to ascertain when things are sufficiently recovered to pass along the prices to the consumer.&nbsp
column4: When the consensus is that recovery has taken hold, then expect to see price increases as the restauranteurs move to recapture some of the profit margin that they might have given up.&nbsp
column5: If the economy, which they're measuring by the unemployment rate, doesn't improve then they'll have to hold off as long as possible before finally giving in to meal price increases.

column1: As my wife asks, what does this mean for my family?
As I've occasionally told her, choose your poison.
column2: Our stated unemployment rate (U-3) is now at 9.8% and the more realistic U-6 rate is above 17% and the average family income continues to decline so there's no leeway in free disposable income.&nbsp
column3: People will continue to cut back on restaurants and there will come a time when the average restauranteur is faced with no choice but to raise prices or fold.&nbsp
column4: So we can keep bumping along with no real employment/wage improvement and keep the prices level or we can watch jobs grow and the prices rise at a rate likely higher than the wages.&nbsp

column1: What this means for this particular family is that despite the chaotic schedules, my plan is to almost completely eliminate restaurant dining in 2011 in favor of fully home cooked food.
column2: We reached the point at which it was easier to grab a quick restaurant meal for sake of the schedule but the drive to cutback spending will simply require that the family and I adapt our palates and expectations accordingly.&nbsp
column3: I'll still see price rises in the grocery store but will still be able to manage it better than just throwing money down a restaurant's hole.

column1:
While McDonald's sounds respectable for keeping things under control, the time will come when they choose the profit margin over the typical American family.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

377,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There are definitive differences in how fathers and mothers relate to children's moods and response to new situations.
column2: Because they have no wealth of experience with which to compare how things are versus how they could be, children can be cranky and unpleasant when confronted with new situations, sensations or circumstances that they don't like.&nbsp
column3: From my experiences watching mothers, many will attempt to reason with the child or explain things, or get the child to verbalize what it is that they're feeling and that is, all in all, a worthwhile approach.

column1: This isn't usually the case with fathers since men are generally neither as verbal nor patient as women.
column2: While some men can chat happily about a multitude of topics, get us onto issues of emotion and feelings and we're about as communicative as a mute with a lisp.
column3: Even if we can verbalize what's on our minds, we're too impatient with children who will meander through any number of issues before finally - maybe - stumbling onto the item that's really bothering them.&nbsp
column4: Get to the point, get to the point, get to the point...

column1: I admire mothers who are willing to expend the time necessary in these situations.
column2: But there is also real value to the male approach of getting to the point and helping the child learn how to simply deal with it and move on.&nbsp

column1: This Christmas holiday was a case in point.
column2: We took the kids to New York City by train to sightsee, take in a Broadway show and experience firsthand a certifiable city-closing blizzard.&nbsp
column3: The practical upshot was that there was absolutely no opportunity for the kids to whine about taking a cab and we were able to happily walk all over Midtown Manhattan.&nbsp
column4: The amount of snow and slush was deep enough in spots to overflow the tops of the snow boots that the kids wore and feet and socks got wet as we trudged up West 49th.&nbsp
column5: Youngest did get wet feet and as he complained about his feet, we noted that Saks Fifth Avenue was nearby.&nbsp
column6: The thing about whining children is that they really are the gift that keeps on giving, continuing and cycling even when the original cause has been rectified.&nbsp
column7: Since it hadn't occurred to me to actually put a spare pair of dry socks in my coat pocket, my wife and I agreed that getting a dry pair of socks was reasonable.&nbsp
column8: The fact that it was Saks Fifth Avenue made it - in the eyes of my wife and daughter - a certifiable slam dunk, can't miss two-fer.&nbsp
column9: Unfortunately, this was meaningless to Youngest, who's a male and looks at department store shopping with the same sense as awaiting a root canal.&nbsp
column10: Even when we explained why we were going in, his attitude darkened further and the whining ratcheted upwards.

column1: We exited at the sixth floor - Youngest's feet are big enough that he was in men's shoes before he could spell men - and wandered back to the sock area.
column2: We found a pair of cotton athletic socks and I took it to a cashier in a different department since our local salespeople were contending with millionaires pondering their AARP discounts.&nbsp
column3: Honestly, if you're able to afford a handmade pair of English wingtips, you're embarrassing yourself to wonder aloud whether you could get a discount on it.&nbsp
column4: The salesman was a dapper, distinguished looking African American gentleman who wore his gray hair far better than I wear mine.&nbsp
column5: His eyebrow cocked slightly at my single pair of socks and when I told him to forget the bag, I explained it's immediate use for a little boy with wet feet.&nbsp
column6: We talked for a brief period and when I stated that Youngest would simply have to wear them and get on with it, he nodded and broke into a wide grin, exclaiming <em>that's what Dads are for. &nbsp

column1: When I returned to our area, Youngest was still surly and my wife was still trying to get him to explain what it was that was bothering him.
column2: The entire time that I was away, my wife had attempted to talk him through which was admirable but useless.&nbsp
column3: I knelt next to him and my thoroughly annoyed point to him was that he now had two options.&nbsp
column4: The first was to put the dry socks on his feet and we'd continue on to see our sights and have a wonderful afternoon.&nbsp
column5: The other option was to leave the wet socks on and continue on to see our sights since I refused to return eight blocks to the hotel for a dry pair of socks.&nbsp
column6: Since we were here purely to help him, he'd have to accept the help or have to deal with the discomfort and complete lack of sympathy from his father.&nbsp

column2: Take the dry socks or suck it up and deal with it - and I'll have no sympathy.

column1: Youngest accepted the first option and donned the dry socks as I deposited the wet ones in my coat pocket (he wore them the next day when his socks got wet again).
column2: He wasn't happy with the options but the stark presentation broke the cycle since he was now able to focus his anger on me instead of on the discomfort.&nbsp
column3: The attention turned from an internalized unhappiness to something that existed beyond himself and when he worked through it in several minutes, his original complaint was rectified and then forgotten.&nbsp

column1: It's easier to learn to deal with it - whatever it is - when you're older because with age generally comes an awareness of others as well as a sense of proportion.
column2: But it's also better learned when you recognize that it's not going to be neither tolerated nor encouraged.&nbsp
column3: So my wife and I will continue the ongoing balancing act as we attempt to help the kids learn to verbalize their thoughts and feelings while still learning how to deal with things so that they don't take over completely.

column1:
And if you're ever in the position of buying a pair of $1200 handmade English wingtips, just buy the damned things and stop kvetching.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

378,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of a father's biggest jobs is to teach his kids.
column2: Teaching situations are presented almost everywhere if you learn to look for them but some of the best teaching opportunities occur when you're traveling with the family.&nbsp
column3: During a Christmas trip to New York City, the opportunities abounded.

column1: • Many restaurants post their menus outside for potential customers to review the meals and costs.
• If you enter a restaurant and the staff presents a limited menu verbally without benefit of presenting a printed menu, prepare for an expensive meal.
• If there's even hint of snow, take snow or hiking boots as well as hat and gloves.
• Who was Raoul Wallenberg and why is his name on a sign near the United Nations?
<li>What are appropriate tips for wait staff, doormen and hotel maids?&nbsp
• Is it ever appropriate to stiff the staff?
• How can I tell which direction is south in the afternoon?
• How are $1200 English handmade wingtips different from Payless wingtips?
• How do you protect your wallet, whether it's in your pants or in your purse.
• How do you say no to someone hustling you on the street.
<li>If you need to ask how much something costs, you probably shouldn't&nbsp
column2: buy it.

column1: • Shoes by Prada are something you shouldn't even ask about in terms of price.
• If a store is having a 70% off sale, how much was the mark-up prior to the mark-down?
• Which fork is used for an appetizer or salad and what's the purpose of the spoon above my plate?
• Placing the used utensils on the plate at the four o'clock position is a signal that you're done with your plate.
• The hotel and wait staff do remember customers based upon how they're treated.
• How to handle the tickets and seating on the train.
• Why trains really are superior to airplanes when the option is available.
• Is there any real value in the number of security/surveillance cameras on street corners?
• How to handle sore feet and muscles.
• The use of pockets in carrying additional gloves and knit hats.
The education is both verbal and non-verbal and occurs even when you don't realize it.
column2:
Whether you realize it or not, they're watching and they're learning from almost everything that you do.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
379,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Over the Christmas holiday, we took the kids to New York City for a Broadway weekend.
column2: While my wife and Eldest took Youngest to see Lion King, I accompanied Middle to Green Day's American Idiot to satisfy his growing taste in punk rock.
column3: It was surprising to see more than a few families there but what truly took me back was that I actually enjoyed the show, so much so that I stood for the ovation before my son did.&nbsp
column4: The jury is now out on whether the boy will continue listening to punk, but that's another article for another time.

column1: What also took me aback was the implicit social commentary about the state of the times - and the family - for today's young adults.
column2: Each of us views events through a prism shaped and framed by our own set of values and mine is clearly shaped by my concerns about the electronic media and role as a father.

column1: While trying to not give anything away, the show's onset and continuing theme is framed by a constant barrage of electronic imagery with a grim message of crisis and war.
column2: The young viewers watch it but you can't tell with the lights dim whether they're intent or simply slackjawed and it's shortly afterwards that the show breaks open with the cover song, American Idiot.
column3: Much of the imagery additionally is in stark design and contrast and beats a rapid tattoo of crisis and impending war engineered by then President Bush and Vice-President Cheney.&nbsp
column4: The older adolescents - remember that according to prevailing medical experts, adolescence gives way to adulthood much later than 21 - are functionally mesmerized by the swift panoply of imagery.
column5: In real life, our teens and youngsters are watching more than 50 hours weekly on various screens and there is typically a constant shifting from one image to another so that there is far less linear thinking than there was when viewing was less.
column6: Literally, before a person can even begin to critically examine something presented, they're jerked onto something else and then onto something entirely different afterwards.&nbsp

column1: When you talk to people, some have few memories of their childhood experiences and when you talk to others, their memories tend to be more scattered, like three dimensional photos that have been pinned to a board for the mind to see.
column2: What pulls these memory photos into some coherency are the thread lines that are placed between them, making each relatable in some fashion to the others.&nbsp
column3: It's these lines providing the context and coherency that help pull the masses of images and experiences into something that makes fuller sense to the person.&nbsp
column4: As children age however, it becomes apparent that few, if any, are capable of placing that thread in a manner that permits them to make sense of what's happening around them.&nbsp
column5: So if there's going to be some understanding, then it's left to someone else to string the thread benefitting the youngster.&nbsp
column6: What struck me as I viewed the entire backdrop of the show was the sense that through all of the variety of images witnessed by these generations - far wider than I ever had as a youth - there's no one really helping them string the threads that bring coherence, leaving them with a giant mess in terms of understanding.&nbsp
column7: It becomes the blind being led by the blind, or those with their own agenda.

column1: At moments in the show, the main character writes home to his mother and derogatorily mentions his stepfather, who has belittled and derided him.
column2: There is only a single mention of his father and that is in a phrase coupled with God
column3: while I seriously doubt that he maintains his real father in a god-like position, the point is clear that in the moment that he views God with the same sense that he'd view his own father, as someone who was far away but with whom he'd want a relationship.&nbsp
column4: It's a hope in moments of distress that he's there and willing to listen to what you need to get off of your chest.

column1: How do I pull of this together into a coherent whole?
column2: It isn't just a diatribe against an apathy that permits an entire generation to electronically anesthetize itself while its parents seek their own relief and release.&nbsp
column3: The kids can be off of the machinery but if someone doesn't make a conscious and deliberate effort to take them in hand - literally or figuratively - then they'll still be badly uninformed and ill-prepared for the world around them.&nbsp
column4: It will require an investment of time, but the good part is that it isn't time spent within a classroom or structured environment
column5: it can be within the car, below the basketball net or simply walking the dog.&nbsp
column6: The point is to avail yourself and simply start talking and in the course of conversations, they'll begin to string the thread that helps connect and bring meaning to the mental pictures posted inside their heads.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
380,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of our mantras since the kids were very small is that all good things flow from schoolwork.
column2: The school assigns a certain amount of work and our expectation is that it will be completed both correctly and in a timely fashion.&nbsp
column3: Well, it at least has to be done - and also turned in, by the way - by the appropriate deadlines
column4: there does come a point at which the kid has to take his lumps for work that's not right so as the kids have advanced, I've curtailed parsing every math answer and compound sentence.&nbsp
column5: But when they're dealing with new subject areas or don't understand something and come to me, where's the line between helping and doing?

column1: I've come to find the difference in:
<li>Is the child still sitting next to me
• Are there electronics nearby to distract the kid?
So long as these four aspects indicate that the kid is involved in the process, then I'll spend as much time as necessary to help get the point across.
column2: In the case of math, I've even gone so far as to create additional problem sets and even a mock test.&nbsp
column3: But if I find that the kid is no longer invested in the process, then I'll shut it down.&nbsp
column4: Surprisingly, when the kids - at least here - realize that PracticalDad's done and now leaving them to their own fates, they become much more willing to invest themselves in the process.&nbsp
column5: It has led to some additional angst as we come to terms with the situation and there have been both times when I've gone back as well as other occasions when I've left in frustrated disgust.

column1: Part of the homework process, if I think that I'm being abused, is a clear and repeated warning that if there isn't immediate change then they're left on their own.
column2: It can lead to significant efforts at manipulation but this back-and-forth between recalcitrant kids and insistent parents is - I believe - a power play on the part of the kids to see just how much they can push the limit and whether they can manuever to their advantage.&nbsp
column3: Despite this though, the kids really do want to know that you're involved and both interested and invested in their work.

column1: The kids ultimately have to learn however, that if you'll walk away because they're sloughing off on you, then they really will be left on their own.
column2: And for a kid, this is a scary place to be.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
381,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As the family grows and ages, the desire by kids to play with Dad diminishes as they develop their own circle of friends and immerse themselves with their own activities.
column2: As my own father used to say, that's as it should be, and I respect that.
column3: But even as they age, they still want to find ways to play even if they reach a place where it's not always&nbsp
column4: cool to&nbsp
column5: ask.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: While they're becoming adults, they are still, in many ways, kids and they want to play.&nbsp
column8: Frankly, there are times when I want to&nbsp

column2: there are instances where&nbsp
column3: I completely miss the signs and I've had to learn&nbsp
column4: to look for them.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: Sometimes it'll be an overt&nbsp
column7: hey, do you wanna...? but it's sometimes the unspoken actions.
column8: A kid comes in and starts physically picking and messing is an obvious note that she's ready to play.&nbsp
column9: A less obvious indicator is the older child who haunts you in your activities, hanging nearby but not actually saying that he wants to play.&nbsp
column10: There have been moments when I've actually shifted rooms to see if the youthful spectre flits behind and if so, then it's an unspoken invitation to play.&nbsp
column11: The haunt won't actually voice his wish but the intent will become clear and it's up to me to put the ball into play.&nbsp
column12: I regret that there have been times when I've been aware of the wish and I haven't taken the opportunity to mess around.

column1: The nature of the play might change with the season or with age, but the desire is still there as the kids come back from their forays in the world to touch base and reconnect with the folks.
column2: Be aware and take advantage of it since those days will come fewer and farther between.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
382,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of my cardinal rules of fatherhood - and one of the hardest to maintain - is to keep my mouth shut when I'm irritated with my mate.
column2: Raising kids can be difficult enough and when the parents are upset with one another, it's easy to spout off about the other parent in front of the kids.&nbsp
column3: The problem with doing this is that it eventually creates an atmosphere in which the child becomes a co-conspirator with the mouthy parent and places the kid in a position in which no child should find herself.&nbsp
column4: The out-of-favor parent subsequently has greater difficulty maintaining control and it's not beyond some kids to practice a divide-and-conquer strategy which can truly damage, if not destroy a marriage.&nbsp
column5: For the most part, I've been successful in following this with a very few exceptions.

column1: But with kids growing and each child fully capable of creating unrest and irritation without assistance, I'm finding that I have to learn to apply the same rule when I'm frustrated with their siblings.
column2: Dealing with small children is akin to a real-life version of Laura Numeroff's <a href=""http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_i_0_38?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&amp
column3: field-keywords=if+you+give+a+mouse+a+cookie+paperback&amp
column4: sprefix=if+you+give+a+mouse+a+cookie+paperback"" title=""If You Give A Mouse A Cookie"">If You Give A Mouse A Cookie and while the physical aspect does ease as they age, the degree of confusion can actually increase as they constantly change plans or act without thinking.
column5: The frustration can worsen for a parent who's trying to keep tabs on things.&nbsp
column6: And because they're now more in the world and out of your sight than when they were young, the capacity for trouble increases significantly.&nbsp
column7: While I can repeat to myself that they're clearly not thinking because their brains are literally being rewired, the frustration can become severe
column8: so severe that I find myself making comments in the presence of one or more of the other kids.&nbsp

column1: Comments like calling a kid knucklehead are acceptable in the moment, but I've found myself complaining about the kid in question - and there are multiple kids in question - to one or two of the other kids.
column2: It might be one thing to actually sit down with one of the kids and ask them, provided they're old enough to have such a conversation, what he or she is seeing or hearing, but spouting off spontaneously in frustration.&nbsp
column3: Again, I'll have to work on adapting the Honor the other parent principle because of the potential problems that can arise if I don't.
column4: Continuing to vent in front of the kids creates a difficult dynamic as it raises the child to the level of the parent, a role for which he is patently unprepared.&nbsp
column5: Further, it creates an unhealthy situation in which one child is clearly on the out against the other parent and child.&nbsp
column6: Finally, it can lead to a sense on the part of the issues child that she is now clearly out of favor with the parent compared with the other children.

column1: Kids are difficult and I shouldn't make it more difficult by shooting myself in my own foot with my own mouth.
Honor the other parent, honor the other child.
column2:
Otherwise, shut up.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
383,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The trips to the stores are done and the data is crunched, and the results of the January 2011 PracticalDad Price Index show that the index of the market basket in January dropped from 100.78 to 100.55.
column2: For all of the talk about the threat of inflation, the index is down for the month so inflation must be a bogeyman...or not.&nbsp
column3: Let's take a look at the results in some detail after one or two comments.&nbsp
column4: First, data doesn't present itself in a steadily increasing or decreasing line from one month to the next.&nbsp
column5: On a monthly basis, numbers can bounce, chop and veer like a senator on a bender and it's on a rolling, averaged basis that trends become more clear.&nbsp
column6: Second, gathering prices can be complicated by a store's decision on various products, such as whether to swap out one product for another and this is something that I encountered during the price surveys.&nbsp
column7: In two instances, the absence of a product from the shelves caused me to simply not price the item at that particular store.

column1: And now for some comments and the results.

<li>Multiple items rose in price - especially in commodity based categories such as rice and grains - but these were offset principally by the drop in cost of a single item, specifically a pound of cooked ham lunchmeat.&nbsp
column2: In this instance, the danger of a small market basket priced at three stores showed as one store apparently swapped out a product with a much lower cost competitor so that the monthly average for that item skewed downwards.

column1: <li>Cereals - store brand kids' frosted flakes, oatmeal and store brand rice chex - all rose in price with the frosted flakes rising almost 15% in a three month period.&nbsp
column2: Likewise, a pound of spaghetti rose from an average of $1.11/lb to $1.18/lb.

column1: • Canned vegetables showed a slight rise from $.89/can to $.92/can and this is attributable to a single store with significant price rises in these items while the other stores held constant.
<li>Store brand vanilla ice cream has shown a consistent rise in three months from November's $1.85/qt to January's $2.04/qt.&nbsp
column2: What's interesting in this case is that one store that held the item price constant did however, change the unit cost from a quart basis to a pint basis, setting up a possible future run-up in price.&nbsp

column1: • Other prices remained flat or bounced around a bit and in another article, I'll start with a three-month rolling average for the prices within the marketbasket.

column2: Russet (lb)

column1: This will be followed shortly by another article laying out the first information on a three month rolling average basis.
column2:
I regret the delay in posting this information and expect that this delay will not be occurring again.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
384,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There's a new economic reality on the horizon and the old ways of spending and consumption are simply going to have to change.
column2: How do I prepare my kids for this new economic world when the message put out by the media continues to be one of consumption and spending?&nbsp
column3: The overarching concept is that if you have to spend, do so by concentrating on value so that you truly get the most bang for the dollar.&nbsp
column4: But how do I achieve that?

column1: First, understand that some of the most effective lessons aren't taught in a sit-down session around a table.
column2: The kids really are watching and taking things in - I was surprised several months ago to find that Middle mastered a particularly effective mimicry of one of my foibles - and to wait for the opportunity to handle things like a classroom is to lose opportunity.&nbsp
column3: Because I believe that basic financial education is crucial for young people, it is something that I'm usually aware of as I spend time with the kids.&nbsp
column4: The opportunities are plentiful as errands are run, trips taken or television is watched and when you see something, grab the chance to ask about it and explore it with them.&nbsp

column1: In our household, we've taken to watching periodic episodes of Pawn Stars and American Pickers and these provide great object lessons in finding value as well as negotiating.
column2: In the case of Pawn Stars, one of the big lessons is that value is often a subjective concept.
column3: You can read somewhere or hear that your collection of antique magazines is worth thousands, but it doesn't mean that that's what you're going to get.&nbsp
column4: Achieving that value depends upon multiple factors and some of those are probably beyond your control.&nbsp
column5: Another significant lesson is that when a negotiation begins, the final value can be radically different from the number named at the outset - <em>just because somebody names a number, it doesn't mean that that's what they will settle for. &nbsp
column6: A corollary of the negotiation lesson is that in many cases, the people negotiating are influenced by factors far beyond purely monetary considerations.
column7: I know what you're saying, but my great-grandpappy loved that item and it would be insult to his memory to take less than what I just demanded.

column1: Second, effective teaching is repetitive and has to be revisited again and again.
column2: Teaching a middle-schooler about the mechanics of compound interest can be done in one session but teaching the real meaning of it will take multiple repeated efforts until most truly grasp the concept.&nbsp
column3: <em>Our trip doesn't pertain to what you see and want and I don't have the money for it.&nbsp
column4: A debit or credit card in the wallet doesn't mean that I have to use it.&nbsp
column5: Since most folks don't pay off their credit cards, does it make sense to purchase a Whopper Value Meal and continue paying for it over the course of the next three months?&nbsp
column6: No, I only brought enough in the wallet for this and I don't have extra for that.&nbsp
column7: Because the kids are fairly persistent in stating when they want something, the opportunities continue to present themselves.
column8: As the older kids have aged, they'll even speak about wanting something but immediately follow with the comment that it doesn't make sense for one reason or another, or that they know that you won't do so for whatever reason that you've taught over the years.&nbsp
column9: It's occasionally done in a way to instill guilt but I don't usually feel guilt.&nbsp

column1: Third, don't worry about specific details but stick to the general principles and hammer them again and again and again and again.
column2: Some of my comments have become a form of family joke but the reality is that the lesson really does sink into their bones and it's visible on occasions when they don't even realize that they've followed them.&nbsp
column3: Yes, I drive an eleven year old minivan nicknamed Gladys the Rolling Dumpster but when you listen to the kids talk, some of the underlying philosophy leeches through as comments are made about <em>it's just a car, not a fashion statement.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: Bingo.
column6: The other aspect to this is that having a few hard and fast principles makes it easier to remember as well as explain.
column7: My memory's just not good enough to recall all of LeRoy Jethro Gibbs' forty-odd rules.

column1: Finally, try to stay consistent and on message since kids are great at smelling out hypocrisy.
column2: There are times when I do veer from the norm financially and I try to remember to explain why I might be deviating from a usual principle.&nbsp
column3: For instance, I'm not big into spending large amounts for kid's and teen's clothing since the kids are both growing and rough on the clothing and the kids are aware of my attitude.&nbsp
column4: But when Middle and I&nbsp
column5: went shopping for some clothing and waterproof hiking boots in anticipation of a winter campout, he was uncomfortable with the cost of a decent pair of boots and was surprised at my willingness to spring for them.&nbsp
column6: <em>It's an investment, son. &nbsp
column7: If you're going to do more camping and hiking, then you need to actually take care of your feet and especially so in sub-freezing weather.
column8: This isn't like a pair of Kmart sneakers that will get trashed sooner than later.&nbsp
column9: And even though you're almost guaranteed to outgrow these boots, I can pass them down to your younger brother since I can guarantee that he'll be able to fit into them.&nbsp

column1: Not everything that I believe and teach is going to stick and
column2: they're going to make some decisions that I find simply dumb.&nbsp
column3: Hell, I make some decisions that some would find simply dumb.&nbsp
column4: But the more that I can pass along to them to help prepare them for this new economic&nbsp
column5: reality will hopefully make their life easier.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
385,"1","1",,"xhtml","

American kids continue to fare poorly in comparison to much of the rest of the world's students and we've thrown a ghastly amount of money at the issue to improve test scores.
column2: We've blamed the educational unions - and yes, there is some validity to those criticisms of teacher protectionism - and we've blamed teaching methods as well as teachers themselves.&nbsp
column3: But a late 2010 poll by Stanford University in which they query adults found that fully 68%, more than two-thirds, blamed parents themselves.
column4: The surprising part of this was that more than half of both mothers and fathers agreed with the assessment.&nbsp
column5: But it goes beyond education however, into general behavior, and I myself wonder, are we really to blame?

column1: If there is blame to be apportioned, then yes, we deserve the lion's share of it.
There's a confluence of elements that have made parenting today's children and teens especially difficult.
<li>A changing and increasingly competitive economy that demands greater and more intense attention for the dwindling share of the economic pie.&nbsp
column2: The prototypical Monday - Friday daytime workweek has suffered as more are thrown out of work or have to work part-time at whatever hours they can in order to provide for food and a roof.

column1: <li>A rise in the availability and prevalence of home electronics so that the large majority of American kids are plugged into some device for an average of 7 hours each day.&nbsp
column2: Couple this with the fact that many of these computers, game systems and televisions are in the kids' bedrooms means that the parents effectively have little control over what the kids are viewing and seeing.

column1: <li>A stubbornly high divorce and single parenting rate so that the kids are overseen by only one parent who also has other household responsibilities with which to contend.&nbsp
• A belief that there are limits to discipline and an increased permissiveness as parents shift away from being authority figures to something akin to friends and buddies.
Practically speaking, the parents who are around are being pulled in too many directions to effectively do those things that a parent needs to do - communicate with, monitor, discipline and enforce.
There are factors over which we have no immediate control, specifically jobs and to an extent, marital/parenting status.
column2: We have to keep a roof over the head and food on the table and I honestly don't know how two people in a bad marriage can effectively keep things together for the kids.&nbsp
column3: But the other factors are huge and are very much within our power.

column1: Those factors within our power are the presence of the electronics and their usage.
column2: Does the child really need a cellphone?&nbsp
column3: Does the child really need a laptop or iPad that they can carry to their room?&nbsp
column4: Does each child require a game system or television set within their room so that they no longer have to leave that room to interact with the family?&nbsp
column5: The point is that we've created - and permitted - an environment in which the kids are allowed independence to such an extent that there is no longer any required interaction with the remainder of the family and parents, and the ubiquitous presence within their rooms means that we've ceded the ability to keep tabs on what they're watching and doing. I'm not a fan of MTV and what they've done with their new show Skins is a prime example of hypocrisy, greed and our inattention to the kids' viewing.
column6: If my basic arithmetic is correct, Skins was viewed by a total of 3.3 million in it's premiere with the majority - 2.7 million - of viewers between the ages of 12 and 17.
column7: The basic arithmetic comes in with the fact that the majority here amounts to fully 82%.&nbsp
column8: My suspicion is that the majority of these kids have parents who aren't aware that they're watching the show in the first place.&nbsp
column9: It is entirely permissible and appropriate for a parent to set limits on what the child and teens are allowed to watch and this doesn't constitute censorship or cruelty in any way.&nbsp
column10: If they're watching something of which you don't approve, turn it off.&nbsp
column11: If you're not around because of work, block the channel or program entirely.

column1: We as adults and parents have also largely bought into the line that kids really aren't all that different from adults, just less experienced and packaged in a pint instead of gallon container.
column2: Despite what's been bandied about in the past, children are not just &quot
column3: little people&quot
column4: and while some say that it takes a village, the reality is that more than a few members of the village are working diligently to use the children as a wedge to separate you from your cash.&nbsp
column5: But in their growth, they bear a striking resemblance to plants.&nbsp
column6: They will absorb whatever attention they're given like a sunflower absorbs sunshine and will continue, like the plant, to twist themselves in the direction of the light source to get everything that they need.&nbsp
column7: Knowing this, it's imperative for their best interests and well-being that you be the source.
column8: The research is becoming abundantly clear that kids are not junior adults and it's imperative that we stop treating them as such.&nbsp
column9: Their brains are being reconfigured as they grow and scientists now peg the age at which the average brain reaches adulthood in the mid-twenties.
column10: If they're going to be out on their own in the world before that time - Please God, let it be so - then it's crucial that they have a solid foundation when they leave the household for the great wide world.

column1: Many families do have to work hard to make ends meet and provide food and shelter.
column2:
But that doesn't mean that we can use that as a reason to absolve ourselves from the responsibility that comes with raising a child and it's ultimately in that that many do fall down.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
386,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Technology is constantly advancing and adapting and it's a given that the young are always ahead of the parents on the techno-curve. It's a given that many parents are looking back to the "
column2: good ol' days&quot
column3: of their youth when they recall a simpler world - although their parents and grandparents seemed to always say the exact same thing. But the past ten years have provided an explosion both in the technological platforms available to people as well as forms themselves. While our predecessors also had to contend with the notion of yakking teens, it was contained by the simple phone technology so that unless a teen had their own phone in their room, or gasp, their own phone line, the amount of information and the number to whom it could be disseminated was limited.
column4: For several years, the technology has gotten ahead of the social fabric and now the adults are starting to push back, as noted in The Guardian article on the rising tenor and amount of criticism of the effect of social media on today's youth.

column1: It's natural for the adults to push back against change and the jury is very much out on the entire affair.
column2: But the article does have a solid point on what one person refers to as the lack of &quot
column3: netiquette&quot
column4: amongst the users.&nbsp
column5: While the hue and cry is about the social networking sites, the problem goes back further to the entire presence of screens within the home.&nbsp
column6: Since the widespread availability of cable television and the ability to run lines to multiple rooms, the number of kids with their own bedroom televisions has grown to fully 70%.&nbsp
column7: With the TV in the room and the door shut, the parents have no real idea of the amount of time being spent on television and unfortunately, this carries over to the affiliated screen devices - laptops, PCs, and so on.&nbsp
column8: Given all of this, what can we do to help start to rein in the kids?

column1: <li>If there's a television in the room, consider whether or not to actually remove it.&nbsp
column2: Most parents are reluctant since the kids - of any ages - can frankly behave like asses in order to inflict enough of their own punishment to make the parent reconsider, but if the time is obviously creating issues then it should be considered.&nbsp
column3: There are devices that can be installed with parental codes to shut down the device after a predetermined period, such as TVAllowance, and this might be a decent alternative.

column1: <li>Understand that you're the parent and it's entirely both your right and your responsibility to keep tabs on the kids habits.&nbsp
column2: Frankly, we've controlled the electronics and I still spend an inordinated amount of time kicking one kid or another off of a screen device.&nbsp
column3: Few children have mastered self-control and this is simply part of being a parent.&nbsp
column4: Deal with it.

column1: <li>Establish ground rules apart from the simple daily amount of time.&nbsp
column2: What is unacceptable use of the device?&nbsp
column3: Trying to surf adult or mature sites?&nbsp
column4: Sexting or cyber bullying?&nbsp
column5: Texting at inappropriate moments?&nbsp
column6: While it's imperfect, lay out the scenarios ahead of time and then list the consequences.&nbsp
column7: Most of the house rules pertain to the cell phone since there's only one cable-ready television and the family PC is in the family room and the texting rules are fairly simple:&nbsp
column8: No texting or phone use when we're at the table for any family meal
column9: no texting or cell phone after 10 PM on any school night
column10: no stopping something else just to respond to a text (if you've started a game with Youngest, finish the damned thing).

column2: Children who grow up knowing that the consequences are enforced will give you less grief when you have to do it.&nbsp
column3: Those who've been given more free rein will resist and this is where things can get ugly as the relationship can occasionally devolve into a test of wills.&nbsp
column4: You have to make a conscious decision as to how much argument you'll tolerate and stick to it.

column1: <li>Make sure that the house rules are followed by the other kids that come into the house because failing to enforce on others while enforcing rules on your own is sending a horrible message to the kids.&nbsp
column2: Don't be surprised if other kids have a clue of the house rules already since kids talk.&nbsp
column3: Kids talk alot.

column1: <li>Be careful of your own electronics use and whether or not it reflects the house rules.&nbsp
column2: Kids can smell hypocrisy a mile away and will point it out as happily as recent roadkill on the interstate.&nbsp
column3: Besides, time that you're spending on electronics while the kids are around is time that you're not spending with them.&nbsp
column4: That is perhaps the crucial element of being a father.

column1: <li>Expect some confusion since what works at one age level simply doesn't work at another.&nbsp
column2: I'm a firm believer in age appropriate and work hard to adhere to the philosophy that what's okay for older kids is terrible for&nbsp
column3: younger ones but that means that there can be more gray areas and simple confusion as I try to keep up with things.&nbsp

column2: They're testing limits and relationships and it's likewise part of being a father.&nbsp
column3: It's not easy, but it's part of it.

column1: There will be an ebb and flow to the electronics usage and there are times when it's okay to let things go, such as on a snow day.
column2: The proof will be in what you see when the kids aren't online or onscreen.&nbsp
column3: How's their weight?&nbsp
column4: How's their sleep?&nbsp
column5: How are the grades?&nbsp
column6: How is their general behavior?&nbsp
column7:
It will require regular evaluation and a whole lot of persistent effort.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
387,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As I get ready for the next data collection foray for the PracticalDad Price Index, I have to wonder if people are clear on the real meaning and cause of inflation.
column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
388,"1","1",,"xhtml","

For a guy who's written about trying to maintain control of the household electronics, it was brought home the other night that I wasn't aware how enforcement has slid as more kids came along and they grew older.
Enforcement is part of the parent's job and I knew - intellectually - that I was being stretched as the kids multiplied and aged but a car conversation with Middle brought home how much.
column2: Part of our primary defense on the personal computer is simply placement in the family room
column3: with me and other siblings that would happily rat out the offender generally around.&nbsp
column4: But we'd previously had some age limits on use of the internet and allowable sites with Middle not being allowed on until a certain age and Middle pointed out that Youngest was allowed on at a younger age than he.&nbsp
column5: My retort was that Youngest had cleared a few specific sites for play and I'd reviewed them - which is true - but Middle's response was that his younger brother was getting on without my permission and I wasn't challenging him.

column1: The simple reality is that with more kids, activities and general stuff, I've fallen into the trap of just checking on the site content but letting things ride for a short while before booting the child off.
column2: In my mind, it was acceptable since I didn't have the time available at the moment to just deal with the probable distraction caused by Youngest, who'd probably need or want something.&nbsp
column3: But my downfall was in failing to recognize how it would be viewed by an elder sibling who saw the youngest getting away with something, and he was entirely correct.&nbsp
column4: The other simple reality is that I've gone back and reviewed some of the basic rules with Youngest, who will have to check in with me anytime that he wants to use the computer, and especially to go onto the internet.

column1: The final reality is that I've had to tell Middle that he was correct and that actions were being taken to rectify things.
column2: And if Youngest just has to wait and entertain himself without a screen, then those are the breaks.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
389,"1","1",,"xhtml","

After a large rise from November to December of 2010, the February 2011 PracticalDad Price Index remained flat with an index level of 100.63 (November 2010 = 100).
column2: While the overall remains static, the increasing cost of commodity-related agricultural products within, such as wheat, cooking oil and sugar have finally started to rise along with that of coffee.

column1: Within that figure, derived by pricing a basket of pre-selected items at three unrelated grocery stores, was a large decrease in the cost of one dozen eggs by 14% that offset price rises in such commodity items as sugar (2.9%), flour (3.6%), canola oil (4.5%) and coffee (4.3%).
column2: Sugar, flour and canola oil had their first price moves since the PracticalDad Index began while coffee's move followed a 9.8% jump from November to December of 2010.&nbsp
column3: What's notable about the rise in the cost of coffee is how it's masked by stealth inflation
column4: &nbsp
column5: throughout the four month period, only one of the three stores actually raised the nominal price on only one occasion.&nbsp
column6: Two of the three stores however, decreased the container size from the original 13 ounces to 11 and 11.3 ounces respectively so that the effective cost of coffee on the original 13 ounce basis rose.

column1: I'd like to touch upon a housekeeping note as to the index figures for the months of December and January.
column2: When I'm pricing different items, I pay particular attention to the item, size/quantity and cost so I didn't realize during those months that a 64 ounce carton of orange juice also varied by whether it was derived from concentrate - the cheaper choice - or not.&nbsp
column3: In these two months, the juice was subsequently priced with both varieties and I've corrected the data to reflect the original juice non-concentrate variety, which is higher, but that originally used in the November pricing.&nbsp
column4: The effect is to skew the data higher than the original index numbers, but the direction remains the same:&nbsp
column5: a sharp one month rise followed by two months at a lower level.&nbsp
column6: I've made note of this and re-evaluated other items as well to assure that this is simply a one-item correction.

column1: What else is notable in the February pricing?
• Eggs and butter both registered declines of 14% and 4.7% respectively to more than offset the increases in flour/sugar/cooking oil/coffee and other items.

• There are additional examples of stealth inflation as one chain has decreased the number of diapers per box from 104 to 96 and another began offering canned beans in a 15 ounce can, down from 15.5 ounces.
column2: In each case, the nominal price of the items didn't change and I've recalculated them on the original size to account for the adjusted prices.

column1: <li>As the actual basic food staples - flour, sugar, canola oil - show their first increase and the business/financial news discusses the rising cost of these raw items, I'm curious as to how long before the price for the finished goods also starts to rise.&nbsp
column2: These would include products such as bread, hot dog rolls, spaghetti and children's cereal.

column1: For the record, listed below are the monthly PD Index figures, both original and revised.
Finally, here's the actual data with the December data corrected as discussed above.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
391,"1","1",,"xhtml","

When I discovered that I was going to be a father for the first time, I spent time reflecting on my own childhood as a gauge to help determine what kind of father I hoped to be and what I wanted to emphasize with the kids.
column2: One of the things that came back to me from my own father was the need to think - about problem-solving, about issues, about courses of possible (in)action (since doing nothing is also a possible route).&nbsp
column3: This was something that I'd also try to inculcate among my kids but I broadened this to include helping them distinguish real meaning from the porridge bowl of crap presented by the various media.&nbsp
column4: I wanted the kids to learn to examine something and be able to determine if it was a load of crap.

column1: While I expected that it could come back to bite, it was in an intellectual sense and I didn't expect it to be so personally difficult.
It was easier as the kids were younger but with the advent of the teen years, the questioning has become more personal and contentious.
column2: There are things that I understand from additional decades of life that a young teen simply cannot comprehend and trying to explain them can be difficult as the words come slowly, with difficulty.&nbsp
column3: The conversation can reveal things about you that, for better or worse, smack of hypocrisy and teens can smell out hypocrisy like a hound on a scent.&nbsp
column4: I sometimes honestly wonder after a conversation with a teen whether I've managed to get the import of my thoughts across or whether it's been garbled into some mutant pretzel shape.&nbsp
column5: And frankly, I believe that parents have a particular authority that flows from the sheer dint of parenthood and now I've got kids questioning me.&nbsp

column1: I can't have it both ways, raising kids to question why things are as they are and yet excluding my own paternal authority.
column2: It isn't fair to them, it undercuts everything that I've attempted to teach and it encourages distrust.&nbsp
column3: So we've had some contentious moments with frustrated conversations that have broken off and come raggedly together again later as we attempt to knit together a common understanding from what feels like the jagged edges of sheared metal.&nbsp
column4: There have been moments when I've begged off of the question at hand, openly stating that I wanted the opportunity to think about how I wanted to say something so that it made sense.&nbsp
column5: There have likewise been moments when we've come together again as one of us has sought the other out and - as happened this weekend - I've had to acknowledge that the youth had legitimate points that required adaptation of my own actions.&nbsp

column1: The point is that communicating with teenagers isn't always going to be comfortable and will take you far beyond your parental comfort zone.
column2:
Expect turbulence and expect some hard feelings and dark moments, but also expect that you're going to have to continue to engage with them as you both adapt.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
392,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Children are cruel and one of the sadder moments of a parent's life is helping a distraught child learn the difference between a friend and a playmate.

It really is simple when the kids are very small because of the large tendency to practice parallel play, in which the kids veer erratically between playing by themselves and playing with one another.
column2: Two little boys can happily play their own backyard games apart from one another and then veer together to play with one another for a period, returning again to solo play after several minutes.&nbsp
column3: But as they develop emotionally and begin to actually interact with one another, then they begin to gain a measure of the other's personality and character.&nbsp
column4: Is he good at sharing?&nbsp
column5: Will he tease maliciously?&nbsp
column6: Does he get aggressively physical and is there some control over his impulses?&nbsp
column7: Kids do take a measure of one another and even preschoolers can assess that he's mean and I don't want to play with him.

column1: But there are other issues that only become apparent as kids grow and these generally pertain to character and emotional development.
column2: The covert cruelty raises its head and the damage begins to appear with the hurt child's feelings, self-confidence and self-worth.&nbsp
column3: It might not manifest itself directly but come out in other ways, such as a markedly decreased ability to handle tasks and frustration, loss of sleep or increased aggressiveness to release the pressure.&nbsp
column4: When the dam finally breaks and you determine that the others' words are the source, then you can have the conversation about the difference between a friend and playmate.

column1: One of the questions or comments is liable to be who else there might be with whom to play.
column2: You can walk through the list of the other kids and then ask, does this child speak this way or say these things? and progressively winnow through the cast of characters in your child's life.
column3: Take a few moments to touch base on the real difference between friend and playmate - will a real friend turn the things that you've said against you? And if a child breaks that simple rule, is this a person with whom you want to play?&nbsp
column4: Is the play so good that it's worth the potential upset and hurt that the other child can cause?

column1: When I've encountered the situations, I've tried to leave the final choice on whether to play with our child, with the child clearly understanding that this is potential price that has to come with this other kid.
column2: If it continues - and there have been moments when it has - then I've finally refused to let the child play with the other out of school.&nbsp
column3:
And in those rare circumstances, there really hasn't been any complaint at all.

column1:
393,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Yes, or at least in several months.

Kraft Foods, a multinational corporation, announced that it will be raising prices in the next several months across several of its key brands to offset the effect of elevated costs of such commodities as sugar, wheat and rice.
column2: They've absorbed the rising costs for months already and have watched their bottom line get pinched in the vise of rising input costs versus slack sales across some of the teen-oriented product lines, such as gums and candies.&nbsp
column3: Apparently the kids have decided that in the competition for their dollars between candy and Apples, the Apples are going to win hands-down.&nbsp
column4: According to the Yahoo Finance article, Kraft is joining the likes of Sara Lee, Kellogg's and JM Smucker in deciding to raise prices.

column1: While what will happen is now discernible in the distance, when it will happen is a ball that's entirely in the air.
column2: We've been apprised of months of economic data which points towards rising inflation.&nbsp
column3: The logic is inescapable since the finished products that sit on the store shelves are composed of the commodity inputs that are rising.&nbsp
column4: How quickly and how soon will these ripple through the supply chain before it gets to us?&nbsp
column5: That depends principally upon the companies that compose that chain, companies that are caught between weak consumer demand generally resistant to price increases and rising costs that force higher prices in order to maintain profitability.&nbsp
column6: But now we're seeing that the companies are finally starting to give way to the rising prices and as more leaks are sprung in the dam wall, those of us downstream in the chain will be hit harder.&nbsp
column7: When it reaches a critical mass to break the dam is now a legitimate question.

column1: In the monthly PracticalDad February Price Index, the items that I price are generally store brand.
column2: My sense and experience is that when someone is really trying to meet a budget, cost is more important than taste and reputation, so I concentrate on the lower priced generics.&nbsp
column3: While all of these corporate announcements are from major food producers, don't think that the store brands will be exempt as food retailing is an industry with a very thin profit margin and the rising input costs will apply even greater pressure upon the retailers.&nbsp
column4: They simply don't have the cushion that an entity such as Kraft has.

column1:
So buckle up for the ride and if you're like me, head on over to Costco for a bulk purchase of Kraft Mac and Cheese.
