394,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's midwinter and the school signs have started appearing, reminding you that it's time to enroll your little girl for kindergarten.
column2: You glance at her and you ask yourself the questions.&nbsp
column3: <em>She's five years old now, but is she ready?&nbsp
column4: Is it the same as when I went through Kindergarten?&nbsp
column5: What can I do to help prepare her for the experience? &nbsp
column6: It's a big step for both of you and you want to assure that she's ready.

column1: The fact that a child is five years of age is solely a baseline established by states as the minimal age at which a child should be able to start the mandatory educational process.
column2: States set a certain date in the Fall - September 1 or October 1, for example - as the cutoff date by which a child must have reached the age of five to even enroll in kindergarten.&nbsp
column3: If the cutoff date is September 1 and the child turns five on September 8, then kindergarten almost always waits another year.&nbsp
column4: When most parents become concerned is when the child's birth date is in the several month period prior to the mandated cutoff date, and the question becomes whether or not the child is ready for the experience.

column1: What are the considerations for kindergarten readiness?
column2: John Berry is an accomplished educator with more than 25 years of experience as a kindergarten teacher and was kind enough to share his observations.&nbsp
column3: In Berry's experience, there are multiple areas that indicate that a child is ready for kindergarten.&nbsp

column1: <li>Foremost is that she should be able to listen to directions and focus for a sustained period of time.&nbsp
column2: What is meant by sustained?
column3: According to Berry, the rule of thumb is that an appropriate time frame is three times the child's age.&nbsp
column4: Remember that this is only a general rule and a child's shorter attention span isn't necessarily an indicator of future problems.

column1: <li>The child should be able to separate from the parents.&nbsp
column2: Children are naturally apprehensive and nervous before kindergarten but must be able to spend time away from parents for the period of the school day, trusting that they'll be getting home.&nbsp
column3: Kindergarten teachers are skilled in handling the children who are distraught on the first several days of school but if there are too many in a single classroom, those first days will be difficult for everybody there - students, teachers and aides alike.

column1: <li>There should be an appropriate level of trust of strangers.&nbsp
column2: We scrupulously teach our children not to speak with strangers in order to help protect them from predators who might approach.&nbsp
column3: But kindergarten is a time for encountering all manner of strangers that range from teachers and aides to bus drivers, custodians and even other children. Children should be able to learn to trust adults that they're only just meeting, yet still remember the stranger rules that they've been taught.

column1: <li>Children should have an ability to care for themselves in terms of personal hygiene, particularly with toilet habits.&nbsp
column2: Accidents will happen but the norm should be that the child can routinely clean herself after using the toilet.

column1: <li>She should have age-appropriate motor skills, such as the ability to cut with scissors and hold and use pencil or crayon.&nbsp
column2: According to Berry, one of the changes wrought by the No Child Left Behind legislation is an increased focus in school on readiness for reading and writing to the exclusion of the fine motor skills activities that would have occurred previously, such as playing with clay, for example.
column3: There simply isn't the amount of time available to do those activities that were done before.

column1: • There is an expectation that she also have a grasp of basic information such as shapes and colors, knowledge that can be learned in a good pre-school program.
There are questions as to whether to send a child simply because she's reached the age of five and kindergarten educators have an axiom:
column2: when in doubt, keep them out.
column3: While it can apply to all children, there is an acknowledged tendency amongst parents to hold boys out a little longer because of slower maturation and emotional development.&nbsp
column4: There are no real issues with having a child wait a little longer, although it can creep up years later if the latter-start child is getting a driver license ahead of his peers.&nbsp
column5: Frankly, there can be far more issues that arise when a child is enrolled in kindergarten before she or he is prepared and those issues will cluster about issues of maturity and emotional development.

column1: If you aren't entirely certain about readiness for kindergarten, find out if your school district has an evaluation program.
column2: If the district doesn't evaluate the students, you can have a conversation about readiness with your child's preschool teacher or other parents who interact with her.&nbsp
column3: Regardless of whether there's a formal evaluation or not, most kindergarten teachers would be happy to provide guidance on determining readiness for upcoming children.&nbsp
column4: Conversations with the schools and kindergarten teachers also help to determine what students might require additional assistance.&nbsp
column5: Schools are obligated to provide special assistance to children who might require it, so you shouldn't be surprised if you find that special needs children are in the class along with the adult aide.

column1: Perhaps the key difference between your kindergarten experience and your child's is due to the No Child Left Behind legislation.
column2: Kindergarten is no longer viewed as an almost free-standing experience prior to the beginning of the &quot
column3: real&quot
column4: school of first grade, but instead as a gateway to school.&nbsp
column5: Consequently, there is a greater emphasis placed upon reading preparation, writing and numbers than in the past and your prospective kindergartener will be expected to master more than would have been expected of you.&nbsp

column1: As the months pass and September approaches, there are things that you can do to help prepare her for the big day.
column2: Certainly, talk to her repeatedly and positively to help alleviate her concerns.&nbsp
column3: Take her to play at the school's playground in the evening&nbsp
column4: or on the weekend so that she can become familiar and comfortable with the school.&nbsp
column5: If the school has any summer activities for the incoming kindergarteners, make it a point to attend so she can meet her new classmates and teacher.&nbsp
column6: More school districts are starting brief on-site&nbsp
column7: programs for preschoolers - such as school library story times - and if you have the opportunity to take her, attend one so that she can see what the inside of the school looks like.&nbsp
column8: Likewise, spend more time working with her on her fine motor skills with such play activities as modeling with Play-doh, coloring with crayons, using connect-the-dot pictures and cutting with scissors.

column1: She's entering a new world and you should understand that she's not going to be the only one learning as the year progresses.
column2: While you might be nervous, as I was, know that there's considerable expert assistance to help your child adjust and have a great year.

column1:
395,"1","1",,"xhtml","

A large part of a father's job is to teach and help prepare the kids for the world and that means that I have to actually follow what's going on in the world.
column2: Much of my worldview is skewed by the knowledge that I have children who will someday have to contend with issues that are being impacted by actions taken now.&nbsp
column3: Given that, I just finished reading the US Treasury Report on the reform of the housing finance system, a k a what the hell do we do with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac?

column1: Everybody knows that the housing market is a complete trainwreck and most are aware that the financial hulls of Fannie and Freddie are so shot full of holes that they've gone into government receivership.
column2: This report outlines the potential steps that the government proposes to bring stability back to the housing market and it's finance mechanism.&nbsp
column3: The upshot is that the mortgage market revert back to a principally private domain with private funding and the only government involvement would be for targeted markets.&nbsp
column4: This involves revoking the $729,000 maximum conforming loan limit (probably not impacting our kids), increasing the cost of mortgage insurance (impacting our kids) and increasing the size of the downpayment to a minimum of 10% (again, impacting our kids).&nbsp
column5: With the expectation that the lion's share of lending for mortgages will revert back to the private sector, the handwriting is clear that the underwriting standards will be returning to the pre-house mania standards of solid credit history, which will absolutely impact our children.&nbsp
column6: After all, the banking sector has to be a good steward of the money entrusted to them now that they can't slough it off on the taxpayer.

column1: So here's the brief synopsis of what my kids will have to consider when they eventually wish to purchase a house:
<li>increased monthly premium for mortgage insurance from today's levels
<li>higher downpayment as percentage of house price (from about 3% to at least 10%)

column2: Intellectually, this is a good thing and something that has to happen for the system to right itself and recover.&nbsp
column3: But I've got a real problem as I look at it.&nbsp
column4: We know that the real income - corrected for inflation - of the average American is dropping or stagnant at best.&nbsp
column5: This means that the amount needed just to get into a house will be higher as a percentage of income and assets than the amounts which we've had to pay in quite some time.&nbsp
column6: Given the poor savings habits of Americans, who collectively haven't saved 10% of their paycheck in decades, this drives the hope of homeownership further away from our children as the ability to gather a sufficient downpayment will be taxed.&nbsp
column7: Couple this with real concern about incipient food inflation, and the kids paychecks will be stretched just trying to keep food on the table.

column1: I suspect that the Treasury authors understand this as well.
column2: They're blunt in their upfront assessment that their goal is not to put all Americans in their own homes, as proposed by George Bush.&nbsp
column3: Their goal is to reform the broken system so as to make it sustainable and&nbsp
column4: safe.&nbsp
column5: A later section of the report flatly states that work must be done to improve the state of financing for multi-family housing in order to attract apartment building owners that will put sufficient money into the properties to make them passably habitable.&nbsp
column6: Hey, if the kids are gonna be priced out, we still gotta find 'em someplace decent to live.

column1: What truly bothers me however, is that the only way - given these proposed changes and the existant income parameters - for a home to be affordable to the kids is for the price to fall.
column2: But this imperils the financial system as housing prices are the foundation of so many Collateralized Debt Securities and everything possible is being done to prevent that from happening.&nbsp
column3: So...my kids or the banks?&nbsp
column4: Guess where that one comes down.

column1: What do I have to do to help prepare my kids for this scenario?
column2: There are several things on which to work, but none of them are simple or foolproof.

column1: <li>Speak frankly with the kids about buying a house.&nbsp
column2: First, a house isn't a home, it's a structure and ignore the advertising about buying a home.
column3: While the kids might not understand all of the details, they'll get the underlying message better than you think that they might.

column1: Speak frankly about the need to save and then go out and model that behavior yourself.
column2: Purchase items with cash that you've saved in a coin jar or alter your own behavior.&nbsp
column3: Kids smell hypocrisy like stink on a skunk and they'll notice.

column2: What exactly are the varying forms of debt and when are they appropriate?&nbsp
column3: How much debt should one be able to carry given a certain income level?

column1: Talk with them and teach them to be skeptical of what they hear and read.

column2: Don't just chat, but talk to them in the car or at the basketball hoop, ask them if they know anything about whatever and see what they say.&nbsp
column3:
And while you're chatting about drugs, chat about the money, too.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column2: After ongoing debate, the fog is clearing and significant rises in the commodity arena - sugar, wheat, corn - are harbingers of the inflation that the Federal Reserve has sought.&nbsp
column3: It also means that costs will be rising for the end users in the supermarkets.&nbsp
column4: I'm young enough to have a kid in the primary grades but old enough to remember the inflationary 1970s and have been asking myself, <em>what did families do to manage with inflation then?&nbsp
column5: What are the best courses of action if inflation, whether stag- or hyper-, takes hold?

column1: For those who are a bit fuzzy on the 1970s, inflation began prior to the decade when the consequences of funding both the Vietnamese War and the Great Society became apparent.
column2: Too much money was chasing through the economy and prices started to rise.&nbsp
column3: Housewives protested the butcher shop when the price of hamburger began to hurt the food budget - where do you think Hamburger Helper came from?
column4: Prices however, rose across the board in a wide variety of items apart from food and inflationary expectations took flight.&nbsp
column5: While everybody talks about the supply shocks of having oil supplies cut off in 1973 and 1979, the reality is that inflation was already alive and thriving.&nbsp
column6: President Richard Nixon attempted to rein in the situation with statutory wage and price controls as far back as August 1971, a full two years prior to the first Oil Embargo. As you might expect, that effort failed - miserably.&nbsp
column7: It took painfully high interest rates by then-Fed Chairman Paul Volcker to bring inflation to ground.&nbsp
column8: In thirty years however, the company line on inflation has changed.

column1: Understand that inflation is precisely what the Federal Reserve wants as it seeks to devalue the dollar.
column2: With no end in sight to out of control federal spending and a grotesque national debt, the plan is to devalue the dollar so that this debt is paid for in dollars that hold less purchasing, if not actually valueless
column3: the presumption however, is that the spending will be brought under control so that the debt really no longer grows and can be ultimately eliminated with these faux dollars.&nbsp
column4: The conventional thinking is also that the average family will return to spending - with renewed credit - as they use their dollars before they become further devalued.&nbsp
column5: For the Fed, it's a policy two-fer as consumption increases while the national debt and interest payments are rendered manageable.&nbsp
column6: With the Volcker experience of the 1980s under their belt, the central bankers believe that they can bring inflation back under control after they've achieved the policy gains.

column1: So, what did our parents and grandparents do during the inflationary 1970s?
First, they surely didn't spend more, as the following graph demonstrates.

column2: They went the opposite way, ratcheting up savings during periods of economic stress.&nbsp
column3: Granted, not only had the average real income risen for decades previously, but the percentage share that the average US consumer spent on non-necessities (exc food, clothing, housing/affiliated expenses) had grown significantly.&nbsp
column4: In 1934-35, the average US family spent 23.8% of it's money on non-necessities while that rose to fully 49.9% in 2002-03.<sup>1</sup>&nbsp

column1: The surprising part of the savings increase though, is that it really didn't come from the non-necessity category.
column2: The previous inflationary period was from the early 1970s to the mid 1980s
column3: non-necessity spending as a percentage of total spending rose from 42.6% in 1972 to 48.6% in 1985.&nbsp
column4: If savings during that period ranged from 8 to almost 12% while spending on discretionary items rose, where did the savings come from?&nbsp
column5: It would have had to come from the necessities category of housing/food/clothing.

column1: So what else did our parents and grandparents do?
Many of them went back to gardening and growing their own food to reduce the rising costs.
column2: In a 2009 USA Today article, an executive with a seed company noted that vegetable seed sales were fully 40% higher than in 2007 and they hadn't "
column3: ...seen this kind of spike in 30 years.&quot
column4: &nbsp
column5: Which places us back in the period when savings were peaking&nbsp
column6: between 10% and 12% of income. One of the retrospectives at the time pertained to the Victory Gardens that their parents had grown to supplement the World War II war effort.&nbsp
column7: Between this gardening and the subsequent low domestic food prices, the percentage of income spent on food dropped from almost 20% in 1973 to 13% in 2003.&nbsp
column8: With an inflationary&nbsp
column9: uptick in food and commodity prices, that percentage spent on food will rise upwards again unless families return to gardening on a scale reminiscent of the 1940s era.

column1: Our parents and grandparents likewise made due with consumer durables, such as automobiles and appliances.
column2: Vehicles in the 1970s were nursed along so that a family had a vehicle for much longer than today's family might.&nbsp
column3: Cars and appliances would be repaired again and again until they really were at the point of complete breakdown.&nbsp
column4: Legendary investment manager Peter Lynch once wrote that he realized that the auto industry - and by extension, the market - was ready for a run in the 1980s when he recognized how far along was the age of the typical American family vehicle.

column1: They also were at a distinct advantage in terms of clothing costs.
column2: Sewing was far more prevalent then than today and families had fewer clothes - and repaired them more frequently - than would occur today.&nbsp
column3: The percentage spent on clothing by the average family then, which was much larger than the 2.9 figure today, was 7.8% while as of 2003 had dropped by almost half to 4.2%.&nbsp
column4: The Walmartization of the American economy is a principal cause of this as American textile jobs flowed overseas to regions with far lower labor costs so that mass market clothing, on a historical basis, became incredibly cheap.
column5: Think about it:&nbsp
column6: when Junior rips a hole in the knee of his jeans, do you patch them or just get another pair at Walmart?

column1: The impact of even relatively stable inflation would be significant, although there are things that we can do.
column2: We can manage to hold the line by:

column1: <li>re-thinking our clothing needs and shopping habits
<li>shifting back to some self-sufficiency with our own gardens
• simply deciding to forego some of the luxuries that have come to permeate our lives, such as the ever-present cup of Starbucks.
• understanding that true leisure time might be in short supply as non-work hours are taken up in the tasks necessary to tend gardens, cook more frequently and sew and mend more.

column2:
We need to also speak more forcefully and vocally about the policies that have brought us to this point, a central bank that's been corrupted by a financial system and a government that cannot control itself.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
397,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Everybody talks about incipient inflation and what it really means, and the most recent data from China - suspect that it is - indicates that the consumer prices there rose
column2: 4.9% year over year from January of 2010.&nbsp
column3: When I mention suspect, bear in mind that they rejiggered their marketbasket and had it been left alone, the rise would have been 5.1%.&nbsp
column4: So what does it mean to the typical family when they see increasing inflation hitting the grocery stores?&nbsp
column5: Percentages can be scary, but what's the real impact?

column1: Let's play with the use the Chinese rate of 4.9% and extrapolate it with some American data.
First, remember that inflation means that there's a decline in the buying power of the currency so that with the same amount of money, you're able to purchase less than you could before.
column2: If the inflation rate from one year to the next is 4.9%, then the same amount at the later date is 4.9% higher
column3: the inverse is that if you maintain the amount spent as a constant, then you're only able to purchase that much less.

column2: According to Bureau of Labor Statistics courtesy of creditloan.com, the average American "
column3: consumer unit&quot
column4: of 2.5 people spent $3753 annually in 2009 for food at home for a monthly average of $312.&nbsp
column5: Bear in mind that when dining out was included, the total annual amount on food rose to $6372.&nbsp
column6: For our purposes, we'll use the $312 as a baseline while understanding that if you've got kids, you're spending more per month than this example bears out.

column2: Assuming all else remains the same, the impact upon the food budget is significant as a $312 monthly budget only purchases what you can buy now for $245.&nbsp

column1: The other problem is that income is at best, flat and for the lower wage groups, actually dropping.
column2: According to the BLS at the same site, the average pretax income of that odd 2.5 average consumer unit declined from $63,091 in 2008 to $62,857 in 2009.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, inflation is a nebulous and inexact thing and to think that it only happens in an orderly and predictable manner is like saying that you can capture a specific number of insects with a single swoop of the butterfly net.

column1: So where do we begin to cut?
column2: The first source is most likely the amount that's spent on dining out, which was about $218/month for the consumer unit.&nbsp
column3: And after that comes a rejiggering of the family menu as brand names go by the wayside in favor or store brands and then a shift in the menu to lower cost alternatives.&nbsp
column4: And that's for families - not consumer units - who still some leeway and aren't already to the point of doing without or going to the food bank.

column1: When this does start to really percolate through the domestic economy, the final acts will be a complete realignment of our priorities as we reevaluate what's truly necessary versus that which we've come to consider as necessary.

398,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The budgetary chickens are coming home to roost as newspapers run stories about school districts having to cut back significantly to meet the financial shortfalls.
column2: With no money forthcoming from the states since they're broke as well, all manner of things are on the block to bring the budget into balance.&nbsp
column3: While some can talk about reinstituting programs later when the money is available, the simple reality is that we're resetting to a new and lower norm of spending.&nbsp
column4: There simply isn't the money to cover all of the promises made and obligations taken on.&nbsp
column5: So what can I do for my kids in what's sure to be a tighter, more competitive educational environment?

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
399,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It can be difficult to follow a child's thought process.
column2: The logic is jumbled and the thinking cluttered with misconceptions and misinformation and following the conversation with a kid is akin to trying to track a rabbit that suddenly disappears down a hole, only to reappear fifteen minutes later from another hole linked to its den.&nbsp
column3: But there is a logic there and it's helpful to make an effort to understand it, especially when it dictates actions and attitudes that are contrary to what we teach and try to model ourselves.&nbsp
column4: Such is the case with Youngest and his desire to lose this year's Pinewood Derby.

column1: If you aren't aware, the Pinewood is a coming of age experience for millions of boys who've gone through cub scouts, in which they turn a Pine block, four nails and wheels into a racing creation.
column2: It's also where a father's own attitudes come into play as to how to help the boy with the car.&nbsp
column3: My own attitude is that it's ultimately the boy's car.&nbsp
column4: I'll help him to clarify his drawings and in the early years, cut the car for him, but it's otherwise up to his own imagination and desire to produce.&nbsp
column5: It's a function of my understanding of the purpose of Pinewood as well as my own awareness of my handiness with tools - I can do basics, but I'm not a craftsman.&nbsp
column6: Both of my sons have produced solidly middle-of-the-pack vehicles that will win a few heats but never take an entire derby.

column1: After last year's race, he was curious about why a particularly cool looking car was so slow as to consistently lose, so convincingly that it won the Most Fuel Efficient trophy, a consolation trophy awarded to assauge the embarrassment of the boy who builds that year's slowest car.
column2: While it's awarded for the slowest car, it's a legitimately nice award that doesn't mock the effort.&nbsp
column3: All of the trophies are Hot Wheels cars and professionally engraved plaques mounted on varnished wood bases and in this year's case, was a Hot Wheels modified 1971 Maverick
column4: it isn't a milk or garbage truck.&nbsp
column5: Over the intervening year, we'd have occasional conversations about Pinewood and it became apparent that not only did he not want to win, but he wanted to lose and do so consistently.&nbsp
column6: He didn't want a sleek vehicle, but an absolute clunker that was the slowest thing on the track.&nbsp
column7: While my wife and I aren't sticklers about having to win - do your best and try, but bear losing with some grace - this was frankly disconcerting.&nbsp
column8: When it came time to start this year's Pinewood car, it sank in that he was actively incorporating design elements that were in last year's slowest car.&nbsp
column9: As we talked further, his thought process clarified into something that was surprisingly mature and honestly, very goal-oriented.&nbsp
column10: But the goal wasn't to win, it was to obtain a trophy.&nbsp
column11: He defined success in a much different way than I did.

column1: You see, I make the trophies, which are cheaper than the good-looking statues and more attractive than the cheesy awards.
Youngest saw the trophies and realized that the Most Fuel Efficient was frankly as attractive as the others, albeit with a smaller scale car.
column2: He wanted a trophy and measured his capabilities versus those of other boys who were either more gifted with their hands or had far more hands-on fathers and decided that in order to achieve his goal, his best shot of earning that trophy was to build a complete loser.&nbsp
column3: To his credit, he actively built his car to lose and when it came time to add white graphite to the axles, which effectively decreases friction on the nail-axles, he declined as he knew that everybody else wanted the graphite added.

column1: Precisely how do I handle a situation in which a child defines success in losing?
column2: Children are concrete and the abstract doesn't come until much later, so the motivation is in a tangible, three dimensional award instead of an&nbsp
column3: ephemeral sense of victory.&nbsp
column4: Youngest determined his goal and then worked to achieve that goal.&nbsp
column5: Do I demand that he abandon that goal and come away with nothing or do I go ahead and support the kid when he's actually using his head and thinking through the situation?&nbsp
column6: It's one of the most surreal scenarios that I've encountered in sixteen years of fatherhood.

column1: He came in dead last of four cars in his first heat and when he raised his arms and cheered, parents looked askance.
column2: When he came in last again and celebrated, a few looked at me and I explained and as the morning wore on, a few parents - me included - also began to cheer when his car lost.&nbsp
column3: When all was said and done, he ultimately failed at his attempt to fail and as a measure of its surrealism, I don't know whether he say that he actually failed or succeeded.&nbsp
column4: I can say that I'm honestly proud of him in his clear assessment of himself and his chances as well as his design that furthered his chance of meeting his goal.&nbsp
column5: The issue sometimes isn't the child himself, but rather the circumstances in which the child finds himself and finding that that's the case can save considerable heartache and grief.

column1: As a final note, we'll be having a conversation amongst the pack leadership about the lesson taught in such a visible reward of failure.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
400,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With the store pricing done and data tabulated, the PracticalDad Price Index rose in March, 2011 to 101.19 from a February figure of 100.78.
column2: This is a cumulative 1.19% increase over the November, 2010 rate of 100.&nbsp
column3: While the market basket has shown only minor upwards movement, there are certain items that stand out.

column1: • The price per one pound of ground beef has been at $3.32, which is 10% higher than the original November, 2010 price of $3.02/lb.
<li>Coffee rose - without any adjustment in the package size - by 9.7% from the February price (from $3.38 to $3.71) and since the Index's inception by a full 25%.&nbsp
column2: This 25% rise incorporates adjustment for two different stores of unrelated chains decreasing the package size while keeping the price steady, aka stealth inflation.

column1: <li>While the price of flour itself has remained steady at $1.99 per five pound bag, the cost of baked goods - bread and hot dog rolls - has begun to rise.&nbsp
column2: Bread rose by 8.9% last month while the rolls have increased by 4.5% since the Index's inception.

column1: • Milk (2%) jumped by almost 5% from February, which was actually lower than the November price, having declined.
• Canola Oil rose by more than 12% from the February price and is now 17% higher than at the Index's inception.

I'm big on teaching the kids how to behave in public.
column2: How do you behave at the ballgame versus at a restaurant versus a wedding or funeral?&nbsp
column3: But there are moments when I have to remind myself that I have to be as mindful of my own behavior as the kids'.&nbsp
column4: This was especially brought home to me this weekend as I watched a proud father make a complete ass of himself at a school function.

column1: Supporting the kids is as obvious as breathing, but how it's done gets dicier as the kids age.
column2: There's a wonderful television commercial in which a child - one time on stage, another on a playing field - looks into the crowd of onlookers and suddenly, the crowd vanishes save for the father, who's now the only one watching.&nbsp
column3: The underlying truism is that the kids both want and need us there and are seeking our approval and pride in their accomplishments.&nbsp

column1: Now, let's adjust the commercial for the age of the child.
column2: In this variant, the kid is now fourteen years of age and as he looks onto the field, there in the crowd is the father.&nbsp
column3: Dad smiles and nods - as in the real commercial - but the crowd remains.&nbsp
column4: The next version of the commercial shows the fourteen year old on the field looking at the crowd as his proud papa suddenly stands and screams out <em>YOU GO, BOY!&nbsp
column5: MAKE ME PROUD!&nbsp
column6: WOOT!!!
column7: In this version, the crowd remains while the exuberant Dad vanishes without a trace.&nbsp

column1: In the version that I witnessed this weekend, the teen was walking down the auditorium aisle to accept an award when Dad suddenly stood and yelled out her name amidst the silent crowd sitting there.
column2: Note that the applause had already finished so it wasn't as if the child received no applause.&nbsp
column3: Sitting next to my sons, I flinched and looked over to see the eldest visibly wince as well.&nbsp
column4: Were that me, I doubt that I would have made it home alive as body parts would have been tossed piecemeal from the speeding car windows as it swerved down the road.

column1: Kids do become more sensitive of public appearances as they age and there are times when even the presence of a parent can cause embarrassment.
column2: <em>Don't mind him, he always breathes that way. &nbsp
column3: Our presence is a reminder that they really haven't reached adulthood and aren't as independent as they think or would like, and acting in a way that publicly draws that to the fore does embarrass them.
column4: I understand that father's pride and am glad that he's had the opportunity to experience it.&nbsp
column5: But the ride home would have been much better had he kept his mouth shut and stayed seated.

column1:
402,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's been five months since I began to track prices on a specific marketbasket of items, and even longer since we began to hear about the return of inflation.
column2: There are some things that I've noted since the process began, including some thoughts while on my hands and knees checking the unit prices on the bottom shelve of the stores.

column1: <li>Listening to commentators and bloggers - whether you agree with their views or not - you suspect that the onset of inflation will occur like a financial tsunami that washes our collective savings out to sea.&nbsp
column2: The reality is that the onset of inflation is considerably more insidious and if you aren't paying attention, then you might not be able to verify that it's happening.&nbsp
column3: <em>Wait, didn't I pay less last month for this?&nbsp
column4: I think so, but there's no receipt to check. &nbsp
column5: When the individual items are shown with prices over time, then you can see that some items do increase over time while others are motionless and still others wander over the margins like a drunken sailor.

column1: <li>You begin to see how individual grocery stores and retail chains are managing with what they're presented.&nbsp
column2: In one instance - formula - I started with the same product at all three stores but after a price spurt at one store, that particular management apparently decided that the product was too expensive to stock for their customers and removed it from the shelves.&nbsp
column3: I consequently now price that formula at only two stores instead of the original three.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, grocery chains quietly downsize the product packaging before they move forward and actually rise the prices
column5: coffee is a case in point as two of the three stores downsized the product and it was only in March that a significant price hike was passed through to the consumer.

column1: <li>Pricing decisions also reflect the actions of the purchasing managers who might somehow get a better deal for that particular month so that the price of the item has actually dropped.&nbsp
column2: There have been multiple occasions when I've revisited a store two or even three times to verify that I didn't foul up and write the wrong data.&nbsp
column3: This isn't to say that there haven't been mistakes, but simply that the motion isn''t always upwards.

column1: <li>How can I describe the sense from pricing explicit items over time and watching their activity?&nbsp
column2: Honestly, it's struck me as though I'm on a beach and aware that the tide is going to come in.&nbsp
column3: I maintain a position, but to help my sense, place sticks at specific positions in the sand to both my left and my right.&nbsp
column4: As I observe, I can see that as a wave washes ashore, one marker will be overrun while its neighbors remain dry.&nbsp
column5: This continues with the immediate waves never quite washing up in the same place but over the course of time, individual sticks are increasingly overwhelmed by water while others might remain less underwater, a function of whatever factor I can't know.&nbsp
column6: And if you aren't paying attention because you're playing with the kids, you suddenly realize that the waves are approaching the towels and scramble to keep things from ruination.&nbsp
column7: It's happened but you can't really say how or when.

column1: <li>What economists - and bloggers - will say is that inflation is not only a monetary phenomenon, but also a psychological one as well.&nbsp
column2: The effect of the psychology is to change the behavior to account for the situation at hand and the case study for this was the Weimar Hyperinflation of post First World War Germany, when the middle class was left destitute.&nbsp
column3: Why save when what you get is going to be worth nothing in the next week or even day?&nbsp
column4: That isn't to say that this is what will occur because honestly,&nbsp
column5: no one can be certain.&nbsp
column6: But the across-the-board increases that people expect will create that kind of psychology, even if it's &quot
column7: only&quot
column8: 10 or 15% annually.

column1: The PracticalDad Price Index will continue and I plan to pass the data along to someone who has a better sense of how it might be analyzed.
column2: The kinks have been largely worked out by now and this can serve as a small indicator of what's happening to us as we live our lives.

column1:
403,"1","1",,"xhtml","

While sides are drawn in the Wisconsin public union fight, everyone agrees that the country and its constituent states are trapped in a case of too many promises, too little cash.
column2: What's playing out now in Wisconsin - and coming soon to Illinois, California and almost every state - is simply the first stage in the fight of redefining our spending priorities.&nbsp
column3: We just can't have it all and something has to give.&nbsp
column4: The local papers over the past several days have brought this to my doorstep as the news announces that our new governor, Tom Corbett, will eliminate the $4 billion deficit via spending cuts alone.
column5: The kicker here is that under his plan, state universities will lose fully 50% of their funding.&nbsp

column1: That's fully one half of their state funding.
column2: It doesn't mean that the university system budgets are going to be lopped by one half, especially since the majority of the university monies don't come from the state treasury.&nbsp
column3: In fact, the amount that Penn State University, the flagship institution, receives from Pennsylvania amounts to only about 8% of its total budget
column4: while I can't find how much a smaller institution gets from the state, it is probably in that ballpark range.&nbsp
column5: On the opposition side, the universities are arguing that that money is specifically used to subsidize tuition for in-state students so that what a Pennsylvanian pays is less than someone from New York or Delaware, hence the students will be the ones in front of the falling axe.&nbsp
column6: One opponent, from the faculty union, stated that tuition could rise by a full 33% should this play out.&nbsp
column7: While it sounds outrageous, the reality is that California raised tuition by 32% in one fell swoop so it isn't impossible.
column8: The likelihood is that truth and reason will take a back seat to the soundbites and the fallout will be somewhere far less than that, although it will increase.

column1: Also on my doorstep is Eldest, who's visiting two of these schools in the next month.
column2: Our mantra has been education without the debt, or as little debt as possible.&nbsp
column3: We view student debt with almost the same abhorrence as a childhood cancer, something that - even with survival - will follow these young people for years, having an impact on their ability to live a decent, sustainable life years after the debt's been incurred.&nbsp
column4: Like most, we've saved some but not enough and already, prospective colleges have been given the axe because of cost.&nbsp
column5: The University of Southern California sounds lovely, but not on the dime that they demand.&nbsp
column6: Likewise, other top institutions.&nbsp
column7: We'll have to revisit plans again and review the prospects and somehow, we'll find a way to make it work.

column1: But here's my problem with the proposal and it's a problem with both sides.
column2: First, if we're going to talk about the necessity for a better educated citizen to compete globally, then we can't place such a radical cut upon the age group that's expected to compete globally for business and trade, a group that's young, inexperienced and realistically has no political voice.&nbsp
column3: The flip side is that the entrenched higher education leaders have no business immediately holding these young people hostage with threats of a one-third tuition increase.&nbsp
column4: If a major institution is going to see it's funding move from 8% to 4% from one source, how does that translate into a one-third increase?&nbsp
column5: Explain to me, please, without the angst and hyperbole, understanding that I live in a college town and see capital spending that's best described as unnecessary.&nbsp
column6: Don't talk about different accounts and different pots of money, because I've worked in the corporate world and understand that these things can be changed and adapted to the new circumstances.&nbsp
column7: It's not easy, but it is achievable

column1: We'll adapt and figure out a way to make it work, but only if both sides recall that not only are they tossing the newest generation of workers into the firing line, they're tossing in our children as well.

404,"1","1",,"xhtml","

I was stunned to find last week that the new Pennsylvania Governor, Tom Corbett (R), planned to cut funding to higher education by fully 50% as he attempts to honor his campaign promise of eliminating a $4 Billion deficit without raising any taxes. The backdraft has been significant and I know folks at a local state university who have been told to prepare for the worst. But apart from the sheer magnitude of the cut, what might it mean for the young people and their families?
column2: It helps to consider other numbers in order to gain a better perspective on the issue, so let's examine things a bit further.

column1: First, consider the higher education budget in perspective.
column2: In the previous year, the higher education piece was about $1.3 Billion, or 4.5% of the entire state budget of $29 Billion.&nbsp
column3: But the amount removed actually constitutes 16.5% of the $4 Billion deficit that's being eliminated
column4: this is disproportionate by a factor of more than 3 times the original contribution.&nbsp
column5: This cut is across all of the institutions in the state system, PASSHE (Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education) which includes not only the flagship Penn State University, but also 14 smaller universities as well as 4 quasi-private universities such of Pitt and Temple.&nbsp
column6: The amount of the state's contribution to higher education has decreased over the past decade or more and will finally fall to a level not seen since the formation of PASSHE in the early 1980s.&nbsp

column1: Second, consider the effect upon individual institutions themselves.
column2: Everybody's first thought upon announcement was to determine what Penn State's leadership would say, but PSU only receives about 8% of its funding via state appropriations.&nbsp
column3: The smaller 14 universities actually receive around 30% of their funding from the state and it's here that the pain will occur, especially since many of these are either operating with an already existent deficit or have only kept up with the already declining funding by eliminating faculty positions and / or programs and upgrades.&nbsp
column4: For a case in point, examine some &quot
column5: back of the envelope&quot
column6: calculations on two state universities, Millersville University (MU) and Indiana University of Pennsylvania (IUP).&nbsp
column7: Given the already strained financial positions and the reality that much spending is already constrained by contracts that won't be completed by the time that the budget passes, it's a fair assumption that much of the funding cuts will be made up on the backs of the students.&nbsp

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column1: The effect would be a single year rise of 12.8% for those at Millersville University and 10.5% for the students at IUP.
column2: While the percentages - back of the envelope as they are - aren't as dire as California's 33% increase in 2009, they are a staggering blow to students and their families.&nbsp
column3: The upshot is that even more students will extend the time that it takes to obtain a degree and the reality is that the longer it takes, the less likely to obtain it.

column1: Budget cuts have to happen and most understand that simple concept.
column2: We have an obligation to care for those less or unable to care for themselves, as we always have.&nbsp
column3: But we also have an obligation to prepare for our future and a large part of that is creating both a citizenry and workforce that can function, compete and prosper against others in the coming years.&nbsp
column4: We can't talk about competing with other states, let alone countries, when we fail to provide reasonably priced education for our young people and the ultimate result will be a more poorly educated and less competitive populace.&nbsp
column5: And a smaller one as they move away to find the financially self-supporting jobs that accrue to regions and states that help prepare their people for the world.

column1:
405,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The press lit up in January with the publication of Amy Chua's Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother, her account of choosing to raise her Chinese-American daughters in the style of the prototypical Chinese mother's "
column2: take no prisoners&quot
column3: philosophy.&nbsp
column4: And as events and circumstances change concurrently, I've had to consider the strengths and weaknesses of that approach.

column1: There's an image of a successful Asian student in almost all of our schools, and behind that image is another - a demanding and exacting mother.
column2: A woman who won't tolerate failure and seemingly sacrifices a personal relationship with her child in order to obtain a child who succeeds but will presumably run for the hills when older and out of the household.&nbsp
column3: Contrast this with the American approach in which parents want the kids to largely try different things and be happy, not to mention be the kids' friends as well.&nbsp
column4: Some Americans have taken this book as a bit of an affront and defended their parenting style and truth be told, there's value to both sides.&nbsp

column1: But first consider the rationale behind the Chinese approach.
column2: Recognize that the Chinese mothers - like all mothers - want what's best for their kids and want them to have a better life.&nbsp
column3: So far, the two groups are matched.&nbsp
column4: But then recognize the circumstances behind the approach.&nbsp
column5: The Chinese society was family-centric and generations could live in the same area without moving a significant distance.&nbsp
column6: And while America as a nation is only 235 years old, Chinese society for at least that long was fractured and trapped in decline after their historic eras, only resurgent in the past several decades.&nbsp
column7: If Chinese parents - like their counterparts almost everywhere - wanted their children to have a better life than theirs and there were only so many opportunities available, then these children would have to truly excel in some manner to avail themselves of those opportunities.&nbsp
column8: The kids would have to know how to apply themselves - and Chua's absolutely correct when she states that it isn't something that comes naturally for most children - and also be able to handle pressure.&nbsp
column9: They would have to understand that the family was the core bedrock of their existence as so much of then-Chinese society wasn't stable, either politically or economically, and it was the young adults who would be coping with the pressure of both raising children and helping care for elderly parents.

column1: The opposing view is the Western/American mother.
column2: Given the freedoms that we've enjoyed, and the historic economic/social mobility that went with it, there's a greater sense that the kids will have opportunities.&nbsp
column3: The long-time generational view has been that the next rising generation would be better off than its predecessors.&nbsp
column4: Indeed, this country is now at least three generations removed from the last great and serious trials of the Great Depression and Second World War and it's only been in the last number of years that parents and adults have begun to honestly question whether that same promise exists.&nbsp
column5: American adults have also enjoyed a greater mobility than their Chinese counterparts and it's not at uncommon to have elderly parents in one region while the adult children are in an entirely different timezone.&nbsp
column6: If the parents were no longer capable of caring for themselves, there were other options available apart from living with the children.&nbsp
column7: We've simply enjoyed so much prosperity and relative ease compared with the remainder of the world that we've been able to spend greater time on leisure and introspection than our peers elsewhere on the planet and the presumption still exists that the paradigm will hold.

column1: This PracticalDad has generally followed the western approach to parenting, albeit with stricter guidelines.
column2: I've been clear with them that they shouldn't try to grow up too fast like their peers since they can only have one childhood.&nbsp
column3: There are plenty of adults trying to recapture their youth and they frankly look like a bunch of damned fools doing so.&nbsp
column4: But there's a greater appreciation for the Chinese approach over the past several years as our economy has undergone significant and worrisome changes.&nbsp
column5: The upshot is that the kids will have to be able to compete globally and if they don't have an appreciation for hard work and discipline, then they're going to have their lunch eaten for them.&nbsp
column6: So there is greater expectation of academic performance than with other families, and a greater amount of time spent discussing the realities of our world with them. Neither my wife nor I are looking to raise self-actualized adults - whatever that means - but adults capable of surviving in a more unfriendly world and doing so in a moral, ethical manner.

column1: Which might be the toughest hurdle of all.
So we'll continue to try providing them with opportunities that are fun and help children grow, but maintain expectations that force them to reach beyond themselves.
column2: Because the world is going to require that they be able to reach beyond themselves far more than we've had to.

column1:
407,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Even before the credit collapse and financial crisis of 2008, I've expected that the long-term economic health of the American family would suffer.
column2: Lousy economic investment - houses, anyone? - and the insanely short-sighted habit of shipping higher-value American jobs overseas so that the manufacturing base is &quot
column3: hollowed out&quot
column4: were key drivers in the premise.&nbsp
column5: When Congress passed TARP in 2008 and the Federal Reserve commenced with its initial round of Quantitative Easing, it was apparent that the government would address the long-term debt issue by trying to devalue the dollar via inflation instead of actually working to manage the budget.&nbsp
column6: The logic was inescapable but the only question was the timeframe.&nbsp

column1: Now we've got a glimpse of what's coming as data confirms that English household income has fallen since 2008.
column2: As discouraging as things appear to be in the US, you can take a little comfort in knowing that England's economy is even more screwed up and the personal level wave is hitting there before it really begins to commence here.&nbsp
column3: The Bank of England has likewise been acting to devalue the English currency and that is now taking off as the most recently reported English inflation rate is about 4.4% per year, ahead of the American inflation rate, which unfortunately is hard to gauge since the government doesn't consider food or fuel as part of the core CPI.&nbsp

column1: The English incomes have been struck from two primary sides.
column2: First, the increasing inflation rate means that - absent offsetting nominal wage gains - the English Pound will be able to purchase that much less than before.&nbsp
column3: Second, the exceptionally low interest rates mean that the money being saved is actually losing value and so eliminating the entire notion of savings.&nbsp
column4: If you lose money by saving, why save for the future?&nbsp
column5: A lesser factor for the English is simply that there economy has an even smaller manufacturing base than we do, so what they can produce that the world will want is minimal.&nbsp

column1: Here's the problem - for them and for us - as we move forward.
column2: As rates remain low and so discourage savings, and price increases really do take hold, then people will develop an inflationary mindset.&nbsp
column3: The effect of such thinking is an unwillingness to save or plan for the future as people spend themselves into financial destitution.&nbsp
column4: As Aesop would describe it, the grasshoppers will overwhelm the ants and devour everything so that nothing is left for the future.&nbsp
column5: The long-term impact for the country of such a mindset is, to put it mildly, horrible.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
408,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Being a parent - I hate the word parenting - is an experience of not being to see the forest for the trees.
column2: When the kids are old enough to enter activities, you want them to try their hands at new things and experiences.&nbsp
column3: Couple that with more than one child and toss in homework and friends and life becomes a blur.&nbsp
column4: Who has to be where and at what time?&nbsp
column5: What's the deadline on this project or that exam and again, would you please explain to me how we came to have three girls spending the night in the basement?
column6: You're running at high speeds in a forest and while you might get smacked by the branches of the occasional foulup, you work hard to avoid running into a trunk that could drop you flat on your back.&nbsp
column7: It's a breathless experience in the moment and more than a little nervewracking.

column1: But there are moments when you can step back and take stock and when you do, you recognize that the forest is beginning to thin out.
column2: There are still plenty of trees to dodge but there are more spots of dappled sunlight on the ground and an instant more breathing room before you have to swerve to the left or right to avoid the next trunk.&nbsp
column3: This occurred to me this evening as I waited for Youngest at his baseball practice, an event far enough from the house that it makes no sense to just drop him off and return later.&nbsp
column4: Middle had a night off from any activity and Eldest had gotten a ride to soccer from a friend.&nbsp
column5: While it's the norm for overlapping activities, Eldest takes her driver's test next week and will be able to start driving herself, freeing me from having to worry about how to get her there or home.&nbsp
column6: I'll still worry about her driving, but that's suddenly a bit of relief from the taxi-servicing.&nbsp
column7: To bring the point home more emphatically, she also commences on the college open-house tour with her mother next week and in a year, the forest around me will be thinned by all that much more.

column1: I spoke last week with a gentleman who's firm has done multiple home projects for us over the years.
column2: He has three sons of his own and the youngest is a lacrosse player in his junior year of college and as we chatted, he commented that he and his wife now treasure each of those games.&nbsp
column3: He recognizes that there are only a relative handful left over the next two seasons and then, that aspect of his life will have ended after roughly two decades of practices, games and tournaments.&nbsp
column4: His forest is now an open grove and ahead of him is open field, free of the obstacles that cause us to react more than act.&nbsp
column5: At a rural baseball field surrounded by copses of trees and pastures, his commentary plucked a particularly melancholy chord in my soul.&nbsp
column6: The tone resonated and on reflection, I decided that as this multiple-sport season progresses, I'll have a greater appreciation for the beauty of this forest in which I find myself.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
409,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As Eldest is within spitting distance of the college experience, she faces the same issue as hundreds of thousands of other students:
column2: how much debt should she take on?&nbsp
column3: And if things are inflationary, shouldn't she absolutely take the maximum amount of debt possible?

column1: There are certain general rules of economic behavior that pertain to specific situations and that includes living in an inflationary environment.
column2: But you have to really think through the circumstances to ascertain if those rules continue to apply to the situation in which you find yourself.&nbsp
column3: One of the precepts of inflation is that a future dollar is worth less than a present dollar because it will only be able to purchase X amount less than could be purchased today.
column4: The upshot is that inflation truly favors debtors
column5: The debt to be repaid is a nominal amount, say $20,000, and that figure doesn't take into account whether that nominal $20K can only purchase what $15K could purchase now.&nbsp
column6: The other aspect is that in an inflationary environment, wages are expected to rise as well - even if not at the exact same rate - to offset the price rises.&nbsp
column7: People are paid commensurately more and thus pay off the nominal with devalued currency.

column1: What do you think is the goal of the US Treasury and Federal Reserve System with all of the Quantitative Easing?
column2: Do you really believe that the United States can pay off a $14+ Trillion national debt?&nbsp
column3: Spur inflation, spur spending and hope - pray - that the executive and legislative branches get a handle on the spending to stop the flow into the debt bucket while the dollar is trashed.

column1: I guarantee you that somewhere out there, some expert will recommend that with an inflationary environment, prospective students and their families should take the leap and incur the maximum amount of debt to pay for college.
column2: The thinking will be that the competitive edge is so keen that a college degree will be painted as the sole hope of making way in the world and that it's the obligation of families to support their youngsters - and the youngsters make a significant investment in themselves - and spend whatever's necessary to obtain that degree.&nbsp
column3: It would be a great time to take on the debt since it could be paid off in devalued dollars
column4: this would be - per experts - a true value play for the upcoming generation.&nbsp
column5: Were this to be suggested as expert advice, I have no doubt that some would go ahead and run up the debt even more.

column1: But does that thinking really hold water in these circumstances?

column2: First, the presumption is that wages would naturally rise following an inflationary surge.&nbsp
column3: The reality is that our real wages and incomes have actually dropped in the past number of years as our high-value jobs have been increasingly outsourced to countries with significantly lower labor costs.&nbsp
column4: As these changes happen, the aggregate effect is that less and less true productive wealth is supporting the wages earned via the service industries with a resulting loss of aggregate income.&nbsp
column5: One of the problems that American businesses are facing now is that the American consumer is so wage hamstrung and debt-laden that they're unable to effectively pass along many price increases that they're having to absorb from their own suppliers.&nbsp
column6: There is simply nothing to demonstrate - absent a wholesale mass-mailing of stimulus checks to consumers - that wages will simply, suddenly turn around and begin rising.

column1: Second, consider the present nature of the student debt.
column2: There'll be greater push for incurring increased debt but is there going to be a concurrent change in the student loan model to ease the burden of that increased debt?&nbsp
column3: Student debt, as I've written before, is far more toxic than any other debt since it can never be discharged in bankruptcy should things really go south for that particular student.&nbsp
column4: He or she can take the credit hit in exchange for erasure of mortgage and credit card debt, auto loans, and whatever else.&nbsp
column5: But the student debt will have to be repaid, even at the cost of that individual's future.&nbsp
column6: Consider this:&nbsp
column7: Sallie Mae, the principal student lender, is a privatised GSE - just like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac - and exists solely to serve the student debt market.&nbsp
column8: As of last year, student debt surpassed consumer credit and was second only to home loans in dollar terms.
column9: Sallie Mae is aware of this and while they spent $3.4 million on lobbying in 2008, they revved the lobbying engines and spent more than half as much - $1.86 million - in the first quarter of 2010 alone.
column10: This rise occurred as the Federal government considered legislation that would remove privatised student lending and the rise in lobbying to prevent shows where Sallie Mae places her emphasis.

column1: Third, what if the dollar really does tank and hyperinflation ruins the currency?
column2: In that unlikely event, a $120K student debt could conceivably be repaid by three days wages.&nbsp
column3: But food and other essentials would be equally expensive and lay claim to those three days wages.&nbsp
column4: <em>Gee, do I eat and house and feed the kids or pay my student loan? &nbsp
column5: The contract however, would still remain in effect and I fully expect that once things stabilized - in whatever form - that the lenders would still demand repayment of their debts in the new dollar equivalent.
column6: The currency is ruined, but the contract is not, and again, the law would still stipulate that student debt was non-dischargeable.&nbsp

column1: The reality is that we, the individuals, presently exist to serve the needs of the corporations and by extension, their shareholders and management.
column2: There is simply too much wealth and power at stake for these few to readily accede to the common good and change in such a way that diminishes that wealth and power.&nbsp

column1: Will these things actually come to pass?
column2: I hope not.&nbsp
column3: But if they should, expect that experts will begin plying the airwaves and internet with advice about the relationship between inflation and debt.&nbsp
column4: And when you hear them, ask them whether the other aspects of debt have changed in any material way as to repayment, terms or forgiveness.&nbsp
column5:
Otherwise, chalk it up as more self-serving white noise.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
411,"1","1",,"xhtml","

We can get the food inflation data from commodities brokers, the Main Stream Media, the CEO of Walmart, or from PracticalDad's market basket.
column2: The April 2011 Price Index is now collected and calculated and the PracticalDad Price Index has risen to 101.96 from March's figure of 101.19.&nbsp
column3: In other words, the 47 items in the marketbasket have risen 1.97% since the Index inception six months ago.&nbsp
column4: The cost of the April marketbasket was $181.91 versus the March marketbasket cost of 180.52.

column1: Yes, the grains are rising and the coffee is percolating along.
Apart from statistical noise and the occasional price drop - yes, that does happen - what's notable for the month?
<li>Grain based products - hot dog rolls and spaghetti noodles - increased 3.5% and 2.5% respectively.&nbsp
column2: This caps off a cumulative six-month price rise of 8.2% (hot dog rolls), 8.9% (white bread) and 9% (spaghetti).

column1: <li>Coffee rose an additional 4.3% - with no adjustment of package size - to an adjusted cost of $3.87 for a 13 oz can of store brand coffee.&nbsp
column2: Coffee's cumulative six-month rise is now 30.7% and part of that rise is due to stealth inflation by two retailers who decreased the package size.

column1: • Paper towels rose by 5.9% during the month.
• While most produce was flat, carrots rose 12.7% for a cumulative rise of 18.3% since November.
• Next to the rise in carrots was the 11.7% for Canola Oil, which has now risen by 31% in the six months since November.
Yes, Canola oil, alias Can(adian) O(il) L(ow) A(cid).
column2: This is a cooking oil derived from the dried and processed seed of the canola plant, grown in quantities mostly in Canada, although it's also grown in Europe and in the US Plains states.&nbsp
column3: It's one of the healthier cooking oils as it's lower in saturated fat and higher in mono-unsaturated fat than other plant-derived oils.&nbsp
column4: It's now used extensively in processed food production and byproducts of the canola oil production cycle are used by more than a few beef producers as feedcake.

column1: As I've looked at the price jumps in the past three months, I've also come to find that there's a high correlation between canola (and other vegetable oils) and heating oil prices because of the increasing use of biofuels to offset higher oil prices.
Practically speaking, this is a great example of watching the rat work through the python.
column2: Rises in an input commodity such as canola oil are partially caused by the rise in oil prices, and then work their way through the processed food pricing structure as well input costs for beef producers.&nbsp

column1: So let's look at the final April data.

Several days ago, I posted the latest PracticalDad Price Index and apart from coffee's monthly rise of 4% - for a rise of 30% in six months - what threw me was an 11% rise in Canola Oil, a vegetable oil used for cooking.
column2: With this huge rise, Canola Oil took the six month prize for an increase of more than 30%.&nbsp
column3: What I've been thinking of since is how something as mundane as canola oil might have repercussions through this economic web that we've constructed and how something as distant as Libya's Gaddhafi now bombing his own oil fields affects the price of bread for Junior's packed lunch.

column1: First though, just what is canola oil?
column2: Read the official Canola Industry literature and you find that it's derived from the seed of the canola plant, grown principally in Canada.
column3: It came into usage in the late 1970s/early 1980s and is generally considered better due to the low amounts of bad fats and high amounts of good fats per serving.&nbsp
column4: It can be purchased in the various sized bottles in the baking/cooking aisle of the grocery store but is also used extensively, along with other forms of oil, in food processing.&nbsp
column5: This is especially the case when the food pertains to baked goods such as breads or cake mixes.&nbsp
column6: How widespread?&nbsp
column7: When I searched the pantry and freezer last night, I found that canola oil was used in the loaf of white bread, the frozen loaf of potato bread, the box of baked snacks in the pantry and also the several boxes of various cake mixes.&nbsp
column8: Humans aren't the only ones eating it, though.&nbsp
column9: The remainder from the processing can be made into seedcake and sold to ranchers to serve as cattle feed, which means that it's also part of the foodchain in the butcher's section.&nbsp
column10: Through the six months of the index, flour prices have been stable with only about a 1% rise in the period.

column1: What didn't occur to me was the extent to which canola is also used as a biofuel source, along with palm oil and our old standby, corn. How much is it used?
column2: Well, enough to make a sizable dent in food costs as potential food is redirected to energy needs.
column3: As I recall, even George Bush commented that we still needed to keep some corn around for food.&nbsp

column1: There's actually significant statistical relationship between oil price and canola oil, such that when oil prices rise, canola and other vegetable oils rise as well.
column2: The long and short is that with oil prices rising as they are - and they are presently tracking to surpass the summer 2008 highs - the biofuel producers will likewise compete with food producers for a finite supply of food, er fuel, whatever.

column1: According to OPEC, there really isn't much slack in their production so that the loss of oil from some place like Libya can't be easily offset.
column2: So when Colonel Gaddhafi decides to bomb his own oil fields to prevent the Libyan rebels from selling it overseas, that field production is removed from use and places a hit upon the supply line.&nbsp
column3: As users bid for the finite supply, the price increases and as the price increases, people think more and more of biofuels.&nbsp
column4: It's akin to watching Curly smack Moe, who in turn wheels about and smacks Larry in a slapstick routine.&nbsp
column5: But the routine isn't all that funny as the food producers are in turn passing the increased cost onto us via the grocery stores.&nbsp
column6: So as you try to keep the food spending down by making Junior eat sandwiches in a packed lunch, understand that the impact isn't coming from the farmers, but instead the seemingly unrelated energy issue.

column1: In this developed economy, we have managed to create a web such that a string plucked outside Benghazi resonates on the supermarket shelf.

As Eldest is looking towards senior year in high school, I've reflected on some of the personal finance items that I've seen other parents do with their kids.
column2: Senior year is a good time to do things like open a checking account, but should I also go ahead and help her obtain a credit card (with my wife and I as cosigners)?

column1: I ask because multiple other parents have looked askance at the easy credit available to the lovably gullible/financially stupid college students and decided that they'd help the prospective college students obtain a credit card via co-signing.
column2: The thought process is that if the kids have experience with the possession of plastic, then they'll be less likely to go apeshit when they get one.&nbsp
column3: The other aspect is that they want to help the child begin to earn a solid credit rating
column4: spend a small amount - $20 or $30 - and then pay it off by the due date.&nbsp
column5: The child learns to think in terms of due dates and becomes used to the concept of disciplined spending.

column2: When I was in college three decades ago (?!?!), it was rare to be able to obtain a credit card.
column3: It might be possible if you had a cosigner or were a senior with a solid lock on a job, but it was generally less available.&nbsp
column4: By the credit crunch of 2008, the cards were available to college freshmen and it became common for college graduates to leave with both student loans and several thousand dollars in revolving credit debt.
column5: Certain lenders preyed - and I use the word purposefully - upon the financial innocence and naivete of youngsters with seemingly free cash.&nbsp
column6: There are some improvements with the Dodd-Frank Act, such as a statement specifying the timeframe and amount ultimately paid if only the minimum due is paid, but the burden of that debt continues with the youngsters.

column2: In the new economic model that is approaching - generalized austerity and lower living standards - it's better for them to learn to live without the panacea of easy credit.&nbsp
column3: I've been preaching debt control and savings for years.&nbsp
column4: The older two have heard - are hearing - the need to leave college with as little debt as possible and I've been explicit that that carries over to the consumer debt as well.&nbsp
column5: I want them to learn to do without or learn to improvise some other means if they need something, and just giving them a credit card now isn't liable to instill that.&nbsp
column6: Hell, giving out a cell phone hasn't led to learning to control the texting, has it?&nbsp

column1: The question isn't settled and at some point in the near future, I'll raise it with my wife and we'll work it through one way or another.
column2:
But until then, there will be no cards.

In an ideal world, parents and kids should communicate freely.
column2: If the child is asked to do something and has legitimate questions as to why, she can ask and Dad has an obligation to explain why.&nbsp
column3: That's the ideal world though, and in the real world, this PracticalDad has on more than one occasion simply responded with <em>because I said so. &nbsp
column4: It clearly isn't the best response and not one that teaches kids the rationale behind why things are - or aren't
column5: - done, such as why it's not good to clean off the muddy shoes in the bathtub or why a window has to be opened because a bedroom is thoroughly penetrated with Axe body spray.

column1: The real world is different from the ideal that parenting experts and child psychologists hold up for multiple reasons.

<li>The child, and that includes the teenager, is using the question as a means of postponing the request and if the kid is really lucky, getting Dad so caught up in the response that the request is completely avoided.&nbsp
column2: Talking is easier that actually getting up and doing something.&nbsp
column3: When the question is one that's been repeated on more than two or three occasions and Dad's comfortable that the kid isn't the drooling village idiot, then the response is an entirely appropriate one.

column1: <li>The child isn't actually asking, but whining about it.&nbsp
column2: There's been more than one occasion when the response is nothing more substantive that because I said so when the question is a reflexively whining why do I have to?
column3: And it's been more than once that PracticalDad's response to that has been <em>when you can ask and not whine, then I'll explain it.&nbsp
column4: Otherwise, because I said so.
column5: Kids have to learn that whining is unacceptable to the request or direction of someone in authority.&nbsp
column6: Make no mistake, the authority in the household can't reside with the kids.

column2: Things in a busy household have to get done and when someone's trying to multitask - and it's not really easy for a guy - then the press of events overtake the ideals of good parenting.&nbsp
column3: This is when it really is important to try to rebound from because I said so, because children are a blank slate and while they're older now, they won't learn how to choreograph a schedule or do something if you don't actually take the time to explain it.
column4: That doesn't mean that conversation won't become tense, but it does mean that I have to make the effort.

column1: • Related to the first bullet point, the fact that a kid will just repeat why out of
column2: stubbornness, even when it's been answered simply and satisfactorily already.&nbsp
column3: Now it's a matter of imposing parental authority on the kid.&nbsp
column4: While some believe that parenting shouldn't be a contest of wills, there are moments when it is and as my father stated on multiple occasions, <em>I'm not losing this argument to a (&amp
column5: *^&amp
column6: *&nbsp
column7: second grader (or third, or fourth, or even ninth).
column8: We do learn from our parents and now that I've got my own, it's a stance that I can appreciate.

column1: One of the keys to parenting is to follow-up with the kid and when I've hauled the phrase out, I've usually tried to have a subsequent conversation when the job is done and the angst is passed.
column2: It's uncomfortable and I've even occasionally apologized, but more often than not, the result has been that the child does understand so that there isn't more angst when the request arises again.
