417,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of the memes that's been gaining credence recently is that the price inflation/deflation argument is close to settled and that inflation is about to reappear in truly significant fashion. More articles are cropping up and the debate is the reason that I began the PracticalDad Price Index in late 2010, to actually monitor developments on a specified basket of 46 items.
column2: But you have to take a moment to think about it and whether certain articles about inflation are truly about inflation or something else entirely.&nbsp
column3: That was the case this morning as I read Zerohedge's somewhat excited article about major inflation on Costco's Survivalist Food Cache, which had jumped in price by 47% over a six month period.
column4: I like Zerohedge and it's on my regular reading list, but some might have to stop and think a bit about this particular article.

column1: Yep, the number 47 is correct and I've no doubt but that it did rise by that much, also taking into account the stealth inflation of downsizing the package amounts.
column2: But there are some things to bear in mind.

column1: <li>Inflation is first and foremost a monetary phenomenon, usually a response to the supply of currency coursing through the economy at that time.&nbsp
column2: That's why economists follow such money supply data as M1 or the larger, more inclusive M2 with such interest and why the skyrocketing M2 amounts have given inflation proponents real grounds for concern.
column3: Other things can cause inflation, such as a supply shock a la the Arab Oil Embargo, but that's not the issue this time around.

column1: <li>Watching a market basket of items at three unrelated stores for six months has provided an insight into the early onset and/or the behavior of price.&nbsp
column2: When most go shopping, they'll typically note that something has gone up in price only if it's something which they constantly buy and with whose price they're intimately familiar.&nbsp
column3: More typically, someone will see the price and think <em>I swear that I didn't pay that much last month, did I? &nbsp
column4: But since almost nobody keeps their receipts and goes back to reference them, there's typically no positive identification and comments fill the blogosphere with observations and questions of whether something was noticed.
column5: Inflation is more akin to having a rodent that runs up and down grocery shelves, peeking its head out so that it's seen peripherally by the shopper.&nbsp
column6: When checked, the rodent is gone but a dropping is left to confirm its presence and as you step back, you see it pop out again three shelves up and twenty feet away.&nbsp
column7: If you don't want to shop in that particular store, think of inflation as akin to one of George Norry's Shadow People, who are typically only noticed peripherally.
column8: It isn't going to happen in such a concentrated instance unless things really are becoming hyperinflationary, or...

column1: <li>Someone sees a chance to make a bit of a killing.&nbsp
column2: When all of the pricing activity is occurring across a wide variety of generally unrelated food products - and lima beans are really not related to cake mixes - and from one particular business source, then whether the price rise is truly inflationary is questionable.&nbsp
column3: My God, inflation is even hitting the company that packages all of the end of the world as we know it supplies...it must be true.
column4: When prices for such a disparate lot of items is rising that much at one clip, then you'll witness it everywhere and certainly not from one supplier.

column1: I suspect that prices will rise given the sheer volume of money that's been thrown into the economy over the past two or more years, but there will most likely be a period of creeping inflation before anything such as that hits.
column2: Besides, the banks have been the recipients of most of that money and we all know how willing they are to part with it, don't we?&nbsp
column3: When they decide to let it loose in the larger economy, then we can buckle up for the ride.

Now Marymount sends parents postcards several times a year, invites them to parents-only events and publishes a full-color "
column2: Guide for Parents.&quot
column3: &nbsp
column4: It is one of a growing number of schools to discover that it's not enough to communicate with prospective students.&nbsp
column5: The colleges are also wooing parents who are digitally tethered to their offspring and want more involvement than writing a tuition check.

column2: - Washington Post: College Catering to Curious Parents As Well As Prospective Students (April 9, 2011)
that it's not enough to communicate with prospective students.&quot
column3: &nbsp
column4: And while there is &quot
column5: digital tethering&quot
column6: involved by some parents, the reality is that many parents are truly concerned about the cost and prospective debtload.&nbsp
column7: We're involved because we're not stupid.

column1: We're now fully engaged in the college courtship process as Eldest is wooed by multiple colleges and universities, which range from huge University of Southern Cal and Georgia Tech to tiny Belmont Abbey College.
column2: She's gone with her mother to several college open houses and will go to several more as interests and options are explored and I'm honestly surprised to think that the higher learning institutions <u>wouldn't </u>include significant activities for the parents.&nbsp
column3: I'm honestly surprised that this piece of common sense hadn't occurred to the marketin...er, admissions folks before now.&nbsp
column4: To their credit, the institutions visited thus far have had excellent sessions for students and parents, some both together and separate so not every university has climbed aboard the Crazy Train.&nbsp
column5: The dean of one college honors program endeared himself to my wife when he stated that one of their primary goals was to provide the best education possible without hanging a mortgage around a kid's neck.

column1: This generation has produced a signficant number of parents who are overly-involved, so much so that the term helicopter parent was coined.
column2: We love our kids and perhaps since many grew up in divorced households, have gone too far in the direction of involvement and protection.&nbsp
column3: But parents have something our kids lack in spades, and that's experience.&nbsp
column4: If a kid has a decent chance of incurring a mortgage sized debt by the age of 23, then he should be shepherded through a visit that's heavy on fun and light on such questions as faculty/student ratios, facilities, financing and work-study programs.&nbsp
column5: There's a local private college nearby that prides itself on a modern student center replete with Mongolian Grill, and if that's the tripe that's talked about with the kids, then parents need to be greatly involved.&nbsp
column6: When I first heard about this the other year, my thought was <em>Mongolian Grill?&nbsp
column7: Hell, where are the Mongolians?

column1: Why do we plan to be involved with the college decision?
• Because the cost of higher education has grown at significantly higher rates of inflation than the core CPI monitored by the government and is expected to continue for the foreseeable future.
• Because the cost of higher education is now significantly more disproportionate to the average family income than it was thirty or forty years ago.
• Because that many more families are now tasked with funding their own retirements than thirty or forty years ago, when our parents and grandparents had pensions.

• Because good jobs for the youngsters are increasingly hard to come by and it's increasingly less likely that Junior is going to be able to obtain an entry level position that will permit him to service the debt load on non-dischargeable student loans.
• Because we understand that there's life beyond college and that young adults should have the opportunity to live, travel and enjoy life before settling down to raise children.
• Because we understand that children are expensive and that our grandchildren will be impacted by the money spent on servicing college debt instead of helping provide for them.
• Because one of the first adult decisions facing teenagers is one with huge financial implications, involving factors with which these teens have little experience.
There are two comments from the article that stand out in my mind after reading the article.
column2: The first is from a parent:

column1: Even when parents try to hang back, it's hard not to get involved, said Allen Barnett of Tuxedo Park, NY, who toured American (University) with his 17-year-old son, Cameron, during spring break last month.
Barnett said he tries to keep his opinions to himself as he shows his son college options.
column2: But at the end of the search, he said, &quot
column3: you always want to make sure they don't make a mistake.&quot

column2: admissions marketing consultant&quot
column3: who stated:

column2: If I could ban parents from the campus visit, I would.&nbsp
column3: They take the fun out of it...People are still trying to figure out these parents.&quot

column1: To Mr. Barnett, I would say that he's not hurting his son or disrespecting his decision-making skills by sharing his opinions.
column2: This doesn't constitute something only in the &quot
column3: mistake&quot
column4: category.

column1: And to the admissions marketing consultant, I can only say that I hope you have triplets.

If you hear the financial and economic news, you'll periodically hear the term BRICS.
column2: It doesn't pertain to a building material - although they are trying to build something - and it isn't something with which to hit - although we're likely to get whacked.&nbsp
column3: BRICS is an acronym for a five nation consortium, each of which has significantly growing economies as well as a wealth of natural resources, such as people, oil, and gold.
column4: These five are Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa and while each is a regional power in its own right, they are now cooperating to further their own interests and create a new monetary system that removes the dollar as the global reserve currency - the linchpin.&nbsp
column5: While the most recent meeting in Hainan, China on April 13 didn't gain huge press, there are distinct consequences that people should understand and these revolve around the dollar.

column1: Remember that the dollar is both the global reserve currency and a fiat currency.
column2: That first means that since the end of the Second World War, all of the world's international transactions and business have been settled in dollars, even when they're between two entirely different countries.&nbsp
column3: This has given us a freedom from the kind of worry with which other nations must contend in terms of their currency's strength and has made international business that much easier.&nbsp
column4: There have been other global reserve currencies throughout history, such as the English Pound and the Roman Denarii and what also tends to accompany a global reserve status is military power.&nbsp
column5: In the other cases, think of the Royal Navy and the Roman Legions.&nbsp

column1: What a fiat currency means literally is there is nothing backing the currency except for the user's faith (the latin fiat) that the money has any value.
column2: There's neither gold nor silver nor any other natural resource backing the dollar, except perhaps for the American taxpayer.&nbsp
column3: Literally, what gives the dollar value is the belief amongst the rest of the world in that phrase on the buck backed by the full faith and credit.
column4: These words have been on the dollar for a long time, certainly longer than we've had a $14+ trillion national debt and annual deficits in excess of $1.2 trillion, and because we Americans generally suck at math, the rest of the world has already figured out what we're now starting to understand:&nbsp
column5: how in the hell do we actually pay this back, 'cause God knows we can't agree on where to cut anything without upsetting somebody.

column1: What's now apparent to the world is that the US Federal Reserve plans to handle this nominal debt load by repayment with greatly depreciated dollars and since they're giving us stuff like oil for what they consider to literally be worthless promises, they're all starting to look around for the exits so that they're not left holding a flaming bag of horsepuckey.
column2: This is where the BRICS come into play as they are growing national economies with abundant natural resources, whether it's oil (Russia and now Brazil), gold (China and South Africa), minerals (South Africa, China, Brazil, Russia, India) or people (China and India).&nbsp
column3: They don't want to give away their resources for flaming bags of horsepuckey and they've also come to realize that because they collectively hold so many dollars and US Treasury bonds in their foreign exchange reserves, any sudden moves that tank the dollar will literally wipe out their foreign exchange reserves in a heartbeat.&nbsp

column2: Their response, provided last week, is to stop settling their mutual transactions with dollars.&nbsp
column3: If China buys oil from Russia, the transaction will be settled in Rubles and Yuan instead of dollars.&nbsp
column4: When Brazil sends raw materials to China, the transaction will be settled in Reales or Yuan.&nbsp
column5: Because these five nations are going to account for an increasing share of the global economy in the next twenty years - and China is expected to overtake the US as the lead economy in about fifteen years - the defacto effect is to grow their way out and render the dollar meaningless.&nbsp
column6: It's akin to a half-drowned and freezing Kate Winslet telling Leo DeCaprio I love you and I'll never let you go...as she lets go and he begins his slow descent to sleep with the fishes.
column7: As this occurs, expect other nations to begin settling their debt in other currencies until the US is left having to settle debts in other currencies as well
column8: the painful moment will occur when the oil producing nations no longer settle oil transactions in dollars, at which point we'll truly be in a world of hurt.

column1: Remember that capital is the blood flowing through the global economic body.
column2: What doesn't receive blood withers, and those entities that can't obtain capital wither likewise.&nbsp
column3: But what scientists have understood for quite some time is that when there's a blockage that prevents the efficient flow of blood in the body, the body can respond by creating capillaries and routes to bypass the area and deliver the blood.&nbsp
column4: In effect, this plan by the BRICS is precisely that:&nbsp
column5: the creation of new financial capillaries to assure that capital flows to the remainder of the global economic body.

column1: While you can become angry with the nasty furriners for their tricky ways, the reality is that they're doing what they must to protect themselves from our own foolishness.
column2: We've permitted our government to live far, far beyond our means and we've sat back while the Federal Reserve System - which is actually owned by the banks and not the government - has been allowed to flood the world with dollars that are increasingly worthless.
column3: Indeed, what's the point of having a signed Babe Ruth card if all that Babe did in his retirement was sign cards like bankers signing foreclosure documents - quickly and in volume?&nbsp
column4: Everybody has one and you might as well clip it to your bicycle spokes.

column1: So what does this mean for us?
<li>In the next number of years, expect that inflation really does take hold.&nbsp
column2: Oil, and all things oil-related, will rise.&nbsp
column3: Likewise with other products, such as clothing made from cotton, leather products, metals and all the way down the line.&nbsp
column4: This will also be the case for food.

column1: • Don't look for any serious rises in wages since we're going to be competing with lower cost labor in these other countries, and there is alot of labor there.
<li>We have to seriously review how we travel and our mobility.&nbsp
column2: At this moment, we're paying just below $4/gallon and Europe is paying the equivalent of $9/gallon and even if we get a handle on our use, the cost will rise significantly still.

column1: <li>As our dollar decreases, and we have to pay higher interest rates to attract lenders, government spending will be so taken up by interest payments that there will be no choice but a significant retrenchment of government spending.&nbsp
column2: We'll have to fully redefine the social contract amongst the various interest groups and decide what we can and cannot afford.&nbsp
column3: Regardless of what you think of Paul Ryan, his recent budget plan is a first crack at this nut.

column1: <li>We'll have to rethink our consumption based economy model.&nbsp
column2: Do we really need to spend this for something in order to be happy?&nbsp
column3: Is there something besides stuff that gives us meaning?&nbsp

column1: • We'll have to reconsider the meaning of the term middle class.
column2: I increasingly think that we've lost sight of the real meaning of the term and have simplistically equated it with consumption and the ability to consume.

column1: <li>We'll have to review our currency and our monetary authority, the Federal Reserve System.&nbsp
column2: Should we place something as crucial as the nation's monetary policy and supply in the hands of a privately-owned body such as the Fed?&nbsp
column3: (And if you wonder, think about a good part of what's gotten us here in the first place).

column1: There are a massive number of issues to consider, so many that the body politic is going to truly undergo a shock in the next number of years.
column2: The changes will be serious and frequent enough that the American family is going to be buffeted as it hasn't been since the years of the Great Depression, so hang on and put on your helmet.

Now that tax day is just past us, the word is out that fully 45% of all Americans don't pay any taxes and unfortunately, this household isn't part of that happy minority.
column2: I mention this because like other topics, I wonder just how I should characterize it when I mention it to the kids because how we view them is often a microcosm of how we view society and our role in it.

column1:
421,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There's been much written in the financial and economic blogs about the prospect of inflation and it's effect upon the American middle class, and much of it is angst-ridden and full of doom.
column2: But prices are trending upwards for food - I track a marketbasket of 46 different grocery items - and it helps to keep some sense of perspective.
column3: That having been said, I read Michael Deane's view of food inflation in the <a title=""SFGate"" href=""http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/04/18/investopedia51782.DTL&amp
column4: ao=all"">SFGate and while I appreciate the attempt to place it in perspective, it misses the practical point.

column1: According to Deane, and he's technically correct, food prices aren't the boogeyman issue since Americans spend far less for food - as a percentage of income - than in most other areas of the world.
column2: There are some regions where food accounts for upwards of 40 - 50% of the family's budget, far higher than what an American family typically pays.&nbsp
column3: Reading Deane's article, the sense is that some prices will rise, but they aren't the cause for concern since we can always rejigger what we presently purchase.&nbsp
column4: Besides, there's so much more that we can conceivably handle given the little that we comparatively pay already.&nbsp
column5: But he views the issue too narrowly.

column1: • We've built a highly complex economic system - almost chaotic in the scientific sense - in which things are connected in an intricate web.
column2: Why does something which occurs in Fukushima have a bearing on next year's homeowner's insurance rates?&nbsp
column3: Foodstuffs are woven into the web and the disgruntled Arab student waving his arms in Saudi Arabia most definitely creates a breeze in the bread aisle.&nbsp
column4: What is affected elsewhere will probably find its way into the food arena.

column1: <li>Many Americans, particularly parents, are scared because they understand that the average income is flat at best and the economic future for our children is not as good as it was for future generations.&nbsp
column2: This means that there isn't likely to be as much to go around to cover a familly's budget.

column1: <li>Deane's article states that inflation is expected to be at 2%, but expected by whom?&nbsp
column2: In November, 2010 I began to track the cost of food at the retail grocer level via the PracticalDad Price Index, which had a marketbasket cost of $178.39.
column3: By January, 2011 the marketbasket cost had risen to $179.38 and by April 1, the price index rose further to a cost of $181.91.
column4: On a year-to-date basis of January to April, this is an increase of $2.53, or 1.41%.&nbsp
column5: Annualize this and we're at a food inflation rate of 5.64%, almost 3 times what's &quot
column6: expected&quot
column7: .&nbsp
column8: This is hard data drawn from a survey of three independent and unrelated grocery stores.

column1: <li>Let's apply this inflation rate to real-life for the more than 44 million Americans enrolled in the federal SNAP (formerly Food Stamp) program.&nbsp
column2: The average monthly SNAP benefit was $133.79.
column3: Since the rate of inflation compounds - it builds upon the previous year - the effect would appear like this.

column1: <caption>Effect of Constant 5.64% Inflation Upon Average SNAP Monthly Benefits</caption>

<li>The effect of only a 5.64% inflation rate upon the SNAP benefits shows that by the end of five years, the average person would only be able to purchase what can be bought now for about $102, or a full quarter less.&nbsp
column2: Critics can contend that this is a static analysis since SNAP benefits will certainly increase, so &quot
column3: it won't be so bad...&quot
column4: but consider that the government benefit increases are based upon the Consumer Price Index, which is reported exclusive of food and fuel.&nbsp
column5: Any increases based upon CPI will certainly increase the monthly benefits but at a far lower rate than that of actual food inflation.&nbsp
column6: Consider what's going through the minds of people who don't yet qualify for these benefits and have children.

column1: <li>Inflation is not only a monetary phenomenon but also a psychological one, and fear feeds into that.&nbsp
column2: You can't fund the necessary and useful projects if everyone is spending their dollars on food and items now for fear of what it will cost a month, week or day in the future.
column3: Like the old fable, our society changes from the proverbial ants preparing for the future to the grasshoppers that live in the moment and are reduced to penury for having eaten everything.

column1: • We're a society that's been programmed for more than three generations to consume and our economy is now composed of about 70% end-stage consumption spending.
column2: Individuals and families will be faced with far harder choices than our grandparents and as spending from flat family incomes shifts back to food, there will be a significant downward effect upon the national economy. And frankly, we have to now push the process of rethinking consumption and in the era of HSN and QVC, that will be no small feat.

column1: So while we're in good shape relative to a family in Kenya or Mumbai, the problem is that we aren't in Kenya or Mumbai.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1: According to a brief news report,
column2: sec=topStories&amp
column3: pos=3&amp
column4: asset=&amp
column5: ccode="">they are.
column6: McDonald's executives, those responsible for more than 32000 restaurants globally and 14000 in the US alone, now acknowledge that rising prices for beef, dairy and other products are squeezing their margins and have updated their own inflation forecast to 4 - 4.5% in the US and Europe alone.&nbsp
column7: Their problem is in figuring out how can pass the price increases along to a customer base that they also acknowledge to be squeezed, particularly when one of their key demographics is the young male - you know, the guy whose age bracket is presently afflicted with an unemployment rate of more than 18% and the worst in more than 60 years of recordkeeping.&nbsp

column1: This is more in keeping with what the PracticalDad Price Index has seen through six months of existence, with ground beef increasing 10% at the retail grocer level and bread products rising about 8%.
column2: The buns - bread products - will be particularly affected by oil prices, but not for the reason that might be suspected.&nbsp
column3: Apart from the cost of transportation to get everything to the various locations, the baked products all contain some elements of vegetable oils.&nbsp
column4: These oils are sensitive to oil prices as the biofuel manufacturers use these as an offset to oil, so that more of the vegetable oils are purchased when oil rises.&nbsp
column5: Dairy costs are being passed along to teh corporation instead of teh consumer however, because milk prices are set at the retail level and cannot be apssed along.&nbsp
column6: There will come a point however, when the dairy producers scream loud enough about their input costs that the milk board will finally have to pass that along to the retail shopper and that particular product will rise as well.

column1: Other restaurant chains, such as Yum's Chipotle Mexican Restaurant, are likewise seeing their wholesale costs rise but haven't been as successful at controlling them as their peers at McDonald's who apparently differ in that McD's will work hard to keep the prices down.
column2: We'll see.

column1: In the meantime, you might as well supersize while you can still afford it.

column1:
424,"1","1",,"xhtml","

I flipped on my browser window and the Yahoo newspage appeared with the apocalyptic statement that America would be overtaken by China by 2016 and that the American age was finished.
column2: Honestly, who's surprised at this?&nbsp
column3: They're a nation of more than 1 billion people with a state controlled capitalistic system with two goals - to provide employment for more people than I can ever possibly count before I die and to overtake the United States to become the dominant global power and redress centuries of political impotence.&nbsp
column4: Us?&nbsp
column5: Well, not so much.&nbsp
column6: The realization of this happening has colored my thinking for years and has had some bearing on dealing with the kids, who will be making a living in a far more competitive world than either my father or I.&nbsp
column7: What can I do so that they're not surprised as many of their generation will be?

column1: The reality is now clear after several years of a collapsing housing bubble and out-of-control public spending and debt.
column2: The standard of living will decline and the competition for gainful, sustainable employment will only get harder.&nbsp
column3: What have I talked about and tried to inculcate with the kids?

column1: <li>First, make them aware of the evolving situation by sharing news and even some of what I've written with them.&nbsp
column2: They're now conversant with the issue of college debt and are aware that it will follow them
column3: they're also aware that while we've saved for college, we aren't going to render ourselves destitute to&nbsp
column4: educate them.&nbsp
column5: They're not on their own, but a significant amount is up to them and their efforts.

column1: <li>Second, talk about current events with them.&nbsp
column2: Make sure that they're aware of the outside world, even if you turn off their electronics to read something to them.&nbsp
column3: That also means that I have to take the time to answer their questions and explain things.&nbsp
column4: The questions might come later instead of at that moment, so I make it a point to discuss things when they raise them.

column1: <li>Third, hold them accountable for their grades.&nbsp
column2: Even if they don't think that grades matter in the real world, grades are &quot
column3: the coin of the realm&quot
column4: for determining future paths and present activities.&nbsp
column5: Activities can be stopped if the grades aren't maintained and truthfully, things have occasionally gotten nasty when grades have turned south for stupid reasons.

column1: • Fourth, be frank with them about their strengths and weaknesses as they get older. When they were younger, I praised them for attributes and traits - you're really smart, etc. - but changed to praising them for their actions
column2: so that the reinforcement pertains to their good actions.&nbsp
column3: After practicing baseball with Youngest one evening, I complimented him on his drive to repeat something until he got it right instead of heaping blanket praise about being a good ballplayer.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, make certain that they know when they've screwed up.&nbsp
column5: Sometimes, things happen but sometimes things happen because of our own failures and screwups.

column1: <li style=""text-align: justify"">Fifth, help them to learn the difference between want and need.&nbsp
column2: This is purposefully blurred by the media and corporations but it will have to be relearned as money tightens.&nbsp
column3: For example, Youngest has his baseball pictures this weekend and while we'll buy some shots, I refused to order a bobblehead with his face imprinted on it on the grounds that it was simply crap.&nbsp
column4: <em>Son, in four years it will be sitting in the Goodwill bin and even they won't take it because it's got your face on it.&nbsp
column5: Assuming it even survives four years.

column1: <li style=""text-align: justify"">Sixth, help them to develop both moral and political beliefs.&nbsp
column2: We spend our time trying to teach morality, but the flip side of the issue is that our youngsters are largely illiterate about history and politics and that's the death knell of a civic nation.&nbsp
column3: I don't need them to vote or believe the same thing that I do, but I do challenge them with what do you think about this?
column4: One is growing up to be fairly conservative while the younger sibling is a budding labor organizer and political radical.&nbsp
column5: More power to them, whatever they believe.

column1: <li style=""text-align: justify"">Seventh, be sure to take the time to talk with them.&nbsp
column2: Chat with them, explain things to them, challenge them.&nbsp
column3: Even if you think that they've tuned out, they're still listening and you'll recognize that in the oddest moments.&nbsp

column1: There's no question that our nation will take economic second place to China within the next number of years.
column2: While bad news sells and our media tendency is to overstate things, there will be major economic and financial changes and no change occurs without pain.&nbsp
column3: The competition will be fierce and there'll be real and significant adjustment to our way of life.&nbsp
column4:
The best that we can do is to recognize it and pave the way beforehand so that they aren't blindsided.

column1:
425,"1","1",,"xhtml","

When times are tough, people get back to reality and again begin debating the value and merit of ideas and institutions and boy, are people starting to debate whether higher education in its present form is still worthwhile.
column2: Given the cost, relative to income, and especially the non-dischargeable nature of the student debt, it's a legitimate debate and one which I have in my own house.&nbsp
column3: Thus far, we've raised the kids with the idea that they'll be attending college.&nbsp
column4: The high school/college graduate income levels are clearly skewed to the college side and with middle-class American jobs steadily being eroded, we've been clear that this is a necessity.&nbsp
column5: But in the past two years, I've begun to question whether that college education has to happen immediately after high school or whether it should wait for a few years.&nbsp
column6: Is the degree itself the issue, or the classic out-of-high-school means in which it's obtained?

column1: Nobody - and I mean nobody - can say with certainty how the economy and job picture is ultimately going to shake out.
column2: Will wages drop enough to make a manufacturing renaissance so that there's a huge demand for machinists and skilled craftsmen?&nbsp
column3: Will things stabilize so that we remain in a permanently stuck service economy?&nbsp
column4: What stays with my wife and I is that there is value in education, enough that a meaningful degree is worth the time and effort to obtain it.&nbsp
column5: The trick is to assure that it's meaningful and obtained in a way that doesn't bankrupt anybody.

column1: In the New York Magazine article, certain points stand out.
column2: Clearly, there's a lifetime&nbsp
column3: income disparity between high school and college graduates but it honestly never occurred to me to consider the impact of college debt weighing upon that college income.&nbsp
column4: Given that, I decided to play with some numbers.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: If you research the average starting salary of a college graduate, the median income of a 2010 college graduate with a job related to their major was $35000 and the median income for someone with a non-related job was only $25000.
column7: With the average college graduate coming out with student debt of $24,000
column8: and a typical repayment term of ten years at the Stafford loan rate of 6.8%, the monthly nut is about $276
column9: according to federal debt/income ratios, this requires a minimum salary of $33,000 and is thus manageable for someone with a $35000 income.&nbsp
column10: Understand that the lesser wage of $25000 is specified as hourly.&nbsp
column11: According to the Heldrich study from Rutgers, after one year out of college, only 53% are employed full-time with 14% in graduate school, 2% in the military and the remainder either unemployed or cobbling together what they can.

column1: While I researched for this, there were any number of 2010 newspaper articles talking about how the average job offer for the 2010 graduate was around $50000 with
column2: the unspoken upshot&nbsp
column3: that things were actually quite rosy.&nbsp
column4: Just remember however, that there's a difference between median and mean and a few truly high-paying jobs can pull the mean (average) up and away from the median, which is where the average junior Joe Six-Pack is going to be.

column1: So where does that leave us, apart from having a disheartened adolescent in the house?
<li>As always, talk with the kids as they age about the mundane reality of personal finance.&nbsp
column2: Want a car?&nbsp
column3: What's going to happen with auto insurance and gas?&nbsp
column4: How much is spent on&nbsp
column5: housing and the ancillary costs, such as utilities?&nbsp
column6: How is health insurance handled?&nbsp
column7: What's this budgeting thingy and why doesn't it consist solely of electronic equipment upgrades?

column1: <li>Step back and take an honest appraisal whether Junior is actually ready for college.&nbsp
column2: While the long-term benefits of college still accrue in terms of overall wage, the stats above show that the short-term pain is significant and could have a long-term impact.&nbsp
column3: Have you talked with Junior enough that there's some semblance of a plan or is this just going to be the general-education-for-two-years-and-hopefully-figure-something-out-by-Junior-year approach?&nbsp
column4: If the latter, there's no shame in discussing whether to work for two years while Junior makes some decisions based upon the reality of the working world.&nbsp
column5: Honestly, the two summers that I spent pouring concrete were significant in recognizing that I wanted a college degree.
column6: Besides, the only temporal restriction upon money stored in a 529 plan is that it's used by age 25 and not upon starting to use by age 19.&nbsp

column2: While the kid might be 18 years of age, most at that age do not have the experience and knowledge base to help them figure out where to turn.&nbsp
column3: By the time that you're into your thirties however, you have a much better sense of where to go and with whom to talk to gather the information for a workable plan.&nbsp
column4: Also speak&nbsp
column5: honestly with them about whether their alternatives make sense.&nbsp
column6: When Eldest was in for her annual physical, the doctor inquired about what she was thinking for adulthood and when she responded in general terms, the physician agreed that that was workable given her grades and skills
column7: I was surprised by the doctor's subsequent comment that the plan for many teens to whom she talked took the path of professional sports and endorsements.&nbsp
column8: If that's the case, then there are parents screwing up somewhere.

column2: plan&quot
column3: doesn't have to be set in stone with six month bullet points (although it would be lovely were it true) and can change as the need arises.&nbsp
column4: What matters is that there's a workable path to a rational destination.&nbsp
column5: It's also helpful to provide a little perspective from someone who's further down the lifepath than someone who's at the beginning and scratching their head.

column1: There are no easy answers in an economy that's presently shifting gears from one model to another.
column2: Change can entail significant pain and the unfortunate reality is that our young adults are among the ones suffering the pain, but the pain can be minimized with some clear thinking, time and perspective.&nbsp
column3: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
426,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The Wall Street Journal is not the place that I'd expect to find an article detailing the challenges of a baby to a marriage, Andrea Petersen's article is a good synopsis of the impact that children can have on a marriage.
column2: My question however, why is this surprising?&nbsp
column3: What has changed in our society that we now think that it's not a challenge and considerable work to raise children?
column4: Ms. Petersen does a good job of explaining the difficulties and providing some&nbsp
column5: tips on handling interpersonal issues, but it doesn't go to the deeper issue.

column2: I'm the father of three and have been home with them since Eldest's birth, and I'll attest to the fact that they are work and can create considerable stress.&nbsp
column3: The nature of that work changes as they age with the physically intensive, demanding activities occurring when they're very young.&nbsp
column4: They grow and learn and can start handling more of the physical aspects themselves but the work becomes more intuitive and cerebral as they enter the world and begin to interact with other children and the remainder of society.&nbsp
column5: Accountancy can be as tiring as digging ditches, just in a different way.&nbsp
column6: Children can be great sources of joy, but that joy sometimes comes with considerable effort.

column1: Why are we surprised at this simple reality of nature?
<li>Caring for babies and raising children is not only a physically demanding job, but one that entails considerable mental stress, especially in families where both parents are working.&nbsp
column2: <em>Who's going to get Junior from daycare?&nbsp
column3: I've got to get this laundry folded and put away, assure that dinner's cooked and that's <u>after</u> I spend time playing with Junior.&nbsp
column4: People sometimes forget that play is an integral part of the parent's job that provides tremendous value to the child's development and that it really is part of their parental job.
column5: The juggling can be stressful and requires constant vigilance to assure that things don't fall apart.&nbsp
column6: This juggling is made more difficult by the fact that you're dealing with children who simply don't see reality or think like adults with several decades of experience.&nbsp
column7: Stress can come from having to be somewhere and the small child decides to pitch a tantrum because the socks don't feel right or doesn't want to turn off the television program.&nbsp
column8: And I say this from not having to worry about covering multiple children along with a job.

column1: <li>Media bombards us with images showing the glossy images of&nbsp
column2: children playing with parents, neat houses and happy families sitting down to mealtimes.&nbsp
column3: These are superficial however, since they don't show the laundry being ignored while Mom plays Chutes and Ladders, the constant picking up of toys and strewn clothing, and the time spent cooking the meals for those happy mealtimes.
column4: There's much work involved in running the household and managing the family and this isn't shown anywhere apart from commercials for cleaning items.&nbsp
column5: One of my complaints about shows such as Supernanny is that the disciplinary interventions are briefly discussed in the alloted timeframe and then there might be brief clips showing the parents putting them to use.
column6: The reality of discipline however, is that it can take a long, long time to train the child to stay in the timeout spot as children will test the parent repeatedly.&nbsp
column7: They certainly don't show the desperate, often emotionally exhausted parent overcoming the urge to strangle the child.

column2: only do we tend to fall for the images in the media, but we've&nbsp
column3: been sold shallow definitions of home and family.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: In a society that prizes time management and quick gratification, we've forgotten that a home isn't a physical thing or place.&nbsp
column7: A home is a sense, a belief and a feeling.&nbsp
column8: It arises from our cumulative actions and attitudes instead of the workmanship of the carpenters and plumbers that completed the structure.&nbsp
column10: structure from the elements but we take that structure and create a home in which to raise our children.&nbsp
column14: the modern notion that a family&nbsp
column15: can consist of more than two parents and biologically related children, then a family is&nbsp
column17: is truly crafted and not just thrown together pell mell.

column2: American marriages in the past two generations, many of today's young parents simply don't have a template&nbsp
column3: upon which to model what's involved in making a home and&nbsp
column4: marriage work.&nbsp
column5: Women do have a&nbsp
column6: biological nesting&nbsp
column7: instinct that, in a sense, predisposes them to understand what's involved but many&nbsp
column8: men simply don't have that.&nbsp
column10: Since most children stayed with the separated and divorced mom, daughters had a model upon which to base their own home and household experience.&nbsp
column13: involved, active father figure upon which to model their own efforts and are, as a group, struggling to find themselves.&nbsp
column16: people don't recognize that enough factors have come together&nbsp
column18: difficult to be a young and involved&nbsp

column1: <li>While Americans work hard, we live in a leisure based society and that breeds self-absorption.&nbsp
column2: It took me awhile to understand that there's a First Law of Fatherhood and that's that it's no longer about me, but about these children that depend upon my wife and I for their survival and upbringing.
column3: It's a mindset that takes some work to adopt and there are still moments when I'd like to pack a bag and catch a train to New York for the weekend, but that means that the responsibilities to wife and kids are uncovered.&nbsp
column4: I can still take an occasional getaway by myself, but that's only after working through the logistics ahead of time.

column1: For everything that I've just written, please don't think that I resent the kids.
column2: They are a blessing and I simply cannot conceive of a life without their presence for what they bring to me.&nbsp
column3: But there is a realistic understanding that's come about from&nbsp
column4: considerable effort and work, much of which was generated by these blessings.

The PracticalDad Price Index (PDPI) rose slightly in May to 102.08 as both coffee and canola oil - a cooking oil akin to vegetable oil - posted gains of 7.2% and 4.9% respectively from April.
column2: While these items had significant gains, the PDPI only&nbsp
column3: increased slightly from April's 101.97 due to&nbsp
column4: offsetting price decreases in&nbsp
column5: several items.&nbsp
column6: This constitutes a 2.08%&nbsp
column7: rise in the 46 item food basket since its inception in November of 2010.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column1: <li>The coffee increases were purely in price&nbsp
column2: alone with no&nbsp
column3: stealth inflationary practices of holding price
column4: constant while decreasing package sizing.

column1: <li>Canola oil rose again on the back of increased demand&nbsp
column2: from&nbsp
column3: biofuel&nbsp
column4: producers as the cost of crude oil&nbsp
column5: remains high.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Canola oil is used in baked products and since&nbsp
column8: crude oil began to rise, the price of&nbsp
column9: bread/rolls has risen more than 8% since November
column11: products had no price changes this month, however.&nbsp

column1: <li>Flour continued flat while sugar, a commodity which has&nbsp
column2: risen in cost in&nbsp
column3: raw form, showed it's first sign of change with a small increase of 1.9%.&nbsp
column4: If sugar continues to rise, expect to see price increases in corollary&nbsp
column5: food products containing sugar, such as the store brand&nbsp
column6: &quot
column7: Frosted Flake&quot
column8: item.&nbsp

column2: of 3.8% as one store raised price while maintaining the package sizing.

column1: • Store brand hot dogs rose 4%, the first bump in that product since the index inception in November.
<li>The per pound cost of a roaster chicken rose 1.9% while the cost of eggs jumped 8.8%.&nbsp
column2: Eggs have fluctuated in price however and are still below the high of $2.01/dozen in December, 2010 while the per pound cost is also below the high reached in February, 2011.&nbsp

column1: <li>The cost of a box of trash bags dropped by 8.5% with decreases noted in two of the stores.&nbsp
column2: In the past several months, I've noticed that these two stores have introduced ultra-low cost household products into their stores.&nbsp
column3: These are typically the types of items that could be purchased in stores such as Dollar Tree or Dollar General and it could be that the grocery stores have introduced the lines to retain the customers who might otherwise take those purchases to the dollar stores.&nbsp
column4: In this case however, the bags continue to be store brand as they were before so it's possible that they've found new, cheaper producers for their products.

column1:
429,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With the average gas price now at $3.99/gallon and the average monthly gasoline bill at $368, families are starting to have to consider how to handle driving and this family is really no different.
column2: But there are some things that are beyond our control, such as driving to work and getting to various activities.&nbsp
column3: Today was one of those examples.

column1: All three kids are in different sports - soccer, volleyball and baseball - and for the first time in years, the soccer field is within two miles of the house.
column2: Volleyball is at the high school, also near the house.&nbsp
column3: Baseball however, is played by the local Little League at practice and game fields located all over Hell and half of Georgia and there are no fields within even a relatively close distance and there's no option but to drive.&nbsp
column4: Today's situation arose as Eldest had a friend spend the night and our understanding was that the friend would come along to the game with us and we'd return her home afterwards.&nbsp
column5: With a half hour drive to get to the field, we needed to leave at noon and at 11:55 AM, we found that the friend had to be home at noon.&nbsp
column6: Despite Eldest's insistence that we could just drop her off and then go to the game, it was necessary for me to leave first with Youngest for the game while Eldest and my wife took the friend home and then to the game separately.&nbsp
column7: We were consequently forced to use two cars to get to a single event when one would have been sufficient with decent planning.&nbsp
column8: This has now been hammered into Eldest's head.

column1: It's ironic that Eldest has begun her driving career as I began mine - at a time of high gas prices.
column2: She was surprised to find that I filled up my tank the other day for $95 and it was reminiscent of my reaction when I found what my own father paid for a full tank in 1979.&nbsp
column3: But she and her peers haven't seemed to have caught on to some of the rules by which we played in the late 1970s.&nbsp
column4: The first rule is that if someone is driving someplace, it's appropriate for members of the party to help chip in for the gas.&nbsp
column5: The second rule is that people don't drive separately when carpooling is available.&nbsp
column6: It wasn't uncommon for someone to volunteer to drive and then pick up others.&nbsp
column7: These simple rules are ones that she and her peers will have to take to heart.

column1: So what else will we try to do to keep things under control and below $368 a month?
<li>Have more explicit conversations about details before making a final decision, such as the exact time a friend needs to be home.&nbsp
column2: A few extra questions would have saved an extra car trip to the baseball game.

column1: <li>Send the kids on bikes or walk more often to local, around-town errands or destinations.&nbsp
column2: My mother recently gave me a pull cart with which to pull bags of groceries and this week, I'll start using it to walk to the local grocery for food and milk.

column1: <li>Decide whether certain trips even need to be made and if so, whether there's alternative means.&nbsp
column2: Carpooling, maybe even buses?&nbsp
column3: Although to be honest, our area is not terribly well served by public transportation.

column1: <li>Once Eldest actually has a regular paying job, decide whether she'll become responsible for the gas for the car.&nbsp
column2: At this point, she's wrapped up in schoolwork and volunteering and doesn't have the money for $95 in a gas tank.

column1: Gas prices have gone up and down through the past thirty years.
column2: But with the question of peak oil and the stagnant American family income, I'm doubtful that it's going to be coming down again anytime soon so we'll have to think through the scenarios and adjust accordingly.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
430,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As the kids age and want more financial independence - but are still bound by child labor laws and a slack summer labor market - how much should a parent participate?
column2: Each of our kids receives an allowance, commensurate with age.&nbsp
column3: But they also want more as they age and that doesn't mean that we're just going to fork over more dollars, so how do we handle it given the parameters outlined?&nbsp

column2: fortunate&quot
column3: to live in a house with an exceptionally&nbsp
column4: demanding yard.&nbsp
column5: Frankly, I've never bought a house with yardwork in mind but if I knew then what I know now, I'd have thought twice about agreeing with my wife about purchasing it.&nbsp
column6: The previous owner was a gardening fanatic who did exquisite work, especially with the heavily sloped backyard.&nbsp
column7: Unfortunately, he spent all of his time on the yard and with three active kids, that simply hasn't been the case here.&nbsp
column8: The back was filled with a runner ivy that has simply overwhelmed and choked out everything and things are officially a mess.&nbsp
column9: While hiring a lawn service to handle the&nbsp
column10: yard and keep the back under control would be the easiest alternative, it's also the most expensive and one that teaches the worst possible lesson to the kids - that unpleasant tasks can be farmed out to someone else and that money solves everything.&nbsp
column11: In a country whose economy is changing and income stagnating, it's the worst possible lesson of all.

column1: In this case then, I decided to hire the kids to work alongside me.
column2: From a conversation with friends this weekend, they thought that I was nuts since it was something for which they would clearly expect the kids to help.&nbsp
column3: In their view, such projects are part and parcel of the family and home life, where if you want something nice, then you have to help keep it that way.&nbsp
column4: While I appreciate the view, there's something about the scope of this project that takes it into a different category.&nbsp
column5: There are other aspects that led me to propose payment.

column1: • If the kids want some extra money but I don't want to just shell it out, then they can earn money through hard work.
<li>The work will be done regardless, and the amount that they earn is a function of how much time that they're willing to put in on the project.&nbsp
column2: They want more, then they earn it and learn that pay depends upon performance.

column1: <li>I'm still saving money on the deal.&nbsp
column2: When we had someone lay mulch three years ago, it cost almost $2000 and took three grown men two full days to just lay the mulch and didn't even touch tearing out the existing foliage.

column1: <li>This is a project and there will be a semblance of order to it, from start to finish.&nbsp
column2: It's important for the kids to see that there's a method to doing something apart from just arbitrary tasks such as emptying trash and mowing the lawn.&nbsp
column3: This will also be a learning experience, much as Eldest's work to refurbish the god-forsaken fish pond that abuts the back deck
column4: it needs some annual maintenance but the savings from her tackling it - and while we did it together, she did the lion's share - were in the range of about $3500.

column1: <li>Holding payment over their heads helps to keep me in the position of &quot
column2: boss&quot
column3: .&nbsp
column4: Kids can and will become a bit contemptuous and shifting myself temporarily from father to boss will cut down on the backtalk and argument.&nbsp
column5: <em>This is why I'm doing this but if you really disagree, then don't get paid.&nbsp
column6: That's life, kid.

column1: This is going to be a major project and will entail a significant amount of work.
column2:
It isn't going to be cheap but it will be far, far less than if I'd hired an outsider to do the job and frankly, if the money is going somewhere, I'd rather that it stay within the family.
