column1:
431,"1","1",,"xhtml","

If there's anything that gives me heartburn, it's the concern about the choices that the kids make for friends.
column2: It really is true what they say:&nbsp
column3: you're judged by the company that you keep and one bad apple can spoil the barrel.
column4: I used to think that it was just my own parents' old school cynicism and closed-mindedness, but I now accept it with the same faith that I acknowledge the sun's rising in the east.&nbsp
column5: How do I manage to keep tabs on who's coming in the door next and how do I somehow separate them from someone who really is a rolling, bleeding, god-awful trainwreck?

column1: Let me start by saying that over the years, I've come to believe that in many cases, the problem isn't necessarily the children so much as it is the parents.
column2: Absentee parents, lackadaisical parents, parents-who-are-trying-too-hard-to-be-buddies, no-accountability parents - there are a plethora of bad parents out there.&nbsp
column3: I'm not perfect.&nbsp
column4: I tend to crankiness and impatience and I don't suffer fools as easily as I once did.&nbsp
column5: When talking with a child's friend about why he was failing a class, the response from both child and friend was that the teacher had it out for the friend ever since his marriage went on the rocks and he couldn't find a good woman.&nbsp
column6: My&nbsp
column7: response was so let me get this straight.
column8: You're failing a class because your teacher can't get laid?
column9: For the record, both are teens and sometimes, an earthy response will cut through layers of nonsense.&nbsp
column10: Regardless, I'm witnessing any number of kids whose parents are&nbsp
column12: and I know this because my own kids are bringing them home.&nbsp
column13: It used to be that there was common ground amongst parents and most kids were raised in a manner with common values and common expectations
column14: this has degraded enough so that kids are doing things that were once considered - at best - inappropriate but they're clueless because no one has actually taken&nbsp
column15: the time or effort to teach them otherwise.

column1: So how do I work through the heartburn?
column2: After all, it only increases as they age and my ability to monitor and control correspondingly decreases.&nbsp
column3: As they age and grow, their friends do the same and they all come under the wider influences of the outside world via increased media exposure, older siblings and even families that break apart over the course of time.&nbsp

column1: <li>Listen explicitly for names and through discussion and further listening, determine who these various children are and the context in which I'm hearing about them.&nbsp
column2: Even if I don't hear their names for awhile, I'll resurrect them in conversation just to hear what's happened with them.&nbsp
column3: It's through this that I've learned who's transferred out, who's wound up in the principal's office and who's even starting to go with whom.

column1: <li>If certain names crop up repeatedly, actually find a reason to visit the class so that I can put a face with this name and take some measure of the child.&nbsp
column2: Given two particular names that I was hearing through the Fall semester, I happily agreed to join Youngest for his school lunch so that I could put faces with names and behaviors.

column1: <li>Chat with neighbors and other parents to cross-reference stories on children and teens and learn more about them.&nbsp
column2: It sounds sneaky at times, but having grown up in a small town, I guarantee that both my parents were cross-referencing with other parents to gain a better sense of who's out there.&nbsp
column3: I was passing along information to another parent the other evening.&nbsp
column4: On one level, it sounds like gossip but the reality is that we're talking about behaviors and things that have happened, which was the tenor of the most recent conversation.&nbsp
column5: Because the schools are rightfully prohibited from discussing individual student behaviors, then comparing notes with other parents is about the only other way to keep tabs.

column1: <li>Encourage the kids to bring their friends home to play so that you can put&nbsp
column2: faces to names and learn their personalities.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: Our&nbsp
column5: old house had a much larger yard with swingset that was conducive to&nbsp
column6: outdoor play but the present house has a small, sloped yard that isn't kid friendly so Youngest heads across the way to play with buddies.&nbsp
column7: Consequently, we invested in redoing the basement and it's common to have&nbsp
column8: kids spending the night on weekends.&nbsp
column9: The point is to have the kids here as much as possible in order to put a face with a name and gain some sense.

column1: <li>Take notes, especially if a child becomes a major concern.&nbsp
column2: When a child develops a friendship with someone, even a trainwreck, it's difficult to have to force a breakoff and the more ammunition that you have the easier that it'll&nbsp
column3: be.&nbsp
column4: It's easier when they're little but becomes more difficult when they age.&nbsp
column5: In one particular circumstance, I had notes documenting seven particular instances in which the particular child had either lied, wound up in the principal's office or set another child up to fail and in a spectacular fashion.&nbsp
column6: Instead of telling my kid that I don't trust this child and he's trouble, I just walked through the instances and then stated that there would be no further contact outside of school.
column7: While I expected argument, the response was muted and acknowledged since there were no arguments to counteract what were real events.&nbsp
column8: I wasn't working on gut or feelings, that kid had screwed up royally and my own could mount no defense.

column1: <li>I try to keep my own commentary about a friend as calm as possible - which can be difficult - in order to keep my own child's defensiveness under control.&nbsp
column2: There have been a very few instances where my own comments have gone over the edge but I work hard to control derogatory remarks or unpleasant remarks
column3: the point is to try to keep the lines of communication sufficiently open that I can continue to gather what facts and observations that I can.

column1: Friends play a huge role in a child's development and there's no way that I can - or should
column2: - pick all of my child's friends.&nbsp
column3: I can listen and observe and then work to help them make good choices.&nbsp
column4: I can even, on occasion, forbid further contact with someone else.&nbsp
column5: But they have to be able to learn to make good choices now and without some guidance, the odds of that happening are less than great.&nbsp

column1:
And we can't guide them when we can't see who else is out there on the horizon.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

432,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Fatherhood is frequently an exercise in living outside of your comfort zone and as kids grow, new situations keep kicking you out of the zone just when you think that you're finally in it.
column2: Much of that is due to the variety and prevalence of youth sports.&nbsp

column1: Kids want to try new things and with only a few guidelines - you start the season, you finish the season whether you like it or not - that's what we encourage.
column2: There are a wider variety of sports available now than when I was in high school and that means that more than a few fathers are on a learning curve as the nascent high school programs begin building rec league feeder programs to develop a pool of upcoming players with skills.&nbsp
column3: Those few&nbsp
column4: fathers with experience step up and help coach, both the kids and the other fathers who don't have experience.&nbsp

column1: This was the case this weekend as we trooped to a high school in another county to watch MIddle participate in a volleyball tournament at the middle school level.
column2: Because that level is only a club sport in our area, there are few teams and in this particular instance, we entered the high school gym to find that the other two teams were the individual grade teams for the host school district.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: Each was composed of the same number of boys as Middle's team while&nbsp
column5: Middle's team also includes several very talented upper elementary school boys who are already developing wicked serves.&nbsp
column6: My own previous experience was limited to smacking a ball around with neighborhood kids and in my twenties, watching female beach volleyball on ESPN.&nbsp
column7: I've at least expanded my knowledge base since - unlike with women's beach volleyball -&nbsp
column8: I'm actually watching the course of play and have managed to puzzle out certain rudiments of the game such as general positions and why net serves can actually be playable.&nbsp
column9: It's also refreshing to see the kids slap hands and buck each other up when things don't go well, a far cry from my own scholastic days of Helen Keller could've caught that pass, you dumbass.

column1: As the small cadre of families entered the gymnasium and sat down, we were able to look at the various sports history banners that decorated the walls as they do at every high school.
column2: The Boys Volleyball banner revealed that this school had championship teams back to the early 1960s, when they still had to inflate the balls with blacksmith bellows, and I wondered whether I'd have to find a local pharmacy to purchase first aid supplies for what promised to&nbsp
column3: be a ritual bloodletting.&nbsp
column4: As boys and families watched this volleyball machine run through it's clockwork drills, one father commented that they needed to start since our guys were getting psyched out watching this display of efficiency and I could only concur.&nbsp
column5: It was like&nbsp
column6: watching the visiting University of Nebraska football team warm up prior to gametime with your kid's team at Hooterville Community College.&nbsp
column7: As one&nbsp
column8: midwestern university student pep club banner once read in the early 1990s, Maintain Dignity Against Nebraska.

column1: The first game was a walkaway and a clinic for Middle's team but as play continued, gears began to mesh and actual volleys took place as players found their groove and began playing as a team.
column2: Adjustments were made after the first two games and suddenly, scores became respectable and games were actually won as the other side proved that they were middle school boys as well.&nbsp
column3: <em>Man, that girl in the third row is smokin' -&nbsp
column4: what ball?
column5: By the end of the afternoon, there was grace and fluidity on both sides of the net and as one father commented to me, you really have to watch it to appreciate and understand it.

column1: So I'll go outside the comfort zone again, as I did with basketball and baseball.
column2: I won't pretend that I can handle the physical and coaching side of the house, which is what often happens with so many sports as fathers step up to spend their evenings watching instructional videos and reading Idiot Guides.
column3: There are other opportunities to help and one of those opportunities will be filled somehow.&nbsp
column4: Rules will be learned and games dissected as happens already with soccer and baseball.&nbsp

column2: Perhaps someday, Middle will find himself helping drill rudiments into a pack of small kids, slapping their hands when they smack the ball in the direction of the net.&nbsp
column3: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
433,"1","1",,"xhtml","

In a recent speech, retiring Secretary of Defense Robert Gates noted that with significant cuts in defense spending, American influence would diminish and wane
column2: in the future.&nbsp
column3: My only response is, yep.
column4: But I'm not clear if that's such a bad thing.&nbsp

column1: Our nation has been around for 235 years, but we've only been in imperial mode for the past several decades.
column2: Our forefathers purposefully wanted us out of foreign entanglements and I've come to conclude that they were correct
column3: the only time that our forefathers were involved internationally was the Barbary War, when we fought pirate states to preserve American trade and even then, some argued that paying tribute was still cheaper than building and maintaining a navy.&nbsp
column4: Jefferson, Madison and Washington would be spinning like tops in their graves if they could see the status of our military establishment and foreign agreements.&nbsp
column5: Human nature being what it is, being #1 - woot! - places a giant target upon your back and the target has been getting rather heavy after several decades.

column1: Everybody wants to be #1 with their giant foam camoflage fingers jutting into the air, but good thing or not, the reality is that we can simply no longer afford
column2: the extensive global military establishment.&nbsp
column3: Let's be honest, the defense spending is only one - smaller - part of the fiscal picture as the bulk of the federal budget is tied up in entitlement programs that need to reworked with the social contract.&nbsp
column4: But it is still spending that begs the question, <em>do we really need this?&nbsp
column5: Do we really need forces remaining in Europe?&nbsp
column6: Do we really need bases in more than 100+ different countries?&nbsp
column7: In a far more low-tech series of opponents, do we really need the exceptionally costly, high-tech weapons systems?&nbsp
column8: What about the Chinese?&nbsp

column1: Folks, the Chinese have their own problems with which to contend.
column2: Besides, they're so busy tying up natural resource contracts globally that if we really wanted to have a war with them, we'd be borrowing barrels of oil from them within the month just to run our planes.&nbsp
column3: Think about it:&nbsp
column4: there's a decent chance that a future war would be about obtaining natural resources that would be principally used in wartime by our military.&nbsp
column5: We've had more than 35 years since the first oil crisis to recognize that we've got a problem, and we've done nothing to truly address that problem.&nbsp
column6: Sorry, but while I truly do support the military - I didn't serve since my Korean War veteran father talked me out of it - I see no reason to sacrifice our young people for oil, resources, or peacekeeping someone else's family feud.&nbsp
column7: The great majority of Americans can't recall who won Super Bowl XXXIII but there are those around the world who remember exactly who stole the family goat in 1598.&nbsp
column8: We don't need to send Mike and Austin to settle the goat feud.&nbsp

column1: A significant part of our economic problem is that we simply spend too much for foreign merchandise while they buy far less of our stuff.
column2: The balance of trade data also shows that much of our imports aren't even for the crap sold in Walmart
column3: we spend it on oil purchased from other nations.&nbsp
column4: If we were able to put significant dents in those oil purchases, that would be money that&nbsp
column5: could be used for other purposes - or even better, not spent at all.&nbsp
column6: There would be less worry about oil supply lines which would diminish the need for the overwhelming foreign involvement and&nbsp
column7: <em>voila!&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column10: There's no conceivable way that we can simply decide to cut out $1.2T without huge pain
column11: it would be akin to saying that we can lose that pesky forty pounds by simply amputating the right leg.&nbsp
column12: But there can be significant and phased changes made to actually help.&nbsp
column13: A greatly lessened dependency upon foreign energy sources would lessen the need for the military force structure.

column1: • Establish clear goals on energy usage and oil purchases.
• Determine what's required to meet those goals.
<li>We are capable of acting in the common interest if properly led.&nbsp
column2: Time is running short and any&nbsp
column3: plan would require a Manhattan Project/Apollo effort to meet the goals that steer us away from the overwhelming energy usage and subsequent dependency on foreign oil sources.&nbsp
column4: Take the money spent on&nbsp
column5: defense and put it into&nbsp
column6: energy, and projects that&nbsp
column7: are usable now.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column11: Ninety years ago, the mantra was a chicken in every pot and a car in every garage

column1: • Start now with the kids - always, always, always the kids - and begin to talk constantly about the need to both conserve and think outside the energy box.
column2: They are the ones who are going to inherit an America that's very different than that with which we were raised and the more that they hear about it, the easier time that they'll have to adjust to it.&nbsp
Our choices ahead are going to be painful as we renegotiate the social contract.&nbsp
column3: What do we owe our senior citizens and what do we owe our children?&nbsp
column4: What do we owe a generation that has been&nbsp
column5: terrible in preparing for the future and how do we wean ourselves of a consumer mentality that's akin to a locust swarm in it's willingness to devour everything?&nbsp
column6: The real money available to us is going to become very dear and if we spend too much of our wealth&nbsp
column7: maintaining what is arguably an empire, we'll be consumed by the cancer that's grown within.

column1: And for the record, Mike and Austin are real young men entering the military.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
434,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Is there a point at which it's morally correct to permit a child to take off the gloves in dealing with a bully?
The local school district teaches my children that violence isn't the answer and that it's wrong.
column2: I agree with that and teach it as well.&nbsp
column3: But the school teaches that it's so wrong, in fact, that anyone found participating in violence will be dealt with summarily and harshly.&nbsp
column4: This includes the child who didn't start the altercation, has a back against the wall and is forced to throw a punch in self-defense.&nbsp
column5: Middle once asked the elementary school guidance counselor, <em>what if I'm against the wall and being beaten?&nbsp
column6: Can I defend myself?&nbsp
column7: The counselor's response was no, yell for an adult to come help.
column8: Well, he continued, what if there's no adult around?
column10: <em>yell for an adult to come help.&nbsp
column11: Here is where we part ways since there are moments
column13: immediately available and if they are, they might not be effective in dealing with the issue.&nbsp
column14: So while I fully agree with the district that violence&nbsp
column16: addressed, and forcefully, is there ever an instance when&nbsp

column1: First, how can I say that adult aides might not be present or effective?
column2: There are certainly playground aides charged with maintaining the peace, but we've got first hand experience with playground aides simply saying stop that and then turning away as the mayhem continues.
column3: To be fair, this wasn't in this school district but at a Christian school at which playground aides would tell out-of-control boys to stop doing something and then pray for the budding axe murderers as the pain-inducing behavior continued.&nbsp
column4: The disorder led to my conversation with the principal and my wife's discussion with the teacher - whose son was one of the bullies - when some order when finally restored.

column1: The adults prayed as one of my kids was victimized, so yes, I can attest that adults might not be effective.
column2: Even in this district, there are children whose recurrent behavior is violent and disruptive, apparently resistant to school discipline.

column1: Violence should be roundly condemned, but again, is there ever an instance in which it is acceptable?
It's not an academic question for the household, especially with Youngest, whose class attracts Hell's spawn like honey draws flies.
column2: Every classroom has problem children with whom teachers and children alike have to contend, but Youngest has already had to learn to deal with a child who hired an older boy to beat him up and that was in first grade.
column3: To his credit, he managed the immediate situation&nbsp
column4: better at seven years of age better than many adults would have in similar circumstances.&nbsp
column5: But this year,&nbsp
column6: a true troublemaker not only came to Youngest's class,&nbsp
column7: he also moved into a nearby abode so that at midyear, he was not only at school, but wandering through the neighborhood and annoying all of the kids.&nbsp
column8: The child - a third grader - would simply stay at someone's house and refuse to leave and one set of parents simply let him spend the night since he refused to go home.&nbsp
column9: They were scared to deal with him and simply let him stay.&nbsp
column10: Why this didn't become a situation for social services is beyond me.&nbsp

column1: His school record was even worse and Youngest had to
column2: testify to the school administration when he heard the child make threats against other classmates, some of&nbsp
column3: those threats being&nbsp
column4: sexually aggressive.&nbsp
column5: He routinely threatened other children and even grabbed Youngest and threw him into lockers, threatening to punch him out.&nbsp
column6: At this point, Youngest's response was simply <em>go ahead and punch me.&nbsp
column7: Youngest is significantly larger than the child and the
column8: kid pulled back
column9: Youngest had no real further problems with him after that, so much so that the child began showing up after school in our driveway to shoot basketball.&nbsp

column1: It was clear that any parental oversight was minimal and we knew from another situation that he'd been locked out of his apartment with literally nowhere to go.
column2: The family line became that he could shoot hoops with Youngest if either myself or Middle - a middle schooler - was present but that he couldn't enter the house and had to adhere to family rules, such as controlling the language and it was here that he was warned off on several occasions by both Middle and myself.&nbsp
column3: After more language issues, he was warned off and I told him one night that he finally had to go.&nbsp
column4: Youngest made it clear as well that he was no longer welcome at the house and the basketball sessions ended and the most that we saw of the child was when he'd cut through the yard to go elsewhere in the neighborhood.&nbsp
column5: Since then, he'll try to chat with Middle but cusses out Youngest and insults both him and our family and he sees no conflict in this contrariness.&nbsp

column2: While I'm generally around, Youngest is now old enough that I'm comfortable leaving him for a short period to run to the grocery and it was during one of these instances that he came around the back of the house to find the bully hiding in a corner of the garage behind the sports/toy rack, which he'd been rifling.&nbsp
column3: Youngest told him to leave and he did so immediately.&nbsp
column4: When describing the situation to me upon my return, Youngest stated simply that if it happened again, he'd punch him out.&nbsp
column5: My response was a simple, curt <em>you won't have any problem with me on that.&nbsp
column6: Since then however, we've made it a point to keep the garage door closed if we're not outside and the kid has simply walked past the house.

column1: I am bothered by the response however.
column2: I believe that the school's zero tolerance is understandable, but that it ultimately breeds victims, people who spend their time searching for someone else to handle the bullies that come through.&nbsp
column3: We have the right to defend ourselves and our property and the reality is that &quot
column4: adults&quot
column5: aren't always going to be around.&nbsp
column6: The alternative however, is that this kid truly is a budding sociopath for whom there are no qualms about escalating violence with a peer and this is where I've gone back to Youngest.&nbsp
column7: Should it happen again, then call for me first and let me handle the issue.&nbsp
column8: Even if the kid takes off, I have no qualms about confronting parents and have done so before
column12: But if I'm not around, then he's clear to do what he thinks is necessary at the moment and I'll support him, even if that means that he's throwing a punch.&nbsp

column1: If it ever comes to that, I guarantee that Youngest will be painted as the villain.
column2: I also guarantee that I'll support my son to the hilt when it comes to this particular problem child.

Measuring a grocery basket of 47 items, the June PracticalDad Price Index came in at 103.18, up more than 1% from the May result of 102.08.
column2: &nbsp
column3: This&nbsp
column4: result means that the market basket's price is up more than 3% from November 2010 and is a significant acceleration from the previous months' results.&nbsp
column5: The average cost of the market basket, calculated from results surveyed at three separate grocery stores, was $184.07 and&nbsp
column6: a $5.68&nbsp
column7: increase from the original November basket cost of $178.39.

column1: Following is a synopsis of the previous monthly results.
There are several notable results from the June survey.

<li>For the first time since the survey's inception in November, 2010, the majority of the basket items with price increases had rises in excess of 5% each as about 15% of the basket items had month-to-month rises greater than 5%.&nbsp
column2: In previous months, most results were due to a few items with significant increases - coffee and canola oil, for instance - while other items had much smaller increases.&nbsp
column3: This shifted in June however and if it becomes a trend, would indicate that food inflation is shifting from an isolated phenomenon to a mainstream condition.

column1: <li>Canola oil - a cooking oil that is also used as a biofuel and thus sensitive to oil prices - increased again by 5.4% to $4.52 for a 48 oz bottle.&nbsp
column2: This is up from the November cost of $3.12 for the same size bottle, a 45% increase in 8 months.&nbsp
column3: While the typical family might use&nbsp
column4: another oil, such as corn or vegetable oil, canola oil is prevalent in the baked goods industry.&nbsp
column5: While the price of flour has been largely static since November, bread/roll costs have risen by almost 10% and this is most likely attributable to the canola oil
column6: in its production.

column1: • Coffee was unchanged for the first time since January.
• Diapers had a small increase due to stealth inflation as one grocer maintained the same price while decreasing the number of diapers per box.
<li>Kitchen trash bags increased significantly after dropping from April to May.&nbsp
column2: Prices were steady in two of the three stores, but the item cost has swung from one month&nbsp
column3: to another&nbsp
column4: in the third store.&nbsp
column5: I have gone back and verified that the correct price was surveyed at that particular supermarket each month and these prices were correct.&nbsp
column6: Even removing that particular item, there was a higher number of items with price increases greater than 5% than in any previous month and that finding holds.

More and more has been written in the past two years about the college conundrum - it's economically important, but the debtload is a killer than can easily offset the benefits - and now the word has become a meme percolating through society.
column2: There comes a point where the talk finally, slowly, takes root even amongst those who've been amongst the status quo and in this case, it's the guidance counselors.

column1: Eldest is a junior now immersed in the college search process, dutifully visiting a few schools that interest her and round-filing the hundreds of mailers and letters that come to the house.
column2: What she's noticing however, is that the guidance counselors at her school are actively talking to her peers and suggesting that perhaps the better option isn't just going off to college as their predecessors did.&nbsp
column3: The new advice is to seriously consider what you want to do and then take the lower level general education courses at the local university/community college.&nbsp
column4: This is a far cry from what I heard several decades ago - there's plenty of money out there and if you and your parents have to take some debt, it's easily repayable - and is driven by three principal factors:

column1: <li>The cost of higher education is significantly than decades ago because the rate of inflation for college tuition is about twice that of standard inflation as measured by the CPI.&nbsp

• Families no longer have the job/retirement security that they previously had, and the job market can't provide enough jobs that allow the graduate to both repay the debt and become economically independent.
• College debt is different from other forms of debt in that it can never be discharged in bankruptcy, but will follow the graduate until repayment or death.
This has now begun to dawn upon the educational establishment and they're finally passing the word along to the kids.
column2: It would be wonderful to see a Deus ex machina moment in which this reality is magically altered and the situation is simply fixed, but reality doesn't work that way.
column3: Real life works in fits and starts, veering one way and then another until a course is finally determined upon which allows progress to be made over time until a new equilibrium is reached.&nbsp
column4: But one of the key elements is that when those within a system begin to quietly influence many small changes that cumulatively determine a larger outcome, and if the guidance counselors are actually pushing this, then I draw some comfort from that.

column1: There is no magic answer to this situation as it's one has been developing for decades.
column2: We've hollowed out our economy via outsourcing.&nbsp
column3: We've ignored the long term investments in pursuit of consumption and shortterm&nbsp
column4: gratification, so there are no savings for the future.&nbsp
column5: We've permitted the financial sector to usurp control of the economic and political process to the detriment of our society.&nbsp

column1: If you don't think that that's the case,
column2: ask yourself why it's perfectly legal - and considered a good business model - to toss easy credit to young people with no experience?&nbsp
column3: Then ask why it's legal for this politically voiceless group to be the one group that is saddled with the most pernicious debt, debt that they can't escape but provides the lenders with a constant cash flow?&nbsp

column1: When the process is bought and paid for, then don't expect sudden miracles.
column2:
But take comfort in the knowledge that slowly the word is spreading, now amongst the educational establishment.

column1:
437,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Online news feeds are running frequent reports about the financial situation in Greece, which has now spilled over into the political arena.
column2: I'm watching with renewed interest&nbsp
column3: because:&nbsp
column4: (1)&nbsp
column5: we're taking the family there in three weeks, and
column6: &nbsp
column7: (2)&nbsp
column8: it's a probable preview of what's going to happen here if we don't quickly and decisively put our own house in order.&nbsp
column9: Greece, ancient birthplace of democracy, is now deciding whether people have sovereignty or must literally surrender it to a foreign central bank and financial complex.

column1: As crowds in excess of 100,000 protest before the Vouli ton Ellinon
column2: (Hellenic Parliament) in Syntagma Square and the random tear gas canister is tossed around like a hackisack, I've started monitoring the State Department website for any official travel advisory.&nbsp
column3: While we've saved and planned for this Italy/Greece trip for two years, we also purchased trip insurance with an eye toward the greek situation.&nbsp
column4: The kids are hepped for Santorini and Athens, but wafting tear gas isn't as appetizing as fresh baklava.&nbsp
column5: The second that we see a travel advisory, that portion of the trip will either be changed or abandoned and we'll fall back to the trip insurance.

column1: While not as visceral, Greece's economic predicament also causes real concern since it's a likely preview of coming attractions in this country.
column2: The MSM line is that Greece brought it's present circumstances on itself with excessively generous - and unsupportable - social benefits.&nbsp
column3: Combine that with tax evasion as a national pastime second only to soccer and there's a recipe for fiscal disaster.&nbsp
column4: Americans are used to contending with the IRS so there's no sympathy for people who avoid taxes like a vegetarian avoiding a Big Mac.&nbsp
column5: This combo was the situation when Greece was admitted to the single European currency - the Euro - in 2000 and in turn gave up their own currency, the Drachma.&nbsp

column1: This move promised benefits, but came at a price.
column2: Member European nations had to agree to controlling both&nbsp
column3: their inflation rates and their national debt load as a percentage of their respective GDP.&nbsp
column4: While this wasn't a problem for the Northern European countries, it was understood that the PIGS in the south (Portugal, Italy, Greece, Spain) would have their work cut out for them.&nbsp
column5: Unfortunately, not only did the Greeks not meet their requirements, but it then became known that they engaged in sophisticated currency manuevers with Goldman Sachs to hide the amount of debt owed.&nbsp
column6: Their national debt was several times higher than had been previously reported, thanks to the GS folks.&nbsp
column7: For a better illustration, picture GS as the guys who worked with a contestant on The Biggest Loser to rig the scale, so that the winner only lost 100 pounds instead of the 225 previously reported.
column8: Big eaters that they are, the Germans were truly torqued.

column1: As global business slowed in 2008, the Greeks were caught in a bind.
column2: Their spending required more foreign loans but the lenders were in too deep to take any further chances and this subsequently shifted the focus from private foreign bank lenders, who were as holed as their American counterparts, to the European nations and the European Central Bank.&nbsp
column3: The present riots&nbsp
column4: are because the common Greek now sees their&nbsp
column5: personal and sovereign futures as hostage to the whims of the monied minority, the plutocracy.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: The lenders want to assure repayment and demand a rollback of social benefits and improved tax collection, which the Greeks have readily abused.&nbsp
column8: But the lenders have also shot themselves in the foot by voicing their willingness to extend loans if&nbsp
column10: sell their public assets and infrastructure to the highest foreign&nbsp
column11: bidder, literally leaving the Greeks as tenants in their own lands.&nbsp
column13: Athenians can have a water system, but it'll be owned by&nbsp
column14: a German bank or the Athens International Airport is sold to a French concern.&nbsp
column15: All of the money will subsequently flee the country and condemn the average Greek to a life of debt servitude.&nbsp
column16: At this moment, the Greek government is actively deciding what properties can be sold to the&nbsp
column18: For a proud, ancient nation, it sticks in the craw to have an historic site named like an NFL stadium...<em>and on the left, you'll see the Heineken Acropolis, presently closed for Oktoberfest.&nbsp
column19: So the Greeks do what they do well, they hit the streets.

column2: Hell, yes.

column1: • Each nation has difficulties with the national debt, largely as a result of social benefits now viewed as sacred - Medicare, Social Security - and requiring renegotiation on a generational level.
<li>Each nation needs foreign lenders to provide funds.&nbsp
column2: Technically, the Federal Reserve is now the largest lender to the Treasury, but once the oil producers recognize it, the dollar is going to be toasted (Damn, I shot my mouth off again.
column3: Good thing the Saudis aren't reading this...).

column1: <li>Each nation has advocates stating that the debt really isn't an issue since there are plenty of physical assets to be sold.&nbsp
column2: Yes, there have been talking heads on CNBC stating that we can meet our&nbsp
column3: obligations by selling our national assets out from under us.&nbsp
column4: <em>And on our left, the Heineken Lincoln Memorial, closed for Oktoberfest.&nbsp

column1: <li>Each nation has a citizenry that has largely left it's future income streams to government payments.&nbsp
column2: There are plenty of scared 60 year olds in both Athens, Greece and Athens, Georgia who are terrified of losing their old age benefits.

column1: • Each nation has a growing sense that their future is now out of their hands and into the hands of a financial plutocracy, answerable to no real political authority.
While it can happen here, there's no guarantee that it will.
column2: So while the&nbsp
column3: kids and wife are watching the tourist sites, I'll be watching the crowds&nbsp
column4: to see&nbsp
column5: how things shake out.&nbsp

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
438,"1","1",,"xhtml","

More people are aware of the serious issue with student debt, especially with the non-dischargeable nature of the debt.
column2: But with this era of too many societal promises/too little money, I was surprised at the report that the US Department of Education actually requested a SWAT team raid a house looking for a delinquent borrower.
column3: There are a few caveats that I'll provide as I link this article:

column1: <li>It's from the Drudge Report, which presumes a certain sensational quality about the news or it wouldn't be there
<li>It's highly unlikely that such an overkill raid was solely in response to a simple delinquency situation.&nbsp
column2: Did the borrower have a history of making threats or carrying weapons?&nbsp
column3: There's much that's not disclosed in the article and it would be helpful to know, although I doubt that we ever will.

column1: • Were there other issues, such as fraud in a large amount?
• Another news report states that the Department of Education denied that it pertained to delinquent loans, but instead to a criminal investigation.
The feds asked for a raid and got it, but no explicit reason as to why.
There is something to take away from this article however.
column2: While I don't expect there to be routine raids on a parent's house because Junior is now a year late on repaying the student loans - the default rate is now more than 13% - they will want the money back and will actively take measures to obtain it.&nbsp
column3: The Internal Revenue Service hired more staff to pursue tax revenues and there is no doubt that the same will happen here.&nbsp
column4: In this new world, the money will be most actively pursued from the most voiceless and least organized, the young.

column1:
This is something that I'll remember as we consider the higher education alternatives.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

439,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Parent and teen communication can get testy and it's no different here.
column2: In our case, it often pertains to questions regarding independence since what one side thinks isn't what the other side thinks.&nbsp
column3: There has to be a balance between the two - the teen being allowed to make independent decisions and the parent having some sense that things aren't entirely out of control.

column1: My wife and I try to provide latitude since the only way that kids learn to handle independence is to actually have some of it.
column2: Our expectation lies in the details:&nbsp

column1: • Who are you traveling with and who else is there?
• What adults are there to supervise, quaint as that sounds?
• Is there a purpose for the event, such as cast/graduation/sweet 16 party, jam session?
• If we agree and there are any changes in plans, then contact us to clarify again.
column2: Changes in circumstances can also change responses.

column1: This last point about changes in plans sounds simple and it really should be.
column2: Except that teens also lack judgment and in their minds, permission given is final.&nbsp
column3: So what if the get-together is now moving more than twenty miles away, to be held at Jack's house?&nbsp
column4: Jack apparently has no last name and is only known by his attendance at Catholic High, hence Jack Catholic.&nbsp
column5: <em>You said that I could and I can handle myself anyway.&nbsp
column6: No, I don't where he lives but I can always follow someone else...&nbsp
column7: This mistaken presumption leads to surprise on the parents' part and if the response isn't handled gently - not always a harried parent's strong suit - it's met by wounded pride and testiness.
column8: Events then proceed to roll downhill to mutual silence and quiet anger.

column1: I have no surefire, easy way to handle circumstances like these.
column2: It's not easy to consistently stay mellow, but one has to try.&nbsp
column3: The only other avenue is to follow the encounter with a later, gentler conversation that tries to make things right.&nbsp
column4: After these repeated encounters, there will hopefully be a reasonable &quot
column5: meeting of the minds&quot
column6: to help maintain the family peace.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

One of my great struggles is having to constantly monitor the various media to assure that the family guidelines are upheld, particularly when it pertains to the movie/television/games ratings and for the most part, the kids recognize that if Youngest is around, then a resolution must be found for the TV-14 program that's presently airing.&nbsp
column3: We try to find a compromise and there are instances in which the television or computer game is halted and other times, Youngest or Middle leaves the room to find something else to do.&nbsp
column4: Tonight is one of those instances however, when I've bent the rules and as Saving Private Ryan came on the television and Youngest got up to leave, I told him that he could stay and watch for awhile.
column5: To her credit, my wife figured that there was method to my madness and said nothing, staying with Youngest as well.&nbsp
column6: Youngest made it through the opening and the combat on Omaha Beach before he dissolved into tears, at which point we found something else on the tube.

column1: It's a painful lesson, for him as well as for me.
column2: As I later explained to my wife, while we work hard to control the media exposure, many other parents do not.&nbsp
column3: Many of Youngest's third grade peers are actively watching R rated movies, TV14 programming and playing the war games such as Medal of Honor and Call of Duty:
column4: Black Ops.
column5: In these experiences, violence is gratuitous and without consequence.&nbsp
column6: If you're hit, you're able to reenter the game.&nbsp
column7: Combat is often marked&nbsp
column8: by a sense of heroism and glory and in movies at least, there's considerable banter and frequent instances of panache.&nbsp
column9: While I'm not a veteran, it doesn't square with the reality of combat as described to me in my adulthood by my own father, a Korean War infantryman.&nbsp
column10: A reality that encompasses terror, grief and brutality as much as brotherly camaderie.&nbsp
column11: Elementary age children are being exposed to a one-dimensional view of violence and brutality and while I won't permit such games or inappropriately rated programming here, when the kids visit their friends, they'll see it there.&nbsp
column12: I'm well aware that my nine year-old son is acquainted with the Nazi Zombies found in <em>Call of Duty:&nbsp
column13: Black Ops, even though I don't like it.

column1: The opening sequences of Saving Private Ryan are profound in their immediacy and terror.
column2: Death comes quickly, slowly, messily, quietly, randomly to someone.&nbsp
column3: A soldier survives an explosion to arise and be struck down immediately by a slug.&nbsp
column4: A soldier exposes himself to pull a buddy out of the way and within two minutes, is yelling to let 'em burn!
column5: I want these scenes to stand against the sanitized, sterile violence found elsewhere in the movies and video games and I want him to understand that there are ramifications to war.&nbsp

column1: Youngest talks occasionally of becoming a soldier, much as I talked of it when I was younger.
column2: He plays with toy soldiers, as I did, and engages in mock combat with his friends.&nbsp
column3: That hasn't changed over the years and<em>&nbsp
column4: I don't expect that it ever will.
column5: But as the level of visual violence escalates amongst our children, I do want him to have a sense that there's something more involved than the stylized and sterile violence that his friends and peers are viewing frequently and routinely.&nbsp

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
441,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The kids are aging and growing and as my father, God bless him, used to say, ...and that's how it's supposed to be.
column2: My problem is that saying that presumes that I have a clue of how it's supposed to be.
column3: I'm very comfortable with many aspects of fatherhood and parenting, but helping prepare a rising high school senior for the world is new and - honestly - scary territory.&nbsp
column4: Where's the balance betweem staying grounded with the family and becoming independent?&nbsp
column5: Because learning independence requires having a degree of independence.

column1: I've been to college and seen what happens with kids who are truly on their own for the first time and drive their proverbial freedom into a brick wall.
column2: There's no perceptible reason why they couldn't handle it while I did, apart from the fact that my parents gave me some latitude as I came through high school.&nbsp
column3: Latitude?&nbsp
column4: In the early Spring of my senior high school year, they took a 10 day trip to Europe and left me to myself and the quiet surveillance of a community of small town neighbors and friends.&nbsp
column5: When I missed school with a virus, the vice-principal's wife dropped by the first afternoon with some food and did indeed verify that I was truly sick.&nbsp
column6: Nothing terrible that some sleep and a quiet diet wouldn't cure and I later found that my father had been made aware while in France.&nbsp
column7: That however, was a very different time and environment.&nbsp

column1: We're going to Europe ourselves in two weeks, but the kids will come with us.
column2: Not because we don't trust them, but because we believe that with the way things are going, these children might never again have the opportunity to see places that they've wanted to go.&nbsp
column3: And trust me, I have no burning desire to travel to these places, but the kids do and so we've saved for two years to make this work.&nbsp

column2: I've said for years that children are egocentric and if I could graph it with degree of egocentrism on the y-axis and age on the x-axis, it would be appear to be an oscillating wave with the low points in the middle years of childhood and the height both in the early years as well as the mid to late teens.
column3: In the early years, the egocentrism is a function of need since they depend on you for almost everything and that lessens as they age.&nbsp
column4: But I've seen it ratchet upwards in the mid/late teens as they gain a taste of independence and a wider, more eclectic set of friends.&nbsp
column5: There are more things to do, a greater diversity in interests and activities, and kids are beginning to develop their own eccentricities and quirks on the&nbsp
column6: adulthood path.&nbsp
column7: I recall those days well as friends became black belts, developed their musical skills to impressive levels and experienced new genres of music.&nbsp
column8: Of course, friends also drank, smoked dope, broke into churches and subsequently drove around the county wearing clerical vestments, made master keys of the local high school and passed almost an entire school year using free gas courtesy of the pump for the district school buses.

column2: And in this era of MTV's Jackass, it's only gotten weirder.

column1: It's exciting and something in which an eager soon-to-be-adult can completely lose herself.
column2: Having seen much of this as well, it's frankly terrifying at moments.&nbsp
column3: So what are we trying to remember as Eldest enters this pubescent free-fire zone?

column1: <li>Always find out who's going to be there as much as possible.&nbsp
column2: Who is she with and if they're at someone's home, are the parents there?&nbsp

column1: <li>As much as possible, where are they going to be?&nbsp
column2: Honestly, I have crawled into the car to take a short detour of six miles to get ice cream at the convenience store two blocks away and fortunately, it appears that what's supposed to happen is happening.
Give us a call about mid-evening to check in and let us know if there are any changes in plans.&nbsp
column3: If there is no call, then the kids should expect a call from us.

column1: <li>Whenever possible, meet the other kids with whom they're spending times.&nbsp
column2: It's not perfect - way, way far from it - but it's a relief to at least put names with faces and there are instances when the vibes can jump out at you.

column1: <li>Take a moment before they leave to remind them of a few items and then hope and pray that they remember the lessons that you've left since they were old enough to listen.&nbsp
column2: Or at least before they started to ignore you because you were no longer cool.

column1: • Go ahead and tell them that there are going to be nights that are at home and not out with the crowd.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
442,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The kids have Goodnight Moon and a plethora of other bedtime stories, but after catching the viral marketing campaign, I made sure to purchase my own bedtime story, Go the F%$# to Sleep.
column2: It's a&nbsp
column3: wonderfully rude bedtime story that perfectly encapsulates the anger of a tired, pressed father whose little one refuses to sleep.&nbsp
column4: The story is best described as&nbsp
column5: That 70s Show's Red Forman, one of my favorite television fathers, channeling Captain Kangaroo.

column1: There's a common perception of children and bedtimes, where the children snuggle up for a story and then gently go to sleep.
column2: It's the stuff of old movies and Hallmark cards but like life, it isn't always that way.&nbsp
column3: Small children either might not want - or be able - to go to sleep and when Dad's at the end of a long day of his own, the tension can become unbelievable.&nbsp
column4: Dad's spent time with Junior and now wants to have a little time to himself, or with Mom, and the kid simply won't call it quits.&nbsp
column5: Sometimes it's due to physical factors, such as too much caffeine or activity at a time when things should be winding down
column6: and sometimes it's because the kid is simply being an ass.&nbsp
column7: <em>How far can I push Dad?&nbsp
column8: If I wear him down, then I'll get to do what I want to do.&nbsp
column9: If he starts letting me tonight, then I can mention it again tomorrow night.&nbsp
column10: At other times, it's because the kid simply hasn't seen much of Dad and will do whatever possible to keep him around.

column2: I've said these same things in a sotto voce tone, hoping to God that I'm not heard and feeling horrendously guilty for not living up to the Hollywood standard.
column3: Children are wonderful and loving.&nbsp
column4: They can also be exceptionally difficult and after hours of work or hours of caring for them, you simply want a break, even if it comes via your own sleep.

column1: While the tenor of the verses clearly ratchets up from one page to the next however, what's thoroughly absent is the sense that Dad's going to go psycho.
column2: Even at the end, Dad is still tiptoeing around and finally takes the child in hand again to begin the process again.&nbsp

column1: The verses are great and the artwork does full justice to the story and the book is thoroughly worth every penny.
column2: So the next time you're thinking about buying a book, put aside the Stephen King and get this one instead.&nbsp

column1: Then be sure that it doesn't wind up in Junior's bookcase.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
443,"1","1",,"xhtml","

People with websites are often driven to keep producing new material, and I'm no different.
column2: But if I'm going to write about fatherhood and the family - and what impacts each - then my first priority has to be those things, and I've settled for a new article about once each three days, on average.&nbsp
column3: Personal matters now dictate that I go quiet for about three weeks, but be assured that I'll be back with new articles and some other changes to the site in the offing.

column1: Thanks for reading the site and putting me on your RSS feed and as the California Governor once said, I'll be back.

column1:
444,"1","1",,"xhtml","

After more than two weeks of traveling throughout Italy and Greece - a long-planned and saved-for trip - we're back and I've tallied some of the practical lessons that I learned from traveling overseas with kids.
<li>Learn about the tipping culture in other countries.&nbsp
column2: We're used to American wait staff working for pittance wages and making up the difference in tips and we consequently tip well so that the folks can hopefully make a decent wage.&nbsp
column3: What we didn't learn until the third day in Italy was that European wait staff draws a regular wage and a tip is appreciated for very good service, but not expected, and about 10% is par for very good service.&nbsp
column4: With the cost of a meal in a decent European restaurant, three Italian waiters made their nut in one fell swoop and they are now lighting votive candles to the patron saint of wait staff in our honor.

column1: <li>Even if the kids are a bit older, and our youngest will be entering fourth grade, pay particular attention to where they are since the crowds can be simply overwhelming.&nbsp
column2: Take proactive measures, such as dressing the kids in identical brightly colored shirts or hats, wearing your own piece of distinctive clothing to stand out in a crowd, assuring that the kids know in what hotel they're staying so that they can tell police, and having a rally point in the event they realize that they're separated.&nbsp
column3: In our case, Youngest was separated three times - and honestly, none were due to his wandering - but in each instance, he used his head and stayed put instead of panicking and wandering.&nbsp
column4: Thank God that he's the one with the strong streak of common sense.&nbsp
column5: Even when the kids are older, you have to maintain some vigilance since teens are insular and many aren't used to paying attention to what's occurring around them.

column1: <li>If the kids are old enough - and you can afford it - they'll want their own room to share and that's honestly a good thing since they will make you nuts.&nbsp
column2: However, they need to know that the &quot
column3: small sink in the bathroom&quot
column4: is actually called a bidet and isn't used for washing feet.&nbsp
column5: <em>Editorial note:&nbsp
column6: they weren't my kids, thank God.

column2: you're nervous, take the time to&nbsp
column3: try the local life and that includes riding the local transportation.&nbsp
column4: Knowing how to figure out the local subway system is a good exercise in reading and deciphering maps, as is finding the local laundromat.&nbsp
column5: Spend time with the map and then do your best, sharing the mistakes with the kids as they occur.&nbsp
column6: It takes more time than just doing it yourself, but the kids need to learn and that's simply a part of being a father.

column1: <li>If at all possible, have some ground rules on souvenir spending.&nbsp
column2: In our case, each kid decided what he or she wanted to spend and if any additional spending was needed after their funds were exhausted, then they could either pass on it or borrow the money and pay it off on the backyard project
column3: at $5/hour.&nbsp
column4: Two of the three kids now owe me hours and one steadfastly refused to spend anything as he's saving for an electric guitar.&nbsp
column5: The second part of our souvenir spending is that the kid can buy anything with their own money, but if he has to borrow, then it has to be on something that is endemic to the place
column6: I can always buy a fedora in the US but not something that's italian or greek made.

column1: • Be ready for an extended period at breakfast. Young children and preteens
column2: will generally awaken earlier than teenagers
column3: and if there's no press, then let the kids make their way down on their own.&nbsp
column4: That said, I will graze through breakfast like a hobbit, sitting down first with the younger one and then sitting down again for second breakfast at tensies with the teens.&nbsp
column5: While my own intake is less, it still makes for a pudgy hobbit-like father.

column1: The last lesson for now is that it can take days for a youngster's body clock to get back into synch.
column2: I started the notes for this article at 4 AM this morning when I awoke and was then joined by Youngest at 615 AM.&nbsp
column3: It's now going on 1030 at night and my own case of jet lag is kicking in viciously.&nbsp
column4:
The day has been one of cleaning and unpacking, writing and riding herd on the occasionally cranky youngsters and it's now time for the hobbit father to turn in for tomorrow's tensies with the Eldest.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
445,"1","1",,"xhtml","

When you've planned and saved for more than two years for a "
column2: once-in-a-lifetime&quot
column3: family vacation, you want everything to go off and it was no different for the recent vacation to Italy and Greece, aka <em>The PIGS Tour.&nbsp
column4: But the latter part of the trip involved several days in Athens and it was while we were in Rome that global news caught and showed footage of the rioting in Athens' Syntagma Square, outside of the Greek parliament and we were left wondering - well, me actually - at what point we pull the plug on the latter portion.
column5: With two teens and a child, precisely when does it become unsafe to travel there?&nbsp
column6: Even if it's physically safe, is it justifiable to take the kids to see a politically polarized site during what's supposed to be a &quot
column7: get away from it all&quot
column8: experience?

column1: If you've been out of town for awhile, the nightly protests in Syntagma Square are the public's response to multiple factors, mostly the Parliament's move to adopt painful austerity measures in order to obtain the next portion of the European bailout money to the tune of about 15 Billion Euros.
column2: In this case, the Parliament voted to adopt the measures while we were in Italy and it was during this time that things spiraled out of control for an evening.&nbsp
column3: Although we left our computers and most of the cellphones at home, I still took a few moments on hotel computers to check the State Department website and find out if there was any travel warning, which there wasn't.&nbsp
column4: Our tour guide, a multi-lingual German woman, called a colleague in Greece and passed along that any issues were localized solely to the Syntagma Square vicinity
column5: the remainder of Athens and the rest of Greece weren't experiencing unrest.&nbsp
column6: The final point was a review of our travel insurance policy.&nbsp
column7: We discovered that the policy doesn't cover changes due to civil unrest and we would&nbsp
column8: not be
column10: prepaid costs of hotel/flight should we&nbsp
column14: Fortunately for us however, it did reimburse us for the cost of emergency evacuation.&nbsp
column16: I'll get back the 15000 Euros that I had to put on the credit card for the taxi to the airport evacuation site...Given all the factors, we were in for the trip and fortunately for us, things had calmed down by the time we were to leave for Athens.

column1: The ride from the airport to our hotel took more than a half hour and we talked with our driver, an engaging middle-aged Greek gentleman, who explained some of the average Greek's perspective of the economic difficulties.
column2: <em>The politicians from both parties have had 40 years to screw things up and they've succeeded.&nbsp
column3: The demonstrations are the work of the communists, damn them.&nbsp
column4: We're screwed...When my wife inquired about finding a decent taverna where the locals eat, he directed us to a city section called Plaka, one of the earliest residential sections of modern Athens and located immediately at the base of the Acropolis plateau
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: he stated that we could find any number of decent restaurants there without all of the tourist schtick.&nbsp
column8: After we checked in and unloaded our bags, we studied the map and found that Plaka was perhaps 1.5 km due west and immediately on the other side of...Syntagma Square.&nbsp
column9: Since it was still in the mid-afternoon, and the cabdrivers were on strike that day, we thought to hell with it and hoofed it westwards.

column1: The square itself was anticlimactic at that hour of the day.
column2: We walked west along Leoforos Vasilissis Sofia, a main thoroughfare notable by some museums, an embassy and attractive apartment buildings and we only became aware that the square was coming up by the increasing presence of one or two policemen, with another carrying a submachine gun another block ahead.&nbsp
column3: In the distance, a block away from the square was a dark blue school bus that&nbsp
column4: had carried in the riot squads, who were clustered along the fence of the National Gardens as they kibbitzed and smoked.&nbsp
column5: At the corner with Leoforos Vasillis Amalias,&nbsp
column6: on the left, &nbsp
column7: was the Parliament building with the Memorial to the Unknown Greek Soldier on the side&nbsp
column8: facing Amalias.&nbsp
column11: was Syntagma Square, notable by the number of banners and posters hanging up.&nbsp
column12: The great majority of these signs were in Cyrillic and a handful of early protestors milled around as though they were awaiting the opening gate for a concert, chatting and smoking as well.&nbsp
column13: When a handful sitting nearby did start a chant, a cellphone would ring and one of the chanters would answer it and sit down to chat with the chant dying away.&nbsp
column14: We continued through the square and as I started to doubt the big deal, we passed another building whose front window had been shattered, apparently by a brick.&nbsp
column15: Other buildings suffered minor damage such as graffiti and cracked windows, but these became fewer and farther between as we moved away from the square.&nbsp
column16: Our after-dinner return was much closer to when things began and it was at this point that we saw the street between the square and the Parliament cordoned off to traffic as the number of protestors had swelled.&nbsp
column17: Ahead of us was a shoulder-to-shoulder line of several dozen protestors, each of whom was wearing a plain mask, albeit not the Guy Fawkes mask&nbsp
column19: As it turned out, they were lined up for a photo op and when the photographer was finished, they removed their masks and dispersed in knots and it was then that I realized that some of the protestors were actually children, some younger than my youngest child.&nbsp

column1: When we asked a protestor what was being yelled, the laconic response was they're yelling against the government and he then simply walked away.
column2: Two young policemen on the corner, dressed in simple outfits and leaning on plexiglass riot shields, were more talkative and explained some of what we were seeing.&nbsp
column3: The protestors began to arrive in greater numbers at about 6 PM and they would finally disperse around 5 AM and excepting the televised coverage, the crowds had been peaceful for the remainder of the nights.&nbsp
column4: As we spoke, they went on to say that while the riot troops were available in case of problems, they were generally out of eyesight so as to not provoke additional difficulties and their own job was to assure that some order was maintained.&nbsp
column5: Honestly, the cops were friendlier and more talkative than the protestors as we had further&nbsp
column6: conversations with the riot police further up the block
column7: one of them even joked with Youngest, who was a bit uncomfortable in the presence of real automatic weapons.&nbsp
column8: It was a very different proposition to see a fully operational submachine than the Nerf and virtual weapons wielded while playing online and with friends.&nbsp
column9: The remainder of the hike back was uneventful, apart from seeing a sandbag&nbsp
column10: gun emplacement hidden behind the trees of the National Gardens,&nbsp
column11: and when the next morning rolled around, there was no second thought about safety and we again returned to that vicinity.&nbsp

column1: For all of the talk and news coverage, it really was a non-event and honestly something that I'm glad that the kids got to see.
column2: There was serious discussion about what's causing the unrest and I'm gratified that when we spoke with Greeks, all three listened.&nbsp
column3: One of my personal goals for the trip was to help the kids understand that there's far more out there than what they see in smalltown America.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, they need to see that there is such a thing as non-violent protest as average people vent their anger at those in power when the standard channels become uselessly dysfunctional.&nbsp
column5: Because when push comes to shove, my fear is akin to the old saying:&nbsp
column6: <em>As we once were, you are now.&nbsp
column7: As we are now, you will become.&nbsp

After a torrid June increase in the cost of the grocery retail marketbasket, July's survey continued to show an increase but the pace was less than the previous month.
column2: The average cost of the 47 item marketbasket rose to $185.00 from June's $184.07
column3: the PracticalDad Index has risen to 103.71 and the three month moving average is now at 102.99.&nbsp
column4: In other words, the cost of the basket is 3.7% higher than the survey's inception in November, 2010.

column1: Unlike previous months, canola oil and coffee were unchanged and far fewer items underwent price increases than in June.
column2: The principal increases were for&nbsp
column3: hot dogs (5.1%), flour (5.2%) and potatoes (8.3%).&nbsp
column4: &nbsp

column1: Go figure, because I haven't got a clue as to why, either.
For the record, July's survey was done one week later in the month than the other months due to travel.
column2: The monthly index results, and the moving average are as follows:

non-concentrate, store brand (oz)&nbsp

With the news of political unrest and potential default in Greece swirling around our own trip to Greece, it was impossible to not have conversation some of the austerity measures being considered by their government.
column2: According to an article in the International Herald Tribune, some of the measures being proposed include:
Solidarity&quot
column3: tax of 1 - 5%&nbsp
column4: on all households to help defray the debt payments

column1: <li>Increased excise taxes on such items as gasoline, tobacco and alcohol
<li>Special levies on on high-value properties and high-income individuals
• Sales of public infrastructure to the highest bidder, which you should read as foreign highest bidder.
Given our tendency to chat with the locals, we got an earful of what it actually entails to average Greeks and we made it a point of sharing that with the kids.
column2: They have to have a sense of what's coming down the pike since their generation will have to contend with the lion's share of the clean-up work.

column1: It's also important to discuss austerity because we're now having to practice some of our own to pay off the bills from the trip itself.
column2: We'd saved for more than two years to pay for the trip and the airfare and most lodging was already paid off, but that didn't count a fair amount of food and incidental spending and when I viewed the amount charged online, I winced.&nbsp
column3: While I intellectually understood the exchange rate of $1.42 to the Euro, it was a different prospect to see how that translated to actual dollars on the statement.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, I wasn't prepared for the foreign transaction fee charged by the card company for each transaction that occurred overseas and the cumulative result was sobering.

column1: We've now decided to practice austerity at home while the outstanding bills are brought back to earth and this has been made clear to the kids.
column2: For instance:

column1: <li>Youngest is now playing a midsummer baseball tournament and instead of spending money on bottled water at the concession stand, we're making sure that we take a half dozen bottles in a cooler
• Any requests for money by the kids are now met by the comment about Europe and the question of whether I've been repaid on the time that's owed me for the backyard project
column2: and that's managed to squelch several requests

column1: • Greater attention is being paid to the home cooking and restaurant meals are now out of the picture.
The bills aren't overwhelming, while shocking, and nobody's going to lose their home over it.
column2:
But while my mother always repeated gotta pay the mortgage first during my childhood, now I can simply say Europe and the same message will be understood.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
much&nbsp
column3: written&nbsp
column4: on the decline of the American Middle Class, facing it's worst time perhaps since the Great Depression.&nbsp
column5: The statistics point out falling income, insufficient assets to support the classic American notion of 'retirement' and a significant number of people who owe more on their house - their largest asset - than it could ever possibly again be worth.&nbsp
column6: But while everyone is focusing on the economic aspects, as though the&nbsp
column7: number of bedrooms&nbsp
column8: is paramount, what's being overlooked is that the true danger to the American middle class lies in the political realm.&nbsp
column9: It's a misdirection that has to be corrected since we've long ago crossed from the purely economic into the political realm and I'm not certain that many realize that fact.&nbsp
column10: The protests in Greece and Spain demonstrate that there comes a point at which the consequences of 'economic' decisions are addressed in a purely political manner as the governments in power attempt to fend off the masses to continue in power.

column1: One of the criticisms of the economics profession is that
column2: economists have tried to wrap a soft, inexact science in a hard science shell.&nbsp
column3: Economics is at its heart the determination of how resources are allocated and used to the best effect
column4: this is itself a political question as perceptions and emotions come into play as much as pure numbers.&nbsp
column5: This packaging however, has carried over into today's society in general as the news programs spend their time throwing numbers around, mesmerizing the&nbsp
column6: audience with the sheer volume of information.&nbsp
column7: <em>Certainly, if we can track this data and put it into neat numeric formats, then there must be a rational and easily obtainable answer, as though juggling the various economic variables were the same as adjusting&nbsp
column8: recipe ingredients for Chef Ramsey.

column2: Today's American economy is notable by the disproportionate size of the financial sector and huge federal deficits, incurred to help the Too-Big-To-Fail financial institutions from their self-inflicted injuries.&nbsp
column3: These injuries didn't arise from economic circumstances, but actually from political actions that backfired.

column1: <li>Excessive and unmonitored risks were taken by these commercial and investment banks because no one was paying attention to them.&nbsp
column2: No one paid attention to them because of a political action, the repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act, which had successfully regulated the financial services industry after the last debacle of the Great Depression.

column1: • The repeal of Glass-Steagall was made possible by massive campaign contributions to Congress from the financial services industry, a political activity which hasn't been satisfactorily regulated since God alone knows when.
column2: What's infuriating is that at this juncture, corporate campaign contributions can't be successfully limited because the Supreme Court has ruled that it infringes upon their right to free speech.&nbsp

column1: <li>Much of the job loss that's plagued us is attributable to a blind, single-minded devotion to free trade regardless of the trade policies of the other nations, whose own policies might permit dumping, currency-pegging and inhumane working conditions.&nbsp
column2: This is mandated in political treaties which coincide with the economic theories that spawn them.
the&nbsp
column3: 2008 collapse of Lehman and the near&nbsp
column4: collapse of the economic&nbsp
column5: system was the passage of TARP, a purely political act.
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: This unpopular act occurred despite widespread civic opposition and with the additional input from the Treasury Secretary - a financial/economic personage - that failure to pass the legislation would probably result in widespread civil unrest and the imposition of martial law, a completely political act.

column1: <li>There has been significant evidence provided that the federal government and the Federal Reserve are involved to some extent in&nbsp
column2: the actions of the equity markets, a purely political act to maintain a semblance of normalcy for the general public.

The effect of these, and other, political acts is to move the government from regulator for the common good to that of co-conspirator with a corrupted and self-serving minority and this is probably the greatest threat to the American Middle Class instead of falling wages and job losses.
column3: The strength of the American Experience has arisen from a shared sense of common values, as laughable as that might seem to certain cynics.&nbsp
column4: These values include hard work, collective honesty and most importantly, a respect and belief in the rule of law.&nbsp
column5: For all of its flaws, there had been a common belief that the Constitution and Bill of Rights were the mainstay of the nation and that the laws were generally just and would ultimately win out to the benefit of the whole.&nbsp

column1: • When corporations are found to have broken the law and the penalty is a mere fraction of the illegal proceeds with no other correction to the offenders, the common values are destroyed.

• When banks are found to undermine ancient common law principles by wholesale forging of foreclosure documents, attesting to the veracity of information that they know to be wrong, the common values are destroyed.

• When banks are found to further undermine the law by subverting the role of the notary public - having employees sign the signature of someone who's dead - and with no meaningful legal response, the common values are destroyed.
• When companies and firms betray their fiduciary interest, face-ripping clients and misdirecting innocents into needlessly risky investments, the common values are destroyed.
• When the government is seen to act as enabler to these same companies and individuals, refusing to let them pay the penalty for their actions, the common values are destroyed.
• When the President and Speaker of the House are seen to be playing golf while the government is mired in budgetary and debt morass, the common values are destroyed.

• When two parents work multiple jobs to provide basics for their children while millions are paid out to corporate executives as the payoff for failed plans and lost jobs, the common values are destroyed.
<li>When a father has to explain to his child why his refusal to do something <em>just because&nbsp
column2: everyone else is doing it&nbsp
column3: isn't dumb, the common values are destroyed.

column1: I've resigned myself to the fact that this country is going to face economic turmoil, unseen since the days of the Great Depression.
column2: I've worked to teach the kids real world lessons about money, credit and values to prepare them for their future in a world with much greater competition and fewer resources.&nbsp
column3: But I will not resign myself to the notion that my children - and all of their friends, classmates and peers&nbsp
column4: - are condemned to live as second class citizens serving as debt serfs to the benefit of a privileged few.

column1: That does not come as the result of economic actions, but political ones.
column2: The work now will be to relearn what was once&nbsp
column3: known amongst our forebears, but since forgotten.&nbsp
