One of the touted punk rock events is the annual Vans Warped Tour, which travels from city to city with a line up of dozens of bands.
column2: While<em>&nbsp
column3: I enjoyed the occasional show in my youth, it's different when you bring the kids.
column4: The music is stunningly loud and the crush in the pit up front tight enough that I'm content to sit in the back and actually enjoy some of the music while I read.&nbsp
column5: Or write, for that matter.&nbsp
column6: But does a middle aged man even have a place amongst this hip venue?&nbsp
column7: Exactly what the hell am I even doing here?

column2: This particular event - tickets purchased almost a half year in advance - is a peace offering to Middle.&nbsp
column3: While I was gone for a weekend with Eldest and her peers, Middle entered an online radio station contest using my name, since I'm technically an adult.&nbsp
column4: He informed my wife, who approved, but neither actually informed me.&nbsp
column5: (Un)fortunately, he won the prizes and the station manager rapidly understood that it was a&nbsp
column6: minor's entry when he called me days later to congratulate me on a win about which I was utterly baffled.&nbsp
column7: Whe he asked about the age of the actual entrant, I told him the truth.&nbsp

column2: first, tell me if you ever use my name and ask permission first
column3: &nbsp
column4: second, don't expect me to lie for you.

column1: I still felt terrible since he missed an opportunity to meet the members of 'Avenged Sevenfold' and receive an electric guitar signed by the band.
column2: Even my wife was appalled at my inability to cope with the phone call and seize the prize.&nbsp
column3: Hence, the concert.

column1: But shouldn't teens go to concerts themselves?
column2: Isn't that part of the experience?&nbsp
column3: Frankly, no.

column1: <li>The event occurred across state lines in a city in which Eldest, who drove, has never been.&nbsp
column2: Middle doesn't have the navigational skills yet and I saw no value in sending two teen minors through major metropolitan rush hour traffic enroute to a concert.&nbsp
column3: Eldest still drove, but I handled the navigational and color commentary duties and given the afternoon parking lot on the expressway, I'm glad that I went.

column1: <li>This is a full-blown rock concert and there are all manner of teens - and adults - there and not all of them give a rat's ass about someone else.&nbsp
column2: We've tried to raise the kids with both the expectation of considering consequences as well as acting in a moral and civilized manner.&nbsp
column3: The unfortunate reality is that a substantial number of kids and young adults haven't been taught the same thing and I've witnessed circumstances in which behavior regresses to a Lord of the Flies level.
column4: If this is their first experience, then I want to at least be in the background to keep tabs on things.&nbsp

column1: <li>I'm continally curious about the teen/young adult scene and what's occurring there.&nbsp
column2: The more information and experience that I have, the better that I'm able to assess what's going on.

column1: <li>Stupidity is contagious and teens whose hormones and judgment are affected by ear-bleeding rock music are especially susceptible to catching it.&nbsp
column2: If you're not certain, you can ask a kid who comes in one evening with green hair.&nbsp
column3: <em>Hey, they said that they'd done it before.&nbsp
column4: What could go wrong?

column1: <li>Taking them isn't the same as being with them the entire time.&nbsp
column2: They brought along a friend and I simply arranged to meet them at periodic intervals, letting them experience the music and event.&nbsp
'Nuff said.

column1: Finally, some of the music is actually good and I've now got several tunes that I'll be buying for the mp3 player.
column2: It wouldn't happen if I were still listening to the &quot
column3: Greatest Hits of My Life&quot
column4: format, so I'll find my spot with the other parents in the back and sit back swilling the $3 bottled water.&nbsp

The title quote is from a college student that I've known since his elementary school years and encapsulates what I think that many are now starting to think.
column2: Ron Paul just opined about the possibility and it's making the rounds of the internet.
column3: Just default and let's get this over with.&nbsp
column4: Now.&nbsp
column5: But what precisely is meant by default on August 2?

column1: Let's consider this from a micro level, the level at which millions are operating when they have to decide whether to pay the mortgage, buy food, or continue to provide the electric and gas for the everyday life.
column2: The United States Government is about to get a glimpse of life for the average Joe and Jane who are struggling to make ends meet since they had their jobs outsourced to China and India, and judging by the verbiage, they are terrified.
The members of the Congress and Executive Branch deserve to be scared.

column1: First, there is still money flowing into the federal household but with the way that the bills and payments are hitting, there's going to be a cash shortfall.
column2: The federal household has a large amount of less-liquid assets - Rolexes, fine china and a monster set of exercise equipment - but there's no longer any federal money market account on which to rely and the emergency fund is exhausted.&nbsp
column3: They could sell the assets but anybody who recognized the need would take it for too great a discount and besides, it would both take too long as well as look bad.&nbsp
column4: And if we got rid of all of the land that Great Uncle Teddy left us, it would be a tragedy.&nbsp
column5: The creditors have continued to provide credit since the payments have been made to date but come August 2, the minimum payment due will fall on the same day that the cash flow is negative and all of the other bills are due.&nbsp
column6: Barry and John have bickered and argued, yelling epithets at one another as they bang on the granite countertops and tossed the occasional cup of Starbucks at one another.&nbsp
column7: So if there's still some money available but a raft of bills, what to do?

column1: Make a priority list of what has to be paid and then work through the various permutations.
column2: Let's see, now.&nbsp
column3: The parents exhausted their savings on educating us and we've got to help them each month with a monthly stipend.&nbsp
column4: The kids have all of their various activities as well as the stuff that we have to provide for them, such as food, shelter and the medicine cabinet full of medications.&nbsp
column5: There are the multiple club memberships, dues and charities which we support and God knows that some good comes from that.&nbsp
column6: Don't forget the security that we pay for since the neighborhood has gotten a bit rougher and seedier
column7: we need to have access to strong security.&nbsp
column8: So how do we cut?&nbsp

column1: In the real world of repo'd cars, terminated utilities and food stamps, people would at one time have considered missing some credit payments.
column2: But the cash flow is so weak and the choices so stark, that more people are unwilling to let the credit go.&nbsp
column3: The business community has noted for the first time that folks will willingly let go of the mortgage while continuing to pay the monthly credit card bill and it's recently reported by a Data collection agency that more of the monthly revolving credit - nearing 10% - to pay for necessities instead of discretionary items.
column4: But like Frank Herbert's Planet Arakis, the spice must flow and people now believe that credit must flow as well.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: What does happen if we miss the revolving credit payment?

column1: We'll certainly get a nasty letter and probably a phone call from the bank since we missed.
column2: The tone and content of the discussion will be ugly and it's going to be embarrassing in the extreme.&nbsp
column3: The bank in turn depends on us for it's own asset quality and dividends to large number of investors, but we've never missed a payment until now and besides, what else is out there in the world of credit quality?&nbsp
column4: No, we're safe in our own house and the security devices and service will keep us from being evicted.&nbsp
column5: But what will happen is that our interest rates will go up appreciably since the bank is going to ratchet up the pressure on us
column6: after all, it's not like there are a lot of solid creditors around nowadays, either.&nbsp
column7: The value of our intangible assets will also take a massive hit so that our good name and reputation are sullied in the eyes of everyone else that could provide credit for us and with no new income streams - it's not like royalties manufacture new income streams - our cost of borrowing there will also go up and do so significantly.
column8: &nbsp
column9: The impact upon our neighbors will also&nbsp
column11: considerable since everybody has depended upon our spending to keep themselves in relatively decent shape - the domestic help, the coffee shop and&nbsp
column14: Net basis, we can get through but we're going to finally have to make some decisions about how we allocate money to the creditors, our parents and the kids.&nbsp
column15: Otherwise, if we stiff the creditors again, they'll truly cut off the funds and we'll be screwed.&nbsp
column16: As ugly as it is, what else is there to force us to make the decisions that must be made?

column1: That's an idea of what goes on at the personal level and there's acknowledgement that the Federal Reserve is working with the Treasury Department to likewise determine what the priorities are and whose check is honored
column2: when the default arrives.&nbsp
column3: But what interests me most is the order of priority and which payments are honored.
column4: Do our servicemen receive their pay and will the elderly continue to receive their benefits?&nbsp
column5: Will our 45 million recipients of SNAP benefits be able to continue purchasing food?&nbsp
column6: Or will the foreign creditors be paid at the expense of the citizenry?&nbsp
column7: Talk is ultimately cheap and it's these actions that will indicate what the politicians truly believe and hold most dear.&nbsp
column8: What do we owe each of our constituent groups - foreign and domestic?&nbsp
column10: will finally force us to make the choices?

column1: When Middle child and I spoke of this earlier this evening, I remarked that no matter what happened, the sun would rise and set and we'd manage to continue having food upon the table.
column2:
What I didn't say was that if we didn't default and finally deal with the issues, we'd probably have food on the table but it was increasingly unlikely that he'd be able to put food on the table for his own unborn children.

column1:
453,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Kids grow and expand their circles and frankly, that's what I want to see happen.
column2: But letting them experience some independence is an area painted with a large swath of gray
column3: there are still plenty of ways that things&nbsp
column4: can go wrong and just because I'm letting them have some freedom doesn't mean that I've stepped back completely.&nbsp
column5: How much information is a parent entitled to and is there any off-limits behaviors on the parents' part?&nbsp
column6: What should my guidelines be?

column1: Years ago, I spoke with a friend whose kids were already teens while mine were either in pull-ups or early elementary school.
column2: Caught in the daily rush of providing physically intensive, high-touch care to three children, I told her that I envied her now that her kids were in middle and high school and able to take care of themselves.&nbsp
column3: <em>I would love to not have that constant demand.&nbsp
column4: It would be a huge decrease in the daily pressure of small kids.&nbsp
column5: Her response was surprising since she actually missed those days
column6: the pressure, she stated, is still there but now it's just different and I worry more than I did before.
column7: Our conversation veered on to other topics but the remark has stayed with me and as my kids are now further along in the age pipeline, I can appreciate what she's saying.
column8: Where are they at the particular moment, who are they with, what are they doing and are there any parents nearby to monitor what's happening?

column1: Spending my teen years in the 1970s - yes, I'm middle-aged! - meant that there wasn't the Wild West of the internet and more likely than not, having a parent who was home and able to keep tabs on what was happening.
column2: In the introduction to the reissue of his Summer of Night, author Dan Simmons writes about his perceived difference between the life of a 12 year old boy in 1961's Elm Haven and such a life today.
column3: He recalls a life of freedom from the post-breakfast hours to late afternoon as kids would hit the bikes and head out throughout their hometown
column4: the contrast is with today and the fear that either something&nbsp
column5: bad will befall the boy or else he's going to fall into a life of crime and delinquency without constant oversight and structure.&nbsp
column6: From my recollection, growing up in a rural Pennsylvania was akin to Simmons' fictitious Elm Haven and to an extent, I agree with Simmons' premise.

column1: There was a major difference between the rural 1970s and today, however and that is the presence of a parent to keep tabs
column2: on the kids and activities.&nbsp
column3: I know that my mother knew - either personally or via phone - almost all of the parents whose kids were my friends and there were certainly phone calls back and forth just to apprise one another if the traveling circus was either moving or up to something.&nbsp
column4: There were friends whose parents both worked, but they still kept tabs via phone and these kids were also welcome at my home at any time and a few spent considerable time there.&nbsp
column5: There are far more parents working today than before, and many of these kids also come from single-parent families whose custodial parent is stretched thin to work and also oversee the activities.&nbsp
column6: It's this badly frayed parental net that makes teen freedom more problematic, I believe, since the parents aren't around to keep an eye on things and also aren't familiar with the parents of their kids' peers.

column1: Summer childcare in my area is easier for the younger kids.
column2: There are multiple daycamp programs through non-profit agencies as well as through the local municipal governments, who hire college students to keep an eye on elementary aged kids at the local parks and pavilions.&nbsp
column3: But when the children enter middle school, they no longer qualify for many of those programs and are left to their own devices - precisely the worst possible time in life to have that happen to a child.&nbsp
column4: The result is that more than a few young teens - impulsive, sexually curious, some not a little gender-confused, and frankly feeling a bit abandoned - spend their time unmonitored with their peers in a weird, whacked stew of testosterone, estogen and other various hormones.&nbsp
column5: It's a recipe that makes me, as a parent, more than a little nauseated and causes the same worry that weighed on my friend years ago.

column1: So what options are there to help handle this?
column2: They need to be able to spend time apart and learn to handle independence, much as many learn to drive a car with lessons, practice and guidance before they actually slide behind the wheel
column3: as Kurtwood Smith remarked in a radio ad&nbsp
column4: for the Masonic Youth Organization, De Molay:&nbsp
column5: you can't just lock them in their room.

column1: • Expect some conflict and pushback as the kids chafe at the perceived tethers, not knowing that you really do want to lock them in their room.
column2: Apart from the aggravation, what they say will give you a sense of what's going through their head and where it's coming from.

column1: • Be explicit about return times so that there's little chance of confusion that escalates into real unpleasantry.

<li>As I'm finding out with two teens and an elementary schooler, consider actually writing the times on a calendar or handy notepad so that you can keep it straight yourself and not appear to be the senile, doddering fool.&nbsp
column2: Kids can blow through multiple plan permutations in a heartbeat and think that you've&nbsp
column3: approved plan G when you're really still at their plan C because of conversation with another child who's calculating plan D on his own.

column2: I understand&nbsp
column3: - I remember - the freedom to go with buddies to the store for a soda or a magazine and I want them to have some latitude as well.
column4: But if you're going to someone's house and end up elsewhere, please contact me just to provide a heads-up.&nbsp
column5: <em>You're there?&nbsp
column6: Fine, thanks for letting me know.&nbsp
column7: If there's a glitch in the plan that might cause delay, then contact me so that we can sort things out.

column1: <li>Try to have a sense of what adults are around and if necessary, take a moment to pick up the phone and call the parent(s) and introduce yourself.&nbsp
column2: They're likely to be relieved to hear that their own kid is spending time with someone whose own parent appears to give a damn.&nbsp

column1: <li>Pick the moments on when to speak about stuff that you're hearing.&nbsp
column2: Teens will do&nbsp
column3: goofy things and it's probably not much different from your own youth.&nbsp
column4: If the teens are scrawling the word kar on their t-shirts and piggybacking one another through the Wendy's drive-thru to order a Frosty, then hell, what are they hurting?

column1: <li>Occasionally check on where they are when they say that they're somewhere.&nbsp
column2: I won't just drive to a location and search for them, but I have altered my driving route if already out just to see if they're around.&nbsp
column3: Then I can mentally cross-reference that with what I'm hearing later when they're home.

column1: <li>Don't be afraid to challenge them if something doesn't appear right or as it was supposed to be.&nbsp
column2: <em>If you were with Steve tonight, why did he call here looking for you?&nbsp
column3: It's certainly uncomfortable and potentially nasty, but the kids learn that you are paying attention and frankly, I believe that more than a few are relieved that you actually are paying attention.

column1: <li>Try to remember to take a few moments to go over anybody else's plans and activities.&nbsp
column2: Teens are notoriously egocentric - like politicians, except that most teens grow up - and will sometimes forget that younger sibling has a championship baseball game or that Grandma's coming to visit.&nbsp
column3: That way, you can both hammer out a plan that satisfies them, younger brother and Grandma without creating needless angst.

column1: • Grab any opportunity available to have the friends over so that you can meet them and make the place available, if at all possible, for sleepovers and get-togethers.
<li>Share your concerns with them about kids and situations and if at all possible, try to be as specific as possible.&nbsp
column2: <em>That kid is trouble!&nbsp
column3: will probably engender feelings of loyalty from your own kid while specific circumstances and events, if you can enumerate them, helps your child delineate why that kid really is trouble.

column1: This is going to be an ongoing exercise that will certainly test our - and our kids' - patience as we work through what's acceptable and find common ground.
column2: There have already been tense moments and each side has had to apologize to the other for testiness, and I anticipate that there will be more until they are finally on their own two feet.

column1: And honestly, the piggybacking at Wendy's sounds like fun.

If anybody is curious about the actual status of the Debt Ceiling debate, I'm enclosing a link to the site for the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
column2: The site has been in existence since August 2010 and they help to parse out the briar thicket that is the federal budget for those of us in the general public.&nbsp
column3: The article is a brief synopsis of the similarities and differences between the plan promoted by House Speaker John Boehner (R - OH) and Senator Harry Reid (D - NV).&nbsp
column4: There's nothing from the President since frankly, the guy's got bupkis.

column1: The topic is one that's gotten some conversation in the house since the prospect of a federal default is increasing daily and it will most certainly be painful for the rest of us should it happen.

This isn't the type of website that tracks closely to the news, but this reported leak by the Administration bears notice.
A recent post was about some commentary that I'm hearing from people to the effect that a federal default
column2: Mebbe We Should Just Default...&quot
column3: href=""http://www.practicaldad.com/index.php/article/452"">might not be such a terrible thing and one of my own observations was that come the early August period, there would still be money to pay some bills.
column4: &nbsp
column5: The government would then be in the position of more than a few average Americans, who have to prioritize their bills and decide what gets paid first.&nbsp
column6: One of my great interests would be who gets paid with the available funds and who gets stiffed.

column1: Bloomberg is now running a report by an unnamed Administration official that if the debt ceiling is not raised, then the Treasury Department would assure that the bondholders - frequently foreign creditors and the banking system via the Federal Reserve System - would receive payment ahead of others.
column2: Honestly, I'm not certain whether there's legislation that mandates that bond payments supersede other payments but the simple reality is that the US government will&nbsp
column3: give precedence to creditors who own US bonds which mature during that period.&nbsp
column4: Frankly, it doesn't matter even if such legislation exists because the government should never have reached this ridiculous state of affairs.&nbsp
column5: This might simply be a leak to ratchet up pressure upon the Congress, whose members will hopefully fear that the public will blame them for all manner of missed benefits.&nbsp
column6: But it points out two salient things:

column1: • The administration refused as recently as a month ago to specify any order of payments, which they apparently now think makes a major difference in whether some compromise - meaningful or not - is reached.
<li>The US government has officially placed the American people on notice that bondholders and creditors will be given priority over the citizenry.&nbsp

column2:
If you want the government to give a damn, make sure that you lend them some money beyond your taxes.

456,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The knock on men is that we're typically uncommunicative and insensitive, whether with our mates or our kids, and this is especially the case with public praise.
column2: It might stem from uncertainty of knowing what to say, but more likely from a fear of sounding too sentimental or simply dumb.&nbsp
column3: But the kids want your approval - certainly private if not public - and there are very few children who don't want to hear it.&nbsp
column4: When we fathers pass on these rare opportunities, we're forgetting the Principal Law of Fatherhood
column5: - that it's no longer about us - and doing a real disservice to our children.

column1: If you doubt the impact and value of these moments, I wish that you could have witnessed such a moment at a graduation party that I recently attended.
column2: The party was to celebrate the high school graduation of a young man, the last child in his immediate family.&nbsp
column3: After time for visiting and eating, the father approached the front of the room and took a microphone, at which time the crowd grew quiet.&nbsp
column4: After thanking everyone for attending, he told the young man that he had a few words for his benefit.&nbsp
column5: The son advanced to the forefront of the crowd and stood directly and attentively before his father as the older man withdrew a simple index card from his shirt pocket.&nbsp

column1: The father read from the card in an unadorned style with no apparent deviation from what he'd penned earlier.
column2: What he'd written was straightforward and simple but the content of his message had a noticeable impact upon his son, who perceptibly&nbsp
column3: straightened as he listened.&nbsp
column4: The words were a combination of blessing and toast, an acknowledgement of his passage into manhood and the pride felt for the man that he'd both become and into which he would continue to grow.&nbsp
column5: It concluded with a few short words of simple and heartfelt advice.&nbsp
column6: The remarks probably lasted no more than two minutes but the brevity didn't detract in any way.&nbsp
column7: For the young man, the effect was clear.&nbsp
column8: He walked forward at the conclusion and swept his father into a bearhug that caused the older man&nbsp
column9: to stumble and recover before the two of them collapsed in a heap.&nbsp

column1: Children, whether boy or girl, crave the attention and affection of their fathers and such a public proclamation of love - and respect - will carry the youngster a long way, no matter what road is chosen.
column2: It's a practice based upon ancient traditions when the parent would finally acknowledge that the children who they'd raised were now adults and equals, deserving of their own respect outside of the family shadow.&nbsp
column3: When I left for college decades ago, my own father wrote a long letter that he packed into my trunk, to be found when I unpacked.&nbsp
column4: I'd long ago decided that such a communication would go to each of my own children, but watching this event has me rethinking the format of the message.&nbsp
column5: Perhaps I'll have to work up the courage to seize such a moment&nbsp
column6: as it appears in the future.&nbsp
column7: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

With the data crunched from the August pricing forays into three separate stores, the average cost of the 47 item grocery marketbasket rose to $187.05 from July's $185.00, for a single month increase of 1.1%.
column2: The August price index is now at 104.85 - from November 2010's baseline level of 100 - for a 10 month rise of 4.85%.&nbsp

column1: What's notable about the August data is that of the 47 items in the basket, 17 - more than one third of the basket - saw their prices rise and six of these had price increases greater than 5%.

When is it appropriate to let the child make a decision of importance?
column2: I'm fairly clear that as the parent, I have the final say in whether something happens or not, but when and how do I start to let the kid make some important decisions of his own?&nbsp
column3: Perhaps the most critical decision of a teen's life is what happens after high school and if there's no experience there because the 'rents make all the decisions, then what happens?

column1: The question raised it's head - again - with Youngest, who's entering fourth grade.
column2: He was playing right field on a local little league all-star team in a double-elimination tournament several weeks ago, and the team was forced to play four games in four straight July days with no breaks.&nbsp
column3: He came off the field at the end of the first game, limping, and we noticed a limp after the second game as well.&nbsp
column4: By the afternoon before the third game, he came up to me limping and we treated it immediately with ice and ibuprofen
column5: that third game went well for his bat but again, he came home with a slight limp.&nbsp
column6: Because this was now the fourth game in four straight days, our plan was to have a quiet day with a lot of rest and that's the way the day went.&nbsp
column7: The problem arose, however, during the pregame warmups as he was shagging fly balls in the outfield and as I watched, I could see - in a single instant - when the look on his face showed that something had definitely gone wrong.&nbsp
column8: Since the coach was still busy with the other outfielders, he limped over to me and said that the knee hurt too bad to play.&nbsp
column9: Let's be frank about what went through my mind.&nbsp
column10: The team only fielded ten players for nine positions, so there was no bench of which to speak and where would leave the rest of the team in 90+ degree heat?&nbsp
column11: Should I pull the Knute Rockne/Vince Lombardi take one for the team speech?
column12: Honestly, what are people going to think of the boy for not going through and of me as well?&nbsp

column1: As I looked at him, I quickly considered that I'd seen him play in the past
column2: with blistered feet and a shiner from taking a ball in the face.&nbsp
column3: He'd also been limping for three straight days with no qualms and while 98% of kids whine about little things, he'd come through some big ones without a whine.&nbsp
column4: As we talked with the coach, his options were to play in entirety, not at all or at least play for two innings and then sit.&nbsp
column5: The boy was clear that he couldn't play and when I briefly revisited the question again, he was certain that he could no longer play.&nbsp
column6: The other aspect is that this is a child who's playing for love of the&nbsp
column7: game.&nbsp
column8: While there's certainly responsibility to the team, there's also a responsibility to&nbsp
column9: protect that love of the game.&nbsp
column10: There's no pay and to make a 9 year old play through even worse pain when he's clearly played through some already would only damage that desire to play further.&nbsp
column12: I looked at the coach and confirmed what the boy said and like that, he was on the bench with ice on his knee.

column1: So how do you handle such a situation?
column2: There's a fine line between understanding when to demand more of the kids and when to step back.&nbsp
column3: How do they respond to pressure?&nbsp
column4: What else is at stake for the options?&nbsp
column5: Are they prone to needless whining?&nbsp
column6: If they actually get their way, are they giving up something else that they obviously like?&nbsp
column7: Life can be damned hard and what our kids will have to face in the future is likely to be harder than ours and we do a disservice by letting them slide or coddling them.&nbsp
column8: The kids learn that they can manipulate us to avoid unpleasant situations and once they're in the world, they'll run into someone who is going to hand them their heads.&nbsp
column9: Yet if we repeatedly force the situation, then they're defeated and learn that they have no ability to make an independent decision
column10: there's value in learning how to make a decision.&nbsp
column11: I'd like to enumerate any number of easily remembered bulletpoints, but it simply comes down to your own sense of the child and the situation at hand.&nbsp
column12: And like many times with children, there are probably going to be miscalls - and God&nbsp

column1: As of now, Youngest is out of all running and impact sports for the near future as the orthopod to whom he was referred found legitimate damage to the knee.
column2: The kid made the right call and frankly, I'm proud of how he handled the situation.&nbsp
column3: But that doesn't mean that he gets a pass for the household chores.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
460,"1","1",,"xhtml","

...tell your child that something they're wearing makes them look ridiculous.
...tell your child that you love them, whether girl or boy.
column2: Kids&nbsp
column3: need to hear&nbsp
column4: more of the corrections&nbsp
column5: for them to learn - which can be tough on&nbsp
column6: the&nbsp
column7: ego - and knowing that they're loved will at least take some of the sting out of it.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: It's probably something you should tell me more than anything else and as I write this, I'm realizing that I don't do it enough.

column1: ...tell your child that what they've done is bad or dumb.
column2: Many adults no longer want to take the time and effort to do so for fear of offending or upsetting the parent, which means that&nbsp
column3: the kid isn't going to hear unless you deliver it.&nbsp
column4: As I've told any of my own kids on any number of occasions <em>for a smart kid, that was an incredibly stupid thing to do.&nbsp
column5: You know better than that.

column1: ...take action about the bad, dumb or poorly done thing.
column2: There are consequences to behavior and sheer stupidity and it's not going to damage them to get called up short and it &nbsp
column3: could frankly save their lives.

column1: ...tell your child that he can do better.
column2: That said, be ready to provide concrete and hard details as to deficiencies&nbsp
column3: and then be ready to assist with how to improve
column4: surprisingly, many kids will appreciate it.&nbsp
column5: As one teen once told me, <em>when I want praise on something that I've done for school, I take it to my mother.&nbsp
column6: Then I take it to my father to see what needs to be improved.

column1: ...raise your voice and/or speak sternly to your child.
column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: Many fathers don't realize that their voice is a valuable disciplinary tool
column5: that can be used to help maintain some order and discipline before things get completely out of hand.

column1: ...tell your child that it's time to move on to something else, especially in terms of dealing with the electronics.
column2: Kids typically have no sense of when to stop and electronics, particularly games, aren't designed to help develop that so it's up to the parents to say enough.
column3: I've had to really work on handling the resulting whining that accompanies such a directive and I still have testy moments, but kids need to do more than just sit in front of a screen.

column1: ...squelch your child when they're older and frankly, the teen ego sometimes needs it in order to be brought back into line.
...take privileges away even when they're older.
column2: They'll survive without the car, cellphone and iPod for a period of time.&nbsp
column3: That said, it's usually helpful to lay out such a prospect with the original groundrules so that you don't come off as arbitrary and capricious.&nbsp
column4: <em>I expect you home by 10 pm and if there's a problem, contact me immediately.&nbsp
column5: If you're late without contacting me, then you lose the use of the car for the next two days/the trip to the beach with the Jones family/the cellphone for a week/whatever works in the situation...

column1: ...talk and share information with the parents of your child's peers.
column2: Kids and teens usually hate it when parents want to call other parents because it appears to limit their independence and at the worst, prevents them from conspiring to do something phenomenally stupid.&nbsp
column3: But a brief chat at least eases some of the angst and reassures that there are others who also pay attention and try to monitor what's happening.&nbsp
column4: My son and his friend, Opie, were embarrassed when the boy's father came to our front door to meet me one evening before his son's first sleepover at our house.
column5: I frankly appreciated it and could easily defend it to the two boys, who grumbled afterwards, and thoroughly understand why that father did what he did.&nbsp
column6: Thank God, I'm not alone here.

column1: ...ask about what adults are overseeing things and nix plans when you're not comfortable.
column2: Hell, I did it last week.&nbsp
column3:
Stupidity is contagious and in an adolescent brain, one of the last things to mature is that part which controls judgment and risk assessment.

It's frankly too early to pay much attention to the speeches of potential candidates, but I was taken aback by the recent comment of former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney:
column2: Corporations are people.
column3: After a mental double-take, I sat and considered his comment since he's liable to be the next Republican candidate for 2012. &nbsp
column4: Technically, he's correct on multiple counts since a corporation is a legal entity formed by people and employing people for the purpose of making money. &nbsp
column5: Additionally, the United States Supreme Court ruled as far back as 1886 that a corporation had legal standing as a person (Santa Clara County v Southern Pacific) and even recently ruled that campaign finance restrictions were actually a muzzling of Corporate America's First Amendment rights, which so far as I'm concerned is proof that enough money can buy phenomenal legal representation.

column1: But for all of the technical points, Mitt Romney is horrendously wrong.
column2: Mitt sees a Hollywood ingenue while we see Gloria Swanson dripping in mascara and powder to hide the wrinkles and age.

column1: His comments might be sincere and I can even understand why he might believe that given his family history. Mitt Romney is the son of a blue-blood republican and 1968 republican presidential candidate, George Romney, who was himself a former governor of Michigan.
column2: But prior to that political post in the early-mid 1960s, he was the president of the now-defunct American Motors Corporation
column3: in the 1950s, he brought that automobile company back against the GM and Ford behemoths on the back of the spunky little Rambler. &nbsp
column4: George Romney was a corporate man, through and through and was also a Mormon who spent time proselytizing in the British Isles, so there's a particular solidity to his moral beliefs. &nbsp
column5: His son consequently grew up in an environment in which the American corporation was a beneficent and powerful entity which employed thousands of people, it's effectiveness proven by the industrial might of the Second World War and its aftermath.

column1: If you read Tom Brokaw's The Greatest Generation or Studs Terkel's The Good War, one of the
column2: recurrent themes is that the Second World War served as a great equalizer amongst American society so that the Wall Street executive's son served in combat just as the son of the steelworker.
column3: While there was certainly a difference between the pay of the American CEO and his typical employee, it was only 24 times the average worker's wage in 1965 but by 1980 had grown to 42 times the average wage.
column4: The most recent results show that this income differential has risen by 2010 to a stunning 343 times the average worker's wage of $33,900 annually.
column5: The large majority of this pay is via the stock options granted in the executive contracts instead of actual wages
column6: there's consequent incentive to focus on the stock price.&nbsp
column7: Through the ensuing decades, that sense of common cause faded as the generation retired and younger generations with increasingly shorter-term sensibilities took over the reins.&nbsp

column1: If the American corporation is people, just how many actually prosper and share the wealth?
column2: More importantly, how many have had their jobs sacrificed on the altar of globalization to maintain profits?&nbsp
column3: To say that the corporation is composed of people implies a certain common leveling, but how many of those who decided to outsource actually outsourced their own position?&nbsp
column4: Gee, Bob, we've got to cut costs so we're moving your position to Indonesia and since we're all in this together, I'm cutting my position as well.

column1: The American corporation as a benign group of Joe Six-Packs?
column2: Complete bullshit.&nbsp
column3: American corporate management bears some responsibility for the hollowing of American manufacturing and the difficulties facing the American middle class as they increasingly shortened the timeframe of their decisions and viewed people as commodities instead of assets.

column1: As for me, I come by my anti-corporate stance honestly.
column2: My father's corporate job put food on my family's table when I was a child and a roof over my head and my first real job was in a large insurance corporation.&nbsp
column3: My last job however, was in the corporate headquarters of the now defunct MCI.&nbsp
column4: On one afternoon, multiple senior staff were discussing the results of meetings amongst the senior financial executives and how they were looking for ways to help boost the share price of an already profitable company.&nbsp
column5: One of the plans being discussed was to show the market their seriousness by cutting costs, including the closure of several midwest call centers.&nbsp
column6: Understand something about how MCI kept their labor costs low
column7: they would set up call centers in rural areas which had suffered some economic hardship, purchasing and renovating a warehouse or closed store in which to house the folks who were actually calling you to sell the &quot
column8: Friends and Family&quot
column10: Because I had to periodically fly to exotic locales like Sioux City, Iowa and Springfield, Missouri, I can tell you that these people were working to pay off student loans, get health insurance and put food on the table.&nbsp
column11: This appalling concept helped me to understand that I was nothing more than a cog that would be willingly sacrificed to the greater glory of Earnings Per Share.&nbsp
column12: When we found that my wife was pregnant, it was certainly one of my thoughts as I decided to resign and stay home with the baby.&nbsp

column1: Not all corporations are evil and not all executives deserve castration, although that too is increasingly irrelevant in light of more women in management.
column2: But America has become too beholden to the corporations that purchase votes and public image in the pursuit of short-term and pyrrhic profits and when it's time to actually consider the political alternatives, I'm going to remember Mitt's mistaken sentiment and ill-considered remarks.

With school - Dad, don't say that word! - rapidly approaching, one of my tasks is to cull through the upcoming Autumn and Winter clothing to see what's available and what is needed.
column2: This no longer happens with Eldest, who's through growing and whose female fashion is off-limits to Dad but it does happen with her younger brothers, who are far from finished with their growth.&nbsp
column3: The process will start with Youngest and after inventorying what's there and making space, I'll move on to Middle
column4: what he's outgrown will then shift downwards to the little brother.&nbsp
column5: But when I recently glanced at the closet and drawers of one of the boys, I wondered <em>how much does this kid really need?&nbsp
column6: How much do any of us actually need?

column1: I remember my own father tossing out that rhetorical question decades ago as he watched my mother bringing in the shopping bags with back-to-school clothing for my sister and I.
column2: He was a Depression child and could probably count his items of clothing on two hands and nowadays, I myself don't recall having so much clothing in my closet and dresser.&nbsp
column3: But he wanted his children to dress decently and wasn't going to poach on his wife's domain as domestic engineer.&nbsp
column4: Some years ago, I took the kids to the barber/stylist and he chatted about his own childhood in the 1950s with them.&nbsp
column5: What struck them, I learned afterwards, was that he lived in what he described as a decent neighborhood and shared his bedroom with his brothers and that each of them had a dresser drawer in which to keep all of their clothing.&nbsp
column6: <em>A single dresser drawer?&nbsp
column7: They all shared the closet?&nbsp
column8: Huh?

column1: So what happened between the 1950s, the 1980s and now?
column2: If you think about it, it's a reflection of what we did to our industrial sector and our fellow citizens as we pursued globalization.

column1: Regardless of what else you might think of the 1950s and 1960s, it was a period of a strong American livable wage.
column2: Families could afford decent housing, transportation and food with money left over for savings and the discretionary items - the items - that made life more enjoyable.&nbsp
column3: It was also during this period that the American appetite for discretionary items really began to take off, as spending for non-necessities, as a percentage of income&nbsp
column4: rose from 32% in 1950 to 35% in 1960 enroute to 48% in 1985.
column5: While spending was ginning up in the growth of the consumer culture, overseas manufacturing was also ginning up in places ranging from Japan to Indonesia, Korea and ultimately, China.&nbsp
column6: The push was on, with far lower labor costs, for greater consumption of fashion both in clothing and footwear and retailers provided all manner of sales and advertising.&nbsp
column7: It's been in the past two decades that Walmart has become the king of cheap clothing as they've flooded the American market with inexpensive clothing.

column1: Business news organs would periodically chronicle the departure of the American textile industry but this was largely unnoticed by most Americans except for the 1970s union commercials.
column2: In these brief ads, women dressed as blue collar factory workers would slowly gather as they sang Look for the Union label...It was a sad and doomed effort to encourage Americans to support their fellow citizens, but against the constant barrage of sales advertising, was as effective as a squirt gun at a three-alarmer.
column3: Now, my son's closet and drawers are full of clothing and while it's too late at night to check them, I guarantee that 99% of it is imported.&nbsp
column4: Yes, it's cheap and there's lots of it, we being good Americans, but all of that money has gone to a multinational corporation that pays pennies on the dollar to foreign laborers.&nbsp
column5: We have effectively gutted ourselves and sold out entire towns in the southern United States and I've been part and parcel of that tragedy.

column1: So just how much does he need?
column2: Where does it need to come from?

column1: First, I won't do to him what I won't do to myself, so earlier this week, I gutted my own dresser as I downsized from five drawers to two and a half of both summer and winter shirts and short pants.
column2: Tomorrow, I'll do the same to my own closet as I cull out the weak and the lame, leaving only the survivors.

column1: Second, I anticipate that he'll be left with probably a half dozen solely-for-play summer shirts and a few more that can be worn for school.
column2: The same will go for winter wear, including one or two sweaters and a pair of good khakis or navy blue dress slacks.

column1: Third, I'll start searching for clothing in the upcoming sizes that are made in the US and as he outgrows the existing and I have to replace them, I'll purchase the domestically made.
column2: While the cost per item is liable to be higher, the flip side is that having to purchase fewer items should mean a zero-net difference and the money will go to American labor.&nbsp
column3: This is provided that I can find it.

column1: The final advantages of this approach will mean smaller loads of laundry and fewer piles of clothing waiting for dispersal to the various drawers.
column2: Likewise, less money will wind up being wasted on clothing that simply takes up drawer or closet space as it loses out to the more favorite articles that are constantly being worn to the point of threadbare.

column1: Our children learn from our own habits as they grow and observe us.
column2: If we're to make these kinds of changes in our economic habits, then it will be easier for them when they're older and the reality is that we're going to have to change.&nbsp
column3: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

Congratulations, interest rates are now as low as they've been since when Ike was President as the interest rate yield on the 10 year Treasury note
column2: blipped below 2% on August 18, 2011.&nbsp
column3: <em>2%.&nbsp
column4: 2%.
column5: 2%.
column6: The most appropriate response&nbsp
column7: can be&nbsp
column8: genteelly texted as WTF?
column9: But to get a flavor of what that actually means, you have to have a sense of what interest rates used to look like before the Federal Reserve System began altering the rate's genetic code, such as just done by the scientist who gave an alligator snout to a chick in utero.

column1: The interest rate was once the prime food source for those who were looking for a steady income stream, whether they were banks or the elderly who were no longer in the work force.
column2: It's true nutrition lay in the meaty, rich segment known as the real return and that in turn was protected by relatively thick layers that fended off the rate's principal predators, risk and inflation.&nbsp
column3: Since the rate's capture and subsequent alteration, the banks have been forced to find other ways to boost their income stream while the elderly have sometimes had to rely on their alternate food source, cat food.

column1: There are even different breeds of interest rates and how they respond to the twin predators, risk and inflation.
column2: All of them are wary of inflation and the longer-term bonds are not only more nervous, but also typically have much larger inflation layers to protect the real rate.&nbsp
column3: The government bonds are less concerned about risk than their corporate brethren, which have significantly larger risk layers as a result.&nbsp
column4: All of the rate breeds get more nervous when the economy is uncertain but the short term government breed responds like a St Bernard while the 30 year corporate and junk breeds are&nbsp
column5: chihuahuas on a meth bender.

column1: Snark and foolishness aside, there are some things to understand when you hear about interest rates and yields.
column2: Understand this:&nbsp
column3: while everyone hears about the stock market and equities, the reality is that they're a sideshow to the bond market's main stage, upon which rests the various national debts and the supporting currencies.&nbsp
column4: James Carville once remarked that when he died, he wanted to come back as the bond market.

column1: Interest rates are nothing more than the cost of borrowing money, much as you'd pay Days Inn for the cost of using their room for a night or Hertz for the cost of that rental car during vacation.
column2: Borrow from me and it will cost you perhaps 3 or 4 or 17 cents for every dollar that you use.&nbsp
column3: It could be 3, 4 or 17 cents depending upon any of the components that typically comprise interest rates.

column1: Historically, interest rates are composed of three segments.
<li>The first is the real return and this is generally what the lender would like to see as a true return for lending the money to a borrower for using his money.&nbsp
column2: It is a function of the lender's preferences and also what other uses he might have for the money.&nbsp
column3: <em>Hey, if I can't get at least 4% real return on my money, then what's the point of lending it?&nbsp
column4: I can use it for my own purposes.

column1: <li>The second component is that which pays the lender for what she assesses as the risk of the return of the money and it's here that the ubiquitous credit scores come into play.&nbsp
column2: If you've been bankrupt like Trump or planning to spend the money on a risky private space exploration company and you're liable to find that the lenders are going to ask for a higher interest rate to compensate them and this will be tacked onto the real return that the lender wants.&nbsp
column3: Historically, interest rates are&nbsp
column4: generally higher&nbsp
column5: as you go further out since there's greater uncertainty as to what's going to happen and that's why the&nbsp
column6: 48 month CD rate pays you a generous 1.0% versus the .3% on the 6 month CD.&nbsp

column1: <li>The third component is the segment that compensates the lender for what they anticipate the rate of inflation is going to be.&nbsp
column2: Bonds pay at a constant rate and that is consequently eroded over time by inflation, which eats away at the purchasing power of the currency.&nbsp
column3: If you know that you're going to be repaid $1000/month over the next ten years, then you certainly want to assure that there's some extra sweetener since $1000/month won't buy in ten years what it buys now.

column1: So the interest rates that you knew in the past were comprised of each of the three elements together.
column2: When rates spiked in the early 1980s, that was a function of the Federal Reserve driving rates up with a healthy inflation premium to combat the effects of inflation rippling through the country at that time.&nbsp
column3: If you miss a credit card payment and the rate is raised, that's a function of the bank's response to what they perceive as the increased risk that you'll default and walk away
column4: the amount of the rate increase is certainly debatable but the rationale behind it isn't.

column1: When you hear about the yield on a particular type of bond, you're hearing about the interest rate of the actual return on what was paid for the bond when it was actually purchased on the market.
Bonds all have coupon rates stating that they'll pay $X per each month or year and the face value of the bond is the amount that will be paid off when the bond reaches maturity.
column2: Consequently, a company issuing new debt might agree to pay $400/year for 15 years on a bond with a face value of $10000 so the stated rate of the bond is 4% annually ($400/10000).&nbsp
column3: But let's say that the bond buyers believe that in the next 15 years, inflation is going to run at a rate of 5%/year so there's actually a 1% loss of purchasing power to the holder of this 4% piece of dogfood.&nbsp
column4: The company needs the money and the sale goes through
column5: where the adjustment occurs is in what folks are willing to pay for the loss of purchasing power and that's the bond's face value.&nbsp
column6: <em>I'll lose 1% annually over 15&nbsp
column7: years?&nbsp
column8: Meh, I'll bid $8500 for it and if I can get the $10000 for $8500, then that's good enough for me.&nbsp
column9: The actual interest rate yield on the bond is consequently 4.7% ($400/8500).
column10: The annual bond payments are still $400 but the bondholder paid less for the bond and that's the value on which the yield is calculated.

column1: The takeaway from the bond market is this:
column2: <strong><em>bond yields are inverse to bond prices and bond prices are a function of supply and demand.&nbsp
column3: Yields drop because prices paid for bonds rise and vice versa.
column4: If the yield on a particular class of bonds drops, then that's because folks are willing to pay something extra for that bond.&nbsp

column1: That's a hard question because it's an interplay between the Federal Reserve and the generalized market.

column4: low rates - until you understand that these rates are on amounts often in the millions and for that day alone.&nbsp
column5: But these have to be predicated upon some standard and for the United States, that standard is the Fed Funds rate, the base interest rate at which banks lend to one another or borrow from the Federal Reserve for their everyday needs.
column6: Presently, the Fed Funds rate is a whopping .25%, which means that banks have an extraordinarily cheap source of funds and the idea is that as the Fed Funds rate is adjusted one direction or another by the Federal Reserve, this will provide some guidance on where rates are supposed to go in the rest of the credit markets.

column3: The hope now is that the easy money policy will somehow flush through the economy and create inflation so that the massive debts are covered by devalued dollars.&nbsp

column4: As low as mortgage rates were in the height of the housing bubble, you can argue that the lack of risk was passed along to the homebuyer with the compression of the risk segment of the interest rate.

It's sometimes the little things that truly stay with the kids as they age.
column2: They might be drawings that you make for them or games that you play and my case, it's the bathtub songs that helped me work with them through washing.&nbsp

column1: Kids respond to music and tunes and simply having a small song for something that has to be done "
column2: makes the medicine go down&quot
column3: far easier.&nbsp
column4: In my case, I would mess with the kids from when they were babies and I had to wash them in the bathtub and soon developed a series of songs that I sang when a new phase of the job had to happen.&nbsp
column5: There was a ditty about cleaning the bottom, a knock-off of Figaro for the hair-washing, and a Doo-Wop tune for drying off with the towel
column6: these were things that I sang to them each night as I bathed them and only stopped when they were old enough to clean themselves.&nbsp
column7: I haven't sung them in years as Youngest has long since been able to handle cleaning himself.

column1: Twice in the past week - once in the car and again at dinner tonight - I've chatted with the two older kids and found that they can recite and sing the doggerel bathtub songs that I sang to them when they were very young.
column2: In the first instance, Middle actually sang harmony as I sang it for him again while driving the other evening.&nbsp
column3: The second occurred at dinner tonight as all three were present and each remembered all of the songs (although Youngest didn't recall as well, a function of my not bathing him as often as my wife).&nbsp
column4: I was stunned at the laughter as they recounted the tunes and the verses and could only think that it's the little things.

column1: Kids don't need all kinds of toys or things, but they do need you.
column2: Find something - anything - that you can make your own with them and then do it again, and again, and again.
column3:
This is what the kids need, and want, more than anything else to connect with you, your time and attention.

Enough with the Spongebob and turn the damned thing off.
column2: It makes you stupid.
&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp

column8: &nbsp
column69: - Periodic comment from PracticalDad to Youngest

column1: And just to prove that I was actually right, a University of Virginia psychology professor published a study in Pediatrics
column2: that found that four year old children who watched Spongebob did worse - in a statistically relevant way - than their peers who watched either PBS' Caillou or just drew with markers and crayons.
column3: In this particular study, 60 four year-old children were divided into three equal sized groups and each was to participate in that particular activity for a short period of time
column4: at the end of the activity, each child engaged in the same particular series of tasks to test such things as the ability to delay gratification and handle games that require a series of rules.&nbsp
column5: The Spongebob kids did only half as well as those who watched either Caillou or drew.

column1: In all fairness to Spongebob - who is actually funny in limited amounts - the issue isn't that particular cartoon but instead, the nature and style of the program.
column2: Caillou is a mellow cartoon that leads the viewer through a simple, plot-driven story and it doesn't make it a habit of radically shifting gears in volume and drawing.
column3: Years ago, one of the recurrent criticisms of Sesame Street was that the constant intersplicing of skits, cartoons and songs would hinder the development of preschool viewers and that is echoed in this particular study.
column4: Programs such as Spongebob and others - Fairly Oddparents,
column5: anyone? - now make Sesame Street appear to be the model in flow and style.
column6: As one other researcher noted, <a title=""Bloomberg.com"" href=""http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-09-12/fast-paced-cartoons-such-as-spongebob-may-harm-kids-brains-study-finds.html"">&quot
column7: not all TV is the same. It's not about no television, it's really about appropriate amounts and appropriate types of television&quot
column8: .
column9: Watching a program such as Caillou, and I've watched it, does require that the child be able to focus on a particular story for a period of time without persistent and chronic interruption and the same goes for the task of drawing and coloring.
column10: There is a level of stimulation to the brain that's more consistent with their age than with the hyperactive Spongebob type of program.&nbsp
column11: With very small children, such simple focusing tasks do&nbsp
column12: have a cumulative effect on the ability to perform as well as to more easily shift gears from one scenario to another, keeping with their age and capacity.

column1: I think that there's another issue apart from the overstimulation however.
column2: Children will often mimic what they see and that's most certainly the case if they like something.&nbsp
column3: Spongebob glorifies stupidity and kids who've just watched another episode of his inanity will, at some level, want to play out what they've seen
column4: immediately immersing kid viewers in a series of exercises requiring the opposite of what Spongebob promotes is setting them up for failure.
column5: This kind of behavior is no different than that of teens who watch Dodgeball for the umpteenth time and immediately spend ten minutes tossing objects at one another, yelling if you can dodge a wrench, you can dodge a ball!

column1: As the one researcher noted, the issue isn't the program itself, although it is indeed phenomenally dumb.
column2: The issue is that we're&nbsp
column3: allowing the kids to spend all of this time in front of a screen without chasing them off and making them learn to do something else.&nbsp
column4: There's value for a child to lay in his bed or look out the window and daydream, just as there's value in drawing, playing with blocks and chasing down neighborhood kids to go play.&nbsp
column5: I understand the draw both of television to the child and of ease for the parent, but it's a battle that's going to have to be waged continuously until they're out of the house.

column1: For your own curiosity, one of the tasks asked of the kids was the Tower of Hanoi
column2: exercise, aptly named since I personally found it torturous to figure out.

column1: <li>When you read or hear something, understand that what you're hearing isn't the whole story and be ready to have to find the whole story.&nbsp

column9: When the TARP took effect, I had a conversation with the branch manager of our bank and according to that person, yes, we took a little bit of that money because we were advised to do so and we've since paid it back in entirety.
column10: That was over two years ago and when I reviewed this Bloomsberg report the other night, I found that my bank had been tied to the Fed via one of the windows and were carrying a loan balance through this program for an average of 400 days.&nbsp
column11: So right about the time that I talked with the manager, my bank was tapped into the Fed window for survival money.

There are moments and evenings that help you see the forest for the trees, as I noted some time ago, and tonight was one of those instances.
column2: While things are busy with kids coming in and out - many of&nbsp
column3: those who aren't ours&nbsp
column4: referring&nbsp
column5: to my wife and I as &quot
column6: Mom&quot
column7: and &quot
column8: Dad&quot
column9: - you get a sense of where you are in terms of life and parenting.

column1: The kids tonight were friends of Eldest who are all leaving for college within the next three days, while she still has a year to go.
column2: But the college visits are on the calendar and her own senior year is shaping up to be breathtaking in its rapidity.&nbsp
column3: Middle was upstairs hogging the phone and as the school year approaches, I tucked Youngest in earlier and curled up with him for a little while.&nbsp
column4: That's now where we are - the eldest with only a year remaining before college and the youngest still asking to be tucked in, but those bedtime days are waning and soon, he'll be big enough that he say goodnight and go up by himself and an almost two decade bedtime routine will be at an end.&nbsp

column1: There were times in those years that I couldn't wait for that routine to end.
column2: Friends talked about this hilarious show called Everybody Loves Raymond and I could never quite get to the television before the final credits rolled and while there's TiVo, it simply wasn't the same thing.
column3: I never actually saw one of Ray Romano's episodes until it was in its seventh or eighth season.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, there were organizations that I didn't join because of involvement with kid-related sports and scouting and <em>geez, I couldn't make a meeting because of X, Y or Z.&nbsp
column5: Now that there's far, far fewer bedtimes than ever before, I find that I'm going to miss them with their opportunities to giggle or chat with the kids,
column6: listen to them breathe as they nod off, or even just awakening slightly refreshed after snoozing myself.

column1: My father used to remark that that's the way it's supposed to be and the guy was correct.
column2: Our job is to clothe, house, feed, teach and protect them until they're able to begin to start taking on some responsibilities themselves
column3: they'll screw up - as we did - but they'll improve and learn and eventually, we'll be left once again to our own devices.&nbsp
column4: That's the way it's supposed to be.

column1: In the press of things, remember to enjoy these days and keep some of them tucked away in your memory for later.
For Ray Romano, there's cable and boxed sets of DVDs.
column2:
For these days however, there are only the memories.

One of the better, truer commercials on television is actually for ED - and no, I don't have a bathtub in the backyard.
column2: In these ads, guys in their 40s are presented with different situations and simply handle them as the announcer comments, when you reach a certain age, you just know how to do stuff...Pulling a horse trailer and the pickup gets stuck in the mud?
column3: Hitch the horses and let them pull you out.&nbsp
column4: Engine overheating and in the desert?&nbsp
column5: Just add water at some roadside cafe.

column1: That's kind of the role of a father as the kids get older and begin to think that they know everything.
column2: Something goes wrong and Dad gets the call and if he's smart, he takes the opportunity to pass along the institutional knowledge that comes with age, if not with trace teams of horses.&nbsp

column1: That's the situation this morning as Eldest heads off to school in the old car.
column2: Because her schedule actually requires some traveling, she drives an old car and lo and behold, she crawls behind the wheel and turns the ignition and is greeted by the sounds of silence.
column3: The battery is officially dead and will have to be replaced.&nbsp
column4: <em>Daddy, Mom's gonna take me to school but can you have the battery fixed for when I get back?&nbsp
column5: Gotta run, bye!

column1: Yes, but you've actually going to do it with me so that you can learn.

column2: quick trip to the auto supply store for a battery and then home to assure that I've got the sockets that fit the nuts on the battery.&nbsp
column3: And then...nothing.&nbsp
column4: When I finally pick up Eldest, it's back home where she spends maybe 15 minutes replacing the battery - taking into account learning how to use a ratchet set - and then is off again.&nbsp

column1: I could honestly have finished the job in less than 10 minutes but it's more important that Eldest learn how to handle these things in preparation for a future out of the household.
column2: These are the kinds of things that most teens don't know and would wind up calling home about when they're off in the real world.&nbsp
column3:
It takes more time and effort, assuring that I've got things and that they're right so that I don't look like the village idiot, but teaching is ultimately one of the most important things that any father can do for their kids.

column2: too many promises and too few resources.&nbsp
column3: It's been coming for years and is finally now rippling through the heart of our neighborhoods, only I doubt that everyone fully grasps what it means.&nbsp
column4: A case in point is the neighborhood bus stop.

column1: I live in a geographically large school district, one of the biggest in our county, and like other districts, it's responsible for providing bus transportation to the various schools.
column2: Like other districts as well, it's being pinched by declining tax revenues and state grants on one hand and the rise in fuel and other costs and the result is an ongoing search for ways to&nbsp
column3: close the gap.&nbsp
column4: There have been numerous measures over the past two years but they've largely been unseen and now they're becoming more obvious.&nbsp
column5: Several weeks before the start of school, the district transportation coordinator sent out the obligatory &quot
column6: bus stop&quot
column7: letters detailing where each child would be able to atch their respective bus
column8: Youngest's moved to a more distant corner.&nbsp
column9: However, it wasn't until everybody showed up on&nbsp
column10: the first day of school that the full extent of the change&nbsp

column1: It helps to understand our neighborhood's geography.
column2: We live in a relatively new development with only one entry road within almost a full mile from an adjoining entry road.&nbsp
column3: When you enter the development, the road has a left turn within 150 yards of the entrance (we'll call it road 'A') and if you continue to go straight, the entry road makes a giant loop of approximately one mile&nbsp
column4: before terminating at road 'A', only about 100 yards from where it begins at the original entry road.&nbsp
column5: In simpler terms, envision a fish hook with a straight line&nbsp
column6: running from the barbed end of the hook back&nbsp
column7: to the hook itself, and that's the neighborhood.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: Previously, there were three separate bus stops on this loop.&nbsp
column10: With the new bus routes, our neighborhood's stops have been slashed from five to two stops.&nbsp
column11: The loop road has been removed from the route and all of the kids now have to walk from their homes on the loop to the first bus stop at the beginning of the loop.&nbsp

column1: On that first morning, Youngest and I walked to the assigned stop, the one furthest from our house - the one located at the hypothetical barbed end of the fishhook while all of the kids from the loop gathered at the stop at the entry road to the development
column2: there were 17 children along with accompanying parents and siblings at this particular stop.&nbsp
column3: As I walked back after Youngest got onto the bus, I fell into conversation with some of the parents from that stop and again later in the day when the kids were to be dropped off.&nbsp
column4: Several had contacted the school district to complain and request that the loop stops be reinstated for multiple reasons:&nbsp
column5: distance from the house (less than a half mile)
column6: nowhere to stand in inclement weather (true) and danger of the intersection.&nbsp
column7: To his credit, the district superintendant actually drove by the stop this morning and spent a few minutes talking with the waiting parents.&nbsp
column8: Frankly, I said nothing since - as I told my wife later - we haven't got a dog in that hunt and I let someone else carry the conversation.
column9: In our view, if the school district moved the bus stop further away in an entirely different direction to save money, then we would've considered it as the cost of doing business.&nbsp
column10: The superintendant commiserated since he lives in the district as well and his own three kids are affected along with everyone else's, but the point was made that cutting that mile loop saves two miles daily and with an entire fleet of buses, the cumulative savings are considerable.&nbsp

column1: This is an open change that confronts parents directly, since many of them don't see the other changes that confront the kids.
column2:
I neither know nor care what the response is going to be, but if this is some of the reaction from simply altering bus routes, then I can't fathom what some of the reaction is going to be for the changes that are down the road as this ebbing tide of resources recedes further over time.

I believe in serendipity and after tonight's dinner conversation about judging people, I was struck by Gonzalo Lira's essay on our collective unwillingness to make judgments.
column2: Mr. Lira makes his case about our unwillingness to pass judgment, especially in light of former Vice-President Cheney's recent book being issued shortly.&nbsp
column3: His stance, eerily similar to mine, is that we have to be willing to make judgments as we go through life and that these judgments are best predicated upon some basis of morality.&nbsp
column4: If there's no framework for making decisions based upon a common sense of right and wrong, then decisions are reduced to the more base calculations of economic, social and political self-interest.

September's pricing of the 47 item PracticalDad grocery basket showed that the cost of the basket rose .81% from August's level with the September index now at 105.71
column2: cumulatively, the cost of the market basket is now 5.71% higher than that at the November 2010 inception.

column1: Inflation at the retail grocery level appears to be starting to surge as the cost of the market basket rose almost 2% from July to September
column2: it had risen 3.71% in the preceding nine month period of November 2010 to July 2011.
&nbsp

column1: So what's notable about the September pricing?
<li>Grocers are making significant changes to keep prices under control.&nbsp
column2: In one instance this month, a grocer kept the same price and size for coffee (@ 11 oz) but went from a can to a vacuum-packed brick.&nbsp
column3: In another, a grocer actually dropped the price of their 42 ounce container of one-minute oatmeal by 30% but did so by completely eliminating their own store-brand and replacing it with a much lower cost off-brand oatmeal.&nbsp
column4: Had it not been for this particular effect, the Index would have been higher.

column1: <li>Produce at the retail level rose again as the average cost of potatoes from three stores rose by an additional 7.9% and apples also rose by a full 10%.&nbsp
column2: Eggs shot up in price by almost 17%, but this product has shown that it can fluctuate in price over the past year so it's uncertain whether such an increase will stick.

column1: • There were fewer items that had price increases than last month, as well as items with rises greater than 5%.
