For the better part of the last three years, there's been an ongoing debate about whether the economic climate and monetary policy is going to lead to either deflation or inflation.
column2: With all of the talk and uncertainty, I decided a year ago to pull together my own retail grocery price index in order to ascertain what was actually occurring in my own little corner of the world, apart from all of the conjecture and commentary.&nbsp
column3: This led to the birth of the PracticalDad Price Index in November 2010 and unfortunately, this baby's growing.

column1: There are some thoughts that should be passed along.
<li>Because I actually managed a local cost-of-living survey when I graduated from college, I do have previous experience in such creatures and this was not a foray into uncharted territory.&nbsp
column2: It took considerable time and consideration beforehand but once established, the process is a straightforward one.

column1: <li>There is no doubt that this is not a national effort and it is purely what's occurring at the retail grocery level for a particular county in the Middle Atlantic region of the United States.&nbsp
column2: However, while there may be differences from the Mid-Atlantic to the West Coast to the Boston-Washington corridor, the question isn't what the actual prices are from one place to another so much as what's happening to the level of the prices.
column3: Having lived throughout the mid-South, Suburban Maryland/DC and Mid-Atlantic regions, I know full well that grapes are more expensive in New Jersey than they are where I live.&nbsp
column4: But I'm hard pressed to say that what's happening with prices in my county is contained solely to my county
column5: two of the three grocers surveyed have operations far beyond the county borders and all three of them obtain their products from wholesalers and manufacturers&nbsp
column6: that are supporting stores across an expansive geographic area.&nbsp
column7: Might prices be up a half-percent less elsewhere?&nbsp
column8: Perhaps, the reality is that they are up significantly beyond what's admitted to by the official statisticians in the US government and that's what this effort shows.

column1: <li>Aside from having previous experience with a survey, I'm also the guy who did the shopping for years (and while my wife does more because she likes it, I still do the lion's share).&nbsp
column2: When I determined what items should compose the 47 item market basket, I drew heavily upon my experience shopping for a very young family of five.&nbsp
column3: What does a family, having recently undergone a 55% paycut, have to do make the dollar stretch farther?
column4: What are the basic items that we need to purchase in order to stock our pantry and feed ourselves?&nbsp
column5: That's why the market basket is stocked with basics such as hamburger, white bread, oatmeal, apples and carrots.&nbsp
column6: The other premise was based upon my experience of sticking whenever possible to store brands in order to save pennies.&nbsp
column7: There are a few products that my wife disliked enough that I returned to name brands, but my thinking was that the cumulative total of buying store brand everything saved enough to make it worthwhile.

column1: <li>This is what makes a 5.71% rise in the cost of the basket frankly scary.&nbsp
column2: The items comprising the basket are basics without any real room for substitution.&nbsp
column3: If you give up arugula, you can shift to iceberg lettuce and if Campbell's becomes too costly, you can go to the store brand.&nbsp
column4: But how do you replace 80% hamburger or store brand white bread?&nbsp
column5: When budgets no longer allow for restaurants, people can opt to cook.&nbsp
column6: But what do you use when cooking oil becomes too costly?

column1: <li>As a child in the late 1960s and early 1970s, I recall news reports of housewives picketing their grocers because the cost of food was rising beyond their budgets.&nbsp
column2: But having watched the actions of the grocers for the past eleven months, I actually have to admire some of their decisions and don't consider them to be the &quot
column3: bad guy&quot
column4: .&nbsp
column5: Understand that the grocery business is one with exceptionally thin profit margins so that there isn't any real ability for them to eat the losses.&nbsp
column6: There have been multiple instances in which more than one grocer has had items for sale with considerable savings prior to raising the price
column7: you can argue that it's done in order to hide the real price increase over the two or three week period - <em>wait, was that the price before I bought it on sale three weeks ago?&nbsp
column8: Nah... - but it's also giving folks the opportunity to stock up on an item in advance.
column9: Likewise, I'm now seeing where the grocer is actually dropping their store brand for that particular size and replacing it with a much lower cost off-brand product.&nbsp
column11: Sure, but it's also an acknowledgement that they understand that folks are stretching and they're acting to assist the consumers.

column1: <li>While two points don't make a trend, the fact that the market basket rose half as much in two months in the previous nine months is worrisome and could indicate that retail food inflation is picking up a head of steam more quickly than the government or Federal Reserve would want to acknowledge.&nbsp
column2: That's precisely why I'm honestly anxious about the pricing that's going to be done in early October.

It had been a brutal session with one of the kids, who frankly refused to do what was asked on multiple occasions.
column2: With a father who used to be a drill instructor, I learned how to get into someone's personal space and face and this is finally what I did when I'd tired of the nonsensical back-and-forth with this recalcitrant 'tweener.&nbsp
column3: The face looked up at me as I glared down, inches from the nose and with that, the child retreated to perform the oft-requested task.

column1: My wife shook her head at me and sighed as she said, does it have to be a contest of wills?
It's a question that has stayed with me since that evening some time ago.
column2: Does there have to be a contest of wills between the parent - and when there's a father around, it often falls to the father - and the child?
column3: Discipline is one of the less pleasant sides of parenting and in today's world, many parents seemingly want to be a friend or pal and nothing puts a dent into being a pal than having to assure that rules are followed and chores performed.&nbsp
column4: It can be much easier and less likely when the kids are smaller - they're more eager to please, their social world hasn't expanded to a point at which they're too heavily influenced by other kids, and they can be more easily redirected when they get stubborn.&nbsp
column5: But shouldn't it become easier when they become older, seemingly old enough to be reasoned with?

column1: Kids do grow and as they're exposed to more people and situations, they start to change.
column2: While I can try to <a title=""PracticalDad:  &quot
column3: ...Pick Your Battles&quot
column4: href=""http://www.practicaldad.com/index.php/article/158"">pick my battles, there are simply some things that I can't let slide and this is where it gets hairy.
column5: The kids are undergoing huge changes as they explore their sense of independence, their unwillingness to appear &quot
column6: under the thumb&quot
column7: before their peers and the general sense that Dad is now a blithering idiot.&nbsp
column8: It's compounded with male teens as some are surging with the testosterone that makes them believe that they're ready to assume the role of Alpha male in the household and that is something that can't be permitted lest the inmates take over the asylum.
column9: It's difficult, and this is coming from a guy who's made it a point to assure that the kids understand from an early age that Mom and Dad have the final say.

column1: So I'll just have to continue to try to manuever through the situations as they arise and hopefully, keep the clashes to a minimum.
column2:
But they're still going to happen.

They're so thoroughly involved in finding their identity and fitting in with a particular group that the various masses of teens change form reminiscent of an amoeba, as various members roll in or choose to - or are expelled - leave, thus altering the amoeba's shape again.&nbsp
column3: It would be a fascinating minuet to watch but that teens generally don't participate in something so intricate
column4: that particular skill comes later.

column1: The best way to describe teens in the group setting is almost as
column2: a tribe.&nbsp
column3: They cluster together and the more time that they're spent unmonitored, the more opportunity that they have to blend their hormonal sauces into what can be a highly combustible stew.&nbsp
column4: It's bad enough when no adult is around to just keep tabs on things, but the pure absence of parental supervision can distill a 100-proof moonshine of sheer lunacy.&nbsp
column5: The kids are gathered around with the metal or techno-pop roaring in the background, the bass reverberating against the walls and as conversation passes with time and merges with the beat of the rhythm, a recognizable pattern begins to emerge from the noise, a patois that seamlessly merges the steadily cadenced rhythm with the muttered conversations that finally emerges as a simple chant reverberating off of the walls...

column1: Hey, ya wanna jump off of the roof?
Hey, ya wanna climb the town water tower and hang upside down?
Hey, ya wanna smack each other with a stick?
Hey, ya wanna get Ozzy's face tattooed on your butt?
Hey, ya wanna ride to the 7-11 on the roof of my car?
The permutations are often novel, especially in this day of Youtube, but mind-numbingly similar in their sheer and utter lack of self-regard and common sense.
column2: Anyone with teens will recognize the egging on and it quietly terrifies me as I can see any number of ways that something can end badly.&nbsp
column3: It's this concern that causes us to provide a place for them to gather, a place that they can be exceedingly, frustratingly and wonderfully stupid, a place that we can at least have a sense of what's happening.&nbsp
column4: If 'wonderfully' seems to be an odd wordchoice, it's one that I use because the rhythmic chant stirs up old, fond memories of when I also belonged to a tribe.&nbsp
column5: One that I've outgrown but still holds a special place in my heart and soul.&nbsp

column1: So my wife and I will provide the facilities as they're wanted, and we'll do our best to keep tabs on the comings-and-goings.
column2: And I'll continue to mutter the occasional silent prayer that our kids not kill themselves in those moments when we can't keep tabs.

This is why I generally try to write while the kids aren't around.&nbsp
column3: I get distracted and hit the 'Submit' button instead of 'Save'.&nbsp
column4: Let's try this again...

column1: According to recent research from the National Academy of Sciences, there's a statistically significant link - the probability is less than .001 that it's a complete fluke- between the time that a guy spends caring for his child(ren) and his testosterone level.
column2: It's hit all of the media outlets from Yahoo to television and by next week, will probably be a movie of the week on Lifetime.&nbsp
column3: The hypothesis is that significant involvement with childcare, defined as greater than 3 hours daily, causes significant decline in the testosterone level as the male shifts from a need to propagate his line to one of actually raising it.&nbsp
column4: The apparent company line is that children in their sweet tenderness naturally soften the savage male heart, bringing the father ever so nearere to the bosom of his hearth and home.&nbsp
column5: Reading some of the media reports makes me see everything in a soft, gauzy glow akin to a Christmas hearth from a Hallmark card.

column1: Let me speak from experience for a moment.
column2: When you're responsible for cleaning up - and after - kids, feeding and caring for them, you have absolutely no time and little desire and energy to father any more.&nbsp
column3: As wonderful as children are, the daily life of raising a small child can be a grind.&nbsp
column4: Toss in a dose of sleep deprivation and there you have it.

column1: Is there a linkage between time spent in childcare and lower testosterone levels?
column2: According to this, yep, and I don't dispute it in the least.&nbsp
column3: But some of the company line of why smacks of a preconceived notion or an agenda.
column4: Testosterone levels can be linked to causes as disparate as chemo and radiation treatment for cancer and the tightness of one's underwear (women think that briefs are sexier, but they can cause a guy to shoot blanks).&nbsp
column5: Testosterone is produced by the male's testes but if you follow the production process backwards from the testes, the testes production is stimulated by chemicals produced by the pituitary gland.&nbsp
column6: The Pituitary gland receives it's marching orders from the hypothalamus, which is a lower level segment of the brain that controls hormone and other autonomic functions.&nbsp
column7: The hypothalamus itself receives it's own set of orders from the cerebral cortex, which is one of the most advanced segments of the brain.&nbsp
column8: Typically, feelings of success, arousal and confidence will spur the cortex to kick the hypothalamus into gear, literally saying <em>hey, go get me some more of that stuff!&nbsp

column1: My own sense is that any cause is more related to the issues in the cortex than anything else.
column2: Raising kids is a challenge on multiple levels and a guy can feel wholly overwhelmed in the early periods.&nbsp
column3: <em>Why is she crying?&nbsp
column4: What does she need - diaper, food or is this colic?&nbsp
column5: How do I handle it when I can't get him to go down for his nap?&nbsp
column6: Damn, who do I cover first when one is crying from an ear infection and the other has just vomited on the sofa?
column7: <em>How can I feel good about myself when I've only had four hours of sleep and haven't showered in two days?&nbsp
column8: It's sometimes a situation of reacting to one situation or another with a recurrent fear that something's been done wrong and that you're

column1: So much for feelings of success and confidence.
There is something that I'd like to see with this study since it does have real value.
column2: The sample consisted of young Filipino men in their early and mid twenties
column3: what is the effect on testosterone several years in the future, after the kids are through the stage of requiring such hands-on, intense attention?&nbsp

column1: We're only one generation of fathers in a lineage of untold generations of fathers and somehow, with some perseverance and considerable attention, we'll do just fine.
column2: But we are different in that we're the first generation of men in a long while to really begin to hit the trenches of childcare and childrearing and we're discovering what women have known for the longest time, that children require a level of attention that impacts almost all other areas of our lives.&nbsp

One of the more unexpected sights at this summer's Van's Warped Tour punk concert was a stand touting Ron Paul as President in 2012.
column2: It stood next to a Libertarian Party stand that attracted teens like moths to a flame with it's tie-dyed marijuana logo flag and some of the teens then slid over to receive free copies of the Constitution from the Paul supporters.&nbsp
column3: According to the adults at the stand, the Libertarian stand provided concert-goers with surveys that helped them identify themselves in the political realm and the large majority of the youth were strongly Libertarian.&nbsp
column4: And providing copies of the Constitution?&nbsp
column5: While my initial take was amused disbelief, I've come to think of it not only as very smart but also as something that's desperately needed.

column1: One of my great criticisms of today's youth - and parents by extension - is that they've willingly tuned out to the world around them.
column2: I sometimes also bear some of the same criticism as it's simply tiring of having to always shoo teens away&nbsp
column3: from&nbsp
column4: the various electronic media, but it's a chronic and recurrent necessity as Youtube and Facebook are infinitely easier to understand than the vagaries and intricacies of abortion debates and budget deadlocks.&nbsp
column5: This was brought home last week by an encounter with Middle, who was stalling on studying his US History assignment on the Constitution.&nbsp
column6: It was hammer and tongs for a short period and then he simply blurted out <em>what's the point anyway?&nbsp
column7: The government's corrupt and none of them give a damn about anything but themselves...whether this was a true statement of his belief or just another dodge (it certainly didn't work) is uncertain, but the fact that he could make such such a statement and then back it up was eye-opening.
column8: After listening to his comments, I could only state that if we really don't make an effort to learn what the document both is and was meant to be, then the political situation would only&nbsp
column10: Surprisingly, he nodded and then moved to take care of his lesson.

column1: The kids are absolutely ill-informed about the world and their place in it, and some of that is on us as parents.
column2: But they're not completely unaware and from what I hear from my two eldest, are irritated at the state of things.&nbsp
column3: The austerity meme is percolating through their walls of indifference and they're actively questioning why the school budget for the Arts is decimated while there's money for installing surveillance cameras in every classroom.&nbsp
column4: For them, it's both a question of priorities and whether such a degree of watching is either safe or necessary.&nbsp
column5: They're also listening to their friends who are now in college and beginning to grasp the difficulties they face as we've managed to give away the employment farm and are on the cusp of an economic downsizing on a generational level.&nbsp
column6: Should they pay greater attention to the Constitution?&nbsp
column7: Absolutely, as now&nbsp
column8: two members of the political class - the North Carolina governor and the former head of Obama's Office of Management and Budget - are questioning whether we should just either not hold elections or turn the business of state to appointed councils to avoid that nasty political bickering
column9: if Ron Paul's libertarian beliefs and punk rock are what motivates our present punkers and future leaders to read the Constitution, then I plan to take my kids to the Warped Tour concerts for as long as they'll want to go.

The stated belief is that fatherhood changes a man.
column2: There's recent research that links fatherhood to lower testosterone
column3: and there's now a new study that finds that fathers actually have a lower risk of death from heart disease and stroke.
column4: Where&nbsp
column5: fatherhood has changed me is in my economic and political views
column6: I'm not the political man that I was before the birth of my children.&nbsp
column7: The inactions of our political class and actions of our financial elites have inculcated a corrupt system that threatens the ability of my children - our children - to have any meaningful life apart from that of serf or debt slave.&nbsp
column8: If you want a clue of how a guy went from conservative Republican to a man who cheered on Bernie Sanders' filibuster, try to view the changes in our nation through the prism of how it actually applies to

column2: the children.
column3: Let's&nbsp
column4: actually focus on a select group which has identifiable names and faces and&nbsp
column5: in this case,&nbsp
column6: it will&nbsp
column7: be my&nbsp
column8: eldest child's&nbsp
column10: If you want to broaden it, then consider all of the kids that you can actually name and recognize from the activities, the bus stop and Chuck E Cheese if that works for you.&nbsp
column12: at the local high school and there are about 450 students in her grade.&nbsp
column13: To make this even more interesting, grab a copy&nbsp
column15: yearbook and consider these statistics as you page through it.&nbsp

column2: ran an article that compiled the changes in poverty statistics over the past several years
column3: and the changes are informative.&nbsp
column4: What makes them scary is to actually apply them in a real life setting amongst flesh-and-blood human beings that you can identify and who walk through your door.&nbsp

column1: In one year - 2009 to 2010 - the percentage of those living in poverty with a family-of-four income less than $22314 rose from 14.3 to 15.1.
column2: The poverty line for only one person is roughly half that, at $11,139.&nbsp
column3: That means that 68 of Eldest's classmates will wind up with incomes below the poverty limit when they're truly functioning economic adults and earning a fulltime - or not - income.&nbsp
column4: They're less likely to have cohesive families and they will actually face the situation of not eating&nbsp
column5: because their maximum weekly income of $200 won't cover food, gas and housing.&nbsp

column1: Of this 15.1%, almost half - 6.7% - aren't even earning half of the poverty line.
column2: So of these 68 classmates - and I can't be certain that even Eldest won't be among them - 30 of them will be literally destitute.&nbsp
Since the start of the recession - which has technically been over, in case no one informed you - the median household income has dropped by 6.4% to $49,445 and hasn't been this low since 1996.&nbsp
column3: A full decade and a half&nbsp
column4: of income growth&nbsp
column5: have been wiped away.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Since neither&nbsp
column8: I nor anybody else&nbsp
column10: any organic income drivers, apart from a mass exodus sponsored by Virgin/Alcoa to mine precious metals on the outer planets of the solar system, Eldest's classmates are looking at a retrenchment of median family income back to levels of decades ago.&nbsp
column11: Forget wide-screen plasma television and say&nbsp
column16: from the planet for Phoebe and Europa, where&nbsp
column18: will likely die in an explosive decompression of a faulty airlock.&nbsp
column19: His widow and kids will receive a tidy life-insurance settlement and a year's free supply of aluminum foil.

column2: only&quot
column3: about 1 in 6 six Americans in poverty, the grinding down of the economic machine is creating casualties as more than 45 million Americans in over 19 million households now receive some manner of food stamp assistance.&nbsp
column4: That's approximately 17% of the households (19 million households divided by 112 million total US households) and if
column5: Eldest and each classmate forms their own future household, the present number means that 77 kids would receive food stamps.&nbsp
column6: Bear in mind that the food stamp&nbsp
column7: trend has been upward and the currect predicament is that there are no economic drivers to help pull things out going forward.&nbsp
column8: As incomes drop and the cost of food increases - the cost of a sample marketbasket in my area has risen by more than 5.5%
column9: - since November 2010, the number of families forced into the food stamp program will steadily climb.&nbsp

column1: Where things get startling, at least for me, is the application of wealth statistics to Eldest's class.
Recent data breaks out the distribution of wealth amongst the American society and the top 1% of our households - in terms of income -
column2: control almost 35% of wealth (high liquidity assets such as stocks, bonds, real estate and business equity&nbsp
column3: less debt) and the next 19% control an additional 50% of the nation's wealth.&nbsp
column4: The bottom 40% of the households control less than 1% of the nation's wealth.&nbsp

column1: Looking at Eldest's class in a microcosm, more than a third of all of the wealth that they produce would be controlled directly by five of the 450 class members and fully 85% of the wealth would be controlled by 90 of them.
column2: The bottom 180 class members would have less than 1% of the cumulative wealth.&nbsp
column3: Because power comes with wealth, the great majority of Eldest's class will have to hope that these five classmates are decent people given all of the power that they'll possess.&nbsp
column4: Since those who reach high financial and corporate positions are increasingly questioned as to their psychological makeup - Hmmm, I wonder if Biff is a sociopath? - I doubt that that's going to generally be the case.

column1: Eldest's class - our children - is going to be subjected to a lesson in making social Taffy.
column2: The stresses of the ongoing economic decline are going to pull more and more downwards on the economic strata and that's bad enough.&nbsp
column3: But the rules and behaviors that have permitted an increasing few to garner more wealth and power, if left unchecked, are going to pull those few further upwards and the middle is going to be stretched thin to the point at which it breaks completely.&nbsp

column1: Try something the next time that you see the children line up at the playground, walk onto the stage for an elementary or high school concert or walk through the doors at the dance at which you've dropped them.
column2: Make a mental count of each sixth child and consign that child to a life of poverty and an inability to even afford sufficient food for their own family.&nbsp
column3: If there are enough, count every other child and consign that child to a life in which they have little wealth and for whom the classic dream of retirement is just that and they can expect to die in the traces.

column1:
Then see if your perspective changes when you realize that one of these is your own child.

column2: &nbsp

column22: - Parent to elderly acquaintance when he was a child

column1: Many years ago, I had a conversation with an older gentleman who related that that was the common phrase uttered by his mother when he misbehaved or did something dumb.
column2: The implication of the phrase was that he had been raised to not only know better but to actually behave better as well.
column3: His parents assured that he knew the difference between right and wrong and could never blame misbehavior or errors in judgment on not having known.&nbsp
column4: In a sense, they wanted to assure that he knew who he was and that he was firmly grounded in the family values.&nbsp
column5: Perhaps it's something that we miss and need to remember when we ground our own children for disciplinary reasons.&nbsp
column6: Grounding isn't just a punitive measure because we're either too terrified to let them out or we just want to throw away the key in complete frustration.

column1: To say that a person is grounded is typically a compliment, such as she's a good person who's really grounded.
column2: If you look up ground in the Merriam Webster's Dictionary, there are a multitude of definitions and one of them pertains to furnishing "
column3: with a foundation of knowledge.&quot
column4: &nbsp
column5: Apply that to the person who's really grounded and you mean that she has a solid understanding of herself and the world around her.&nbsp

column1: When kids screw up, and it can be spectacular, one of the common parental responses is to ground the child from favorite activities or pastimes so that they learn from the transgression.
column2: But that can also mean banishment to the bedroom or some other place away and apart from the family.&nbsp
column3: In the short term, it means that the child will stay alive a little while longer and that you will too because that risk of stroke&nbsp
column4: is lessened when they're absent.&nbsp
column5: Unfortunately, it's only to likely be a short term fix if there's no continual involvement and followup to re-engage and help him remember who he is and what the family values are.&nbsp
column6: In the heat of the moment, we forget that the root of the word discipline pertains to&nbsp
column7: learning and teaching
column8: and that means that we have to be the adults and put away the anger and fear
column10: we must make purposeful efforts to spend time with them in whatever way possible to help reconnect them to the family values and lessons.&nbsp
column11: <em>I have to rake, come hold the bag for me.&nbsp
column12: I'm going to take the car in for an oil change, come along and we'll go next door for a soda.&nbsp
column13: Come and watch this with me, I think that it's something that you'll appreciate.&nbsp
column14: I'm going to walk the dog so get your jacket on and grab a plastic bag.&nbsp
column15: In other words, it does no good to ground them if we make no further efforts to ground them as well.

column1: The next time that you have to ground your child, take a little time to cool off.
column2: Spend the evening away from him, take a walk, drink a beer or go beat your head to a bloody pulp against the wall.&nbsp
column3:
After things are back in perspective, then go back and start the hard work of actually grounding your child.

The October results of the PracticalDad Price Index came in as the average cost of the 47 item marketbasket fell by $.23
column3: the October index level is 105.58 and down from September's 105.71.&nbsp
column4: The long and short is that the cost of the marketbasket has risen by 5.58% from the original cost in November 2010.

column1: The month saw small price rises in 14 items against price declines in six products.
column2: That said, the decline is due to a grocer making a significant change in their generic diaper packaging as they apparently heard &nbsp
column3: Representative Bernie Sanders' filibuster refrain ...and mothers can't afford diapers.
column4: There was a small total price rise in the package, but the number of diapers in that package increased significantly, from 76 diapers per box to 96 diapers per box, thus driving the per diaper cost down significantly (by more than 15%).&nbsp
column5: Had it not been for this instance, the market basket would have risen to 106.1 and providing yet another increase.

column1: This particular grocer also managed to drive down the cost of their generic spaghetti sauce, probably by finding a different supplier

column10: For good measure, let's throw in the failed shot at globalization in which corporations outsourced hundreds of thousands of jobs and thousands of factories.&nbsp
column11: I get the whole money will flow to the lower wage areas as our labor costs are too high meme, but this became a wholesale gutting of our industrial base as our senior executives went for the Wall Street gold that comes with higher share prices and stock options.

column9: text-decoration: none"">There was a time when I thoroughly agreed with him, when there were huge gaping holes in the welfare programs that permitted generations to go without having to find a job.&nbsp
column10: My wife and I worked long and hard and it didn't seem right that we'd come home at 8 PM to eat briefly, watch a half hour of television before going to bed and starting the whole process again
column11: the generational Welfare poster models could get by without having to do that.&nbsp
column12: Time and a bit of perspective has changed that view.&nbsp
column13: Of course, there was also a time when an executive who screwed up massively got the black boot instead of the golden parachute.

column9: text-decoration: none"">I also blame the big banks.&nbsp
column10: Our national debt has gone on to ludicrous levels, almost 100% of GDP and dangerously near if not past the point of tipping the country into insolvency, partially to help support the financial system.&nbsp
column11: This is a system that has drunkenly acted to goose their profitability by providing loans to anybody that could fog a mirror and then slipped into Patient Zero mode with Wall Street by passing the ebola-laced loans to investors across the world.&nbsp
column14: I am shocked, shocked that gambling is going on in here."
column16: These same financial establishments reached Too-Big-Too-Fail status and the executives realized that they could figuratively boink any bad asset in the world and we'd have to keep dosing 'em with expensive antibiotics since we really had no choice.

column11: But they are poster children for the literal collapse of ethical and moral behavior in our society as they pursued financial gain to any end, completely devoid of any concern about the damage that would be ultimately wreaked upon other individuals and society as a whole.&nbsp
column12: Frankly, even I bear some responsibility for this mess as I also bought into both the globalization and materialism philosophies that helped bring us into this place.

column9: text-decoration: none"">Do I blame someone for being poor?&nbsp
column10: In the previous version of America, some poor person could rise to higher economic levels because of their smarts, actions and sheer luck.&nbsp
column11: But when folks are laid off because their employer outsources or simply goes bankrupt, this simply isn't their fault.&nbsp
column12: In most cases, they played the game by the rules as they understood them and became collateral damage.&nbsp
column13: People can be poor because of bad decisions in a good economy, but with this mess that we've got, many of the &quot
column15: are folks who are collateral damage in a much larger drama being played out around them.

The media question right now is what does "
column2: Occupy Wall Street&quot
column3: really want?&nbsp
column4: The media visiting see all manner of signs and wonder what the protestors want
column5: what are the demands?&nbsp
column6: They're belittled by many pundits such as Hannity and Coulter, who stated that they need to get a job, take a shower and move on.&nbsp
column7: What truly motivates them apart from envy of what the successful have accomplished?&nbsp
column8: My own mother - a solid Fox News viewer - stated her dislike of them and was taken aback when I not only tried to explain the movement, but actually&nbsp

column2: driving this?&nbsp
column3: Let me paraphrase my vent.

column1: After a decades long binge, the occupants of
column2: neighborhood America are awakening to find that their vicinity has been trashed.&nbsp
column3: A potent mix of 'shroom and grain laced Kool Aid was prepared and handed out and many drank, some much more than others.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: The music&nbsp
column6: was crashingly loud and the lyrics were slick:&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: <em>You can have it all
column9: You have to do what's right for you
column11: more is better and there's no reason that you should feel bad
column15: In the course of this national debauch, we neglected our infrastructure, spent our money on the crap that was peddled to us - hell, we made a folk hero out of a chamois pimp - and let the most selfish of us take over the city council.
column16: Put simply, we've had front row seats to the financial equivalent of the sacking of Rome.

column1: Our youngsters - whom we've cumulatively permitted to electronically anesthetize themselves because we were too stoned on the punch to care - are finally waking up and coming out to take their place in the neighborhood to find that the shutters are off, the roofs are holed, the street lights are burnt out and the sewage system is backing up.
column2: If you think that &quot
column3: electronically anesthetized&quot
column4: is a poor choice, consider this.&nbsp
column5: There are 168 hours in each week and the teens are in school for about 40 hours weekly during the school year, or about 24% of their week.&nbsp
column6: The average teen also sleeps an average of 7 hours nightly - too little for their bodies - for 49 hours weekly, about 29%.&nbsp
column7: The average teen spends 50 hours weekly tied into some electronic device - television, computer, etc - for another 29% but an hour more plugged in than is spent sleeping.&nbsp
column8: This is time that's not spent learning about the reality of the real world around them and when suddenly thrown into it after years of false messaging, the cognitive dissonance is overwhelming.
column9: It's something out of The Matrix as these kids are left trying to reconcile what they've heard with what they have to contend.

column1: The economics solidly support the notion that a college degree is necessary for a better future as incomes exceed those of high school graduates and they're aware of this.
column2: But the debt incurred to obtain the degree can never be discharged and they're saddled with it
column3: they'll work multiple jobs, without benefits, to help pay the debt.&nbsp
column4: While the real, flesh and blood entities are held to account, the fictitious legal entities, the corporations, are given all manner of assistance to help cover for their mistakes.&nbsp
column5: There are no consequences for horrendous decisions and practices and the corporate leadership still manages to receive the benefits for whatever they do both right and wrong - socialize the losses and privatize the gains.
column6: Yet these leaders have actively pursued practices that have sent the jobs overseas, living wage jobs that are desperately needed by the new generation to help remove the load and permit them to start a decent life.
column7: In this new economic world that's been created, there are certainly jobs but these are and will continue to such positions as baristas and desk clerks.&nbsp
column8: The factory and lathe jobs?&nbsp
column9: These went to China with the factory equipment.&nbsp
column10: The kids are awakening to find that what they've been told and touted is pure rubbish.&nbsp
column11: In their thinking, and I agree, they'll be held to task for their debts while the corporate and financial leaders will continue to be coddled and protected for their actions and inactions.&nbsp
column12: They expect no assistance from the elected officials since many are in the pockets of the contributors who've financed their (re)elections and helped to maintain a privileged lifestyle in which they aren't required to participate in the same systems - health insurance, for instance - as the rest of us.&nbsp
column13: What else is there to do but to take to the streets, as did some of their forebears?&nbsp

column1: Given how many of these youngsters are already working multiple part-time jobs to somehow cobble together a life that ultimately frees them from what is essentially debt serfdom, I don't believe the assertion that they're unwilling to work.
column2: I hear the increasing attacks on them coming from conservative commentators and candidates, such as Herman Cain, and for the first time truly believe that a class war is now being fully engaged.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: These youngsters are now pushing back and it's becoming apparent by both the verbal attacks and police mace attacks on young women that the established order doesn't like it.&nbsp
column5: What these folks have to consider is that these protestors have parents, whom Nixon would have referred to as the great&nbsp
column6: Silent Majority, and that we aren't going to sit back and let our children be abused by the Powers That Be.

column1: If my children should decide to join this effort, then I'm likely to join them.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
<em>...like talkin' to a brick wall
column3: they see me movin' my lips and nod just to humor me
column4: &nbsp
column5: does anybody even understand a word that I say?&nbsp
column6: Talking to teens can be an immensely frustrating exercise as their egos and hormone-addled brains seemingly overwhelm the message of what you're trying to get across.
column7: Ask them several minutes later what you were saying and you're liable to get a cocked-head impersonation of Laddie, the wonder Spaniel.&nbsp
column8: But there are moments when you realize that someone really is listening and it's not always the teens, but the younger ones who hear what's being said and then process it in interesting and occasionally sad manners.

column1: This was the case with Youngest, who's still in elementary school and hears the conversations with Eldest, who's progressing on the college search.
column2: In the course of conversations, he's learned about 529 plans, scholarships and such a thing as a SAGE account.
column3: He understands and God love him, has taken the academic discipline to heart as he faithfully keeps up with the homework without prodding and little complaint.&nbsp
column4: But I was surprised by a recent conversation with him about this distant, post-high school event on the horizon.&nbsp
column5: Youngest knows that a young neighbor recently left for the Air Force and was suddenly talking about plans to enlist when he turned 18
column6: many boys talk about joining the army or marines as though it's a grand continuation of their childhood soldier games, but Youngest spoke with a considerably different bent.&nbsp
column7: This was laying out a plan to spend several years in uniform and then a return to civilian life to pursue studies under the college benefits plans.&nbsp
column8: While this is certainly a possibility, it's generally bandied about by much older teens and when I reminded him that we were saving for him as well, he responded to the effect that we also had his older siblings to cover and besides, we would then be approaching the years when people are starting to actively consider retirement.&nbsp
column9: What would be available to him would likely be minimal as the well would be dry (my words, not his).

column1: I would have been less surprised to hear him uttering obscenities that he might have picked up on the Howard Stern Show.
It could be considered an isolated situation save for another conversation with a very close friend, who related that her youngest son had spent considerable time and thought on the same issue.
column2: <em>The folks are talking with my sister about how to handle college and how she's really going to have to work to help with scholarships and grants since there isn't enough saved.&nbsp
column3: Geez, Dad's getting old and when I get there, he and Mom are gonna be way more tired.&nbsp
column4: The education is really necessary and how am I gonna handle this?&nbsp
column5: It then sank in that someone really was listening to what was being said to his older siblings.
column6: Unfortunately, he didn't have the base of knowledge or experience to be able to process it properly and was quietly going about his way to handle it as best as he might be able.&nbsp
column7: In that moment, my eyes teared and I almost wept.

column2: Keep talking, even when you think that you're absolutely beating your bloody head to a pulp and the kids are making jokes about it.&nbsp
column3: The politicians call it staying on message and while they all are skewered by Leno, Letterman and Stewart, the truly successful politicians do exactly that.
column4: The message gets across and the lessons are - in most cases - driven home to the listeners.&nbsp
column5: But as you repeat the message again and again, take a moment to consider what I didn't, that there are younger ears listening and taking what's being said to heart.&nbsp
column6: When you have the opportunity, pull that youngster aside and ask what he thinks that he's heard and if there's a discrepancy, take that moment to reassure him that he's neither alone nor left as the leftover child forced to fend for himself after the older kids have sucked the nest dry and moved onwards.

column1: And even when the teens give you the Spaniel treatment, understand that they
column2: are listening, too.&nbsp
column3: Keep talking.

486,"1","1",,"xhtml","

With college on the horizon for Eldest, followed in intervals by Middle and Youngest, the question is how to cut down on one of our biggest expenditures - food.
column2: It's a puzzle since it's one thing to say oh yeah, I'll cook for the family but it's another thing completely when the other factors are the chaotic scheduling due to three different kids with activities and the presence of a vegetarian in the household.
column3: It's now a reality that the traditional family meal is the exception to the rule and it would be easy to just pop a precooked meal, a la Stouffer's in the oven.
column4: But time truly is money and the cost is truly lessened if it's cooked.

column1: This will be an ongoing project to cut down on the food spending while still meeting my primary constraints:
<li>Creating a decently cooked meal that can be easily heated/reheated for the various kids and spouse who are constrained by schedules
<li>Creating a meal that, while requiring some investment in the initial preparation, won't take significant reheat times since I'm the one providing much of the transportation
• Creating a meal that tries to honor Eldest's dietary choice of being a vegetarian (actually an ovopescavegetarian since she will eat eggs and fish
• Creating a meal that uses fresher and easily obtainable ingredients to cut down on the costs.
And yes, I'm going to walk through the scheduling and thinking as I outline what I'll be doing regularly.
Today's situation was work for Eldest, theatre practice for Middle and an undetermined return for Better Half.
column2: The kicker however, is that the following night consists of either work or activities for everybody and on top of that, I'm gone as well so whatever is prepared today has to be easily reheated by various folks at different times before they exit.&nbsp
column3: Since soup is something that almost always improves in taste with time, the choice was soup.&nbsp
column4: On the island was a butternut squash and there were plenty of Gala, Honeycrisp and Fuji apples in the garage so a quick review of the internet led to this 12 serving recipe for Roasted Butternut Squash Soup with Apples and Bacon.
column5: Yeah, there's a vegetarian in the house but&nbsp
column6: there are occasions when I'm asking for a little flexibility
column7: our own menu has largely shifted out of chicken and red meat since the dietary change occurred so a little bacon is alright on the rare instance.&nbsp
column8: Since I was also already cutting up an apple for the soup, I went ahead and sliced extra and threw them into the crockpot to cook on high for several hours.&nbsp
column9: The complement to the meal would be simply bread with butter.

column1: Given that I already had all of the ingredients in the house, it was an exceptionally inexpensive meal for what's turning out to be two nights of food.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
487,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's one thing to be aware of a problem like the issue of student debt, and even to write about it rationally.
column2: But when the kids actually begin the college search process and are engaged in it, that rationality can really become endangered and that's not just on the part of the kid.
column3: The emotions - and guilt - swirl about and cloud the decision-making better than a lawyer sniffing a settlement.

column1: Eldest is in the heart of the process now and as I write this, is on the road returning from an overnight visit to a private college.
column2: This is the third overnight experience that she's had along with two standard visits and interviews and there's still another to come in about three weeks before she winnows her choices down the select few.&nbsp
column3: At each visit, the effort is made to pair the prospective students with the most engaging &quot
column4: ambassadors&quot
column5: who put the best face on the institution and sell it to the max.&nbsp
column6: Throw enough students at this particular marketing wall and a few are going to stick and opt for that college.

column1: This is a highly emotional, well-spun process and it can cause almost anybody to lose sight of the salient facts.
column2: Students talk about the experience and look for the best &quot
column3: fit&quot
column4: , gauging whether the physical reality seems to mesh with the glossy, crisp photos of smiling students amidst plush facilities and noshing at yogurt bars.&nbsp
column5: As I write this, a brochure from Wisconsin Lutheran College is at my right and there are various photos of students in a diverse series of activities below a large photo of color-clad trees, apparently in that one week period between summer and the onset of northern mid-west blizzards.&nbsp
column6: The interior is filled with quotes and captioned photos of the faculty and students and is solely intended to sell the emotions
column7: in this regard, Higher Ed is no different from the &quot
column8: Home&quot
column9: builders, who always mention that they're selling homes instead of houses.&nbsp
column10: Likewise, there's also been correspondence to the us, the parents, reassuring us that they also only want what's in our child's best interest and oh yes, by the way, this is an investment in their future.

column1: And the eighteen years that we've spent so far is...what?

column2: Eldest is deeply aware of the debt situation and doesn't want to mortgage her future.&nbsp
column3: We want her to enjoy the college &quot
column4: experience&quot
column5: and naturally want what's best for her.&nbsp
column6: But certain phrases crop up, such as best fit and experience - which is naturally the one that's displayed in the brochures and online.
column7: The guilt is there - did we save enough and could we have saved more?&nbsp
column8: Yes, there might have to be some debt, but are we betting against our child when we seriously consider some of the more highly priced options?
column9: After all, there's always a crying need for a good lawyer, dentist, fireman, photographer and isn't she the one that could get through it?&nbsp
column10: Our talks work through this process as best fit is paired off against debtload and the point is reiterated that the final decision among decent options will most likely come down to the financial package as I try to shove aside the emotional baggage that I carry.
column11: To her credit, Eldest - a rocket scientist who will have finished 15 credits of college coursework by her high school graduation - has culled out the majority of the highly priced private colleges except for one with a screamingly good program in which her interests lie.

column1: As I struggle with cynicism, I then get a cold dose of reality from this infographic explanation
column2: about the student lending system.&nbsp
column3: The reality is that student loans were ruled as non-dischargeable in the first place as graduates in the 1970s scammed the system by declaring bankruptcy upon graduation and dodging repayment.&nbsp
column4: With loss rates rising, the systemic response was understandable.&nbsp
column5: Yet some very smart - and not terribly moral - people understood their advantage and built a system around it to secure their particular little empire.&nbsp
column6: When an agency like Sallie Mae owns its own collection agency and spends millions in lobbying, they've got themselves an empire.&nbsp
column7: <em>Bang!&nbsp
column8: I'm all the way back to my hardnosed stance.

column1: Blow away all of the smoke and the salient facts are these.

column2: It is the 21st century equivalent of the high school diploma and it does make an economic difference.

column1: <li>If it makes a hard economic difference, then the final decision has to be based principally upon the hard economics of the decision.&nbsp
column2: What's the cost and what's the aid package?&nbsp
column3: Whether Dear Ol' Wassamatta U has a primo yogurt bar or Mongolian Grill is irrelevant and that must be pointed out to the kid.

column1: <li>While debt is a personal bugaboo, reasonable debt is a tool provided that the job prospects for the career support the ability to repay the debt.&nbsp
<li>In today's economy - depressed, recessed, generally suckish, whatever you wish to call it&nbsp
column2: - the jobs available to manage that debt are simply not available.&nbsp
column3: If you have any doubt, just consider all the adults doing jobs previously held by our teenagers.

column1: <li>College is only three or four years of an actuarially long lifespan.&nbsp
column2: Does it make sense to mortgage the next ten to fifteen years for those few?

column1: • What you get out of something is wholly dependent upon what is put into it.
The college search will continue and I truly have no clue where she'll go.
column2: My great wish however, is that whatever college is finally chosen has the best program for the money that's available.&nbsp
column3: And then we'll start going to work on child number two as we take up the bean diet.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
488,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There are stereotypes borne of reality and one of these is of the chinese mother, as popularly memorialized by Amy Chua in her 2011 bestseller,
column2: field-keywords=battle+hymn+of+the+tiger+mother&amp
column3: sprefix=battle+h"">Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother.
column4: It's one thing to read it but another thing entirely to get a first-hand insight into the thinking of the Tiger Mother
column5: it was something that I received the other week when I gave a lift to the Tiger Mother's daughter and she, my daughter and I had an illuminating conversation.

column1: In Chua's book, she decides to raise her two Chinese-American/Jewish daughters in the Chinese manner.
column2: The child is given real opportunities but the quid pro quo is that the child is expected to perform and do so in exemplary fashion.&nbsp
column3: Practicing for violin lessons during vacation?&nbsp
column4: Check.&nbsp
column5: Repeated drilling of lessons?&nbsp
column6: Check.&nbsp
column7: While I consider my wife and I to be fairly hardnosed about expectations of children, I couldn't conceive of demanding such from my own kids.&nbsp
column8: My own general guidelines of the kids are to do your best, respect your teachers and coaches, and don't ever waste my time.&nbsp
column9: <em>Don't want to practice for the music lessons that you requested?&nbsp
column10: Fine, learn to play the damned thing on your own.&nbsp
column11: In an earlier article, my thought was that this general attitude arose from living in an unstable society where there few opportunities and those only went to those who were the absolute best.
column12: China has had longer periods of economic and political instability longer than this country has been a republic and if parents want the best for their children, they'll provide it by pushing the kids to be able to survive in that society.

column1: In this particular conversation, Tiger Mother's Daughter - hereafter referred to as TMD - was asking about health insurance and pension plans
column2: bear in mind that this is a 17 year-old.&nbsp
column3: When she mentioned pension plans, my mental response was akin to bwahahahahahahahahahaha*snort* but I answered her in a matter-of-fact way.
column4: <em>Honestly, very few companies still offer pension plans anymore.&nbsp
column5: If people want to retire, then they'll have to save it for themselves in some plan such as an IRA or 401k and I wouldn't hold your breath trying to find that kind of company anymore.&nbsp
column6: Ironically, I thought, those few who do still have pension plans can probably offer them to the administrative staff since they've outsourced all of the labor to China.
column7: Her plans involved some form of engineering, perhaps for the military, since her SAT math scores were higher than I can count and I confirmed that yes, the military did offer a pension for years of service.&nbsp
column8: <em>The flip side is that our spending is so out of whack that the military is probably going to take some real budget hits, so you have to be aware of that.&nbsp
column9: To her credit, her own thinking was that she could go the business school route and there's where I responded with a Ding*Ding*Ding inflection in my voice.
column10: With your abilities, grades and language skills, yeah, you'd be snapped up.

column1: It was in this conversation that I could hear the mother's fears and motivations come through.
column2: They were immigrants and while that's tough for everyone, she was shielding her daughter from the true unpleasantries that come with parenting and adulthood in such a situation.&nbsp
column3: I could discern her thinking <em>please, I don't want her to hate the surroundings in which she might have to raise her own child
column4: I don't want her to wonder about where the food's going to come from
column5: I want my grandchild to have better than I could give you, my love.

column1: In terms of family structure and child-rearing, the Chinese are almost in a completely different dimension from the typical American family.
column2: We view them as comical absurdities in their demands of their kids and the responses when the kids do stupid things - and boy, kids will do stupid things.&nbsp
column3: But getting even a tiny glimpse into that world is eye-opening and that's even for someone who's already considered by the kids to be pretty hardnosed.&nbsp
column4:
Given what this country has already been through economically and I expect will go through in the near future, I'm appreciating the demands placed a bit more than I did before.

One of my peeves is that our kids have such a lousy handle on history - hell, most of us have a lousy handle on it - and we don't recognize that history "
column2: doesn't repeat itself, but it does rhyme&quot
column3: because human nature doesn't change.&nbsp
column4: In its own way, the Tea Party and Occupy Wall Street are simply two sides of the same nickel that's been reminted from it's original design 200 years ago.&nbsp
column5: It's apparent from reading multiple sources - and hearing others, like Hannity, LImbaugh, etc - that the work is on to paint these protestors as wackos, malcontents and screwups who can't get or hold a job, conspiracy theorists who blame others for their own predicament, or professional political activists who've now latched onto a new cause that sucks in all of the unwitting dupes just mentioned above.

column1: History doesn't repeat itself, but it does rhyme.
That said, feel free to see if you can correctly identify who stated each of the quotes or passages that follow.

column1: Think twice - even three times - when you read, watch or listen to the media.
column2: Both OWS and the Tea Party are two sides of the same coin, one minted in dissatisfaction, disaffection and distrust of the corporate and political establishment
column3: an establishment that is really now joined at the hip like&nbsp
column4: a pair of freakishly bloated Siamese twins grabbing food from the plates of others and cramming it into&nbsp
column5: one another's&nbsp
column6: mouths.&nbsp
column7: The fear and concern is genuine and is a natural occurrence to what's clearly seen as the usurpation and corruption of the system&nbsp
column8: for the benefit of a very, very select few.&nbsp

column1: This has happened before and my hope is that it's corrected so that it can happen again in another hundred or so years.
column2: When you see members of Generation Y yelling in the streets and middle class oldsters sitting with tea bags dangling from fishing caps, ask yourself what Madison, Garfield, Roosevelt and Wilson would say and do and while you're at it, throw in FDR, Jefferson and Jackson as well.

For those who are interested, here is a link
column2: to the declaration issued several days ago by the Occupy Wall Street Working Group.

column1: For all that the Main Street Media is doing to paint them as wackos, screwups, babes-in-the-woods and malcontents, the declaration provides substantive and eye-opening reading.
column2: The goals are ambitious and direct, even if messy in the sausage-making aspect of politics when and if they come about.&nbsp
column3: Boiled down to the bare-bones essentials, the gist is this:

column1: • Our nation is squandering its resources on foreign adventurism and non-renewable energy, replacing active measures of research and application with a steady stream of military spending

<li>Our nation is failing to look to the future by saddling its young people with non-dischargeable debt, yet failing to promote policies and industries that provide them with the wherewithal to retire the debt and make a reasonable wage
<li>Our nation is committing political and social suicide by permitting a very small minority of people to control a wildly disproportionate measure of the national wealth
• Our nation's government is actively abetting this since it has been financially coopted by that very small minority who have prospered.
While the term fascist been lobbed about like a verbal hand-grenade over the past five decades, the Working Group is absolutely correct in their opening quote by Benito Mussolini - Who?
column2: Oh yeah, the Italian dude who was buddies with Hitler during the Second World War, you know, the one right after the Civil War&nbsp
column3: - that fascism is a combination of big government and big business.

column1: I suggest that you read it, even if you prefer the Tea Party over the young punks screaming, chanting and beating drums on Wall Street.
column2: You might be surprised to&nbsp
column3:
find yourself nodding your head.

column1:
496,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Experts say that you should start reading with the kids when they're very young, but when are we supposed to stop?
The benefits to children of reading with them are manifold.
column2: From the earliest age - and my wife and I read to ours from the earliest days - the child learns much.&nbsp
column3: At first, the child learns to listen to the cadence, tone and inflection to assist them as they themselves learn to speak, even from learning the most basic sounds.&nbsp
column4: As they grow and begin to master the various sounds, their brains can start to follow basic concepts that might be found in very simple books, such as shapes, colors, animals, textures and trucks.&nbsp
column5: Hold a child in your lap with a cardboard book with easy-to-manipulate pages and the child can even start to get in some manual dexterity practice as she improves at grasping and turning the pages.&nbsp
column6: By the time that they're in preschool, you're off to the races with stories that not only feed their imagination, but help them with practical skills such as learning how to sit and listen for a short period of time
column7: as they age, the skill increases and enhances their ability to concentrate for longer periods also.

column1: With the first two children, it was simple as they were only about two years apart and by the time that they were in early elementary school, they'd heard stories such as Peter Pan, The Chronicles of Narnia, The Hobbit
column2: and <em>A Christmas Carol.&nbsp
column3: Each has since moved on to their own preferred genres and are now fully into adult fiction
column4: Eldest loves chick lit and Middle prefers F Paul Wilson's <em>Repairman Jack.&nbsp

column1: But it's been far more sporadic and intermittent with Youngest, who's still in Elementary School and whose reading times have been greatly affected by the general uproar that comes with active older siblings.
column2: He's an advanced reader and unlike his elder siblings, prefers non-fiction and science to the fiction realm, which makes it difficult to stay awake in the evening hours while reading with him.&nbsp
column3: Frankly, alligators and gecko lizards put me to sleep.&nbsp
column4: His technical skills haven't suffered in the least and the verbal acuity has only been brought even further along by trying to keep up with precocious siblings
column5: I was appalled to discover last week that he's even been introduced to Urban Dictionary, although I'm unclear if that's courtesy of Middle or someone from elementary school.
column6: Youngest however, still wants to read with me and while it does crimp into the evening hours and activities, it's something to which I look forward.&nbsp
column7: It's not even about story anymore, although it certainly makes a difference.&nbsp
column8: Instead, it's about spending some quiet moments alone with one another and enjoying something together.&nbsp
column9: I've had to learn to decide in advance what I'd like to introduce and do so in enough time to make it timely.&nbsp
column10: Consequently, we began Ray Bradbury's <a title=""Amazon.com"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/Halloween-Tree-Ray-Bradbury/dp/0375803017/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp
column14: in the latter part of September and finished it a week before Halloween itself.&nbsp
column15: While Youngest has pulled out Joshua Mowll's <a title=""Amazon.com"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/Operation-Red-Jericho-Guild-Specialists/dp/0763626341/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp
column19: and we've begun that, my intent is to finish it as quickly as possible so that we can introduce him to Dickens' A Christmas Carol.

column1: The time is coming when he'll outstrip the desire and choice of literature as did his siblings and reading with Dad will go the route of toy soldiers and teddy bears, and as my own father said that's the way it's supposed to be.
column2: But he's still got the desire and amidst all of the general hoopla, I've realized that these are moments that I've got to grab onto with both hands because the days are dwindling fast.&nbsp
column3: So after Halloween tonight, we'll come back and split out the candy and after he's ready for bed, we'll curl up with the Guild Specialists of Operation Red Jericho.

column1:
And while I'm thinking about it, perhaps I'll yank out my old tape recording of Orson Welles' War of the Worlds broadcast and we'll curl up to the Martians landing at Red Hook, New Jersey.

With Eldest in the midst of the college search, we're exquisitely aware of the college costs and how her choices impact the issue of debt - and vice versa.
column2: So it was eye-opening to see how student debt doubled in little over a decade
column3: and actually rose by $100 Billion in one year alone.&nbsp
column4: As many Americans with jobs cut back on their spending and credit card debt, our youngsters are being forced to take on increasing amounts of debt to earn what is the 21st century's equivalent of the high school diploma.

column1: Our goal is to have our daughter come out of college with no debt and we've saved enough over the years to make that happen under certain circumstances and we've shared those circumstances with her for the past several years
column2: God love her, she's taken the conversations to heart and studied to academically achieve what I never could have.&nbsp
column3: The difficulty is that there are plenty of other academically capable seniors also out there, competing against one another for the grants and scholarships that are probably stagnant in their own growth because of the lack of any real returns on the funds in their endowments.&nbsp
column4: It's hard to restock the larder when you're bound by fiduciary requirements and the only real returns today seem to come from a big win in the Powerball.

column1: So what are the various options to help the kids, apart from saving on your own?
<li>Find out what the graduation requirements are for high school as soon as they're freshmen and lay out in advance what the various routes and alternative paths are.&nbsp
column2: Don't assume that the high school counselors are going to magically assure that everything's done and set for your kid.&nbsp
column3: Late this summer, we found out that while Eldest needed another course in English to graduate, the school enrolled her in yet another History course instead
column4: if we hadn't kept up with it, she'd been in the position of having to jury rig some weird second-semester combination just to graduate from high school with greater than a 4.0 average.

column1: <li>Investigate if any neighboring community colleges or state universities allow capable high school students to take coursework there.&nbsp
column2: If so, then talk to the high school counselors and administration about what high school courses can be replaced by the college courses instead.&nbsp
column3: Some high schools permit this - as ours does - and the students get a three-fer on the deal.&nbsp
column4: The high school provides credit towards graduation, most colleges and universities will accept the credits on the lower level courses after the student graduates from high school, and the college courses bolster the high school grade point average.&nbsp
column5: For instance, a high school might weight a college prep course with&nbsp
column6: three credits, an honors class with&nbsp
column7: four credits and a college course with five credits
column8: this is how there high school graduates coming out with GPAs of 4.1 and above.&nbsp
column9: The other advantage to this is that there's greater up front cost, but it can be handled in much smaller bites over a longer period of time as the courses are gradually completed over two years and you aren't left with some whopping large bill later on.&nbsp
column10: In Eldest's case, she'll graduate high school with a full semester of college credits already under her belt.

column1: <li>Assure that the kids have a real sense of what the greater wide world is like.&nbsp
column2: Come Junior and Senior year of high school, they'll be pelted with glossy brochures extolling the virtues of Dear Ol' Wassamatta U, ripe with pictures of smiling young adults, none of whom seem to be half-naked or hungover.
column3: While the large majority of them want independence and to be away from the soul-crushing atmosphere of the parents, they also don't want to pay attention to the world around them so that they come into the real world as startled and screaming as the day that they were born.&nbsp
column4: In a sense, the youngsters protesting at OWS are being brought kicking and screaming into a world in which they've been not only dropped on their heads at birth, but used as financial hackisacks by the staff on cigarette breaks.&nbsp
column5: <em>What does this mean on a practical level?&nbsp
column6: From high school freshman year, when the grades really do start to count for the college experience, show them what's been saved so far - if any has been saved.
column7: Explain to them where it's at and while $5000 might seem like a lot to a 14 year old with no sense of proportion, then take them to the website for the nearest state university and contrast that with the cost of a semester there.&nbsp
column8: Over the years, continue talking to them about the necessity of a degree and as they age, bring in the concept of wages so that they can start to understand the idea of debtload.
column9: In Eldest's case, she discovered what a 529 plan was during the spring of her Freshman year and is now fully aware of what's been saved for her versus what the various alternatives cost.&nbsp
column10: Middle has already had this same conversation even earlier than his older sibling and even Youngest - in elementary school - is aware of the generalities if not the specifics.

column1: <li>Take the time - years in advance, if necessary - to find out what the various mechanisms and opportunities are out there.&nbsp
column2: Explore college scholarship websites, follow up with the guidance counselors and keep tab on what the kids are thinking so that you're not unduly scrambling in the few months between the end of junior year and the start of the application deadlines.&nbsp
column3: Even then, it's a daunting process.

column1: <li>Talk to the kids, persistently and consistently on message.&nbsp
column2: There will come a point when they roll their eyes&nbsp
column3: and&nbsp
column4: try to defer and avoid hearing it, but the truth is that they do listen to what's being said.

column1: Eldest is winnowing down the field of alternatives as she mosies through the process.
column2: There have been moments when I've hated having to point things out to her because I don't want to intrude on what should be fun years, but those moments of discomfort are offset by the knowledge that there is at least some semblance of an informed decision.
column3: While I have no idea where she'll wind up or even if there's going to be some debt afterwards, it's become clear that she's taken the conversations of the past several years to heart.
