column1:
493,"1","1",,"xhtml","

When you go places overnight with the kids, you often have the opportunity to kibbitz and share perspectives with other parents in similar situations and such was the case the other night.
column2: Specifically, the question batted around was whether the actual degree, that almost-magical parchment for which millions of students and parents&nbsp
column3: impoverish themselves, was more or less important than the college experience itself.&nbsp

column1: The conversation was with a woman for whom I have considerable respect.
column2: Her eldest child is enrolled at a prestigious national liberal arts university and has a significant merit scholarship
column3: that said, the scholarship doesn't cover even half of the annual tuition/room and board and it's up to the folks to carry the load on this.&nbsp
column4: She's a person who - along with her husband - has done a terrific job of raising the kids and assuring that they have opportunities to broaden their horizons.&nbsp
column5: The two kids clearly have been raised with expectations, rules and accountability and they are, in simple terms, truly a good couple of kids.&nbsp
column6: As we talked, her clear sense was that while the degree matters, what truly matters is that kids take full advantage of the college experience.&nbsp
column7: Travel abroad, unique courses, top quality faculty and&nbsp
column8: students of the same caliber and apprecation of education are crucial and worthy of the cost involved if the student takes full advantage of them.&nbsp
column9: This is the message from parent to student and God love 'em, the folks are moving heaven and earth to make it happen.&nbsp
column10: To her credit, the student in question is likewise taking advantage of the opportunities provided to her by her folks' sacrifice.

column2: comments could be categorized as respectful disagreement.&nbsp
column3: I was fortunate to grow up in a time when, while a private university was still expensive compared to public institutions, it had not become wholly disproportionate to the typical income of the time and I acknowledge that.&nbsp
column4: My comments ran along the lines that the times and the model have changed in the intervening thirty years.&nbsp
column5: The costs are disproportionately higher as the tuition/room and board inflation rate have risen at a rate higher than the standard CPI - assuming that you don't believe that that number is gamed anyways - and the average family income is now down several percentage points from four years ago.&nbsp
column6: Likewise, higher education is no longer the realm of ivy-covered non-profits with memorable fight songs and old buildings.&nbsp
column7: It's a big business - which one blog commenter refers to as Big Ed - in which almost two dozen college presidents receive wage packages in excess of $1 million
column8: the primary funding institution, Sallie Mae, by all appearances is a fiefdom&nbsp
column9: unto itself with it's own collection agency and a lobbying budget that has surpassed a million dollars annually.&nbsp
column10: If a nobleman has men-at-arms to collect the peons' taxes and ingratiates himself with the king to maintain good relations and access, then the nobleman by definition has a fiefdom.&nbsp

column1: Perhaps the greatest damage to the argument has been the issue of the non-dischargeable college debt, which figures in Occupy Wall Street's 99 Percent Declaration.
column2: While we've outsourced our living-wage jobs and manufacturing base, we're made it damned near impossible for the new crop of students coming out as they've bought into the dream and mortgaged themselves to do it, only to be told <em>by the way, that degree gets you a barista position with no benefits.&nbsp
column3: In the conversation noted above, the young woman will probably come out with no debt courtesy of her parents, who in turn will be most likely laden to the hilt.
column4: The student debt issue won't apply since they'll have the debt, but it begs the question of what precisely we, as parents, owe our children.&nbsp
column5: Do we owe them our own future in order for them to have the experience?&nbsp
column6: The conversation in my own home recently contained the comment that we owe you an education, but that doesn't mean that we have to bankrupt ourselves (and for the record, the child isn't asking us to do so).
column7: We have to take the adult long view and consider who's coming up later in the family pipeline, as well as our own old age needs.&nbsp
column8: Both my wife and I are&nbsp
column9: grateful that at the same time that college is on the plate, we're not also forced to throw additional financial resources at helping our own parents on the other slice of the sandwich bread.&nbsp
column10: While I hope that things improve, I'm confident that this is all part and parcel of a permanent ratcheting downwards in the national economy and if that's the case, then Eldest and her younger siblings will have their hands full caring for their own future broods.&nbsp
column11: When I'm in my dotage is likely to be the worst time for them to have to assist financially in terms of their own economic and financial lives.

column1: Some might view my friend's beliefs as too idealistic and lacking in common sense.
column2: Others might see me as a raging ass who's so selfish that he'll take experiences from his kids' mouths for sake of a dime.&nbsp
column3: What's important in this is what you consider.
column4: <em>What do you owe your children and how far does that extend?&nbsp
column5: If you won't pay for &quot
column6: the experience&quot
column7: , what will you do to offset that?&nbsp
column8: Will you make a similar investment in your time and talent that these other parents have done?&nbsp
column9: Look down the road a distance and even consider what you think is on the horizon.

column1:
These are valid questions and ones that should be considered and debated when the kids are younger and before you're forced into a values decision that you might come to regret.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
The word is out that the President will be announcing executive orders to assist college students and graduates who are mired in debt.
column2: The changes, which accelerate congressional actions, are threefold:

column1: <li>The maximum repayment is to be capped at 10% of income instead of the present 15%
<li>Any debt remaining will be forgiven after 20 years instead of the present 25 year period
• Loans from two existing programs will be consolidated at a rate approximately .5% lower than it currently is.
The expectation is that the changes will apply to approximately 7.5 million people with individual savings of about "
column2: several hundred dollars&quot
column3: monthly.&nbsp
column4: Let's do a back-of-the-envelope exercise to ascertain the effect here.&nbsp
column5: Assume that there are 7.5 million affected with an average monthly savings of $300, or $3600 annually.&nbsp
column6: The total annual savings are in the vicinity of $27 billion (7.5M @ $3600), which is less than 3% of the approximately $1 T owed for higher education.

column1: It's a start, but it amounts to tinkering with the machinery.
column2: It doesn't go to the root issues that face our youngsters.&nbsp
column3: First, that the rate of inflation for tuition continues to rise at a clip disproportionate to the overall CPI and is now far more outsized to the average family income than it was several decades ago.&nbsp
column4: Second, it doesn't address the fact that there are simply very few sustainable, living wage jobs for graduates.&nbsp
column5:
Until these core issues are addressed, either by the market or the government via some workable, commonsense policy, then the kids are going to continue to face difficulties that force them to postpone their true adult lives, out of the nest and on their own.

column1:
497,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The marking period is just ended and when the report card comes home from elementary school, I'll think twice about which segment my eyes run to first - the grades or the social development/class behavior comments.
column2: This is on the heels of a conversation that I had with another father as our boys got ready for a Fall baseball game, and the father, Scott, &nbsp
column3: presented me with a viewpoint on an issue that I never truly considered before.

column1: Although the format might differ, almost all elementary schools break out their report cards into two sections.
column2: The one section pertains to the grades that were earned while the second covers the social development and behavioral aspects of Junior's time at school.&nbsp
column3: The teacher usually also provides a brief written synopsis of how Junior's developing and interacting with the teachers and peers.&nbsp
column4: I can't speak for other districts, but our elementary report card lists the grades on the left hand side of the page, which are then followed by the development/behavior aspects in the remainder
column5: the teacher's assessment paragraph is written on a separate sheet of paper.&nbsp
column6: As we read from left to right, and the grades are placed on the left side, they are naturally the first thing to be seen.

column1: Scott's take on the report card was that he really went right past the grades and focused on the developmental/behavioral aspects of his son's school experience.
column2: In his view, the more important aspect at this level of school was how his son was developing and interacting with his peers
column3: grades certainly mattered, but a poor grade could flow from simply not understanding the material or else from something that was discussed in the development/behavior section.&nbsp
column4: In the case of the former, measures could be taken to help the child understand the material better and bring the grade up.&nbsp
column5: In the case of the latter, then it didn't matter what you did with assistance and remedial work, but would still require more intentional - and usually more difficult - work on the question of behavior and development.&nbsp
column6: Drilling a kid on the multiplication tables to improve performance is far easier than trying to parse through why Junior behaves a certain way or whether there's something else coming into play in development.

column1: This viewpoint was simply something that I've never considered.
column2: Ours is a grades first household - You want to try this?
column3: Then show me the grades, first. - and while the other aspects are indeed just as important, they were something that I went to after I'd satisfied myself that the grades were in order.
column4: The father has a legitimate point in his comments.&nbsp
column5: Grades are frequently symptoms of a deeper, underlying issue and even if the immediate issue of the grade is corrected, the developmental side can fester until it erupts much later if it isn't addressed early.

column1: When the report card comes out of the backpack in about a week, I'll be remembering his comments before I read the report.

For the second consecutive month since the 47 item market basket peaked in September, 2011, the cost of the market basket actually declined.
column2: The November market basket cost was $188.31, down from October's $188.34 and September's high of $188.57.

column1: In each month, there are a number of items with price changes, either higher or lower, but what's notable about the November pricing is that for the first time, the number of items with price decreases was larger than the number with price increases.
column2: For the record, 12 items dropped in price versus 11 items with increases
column3: this figure is double October's finding of only six items with price declines.

People who didn't provide clear guidelines to the kids as they grew and who didn't pay attention to what was going on.&nbsp
column3: People whose kids obviously didn't know what they would say on a particular question.&nbsp
column4: And yet, it happened to me and it was stunning.&nbsp
column5: Within a two week span, each of the older kids asked if they could attend a co-ed sleepover.

column1: For the record, most of the comments in the above paragraph are snark although the requests did have me asking them do you honestly think that I would even consider saying yes to this?
column2: The reality is that no matter what you do in raising the kids, no matter how clear the expectations and how insistent you are upon those pesky, stupid values thingies, the kids will frequently want to go do something that is contrary to what you believe is right, let alone proper.
column3: Coed sleepovers are just one more instance of the ongoing conflict between the family's values and society's values.&nbsp

column1: The separate questions led to a reasoned conversation with one child and a more testy exchange with another who didn't like the exasperatedly blunt no that came in response to the question.
column2: And I admit that I could have handled the question better in the moment.&nbsp
column3: Regardless, why would I say no to such a request, especially since the parents are going to be there?

column1: <li>Parents are older and at some point, are probably going to sleep and when that happens?&nbsp
column2: Well, gasoline, meet match.&nbsp
column3: Teens in groups are frequently combustible
column4: with a noxiously potent stew of testosterone, estrogen and poor judgment and putting a bunch of them in the room together for a prolonged period without supervision is asking for major trouble.&nbsp
column5: It doesn't mean that there will be issues or problems, but it ranks up there with - as PJ O'Rourke once wrote - giving whiskey and car keys to a bunch of teenage boys.&nbsp
column6: Remember, the teen battle cry is What Could Go Wrong?

column1: <li>Are the parents even going to be there?&nbsp
column2: Teens are exquisitely sensitive to perceptions of parental overinvolvement and any infringement upon their growing independence and will actively discourage any contact between parents, whether because they're actually plotting or just hate the concept of checking up.&nbsp
column3: There is an active divide and conquer strategy among some teens and it can become unpleasant for parents who override their wishes.&nbsp
column4: That said, I've never had a poor exchange with another parent and have actively defended parents who have come to our front door for pickup or dropoff.&nbsp
column5: Four minutes of facetime doesn't mean that Frank can tell whether I'm an axe murderer, but it does give a decent insight into what's going on in the household.

column1: <li>There's also the question of propriety, the increasingly antiquated noun which the root of (in)appropriate.&nbsp
column2: <em>What does it matter what a bunch of people think of what I do?&nbsp
column3: These are the same people that might be called upon to hire you for a part-time job, write a job or college recommendation or even wonder whether they want you to date their own child in two years.
column4: Honestly, it also bears upon my own reputation and I have no intention of placing my reputation in the hands of a tribe of teenagers.&nbsp

column1: <li>Everyone does it and besides, almost all of the kids there are either&nbsp
column2: lesbian&nbsp
column3: or gay.&nbsp
column4: <em>Really?&nbsp
column5: And are you lumped into that category by the other kids trying to finagle their folks into agreeing to this?

column2: When the kids are adults and on their own, then their actions are their own responsibility and they live with the consequences.&nbsp
column3: But as a parent, I do have a say in what's considered to be acceptable behavior and letting legally minor children cohabitate, even for one night, isn't right.

column1:
The question hasn't been raised again but I suspect that it might and once again, it will probably be a tense exchange as the kids test the boundaries and limits.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column2: Long Live the King!

column1: The classic lines were to be uttered by a Royal Chamberlain to announce the death of a monarch, followed by an oath of fealty to the new king.
column2: These words stay with me as I consider what's occurring around me, and I've actually paraphrased them to my older children as we talk about financial issues and money.&nbsp
column3: The old model is dead, long live whatever it is that's coming, but I'll be damned if I know.

column1: For the past several generations, our economic model has been predicated upon end-user consumption.
column2: That's us, folks, as we spend unbelievable amounts on stuff and then in a few years, try to sell it at a garage sale to make some more to either cover the bills that should've been paid in the first place, or else buy a bit more stuff.&nbsp
column3: But with the wall of debt that's been built over the past 25 years - personal, corporate and public - there's simply no way that we can continue with this model, and all of the drama in Europe is ultimately about the realization that there simply aren't enough productive assets to support their Picasso's version of a Jenga tower.&nbsp

column1: I'm not smart enough to foresee what's coming and frankly, don't believe anyone else who states that they do because much of the policy response is being made up on the fly.
column2: But it's become very clear that this model of economic growth based upon consumerism is dying, and doing so quickly.&nbsp
column3: That's the message that I now try to hammer into the heads of my children as they grow into a very different economic environment.&nbsp
column4: The principal lessons?

column1: <li>Learn to live on less and save your money.&nbsp
column2: There's presently a war on savers as rates are kept excruciatingly low, but rates swing on a pendulum and at some point, they'll be forced upwards again.&nbsp
column3: Those who will do well at that time will be those who have learned how to live within their means now and the psychic adjustment will be much less difficult.

column2: Do you want a home of your own?&nbsp
column3: Then work towards that.&nbsp
column4: Do you want to educate the kids with little debt?&nbsp
column5: Then work towards that.&nbsp
column6: But remember that despite what the advertisers proclaim, you can't have it all.

column1: <li>Figure out what really matters yourself and then actively share that with the kids.&nbsp
column2: Share with them that there are people who don't have such basics as a secure home and food, then share with them how important these things are in comparison to new cars or the latest electronic gear.&nbsp
column3: Frankly, when I pray with Youngest at night, I purposefully give thanks for food and four walls and a roof
column4: he learns that if I'm thanking God for that, then it must be important.&nbsp
column5: If you're not a believer or don't pray, find another way to get the message across.

column1: <li>Teach the kids about needs versus wants.&nbsp
column2: Talk with them about the concept of friendship and help them determine who really cares and matters.&nbsp
column3: <em>Dad, isn't it cool that General Mills will donate a dime of each cereal box sold to our schools?&nbsp
column4: Well, Daughter, if they really cared about education, then they'd just go ahead and donate the money anyway, wouldn't they?&nbsp
column5: Why does a multinational corporation need my help to support education?
column6: We're not so much a society anymore as a multi-dimensional marketing cohort.

column1: <li>Learn to pay attention to the world around you.&nbsp
column2: Observe what your&nbsp
column3: peers are doing and ask yourself,&nbsp
column4: does this make sense?
column5: It's a wildly difficult concept for most teens, but&nbsp
column6: talking about it helps to&nbsp
column7: lay the groundwork for the future and that's what this whole process of childrearing is about, preparing them for the future.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: My own father would talk to me about things and in the moment, he&nbsp
column10: sounded as if he were speaking Greek, but it then began to register and things made much more sense.&nbsp
column11: You are, in a sense, planting seeds.

column1: • Make it a point to start telling your child no.
Economic models don't change immediately and certainly not quietly.
column2: But if you can recognize things and at least begin to&nbsp
column3:
prepare the kids for the future, they'll be ahead of the pack when push comes to shove.

column1:
501,"1","1",,"xhtml","

If you're like me, you sometimes think if I had said that to my old man, he'd have had me against a wall.
column2: Such was the sense the other evening as an encounter with my teens and a few of their peers blossomed into a surreal fencing match over Seth McFarlane's Family Guy.
column3: The point of the conversation was whether I was (huh)whipped, and if you watch Stewie, you get the reference.

column1: For the record, I find Family Guy to be screamingly funny even if it does occasionally veer into the realm of the insensitive
column2: McFarlane's parody song about Terry Schiavo is a case in point.&nbsp
column3: My wife however, finds it utterly distasteful.&nbsp
column4: Consequently, I - and the older kids - have watched it in her absence but make it a point to keep it off when she's around out of some respect for her opinion.&nbsp
column5: Years ago, I even purchased Season One on DVD but after realizing how much she hated it, I put it away in a secure place and have never actually watched it, again, out of respect for her real dislike of the program.&nbsp
column6: I've never actually gotten rid of it because I'd forgotten about it.

column1: The situation occurred when the two teens, along with several of their peers, asked if they could watch the DVD collection and I refused to get it for them.
column2: They persisted - no self-respecting teen stops at the first shot - and when I held my ground and explained that I'd put the set away out of respect, was informed that I was whipped.&nbsp
column3: The sparring continued and in reference to the fact that it was Family Guy, I corrected them by stating that I wasn't whipped, but actually (huh)whipped (for the uninformed, when a word starts with "
column4: wh&quot
column5: , Stewie pronounces it by saying &quot
column6: huh&quot
column7: in front of the &quot
column8: w&quot
column10: My initial thought was that the comment was truly disrespectful and I admit to almost losing my temper, but decided in the moment to pursue the discussion.&nbsp
column11: My goal was to make them think about adult relationships and the question of what a&nbsp
column14: This multi-level, multi-player conversation continued on one level, funny, and on another, deadly serious as different scenarios were explored.&nbsp
column15: What does it mean to be &quot
column18: <em>Several of you have boyfriends or girlfriends - if you refuse to do something out of respect for them, does that make you whipped?&nbsp
column19: How do you feel if your significant other does something, knowing that you really detest it?&nbsp

column1: The encounter lasted for several minutes, about what you'd expect from a pack of teens looking for a few yucks, with the result being that they settled on another movie and they then disappeared downstairs.

column2: are these.&nbsp
Parenting is going to take you outside of your comfort zone as you're challenged by kids who are pushing the boundaries in their testing of independence.&nbsp
column3: It's much easier to somehow simply slough off the topic but it's our obligation as parents to swallow our bile and stick through the unpleasantry just so that the words are out there.&nbsp
column4: The kids might not like it, but I guarantee you that they're listening and processing if you're willing to proceed.

column1: <li>The kids will learn about how to manage their relationships by watching you and how you consider your mate.&nbsp
column2: Each adult relationship has its dysfunctionality and the kids will pick up on that, but they'll also pick up on the good things that you do and how you choose to honor your mate.&nbsp
column3: In that moment, to allow myself to be manipulated by a pack of teens so as to not appear (huh)whipped by my spouse would have taught horrendous unspoken lessons.

column1:
And for the record, I'm throwing out the Season One DVD set when I can remember where I put it.

Eldest leaves this afternoon with her mother for the last college visit, an out-of-state overnighter and with that, it then becomes a game of wait-and-see.
column2: Wait and see who finally accepts her - although she's a rocket scientist, like her mother - and wait and see what the final numbers are for the cost after the financial aid packages are received.&nbsp
column3: But does it have to be a wait-and-see scenario or&nbsp
column4: can she just acknowledge an acceptance and be done with it before Christmas?

column1: The biggest lesson that we've learned from watching others in the past several years is that you should never, never, ever apply to a school early admission and that is because it's a question of timing.
column2: The typical early decision process is meant to be completed in the November/December timeframe, which is at least weeks in advance of when the standard FAFSA financial aid paperwork is due from the families to the institutions.&nbsp
column3: Any student who applies early decision is contractually locked into attending without ever knowing what the financial aid package is going to be and we've witnessed multiple situations in which the final package from the early decision institution wasn't what the teen and parents expected.&nbsp
column4: There are&nbsp
column5: occasions when early decision isn't an issue, but the implications can make it problematic.&nbsp
column6: The consumer advice given to parents has been that early decision should be largely avoided, with the student and parents using the various aid packages as negotiating levers to improve the financing from the favored college.&nbsp
column7: <em>If you can shift $5000 from Parent Loans to grants, then Fiona can make it as one of your incoming students and boy, what an asset she'd be!&nbsp
column8: She's a poster child for Ol' Wassamatta U and can't you just imagine that tousle-haired, cross-eyed, gap-toothed smile on the cover of your 2014 recruitment brochure?&nbsp
column9: The institutional rejoinder is that the demand for their services is high enough that there are other students who can fill that spot, as though our kids are cogs in the Big Ed machinery.
column10: But the drumbeats about the college debt are sinking in as my wife learned in a recent admissions lecture that the number of schools being applied to by high school students has increased significantly in the past several years
column11: the upshot is that the colleges are no longer certain how many students will actually accept offers and these institutions are in business, with seats to be filled come September.&nbsp
column12: So it's still worth the effort to take a shot at negotiating the package.

column1: In our case, Eldest is interested in a college that is upfront about this early decision dilemma.
column2: Their practice is to give the families a best-guess estimate on what they could expect from an aid package should their child want to enter via early decision.&nbsp
column3: The caveat is a quid-pro-quo in that the family provides a non-FAFSA financial statement in the Fall and the school provides an estimate of what to expect with an aid package in the Winter/Spring.&nbsp
column4: There's some uncertainty on both sides as the family numbers might not be what in January what they were earlier and the aid package might not be exactly what was promised, but the numbers might be enough to actually make the case on whether or not early decision should even be on the table.&nbsp
column5: This past weekend, my wife and I sat down with the financial paperwork to complete this college's process and we'll now see what the prospect looks like.&nbsp
column6: If it's out of the ballpark, then we'll have to consider whether the application is early or regular decision.&nbsp

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
503,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Keep talking, they're listening is a constant refrain in my head with my kids, even if the eyes roll and the response is an exasperated FINE!
column2: But that only goes so far and even if they're listening, they might simply choose to ignore it.
column3: In that case, when should I stop simply saying anything at all?&nbsp
column4: Is there value in the object lesson and is the potential severity of an incident such that there's benefit in there's actually greater value in an object lesson learned?

column1: Parenting is partially a job in assessing risk - what can go wrong and just how bad can it be - and reacting to it accordingly.
column2: In the child's early years, the great majority do everything possible to protect our kids.&nbsp
column3: There's an entire industry built around safety devices and we buy into it accordingly.&nbsp
column4: As a former claims adjuster, I remember the times when Eldest was napping in her crib and I dropped to hands and knees to survey the world from the baby's level, asking myself <em>what are the hazards here?&nbsp
column5: At those ages, the child simply doesn't recognize what can hurt her and it's my job to protect her.
column6: But as she grows, she begins to understand and put things together and can actually modify her actions to Dad's instructions and that's where the fun starts.&nbsp
column7: If I take her to the park and she persists in doing something stupid, at what point do I simply decide to let her have an object lesson?&nbsp
column8: What could go wrong and how bad could the likely results be?&nbsp
column9: There are no clear answers and what one father perceives can be very different from another father.

column1: The nature of the situation changes as the kids age and grow, but it continues to exist.
column2: By a certain point, you can't protect them from their own stupidity all of the time because you're simply not around and you can't wrap them in a bubble, but there are other ways to teach the object lesson
column3: it now goes more frequently to the concept of self-responsibility.&nbsp
column4: In my case, it goes to the world of school and the ubiquitous permission form because as I've told Middle repeatedly, <em>Dude, these exist for a reason apart from killing trees.&nbsp
column5: It's been often enough that deadlines have passed simply because no form was ever delivered and in some cases, never even remembered that forms were even handed out
column6: the resulting angst as we scramble to keep situations under control creating sufficient uproar that it becomes apparent that jawboning simply won't work.&nbsp

column2: The beauty of the internet is that we can surveille what's happening via the school district website and see what's on the horizon and that was the case several months ago as the word went out <em>Remember to have your forms in by April 1 in order to attend the end-of-year field trip to the Amusement Park!&nbsp
column3: Given the repeated situations, the decision was to sit on it and sure enough, the form wasn't turned in and Middle missed the field trip.
column4: However, since his option was to then sit in a classroom for an all-day study hall, I kept him home and he did significant yardwork.&nbsp
column5: We thought that the lesson was learned but sure enough, the missed form occurred again last week as a Fall play cast party was thrown in doubt and when I responded to another parent that he probably wouldn't attend because of a blown form, her response was that it was a harsh lesson.
column6: Since I'd also stated that I suspected that there was a permission slip out there that I'd never followed on, the comment was directed at me.&nbsp

column2: Probably so since the kid truly did an outstanding job with the show.&nbsp
column3: But I, like many parents, tire of the constant picking that occurs because the kids can't or won't step up to the plate on issues of responsibility and when the opportunity to let the system teach a lesson, I'm going to grab it with both hands and ride it for all that it's worth.&nbsp
column4: The kids will learn that a favored activity isn't going to happen not because Dad didn't make it happen, but&nbsp
column5: because they didn't make it happen.

column1: As it went, Middle did make the cast party since he found out that the form was due at the door and had it to me that morning before the final show.
column2:
Frankly, they were nicer than I'd have been.

column1:
504,"1","1",,"xhtml","

What should I be aware of if I'm going to stay home with the kids?
column2: It's a move that's being increasingly made by men, whether by choice or by necessity, via job loss.&nbsp
column3: Whatever your situation, there are certainly things to be considered since the overwhelming majority of men were never raised with the thought that they'd be the primary caregivers for their children and it was never in their top 25 list of occupational choices when they were kids.&nbsp
column4: So what should you consider?

column1: Is this something that you're doing while you're looking for a paying job or is this a more permanent role?
column2: It matters because it impacts how you structure the day with the kids, and with kids, structure is crucial.&nbsp
column3: Children thrive when they have some sense of structure and routine because this creates a sense of security and with this sense, they're more likely to actually feel more secure and confident of their ability to handle life.&nbsp

column1: If you understand that this is a one year gig, then give serious consideration to maintaining a bedtime/morning routine that reflects the fact that your child will have to arise early enough to make it to daycare in the future.
column2: This doesn't mean that every morning has to be up and moving by 6:15 AM, but if you get into the habit of letting the kids awaken later, then you'll have to be prepared to gradually work them back into that schedule when the return-to-work date becomes closer.&nbsp
column3: Kids can be flexible but most will do better if they're eased into something over a period of time.&nbsp
column4: If you're staying home with the kids while you're looking for a job, then try to take the kids into account as you do the followups.&nbsp
column5: If the kids need to be quietly occupied while you handle phone calls, then&nbsp
column6: consider when those calls have to happen and build the television time into that time frame
column7: early afternoon calls dictate that screen time occurs in the early afternoon.&nbsp
column8: Bear in mind however, that having the kids in front of the television or computer for the average six hours daily is probably one of the worst things that can happen so you also have to structure other activities for the morning and late afternoon.

column1: How do you handle being the odd-man out?
Everybody's talked about job discrimination for women and it's a legitimate issue with true grievances, but most aren't aware that the issue has also existed for men who are at home with the kids.
column2: While it's certainly better than it was and there are many women who have happily accepted my children and I into their lives, the fact is that there have been some who aren't comfortable with their children playing at the home in which the man is the primary caregiver.&nbsp
column3: While it's not an issue now that my kids are a bit older - and we actively encourage our kids to bring their friends here - there were definitely periods when they were very young that I, and my kids by extensions, was the odd man out.&nbsp
column4: When Eldest - now a high school senior - was very little, I had a real sense of being isolated as neighborhood mothers that I met at the park would balk at establishing playdates when they discovered that I was the one with whom they and their kids would be spending time.&nbsp
column5: In the moment, it was terribly frustrating as my toddler was unable to play with her peers outside of the park.&nbsp
column6: Was it because of me personally?&nbsp
column7: Were there concerns about the appearance of any sexual impropriety?&nbsp
column8: Were they uncomfortable with the fact that a historically female role was now being filled by a man?

column1: Do you and your mate have common expectations?

The blending and shifting of parental roles has really grown in the past quarter century and while it seems like a long time on a personal level - I wasn't even married then - it isn't a long span on a societal level.
column2: We've now had roughly two generations of women who have been raised with the idea that they are every bit as capable as men professionally, but the offset is that we've only had about one generation of men who have begun to literally decide that they are every bit as capable raising children as their mates.&nbsp
column3: Does it make the women bad mothers?&nbsp
column4: Absolutely not.&nbsp
column5: Does it mean that men are automatically great fathers?&nbsp
column6: Absolutely not.&nbsp
column7: But it does mean that there are very different levels of expectations by both parties on what's involved in raising the kids and running the household.&nbsp
column8: It also means that there's real potential for anger, miscommunication and discord on the part of both of you.

column1: Where's the balance between housework and hands-on childrearing?
column2: Who's responsible for paying the bills and the everyday finances?&nbsp
column3: Who's responsible for the longer-term financial planning?&nbsp
column4: Is it one of you or do you&nbsp
column5: share?&nbsp
column6: Who decides the menu and does the cooking?

column1: Even if and when you and your mate answer these questions, consider what the expectations are within each of the categories and even whether the expectations are achievable by the parent charged with the role.
column2: This is especially the case regarding men and housework since most men were never purposefully taught about housework by their parents, either what should be done or how it's done.&nbsp
column3: The result is that working women returning home are frustrated that one thing or another either hasn't been accomplished or else is poorly done with the woman doing it herself to much exasperation on both her, and the man's, part.&nbsp
column4: Honestly, this is an area which has periodically plagued me and it's only been through considerable effort and time that my wife has come to realize that housework simply wasn't something that I was ever taught
column5: &nbsp
column6: I've had to learn to acknowledge that questions borne out of frustration are simply that and that I really should learn so that's it done properly in the first place.

column1: Do you define your value to the family in terms of money alone?
Men have historically been the breadwinners and have come to very narrowly define their contribution to the family in terms of how well they provide, and that's measured in dollars and sense.
column2: Women have viewed their role in a wider sense apart from money, although that's also been included to some degree as economic necessity dictates.&nbsp
column3: Spend some time deciding how you view your role/contribution to the family and whether you actually believe that there's more to it than money alone.&nbsp
column4: Just as I've met women who didn't quite know what to do with a male homemaker, there have also been men who've been dismissive because I have no income so you're going to periodically hear it from both genders.

column1: How comfortable are you with uncertainty and doubt?
This sounds odd and it's taken me some thought
column2: to consider whether to include it, but raising children is an uncertain proposition.&nbsp
column3: The uncertainty starts early - why is she crying?
column4: What's going on with her teeth? - but is localized to a specific area bounded by the child and the immediate vicinity.
column5: But as the child grows and moves out into the world, and that's precisely why we're raising them, the circumstances and the reasons for the uncertainty change from the physical and concrete to the mental/emotional and the abstract.&nbsp
column6: <em>How is she developing?&nbsp
column7: Who are his friends and how is he interacting with them?&nbsp
column8: Because men have historically directed themselves outwards, it's been the women who've focused on these aspects and these questions and concerns.
column9: Now that women are increasingly spending their time and attention with the outside world, it's up to the father to begin taking up that particular slack.&nbsp
column10: These are questions for which there are no easily discernible answers and it's a world of grey.&nbsp
column11: Understand then, that if you're going to take much greater responsibility for the childrearing, then you have to be both willing and able to consider these amorphous areas.

column2: homemaker&quot
column3: - was never something on my radar and when my wife first suggested it years before the birth of our first child, my response was incredulity.&nbsp
column4: But despite the challenges and trepidation, it's been an experience that I&nbsp
column5: wouldn't trade for the world
column6: in a sense, a journey in a country largely unexplored by many of my male peers.&nbsp
column7: Like any successful expedition however, the trick is to have a sense of what lies ahead and some decent preparation for what's to come.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

Every job has its own slang and over the years, I've heard any number of words and phrases to describe childrearing.
column2: Here are some of my favorites.

column1: A blowout is anytime that an infant or toddler defecates in such volume or force that the mess escapes the diaper and travels throughout the clothing.
column2: The worst blowout occurs with the mess traveling up the back and soiling the clothing
column3: since much infant clothing involves something that's pulled over the head, this type will throw a wrench in the schedule as removing the clothing - and mess - will almost certainly get into the hair, requiring a bath.

column1: Junior's blowout was so massive that I almost called in the National Guard.
The stage in development in which a child's body has outgrown it's own capacity to adequately control and manuever it, marked by outsized hands and feet.
(After watching Junior trip twice and fall once enroute to the curb)
column2: <em>Junior's looking rather coltish this morning, isn't he?&nbsp
column3: See Also:
column4: Now that his shoe size is higher than his ability to count, he's officially in the colt stage.

column1: The spoken part of the phrase, the unspoken first part being "
column2: half-ass&quot
column3: .&nbsp
column4: Half-ass Charlie refers to those kids and teens who will do the most slapdash job possible just to say that it's done.
column5: This term was used by a school custodian in a conversation about students who'd been tasked with helping to clean as discipline for misbehavior.

column1: She should know better than that, that job's the work of an absolute Charlie.

column2: A mother who was commenting on the parenting of teens, <em>it's like being pecked to death by ducks.&nbsp
column3: The repeated and sometimes infuriating practice of being hounded by 'tweeners and teens who persist in their interruptions and requests, even despite having been consistently given an answer already.

column1: When Junior doesn't like the answer that he's given, he goes right into duckpecking mode.
column2: See Also:
column3: He's a nasty little duckpecker, ain't he?

column1: The physical reaction of rubbing one's face with the hand out of sheer disbelief at what Junior has just done or said.
column2: This is&nbsp
column3: sometimes a precursor to a massive headache or mild stroke.

column1: Mike had a facepalm moment when he walked into Junior's room and found that the boys had used the wall for knife-throwing practice after practicing their signatures with permanent marker on the bedroom's hardwood floor.
An action, typically used by kids and tweeners, to keep annoying people away.
column2: When the user is being bothered by someone, he either spits or heavily licks his palm so that it's copiously wet and then sticks it in the face of the annoying party,&nbsp
column3: thus repelling him backwards to avoid having spit rubbed in his face.&nbsp
column4: The term is inspired by the Jedi of the Star Wars films (although I've never seen a clip of Obi-Wan hocking a loogie into his hand).

column1: Randy wouldn't stop looking over my shoulder during free reading so I did a force push to get him to go away.
Based upon the premise that if you give a monkey a hammer, that's what he'll use for every problem and challenge.
column2: This is the situation in which a child of any age uses what they know to achieve the task at hand, regardless of the damage done to the item.

column1: Several days after reading this and mentally noting the phrase on Zerohedge
column2: just last week, my wife and I got to experience it first hand.

column1: The kids really monkeyhammered the KitchenAid Stand-up Mixer
column2: when I asked them to clean the dried&nbsp
column3: batter off of&nbsp
column4: it, they tossed it into a sink full of hot, soapy water and then rinsed it off with the spray nozzle.

column2: Even if the kid winds up spending more time with you than at their own home, they're an Opie.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, your own kid is someone else's Opie.

column1: I went to pick up Junior after practice and ended up giving rides home to three other Opies.
A child with a tendency to wander away, as in Where's Waldo now?
Oh great, I'm chaperoning Fiona during the field trip.
column2: I hear that she's a Waldo.

column1: A term once used by another father as we discussed the upcoming Kindergarten year for our respective sons, who are two weeks apart in age.
column2: It refers to a kid who, while not retarded or dumb, is simply odd and spastic.

column1: Y'know, every father's fear is that when the bus pulls away on that first morning, his kid's gonna be the windowlicker.
column2: The one kid who, while all the other kids are waving goodbye, is licking the back window instead.

column1: I still laugh when I think about that particular remark.

With the news that the 2011 Christmas shopping season opened with Black Friday sales up about 6+% from last year, it might be interesting to compare - on a personal level - how this Black Friday compared with previous Black Fridays.
column2: For more than five years, I've been one of those folks who showed up in line for the earliest sales in order to get the sales items under the Christmas tree and with the older kids, it's become a family tradition to go out in the middle of the night with close family friends and tagteam different stores and sales.&nbsp
column3: This year, the kids are getting older and we've made it abundantly clear that our summer family vacation was the big gift, so I almost didn't go
column4: Middle asked so that he and a friend could do some shopping on his very limitied budget and I agreed and spent my time people-watching with a cup of coffee.&nbsp
column5: So what's different this year?

column1: The first difference is how the marketing gurus and retailers are now playing up the shopping with advertising and the sales of "
column2: loss leading&quot
column3: items to get people in the doors.&nbsp
column4: I rarely shop at Toys R Us anymore but was there&nbsp
column5: one morning last week and in a chat with the sales clerk, she commented that instead of opening at midnight like other retailers, they were actually opening at 9 PM on Thanksgiving night and that she'd be there even earlier.&nbsp
column6: She shook her head and simply said, they're taking our holiday from us.
column7: In the moment, she meant her employer while I saw it as the entire economic machine.&nbsp
column8: Throughout the days prior to Thanksgiving, the media was filled with ads and reminders about the offers that would be available and how the earlier hours were there to be even more hospitable to the customer.&nbsp
column9: While the ostensible thrust is great deals and savings for the debt-laden consumer, the reality is that this is purely another way to gin up sales figures for the retailers, another in the panting gasps of the consumerist mentality.

column1: Second, there were far more small children out than I recall seeing when I first started going out years ago.
column2: Seven years ago, the stores that were open at 4 AM had lines snaking through the cold outdoors and were populated entirely by adults, more than a few of whom were grandparents.&nbsp
column3: This year, the doors to the mall themselves were open by midnight and when I wandered through the food court about 2 AM, the child's playarea had at least a half dozen small children running and playing.&nbsp
column4: Are the parents so strapped that they'll take the kids out at those hours in order to help assure that the tree has gifts?

column1: Third, there are far more stores opening at the early/late hours than there were eight years ago
column2: so much so that the mall itself opened its doors at midnight.&nbsp
column3: When I first started going out, there were only a small handful that opened at 4 AM and a line would form outside a mall entrance, people prepared to enter when the mall doors were opened.&nbsp
column4: By the time that I left at 330 AM for breakfast with the kids, roughly half of the mall stores were open and the place was crawling with more people at that hour than on a typical weekend evening.&nbsp
column5: What's also of note is that a number of those stores open early eight years ago are now consigned to the retail morgue - Linens N Things, Circuit City, KB Toys - and I wonder, how many of these stores now opening at these hours are also not long for this world?

column1: Fourth, despite the news reports of shopper violence, it's apparent that the retailers are pushing to maintain control.
column2: Walmart now staggers when certain items are put on sale and those interested have to come early for a ticket and then return later to a predetermined line.&nbsp
column3: Other retailers have staff outside beforehand helping to maintain order and there was significant police and security presence at the Walmart and mall.&nbsp
column4: It left a bitter taste in my mouth as it reinforces the notion that we consumers exist solely to enrich the corporations and must be controlled as they happily take our money.

column1: Even after Black Friday had ended, the retailers were ginning up the sales machine for what they refer to as Cyber Monday.
column2: You don't want to go out because you're working the next day?&nbsp
column3: Not to worry since you can now get all of the deals online!&nbsp
column4: Because we have a UPromise credit card and take the rebates as they're needed, my wife went online last night and noted that at some retailers, such as Sears, the rebates were not only higher at 10% of the sale price, but that using the credit card for the purchase would yield rebates of 21%.
column5: Rebating one fifth?
column6: It's telling about the health not only of the retailer, but also of the credit card bank, which is Bank of America.&nbsp
column7: The credit card rate is in the teens - we usually pay ours off monthly - and with most cardholders carrying a balance, the drive is to keep the balances high&nbsp
column8: and collect the interest and fees for the bank's bottom line.

column1: What's happening is a huge exercise in what financial types call pulling the demand forward.
column2: The premise is that there's an organic demand for merchandise as people replace what they have or either shift upwards or downwards and that offering such deep discounts will cause them to buy what they need or want now instead of waiting until later.&nbsp
column3: But the problem is that once that demand is pulled forward, what's going to sustain it in the future?&nbsp
column4: With declining real incomes and uncertainty as to jobs, people are likely to grab what they can now, but the wallet will be closed later.

column2: With the kids growing and the checkbook shut, my purchases were minimal.&nbsp
column3: The bulk of my time was spent nursing&nbsp
column4: a cup of coffee and enjoying a very early egg breakfast with Middle and his friends.&nbsp
column5:
My expectation is that next year, it'll simply be the breakfast.

December's marketbasket was priced and the data from the three unrelated stores shows that prices are up again after a three month respite, to an index level of 106.49, or about 6.5% from the original prices in November 2010.
column2: This is a rise of almost one full percentage point and is the highest monthly increase since July's jump of 1.14%.&nbsp
column3: This increase is on the back of four items - store brand frosted flake cereal (5.1%), peanut butter (4.7%), Gorton's Fish Sticks (9.7%) and potatoes (18%).&nbsp
column4: The peanut butter increase is purely a function of supply as the crop suffered and the fish price is on the back of a 28% rise at one particular store, so it's uncertain if this is a precursor to the other stores raising prices or simply a&nbsp
column5: &quot
column6: one-off&quot
column7: &nbsp
column8: abnormality.&nbsp
column9: The other item of note is that once again, the number of items with a price increase (15) is higher than those with price decreases (7), a reversal of the November situation in which prices actually dropped.

508,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There are any number of teachable moments for kids, instances in which you can seize the opportunity to explain what's seen as well as what's happening in the world.
column2: Such was the case this weekend as I drove Youngest to the library in a nearby city and passed the small local Occupy encampment, which presented a spectrum of topics to consider.&nbsp
column3: This was especially the case as I honked at a middle-aged man holding a sign which read Honk if you remember when torture wasn't an American value!

column1: Dad, why were you beeping the horn?
column2: I responded as to why I honked the horn and what the sign said, which led to a conversation about torture.
column3: To his credit, Youngest - at age&nbsp
column4: nine - knew precisely what waterboarding was and we chatted about both why it was used and why people were opposed to it, now including me.&nbsp

column1: Is that the only torture that we use?
column2: My answer was that while it was the only torture technique that our country utilized (so far as I know), we did ship prisoners off to other nations who were open to other, more imaginative methods.
column3: <em>Well, what's the difference then?&nbsp
column4: By this point, we'd pulled into the library parking lot and I could only tell him that so far as I could see, he was right in that there was no difference.
column5: I didn't mention that those who assigned a difference were only raising a facade - frankly because then I'd have to explain the meaning of the term <em>facade.&nbsp
column7: The exchange, from honking to parking, took about five minutes and that was a decent timeframe for his age level.

column1: Bill Cosby once performed a hilarious routine about kids and questions, entitled Why is there air?
column2: The Cosby response was a simple four words:
column3: to blow up basketballs.
column4: The gist is that kids are curious and want to know what's going on around them and it's one of my primary responsibilities to explain the world to them.&nbsp
column5: But the younger ones neither want nor need lengthy lectures or conversations.&nbsp
column6: They simply need a few minutes at most to give the basic reasons.&nbsp
column7: In Cosby's monologue, the child was probably a preschooler and not into upper elementary school, but the point is the same.&nbsp
column8: Keep it simple and neat, and then break it off lest the kid go into his yada yada yada mode.

column1: Daily life is rife with teachable moments, some sweet and others not so - like waterboarding and torture.
column2: Regardless, keep your ear tuned for the question and be ready to engage whenever it arises.

column1:
509,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The lives of families are usually intertwined with animals.
column2: It might be because the young couple got an animal after settling down or simply because the kids want one.&nbsp
column3: With the PracticalDad household now the residence of yet another cat and a purchased-but-not-yet-brought-home snake, the questions remain, what are the issues regarding pets and when is it too much?

column1: What to consider with kids and pets
The first and simplest question is, can your family actually handle having a pet?
column2: All parents talk with the kids, once they're a little older, about their need to take some responsibility in caring for the animals.&nbsp
column3: Preschoolers can certainly be taught to parcel out the dog and cat food, or sprinkle a little bit into the fishtank, but the reality is that actually remembering to do it is going to probably devolve upon the parent.&nbsp
column4: The corollary to this is that if the kids are already involved in some other activity and the animal needs to be fed, then consider how you'll react when you're reminder is met with either inaction - requiring another, more pointed reminder - or the roll of the eyes.&nbsp
column5: If your schedule is full enough that a small activity such as even feeding, let alone walking and fecal duties, creates a mood-altering imposition, then reconsider it again.

column1: Will the pet continue to stay small and cute, or is it going to grow into some else entirely?
column2: Kittens and puppies are cute enough for many that it makes up for the actual work that's involved with very young animals.&nbsp
column3: But these grow up to be adult animals with their own personalities and quirks and the ongoing care will no longer be outweighed by the cuteness factor.

column2: About a year ago, Eldest showed up at the backdoor with a friend that she wanted me to meet - that's a danger signal by itself - and the box that the friend had brought along.&nbsp
column3: After the introduction, during which my eyes periodically wandered to the magic wonder box, she divulged that the inhabitant was a duckling for whom her friend was trying to find a home.&nbsp
column4: Why?&nbsp
column5: Because her friend had thought that a duck would be a wonderful addition to the family and her own father had laid it at her doorstep.&nbsp
column6: <em>Not only are we not taking in a damned duckling, but you're going to find it a decent home.&nbsp
column7: We were probably the fourth stop on the duckling's home adoption tour and when the girls couldn't even identify what it would do in the coming wintertime - I think that it'll head south... - her mother and I agreed to foster the duckling until we found a decent farm on which it could live.
column8: Dogs and cats make sense, even hamsters and snakes, but to consider taking in a duck solely because we have a small fishpond is lunacy.

column2: Well cared for animals typically have their own particular foods and diets and that's a cost.&nbsp
column3: Cats additionally require litter and when you factor in the vet bills, having pets can be expensive.&nbsp
column4: Wander through the local humane league and you'll probably find any number of sad animals who've been given up their owners because they couldn't handle the cost.

column1: Apart from clear factors such as cost and sheer generated workload, this is a highly subjective question.
column2: In our household, the kids who want to bring in additional pets had better be able to answer certain questions and get their information straight for the verbal quiz.&nbsp
column3: While Eldest campaigned for years for a reptile or snake, she could never quite get the information straight and her answers led to other questions.&nbsp
column4: <em>So this thing doesn't eat mice, but just crickets?&nbsp
column5: Do they have to be alive or dead crickets and must I concerned about crickets escaping into the house?&nbsp
column6: What about the noise that these crickets are going to make through the night?&nbsp
column7: Youngest however, was watching this and through the years, prepared himself so that when we talked about it, he was clear on what was involved in caring for a reptile or snake.
column8: For his part, he's willing to feed it a mouse each week and is very clear that the day that I have to stun a live mouse and feed the snake is probably the snake's last day in this household.

column1: The upshot is that he purchased a snake with his own money this weekend and we covered the habitat for his Christmas.
column2: When we assembled the various parts of the habitat last night, he didn't grumble when I made him read the instructions aloud to me and he even commented that this item or that was something he didn't realize.

column1: The other aspect to whether it's too much is the question of time.
column2: Eldest still campaigns for yet another pet in her room but we've told her no since with less than a year until college, she wouldn't be around to care for whatever it was she wanted and the uncertainty as to college dorm regulations made it impracticable.&nbsp
column3: It's one thing to take in a family pet with run of the household, but another entirely to take in a creature which has appeal to only one person, who's only there for a certain time longer.

column1: So as it stands now, we're up to one dog, four cats and in the next day, a corn snake.
column2: That's enough for me.
