column1:
510,"1","1",,"xhtml","

On a short trip out of state today, I stopped at a sandwich joint for a quick lunch and as I waited, two of the counter waitresses talked about their Christmas shopping plans.
column2: One listened as her coworker spoke of continuing to search for great deals so that her kids could have a good Christmas day.&nbsp
column3: The listener then complained that she now felt guilty for cutting back on Christmas presents.&nbsp
column4: On the cusp of a syndicated story about kids' letters to Santa during recession
column5: and how they're feeling the pinch, it begs the question of how to handle Santa and the kids when the money is truly tight.&nbsp
column6: Do you further impoverish yourself to keep appearances for the kids?

column1: On the appearance hand, many parents want their children to believe in Santa for as long as possible.
column2: There's a bittersweet wistfulness in the soul when the kids are old enough to leave Santa and what he represents
column3: there's still years of their presence - but an innocence is gone.&nbsp
column4: For the parents who are caught in a financial bind, Santa also represents a reprieve from the daily tension that the kids certainly notice when Mom and/or Dad are confronted with financial hardship.&nbsp
column5: <em>What do I pay now?&nbsp
column6: Can I get an extension on this?&nbsp
column7: Children are sensitive to their parents and can easily discern when something's not right and the thought is that, at least on Christmas Day, things are as they're presented in the media and popular culture.

column1: But appearance can and does give way to hard reality.
column2: This particular story line has run before with similar stories in 2008, 2009
column3: and 2010
column4: and this reappearance is sympomatic of the ongoing implosion of the American Middle Class.&nbsp
column5: Kids are acutely aware that things are bad and are going to the one source that can work some kind of magic for their families, Santa Claus.&nbsp
column6: The key point however, is that in the midst of the correspondence, they aren't asking for themselves but instead for either what benefits the family or their parents, so that some sense of stability can be gained.&nbsp
column7: This, I think, is the key to the entire situation.&nbsp
column8: Parents have grown in an era of materialism and are almost programmed to think of the season in terms of things and wrapped presents
column9: but these kids are now in the fourth year of a Great Retrenchment and those in the bind are writing off the materialism for something more fundamental, and that's a sense of stability and control.&nbsp
column10: <em>Santa, forget the RC car and just help Dad find a job.&nbsp
column11: Then we can get back to what we had before.&nbsp
column12: What the kids are truly looking for is a sense of family, belonging and stability and that doesn't come from a specified number of wrapped gifts but instead from the time and efforts that we fathers and parents put into them.

column1: There's no clear answer to this question and some will disagree with me profoundly.
column2: But in the final balance, what's the point of pushing Santa for the kids if the ensuing angst over how to cover the rent ruins the holiday season?&nbsp
column3: The kids would much rather know that the parents are doing everything that they can to keep things together and if they can contribute, then that's one way that they're probably willing to do so.&nbsp
column4: Our job as parents is to maintain as even a keel as possible and that's truly what the kids want, is to know that things are covered as much as possible.

column1:
If you're uncertain, then talk to the Santas when you see them in the store.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

513,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of the common questions for parents with kids is do I hafta?, particularly regarding going along to another sibling's event or activity.
column2: The answer is a no-brainer when the child is too young to be home alone but when they can be left alone for a short period, or longer, but then it does take greater thought.&nbsp
column3: When can, and should, kids be allowed to stay home alone instead of tagging along for the sibling's activity?

column1: Most kids are egocentric and this ramps up to a roaring crescendo in their early to mid teens.
column2: If their sibling has something going on, the chronic refrain is the plaintive do I hafta?
column3: It can be irritating since the question is repetitive and when there are more than one child involved, the decision may lead to discord as the budding jailhouse lawyers pick the answer apart.&nbsp
column4: <em>She didn't have to go, why do I?&nbsp
column5: But he got to stay home and I have to go?&nbsp
column6: Where's the justice?&nbsp
column7: (Seriously, one of my kids lofted that comment and I simply laughed aloud in the child's face).
column8: What are some considerations on whether the child stays or goes?

column1: <li>How long can the child reasonably be home alone?&nbsp
column2: Kids don't mature at the same rate and some elementary schoolers could be home while you run older sibling to a practice.&nbsp

column1: <li>Is there the possibility of intervening stops?&nbsp
column2: With cellphones, the prospect of plan changes rises as you're called with a request to stop somewhere and pick something up.&nbsp
column3: How far out of the way does that take you and can the child manage that (with a phone call letting him know)?&nbsp
column4: There have been instances when I've refused the request because it didn't seem right to leave the child home any longer than was already the case.

column1: <li>Is the sibling's activity a practice or an actual event, such as a game or a concert?&nbsp
column2: If there's only a practice, then the questions&nbsp
column3: are whether you need to stay for the practice and it's duration.&nbsp
column4: If it's just a drop-off, then perhaps the other can stay home but if it's far enough away that it's better to just stay, then toting the sibling makes more sense.&nbsp
column5: Our school district is geographically large and rec league soccer practices could be far enough away that it was impractical and expensive to come home and on those instances, I made it a point of bringing the others along and they could bring their books or games.&nbsp
column6: If it's an actual game or concert, then only a sibling's competing activity or schoolwork could keep the child home and in those instances of schoolwork, it's been understood that we'll check homework or quiz.

column1: <li>Do you actually trust the kid to be home, either alone or with siblings?&nbsp
column2: If you don't, then you can anticipate considerable blowback but the risk of something bad occurring outweighs that.&nbsp
column3: Some years ago, an acquaintance related that&nbsp
column4: she went to the grocery store, figuring that she'd be gone only for an hour and that her 'tweener son could be alone with her teen daughter and friend.&nbsp
column5: She returned home to find the boy handcuffed to a chair with his hair full of bows.&nbsp
column6: He'd cuffed himself to the chair, not knowing that there was no key, and sister and friend decided to take the opportunity to do his hair for him.&nbsp
column7: As she stated at the time, so I won't be leaving him home alone with her for awhile.

column1: <li>This leads to the next question,are any of their peers going to be there?&nbsp
column2: Stupidity is contagious and the ability of 'tweeners and teens to assess risk ranks up there with the ability of Lindsay Lohan to make a community service date.&nbsp
column3: It's a very short list of kids with which I'm comfortable being at the house unmonitored.

column1: So what do I say when the kids, of whatever age, find that they're coming along to sibling's game?
column2: The language that we've used is that this is simply something that family does for one another, a visual way to show that we support each other in our chosen activities.&nbsp
column3: While I can say that other parents say the same, it's nice to find out that the kids talk with one another and find that the other parents really are saying the same thing as Middle noted during a chat with an acquaintance at school.&nbsp
column4: <em>Yeah, my folks say that I've got to go my brother's ballgame because that's what a family does for one another.&nbsp
column5: A tack that I've taken with the older kids is this:
column6: While a good part of your life was spent without Youngest in the picture, you've always been a part of his life and he's never known life without you.
column7: You'll be going off to college - or wherever - and you simply won't be around to see all of the cool things that he's probably going to do as he grows, and while he's always been there for you, you won't be there for him.&nbsp
column8: This is a comment that I've only had to make once or twice and with each of the older kids and each time, it was met with a quiet look as each assessed its validity and acknowledged its truth.
column9: It might not work with all kids, but I was gratified that neither Eldest nor Middle scoffed and derided it.

column1: Like other parts of parenting, it can be frustrating to listen to the backtalk and griping.
column2: But this is how the kids are learning that a family is more than just an accumulation of biologically related bodies within a household.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
512,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Teens might be great with electronics and technology and their superiority gives them bragging rights over many parents
column2: unfortunately, they then think that this transfers over to their understanding of what goes on in the real world.&nbsp
column3: Part of my job is to explain the real world to them, a world that is more complex and less forgiving than they'll understand for years to come.&nbsp
column4: Such is the case of explaining the consequences of stupid and/or illegal actions.

column1: One of the kids shared that some friends were caught shoplifting $2 rubber wristbands from a mall retailer that caters to teens.
column2: As explained to me, the manager caught them trying to exit the store with the trinkets and took them back to the office, where they subsequently were interviewed by both mall security and the local police.<em>&nbsp
column3: Parents were subsequently contacted and the kids were released to their custody.
column4: The subsequent conversation ran along the lines of...

column2: The cops said that it happens all of the time and nothing's going to hit their record if they don't do it again.&nbsp

column1: So you're telling me that the police just released them with no actions taken by the store?
My kid responded, well, they do have to pay a fine but nothing's going on their record, so it's really okay.
Kid, I retorted, if there's a fine to be paid, then there's a paper trail and believe me, something is going to hit their juvenile record.

column2: he interjected - <em>there's no record.&nbsp

column1: It was at this point that my kid got a real-world lesson.
column2: <em>Lemme tell you, there's a juvenile record and there's an adult record.&nbsp
column3: Your buddies have three years to not do something like this again in order for it to avoid their adult record.
column4: If they screw up again, then they start off their adult life with a criminal record.&nbsp
column5: Period.&nbsp
column6: What does this mean?&nbsp
column7: When these kids go out to apply for summer&nbsp
column8: jobs and are asked on the application if there's any criminal history, they're screwed.&nbsp
column9: Forget about lying on the application because more and more employers are doing background checks and who wants a thief working for them?

column1: My child pursed his lips and said nothing for a few seconds as he digested this.

column2: I asked.
<em>One guy's parents were super-pissed and he's not only grounded, but he's lost all electronics and his guitar.&nbsp
column3: Same with the other guy, but his folks didn't yell.&nbsp
column4: They just shook their heads and asked what he'd been thinking since he had at least $20 in his wallet.&nbsp
column5: Not much of a problem.

column1: No, I said, it's a problem because he's truly disappointed his parents.
column2: Their kid doesn't even have the excuse of saying that he didn't have any cash.&nbsp

column1: Kids and teens will screw up and sometimes in a way reminiscent of a 20 car NASCAR wreck.
column2: They don't have the experience and understanding to place events in a proper context and it's our job to teach them what the consequences of their actions will be.&nbsp
column3: If we don't do so, either because we're busy or it's unpleasant - whatever the reason - then they'll fall back to the default position of getting their information from their peers and in this case, the peers who actually screwed up.&nbsp
column4: The same kids who will minimize&nbsp
column5: out of embarrassment, a desire&nbsp
column6: to look cool or sheer incomprehension of what's actually happened.

column1: The kids will make all manner of comments that can lead to conversations and some can be postponed to a more opportune moment.
column2: This conversation however, was one that had to happen at that moment for fear that not making the point could lead to the conclusion that even Dad didn't consider it a big deal.&nbsp
column3: Oh yeah, it's a big deal.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
515,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Most parents can identify the moment when the kids tune out since the eyes glaze over and with a few, the mouth actually drops open.
column2: When younger siblings are present however, I continue what I'm saying since I want them to hear what's being said.
column3: In a sense, I'm playing to an audience and there are instances in which it's apparent that they're taking the commentary to heart.&nbsp
column4: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
516,"1","1",,"xhtml","

``You have never seen the like of me before!'' exclaimed the Spirit.
``Have never walked forth with the younger members of my family
column2: meaning (for I am very young) my elder brothers born in these later years?'' pursued the Phantom.

column1: ``I don't think I have,'' said Scrooge. ``I am afraid I have not. Have you had many brothers, Spirit?''
``More than eighteen hundred,'' said the Ghost.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: - Scrooge's Encounter with the Ghost of Christmas Present, Dickens' A Christmas Carol

column1: None of us have walked with all of the previous ghosts, now numbering more than 2000.
column2: &nbsp
column3: When you're enmeshed&nbsp
column4: in the fabric of life with children, it sometimes seems as though it will always remain the same - Santa Claus pictures, toys and after-bedtimes evenings spent wrapping and hiding.&nbsp
column5: But step back and observe and you find that while the ghosts are very similar,&nbsp
column6: they are subtly different over time until you&nbsp
column7: realize that the being is entirely different
column8: simpler, quieter and more genteel.&nbsp
column9: This is the progression of Christmases as the kids age and move further into the outside world.&nbsp

column1: As the kids age, they take the commercial idea of a gift-wrapped, shiny Christmas and unknowingly burnish it
column2: to a marvelous core that really doesn't require all of the accompanying bells and whistles.&nbsp
column3: It's a core composed of the elements of family and friends and if you believe, faith.&nbsp
column4: Listen to the kids' memories and you find that it usually isn't the toy that's remembered from any particular year so much as what happens with the toy afterwards, all of the memories that come from playing with it and frequently, with you.&nbsp
column5: Take a moment to consider each ghost and examine it for what it is,&nbsp
column6: then burn it into your memory alongside each of its siblings.&nbsp
column7: It will make you appreciate what you have all of the more.

column1: May you - and your family - have a wonderful Christmas season.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
517,"1","1",,"xhtml","

In today's world, I can't help but think of computers when I consider the differences between the male and female brains. One of the criticisms of men in family relationships is that "
column2: things aren't what they were&quot
column3: and that's largely because the hard drive atop a woman's shoulders is crunching data and work functions almost continuously to the exclusion of the game processes.
column4: But even if men are standing up and doing more, there's an additional difference and that becomes glaringly obvious at Christmas - we're running completely completely different operating systems at different speeds.&nbsp
column5: Women are at the higher speeds on a Windows 7 while we're hammering along with XE on a three year old laptop.

column1: I fully believe that men can do as well at raising kids as women, maternal intuition notwithstanding.
column2: But I do believe that women are simply better able to multitask than men and especially in the case of details.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: In this household, things move along well until late October&nbsp
column5: and then we shift into the seasonal holiday mode in which my wife's ability to remember the smallest details simply puts me to shame.&nbsp
column6: Youngest is old enough to get a real tie and if we get this, he can wear it with the following outfits...Eldest has a sweater that would go great with this necklace...Let's face it, I'm the one managing the clothing and laundry and I haven't the foggiest notion of what they've got in terms of colors and style.
column7: In case you wonder if I'm just style-impaired, consider the following.

column1: Remember when we got my father that sweater four years ago?
column2: Nope.

column1: Would best friend be able to use this purse?
column2: Haven't a clue.

column1: Do you know if Middle needs new dark socks since his feet have grown?
column2: Nuh - uh.

column1: The modern Christmas season has become a complex dance with intricate moves along a multi-dimensional dance floor.
column2: This is partially due to the influence of the consumer model in which we equate a quality Christmas with the number of gifts given and partially because of the way that the families are now geographically dispersed throughout the country.&nbsp
column3: There's simply more to do and cover for people to have what is considered a good season.&nbsp
column4: The other influence is probably due to the simple difference between men and women
column5: I believe that women are hard-wired to be more empathethic and concerned with the feelings of others than men, so they place a greater emphasis on these details than their mates.

column1: But the reality is that if you hooked up a wife and mother's brain to a computer diagnostic, you'd probably find more processes running than that of their mate.
column2: &nbsp
column3: I&nbsp
column4: suspect that&nbsp
column5: if the men made more of an effort to upgrade their processes, they'd probably find that their mate would correspondingly let the processes slow down.&nbsp
column6: There's still be a qualitative difference however, and I don't think that that leap is going to be easily made.

You can understand something intellectually, but that doesn't mean that you fully grasp the import of its meaning.
column2: It's this difference that shifts an issue from sterile discussion to true debate, as those who feel it in their gut push the envelope and make their points in ever more forceful tones.&nbsp
column3: This comprehension shift happened to me this past weekend as the ongoing erosion of the American Middle Class took on a far more personal and visceral meaning.

column1: My most important job as a father is to teach my children about the great wide world and help prepare them to survive in it.
column2: Doing that means that I also have to pay attention to what's going on around us and how these things impact the world in which my children will live.&nbsp
column3: The rise of the corporate society and the official preference of the uber-rich at the cost of the middle class has clearly shaped what and how I teach my children about the adult world.&nbsp
column4: We've taught the kids that an education is essential for economic survival and have done what we can to see that it's obtained with as little debt as possible.&nbsp
column5: But spend a lot of time around kids and teens and you begin to think of many of them as your own
column6: you watch them grow from small children and fill out, physically at first and then in terms of mind, emotion and character.&nbsp
column7: When this happens, you begin to worry about the kids who aren't being given much guidance and support and it can be painful.

column1: The case in point occurred when I was speaking with Eldest about one of her close, a young man who's shown significant character and maturity.
column2: He'd already graduated from high school and was working and our questions - my wife and&nbsp
column3: I - pertained to what was happening with his plans for community college to get the higher ed ball rolling again.&nbsp
column4: As I spoke with my daughter, I reiterated my well-rehearsed commentary on the need for the education but then simply stated <em>if he doesn't get things moving while he's young, he's going to spend his life on the other side of the great divide.&nbsp
column5: It struck me as an odd phrase at the time and when I reflected back on it later, my reaction was far more visceral than it had been previously.

column1: Economic and political policies, as well as long-standing social habits,
column2: are eating away at the middle class and if changes aren't&nbsp
column3: made, future America - our children's America - will consist of two groups on either side of a chasm.&nbsp
column4: There was once ground which permitted both groups to live together but the existent policies&nbsp
column5: will continue to undermine this until it collapses into an unbridgeable gap.&nbsp
column6: Once this happens, separating the small group on one side from the large group on the other, then there will be nothing to bind them together and our nation will devolve into a state of nightmarish proportions as the larger group struggles to survive and the smaller one fights desperately to maintain its advantage in resources and opportunities.

column1: While I want this young man to succeed, I'm ashamed that my great divide remark was so contained to one person.
column2: I've come into contact with so many children and teens and it's unacceptable that a handful gain the one side while the rest are stranded on the other
column3: each should be responsible as adults for their own movement forward, but permitting the presence of the divide robs the mass of even the opportunity to move.&nbsp
column4: If our Constitution states that each has the right to pursue happiness, the chasm's existence is inherently unconstitutional as it robs the many of that right.&nbsp
column5: Many will be bound, despite their efforts, to a life without the opportunity to advance themselves beyond their present station and our nation is at a loss for it.

column1: There are no simple, cookie-cutter responses to this erosion and things will change neither easily or quickly.
column2: But there are some basic things to remember and adopt.

column1: <li>Begin to pay attention to what's going on around you.&nbsp
column2: Question what you read and hear in the main stream media and when you hear a pundit, ask yourself what that person and his or her sponsor has to gain.&nbsp
column3: Then share with your family and friends and spread the word.

column1: <li>Teach your children not to believe what they hear and see in the media.&nbsp
column2: You cannot have it all and will have to make choices.
column3: The newest product model or version won't make you happy or satisfied.&nbsp
column4: You cannot expect to live on support but will have to hustle to make your way in the world.&nbsp
column5: The old economic model of spend, spend and spend is no longer operative.&nbsp
column6: And yes, you're going to have to study and above all, think.

column1: <li>Amend your buying habits so that you don't automatically purchase the lowest cost item, which will probably be made in China or elsewhere in the world.&nbsp
column2: Think about where an item originates and whether your purchase supports your fellow citizens.

column1: <li>Likewise, buy local when and where you can.&nbsp
column2: As I age, my buying priorities are becoming local first, domestic second and finally, foreign if necessary.&nbsp
column3: This way, I'm putting my own kids and their peers to work first and supporting their livelihoods.

column1: <li>Pay greater attention to the electoral process and what the candidates are doing instead of saying.&nbsp
column2: Skepticism is a healthy thing and ask whether they're consistent in their beliefs
column3: if necessary, turn off the main stream media and shift to the internet.&nbsp
column4: You'll have to work harder to skim the wheat from the chaff, but it's worthwhile.&nbsp

column1: <li>Finally, remember that our country has been here before, in the post-Civil War era of the Railroad Tycoons and Robber Barons, when a very few took dominion over our nation's wealth and resources.&nbsp
column2: Our ancestors dealt with it then and we can deal with it as well.

column1: But remember also that it took the work of many to elect men such as Theodore Roosevelt and his peers.
column2:
And many, many votes.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
your mate ever suddenly leave&nbsp
column3: to disappear, reappearing again in a few minutes with an armload of laundry/stuff/toys?&nbsp
column5: Do you ever wonder why your mate gets cranky, occasionally snarling about fair share or even simple appreciation?&nbsp
column7: Is there ever a moment in which there's a sigh as she escapes to respond to a buzzer?&nbsp
column9: If you've at least noticed these things, you're ahead of some guys who don't even recognize that she's dancing&nbsp
column10: the minuet, a particularly slow and monotonous variety that keeps the rhythm of cooking and housework as everything is done to keep the household moving and everyone on an even keel.

column1: A family is a complex organism and each moves to its own rhythm and tempo - rarely the same and often punctutated by syncopation, especially as the kids age and develop their own interests.
column2: The varying tempos means that greater attention must be paid to what's required to keep everything moving and everyone on an even keel.&nbsp
column3: I don't understand if it's training or some sort of gender hardwiring, but I believe that the average woman is better able to multitask
column4: a variety of chores and activities than the guy.&nbsp
column5: Men are certainly able to learn and adapt, but I've come to know some&nbsp
column6: women of whom I frankly stand in awe.&nbsp

column1: There are multiple elements to running the household - cooking, laundry, childrearing, cleaning - and most men would probably view them as discrete items, akin to blocks that can be stacked atop one another.
column2: <em>Now the laundry is entirely done and I can move on to the cleaning.&nbsp
column3: Once that is done, then I can read to the kids and afterwards, start dinner.&nbsp
column4: Each item has a finite edge and end and never violates the space of the next block.
column5: Women have learned that each element is actually akin to a strip of cloth or thread.&nbsp
column6: Each is discrete but instead of stacking, each element is interwoven with another through the course of the day's and evening's activities, resulting in something that appears to have been knit together.&nbsp
column7: <em>I'll sort the laundry and get a load of darks going, and then I'll read to Junior.&nbsp
column8: After a short book, I can move the washer load to the dryer and reload the washer and while that's running, I'll take care of early dinner preparation.&nbsp
column9: It's a creation of one element followed by another, and then back to the first and then to the third
column11: the result is that the guy's elements are akin to a colorful Lego tower while the woman's creation is a well-knit scarf.&nbsp

column1: The difference between the two is that most men haven't truly learned that the key to keeping things running is to shift back and forth between the elements, juggling them as deftly as a circus performer.
column2: You use a labor-saving device that takes a half-hour to run and then you shift into something that can be accomplished in twenty minutes, such as reading a children's book or cutting vegetables.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, you fold the laundry and then come back to it later, breaking the larger task into smaller segments.&nbsp
column4: Because they've done it for so much longer and been able to watch their own mothers, women have a much better sense of what's involved and how they interplay.&nbsp
column5: Men can learn it too, but it will take considerable effort, attention and time before they can even begin to create a piece as intricate as their mate's.&nbsp

column1: The archetypal father was someone who came home from work and played with the kids, and then did the finite, discrete tasks that were akin to projects - the honeydew list.
column2: Fix something, paint something and move on to the next item.&nbsp
column3: There would be singular differences between each which provided some variety and interest.&nbsp
column4: Women have known for generations that even after this was painted or that was fixed, they were left with the same four elements
column5: there was - and is - never an end to the process.&nbsp
column6: The result is a sense of having to dance the same dance, keeping everything moving, with never a difference in the music for variety and worse, no one to watch them or realize how well they dance their particular minuet.&nbsp
column7: Everyone likes an audience from time to time, observing and appreciating them for what they've managed to accomplish and for some dancers, this is sufficient.&nbsp
column8: But if you think of it, dancing is something that's meant to be done with a partner and most women find that the additional dimension of a partner gives meaning to the dance and respite from the boredom.&nbsp

column1: Stop, observe and think about what you're seeing if your mate is responsible for the household management.
column2: Consider what's involved and at least acknowledge&nbsp
column3: the job&nbsp
column4: being done.&nbsp
column5: Better yet, find the rhythm and give her a partner in the dance.

True change only happens incrementally and like anything else, you only notice it at moments when you have an a-ha! moment.
column2: For me, one of the primary indicators of changes in the social view is in the content of television commercials and what while most of my time isn't spent on the television, there have a few commercials which both show considerable change and the potential for generational conflict ahead.

column1: One of my gripes through the years has been the perception of fathers as portrayed in the media.
column2: With only the rare exceptions - Seventh Heaven's
column3: Reverend Camden and Parenthood's Adam Braverman - fathers have normally been portrayed as lovable dolts (Ray Romano) or complete idiots (Al Bundy, Homer Simpson and Peter Griffin).
column4: These are reflections of society's views of men and fathers from a generation or more touched by divorce and absentee fatherhood.&nbsp
column5: But a recent commercial gave me a pause as its 30 seconds portrayed a reflection of the re-engaging father.&nbsp
column6: In it, two children are preparing to brush their teeth as their father - no mother to correct him or chuckle at his well-meant but errant effort - explains why he purchases a particular brand of dental hygiene product.&nbsp
column7: He's young and dressed - as I frequently dress - in a casual button shirt and khaki slacks.&nbsp
column8: The sense of the commercial is that Dad's competent and in charge and the kids are alright with that and is a far cry from other commercials in which Mom can be seen correcting Dad for a goof.

column1: The other two change commercials aren't about fathers per se, but instead about the opposing views of
column2: the boomer generation and Generation Y.&nbsp
column3: There's been ongoing commentary about the values and behavior of the Boomer generation and the first commercial clearly plays upon that.&nbsp
column4: In the scene, a man is seated at a nicely set dinner table and both he and his wife complain about having been forced to curtail the sushi that they love, yet the woman brings him a small plate of food.&nbsp
column5: At that moment, as he cuts into the dish, their daughter enters and asks if they know what's happened to her two fish.&nbsp
column6: They each feign ignorance and as the father digs in, quips <em>what are you gonna do?&nbsp

column1: In the second set of commercials, young adults are in their respective apartments worrying about how their empty-nest parents are doing now that they're out of the house.
column2: They're typically online and the commentary pertains to the vast number of Facebook friends whereas their folks have so few.&nbsp
column3: As the commercial continues, they're concerned for their folks while the scene flips to a shot of the folks -&nbsp
column4: Boomers - going to a kegger with their friends and another set of Boomer parents gets out to ride horseback.&nbsp
column5: The copywriter is conceivably a Boomer who's poking fun at the youngsters' apparent belief that life is lived plugged into the Matrix.&nbsp
column6: But what struck me watching it was the contrast between the two generational lifestyles
column7: apart from the real/virtual aspect, was the question of money.&nbsp
column8: While the younger generation is much more into the Matrix than my own peers, I suspect that part of that pastime popularity is that it's much cheaper than activities as boarding or renting horses as that generation continues to spend money on less than wise choices.

column1: The final change commercial again pertains to the Generation Y adults and money in them, from both State Farm and Toyota, the young twenty-something woman is saving and scrimping to cover either the auto insurance or the down payment for her auto.
column2: It differs from years of commercials in which cars were sold with little down and zero percent financing and harks back to a time, generations ago, when necessary items were purchased with hard-saved cash.&nbsp
column3: The clock is spinning backwards in terms of personal finance and we'd better get used to it.

column1: So what do these commercials have to do with me?
column2: My sense of them is that first, it's my responsibility as a parent to recognize the change and work to teach my children accordingly, both through discussion and example.&nbsp
column3: If they have to learn how to live a more constrained lifestyle, it'll be easier if it's modeled for them here.&nbsp
column4: Second, change never goes down easily and the anger towards the Boomer generation will only intensify as the youngsters face their national future.&nbsp
column5: While I don't envision a life of spartan simplicity, I doubt that it's in my best interests to throw the green years pay away on frivolity to only have to return to the kids in the future for help.
column6: Once they're through, our obligation is to assure - as much as possible - that we don't unduly burden our children because of our own foolishness.

column1:
522,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Cell phones can be wonderful tools, but several other parents and I have noted they can be impediments when in the hands of teens.
column2: The problem that we've all noted is that while the kids can be in almost instantaneous communication with one another to plan something,&nbsp
column3: anyone's&nbsp
column4: different thought, idea or issue is&nbsp
column5: immediately brought up to the cell-linked hive mind and innumerable alternative plans are spun to the point that ultimately, either nothing occurs or what happens in no way resembles the original plan.&nbsp
column6: Not to say that the &quot
column7: old days&quot
column8: were necessarily better, but with only one line to a house and the pain-in-the-neck nature of plan changes, a plan that was generally agreed upon was maintained.&nbsp

column1: The term Plan 9 or Plan I came into being in this household when several months ago, I watched Eldest run the gamut in the kitchen.
column2: My wife and I were puttering in the kitchen when Eldest entered and announced that she and several friends were going to gather for something or another.&nbsp
column3: Shortly after she entered, her cellphone noted an incoming text and when she read it, she reported that somebody had asked if someone else could come - and naturally, that led to the question of how the newb would be transported and who could do so.&nbsp
column4: As she plunked in a response to the hive-mind, I glanced at my wife and commented that this was going to be&nbsp
column5: <em><span style=""display: none"" id=""1326739401323S"">&nbsp
column6: Plan B.
column7: Eldest finished her texting and was in the process of putting down the phone when another came in with someone else tossing out a question, which led to another furious round of texting and a quietly dry Plan C commented to my wife.
column8: By now, there was a full-fledged exchange of texts from the hive-mind and my wife and I slowed down to watch the process.&nbsp
column9: I was now standing at the kitchen island nursing a cup of coffee and as Eldest would remark upon the newest response, I'd remark that this was Plan D...wait, now here comes Plan E...whoa, someone else has some input for - wait for it - Plan F...nah, that's not gonna work so we're onto Plan G...okay, so it looks like we're set for Plan H...nope, Plan I.
column10: My wife handled it more gracefully than me since I was openly laughing as I&nbsp
column11: remarked upon this trainwreck of a social gathering.&nbsp
column12: Eldest finally harrumphed with a nasty glance in my direction and left the kitchen and to this day, I don't know if they managed to round the bases to Plan Z.

column1: The upshot of this is that first, Eldest frequently makes her hive-mind plans out of my presence.
column2: Second, we've learned that there are liable to be changes in the plans between when they're made and when the car leaves the driveway.&nbsp
column3: Knowing that the hive tries desperately to bend to the needs of the members, changes can occur and our request is that we apprised of significant changes, such as final destination or time of return
column4: we also reserve the right to veto anything that we deem necessary and yes, I've kept the prospect of a physical location check on the table.&nbsp

column1: When a teenager leaves the house with friends, you can never be certain of where they're actually going to wind up or what the final plan is.
column2: Especially with this hive-mind generation, plans seem to change in&nbsp
column3: a heartbeat and you can only lean upon faith and what you've taught them as you've raised them
column4: that there are such things as respect, limits, consequences and ultimately, right-and-wrong.&nbsp
column5: There can be legitimate changes in plans that entail acceptable deviation and it's our job as parents to work with that.&nbsp
column6: But ultimately, they need to know that the cellphone connects to home and once that call is made, the constant changes will stop and&nbsp
column7:
gel into a firm plan for the remainder of the gathering.

column2: of raising a child is&nbsp
column3: discipline, at whatever age.&nbsp
column4: That said, disciplining the child becomes even harder as she ages and in the teen years, it can become a damned unpleasant thing for which&nbsp
column5: parents&nbsp
column6: can be&nbsp
column7: unprepared.&nbsp
column8: Teens are affected by their peers - some of whom have little or no parental discipline - and frankly, the media.&nbsp
column9: They're affected by their own bodies, which are producing a complex and potent hormonal chemistry regardless of gender and they're affected by their own sense of growing independence and competence.&nbsp

column2: almost three&nbsp
column3: generations removed from the bestselling&nbsp
column4: parent books&nbsp
column5: of Dr. Benjamin Spock, who was mistakenly believed to have taught that it wasn't in the child's best interests to be disciplined, discipline being equated with punishment.&nbsp
column6: Parenting experts say that we should be firm and in control with the intimation that voices should never be raised and that if we handle it correctly, then the teen will desist and all will be well.&nbsp
column7: And somehow, the belief has seeped in that we should be our childrens' friend first and foremost and friends simply don't treat one another in a nasty way.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: The final result is, I believe, that there are many parents who will defer to the teen who pushes the limits and boundaries in the belief that what's required to keep them within them is not&nbsp
column10: acceptable as portrayed in the popular media.&nbsp
column11: And the inmates wind up running the asylum.

column1: Discipline is ultimately rooted in the notion of teaching and learning, which is a far cry from simple punishment.
column2: If you have just a quick, quiet conversation to point something out to them, you're actually engaging in discipline and it's frequently enough to keep things in order.&nbsp
column3: The difficulty is that as they age, all of the factors already mentioned come into play and make correction more difficult
column4: if you haven't already been quietly covering things with them, then it's going to appear even more onerous than it would otherwise.&nbsp

column1: Even if you've paid attention and had the ongoing conversations through all of the previous years, handling discipline with teens will become testy for all of the reasons proffered above.
column2: While the teens are motivated by whatever they want - most likely short-term or short-sighted - you're the one with the sense of the larger picture and that's fine except that the pressing teen doesn't see it that way.&nbsp
column3: There will be pushback and questions and even when the questions are answered, the rationale will be challenged and it can happen persistently.&nbsp
column4: Because the kids are now older, any number of issues will be thrown at you in sometimes forcible short order and in the moment, you have to determine the wheat from the chaff and move accordingly, all the while keeping the end goal in mind.&nbsp
column5: You have, in a sense, been ushered by your teens into Hogwarts, where the staircases move while you try to&nbsp
column6: reach where you&nbsp
column7: need to be.&nbsp

column2: aren't easy as&nbsp
column3: sometimes&nbsp
column4: frustration seeps in amongst both generations and voices are raised against one another.&nbsp
column5: It isn't a pretty scene and if you've consumed the popular parenting media, you'll feel like a failure because it isn't as calm, controlled and easy as it is made to appear.&nbsp
column6: When the time is less tense, you can&nbsp
column7: re-evaluate what's been said and even go back and revisit the issues with your teen
column8: communication is an ongoing process.&nbsp
column9: When these instances occur, it doesn't mean that you're a failure as a parent.&nbsp
column10: What it means is that you're having to grapple with the change that occurs with growing kids and change isn't easy.&nbsp
column12: simply taking the easy road, acceding to the demands of frequently irrational teens because it means a few moments of peace.

column1:
524,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of a parent's responsibilities is to control their child and nothing is more frustrating than a parent who can't or won't control their child in public.
column2: When should&nbsp
column3: you&nbsp
column4: step in and provide control&nbsp
column5: if the other parent won't?

column1: This question arose recently at a scouting event in which boys - fourth and fifth grade levels - were gathered at a
column2: science museum to earn an Engineering badge.&nbsp
column3: This was a four and&nbsp
column4: a half hour workshop run by a museum staffer, for which admission was charged.&nbsp
column5: Parents were present and while I'm a scout leader that arranged for the boys in my group to attend, I wasn't present because of another obligation.&nbsp
column6: According to other parents to whom I spoke, there was a particular boy from another group who simply ran wild and disrupted things
column7: even the other boys from my group were appalled at his behavior.&nbsp
column8: He ruined experiments and talked back to the staffer and in one experiment involving electricity, actually injured one of the boys from my scout pack, who showed several of us the mark on his stomach at a scout meeting four days later.&nbsp
column9: A father who was present backed up the accounts and the event involving the electricity.

column1: On one level, the museum bears responsibility because the staffer didn't act to control the child when he was found to be openly disruptive.
column2: But the reality is that this is a staffer who's paid to present a program and not discipline children who are there with responsible adults, either parents or scout leaders.&nbsp
column3: The boy's father was present and at no time stepped in, but simply sat back and watched his child misbehave and openly create problems.&nbsp
column4: No other adult stepped in either, apparently for fear of appearing to overstep boundaries and upsetting the father and the result was that when I met with the boys several nights later and asked about the event, what I heard was a story about a trainwreck instead of electrical circuits and bridgebuilding.&nbsp
column5: This was confirmed by the parents who were present with our boys.

column1: It's an unpleasant and uncomfortable situation, fraught with the prospect of further conflict if the other parent is an ass who won't like seeing Junior chastised.
column2: But when should you step in?

column1: • When you believe that the other parent will simply not intercede AND there's real prospect of injury should something go wrong, like children throwing rocks at kids who are coming down the sliding board.
• When it's an event for which you've paid money and a lack of control threatens to ruin it for your child and other children.
• When it's not only misbehavior, but open bullying of your child and the other parent will not intercede.

column2: In the last instance, it might take a little time to see how your own child handles things.&nbsp
column3: Years ago, when Youngest was not quite three, we were at a mall play area when he encountered a child who by size and appearance was several years older.&nbsp
column4: This child would purposefully run into Youngest and knock him down, then return to his mother, who was also clearly watching events.&nbsp
column5: Youngest was knocked down twice and purposefully shoved down once and in the middle of this, she and I exchanged looks as things unfolded.&nbsp
column6: When the last shove occurred, I moved to intercede but stopped as&nbsp
column7: Youngest got up, walked over and punched the bigger kid in the face.&nbsp
column8: To his credit, Youngest proceeded to play while the other boy&nbsp

column1: Each of us has a responsibility to monitor and control our children.
column2: It can be embarrassing to have to do so in public, but that's one of the prices paid for having kids in the first place.&nbsp
column3:
Each of us likewise has an obligation to step up when we see a child's misbehavior being willfully ignored by the idiot parent, and I say that because if you don't, that's how you look to the rest of us.

column1:
525,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of my primary jobs as a father to teach my kids, especially about what goes on in the outside world.
column2: It's often fun but can be occasionally unnerving, especially when it pertains to protecting your children from sexual predators
column3: you don't want to ruin their innocence nor do you want to teach that each stranger is a danger.&nbsp
column4: Teaching about the prospect of sexual molestation is something that we've done, with age appropriate language, since the kids were in preschool but the questions have arisen again since the onset of&nbsp
column5: the Sandusky allegations out of Penn State.&nbsp
column6: Understand that if the kids aren't overtly listening to the news, something of this nature seeps over into their conversations with their own peers via over sources.

column1: What surprised me from my own children was a question raised by Youngest, who looked at me one evening and asked, why didn't any of these kids ever say anything?
column2: My response was that there were probably multiple reasons:

column1: • A sense of powerlessness, as these were boys from predominantly broken homes while the adult in question was a widely respected member of the community with many accomplishments and in their minds, who would believe them?

• A sense, perhaps fostered by coming from a home in which there was minimal presence of a father, that they were unworthy of unconditional love and would have to somehow earn that love and attention from a man.
• Fear of what might happen to them if they did say anything.
• Shame that they somehow contributed to what occurred to them and that discovery might damage whatever love they already did receive, principally from their mothers.
These would lead to some of the points that can be covered as you talk with your kids.
<li>You'll certainly ask many questions if this kind of situation is brought forward, but asking for information doesn't mean automatic disbelief
column2: they simply mean that you're searching for more information in order to help you help them.

column1: • You love them simply because they're your children and that your love is unconditional, never depending on their actions or attitudes.
<li>Reassure them that if they do find themselves being threatened in such a situation, you can and will&nbsp
column2: protect them.&nbsp
column3: This is something that a strong&nbsp
column4: father can do&nbsp
column5: better&nbsp
column6: than most&nbsp
column7: mothers.

column2: While having a father present doesn't mean that your child won't be molested, the reality is that predators actively search for and target children from broken or strained families.&nbsp
column3: Children, whether very young or teens, want and need your love and support and if they perceive that it's not there, will seek it out and it's this search that can bring them into the sights of predators.

The past four decades have been an almost perfect storm for the adult male role model.
Divorce has wreaked havoc upon the American father as families were broken and in many cases, the father was significantly - if not altogether - removed.
column2: Simultaneously, two organizations that could provide alternative&nbsp
column3: solid male role models - the Boy Scouts and the Catholic Church - were beset by problems with pedophiles who preyed upon the now at-risk children.&nbsp
column4: Within the span of about two decades, the sense of trust that had previously permeated middle-class America was shattered as male positions that had been respected were viewed with derision and mistrust.

column1: In the ensuing years, litigation has been filed and settled and perpetrators have been locked away.
column2: The Scouts especially have taken child safety to heart and instituted criminal background checks of all volunteers with direct child/youth access, coupled with a serious effort to assure that the outrages of the 1960s and 1970s don't reoccur.&nbsp
column3: Although I'm not Catholic, my understanding is that there have been measures taken by the Church as well.&nbsp
column4: Despite efforts to both improve the recruitment and training&nbsp
column5: of volunteers, we now have the allegations about Jerry Sandusky to throw a dent into efforts.&nbsp
column6: Apart from the entire Penn State administrative debacle, there are concerns and allegations that Sandusky used the The Second Mile Foundation, founded to help at-risk youth, as a personal game preserve during his involvement there.
column7: The effect will be an even greater effort to prevent these situations from recurring and, perhaps, another big hit on the adult male role model as childless men who are willing to volunteer steer clear for fear of automatic suspicion.&nbsp
column8: If this occurs, then about the only group of men who aren't under&nbsp
column10: will be those of us with skin in the game, our kids.

column1: Children want and need men, and the positive models that they provide, in their lives.
column2: Likewise, the activities that benefit our kids don't run themselves and need our involvement to function and thrive.&nbsp

column1: So if you're thinking of becoming a volunteer, what are some points to consider?
<li><em>Does the organization have any requirements or guidelines on child safety?&nbsp
column2: Most established organizations, such as the Boy Scouts/Girl Scouts and Big Brothers/Sisters, have established criteria for volunteering and guidelines for interactions with the kids.
column3: While I personally dislike having to submit to a criminal background check, it's simply the cost of doing business in today's society and ultimately serves to help protect both me and the kids.&nbsp
column4: I'd frankly feel less inclined to volunteer with any group that didn't have a vetting process and safety guidelines for fear of setting myself at risk.

column1: <li><em>Are there other volunteers or are you carrying the load?&nbsp
column2: Apart from the sheer equity of having others pitch in, are you going to be the only person who's actually dealing with the kids?
column3: More than a few parents will dump their kids and run and if you're the only adult present, then you are at risk for any sort of allegations.&nbsp
column4: The true heart of a child-safety policy is the idea of &quot
column5: two-deep&quot
column6: leadership, meaning that there's simply another adult present, and I've been fortunate to have parents and co-leaders who've been willing to stay behind with me and other kids whose parents are late to pick them up.&nbsp
column7: I've actually cancelled meetings when the two-deep rule has fallen through.

column2: your speech?&nbsp
column3: I've been described as "
column4: earthy&quot
column5: in my speech and I've had to make a conscious effort to monitor and control it.&nbsp
column6: Like the language, I've had to learn to monitor the content.&nbsp
column7: If you tend to run at the mouth or aren't willing to exercise restraint, then you need to find another outlet.

column1: <li><em>Are you prepared to control your physical conduct and mannerisms?&nbsp
column2: Some men are naturally more affectionate than others or more physical in their displays of emotions.
column3: If you're affectionate with your kids, understand that you have to curtail yourself with other children and especially in today's environment.&nbsp
column4: It's fine to hug an upset child in the presence of other adults,&nbsp
column5: but you have to be conscious of physically displaying affection with other people's kids lest things be misconstrued.

column1: <li><em>Are you aware enough to sense when&nbsp
column2: a conversation or situation is about&nbsp
column3: to&nbsp
column4: go out of control?&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: Do you think that you can manage to handle it&nbsp
column7: if does?&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: Couple spontaneity with poor self-control you've got the makings of a decent trainwreck.
column10: Can you sense when things are about to go wrong and can you also sense when to bring it to the attention of the parents?&nbsp
column11: On more than one occasion, I've had to being situations under control and since it might involve a raised voice, I've&nbsp
column12: let the parents know what occurred and what was said.&nbsp
column13: It lets the parents know up front so that they can address things, and gets the facts out instead of the typically garbled walk-about story that kids and teens provide.&nbsp

column1: <li><em>Are you better with different age groups or different genders?&nbsp
column2: Not all age groups are created equal and you need to consider the age level of the kids within that group.
column3: Likewise, do you relate better to girls or to boys?&nbsp
column4: Except for coaching a sport, there are more opportunities for men to interact with boys and male teens than for girls.&nbsp
column5: The Girl Scouts have strict criteria for the interaction of men and girls and even if you do well with those criteria, will the other parents be comfortable with a male Girl Scout leader?&nbsp
column6: I was asked years ago to lead my daughter's troop and when I discussed it with some female acquaintances, their comment was that they'd be comfortable with me as their daughters' leader, but they'd be very wary of a man that they didn't know.&nbsp
column7: I declined to participate and found some involvement with my daughter via soccer and basketball.

column1: The need is there and even with the increasing attention, the rewards outweigh the cost.
column2: But before you decide to throw your hat into the ring, take some time to consider&nbsp
column3: these points&nbsp
column4: so that your decision is the best for you, the kids and the organizations.

Sage career advice to teens and young adults is to find a way to do what you love.
column2: But what if what they love won't allow them to support themselves, let alone a family?&nbsp
column3: What kind of conversation should the parents be having with the kids as they consider adult careers?

column1: There was once a time when the child's vocational choices were established by the parents.
column2: College was for the wealthy and consisted of classes in dead languages and Natural Philosophy, while those in the mercantile class sent their boys off to apprenticeships
column3: daughters were simply married off with the expectation of raising a family and the only hope for them was that the husband was a good provider.&nbsp
column4: If a child truly loved a particular interest, then they would pursue it as an avocation on their own time after they'd provided a roof and food for themselves.
column5: Avocations were chosen by the kids, but the vocations were selected by the parents.&nbsp

column1: The pendulum has swung back to the other side and many kids over the past several decades have gone into college for both satisfaction and career.
column2: That was fine in the old, more affordable, model but we've run into two major issues in the past ten or so years.&nbsp
column3: First, the cost is far too great to permit the vast majority to study for the sake of intellectual satisfaction since the career path for English Lit majors is exceptionally short and rocky.&nbsp
column4: Second, the hollowing out and zombification of our economy means that even kids coming out with career aspirations are finding that there are simply no positions available.&nbsp
column5: We now have baristas and convenience store clerks with Master degrees for lack of anything else.

column1: With a kid on the cusp of college and two more in the queue, the questions are how directive should I be and precisely what do I say?
column2: As full disclosure, I took my own father's strongly suggested advice
column3: that I earn a Business degree instead of Journalism for the sake of employability and decades later, I'm writing a website while raising kids and managing a household.&nbsp
column4: One of the lessons is that you can never know what's coming down the road.&nbsp
column5: It's a ticklish situation since these kids are passing to adulthood with little experience and a potential mortgage before they even hit the workforce, yet choosing the route of one's life is the hallmark of adulthood.&nbsp
column6: If we've raised them to stand on their own and be accountable for the decisions and consequences, then it's a blow to the ego to suddenly deprive them of their decision and that's especially given that many kids are coming through with the bills in their own names.&nbsp
column7: Here are some of the things that we've either discussed or tried to do in the past several years.

column1: <li>Talk openly about the non-dischargeable nature of college debt and the need to be able to select a route that at least gives the possibility of an income that covers the debt load.&nbsp
<li>Talk openly about the market for certain occupations and whether the average income allows the graduate to cover the nut.&nbsp
column2: When Eldest did an online career assessment survey through her school, I walked through some of the occupations that spit out in response to her questionaire answers and touched base on whether there's a bit market for such positions as casting director.

column1: <li>Talk openly about the college marketing circus so that they understand that they don't have to attend MIT, Caltech or Swarthmore to obtain a good education.&nbsp
<li>Spend some time looking at the incomes for that occupation and share it with the teen.&nbsp
column2: One of the kids, who has a talent and drive for the theatre, has already had the concept of income streams introduced and in a later conversation about music, stated that he was seriously working with his guitar so that he could have a fallback income stream when the theatre gigs were light.&nbsp
column3: *Ding*Ding*Ding!

column1: <li>Share the status of their college savings with them, if any.&nbsp
column2: Likewise, actually walk through what would be required for debt repayment so that they can compare that with the average income and work through a mock budget.&nbsp
column3: If they take on $X debt, what will they be giving up for the foreseeable future after graduation?

column1: The long and short is that it's going to be their decision and they're now - or will soon be - adults.
column2: But most of them aren't stupid and if you're willing to take the time to engage them, they'll listen.&nbsp
column3: At the minimum, there'll at least be a semblance of an educated decision and that's more information than they'll get anywhere else.

PracticalDad's 47 item retail grocery basket actually declined in cost when priced for February, from an average of $189.91 in January, 2012 to $187.14
column2: the index (November 2010 = 100) now sits at 104.90 and is down from January's 106.46.&nbsp
column3: The three month moving average is likewise down from it's January peak of 106.17 to 105.95.

column1: There are some comments that go along with this data.
<li>There is a bias in dealing with a small survey (47 items priced in three stores) in that issues with particular items within particular stores can skew the results.&nbsp
column2: In this case, two separate grocers have had outsized price increases in two separate items (one per each store) over the past several months and since January, these two items have dropped in cost.&nbsp
column3: The result is that there's a disproportionate change to the downside as well.&nbsp
column4: It's possible that these two items might be indicative of a larger issue within the grocery supply chain, but it's impossible to know.

column1: • Despite these two items, February is the first month since the November 2010 index inception in which there are more items dropping in price than increasing (12 decreases versus 10 increases).
<li>One of the items (spaghetti sauce) dropped in price as one grocer decreased both the item size&nbsp
column2: and the cost, even adjusting upwards back to the original size of 26 ounces.&nbsp
column3: This however, does give greater latitude with potential price increases for that item&nbsp
column4: moving forward.

Two of the better recent chickflicks of the past several years - Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants and Mamma Mia - occur in Greece.
column2: &nbsp
column3: After viewing the former with her girlfriends one evening several years ago, Eldest came into the kitchen and announced that she would love to go to Greece.&nbsp
column4: My wife, loving travel herself and envisioning the Holy Grail of family vacations, mentally went Boo-Yah! and plans were laid.
column5: The trip coincided with the summer of Eldest's upcoming senior year
column6: after college started, all bets would be off as to future availability for a trip with the entire family.&nbsp
column7: After more than two years of saving, we hit the road to Greece and Italy.

column1: The trip was instructive in a real world sense, as well.
column2: Along with the Acropolis and other historic sites, the kids got to experience (peaceful) political protests, riot-damaged buildings and the presence of riot police, armed with automatic weapons
column3: it wasn't what I envisioned originally, but hey, it's educational nonetheless.&nbsp
column4: Consequently, what happens in Greece has&nbsp
column5: a more-than-intellectual interest to our family.&nbsp
column6: As we've talked about it periodically, including today's conversation about the impact of any potential return to the Drachma, it's been important to keep the players and events straight.&nbsp
column7: So where do we stand at the moment?

column1: As of today, the Greek government is having to decide whether to accept the demands of the "
column2: Troika&quot
column3: for continued and additional austerity measures, including the abolition a paid national holiday and reduction in pensions to the tune of about 35%.&nbsp
column4: If they don't, then the Troika - the European Central Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the European Commission (the governing body of the European Union) - will refuse to release the 130 Billion Euros to the Greek government that it needs to survive.&nbsp
column5: And what happens if they don't get the money, among other things?&nbsp
column6: At stake is the next installment of 14.5 billion Euros that the Greeks owe on their outstanding debt
column7: they don't pay it - and without that money, they can't - and they're officially in default.&nbsp
column8: Let's have some perspective here since we're used to dealing in dollars.&nbsp
column9: As of 2010, the Greek GDP was about $304 Billion
column10: at the June 2010 exchange rate of .819 Euros to the Dollar, this means that the Greek GDP was about 249 Billion Euros.&nbsp
column11: This 130 Billion Euro payment that the Greeks need to survive amounts to 52% of their 2010 GDP and if this were occurring here in the US, a proportional amount that we'd need would be in the order of $7.3 Trillion (yes, that's trillion).

column2: First, their government is chronically incapable of collecting taxes since tax evasion is as big a national sport as soccer with a resulting chronic shortfall in revenue.&nbsp
column3: Second, the Greeks are unwilling to part with their social welfare/retirement benefits, which are amongst the most generous in the world.&nbsp
column4: This particularly galls the thrifty Germans, who have a retirement age about a decade later than the average Greek and who see their best and brightest go into Manufacturing, while the best and brightest of the Greeks become tax accountants.&nbsp
column5: Third, some Greeks believe that something is owed to them by the Germans, who've never actually apologized - <em>ummm, yeah, about that 1940 invasion and famine...sorry, ok?&nbsp
column6: Now pay up, you sheepherding deadbeats - let alone reimbursed them for all of the damage caused during the Second World War.
column7: Fourth - and probably the most important point - is that there's an amount of gamesmanship occurring.&nbsp
column8: The old saying is that if you owe the bank $100 and can't pay, you have a problem but if you owe them $1 Million and can't pay, then the bank has a problem and that's the issue here.&nbsp
column9: Greek bonds are held by European banks to a large extent and any default or significant &quot
column11: of the bond values will leave them insolvent and these banks are already suffering from too little capital.&nbsp
column12: Greeks believe that if they stall long enough, they can drive a hard enough bargain to minimize the damage that they know is going to occur.

column1: The final reason that the balk has become almost concrete is that the Germans - who as one of the few financially AAA rated countries in Europe - are the real backstop behind the European bailout.
column2: They've seen this continue for more than a year and are at the point that some of their Ministers are demanding that if the Greeks really want the money, then they'd have to give up control of their public budget and spending functions to non-Greek Europeans
column3: the Greeks would essentially be giving up their sovereignty.&nbsp
column4: Consider the backlash here if we were so in hock that the Chinese demanded control of our fiscal autonomy in return for funds.

column1: The situation is simply so impossible that if it were presented to Solomon, he'd sit down with a fifth of Jack Daniels and call it a night.
So if things are that screwed up, why are they worried about Greece?
column2: Again, it comes down to the banks.&nbsp
column3: The European banks are badly undercapitalized and any truly significant hit on their Greek bonds could be devastating to them, let alone to their ability to continue making sufficient loans to actually healthy businesses that need money.&nbsp
column4: These banks are tied up amongst one another in a web effect and the great fear is of a financial lock-up that would make the 2008 Lehman collapse look like a cakewalk.&nbsp
column5: The web effect even carries over to domestic American banks and there's fear of difficulty here, even if not to the extent of Europe.&nbsp
column6: And once Greece goes, next up is Portugal with its own issues and then Spain and finally, Italy.&nbsp

column1: The final point is that after actually being there, and talking to the merchants and history guides, the fishing captains and average folks - and yeah, even the riot police were pleasant - this is not simply an intellectual exercise.
column2: It's a devastating occurrence with real-world consequences that are tragic and instructive if you're willing to pay attention.&nbsp

Painful austerity and loss of sovereignty, or economic collapse and your nation?

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
530,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Regardless of what happens with Greece, whether they come to an agreement with the Troika or not, here are some things that I've taken away from watching it.
This is what society will look like when the bills finally come due and money that's needed goes instead to the lender.
There's only so much wealth circulating in a society and when critical mass is reached, that wealth will have to go to pay off the lender.
column2: Crucial services will be unmet and the social net will suffer as that wealth is diverted to repayment.&nbsp
column3: As it stands in Greece, pharmacists are having difficulty getting medications filled for people since the government ministry doesn't have the money to pay suppliers.&nbsp
column4: People on pensions are looking at cutbacks of more than a third.&nbsp
column5: Families with no income are beginning to consider giving children up for adoption or simply leaving them with the village churches. With almost one half of all Americans living in a household receiving some form of government aid, any cutbacks in domestic assistance are going to have outsize effects upon our families.

column1: Family will matter greatly, moreso than is the American case now.
One of the conversations that we had was with a driver who was taking us from Athens International to our hotel.
column2: About half of the Greek population lives in the vicinity of Athens, which grew tremendously in the past three decades.&nbsp
column3: What he's witnessing however, is that more and more are leaving Athens and returning to the villages in which their families reside.&nbsp
column4: There, they'll find support from their families and weather what's about to come with the hope that eventually, they'll be able to return to a semblance of prosperity afterwards.&nbsp
column5: The point is, they have family with which they can shelter the hardship
column6: the geographically extended and transient nature of the American family today makes that possibility dicier than would occur in a stationary, family-centric society like Greece.&nbsp
column7: If things really go to hell, do you have family upon whom you can fall back?&nbsp
column8: Likewise, how far does your own net extend?

column1: He who pays the piper, calls the tune.

Some members of the German government are openly stating that Greece's intransigence/incompetence/stalling requires that the European government take over the Greek government's budgeting and spending authority.
column2: This is frankly a financial coup d'etat and brings home the point that whoever controls the finances ultimately drives the process.
column3: In a recent post on Greece, I equated this threat to a situation in which we'd see the Chinese, who hold large amounts of our bonds, come in and demand control of our spending process in return for their capital.
column4: However, this wouldn't be a realistic alternative since the Chinese are neither the principal buyers nor holders of our bonds anymore
column5: last year, the Federal Reserve System of the United States
column6: became the top non-governmental holder of the federal public debt in the world, at $1.65 Trillion.&nbsp
column7: So a private banking entity - which is what the Federal Reserve actually is - is now the top holder of US debt with 46% more holdings than the second place Chinese and with the Chinese cutting back, it will only grow further.

column1: Understand first that the Federal Reserve System in not part of the Federal government, but instead is a private entity owned by the various member banks
column2: as part of the charter granted by the federal government in 1913, it is owned by the member banks but the leadership is confirmed by government, hence the periodic news that one person or another has been confirmed as Fed chairman by Congress after nomination by the President.&nbsp
column3: <em>Otherwise, it is a private entity.&nbsp
column4: That scenario worked for decades, but with the repeal of Glass-Steagal and the unregulated growth of derivatives, it's become apparent that the Federal Reserve now serves the interests of the banking system first and foremost.
column5: Now that you understand this, consider the banker/financier excesses of the past years and ask yourself if the holders of the debt are going to be willing to sacrifice for the common good or if they'll look to their own interests first.

column2: pays the piper, calls the&nbsp
column3: tune.&nbsp

column10: - Friends with a child who's a HS senior

column1: Senior year is supposed to be the piece de resistance for high school students.
column2: In January, the principal at Eldest's high school actually had a class meeting with the seniors to warn them that they still had obligations and shouldn't fall prey to senioritis.&nbsp
column3: For parents with kids facing higher education, there's a definite pressure as the post high school search ensues and plans have to be made for what happens afterwards.

column1: In our household, the pressure is off slightly as Eldest has finally come to a decision on college.
column2: There's no more questioning and waiting, tapping both literal and figurative toes as her internal gears grind to a conclusion.&nbsp
column3: But that relief lasted only a short time as the reality of the financing comes into play.&nbsp
column4: The captioned quote was made by a friend that I encountered as I passed through a coffee shop
column5: she and her husband were sitting and commiserating after finishing their taxes.&nbsp
column6: The next step for them, as for us, is the completion and submission of the dreaded FAFSA.&nbsp
column7: Even though I haven't looked at it yet - that occurs this weekend - the form's notoriety is such that it&nbsp
column8: inspires a palpable dread and desire for a stiff two-finger shot.&nbsp
column9: Once that's done, then comes the response from the college with the details of what's offered.&nbsp

column1: The institution's response to the financial data is also something that should be interesting.
column2: One of President Obama's higher education reform policies pertains to an effort to simplify and standardize the college financing letters
column3: as well as somehow establish a lid on college costs.&nbsp
column4: The rip on the institutions, particularly the for-profits such as Phoenix, is that their information is convoluted enough that the average student and parent finds it difficult to decipher accurately.&nbsp
column5: While I don't expect an issue from this particular college, the first gander should be an interesting one.

column1: So my friends and I will have similar days.
column2: We'll bedeck ourselves with ink-proof bibs and like a diner facing an elephantine dish, start eating it just one bite at a time.&nbsp
column3:
I guarantee that I'll have indigestion afterwards, too.
