column1:
532,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Although there are still younger ones in the house, Eldest is now officially in the last semester of her senior year in high school.
column2: In the moment of raising kids, it didn't seem as though it would end but in retrospect, it's gone quickly.&nbsp
column3: And it's now that I fully understand what other friends have said through the years:&nbsp
column4: <em>I think that he's gonna stay home tonight since he's leaving in only a few months.&nbsp
column5: The difference is an intellectual understanding versus the visceral comprehension that you feel in your gut.
column6: With the knowledge that your child wants to spend time with the friends but is still leaving the roost soon, how do you balance out the competing interests so that the kid gets to do what she wants while you still get to spend some meaningful time before that final departure?

column1: Most teens are at the height of egocentrism.
column2: While they can participate in all manner of group activities and volunteer heavily, their world still revolves around themselves and there's an understanding that when they leave high school, that world is going to change dramatically.&nbsp
column3: These bonds and friendships that have formed over the socially intense teen years will forever change as they go off to college, join the armed forces or - hopefully - get a job.&nbsp
column4: Couple that with their passion and sense of invulnerability&nbsp
column5: and the world's their oyster.&nbsp
column6: Until this passage into the birth of legal adulthood, they&nbsp
column7: will want to play.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column2: versus family time is a question with which we wrestle here.&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: Different parents will have different takes and levels of acceptance and my own varies as&nbsp
column5: well.&nbsp
column6: But when your&nbsp
column7: high school senior comes to ask whether she can spend&nbsp
column8: half of the day tomorrow with some buddies, what might you consider?

column1: <li>Are there actually any family activities planned?&nbsp
column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: She is still a member of the family and there are still others living within it, others who appreciate her presence at concerts, shows or games.&nbsp
column5: While she might look upon it as a journey into Dante's Purgatory, spending time can help remind her that there are others who still enjoy her presence.&nbsp
column6: Likewise, these can help reinforce that there are certain family values that are likely not going to be emulated amongst her peers.

column1: <li>What else is going on within the schedule?&nbsp
column2: Many teens are still getting a handle on time management and if they're not used to keeping a calendar, then they're liable to be missing something
column3: even if I don't know exactly what her schedule is, I can still ask her what's happening with things like school subjects, work, status of chores and tasks to prompt her memory.&nbsp

column1: <li>How often has she been around recently?&nbsp
column2: If she's not been to a family meal in a period of time, then it's reasonable to expect her presence to check in on things with her parents and siblings.&nbsp

column1: <li>If there are younger siblings, do they seem to miss her?&nbsp
<li>Likewise, what standards do you think are being set for the younger siblings as they age?&nbsp
column2: If they perceive that the elder sibling is constantly gone, they're going to expect the same treatment.&nbsp
column3: The problem with the younger one is that they'll expect it at a younger age since they don't have a great grasp on time.&nbsp
column4: Senior sibling is going to a local concert and not&nbsp
column5: home until 11 PM?&nbsp
column6: They'll remember the concert and curfew time, but they won't recall that she was a senior at that time.

column1: <li>Naturally, what are the details - who, what, when, where, how - and what's the track record?&nbsp
column2: She's still a minor and if something goes wrong, you'll get the phone call, so you can certainly put the kabosh on something even if it's going to be unpleasant in the household for awhile.

column1: <li>It's not selfish to say no if there's something that you'd like to do with her.&nbsp
column2: If she's simply going to be stuck in the house while you do whatever you do with no attention paid to her, then you might as well let her go.&nbsp
column3: But if there's something that you'd like to do, then you've got a right to&nbsp
column4: your time with her

column1: There are no simple answers and what one father finds acceptable might be another's anathema.
column2:
Parenting teens is sometimes an inexact science, but it's helpful to have a sense of what some of the considerations are when she's standing next to your chair with phone in hand and a question on her lips.

The Big Bang Theory is loaded with subplots as the characters grow and one of the funnier ones is Howard's developing relationship with Bernadette.
column2: Howard -&nbsp
column3: the only one of the four nerds without a doctorate -&nbsp
column4: has met, fallen in love with, and become engaged to Bernadette.&nbsp
column5: In the present story-line, she's now going to receive her own doctorate and is being lucratively headhunted by a major pharmaceutical firm.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: It reflects&nbsp
column8: the gender-bending of our&nbsp
column11: now able to earn more than men and men are considering their own role with the family
column12: some of the humor is also derived from the reactions and commentary of the peers to this development.&nbsp
column13: This is based upon reality as people do have to come to terms with the concept that the man is filling the role of the Missus - the one who stays home to keep things in order and run the household.

column2: stay-at-home-dad&quot
column3: - and I really dislike the term - I've had multiple encounters through the years with society's efforts to work through the gender-bending implications.

column1: • My wife is a physician and we've received mail addressed to Dr. and Mrs. with her name following.
<li>I've been introduced as the wife on more than one occasion, once in front of a group of more than 20 people.&nbsp
• When the kids were very small, playdates were sometimes a problem as many mothers were uncomfortable with the concept of having a father in a traditionally maternal domain.

<li>A medical spouse group - which existed to support one another and perform charity work for selected projects - invited me to join them with the hookline <em>if nothing else, you'll get to meet some very attractive middle aged women.&nbsp
column2: For the record, I didn't attend.

column1: • There have been multiple jokes in the distant past from other guys about knitting and crocheting, but the last one was about two years ago and even that last remark came from a man who worked as a nurse.

column2: of the family have&nbsp
column3: changed dramatically over the past several decades and for several reasons.&nbsp
column4: The first is because of the social change wrought by&nbsp
column5: women who were looking for greater opportunities and freedom than what had been offered to their mothers and the chance to define themselves as more than just a mother.&nbsp
column6: The second is the change in the institution of marriage
column7: the acceptability and ease of obtaining a divorce while more choose to live together outside of marriage.&nbsp
column8: The third is economic as families find that incomes aren't keeping up and traditionally male-dominated industries - construction and manufacturing - suffered disproportionately because of the most recent recession and globalization.&nbsp
column9: Instead of by choice, necessity is now forcing mothers to step up to the economic plate.

column1: But society's views haven't kept pace with the parental and family changes and it's this discrepancy that provides fodder for The Big Bang Theory.
column2: As men take a larger role in child-rearing and the family's life, the laughs will become harder to mine.
column3: Viewers will watch a particular scenario play out and find it less humorous because they can actually identify with something that's purportedly novel and question why it's supposedly funny enough to be filling airtime.&nbsp
column4: Reality is forcing us to adapt in ways that weren't considered by our grandparents and society's labels are slower to change to those adaptations.&nbsp
column5: I don't see that terms such as father, mother, husband and wife will ever change.
column6: But the truth is that as men take over greater household and family responsibilities, we'll render the Missus obsolete.

If there's anything that drives fear into the heart of a parent - apart from orthodontists - it's the dreaded FAFSA.
column2: This instrument, the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, garners the financial information used by colleges to ascertain the size and composition of financial aid packages for students that have applied to college.&nbsp
column3: Listen to enough parents and the sense you get is that it's an unpleasant, painful necessity, akin to having to complete the last inning of a baseball game when you're down by more than two dozen runs.&nbsp
column4: <em>C'mon guys, we can do it!&nbsp
column5: We can pull this one out!&nbsp
column6: We can...aw, to hell with it.&nbsp
column7: But is it the creature it's made out to be and what's it really like to complete it?

column1: The FAFSA has especially taken on greater meaning in the past two decades as college costs have spiraled upwards, disproportionate to the actual cost of living for everything else.
column2: We've been told that education is the key to the future&nbsp
column3: in a knowledge-based economy and the income data is clear that kids with college degrees earn more over a lifetime than those with just high school diplomas
column4: parents consequently want to assure that the kids get the education they need to survive, let alone succeed.&nbsp
column5: This instrument is the key tool used by colleges and universities to allocate the available funds amongst the mass of kids and families desiring that key to the future.

column1: <li>The form for each upcoming school year is available on January 1st of that year
column2: so the 2012 - 13 school year allocations are based upon the FAFSA instrument available on January 1, 2012.&nbsp
column3: Most institutions want the completed data by March 1, so there's a two month window in which to gather the data and complete the FAFSA.&nbsp
column4: Curiously, this two month window coincides with the peak drinking season of middle-aged men.

column1: <li>Much of the data collected pertains to demographic and family information.&nbsp
column2: How many other siblings are there and more importantly, are any of them in college?&nbsp
column3: Is the child in question an emancipated minor (did you kick his lazy butt out and have him legally declared an adult at age 11)?&nbsp

column1: <li>The actual financial data collected depends heavily upon the family income and non-retirement assets of the family, so you ideally need to have completed the federal taxes when you sit down with the FAFSA.&nbsp
column2: You can complete the instrument with estimates as to your adjusted gross income and colleges will make provisional decisions, but these are subject to revision when the 1040 is submitted.&nbsp
column3: Guess wrong in February and you're liable to receive an unpleasant surprise in May.&nbsp
column4: If you're like most and the bulk of your assets are tied up in retirement funds, then the financial information required is much less onerous than if you own rental properties and have payments from the installments of land sales.&nbsp
column5: Of course, if you have rental properties and payments from land sale installments, you might want to seriously consider bagging the entire process unless you enjoy a good laugh.

column1: <li>The form can be completed online and in our case, took less than an hour to complete.&nbsp
column2: Much of the effort on my part came from actually completing and submitting the returns earlier than I normally would.

column1: <li>The FAFSA now has an electronic download linkage with the IRS so that your relevant tax data can be simply downloaded from the IRS.&nbsp
column2: That said, there is about a two week IRS processing lag so if you're filing the FAFSA immediately after your taxes, just use a hard copy of the return for reference purposes.&nbsp
column3: The relevant questions will point you to exactly what lines on the forms are required for the actual answers, so it's not difficult.

column1: <li>The instrument is actually well laid out.&nbsp
column2: In some sections with a significant number of questions, the system only asks you one question at a time and after you've answered and clicked Next, will come up with the next question.
column3: That way,&nbsp
column4: it's assured that all of the questions are answered and you're assured that your mind isn't going to be blown by the number of questions (more than 80).

column1: <li>Because it's capturing data for a large mass of families, think of a Bell Curve.&nbsp
column2: While there are a lot of questions asked, the large majority of families are within about 80% of the curve and many of the questions are designed to capture information for those at the outlying ends of the curve.&nbsp
column3: Again, it took us less than an hour to complete the form.

column1: <li>The only paper document that we required was the recently completed tax return.&nbsp
column2: Otherwise, we handled it on two laptops as my wife did the form while I used mine to obtain asset values from the bank and 529 websites.

column1: <li>The completed instrument will only be submitted to those institutions that you specify.&nbsp
column2: While each has its own unique code identifier, there is a search function that allows you to search for, and load, the identifier instead of having to cuss your way through a stack of college correspondence.&nbsp

column1: <li>When completing the assets section, there is clarification for the various assets.&nbsp
column2: This is especially helpful if you have a 529 plan and have to allocate it as a student asset or a parental asset.&nbsp
column3: Parsing these definitions were the most complicated part of the entire process.

column1: • The response to the completed paperwork is called the Expected Family Contribution
column2: and ours was available shortly afterwards.&nbsp
column3: The EFC is not the final answer for what your child will receive, but it's a figure that's used by the college financial aid staff as they calculate what the kid's offered and what one offers might be very different from another.

column1: Let's start with the EFC since that provided the greatest laugh of the night.
column2: Multiple factors compose the EFC calculation, including the number of kids in the family, assets and income
column3: what struck me was, in a sense, comparability to sitting down with a mortgage broker to discuss what size loan you can afford.&nbsp
column4: In the&nbsp
column5: mortgage case, I've had brokers state that we can afford a certain amount while the reality is very different.&nbsp
column6: Likewise, our EFC - and no, I'm not going to share - was such that it would be theoretically affordable if we ignored everything except for the most basic of necessities and frankly, I'm not certain how we'd make it with that.&nbsp
column7: The EFC is a starting point, but not one necessarily grounded in reality.

column1: The instrument itself was straightforward and I've had greater issues
column2: preparing my state income taxes.&nbsp
column3: The site is well-designed and after finishing it, it was apparent that there's considerably greater&nbsp
column4: emotional overlay to the FAFSA than actual pain.&nbsp
column5: As we&nbsp
column6: parsed the questions and completed the form, what stayed with me was the question of whether we'd done enough through the years.&nbsp
column7: <em>Could we have saved more?&nbsp
column8: What if I'd invested this way instead of another?&nbsp
column9: How will we manage it when Middle and Youngest are up the plate?&nbsp
column10: And above all, the hard realization that Eldest really is going to be leaving for college in six months.
column11: Dear God, she's leaving...where did the time go?

column1: My father sometimes commented that things were generally much easier if your ducks were lined up in a row first.
column2: Take your time, line up your ducks and the FAFSA isn't going to be a major issue.&nbsp
column3: It's helpful though, to check your emotions at the door.

With only one cable-connected television in the house and not much interest, I generally let the choice of programming to others in the family.
column2: But my one gotta-see-this&nbsp
column3: show is Lifetime's Dance Moms, a "
column4: reality&quot
column5: show that sends up the thoroughly over-the-top behavior of hovering stage moms who've invested everything in helping their pre-teen daughters achieve their dreams of becoming dancers.&nbsp
column6: It's the latest installment in television's Women-Behaving-Badly programming genre and is yet another shot at mothers who've opted to stay out of the workforce.&nbsp
column7: However, it's insanely entertaining and in it's way, does raise questions about parental expectations, behaviors and how we should handle ourselves with kids and coaches.

column1: As a full disclosure, let me state that two of our three kids have been on stage and one is now starting to toy with the notion of the theatre as a career.
column2: We've taken kids to auditions and the one child has had two years of dance classes, so my wife and I have seen examples of parents with their ears to the closed audition doors.&nbsp
column3: When my wife took Middle to a theatre audition and saw the behavior of some of the parents there, she quietly told him that she'd stay in her seat and be cool and he thanked her.&nbsp
column4: There's no reason that our child's reaction is any different from any other child, who's typically embarrassed simply by the fact that their father is breathing so loudly.&nbsp

column1: Going to games and performances isn't being a stage-parent
column2: &nbsp

column1: A friend's daughter has a good role in the middle school play, which has only two performances in one weekend.
column2: She contacted me last week and asked - since she referred to me as an &quot
column3: experienced stage-dad&quot
column4: - whether we went to only one performance or more than one.&nbsp
column5: My thought was that she appeared to be concerned about being perceived as a stage-mother
column6: my response was that if was only two shows, see them both since she wasn't likely to see her in that role again.&nbsp
column7: Frankly, seeing your kid in a public event - game, concert, play, whatever - is something that parents should be doing and isn't even close to being a helicopter parent.

column1: There are excellent reasons to not go to something, such as work or competing kids' events.
column2: If the child is in a theatre production with several weeks of performances, even reduced-rate&nbsp
column3: tickets are cost-prohibitive.&nbsp
column4: But the great majority of kids want their parents and family there, so long as they behave and that&nbsp
column5: is the issue with the stage-parent.&nbsp
column6: Being a responsible, caring parent means that you should support the kid as she explores new interests
column7: it lets you see how she's developing and frankly, it's fun.

column1: Consider the level of the activity and the coach's qualifications
The great majority of kids will roll in and out of any number of different activities and with such a wide variety offered, the lion's share of the work will fall to volunteer parents.
column2: There are always coaches at the various levels who've never played the game and if these folks weren't interested, then the activities simply wouldn't happen.&nbsp
column3: They're managing things on the run with their own families and work and they simply don't deserve the crap that they're something dished.&nbsp
column4: If your kid is playing baseball at the 8 year old level, then you'd better be ready to step up and consider coaching yourself if you don't like the way that a coach is handling things.&nbsp

column1: That changes however, as the kids advance and really take to a particular activity.
column2: In the Lifetime show, the dance instructor is a professional who requires a contract from each family and is charging them thousands of dollars annually for the highest level of instruction.&nbsp
column3: It's at this point that the parent, as the employer of the independent contractor, does have some claim upon how things are being done.&nbsp
column4: This isn't the same thing as my hiring a guy to do some construction work
column5: he might have the expertise that I don't have, but he'll work solely for me and any issues that we have will be solely between us.&nbsp
column6: A coach of any kind is in a more difficult position since that person is not only responsible for one client, but multiple clients simultaneously and in the same venue.&nbsp
column7: The rancid icing at the top of this cake is that the parents who are paying for this level of attention and expertise are focused heavily on their own child's development and the potential for personality and interest clash is huge.&nbsp
column8: Potential scholarships, parental aspirations and dreams of the big time make for a potently combustible blend of ambition on the sidelines.&nbsp

column1: If you're at this level of investment, the reality is that you do have a vested interest in the outcome and some word in how things happen.
column2: You're hiring the coach for expertise and from that standpoint, you're best served by just shutting up and letting it happen.&nbsp
column3: But there are other factors in play as well&nbsp
column4: - personality,perceived or real favoritism and parental objectivity.&nbsp
column5: Some folks simply think that every scribble drawn by Junior is someday bound for Sothebys.&nbsp
column6: The issue then becomes how you manage potential conflict
column7: we embarrass our kids simply by breathing the same air as their peers and they'll&nbsp
column8: probably also possess some loyalty to that coach.&nbsp
column10: you were so damned smart, you'd be doing this instead of the coach.&nbsp

column1: One of the repeated behaviors seen on Dance Moms is the interruption of the practice by one or another mother who's torqued about something with her child.
column2: The mother enters the practice studio as cameras roll and proceeds to question something and the coach responds.&nbsp
column3: The kids are left there to stew in embarrassment and a burning desire to smack mom with a tire iron.&nbsp
column4: While this is reality television, which means that everything is played to the hilt, there are situations in which a parent interrupts a practice or event to publicly register their complaints with the coach
column5: when Youngest signs up for Little League baseball, we parents are obligated to sign an agreement outlining our behavior at practices and games.&nbsp
column6: Just to show that the parental behavior also flows in the other direction, to the child, our local pool decided to make all parents and guardians watch the swimming lessons from beyond the fences several years ago when a mother - angry at her recalcitrant daughter - walked over to the child and threw her bodily into the pool.&nbsp

column1: While we're protective of our kids, it's incumbent upon us to be even more in control of ourselves in these situations.
column2: The angry parent will not only offend the person who's taking on the obligation of working with his child, but will likely also offend other parents as well as embarrass the child in question.&nbsp
column3: Hold off until&nbsp
column4: afterwards and handle things privately&nbsp
column5: and if there's no progress with whatever situation, then decide if you need to elevate it to the next level, such as the local league or governing body.&nbsp
column6: If the coach is paid, as the dance instructor, then you simply have to decide if the child really is being served best there and if not, go elsewhere.&nbsp
column7: The last thing that you need is the reputation of a dance mom diva.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
>&nbsp
column3: Today was one of those days when a radio PSA actually had an impact as it spurred memories of hauling toddlers everywhere and having them constantly underfoot.
column4: The PSA in&nbsp
column5: question is for Born Learning, a public education/advocacy campaign sponsored by the Ad Council and the United Way which promotes the everyday, omnipresent opportunities to teach even the smallest children.
column6: The underlying message is that children, from infants onwards, are eminently capable of learning if we're willing to put it in front of them
column7: the presentation doesn't have to happen at a table with a book or in any formal setting.

column1: The aired PSA featured a father - guys, teaching about the world is at the heart of fatherhood - chatting with his toddler while driving.
column2: He points out a red car - VROOM VROOM! - and talks about color, the fact that the car can go and praises his son when he grasps the concepts.
column3: The underlying adult humor is the introduction of the blue police car which will soon give the red car's driver a pink ticket.&nbsp
column4: It drives the point home that our children are eager to be engaged and the opportunities to teach are literally endless, provided we put forward the thought to notice them and effort to pursue them.

column1: What are some of the things that you can do?
• When you carry your baby up the stairs, quietly count them as you go.
• When you pick something up, simply state what it is and perhaps sound out the first letter (A is for Apple).
• If you see a bright color, state what that color is and see if your child can repeat or sound out the word.
• An example from the website is having your child hand you a specified number of something when you request (Please hand me three eggs...)
Consider this if you don't think that what you do is really having an impact.
column2: The starter on my wife's car died this weekend and through the course of a teen-directed scenario, it was ultimately replaced by a 20 year-old friend of Eldest's.&nbsp
column3: As he dismantled the air intake and removed the air filter to even reach the starter, we chatted and I found that this young man had been under cars with his own father from the time that he was less than&nbsp
column4: two years old.&nbsp
column5: His story was confirmed by someone else there and while I don't recommend taking Junior the toddler under the chassis, it goes to the heart of the fatherhood experience.&nbsp
column6: Your job is to teach and along with the mundanities outlined, you can include your kids in your own favorite activities and use that to bring them along.

column1: Your infant's mind is akin to a blank canvas sitting in a studio.
column2: By pure dint of living, that canvas will be filled with all manner of media, figures and images.&nbsp
column3: Your job as a father is not to paint that canvas, but to help direct and guide the child as she fills the canvas, providing suitable imagery for the work - do you really want your kid channeling Chris Rock? - and helping to establish a context so that everything becomes coherent, enabling the child to gain a full appreciation for her world.
column4: The unfortunate reality is that if you aren't going to do it, there are plenty of others out there who will happily take on the project, but the materials won't be satisfactory and it won't be in the child's best interest.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
538,"1","1",,"xhtml","

A significant part of my job as a father is to help prepare my children for life in the great, wide world.
column2: It's challenging enough with the constant societal change and the impact of their peers, but how do I help raise them for the future if that future is fundamentally different from the past and present&nbsp
column3: with which I have experience?&nbsp
column4: This is the situation faced by millions of American parents who grew up in a world-class economic powerhouse and are now suddenly experiencing the tectonic shifts that are afflicting and winnowing the middle class.&nbsp

column1: This was noted in a Bloomberg article chronicling the economic stresses faced by Wall Streeters who've lost the significant bonuses that helped them maintain a certain lifestyle.
column2: The money quote is from Andrew Schiff, a fund spokesman who comments<em> I wouldn't want to whine.&nbsp
column3: All I want is the stuff that I always thought, growing up, that successful parents had.&nbsp
column4: Mr. Schiff is bringing home around $200k annually but to be fair, is stuck living in New York City, an exceptionally high cost of living area
column5: note that his 1200 square foot abode is about $1.5 Million and that's close to eight times the cost of something equivalent in my area.&nbsp
column6: Leaving aside the political and economic angst about fairness and the 1%, there are some points to be made here.

column1: The first point is the simple mismatch of expectations with economic reality.
column2: Thirty years ago, almost two-thirds of American workers could depend upon defined benefit pension plans to aid them in their retirement.&nbsp
column3: Less than one fifth of American workers can factor that into their planning today.&nbsp
column4: My late father was one who was assured of a pension&nbsp
column5: and my mother still receives a monthly pension check from his employer.&nbsp
column6: If you think that kids don't pay attention to what fathers say, I can recall mine telling me - when I was in my teens - that I probably wouldn't be assured of having a pension and once the 401k plans were introduced, I was certain that the old man was right again.&nbsp
column7: You can't teach your kids about the world if you aren't paying attention to what's happening around you and evaluating - and re-evaluating - it.&nbsp
column8: With college upcoming, we explained to our kids that the college options were limited by the absence of a pension and our need to help assure that we don't wind up living in their basement.

column1: The second point is the consumerist mentality of many Boomers and Gen-Xers.
column2: Starting in the post-World War 2 period, American Business - and Government - ramped up the consumer spending mantra as an offset to government and business investment spending
column3: it was to serve as an economic driver in lieu of those and clearly, that paid off as now our personal savings rate is minimal and everyone looks to the US consumer to carry the global economy.&nbsp
column4: That a teenager looked at the material&nbsp
column5: niceties of other parents thirty years ago and evaluated that as worthy isn't surprising - it's a testament to the effectiveness of advertising and manipulation.&nbsp
column6: But we're now at the logical endpoint of consumerism, in which we must now make conscious decisions about what's affordable under our income and what isn't because we no longer have the income to satisfy the desires ginned up by the advertising machine.

column1: This leads to the third point, which is to evaluate how the parents of our generation - those that Schiff watched - did in their own financial planning.
column2: Remember that thirty years ago, about two-thirds of American workers were set up in a pension plan and the understanding was that while it wouldn't be Easy Street, the basic income was covered.&nbsp
column3: Fast forward to today - actually 2008, for which data is available
column4: - and the following is known about our parents' financial health.

column1: • The non-pension median income from saved assets amounted to $1542 annually, or about $128.50 each month.
• Now only 40% of Americans over aged 65 have a pension plan.
• Fully 55% of older Americans rely on Social Security for more than half of their retirement income.
We - Schiff, all of us - watched the great and powerful Oz and didn't pay attention to the man behind the curtain as he pushed a consumerist mentality.
column2: What we saw was existing in an intellectual vacuum with no other information to provide an adequate context for understanding.

column1: This leads to the fourth point, that kids - mine included - like the niceties and can be budding little curmudgeons when they don't get what they want.
column2: But pay attention to kids who've seen their families wrecked financially and the wish is that they had their family life again, where there was less parental stress and discord caused by financial issues.&nbsp
column3: The kids want a home, not a house
column4: when push comes to shove.

column1: What stays with me more than anything else from Mr. Schiff's embarrassment - and the guy's become a poster-child for the Occupy Wall Street crowd - is that it's my responsibility to teach my children about the world.
column2: The schools will take care of the reading and math, with some help and buttkicking from my wife and I, but parents have to take the time to teach them about the world
column3:
if we don't, then those in the corporate world and media will and it won't be to the ultimate benefit of our children.

column1:
539,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Last night was a night in which the families gathered for the bi-weekly Sunday evening dinner, an event which has preceded the birth of a now-fourth grader and is seeing the eldest of the two broods' half-dozen kids interview for a graduate position in chemical engineering.
column2: As kids now move in and out with college and schedules, it's fascinating when the elder ones return because you can gauge how their thinking is changing.&nbsp
column3: The eldest, the soon-to-be college graduate, was in town and as happens with his presence, the conversation moved to national politics.&nbsp
column4: He's a conservative republican cut from the Alex Keaton mold (yeah, Google that one) but his politics have mellowed a bit as he's encountered more of the real world.

column1: We discussed the Republican field and it became clear that despite his preference, he was most interested in a Republican who was best able to beat the incumbent.
column2: My own opinion is framed by a sense that we've officially entered a new age of Robber Barons - yes, I plan to read Janet Tavakoli's <a title=""Amazon:  The New Robber Barons"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&amp
column3: field-keywords=janet+tavakoli+new+robber+barons"">The New Robber Barons
column4: after finishing Matthew Josephson's 1962 history, <a title=""Amazon:  The Robber Barons"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/The-Robber-Barons-Matthew-Josephson/dp/0156767902/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp
column5: ie=UTF8&amp
column7: sr=1-1#reader_0156767902"">The Robber Barons
column8: - as the MF Global mess has demonstrated how badly the rule of law has been damaged.&nbsp
column9: In this view, the best means of handling the situation and beginning to heal is to aggressively mete out perp walks to those found guilty of fraud and financial malfeasance.&nbsp
column10: The young man looked at me and while I stated that I would prefer&nbsp
column11: another of all of the present candidates, my own preference for a candidate was Andrew Jackson.&nbsp
column12: We're at the stage that the fraud and financial control has become so entwined with governance and the economy that remedying it will require significant pain, akin to undergoing&nbsp
column15: any leader willing to perform such a surgery is someone with a firm sense of right and wrong, the ability to understand the repercussions of not doing the surgery and the courage to withstand the coming firestorm of criticism.&nbsp
column16: I can't speak for any of the others, but I do know that Jackson did handle a similar situation in our history with the Second Bank of the United States.&nbsp
column17: At a minimum, it contributed to the Depression of 1837, which was itself called&nbsp
column18: the Great Depression by those prior to the 1929 event.&nbsp

column1: The Second Bank of the United States, a Federal period forebear of the Federal Reserve System, was chartered in 1816 to act as a bank for the nation
column2: &nbsp
column3: it's charter confirmed that it's role was to help maintain and regulate a strong currency so that the scattered individual state banking laws were strengthened and standardized.&nbsp
column4: It provided&nbsp
column5: credit to many state banks and held their deposits as well.&nbsp
column6: Like today's Federal Reserve System, it was an entirely private entity and was perfectly capable of turning a profit for its shareholders and directors.&nbsp
column7: Unlike today's Federal Reserve System however, the Second Bank of the United States was far more conservative in its management of the currency
column8: today's Fed governors would be akin to the frontier state bankers and politicians who favored the easier creation of money to fund the exploration, expansion and settling of the frontier.&nbsp
column9: The kicker to the bank's creation was an that it's charter was only for twenty years, a political feature designed to placate the original opponents
column10: at the end of twenty years, the charter would be renewed by Congress if it deemed the bank's performance successful.&nbsp
column11: The federal government itself provided much of the Second Bank's backing by making it the sole depository of all federal government funds, giving it&nbsp
column12: a huge leg up on everyone else.

column1: Fast forward to the early 1830s and a congressional committee found that the bank had
column2: fulfilled its function.&nbsp
column3: However, Jackson - a populist democrat - was bothered by commentary from the bank's directors as to how much power and pull that they truly exerted and felt that leaving such a function in the hands of a private entity was ultimately fatal to the public good.&nbsp
column4: He vowed to veto the charter's reapproval.&nbsp
column5: The final conflict came when the bank's chairman, Nicholas Biddle, decided to put the screws to Jackson for his stance and actually began to pull the credit that it had extended to a number of smaller banks.&nbsp
column6: Cut off from funds, these banks were unable to meet the demands of depositors and a series of bank runs - directly resulting from Biddle's actions - ensued.&nbsp
column7: An enraged Jackson, and it didn't take much to anger him in the first place, responded by pulling the government's deposits from the Second Bank, thus radically diminishing the bank's strength and ability to extend credit even when necessary.&nbsp
column8: The Second Bank lingered on for several more years before it finally went bankrupt.

column1: Present scholars still debate whether Jackson's actions actually caused the Panic and Depression of 1837 and some dismiss it as a sideshow, pointing to purely technical factors such as the collapsing price of cotton and/or the capital flow from London.
column2: Others ignore the technical side and focus solely on Jackson's act, placing the blame squarely on his shoulders and absolving Biddle's actions.&nbsp

column1: What I take from the episode and its relation to America's present structure is different however.
column2: Our society places great emphasis on specialization and the role of experts, believing that things are better run when the experts are in control.&nbsp
column3: Bloggers such as Yves Smith
column4: have well-documented how the economics profession has managed to repackage itself into a Whitman chocolate product, wrapping a soft science&nbsp
column5: center inside of a hard science shell and the result has been that many have simply begun to think of economic and monetary policy as being solely the province of the economic technocrats.&nbsp
column6: We've both forgotten and ignored the fact that the control of a currency is ultimately a political function as it fully impacts all members of the society.&nbsp
column7: Statistics can be used to quantify measurements, but it is ultimately impossible to quantify human behavior in both good and bad forms.

column1: As before, we've placed the control of our currency and banking into private
column2: fully private hands and it's now clear that the public interest is being sacrificed by these private interests.&nbsp
column3: The government retains regulatory functions, but these have been neutered by campaign purchase of the political system.&nbsp
column4: Eyes have been averted as unsupervised hedge funds have used high-capacity computers and advanced algorithms to turn the stock market into a literal casino as huge blocks of shares are traded based upon mere price points being reached.&nbsp
column5: The market's integrity has been affected as on multiple occasions, mechanistic&nbsp
column6: computerized trading has caused the buying pool for a particular company to simply evaporate, resulting in a &quot
column7: flash crash&quot
column8: in which the share price declines dramatically for no rational reason.&nbsp
column10: A private Federal Reserve System has, to keep a self-interested financial sector afloat, willingly punished savers by pursuing and maintaining artifically low interest rates and willingly pursues expansion of the money supply to devalue the currency so that we can continue to spend profligately and yet manage the massive public debt.&nbsp

column1: What does any of this have to do with fatherhood and the family?
column2: Wouldn't a Jacksonian response - bringing the monied interests to heel&nbsp
column3: and the Fed under government control - create economic devastation and destroy families as happened in 1837?&nbsp
column4: It certainly would, but it would also bring the monied interests back under public supervision so that such singularly self-interested policies were discontinued.&nbsp
column5: The reality is that this is already contributing to the destruction of families as the American Middle Class is whittled away and the opportunities for our children are eliminated.&nbsp
column6: At the end of the evening, I sat at an empty table and considered the future for our six children and then for all of the other kids that they know and without the rule of law embodied by our Constitution, their collective future is truly bleak, indeed.&nbsp
column7: Without that Constitutional rule of law, reclaimed by Jackson, what would have happened on the subsequent questions that we've addressed so well - slavery, women's suffrage, civil rights?&nbsp
column8: Where would we have stood when Hitler rose to power if we permitted a few private individuals to gain control of the levers of government in 1837?

column2: The question now is whether we are able to rouse ourselves and re-commit to our civic duties.&nbsp
column3:
If we cannot do and endure what's required, then our children will truly face what our forebears feared for their own children, the lack of a meaningful future.

I never let the facts get in the way of a good story.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column26: - Tom, a friend of the PracticalDad

column1: Just like Tom doesn't let a fact get into the way of a good story, so Rush Limbaugh didn't get the facts straight in the face of an opportunity to once again provoke a conservative/liberal spitting contest.
column2: The newest - and perhaps most costly - imbroglio arose when Limbaugh took a twenty-something female Georgetown University student to task when she appeared before Congress to press for government coverage of oral birth control, i.e. &quot
column3: the Pill&quot
column4: , for all women.&nbsp
column5: Limbaugh looked at her age and student status, pronounced her a slut and the fight ensued.&nbsp
column6: Despite the wildly poor choice of words, his defenders are stating that the woman was herself disingenuous.&nbsp
column7: The fact lost in the newest skirmish of the culture war is that oral contraceptives actually have benefits apart from the prevention of pregnancy and that it's not uncommon for its prescription to teenage girls because of these benefits.

column1: Guys truly don't understand the discomfort and pain that comes with a woman's period.
column2: We can nod our head in sympathy but we'll simply never get it.
column3: That said, something with which fathers should become familiar is the set of facts and processes of the menstual cycle even though the typical father&nbsp
column4: thinks about his daughter's reproductive health with the same relish that he considers next week's colonoscopy.&nbsp
column5: Females have dealt with their cycles and periods and your daughter will do the same as she grows and matures, and there are over-the-counter medicines available to assist with the discomfort and symptoms.&nbsp
column6: However, there are occasionally instances in which a woman's menstrual cycle operates outside the normal Bell Curve in terms of bleeding and period length and in these instances, an oral contraceptive is actually beneficial&nbsp
column7: in regulating the system.&nbsp
column8: In these cases, the medicine - which it is - is prescribed and the fact that the patient might be only fifteen years of age wouldn't necessarily be material if it helps control the situation and alleviate the symptoms.&nbsp
column9: A man might be philosophically opposed to the idea of a minor receiving an oral contraceptive but that opinion will probably change if he finds that his own child is suffering unnecessarily.

column1: Certain things will jar a father and I suspect that the prescription of an oral contraceptive is near the very top of that list.
column2: But what it means is that, even if Mom's around to ride herd on the process and help the daughter,&nbsp
column3: you need to be at least aware of&nbsp
column4: the daughter's reproductive health.&nbsp
column5: This doesn't mean that you walk in and start asking about her reproductive organs - Eldest once commented to me that it felt odd that her father could actually talk intelligently about menstruation - but it does mean that you pay attention if the topic is raised, either by your daughter or her mother.&nbsp
column6: If there's no mother around, then you simply have to swallow your discomfort and deal with it.&nbsp
column7: Anything that pertains to your child's health is important to understand, even if you and your mate opt to have a particular sphere of influence by dint of your gender.

column1: Should the government be responsible for covering oral contraceptives?
column2: At one glance, perhaps not since the most common usage is for something of convenience rather than necessity.&nbsp
column3: But what Limbaugh and the other pundits need to understand is that when you paint with a very large brush, you also slop over&nbsp
column4: the areas that have no place being painted in the first place.

column1: For reference on the uses and other
column2: benefits of oral contraception, go to eMedExpert.com.

Youngest entered the door from the garage and even around the corner, I could hear the shoes squishing with each step.
column2: Dad, he said, I'm really sorry but I just slipped into the creek when I was down there with the guys.
column3: My first impulse was annoyance that the kid had gotten his feet wet in the winter, even if it has been an almost Spring-like day.&nbsp
column4: But after listening to him describe his adventures, there was a greater sense of pleasure that the boy was having a Huck Finn experience with his buddies in the out-of-doors and the sneakers simply went into the dryer.&nbsp
column5: Many parents compare their kids childhood with their own and the sense - at least from other fathers with whom I've talked - is that there's far less unregulated and unsupervised play today than before.&nbsp
column6: If we want to encourage this return to some simpler pleasures for our kids, what are some things to bear in mind?

column1: In this age of media-driven angst over child safety, the first and obvious concern is safety.
column2: Every parent fears the prospect of a stranger abducting Junior since these cases make the top of each newscast, but the statistics - the most recent that I can find compiled in 2002
column3: - show that of approximately 800,000 missing children, 69,000 arise from abduction and of these cases, only about 12,000 were taken by someone not related to the child.&nbsp
column4: While the numbers in 2012 are certainly different, I expect that the general proportions remain the same with only a small percentage of abductions from strangers.&nbsp
column5: Having said that, safety is still the predominant concern.

column1: • I've reinforced to the kids that they're free to go to the creek, in a neighboring municipal park, only with another person and never alone.
<li>I've made it a point to visit the area myself so that I can see what the environment is like.&nbsp
column2: In this particular case, I visited the area - along with other local spots which might be of interest to kids - when we moved into the neighborhood several years ago and am already familiar with where he's playing.

column1: <li>Youngest has wanted to show me his &quot
column2: fort&quot
column3: and in the next several days, with decent weather, I'll take him up on his offer so that I can get another glance at the area in which he and his buddies are playing.

column1: • While this is a small creek, he's been told that he's not to be down there after rainstorms because of higher water levels.
• We've reviewed basic safety rules, such as might be found at Klaaskids.org.
• The clear expectation is that he'll only be there after clearing it with me first.
• While I don't believe that this merits a cell-phone, and others might disagree, it certainly means that he has to have a watch along with which to keep track of time.
We want our son to experience a wide variety of activities but he still needs the ability to simply play with friends.
column2: The time spent at the creek is invaluable to his growth and development
column3: he learns to interact with others in a free give-and-take that teaches&nbsp
column4: compromise and resolution and it allows him to exercise his imagination.&nbsp
column5:
Where else can he have a fort that boasts a second floor bedroom next to a laser battle station?

The March 2012 PracticalDad Price Index is complete and the results show that while there's been a slight rise from February's result of 104.90 to March's 105.26 (November 2010 = 100), this is still below the December 2011 peak of 106.49.
column2: In real terms, the cost of the 47 item marketbasket is now 5.26% higher than the index inception in November 2010.

column1: What's most notable about the March result is that the price of a pound of 80% lean ground meat has jumped by 10% to $4.14.
column2: Nothing else stands out except for peanut butter, which continues it's rise and is now actually rationed in certain stores.

column1: There's been an ongoing debate about whether the
column2: present economic environment is inflationary or deflationary, with the focus on the most commonly viewed aspect of prices.&nbsp
column3: The data thus far has shown that the market basket peaked in December, 2011 and the subsequent index readings would support a deflationary conclusion.&nbsp
column4: But given the most recent commentary about an uptick in prices, this didn't jibe with what I've seen.&nbsp
column5: Consequently, I&nbsp
column6: re-examined the data and re-calculated the indices - with the same data - at three month intervals but only for actual food items.&nbsp
column7: The market basket is 47 items, but these include non-food products such as diapers, bath soap and household/beauty products.&nbsp

column1: The upshot is that when the non-food items are stripped out of the basket, the food categories (bread, cereal, dairy, grocery, meat, produce and staples) are actually rising and at an increasingly higher rate than non-food categories.
column2: As money is continually injected into the system, it's making the way into the commodities and food arenas with a correspondingly greater effect.&nbsp

With the push for austerity continuing - despite persistently running a pesky trillion dollar budget deficit - the word is out that the government is acting to save several billion dollars by doubling the interest rate on subsidized Stafford loans.
column2: The Stafford loan is one that's used principally by lower and middle-income undergraduate students and the subsidized rate - where the government&nbsp
column3: covers the interest cost while the student is in school -&nbsp
column4: is slated to double from 3.4% to 6.8% starting in July 2012.&nbsp

column1: The public is increasingly aware of the issue of student debt, which has now supplanted both auto loans and credit card debt in magnitude.
column2: Couple this with the concept of doubling the interest rate and it's newsworthy.&nbsp
column3: Before I start my own rant, I thought that it would be good to determine what this means in a real-world situation, for an 18 year old freshman set to attend good ol' Wassamatta U.&nbsp
column4: The parameters of the subsidized Stafford loan are that it has a ten year repayment term with a present rate of 3.4%
column5: a student with dependent status can borrow up to $20,500 cumulatively over four years (Scenario 1)&nbsp
column6: and an independent student with no family support can borrow a total of $57,500 (Scenario 2).&nbsp
column7: Using the Bankrate.com student loan calculators
column8: with these parameters, the monthly repayments&nbsp

column1: The nominal figures, at least for the kid with dependent status, don't seem to make much of a difference but those of us reading this are years beyond college and not staring at these bills with a deer-in-a-headlight expression on our faces.
column2: There are several things that I take from this situation.

column1: First, while our public spending is clearly out-of-control, a move like this smacks of a public relations move to show the electorate that Congress is on the ball to cut wasteful spending.
column2: The problem however, is that this is simply piling on a group that is politically voiceless and powerless because of youth and a lack of experience.&nbsp
column3: The TBTF financial institutions are coddled and sheltered from the consequences of their actions and the middle-class still capable of getting a mortgage can obtain&nbsp
column4: one at a rate&nbsp
column5: less than 4%.&nbsp
column6: But these kids are going to have to accept a doubling of their interest rate.&nbsp
column7: Congress is simply trying to treat a hemorrhaging stump with a three inch gauze pad and medical tape.&nbsp
column8: We've pushed the concept of a knowledge-based economy for years yet when the kids are moving to prepare themselves, many with families that only have limited means to assist them, society and government are&nbsp
column9: stating that they're on their own.

column1: Second, how far out of touch are the members of Congress from the typical American family with a kid facing the issue of paying for college?
column2: The most recent data, as of 2010, shows that the average net worth of a member of Congress rose to $3.8 Million
column3: &nbsp
column4: this is an increase of 23% from 2008.&nbsp
column5: When your financial situation is such that your kids aren't going to face questions of paying for higher education and you live in a cloistered environment like the nation's capital, you aren't going to appreciate the real world, fly-over country consequences of your actions.

column1: Third, there's a further impact upon the economy.
column2: Experts state that one of the large drivers of the economy is the homebuilding industry and construction.&nbsp
column3: However, we have an inventory glut of millions of empty houses and anything that impedes the formation of new households to whittle down that glut is ultimately counterproductive.&nbsp
column4: With kids coming out of school with tens of thousands of dollars in non-dischargeable debt wrapped around their neck, they'll avoid any thought of forming a new household and the situation is only worsened.&nbsp
column5: Couple that with a higher young adult unemployment rate and lousy prospects and these guys are going to run for the family basement.

column1: While people should be responsible for their own - and their kids - education, the reality is that this nation has a long history of supporting education.
column2: The heritage of the land grant universities of the 19th century
column3: and the GI Bill of the 20th century demonstrate our&nbsp
column4: ancestors' recognition of the importance of education.&nbsp
column5:
This proposed action by Congress is simply an act as short-sighted as these previous Congressional actions were far-sighted.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column2: to purposefully embarrass a child in order to maintain control or apply discipline?

column1: For all of the talk about how wonderful children are - and yes, they are - there's another viewpoint and that's one not discussed unless you're sitting with a group of parents who are up to their elbows in raising and managing their children.
column2: These folks, who do the toting, waiting and cajoling, are hardnosed because they see the unpleasant mess that comes with raising kids and when several parents gather, the philosophies, techniques and tactics naturally arise in conversation.&nbsp
column3: It was in such a gathering that I sat waiting for Youngest and the conversation turned to the question of embarrassing the child in front of her peers.&nbsp

column1: One parent commented about a recent situation in which the child publicly misbehaved with a group of friends and was
column2: immediately chastised in&nbsp
column3: front of the peers for&nbsp
column4: a disciplinary two-fer.&nbsp
column5: Parental discipline was joined by peer embarrassment to lock down the&nbsp
column6: misbehavior.&nbsp
column7: I don't know the circumstances of the misbehavior,&nbsp
column8: but the correction&nbsp
column9: certainly met the criteria of handling discipline immediately
column10: and if the situation was serious in any way - such as bordering on illegality or physically dangerous - then that chastising in the moment would be entirely appropriate.&nbsp
column11: But it was in subsequent conversation that things became unclear.&nbsp
column12: Another parent commented that the presence of friends was immaterial to disciplining her kid and when others agreed, a third parent remarked that embarrassing the child publicly was a potent technique as the kid knew to stay in line when with peers.

column1: I appreciate that last comment about the effect of a kid's peers.
column2: When kids are in groups - and this becomes more problematic towards and during the teen years - the group dynamic can become combustible and raucously out-of-control.&nbsp
column3: Middle-school boys are sometimes only a hairs-width away from devolving into a Lord of the Flies scenario.
column4: With more parents either absent or failing to supervise their kids, the potential for misbehavior rises and anything that a frustrated or scared parent can do to put the brakes on errant behavior might seem to be fair play.&nbsp
column5: Both my wife and I have meted out discipline in the presence of friends but only because it had to be handled in the moment and frankly, that discipline extended to the friends as well.&nbsp
column6: If embarrassment arose, then it was purely a by-product of the situation.

column1: To purposefully inflict embarrassment seems to be ultimately counterproductive however.
column2: There's a point where parents, fathers especially, become an embarrassment by sheer dint of...simply being parents, and fathers especially.&nbsp
column3: <em>Oooohh, lookit that on his face.&nbsp
column4: He always has a few hairs that corkscrew out of his eyebrows like some demented cockroach on a meth bender.&nbsp
column5: Don't mind him, he always breathes that way...&nbsp
column6: Given the typically
column7: lowered&nbsp
column8: state of parent/child relations in the teen years, it doesn't make much sense to&nbsp
column9: further antagonise your kid and drive him further out of your sphere of influence.&nbsp
column11: if we're going to raise our children to make their way in the world, then we have to allow them to use the teen years to move into it gradually with support and supervision.&nbsp
column12: This means that we have to recognize and work through all of the various other spheres that will touch upon them during this time.&nbsp
column13: There are people in this world who will happily, like Lampwick from Pinocchio, lead them astray to their own ends and without concern for their well-being and if we purposefully create ill-will, then we create an even steeper slope upon which we must walk.

column1: As I considered the question for this article, I thought about how I've handled things with my own kids.
column2: When I've seen something that requires immediate correction - typically involving a safety issue - then I've dealt with it in the moment and the chips fell where they may.&nbsp
column3: But more often than not, I've taken the child to the side, such as the other night.&nbsp
column4: In that instance, another kid was there and I pulled mine aside to straighten things out without fuss.&nbsp
column5: However, I also stated that if I witnessed the behavior again, then I would put both of them on the carpet and the chips would fall where they may.&nbsp
column6: The saving grace with this child is that I've managed to be consistent enough through the years that a follow-through&nbsp
column7: was certain.&nbsp
column8: In this particular instance, the misbehavior ceased and I didn't have to follow-through.

column1: Embarrassment is a potent tool, lethal in it's effect upon a child.
column2: My choice would be to treat it as an unfortunate consequence of a necessary correction in the moment, but I wouldn't utilize it as a sledge to hammer the kid.&nbsp
column3: Staying connected with them through the formative 'tween and teen years is difficult enough.

545,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Tonight was an evening spent with Youngest at Disney's John Carter on Mars, one of the rare exceptions that I bent the rule on taking a child to a PG-13 movie before their 13th birthday.
column2: The action and special effects were excellent, but we spent some time sitting in the seats afterwards as I explained some of the background for the thousand year conflict in which the hero suddenly found himself.&nbsp
column3: When we left the theatre at 10:30 and entered the parking lot, I found myself, and Youngest, alone and being stopped by a panhandler with a sad tale of woe and in search of bus fare.&nbsp
column4: What to do?&nbsp
column5: What do you do in one of those distinctly unpleasant situations when you're with your child?

column1: As he approached, I stopped and he at least had the common sense to stop several feet away and not close any further.
column2: He immediately went into his story about being stranded and in need of bus fare to somehow make it home to another county, despite being more than three miles from our local bus station.&nbsp
column3: As he plunged onwards into the story, I stood between him and Youngest and simply told Youngest to immediately go back into the lobby to wait for me.&nbsp
column4: The boy, who recognized that something was wildly amiss, complied without question and I heard him walk back.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp

column1: The panhandler was probably in his early twenties, with a closely shorn head and a poor growth of beard upon his chin and cheeks.
column2: He was dressed in a loose camo jacket and a baseball cap worn askew on his head.&nbsp
column3: He had a sunken, haggard appearance and as the old expression goes, looked like he'd been ridden hard and put away wet.&nbsp
column4: My frank opinion was that he was a junkie looking for his next hit.&nbsp
column5: Before he could get further along, I simply pulled out my wallet and removed $6 with the comment that that was all that I could spare.&nbsp
column6: He took the money&nbsp
column7: and thanked me, then actually removed his own driver's license to show that he was legitimate
column8: I have no idea as to whether it was a real or fake ID and frankly couldn't have cared less at that moment.&nbsp
column9: He muttered about the embarrassment of his situation, then turned and walked off.&nbsp
column10: After seeing him move off into the next row of cars, I turned and returned to the theatre where Youngest was waiting for me in the lobby.

column1: I asked him if he understood what had just happened and he admitted that he wasn't clear, so I explained.
column2: We spoke briefly, then at further length in the car, about panhandling and the fact that many of these stories weren't true, but intended to elicit sympathy.&nbsp
column3: In the ideal world, we recognize it for what it is and decline, politely at first and more forcefully if necessary.&nbsp
column4: But in the ideal world, you aren't accompanied by a child and this guy was smart enough to understand that his success rate rose in the presence of a child.&nbsp

column1: When we got home, he did what kids do and immediately launched into the story to his mother.
column2: We talked about the situation and&nbsp
column3: I have to agree with her that my acquiescence in forking over a few bucks has reinforced his belief that panhandling parents is more profitable than other targets.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, she acknowledged that I had a good point in handling as I did.&nbsp
column5: Ultimately, Youngest stayed safe and the guy took off as soon as he got some cash.&nbsp
column6: I might even have handled it differently had Middle or Eldest been along instead of Youngest, provided that he'd even had the nerve to approach two or more full-sized people.

column1: There's a preferred way to handle unpleasant situations like panhandling, and giving over a few bucks isn't preferred.
column2: But having to contend with it while worried about your child's safety often means that the optimal case isn't practical in the moment.&nbsp
column3: Time and locale matter and the middle of a crowded city street is different than a darkened late evening parking lot.&nbsp
column4: The best that I could do - as I quickly considered it - was to simply move Youngest out as quickly as possible and avoid any reason for a potential conflict.&nbsp
column5: Yes, I'm frankly embarrassed but Youngest is now safely tucked into bed and tomorrow, when we're both fresh, we'll touch base about it again to learn what can be learned.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

546,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Part of fatherhood is living outside of your comfort zone, at least until you get the hang of whatever new thing that you're having to do.
column2: Changing diapers, learning to discern why your baby is crying, or&nbsp
column3: reading The Idiot's Guide to Soccer in order to coach a kimdergarten team
column4: are all examples of men doing things that they were simply never prepared for.&nbsp
column5: A major topic that takes men out of their comfort zone is having to teach &quot
column6: the birds and the bees&quot
column7: to their children
column8: while most things are easily managed once you get the hang of them, having &quot
column10: will almost always be nebulous and fraught with uncertainty.&nbsp
column11: It is, however, one of the most important things that a father needs to do and that's especially at a time when the media extols sexuality and fewer parents seem to monitor their kids.

column1: So what are some of the things to consider?

column2: the talk&quot
column3: implies that there's actually going to be a verbal communication between you and your child.&nbsp
column4: As much as I loved my own father, my version involved walking into my bedroom while in middle school and finding a small book about human reproduction lying on my bed with no words or comments ever actually spoken.&nbsp
column5: The result, being one of the 7th grade&nbsp
column6: walking dead, was that I put the booklet on the shelf and continued to get&nbsp
column7: misinformation from my buddies
column8: in today's world, that's the worst possible thing that could happen.&nbsp
column9: The fact that I got through unscathed is more of a testament to my own fear of screwing up, literally and figuratively.&nbsp
column10: Your kids want to know that you're there, that they can depend upon you, and that there's some stability and that only comes through ongoing efforts at communication.&nbsp

column2: the talk&quot
column3: isn't and shouldn't be a singular event.&nbsp
column4: There are different aspects including basic informational, aka the parts and the source of babies, then later the physical processes of puberty.&nbsp
column5: The basics of the body parts are&nbsp
column6: something that can be done as early as the toddler and preschool years and a great time to do so is while they're being bathed, naming the various parts as they're being washed and rinsed.&nbsp
column7: The keys are repetition and simplicity, using the same terminology again and again until the kids are able to use the language themselves.&nbsp
column8: Simplicity means that you focus on the basic, visible body parts such as the penis or the vulva/vagina (actually, the vagina is inside the female and the vulva on the outside).&nbsp
column9: Don't worry about what isn't visible because at those ages, out of sight truly is out of mind but also expect to have to go over it multiple times until they've got it pat.

column1: Since I was responsible for bathing the kids before my wife could make it home, one of
column2: the&nbsp
column3: earliest questions that I faced&nbsp
column4: with a young toddler was whether I should use the names for the anatomy - nipple, penis - or&nbsp
column5: cute nicknames instead.&nbsp
column6: My own parents used nicknames, but after considering it and chatting&nbsp
column7: with my wife, we decided to use the proper terminology.&nbsp
column8: There were several reasons for doing this:

column1: <li>Different parents might use different names and I clearly recall using the family nicknames in front of kids who laughed in my face
<li>I likewise recall hearing friends use their family's phrasing - or even the proper terms - and having no idea what they meant

<li>It sets the standard for the years to come that in some matters, particularly involving the body and sexuality, I was clearly the parent and not a buddy or someone who spoke on the same level as their peers
<li>Using nicknames might send the signal that there's something wrong or embarrassing with it, so you shouldn't use the proper name
• It simply felt right as using cute terms made me feel ridiculous.
This isn't about shame or something from the magical land of wonders.
column2: It's about body parts.

column1: This earliest phase is also a time to start working on the basics of child safety, particularly regarding who's allowed to touch their "
column2: private parts.&quot
column3: &nbsp
column4: The littlest ones should hear very simple and consistent instructions with the catchphrase, tell Daddy and Mommy right away.

column1: Explaining where babies come from is a very personal choice, but remember one thing:
column2: just because kids want to know something doesn't mean that they want or need the full details.&nbsp
column3: Bill Cosby's comment on children and information is spot on:&nbsp
column4: <em>Daddy, why is there air?&nbsp
column5: To blow up basketballs, honey.
column6: In our case, the kids knew at an early age that babies came from their mother but didn't bother with the how and
column7: why until much later and that was the cue to go into the larger questions of love and sex - commitment, love, marriage.
column8: These didn't have to be lengthy conversations and in fact, could be simple comments passed back and forth.&nbsp
column9: When Eldest was a preschooler, we'd chat at the table and she stated consistently that she'd have a baby and then get married
column10: my likewise consistent response was that marriage came before the baby and this dance continued until she further understood the idea of marriage.&nbsp

column1: Don't assume that the natural progression of the conversation is (1) body parts, (2) puberty/processes and (3) greater meaning of love and sex.
column2: The reality is that most kids have little interest in the inner workings of the human body and view it like a TV set:&nbsp
column3: I just wanna make sure that it works when I press the power button.
column4: Before they've reached that point of intellectual interest, they'll have many encounters with both the media and unmonitored kids who push a physical, consequence-free view of sex so it's important that you start your conversations with them early and often.&nbsp
column5: The point is to speak with them repeatedly and it can occur anywhere the opportunity presents itself, while riding in the car or under the driveway basketball pole.&nbsp

column1: There will come a point at which you do have to start talking to them about the changes that will start happening with puberty.
column2: Puberty isn't&nbsp
column3: a single event at which they're suddenly adults and as I recall it, it sure as hell isn't a&nbsp
column4: magical time, either.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: It's a years-long process&nbsp
column7: in which the body's&nbsp
column8: hormonal chemistry can change long before a hair sprouts on a face or a&nbsp
column9: breast grows and it's best that they have some clue of coming before they experience a physical event - wet dream or period&nbsp
column11: You can handle it like a seminar discussion with the child at the kitchen table for that specific&nbsp
column12: purpose or you can look for clues or comments that it would a good time&nbsp
column14: One son's comment that he couldn't sing as&nbsp
column16: a few months ago led to a conversation about&nbsp
column18: The point is to have the conversations and they need to be sooner than later.

column2: &quot
column3: the Talk&quot
column4: that fathers face is&nbsp
column5: whether, what and how much to discuss with daughters.&nbsp
column6: I'm fortunate in that&nbsp
column7: my&nbsp
column8: wife had discussions with my daughter and most men are in the same boat.&nbsp
column9: For those men who don't have the luxury of an&nbsp
column11: woman in his daughter's life, then it truly is imperative to determine how&nbsp
column12: you want to go about it.&nbsp
column13: There really is a gender divide here and it's phenomenally uncomfortable for a father to talk about&nbsp
column16: when I consider the prospect of having to have done that, the concept of having my tongue ripped out isn't so bad&nbsp
column17: and the daughters find it uncomfortable as well.&nbsp
column18: In these cases, you have three options:

column1: <li>Get your information straight and enter the conversation yourself
<li>Sit down with your daughter and a woman that both you and your daughter trusts, such as another family member,&nbsp
column2: school nurse or a teacher

column1: • Arrange for the girl to sit down separately with that trusted woman while you remove yourself from that part of the process.
The point is that this is a bridge that must be crossed because the repercussions of not crossing it are high.
column2: Even if you leave the female sexual health to the mother or another woman, there's no reason that you shouldn't be involved in every other aspect with your daughter.&nbsp

column1: The point of this article isn't to slam using a book or booklet to teach about puberty and the facts of life.
column2: The point is that this topic isn't a one-off event but repetitive over the course of years and that it can't be covered solely by giving your kid printed material.&nbsp
column3: The book is helpful in assuring that the information is correct and consistently presented and many parents hit the puberty aspect by reading such a book with their children.&nbsp
column4: But a book alone won't ease a child's fear that the experience of a new event is harmful or that they've done something wrong, nor will it present your values and place situations in the proper context.&nbsp
column5: It might even be especially helpful for you to read so that you don't goof and refer to a female reproductive organ as a Filipino Tube.

column1: If men are going to truly take an equal role in the raising of the kids, then they must reconcile themselves to the notion that they have as important a role as the mother in teaching about the body, reproduction and sex.
column2:
Now go shoot hoops with the third grader and see what conversation evolves.
