If you follow the news, you're going to hear that the jobs data shows a solid performance
column2: and that with the stock market at post-2008 highs, the economy has turned the corner and we're on the mend.&nbsp
column3: But you look around or listen to others and the sense is that what's reported doesn't jibe with the reports.&nbsp
column4: Can you trust the news or is there a discrepancy?&nbsp
column5: How do you check what CNBC and Fox Business are throwing out?&nbsp
column6: You have two options.&nbsp
column7: The first is to go to the source material for the news reports themselves and the second is to simply pay attention to the small indicators around you.

column1: There's an increasing distrust of the main-stream media, and that's especially if you get your economic news from cable sources such as Fox Business or CNBC.
column2: The beauty of the internet is such that you can review the sources for these stories and we'll take a gander at the US Bureau of Labor Statistics
column3: news release that provided the source for the HuffingtonPost.com article.&nbsp
column4: In the press release, the private payroll job rise actually came to 233,000 jobs instead of the 277,000 jobs overall that the HuffPo article referenced.&nbsp
column5: Of these 233,000:

column1: <li>45000 were in the temporary employment sector (19%)
<li>41000 were in the food service sector (18%)
More than a third of these job-finders are working for minimum wage/tips or no benefits while a full quarter of the job recipients are in a sector that's heavily dependent upon government spending.
column2: With the government spending a deficit greater than $1 T annually and attention sure to be paid to the Medicare/Medicaid budget segments - anybody notice the television commercials announcing the campaign against Medicare fraud - is there doubt that these programs will undergo significant reform in the future?&nbsp
column3: When this happens, the healthcare sector will be rocked and that sector will go flat at best.

column1: If you sense that people are continuing to cut back or feeling the pinch, this macro-level view helps explain why that's the case.
column2: The jobs are there, but they aren't the jobs that our grandparents, or even our parents, had and there's no advancement future in a temporary position.

column1: The other way to check out what's going on is to simply pay attention to what's going on around you.
column2: A look at the state of youth sport programs in my area is a clear indicator of our situation.&nbsp
column3: Eldest has played soccer since elementary school and has participated in the area's rec soccer league
column4: she's good enough that she'll actually play Division III women's soccer when she attends college in the fall.&nbsp
column5: Through all of that time, there have been teams at age levels from pre-K to U-19 and three years ago, the local rec league participation was strong enough that the U-19 (females between 15 and 19) level fielded three teams.&nbsp
column6: Two years ago, that division could field two teams of about 14 players apiece but with other activities and part-time jobs, there were games in which Eldest and her teammates played Ironman soccer, down a player for the entire game with no substitutions.&nbsp
column7: When Spring sign-up arrived again, I contacted the league and found that the U-19 division was defunct because there weren't enough to field even one team.&nbsp
column8: There's is cyclicality in any activity and I chalked the situation up to that.&nbsp
column9: In the meantime, Eldest asked to play for a nearby area's soccer club in order to keep her skills up and she signed up for that team instead.

column1: When no notice that any first practice was forthcoming, I spoke with that club's president - who was also going to be coaching Eldest's team as well - about the status.
column2: After getting the details, we chatted and I discovered that his club, which historically fielded three or four teams at that level, was now down to one team of 19 girls.&nbsp
column3: This is actually more than you want for one well-stocked team but there weren't enough for two teams and the decision was to turn no girl away.&nbsp
column4: Not only were these two clubs, that used to field five or six well-manned teams, down to only one team, but several of the 19 girls on the squad were like Eldest, soccer refugees from localities that could no longer field teams.&nbsp
column5: What was once an eight or nine team county league was now down to five and this couldn't be explained by the cyclicality of a single club's program.&nbsp
column6: It's possible that the decline is due to families opting not to pay for soccer for the older kid because of stretched incomes, but not definitive.&nbsp

column1: From my perspective, it wasn't definitive until I had a conversation this weekend with Youngest's baseball coach.
column2: As we watched the boys throw and do warm-ups in the pouring rain, we discussed players and he commented that there were more boys moved up to this level than in any previous year.&nbsp
column3: I mentally ran through the teams and there are as many teams in this level as in previous years, but why were they moving the boys up instead of leaving them at the lower level?&nbsp
column4: It's possible that the younger crop of boys simply has better skills than in previous seasons and that would account for the shift upwards.&nbsp
column5: But given the other conversation with the soccer club president, I suspect that it's something different and related to money.

column1: There's a natural winnowing process in sports, in which
column2: most children&nbsp
column3: get to try something new.&nbsp
column4: This is how the kids learn what they like or dislike and it helps teach some basic people skills apart from kicking a ball with the instep or loading up before you swing the bat and parents don't begrudge the opportunity for their kid to have that opportunity.&nbsp
column5: But kids develop preferences as they grow and this contributes to that process
column6: kids also understand more and aren't stupid to what's happening with their family.&nbsp
column7: I believe that the increasing stretch of the family budget is increasing the pinch and parents who, two decades before, might have permitted further exploration are now deciding that the kids are old enough to understand and cutting back accordingly.&nbsp
column8: This is exacerbated by gasoline prices at almost $4/gallon and the cost of driving to&nbsp
column9: playing fields all over Hell and half of Georgia.&nbsp
column10: Am I positive that this is the case or am I viewing everything through money-colored lenses?&nbsp
column11: It's impossible to say for certain, but I'll keep these two Main Street datapoints in the back of my mind as I continue to watch what's going on.&nbsp
column12: The point of the exercise is to see whether what's happening on Main Street jibes with what Wall Street - and by extension, the government - says and at what point they diverge.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
theme in&nbsp
column3: which a society, facing defeat, responds by using its youngsters - the seed corn - as a means of keeping itself alive.
column4: Whether it's the Germans in World War II or the Confederacy after 1864, the image is one of teens&nbsp
column5: and&nbsp
column6: children sent to the front line to stave off an inevitable defeat.&nbsp
column7: This is&nbsp
column8: recently brought to mind as separate sources&nbsp
column9: converged to illustrate that our present&nbsp
column12: profitable bubble model as it now&nbsp
column13: extends faux-friendly credit to the young and then feasts on them when they cannot repay.

column1: The first source was a brief Fitch Ratings release
column2: that discussed the safety of Asset-Backed Securities composed of student loans.&nbsp
column3: The size of the student loan pool is now greater than auto notes and credit cards and is in the vicinity of $1 Trillion and according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, approximately 27% of these loans - more than a quarter of a trillion dollars - are now more than 30 days past due.&nbsp
column4: Of this amount, more than $67 Billion in student loans are more than 270 days in arrears, which is a technical default.&nbsp
column5: Student loan backed ABS products are no different from their well-known cousin, the Mortgage Backed Securities products in that the cash flow stems from the cumulative payments of all of the borrowers as they repay their loans.&nbsp
column6: Like the MBS however, there was a glut of lax loans made and more are now in default.&nbsp
column7: The bulk of the poor lending was done by the for-profit institutions whose admissions and financial aid people directed prospective students into taking on excessive loans and several years later, with the education finished and insufficient income, the student borrowers are going into default.&nbsp
column8: The for-profit colleges, such as Phoenix, made money while the students are held to account. For the record, the graduation rate at the for-profits is 22%, less than half of that for public universities.

column1: Fitch's good news however, is that the ABS are relatively safe for two reasons.
column2: First, the products were structured in a better fashion with greater contractual protection.&nbsp
column3: Second, the Federal government is backing the loans in multiple ABS via the FFELP (Family Federal Education Loan Program), under which the large majority of the loans were written.&nbsp
column4: This is great for the owners of the ABS, which happen to be almost entirely corporations and financial institutions.&nbsp
column5: For the actual individuals in the picture - those who are carrying the defaulting loans - it isn't great as the Federal government expects to get the money back.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Corporations profit (for the win again!) as the US Department of Education is shelling out more than $1 billion in commissions
column8: to private contractors to collect on the deficient loans.&nbsp
column9: Naturally, these contractors are wholly-owned subsidiaries of such stalwarts as JPM and Sallie Mae.&nbsp
column10: One of the most glaring comments in the article was that a person in arrears on both taxes and student debt found the IRS to be more compassionate and willing to consider alternatives than the student debt collector
column11: the IRS handles its collections issues internally.

column1: The collections issue stems from the high-pressure methods and threats used on the individuals.
column2: Bloomberg personalizes its story by focusing on a person in default, a disabled man who is 52 years of age
column3: but the reality is that most of the students in default, of whom there are more than 5 million, are young adults.&nbsp
column4: These are not the life-experienced, uber-organized seniors but that group of adults with the least experience and cohesiveness
column5: these are the adults with the fewest self-sufficient job opportunities and yet will be hounded into their adult years.&nbsp
column6: Their lives will be dogged and their ability to form households, which is crucial to any true recovery in the housing/construction sector, will be crippled for years to come as their meager financial resources are stripped.

column1: People should be responsible for their debts.
column2: But there is a systemic aspect here as those who are least experienced and able to evaluate the alternatives are most pressed to take on debt to better themselves and prepare for their future.&nbsp
column3: When the debt is incurred and the kids&nbsp
column4: are into the world - without the opportunities available to previous generations - the pressure is on to honor the debt payments regardless of their circumstances and ability to pay.&nbsp
column5: The individuals will be hounded and threatened, while the entities which do the hounding are part of a group which increasingly ignores its own contractual obligations, dragging out payments, ignoring deadlines and gaming the system in any way to further their own fortunes at the expense of the whole.

column1: In permitting a system to enslave and wreck the lives of a large segment of our young, we're cutting off our own national future.
column2: We've allowed a system to develop that is cannibalizing society's future productive members, harnessing them to debts that will take years to satisfy and barring their ability to create their own households and families, the things that are crucial to the vitality of our country.&nbsp
column3: The combination of expensive higher education and harsh debt is certainly profitable in the moment.&nbsp
column4: But it's continuance will prove to be its own destruction as fewer are able to participate and the weight of the process will collapse.&nbsp
column5: If we permit the present system to eat our young now, there won't be enough productive members - or opportunities - to support a vibrant society and economy in the future.

With Eldest leaving for college inside of six months, the nascent-adult mail has started to flow and one of the pieces to her the other day was a credit card application from First Financial Bank USA.
column2: The bank is a credit card provider that specializes in credit for college students and touts itself as a leading quality provider of credit for new credit users.&nbsp
column3: Inside the envelope was a letter to the kids, a separate note to parents and a sticker sheet showing all of the options available to personalize the front of the student's new card and the obvious message is that it's a great time to get your first credit card so that you can learn to manage credit and build your infant credit history.

column1: But is it really a great time to do that?
What bothers me about the continued marketing of credit
column2: to our young people is that it's a recipe for life in an economy requiring a completely different mindset than before.&nbsp
column3: You need to understand something about the credit explosion of the past sixty years - it lubricated and accelerated the shift in our economy from an industrial spending base to a consumer spending base.&nbsp
column4: At the end of the Second World War, government and business leaders were at a crossroads and knew that signficant changes had to be made in the economic drivers.&nbsp
column5: From the Industrial Revolution until the Great Depression, economic growth had been predicated upon capital investment spending by business as the country grew and was developed.&nbsp
column6: That spending utterly collapsed in the Depression and despite the best efforts by FDR to get liquidity into the system via government spending, a traumatized American consumer literally threw the money into the mattress as protection for any further problems.&nbsp

column1: At the end of WWII, the public debt was stretched by payment for the war effort and the government wasn't seen as a viable alternative for economic growth and all eyes turned to the American Consumer to lead the way out.
column2: The birth of the modern credit card - Diner's Club - led to a realization that available consumer credit was a great way for the average American to lever his growing income into spending that could reshape the economy.&nbsp
column3: The fact that the US government allowed individuals to deduct their credit card interest from their income taxes until the mid 1980s was proof positive that consumer credit was a policy tool to push spending.&nbsp
column4: But we're now at the point at which families not only have to delever - pay off the debts - but learn to live within their means and relearn that they themselves are the ones responsible for their own retirement and future
column5: this is all within the framework of lessened income growth.

column1: I'll admit that the marketing to college students, the majority of whom now have their own credit cards, is better than it was. Prior to the passage of the CARD (Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure) Act of 2009, card issuers enticed students to their cards with such freebies as mugs, frisbees and t-shirts and the kids lapped it up
column2: it was only after they began to receive the bills that they realized what they were in for. Colleges that permit marketing to students on campus are obligated to certain requirements and the shiny bangles that captured the attention of the previous generation of students are now gone. The CARD Act of 2009 went some way to cleaning up certain wild-west aspects of the retail credit industry. On the offering side, it did end the superficial bangle show that captured the fancy of many young adults. On the billing side, it also mandated that bills sent to cardholders show such things as the length of time required to pay off the amount owed if only the minimum amount was paid. This particular aspect alone was eye-opening for new users as they realized that making only the monthly minimum was a long-term financial hemorrhage.

column1: One of the lines sold to the American consumer is that credit is simply another form of liquidity and that if you don't have the money now, just use the plastic and pay it off later.
column2: The problem is that the liquidity isn't yours but someone else's and that someone will demand repayment.&nbsp
column3: This is particularly hazy to the youngsters who haven't the experience to fully comprehend this and are generally flush with the new-found personal and financial freedom that comes with college.

column1: In the case of the offer to Eldest, the only thing that we had to do was show her the APR of 29% and she immediately blanched.
column2: It wasn't necessary to show her the misleading commentary nor take her to cardoffers.com, a website that offers side-by-side comparisons of the various cards available as well as cardholder comments critiquing their card.
column3: In the case of First Financial Bank USA, there were more than 130 comments and the majority were strongly negative.&nbsp
column4: When it finally becomes time for Eldest to consider a card, then we'll go to that site and parse through the card language to better understand the product.&nbsp
column5: For now however, she's best served going through at least part of college without a credit card.&nbsp
column6: She'll be forced to manage her cash and even learn to do without and if she's pressed, her mother and I are only a phone call away.&nbsp

You're pressed for time and the kid has a sports practice.
column2: That's at least an hour or more that you can use to run an errand or go home and clean up the kitchen, assuming that the practice is nearby.&nbsp
column3: Do you stay for the practice or do you leave the kid there and get the other stuff done?&nbsp
column4: What could go wrong?&nbsp
column5: That's the&nbsp
column6: question that I asked myself tonight and&nbsp
column7: about a minute before I was going to leave&nbsp
column8: to handle another&nbsp
column10: caught a pitched baseball in his windpipe, providing me with about five solid seconds of&nbsp
column11: pure terror as he struggled to regain his breath.&nbsp
column12: After a few minutes of gasping and gagging, he was able to return to the catcher's position and finished the practice there and&nbsp
column14: home, Mom the physician administered ibuprofen to control any swelling and had him on the sofa with ice on his throat for a full half-hour.

column1: We want our kids to try different things and find something that they love, something
column2: that helps them to thrive and grow.&nbsp
column3: If the activity is a sport, then we outfit them with the necessary gear and haul them to the practices and games
column4: we cheer for them or coach them, all the while understanding that a sport has some inherent risk of injury.&nbsp
column5: For many sports, it's likely to involve bruises from incidental contact or some muscle injury and that's simply a part of life.&nbsp
column6: Our household has witnessed balls to the face, significant bruising and more than one trip to the orthopedist for serious sprains and torn knee cartilage.&nbsp
column7: These however, are injuries that aren't potentially life-threatening and when the kids are older at least, can be handled by the coach.&nbsp
column8: My choice - backed by my history - is to stay for the practices whenever possible and I'll work the schedule accordingly to make it happen.&nbsp
column9: This night was one of the few that I figured would be okay to be gone.&nbsp
column10: So what have I considered and learned&nbsp

column1: <li>What's the level of play for the sport in question and how old are the kids?&nbsp
column2: At the rec league level, the coaches are all volunteers whose own kids are involved in the sport.&nbsp
column3: While coaches, they have a parent's perspective but are responsible for the entire group in addition to their own.&nbsp
column4: A child who's suffered an injury is usually different from a teenager since there's likely to be a strong emotional overlay caused by fear and that can fully engage an adult's attention.&nbsp
column5: Toss in a serious injury and the rest of the kids on the team are liable to require greater attention as well and you can say goodbye to any actual practice.&nbsp
column6: If you're at a scholastic level, then the kids are under the care of the school, which has protocols for injury.&nbsp
column7: At the scholastic level, the practices will be likely held at a time where you're still at work.&nbsp
column8: Additionally, the kids are old enough that there's sufficient maturity and experience to carry them through the initial situation without your presence.

column2: After two years of request, we permitted the grandparents to purchase catcher's equipment for Youngest and that equipment came in a single set.&nbsp
column3: I failed first in not knowing specifically what baseball catchers required for safety and secondly, in assuming that the set included everything necessary for the youngster.&nbsp
column4: At a certain level of play, boys do require a cup and athletic supporter but I didn't realize that there was a throat guard for baseball catchers.&nbsp

column1: <li>Do I actually have my cell phone in the event that I have to leave and something goes wrong?&nbsp
column2: If I have to leave one of my kids at a practice and in the care of the coach, it's my responsibility to at least be accessible.

column1: <li>Do my kids actually know any of the other parents there?&nbsp
column2: It'll be easier for the hurt child if at least there's another adult face that they know apart from the coach.

column1: Tonight's incident was a dodged bullet, and the bullet was a potential hollow-point for what might have happened.
column2: The throat guard's purchase will be an immediate fix, but I'll think even harder next time I'm in the position of having to decide whether to miss a practice.

Recent grocery trips continue to demonstrate how the purchasing power of the middle class is eaten away as prices remain constant while packaging changes.

My wife came home recently with a full grocery load and commented that she'd felt taken since the spaghetti that she'd bought on sale was actually now packaged in a 12 ounce box instead of the standard 16 ounce container.
column2: The grocer and producer ostensibly held the sale to camoflage the price increase
column3: most people don't take the time to record prices and wouldn't catch on that such a product change had been made.&nbsp
column4: The effect is that someone can look at something and swear that they'd paid less for it before, but couldn't certify that that was indeed the case.&nbsp

column1: A similar comment was made this week as brand name mayonnaise was purchased on sale with the subsequent realization that product came in a 30 ounce jar instead of the previous 32 ounce jar.
column2: The sense now is that when we see products sold at strong sale prices, there's a decent likelihood that the product will undergo a size decrease.&nbsp

column1: Another factor that impacts the price is the quality and availability of the component ingredients, such as the "
column2: pink slime&quot
column3: that's been added for years to ground meat.&nbsp
column4: With the recent controversy about the quality and safety of the meat byproduct, more grocers are announcing that they'll no longer be including the substance in their ground beef product.&nbsp
column5: The same week that Supervalu and Safeway announced that they'd no longer include the byproduct, two regional chains that service our area also announced that their ground beef wouldn't have the filler.&nbsp
column6: Note that these two chains are part of the three store price index that I've followed since November 2010.&nbsp
column7: A month prior to the announcement, in February 2012, these two stores showed significant increases in the price of their 80% lean ground beef and the local store didn't have the 80% lean for sale at all.&nbsp
column8: The new, higher price is still in effect - duh - but the local store still doesn't have the 80% lean on the shelf.&nbsp

column1: The upshot is that another of the factors is the value upon which we place the quality of our food.
column2:
If we truly want safe food, then there's going to be a premium that will have to be paid to ensure that the food is safe for consumption.

column1: Children are not little adults, but as
column2: they&nbsp
column3: become adults, they'll&nbsp
column4: find their own interests and tastes.&nbsp
column5: If my job is to support them - whether financially, logistically, emotionally and morally&nbsp
column6: - then that means that I'm going to become familiar with topics and activities with which I'm familiar.&nbsp
column7: We fathers will be forced outside of our comfort zones as fathers&nbsp
column8: who played baseball purchase The Idiot's Guide to Soccer and hunters become conversant with music and theatre.
column9: In my own case, Middle's sudden entry into the world of garage bands means that I'm so far out of my own zone that I need a compass and Sherpa guide to find my way back.&nbsp
column10: What are some things that I've had to learn in this situation?

column1: The first thing that I've had to realize is that a garage band involves not only the household, it involves the entire neighborhood.
column2: Even with the garage door down, amps and speakers are loud enough that the sound is only muted as it rolls down the street.&nbsp
column3: Even at the outset, when we imposed curfews on practice times to spare neighbors with small children, the comments were such that we moved the band into the basement.&nbsp
column4: I was surprised that the boys actually listened as the situation developed and while the location is less than perfect for them, they're just happy to have a regular place to practice.

column1: What can be done to minimize the damage to the ears of practicing in an enclosed area?
column2: Early rock-and-rollers are notoriously deaf and it's our desire to see that this doesn't happen here, so finding earplugs are a necessity
column3: stressing that they be worn&nbsp
column4: - which Middle hasn't opposed thankfully - is also incumbent.&nbsp
column5: Fortunately, I haven't had to threaten to interrupt practice to perform ear inspections to assure that they're being worn.

column2: Lyrics can be famously profane and it's been made clear from one infraction that cursing won't be allowed.&nbsp
column3: I'm fortunate in that their preference is punk and not &quot
column4: screamo&quot
column5: , in which case I couldn't tell the difference between the Catholic liturgy and a string of Howard Stern's rants
column6: to date, there's only been one instance of having to say something for inappropriate language.&nbsp

column1: How are the logistics being handled, especially in terms of moving equipment?
column2: None of these kids have licenses and if there are gigs - and there are two already lined up - then the odds are that one or more of the fathers are going to add roadie to our job responsibilities.&nbsp
column3: Even if the equipment isn't being moved, then how are kids getting home and are any of them staying for dinner?&nbsp
column4: Teens are notoriously horrendous planners and it's reached the point that if I know that there's going to be a practice, then I'm simply cooking for the&nbsp
column5: band as well as the family.&nbsp
column6: These are the days that work best for crockpot meals.

column2: plan&quot
column3: these sessions, are they on days when there's a certifiable adult in the household?&nbsp
column4: We've been adamant that either my wife or I be present and when Middle protested vigorously, quoting the teen battle cry of what could go wrong? I responded that with the presence of several teenage boys, I could return home to find a smoking crater where our house used to be.

column1: These are only the first of the lessons that will arise from this new endeavor.
column2: As one father commented to me last weekend, wait until they start bickering.

I wish somebody had told me I couldn't get a job with a degree in Western Civ.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column19: - Travis, American expatriate tour guide in Rome, 2011

column1: A recent article on poor employment prospects of young college graduates
column2: in USA Today demonstrates the miserable situation in which the kids are finding themselves.&nbsp
column3: Fully 53% of the college graduates under 25 are either unemployed or underemployed and there are now more job prospects for retail than engineering and with the majority of graduates laboring under some degree of student debt, people are finally realizing the systemic pox that has been placed upon their house.

column1: This isn't the first time that the prospects have been dim for college graduates.
column2: I graduated college in the early '80s and had a drawer full of rejection letters in a fruitless quest for employment
column3: my first real job - which permitted me the financial independence to set up my own household - didn't come along for more than another year.&nbsp
column4: But, apart from a starry dream to begin mining asteroids, does our economy have the potential to create sustainable job prospects for all of these youngsters?&nbsp
column5: With children growing and already aware that some form of higher education is important for their long-term prospects, what should I keep in mind?

column1: <li>First, that kids will receive all manner of commentary and advice from the surrounding media - usually with a pricetag attached - so it's important for me to keep talking.&nbsp
column2: The italicized comment was made to us by a young American expatriate working in Rome as a tour guide
column3: he'd graduated from a California university about four years ago with a BA degree in Western Civilization and was unemployed here in the states.&nbsp
column4: He showed considerable courage and creativity by taking his show on the road to what he termed the cradle of western civilization and was building a life for himself.&nbsp
column5: It's possible that his parents did tell him about the immediate employability of a Western Civ degree and he was too stubborn or zoned out to pay attention to it but I've seen multiple cases first hand in which the parents are saying nothing on the premise that the kid has reached adulthood and has to make his own decisions now.&nbsp
column6: The kid might now be an adult and responsible for her own decisions, but it's still imperative that I at least provide some commentary so that it's an informed decision and fully in her best interest.

column1: <li>Second, understand that what works for one child might not work for another.&nbsp
column2: Eldest's strengths lend themselves to the academic route and there's enough scholarship - with savings - to get her through without debt.&nbsp
column3: Middle has a radically different toolbox and isn't equipped for that route, so perhaps the advice&nbsp
column4: offered by&nbsp
column5: economist Richard Freeman, If you're not sure what you're going to be doing, it probably bodes well to take some job, if you can get one, and get a sense first of what you want from college.
column6: It's several more years until he's faced with the decision, but the route that he takes might not be the one taken by his sister.

column2: if there is&nbsp
column3: a need to&nbsp
column4: use&nbsp
column5: debt to&nbsp
column6: finance college, be sure that you're part of the process and walk through the payment obligations with&nbsp
column7: your kid.&nbsp
column8: As mindful of the&nbsp
column11: to remember that debt is as much of a tool as a hammer or a screwdriver.&nbsp
column12: One of the non-systemic issues is that with many people, they treat it as the only tool in the box so that they're hammering when they should be trying a screwdriver instead.&nbsp
column13: If it truly takes some debt, then at least walk through the repayment obligations so that there's an understanding of what the future bill is going to be.

column2: the lesson that the&nbsp
column3: present system isn't&nbsp
column4: truly built to service humanity but the other way around.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: <em>You&nbsp
column7: truly need an education and we'll help you get it!&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: Don't worry, your job prospects will increase and it won't be a problem&nbsp
column12: if you're sitting at the table and don't know who the sucker is, it's you.

column2: >&nbsp
column3: If this were a truly cyclical situation, then my response to Eldest would be to hunker down and it will work out in the end.
column4: But I believe, as do many others, that this isn't the typical job cycle and it's incumbent upon my wife and I to pay close attention to her college choices so that she doesn't wind up an expatriate in Rome or drilling for ores on some asteroid.<span id=""1335527942537E"" style=""display: none
column5: >&nbsp

554,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Childhood is a time of wonder, but that childhood doesn't have to be your own.
column2: Fathers also have a sense of wonderment as they look at their children.

column1: We wonder how many diapers we'll have to change before our precious is finally potty-trained (for the record, I've done
column2: rough calculations and I've legitimately changed more than 10000 of 'em).

column1: We wonder how our mates can be so involved in pre-baby planning items that leave us slackjawed and glassy-eyed.
We wonder how much stuff can fit in one small diaper.
We wonder how many times Junior can watch the same episode of Spongebob and still laugh.
We wonder how often we can seek out the source of a noise without having a minor stroke.
We wonder if there's truth to the old saying that God protects small children, drunks and the United States.
We wonder if we can again figure out, let alone explain, the math that's being presented to us for help by our children (I signed off on Eldest's homework when she hit 10th grade).

We wonder how much food one boy can possibly eat in the course of a day, and we marvel at how sparse is the refrigerator at our own elderly parents house (assuming that income isn't forcing them to choose between food and medicine).
We wonder about the source of these gifts that each child has (I was a lousy athlete and musician, unlike my own three).

We wonder, as we look at our babies, what they'll look like at different ages and as adults (if you have an infant, make yourself a promise to purposefully look again at their sixteenth and eighteenth birthdays).
We wonder, as we look at our children, on their sixteenth and eighteenth birthdays, where the time went.

column1:
555,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's been joked about on Big Bang Theory and parodied with ESPN style "
column2: World Championships&quot
column3: , but there's something still very cool about the classic kid's game of Rock, Paper, Scissors.
column4: In an often messy adult world where people can't settle their differences, it's a refreshing reminder that disputes can be resolved in a painless fashion.&nbsp
column5: Such was the lesson taught by Youngest's recent Science Fair project.

column1: Last week was Youngest's Science elementary school Science Fair and he and one of his buddies opted to do a project together, with the initial concept involving "
column2: something about momentum&quot
column3: .&nbsp
column4: Knowing Youngest's proclivities, I suspected that it didn't involve toy cars or tennis balls and after the two of them spoke with my wife - the Science Fair Queen - it narrowed down to examining the effect of drag upon a moving object.&nbsp
column5: The final project entailed a comparison of the average running time of a Razor scooter compared with the same scooter bearing a 2' x 4' plywood board tied to the front run on the same downhill course.&nbsp
column6: Since the experiment required that the rider be the same for all of the trials - and it involved wearing a motorcycle helmet - the final question came down to who would ride the scooter down the course.&nbsp
column7: As I sat at my desk eavesdropping on the conversation, an acceptable and useful habit, the boys decided to resolve the dispute with Rock, Paper, Scissors and when I simultaneously heard Youngest call out Crap! while his buddy cheered, I knew the question had been decided.
column8: The project came off well but what was refreshing was the willingness of the boys to abide by the game's outcome
column9: there was no rancor and no pissiness about unfairness and I can only wish that most of the adults in this world had the same attitude.

column1: The game has a place in our relationship, a practice that occurs while waiting for shopping females, a bus or simply killing time.
column2: I can still take the boy in most physical activities, but he's been consistently able through the years to beat me in prolonged game sessions and it was only this weekend, after a sixty round session that he explained his strategy for beating me and most others that he plays.&nbsp
column3: The key is that he's got a strategy while the rest of us - kids and adults alike - are simply throwing out hand gestures in the hope of winning a particular round.&nbsp
column4: His practice occurs when he loses a round and the opponent throws out the next gesture
column5: he expects that the person will throw the same gesture with the thought that if a gesture won before, it should hopefully win again.&nbsp
column6: He responds with the gesture that can best it and more often than not, he wins that round.&nbsp
column7: Sometimes, the person even tries that gesture again and he'll make a call on whether he thinks that his opponent would be the type to try that.&nbsp
column8: Over a game with multiple rounds, he'll statistically take the majority from the opponent.&nbsp
column9: After he explained himself, I simply sat and stared at this ten year-old and wondered at how his mind works.

column1: There's another point to be made however, and it goes beyond a seemingly mindless, pointless game.
column2: Take the time to engage the kids in these activities, while waiting at the mall or under a basketball hoop and you'll be surprised at what you might learn.&nbsp
column3: It might simply pertain to a new favorite flavor of ice cream but again, it might offer a potent insight into the child's life.&nbsp
column4: When I find that Youngest is starting to play the teen version - Rock, Paper, Scissors, Balls - then I'll know that he's arrived at the onset of male puberty.

column1:
556,"1","1",,"xhtml","

In the past, the mother has historically been the parent who looks inward to the family while the father has looked outwards.
column2: It's been Mom who's taken the lead in taking the household and turning it into what the family comes to call home, but that's changing as more fathers return home.&nbsp
column3: I frankly thought that I'd taken on pretty much everything that mothers have until several weeks ago when a project that required a number of family photos through the years raised it's head, and my only thought was oh crap.

column1: Multiple projects through the years - science fairs and scouts for example - have led me to craft stores and I've always walked past the scrapbooking section with a cursory glance.
column2: Yeah, my thinking went, that's just lovely but it's something that mebbe I'll worry about later.
column3: Unfortunately, there was a parental project for graduating high school seniors and the need for the photos made me realize that later is now.
column4: The result was a scramble through boxes of old photos and the wholesale reloading of camera cards onto my laptop in a search for meaningful and good photos of Eldest through the years.&nbsp
column5: As the project continued, it became apparent that we also had rolls of old 35 mm film in multiple drawers and while it was too late to use them - meaning that Eldest's 'tween years are missing from the project - the first of them were dispatched to a local camera store for developing.

column1: My wife originally had a plan for all of these photos and started more than 15 years ago to try to create a photographic history of the kids' lives with the intent of giving each a significant album when they reached adulthood.
column2: It was a wonderful thought and she kept at it for the first three years of Eldest's life but the arrival of Middle - let alone Youngest - to the family meant that the project was relegated to the various drawers throughout the basement.&nbsp
column3: To be honest, it was something that I found cute but not terribly important as the kids grew and activities took over but now I've come to realize that the albums truly do have significance for them.&nbsp
column4: Eldest knows about the project and was annoyed to find that I refused to show her
column5: other parents have commented that the projects that are being done for their own kids are among the highlights of that particular evening for them.&nbsp

column1: It's now apparent that I badly underestimated the value of the albums and memorykeepers.
column2: The kids want, especially as they move into the world, to have a sense of who they are and where they're from and making the effort to provide something can only be of benefit to them.&nbsp
column3: While I believe that men can do most of what women can in the home, I doubt that most of us have the female sense of taste and that's certainly true in my own situation.&nbsp
column4: However, I'll make what was once referred to as a rum go of it in the attempt to provide a scrapbook that isn't a (s)crapbook.

column1: One of the infuriating aspects of the US Government's CPI is that they use it for the basis for determining other things, such as benefit levels, while maintaining that food really isn't a core component.
column2: While this price index began in November 2010, I began in March 2012 to also calculate the index to show the activity of food prices within the marketbasket exclusive of non-food items (aluminum foil and Dial soap, for instance).

column1: The additional calculation revealed that when non-food items are stripped away, food prices are accelerating at a greater pace
column2: their activity is masked by the generally flat price activity of the non-food components.&nbsp
column3: Consequently, the February 2012 results showed that the cost of the original marketbasket had increased 4.9% (from 11/10's 100 to 2/12's 104.90) but the pricing of the food items alone had actually increased by 7.67% (from a food-only basis of 100 in 11/10 to a like basis of 107.67 in 2/12).&nbsp

column1: The results of the May 2012 pricing to three unrelated grocery stores shows that the overall index again increased to 106.49, which matches the previous high of 106.49 in December 2011
column2: this indicates that the actual cost of the 47 item marketbasket rose 6.49% in that 18 month period.&nbsp
column3: When food items alone are considered and evaluated on that basis, the food-only index comes in at 109.65 so that the prices of the food items alone have risen by 9.65% in that 18 month period.&nbsp

column1: <li>Stealth inflation struck again with a grocery chain now selling sugar in 4 pound bags instead of 5 pound bags.&nbsp
column2: As per procedure, I am recalculating the product to the original size to maintain consistency.&nbsp
column3: At some point, expect one or more of the other chains to do the same and the price of sugar to rise accordingly.

column1: <li>Of the 47 items in the marketbasket, 13 had price increases while 7 declined in price.&nbsp
column2: The largest increase was the price of a pound of roaster chicken, which rose 13.4% from April.

column1: Comparison of Regular and Food-only Indices at three month intervals

column1: My better half is out of town for several days and I'm keeping things together as usual.
column2: It's infinitely easier now than when the kids were little, but the question from the two older kids tonight was the same:&nbsp
column3: why are you so cranky tonight?

column1: A friend with older kids once commented that the pressure of raising kids is still there as they age, but it's different and she was correct.
column2: Young children will wear you out with the constant physical demands of feeding, changing, washing and everything else that goes with small ones
column3: even when there might be no physical demands, they want something akin to the fictitious mouse
column4: of Laura Numeroff's excellent children's story, <em>If You Give a Mouse a Cookie.&nbsp
column5: I should be grateful now because we had an operative curse in the household for years as anytime that my wife departed on a business trip, one or more of the kids fell ill.
column6: After it happened twice, I palpably dreaded these trips because they could be - and were - met by episodes of pneumonia, bilateral ear infections and intestinal viruses.&nbsp
column7: Some people have animals that can portend a departure by seeing an open suitcase on a bed, but we had latent viruses that perked up when the luggage came up from the basement.

column1: I'm now past the point of changing blown out diapers and having to spoon-feed the kids but in a sense, they're still intensely demanding with their short attention spans and raging egocentrism.
column2: If they want something to drink, they can get it but there's no guarantee that the glassware will make it back to the kitchen.&nbsp
column3: Towels will be used and dropped where they are and if a teen doesn't like the answer to his question, the ensuing conversation can become rancorous and potentially end in a raging indictment of my personal sense of honor, fairness and a general&nbsp
column4: condemnation of the useless values engendered by western civilization.&nbsp
column5: Where one indicts openly, another can respond with sullen silence and pointed use of the dreaded death glare, hoping, like Big Bang Theory's Sheldon Cooper, to telepathically instigate a minor stroke for nixing plans with the peers.
column6: When there are children of different genders, school levels and personalities, the increased stress is more exponential than arithmetic as you bounce along from one pin to another.

column1: Despite it all, I should be grateful because the Eldest leaves in the Fall for college and when she's out, her presence - and death glare - will be sorely missed.
column2: Perhaps it will be hardest on my wife however, as she'll be left to swim in a pool of 'tween-age and teen-age testosterone.&nbsp
column3:
In the moment however, the gratitude will have to wait until each is abed and quiet, adult rationality returns to the household.

column2: Colorado Springs&nbsp
column3: regarding a white second grader who&nbsp
column4: appeared at his school history day&nbsp
column5: as Martin Luther King, Jr while wearing black face paint to appear as an African-American.
column6: The child was participating in a history presentation in which students dressed up as various historical figures for a &quot
column7: wax museum&quot
column8: display and when he came to school, the teacher and administrator were surprised to discover that he was wearing black make-up to cover his face
column9: they asked his parents to remove it and when they refused to do so, they took him home.&nbsp
column10: It is unclear who contacted the media and the slant of the story appears to be that this is once again political correctness run amok as a poor second grader is punished for attempting to do a realistic display on an individual.

column1: Let's start with the premise of the history project, since Youngest's entire grade was involved in a similar extravaganza this past week.
column2: The premise is that each student chooses an historic figure to study and in Youngest's grade, make a short presentation about that individual in the first person.&nbsp
column3: Each student must research the life of that figure, write a three paragraph report in the first person - I was the indian maiden who led Lewis and Clark... - and then pull together a costume for the presentation.
column4: Each student has two minutes to present themselves to the listener, and the wax museum approach means that the student adopts a frozen stance that's meaningful to that personage.&nbsp
column5: Starting from the pose, the student then presents the report to the various listeners, who then move on to the next student at the end of the two minutes.&nbsp
column6: In Youngest's history session, entitled Blast From the Past, each student is at a station in the school's multipurpose room and at the end of the two minutes, a bell rings and the listener moves on to the next student
column7: the idea is to mimic what you'd find in Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum.&nbsp

column1: I can appreciate what the child was attempting to do since baseball-loving Youngest opted to report on Jackie Robinson, the first African-American to break into the major league after the end of the Second World War.
column2: His research was decent and he asked if we could somehow get a retro Brooklyn Dodgers uniform and we sprang for a jersey with Robinson's number and name on the back.&nbsp
column3: About three weeks prior to the event, Youngest also asked if I would help him put black shoe polish on his face so that he could truly get into character.&nbsp
column4: I asked him if his teacher approved of this and he assured me that she would be and when I subsequently saw her, she agreed that the presentation would be better with just the uniform and report and the makeup plan was consigned to the trash.&nbsp
column5: We talked about the rationale for not using the makeup and it was here that he learned of stereotypes and old-time minstrel shows.&nbsp
column6: Curiously, the three African-American boys in his class all opted for non-black figures such as Davy Crockett, Abraham Lincoln and Wayne Gretzky.&nbsp
column7: For this presentation, Jackie Robinson was white and Wayne Gretzky was black.

column1: What I find curious and irritating about the story is the question of who sent the story to the media.
column2: According to another <a title=""Associated Press"" href=""http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_MLK_COSTUME_DISPUTE?SITE=AP&amp
column3: SECTION=HOME&amp
column4: TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&amp
column5: CTIME=2012-05-18-14-22-11"">AP article, the school wasn't aware before the child showed up that he'd be in the makeup and they asked the child and parents to remove the makeup before the event started.
column6: When the family refused, they - the parents - subsequently removed their son from the event
column7: this action was a parental action, not a school action.&nbsp
column8: Had I been the teacher&nbsp
column9: or principal, I would have also asked the parents to remove&nbsp
column11: The schools are public institutions charged with serving&nbsp
column12: all members of an increasingly diverse society and there has to be&nbsp
column14: permitting black face makeup would be akin to serving&nbsp
column16: at a school function celebrating children with Muslim&nbsp
column18: While Political Correctness has been carried to unacceptable extremes, the school officials do have to exercise common sense and this situation is one of simple common sense and not political correctness.&nbsp

column1: A reporter also contacted Steve Klein of the King Center in Atlanta for his comments and Mr. Klein was frankly correct in his assessment that there was no intent on the boy's part.
column2: The child was asked to portray a person of historic significance and Dr. King's race was central to his significance, as was Jackie Robinson's.&nbsp
column3: Frankly, the kid wanted to do the best job possible and if Dr. King was black, then he thought that he should be as well.

column1: Ultimately, my criticism unfortunately lies with the parents here.
column2: They probably didn't consider the minstrel show stereotype given our sorry understanding of our own history and to bring the kid to school in that makeup can be chalked up as <em>oops, I didn't know that...&nbsp
column3: But with current controversies about the shooting of Trayvon Martin or whether some local police departments are understating the issue of black youth gangs, to allow your child to appear on television in black-face makeup is placing him in a charged and critical limelight.
column4: Our job as parents is to raise the kids and if there's going to be media coverage about them, it should be in a positive light
column5: allowing them to become poster children in an ongoing controversy about political correctness - or any other divisive issue - is akin to putting a figurative target on their back.&nbsp
column6: Several years ago, the comic-actor John C. McGinley appeared on Glenn Beck's radio program and politely called Beck on the carpet for using the term retard on his show.
column7: McGinley apparently has a child with Down's Syndrome and simply, and eloquently, stated that using the terminology was piling on, picking a fight with someone who was incapable of fighting back.&nbsp
column8: This boy's parents have unfortunately allowed him to be placed in a situation in which he's liable to be forced to contend with a situation for which he's unprepared.&nbsp
column9: There are true believers with agendas for whom their agenda is all that matters and the person in the way of that agenda is simply fodder for the media cannon.

The common question is, do you write the site or does the site write you?
In other words, how much pressure is there to constantly put out material?

My writing has slowed a bit in the past two months and this diminished output will continue for a short while longer as we grapple with the changes that come with multiple children and new phases of life.
column2: Please bear with me for a bit longer and while the articles continue, the pace will pick up in a bit.

column1:
Thank you reading PracticalDad and putting me on your RSS feed... It's greatly appreciated.

561,"1","1",,"xhtml","

My wife and I were discussing the ongoing yardwork issue last week when the topic turned to whether Youngest is now old enough to pitch in on mowing the grass.
column2: He's huge for his age - he was born in the midst of a growth spurt that hasn't quit - and he has uncommonly common sense for a kid of his age.&nbsp
column3: The problem however, is that he's still in elementary school and there's another two years before he's into middle school, so the question was whether he was ready to handle a power mower.

column1: No two kids are the same and while one might be ready for a certain responsibility, it's not a given that the sibling will be ready at the same age.
column2: It might be a function of physical capability but more often than not, it's an issue of judgment and sense of responsibility.

column1: When we talked about the matter, we had to think about when our older kids actually began to cut the grass.
column2: What I've come to realize is that if you don't keep explicit notes, kids are akin to old appliances in that you lose track of time.&nbsp
column3: <em>Lessee here...we bought that refrigerator about five years ago, no?&nbsp
column4: Wait, we got it right after Grandma moved in with us and she actually died about 15 years ago.&nbsp
column5: Yep, it might be time to replace it instead of repairing it again. &nbsp
column6: Eldest actually was older when she began to mow the yard but that was a function of having a riding mower with a larger yard.
column7: She began to use the riding mower the summer before Middle School and then, she only did the yard when I was actually doing other outside chores and able to keep an eye on her handling of the machine.&nbsp
column8: We subsequently moved to a house with a much smaller yard - but God, the landscaping makes this one far more difficult - and I replaced the riding mower with a simple self-propelled lawnmower.&nbsp
column9: Middle was by now in late elementary school when I broke him into the process and like with his older sister, I spent time outside watching until I was comfortable that he could handle the mower, especially on slopes.&nbsp

column1: My own professional background is in claims adjusting and risk management and I thought that I'd seen enough to assess risk better than most.
column2: But it was still Middle's experience that taught me that there's more than just a moving blade on a mower to injure someone.&nbsp
column3: We'd been through the discussions and oversight and Middle had learned about the dead man's handle, removing the spark plug cap and how to mow on slopes
column4: I'd cleared him and he was happily mowing the yard on his own recognizance.&nbsp
column5: <em>By the way, happiness is a short-term phenomenon and wears off with repeated exposure.&nbsp
column6: While I was in the garage one afternoon, I heard a scream and seconds later, Middle ran into grasping his wrist
column7: he'd turned off the mower and to check something, grabbed hold of the hot engine block.&nbsp
column8: There was a significant second degree burn on the palm and it reminded me of the Gestapo agent in Raiders of the Lost Ark because the grille of the engine block was imprinted on his skin like the hot amulet had been imprinted on the Gestapo agent's hand.
column9: The point is that even if you think that you've covered all of the bases, there's probably something that's going to bite because you simply assume that the kid knows what you know after years of experience, and they simply don't.&nbsp

column1: We're still undecided on whether Youngest is ready and have agreed to disagree on the use of the power mower.
column2: From a practical standpoint, this means that Youngest won't be cutting the grass yet since the repercussions to our own relationship would be dire if I permitted it and he suffered a serious injury.&nbsp
column3: Parents can differ and one can acquiesce to another's judgment on small things, but the prospect of losing a hand or foot moves the situation to a different level and it's simply worth it to wait for the day that we both agree on the readiness.

column1: Middle's painful experience has managed to work out in a weird way for him.
column2: The scar to the palm is minimal but a sufficient number of nerve endings were damaged that he's turned it into a talking point amongst his buddies as he'll occasionally put the hand over a lit candle or lighter to prove his toughness to the guys
column3: and no, I don't approve and have warned him against it repeatedly.&nbsp

column1: Like I said, it's not the physical capability but rather the judgment.
column2: Teenagers, oy.

column1:
562,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Despite all of the talk of recovery and normalization, the new normal - austerity
column2: - ripples&nbsp
column3: through the real economy.&nbsp
column4: As the public sector sheds jobs, this includes the educational system across the country.&nbsp
column5: While everybody can claim a share of the pie, the reality in Pennsylvania is particularly acute since state law requires that school districts fully fund their teacher pension plans and in the next several years, this contribution will rise from approximately 7% of school district budget to about 18% and if taxes aren't going to rise proportionately, the money has to come from somewhere.&nbsp
column6: But where?&nbsp
column7: And just how good is the information that you're hearing?

column1: What I've concluded is that the kids are paying attention - at some level - but that information is either third hand or badly misconstrued.
column2: Eldest came home several months ago with the observation that the district's music program was on the chopping block as the school administrators were suddenly hanging around and talking to the kids and &quot
column3: asking questions.&quot
column4: &nbsp
column5: She followed this up with the synopsis of another conversation that she had with a teacher, in which it was said that the wave of the future was to cross-teach so that music would be rolled into the physical education program.&nbsp
column6: I politely listened and then promptly filed it in my mental uh-huh drawer.
column7: But the other day, I came across an article that discusses another school district discussing cuts in the music and arts in order to strengthen the core academic programs.

column1: My home state, Pennsylvania, instituted the Pennsylvania System of School Assessment - PSSA -
column2: tests in response to Bush's No Child Left Behind legislation
column3: the intent is to monitor how kids are performing and rating the schools accordingly.&nbsp
column4: Schools with poor performance are forced to institute remedial action plans and if they don't work, I assume that they wind up in administrative detention.&nbsp
column5: The reality of the PSSA is that the schools have universally found themselves teaching to a test and it's grating to a parent's nerves to only hear from little Johnny that they spent half the day doing review work for topics that about two-thirds of the students already know and a small fraction will never know because they were whacked in the head with the stupid stick.&nbsp
column6: Like the comedian Ron White once said, you can't fix stupid.&nbsp

column1: The state however, is moving beyond the PSSA tests and is in the process of implementing the Keystone Tests, which commence for students in the class of 2015.
column2: These exams will cover a variety of topic areas - Algebra 1 &amp
column3: 2, Geometry, Civics, Science, US and World History amongst others - and seniors will have to pass a certain number of them in order to graduate.&nbsp
column4: Those who don't pass the requisite amounts will not graduate.&nbsp
column5: The difficulty for the districts however is that the state continues to alter the requirements and thus presents the local educators a moving target that must be hit starting in 2015
column6: &nbsp
column7: the districts are left trying to plan to meet a goal that might yet change again.&nbsp
column8: A local school district, considered to be one of the wealthier ones, is now actively considering how to cut the arts programs in order to put the money into the core academic courses mandated under the Keystone Test Program.

column1: Our educational system's priorities are reverting to a period predating America's economic golden-age, which began after the end of the Second World War.
column2: These priorities are assuring that the mass of youth are able to handle the most important aspects while leaving the non-essentials - and that's what the coming debate is going to cover - to those who find them interesting.

column1: What else are the local districts doing to handle the austerity crunch?
<li>Three local districts, each with strong academic programs, are pooling resources to offer combined higher-level courses to their students.&nbsp
column2: The classes, such as Advanced Placement Physics, would be held at one central campus location and the students from the three districts would travel to that site for the course.&nbsp

column1: <li>One rural district is actively cutting back the athletic program and is shifting to a pay-to-play model, in which the students must pay a fee to play a particular sport.&nbsp
column2: The Athletic Director's position has been eliminated and that work is now handled by a vice-principal and the district is trying to herd cats by getting the various sport booster clubs to merge into&nbsp
column3: one sports booster club to fundraise for all sports.

column1: <li>Report cards are no longer mailed to the home, but are given to the students to give to the parents.&nbsp
column2: The reality however, is that any parent with a computer is now able to access their child's grades via the school district website.
