column1:
563,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The results of the June 2012 PracticalDad Price Index show that while the total market basket index declined slightly from May's 106.49 to June's 105.91 (November 2010 = 100), the food items portion actually rose significantly from May's 109.65 to June's 110.85.
column2: The upshot is that the cost of the total market basket rose by only 5.9% from November 2010 to June 2012, the actual food items themselves rose by 10.85%, a full 5% more.&nbsp
reporting&nbsp
column3: format of the PracticalDad Price Index changed as I began to calculate the index on both a full market-basket basis and a food-only market basket basis.&nbsp
column4: There are 47 total items in the PracticalDad market basket and of these, 37 are actual foodstuffs with the remaining 10 being household, over-the-counter medication and personal hygiene products commonly purchased at grocery stores.&nbsp
column5: All 47 items together comprise the total market basket index while the food-only index is based solely upon the 37 items.

column1: When you sense that food costs are rising more rapidly than other costs, this is a datapoint which supports that notion.
column2: While the two indices moved in tandem from November 2010 to August 2011, it was in November 2011 that the prices for food themselves began to separate from the remainder
column3: the activity amongst the non-food items masked the cost activity.&nbsp
column4: From November 2011 to June 2012, the total index wandered in a narrow range from 105.56 to 105.91
column5: during that same period, the food-only index rose consistently from November 2011's 106.38 to June's 110.85.&nbsp
column6: In the three month period of February - May 2012, the food-only index increased by almost two full percentage points.

column1: While there have been instances which supported the existence of stealth inflation, where prices are constant or drop slightly but package sizes decrease, June's pricing at three separate grocery stores found three instances of package changes:
<li>one grocery store continues to sell hot dog rolls in 8 count packages, but the weight of the package decreased from 12 to 11 ounces
<li>another grocery chain joined its brand competitors by decreasing the Orange Juice packaging from 64 ounce cartons to 59 ounce cartons

• the feminine pads are in the process of changing package sizing from 42 to 39 count cartons and this is in process as the local grocer still carries the old size package while the separate chains now carry the newer, smaller packages.
As before,the prices are adjusted to account for the stealth inflation.
So the next time you bite into that grilled hot dog and marvel at how it plump it is, there's a good chance that it actually isn't.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
564,"1","1",,"xhtml","

...and apart from DC Comics making money from it, how is that any different than what the kids see when they go to the mall?
One of the traits of our society that I do admire - and there are
column2: still some&nbsp
column3: - is that over time, Americans have the capacity to accept change as generations come and go.&nbsp
column4: People can argue that racism still exists and to an extent, it still does, but so long as there are people, racism will always exist to one degree or another
column5: the same goes for religious bigotry and sexism.&nbsp
column6: But the prevailing attitudes change and society as a whole becomes more tolerant and what was once harassed is able to come out into the open.&nbsp
column7: So it is with homosexuality.&nbsp
column8: In the relatively short time frame of four decades, homosexuality has shifted out of the closet and into the mainstream consciousness as gay men and women protest and proselytize for their rights.&nbsp
column9: Their road has not been easy and there's been a tendency to flaunt their beliefs in ways that cut against still-extant Christian values, but there has been demonstrable progress.

column1: Unless parents want to raise their kids in a compound, there's no way to shield them from societal change.
column2: What we can do is pay attention and use the instances to teach the lessons that we want pass along our values to the kids.&nbsp
column3: Our first foray into explaining homosexuality was when Eldest was in elementary school
column4: on a trip to the mall, she saw a lesbian couple walking down the corridor with arms around one another's waists and as they passed, she turned and watched them from behind as they walked away.&nbsp
column5: The questions soon arose but our first lesson was not to stare at someone as it's impolite.&nbsp
column6: After that point was made, there was further conversation about the basic difference between homosexuality and heterosexuality.&nbsp
column7: <em>The big difference, Eldest, is that gay people find romantic interest in someone of their own sex...&nbsp
column8: Regardless of whatever you believe about the issue, you have to ready and able to discuss it with them and not just turn away because it isn't going to go away.

column2: DC Comics' action is really in the interest of profit and not in empowering gay role models for impressionable young readers.&nbsp
column3: As social mores shift and change, these events are going to occur and as parents, we have to aware of them and be ready to discuss it with the kids.&nbsp
column4: They do see sexual identity issues amongst their peers as their friends and acquaintances - maybe even they themselves&nbsp
column5: - puzzle it out, even at the&nbsp
column6: elementary school level.&nbsp
column7: Use the opportunity to make whatever point you want, but don't think that you can just ban it because these developments are everywhere.

column1: Middle and Youngest are both comic book fans and when I shared the story with them at Saturday's dinner, their response was surprise.
column2: It didn't make them want to avoid the character and the conversation shifted to the plot details including how there could be two Green Lanterns in alternate universes.&nbsp
column3: But I thought that Hal Jordan was into women, at least he was in the movie...Where the conversation broke down was in the actual dialogue between Green Lantern and his boyfriend as the superhero described a
column4: planned date as magical
column5: even the 10 year-old noted the incongruity between a powerful superhero and stereotypical language.&nbsp
column6: <em>Dad, why couldn't he have just said &quot
column7: fabulous&quot
column8: ?

column1: So just a quick note to the writers at DC - if you want to shatter stereotypes and empower gay youngsters, avoid the trite terminology.
column2: You're killing yourselves.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
565,"1","1",,"xhtml","

My father once remarked that watching his two children brought him joy.
column2: While I appreciated the sentiment in that moment many years ago, it was only when I became a father with my own three trying out new interests that his comment really took root.&nbsp
column3: Seeing the kids have fun and trying new activities is, on one level, frustrating for the schedule and time
column4: but when&nbsp
column5: I see them find those activities at which they do well, then it truly does become what one person calls<em> a joyful thing.&nbsp
column6: That is until they reach a point at which it begins to shift from simply being a fun activity
column7: to an avocation at which they want to excel, and you're forced to see them begin to suffer the physical and psychic bruising that comes with real competition.&nbsp
column8: Such was the case this weekend with Youngest's baseball playoff game.

column2: Throughout our life together, my wife and I&nbsp
column3: lived in cities with minor league teams and have taken advantage of the opportunity to enjoy decent ball, good seats and cheap beer
column4: Youngest has been bitten by the love for the game and now plays each season and is frankly developing into a good player.&nbsp
column5: He's at the age at which baseball-loving boys begin to consider what position they wish to play and in his case, he sees himself as a catcher.&nbsp
column6: He's realistic enough to understand that he'll never be a fleet-footed outfielder or pitcher&nbsp
column7: but&nbsp
column8: in his&nbsp
column10: he has begun to stake a claim behind the plate.&nbsp
column11: Given his young age, we held off three years of requests before finally caving in and getting him catchers gear of his own.

column1: It's helpful to understand something about Little League baseball and the catcher's position.
column2: For the first&nbsp
column3: two&nbsp
column4: levels of Little League baseball, no stealing is allowed and it's at the AA level (8 and 9 year olds) that the kids are allowed to begin to steal second and third base
column5: until this point, the catcher is simply a backstop with arms.&nbsp
column6: It's at the AAA level (9 and 10 year olds) that the catcher becomes important as it's at this level that the runner is now allowed to steal home and score a run and it's also here that the talented kids start to understand the strategies and tactics of the game.&nbsp
column7: The catcher's position has been called the field general since from his
column8: spot behind the plate, he can see where his fielders are and actually make adjustments and I've witnessed two boys who - at this level - have played as though born to the position.&nbsp
column9: But there's a double-edged sword for the catcher since he's also catching for kids who, even when they're good, can be wild with a sizable number of passed balls and with the catcher's cumbersome&nbsp
column10: gear and inexperience, the plate is&nbsp
column12: the taking by aggressive baserunners from third&nbsp
column14: The safeguard for the catcher at AAA is that the batting team can only steal home twice per inning.

column1: While Youngest wishes to be the catcher, this season's reality was that a recurrent knee injury kept him from playing there due to the stress of constant squatting.
column2: He missed the first game and spent the remainder of the season in the infield and the catcher's mitt was relegated to two younger players who were repeatedly burned at the plate by aggressive baserunning.&nbsp
column3: He was finally cleared for catching and his first appearance as catcher was the first playoff game this weekend and in the final practice two nights before the game, his coach had him don his gear for passed ball drills behind the plate with a cadre of teammates repeatedly trying to steal home - and frequently succeeding.&nbsp

column1: The game was against a team that runs well and aggressively.
column2: While I doubt that they hit as well as Youngest's team, they're coached to take advantage of mistakes and in the first two games played against them this season, they beat Youngest's team by aggressive baserunning, including consistent steals of home plate.&nbsp
column3: It was clear that the strategy would be more of the same and if there was to be a change, it would be up to Youngest to make that change by keeping them from stealing home plate.

column1: We live in a world in which some schools and organizations have dumbed down sports by abolishing the idea
column2: of winners and losers.&nbsp
column3: Everybody should get a ribbon for participating and our kids apparently need their self-esteem bolstered more than their skills.&nbsp
column4: But that's not how life works and in this particular organization, there comes a point at which kids play not only for fun but also to win.&nbsp
column5: There are always far more teams at the youngest levels of a sport as everyone tries it out for size but within a few years, the funsters have departed and the number of teams have decreased to accommodate the kids who truly love the game.&nbsp
column6: It's also at this point that the kids realize that if you're going to play, you should play to win and the coaches are there to&nbsp
column7: develop their skills and teach them to win
column8: sometimes, winning is more than just physical attributes but also thinking about what you need to do to win and the coaches have to model that for the kids.

column1: The upshot was that the opposing coaches did more of the same, sending runners from third on every passed ball opportunity, and Youngest took his lumps behind the plate as he repeatedly tore off his mask and helmet,
column2: searching furiously for the ball as it rolled around the backstop area.&nbsp
column3: The pitchers did what they were supposed to do as they advanced to cover home, but while there were some close plays, the runs scored.&nbsp
column4: The boy got banged up in the melees but to his credit, he refused to quit and stuck through the game.&nbsp
column5: My first inclination as I watched the play was anger towards the opposing coaches for taking advantage but there was a begrudging respect for their strategy as they taught their own kids that they could win with more than pure hitting.&nbsp
column6: This was a learning experience on both sides of the ball, joyful on one and painful on the other.&nbsp

column1: Despite the painful learning experience, Youngest still wants to catch and I admire him for that.
column2: There will be other such lessons - both in baseball and life - in his future but learning from them now will help him in such instances in the future.&nbsp
column3: There comes a point with the kids that shielding them from adversity only serves to hinder them in the future as bosses and clients will not be so forgiving of errors.&nbsp
column4: So teach them to play to win now, when their losses won't have more serious consequences.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
566,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Our media topics are a reflection of what concerns us at the moment.
column2: In the 1950s, fear of nuclear war and radiation was reflected in numerous science-fiction films such as Them
column3: our concerns about succumbing to Communism's soulless collectivism was played out in the classic Invasion of the Body Snatchers.
column4: Our revulsion to&nbsp
column5: militarism and the failed Vietnamese War played out in The Deer Hunter, Full Metal Jacket and Apocalypse Now.
column6: As I flip around the television dial, it becomes apparent that there's another meme afoot and that pertains to our opinions towards wealth and a growing awareness of
column7: our economy, how far we've fallen and what we face.

column1: It dawned on me the other night as I sat before the television.
column2: The History Channel was touting the high cable ratings of such shows as Pawn Stars, American Pickers and Swamp People
column3: it brought to mind the trendsetter for the bunch, Mike Rowe's Dirty Jobs.
column4: To check myself, I flipped on the On Demand menu and noted that the majority of the History offerings were for shows that dealt with cashing in on old items or dangerous occupations.
column5: Unlike the network's early origins, not a single show itself dealt with historical events.&nbsp
column6: As I surveyed the channel offerings, certain other popular cable shows dealing with wealth caught my attention.&nbsp
column7: There are multiple shows about Housewives behaving badly in places like Beverly Hills, New York and Atlanta and my guilty favorite, Dance Moms, which pertains to mothers who spend inordinate amounts of money to have their daughters taught dance.

column1: We've turned the page from that '80s fave, Robin Leach's Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.
column2: We admire the concept of wealth and God knows that enough of us play the lottery in the hopes&nbsp
column3: of striking the Big One, but we no longer put the wealthy on a pedestal.&nbsp
column4: As ill-thought economic policies cut a swath through the middle-class and the American concept of succeeding is ground down, we look at the wealthy in a new and more biased light.&nbsp
column5: Each of these shows the shallow and petulant behavior of someone with money behaving badly and our collective response is akin to rubbernecking at a serious accident - we know that it's bad but we can't stop looking.&nbsp
column6: Likewise, it provides a salve for our damaged aspirations with the thought being Wow, money can really do terrible things to a person...thank God that'll never happen to me.

column1: Yesterday's beautiful June weather also brought out a huge number of yard sales as people took the opportunity to both purge their household of accumulated crap and raise money to pay bills.
column2: I was out early as Eldest rented space at a large church-sponsored yard sale - raising money to help offset the cost of a planned beach trip - and my job was to deliver the tables to the site.&nbsp
column3: The number of yard sale signs in the early morning neighborhoods was impressive and there were a significant number of buyers as well with cars parked up and down various streets near each sale.&nbsp
column4: We've become programmed to the decades-long consumerist mentality that equates purchase with pleasure but as our incomes recede, we must find new and cheaper ways to feed our habit and the yard sale is a good alternative.&nbsp
column5: Shows like Pawn Stars and American Pickers foster a more critical eye amongst some shoppers as people realize that amongst all of the crap for sale amongst this great kitschfest, there are really items of some value and the hope of a growing number is that they'll find that occasional item of worth and value that could truly be a financial windfall.

column1: We are, in a real sense, like the Berliners of 1945 who cull through the rubble in the hopes of finding something worth salvaging in the debris.
column2: Except that the bricks and timber are the mounds of cheap clothing and miscellanea on which we've willingly spent our money.&nbsp

column1: The yard sales are a great way of fulfilling needs on a limited budget if you're willing to take the time to look.
column2: But the next time that you're out, consider what's being sold by whom and then take a look at whether it would be acceptable to the guys of Pawn Stars and American Pickers.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
567,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Eldest graduated from high school the other evening, ending thirteen years of public education before moving on to the next stage.
column2: So there's a vested interest to read that a high school actually withheld the diplomas of four graduates
column3: because of their families excessive celebrating.&nbsp
column4: Were the superintendent and principal correct in their action?

column1: Let's set the stage for the personal event.
column2: Eldest was one of 461 students to graduate in her class and the ceremony was held in the air-conditioned gym of a local university
column3: the district shifted the ceremony there after multiple attendees fainted in the high school facility two years ago due to the heat.&nbsp
column4: There's a decent sound system and the event occurred in an orderly process as the graduates received their diplomas in two separate lines entering from opposite sides of the stage.&nbsp
column5: Cameras set up opposite each line allowed a video feed of each graduate to one of two separate large screens so that the thousands of people there were able to see their kid receive their diploma.&nbsp
column6: The ceremony was so smoothly handled that the 461 graduates received their diplomas in the span of approximately fifteen and the entire ceremony was completed in 90 minutes.

column1: At the outset of the ceremony, the principal spoke and as part of his remarks, asked that parents and guests refrain from any applause or cheering until the end so that all of the families there were able to hear the name of their own child being announced.
column2: It was only a few minutes into the actual awarding of diplomas that the first family began to cheer and then, multiple other families yelled vociferously and in one instance, the family blew noisemakers.&nbsp
column3: The large majority of the guests followed the request, but a small minority refused.&nbsp
column4: Sure enough, in each instance of celebration, the names of at least one or more subsequent graduates were rendered&nbsp
column5: unintelligible in the din and those families might have seen the child on the screen, but never heard the name being announced.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Despite the noise and intermittent hoopla, the ceremony occurred without interruption and those that couldn't hear their graduate's name called were simply out of luck.

column1: Based upon the linked article, the Cincinnati school district is several years ahead of ours in terms of the issue.
column2: Eldest's class was frankly warned by the administration that any misbehavior or excessive display on their part could imperil the receipt of the diploma.&nbsp
column3: I have little doubt that the Cincinnati administration did the same and managed to bring the graduates under control - assuming that they actually followed through on their threat.&nbsp
column4: But it became apparent that the issue wasn't with the graduates but with the families themselves and after multiple efforts to request mutual respect of one another over the course of several years - and heated complaints from other parents - they settled upon a policy of holding the diploma pending appropriate behavior by all parties.&nbsp
column5: This policy was announced in writing and disseminated with the tickets that were distributed to the families so no one can say that they shouldn't have known.&nbsp
column6: The only remaining question would be whether the school administration would actually follow through on the new policy.&nbsp

column1: When the event occurred, multiple families celebrated and according to the article, it wasn't the noise level so much as the duration.
column2: This meant that the families immediately following their own kids weren't able to hear the names called and the school responded as had been promised.&nbsp
column3: Be clear on something here:&nbsp
column4: the only thing withheld is the actual paper diploma and the four graduates were able to participate with their class in the ceremony.&nbsp
column5: Their names were announced and they walked up and - if there school is like Eldest's - received the leather folder which was actually empty as the diplomas themselves were disseminated at the end of the ceremony after the class had filed out to whatever tune was played.&nbsp

column2: The public culmination of thirteen years of public education is the graduation ceremony.&nbsp
column3: Critics can say that public education has been dumbed down enough so as to render the achievement meaningless but there are plenty of kids for whom it is an&nbsp
column4: achievement and the same goes for their families.&nbsp
column5: Together, many have weathered whatever challenges might have arisen in that period.&nbsp
column6: Families have been affected by lost jobs and foreclosed houses, the dissolution of families caused by divorce or the difficulties arising from substance abuse.&nbsp
column7: The ceremony is, for many, the public capstone to their thirteen year experience and is as important for them as for others. &nbsp
column8: I understand how important it is to the families to hear their child's name publicly proclaimed and I suspect that any of these four families would be hurt to find that their graduate's name was omitted.&nbsp
column9: So here's the trade-off that the school has put forward:&nbsp
column10: go ahead if you want to cheer so lustily that the following names are unintelligible but expect that the diploma will be withheld as a small token to the graduates who receive their diploma but whose recognition has been virtually erased by your own noise.

column1: My sympathies lie with the graduates, both those with names drowned out and those celebrated.
column2: These kids have a common bond not shared by the families and I suspect that there's some loyalty to one another that the families don't understand.&nbsp
column3: Many kids tend to be easily embarrassed by their family's actions and if these four are like mine, the discipline is doubled as the withholding of the diploma is matched by the embarrassment at their parents' behavior.

column1: If my own school district should decide to pursue such a policy, I will support it and I know of about five other families who will as well.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
568,"1","1",,"xhtml","

While many are still out of the loop as to global financial developments - Spain has just joined Greece in the bailout line and Italy is looking peaked - enough are starting to become anxious about how they might be prepared in the event that the wheels come off of the economic bus.
column2: One of the big things that people tend to do, especially if they listen to Glenn Beck or are into Doomer mode, is assure that their larder is fully stocked.&nbsp
column3: This isn't as extreme as it appears as the unemployment rate is again rising and folks are wondering if and when they're liable to be next.&nbsp
column4: But stocking the pantry isn't a one-off proposition and I'm going to spend the next day or two in reviewing the status of what's in our own larder.

column1: Most American households didn't have the stocked pantries prior to the Great Depression.
column2: With a higher percentage of the family income spent on food and limited storage space in much smaller homes, many housewives did their shopping on an almost daily basis at the neighborhood grocer.&nbsp
column3: The arrival of the supermarkets in the 1920s and improvements meant that food was more readily available and easily stored but that didn't translate into a societal change until the Great Depression.&nbsp
column4: Older Americans, children of the Depression, recalled the memories of bare pantries and no money and made major changes when they established their own households so that their own children wouldn't undergo their own experiences.&nbsp
column5: I recall, as a child, asking my own mother why we had so much in the pantry and her comments to the effect that she wouldn't be caught shorthanded again.&nbsp

column1: Times are tense yet again and the reality is that there's the prospect of another Lehman-style financial crisis as the Europeans face a continent-wide debacle due to huge debts and a structurally weak currency.
column2: How is it structurally weak?&nbsp
column3: Remember that a currency is not only an economic device, but also a political one as it's heavily dependent upon the policy choices and politics of it's nation.&nbsp
column4: The European bind is that they've got a currency which presupposes a political structure with full integration such as the United States has with it's Constitution, yet their funding is heavily dependent upon the individual actions of the constituent states such as occurred in the earliest&nbsp
column5: years of the US during the period of the Articles of Confederation.&nbsp
column6: It's a round currency in a square political hole.&nbsp
column7: The simple reality is that the global financial system is so interdependent that what happens in Greece will not only affect the French, Spanish and other banks, but have a derivative effect upon the American banks which have all manner of exposure to the European banks.&nbsp

column1: Which brings us back to the family pantry.
column2: One of the key policy responses to these issues has been a repetitive flooding of liquidity into the financial markets from the various Central Banks and when they fill the buckets, the buckets tend to slosh around to other areas
column3: one of the key areas is in the realm of commodities, particularly food.&nbsp
column4: What's become apparent from monitoring prices via a simple grocery basket
column5: - the PracticalDad Price Index - over 18 months is that food costs are now accelerating and their effect is being masked by flatter non-food prices within the grocery cart.
column6: Food prices are rising but incomes are not, so if you're going to stock up, you have to assure that the resources that you expend now are as effective as possible.

column2: that you are actually going to pay attention and manage&nbsp
column3: the household food supply.&nbsp
column4: It's something&nbsp
column5: on which I could personally do better, so time will be spent&nbsp
column6: on the process.

column1: <li>What do we presently have in the pantry?&nbsp
<li>What is the age of the supply, i.e. am I sitting on cans eight years out of date?&nbsp
column2: If you think it odd, understand that the Boy Scouts do an annual food drive for their neighborhood food banks and in sorting the food collected, we've come across cans of beans more than a decade past their expiration date.

column1: <li>What do we actually need and what mismatch exists?&nbsp
column2: Am I sitting on 20 cases of corn while I really need flour?

column1: • What system must I begin to use to assure that this occurs more than once each decade with the loss of hundreds of dollars of food?
While this process happens, there are other and more general questions to answer.
column2: What is the time frame for which I need to prepare, end of the world or just a few months of supplemental food to help ease my future cash flow?&nbsp
column3: How much am I willing and able to share with others, and who are those others?

column1: The final upshot of the project is that this is another reminder of how our way of life is resetting to an earlier time, when families had to make much more conscious decisions about how to use their resources.
column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
569,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Another Father's Day is upon us and it's ironic that it was preceded by a controversial Time magazine cover and article
column2: asking women if they're &quot
column3: Mom enough&quot
column4: .&nbsp
column5: It's another shot in the on-going, low-intensity war amongst mothers pitting stay-at-home moms and working moms as a significant minority of the stay-at-homes practice attachment parenting
column6: the philosophic premise is that strong bonds and stronger babies are the result of a high-contact environment between mothers and infants.&nbsp
column7: Natually, there are women - such as the young mother on the cover - who tend to take the philosophy to an extreme.&nbsp
column8: It does however, beg the question of what it means to be a father.

column1: If I'm going to be a father, what does that mean?
column2: What precisely does a father do and what is my primary role with the kids and family?&nbsp
column3: This isn't a theoretical exercise as several decades of social and economic change have whipsawed the American family and American fathers in particular.

column1: While the divorce rate amongst American marriages has leveled off in recent years, it rose significantly from the 1960s in part to the adoption of no-fault policies by many states.
column2: With courts siding with the mother for child custody, a significant number of children found themselves in family units in which there was minimal paternal involvement.&nbsp
column3: These kids became adults and the results of the divorce became apparent as co-habitation became acceptable with fewer opting to marry so as to preserve their ability to simply walk away should things not work out.&nbsp
column4: The girls of divorce also saw their mothers struggle as they were forced to both parent the kids and keep a roof over the heads
column5: while difficult, there was a role model for the girls.&nbsp
column6: The boys of divorce weren't so fortunate as the fathers were largely removed and sidelined, some struggling to stay involved in a meaningful way and others simply giving up.&nbsp
column7: These boys were often left with no meaningful role model for a father who was involved on a regular basis.

column1: Television has been a central role in American culture since the early 1950s and the portrayal of the American father has changed dramatically in that time.
column2: Jim Anderson of Father Knows Best is an early
column3: portrayal of the American father, but while unrealistic, Dad was portrayed positively.&nbsp
column4: The paternal roles shifted with society over the decades until the late 1980s with the arrival of Married with Children's Al Bundy, and the floor completely gave way under television's view of Dad.
column5: While the entire family structure was lampooned, the idea of Dad took a huge hit and the hits kept on coming with Homer Simpson and any number of other television fathers who were portrayed as clueless, well-meaning fools who were kept in line by the watchful eye of Mom and more often than not, the kids.&nbsp
column6: There were isolated instances in which fathers received a friendly portrayal, but it's only been in the past two or three years that the father has begun to receive realistic portrayals, such as in NBC's Parenthood.

column1: Women have advocated for change in their place in society and that's a good thing as
column2: our resources are wasted when&nbsp
column3: half of our society's members are relegated to very gender-specific roles.&nbsp
column4: But change isn't always pretty nor is it easy.&nbsp
column5: Hard-core feminists have advocated for the right of women to fully enter the political and business realm, but while that push talks up the ability of women, it has frequently also entailed denegrating men in different facets.&nbsp
column6: For more than a generation, women entered the workforce with the expectation of having a successful career and a family
column7: the notion was pushed by media and feminism that you really could have it all.&nbsp
column8: Unfortunately, being successful financially and professionally requires commitment and time -&nbsp
column10: There's an additional impact upon children as a small but growing number of women opt to finally become single mothers after spending the time and energy to become professionally successful at the expense of their personal lives.&nbsp
column11: While the number is small, the ripple effect is the question what's the use of a father? to younger women.

column1: It's become apparent in the past decade that the Golden Age of the American economy is coming to a close.
column2: Globalization has shifted high-value employment overseas and our own economy has become much more dependent upon the service and public sectors for employment.&nbsp
column3: Family income is now dropping and it's become apparent that the American standard of living has been maintained by an easy flow of credit
column4: we could afford the niceties because of our ability to borrow to pay for them but the debt has reached strangulation levels.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: The effect&nbsp
column7: of globalization has also been pernicious upon the family as&nbsp
column8: many of those jobs flowing&nbsp
column11: Likewise, the collapse of construction spending meant that&nbsp
column12: predominantly masculine construction jobs also took hits.&nbsp
column13: Women in the workforce is now not only a matter of choice, but of necessity.&nbsp

column1: All of these factors have come together in a nasty, potent brew greatly affecting the institution of fatherhood in America.
column2: Men are working under considerable pressure to create workable models of fatherhood for their children and it would be helpful if there was at least a template of expectations against which they could draw the components.
Redefining Fatherhood - A Response

570,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The American Family is now in the process of finding its way to a new normal as the rising consumption pattern of the past 50 years meets the declining income pattern of the past decade.
column2: While there's cyclicality to the economy, it's dawning on us that what's occurring now is not cyclical but structural, as the American economy finally gives way to the consequences of errant policy decisions and global competition.&nbsp
column3: Parents have to now consider what they can actually afford as they balance the costs of raising children with the realities of preparing for the future in a fiscally-constrained society.&nbsp
column4: This particular point is brought home in the present question in my mind - if a child has a non-scholastic interest in something, what is the value of private lessons and how far should those lessons&nbsp
column5: be taken?

column1: One of the keynotes of the employment picture in the past two years is the rise of the part-time job in lieu of full-time employment.
column2: Young adults are graduating college with iffy job prospects and certain debt while more than a few middle-aged folks are suddenly finding themselves out of work as well.&nbsp
column3: Teen unemployment is high as the kids are caught between traditional jobs now being handled by adults and child-labor laws that restrict what employers are willing to offer.&nbsp
column4: What's cropped up more noticeably on my radar, especially in terms of sports, are the personal coaches who are happy to work with the kids at a rate of $35/hour or higher, if there's an actual facility involved.&nbsp
column5: This supplements the traditional realm of the music teacher, who historically taught the child instrumental or vocal music.&nbsp
column6: As more people are stretching to figure out ways to make money, they're taking what talents they might have and putting them on the market as instructional services.&nbsp

column1: But what should I consider if these are a prospect?
column2: The cost of footing the bill for&nbsp
column3: a teen soccer development team can run a family into the thousands of dollars annually and the same can be spent locally at a baseball training facility.&nbsp
column4: Is it worth it?

column1: As a full disclosure, we've forked over money
column2: for piano and vocal lessons
column3: the former simply because we believe that it's important for children with any interest in music to learn how to play piano and read music and the latter more recently because Middle has a good voice and a budding interest in the arts as a career.&nbsp
column4: But the sports realm is a different issue for us.&nbsp
column5: Youngest&nbsp
column6: wants to play drums but his talent is physical
column7: as Eldest - his sister - once commented, he's the family jock.
column8: He's played soccer and wants to take up both football and rugby when he's older, assuming that his mother and I finally agree on whether those are options.&nbsp
column9: But his love is baseball, which he's played for years now.&nbsp
column10: His fielding is good and he's proven to be an okay pitcher, but his real talent has been at the plate and that's where the question now arises.&nbsp
column11: He's continually hit in the upper .300s and he rarely strikes out
column12: he's got an ability to put the bat to the ball and at least put it into play.&nbsp
column13: In the movie Moneyball, a scout talks to a prospect's parents and comments that baseball is a game that the true players love but one that tells many at some point that it no longer loves them back and they move on.
column14: Youngest is getting to a competitive level where more kids are finding that the sport doesn't love them as much as they love it and they're being winnowed away.&nbsp
column15: Apart from a week-long summer baseball clinic run by the local university program,&nbsp
column16: do we cough up some extra money to hire someone to work with him personally?

column1: As I write this, the back of my head is snorting derisively as it states Seriously?
column2: It's a kid's game fer chrissake...
column3: and I partially agree with that.&nbsp
column4: But it also comes down to three factors - expectations, odds and finances.

column1: What are the expectations from such an act?
column2: Am I looking for the next great batting champion or just helping the kid?&nbsp
column3: More importantly, does he want this or this being done for me?

column1: What are the odds on potential outcomes?
column2: It's statistically damned near impossible that he, or any other kid, will ever make the big leagues.&nbsp
column3: But there's a greater likelihood that with some effort, he can turn this love for the game into assistance with his college education
column4: I know several families who have staked their kids' college on massive investments in sport clinics and special teams, more than I expect to spend.&nbsp

column2: This won't be taking the place of the 529 plan, but is there some way that I can funnel some funds off to cover the expense?&nbsp
column3: There's also an additional perspective to finances and that's in the future.&nbsp
column4: I spoke with the mother of an elementary age softball player who was paying $35/hour to a young woman who played softball seriously through college and her comment was that if her own girl stuck with it, she could also wind up with the skill set that would allow her to make some on-the-side money from coaching future youngsters.&nbsp

column1: That's precisely where we need to understand that we are employment-wise.
column2: There are no longer going to be any major corporations that will carry you on the books for your lifespan and looming public austerity makes the dole iffy at best.&nbsp
column3: You're going to have to assess your skill-set and creatively figure out what you need to do to cobble together an income-stream to support yourself and your family.

column1: And remember that if you are able to handle such an expense in some form, you're doing more to put food on another family's table than purchasing crap from Walmart.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
Father's Day article
column3: asked the question what is the role of the father?
column4: There have been huge changes affecting fatherhood and the family in the past four decades and as is typically the case, the structure has been badly outpaced by events and trends.&nbsp
column5: As families have struggled with the upheaval, attention has turned periodically in the press to&nbsp
column6: the attempts to cope
column7: with women now heavily in the workforce, the question has generally been asked as how much housework and childcare is the father doing to assist the mother.&nbsp
column8: Is Dad doing enough in the household to help Mom?&nbsp
column9: How much time is spent on dusting and childcare activities to make life easier for Mom, who's also now in the workforce?

column1: On one level, those are entirely appropriate questions.
column2: Caring for, and raising, children is hard work
column3: it's physically intense when they're younger and more intellectually and emotionally intense when they age and move out to interact with the world.&nbsp
column4: But the undertone of the conversation is that&nbsp
column5: Dad is the junior partner in terms of the parenting with the bulk of the real power in the hands of Mom, who's more qualified and capable&nbsp
column6: of managing the kids.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: This isn't just a&nbsp
column9: media perception either, but one that&nbsp
column10: men themselves have stated in the media.&nbsp
column13: the comments of fathers in national publications that <em>I'm just&nbsp
column14: watching the kids until their mother gets home and
column15: the kids are my boss, I work for them.
column16: Seriously, the kids are your boss and you work for them?
column17: Sweet Jesus, that's the kind of&nbsp
column18: scenario played out in comic books in which the Joker is somehow made warden of Arkham Asylum.&nbsp
column21: While I no longer listen to Limbaugh, he is right when he states that words have meaning and while that father meant that he worked in the household on their behalf, the wording leaves one with the sense that many fathers view themselves as the junior member of the parenting partnership.&nbsp

column1: In the main, most mothers do have innate insights into their kids' heads and feelings that most fathers don't, and probably never will.
column2: Perhaps the best description of a mother's insight was penned by JM Barrie in the first chapter of Peter Pan:

column1: Mrs. Darling first heard of Peter when she was tidying up her children's minds.
column2: It is the nightly custom of every good mother&nbsp
column3: after her children are asleep to rummage in their minds and put things straight for the next morning, repacking into their proper places the many articles that have wandered during the day.&nbsp
column4: If you could keep awake (but of course you can't) you would see your own mother doing this, and you would find it very interesting to watch her.&nbsp
column5: It is quite like tidying up drawers.&nbsp
column6: You would see her on knees, I expect, lingering humorously over some of your contents, wondering where on earth you had picked this thing up, making discoveries sweet and not so sweet, pressing this to her cheek as if it were nice as a kitten, and hurriedly stowing that out of sight.

column1: It's lovely writing but in the language of the twitter generation, Moms are generally better at getting inside the heads than Dads.
I'm trying to not sound sexist, but while women are better turning inwards to the family, I believe that men are generally better at facing outwards, towards the world.
column2: When the kids were very little, I believed that my first and foremost job was to not only care for them, but protect them.&nbsp
column3: They were incapable of handling whatever was out there and it was my job to assure that&nbsp
column4: no harm came to them.&nbsp
column5: But as they grew and moved out into the world, the physical aspect lessened but the sense did not.&nbsp
column6: My job was to prepare them as much as I could - and they were willing - for life in the world.&nbsp
column7: My job as a father is to teach them not only about the world but also, and more importantly, how to handle what came their way.&nbsp
column8: This could be done via conversations but also by example and behavior.&nbsp
column9: How do you handle people who might come to the front door?&nbsp
column10: What do you need to remember about handling money matters with salespeople and others?&nbsp
column11: Are there situations that you and the kids witness that need to be discussed?&nbsp
column12: For example, my wife and I were taking the kids to a summer evening event in a nearby city and as we drove down a street, saw a man - surrounded by others - beating another man.&nbsp
column13: As my wife dialed 911 from the cellphone, I wheeled the car up a side street and away from the fight.&nbsp

column2: Why didn't you help the guy?&nbsp

column1: Because I'm in a car with three children, the oldest in middle school and there are a number of people surrounding this fight.
column2: Why aren't they stepping in&nbsp
column3: and am I creating more issues by trying to intercede?&nbsp
column4: What happens if I'm outnumbered and the disturbance shifts to our car?&nbsp
column5: Courage is important but smart is even more so.&nbsp

column1: Our world is an unfriendly place and it's only becoming moreso.
column2: Behaviors have grown more callous and crude and if there's nobody to teach kids how to respond to unpleasant people and situations, then the potential for more problems rises.&nbsp
column3: Not only is our world increasingly unfriendly, it's increasingly complex.&nbsp
column4: Kids might be technological whizzes, but they've so immersed themselves in their electronics that they pay no attention to the actual workings of the world.&nbsp
column5: <em>Turning in a job application is only the first step in the process.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: Have you actually asked somebody for&nbsp
column8: a reference before they get a phone call from a potential employer?&nbsp
column9: When and how are you going to follow up?&nbsp
column10: What do you think that you're going to&nbsp
column12: If you want to go to the beach after graduation, where do you plan to stay?&nbsp
column13: Is there a contract that you have to&nbsp
column14: sign and more importantly, have you read it?&nbsp

column1: Situations and circumstances in the outside world can certainly be handled by women, but there are moments when a male presence makes a difference and it's important for the kids to see how.
column2: This is especially the case for boys, who desperately need a stable male presence to provide a model for manhood.
&nbsp
column3: Educate them.&nbsp
column4: Search out and seize teachable moments at all ages, whether it's pointing out how a helicopter is like a hummingbird, how to handle a bully or change the tire on a car and bicycle.&nbsp
column5: Do your best to manage yourself in tense situations so that they have a model on which to build their own behavior when older.&nbsp
column6: Explain the world to them at every opportunity, talk to them, chat with them and reinforce your core values and beliefs whenever possible.&nbsp
column7: Understand that even when you aren't overtly teaching, they are watching you intently and learning as they go.&nbsp

column1: All of the other stuff - housework and childcare - matters greatly as it's upon this mundane minutiae that households are given form and structure and turned into homes.
column2: The women in your lives deserve your support and they in turn owe you likewise
column3: just remember however, that raising children should be a partnership between mother and father and the best partnerships are built among equals with neither one being junior to the other.

column2: When the children are youngest, they'll be behind you for their protection.&nbsp
column3: As they grow, they'll learn to take a place at your side and when they're adults, they'll advance ahead of you into a new world of their own with its own trials and pleasures.&nbsp
column4: And when they become parents, the cycle will continue anew as they protect their little ones standing behind them.

One of the concepts that Econ 101 students learn is that of the inferior good, which isn't actually a comment upon the quality but rather it's affordability versus other goods.
column2: In other words, an inferior good is one that's used to replace a more expensive or unavailable one when times get tough
column3: Spam is a classic example as sales generally rise during periods of economic downturn and folks move away from more expensive meats to make the budget work.&nbsp
column4: When times improve, then the sales scale back accordingly.&nbsp
column5: In today's environment of rising food prices, Postum would be such an example of an inferior good.

column1: Postum was created by CW Post in the 1890s as an alternative to coffee, which he disliked because of the caffeine content.
column2: In it's life - it was finally discontinued by owner Kraft Foods in 2007 - the formula was basically toasted grains mixed with molasses.&nbsp
column3: Although it didn't taste like coffee nor was it billed as a coffee substitute, Postum sales skyrocketed in the World War II years as real coffee was rationed and millions of Americans shifted to Postum in lieu of the bean.&nbsp
column4: My own recollection is that it resided in my grandmother's cabinet and I recalled seeing the bottles in out-of-the-way sections of the coffee aisle shelves until they simply vanished.&nbsp
column5: America's love affair with coffee has flourished and one of our most expansive corporations revolves around setting up coffee shops
column6: we have no concern with caffeine as our youngsters swig Mountain Dew and the teens graduate to Monster, Venom or Rock Star.&nbsp
column7: Postum simply couldn't compete.

column1: But Postum will be making a comeback
column2: in the near future courtesy of former drinkers who bought the trademark and did the formulary work to get the taste right.&nbsp
column3: There are certainly going to be those who drink it for the taste but I suspect that others will try it as an alternative to coffee for reasons of cost.&nbsp
column4: When the PracticalDad Price Index began in November 2010, the cost of a 13 ounce store-brand caffeinated coffee can was $2.96
column5: had the packages not been downsized to either 11 or 11.3 ounces, the equivalent cost would be $4.43 for the same 13 ounce can - an almost 50% rise in only 20 months if you account for the downsizing.&nbsp
column6: If you're paying less for a can of coffee than the average here, it's probably because that can is less than the old standard 13 ounce can.&nbsp

column1: What happened with the marketbasket from June to July 2012?
column2: The index level increased again&nbsp
column3: from June's 106.49 to 106.77 (November 2010 - 100.00) so that the cost for the basket is 6.77% higher than November 2010
column4: looking in prices for the food component of the basket alone - 37 of 47 total items - the index rose to 110.32, more than half again as high as the full component.&nbsp

column1:
As much as I love coffee, I probably will try a cup of Postum when it returns.

There's a growing brouhaha in England and heads in the banking sector there have already begun to roll.
column2: It has nothing to do with hookers or rogue traders that spend the company dime on cocaine futures
column3: rather, it pertains to something as innocuous as the financial equivalent of a screw, an interest rate called LIBOR, which like a screw serves as an underpinning to a large portion of the global financial structure.&nbsp
column4: While the action is in England, the effects are felt here as LIBOR is used in financial instruments in the US and the reality is that there are American banks which contribute to the determination of LIBOR.&nbsp
column5: Did they participate?

column1: When most people think of banks, they think that the institutions are free-standing entities that compete with one another for business with minimal interaction
column2: any additional funding needs can be achieved via working through the Federal Reserve System (although the sense is that things are pretty bad if that's the case).&nbsp
column3: For the smaller banks, this is par but&nbsp
column4: the&nbsp
column5: larger banks - especially those deemed Too Big To Fail - have daily funding and liquidity needs that outstrip what they have on hand.&nbsp
column6: These banks consequently interact with one another each day and those with extra will lend to the other institutions at a very small rate, small because these lending institutions expect to have the money back very soon and also because they know with whom they're dealing.&nbsp
column7: Consequently, the rate that these institutions charge one another is exceptionally low and requires no collateral for the extremely short duration.&nbsp
column8: LIBOR - London InterBank Operating Rate - is the name of this rate.

column1: LIBOR came about because of a nudge from the British Banking Association in the mid-1980s.
column2: With the introduction of a wide range of new and complex products - adjustable/variable rate mortgages, interest rate swaps, and other goodies - in the early 1980s, it became apparent that there had to be a common rate upon which
column3: the various products could be based&nbsp
column4: else&nbsp
column5: for contractual purposes.&nbsp
column6: Because London continued to be home to a significant part of the global financial community, the BBA pushed the financial community to develop such a uniform rate and LIBOR was born, taking effect in 1986.&nbsp
column7: Understand that while the name implies a solely British scale, the actual LIBOR rate is determined by the responses by only a handful of banks from the international community and is updated daily.&nbsp
column8: These daily rates are then used in an immense number of financial contracts occuring globally as the reference point for the payments that pass from one party to the other.&nbsp
column10: The cumulative financial value of the contracts with some input from LIBOR are in the hundreds of trillions of dollars - that's Trillions, with a T.

column1: The issue with LIBOR, and it's so far claimed the top three executives of Barclays Bank - a major international bank based in Britain - is that it's become clear that the daily rate has been gamed by at least several of the banks.
column2: The member banks are expected to report a particular rate each day based upon their best estimate, but Barclays is the first to have been found to have underreported what their rate would be in order to do favors for other institutions
column3: this means that the true rate of interest is actually higher than the artificially low rates reported as the official LIBOR rate for that day.&nbsp
column4: The difference is unknown at present and would depend upon how many member banks colluded in the rate reports and to what extent was the level of underreporting.&nbsp
column5: For each of those days affected, any number of variable rate mortgages and other rate-sensitive contracts, would be consequently affected.&nbsp

column1: The CEO of Barclays, Bob Diamond, recently testified before a Parliamentary Committee regarding the LIBOR scandal.
column2: His testimony was Barclays actually&nbsp
column3: was pressured to do so by&nbsp
column4: the Bank of England, the equivalent of the English Fed
column5: but the note to file after the BoE/Barclays conversation not only supports his claim, but unequivocably states that not only were other banks rigging their LIBOR submissions, but that the BoE knew of it and wanted Barclays to fall in line with the other rigging banks.
column6: The old saw is that prisons are full of innocent men and given our present who ya gonna believe environment, there will be questions as to the veracity of the note.
column7: But the damage is done as there's a strong discrediting of the entire financial establishment, profit and regulatory alike.

column1: So long as LIBOR is now under suspicion, there's now a pall over the use of many of these products.
column2: There's a true impact on rate sensitive contracts in the works but not yet signed.&nbsp
column3: Is this truly the real rate or is it rigged?&nbsp
column4: Is there some other rate standard that can be used in it's stead and how dependable is it?&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: There's a potential impact on mortgages as lenders slow down lending to&nbsp
column7: see how this plays out and families waiting for word on whether they will be able to purchase a home.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column10: the difference of 3/4 of point in a mortgage rate can be in the&nbsp
column11: hundreds of dollars, so what does this do to home sales?&nbsp
column13: One of the other great losers in this episode are the various non-profit and governmental entities that might engage in interest rate swaps to help control the cost of capital projects.&nbsp
column14: Will needed infrastructure projects - bridges, sewer treatment plants, road work - be able to move forward or will they&nbsp
column16: With Stockton, California now in bankruptcy and other entities - Detroit, Harrisburg, Jefferson County, Alabama - as poster children for fiscal disaster, how will necessary work move forward?&nbsp

column1: This is simply for the world moving forward and says nothing about the rate sensitive contracts that are already in place.
column2: Frankly, if I had an interest rate swap and heard this news, I'd pull the paperwork and review it in a much more skeptical light with an eye towards litigation.
rigged baseline reference point are massive.

column1: The LIBOR rate is a global reference point, much as the gram is a standard for determining mass or the gallon for measuring volume.
column2: &nbsp
column3: But unlike the gram and gallon, there is no true governmental oversight for the protection of the LIBOR rate
column4: the English government essentially let the determination of this global standard to an insular&nbsp
column5: financial industries community that put itself ahead of the common good.&nbsp

column1: If you want a comparison, suppose that governments failed to inspect and regulate gasoline pumps but let the maintenance and standardization of those pumps fall solely to the oil companies?
column2: What would you think if you were paying for 20 gallons of gas each week but were in reality only getting 17 gallons in your tank?&nbsp
column3: Would you be angry with Exxon-Mobil or BP for abusing your trust, let alone your wallet?

column1: What would you think if Otis Elevator purposefully used defective materials in the production and installation of elevators?
What would be your response if you found a roach in your
column2: kid's Happy Meal and then found that the local health department had suspended restaurant inspections because they considered the&nbsp
column3: folks at McDonalds&nbsp
column4: to be okey-dokey&nbsp
column5: 100% upright citizens?

column2: your roller-coaster car went barreling off the rails on that last hair-pin turn, would your last thought - before your brain splattered against the pavement - be to curse the state for not inspecting the ride before it opened?

column1: What would you think if you found that your hoped-for home, in the neighborhood with the school you want for your kid, was suddenly unaffordable because your lender had to adjust the rate on the prospective loan to account for a gamed LIBOR reference rate?
column2: What if they simply&nbsp
column3: became&nbsp
column4: Loan Nazis and said no loan for you!

column1: These examples don't mean that I have a blanket distrust of business, at least not Otis.
column2: But each of these areas are under public regulation and inspection because there's a long history that demonstrates that companies and individuals can prefer private gain over the common good, even to the point of death.&nbsp
column3: In each of these industries referenced, there wasn't some uniform inspection and enforcement mechanism simultaneously enacted in a piece of blanket legislation
column4: the regulatory oversight was created on an as-needed basis and that need was usually prompted by some scandal involving death, serious threat to the public welfare&nbsp
column5: or serious financial loss.&nbsp

column1: No one has died, but there's damage nonetheless.
column2: The losses put to the public treasury are already&nbsp
column3: in the trillions of dollars and these losses detract from more important uses, let alone the knowledge that we're mortgaging our grandkids' future with the debt.&nbsp
column4: The failure of the fiduciary component of the financial industry has allowed self-interested bankers to plunder their clients' savings.&nbsp
column5: The failure of the fiduciary component has allowed the banks to wholesale gamble with their capital, knowing that any failure would be made good by the public trough.&nbsp
column6: If you aren't certain of this, consider the recent issue regarding JP Morgan Chase's $9 Billion screwup that led to their CEO's appearance before Congress.&nbsp
column7: While the drama is on in Britain, the problem doesn't lie solely with the English government.&nbsp
column8: This is a pointed example of what occurs when oversight and regulation ceases and people with signficant incentives to cheat are left to their own devices and it happens in the US just as it does in other western nations.&nbsp
column9: The US deregulated the financial services industry in the 1990s and the result since then has been an ongoing parade of unethical and sometimes illegal behavior in the time since.&nbsp

column1: Planes aren't falling from the skies nor are bridges collapsing as a result of this particular episode.
column2: But the banks have still tampered with the screws that hold the financial structure together and when that structure finally goes, the suffering will be immense.&nbsp
column3: If you aren't certain, just look at the generational scars left by the Great Depression.&nbsp
column4: There is an occasional thought that nags at the back of my mind however.&nbsp
column5: The view of the government's role before the Great Depression is one of benign neglect as it permitted Laissez Faire capitalism to run it's course...

column2: our society&nbsp
column3: be like if government was known to have taken an active role in promoting and facilitating the excesses of the late 1920s?

When we purchased our present home in 2007, we found that the yard
column2: was a high-maintenance affair with a do-it-yourself pond already installed.&nbsp
column3: After a fish-killing algae bloom in 2009, we began a major yard renovation
column4: project to both refurbish the pond and tear out almost 800 square feet of out-of-control periwinkle.&nbsp
column5: Since we'd had a quote of over $5000 to redo the pond, we thought that we could do it cheaper (a win) and instill some entrepreneurial drive in the older kids (For the Win!).&nbsp
column6: Since beginning the project in 2010, its end is now within sight and I've had to look back to see what I'd do differently.

column1: <li>First, don't let the kids determine the pace of the project.&nbsp
column2: I'll grant that it's been a long - loooong - project tearing out hundreds of square feet of overgrown myrtle, landscaping the first half, installing a two-tier vegetable garden and mucking with a dying fish pond.&nbsp
column3: The intent was to do the work and let the kids do a large amount of the grunt labor within the context of the usual summer activities, prompted by good old greed.&nbsp
column4: But I miscalculated on the variety and time constraints of the activities and things lagged.

column1: <li>Second, I simply didn't realize that the bulk of this is pure stoop, grunt labor and that the kids aren't interested in hours and hours of grunt labor.&nbsp
column2: They'd do some work but with the interspersal of activities, it was never enough to gain critical mass.&nbsp
column3: While I'd become concerned that there was laziness that didn't bode well for the future, especially on Eldest's part, her subsequent part-time job has reassured me that she's got a decent work ethic.

column1: <li>Third, the kids aren't just going to go outside and work unless I prompt and actually join in, and set the example.&nbsp
column2: When I was there, it went better than when it didn't.

column1: <li>Fourth, I discounted Youngest, who's now old enough to put in the physical work and has actually proven to be more reliable and motivated than his older siblings.&nbsp
• Finally, there's something to be said for simply saying let's get this done and be finished with it and making it a priority ahead of other work.
column2: It's something that I should have done last summer.

column1: But had I done that, Youngest wouldn't have made the money that he's made thus far.

So for now, the last segment of the new waterfall awaits and then - then - we can actually enjoy the backyard.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

575,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Readers know that I have three children - Eldest, Middle and Youngest - and as it usually happens, life changes.
column2: In this case, it changes because Eldest is moving off to college in a month and if the proliferation of empty boxes awaiting use didn't bring that home, the arrival of the first tuition bill did.&nbsp
column3: Within a one week span of the bill's arrival, she also received other correspondence offering student loans and if I didn't know better, I'd almost think that it was serendipity that such mail would arrive in such a timely fashion.&nbsp
column4: What went through my mind in the moment and afterwards?

column1: First was the simple realization that the bill was addressed to The Parents of...
column2: While she's now eighteen and nominally an adult - are our high school graduates truly adults (hmmm, there's a question) - the money enchilada comes back to us.
column3: This was especially interesting since we learned at parent orientation weekend that the institution could only send us report cards for the first two years unless the offspring signs a permission form allowing them to do for the final two or so years.&nbsp
column4: At least we're clear that our role in the eyes of the college establishment monolith is that of a financial donkey.

column1: Second, the simple question when did this happen?
column2: My flashback was to a two-year old toddler posing for a picture on her first day of preschool, a small blue tote bag slung over shoulders wearing a bright yellow play shirt, face framed by fine brown hair cut in a page-boy&nbsp
column3: style.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: At that moment, she was an only child and in the intervening years would be&nbsp
column6: joined by her two younger&nbsp
column7: brothers.&nbsp
column8: That question was followed by a momentary panic with such&nbsp
column9: questions as have we done enough? and could I have done a better job of investing what was saved?
column10: The pit-of-the-stomach queasiness was only made worse when I tore off the computer envelope tabs and looked at the dollar figure for the first semester.&nbsp
column11: Despite the fact that I've run the numbers and knew what they already were, the emotions exploded out of the box like a knife-wielding, meth-addicted jack-in-the-box.&nbsp

column1: Third, despite having run all of the numbers ahead of time, actually looking at the amount of the first bill was a gut-checking experience and especially since the dollar figure in the amount due box was significantly less than what I expected.
column2: My family knows that when truly surprised, my standard response is what the hell? with the register dropping on the second word and then rising - along with a crescendo - on the word hell.
column3: After momentary confusion, I found that the difference was accounted by the school's assumption that some of the money was coming from a federal direct unsubsidized loan despite our never telling them that that was what we'd be doing.&nbsp
column4: The college financial aid office explained that their bills automatically include that and I had to specify that our intent was to handle this without debt, although circumstances with two other kids might force a future change.&nbsp
column5: It bothers me that the institutions continue to raise the costs with the expectations that the families and kids are having to incur even more debt.&nbsp
column6: While some increases are expected, the fact that the past two decades of rises have far outstripped family incomes.&nbsp
column7: It all comes back to the fact that higher education is a big business
column8: if you don't believe it, consider that student debt is now higher than credit card debt or auto loans.

column1: Fourth, within days of the tuition bill's arrival, Eldest received separate credit offers from Sallie Mae
column2: and Citibank.&nbsp
column3: Sallie Mae's offer openly played to the emotions with the line that time was running out for a loan before the start of the school year but they'd sweeten their offer with some manner of free credit insurance for a period of time.&nbsp
column4: Citibank's offer was more bland but again, the timing was supposedly serendipitous.&nbsp
column5: Honestly, if you're faced with the prospect of having to take on tens of thousands of dollars, you shouldn't be rushed into it and kids can simply be tricked into the sense that it's now or never.&nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: The matter should be approached in such a manner that the prospect of a Sallie Mae letter is irrelevant and can be directed immediately into the trash and teens/nascent adults don't have the perspective and experience to realize it.

column1: Fifth, now that the bill is here, what is the mechanism for drawing money from the 529 to cover this?
column2: Money has been plunked there periodically for years but what has to happen to actually get it out in a timely fashion?&nbsp
column3: By now, Eldest knows that the bill is certainly here and has to be covered by a certain date and this presents a learning moment in how to handle processing.&nbsp
column4: The question was answered in a few minutes and she walked through the withdrawal paperwork with me so that she could see what was involved.&nbsp
column5: Can she do it going forward?&nbsp
column6: No, since it's in my name as her custodian but it's helpful for her to see the background structure, something about which the great mass of kids are woefully unaware.

column1: The process is now in motion and the bill filed away until mid-August.
column2: Now it's time for her to cull and gather and fill those boxes for the trip out.&nbsp
column3: And then, the reality will sink in again.
