580,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Life is supposed to be less hectic as the kids grow, but even with Eldest on the cusp of college, the summer passed quickly and busily.
column2: The changes brought home - with startling clarity - one of the more disturbing articles read during the break, the mass of material possessions for the typical American family.&nbsp
column3: I thought, had hoped, that I was atypical but apparently I'm not.

column2: July article in Boston.com
column3: pertains to a recent book published by UCLA sociologists, Life at Home in the Twenty-First Century (
column4: ie=UTF8&amp
column6: sr=1-1&amp
column7: keywords=life+at+home+in+the+twenty-first+century"">Amazon.com).
column8: I first became aware of the study several years ago when researching a previous article about electronics
column9: at that time, the sociologists were reported to be spending time in 32 different&nbsp
column10: households to study how the families interacted with one another as well as the impact of technology.&nbsp
column11: Indeed, the thrust of the article was that while parents were concerned about the kids' use of technology, they were ceding that ground to them because they were intimidated by it.&nbsp
column12: But what also caught their eye was the impact of the sheer amount of stuff that these families had accumulated and that finally became the basis of the linked book.

column1: There was an eerie sense that these folks were in my own home, taping my own family as it wended through life and the myriad projects, the most disruptive of which was the room swap.
column2: With Eldest leaving for college, she offered to swap bedrooms with Youngest
column3: hers was the largest of the kids' rooms and his was the smallest although it's become apparent that within three years, he'll physically dwarf her.&nbsp
column4: My wife's input was that along with the physical shift, each could repaint the room in a color scheme of their choice to which my thought was crap, no fourth grader is gonna paint his own room in two tones and her schedule won't permit her to paint his as well as hers...so I'm on the hook for his.
column5: Repainting a room is disruptive but controllable as furniture can be shifted to the center and covered with tarps but to actually change rooms means that at least one room of furniture is coming out to the hallway and that's what happened
column6: however, when the furniture began to stay in the hallway, I pressed Eldest and she admitted that culling through all of her accumulated stuff was a bit overwhelming and it was after that admission that the process began to move along.&nbsp
column7: The painting on Youngest's room - which would become Eldest's - was complete and while her furniture was moved in, Youngest's furniture remained in the hallway until I painted his new room
column8: even then, some items that were not going in stayed in the hallway until this morning when I finally caved in and removed them.&nbsp
column9: Furniture will stay in storage for when the kids start their own places, but the rest has gone to Goodwill or the trash.&nbsp

column1: There any multiple reasons for the massive accumulative of kitsch, crap and stuff.
<li>We've been literally programmed and conditioned by decades of advertising that consumption is good.&nbsp
column2: After the end of the Second World War, business and political leaders made a conscious choice to push advertising that condoned and encouraged consumption.&nbsp
column3: Why?&nbsp
column4: Because with the end of the war and the move by government to once again balance the books and pay off the debt - quaint, isn't it? - there would be no driver for business and capital investment unless the American consumer took up the slack
column5: but they also remembered that many citizens would need a strong nudge since the collapse of the banks during the Great Depression left many literally squirreling away their cash in mattresses and under rocks across the country.&nbsp
column6: So go ahead and spend, it will demonstrate how well off you are.

column1: <li>Bad news sells and an ongoing proliferation of disaster/war/collapse scenarios creates a mindset among people that they have to be prepared.&nbsp
column2: But prepared, how?&nbsp
column3: We consequently stock up on food and consumer staples that take up space and expend cash but is that really necessary?&nbsp
column4: Is it realistic to hoard tampons in anticipation of becoming a feminine products broker The Day After?&nbsp
column5: Likewise, the spectre of inflation means that people stock up now because they're conditioned that they'll have to pay more in the future.&nbsp
column6: The ongoing debate in this household is whether the number of toilet paper rolls should be in the three digit range.

column1: <li>As more mothers returned to the workforce in the 1970s and afterwards, the stress on the American family rose accordingly.&nbsp
column2: The housework, laundry and cooking continues despite the job and as parents - or parent, as it were - stretched to perform those tasks, there was a greater willingness to buy stuff to occupy the kids so the parents could proceed accordingly
column3: the impulse to purchase was also nudged by parental guilt for having to spend greater time away either because of work or simple exhaustion.&nbsp
column4: We&nbsp
column5: allowed the kids to anesthetize themselves so that we could anesthetize ourselves from the daily stress of living.&nbsp

column1: The issue matters for economic and moral reasons.
column2: Economically, the tide is turning against the American family as incomes drop for the large majority of families.&nbsp
column3: There simply isn't going to be the funding available to pay for all of these niceties and still keep a roof over the head and food on the table and if the kids don't see conscious decisions and sacrifices made, many won't be able to adjust when they enter the adult world.&nbsp
column4: Morally, the chronic consumption is oriented inwards and discourages empathy and the building of character
column5: that requires an ability to see and live beyond oneself and if a kid is obsessed with their stuff, they won't develop that empathy and character.&nbsp
column6: The teen years are, in a sense, a time of cocooning when the child becomes an adult.&nbsp
column7: While we can't protect them from everything, we can and should try to assure that the most egregious is absent and abject materialism would certainly count as egregious.

column1: Over the past several years, my better half has occasionally wondered why I'm so into downsizing and I have to point out that it isn't downsizing, but simply trying to control the crap that's coming in and through the household.
column2: The process will continue but I'll have to make a more concerted - better - effort to manage and eliminate the stuff so that the kids understand that we should be able to control it and not have it control us.&nbsp
column3: Likewise, the lesson will be repeated again and again that these things require money that could be better used elsewhere instead of enriching some retailer.

column1: I fear that our society's children will be faced with choices that we never had to make.
column2:
While I can't protect them from those choices, I can work now to lessen the pain of the repercussions when that time arrives.

With the drought continuing across the US
column2: and affecting the corn and - probably - soy supplies, the word is out to expect an increase of about 3% in food prices in the next year.&nbsp
column3: While I'm not certain, it sounds as though they assume that there will be no other food increases apart from what's happening to the national crop because of the drought.&nbsp
column4: That unfortunately isn't the case as food continues to rise.

column1: The results of the August 2012 basket pricing of 47 items showed that the full index declined slightly to 106.68 from July's level of 106.77 (November 2010 = 100).
column2: When you strip out the ten non-food components of the grocery basket however, the food-only index rose from July's 110.32 to August's 110.88 (November 2010 = 100).&nbsp

column1: While there's always some give and take, especially due to seasonality, amongst the food prices, what was notable was an 8.8% rise in the cost of Red Delicious Apples (3# bag)
column2: and and a 10% rise in the cost of a can of Dark Red Kidney Beans.&nbsp
column3: In each case, one of the three stores suddenly showed a price spike which drove the average cost upwards and I anticipate that there will be some followup amongst at least one of the other two stores in the next several months.&nbsp
column4: This is indeed the case for the stealth inflationary packaging of sugar, which has now had a second store decrease the standard size bag from 5 to 4 pounds.&nbsp
column5: While there's a nominal price decrease, the real effect is an increase in the cost of sugar as the consumer will have to purchase more or cut back use accordingly to make a bag of sugar last the same time span.

column2: The summer has been busy with projects, activity and preparation for college and yes, I have written less accordingly.&nbsp
column3: Please excuse this and know that after a coming week off-line, the thoughts and articles will return in volume.&nbsp
column4: Until then, continue to have a good summer and thanks for reading!

There's a reason that I don't do much writing when the kids are around and things are hopping.&nbsp
column3: In this instance, I looked up as everyone cheered for an American Olympic gymnast and bang! I'd inadvertantly hit the key that posted the previous incomplete article to the site and RSS...so here's the second effort at the article.
column4: My apologies.

column1: History doesn't repeat itself, but it does rhyme.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column1: It's been five years since the start of the global credit crisis, which has morphed and metastisized from a bunch of over-leveraged homebuilders and mortgage lenders to nations seeking bailouts and the potential collapse of a multinational political union and currency.
column2: We've witnessed multiple scandals that don't seem to scandalize and an alphabet soup of European acronyms
column3: but while there are excellent websites to keep tabs on the ongoing trainwreck, it's difficult to understand events in any kind of historical context.

column2: Seriously?

column1: Fiat currency, regulatory capture, gold standard, widespread corruption...these are not new instances and their reoccurrence simply gives the lie to the nonsensical notion that history ended with the collapse of the Soviet Union.
column2: Twain was correct when he noted that history might not repeat itself, but it does rhyme.&nbsp
column3: Consequently, it's helpful to have a sense of where we've been before to gain an insight to where we might have to go again.&nbsp
column4: If you have some time for reading, I'd suggest the following series of books that&nbsp
column5: would provide a good overview of that particular topic.

column1: The Money Men (H.W. Brand, 2006) - This is a good overview and relatively easy read for the start as it touches upon five Americans who were intimately involved in the finances of the country through its first hundred and fifty years.
column2: Commencing with Alexander Hamilton, it examines the roles of the trailblazer (Jay Cooke), the crooked (Jay Gould), the rescuer (J.P. Morgan)&nbsp
column3: and the power-hungry (Nicholas Biddle).&nbsp
column4: It's particularly the conflict that arose between Jackson and Biddle's Bank of the United States that highlights the ongoing tension between and a democracy and the monied interests.&nbsp
column5: The present day upshot of that story, which culminated in the Panic and Depression of 1837, is that resolutions are sometimes painful with much collateral damage.

column1: The Robber Barons (Matthew Josephson, 1973) - Josephson's book looks at the usual cluster of industrialists and financiers from the legally unfettered Gilded Age of the late 19th century (Carnegie, Rockefeller, Vanderbilt and Jay Cooke) and introduces you to others, such as Daniel Drew, who was a master at manipulating the stock market and particularly enjoyed taking advantage of economic upheaval (There's good fishing in troubled waters).
column2: What's interesting as you read is to consider how many of these names are also now the names of colleges and universities.

column1: The Panic of 1907 (Robert Bruner and Sean Carr, 2009) - As economic chaos goes, this wasn't a particularly terrible blow to the entire economy and scarring was contained to the financial and banking sector as it arose from bank overleveraging and speculation.
column2: What's notable about this event however, is that it set the stage for the creation of the Federal Reserve System in 1913 as politicians and bankers realized that there really was a need for a central bank to act as the lender of last resorts for the national banking system.&nbsp
column3: In this particular instance, the banker of last resorts was J Pierpoint Morgan (you'll remember him from The Robber Barons).
column4: In a series of episodes akin to what we'd consider a situation comedy, Morgan provided nighttime wagon loads of cash to meet the demand of panicking depositors when the doors of selected institutions opened the next morning.&nbsp
column5: How did he decide what banks were worthy of the money?&nbsp
column6: By sending in his trusted lieutenant, Benjamin Strong, to evaluate the banks' books through the night before and if Strong gave the thumbs up to Morgan, the wagons would be dispatched.&nbsp
column7: Thumbs down?&nbsp
column8: Those institutions died like defeated gladiators.&nbsp
column9: Had Morgan not acted, the episode would have left a much greater dent in the economy.

column1: The Lords of Finance (Liaquat Ahamed, 2009) - This centers upon the four principal central bankers - French, American, British and German - of the tumultuous first quarter of the 20th century.
column2: It examines the personalities of the four, including American Benjamin Strong (from The Panic of 1907) and the efforts of the four to manage their respective currencies through the chaos of that period.
column3: There are two topics of particular interest to today: first, the role of gold as a backing to a particular currency and the effect of managing a currency without having a solid standard of value to anchor it
column4: second is the tragedy of Weimar Germany, which opted to devalue the Deutschmark as a means of addressing a crushing national debt.&nbsp
column5: This doesn't mean that our own period is bound for hyperinflation, but it's certainly instructive in the lessons.

column1: The Big Short (Michael Lewis, 2010) - Michael Lewis has a gift for telling a story, for getting to the essence of something and making it understandable to a layperson and that's precisely what he's done with the heart of the financial crisis.
column2: This is the book that explains how the financial crisis of 2008 was born, and borne, within an obscure, opaque financial product that was marketed to the global community.&nbsp
column3: It lays out the collapse of ethical standards and the unbelievable myopia of a financial community that truly drank it's own Kool Aid before hitting the skids in late 2007.&nbsp
column4: This is the one book that I've both given and suggested to others because it's the keystone to understanding the mechanism in layman's terms.&nbsp

column1: House of Cards (William Cohan, 2010) - Before Lehman Brothers went down in 2008, the financial community got a foretaste of what was to come with the collapse of Wall Street firm Bear Stearns.
column2: It starts with the events of the firm's last several days before it's purchase by JP Morgan Chase for $2 a share (at one point within the previous two years, it had traded at over $170/share) and then shifts backwards to explain how it got to that point.&nbsp
column3: The ultimate lessons are (1) what happens when a firm is too highly levered by debt as it chases performance, and (2) what happens when the assets (as explained in Lewis' The Big Short) are so opaque and illiquid that they are almost impossible to value and sell.

column1: Econned (Yves Smith, 2010) - Yves Smith is the nom de blog for a retired Wall Street executive who began chronicling the absurdities and excesses of the financial system in her website Naked Capitalism.
column2: Smith lays out the changes in the Economics field and how the practitioners and academicians successfully managed to sell a soft science (psychology based) center wrapped in a hard science shell starting in the middle of the 20th century so that they became the priests of the financial and monetary field.&nbsp
column3: When they became the unchallenged priests by the end of the 20th century, the stage was set for decisions that fit well into a theoretical realm but horribly in the actual world in which we live.lin

column1: With kids, who has the time to read this stuff anyway?
column2: If I'm going to be a good father, I can't spend my time engrossed in reading unless it's with Junior and Goodnight Moon or Peter Pan, right?

column1: The truth is that these are books that I've read over the course of late nights for the past several years and they've gone a far way to helping gain a grasp on what all of this means.
column2: My recommendation for the best start is to attack Lewis' The Big Short for a synopsis of the product and spread throughout the global community.
column3: Then go back to Brand's The Money Men with special emphasis upon the section for Nicholas Biddle, who led the Second Bank of the United States when it clashed with Andrew Jackson in the 1830s
column4: this is a foretaste of the same issue that we face today as the monied interests line up to control the political system in which the rest of us live.

column1: I would say happy reading, but there's nothing happy about it.

This past weekend was Eldest's college check-in, a week earlier than most other students because she'll be playing soccer
column2: while everything was abbreviated because of the tight schedule, the Dean of Student Life gave a brief talk to those few of us parents there, shortened from the fuller speech that he'll give next weekend at regular orientation.&nbsp
column3: While he gave out a few informational tidbits, he also spent a fair period talking about the need for parents to step back from the kids and let them find their way.&nbsp
column4: What caught my attention was that by his definition, I fit the definition of a helicopter parent.&nbsp
column5: Seriously?

column1: The Dean's comments were that our generation of parents are reputed to be helicopter parents, who "
column2: hover&quot
column3: over the kids.&nbsp
column4: But in his description, our generation made it a point of attending all - or most - of the kids' events, whether musical, theatric or sport.&nbsp
column5: He commented that his own father made it to perhaps one of his games when he himself played sports four decades ago.&nbsp
column6: But now it was time for us to step back and let the kids to care of the institution in their next phase of growing into adulthood.&nbsp
column7: While I might have misconstrued his comments - doubtful - what struck me was his narrow, misplaced definition of a helicopter parent.&nbsp
column8: Is it hovering to attend as many games, concerts and plays as possible or is that just part of being an engaged and active parent?&nbsp
column9: Are we actually smothering the kids by showing up consistently and repeatedly?

column1: There is a practical and economic side to the increased attendance of today's generation versus the grandparent's generation that the Dean referenced.
column2: Forty years ago, kids didn't have the plethora of choices available for sporting and other activities that our own children have today.&nbsp
column3: There might have been a non-school related baseball or football organization, but there simply weren't the options otherwise.&nbsp
column4: There's also a fear amongst today's parents that options must be made available to the kids
column5: on the one hand, it permits them to grow and experience new activities that weren't available to us when we were younger, and there's a concern that if a kid isn't kept busy, he or she will be more likely to fall prey to the scarier aspects of unsupervised life.&nbsp
column6: So parents willingly sign the kids up.&nbsp
column7: Now comes the economic aspect - with gas at high levels, the money being spent isn't going to be wasted so the folks will assure that the kids make it where they need to be and then will stay because it doesn't make sense to waste gas by leaving and then returning later.&nbsp
column8: The time spent on the road to and from the activity is literally wasted, so the thought is to make the best of things by bringing a novel, a laptop or in my case, the occasional notebook for ideas and thoughts.

column2: As I sat and made notes for this article yesterday, Youngest wandered in and asked what I was doing.&nbsp
column3: He listened and cocked his head, puzzled at the term helicopter parent
column4: after I explained, he stated that he actually referred to them as shelter parents because their intent was to shelter their kids from any and all possible harm.
column5: &nbsp
column6: We discussed it from the standpoint of baseball - his first love - since his practices had started the previous evening.&nbsp
column7: Did he actually want me there and did he want me at his games?&nbsp
column8: The practice is a moot point because the field is located far enough into the countryside that I take&nbsp
column10: before leaving, but the games were a legitimate question.&nbsp
column11: He emphatically stated yeah, I like it when you see me play with the proviso that I not behave like a shelter parent.
column12: To him, a shelter parent was one who interceded with the coach and referee when something went against the kid and when I asked about when he might be getting chewed out by the coach, he simply shook his head and commented that that was all part of it.&nbsp
column13: He referenced an incident at a ball game last year when a teammate's irate father yelled at his coach and publicly pulled the teammate from the team and dugout because the coach had reprimanded him for poking a teammate in the eye with his finger and that would certainly qualify as a shelter parent.

column2: is actually a better description than that which is commonly used.&nbsp
column3: It more accurately describes the issue of parent and child relations and also points out that the kids aren't stupid, they really do understand there's going to be a time when they have to take a place in the world and that we won't be there, so they need to learn to deal with it.

column1: Your kids want to have you there as much as possible.
column2: They want to impress you and earn your respect and approval, so don't worry about what others might think about your attendance.&nbsp
column3: It might be beneficial, if they're old enough to understand, to have a talk with them about what does and doesn't embarrass them so that there are some ground rules with which both kids and parents are comfortable.&nbsp
column4: Before that point, simply accept that they want you there.

column1: Eldest is now going to play college soccer in another state and of about 14 games on her roster, her mother and I will only be able to attend two games.
column2: We'll follow the results on the college website and via&nbsp
column3: updates from her, but we won't be able to see her play as before.&nbsp
column4: So it's guaranteed that in the next decade, I'll attend every baseball and volleyball game, every concert and play that is practicable because it really does come to an end and when it does, I will miss it.&nbsp
column5: And the kids will miss us if we're not there.&nbsp
column6: This isn't hovering, it's simply being a responsible and engaged parent.

Listen to the kids and teens today and one of the arguments in favor of pot smoking is that it is supposedly a harmless drug, even less damaging than alcohol.
column2: I've heard kids point to the medicinal uses for which pot is now legal in California - with a doctor's script, I point out - and the political/budgetary arguments that we simply can't afford to keep spending resources on the enforcement of marijuana control laws.&nbsp
column3: Frankly, they do have a point there and I've&nbsp
column4: told the older kids that at some point in the next decade, at least one state will probably legalize marijuana - and then move to tax the living hell out of it.&nbsp
column5: But I'm a child of the 70s and knew more than a few guys who'd rather score a high than a decent grade and my sense was that it did have a long-term impact on their ambition and IQ, even if I couldn't prove it.&nbsp
column6: Now there's a long-term study that links IQ loss amongst adults to marijuana usage in their teens.
column7: While it's not anywhere close to certain that the information would have an effect - the teen battle cry is what could go wrong? - it's worth a shot at sharing the information with them.

column1: The study was a collaborative effort between Duke University and King's College London and actually began with interviews with teens back in the early 1970s in New Zealand.
column2: Through the ensuing years, the study team kept contact with the participants and at intervals, administered&nbsp
column3: IQ tests
column4: to further evaluate the participants, they interviewed family or friends that the participants themselves suggested.&nbsp
column5: The upshot is that participants who began to regularly smoke weed in their teens suffered an eight point loss in their IQ levels by their adulthood
column6: those who began later also suffered loss but there was some recovery in their adult years.&nbsp
column7: Given some of the kids that I knew in high school and college, this isn't a surprise.

column1: So what to do with the information?
column2: Short of locking teens in their rooms or homeschooling them and rigidly controlling their outside access, they'll spend considerable time out of your sight and control and you can only hope that you've given enough information - and helped build enough character - that they make the right choice.

column1: <li>Obviously, mention the study and show the article.&nbsp
column2: In my household, the information came via the laptop on the kitchen island during the morning kitchen routine prior to school.&nbsp

column1: <li>As always, make a values statement and offer some moral component.&nbsp
column2: Yes, it's factual information but some kids need to have it placed in the context of our values
column3: you don't have to beat them over the head and chant it's bad, it's bad, it's bad!!! but some quiet commentary can be helpful.

column1: • I don't know of any public schools that don't do random drug testing of athletes and kids involved in activities, so remind them that one blown drug test can have major repercussions on their favorite activities.
<li>Stay on message and be prepared to go back to it again and again and again, even when they roll their eyes at the old fart who just won't shut up about it.&nbsp
column2: Work to find new avenues to raise the issue instead of simply preaching but understand that they're actually listening.

column1: Like many other aspects of being a parent, there are no simple and straightforward rules.
column2: But what is necessary is the willingness to go back and revisit the issue whenever possible.&nbsp
column3: Pay attention to the media for anything that supports your stance so that it doesn't appear that it's just the old man back on the soapbox for another fun episode of meaningless redundancy.&nbsp
column4: But hang in there and keep with it, because it's certain that elements of the popular media - and their peers - are pushing the other side of the argument.

583,"1","1",,"xhtml","

My biggest job as a father is to prepare the kids
column2: for the adult world and that means exposing them to a wide variety of real world experiences.&nbsp
column3: Partner that with the civic responsibility to vote and the upshot is that it's also my responsibility to also provide a real world perspective on the American political system.&nbsp
column4: There will be conversations about the candidates through the Autumn - especially with Middle's enrollment in an Honors Government/Civics course - and I'll take one of the kids into the polling booth with me to see how it functions.&nbsp
column5: But should I make sure that they're able to see the purely Americana phenomenon of&nbsp
column6: a quadrennial political convention?&nbsp
column7: Is there value in letting them see the process - and spectacle - of a political party nominate the candidate?

column1: The process is historic, reaching back beyond Lincoln to the now-defunct Whigs and Federalists whose barbs and newspaper attacks make Fox/CNN look like child's play in comparison.
column2: It's also grueling for the candidates as well as the rest of us.&nbsp
column3: Kissed babies, deep fried oreos and calloused hands combine with breathless coverage of the candidates' personal lives and policy wonkery make for a truly odd experience.&nbsp
column4: The Republican nominee is offsetting his Cayman/Swiss accounts with his wife's comments on Fox News that she purchases his clothing for him at Costco while the incumbent president is trying desperately to keep his vice-president from blaming the start of the Second World War on the Latvians - yes, it's absurd but no more absurd than some of the other things that he's said.&nbsp
column5: But through all of the mess, the highlight of the process is the political convention, where the delegates are allocated and counted to determine the party's choice for nominee.&nbsp
column6: It's hoopla and entertainment and if fortunate, some actual policy might be adopted and decisions made in the limelight, but that's only if someone somewhere has screwed up royally.

column1: Any history buff can tell you that this is nothing new and that backroom deals have been made since the earliest days of the nation.
column2: There have always been political brokers and bosses but with the absence of a pervasive 24/7 newsmedia, many Americans actually believed that the system worked and they had a say in the process.&nbsp
column3: But I look at the system and process now and am wildly unimpressed and cynical about the entire circus
column4: what is the value of watching it with the kids when I believe that it exists solely as a Potemkin facade for a corrupted political process?&nbsp
column5: Am I doing my children a disservice by giving time to a political sideshow that's as rigged as the 1950's gameshow, The $64,000 Question?
column6: On the one hand, they desperately need to understand how the process of democratic elections work and they also need to understand how each person's input should matter.&nbsp
column7: But that isn't the same thing as getting sucked into a slick sideshow designed and programmed to generate a mindless, manipulable enthusiasm.&nbsp

column1: • The legislative branch of government utterly disregards the overwhelming opposition of the public and bails out a single sector from it's own self-inflicted wounds - yes, I'm still on this kick.
<li>Two branches of government are thoroughly unable to provide even such a basic tenet of stewardship as&nbsp
column2: a functional budget.

column1: <li>The government continues to fund prisons - via the private sector - but is unwilling or incapable of pursuing major financial fraud
column2: there is now a de facto dual system of justice dependent solely upon one's economic status.

column1: • The Chief Executive believes that he has the right and power to determine when an American citizen can be assassinated.
• Politicians of both sides decry spending out of one side of their mouths while promising continuing goodies out of the other side.
• Our tax code is so complex and opaque that even tax attorneys can obtain different results from the same set of financial data.
• Debate is reduced to soundbites and nastiness so that a real exchange of ideas is rendered almost impossible.
Children and teens are wildly susceptible to sensational claims and comments
column2: we've allowed them to become so cocooned in their own electronic world that they might possess a diploma or degree but are poorly prepared for the workings of the real world.&nbsp
column3: If it's ultimately my responsibility to teach them about the world, I want to do it without having to compete with the programmed glitz and asshatery of the political parties which are designed purely for smoke and mirrors.&nbsp
column4: There will be conversations about the election and candidates, as there have been already and along with taking them to vote, we'll follow the election night coverage.

column1: One convention - the Republican - is now in the record books and none of us turned it on.
column2: When Romney was nominated and spoke, we watched the Food Network's Chopped.
column3: Even though the President will speak during the Democratic convention, I guarantee that the set will either be off or turned to something else.&nbsp
column4: When the smoke has cleared, then we can have some discussions about what all of this means without the nonsense.

column4: of sugar was also downsized from the standard five pound bag to a four pound bag.&nbsp
column5: As always, I've adjusted the price per four pound bag to reflect what it would cost comparatively at five pounds to account for the&nbsp
column6: package&nbsp
column7: size decrease.

column2: New York Times ran an article forecasting food price rises due to the effects of the 2012 drought
column3: and much of it pertained to the drought's effect upon the corn crop.&nbsp
column4: But corn isn't only used for animal feed, but also cooking oil and biofuel and the drought will also affect other crops, particularly soy and wheat and these will rattle through the economy as we move forward.&nbsp
column5: Given the level of oil prices, there will probably be a double whammy&nbsp
column6: on cooking oil as these variants are also used in biofuels which are already affected by oil and gas prices.&nbsp
column7: As sugar prices rise, despite the nominal decrease because of package downsizing, expect to see further increases in all foods which contain some degree of sugar, such as breakfast cereals, pastries and baked goods, and other dessert foods.

column1: If there's any question about the ongoing conditions, I'm writing this with a standard size (12 ounce) can of Spam next to my laptop.
column2: The product, produced by Hormel Foods, is now celebrating its 75th anniversary and is one of the principal reasons that Hormel Foods Corporation saw strong sales growth in the last quarter.
column3: The expiration date on the bottom of the can says Best By April 2015 and I can only presume that sales are being driven both by those who are stocking up as well as the increasing number of families on Food Stamp benefits who are seeing their protein sources slowly priced out of their range.

column2: is the purpose of a higher education?&nbsp
column3: More importantly,&nbsp
column4: does it still make sense in today's world?

column1: Cumulative student loans are now, at more than $1 Trillion,
column2: larger than either credit card debt or automobile loans.&nbsp
column3: Students taking on such debt are responsible for it - period - as are all those who cosign for them, even retirees on fixed incomes.
column4: If you owe it, they will come.
column5: Yet despite this, higher education is still billed as the key necessity for entry to that promised land, the American Middle Class
column6: the statistics are that those with the degree typically outearn those without it.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: But as the youngsters continue to take on debt and find themselves with minimal employment prospects to support the debtload, it's helpful for the parents - who sure as hell should be having input into the decision - to be clear as to why this happening.&nbsp
column10: What is the purpose of a higher education and does it make sense for my child?&nbsp

column1: Our nation has had a love affair with higher education, even if most of its earlier citizens could never afford to attend.
column2: The great Land Grant universities of the latter 19th century - Auburn, UCal/Berkeley, Rutgers, and more than 140 other well-known universities - were established
column3: under the&nbsp
column4: auspices of&nbsp
column5: congressional action to&nbsp
column6: provide research and education in improved agricultural techniques and&nbsp
column7: ensure that decent education was available to the general public
column8: it was believed that any person would be able to better him or herself accordingly, and also become better citizens in the process.&nbsp
column9: While the majority of the populace didn't attend these institutions, their existence did increase the availability of education to the masses and sent an important message about our national values throughout the rest of the world.&nbsp
column10: Just as the establishment of the land grant universities opened the educational gates, the passage of the GI Bill in the late 1940s opened them further with the message that higher education was of value
column11: we'd reward our veterans for their service with education to help them move on with their lives and care for their families.&nbsp
column12: Education matters because an educated citizen is engaged, productive and less likely to be dependent upon the state in the long-term.

column1: Has that changed for any reason in the past twenty five years?

column2: It's especially even more important today as more Americans are dependent upon the Federal government for Food Stamps and Disability Income, both of which are at all time high levels.&nbsp
column3: But these programs are fiscal outlays and their existence means that not only is there an outlay, but there's damned little chance that the user is going to be paying taxes back to the government.&nbsp

column1: The big difference now is that there's a chasm between our words and sensibilities, and the reality of our policy actions.
column2: As costs have risen far above even medical care costs, Catherine Rampell of the NY Times is correct that a significant portion of the cost has been shifted from the public to the individual family and student by dint of state budget cutbacks through the past twenty years.
column3: According to the national group, the State Higher Education Executive Officers, the average state budget's contribution per Full Time Enrollment dropped in 2010 to a level last seen in 1980, adjusted to constant dollars for inflation.
column4: The Reagan Revolution coincided with the move to the &quot
column5: knowledge based economy&quot
column6: so that when there was an increased need for higher education, we began to push the full financial demands onto the family and the youth
column7: we forgot that government does exist to help provide certain functions for society and the nation.

column1: It still makes sense to pursue higher education, but not in the manner that of the Boomer generation.
column2: The presence of a sheepskin isn't an automatic guarantee of success&nbsp
column3: but the educational bar has been permanently raised so that it's more necessary than ever so greater care must be taken to craft a plan that meets the need at the minimum cost and with the minimum debt.&nbsp
column4: Parents have to truly begin paying attention to the issue and take a greater role in helping their kids determine their best route
column5: it's irritating to read about college graduates who complain that they've come out with a degree in Art History and $100,000 in debt.&nbsp
column6: Either they simply chose to ignore what was said or the parents had simply checked out, thinking that&nbsp
column7: after high school, they were officially adults and now officially left to their own devices.

column1: The phrase making sense is now qualified and no longer a blanket phrase.
column2: We have to once again focus our attention on the kids as we did when they were much younger and required greater effort.&nbsp
column3: What are their interests and skill sets?&nbsp
column4: What is their maturity level and should they spend a few more years at home now in order to avoid having to boomerang later?&nbsp
column5: What plan works best for them?&nbsp
column6: They should answer these questions, but it's up to us to ask the questions in the first place.&nbsp
column7:
Only when we've gone to the effort and through the process will we know if a higher education makes sense.

column1:
586,"1","1",,"xhtml","

We've now had about a generation's worth of helicopter parents, hovering over their children from the toddler years and in some cases, even into the workforce.
column2: A local hospital, at which a close friend works, even had a seminar for managers about how to relate to the new generation of employees
column3: her response was less than lukewarm.&nbsp
column4: But the meme is changing and more adults are questioning how helpful this approach has been, especially in light of the changes rippling through the national economy.&nbsp
column5: Paul Tough recently published <a title=""Amazon.com"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/How-Children-Succeed-Curiosity-Character/dp/0547564651/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp
column6: ie=UTF8&amp
column8: sr=1-1&amp
column9: keywords=how+kids+succeed"">How Children Succeed: Grit, Curiosity, and the Hidden Power of Character, which probes whether high grades are sufficient in and of themselves for success or whether a child's grit and character are more important.
column10: The key term in his title is grit, which we can define as the ability to persist through a difficult situation or circumstance.
column11: In a future in which livelihoods are likely to be more hardscrabble and financial freedom more difficult to attain than before, grit is indeed likely to be key.&nbsp
column12: But how do we help our children develop this particular character trait?

column1: Our society is full of examples of people who've overcome to achieve success.
column2: In a recent interview with Time magazine, Dwayne Wade was asked whether his upbringing in a challenging environment contributed to his resilience
column3: he responded that <em>I give a lot of credit to my upbringing in Chicago.&nbsp
column4: It taught me to be tough, to want more, to want to be better.&nbsp
column5: It made me appreciate things.
column6: But does that mean that our kids have to go through difficult childhoods in order to develop resilience?&nbsp
column7: What does that mean for parents who work assiduously to assure that their kids don't encounter the inner-city life that claims far more youth than produces successful survivors like Wade?

column1: Grit and resilience are - at a basic level - simply components of a person's natural character
column2: there are some who have the ability to persist in spades while there are&nbsp
column3: a few&nbsp
column4: who are simply so fragile that it doesn't exist.&nbsp
column5: My own sense is that it's akin to a bell curve with the majority possessing it in some degree, waiting to be brought out and developed by upbringing and life.&nbsp
column6: Unless our children encounter truly difficult circumstances in their youth, we can never know exactly how they respond when life forces them to that truly dark place that almost all of us will encounter in our lifetime.&nbsp
column7: Until then, all that we can do is assess what we do see every day and try to instill and teach that which does reinforce grit and resilience.&nbsp
column8: But what are some of those things that we can do?

column1: First, understand that our kids are watching us and learning from us in everything that we do.
column2: Our attitudes and behaviors, our responses and opinions all are being sopped up even though we aren't aware of it in the moment.&nbsp
column3: How am I acting when things don't go my way and what do I say?&nbsp
column4: In my childhood, the response to most difficulties was a shrug and the phrase you'll have this
column5: when I once asked my father - a Korean War veteran - how he could be so calm, his response was since there aren't half a million Chinese shooting at me, it's really not that bad.
column6: This isn't to say that there weren't&nbsp
column7: and aren't going to be profanities when things screw up, but things go on.&nbsp

column1: Second, don't be afraid to tell your children no.
column2: The earlier that they learn that things aren't always to go their way, even little things, the more resilient they're likely to be when a big thing doesn't go their way.&nbsp

column1: Third, don't be afraid to let the kids struggle.
column2: If she brings you homework for assistance, work hard - and it can be work - to assure that you're only assisting and not actually doing the work for her.&nbsp
column3: In moments when sloughing off occurs, send her away despite her protests.&nbsp
column4: If she returns with a different attitude, then work with her and if not, let her suffer consequences.&nbsp
column5: This even goes beyond schoolwork.&nbsp
column6: When Youngest was three years old, I took him to a playarea and he was pushed down by an older child, who was being watched by his own mother.&nbsp
column7: Youngest got up and continued playing and was then pushed down again by the same child.&nbsp
column8: He looked at me and noted that while watching, I wasn't moving
column9: I was honestly curious as to what would happen and had decided that if occurred a third time, I would intercede.&nbsp
column10: The third time happened and just as I got up to go over to speak to the bully's mother, Youngest arose, walked over and punched him in the face.&nbsp
column11: The bully returned to his mother, I returned to my seat and Youngest returned to play.&nbsp

column1: Fourth, understand that whining and kvetching by children isn't a sign that they won't be resilient during tough times.
column2: Almost all children whine to one degree or another and this is a function of inexperience.&nbsp
column3: They don't yet understand how to process frustration, so it comes out verbally.&nbsp
column4: They don't yet understand that their parents can't or won't always intercede on their behalf so that their complaints are useless.&nbsp
column5: They don't have the experience of other difficulties against to which they can compare their present issue.&nbsp
column6: A splinter is painful, but they've not yet encountered the longer term pain of broken bones, muscle pulls and other ailments.&nbsp
column7: Whining, while mind-numbingly irritating in the moment, generally resolves with time and isn't necessarily an indication that the child will fold.

column2: If school work isn't turned in, let the grades suffer and if necessary, even impose consequences of your own.&nbsp
column3: If the child makes a poor choice with their spending money, don't intercede to pay for what they really want when they've blown the money on something else.&nbsp
column4: Watching him suffer consequences can be a painful experience for a parent but it serves as an object lesson that Dad isn't going to always shield him from the repercussions of his (in)actions.

column1: Developing character isn't a one-off event, but instead a lengthy process.
column2: It can be fraught with frustration and angst along with quiet conversation and praise.&nbsp
column3: Surprisingly, I'm also learning that even with Eldest now in college, that character development is still occurring so my wife and I aren't off of the hook.&nbsp
column4: There are certainly other things that might occur to you to foster resilience in your children, especially since they're often so different in personality and circumstance
column5:
just stay the course and continue to work at it and hopefully, their dark place won't swallow them when they meet it.

column1:
587,"1","1",,"xhtml","

One of the questions with which I wrestle is about when and how to introduce the kids into the real world, the world in which we have to make choices and our dreams don't always come true.
column2: This is especially relevant in light of the ongoing conversation about whether a college degree is worth the money that's going to be spent obtaining it. &nbsp
column3: &nbsp

column1: We'd been talking about Eldest's experiences thus far in college, including playing soccer.
column2: Youngest looked at me and asked Dad, can I major in baseball? since he loves the sport and has aspirations of a pro career.
column3: It was during the following conversation that he now understood that while she played for love of the game, her college studies didn't involve soccer but were geared towards something else entirely.&nbsp
column4: He also learned the words vocation and avocation
column5: the former pertaining to what one does for a living and the other to what one does for enjoyment and love. As he learned, they can sometimes be one and the same but more often than not, they're different.&nbsp
column6: Youngest cocked his head and nodded, silent for a moment.&nbsp
column7: In that interval, I told him that he could certainly play baseball in college if he wanted - and was good enough - but that the course of study would most likely be different.&nbsp
column8: He leaned back against the kitchen counter and then inquired whether he could study to be a history teacher instead.&nbsp

column1: Damn, I thought, another career with lousy job prospects.
column2: My response was a - hopefully - encouraging <em>sure, if that's what you really want and are good at it.&nbsp
column3: I don't see why you couldn't take that route, but I wouldn't worry about it now since there's still plenty of time before college.&nbsp

column1: When to begin these conversations is a matter of personal choice, although we've held off on the conversations until middle school
column2: this is the point at which&nbsp
column3: our local school system begins to have kids look towards the future by engaging in career shadowing.&nbsp
column4: If the&nbsp
column5: kids have to start looking at potential careers, then it's a logical starting point for household conversations.&nbsp
column6: When Eldest talked about becoming a marine biologist, our family conversations veered towards what courses might be involved and what schools offered the degree.&nbsp
column7: Where were they located and did they mesh with the type of college environment that she'd thought would be a good fit for her personality?&nbsp
column8: Did the career require solely a bachelor's degree or was she looking at further graduate work to become a viably employable biologist?&nbsp
column9: Was this a career that would permit her to move or would she be restricted to certain geographic areas?&nbsp
column10: Could we get her through with minimal or no debt?&nbsp
column11: I offered my own trenchant question:&nbsp
column12: <em>If you're asking me to remove your dead pet hermit crab because it's gross, is this the career for you?&nbsp
column13: The point is to probe and engage, discuss and explore options and questions with them until they're more clear on what's involved.

column1: While I'd thought that the school system was an ally in educating your child - and in most ways it is - I've come to learn that there are instances when the system automatically slots kids into prearranged tracks that really aren't appropriate for them.
column2: Don't just assume that the system is the expert in your child's best interest and don't be afraid to buck it if necessary.&nbsp
column3: The great majority of secondary schools have tracks for students broken into three segments:&nbsp
column4: Career Prep (for those not deemed ready or able to attend college)
column5: College Prep
column6: Honors (for more advanced study).&nbsp
column7: Based upon grades and teacher/counselor assessments, your kid will be matched to a level that ultimately leads to a certain conclusion.&nbsp
column8: During a baseball practice several weeks ago, I chatted with a mother whose older son was presently in the local high school.&nbsp
column9: This student, a Junior, was intellectually advanced and the school counselor was strongly that he take both Advanced Placement Physics and Advanced Placement Calculus, courses that would prepare him for a career in science and engineering after attaining a college degree.&nbsp
column10: But they were balking at the placement as the boy's interest was in becoming a heavy engine diesel mechanic and he was gifted with an ability to understand the practical workings.&nbsp
column11: As she said, <em>Why should we prepare him for college when his skills are outside of that?&nbsp
column12: Why take on all of that debt when the degree will have no bearing on his employment?&nbsp
column13: The final remark saddened me as much as I'm sure it did her:
column14: <em>We're making it paycheck to paycheck and he's probably going to have to work the same way that we do.&nbsp
column15: The student debt will just make it worse.&nbsp

column1: That comment is a microcosm of what all of us fear as parents.
In the summer of 2011, we took a family vacation to Europe - a trip for which we saved for several years.
column2: On our first day in Rome, we took a guided tour of the catacombs and surprisingly, our guide was a young American expatriate who'd come to Rome in search of work.&nbsp
column3: His degree was in Western Civilization and saddled with student debt and unable to get a job here, he'd taken what amounted to a desperate, courageous gamble by putting that education to use as a guide in the cradle of Renaissance civilization, Italy.&nbsp
column4: One of his comments in our conversations actually haunts me:&nbsp
column5: <em> I wish that someone had told me that I couldn't get a job with a degree in Western Civ.&nbsp
column6: No parent wants to potentially shatter a child's dream by pointing out the pitfalls and practicability of a career option.
column7: But keeping silent or leaving the route to someone else can shatter the dream with a burdensome debt that can take decades to satisfy.&nbsp

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
589,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Jimmy Fallon understands that kids are funny and many of his commercials demonstrate this as he plays foil to toddlers and infants.
column2: But while his new show, Guys With Kids, ostensibly pertains to kids, the humor comes from exploring the changing and new frontiers of fatherhood.
column3: Some reviewers find nothing funny about the show but as a guy who's spent years on the cutting edge of bending gender roles, it's also spot on in touching upon some of the issues facing men who now take an active father role.

column1: Each of the three main characters, all close friends, is representative of a different fatherhood model - the traditional working father (Zach Creggar as Nick), divorced with joint custody (Jesse Bradford as Chris) and homemaker father (Anthony Anderson as Gary).
column2: This trio is part of a new generation of television fathers, akin to NBC's Parenthood, who take an active, involved and hands-on role in the care and raising of their children.
column3: Humor aside, how does this particular program do a decent job of examining what men face and how things are changing?

column1: They actively incorporate the kids into their daily lives.
column2: It's jarring to see dads take their babies into a sports bar, but they want to maintain their friendship and instead of having to find sitters so that they can gather separately, they take the kids along with them.&nbsp
column3: There's an acknowledgement that fatherhood isn't compartmentalized into one facet of a man's life, but instead permeates it so that if the other guys have kids, they just bring them along as well.&nbsp
column4: In previous eras, the kids would be at home with the mother or the babysitter while the guys gather but with men taking a larger role, they adapt accordingly to make it work.

column1: Does Mother automatically know best by dint of childbirth?
column2: The divorced dad contends with a sense of parental inferiority when his concerns and opinions are undercut by his ex-wife's rote response of grew inside me to any disagreement that they might have about the baby.&nbsp
column3: The explosion in the divorce rate in the 1970s left many fathers out in the proverbial cold as the legal system simply adopted the credo that mother knows best in terms of the well-being and care of the child and realistically, the typical father back then wasn't clued into the daily issues of childcare and raising kids.&nbsp
column4: But two generations of fatherhood advocates have argued that men are capable of effectively and lovingly raising children and the actions of a new generation of fathers - many of whom have the insight of having been a child of divorce - have taken the opportunity to heart and the court system has begun reassessing whether custody questions should be determined solely by gender.

column1: While I do believe that there's such a thing as maternal intuition, I
column2: think that it's partially a function of having spent so much time around the children that a feel is developed for what's occurring.&nbsp
column3: Years ago, I spoke with a new mother who admitted that when her husband asked her a question about the baby, she responded that she was also new to the baby experience
column4: that fact that she had given birth to a baby didn't necessarily make her an immediate expert on what was best in the moment.&nbsp
column5: The key difference is that there's a broad and deep support network for new mothers, a huge sisterhood of maternal mentors that really doesn't exist for new fathers.&nbsp
column6: Likewise, the media is constantly churning out a supply of new and/or reissued materials for the mother.&nbsp
column7: But even this network breaks down, as evidenced by the existence of lactation consultants
column8: this subspecialty would never have come into existence had two generations of mothers not bought into the Madison Avenue schtick that mother's milk wasn't as good as manufactured formula.&nbsp
column9: When the medical evidence conclusively showed that nursing benefits outweighed that of formula, literally an entire generation of mothers had no clue how to nurse and even their mothers couldn't help them because they themselves didn't know how to nurse.

column2: There's a common image of a frazzled housewife with small children, chronically ill-tempered and a wee bit squirrelly with the kids all around them.&nbsp
column3: Bill Cosby did a terrific routine on the changes in his beloved wife when she encountered doofus husband feeding the kids cake for breakfast and her response to this ridiculous situation.&nbsp
column4: The upshot through the years is the perception that these changes and images are largely common to women by dint of being...women.&nbsp
column5: But the reality is that spending all of your time in the homemaker role is what makes the person change, regardless of the gender.&nbsp
column6: I speak from experience and truly laughed aloud when Gary, the stay-at-home dad, commiserated with Nick's wife - also a stay-at-home mom - about what the working mates don't realize.&nbsp
column7: Yes, they dished and I've been in the same situation where a group of us sit and share war stories.&nbsp
column8: The effect upon a father, tasked with cleaning up after and raising multiple children, will likewise make him cranky and a bit forgetful.

column2: Both married fathers joke about enjoying &quot
column3: playing with&quot
column4: the divorced father's life, helping him meet new women
column5: they live vicariously through him.&nbsp
column6: It doesn't mean that they don't love their mates, but they recognize that the full-time responsibility of child-rearing and providing a roof means that the freedom that being single allowed is a thing of the past.&nbsp
column7: When you're responsible for the care and raising of children, even teens, you don't have the latitude that existed before their arrival.

column1: What has truly taken me aback however, has nothing to do with the show itself.
column2: As I took notes prior to beginning this article, I came across a television critic's review
column3: in which the reviewer described the three men as emasculated.&nbsp
column4: I actually watched the show again and nowhere in it do I find anything that would denote the three characters as being anything less than men.&nbsp
column5: Goofy, sometimes uncomfortable with their responsibilities?&nbsp
column6: Absolutely, since that's the nature of television and the situation in which many new fathers find themselves.&nbsp
column7: But as the show revolves around men being responsible and taking care of children, the nagging sense is that there's a belief that caring for the kids is emasculating and that men who step up to that role are less than real men.&nbsp
column8: I believe that there's nothing emasculating about the role but if the reviewer would like to see us return to the traditional masculine role, then we'll just go back&nbsp
column9: to leaving the kids unsupervised while the mothers are out working, and we'll see how that works out in another decade.

column2: I'd rather be a guy with kids.

If anything has caught my attention through the myriad articles about student debt, especially those with first-person stories, it's been the recurrent comment, I wish someone had told me...
• how much that I'd be paying each month...
• that I couldn't get a job with this degree...
<li><em>that I didn't need to attend a private college instead of a public university...&nbsp

column2: persistent thought was to wonder where in the hell the parent was.&nbsp
column3: These major financial and career decisions - with repercussions lasting for decades - are being made by teens with&nbsp
column4: no actual life experience.&nbsp
column5: The deeper questions beyond these however, are whether 18 and 19 year-olds are&nbsp
column6: adults and when we should&nbsp
column7: expect that our&nbsp
column8: offspring have reached adulthood.&nbsp

column2: More parents are finding that their kids are retreating back to the nests, or seem to be only treading water instead of swimming for the bright, distant horizon as they remember that they themselves did.&nbsp
column3: Our history is seemingly filled with examples of young people - adults - taking on the mantle of responsibility in any number of ways, whether in terms of career, marriage and family, or simply extraordinary acts of adventure and exploration.&nbsp
column4: Of course, our history is also littered with far more bodies than we seem to have today, as more died much earlier in life of accident or previously incurable disease.&nbsp
column5: <em>Cholera, it's what's for supper...&nbsp
column6: As much as we love our kids, after years of caring for and raising them, there's an expectation that life after a certain point will be more relaxed with less of the stress that comes with children and teenagers and there seems to be
column7: a degree of regret when they do return, both that they're unable to move outwards into
column8: a new life for themselves&nbsp
column9: and that we have to return to
column12: No offense to anyone reading this in their&nbsp

column1: To say that it was an academic question would imply that it was already
column2: settled&nbsp
column3: and it now appears that it isn't by any stretch of the imagination.&nbsp
column4: Through the mid 1990s, the credo was that adulthood was defined by certain specific life actions - marriage, setting up a household, leaving home for a new job, having a child.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: But a psychologist named&nbsp
column7: Jeffrey Arnett&nbsp
column8: did the unthinkable and actually interviewed approximately 300 young adults, all in their twenties.&nbsp
column11: was that adulthood wasn't a discrete location reached after passing identifiable waypoints, but that it was a process, fluid and imprecise with the interviewees responding that they often felt &quot
column13: adulthood and adolescence when presented with specific questions.&nbsp
column14: This new view has become known as emerging adulthood.
column15: The defenders of the other side - that adulthood was reached by the assumption of specific roles at completing certain life actions - maintain their stance and that there's no such thing as emerging adulthood
column16: instead, it continues to be the purpose of the adolescent/teen years to prepare the way to adulthood.&nbsp

column1: The literal question is whether there really is such a thing as emerging adulthood or are young people simply "
column2: stalled&quot
column4: and somehow unable to reach adulthood?&nbsp
column5: While I'm uncertain as to the answer myself, my own question is different:&nbsp
column6: <em> if they are indeed &quot
column7: stalled&quot
column8: , what's happening during the adolescent years that's no longer preparing them for adulthood as with previous generations?

column1: Certainly one of the biggest differences is that so many more of our children are living in single-parent families.
column2: We've gone through about two generations since the divorce rate exploded in the 1970s and there's certainly an impact that arises from growing up as a child of a split family,&nbsp
column3: most especially when the father figure is absent.&nbsp
column4: The obvious difficulty for the children is that the mother, who routinely got custody, was stretched like taffy as she had to both provide a roof over the head as well as parent and keep the house in a semblance of running order.&nbsp
column5: I don't believe that it's a generalization to state that by nature, the mother has historically been oriented inwards to the family with an attention to detail and sensitivity that keeps the household and family in order.&nbsp
column6: Conversely, the father was the parent who directed his attention outwards in order to help provide food, shelter and protection for the family.&nbsp
column7: It was by watching the father that children learned best how to respond to the challenges provided by the outside world, and who made them feel most secure from its real and perceived dangers.&nbsp
column8: When the father was removed - and the mother had to stretch to cover the difference - a significant minority of children suffered a loss and were consequently hampered in learning what a father could teach.&nbsp
column9: Their collective ability was eroded and coupled with the continuing numbers of children affected by divorce, the cumulative erosion to what children could learn from a good father was deep and significant.&nbsp
column10: This isn't to say that all fathers are great models of how to respond to and interact with the outside world, but there's been a significant cumulative erosion through two generations.

column1: Even with this erosion across more than one generation, today's generation is one which
column2: we've permitted them to insulate themselves from the outside world by cocooning within electronics.&nbsp
column3: With kids today now spending more than six hours daily in front of some form of electonic screen - not counting the time tethered to an mp3 of iPod - they're spending time alone and physically disconnected from the human interaction that they need for learning to live in the real world.&nbsp
column4: They readily inhabit a virtual reality in which they're connecting with all manner of people who create an online avatar that's often nothing like their physical reality.&nbsp
column5: Even for someone who's worked through the&nbsp
column6: years to keep the electronics under control, the pull is insidious.&nbsp
column7: The result is that we have individuals who thrive in a virtual reality but are wholly unprepared for the harsher physical reality
column8: this is especially the case for young people who are now having to work for older people who have far more and greater experience in this world.

column1: This leads to the fact that our society is a far more complex place with greater demands than in previous decades and generations.
column2: While younger people are more comfortable with the personal technology than older people, the country runs on more complex structures than in the past.&nbsp
column3: There's a greater interconnectedness amongst the questions and issues facing&nbsp
column4: us that requires attention, effort and critical thinking to understand.&nbsp
column5: When you're spending your time paying greater attention to the screens than the world around you, you're at a huge disadvantage to someone who has paid attention.&nbsp
column6: With the Occupy movement seemingly comatose after only a year of existence, its detractors dissect it and criticize the apparent naivete and hamhandedness with which it functioned.&nbsp
column7: My thought throughout its existence was that it was akin to the political baby steps of a new generation having to learn to walk and function all the while being pushed about in the midst of a riot.&nbsp
column8: <em>No shit they're disjointed and a bit goofy, they've finally unplugged and awakened to the political and social reality and are thrashing about.&nbsp
column9: It's like watching Neo being unplugged and flushed from the Matrix cocoon.&nbsp

column1: We've created an economic system predicated upon consumption, much of it increasingly mindless.
column2: &nbsp
column3: Research has been done in improving advertising and driving the typical consumer into a decision that's collectively good for the system, but bad for the individual.&nbsp
column4: More is better, so supersize it...housing values only go up...go ahead and take on the college debt, it's a good debt and an investment in yourself...If you're a young person who's been heavily tied into the electronic world, not paying attention to what's occurring around you and there's no one trying to take the time to explain this to you, then you're fodder for the system until you suffer enough damage that you're forced to critically
column5: re-examine and&nbsp
column6: figure it out for yourself.&nbsp
column7: The flip side to this is that our consumption shortsightedness has sent a large chunk of our livable wage jobs overseas
column8: there aren't the requisite jobs around anymore that will support the debt that's incurred on behalf of the system.&nbsp

column1: Let's face it, it's hard to feel like an adult when the economic circumstances of debt and livelihood prevent or slow those steps that mark the supposed waypoints into traditional adulthood.
column2: Likewise, it's hard to feel like an adult when there's no one older to tell you that uncertainty and fear don't depart just because you're now considered an adult.
column3: That continues and you simply learn to harness it.

column1: I do understand how you can feel "
column2: in-between&quot
column3: adulthood and adolescence.&nbsp
column4: My college graduation occurred in the midst of a severe recession and my job-search efforts only resulted in a huge stack of rejection letters that festered in a desk drawer
column5: when a friend came by one day to grouse that his B in Accounting was screwing up the GPA, I simply pulled the stack out and tossed it in front of him, telling him to shut up and get the hell out of here.
column6: My first year or more out of college was spent back living in my old bedroom, working at a job that barely paid enough to allow me to live at home on the highly reduced rent that my parents charged me, what my father jokingly referred to as Section Dad Housing.
column7: I now had the responsibilities that came with a job but wasn't able to take on the other aspects of adulthood, living on my own and setting my own rules and boundaries, exploring the freedom that ostensibly came with true adulthood.&nbsp
column8: But those were feelings and that didn't mean that I didn't continue the adult route of working at the job and continuing to search for a job and career that would permit me to be fully responsible for myself, my actions and decisions.&nbsp
column9: Conversations with both of my parents&nbsp
column10: taught me that uncertainty, nervousness and fear don't just go away because you're the adult
column11: what changes is how you have to respond to them and handle them.&nbsp
column12: To hear your 60 year old father admit uncertainty in the face of job and career change is highly instructive.&nbsp

column1: The upshot from my vantagepoint is that today's typical 18 year old isn't an adult, but is as Eldest's college dean described, an adult-in-training.
column2: It will be our job to engage in the delicate, mistake-prone shift from guardians to - hopefully - good friends as she takes on her own decisions and grows in her own ability to handle her responsibilities.&nbsp
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
Meet the Teacher&quot
column3: night at the beginning of the school year and ours occurred two weeks ago.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: The purpose of these events is an opportunity for parents to meet the teachers and put a face to a name on the schedule.&nbsp
column6: It's also there for teachers to provide parents and guardians with a background on some of what's upcoming during the year
column7: the curriculum that's being used and what their expectations are for the students.&nbsp
column8: This in and of itself is refreshing since there's typically a gaping disconnect between what the kids report and the reality of things.&nbsp
column9: At our district, the elementary events are scheduled in the late afternoon through early evening with a short interval until the beginning of the high school event, a courtesy extended to parents with kids at both levels.

column1: I raced from Youngest's event at one school to Middle's event at the other and while missing the Principal's opening remarks at the latter, I made it to Middle's
column2: First Block class in time to get the appropriate paperwork and hear the teacher.&nbsp
column3: What struck me at this session - and through later sessions with other teachers - was the verbal kudos given by the teachers for taking the time from our busy schedules to attend.&nbsp
column4: While not every teacher mentioned it, I heard it more than once that evening and I'd lay odds that the Principal said something similar in his remarks.&nbsp
column5: <em>You're giving me kudos for attending Meet the Teacher night?&nbsp
column6: Seriously?&nbsp
column7: While there are some who deserve such because they've had to miss second shift work, they're in the minority.
column8: The rest of us are there because it's in our best interests as parents and taxpayers to get a gander at what's in store for the year with our kids
column9: indeed, it's my expectation to attend unless death or distance keeps me otherwise occupied.&nbsp

column1: We live in a district where the parents apparently do give a damn since the parking lot at both schools was full and parents and grandparents flooded the hallways between sessions.
column2: &nbsp
column3: But even then, it was jarring to think that&nbsp
column4: the educators felt it important to recognize us for something that's as necessary and part of our parental responsibilities as coming to meet the teachers.&nbsp
column5: Parents have basic elemental responsibilities for the kids - food, shelter, clothing and assuring an education.&nbsp
column6: While we don't homeschool the kids, we still have to assure that things are proceeding apace and these sessions are part and parcel of providing that responsibility.&nbsp
column7: Parents shouldn't be so dumbed down and out of touch that we have to receive strokes for&nbsp
column8:
something as simple as attending a Meet the Teacher event and I can only wonder, what's being said amongst the educational community that educators need to praise us for something so simple.
