The shirt somehow came into the house, probably on the back or in the gym bag of one of the plethora of kids that visit or spend the night and typically, wound up in the hamper.
column2: It was a grey t-shirt with large orange block letters exclaiming Just Do It and after washing, went into Youngest's dresser drawer
column3: it was&nbsp
column4: his size and while I didn't recognize it, I put it there just so that it had a place and wouldn't wind up in yet another of the piles of stuff that litters the household.&nbsp
column5: My thought was that I'd figure out the owner later when some of the guys wound up here.&nbsp
column6: But when Youngest came down for breakfast before school the other morning, he was wearing the shirt.&nbsp
column7: I looked at it and then the clock as he'd pushed the time to the limit before having to scoot for the bus.&nbsp
column8: It wasn't one that we considered school appropriate but it was an instance that I decided to let slide with a warning, just so you know, that shirt isn't returning to school after today.
column9: He glanced at me and asked why he couldn't wear it and in that moment, I had to stop and think carefully before responding, mindful of the time and yet still wanting to give him a coherent answer.

column1: Bill Cosby has mined a huge amount of material from his kids and the brief comment that stays with me about children is the
column2: question and response, <em>Why is there air?&nbsp
column3: To blow up basketballs.
column4: The core of the response is that kids are curious and want an answer, but they don't have the attention span and will tune out the response until they get a bit older, so you'd better keep it short.&nbsp
column5: When to start going into greater depth is dependent upon your sense of the kid and the circumstances.&nbsp
column6: He was curious,&nbsp
column7: without attitude and there was enough to get a decent response without a curt because I said so.
column8: I asked him to wait a moment while thinking about a decent answer
column9: <em>you know how much money corporations make, and that you've heard me say that they have too much power, right?&nbsp
column10: It bothers me that we pay money for the shirts with these taglines that give them free advertising on top of the money that we've already spent.&nbsp
column11: It winds up giving them even more money and makes us nothing more than another tool.

column1: He cocked his head in that way of his and then asked, well what about Under Armour?
column2: They have their logo on their shirts and even on my cleats.&nbsp
column3: Do I have to give up the cleats?

column2: <em>I don't have a problem with a logo by itself...almost everything has a logo and that's all part of advertising.&nbsp
column3: But when it's so huge and obviously just an ad for their tag line, then I think that we can do without it.&nbsp
column4: At some point you say enough and that shirt is past that point.
column5: I considered having him go upstairs to change it after the comment, but the exchange was so measured and without angst that I figured that one day would be fine
column6: the shirt would simply never make it back from the next load of wash.&nbsp
column7: Youngest nodded and went back to finishing off breakfast and afterwards, the shirt went on its sole trip to school.

column1: There have been plenty of times when the situation hasn't worked, either because the kids resisted the request which made for a problematic civil conversation or because I couldn't find the right words to get the point across.
column2: But when it works, it can be a beautiful thing for the brevity and effect and with younger kids, brevity is better.&nbsp
column3: When it came time that evening for baseball practice, I glanced at Youngest's cleats.&nbsp
column4: Under Armour makes cleats?

The PracticalDad market basket of 47 grocery store items was taken and calculated today, with two years of consistent pricing now under the belt.
column2: There's been much speculation about what will occur to prices once the Federal Reserve's next round of Quantitative Easing - the third to date - works through the economy and while everyone has an opinion, the data from the basket shows that while the Total PracticalDad Marketbasket Index decreased by more than a full basis point to 106.42 (from 107.50), the Food-only segment of the basket rose slightly from September's 111.67 to 111.80
column3: this is an increase in the food-only segment of 11.8% since the index's inception in November 2010.

column1: A grocery market basket of 47 items - of which ten of those are not edible food products - is admittedly a tiny sample of the thousands of items available in the standard grocery store.
column2: But&nbsp
column3: having been the family shopper and cook&nbsp
column4: for years, I believe that it's an accurate microcosm of the typical family's essential shopping list, stripped down to what a typical family trying to make ends meet would purchase.&nbsp
column5: Given the uncertainty over the monetary policy actions, especially as it pertains to food, I've begun to track the spread between the two index values with the thought that it would be, while only a datapoint, indicative of the impact of easy money upon foodstuffs.&nbsp
column6: After all, we can cut back on non-essentials such as books and trips, but our ability to cut back on basic foodstuffs is limited.&nbsp
column7: Unless of course, we plan to starve.

column1: One of the best comments that I've ever read about inflation in light of present monetary policy was posted by "
column2: Dryfly&quot
column3: , a commenter on www.calculatedriskblog.com.
column4: Several years ago, he wrote that we'll probably see deflation in what we want and inflation in what we need
column5: declining incomes will force us to cut back on non-essential purchases while the exceptionally loose monetary policies will force prices upwards on our essentials, especially food.&nbsp
column6: The non-essential cutbacks will cause manufacturers to keep a lid on their pricing, while the food and commodity producers will be able to - within reason - pass these through to the consumer.&nbsp
column7: It might not be perfect, but I think that the spread will serve as&nbsp
column8: a reasonable indicator of the effect of monetary policy upon prices, especially the essentials versus the non-essentials.&nbsp

column1:
Expect to see the spread each month as we move forward.

column2: stealth&quot
column3: inflation and to what extent does it hide the real effect of price increases to the consumer?

column1: People who do the family shopping can tell when things have obviously gone up in price, a pound of hamburger being a classic example.
column2: But there are instances when the shopper will look at something and suddenly wonder if the package - the container itself and not the design - is different.&nbsp
column3: The sense is occasionally akin to seeing something out of the corner of your eye and wondering whether that actually occurred or if you imagined it.&nbsp
column4: What is now referred to as &quot
column5: stealth&quot
column6: inflation is when a manufacturer alters the package size in order to minimize the price increases that are being&nbsp
column7: passed on to the consumer
column8: if you know that too large a rise in price will cause the consumer to shift elsewhere, you simply pass through a smaller increase and quietly cut the package size so that less is being sold per package.&nbsp
column9: The net effect is a nominal price decrease - or no change - on the package but a slight increase in the package's profit per unit (ounce, for example).

column1: The real impact of stealth inflation is that the true price that people pay is understated by an unknown amount.
column2: The sticker for the item sold might say $1, but in reality,&nbsp
column3: the consumer has to pay $1.10 for the same amount than was purchased before.&nbsp

column1: With questions about how the monetary policies of the Federal Reserve - Quantitative Easing and ZIRP - affect the economy and whether they would ultimately fuel inflation, I created the PracticalDad Price Index in the Fall of 2010.
column2: The index consists of 47 separate items commonly available in the grocery store and each is for the less expensive store brand, unless there was no generic equivalent available at any of the three unrelated supermarkets.&nbsp
column3: The philosophic premise behind the basket is that it's composed of common grocery items that would be purchased by a cost-conscious parent, trying to make ends meet on a simple monthly budget
column4: it doesn't presume to be the full quantity of food that would be purchased by a family of X members for a month but only the type of common item that a family would purchase.&nbsp

column1: The key to running a price index is consistency.
column2: Not only must you track the specific kind of item, but you also have to keep tabs on the packaging size as well.&nbsp
column3: Comparing one size can in a store to another size in a different store is an apples to oranges comparison and thus useless
column4: in the case of the index's ice cream entry, one store's generic container was different from the others and I was forced to price on a unit (per quart) level.&nbsp
column5: The problem with pricing on a unit level is that it becomes impossible to account for stealth inflation and that was one of the factors that I wanted to track.&nbsp
column6: Over the two years, when I've noted instances of stealth inflation via packaging, I've adjusted the item's price to what it would be for the original container size.&nbsp
column7: For example, all the grocery stores in November sold store brand coffee in 13 ounce containers.&nbsp
column8: When a store began to sell in 11 ounce containers, I converted the new price for the 11 ounce container back to an equivalent amount for the original 13 ounce container.&nbsp

column2: Store A sold coffee at $3.50 in a 13 ounce container.&nbsp
column3: The next month, it sells coffee for $3.40 - a nominal price decrease - but the container is now 11 ounces.&nbsp
column4: Recalculating for the change [($3.40/11)*13] yields an equivalent price of $4.02 for a 13 ounce can, were the coffee sold in the old container size of 13 ounces.&nbsp
column5: <em>Et Voila!&nbsp
column6: A nominal decline of 2.8% hides a real increase of 14.8%.

column1: The first pricing occurred in November, 2010
column2: with the full cost of the initial basket at $178.39, which became the index basis level of 100.&nbsp
column3: It wasn't until the Spring of 2012 that I considered the effects of policies upon food alone and apart from non-food items
column4: of the 47 items in the basket, ten are not food items per se, but grocery items such as soap, aluminum foil and ibuprofen.&nbsp
column5: I subsequently returned to the data and separated the ten non-food items from the remainder with the result that of the $178.39 spent on the entire basket, $89.14 was spent on food only.&nbsp
column6: This amount of $89.14 for November 2010 became the index basis level of 100 for food only.&nbsp
column7: Of the 47 items in the marketbasket, five items have undergone package decreases in the past two years, either in all of the stores (coffee, sugar and women's pads) or in at least one of the stores (orange juice and kidney beans).&nbsp
column8: Each of the items is recalculated to account for the stealth inflation.

column1: The results of the October 2012 - the 24th month of data collected -
column2: are presented below for both the Total Index and Food-only Index (November 2010 = 100).&nbsp
column3: The first column - &quot
column4: Actual&quot
column5: - is calculated for the Index and accounts for the impact of stealth inflation.&nbsp
column6: The second column - &quot
column7: Nominal&quot
column8: - lists the Index figures using the nominal prices on the grocery store shelves, without adjusting for the impact of stealth inflation.&nbsp

column1: In the Total Index, the nominal figure of 5.02 is a startling 28% [(6.42-5.02)/5.02] understatement while the Food-only Index is 16% understated [(11.8-10.17)/10.17].
column2: In fairness, the massive Total-Index understatement can be statistically attributed to the&nbsp
column3: oversized effect of the price activity of one item - specifically women's pads - in relation to the total dollar value of the basket.&nbsp
column4: The pads&nbsp
column5: have undergone large price declines in both nominal and real terms over the two year period and this has produced an outsized effect upon the basket.&nbsp
column6: But when this item is removed along with the remainder of the non-food products to leave only foodstuffs however, there is still a significant 16% differential between the nominal and the stealth-adjusted figures.

column2: &nbsp
column3: A great deal, both in terms of Fed policy and actual&nbsp
column4: government spending, is predicated upon the possession and use of accurate information.&nbsp
column5: If the information is badly misrepresented or skewed, then the policy actions will be correspondingly skewed.&nbsp
column6: The Fed and the government presently state that inflation, the core-CPI, is minimal and are pursuing policies intended to provoke an upshot of inflation.&nbsp
column7:
But is the price information that they're using accurate or are things percolating along even more than is reported?

If we're going to slowly dig our way out of our collective economic hole, we're going to have to make fundamental changes in our spending patterns, one of the principal aspects being a concentrated effort to buy local.
column2: &quot
column3: Local&quot
column4: is a general geographic term, definable by the type of product being sold and it's origin of manufacture.&nbsp
column5: But the more is better meme has become so entrenched in the national psyche that acting contrary to the meme can create significant internal conflict and cognitive dissonance.
column6: It might seem easy, but breaking the consumer programming can be harder than it appears and will take a conscious effort
column7: I experienced the&nbsp
column8: discomfort with a recent purchase for an upcoming child's birthday.

column1: Middle is in his mid-teens and at a stage in which he's now aware of his appearance.
column2: That however, is butting against the fact that he's probably not yet finished growing and I know that he'd like at least one more spurt so that he's officially taller than his old man.&nbsp
column3: He recently asked for clothing for his upcoming birthday and the reality is that what he had last winter is going to be too short when he pulls it out for this winter.&nbsp
column4: Knowing that the article&nbsp
column5: - he hasn't had the birthday yet and I know that at least one of his friends reads this for some odd reason - isn't going to be cheap, I began to shop accordingly.&nbsp
column6: My intent was to purchase the desired item, but one that was made in this country.&nbsp
column7: As I went shopping however, it became apparent that anything sold in any of the department stores was manufactured overseas, even if the headquarters were domiciled domestically.&nbsp
column8: Let's be frank, the goal is to push money to the worker and not to the management.&nbsp
column9: The next step was to shift to the internet, via UPromise.&nbsp
column10: This isn't a marketing shill, but if money is going to be spent online, I'd rather see a small segment come back to the college savings accounts.&nbsp
column11: What I learned however, was that the article is available from domestic manufacturers but at much - in this instance, twice as - greater prices.&nbsp
column12: Clothes shopping isn't well-suited to the internet and with all of the major retail outlets pushing foreign-made brands, I suspect that there isn't sufficient demand to allow the higher labor costs to be offset by higher volume sales.&nbsp

column1: The upshot was the classic putting your money where your mouth is scenario.
column2: There is a general amount that can be spent for the birthday and honestly, purchasing the domestic article would handily blow that budget out of the water.&nbsp
column3: As it is, the foreign made article available at the department store also pushes the budget but allows for the purchase of one or two smaller items.&nbsp
column4: As I stewed on the decision, the constantly reinforced more is better meme smacked me in the mental head and led to true cognitive dissonance:
column5: &nbsp
column6: birthday satisfaction&nbsp
column7: or common good?&nbsp

column1: With the end of the Second World War, there was a conscious
column2: decision by American business and the government to push much greater rates of consumer spending.&nbsp
column3: Both parties remembered how business spending collapsed during the Great Depression
column4: that was replaced by the new Keynesian philosophy of pushing government spending, which Roosevelt embraced in his first two terms in office.&nbsp
column5: But government spending exploded during the Second World War, driving business investment and spending and allowing the American economy to again reach full employment.&nbsp
column6: The Axis' defeat, and subsequent military downsizing, did leave the question of what would happen to the economy as government leaders believed in that quaint notion that the government's budget had to be balanced.&nbsp
column7: The drop in defense spending did lead to a recession just as millions of American men came home...what - or who - would take it's place?&nbsp
column8: Picture three players at a card table and two of them were working in tandem with a common strategy.&nbsp
column9: As the old axiom goes,<em> if you're at the table and don't know who the sucker is, it's you.&nbsp
column10: That third player was the American consumer, who wanted a better future after two decades of economic collapse and global war.

column1: Pent up demand was fed by the new instruments of television advertising and the soon-to-be created credit card and the horses were out of the gate.
column2: If you don't believe that the government was complicit with the business community, just look at all of the tax deductions available in the IRS tax code.&nbsp
column3: While everyone talks about the tax-deductibility of student debt and mortgage interest, most have forgotten that until its repeal in Reagan's 1986 Income Tax Revision Plan, the average person could also deduct their credit card interest payments from their federal income taxes.&nbsp
column4: It was during the early 1980s that the government decided it needed the tax revenue more than the public policy goal of building a consumerist society and the deduction ended
column5: the consumer mentality train was happily rolling onwards.

column1: But while the train was speeding down the tracks at this time, foreign competition increased.
column2: Remember how the Japanese were going to rule the world?&nbsp
column3: American corporations were losing market share and profit margin and corporations began to address at least the latter by shifting their production overseas.&nbsp
column4: Textiles left the south, shoes left New England and autos departed from Detroit.&nbsp
column5: If Americans wanted to purchase inexpensive consumer items, Walmart also began its historic and explosive growth, reimporting these departed items from far cheaper shores to an American consumer who didn't realize that the economic ground was shifting beneath his sneaker-clad feet.&nbsp
column6: The effect was that the corporate sector switched the track beneath this speeding train, changing it to a line that was now running on an incline while the American consumer was slowly running out of fuel.&nbsp
column7: A railroad coal car might look full when it starts, but it eventually runs out of the coal.&nbsp

column2: The train is running out of fuel and the management is telling us to shovel for all our worth, but the fuel is depleting.&nbsp
column3: We've become conditioned to shoveling despite the growing realization that the only way to make the train keep running is to go more slowly and do a better job of managing what we have.&nbsp

column1: Do I have to spend more than 96% of my disposable income in order to be happy?
column2: Will that thingymabob make me more satisfied?
column3: &nbsp
column4: It's a personal decision for each of us and I can now attest that breaking the mantra of six decades will require work and real readjustment of my priorities.&nbsp
column5: But it's one that we have to begin making now.&nbsp
column6: The economic future facing our children truly is going to be more constrained than what they have now and if they don't learn how to make more responsible choices from us while we're not completely over the barrel, then they'll be forced to contend with a cognitive dissonance that dwarves the discomfort which I faced.&nbsp

column1: So what happened with the present for Middle's upcoming birthday?
column2: The result was a &quot
column3: victory&quot
column4: for the personal budget over common good as I went with the sale and got the price differential.&nbsp
column5: But the dissonance is still there.&nbsp
column6: I'm annoyed with myself for not recognizing the size of the price differences and accounting for it up front.&nbsp
column7:
More importantly however, is the realization that there has to be purposeful conversation over the question of how much is enough? so that this little foray into globalization can have a different ending.

column1:
596,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The conversation has nagged at me for a week now.
column2: I was speaking with a mother who was also a high school English teacher and we chatted about teens and teaching.&nbsp
column3: As we spoke, she looked at me and commented that where we were failing was in preparing the kids for the practical aspects of life, such as keeping a checkbook and managing personal finance
column4: she's entirely correct in her assessment.&nbsp
column5: But she followed with another comment, that we aren't preparing them to be good consumers.
column6: It was shortly afterwards that the conversation fell victim to the press of dealing with our elementary school boys, but that particular comment has come back to me repeatedly since then.&nbsp

column1: We aren't preparing them to be good consumers?
column2: On the contrary, we've raised them to be great consumers.&nbsp
column3: We're doing a lousy job of being good post-consumers.&nbsp

column1: I understand the point that she was making in the context of the talk about personal finance.
column2: Our kids generally have a poor understanding of money and how to handle it, a function of&nbsp
column3: society's and parental inattention, as well as a purposeful effort to encourage consumerism.&nbsp
column4: How well do we live within our budget, save, keep track of our expenditures?&nbsp
column5: How do we maximize our money so that we're being the most efficient and effective with the funds that we have available?&nbsp
column6: But the choice of the word consumer, while not meaning that that's all that we are, is telling.
column7: We should teach our children how to be consumers...

column1: Shopping has become the manner of soothing our angst and alleviating our fears.
column2: George W. Bush completely lost me in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks when he stated that we shouldn't let ourselves be held hostage to terror, but that we should go out and shop despite the fear.&nbsp
column3: Seriously?&nbsp
column4: <em>When the going gets tough, the tough go shopping?&nbsp
column5: Some will say that it was just a poor choice of language, that shopping was a simple word denoting a wider spectrum of popular activities.
column6: But&nbsp
column7: I recall&nbsp
column8: no language about overt public sacrifice, about what we needed as a nation to give up to pull together in common cause for what occurred and that is telling.&nbsp
column9: Where is the language about our collective values?

column1: My sense is that we've fully given over to the material consumer programming pushed by the corporations, media and government to the exclusion of the non-material for life satisfaction.
column2: To consider this, let's look at QVC and religious affiliation as proxies&nbsp
column3: for material and non-material satisfaction respectively.&nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: QVC began as a fledgling entrepreneurial effort in 1986, two years after the start of HSN
column6: in the earlier years, before and after it overtook the older HSN, it enjoyed growth of over 12%.&nbsp
column7: By the first decade of this century, growth had dropped to the single digits and in 2011, corporate revenues rose about 6.4% from 2010.&nbsp
column8: When you look at the QVC&nbsp
column9: on-line age demographics, the largest segment is the boomer generation cohort of 55 - 64 years of age.
column10: It's followed by the 65 and over group and then by the second boomer cohort of 45 -54 year-olds.&nbsp
column11: The first and third age cohorts are the boomer generation in almost entirety, a generation nursed on the earliest precepts of consumerism, delivered via television and a truly flush economy.&nbsp
column12: The 65 and overs are perhaps the last wealthy generation that we're going to be seeing, a group that does recall the lean years of the Great Depression and Second World War.&nbsp
column13: Don't forget that the retirement assets of the boomers aren't where they should be, particularly for the younger boomers.

column1: On the other side of the ledger, take a look at religious affiliation, as recently viewed by Pew Research.
column2: Remember that this is a proxy for non-material values and not necessarily a cry that you had better get thee hence to a church.&nbsp
column3: What's notable in the survey is that the percentage of Americans who have no affiliation to any particular religion or denomination rose to fully 20% of the population
column4: the group taking the biggest hit was the staid mainline denominations (Lutheran, Methodist and the like) cohort.&nbsp
column5: But the telling story is again within the age groupings.&nbsp
column6: About 37% of the respondents within the 30 - 49 year-old cohort had no religious affiliation
column7: 35% of the respondents in the&nbsp
column8: 18 - 29 year-old cluster had no affiliation either.&nbsp
column9: In comparing the two proxies, it would appear that the parents - the&nbsp
column10: two largest QVC cohorts - were buying into the push for a consumer mentality and letting it overtake the other values historically handed down within the family.&nbsp
column11: It hasn't been put to the statistical test, but it does make a certain sense.

column2: for our children&nbsp
column3: however, is that the American consumer model is now dying.&nbsp
column4: Family incomes are dropping - by approximately $3000 since the start of the Obama Administration - and there's a record number of Americans now receiving food stamps.&nbsp
column5: You can argue that the &quot
column6: improvement&quot
column7: since the financial crisis of 2008 is purely a result of repeated episodes of Quantitiative Easing with the Federal Reserve tossing cash into the system like confetti at Mardi Gras.&nbsp
column8: Many living wage jobs have been shipped overseas and will only come home with lower labor costs, meaning less money for our families, who are still working on the consumption model.&nbsp
column9: We're simply now at the point at which we have to learn - and teach&nbsp
column10: our children - that the easy personal financial choices of the past six decades are an end.&nbsp
column11: We've now officially entered the Post-Consumer era of American History, when the choices are harder and the opportunities fewer.&nbsp
column12: If you have any question about the validity of that statement, consider QVC once again.&nbsp
column13: In March of 2012, QVC inked an agreement with China's national radio broadcasting group to begin a joint venture into tapping into China's burgeoning middle class as occurred here.
column14: The sights are likewise set on Brazil and India, two more members&nbsp
column15: of the so-called BRIC group of nations, as
column16: QVC joins the rest of the corporate flock&nbsp
column17: moving on to greener pastures after eating the local fields to the financial roots.&nbsp

column1: There's an awareness that our kids don't have a handle on personal financial management, and that's true.
column2: But looking at that technical side - the use of credit and balancing a checkbook - is missing the greater point.&nbsp
column3: It's akin to saying that we need to teach the youngsters better ways to manufacture buggy whips when every Tom, Dick and Harry is setting up an automobile manufacturing company.&nbsp
column4:
It's time to recognize where we are and move on accordingly.

599,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Pay attention to what's occurring around you and you notice that amongst all of the various

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column2: who should pay for a kid's higher education?
is well-settled at the elementary and secondary levels as each local school district is empowered to levy property taxes to pay for school.&nbsp
column3: The practice was allowed under the philosophy that it was in the public interest to educate the youngsters so that they could take a functioning role in society and not be a burden.&nbsp
column4: Some may argue about the technicalities - whether they were trained to be cogs in an industrial state and etc - but the premise remains, that they should have a basic level of knowledge in order to survive.&nbsp
column5: But what happens&nbsp
column6: after they reach an educational level at which they supposedly have the requisite tools and skills to support themselves?&nbsp
column7: This isn't an effort to take any particular stance - I'm still uncertain in my own mind - but is rather an attempt to help myself work through the issues.

column1: The first issue is, what exactly is the point of a higher education?
column2: If tens of thousands of dollars are spent on a degree, shouldn't you be certain why you're spending it?&nbsp
column3: There's a fascinating chart in Time Magazine's article on college, College is Dead, Long Live College, that fundamentally displays the disconnect between the educational establishment and the general public.
column4: A poll was taken of adults in the general population and college leaders asking each what is the most important reason to go to college?&nbsp
column5: The responses are startling in their disconnect and awareness of what's occurring in our society.&nbsp
column6: Fully 54% of the general population adults believe that the two principal functions of college are to gain skills/knowledge for a career and increase earnings power.&nbsp
column7: Fully 55% of the college leaders believe that the primary reasons for college are to learn to think critically and to become an informed citizen in a global society (although to be fair, 21% of the college establishment believes that earnings is a primary role as well).&nbsp
column8: Nevertheless, there is a massive disconnect between the product designed by the establishment and the product desired by the populace, yet the populace is being forced to purchase the product by their employer.&nbsp
column9: It's akin to knowing that you need a minivan for two kids but have to pay for a convertible because your employer mandates it.&nbsp
column10: So what if it doesn't work for you, buy it or else find a new job.

column1: The notion of teaching critical thinking itself demonstrates that the college establishment is out of touch with the reality of today's millenial generation.
column2: While critical thinking is crucial to real success, let alone an appreciation of&nbsp
column3: what life can offer, it's become a lost art for many high school students and graduates.&nbsp
column4: Critical thinking requires a sustained effort at questioning and then evaluating the information to determine what's actually happening.&nbsp
column5: It also involves a willingness to learn about the world around you and&nbsp
column6: explore connections between seemingly disparate elements to get to the true reality, not just the virtual.&nbsp
column7: But the educational establishment is finding that the capacity to think critically amongst this generation is lacking
column8: the article references <a title=""Amazon.com:  Academically Adrift"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/Academically-Adrift-Limited-Learning-Campuses/dp/B005YPIN32/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&amp
column12: keywords=academically+adrift"">Academically Adrift, which reported research showing that three full semesters of college had "
column15: impact on critical thinking, complex reasoning and writing skills...&quot
column17: As Jethro Gibbs would say, <em>gee, ya think DiNozzo?&nbsp
column18: Starting decades ago, we parents began to permit our children an increasing amount of time on screens of one kind or another until today's level at which the average teen spends more than six hours daily immersed in electronics.
column19: MTV, Youtube, Facebook and other forms of social media distract them from the real world and the constant flow of imagery and gab lends nothing to the development of critical thought.&nbsp
column20: If you want an eye-opening view of the world at least partially inhabited by many high school and college-aged kids, try reading Texts From Last Night
column21: for a glimpse that's simultaneously hilarious, mind-bending and ultimately depressing.&nbsp
column22: American society today is predicated upon avoiding any critical thought whatsoever, so good luck to the college establishment.

column1: The second issue is the sea change in
column2: our attitudes towards the&nbsp
column3: role of government since&nbsp
column4: Reagan's&nbsp
column5: (in)famous comment that &quot
column6: government is the problem, not the solution.&quot
column7: &nbsp
column8: That&nbsp
column11: the entire pendulum swing that's moved towards privatization of many formerly public services, including the prison system and now education.&nbsp
column13: Even though a significant portion of the population was never able to attend college until the mid&nbsp
column15: our nation deemed education to be of value
column18: the creation of colleges and universities - in the midst of the civil war
column19: - and then greased the skids to higher education for the masses with the passage of the GI Bill.&nbsp
column20: This belief in the practical and moral value of education led to increased spending through the &quot
column22: of the American economy, before the onset of these present structural changes.&nbsp
column23: But Reagan's efforts, like those of his fans such as Limbaugh and Hannity, have kept proponents of the public sector on the defensive since then.&nbsp
column24: What is the value of government and what is the role of government?&nbsp
column25: Apart from defense - and with private security like Blackwater, even that - what do we need the government for when&nbsp
column26: the private sector can handle things nicely?&nbsp
column27: And it's been that way with higher education as states attempt desperately to balance their budgets.&nbsp
column28: With ongoing commentary about wasteful spending and the need for individuals to take care of themselves, the politicians have taken a goodly share of funds from education, leaving it to the students and families to make up the difference.&nbsp

column1: Apart from decreasing funding for public education, the private sector has also moved into education in a major way with the creation of for-profit universities and on one level, that's fine.
column2: But why do they believe that they can make money at all when there are so many other institutions of higher learning?&nbsp
column3: If you look at the majority of the degree programs offered by the for-profits, they've read the cards well and moved nimbly into the skills areas for which they perceive demand, such as electronics, less technical health care training and of course, law enforcement certification programs.&nbsp
column4: There are two year programs galore that meet the population's push for jobs-related education.&nbsp
column5: But one of the other reasons that the for-profits have gained ground has been the availability of relatively lower interest student loans through the past decade, courtesy of the federal government.&nbsp
column6: With flush times, the money was available for education and the for-profits - Phoenix, Kaplan, etc - readily sold their programs to an increasingly larger number of people.&nbsp
column7: But the rear-view mirror shows something else.&nbsp
column8: The completion rate of the for-profits lagged far behind that of the non-profit institutions, only 32% versus 55% for all institutions, as far more students leave with unfinished degrees than their non-profit counterparts.
column9: Likewise, there have been significant fines for student recruitment practices as bonuses for admissions counselors were akin to the commissions for shady mortgage brokers who were paid for the number of loans that they were able to write.
column10: So once again, the availability of cheap money coupled with minimal oversight led to a corrupted educational process that served few well.

column1: The third issue is that more than a few parents have done as little critical thinking as their offspring.
column2: Folks likewise bought into the past several decades of consumerist behavior and again, fueled by cheap money and a persistent barrage to consume, found themselves suddenly unprepared for the loss of living wage jobs for themselves, let alone their kids.&nbsp
column3: Hearing the data trumpeted again and again that the degree was the entry to the new &quot
column4: knowledge based economy&quot
column5: - honestly, what economy isn't? - they simply panicked and pushed the kids through the institutions while piling on the debt for themselves and then, the kids.
column6: It's now apparent that the adults are unprepared for any meaningful retirement and are increasingly being pushed to no-benefit part-time employment
column7: even when the opportunity existed to save for college, it didn't happen and it's now, for the larger part, too late. &nbsp

column1: So how do we recreate or rejigger the system so that it again works?
column2: There are obviously no easy, one-size fits all solutions.&nbsp
column3: The macro solutions are about reordering our priorities and determining where we place both them and our money.&nbsp
column4: What do we owe our youngsters and in turn, what are our expectations of them?&nbsp
column5: I do believe that another aspect is that if government is going to be involved in the higher education process, then it has to do more than provide loans which have proven to create moral hazards.&nbsp
column6: We've decided, in more truly dire circumstances, to support education and I see no reason that we shouldn't reverse ourselves and put our backing there again.&nbsp

column1: On a personal level then, parents have to step up in a non-financial sense.
column2: The present reality is that traditional higher education is increasingly beyond the means of many American families.&nbsp
column3: But there should be no reason that a kid should say that she didn't know what it would cost to repay the loans or that she couldn't find meaningful employment with a Western Civ degree and it's up to us as parents to impart that information.&nbsp
column4: We must pay greater attention to the world around us and plan and act accordingly.&nbsp
column5: We must pay greater attention to our children and help them ascertain their skills and talents in a meaningful fashion.&nbsp
column6: We must be willing to help teach them think critically, first and foremost by kicking their butts off of the electronics and back into the real world, even if it means that we lose more of our own increasingly rare free time.&nbsp

Education is certainly different today from what I knew, and that's especially in terms of the technology.
column2: Elementary classrooms have Macs, the middle schoolers have classes in using&nbsp
column3: programs like Word and interested high schoolers can learn how to use Flash animation
column4: most of the local high school classrooms now use Smartboards
column5: that are frankly light years ahead of what I had.&nbsp
column6: But the schools - locally, the middle and high schools - also now have online programs that allow you to access all of Junior's grades on a real time basis
column7: at the middle school level, when the kids are literally the walking dead, there's also a program to keep the parents up to date on the daily assignments.&nbsp
column8: But how often and to what extent should I utilize them?

column1: The grades program is entitled Sapphire, a product of K12 Systems, an educational software firm.
column2: The package is comprehensive for the using district
column3: teachers can enter grades and make comments on the system
column4: students and parents can check their grades as often as they wish and even the school nurse has a tracking module.&nbsp
column5: From the time that Eldest entered middle school - and she's now a college freshman - the parents were advised to check Sapphire regularly in order to know how the kids are doing.&nbsp
column6: Depending upon the adminstrator or teacher, the advice was to do so daily.&nbsp
column7: Parents were likewise told at the outset of middle school to regularly keep tabs on the daily homework assignments&nbsp
column8: via Moodle, a separate package upon which teacers can handle online quizzes and homework assignments, not to mention a readily available platform upon which to list the present assignments and projects due.
column10: upon the teacher and grade level, Moodle can even be used as a teaching&nbsp
column13: I was surprised to find that Youngest was recently doing&nbsp
column14: an extra credit quiz on Moodle over the past weekend.

column2: &nbsp
column3: While I'm uncertain as&nbsp
column4: to the&nbsp
column5: package cost of the platform for the district, it certainly&nbsp
column6: fits in well as a worthwhile investment despite the austerity that's continuing to work through the local school systems.&nbsp
column7: There's less need&nbsp
column8: for the use of paper&nbsp
column10: the waste that especially hits the younger kids homework sheets are mangled&nbsp
column11: or lost either enroute to or from the home.&nbsp
column15: the planners that many schools have handed out to students at the onset of the new school year.&nbsp
column18: given each student a planner for years but the quality and size of the planner has diminished considerably in the past two years as this line item&nbsp
column19: has fallen to the budget necessities.&nbsp
column22: continue to check the provided planner, especially for the younger students, but Youngest's teacher actually suggested that the parents provide a larger planner for use.&nbsp
column23: In the local district, Moodle is especially effective for the middle school parents as this is how the teachers post homework assignments and projects for the students
column24: it's at this age that the child's ability to organize and think clearly is particularly hard hit.&nbsp
column25: By the time that the kids hit high school however, that aspect of Moodle is finished and it really is up to the student's ability to keep and maintain a planner...and the parent's ability to keep up with that as well.

column1: But if our job is to raise them and prepare them to make their way in the world, does this technology ultimately help or hinder?
column2: For all of the school system's commentary about the need to keep tabs, what sank in for me came from a high school math teacher with teens of her own.&nbsp
column3: As a parent, she only touched base in the system herself but once every two weeks
column4: how were the kids doing and what were there any issues that seemed to be cropping up, such as recurrent missed homework?&nbsp
column5: As we spoke, her thinking mirrored mine - and I felt like a terrible parent because I wasn't checking every night - in that the kids weren't really learning consequences if they weren't allowed to screw up (as kids and teens can do in such combustibly magnificent fashion).&nbsp
column6: Gee, you got a D because the homework wasn't turned in...there goes that particular privilege.
column7: Likewise, the kids gain a sense that the 'rents will also be there to backstop them and they don't pay attention to the time management and organizational skills that life requires.&nbsp
column8: On a personal level, my own kids hate Sapphire and Moodle because it creates - for them - a sense that they have no independence and are forever tied to the apron.&nbsp
column9: In a small way for them, it retards their belief that they're moving onwards to adulthood

column1: There's no tried and true approach to the technology since no two children are alike.
column2: In this household, one teen's ability to organize and manage work meant that&nbsp
column3: these were rarely utilized while a sibling's lack of structure led to greater use (and bloodshed).&nbsp
column4: It's taken time to reach a balance so that the child doesn't feel as though independence is retarded while I'm comfortable with what's going on with the schoolwork.&nbsp
column5: There have been repeated conversations about expectations and consequences and this child seems to understand that if the performance - matching the abilities - isn't there, then privileges will disappear and consequences will occur.&nbsp
column6: Welcome to adulthood.

column2: Note for both indices that November 2010 = 100.&nbsp
column3: The difference between the Total and Food-only indices are that the Food-only shows the price activity of only the actual food items within the marketbasket with the non-food items removed (foil, soap, trash bags, diapers, etc.).

column1: The Total Index is up from October's level but still not back at the previous index high of 107.50, hit in September 2012.
column2: Unlike that however, the Food-only Index never faltered and has once again hit an all-time high of 113.04.&nbsp
column3: What that literally means is that the cost of the same 37 food items in the market basket are now 13.04% higher than at the Index's inception in November 2010.&nbsp
column4: To see a complete roster of the items in the basket, see here.

column2: Spread&quot
column3: refers to the difference between the two indices and is an indicator of the rate at which food prices are advancing ahead of all prices, which include non-food items as well.&nbsp
column4: Given the small number of non-food items in the basket, it would be considered statistically invalid.&nbsp
column5: But on a gut, common-sense level, it does provide some insight into how the price of food is behaving in relation to other prices in the current economic and monetary environment.&nbsp

As a father, I'm supposed to be respectful of our institutions and try to teach the theory of why things are the way that they are.
column2: Yet I still try to raise the kids to be skeptical and not believe everything that they hear and there are times when it's damned near impossible to find the balance.&nbsp
column3: The last two weeks of this 2012 presidential campaign are an example of those times.

column1: There's obviously a great deal riding on the outcome and I agree that this is an election with a meaning.
column2: The country is in need of true change beyond what is typically seen in a change of political parties, even when there was a real difference between them.&nbsp
column3: The debt situation - personal, student, governmental - cannot continue and the powers that be have to learn that you can't solve what is fundamentally a solvency issue by issuing still more debt.&nbsp
column4: The social contracts amongst our citizenry have to be fundamentally rewritten.&nbsp
column5: What do we owe our elderly and what fair claim do they have upon the national resources?&nbsp
column6: What do we owe our young people so that they have a real chance to pursue happiness, unencumbered by debt?&nbsp
column7: What must we do to truly rebuild our educational system so that it meets the needs of the individual and society?&nbsp
column8: One of the exercises in Middle's Honors Civics class was a web-based internet exercise in which the students had to balance the federal budget.&nbsp
column9: His response one evening was that <em>we're screwed because if you make the cuts, people hate you and if you don't, the debt blows up.&nbsp
column10: It was an eye-opening experience for him.

column1: There have been conversations with Middle and Youngest - Eldest is away at college - about the system and the election.
column2: Middle's Civics&nbsp
column3: teacher has done a good job of exposing them to current issues as well as the traditional aspects.&nbsp
column4: One evening's conversation was about campaign finance and I was surprised that he knew about SuperPACs and the issue of soft money spending on advertising.&nbsp
column5: On a truly family level perspective, the spate of last minute get out the vote calls has been unprecedented, to the point that I've actually disconnected the telephone and one person to whom I spoke today noted on her Facebook page that any friends who wished to contact her would have to do so by cellphone over the weekend.
column6: Much of this is funded by soft money.&nbsp
column7: The calls have been so annoying that I've actually taken the time of pollsters and proceeded to lie through my teeth so as to get a little revenge for this nonsense and I've admitted such to the kids.&nbsp

column1: The other aspects that have come up persistently here relate to the parties and the candidates, particularly that there are no true differences between them.
column2: Despite all of the talk about policies, they might as well combine them and name the resulting creature Rombama.
column3: Despite the taped endorsement from Colin Powell in which he states that the financial system has stabilized and recovered, the reality is that the financial system has become a cause of the zombification of the remainder of the real economy and a principal contributor to the monetary policies that grotesquely pull demand forward and penalize savers.&nbsp
column4: If our forefathers could see what our leaders are permitting, they'd literally stick a foot up their collective ass.&nbsp
column5: While the system was truly at the point of collapse in 2008, Obama should have made true reformation of the financial system the first priority instead of pursuing Obamacare
column6: he instead proved to be a tool of the financial leaders.&nbsp
column7: His candidate counterpart simply lost me with his comment that corporations are people, too.
column8: He can talk as much as he wants about cutting taxes and balancing the budget but he has to be substantive as to how he'll handle spending.&nbsp
column9: If a teenager can take a computer exercise and see how totally screwed up things are, then I'm not hopeful at the soundbite hoopla.

column1: That simple comment is the crux of the problem facing our country today, the rise of the corporations and their power in the face of the individual.
column2: I'm not raising my children to be consumers and that is precisely what the system's leaders want.

column1: Tomorrow, I'll do my duty and vote and because the elementary schools are closed to serve as polling places, I'll take Youngest along with me.
column2:
He can hold my nose for me.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
we owe&nbsp
column3: our children?&nbsp

column1: Don't think that such a philosophic personal question has no bearing on the public issues.
column2: It's clear that&nbsp
column3: our nation cannot continue on the present course.&nbsp
column4: The power structure has shifted to the corporation and the wealthy few, who have successfully manipulated the political system to support economic and monetary policies that sacrifice the great majority to their own&nbsp
column5: benefit.&nbsp
column6: We've failed to pay attention to our society and have succumbed to a consumerist mentality that has literally turned Aesop's Grasshopper and the Ant on its head.
column7: Our late generation boomers have done such a poor job of savings that they're unable to retire in the classical sense and are unwilling to give up positions to the younger generation, who themselves are overladen with debt in their quest for the middle class.&nbsp
column8: As I've said before, we have to renegotiate the social contracts amongst ourselves...but where to start?&nbsp

column1: The only way to truly start the conversation is in the home.
column2: &nbsp
column3: What do I, as a father, owe my children?&nbsp
column4: It isn't an odd question because how we raise our children is crucial to their ability to cope with the changes that the country will have to endure in the coming decades.&nbsp

column1: It's been a long, hard four decades for American fathers.
column2: We've been gone from a significant number of our children's lives and frankly, it shows.&nbsp
column3: The rise of the divorce rate led to children being often given to the sole custody of the mothers with the father being marginalized.&nbsp
column4: The court system held to old beliefs that the children were best left to the care of the mothers, who were better parents by dint of simply being mothers
column5: to be fair, the father before the 1970s usually did have little experience with the kids and would have been completely at sea, at least for the beginning.&nbsp
column6: But the presumption held that fathers were automatically worse parents by dint of simply being fathers.&nbsp
column7: The perversities of the old welfare system, in which women received additional government stipends to support more children, led to the growth of inner-city populations in which the presence of a father became the rare exception and not the rule.&nbsp
column8: These two roads led to the almost complete marginalization of the American father, a punch-line in any number of popular situation comedies such as Married With Children, The Simpsons and Family Guy.
column9: There were certainly other shows, such as Cosby, but the damage was done as it's easier to tear down than to build up.

column1: But long struggles by fathers through the years are turning the tides.
column2: Court systems no longer automatically rule on behalf of the mother and I personally know of situations in which the fathers are suing for full custody of the kids, having patiently documented and worked to show that they were decent parents.&nbsp
column3: There is organized recognition by fatherless men that they themselves suffered for lack of a father and wanting to assure that it doesn't occur with their own children.&nbsp
column4: The media is now portraying men - in commercials and on television - as equally capable parents, albeit with a different perspective than traditional motherhood.&nbsp
column5: Jimmy Fallon's sitcom, Guys With Kids, is a prime example of men - each in a different marital status - making their children a primary focus in their lives and making fatherhood work.

column1: As we reconsider our mutual obligations, what do we - fathers - owe our children?
<li>More than anything else, we owe them our time.&nbsp
column2: The economy is changing as we watch
column3: while the unemployment rate is down, the jobs that are being created are mostly part-time and without benefits so that longer hours and more jobs are required in order to keep the family income afloat.&nbsp
column4: Families will find, even as they cut and adjust their spending, that they're going to be working longer hours.&nbsp
column5: Both parents will be stretched and fathers will have to step up to greater levels in sharing the household and childcare duties.&nbsp
column6: But childcare is more than simply cleaning and feeding
column7: childcare involves reading to and playing with them, overseeing studies and monitoring their friendships and play.&nbsp
column8: This means that there's simply going to be less time available for fathers to spend on themselves, something that our forebear fathers were loathe to do without.&nbsp
column9: This is a return to the first principle of fatherhood, that your life is truly no longer your own.

column2: The stereotype of Dad behind the morning newspaper is old and frankly, I'm not sure if it's even operative anymore.&nbsp
column3: But Dad has to have a vibrant and engaged voice in the daily conversation with the kids.&nbsp
column4: This is especially important as we've realized that the kids are now spending more than 6 hours each day nestled in an electronic cocoon, without benefit of a parent who can help bring order and context to all of the imagery that's presented to them.&nbsp
column5: The children are literally bombarded with imagery and sound and it often comes in rapid waves.&nbsp
column6: One of our jobs is to enforce some discipline on the electronics and then talk with them about what's happening around them to bring context to their world.

column1: <li>We owe them a respect for their mother, even if we're divorced.&nbsp
column2: Children love both of their parents and desperately want to know that even if they're not together, they can pull together for them.&nbsp
column3: They neither deserve nor want to be caught in the middle of squabbling parents and we've witnessed the angst and distress of kids who are caught amidst dueling parents.&nbsp
column4: I was driving with Youngest last week and the conversation turned to several&nbsp
column5: of his friends, all of whom have parents separated or divorced
column6: he remarked that if we broke up, he hoped that we would behave like one particular friend whose parents were civil and actively worked to maintain a decent relationship for the boy's benefit.&nbsp
column7: It was frankly startling.&nbsp
column8: So even if you think that she's a screaming banshee and she sees you as the devil incarnate, you're going to have to find a way if at all possible to keep an even keel.&nbsp
column9: In other words, if there's nothing nice to say, say nothing at all.

column2: This is more than just time because supporting them means that we're also going to have to leave our comfort zones and learn about what they enjoy as they experience new things.&nbsp
column3: I'm a case in point as I've had to learn how to keep the basketball and baseball score books and scoreboard, and am learning the basics of the garage band on the fly
column4: I have no experience in any of these things but if it's reasonable, respectable and enjoyable, then they should be supported as they explore their interests.

column2: There's been a tendency in the past several decades for parents to want to be friends instead of parents, people who have to say no, maintain discipline and administer punishment and trust me, it can be contentious and unpleasant.
column3: The kids have to understand that there is a hierarchy and that someone is able to make decisions devoid of the angst and drama that frequently accompanies the teen years.&nbsp
column4: Likewise, someone has to take the long-term view and that's something about which most teens are simply incapable due to the inexperience and the still turbulent hormones that drive much teen decision-making.

column1: <li>We don't owe them guilt for not being able to give them what they want.&nbsp
column2: As incomes decline and families rejigger to meet their needs, parents simply won't be able to provide all of the accessories that are peddled and that might have been afforded in the past.&nbsp
column3: Kids can learn to do without and it's frankly important that they do so, that they learn to differentiate between need and want
column4: it's a distinction that's actively blurred by the corporations that peddle their wares.&nbsp
column5: Consider this however:&nbsp
column6: if you don't give them the latest version of iPod or the Xbox but instead make a concerted effort to spend more time with them and interacting with them, you'll instead be giving them the paternal involvement that you yourself might never have had.&nbsp

column1: It's possible that if you think about it, you'll have your own criteria of what you owe your children.
column2: The point however, is to actively think and define what you should do.&nbsp
column3: That's at least half of the fight and a good headstart for the kids.&nbsp
column4: Then the trick will be to honor them to the best of ability.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
In a couple of years, states will begin legalizing marijuana and they're going to tax it for the revenues.
&nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: - PracticalDad to Eldest and Middle, 2009

column2: Granted, these aren't the legislators of Colorado and Washington simply saying yep, we're broke so let's legalize and tax
column3: &nbsp
column4: this is the result of public referendums brought about by marijuana activists.&nbsp
column5: Perhaps even as recently as five years ago, they might have been beaten back but we're now in the throes of the first real public realizations that all of the promises made to various constituencies are costlier than expected and that the money isn't there to support them.&nbsp
column6: These votes are the opening of a new front in the ongoing and growing fight about austerity, what we can - and want to - afford with our public dollars.

column1: This budgetary impact was actually part and parcel of the approach crafted by the legalization proponents, particularly in
column2: the state of Washington.&nbsp
column3: The proposal was that&nbsp
column4: there would be a 25% tax on marijuana with the money going to the state coffers, and I suspect that&nbsp
column5: it was a major&nbsp
column6: reason that it passed.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: The&nbsp
column9: voters recognize that there are obligations, particularly for their own&nbsp
column10: favorite projects, but the tax revenues&nbsp
column11: won't support them without significant cuts.&nbsp
column15: somebody somewhere, then the alternative is to find a new source of revenue&nbsp
column16: and dope has the potential to be a big source.&nbsp

column2: succeed easily because of the opposition from the Federal government, which has sworn to oppose legalization in any state.&nbsp
column3: And while&nbsp
column4: it has partially to do with the welfare of the kids, a significant portion&nbsp
column5: also comes down to&nbsp
column6: money.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: We all know that money runs the government, both in terms of paying for the services rendered and the votes.&nbsp
column9: There are multiple lobbies that oppose marijuana's legalization for their own financial ends and have spent money as an investment to assure that it continues to remain illegal.&nbsp
column10: First and foremost of these is the lobby for the for-profit private prisons, principally Corrections Corporation of America.
column11: How extensive is the use of private prisons?&nbsp
column12: CCA was the first in 1983 and continues to be the principal player.&nbsp
column13: With an incarcerated population of 2.3 million people, private industry is responsible now for 130,000 prisoners, or about 8% of that population.
column14: While it might not appear to be that large an amount and not worthy of concern, consider this:&nbsp
column15: while the private prison population rose by 37% from 2002 to 2009, the amount of money spent lobbying rose by more than 150%.
column16: With the trend towards privatization continuing in the wake of the Reagan Revolution, incarceration is increasingly about revenue instead of rehabilitation and atonement.&nbsp

column1: Along with the private prisons, there are other aspects of the legal system with a vested interest in continuing the prohibition of marijuana.
column2: There are prison&nbsp
column3: guard unions, especially in California, with an interest since anything that continues to provide a constant supply of inmates and the accompanying revenue stream accrue to their benefit
column4: with budgets on the cusp of real shrinkage so that the profit margin per inmate declines, there's an interest in increasing the volume of inmates in order to maximize the profit and payroll for the union members.&nbsp
column5: There's also an interest for the legal enforcement community since the affected budgets mean that there's a greater need to obtain grants available for drug enforcement in&nbsp
column6: order to meet the payroll and keep the money flowing.&nbsp

column1: In researching this article, I was surprised to see the strange bedfellows who went along with the legal community to oppose marijuana legalization. Both the pharmaceutical and recreational alcohol lobbies
column2: have ponied up money to oppose legalization
column3: the former because of the concern about competition of pot with prescription medications and the latter because of simple competition with legalized recreational alcohol.&nbsp
column4: In California, the beer distribution lobby actually donated to defeat California Proposition 19, which would have legalized marijuana in that state.&nbsp

column1: So the lines are being drawn as everybody takes a side to determine how the draining pot of resources is allocated to use.
column2: Private monies will be spent and those without private funds will increasingly take to the hallways and streets to demonstrate for their own viewpoint.&nbsp
column3: As a parent, it will be my job to assess the viewpoints and then make the best decision on behalf of my kids.&nbsp
column4: Personally, I know how I was raised and the values with which I was inculcated.&nbsp
column5: The hard part will be take those views and assess in the cold, hard light of day to see if they still make sense.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1: If you think that Occupy Wall Street is dead and forgotten, then you might be interested to discover Rolling Jubilee.
column2: This refers to a livestreamed concert event to raise money to purchase distressed debt and then - in a true twist - forgive it so that the debtors are left with a clean slate.&nbsp
column3: The term jubilee refers to the Old Testament biblical practice of a periodic forgiveness of debt across society so that all start again with a clean slate.

column2: distressed&quot
column3: &nbsp
column4: - old - debt and then pursue it for collection via legal means.&nbsp
column5: It's frankly a lucrative venture but one so seamy that it's left to the vulture financial types because you're pursuing people who are truly down.&nbsp
column6: The lucrative nature of the practice stems upon the fact that the debt is purchased for pennies on the dollar to reflect the likelihood of full repayment.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: The seaminess is that you're dealing with people who typically have nothing and it's going to require real pressure to get anything back.&nbsp

column1: There was a time years ago when I investigated its cousin, tax lien purchases, as an investment possibility
column2: I subsequently wrote it off because it simply seemed morally repugnant to prey upon someone in such a circumstance.&nbsp
column3: This isn't to say that all debtors are victims since the taking on of debt often involves choice and free will, but we do live in a consumerist system in which the finanical sector has a largely free hand and that's especially the case in regards to debt collection.&nbsp
column4: The collectors don't care about the why and how, just the money.&nbsp

column1: I know that I'm around that evening and will probably stream it with at least one of the kids.
column2: But even if I'm not going to stream it, I will put my money where my mouth is and donate because some folks truly are victims and I'm not comfortable letting them suffer for the sins of some of their peers.&nbsp
column3: My hope is that they in turn learn and adapt accordingly.

column1: And all of that aside, I'm going to continue to work to assure that my own kids have the knowledge and capacity to avoid that debt mess in the first place.
column2:
Because home is where it all begins.

You're gonna wanna put a bullet in your head when she finally brings home a boyfriend.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp

column1: This friend commented the above to me over lunch prior to Eldest's birth and it was funny in the moment, especially since his girl was 15 and my unborn
column2: was seeming light years away from that point.&nbsp
column3: But time passes quicker than you realize and suddenly, she's talking about boys and soon there's some acne-riddled, pubescent&nbsp
column4: bucket of testosterone staring you in the face.&nbsp
column5: Dear God, he was right...shoot me now.

column1: Whether it's a boyfriend or a son's girlfriend, how do you even begin to handle it?
column2: The teen years are a time of massive change and that's the way that it should be, with the bodies growing and changing and the brains literally rewiring themselves during that period.&nbsp
column3: Part and parcel of that process is the development of sexuality, typically in the opposite gender but occasionally in the same.&nbsp
column4: Regardless of the orientation, there is so much for them to learn...most especially how to treat and interact with someone with whom they're interested.&nbsp
column5: So understand that it's coming and prepare yourself for the day, because it will arrive.

column2: So much of how you respond will depend upon your own values
column3: it's fine if you disagree with what I write, but accept it simply as a point of departure for your own conversations and decisions.

column1: First, understand that the kids are a blank slate in most areas
column2: and will learn from watching you, even when you're unaware of it.&nbsp
column3: Think about how you interact with your &quot
column4: significant other&quot
column5: on a daily basis.&nbsp
column6: As much as I hate using that term, the reality is that there are now ex-wives and husbands, live-in/unmarrieds, girlfriends and even boyfriends
column7: regardless of the status, how do you treat that person and how do you display affection?&nbsp
column8: It isn't necessarily an overt decision and display, but understand that they will take their cues from you.&nbsp
column9: The flip side of this is that if they're allowed to spend hours each day in front of unsupervised television and computer, what they'll learn about sexuality and the treatment of others is going to vastly different from what you'll think is appropriate or warranted.&nbsp
column10: This is one of the primary reasons that we enforced the rules on electronics usage from an early age.

column1: Second, understand that your child's definition of dating, boyfriend and girlfriend might be radically different from your own adult definition.
column2: I was surprised one evening by Eldest, in her sixth grade year, when she asked at the dinner table if she could have a boyfriend.&nbsp
column3: It's fortunate that my wife took the lead and in the ensuing conversation, found that her definition was far more simplistic than I envisioned and it was innocent enough that I didn't have a stroke.&nbsp
column4: It also however, led to overt discussion about behaviors and further conversations about attitudes and morality.&nbsp

column1: Third, is there a specific age at which you'll actually permit the child to actually go out with someone?
column2: Eldest and Middle both had dating relationships at the age of 15, albeit with ground rules, fixed transportation arrangements and curfews.&nbsp
column3: But I spoke with another parent the other evening and they were adamant in not permitting their child to date until 17, noting that their principal responsibility during the earlier years was the schoolwork.&nbsp
column4: While I can respect that, part and parcel of the teen years is learning how to manage relationships.

column1: Fourth, what are your expectations and your ground rules?
column2: Be sure to communicate these clearly and explicitly to the kids, including the repercussions if these are broken.&nbsp
column3: In the PracticalDad household, no boyfriend or girlfriend can visit unless one of the adults is present and all doors must remain open
column4: there is a clear understanding that we also have access to all areas of the house so that&nbsp
column5: we're free to come down to the basement mechanical room - adjacent to the family room - at any time.&nbsp
column6: There have been instances when I've gone there simply to prove that I can.&nbsp
column7: What are the transportation arrangements?&nbsp
column8: Who has to be home and when, and how are they getting there?&nbsp
column9: There have been occasions when the teen relationships have taken a back seat to other business simply because plans weren't checked out with me in advance.&nbsp
column10: What are the guidelines - if any - on public displays of affection?&nbsp
column11: It's been a point here since we've actively opened the household to the significant others but there's still a younger sibling&nbsp
column12: in elementary school and he doesn't need to be exposed to too much.&nbsp
column13: if we're going to control it on the screen, then we're going to control it here as well.

column1: Fifth, how much do you want to include the significant others in family life?
column2: Are there family events or evenings that are off-limits to outsiders or are you willing to open them up?&nbsp
column3: One of the things that you should consider is that there are more than a few teens with no significant adult supervision or involvement in their lives and being inclusive not only allows you to keep a better eye on what's going on, it also allows them the opportunity to see the workings of an involved and active family.&nbsp
column4: It doesn't mean that your family is perfect, but it's a sad fact that at least you have an engaged family while these kids might not.&nbsp
column5: Accept it as a truism that kids coming from situations in which there isn't an active and engaged family will want to spend time with your own family
column6: and the other truism is that you will in turn begin to care for them regardless of their status with your kid.&nbsp
column7: I know of situations in which the ex-boyfriends and girlfriends continue to maintain contact even after their own relationship has ended.&nbsp

column1: Many fathers aren't aware of the power of their own example until the kids are old enough to begin their own tentative relationships.
column2: Understand now that the sons will see how you treat your mate and model that accordingly and your daughters will learn how they in turn should be treated.&nbsp
column3: There will always be disagreements and fights, but it's the manner in which they're handled that makes the difference.&nbsp

Today is a day that will be spent on errands and some shopping for the upcoming holidays and there's now an additional item on that list, a box of Twinkies.
column2: They aren't something that I've actually purchased before - so I suppose that I'm part of the reason for the Hostess Corporation demise -&nbsp
column3: but the soon-to-be Hostess bankruptcy makes them an interesting household piece for discussion.&nbsp

column1: The privately held corporation's bankruptcy has been an item for discussion in the past several days as the Teamsters union put the kabosh on the contract offered by Hostess management.
column2: The interplay of news has been entertaining as one article's spin puts a negative light on the union's refusal to ratify the contract, killing the company, while another highlights that the existing management is going to still distribute more than $1.5 million in bonuses.&nbsp
column3: The lessons for the kids in the next several days could be far-reaching and could go in any number of directions.

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
Holidays come and go, kids return and then depart, cars are wrecked (no injuries, thank God), motherboards on laptops die, and certain milestones are reached.&nbsp
column3: This particular milestone is that the PracticalDad site readership surpassed 60,000 regular readers on the RSS feed.

column1: The site began four years ago with a single intent and two simple parameters.
column2: The intent was to write about fatherhood and family, showing that men could be as capable in parenting as women although it's morphed somewhat as I've tried to explore how what's happening with society and economy affects our families.&nbsp
column3: The first parameter is that I not produce anything that would embarrass anyone within the family
column4: not everything written has been posted as review and reflection caused me to delete articles because they might be embarrassing to one or more of the kids.&nbsp
column5: The great majority don't personally know Eldest, Middle or Youngest but a few readers do and the kids don't need a neighbor nodding the head and thinking ""so that's why he looked like he was having an aneurysm.""&nbsp
column6: The second parameter is that I simply don't write crap.&nbsp
column7: There's enough nonsense on the web and I don't need to add to it and again, several articles were simply deleted because they left an odor on the keyboard.

column2: And please don't think badly if this note's format is odd because there's something squirrelly with how the new laptop's mouse interacts with the site's programming/writing module.&nbsp
column3:
Life happens.
