Go see this movie. Take your children, even though they may occasionally be confused or fidgety. Boredom and confusion are also part of democracy, after all. &ldquo
column2: Lincoln&rdquo
column3: is a rough and noble democratic  masterpiece &mdash
column4: an omen, perhaps, that movies for the people shall not perish from the earth.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: &nbsp
column7: &nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column11: - A.O. Scott, New York Times, November 9, 2012

column1: That is precisely what I did as Middle and Youngest, and Middle's girlfriend, came along this weekend to see Spielberg's Lincoln.
column2: While I don't know the age of Mr. Scott's own children, I do know that the material wasn't beyond the grasp of an intelligent ten year-old so long as there was some pre- and post-movie background provided.&nbsp
column3: While this particular adventure pertained to a movie, it goes to the larger matter that as a father, my greatest job is to help prepare the children for living in the great wide world and the state of American politics and the questions of personal liberty, security and the Constitution certainly are addressed in this film.

column1: The film itself was superb, everything that I'd expect from Kushner and Spielberg
column2: it leaned heavily upon Doris Kearns Goodwin's 2006 book, <a title=""Amazon.com"" href=""http://www.amazon.com/Team-Rivals-Political-Abraham-Lincoln/dp/0743270754/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp
column3: ie=UTF8&amp
column5: sr=1-1&amp
column6: keywords=team+of+rivals"">Team of Rivals, a good history but definitely improved with the personal touch that comes from the visual work of Spielberg.
column7: But to appreciate it in its entirety, it requires a basic level of knowledge that many of our kids lack today.&nbsp
column8: What was striking even before the movie trailers ran was that Middle leaned over and whispered Dad, you're like the fourth youngest person here and when I glanced about at the several dozen viewers present, he was right.
column9: Middle could appreciate it since he's immersed in an Honors Civics course and it was his education that provided the impetus for the evening
column10: Youngest however, could still appreciate it since we'd recently completed a ten mile hike at Gettysburg and is a budding history buff.

column1: Apart from simply seeing a Spielberg film and having the kids learn something (hopefully), I had certain goals for the three kids.
column2: My first goal was to help them understand that history isn't some dry subject but a living process, made by flesh and blood individuals who suffer, strive and often act only upon faith with no guarantee of ultimate success.&nbsp
column3: Lincoln - like all of our forebears - was flesh and blood and not a demi-god as we've made them all to be.&nbsp
column4: The second goal was to help them understand that the Constitution is largely a document of parameters and rules, not an explicit guide of regulations or an assembly book for government.&nbsp
column5: As during the Civil War, our society is beset by questions of the balance between personal liberties and national security.&nbsp
column6: Lincoln took great efforts to protect and defend the Constitution upon his inauguration and in doing so, he ran roughshod over basic precepts of free speech and habeas corpus
column7: he admits as much to his cabinet during a scene in the film as they demand to understand why he believes it so important to enact the 13th amendment.&nbsp
column8: These larger questions aren't new and will continue to haunt us.

column1: The most interesting exchanges about the movie occurred during the next evening's meal as the film was described to my wife, who was out of town the previous evening.
column2: She glanced at Middle and inquired who's the director? to which he replied Spielberg.

column1: Why was it released now? she asked.
I responded well, it didn't occur before the election so it can't be called a clear endorsement for an African-American president, sort of "
column2: look how far we've come since the 13th amendment&quot
column3: .&nbsp
column4: The boys listened.

column1: No, she commented, but it's certainly a good piece to have out in the aftermath of the Obamacare passage.
column2: People want the big concepts like healthcare reform, but don't want to see all of the little deals that go into the passage of such legislation.&nbsp
column3: As the conversation meandered, we questioned whether Obamacare is actually something good.
column4: It's 1400 pages that almost no one has actually read and many are opposed to it, sometimes viscerally.&nbsp
column5: Yet the 13th amendment's passage was likewise opposed, sometimes viscerally and in the moment of it's passage, it required the courage and great effort of a minority to enact it.&nbsp
column6: The point to the boys was this:&nbsp
column7: all that you can have at that moment are your convictions and it won't necessarily be until sometime later that you learn whether the fruition of those convictions was truly successful.&nbsp

column2: Don't presume that the schools are going to teach your children everything that they need to learn to survive in the great wide world.&nbsp
column3: Look for your opportunities to expand their horizons and think about what you want them to take from those opportunities.&nbsp
column4: Make it a point to ask them what they noticed or thought and then just chat with them.&nbsp
column5: There are moments when they cock their heads and give you that Laddie, the Wonder Spaniel look but there will also be moments when you can watch the lights being turned on in the rooms inside their head and it's those moments that provide profound satisfaction.
column6: Don't let them nag you out of it just because it might be out of their comfort zone
column7: kids will bitch, whine and kvetch since that's what they do.&nbsp
column8: Suffer it and push them so that they experience something that's ultimately in their best interest and remember that since you're the parent, you should know better than they do what's in their best interest. &nbsp

column1:
610,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Youngest and I went on a recent hike with a group on a cold mid-November morning, meeting the others in a local parking lot.
column2: When I arrived, one of the kid hikers - in upper elementary school - stood in the parking lot next to his parent's van wearing nylon gym shorts, a t-shirt and thin cotton windbreaker.&nbsp
column3: The parents weren't going along with the boy, who would be with a group of us.&nbsp
column4: When I walked over and said hello, he commenced yakking with Youngest and I quietly asked his parent whether that attire would really be sufficient for a long hike in chilly temperatures
column5: the forecast called for gusty winds and as it turned out, brief snow flurries.&nbsp
column6: The adult looked at me and stated that that's what he always wore in cold weather, he didn't wanna wear long pants and heavier clothing so that's what he was going in.&nbsp

column2: Seriously?&nbsp
column3: Seriously?
column4: I mean, seriously?

column1: Since I was the guy who planned this hike of almost ten miles, it was up to me to decide whether or not I'd make an issue of it.
column2: I commented that the boy was liable to become cold and the guy stated that that's what the boy always wore and that he'd be alright.&nbsp
column3: My verbal response was okay but the mental response was far more prolific.
column4: I grew up in a ""highway household"" in which the parental mantra was my way or the highway and I'd frankly fought this particular battle in my household on innumerable occasions until the older kids reached an age that they'd learned to suffer well from their choices.
column5: My own personal decision was that the boy was going to have to suffer from his choice and parent's unwillingness to press the issue.&nbsp
column6: When we reached a later point in the hike in which the wind was blowing across the open fields and the boy was visibly shivering, my only response was to suggest that he zip up the windbreaker and hustle a little faster.&nbsp
column7: I wasn't about to play the dutiful parent and offer my own fleece jacket to keep him warm
column8: &nbsp
column9: in my mind, my obligation was to bring the kid back alive and unharmed and if he'd been attacked by wild dogs, I'd protect him.&nbsp
column10: But I was damned if I - or anyone else - was going to suffer for his own parent's unwillingness to be the adult for his own kid.&nbsp

column1: The reality is that parenting can be unpleasant - damnably so - at times.
column2: Kids naturally push the boundaries as they grow and try to assert their independence and judgment and it can occasionally require Solomon's wisdom to ascertain when they're alright in doing so and when they need to toe your line
column3: &nbsp
column4: there have frankly been any number of instances when my own choice led to unnecessary frustration on the part of both sides and I can look back and say woulda, shoulda.
column5: What bothered me now was that the kid was going to be out of the parent's presence and any issues would have to be handled by me or another parent. If I'm going to have an Opie along - and that's pretty often - then I don't want to be in the position of having to pick up for the other parent's unwillingness to be the adult.
column6: When my kids are in someone else's care, there's an expectation that the other parent will be responsible for them but that doesn't extend to even meeting their minimal needs simply because I don't want to deal with any unpleasantries.&nbsp

column1: If there's ever a time to deal with the tantrums and rancor, it's when they're youngest.
column2: As they grow, they'll learn that while they push the boundaries and learn to actually argue with you on a more mature level - Dad, this is why I think that I should be allowed to wear pants like these... - they'll also become used to the notion that you're actually the parent with a final say.
This means that I'll have to wrestle with the unpleasant moments because it's ultimately in their own best interests that I do so.&nbsp
column3: They don't have the experience or the judgment to determine when something is ultimately harmful in the long run, such as wearing inappropriate clothing for the weather.&nbsp
column4: But thinking of them is only part of the equation since there's also a duty to the other parents who have to deal with my child in my absence and I owe them what I in turn would want for myself when managing their kids in their absence.&nbsp
column5: It creates discord in their own household as their kids naturally point at the Opies and throw their own behavior back in the parents' faces, and the folks in turn are forced to not only try to explain their own rationale, but explain the reasoning of those other parents.&nbsp
column6: The simple truth is that I've actually explained the behavior of other parents by remarking they let it occur just because they're idiots, son.

column1: If your own kid doesn't wanna, please be sure that he's old enough to live with the results of his choices.nbsp
column2: If he isn't old enough, make sure that you're around to contend with him because he's liable to not like my own response to the consequences of his (in)actions and kvetching.&nbsp

column1: The total cost of the basket rose to an average of $192.79 for a December 2012 index level of 108.07 (November 2010 = 100)
column2: this is a full point increase from the November 2012 index level of 107.06.&nbsp
column3: Consequently, the cost of purchasing the same 47 items since November 2010 has risen more than 8%.

column1: What caught my eye was that when the ten non-food items (such as foil, soap, shampoo, diapers, etc.) are stripped from the basket and foodstuffs alone are considered, the Food-only Index has risen further and at an even higher rate than the Total Index.
column2: The Food-only Index actually rose more than 1.25 points to an index reading of 114.33 (November 2010 = 100)
column3: the upshot is that considering the 37 food items alone (such as eggs, milk, a pound of ground beef, sugar, etc.), the cost of buying the same identical foodstuff items has risen 14.33% from November 2010.

column2: Spread&quot
column3: column refers to the difference between the two indices - the 37 food item index and the complete 47 item index - and is indicative of the way that food prices alone are rising when compared against a basket that also comprises non-food items.&nbsp
column4: I make no pretense it is a statistically valid measure given the paucity of items, but it is a measure that's more easily comprehensible to the average person.&nbsp
column5:
The long and the short of the spread is that it shows that when the effect of non-food prices are stripped away, the basket's food prices themselves are increasing at an even greater pace.

Pay attention to the news and you hear that the CPI has increased by .x% for a particular month, at an annualized rate of y%.
column2: You also shop and can see that, somehow, the price of something has risen.&nbsp
column3: But by how much and what does this mean in terms of reality?&nbsp
column4: I thought that it would beneficial to look back at the prices for items in the PracticalDad grocery basket in 2010 and then compare them with the prices today.&nbsp

column1: What a family buys at a grocery store is more than just food, and includes items for the household and body, such as paper towels, feminine products/pads and diapers.
column2: It's these three items that by themselves, comprise a full 20% of the basket's dollar value and it's these three items that have been either seen no price change or an actual drop in the past two years.&nbsp
column3: This means that their presence in the basket hides the effect of price rises on other items and it's for this reason that I began to split out the food costs earlier this year.&nbsp
column4: While the full Index of 47 items rose by 8% since November 2010, the cost of the 37 food items increased by a higher 14%.

column1: Items that are obviously related to commodities saw the greatest rises, such as bread (wheat), orange juice, coffee and cooking (canola) oil.
column2: Others saw more moderate increases but the large majority of items within the basket saw an increase of one kind or another.&nbsp
column3: Following is a short recap of some of the items at random.

column1: <li>In some instances, it's the result of simple supply such as a failed peanut crop in late 2011 and early 2012.&nbsp
column2: The supply of peanuts was so constrained that some stores actually had a limit on how many jars of peanut butter could be purchased at any one time.&nbsp
column3: The same occurred this Fall with apples as a poor apple crop in some parts of the country led to higher prices.&nbsp
column4: The cost of a gallon of apple cider locally spiked recently to $6.99.

column1: <li>In the case of certain commodities, it's frankly related to ongoing lax easy money policies.&nbsp
column2: Major investors - including large investment houses and hedge funds - look at the environment for investing and push money to assets that are tangible and will have an ongoing demand.&nbsp
column3: People don't actually have to purchase iPods or Chevy Volts, but they do have to feed themselves and their families so the money for the futures contracts flows to those items.&nbsp
column4: If you recall the movie Trading Places with Dan Aykroyd and Eddie Murphy, the corollary plot pertained to the acquisition and use of inside information on the orange harvest.

column1: <li>Some items see their rises because of corollary rises in other products.&nbsp
column2: The cost of generic sugar flakes cereal rose higher than oatmeal or generic rice chex cereal because the sugar and wheat ingredients saw rises of greater than 10%.&nbsp
column3: Canola oil saw a major spike in 2011 because crude oil's spike led to an increased demand for biofuels
column4: since the canola crop also goes to biofuel, the increased demand for canola led to a corresponding rise in the cost of the cooking oil.&nbsp
column5: The price of a pound of ground beef (80% lean) rose 30% over the past two years and a significant spike occurred across the three surveyed grocery stores after a media brouhaha over the use of pink slime
column6: the rationale behind the increase would be that grocery chains eliminated the additive and were forced to raise prices accordingly.&nbsp

column1: There is one thing to takeaway from this and that's the realization that in most cases, prices aren't going to go down once they rise.
column2: There can be circumstances that lead to price decreases, such a new supplier providing an item for a grocer, but by and large the cost of food isn't going to magically decline once it rises.&nbsp

column1: While taking a moment to check some online news, I came across a headline banner proclaiming
column2: utm_medium=advertising&amp
column3: utm_campaign=gdn_cont&amp
column4: utm_content=trades"">the benefits of purchasing a new home instead of a used one.
column5: This is probably the first headline banner that I've clicked in more than a year just because...well, just because I was curious.&nbsp
column6: The site is a product of some construction advertising LLC and proudly exclaims all of the many reasons that purchasing a new home is sooooo much better than a used home.&nbsp
column7: For instance, you can relax in it knowing that you're the first to ever own it
column8: that you can configure the house to your desires instead of configuring your family to meet the floorplan
column9: that it can have the highest quality materials and energy efficiency
column10: that many of these are located in posh developments with attractive amenities (cue picture of mansion with lit pool in front of it).

column1: My thinking and philosophy - and writing - has changed dramatically since I created this site in 2008.
column2: The thrust of real-world education for the kids is that they're going to live in a world of markedly fewer opportunities than were afforded to most of my generation and that in today's society, the corporation rules to the detriment of the individual. They will be catered to and feted via advertising with the sole purpose of becoming good consumers charged with the task of spending their money on the latest and greatest gadgetry even if it makes no significant difference to their ultimate well-being (want/need).
column3: The goal of advertising is, indeed, to convince the individual about what their ultimate well-being actually is.

column1: But this kind of banner advertising isn't accounting for the real world, the world in which we live.
column2: It doesn't account for the world in which the median American family income has dropped about $5000 since the 2007 recession and the majority of new jobs are part-time without any benefits.
column3: What's actually driving the banner ad is the actual desperation of the builders as they see ongoing mediocre demand for new housing and the competition that's coming from the much lower cost stock of existing homes
column4: that industry sees that people are nervous about their world and happy to mix up a potent batch of new Kool-Aid for the public to consume.&nbsp
column5: Unfortunately, if the median family income has dropped by such an extent, is it in the best interests of your own family to stretch and shoot for that demographic?&nbsp

column1: If nothing else, it goes back to a purposeful obfuscation on their part, a deliberate confusion that purchasing this building makes it a home.
column2: This is the ultimate example of the age of self-gratification, that you purchase a ready-made structure home much as you could toss a TV dinner into the oven in the 1950s and call it a family meal.&nbsp
column3: What you are buying is a structure, a house that will take considerable work and effort on your part to create a home for the family.&nbsp
column4: A house is built from physical materials, a home is made from the family's values and habits, it's practices and love.&nbsp

column1: It's fine to look and dream about what if for the kids and family, but take the images with a grain of salt.
column2: If you want Kool-Aid, go to the grocer instead of the &quot
column3: home&quot
column4: builder.

That anybody takes another human life is a tragedy, compounded by the subsequent suicide in front of others.
column2: Lives are altered in so many ways and the recriminations begin as fingers point in so many directions,. fingers often pointed by people who compound shock with cluelessness in vain search of an answer.&nbsp
column3: That it happened is terrible enough but now comments are being made that add fuel to the fire for gun control, most especially Bob Costas and his halftime commentary about gun control.
column4: The gist of his remark was that young men are incapable of self-control and that permitting them ready access to weapons is simply setting the stage for tragedy.&nbsp
column5: But what does this mean when a family is about to train the kids in the use of firearms?&nbsp
column6: Is Costas right in his comments that our youngsters are incapable of self-control and thus in far greater danger by sheer dint of ready access to weapons?

column1: The comments are outlandish, but timely since we're going to proceed with firearms training come Spring.
column2: I'm not a survivalist and have no bunker accessible via a hidden passage beneath the fishpond waterfall, but we will - now that the youngest is old enough - teach them how to use the firearms safely.&nbsp
column3: This is partially for the sheer fun of it as well as the fact that society has grown coarser and more violent and I want to be sure that they have a firm handle on things.&nbsp
column4: There's a greater availability of gun and firearm games on various platforms, such as Xbox and Wii, and while we've worked hard to control access, I know that they're playing with friends at their houses
column5: if they're going to do so, I want to assure that they actually have an understanding of the real thing.&nbsp
column6: This is akin to finally letting the nine year-old watch Saving Private Ryan so that he has a clue that the violence in warfare isn't the sterile, harmless type that they're fed online.

column1: There are several issues that I have with the comments and controversy arising from the tragedy.
<li>The first is the confusion that's shown by some commentators about the Second Amendment.&nbsp
column2: The fact that we have a significant standing mililtary doesn't mean that weapons for the populace is unnecesary
column3: part of the right to own arms is that the citizenry have the right to protect themselves from the government should things slide out of control.&nbsp
column4: While we depended upon a militia at the founding of the nation instead of a standing army, there was real concern that the populace also be able to defend themselves from tyranny.

column1: <li>The second is that this is a response to an exceptionally high profile case
column2: there isn't the outcry over the chronic gun violence that permeates inner city America or the Mexican border and I doubt that this incident should throw the whole thing over into a repeal of the Second Amendment.

column1: <li>The third is the simple realization that football is a violent sport and a profession that rewards violence
column2: the men who play football are, as a whole, more aggressive than the average person.&nbsp
column3: This means that these men live their lives with a familiarity of violence that the large majority of Americans don't understand.&nbsp
column4: Their world is contact and damage and while I don't expect that the great majority are going to wander around beating the average joe to a pulp, I do expect that they have a greater sense than the average joe of how situations can go awry and lead to violence and they want to be certain that they're protected.

column1: <li>The fourth point is that I don't view this tragedy as one that's attributable solely to Belcher's age and gender, but one that's ultimately attributable to some degree of instability and mental illness.&nbsp
column2: This is a man who lost control and after killing his girlfriend - the mother of his child - was overwhelmed by remorse to the extreme.&nbsp
column3: This situation could have easily occurred, and does, within the general population.&nbsp
column4: If a plumber goes kills another and then himself, we don't blame it on his age and gender.

column1: What Costas should refer to is a situation akin to the controversy surrounding sportswriter Jason Whidlock's criticism of Colin Kaepernick's tattoos.
column2: Whidlock's commentary was that the extreme tattooing was symbolic of a prison culture that didn't jibe with the persona of a professional quarterback
column3: this does tie into the gun violence issue in that multiple football players have been embroiled in the past decade in the thuggish behavior that derives from the gangsta mentality of the inner city gang.
column4: Multiple players - Adam &quot
column5: Pacman&quot
column6: Jones, Santana Moss, Ray Lewis - have been involved in deadly situations with gun usage.&nbsp
column7: Along with Michael Vick's dogfighting, these evolved from the violent, unstable mentality fostered by the inner city gangs in which nobody else matters but another member of your own group.&nbsp

column1: So how does this relate to my own family scenario?
column2: The gangs have always existed, but have especially flourished in the broken family environment of the inner city.&nbsp
column3: The gang becomes the family to the member instead of the parents and siblings and the gang imprints its own family &quot
column4: values&quot
column5: onto the new member.&nbsp
column6: While these values permit and encourage the use of weapons, they do nothing to teach the responsibility that must extend naturally with the potential of the weapon.&nbsp
column7: Guns are simply symbolic of the real issue here, the rise and celebration of the gangsta culture via popular media and electronic gaming
column8: a culture that sprouted from the destruction of the family in the inner cities.

column1: If Costas wants to focus his attention somewhere, then he should focus it here.
column2: I'm angry that in their view, so many responsible families will suffer for the irresponsibility of the few who flourished and fell in the rise of the <em>gangsta&nbsp
column3: culture.
column4: I live in a state in which hunting and firearms flourish and I know of so many parents who take great care to assure that their children understand and respect the power of the gun.&nbsp
column5: Ths issues are so much deeper than portrayed in the media and I resent that for a few, the ready elimination of a symbol is tantamount to resolving the issue.&nbsp
column6:
If you're going to have or bring a weapon into the house, be certain to exercise the responsibility that comes with it so that the media monster isn't fed with even more fodder.

615,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The wolf will live with the lamb, the leopard will lie down with the goat, the calf and the lion and the yearling together
column2: and a little child will lead them.&nbsp

column1: On the cusp of the announcement by catholic
column2: Belmont Abbey College that they were cutting their annual tuition by a full third starting in 2013, it only seemed appropriate to lead with a biblical quote.
column3: The news over the wire was that the college was cutting tuition by $10000 to about $18000 starting in 2013 and in the announcement, they stated that they were doing it in response to the ongoing disproportionate rise of college tuition over the past two decades.&nbsp
column4: I have to applaud their action as they acknowledge in their statement that many good students are discouraged from applying to colleges based on the published price alone.
column5: They are realizing that the financial maneuvers in the college financials appear to be, as one close friend stated, just so much funny money
column6: both she and we were told to ignore the published price and focus on the actual price, net of grants, work-study and loans.&nbsp
column7: The process is confusing to many and can be offputting, as more and more kids and families look at things and say to hell with it.

column1: In all fairness, Belmont Abbey isn't actually the first small school to cut their tuition but they are among the first of several small schools - the little children - who are saying enough.
column2: Part of it is, I believe, an actual sense that things truly are out of control and that they have a moral obligation to do what they can in both the micro and macro sense of helping to lead the way.&nbsp
column3: Part of it is also simply an act of enlightened self-interest as the understanding that folks are staying away because of the published price.&nbsp
column4: While Belmont Abbey states that they're in a good position with new infrastructure and a full class of students, they also are looking at the other trends in American society and recognizing that if they aren't in trouble now, then they will be.&nbsp

column1: While the much higher rise in college costs is the major factor in the equation, it's now being slowly eclipsed by the realization that the ever-dependable middle class is being throttled.
column2: Since the recession of 2007, family incomes have declined and there's simply no sign that they're coming back as the majority of jobs being created are part-time only and more Americans are forced to eat courtesy of local food banks and the US Government's SNAP program.&nbsp
column3: Barring an economic miracle to massively bolster family incomes, and that's not remotely likely, then the institutions will be forced to make the cuts themselves and put the word out.&nbsp
column4: While some may think that the colleges are panicking, the rule of thumb is that he who panics first panics best and those institutions will be ahead of the curve.&nbsp

column1: So if Belmont Abbey's action gains legs and spreads, that's only part of the battle.
column2: There should also be work done to make the process easier to understand for the average family, and that's something that can be done by the higher education establishment.&nbsp
column3: But the families have to do their part and actually pay attention to the process and not simply leave it to the hands of the kids who don't have the experience necessary to adequately assess all of the complexities in the process.&nbsp
column4: This doesn't even consider what would be necessary on a national level to stem the economic decline at the family level.&nbsp
column5: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
616,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Change usually happens incrementally and with such stealth that it creeps into your consciousness like an ex-boyfriend slipping into the backpew of the wedding service.
column2: But occasionally, you get that instant aha! moment when you see something that registers immediately.
column3: Such was the case when I took Middle for an annual physical last week and realized that the doctor's office was full of men and that all of them had babies and toddlers.

column1: There was a time when I took the kids - much younger then - to the pediatrician's office and found myself the sole non-physician male in the entire office.
column2: Mothers and grandmothers were there with kids of all ages and for any number of reasons and there I sat, reading a well-thumbed Dr Seuss book to one or two children while I awaited the call of our name.&nbsp
column3: But last week was eye-opening on multiple levels.&nbsp
column4: The first level was the simple presence of so many fathers concentrated in one area, actually outnumbering the number of women who weren't on staff
column5: there were mothers in the area, but there appeared to be more fathers there.&nbsp
column6: The next level was the earliest years with the kids were spent in the DC region, which would certainly qualify as one of the forerunners in the fatherhood movement as men became more involved.&nbsp
column7: But last week's excursion was to a suburban physician's office in a very politically and socially conservative area.&nbsp
column8: There were men there with their wives, but I noted several bringing multiple kids in by themselves and all that I could think of was a paraphrase of the old commercial tagline, you've come a long way, buddy.

column1: The 1970s seems to be the definitive decade for when the family structure began to go off of the rails.
column2: It was an economically difficult decade that really pushed more women to go back to the workforce and the increasingly vocal Feminist movement - born in the late 1960s - made it socially and politically acceptable for this to happen and women went back to the workforce in much greater numbers.&nbsp
column3: The increased rise of the Great Society welfare program led to a literal destruction of the paternal figure in the inner city.&nbsp
column4: Finally, the increased acceptance of no-fault divorce made divorce far easier to obtain yet the delay in the recognition that fathers could also be fit parents led to true hardship for fathers.&nbsp
column5: Advertisers watched this and jumped aboard the bandwagon to target products to this new and potent feminist wife/mother market and rolled out such taglines as you've come a long way, baby and she can bring home the bacon, fry it up in a pan (and never, never let you forget you're a man).
column6: The decades passed and as wages slowly closed the gender gap - and yes, I know that there's still a discrepancy - and women moved into upper echelons, there were any number of publications and articles that told women you can have it all as it showed pictures of attractive mothers in upscale clothing playing with the kids or working around the house.
column7: But the difference was that more and more of those decades' kids grew up seeing that Mom was actually being pulled and twisted like taffy to make things work while Dad simply wasn't a factor in many cases.

column1: We're now two generations removed from that initial period and the kids are parents in their own rite.
column2: They're not stupid and have watched what their parents went through and in many cases have decided that there has to be a better way.&nbsp
column3: Men want to be the fathers to their kids that they often didn't have and the women want help so that there's some sense of balance
column4: they want to be a person with a life, not a Twizzler.&nbsp
column5: There's recognition that there's a cost to having it all and it isn't only financial, but also physical, emotional and even moral.&nbsp
column6: So more fathers are taking the opportunity to take up the slack with the kids in the daily life and that's only fair, even if they know that it puts a serious crimp in the career plans.&nbsp
column7: They understand in today's world that while it can be hurt to have the employer let them go, it's far more painful to know that their child let them go.

column2:
Ignore anyone that tells you that you can.

617,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Most fundamentally, the question is whether people are fully understanding of the limits to central banks' abilities. It is, to repeat, not to be critical of actions to date to wonder whether private market participants, and perhaps more importantly governments, recognise what central banks cannot do. Central banks can provide liquidity to shore up financial stability and they can buy time for borrowers to adjust. But they cannot, in the end, put government finances on a sustainable course and they cannot create the real resources that need to be found from somewhere to strengthen bank capital. They cannot costlessly correct earlier misallocation of real capital investment. They cannot shield people from the implications of having mis-assessed their own life-time budget constraints and as a result having consumed too much.

column1: Serendipity lives and this quote came on the cusp of a long, rambling conversation with Middle the other evening after watching Will Ferrell's The Campaign.
column2: One of the perks of living in this household is that as the kids get a little older, I'll occasionally permit them to watch an R-rated movie with the proviso that I have the opportunity to pause and explain a few things.&nbsp
column3: First on the list was that the film's fictitious Motch Brothers - Dan Aykroyd and John Lithgow - are satires on the real-life billionaire Koch Brothers, who muscled into the nascent Tea Party Movement for their own personal benefit.&nbsp
column4: Second on the list was the plot twist by the brothers to purchase up the congressional district and then import Chinese workers
column5: for the brothers, it was a win-win with no shipping costs and almost slave labor wages.&nbsp

column1:
But it was at the China juncture that the conversation took flight as it turned

The news from Danbury, Connecticut strikes home with a visceral fear as the reality is that this madness isn't relegated to a third world nation or ghetto free-fire zone.
column2: This happened in a small town with a school that probably looks very similar to most other elementary schools across the country.&nbsp
column3: When Youngest came home, I met him on the front porch and gave him a hug and when he goes to school in the morning, I'll see him off from the front porch again.&nbsp
column4: While it's statistically highly unlikely that anything is going to happen and I'll see him again in the afternoon, the randomness and severity of the violence gives me a lingering sense that this is akin to watching a teenage child leave for service in the military.&nbsp
column5: On top of the shootings at Columbine, Nickel Mine and Virginia Tech, there's a raw feeling that anything can happen and I had better make it a goodbye when he departs.

column1: Like many people, I wonder what's happening in our society that this is occurring with seemingly greater prevalence and I certainly have some opinions.
column2: But when the family discussed it this weekend, Eldest - home for college break - commented that she felt it disrespectful that Facebook and other social media was full of opinion and invective so soon on the heels of this tragedy.&nbsp
column3: My two cents will consequently wait as she's correct.

column1: What I will offer is that you take an extra moment when you last see the kids and give them another squeeze, or if the teens are grumpy, suck up the annoyance and give thanks that they're there to annoy you at all.
column2: It's something that I've tried to do with mixed success but will make the extra effort going forward.&nbsp

We spend much of our lives in a forest for the trees environment, pressed by details that keep us from seeing the big picture.
column2: Many men see themselves as the junior member in the parenting partnership, noting how the mothers seem so much more at ease with the kids and consequently step back from the daily merry-go-round that is part and parcel of raising children.&nbsp
column3: The thought is that I'm really not that important here and they need their mother more than me...

column1: It is a real thought process for more than a few fathers.
column2: But fathers do make a huge difference in the kids' lives and their presence is missed when they're not there or involved.&nbsp
column3: This was borne out by an English survey of 2000 parents, who were asked what their children asked for
column4: the results were compiled into a roster of the fifty most requested Christmas gifts.&nbsp
column5: While I'm not certain of the full list, what was relevant here was that &quot
column6: a father&quot
column7: was the tenth most requested Christmas gift.&nbsp
column8: It's not #1 on the list, but it's certainly not at the bottom either and it's a testament to what men bring to the table as parents.&nbsp

column1: So when you start to wonder how much you really matter or whether you're just as important as mom - and no, I don't plan to choose one over another - consider the Christmas list.
column2: And have a wonderful season.

column1: You don't pull the mask off that old Lone Ranger
And you don't mess around with Jim.

column2: &nbsp

column37: -You Don't Mess Around with Jim (Jim Croce, 1972)

column1: And if the financial authorities have their way, you never, ever save.
column2: With the prevailing rates kept artificially low - I recently saw an online ad touting a terrific APR of .9% - and the advertising drumbeat continuing to push consumption, the economic system is set to continue driving everyday Americans to spend and consume.&nbsp
column3: But the ability to save is crucial and is especially important for the kids to learn as we prepare them for their future.&nbsp
column4: They face an economic future that will be radically different from what we ourselves faced as children and their ability to live within their means will be crucial to their well-being as they face choices that we never faced.

column1: There's been a recurrent mantra throughout the years with the kids, one that's typically uttered when one or more of life's speedbumps occurs:
column2: ...and that's why we save.
column3: Writing the check for an electrician's or plumber's visit?&nbsp
column4: <em>...and that's why we save. &nbsp
column5: Having to replace an old used car that hit a deer?
column6: <em>...and that's why we save. &nbsp
column7: Paying to register a kid for any number of the activities?
column8: <em>...and that's why we save. &nbsp
column9: It's not a mantra that's shouted in their ears as the check is waved in front of their faces, but one that's repeated often enough that at some point in the future, they'll recognize it as they go about their adult financial activities.
column10: My mother's mantra - gotta pay the mortgage - began to surface in my own brain when I was a young adult now responsible for myself.
column11: <em>Gee, mebbe I can buy that little Miata and take a trip to Cancun with co-workers (...gotta pay the mortgage). &nbsp
column12: After a few moments of assessing my paycheck, I did neither.

column1: There are certain things that we've explicitly done - or tried to do - with the kids through the years.
• Direct a specific percentage of their allowances, and paychecks when older, to their savings account so that they learn that such a thing exists.
<li>When they ask for something, talk through whether they actually need that item or simply want it.&nbsp
column2: The follow-up, typically with toys and electronic games, is to point out that they already items similar to the requested item.&nbsp
column3: Gee, son, a Nerf Rapid-Fire gun would be great but you already have two other Nerf guns and have lost all of the darts...

column1: <li>Ask them to contribute some of their own savings for pricier items or events.&nbsp
column2: This doesn't mean that the first grader chips in for amusement park tickets, but high school students can chip in a portion of the cost of a chorus trip to a distant city
column3: this is especially the case when fundraising opportunities are available.

column1: • Decide what's appropriate for the cost of adult items, such as chipping in on gas or on insurance for the car.
<li>When the kid starts talking about purchasing this or that particular item, talk with them about what else is hanging out there in terms of needs and/or wants.&nbsp
column2: The kids truly aren't used to thinking in these terms and on more than one occasion, a light has gone on behind the eyes and the commentary has been shelved.

column1: There is presently no true financial rationale for saving, even if for no other reason than to avoid having to pay the interest cost of plunking something on the credit card.
column2: Some might have the discipline to immediately pay the items off and run with whatever points or rewards are offered with the card, but the reality is that most will not.&nbsp
column3: The payoff however, will be in the future because the rates cannot stay at these levels indefinitely and when they snap back to higher levels - and reversion to the mean is a bitch - times will be truly harder than what they are at present.&nbsp
column4: Anybody with memory of the interest rate spikes of the early 1980s recalls that these were accompanied by wrenching economic pain
column5: couple that with today's reality of dropping incomes and fewer benefits and what we face in the future will be horribly memorable in its own right.&nbsp
column6: The flip side is that those who are capable of living within their means and saving money will be able to actually prosper.

column1: There is a reset of the economic system coming, although I don't profess to know whether it's coming in the form of a stock market crash, rampant inflation or even the Sta-Puff Marshmallow Man.
column2: My job is help cut through the crap foisted by our economic system and teach the kids so that they don't wind up scarred and crushed by economic hardships because they didn't know better.

Over the holidays, the most recent
column2: poors"">Case-Shiller Index
column3: results were released for October 2012
column4: and the business media ran with them.&nbsp
column5: According to the data, while the index declined .1% from the previous month for both the 10 and 20 city indices, the two were up 4.3% and 3.4% respectively from October 2011.&nbsp
column6: That's good - for the financial sector - since one of the primary reasons for the Fed's artificially low interest rates is to keep a prop under housing so as to keep any more ABS products from imploding.&nbsp
column7: But what continues to catch my attention is that the media predominantly refers to these as home prices, and not housing prices.

column1: There's been a fundamental change in our perspective in the last five decades, especially within the past three.
column2: Spending on discretionary items rose significantly during the Fifties as rising income meant that the typical American family could not only cover the basics - clothing, food, housing - but also save and then have even more to spend on &quot
column3: fun&quot
column4: things.&nbsp
column5: A young adult generation that came of age during the deprivation and fear of the Great Depression and Second World War basked in the relative ability to do as they pleased, even as they remembered the darkness that they'd survived.&nbsp
column6: But that memory didn't get passed along to the subsequent generations even as the sense of entitlement grew.&nbsp
column7: The American family had to have more - more televisions, more automobiles, larger houses - in order to compete with their neighbors and more importantly, feed the new economic model of mass consumption.&nbsp
column8: Leisure became a principal preoccupation and ease of use a goal.&nbsp
column9: Swanson showed us that factory-made frozen dinners could be preheated and the family could share their meal in front of the television set.&nbsp
column10: When mothers began entering the workforce and feeling the stress of juggling provider/homemaker roles, McDonald's told them that you deserve a break today, so go get up and get away...
column11: The push to make things easy was on and has continued in full drive mode for decades now.&nbsp

column1: This drive for the good life has carried over from the small things - TV dinners and fast food - to the larger ticket items and that now includes houses.
column2: As residential development grew larger and builders began to market larger subdivisions, they appropriated the word home and made it their own.
column3: For a generation of young adults that suffered&nbsp
column4: heavily from divorce and broken homes in their youth, the presented images of clean, spic and span homes with smiling families - often unlike their own memories - was a natural sell that played heavily upon their emotions and dreams.&nbsp
column5: Starting around 2007 and afterwards, many families found that the purchased dream was anything but.&nbsp
column6: It wasn't a home but merely a structure, and a pondeously heavy one at that.
column7: There was nothing easy about having to manage the household and work to support an onerous mortgage, taken out to purchase far what was beyond one's means.

column1: Understand the difference between a house and home.
column2: A house is what's peddled by the real estate developers, a structure that's supposed to be sturdy enough to withstand elements and provide a roof over the heads of you and your children.&nbsp
column3: It's nothing more than the accumulation of materials and time put in by construction workers until they move along to the next structure for the next family.&nbsp
column4: Yet&nbsp
column5: a home is more than that.&nbsp
column6: A home is a sense of belonging, a feeling that arises amongst the family members who all help to create it through shared activities and events, many of which are mundane yet still crucial to living a life.&nbsp
column7: Making the home clean, creating and sharing the meals, doing the&nbsp
column8: homework and participating in the various activities and celebrating the events that help the children learn and grow.&nbsp
column9: But creating a home requires work, persistent and sometimes difficult
column10: we've been so cumulatively lulled by the media messages that we forget how much challenge, thought and elbow grease can be involved in rearing children so that they can become - seemingly impossible at moments - productive and moral adults.&nbsp

column1: Ignore the message of the homebuilders and take back the word home.
column2: No builder will&nbsp
column3: appear at the child's ball game or concert.&nbsp
column4: No builder will awaken at 3 AM to comfort a child who's sick or had a nightmare.&nbsp
column5: No builder will respond to the call from the principal about misbehavior.&nbsp
column6: No builder will spend the money - let alone time - to pay for the activity that so interests the child.&nbsp
column7: No builder will quiz the child on spelling or scientific principles and no builder will walk through the report card results with them at quarter's end.&nbsp
column8: All of these are only a small part and parcel of what's involved in creating a home and at no time have I ever seen a builder's representative present.&nbsp
column9: The physical structure in which you live - single family, apartment, condo - are usually irrelevant to any of these things.

Rupert Murdoch recently tweeted that we should expect "
column2: runaway inflation&quot
column3: , or at least that's what he had an assistant tweet, after the passage of the so-called fiscal cliff deal in Congress.
column4: The premise of the commentary centers around the simple fact that the dollar is a fiat currency and it's strength dependent solely upon the perceived ability of the American taxpayer to finance the national debt.&nbsp
column5: Load up on more debt and fail to make the necessary fiscal cuts and Joe and Jane World are going to say meh and begin shifting to some other currency, at which point, well...suffice it to say however, that inflation is precisely what the government and Federal Reserve want.
column6: That said, they might have to wait another month as the pricing of the PracticalDad Price Index is complete for January 2013 and the powers that be didn't get their way.

column1: There was a small decrease in the Total Index (47 grocery store items) from December's 108.07 to January's level of 108.01 (November 2010 = 100).
column2: However, there was a greater than full point drop in the Food only Index (the 37 food items comprised in the entire 47 item market basket), as the Food only Index dropped from December's 114.33 to January's 113.24.&nbsp
column3: It wasn't that so many items dropped across the board as much as one or two grocers of the three sampled were able to replace items with lower cost alternatives.&nbsp
column4: The most dramatic example of this was the effect of Senator Bernie Sanders' Dexcember 2010 filibuster upon diaper prices.&nbsp
column5: I don't know for certain whether there was a direct causal link, but Senator Sanders' memorable refrain was ...they can't afford diapers... and several months later, a major grocer introduced a much lower cost box of diapers.
column6: This particular month, a grocer introduced a much less expensive spaghetti sauce, something done by another grocer early in 2012.&nbsp

column3: Only Congress can get away with slacking off in such a fashion.

column1: I honestly found it hilarious to find that Rupert Murdoch had a Twitter account.

column1: And one last item for the record.
column2: I do not have a Twitter account, but found last year that some enterprising Canadian woman had taken my online name for a Twitter account and had been sending out coupon and sales notices.&nbsp
column3: She'd also set up a Twitter account with a moniker that closely resembled another website's name, doing the same thing.&nbsp
column4: So if you find yourself looking at a tweet from &quot
column5: PracticalDad&quot

While I've tried to stay up on all that's been going on in the economic and financial mess, I'm still an outsider and not privy to the inner workings of the financial machine.
column2: But there's now a site that I'd suggest that you follow and that's called Bankers-Anonymous.com.

column1: The aptly named site is written by a former Goldman employee and hedge fund manager who's come to view his former profession with a somewhat jaundiced eye.
column2: He writes for those who are interested but don't have the knowledge base that he brings to the table.&nbsp
column3: In other words, the rest of us.

column1: Take the time to read what he writes.

It will be time well and fruitfully spent.

All kids have their stories to tell and it's important to listen.
column2: But if my job is to teach, then it's also important to dig further and help them ascertain what really happened and that can be unpleasant for both kid and father.&nbsp
column3: That's why post-mortems are difficult, because they expose the sometimes gruesome unpleasantness of why something occurred
column4: but the post-mortem can also serve to explain how to avoid having it happen all over again.

column1: It was another of those playground incidents in which a kid loses his cool and in the heat of the moment, makes threats and then finally chucks an inflatable rubber ball into the face of another kid in a pique of anger.
column2: Such was the story from one of my own kids, who was the recipient of the ball in the face and on telling the story, becoming rightly angry again.&nbsp
column3: The unfortunate problem was that I didn't just nod my head and sympathize out of blind loyalty, but began to ask questions about the incident
column4: this was especially the case since the ball thrower had a reputation for becoming upset, but never before with Youngest.&nbsp
column5: After hearing the initial report, I asked him to begin again and as he progressed, I would stop him and ask for more detail.&nbsp
column6: What came through was that Youngest wasn't the cause of the initial situation and subsequent anger - spilling the gas, so to speak - but he did make a subsequent comment that lit the match, pushing the other kid over the edge.&nbsp
column7: His remark was under his breath, sotto voce, but it was overheard and that was the spark for the rubber ball explosion.
column8: The quiet comment wasn't remotely helpful to the circumstance at hand.&nbsp

column1: When I understood what happened, I asked what he'd learned from the situation and when there was no response, I commented that he'd figuratively lit a match and tossed it onto spilled gas
column2: this wasn't an errant ball, but one that he did cause to be chucked at him.&nbsp
column3: The first lesson was that if he was going to make remarks, he had to be ready to stand by them.&nbsp
column4: The second lesson was that if there was situation between others, his best course of action was to keep his mouth shut and not make himself a target instead of others.

column1: His response was one of anger and confusion, questioning why I'd take the other child's side instead of his.
column2: I had to explain that I wasn't and that the other child was clearly wrong for pegging him with the ball.&nbsp
column3: But there were lessons to be learned from the situation and my job was to help him learn those lessons so that this didn't happen again, getting hurt for no other reason than opening his mouth when it should have stayed shut.&nbsp
column4: It wasn't what a child would want to hear from Dad, but there it was in all of it's painful reality.

column1: Everyone has a tendency to embellish their own story one way or another.
column2: We make ourselves the heroes in good circumstances and frequently the victims when things don't go our way.&nbsp
column3: This is usually accentuated in children but I have seen a few adults who give the kids a run for their money.&nbsp
column4: What's important for me, as a father, is to slow the process down and help my child figure out exactly what happened.&nbsp
column5: What the progression of events and at what point did things go off the rails?&nbsp
column6: It's not easy and sometimes impossible since kids are neither the most reliable nor objective storytellers in the known universe.&nbsp
column7: But it has to be attempted and if unsuccessful...well, at least you tried.&nbsp
column8: The only sure thing is that your child will be angry with you for not reflexively taking his side in the situation
column9:
but that's part and parcel of being the parent, because it has to happen.

column1:
626,"1","1",,"xhtml","

If you want to strip all of the speciousness away from an issue and understand it's true meaning, try to explain it to a teenager.
column2: When they get it, they typically ignore the niceties and go directly to the meat, often with refreshing candor.&nbsp
column3: So it was that after Middle and a buddy came in from school, I posed them a question in order to see what they'd both understand and say, specifically about the Trillion Dollar Coin.

column1: As we stood in the kitchen, I told Middle that I had some outstanding debts and couldn't pay him his overdue allowance but I could give him a Toonie - a Canadian two dollar coin - that I'd had sitting in my jewelry box.
column2: Middle and his buddy stood there looking first at me and then at the Toonie sitting on the island, then back at me as if I'd lost my mind.&nbsp
column3: To him, this was simply a Toonie, worth about $2.02 at present exchange and nothing I said otherwise made a difference.&nbsp
column4: He pressed my seriousness again and I dropped the charade
column5: I explained the concept of the Trillion Dollar Coin and its proposed use to circumvent the newly breached debt ceiling and then asked them what they thought.

column1: That is such scumbaggery was his single comment.
When I pressed the two of them as to their thoughts on the issue, they came up with the following.
<li>First, nobody in their right mind in our town would accept a Toonie, and especially if it they represented it at the convenience store for an arbitrary value that I'd assigned to it.&nbsp
column2: If they wanted to buy Red Bulls, three bags of Doritos and a gallon of ice cream, the clerk would never accept something that I'd given to them with an arbitrary value attached.&nbsp
column3: Assuming that the guy even took the Toonie, it was still only worth $2.02 American dollars and not the value of the overdue allowance.&nbsp

column1: <li>Second, nobody in their right mind in the real world will see this as anything other than complete nonsense.&nbsp
column2: The debt will still be incurred and the interest will still have to be paid in the real world.&nbsp
column3: The Federal Reserve might go along with the fiction, but the other buyers of government debt still look at such issues as the ability to carry the interest payments and the solvency of the issuer.&nbsp
column4: D'ya think that the Chinese are gonna go along for this?

column2: A quarter is a quarter because there's common acceptance that it's worth that amount.&nbsp
column3: The US government says that the quarter is worth 25 cents and the market accepts that
column4: the quarter will purchase 25 cents worth of a good or service, no more and no less.&nbsp
column5: But when the market no longer believes that a good or service is worth 25 cents, then the market demands another value - usually higher.&nbsp
column6: It doesn't mean that the quarter is worth less than 25 cents, but that it will purchase less than what it purchased before.&nbsp
column7: Said another way, the cost of the good/service has increased because the quarter will purchase less than it did.&nbsp
column8: A candy bar once sold for a quarter - and a guy with a kid in elementary school can remember those days - but today, it sells for more than four quarters
column9: the quarter is still worth 25 cents, but the market has decided that all things considered, the item now takes four times the money as before.&nbsp
column10: The convenience store clerk might not accept my claim that a Toonie is worth all of the junk food bought by the boys since I'm just me and don't have access to intercontinental missiles, carrier battle groups and all of the hookers and blow that Congressional privilege can obtain.&nbsp
column11: In the micro world of the local convenience store, the market has decided that I'm just full of crap.&nbsp
column12: There can also come a point where the market - the many members of the world economy - decides that the US government is likewise full of crap for arbitrarily assigning a large value to a single coin as an accounting dodge.

column2: They themselves realize that this is solely an accounting gimmick and that the Federal Reserve is a willing accomplice to our collective failure to stem spending.&nbsp
column3: But the rest of the world, for whom wealth is a bit more precious and hard-earned, isn't going to look googly-eyed at our grand achievement.&nbsp
column4: They will continue to assess the nation's ability to service and stand good for the debt and will act accordingly and if they see that our national accounting standards have devolved to the level of I still have checks so I can't be out of money, then they'll simply leave our debt issuance alone entirely.
column5: : The result would be that real interest rates would spike - a painful thing - or the Federal Reserve would have to become the sole buyer of government issuance - overt monetization of the debt.&nbsp
column6: So many dollars will be willingly issued with no concern for value that it will be rendered worthless.

column1: The boys' had no idea about the constitutional issue regarding this act and I wouldn't expect them to.
column2: But they were smart enough to appreciate the role of the market in this, which is frankly surprising since those who uphold the market are derided by the economist apologists as out of touch
column3: the government can say and do anything because they're the government and their decree is what matters.&nbsp
column4: But Don Quixote believed in his imaginary world, where a windmill is a dragon and a whore a damsel.&nbsp
column5: If the United States Government plays the Don Quixote, abetted by the Federal Reserve's Sancho Panza, then the world will soon treat them - and us - with the same disregard.&nbsp

column1:
I'm now wondering whether the money spent on college and economics courses will actually ruin the boys' ability to think.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

627,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Our kids are now facing a new world that's different from the one in which they were raised, having been sheltered from reality by parents who in many cases took on debt to maintain a lifestyle that they could no longer afford.
column2: The &quot
column3: new&quot
column4: changes in the tax code - the increase in the social security payroll deduction being only the first - are leading to yet another decline in take-home pay and are eye-opening for recent college graduates.&nbsp
column5: A 21 year-old woman was correct in her assessment that this would lead to longer term effects harmful to the economy, such as retarding the growth of new households for the future.
column6: But these are only the earliest and easiest of the choices that they will face.&nbsp

column1: The simple reality which we face is that there are too many fiscal promises piled upon too small a base of productive assets to adequately cover them.
column2: We're looking at years of federal deficits in excess of a trillion dollars annually as the government becomes the pump which pushes money through the economy via defense spending, Social Security and Social Security Disability Income benefits, the SNAP program.&nbsp
column3: The young college graduate mentioned in the article states that the money now leaving her paycheck to the government via the increased payroll tax will mean less for entertainment.&nbsp
column4: But the cascade of spending and the coming increase in taxes - because meaningfully cutting spending will alienate a good portion of the almost half of the citizenry receiving some government benefit - will mean that more than entertainment is going to go away.&nbsp
column5: The youngsters of Southern Europe - Spain, Greece, Italy - are seeing their prospects disappear and if this country can't get a handle on the spending, then our young adults will follow in their track in several years.

column1:
Because the difference between the United States and Southern Europe is no more than a few years.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

628,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Years ago, I taught Sunday School in suburban DC and was fascinated by the conversations with the then-teens, kids who are now in their early 30s and possibly with children of their own.
column2: The one conversation that sticks with me pertains to fashion and choice of clothing brand
column3: two teens were slamming someone viciously - in absentia, naturally - and when I asked why she so upset them, the first response was that she was a Hollister kid.
column4: They saw my confusion and patiently explained, to the retarded adult, that they simply didn't like anybody who was Hollister and that they spent all of their own time with Polo kids.
column5: It was a slap-in-the-face event that drove home how badly we'd become branded.&nbsp
column6: But does there reach a point at which the kids revolt at the branding and begin to draw their own conclusions on the values that come with branding?

column1: I grew up in a corporate household with corporate values and my last paying gig before opting to stay with the kids was in a corporate headquarters.
column2: I'm no fan of corporations and their exponentially greater political and economic power and one of my great concerns with the kids is how they'll manage to maintain their individuality and integrity in a corporatist society.&nbsp
column3: So I was taken aback when Youngest, the elementary school kid, came home from school and began bemoaning that Disney was thinking of buying DC Comics.&nbsp
column4: He knew of Stan Lee's legacy and that he'd already sold Marvel Comics to Disney, likewise with George Lucas' Lucasfilm sale to the Mouse.&nbsp
column5: That particular news item truly brought a surreal conversation about populating the Star Wars stories with Disney characters. This proposed sale was news to me and as we talked, I asked what it was that bothered him the most.&nbsp
column6: Youngest explained that he was afraid that Disney would dumb down the story lines and characters
column7: and being a boy, he was bothered that the level of violence in the story lines would decrease.&nbsp
column8: We're all concerned today about the propensity of violence but the simple fact is that the typical boy has a natural affinity for agression and making things go boom and comic books are an old-fashioned way of honoring that.

column1: What Youngest was saying, in an elementary level fashion, was his concern that yet another corporate takeover would again take something away from our culture - yes, comic books can be considered cultural - in the quest for profit and earnings per share.
column2: Marvel and Lucasfilm are now iconic, but they each sprouted from the fertile imaginations of Lee and Lucas and did so in humble environments.&nbsp
column3: When everything is controlled by the corporations - financial and otherwise - then we've lost something of ourselves and our national character.&nbsp
column4: We're already at a point where strip shopping centers, office complexes and malls litter enough of the countryside that regional architectural differences are being lost
column5: Topeka is some ways is no different from Savannah, which is no different from Bangor.&nbsp
column6: Couple that with the fact that much of the investing capital is controlled by a small cadre of financial types and we're at risk for not just cultural homogeneity, but also cultural and technological stagnation.&nbsp
column7: Could George Lucas get the backing necessary for his idea?&nbsp
column8: Could Stan Lee manage to obtain the capital to start Marvel today?&nbsp
column9: At least not without having to give up the special something that made these things so distinctive?&nbsp
column10: It's telling that an elementary school kid could at least sense the blandness of a corporate world, controlled by a small cadre of individuals who decide what has merit and how the advertising dollars go to support the brands that they deem of value.

column2: At the time of this long-ago Hollister kid conversation, my wife was pregnant with Eldest, our first-born child.
column3: Eldest's first job in high school was at Hollister and she worked there through this past Christmas season.&nbsp
column4: Corporate policy dictated that all employees wear brand apparel for their shifts and I understand that.&nbsp
column5: But I take comfort in the fact that when she has a preference for shopping, it's at Goodwill.&nbsp
column6:
Maybe Eldest also understands what Youngest understands as well.
