column1:
629,"1","1",,"xhtml","

That time of year is here again, the mid-winter companion of NFL playoff games and college hoops and the bane of fathers everywhere, the Pinewood Derby.
column2: The time when fathers with a clue have to fight to not overtake the project - or not so much - and fathers without a clue roll their eyes and prepare for a long, l-o-o-o-n-g weekend.&nbsp
column3: But this year's different since it's Youngest's last Pinewood and it will be the last of ten consecutive years for which the PracticalDad household has had an entry.&nbsp
column4: It's also the last for me since I've been overseeing the efforts of multiple fathers to set up the track - replete with laser-tripped starter and finish lines and dedicated PC with racing software.

column1: The same question exists this year as before, whether Youngest can win the prize for slowest car and it simply reinforces the surreality of the situation: has he won if he loses or will he fail if he wins?
column2: I'm fortunate though, in that he's not thinking now in terms of sheer losing but producing a car that reflects his slightly goofy sense of humor.&nbsp
column3: With luck, there'll be a universe of two different trophies that he can win, Most Fuel Efficient or Funniest Car.

column1: So the next week is going to be consumed with preparations for the race day - assuring that the software works and that the equipment is up to snuff, that the process is in place for the weigh-in of the cars and that we have enough volunteers in place to manage the process, and that the trophies are completed in a timely and good-looking fashion.
column2: The food will be left up to someone else entirely.&nbsp
column3: But the hardest work will be with Youngest, helping him through the process of creating a decent car without actually taking over the hands-on aspects themselves and that will be more mental, ascertaining in advance what questions have to be asked that can lead him to decisions on how to proceed.&nbsp

column1: Some months ago, I chatted with a mother at the store
column2: this woman had also spent ten years as a cub scout leader for her two sons.&nbsp
column3: I asked whether she missed it, the meeting preparations and all of the background work that came with being a volunteer for a kid's organization.&nbsp
column4: She responded that yes, I actually do miss it.
column5: In the aftermath, you forget the headaches and time spent, the misbehavior and the sheer lunacy that can result from children gathering together for events.&nbsp
column6: When the next weekend's Derby is finished, I suppose that I'll also miss it and everything that it entails.

column1:
630,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It used to all be on the mothers, but even involved fathers are now used to all of the work - preparatory and otherwise - that comes with traveling with kids.
column2: What isn't always obvious is how things change as the kids age and the awareness can creep up on you, smacking you in the head with the figurative lead pipe.&nbsp
column3: This was the occurrence on a recent Christmas holiday trip to Washington, DC.

column1: Some things are the same and I've adapted them over the years.
column2: First is the purely preparatory logistical work that the little kids will never notice and about which they'll absolutely never care.
column3: But as the kids grow over the years, the preparations are adapted by first involving them - flush all of the toilets and lock all of the windows, empty all of the trash and get it to the garbage cans, find the cats before short trips so that they're not locked in a room for three days - and then asking to be responsible for certain jobs.
column4: It doesn't relieve me of the responsibility to oversee their own tasks, but it does make things easier.&nbsp
column5: By the afternoon of our departure over the holiday, I made it a point to stand there amidst the kids and orally recite the list of items.&nbsp
column6: It didn't mean that they'd automatically remember it, but it was one of those osmotic processes that the kids should take in through repetition over the years.&nbsp
column7: <em>Mail stopped.&nbsp
column8: Windows locked.&nbsp
column9: Dog kenneled and cats accounted for.&nbsp
column11: It's a process that helps me and hopefully teaches the kids that these good things only come with preparation.

column1: Second is the status of the family vehicle.
column2: Are the tires alright and headlights okay, or are we driving a padiddle? It's not something that I generally do with the kids, but the obvious one is whether the gas tank is full.&nbsp
column3: The working definition of stupid in my wife's family is to run out of gas, especially because there's a gauge to tell you the status.
column4: The kids are involved in cleaning out the vehicle of old debris and stuff so that it's neat, clean and ready for a fully new load of debris and stuff.&nbsp

column1: Whether traveling overseas or not, safety issues matter although the presence of cell phones makes things easier.
column2: What's the rally point in the event that everybody's separated?&nbsp
column3: Have the kids without - and even with - cellphones learned the phone numbers by heart?&nbsp
column4: Do they remember the name of where we're staying and the area in which it's located?&nbsp
column5: It matters if you're staying at a hotel chain and there are multiple hotels in the area.&nbsp
column6: Are you wearing something that's easily identifiable to them, such as a colored cap?&nbsp
column7: They'll willingly wear identically colored clothing when younger but you're liable to catch some blowback as they age and balk at bilious pink sweatshirts carrying the family reunion announcement.&nbsp

column1: What did bother me was that we had to negotiate wake-up times with the teens, whose body clocks are apparently set to Manila time.
column2: We could certainly say that we'd be moving at a particular early time - say 9 AM for them - but the reality is that it's difficult for kids and teens to simply shift their bedtime and rising routines without some consequence
column3: our response is to simply accept that we'll be moving a little later than the earlybirds.&nbsp
column4: Other parents are free to disagree accordingly.&nbsp
column5: What wasn't negotiable however, was that once they were moving, they weren't to spend their time tethered to Facebook or the cellphone
column6: if they just want to dither electronically, they can do it at home for free.&nbsp
column7: The additional factor was that Youngest is still years away from the teen years and still arises earlier.&nbsp
column8: He consequently got to stroll downtown DC with me and see things that his slumbering siblings missed, such as the construction of Presidential Inaugural Viewing Stand and the National Christmas Tree, albeit in the early morning.

column1: There's an explicit understanding in our household that traveling means that you're going to not only see the local sites, but also eat the local food.
column2: It seems odd, but America is now so culturally homogenous that many kids think of vacation as an opportunity to eat at Applebees or go to the resident mall to shop and these prospects are everywhere.&nbsp
column3: My job in preparing for the trip was to handle the itinerary - my wife handled the accomodations - in such a way that everybody got something of value.&nbsp
column4: The planning was open with the kids and the thought process involved was open as well.&nbsp
column5: It's Christmas in DC and while we're staying in a hotel, the Smithsonian is a superb range of museums and it's free, so like it.
column6: If you want to go the National Zoo, what's the weather forecast and on what day does that make sense? &nbsp
column7: What food is endemic to the DC vicinity?
column8: Surprisingly, I opted for Thai on one evening and the next was a visit to Ben's Chili Bowl.
column9: Part of the thought process was to also have some conversation with them about history and culture, and how something as simple as a restaurant could reflect the personality of an area.&nbsp

column1: Change happens and I like it, it keeps me fresh.
column2: But change is best when some thought is given to it in advance so that it can be managed.&nbsp
column3: Things will always go wrong, but you're not as likely to have a tripbuster if you think things through first, and that's the big lesson for the kids as they age.&nbsp
column4: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
632,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There was an article in MSN Money over the Christmas holiday - Why Teens Fail at Managing Money - with the premise that teens are ill-prepared to survive in the modern financial world.
column2: Several individuals quoted in the article believe that all high schools should be mandated to teach a personal finance course
column3: thirteen states presently require that high schoolers receive such a course.&nbsp
column4: But there's significant blowback from educators who cite the cost involved and also the simple fact that they believe themselves ill-prepared to adequately teach the material.&nbsp
column5: The&nbsp
column6: truth is that&nbsp
column7: personal finance isn't just&nbsp
column8: a series of techniques about cash&nbsp
column12: of not only what they know about money, but&nbsp
column16: aren't derived from discrete lessons at specific points&nbsp
column21: medium of exchange - thereby eliminating the need for barter - and a store of value.&nbsp
column24: how we use money is a store of our&nbsp
column25: values and that comes from immersion within the family.

column1: Both money and debt are tools, as much in their way as a screwdriver or hammer.
column2: But if you give a child a hammer or screwdriver, you see that things don't go the way that the kid expects.&nbsp
column3: Nails are bent to hell and back and learning how to drive a nail straight requires a degree of practice that only comes with time.&nbsp
column4: Kids also tire of the repetitive nature of constantly turning a screwdriver and after some turns, will usually look at you with an okay, can you finish this and we'll move onwards expression.
column5: The upshot is that any skill, let alone mastery, will only come with time.&nbsp
column6: It's a bit absurd to think that giving a kid a course in personal finance in high school will provide them with the requisite skills to successfully manage their finances.&nbsp
column7: Knowing how to budget is only a fraction of the battle if the discipline to maintain it isn't there, and the constant effort to blur need and want makes it problematic.
column8: One of my taglines when I hear the kids mention wanting something is yep...need, want.
column9: That ability to discriminate can only come with constant reminders and conversation and those won't come in schools.

column1: It's also important to know when to use the specific tools and that comes with experience as well.
column2: There's a telling quote from a father within the article, telling in that it gives a glimpse of present attitudes about spending and debt.&nbsp
column3: The father comments that his teen wouldn't know about how to finance the purchase of a computer.&nbsp
column4: My first thought was to wonder why he wasn't sitting down with the kid to examine how to finance a computer purchase.&nbsp
column5: But the next thought was to wonder why a computer would have to be purchased with credit anyways.&nbsp
column6: Kids are deeply susceptible to the advertising-sown want/need confusion, and what a kid actually needs in a computer might be very different from what's really wanted
column7: that confusion can amount to hundreds of dollars.&nbsp
column8: Help the kid work out what's truly best and then explain the cost differential between using money that's been saved and money that's borrowed.&nbsp
column9: Then put that difference in terms of opportunity cost of the next alternative, such as dinner and a movie with friends.
column10: Perhaps the device has to be purchased now, in which case financing might have to be an option.&nbsp
column11: But if the kid can wait, then it might make more sense to wait and save the money instead.&nbsp
column12: The unasked question is whether the father could wait for such a purchase.

column1: Truly learning something and taking it to heart occurs over time, with lessons and comments delivered persistently and consistently.
column2: Once you've gone over something several times - and going over it doesn't mean that it has to be an hour long talk - then develop simple taglines that you can use when the situation comes up again.&nbsp
column3: If I'm paying a repair bill with cash or check, I'll comment ...and this is why we save.
column4: If the kid is yakking on about buying something, I'll simply glance and say yep...want, need.
column5: When we were saving for a trip to Europe, a process that lasted about two years, any of the kids would come up with the suggestion to buy something or do something that required money and my response would be a curt Europe.
column6: There reached a point at which one of the kids started speaking and then cut herself off, saying <em>oh yeah, Europe.&nbsp
column7: The tagline with which I was raised was my mother's we gotta pay the mortgage.
column8: It didn't go into the specifics of which mortgage product is best or how to calculate what we could afford, but it constantly reinforced the lesson of putting the need ahead of the want.&nbsp

column1: The article is correct in the view that many parents do a poor job of teaching about money because we ourselves are poor with money.
column2: Since the end of the Second World War - three full generations - the push has been for consumer spending to drive the economy.&nbsp
column3: This consumption approach is spurred by sophisticated and persistent advertising, and many of today's parents and grandparents have been fully caught up in it, rendering us both poor examples and teachers for the kids. The impact has been such that many baby-boomers are unable to retire because they simply haven't saved and the knock-on effect is that the young adults are now having to compete with the boomers for jobs.&nbsp
column4: <em>(Hmmm, there's a question, what do we owe our elders?)&nbsp
column5: If we want our own kids to avoid that same trap, then we're obligated to do a better job of financial management so that they can learn from us.

column1: Apart from the issue of financing a purchase instead of saving for it, there are two other aspects that highlight how truly out of touch today's financial management principles are with reality.
column2: The first was a teen's comment that his family did discuss the stock market at the dinner table and how it was doing
column3: my own conversations with the kids are about how the stock market is the last place that a simple individual investor like me should be.&nbsp
column4: The market is presently a rigged casino.&nbsp
column5: High Frequency Trading with programmable algorithms make crooked practices like front-running and quote-stuffing make classic investing impossible
column6: likewise the presence of overwhelming liquidity courtesy of the Federal Reserve via the major financial institutions proprietary trading desks utterly divorces the market from the reality of economic life around us.&nbsp
column7: When I know families in middle-class Brady Bunch neighborhoods raising chickens for food, the market is simply not realistic.&nbsp
column8: The second is one contributors comments about the value of learning the principle and value of compound interest saving.&nbsp
column9: In a world in which the savings account rate for kids is .1% and a good CD might be in the area of 1.5%, there's no effective value at all in compounding.&nbsp
column10: The words promote savings but the actions promote spending at the punishment of savers.&nbsp

column1: Children can learn with lesson plans, but what sticks best are the small repeated doses of a consistent set of messages, the so-called teachable moments.
column2: Determine what you want to teach and use pay attention to what's going on around you and those moments will present themselves.&nbsp
column3: If there's a moment that you can have a short conversation, grab it.&nbsp
column4: If not, make it a point to revisit it when the opportunity to talk does present itself.&nbsp
column5:
These repeated lessons over the course of time will do far more to teach the kids about money and personal finance than they'll ever get in a classroom.

column1:
633,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Most movie fans know Christopher Nolan as the renovator and director of the recent Batman movie trilogy.
column2: But many may not be aware that one of his early films, Memento, is considered by some critics to be one of the best suspense films of the century's first decade.
column3: In the film, the protagonist is searching for the killer of his wife, yet suffers from a form of amnesia in which he's incapable of maintaining short-term memories.&nbsp
column4: What's notable about the film is that he works through the problem with the aid of polaroid photos, which he posts to a board and then strings together in an effort to create linkages that make sense to him, a sense of context.&nbsp
column5: This metaphor stays with me because as a parent - whose principal job is to raise the children to take their place in the great, wide world - I'm helping the kids string together their mass of experiences and memories into a recognizable form that gives rich context to the world in which they live.

column1: Ask kids who are home from school what they did that day and you're liable to get an i dunno or perhaps one or two snippets of something.
column2: Many won't take the time to process unless they're prompted to do so and those experiences will most likely remain isolated photos on the memory board unless something happens - by chance or purpose - to pull them together.&nbsp
column3: This isn't about speaking to them as soon as they walk in the door or you pick them up, but it's about making the time and effort to talk with them, to draw them out and learn the experiences so that any conversation can lead to the possibility of making the connections.&nbsp
column4: The conversation can lead to any number of potential topics:&nbsp
column5: <em>how do you complain to the bus driver - or any adult - if you feel you're being unfairly singled out (without sounding like you're whining?)
column6: what is the point of reading &quot
column7: The Great Gatsby&quot
column8: , or any older novel?
column9: why can't you punch a girl back, and what does it mean if she's smacking you in the arm?&nbsp

column1: Conversation might not flow the way that you'd like, and it sometimes doesn't even flow at all.
column2: Well...how 'bout those Mets?
column3: The unfortunate reality however, is that there is an ongoing conversation with your kids and it's coming from the entertainment/media complex.&nbsp
column4: For decades now, the complex has offered up examples with lousy messages, going back to Fast Times at Ridgemont High's Spiccoli, through Beavis and Butthead, South Park's Cartman and all of the gangsta culture thrown about via multiple media.
column5: Violence is endemic, women are demeaned - it might not matter now, but it will when you have a daughter - and poor behaviors such as drinking, drugs and gratuitous sex are celebrated.&nbsp
column6: I'm not Amish and our kids have access to the electronic media, but the point is that unless you're willing to fully disconnect their media access, you have to be prepared to engage them whenever possible so that they begin to make the connections that you know truly need to be made.

column1: Helping them make these connections, helping them build a coherent framework through which to interpret the world and interact with it, is not a one-off process.
column2: This is a life-long endeavor and commences from the day of their birth
column3: if we handle it properly, it will continue until the day of our death.&nbsp
column4: But the connections that are made will take these seemingly isolated instances and not only link them, but transform them from a two-dimensional board into a three-dimensional structure that helps them navigate their own lives and sustains them in those truly dark places that can exist in adulthood.&nbsp
column5: This is our purpose as parents, to raise them to make their way.&nbsp
column6: Leaving the conversations to the media complex is ultimately as harmful as starving them.&nbsp
column7: &nbsp

column2: And while they can't or don't always want to show it, they do want your attention and conversation.
","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
634,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The kids know from listening to me - typically in a shoe-propelled rant at the University of Phoenix television commercial - that their enrollment in a for-profit institution is unlikely.
column2: We live in a corporate age and this is just another attempt by the corporations to milk us for increasingly scarce dimes.&nbsp
column3: But if there's strength in numbers and we hold that education truly is critical in this post-manufacturing &quot
column4: knowledge-based&quot
column5: economy, there is a crucial role for the government to be involved.&nbsp
column6: There are three policy legs - tax, fiscal and monetary - and both state and federal governments are involved in the tax policy with tax-advantaged savings programs to help with tuition.&nbsp
column7: But in a time of rapidly increasing tuitions, tax policy is the least important.&nbsp
column8: What's the value of a tax savings if you can't afford the education in the first place?&nbsp
column9: That leaves fiscal and monetary policy, and which is the true place for the government?

column1: For the greater part of our nation's first century, government had no role in education whatever
column2: any schools formed were solely at the local level to provide the rudiments of reading, writing and arithmetic.&nbsp
column3: Higher education was available via private institutions and was the province of the affluent or the exceptional, who worked assiduously to finance their studies.&nbsp
column4: The federal government's initial foray came - incredibly enough - during the Civil War when the urgings of an idealist Congressman led to the passage of the Morrill Act of 1862 and the creation of the Land Grant universities.
column5: Even here, the national government didn't provide money, but simply free land - and boy howdy, did we have it then - with the caveat that the subscribing states sell part of the land for seed money for an institution, to be built on a portion of that free land.&nbsp
column6: The congressman's efforts were the fusion of two elements:&nbsp
column7: one that he believed and another that he understood.&nbsp
column8: The belief was that a person would both prosper and become a more enlightened citizen if they had access to an education that provided the skills and tools to better their circumstances.&nbsp
column9: The understanding was that the nation required a skilled, educated populace for it's growing and changing needs.&nbsp
column10: One fed the other in a virtuous circle.&nbsp

column1: The Morrill Act also laid out the premise that meeting the educational needs of the population were best left at the state level
column2: different regional needs could be best managed at the lower level, which had greater familiarity with its needs and circumstances.&nbsp
column3: So apart from creating a framework within which the states could establish their systems - building the sandbox - the federal government stepped aside and left the growing fiscal needs of higher education to the various states.&nbsp
column4: It was throughout the growing industrialization and prosperity of the next century that the states, with the footing provided by the Morrill Act, created an infrastructure of institutions to provide an reasonably affordable higher education to the young.&nbsp
column5: The apogee of this educational availability occurred in the years after the Second World War, when the nation entered an era of affluence that had never before been seen in history.

column1: But this availability was funded directly - via fiscal spending - by the states.
column2: Times were flush and the resources existed to fund higher education, and the states put up the funding to make education affordable for the masses.&nbsp
column3: Labs were funded, buildings built and faculty salaries paid by purposeful state funding.&nbsp
column4: But the world changes before we're aware of it and as funding continued, additional demands were made upon resources by others and state funding for social needs rose.&nbsp
column5: The states also felt the impact of the &quot
column6: Reagan Revolution's&quot
column7: mantra that government isn't the solution, it's the problem.
column8: Spending was questioned and the line items that could actually be managed were slowly pared away
column9: but spending on social needs programs continued and the emphasis in state government spending went from preparation to caretaking.&nbsp
column10: By the first decade of the 21st century, per capital spending by state governments - the fiscal policy - was in decline.&nbsp
column11: State colleges and universities were seeing that the average family incomes of their students was rising
column12: it's counter-intuitive since you'd think that was a good thing.&nbsp
column13: But what it means is that the students from the higher income families themselves were being squeezed out of the private and into the public institutions, while the students from the lowest income families were squeezed out of the public institutions entirely.&nbsp
column14: It's now where we're at, with purposeful fiscal spending in decline by the states.

column1: While there was an apogee and subsequent decline in fiscal spending and policy for higher education, there was also movement in the monetary policy towards higher education.
column2: While fiscal policy pertains to actual spending - putting your money where your mouth is - monetary policy is about simply making the money available, in volume and at low cost.&nbsp
column3: The crunch and upwards in student debt occurred in the first decade of the century, propelled by twin engines.&nbsp
column4: The first engine was the real need for borrowed money as the tuition finally outpaced the ability of the average family's falling incomes, forcing many families and students to truly borrow large sums.&nbsp
column5: The other engine was the glut of easy money made available as the Federal Reserve truly opened up the money supply after the dotcom and housing bubble collapses.&nbsp
column6: Families were now forced to let the students take on the debt themselves as their own circumstances worsened, and the Fed's easy money policy made it available in spades.&nbsp
column7: As states scaled back their per-capital student spending and costs rose, the federal government stepped in with easy money.

column1: Here's the thing about monetary policy and higher education however:
column2: it's a chicken-or-the-egg proposition.&nbsp
column3: Escalating tuition and decreasing government support made an easy monetary policy seem beneficial since abundant money made the college education work.&nbsp
column4: Yet part of the tuition problem was due to the existence of an easy money policy.&nbsp
column5: On one hand, institutions had no impetus to control their spending since the money was available, even if it was funneled through the students from the lenders.&nbsp
column6: As competition raged amongst the institutions, they began to market the experience as well as the education and money was frankly spent on sheer frivolities
column7: if your college markets a climbing wall and Mongolian grill, then it's frivolous.&nbsp
column8: On the other hand, the easy money availability led to predatory recruitment practices by for-profit institutions
column9: the present default rate at for-profit institutions is double that at public and triple that at non-profit institutions.&nbsp
column10: The money created an impetus to defraud the students.

column1: There is a distinct difference between the effects of fiscal and monetary policy on higher education.
column2: But the effect of easy monetary policy is largely the same in higher ed as in the other arenas:&nbsp
column3: it breeds laziness and radically increases the prospect of moral hazard.&nbsp
column4: The laziness is on the part of the public, who simply look at the low cost loans and the advertising and don't consider other aspects until it's too late
column5: the institutions are equally lazy as the stream of funding lulls them into thinking that choices don't have to be made and decisions can be deferred.&nbsp
column6: The stream of funding propels the amoral into acts of immorality as the rewards far outweigh the cost of the penalty.&nbsp
column7: If you doubt this, ask yourself whether the penalties meted out to institutions even meet - let alone exceed - the profits garnered.&nbsp

column1: Fiscal policy however, literally means that you're putting the money where your mouth is.
column2: It means that there's an actual debate - contentious, perhaps - about not only how society perceives the value of higher education but also how funding is apportioned to support that value.&nbsp
column3: If the nation truly believes that education matters for the good of the person and the nation, then funding should be allocated to support it accordingly.&nbsp
column4: As the phrase goes, money talks and bullshit walks.

column2: We've confused money with the real and productive assets that support the debt that's been incurred.&nbsp
column3: The costs of an education have far outstripped the debt-servicing ability of the average American family's declining income, yet we've restructured ourselves as both a service and knowledge-based economy that notionally requires a college degree for any real financial success.&nbsp
column4: Student debt is now a bubble and the smell of the easy money has led to poor personal decisions and corrupt business decisions that taint monetary policy.&nbsp
column5: Even if tuition at an increasing number of institutions is cut, the college cost/family income ratio is so disproportionate - and the job market so bleak - that it would take decades for any proportionality to be restored.&nbsp
column6: If we truly value education at both the personal and national level, then there's no other choice but to provide fiscal policy support to the public institutions.&nbsp
column7: The eras of easy money and unfettered prosperity are over.&nbsp
column8: Dead.&nbsp
column10: There is a time coming, and soon, when we'll have to make conscious choices first about what we truly value and then about how we'll allocate the remaining resources amongst those values. Our mettle is going to be tested and it will be truly unpleasant.&nbsp
column11: If there's a bright side, it's the realization that the value question isn't new ground but has already been addressed.&nbsp
column12: At least we don't have to revisit in the midst of a civil war.&nbsp

column2: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

Disproportionate rising costs,  slashed public education budgets and arguments over what to afford in  the face of out-of-control public spending merge with falling incomes  and inadequate job growth to create huge angst and debate over where we  go from here.&nbsp
column3: The present model appears to be broken.&nbsp
column4: Is it fixable  and if so, how do we fix it?&nbsp
column5: Or do we chuck it completely and simply  adopt another model?&nbsp
column6: With the present distrust of government, perhaps  we should just leave higher education to the private sector?&nbsp

column1: Youngest and I sat watching The Big Bang Theory the other evening when The University of Phoenix, a for-profit university, ran a commercial.
column2: In the ad, a contented looking African-American woman was driving through a homogeneously corporate parking lot in search of a space.&nbsp
column3: As she drove, the voice-over announced that the University of Phoenix was working in conjunction with other major American corporations to provide the skills needed by Americans to earn a good and productive living.&nbsp
column4: The list of corporations was impressive - Microsoft, Avis, Google, McDonalds, Cisco, Adobe - and one that most would associate with the upscale white-collar jobs desired by most.&nbsp
column5: It was a provocative message that resonated to the higher ed themes that concern us most:&nbsp
column6: what jobs are out there to provide for me and a family and how can I make a decent-enough wage to repay the debt that I'm going to incur?&nbsp
column7: This would presumably be what Secretary of Education Arne Duncan referred to as a &quot
column8: ...very good debt to have&quot

column1: Before we start to entertain the notion that the private sector is the best provider of higher education, let's consider some statistics thus far:
• In September 2012, the federal Department of Education released results showing that the three year student loan default rates were 13.4%.
column2: Bur of this,<em> the default rate for loans to student at for-profit institutions came in at 22%, or more than one-fifth of all loans to students in that sector
column3: the default rate for students in public institutions was about 11%.
column4: While there's no word on this sector breakout, the most recent data is that the overall student default rate has climbed to greater than 15% as of October 2012.

column1: • For-profit institutions have been involved in multiple investigations and settlements for illegal or unethical practices, such as deceptively marketing to veterans to gain access to generous veteran educational benefits.
column2: See also here, here, and here.

column1: • The graduation rate of for-profit institutions is only 28%, less than half of that at public universities.
Let's shift outwards, from the private-sector education system to the private sector in general.
column2: The private sector is entirely that - private - and exists to enrich the owners and members of the private sector.&nbsp
column3: The private sector generally consists of any for-profit business and can range from Joe's Shoe Repair to Exxon.
column4: In the case of for-profit universities however, the private sector consists of large corporations, capital holding companies and some exceptionally wealthy individuals.&nbsp
column5: So who owns the for-profits?&nbsp
column6: There are hundreds of actual for-profit institutions, but we'll look at four for our purposes:&nbsp
column7: University of Phoenix
column8: Kaplan University

column1: <li>University of Phoenix is owned by the Apollo Group (NYSE), and the principal shareholder is John Sperling, now a billionaire.&nbsp
• Kaplan University is a subsidiary of the Washington Post (NYSE), among whose principal shareholders are Aberdeen Asset Management, Berkshire Hathaway and ING Investment Management.

column2: Howell, a wholly owned company of Versa Capital Management in Philadelphia.

column1: <li>ECPI is a smaller, regional for-profit operating in the southeast US, principally in the Tidewater region of Virginia and the Carolinas
column2: it is owned by the Dreyfus family and the founder's son, Mark, is currently the President.

column1: Most of these entities exist to maximize Return on Investment and Equity, nothing more and nothing less.
column2: While I can't speak for the family-owned institution, there's no effective oversight of the entity that might be provided by a Board of Directors that's tasked with specific responsibilities and is able to help parse out those instances when profit might compete with the original charges of the founding charter.&nbsp
column3: Frankly, for the great majority of for-profits, there is no other original charge in any founding charter.&nbsp

column1: If you follow, many of the actionable complaints about the for-profits are in the area of admissions.
column2: Fines have been levied and paid by multiple for-profits because of deceptive advertising
column3: pertinent rates - graduation, employment - were falsified and loan programs misrepresented in order to gain enrollees.&nbsp
column4: The intent of the actions has been to gain access to the loans that were easily available via lax standards, and you don't blow a trillion dollar loan bubble by upholding underwriting standards.&nbsp
column5: There are existent study programs in the for-profits and there are certainly graduates, but the reality is that many marginally qualified students were enrolled without the infrastructure in place to assist them once they were there.&nbsp
column6: But even after the student left, the school was able to keep the money and the responsibility for that money was still left to the student.

column1: Does that also happen at the public sector and non-profit sector?
column2: Sure.&nbsp
column3: But the difference is that the institutions in the public and non-profit sectors are subject to a more rigorous accreditation standard than are the for-profits.&nbsp
column4: There are also public and not-for-profit charters that provide some measure of guidance beyond the simple profit motive and Boards that are both composed of a more diverse group of people, as well as being closer to an effective oversight level than the Board of a major corporation that owns a for-profit institution as a division. Given these aspects, the moral hazard promoted by a monetary policy of easy availability and low interest rates is lesser than for that of an entity for whom profit is the principal and overwhelming measure.&nbsp

column1: There is a niche for institutions that cater to non-traditional students and entities like the University of Phoenix grew out of an effort to fill that niche and do so profitably.
column2: Profit by itself isn't a bad thing, either.&nbsp
column3: But the absence of any effective oversight and more importantly, an exceptionally easy monetary policy that invites moral hazard, led to a morphing of a niche into something that has saddled the nation and its citizens with inexcusable results.&nbsp
column4: The private sector should stick with the niche, but the bulk of the education of our young people should be left with the public and non-profit arenas.

column8: - PracticalDad's Father

column1: My father's comment to me as a teenager came back to me when I read that there was a move afoot in Congress to tax legalized marijuana after passage of the legalization referendums in Washington and Colorado.
column2: After decades of demonization and imprisonment, the federal government is simply going to shift gears and tax it for the revenues.&nbsp
column3: My father's message was that the system was built to look out for others, and in the 1970s, others meant minorities and women.
column4: But the message is still pertinent even if heavily modified.&nbsp
column5: The system now is built to look out for itself and the people - regardless of race, religion or gender - exist to serve this equal-opportunity system.&nbsp
column6: This latest iteration is a message that I've passed along to my own kids on several occasions.&nbsp

column1: This article prompted several things to occur to me as I was otherwise occupied today.

<li>The article referenced that probable jurisdiction for the regulation of legalized marijuana would reside with the ATF (aka the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms) although it could be renamed the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Marijuana and Firearms.&nbsp
column2: If it does reside there, a little honesty - like that's going to happen - would be refreshing:
column3: rename it the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Marijuana, aka The ATM.&nbsp

column1: • Successful politicians understand the importance of the care and feeding of their constituencies. A significant constituency in the law-and-order world is the private prisons lobby, which contributes millions to politicians
column2: they strongly oppose legalization since a fair minority of the inmates are there for marijuana related offenses.&nbsp
column3: Legalization is a threat to their revenue stream and if the Congress is to successfully feed and care for the prison lobbyists, then something must replace the lost revenue stream.&nbsp
column4: If pot is legalized, what's criminalized?

column1: <li>With all of the concern over terrorists - foreign and domestic - and homegrown whackos toting real hardware, then firearms might shift from the ATF to the Department of Homeland Security.&nbsp
column2: DHS has significantly upgraded their weaponry with thousands of real automatic weapons and millions of hollow-point bullets
column3: they sorely need a reason to justify this.&nbsp
column4: Securing and maintaining control of the sheer number of weapons domestically requires the administrative heft of a larger DHS instead of the ATF.&nbsp
column5: If the government can work with the media to sufficiently scare the populace, then having one of the targeted guns could become a truly criminal offense.&nbsp
column6: Wait a minute...
column7: Now there's a win-win scenario.

column1: It's our responsibility as parents to look out for the well-being of our children.
column2: Make sure that you don't start believing that the government is your ever-dependable ally.

The most recent talk in the macro world is now about currency wars as nations devalue their currencies in a race to the bottom with the goal of making their products more attractive to overseas buyers.
column2: The offshoot of devalued currencies can be inflation, which is what the central bankers and treasury folks want.&nbsp
column3: But while all of that is in the macro world, what's happening in the micro world of the grocery shelf in front of you?&nbsp
column4: If the bankers saw the 47 item PracticalDad marketbasket, they'd waste a bit more ink because the February 2013 index fell to 107.81 from January's 108.01 (November 2010 = 100).&nbsp

column6: The Food-only Index is still three quarters of a point below the high of 114.33 reached in December 2012.

If you want to have a sense of what's going on at the moment with the economy and what the fuss is about with currency wars, it's helpful to understand the five letters CIGXM.
column2: They're aren't random letters and it isn't an acronym
column3: these are the five variables for a basic economics formula for the determination of a country's Gross Domestic Product:&nbsp
column4: C + I + G + (X - M).&nbsp
column5: These aren't random variables but instead delineate the five core categories of aggregate spending that drive a nation's economy.&nbsp
column6: The five are:

column1: I = Investment Spending (aka business investment, what companies spend in order to earn money)
While they're listed in a particular order, it's more helpful to think of them in some historical context.
column2: Each plays a role but not always in equal portions
column3: each however, has provided an outsized contribution in a period of our history so let's look at them in order of history so that it makes some sense.&nbsp
column4: Rewritten as development drivers, the equation could be I + (X - M) + G + C.

column1: Remember that for the first 60 or so years of our nation's history, we were mostly an agrarian nation.
column2: The industrial aspect didn't truly take off until around the 1840s when innovations in manufacturing and transportation gave the first outsized push to the national economy.&nbsp
column3: We'd grown beforehand, but it was largely on the back of our agriculture and harvesting of our natural resources until then.&nbsp
column4: But the industrialization began in earnest in the 1840s, especially with the textile industry as mills grew up in river towns across the country, fed by the cheap cotton that now came up in bulk from the south.&nbsp
column5: This was the first stirring of the I - Investment - portion
column6: spending by businesses to domestically produce what was needed by a growing nation.&nbsp
column7: It was one thing to build a transcontinental railroad, but the businesses that built them needed the items to make them run:&nbsp
column8: locomotives, steel, and even the machinery necessary to build them in the first place.&nbsp
column9: Likewise with textiles, guns, and everything else that grew with the young, spreading nation.&nbsp
column10: This I portion drove the economy through the First World War and into the 1920s before it finally collapsed with the Great Depression.

column1: The national development was also spurred through this period by an increasing drive to export American products abroad - the X variable.
column2: Developing and spanning a nation required vast amounts of basic manufactured goods, such as steel.&nbsp
column3: With the natural resources here, these industries grew dramatically so that we needed less imported machinery as we manufactured more and more of our own necessary materials.&nbsp
column4: By the First World War, we'd developed a huge export driven machine, especially to the British and French&nbsp
column5: as they desperately fought the Germans.&nbsp
column6: We lent money to them in huge amounts and with the end of WWI, we took over as exporter to the world and ran a massive trade surplus <em>(X - M, with X &gt
column7: M).
column8: The thrifty Chinese have used the same mercantilist policies as we did during those years, actually lending us the money - via purchasing of US Government debt and subsequent federal deficit spending - to purchase their goods at Walmart.&nbsp
column9: For about the past two decades, we've imported far more and run chronic trade deficits<em> (X - M, with X &lt

column1: The economy was mired through the first years of the Great Depression as everything - and I mean everything - literally collapsed.
column2: Hoover actually did some basically good things, but was constrained by the notion that the government had to balance the books and if there were no tax revenues then there could be no spending.&nbsp
column3: FDR's arrival in Washington led to the adoption of deficit spending that was proposed by John Maynard Keynes, who used this very formula as the basis of Keynesian economics.&nbsp
column4: Keynes was literally saying <em>Dude, if C and I are shot and nobody's got the money for anything, then G is the only gun left in the arsenal, so go for it.&nbsp
column5: In his defense, Keynes didn't mean that the government should go hogwild like a horny cowboy just paid after a cattle drive up the Chisholm trail
column6: he was clear that when things were back on an even keel, the government should pay off the debt.&nbsp
column7: Shore, Jethro, hit the town but jes' 'member that youse gotta set some money aside fore when yer too old to be a-drivin' herd.

column2: Like PJ O'Rourke once wrote:&nbsp
column3: giving money and power to politicians is like giving whiskey and car keys to teenage boys.

column1: The truth is that the government continued spending through the Second World War and actually did try to control itself at the end of the war.
column2: The budget had to be balanced and that naturally led to huge slashes in defense spending and the question, <em>if G is no longer the driver to pay for I and the world is literally wrecked, what variable becomes the driver?&nbsp
column3: Oh yeah, C - us.
column4: There has been a deliberate effort to get the American consumer to part ways with the income in the past three generations and it's been wildly successful as first credit card and then student debt hit massive levels.&nbsp
column5: As the consumer began to actually max out in the 1990s, the federal government's spending reached massive levels and it too began running chronic budget deficits but this government spending helped mask the increasingly tapped-out consumer condition. How?&nbsp
column6: Via immense spending with funding courtesy of the Chinese and easy credit courtesy of the Federal Reserve.&nbsp

column1: Are you seeing where we now are and where this is going?
column2: C is now as tapped as G.
column3: There is some controversy as some American businesses - I - have significant money parked offshore and aren't truly using it productively and members in G want to see it come home.
column4: But the folks in I - companies like Caterpillar and Apple - are resistant because they simply aren't stupid.
column5: <em> Aw hell, Jethro wants more money but if I let him have it, he'll jes' spend it a-whorin' and drinkin' up in Abilene...&nbsp
column6: They recognize that things won't end well and are trying desperately to hang onto the money to tide them over.

column1: So if the domestic C and G are tapped, and I is keeping it locked up away from G because G is a horny drunk.
column2: The only driver left is X and the new currency wars of nations actively devaluing their currency are an effort to make their products more affordable to other nations.
column3: This is the impetus of Japan as it devalues the currency to keep business flowing to it's export driven economy.&nbsp
column4: This is also partially our strategy, although the other intent is to pay off the debt with a devalued dollar.&nbsp
column5: More countries will take this approach - Venezuela's overnight devaluation of 46% is the newest example -and what some term the race to the bottom will continue.
column6: But as everybody pursues X, the value of any trade surplus is negated as the respective currencies are destroyed.
column7: Everybody's come to Abilene for one last mind-bending debauch

column1: Any cowboy with a lick of sense knew that an Abilene bender would be followed by a blistering hangover.
column2: But the thinking of our present crop of hands in G is this:
column3: <em>Hangover?&nbsp
column4: Hell, I caint get no hangover ifen I jes' keep a-drinkin'.&nbsp

column1: The tagline in the blogosphere is that this isn't going to end well.
column2: And it won't.&nbsp

column1:
639,"1","1",,"xhtml","

So the Keynesian view of macroeconomics is based upon the simple formula of C + I + G + (X - M) and the reality is that the Consumer (C) and the Government (G) are tapped out.
column2: The business sector with cash is sitting on the sidelines. We're watching multiple countries - principally the US and Japan - setting the scuttling charges on their currencies as they sink them in pursuit of devaluation to spur exports
column3: the fact that the system is cluttered with so much debt that nobody is really going to buy makes the policy folks look dumb.&nbsp
column4: How does this macro play effect my family at the micro level?

column2: send you shill messages with the promise of the real information for only $29.95.&nbsp
column3: But there are no magic answers, no way to fully innoculate yourself unless you opt to move to a doomstead in the midst of Montana and buy your kids their own personalized .38 snubnoses.&nbsp
column4: <em>Mommy!&nbsp
column5: Daddy!&nbsp
column6: The Tooth Fairy brought me a shiny new hollowpoint!!&nbsp
column7: When that idea truly circulates at a mass level, then even the doomsteads won't be safe because we'll have regressed to the most primal level and it's the director's cut of Mad Max at your neighborhood...neighborhood.
column8: The solutions are so mundane - like, sooooo not abracadabra - that I've pondered for a week whether to even finish this article.

column1: The management of CIGXM at today's family level is about preparing the kids for that great oxymoron, the constancy of change.
column2: People will adapt and change as the fabric of society warps and yaws to the greater movements that occur in the world.&nbsp
column3: In the case of CIGXM, there are three great movements.&nbsp

column1: The first is that the systemic model of consumption - existing for about three generations now - is exhausted and the efforts to continually stimulate consumption simply and boldly illustrate that we the people have simply become fodder for the greater benefit of a system.
column2: We must understand that the majority of policy actions are designed to separate us from our money for the benefit of an economic system whose wealth is predominantly controlled by a very small percentage of the population.
column3: If it sounds overtly political, the simple reality is that it is
column4: money and power for certain people are attractors to one another akin to crap and stink.&nbsp
column5: The effective neutering of the regulatory structure via the repeal of Glass-Steagal and the uncontrolled entry of dollars into political coffers has allowed a stench that permeates society and actively affects the health of our younger generations. Understand that the constant ring of buy! buy! support the economy! only serves the true interests of a relatively few.

column1: The second is that in the age of globalization, increases in business spending don't automatically mean an increase in American jobs.
column2: The short-term drive for profits means that the cost of labor has become a more flexible factor in cost control than retooling and reinvestment.&nbsp
column3: As with the consumption model, the unfettered access to political votes that comes from uncontrolled campaign finance means that tax advantages also accrue regardless of where the jobs are located.

column1: The final is that we're going to be entering a true national dialogue over the real role of government, particularly at the federal level.
column2: The Keynesian model of government spending as an economic driver is also exhausted as the federal debt - nominal and real (accounting for the true unfunded liabilities) - has reached the point that the dollar itself is endangered.&nbsp
column3: Issues such as the legalization of marijuana and gun control will beg the question whether the government exists to serve the people as set out by the founding fathers, or whether it exists to serve itself at the expense of the people.&nbsp
column4: What does it mean if the government propounds the view for decades that a substance is inherently harmful and dangerous but alters that view within the course of weeks with an eye to taxation?&nbsp
column5: What does it mean when local police departments are forced to announce that it cannot or will not answer certain crime calls but the people are actively discouraged from owning the means through which they can protect themselves?&nbsp
column6: Further, what does it mean that the federal government simultaneously purchases immense quantities of ammunition for it's own internal security arm?&nbsp
column7: What is the perceived threat that justifies such prosaic, yet vital, actions?

column1: What this means is that what the family is undergoing isn't recessionary, but actually regressionary.
column2: The discretionary spending patterns of past decades are falling away with each thousand dollars of family income lost.&nbsp
column3: Parents will have to be conscious of how their income is spent, knowing that the kids have to be educated with as little debt as possible, the house paid for and their own elder years covered with little expected help from the future government.&nbsp
column4: There will have to be a greater awareness of the world around them and an explicit examination of their own values as those values are expressed in how the family monies are spent.&nbsp

column1:
640,"1","1",,"xhtml","

I was taken aback to read Paul Krugman's recent column,
column2: emc=rss&amp
column3: _r=0"">Kick That Can, over the weekend.
column4: There's been considerable press and debate over the economic necessity - or not - of austerity and the events taking place in Greece put a very human face upon it.&nbsp
column5: Austerity is now in the pipeline here at home and the debate is on over how much debt is supportable and at what point the plug is pulled on further spending.&nbsp
column6: Krugman's stance is that the damage of reducing government spending - remember C+I+G+(X-M) - with no other driver available would be too much for the economy.
column7: Of course, the bulk of government spending at the moment is directed towards either the sandbox wars or untouchable entitlement spending which add nothing to reinvestment.&nbsp
column8: After reading his column, all that I could think of were forest fires.

column1: The US Forest Service was founded by Teddy Roosevelt as we'd gone through our lumber resources like a hot knife through butter.
column2: Protecting the forests meant protecting it from any threat, including  that of forest fire.&nbsp
column3: Fire killed trees and left areas denuded for years  to come.&nbsp
column4: But through decades of study and experience, the Forest  Service learned that there was actually a place and a purpose for fire
column5: while it did damage, it also cleared away the undergrowth that clogged  the forest floor and prevented substantive new growth if left  untreated.&nbsp
column6: My family and I have driven through smoke-choked areas, the roads marked with signs advising that there were controlled fires ahead.
column7: Clear away the debris and invasives and set the stage for the real new growth.

column1: This is also the way of capitalism and why capitalism has proven to be such a good economic model for real growth.
column2: Credit is misallocated over  time and even with real growth, there is a considerable amount of  deadwood that builds up.&nbsp
column3: The downturns are occasions when the deadwood  is cleared away and the stage is set again for further growth.&nbsp
column4: In terms  of humanity, the effect is one of job loss and economic pain and those  are the realities that have to be addressed by public assistance  programs and personal preparation.&nbsp
column5: It's not an idea that is popular or  pleasant, but it is the reality in which we have to live.&nbsp
column6: Despite our best public and private efforts, things are messy and there will be real-life pain.

column1: Some argue that we haven't had true capitalism for more than a decade and I can ascribe to the idea of bifurcated capitalism, capitalism for the masses who must pay for their financial errors while the Too-Big-To-Fail institutions are protected from their excesses and errors.
column2: So much has been spent, so much debt incurred, in preventing any failure that might clear away the undergrowth - and yes, even good wood - that the economic forest is thoroughly dense with should-be dying businesses and kudzu-like predatory practices that siphon off so much real wealth.&nbsp
column3: What's happening now is the opposite of forest fires
column4: it's the rampant addition of fertilizing liquidity across the financial spectrum in the hope that the good wood will somehow grow fast enough that it will eventually actually overtake the forest again.&nbsp
column5: But this is impossible since the fertilizer not only goes to the invasives as well, but they gain even more by leeching onto the healthy growth and siphoning off of them until they finally succumb.&nbsp
column6: The result is a blighted, tangled mess that produces nothing of value.&nbsp

column1: Despite the best efforts of Forest Service and Federal Reserve, there will be forest fires.
column2: But so many aspects have come together that I fear a true conflagration, an economic burn that will lay waste to the nation's economy:

column1: <li>The repeated deficits that ratchet up the national debt to levels that are simply unpayable
<li>The failure of the Congress to even pass a rudimentary budget that actually addresses our priorities
<li>The willingness of the Federal Reserve to abet this travesty by expanding their balance sheet to handle the newly printed government debt
<li>The continuing uncontrolled actions of the Too-Big-To-Fail institutions that further lever themselves to levels of derivatives that make the levels of 2008 pale
<li>The unwillingness or inability of the government to regulate these institutions and bring their actions to heel
• Further, the failure to meaningfully prosecute for the financial crimes - and yes, they are crimes - so that a truly painful punishment is exacted and a lesson is taught
• The willful compliance of the business networks in propagating a view that all is well and that is out of touch with the reality on Main Street.
Bad news sells but in my worst moments, I have to concede that the next forest fire could rival that which struck the 1920s German Weimar Republic or the 1990s Soviet Union.
While this kind of view is often nay-sayed and derided, the reality is that this concern is permeating our society and especially in how it impacts families and child-rearing.
column2: There's been an awareness of helicopter parenting and well-deserved criticism of it since it doesn't augur well for children who must move into adulthood.&nbsp
column3: Sites such as Free Range Kids question whether we've become too over-protective and promote a more balanced view of society's threats.
column4: There's an understanding that the economy has shifted tectonically and the conventional wisdom of how to succeed is actually hurting our young people by saddling them with toxic debt.&nbsp
column5: Even before they reach that young-adult level, we're becoming aware that our teens are financially illiterate, even for surviving in an economic consumption model that's simply unsupportable moving forward. The upshot is that while nobody in the mainstream is willing to say it, the concerns are circling at the family level.&nbsp

column1: As parents, our role is to not just to provide food and shelter, but ultimately to raise children who have the resiliency to survive what life throws at them.
column2: There will always be forest fires and it's our jobs to give them the character and tools to manage through them.&nbsp
column3: But our collective failure to press for action only sets the stage for fires that will burn through everything and scar our children for generations.&nbsp

This afternoon marks Youngest's final Blue-Gold Banquet as a cub scout, the one at which he formally leaves because he's now too old.
column2: He has chosen to move on to boy scouts and part of the ceremony will involve him and his four compatriots officially becoming members of different troops and when he crosses that bridge, ten years of cub scouting for the PracticalDad family will be finished.&nbsp
column3: Raising kids is a forest-for-the-trees experience except for the moments when you reach a ridge that permits you to view you to see where you are on the journey, providing a panoramic view of where we've been with the kids and where we still need to go.

column1: As the literal and figurative greybeard for this particular pack, I've taken on much and have planned the actual ceremony
column2: walking through the ceremony has struck me as to the passage of time.&nbsp
column3: When we began this process, Eldest was in elementary school and herself a girl scout.&nbsp
column4: Middle began scouting in the first grade and Youngest was only a baby in Mom's arms.&nbsp
column5: What I'll see this afternoon is Eldest back from college as a surprise for Youngest, and Middle in the audience as a high school student.&nbsp
column6: Another trail from the road is circling back onto itself, closing the loop and a look back from the ridge reveals any number of looped trails that we've encountered and passed.&nbsp
column7: Looking ahead shows more valleys with the road but the road itself is changing as the kids continue to age, grow and even mature into adults.&nbsp

column1: You don't realize the passage of time and how things change until you reach those ridgelines when the trees have thinned out for a short period.
column2: When you do reach that point, take a few moments to pause and appreciate both what you've had as well as what you have.&nbsp

column1: Then plunge down the hill and back into the forest amidst the trees.

642,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Late winter is the time for the school science fairs and Youngest just continued the family tradition/requirement of participating.
column2: What does this have to do with prices and inflation?&nbsp
column3: Simply because his experiment pertained to the conversion of potential to kinetic energy, via the mechanism of a torsion spring on an onager catapult .
column4: A torsion spring is simply the twisting of opposite ends of a material in opposite directions so that tension - potential energy - is stored in the material
column5: when the onager's throwing arm is depressed and released, the resulting launch of an object is the conversion of the potential to the kinetic energy.&nbsp
column6: With the massive increase in the money supply, albeit offset by the diminished velocity of money, the question of inflation is akin to that of the torsion spring.&nbsp
column7: The Federal Reserve has wound a financial torsion spring that has significant potential energy to generate inflation when the appropriate conditions are met.

column1: But the March 2013 PracticalDad Price Index result presently indicates that while some prices have risen, the total cost of the 47 item market basket has actually dropped once again to 107.24 from February's 107.81 (November 2010 = 100).
column2: Split out the 37 food items to their own index and the Food-only Index rose from February's 113.24 to 113.59
column3: life is good provided that you don't have to eat.&nbsp
column4: The spread - an indicator of how food prices are diverging from non-food prices - for the two indices rose to 6.11, the third month in a row in which it rose.&nbsp
column5: The spread is still less than the all-time high of 6.26 reached in December, 2012 (which is when both indices maxed before collapsing in January 2013).
