column1:
675,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The letter from the local high school came in the mail two weeks before first day of classes, amidst an assortment of administrative odds and ends, and I frankly didn't catch it's significance until after the new school year began.
column2: What prompted me to go back and review it again was a comment from Middle, who's now in high school
column3: he remarked that he'd be getting a laptop in January and when I responded that it was unlikely, he told me that it was being given to all high school students as the start of a new ""1 to 1"" program.&nbsp
column4: This news was problematic since we've made it a point to not provide the kids with their own laptops until going off to college and this was what happened with Eldest, who received a laptop as a graduation present in May of her senior year.
column5: This was compounded a day later by Youngest's comment that they - his sixth grade class - had been told that they could now bring in their smartphones, laptops and iThingies starting in the Fall in order to also access the web with their teachers.&nbsp
column6: Because we do try to control the level of access and amount of screen time, Youngest has none of these devices.&nbsp
column7: So...what to do when the family technology policy collides squarely with the policy initiatives of the local school district?

column1: This initiative revolves around grant money that can be used to purchase inexpensive laptops for the high school students.
column2: In January, 2014, each district high school student will receive a new laptop, to be used throughout their secondary education period and afterwards, each class of incoming freshmen will receive the same for their four year period.&nbsp
column3: The rationale for this program is the letter's reference to the opportunity for students to now take full advantage of all that technology offers in terms of educational opportunity and there are certainly good reasons for such an investment.&nbsp
column4: The presence of the laptops permits faculty to direct their students to a much broader scope of information available through the internet, potentially opening more young minds to possibilities.&nbsp
column5: Likewise, it's ""green"" and there is far fewer paper used and far more trees saved.&nbsp
column6: A more prosaic reason is that with more resources available online, even textbooks, the school has less cost for school supplies.&nbsp
column7: Wow, someone else's money for a one-time investment and X% of our own costs go away...For The Win, Baby!

column1: While it's a win for the school district, it's both a question and just one more thing to monitor within the household.
column2: We're not Amish by any means and there's certainly screen time going on within the household, but it's been a conscious decision and ongoing effort to create family guidelines, monitor activity and enforce limits regarding electronics.&nbsp
column3: The remaining two kids in the household - Middle and Youngest - are definitely behind the curve from an electronics standpoint as there are no game systems, iThingies or smartphones although Middle now possesses a cell phone to match his driver's permit.&nbsp
column4: There are families for whom this particular policy initiative would be a dealbreaker, family policy now ostensibly being dictated by a public entity
column5: there are some - admittedly a very few - who would opt instead for a different route of education and pursue either a private institution or else homeschooling.&nbsp
column6: The irony in this situation would be that a considerable amount of homeschooling is now done via cyberschool, in which case a separate computer might also have to be purchased for the student.

column2: Homeschooling isn't an option here since we do find great value in public education, apart from the academics alone
column3: although I'm annoyed from reading the letter that this program was taken on after considerable reflection by staff and faculty with no mention of parental involvement.&nbsp
column4: The best that we can do, if we're to stay within the system, is to simply shoulder the burden of amending the house rules and continuing to uphold them as best we're able.&nbsp
column5: In Middle's case, the laptop will have to be used in common areas and out of the bedroom
column6: free surfing will have to occur on the family computer as before and I'll wind up having to check more often to assure that the technology isn't being overused.&nbsp
column7: Youngest's case is different however.&nbsp
column8: We've known that many more of his friends have unfettered access to the web, both in terms of their personal devices as well as parental oversight and we aren't willing to provide him with a device despite what the school is now offering for the nascent middle-schoolers.&nbsp
column9: It's bad enough that I'm now going to have to add one more piece of technology to the list, but adding another for Youngest is unacceptable>&nbsp
column10: What Youngest's teacher did advise was that any device with a wireless capability would work, including a Nook HD or Amazon's Kindle Fire and that presents an option
column11: not that we're going to purchase one for him but one for the family that could be taken to school during the day but would be returned to the kitchen upon returning home...in other words, mine.

column1: This initiative isn't something that's going to break our relationship with the school district, and the simple truth is that it will probably be of value.
column2: But it's not an innocuous change and has a direct bearing upon how we've heretofore chosen to raise the kids and run the household.&nbsp
column3: There are plenty of other changes that school districts roll out and the cumulative effect of some of these programs has been to push parents into disaffection with the public system, sometimes to the extent that they simply withdraw their children and seek other educational alternatives.&nbsp
column4:
I can intellectually understand their discomfort but there hasn't been anything to date that has actually made me sit back and say hmmm... and while this one isn't a dealbreaker, the understanding has now shifted from the academic and intellectual realm to that of the real world, the one that we inhabit each day.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
676,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Parents want to protect their kids, not only from harm, but also from the knowledge of some of the terrible things that occur in contemporary society.
column2: We might discuss such things when they age, but a picture is worth a thousand words and no amount of classroom or dinner-table discussion can bring home the impact of what occurred and it's unclear when the kids might be ready for a more visceral examination of an event.&nbsp
column3: Such was the question in this household as I pondered whether Youngest was now old enough to view a CBS news documentary - What We Saw - issued about a year after the attacks.

column1: The documentary is a 2002 hardcover book with accompanying DVD that relates the events of 9/11, commencing with Bryant Gumbel's morning interview with a witness to a purported plane collision with the first of the two towers.
column2: It then moves through the rest of the day as New York and Washington, DC reel from the events, and further recounts the actions of the passengers on United's Flight 93 as they willingly sacrificed themselves and took the plane into a remote Pennsylvania field.&nbsp
column3: The scenes of the devastation are still frightening and visceral to watch
column4: in one news clip, a person opts to jump to his death instead of burning alive atop one of the towers and we can watch this poor soul plummet for hundreds of feet before a nearby building mercifully hides his final impact from our view.&nbsp
column5: Not everything is grisly and there are segments on the ensuing rescue efforts, patriotism and the resultant move into Afghanistan in search of the now dead Bin Laden.&nbsp
column6: It was a book that I purchased years ago precisely for the purpose of showing to the kids when they were old enough to more fully take in its meaning, and it was shown to each of the older two kids when I deemed them old enough.

column2: At the time of the attacks, he was still in utero
column3: he has spent his entire life in the shadow of those attacks and all that's changed since then.&nbsp
column4: There is no understanding of life before the TSA, drones and a constant threat - real or imagined - of terrorism.&nbsp
column5: The seemingly ever-present surveillance camera was far less prevalent and we didn't seem to be living with a sense of constantly impending menace.&nbsp
column6: Youngest has certainly known about the attacks from his mother and I, school and the media, but he'd never been exposed to the visual panoply of that time.&nbsp
column7: Making it an even harder question is that we've tried - and never fully succeeded - to keep him away from the graphic violence that permeates video games and the media.&nbsp
column8: He's certainly seen violent movies, although rarely until this past year, but we've made efforts to keep the graphic combat games away and there is no - for now, but that will change - game system in the house.&nbsp
column9: The upshot is that he hasn't become desensitized to the violence that permeates our environs.&nbsp
column10: This was brought home two years when I finally allowed him to watch the first part of Saving Private Ryan and he only lasted through the initial assault on Omaha Beach before having to stop watching.

column1: The boy has an interest in history and the world around him, and preparing him and his siblings for the world is my principal role as a father.
column2: It's become an increasingly ugly world, one in which terrorists kill others for media coverage, the deranged arm themselves to hunt for our most vulnerable and schools now openly discuss what to do in the event that a gunman comes strolling down the main hallway.&nbsp
column3: Given his interest, his maturity and the nature of how we've had to adapt, I opted to share the DVD with him years before I did so with his older siblings.&nbsp
column4: We'd watch for a few minutes and then he'd pause the program to ask a question or listen to an explanation I'd offer for something that was on-screen.&nbsp
column5: It was a brutal experience and there were moments when I wept along with him as we viewed the CBS news reports until we could watch no further, ultimately turning it off midway through the program.

column1: Our job as parents is to prepare our children to make their way in the world.
column2: This means that we must pay attention to the world around us so that we can adjust plans and actions to fit the times, and what might have worked for an older child might have to be re-evaluated  for the younger kids that follow.&nbsp
column3: It also means that we must be personally involved teaching these things, as uncomfortable as they might be.&nbsp
column4: We cannot leave the lessons for the schools alone, and we certainly shouldn't leave them to the media culture
column5: the children require a sense of context to help them make full sense of what they see and we parents are the ones who can best provide that background and context for them.&nbsp
column6:
We know how they process information and whether or not they're ready for the more unpleasant lessons of life around us.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
677,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's irritating that so many don't seem to realize how much of the greater world truly does impact their everyday lives, seeming to think that the world exists beyond their own cocooned existence.
column2: We live in a world that is almost - in some ways - a Kevin Bacon game as what does happen elsewhere truly impacts us in ways that we don't expect.&nbsp
column3: These links go beyond the pedestrian there's yet another near-war in the Middle East so oil prices are going to potentially rise and stretch farther than we realize
column4: things occur elsewhere that gain little notice here but can have a considerable bearing on our lives.&nbsp
column5: Such is the case when I noted an article from ABCNews.com, in which the Argentine government is criminally charging economists who challenge their reported inflation data.
column6: My larger mental self says okay, that's eight thousand miles away and twelve miles down the rabbit hole but my smaller, more provocative mental self is far more cautionary of the news.

column1: Let's step back a ways first, however.
column2: Argentina is the favored poster child for images of sovereign defaults, a nation with significant resources that should be far wealthier than it is
column3: it's a nation which has undergone revolution and a bloody military junta that kidnapped and tortured thousands of its own civilians - many of whom were young adults - in an effort to eradicate domestic terrorism, but wound up attacking legitimate and peaceful opposition groups.&nbsp
column4: After coming through that period several decades ago, the existant government simply confiscated the savings of the public
column5: the Argentine middle class was literally wiped out overnight as their bank accounts simply went poof at the stroke of a governmental pen and the click of a keyboard.
column6: Since then, the government has forced Argentines with dollars to convert them into Argentine Pesos and/or Peso denominated bonds, flooded their monetary supply with pesos in a loose accomodative policy, asked for foreign investors to participate in energy exploration while simultaneously demanding that they submit to quarterly governmental audits and most ominously - like the accumulated debris of the previous actions wasn't enough - been accused by multiple parties - both domestic and the IMF - of openly falsifying their inflation data. &nbsp
column7: The government has felt threatened enough that it's now pursuing criminal actions against a small group of economists who publicly post their own estimates as the real rate of inflation in the Argentine economy.

column1: So what does that have to do with me?
column2: Plenty, since I've run a cozy, low-tech monthly price index to keep tabs on the level of grocery prices for almost three years. &nbsp

column1: There's been a growing distrust of our own government over the past decade, one that's moved out of the right wing blogosphere and directly into the middle of the American mainstream.
column2: Part and parcel of that has been a sense amongst financial bloggers and commenters that the numbers aren't exactly as they appear
column3: this is especially the case with the employment numbers coming out of the Bureau of Labor Statistics and their purely statistical birth/death adjustment model.
column4: There have been more than a few months where the only improvement in the employment rate has been solely due to the application of this statistical model, followed several months by a readjustment that retroactively increases the number of unemployed Americans. &nbsp
column5: This growing skepticism has carried over to the inflation data since many can't conceive of how the Federal Reserve and US Government can respectively keep interest rates at zero bounds and still spend like a Beverly Hills housewife on a meth-driven shopping bender. &nbsp
column6: Others - such as John Williams Shadowstats and MIT's Billion Prices Project
column7: - have been created to keep tabs on prices, either via separate analysis of existing data or the mass accretion of global prices from online retailers. &nbsp

column1: This PracticalDad has neither advanced degrees in Economics or Mathematics nor access to significant computing power.
column2: What I do have is the experience of having participated in a cost-of-living index early in my professional life and the knowledge that comes from having shopped and cooked for a family for far more than a decade. &nbsp
column3: I could watch the fireworks and blog bullshit at the situation or actually utilize the skills and create my own index
column4: this I did with the PracticalDad Price Index, which debuted in November 2010.
column5: It's an admittedly kitchen table affair that trades breadth of data for a grocery marketbasket of 47 separate items that is immediately understandable for the typical parent. &nbsp
column6: Other bloggers have commented that while it's interesting, it isn't national in scopeand they're right. &nbsp
column7: However, it simply provides a consistent monthly glimpse of grocery price activity in one locality. &nbsp
column8: While there are certainly price differences from one region to another, the fact is that the index monitors the change in prices from a baseline and not the prices themselves. &nbsp
column9: In the aggregate, prices rising due to factors in one region will most likely rise at a similar pace in another region. &nbsp

column1: The Argentine government's action is cautionary in demonstrating the extent to which those in power will go to assure their continuance in power.
column2: Our college graduates have been told that a higher education is necessary because our economy has become a knowledge-based economy
column3: the implication is that knowledge is crucial and henceforth, knowledge is power. &nbsp
column4: When true public knowledge is monopolistically controlled, those controlling it have the power. &nbsp
column5: The Argentine economists are a direct threat to those in power within the Argentine government. &nbsp
column6: Will such a governmental challenge to information occur here? &nbsp
column7: Could someone like John Williams and an institution like MIT be threatened? &nbsp
column8: Could that actually happen to me and if so, what would I do? &nbsp
column9: While I frankly doubt that it could happen here, it's sobering to consider it should it actually occur and I don't know what my response would be. &nbsp
column10: It's one thing to put out a datapoint, but what do you do when those in power try to erase it? &nbsp
column11: This is truly what I find so admirable about these few in the Argentine Wonderland, that they're willing to undergo the risks of speaking truth to power

column1: Of course, I never thought that I'd be able to purchase depleted uranium shotgun loads for drones, either.

678,"1","1",,"xhtml","

As I sat with Middle at the kitchen island yesterday morning, I commented that this was the first day of the government shutdown.
column2: He yanked his head upwards in surprise.&nbsp
column3: <em>What?&nbsp
column4: How can this happen?
column5: The conversation ensued as I explained that certain functions would certainly continue and that the world wasn't going to come to an end
column6: the linkage was inevitably made between the rollout of the new Affordable Care Act, aka Obamacare and the debt issue and how the last minute Republican spending included a year-long delay in the individual policy segment of the Act.
column7: It was here that he discovered that the Congress, in it's infinite wisdom and deep compassion, was exempt from the law and actually had its own healthcare program.&nbsp
column8: Greedy Bastards was his simple response.

column1: There are certainly many other aspects to the issue, difficult to parse through in short time frames and hard to keep clear and factual in light of tweets he was receiving about how the Republicans are to blame for this mess.
column2: My response to that on the car ride to school was a succinct pox upon both parties
column3: each has contributed mightily to the mess and neither is beyond reproach.&nbsp

column1: But with such rancor and smoke, how do I get a factual and informative basis across to this smarter-than-average teen?
column2: I'm certain that he'd prefer to ignore it since it disturbs his zen, but his generation is going to be paying for this slow-motion trainwreck and it's best that he have a clue now, sooner than later.

column1: The first point to remember is to keep it as factual as possible
column2: calling a particular politician a raging cretin - even if he or she is a raging cretin - is certain to create a block because it's indicative that Dad's simply back on his soapbox.&nbsp
column3: Blah, blah, blah, runaway deficits, blah, blah, blah like the famous Far Side cartoon.
column4: Dad feels better but it's rolled off with no impact whatsoever.

column1: The second point is to actually use correct facts.
column2: It's become nigh impossible with the mainstream media cherrypicking their information, depending upon whether they're CNN, Fox or MSNBC so be prepared to go to other sources for the information.&nbsp
column3: The other aspect to this is that if he's embarrassed in front of friends, classmates and teachers because of incorrect information, then he's going to simply turn you off when you begin to talk about it.

column1: The third point is to present it in bite-sized bits.
column2: Most parents don't spend a huge amount of time with the kids and as they age, your available time with them shortens so you have to be prepared to grab the moment and present a segment.&nbsp
column3: Kids also don't have the attention span that they might have had fifty years ago because of the prevalence of the ubiquitous electronics.&nbsp
column4: Try to squeeze in too much and you're going to reach concentration overload with many kids sooner than later.

column1: The fourth point is to be consistent in your beliefs and conversation.
column2: With enough time and effort, the conversation will shift from the factual to the philosophical and here's where the core of values teaching takes place.&nbsp
column3: You might not think that they're out of the zombie state yet, but they are actually thinking and working to put two-and-two together
column4: if you make the effort to bring them along, many will make the effort to coalesce everything into a coherent whole.&nbsp
column5: Your inability to remain consistent in your own beliefs will simply sabotage the entire process as they will root out the inconsistencies.&nbsp
column6: And this I speak from experience as a few instances of waffling have brought forward cogent, almost surgically precise questions that made me stop and re-think what I'd said so that I could either clarify or, in one particular case, acknowledge that I'd been wholly inconsistent.&nbsp
column7: The simple truth is that kids can smell out hypocrisy like a dog can sniff out a bone.

column1: Issues of such complexity are not made for one-off conversations.
column2: They require multiple efforts and considerable thought, both of what was already discussed and what should be covered next to help clarify things further.&nbsp
column3:
But if my job as a father is to prepare the kids for their future, then it's my responsibility to think through the process and then make the effort so that they don't suddenly awaken in ten years, upset that they didn't have a clue of what was coming.

679,"1","1",,"xhtml","

There are moments that freeze your parental heart, brief instants that bring forward all of the fear of what can go wrong and these moments are often affiliated with teens and driving.
column2: Tonight was one of those instances that led to a call from my wife about Middle, who had been involved in a minor collision in a friend's car just a minute after leaving our home.&nbsp
column3: She actually came upon the accident scene when she left to join me at Youngest's baseball game, which was a shock in itself when she recognized the crunched vehicle as the one that had been sitting in our driveway just moments before.&nbsp
column4: When I answered my phone standing next to Youngest's dugout, her first words were everyone is alright
column5: while they were meant as an immediate salve for what was to follow, the intellectual understanding was overwhelmed by the emotional recognition of what could have happened instead, what's happened to thousands of teenagers in automobiles.

column1: When your kids leave the house and start to go into the world, there will be such calls.
column2: They'll come from teachers and principals, school nurses and coaches, even from your child herself.&nbsp
column3: They might even come from a policeman on that rare and terrifying occasion.&nbsp
column4: The point is to understand that the calls will come and the best that you can do is to, as the Old Testament prophet might say, gird your loins for that moment so that you manage it well.&nbsp
column5: The only way to avoid the prospect of such calls is to keep the kids continually underfoot and dependent and that utterly defeats the job of being a parent, which is to prepare your child to take his or her place in the great wide world.&nbsp

column1: And in the great expanse of time between those calls, continue to listen and teach, tell them that you love them and say a silent prayer when they walk out the door.

Ben Bernanke will end his term as the Chairman of the Federal Reserve System most noted for his now famous comment about combating deflation with a helicopter money drop if necessary.
column2: But the monthly review of the 47 grocery items in the PracticalDad Price Index shows that significant inflation still hasn't reached the grocery stores as the October 2013 Total Index dropped very slightly to 108.35 (November 2010 = 100) and the 37 item Food-only Index declined by more than .75 points to 112.98 (November 2010 = 100).&nbsp
column3: On the basis of the Food-only index, this is the largest decrease since the greater than 1 point drop from December 2012 to January 2013 and is the lowest level by that index since October 2012, a full year ago.

column1: The discrepancy - minimal decrease in Total Index versus significant decrease in Food-Only Index - is explicable.
column2: There were six price increases offset by six price decreases amongst the 47 items
column3: but the significant price rises were for non-food items (soap at 2.7% and trash bags at 11%) while the three significant drops were in ground beef (2.4%), roaster chicken (3.1%) and apples (9.1%).&nbsp

Every generation has it's own fears and concerns for the future and this generation of parents isn't any different in that regard.
column2: A former pastor with two sons - the oldest of whom is now pushing 40 - once commented that when his wife was pregnant with their first in the mid-1970s, they wondered why they were even going to bring kids into that then-challenged world. &nbsp
column3: But there are new challenges facing our youngsters with which previous recent generations didn't have to contend, threats which are almost existential given the youngsters' electronic habits and tethers. &nbsp
column4: While I've actively talked with the three kids about economics and civics, the ongoing disclosures about the extent of the NSA surveillance apparatus appall me and send a literal shiver through my soul. &nbsp
column5: What do I teach the kids about this and how do I help them adjust to this new threat?

column1: Because the vast extent of the NSA and intelligence apparatus poses a threat to the heart of a free society.
column2: It is also a dagger that cuts through the heart and soul of this young, online generation.
In the first half of the 20th century, we were threatened by fascist dictatorships and after their defeat, the mantle passed with the Cold War's onset to the communist threat. &nbsp
column3: The Soviet Bloc's implosion in the late 20th century came hand-in-hand with the rise of militant Islam
column4: while terrorism has existed for decades, the ability of radical muslims to kill thousands of Americans in a single stroke awakened us to yet another threat. &nbsp
column5: There is a threat out there...but then again, there's always a threat out there.

column1: The Presidential Oath requires him - and someday, her - to protect and defend the Constitution against all enemies, foreign and domestic.
column2: We've lost sight that there are also domestic enemies and not all of them wear white hoods or appear in such an obvious fashion. &nbsp
column3: My wife recently commented that everything seems to be building up and my response was that it's because we never actually resolve anything. &nbsp
column4: The budget issues aren't resolved and we kick the can down the road with continuous spending appropriations and new debt ceilings. &nbsp
column5: Trillions of dollars are generated to support an aberrant financial community but no restructuring or regulation is performed to assure that there's no repeat of 2008 (and I live with the belief that it will, and in spades the next time around).
column6: The news cycle simply adapts itself and the old controversies are outshouted by the new and improved controversies with no resolution. &nbsp
column7: I've concluded that the new domestic threats are those who wield the power to circumvent the common good, preventing critical regulatory oversight - remember that one of the legitimate roles of government is to regulate the worser angels of our nature - and pursuing policies that benefit corporations and legal entities but are detrimental to the individual
column8: using money to purchase political access and votes that again, benefit the few and fictitious but are at best, neutral to the individual. &nbsp
column9: The refusal by the Obama Administration to grant a one-year delay to individuals but instead giving it to corporations is a massive check engine light. &nbsp

column1: So we've created this pervasive, intrusive intelligence apparatus capable of giving American society a collective electronic colonoscopy.
column2: The oversight has been minimal and as the bureaucrats push forward in their quest for security, those who question it or attempt to shed light on it are legally persecuted in the name of national security
column3: it's not for nothing that the Obama Administration has reached new heights - or lows, depending on your perspective - in pursuing whistleblowers so that examples are set to discourage others of conscience. &nbsp
column4: And at the same time, the monied few with the ears and pockets of the political class continue to garner greater influence as they help the career politicians in a mutually beneficial relationship. &nbsp
column5: At what point does this relationship become the cornerstone of a new fascism, a parasitic collusion of the corporate and political classes?

column1: And I'm respectful of the arguments that support the notion that we're already there.
So what do I do to help prepare the kids?
column2: This great steaming pile of hot mess goes to the heart of their plugged-in collective consciousness, especially at a time of their lives when they're unaware both of the consequences of what they say and the reality that this is being recorded en masse and held for whatever moment is best suited for use against them? &nbsp
column3: The answers are infinitely time-consuming, low-tech and prosaic.

column1: <li>Take every opportunity, from the earliest possible moment of their lives, to talk with them. &nbsp
column2: This sets the stage for the latter days of youth when you want to pull them aside for specific issues
column3: they won't be looking at you like a geriatric freakshow and you won't be at an utter loss for words.

column1: <li>Take every opportunity to set an example of a non-wired life by putting down your own cell phone and removing your own ear buds. &nbsp
column2: In the past several months, I've noticed more parents - fathers and mothers - walking the kids while plugged into an iPod or cell phone. &nbsp
column3: The concept of the daily walk is more than just taking the kid outside to blow off the stink
column4: the concept is to fire their synapses as they grow, showing them new things and interacting with them. &nbsp
column5: They'll be more understanding of important cell phone calls when they're older if they don't see you on the damned things all of the time. &nbsp
column6: Likewise, when they're older, they'll be a bit more understanding if you ask them to remove their own.

column1: • Raise them as skeptics, not just chatting with them, but challenging them so that they don't simply accept any party line.
column2: I've had a lifelong habit of tossing out outlandish tidbits in conversation to see whether they'll learn to challenge it as true
column3: this isn't a harmless exercise and encouraging skepticism can come back to bite
column4: when they're older. &nbsp

column1: <li>Pull them aside to share news articles with them when they're old enough. &nbsp
column2: There have been any number of times when I've pulled one or more kids aside to clue them in on something that I believe that they should know. &nbsp
column3: The occasional response is akin to a tilt of the head reminiscent of Laddie the Wonder Dog, but there also discussions that go places that I didn't expect. &nbsp
column4: Inform yourself and then inform them.

column1: <li>Set - and live with - ground rules on the electronics. &nbsp
column2: Don't be afraid to turn them off and don't avoid the nastiness that comes with kids not getting their way.

column1: <li>Teach them about what's private and what's not. &nbsp
column2: Teach them about family business and also about personal business. &nbsp
column3: When one of the kids takes family business outside the family, send the child away from the table the next time something sensitive is discussed, even if the other siblings remain at the table. &nbsp
column4: Then follow it up with a conversation about the excusal and you'll find it a potent lesson.

column1: <li>Take them to a website with old articles or comment threads and show them comments written several years ago to prove that it doesn't go away. &nbsp
<li>Keep tabs on their online activity and accounts. &nbsp
column2: Tell them if they've crossed a line and act upon it if necessary.

column1: • Teach them to NEVER place identifying personal information online, especially a public site with exposure to many.
<li>Wake up yourself to the current events around you.&nbsp
column2: For this issue, follow the Electronic Frontier Foundation and read more of Glenn Greenwald in The Guardian
column3: yeah, it's an English paper but don't look for heavy content in most domestic American papers.&nbsp

column1: There's more at stake here than just personal information for our youngsters.
column2: It's another part of the machine that's slowly being built around us that can be used for far greater, more insidious control in the future.&nbsp
column3: I wouldn't want it for myself and I certainly don't want it for my children.

There's been a spate of recent articles (here and here) about how men are doing more of the shopping and the cooking.
column2: There are other articles out there since things were spurred on by a research firm faxing poll results to various media outlets, but you get the drift.&nbsp
column3: Several of the articles even mention that some of these men are fathers who do most, if not all, of the cooking and one article even shows a young father carrying his preschool daughter in his arms as he rolls the cart down the aisle.&nbsp
column4: Which leads to the topic at hand, what are some things to remember if you go grocery shopping with the kid(s)?

column1: Having been the stay-at-home since Eldest's birth (she's now in college) and with others at intervals back through elementary school, I've been the one who's trotted through the grocery aisles across the years.
column2: The majority of those years have required that I take one or more kids in tow and for several, all of them were along for the excursion
column3: what are some things to remember and consider when the kids are along at the store?

column1: • Understand that your child is now a living, crying, potentially bleeding egg timer that's set to ring when the patience is exhausted.
column2: Having a plan and list is crucial since your freedom to browse is now as limited as the attention span of a Labrador Retriever on meth
column3: planning is crucial for both economic and behavioral issues.&nbsp
column4: What do you need to buy and where is it located?

column1: <li>Before you even leave the house, consider how much has to be accomplished and whether it can even be accomplished in the framework of your child's body clock.&nbsp
column2: Children require structure and that means a nap for most kids age three or younger so trying to accomplish a large shopping trip immediately after lunch is setting up for unpleasantries as the child simply tires and becomes unable to handle waiting in the cart.&nbsp
column3: Even kids who no longer nap still tire and are subject to the stresses of the late afternoon witching hour when their energy ebbs and they become crankier and less patient.&nbsp
column4: For me, late afternoon grocery trips were minimal and solely for emergent reasons (dammit, I thought that I had that...)
column5: some shopping was simply done in the evening by myself because it was obvious that one or more of the kids was not able to handle it that day.

column1: <li>Set the stage for the behavior by stating your expectations prior to even entering the store.&nbsp
column2: Talk to your toddler about what's going to happen and gently let him know what you want to see in terms of behavior
column3: you can also let him know the consequences of misbehavior which is important if you employ the three-count method of discipline (which I still do even today, to the kids' general annoyance, because it continues to work).

column1: • Understand that distraction is as good as discipline for keeping small children in line. : Eldest had a toy phone that beeped and Middle had a keyring with useless keys, each of which was kept in a pocket for the moment that their patience began to wear thin.
<li>Consider the shopping experience with your child to be an excellent teaching opportunity, particularly when they're preschoolers.&nbsp
column2: The grocery store is a great place to work on colors, shapes and names of items when they're very little and counting when they're a bit older.&nbsp
column3: <em>How many yellow bananas are there?&nbsp
column4: One, two, three...

column1: <li>Let the kids help as they age
column2: you can even turn it into a game by asking them to find certain things with prizes for reaching a certain number correct.&nbsp
column3: That said, don't send preschoolers to the other side of the store for that item that you forgot...

column1: <li>Make a conscious decision whether or not good behavior will be rewarded with a physical treat, such as a donut.&nbsp
column2: On the one hand, you can argue that good behavior is simply expected and shouldn't be rewarded as though it was out of the norm but on the other hand, can you really turn down the opportunity for a shared donut?

column1: <li>Understand that you're going to be multi-tasking and that the intensity of the multi-task will rise with the number of children along for the jaunt.&nbsp
column2: Expect to be tired when it's finished and don't be surprised if your patience is tested.

column1: Shopping for groceries and cooking is just one aspect of how men are continuing to step up and take a greater role in the family just as women have stepped up to take a greater role in the work force.
column2: The experience of taking the kid(s) can be a challenge and a great shared experience and the difference between good and bad will depend upon what you expect and what you do to prepare.&nbsp
column3:
Once men are more fully established in the kitchen and store, it's only going to be some years longer until they're also taking more responsibility for the housework.

column1:
683,"1","1",,"xhtml","

...but that's only looking at one side of the family's equation.
column2: Not only will what they have purchase less in real terms, but millions of families will actually have even less as they moved forward.

column1: The intent of the PracticalDad Price Index has been to ascertain what's really going on with food prices via a 47 item marketbasket, followed consistently at three separate and unrelated grocery stores.
column2: It began in November, 2010 (11/10 = 100.00) after considerable controversy over the impact of loose monetary policy courtesy of the Federal Reserve System
column3: this or that is going up, what's going to happen to food?&nbsp
column4: But what's been happening to the average American family isn't solely the result of loose monetary policy
column5: the middle-class family has also been whacked on the income side so that they're being eaten away from two different directions.&nbsp
column6: It was an unpleasant irony that the day on which I did the price surveys was the same day that the federal SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) was cut by 6% in a budgetary move.
column7: It's not as though you couldn't see one coming from months ago as the media was increasingly full of stories about fraud within the SNAP program, painting an untold number of beneficiaries as undeserving of the program
column8: other stories told of governmental quotas for enrollment so that the administrators were graded on how many new beneficiaries joined their program during each period.&nbsp
column9: The set-up was in the media to pave the public opinion way for future cuts.

column1: The fortunate item this month is that the PracticalDad Price Index actually is dead in the water from October, 2013. The Total Index of all 47 items in the grocery store marketbasket was unchanged from October's Index of 107.83
column2: the 37 item food component (which excludes non-food items such as soap, aluminum foil and etc.) actually declined slightly to 112.81 in November from October's 112.98.&nbsp
column3: Apart from the occasional upwards month - such as September's greater than half point jump to 113.76 - the November Food-Only Index continues the downward trend from that Index's high point of 114.33 reached in December 2012.&nbsp
column4: Note that the 37 item Food-only Index had actually jumped by greater than 2.5 points from October 2012, an annualized rate in those three months of 10%
column5: this has fortunately backed off and we're now at a level last seen in October, 2012.

column1: So here are the results for both the Total Index and the Food-only Index for the past four months.

column1: We're now into the secular Christmas season, as judging by the lights and outdoor ornaments that I've begun to see on local retailers and homes.
column2: And it's only November...The point to be made is this however:&nbsp
column3: I am certain that there is fraud in the SNAP program, just as there's fraud in the Social Security Disability Income program, the student loan program, Medicare/Medicaid and any number of other social/economic aid and entitlement programs.&nbsp
column4: You can't have more than a full generation of out-of-control spending - coupled with a decade of (near)Zero Interest Rate Program rates - without fostering a rushing stream of liquidity flowing through the economy.&nbsp
column5: That alone tempts the amoral among us, who then view the lack of regulatory enforcement enriching the highest echelons of society as an invitation to cut themselves loose to the stream and take some for themselves.&nbsp
column6: But there is a crying need for food amongst the poor and now even the middle class who are struggling
column7: food banks are already pressed and are terrified of the long-term effects of these cuts in SNAP benefits on their supplies.&nbsp

column1: In this coming season - hell, for the entire year - make it a point to reallocate any charitable giving to the local food banks.
column2: If you have the resources, purchase a bag of groceries at your shopping trip and drop it off at a nearby food bank.&nbsp
column3: The powers that be in the government and the financial sector have made it abundantly clear where their priorities lie and it's going to be up to us to take care of one another.&nbsp
column4: As my own father said to me in my teenage years, <em>you better be able to look out for yourself because the government isn't going to do it. &nbsp
column5: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
684,"1","1",,"xhtml","

After a few rocky decades for the American father, things - as least as I can tell in the media barometer - seem to be leveling out.
column2: We've gone from the tasteless Al Bundy and Homer Simpson to more functional father-models as demonstrated in NBC's Parenthood and ABC's Castle.
column3: Television commercials show fully functional Dads overseeing bedtime activities and homework, as well as managing laundry.&nbsp
column4: A recent survey found that men are taking a far greater role in grocery shopping and cooking, a byproduct of more women working, fewer employment opportunities and greater interest spurred by the Food Network (a much-watched network on our television).
column5: But all of that's now happening on one end of the age spectrum, fathers and kids.&nbsp
column6: As these younger men age and the kids grow, the increasing family responsibility will begin to show itself on the other end of the age spectrum as they become responsible for one or both of their parents
column7: they will be taking on what was historically taken on by the women in American society.

column1: The pace of my writing since the Spring - steady, but not prolific to begin with - has slowed considerably in the past few months.
column2: Part of this can be attributed to the activities and presence of kids home from school as well as the completion of years-long backyard reclamation projects.
column3: But what also took up considerable time was the reality that I was now officially a part of the sandwich generation
column4: that phase in life in which I was not only responsible for the care of kids but also the care and oversight of an elderly parent.&nbsp
column5: Because I live much closer to that parent than my sister and my schedule is more flexible, the bulk of the oversight has fallen to me.&nbsp
column6: It's an experience which I never considered having to do, but then again, most of my adult life has been spent in an alternative route that was inconceivable in my youthful ambitions.&nbsp
column7: On a societal level however, it's also new because the onus of caring for the aging parents has fallen to the women, whether they be daughter or daughter-in-law.&nbsp
column8: The sons have typically deferred to the women because the matters fall to the purview of home management, a woman's role and one in which most men felt utterly incompetent.&nbsp
column9: But that too, is going to have to change in several ways.

column1: First, roughly the past three American generations - three 20 year generational spans, dating back to 1950 - have lived and been raised in the nuclear family model of parents and their immediate children, sans grandparents.
column2: That model broke onto the American scene in the early part of the 20th century with increasing industrialization and the rapid growth of the transport network, which allowed adult children to move for a supportable wage living with the knowledge that they could more easily get back to their own aging parents if necessary.&nbsp
column3: By the 1950s, the nuclear family was the standard model and one that worked for the country as the nation's superpower status provided expanded economic opportunity.&nbsp
column4: My own upbringing was spent four hours away from where my own parents were raised, and my experience with extended family usually consisted of a semi-annual trek to the western part of the state to listen to my mother and her three siblings semi-playfully trashtalk one another around the evening poker table.&nbsp
column5: If and when things with the grandmothers were problematic, much could be handled via local relatives, the social services network via phone and a trip westwards to tie up loose ends.&nbsp
column6: I say grandmothers because the grandfathers did what men of that time did, die at a much earlier age, early enough that I neven met either of them.&nbsp

column1: This leads to the second point, which is the present disparity between the age of retirement and the age of death.
column2: In 1950, when the nuclear family truly took flight, the average person retired at 67.3 years of age but the average age at death was 68.2 years.
column3: <em>Congratulations, here's your watch for years of faithful service.&nbsp
column4: Now figure out who gets it because you've got about a half-year 'til you get to pass that l'il beauty on.&nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: By 2000, the average person's retirement age was 61.5 years and age at death, 77 years.
column7: <em>Congratulations, here's your watch for years of faithful service.&nbsp
column8: Don't sweat who gets it because you'll probably have to replace it once before you die. &nbsp
column9: In three generations, we've gone from a retirement span of less than six months to more than 16 years - and the most recent comparable statistics for retirement age are thirteen years old - so there's more time that the parents have to decline in their capabilities than existed in 1950.
column10: Medicine has progressed sufficiently that people can live for prolonged periods with conditions and diseases that would have simply killed them in 1950.&nbsp

column1: The third point is well known, the simple economic differences between the now retiring boomers and their 1950 peers.
column2: The elderly are not a monolithic block, but composed of separate groups with their own generational experiences and economics.&nbsp
column3: The predecessors viewed Social Security as a supplemental income to their own savings, and many of them had pension plans that didn't have the investment timeframes facing today's surviving pension plans.&nbsp
column4: For a relatively period of time, they were financially comfortable before disease simply swept them away.&nbsp
column5: Today's boomers grew up consuming instead of saving and for them, Social Security is a primary source of income instead of a supplemental source. There's now a growing awareness of the pending shortfall in the Social Security program as America ages, and there are alternatives being batted around funding solutions.
column6: But these would be unpopular with the wealthier citizenry and given the status of power due to wholly ineffective campaign financing regulations, passage of such measures is problematic.&nbsp

column1: This leads to the fourth point, which is the availability of resources to assist the elderly.
column2: My parent has sufficient assets to permit living in what is comparable to a top-tier independent living community that provides for all levels of care, from independent apartments and cottages through assisted living to skilled care for end-of-live issues.&nbsp
column3: But this parent is a Depression-era child with that generation's sensibilities of want and deprivation leading to a savings ethos to supplement the then-extant pensions.&nbsp
column4: The description of life there that I hear indicate a few problems on the horizon as their clientele dies and is replaced by younger occupants
column5: remember that the elderly are not as monolithic as AARP would like you to believe.&nbsp
column6: Apartments now seem to be unoccupied for a longer period before being sold again, and empty apartments can now be rented to residents' guests for short-term stays.&nbsp
column7: The food is still top-notch, but there's an increasing use of chicken for protein and the once-monthly Prime Rib night is a memory.&nbsp
column8: Because it's located in a rural area, the executive chef arranges for bulk purchase of greens and fruits from local farmers and seasonally, capable elderly volunteer to go to the cafeteria to help clean and prepare the produce by snapping beans or husking ears of corn.&nbsp

column1: So the younger elders aren't as financially prepared as their predecessors.
column2: The burden for the increased care falls upon the social net established over the past several decades by state and federal governments with a correspondingly larger demand upon the budget
column3: but if the budget is constrained, then the result is that there's fewer dollars per elderly recipient.&nbsp
column4: If the budget is cut, then the result is an even fewer amount of money per elderly recipient.&nbsp
column5: With deficits running in the range of $1 Trillion annually and entitlement programs such as Social Security and Medicare comprising the lion's share of that budget, is there any real doubt that there's going to have to be a significant restructuring of the programs?&nbsp
column6: Where else will the elderly be able to turn?&nbsp

column1: There are several things that already are - or will - come from this.
<li>The average retirement age will rise, if it hasn't already started to do so, as seniors defer retirement and remain in the workforce.&nbsp
column2: This puts pressure on the younger generations as there are fewer supportable wage jobs that permit the younger to leave their own parents' houses and start their own households.&nbsp

column1: <li>The retirement center model, such as my parent's, is a damaged concept as fewer elderly will be available to buy into them.&nbsp
column2: Fewer full service retirement communities will be built and those existing will have to either find new ways to deliver existing services or eliminate some of those services entirely.

column1: <li>There will be increased antagonism between the younger generations and the elderly as each begins to fight for existing resources.&nbsp
column2: I honestly don't anticipate that the media will make an effort to downplay the hostility and some will even spur it since bad news and controversy sell.&nbsp
column3: Understand that there's already some hard feelings by young adults because of the manner in which the Boomer generation has managed resources and parenting
column4: this has the potential to harden those feelings even further by a considerable degree.

column1: <li>There has to be a wholesale renegotiation of the social contract between generations.&nbsp
column2: The younger have to recognize that the elderly do require assistance while the elderly have to be willing to manage on less in order to give the youngsters their own opportunities to pursue life, liberty and happiness.
It's common to refer to those who fought and won the Second World War as The Greatest Generation.&nbsp
column3: But each generation has it's own demon with which to contend and this restructuring of our programs and resources - and the accompanying pain which it will incur - will be the demon for our youngsters.&nbsp
column4: My suspicion and my hope is that future generations will refer to our youngsters as The Greatest Generation, not for war, but for the sacrifices that they were forced to make to assure that all - including their foolish, selfish Boomer parents - received the care that they required.&nbsp
column5: ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column1:
685,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Things change a person's political perspective - age, experience, education - but something else that changes a political perspective is parenthood.
column2: Through most of my young adult life, I could be classified as a socially liberal and fiscally conservative person.&nbsp
column3: I did listen to Limbaugh but spent late afternoon drivetime with NPR to get a different slant on the same topic on which Limbaugh had opined just a few hours previously.&nbsp
column4: Now I no longer listen to either but choose to get the news from a wide variety of internet sources, including foreign newspapers.&nbsp
column5: But fatherhood changed that political perspective and I'm now...well, I'm not entirely certain how to categorize it but it's safe to say that I'm simply angry with what our political, corporate and financial sectors have become.&nbsp
column6: But while I'm angry with them individually, their proto-fascist collusion in the past decade or more drives me to outrage for this legacy that's being crafted for my - our - children.

column1: What our nation is becoming is increasingly fascist.
column2: The exact definition of fascism is murky, dependent upon multiple factors.&nbsp
column3: But Franklin Delano Roosevelt best described it thusly in his 1938 address to Congress on the curbing of monopolies:

column1: The first truth is that the liberty of a democracy is not safe if the people tolerate the growth of private power to a point where it becomes stronger than their democratic state itself. That, in its essence, is Fascism&mdash
column2: ownership of Government by an individual, by a group, or by any other controlling private power.

column1:
686,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Despite all of the family activity over the past several months, there have been a number of significant conversations with the kids, singly or together.
column2: There's so much happening in our society - well, that's nothing new but the nature of it is far more important than other issues - that these conversations have to happen.&nbsp
column3: There are moments when any of them will look at me with the cocked head pose of Laddie, the Wonder Spaniel - blah, blah, NSA, blah... - but there are also moments when the monologue shifts to a dialogue and it's then that the real education can occur, that time when what is learned in school is fleshed out in the real world and the family values are further transmitted.

column1: Decide what you believe is the most important for them to know and work from there.
column2: For me, there are several large issues that come together into one overarching monstrosity of a theme.&nbsp
column3: Issues such as the legalization of marijuana, the ongoing failure to reform the financial system, the growth of the surveillance state and campaign finance reform are seemingly unrelated on one level but tightly intertwined on another level.&nbsp
column4: Each is part and parcel of the coalescence of a corporate and political structure - fascism in it's simplest form - that seeks to maintain itself at the cost of the individual's rights and liberties.
column5: The legalization of marijuana is, on one level, a purported triumph for individual liberty but the system's willingness to alter decades of law and policy in the interest of yet more tax revenue is the worst form of cynicism.&nbsp
column6: We've talked for years about an equal opportunity system that pays no credence to race, gender or creed and congratulations to us - we're now well down the road to a system of governance that doesn't give a good goddamn about the color of your skin, your gender or what you believe so long as you feed the system via votes, tax revenues or payments for stays in private correctional facilities.

column1:
687,"1","1",,"xhtml","

It's interesting to watch and listen to groups of people, especially in terms of male/female relationships.
column2: Such was the case this weekend as Youngest helped me run a cub-scout rocket launch - yes, he's still in elementary school but I trust the kid implicitly to run a launch pad for younger kids (with another father overseeing from the sidelines) - that was attended by scouts, siblings and families.&nbsp
column3: What was striking was the response of multiple fathers when something with the rocket didn't work properly, whether the fins fell off the rocket pre-launch or it burned on the launch pad.&nbsp
column4: Each of these guys threw Momma under the bus.

column1: Don't look at me, I helped paint it,
column2: You helped glue the fins on.

column1: Hey, you helped build it, not me.
There was a third comment, but I frankly didn't hear it clearly since I was helping to pack wadding and load engines into the Estes Viking rocket of kids that came to the engine table.
The point was that in each case of malfunction, some father somewhere threw the mother under the bus.
column2: It was one of those eyebrow-raising, head-cocking events that left me quietly abashed at the behavior of my father-peers.&nbsp
column3: Understand that there are multiple principles that I've come to adopt about dealing with family and kids.&nbsp
column4: The second rule - and I don't have anywhere near as many as Jethro Gibbs since my memory isn't that great in the first place - is that I should uphold the mother when I'm dealing with the kids.
column5: That doesn't mean to praise her unstintingly
column6: as the kids grow, there will likely be conversations where you have to help explain why things might have happened a certain way, and you can only hope that the mother returns the favor for you as well.&nbsp
column7: But it does mean that you treat her with the respect that you would hope you would be treated by her in your absence.&nbsp
column8: Or as happened the other day, in your presence.&nbsp
column9: Each of these separate fathers simply sloughed off the blame and threw their mate under the bus so as to avoid embarrassment.

column1: There are several points to consider here.
column2: It's clear that American society is continuing to undergo a significant change in terms of parental gender roles for multiple reasons.

column1: • More young men are reflecting on their own upbringing in the past twenty years and deciding that they'd like to have a greater role in their kids' lives than their own fathers had in their own childhood.
• More women are taking a much greater role in the workforce, removing them from the home requiring that their mate step up accordingly.
• Job losses and a poor economy - notwithstanding the easy credit addiction of the crackheads on Wall Street causing a new Dow/Nasdaq highs - are keeping more men at home
Despite the fact that men are now doing far more of the grocery shopping and cooking than their predecessors did, there are still some gender roles that the women don't want to see changed.
column2: How do I know?&nbsp
column3: Because more than one mother has commented such to me through the years, especially when it comes to boy-related activities.&nbsp
column4: The divorce rate through the past several decades has been in the vicinity of 50% and more than a few of the fathers fell out of the picture, leaving Mom to have to cover the activities that were historically designed for the men to handle.&nbsp
column5: This involved the handiwork activities such as building with tools as well as camping.&nbsp
column6: They themselves had grown up in a largely intact environment where Dad was around to handle such activities for the boys
column7: they themselves were not terribly exposed to such things.&nbsp
column8: This went as well with the men
column9: a fair portion were raised without the men to demonstrate and teach so that they didn't have the exposure to the more male-oriented activities and skills.&nbsp
column10: The result is that there's a significant percentage of a parental generation without the exposure to these male-oriented activities.&nbsp
column11: When it's just the Mom involved in the parenting, then she has no option but to step up and make the effort for her son.&nbsp

column2: I can speak from experience that any Dad wants to be respected by his kids and in an environment that prizes wise-assery and irreverence, it can seem hard to keep.&nbsp
column3: My own father would never do the outdoor activities with me because of a promise that he made himself after returning from the Korean War - Son, I spent a year sleeping outside with a half-million Chinese trying to kill me so I'll be goddamned if I ever sleep outside again - yet one of my kids thrives on the outdoor stuff.
column4: I've got no option but to suck up and try to learn as I go in order to provide such an experience.&nbsp
column5: The same goes for building rockets and pinewood derby cars
column6: outside my realm of experience but something that must be worked through to provide for the child.&nbsp
column7: My wife leaves that to my responsibility with the understanding that while I'm not an expert, I'll do my best and leave it at that.&nbsp

column1: The kids aren't stupid and they'll figure out sooner than later that Dad isn't perfect.
column2: What matters to them however, isn't that Dad is the expert on all things male.&nbsp
column3: What matters to them is that Dad is active in their lives and doing everything that he can.&nbsp
column4: If you aren't familiar with something, then do your research beforehand and if necessary, practice out of their presence.&nbsp
column5: Practice with them and if something doesn't work right, walk through the problem so that they learn that not everything does go right the first time.&nbsp
column6: Sometimes, it doesn't go right the second, third or fourth time either but if they don't see that, they won't learn otherwise.&nbsp
column7: When it goes right, celebrate.&nbsp
column8: What the kids want is your presence and attention and learning together is something that provides both in spades.&nbsp
column9: If you're truly not comfortable with something, then tell them why and don't feel guilty about it.&nbsp
column10: Youngest already knows that I will never take him hunting and not for reasons of conscience.&nbsp
column11: That is an activity for which I can simply not acquire sufficient expertise in time without endangering him or others.&nbsp
column12: But he does know that when his mother and I deem him old enough, we'll assure that he goes out with another father who is sufficiently competent and experienced to take a young hunter.&nbsp

column1: Part of the old code of manhood was the ability to suck it up and shoulder your load without complaint or fault-finding.
column2: So do your best and shoulder the load.&nbsp
column3: Understand that despite the changing, shifting of the household and workplace roles, there are still some things that your mate expects that you do with the kids.&nbsp
column4: And if, after doing your best, fins fall off and rockets explode on the launch pad, nosecones fail to pop so that the rocket sails with a thwack into wet ground of the parking lot pavement, then that's simply life.
column5: Not to mention that participating in such controlled chaos is honestly cool to experience.

column1:
Because things go wrong despite best efforts and the kids aren't learning much of a lesson with Dad throwing Momma under the bus.

The results for the December 2013 PracticalDad Price Index are in and after a several month period in the doldrums, the total index for all 47 grocery items rose to 109.35 (November 2010 = 100).
column2: This 1.5 point rise - from November's 107.83 - is due in large part to the half point increase in the 10 non-food items in the grocery basket
column3: the non-food components rose significantly based upon the increases in trash bags and more significantly, the stealth inflation rise in infant formula.&nbsp
column4: The 37 item Food-Only Component Index likewise rose slightly more than a half point, from 112.81 in November to 113.41 in December (11/10 = 100).

column2: the nominal price on the item remains the same so the consumer might not realize until later that the package size has actually decreased.&nbsp
column3: In the case of the infant formula that's part of the PracticalDad basket, the manufacturer - Mead Johnson - decreased the size of Enfamil Premium formula from a 23.4 ounce package to 22.2 ounces, a decline of 5.1%.&nbsp
column4: The nominal price at the stores remained unchanged over the course of the two months, yet the impact of the stealth decrease meant that a real increase of 5.4% in the cost of the previous amount of the formula for the consumer.&nbsp
column5: There are several other notable items that I've learned about stealth inflation from monitoring the PracticalDad Index basket for the past three years.

column1: <li>The change is not instantaneous but occurs over time such that the increase's impact is diffused instead of an in-your-face event.&nbsp
column2: In the case of a national manufacturer, the change can be affected across different grocery stores by the amount of inventory held by that grocer in stock.&nbsp
column3: One of the grocery chains was selling the 23.4 ounce formula packages but the shelf sticker had already been changed to account for the new 22.2 packages
column4: when the old inventory is depleted, it will be replaced by the smaller packages so that the product matches the sticker.&nbsp
column5: This situation also occurred with Poise Women's Pads, manufactured by Kimberly Clark, as one of the grocerys continued to sell the 42 pad package - with the revised 39 pad package sticker - until that inventory was sold out.&nbsp

column1: <li>The effect of stealth inflation is also diffused by the fact that the different manufacturers are doing it at different rates and at different times.&nbsp
column2: Stealth inflation hit the generic label cans of coffee about two years ago and it took several months for the three different grocers to all move out of the original 13 ounce cans to their lesser sized cans.&nbsp

column1: <li>Having said that it occurs over a period of time, understand that once a single manufacturer engages in stealth inflation by decreasing the package size, others will follow suit.&nbsp
column2: This is demonstrated by Kimberly-Clark, the manufacturer of personal care products such as Poise Women's Pads, Cottonelle toilet paper and Huggies diapers.&nbsp
column3: An article in Zerohedge highlighted that Kimberly-Clark would be decreasing the size of diaper packaging in Q1 of 2014.
column4: Given that manufacturers follow suit over time, I anticipate that stealth inflation will further hit young families as other diaper manufacturers follow suit to also maintain their profit margins.&nbsp

column1: <li>Stealth inflation doesn't just occur because of the rise in the input commodities, such as sugar and coffee.&nbsp
column2: These are also purely business decisions to pad corporate profits with no thought as to the situation of the consumer.&nbsp
column3: The language used by Kimberly-Clark in their Q3 2013 Recap - highlighted in the Zerohedge article - makes no reference to the increases in input prices.&nbsp
column4: It refers to these different products as high margin businesses
column5: decreasing packaging sizes is purely a business decision that benefits the corporation bottom-line. So the cost of Huggies diapers will rise - following the practice of other diaper manufacturers - which further crimps the budgets of young families who are already whacked with declining family incomes.&nbsp
column6: Since Kimberly-Clark has also decreased the package size of it's Poise Women's Pads (from 42 pads per package to 39), I wouldn't be surprised to see a profit-driven decrease in package sizing for Depends Undergarments, which also impacts an income-afflicted marketing cohort.

column1: So what's the takeaway from all of this for the family?
column2: It's the lesson to be passed along to the kids that they are going to have to pay attention to the world around them, a difficult thing to do when wrapped in an electronic cocoon graciously provided by Apple and furnished by Google.&nbsp
column3: They exist for the benefit of the corporate bottom line, regardless of their own circumstance.

column1: As my own father once told me decades ago:
column2: Nobody's looking out for you, kid.
