782,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The pricing for the 47 item PracticalDad Price Index marketbasket is complete and after looking at the results, the one phrase that crossed my mind is welcome to the jungle.
column2: The changes that I'm seeing from one month to the next are symptomatic of what's occurring in the larger economy in multiple ways.

column1: In terms of pure numbers, the 47 item January 2016 PracticalDad Price Index declined from December's 104.92 to January's 104.54 (November 2010 = 100) while the 37 Food-Only Subindex dropped more than a full basis point from December's 106.39 to January's 105.25 (November 2010 = 100).
column2: Please note that for the Food-Only Subindex, the cumulative decline from the December 2014 apex of 115.13 is now greater than 65%
column3: it took more than four years of quantitative easing and loose monetary policy to bring that subindex for the 37 item foodstuff item marketbasket up by more than 15%.&nbsp
column4: With the cease of QE and persistent economic pressure upon the family, it's only taken 13 months to undo it.

column1: So how is this akin to a jungle?
column2: You have to understand why the three store average dropped as much as it did in one month - unbelievably (to me, at least), the cost of a pound of 80% lean ground beef actually dropped by an average of 5.4%.&nbsp
column3: If you're going to store or watching the news, you'd be in company with me at this drop.&nbsp
column4: But what was surprising - and informative - was the cause for the decline.&nbsp
column5: All of the surveyed stores sold their 80% lean beef in store wrapped packages but last week, two of the three - each a part of a chain - were selling their 80% in a large, pill-shaped package called a chub instead of the usual packaging.
column6: I'd seen the chubs before, but they had always been for the lower margin/higher fat 73% lean and because they were not part of the survey, I'd simply ignored them.&nbsp
column7: When the numbers were tabulated and the indices found, I decided to go back to the two stores to examine the beef further.&nbsp
column8: Each of the chubs, now sold in the two chains, were produced by a firm called JBS LLC, USA
column9: this is the American subsidiary of a Brazilian multinational meat packing firm founded in Brazil in 1953.&nbsp
column10: As I perused further, I saw that JBS had done a serious job of growth via acquisition of firms both in the US and elsewhere.&nbsp
column11: They have diversified first across types of protein so that they now produce poultry as well as beef and they've diversified vertically by the purchase of massive feedlot operations used to fatten cattle prior to slaughter
column12: in 2008, they purchased Five Rivers Cattle Feeding to make them the largest cattle feeder in the world.&nbsp
column13: They further extended their control by the 2010 purchase of the McElhaney Feedlot in Arizona, which increased their cattle feeding capacity by more than 130,000 head at one time.
column14: So the producer of the chub is a massive presence in the beef production industry.

column1: What scares the central banks about deflation is that during the Great Depression, money became so scarce that many companies lost control of their ability to set and maintain prices, resulting in their ultimate bankruptcies.
column2: Competition amongst producers simply came down to which could survive long enough, a truly dog eat dog scenario.
column3: This is eerily reminiscent as money continues to flow out of the middle class and budgeted food dollars are replaced only partially by government food stamp programs, placing greater pressure on the grocers and by extension, the producers.&nbsp
column4: As the preceding information about JBS SA shows, this is a firm that's built for survival via sheer economies of scale.&nbsp
column5: What's also notable about this change in the offering of 80% lean is that the chub is now the package offering for a higher grade of ground beef.&nbsp
column6: If you accept the proposition that the lower and fattier grades of beef are the province of those with less money, then a shift in packaging to the chub by a mass producer is an indication that the extent of the family budget woes are creeping throughout the middle class.&nbsp
column7: Obviously, executives at the grocery chains are noticing drops in sales and are aware of why and rolling out a lower priced alternative is the logical response.&nbsp
column8: However, this is not the kind of indicator that you want to see.&nbsp

column1: The jungle metaphor also refers back to one of the great impact novels of the early 20th century, Upton Sinclair's The Jungle.
column2: Sinclair's book was a work that exposed the conditions of the meat-packing industry of that period and by extension, the conditions that prevailed overall when businesses were able to operate without any form of oversight to enforce the most basic sanitary conditions.&nbsp
column3: It helped to establish the mindset that there was a legitimate role for government in the regulation of heretofore laissez faire competition.&nbsp
column4: One of the later upshots of this was the establishment of the Food and Drug Administration to oversee the safety of what goes on the table.&nbsp
column5: This isn't to necessarily say that the packing conditions are horrible and the product tainted, but when businesses get to the size that meat production is akin to factory conditions, then it does make me wonder.

column1: And now to the results of the Indices for the past six months.

column2: The pace of writing over the past number of months slowed significantly, even to a crawl, but the conversations with the kids have continued regardless.&nbsp
column3: Late this past summer, prior to his own departure to freshman year of college, I was talking with Middle about college costs and he looked at me and asked ""how in the hell did this happen?""&nbsp
column4: It's a great question deserving of an answer, but like so many others, not one that has an easy answer.&nbsp
column5: What follows is a series of articles looking at the interconnected factors that have contributed to the disproportionately high cost of college.

column1: Higher Education is a hot, steaming mess.
column2: If you look at the number of colleges and programs offered, you might not think so, but in terms of actually obtaining that college degree, it really is a hot, steaming mess.
column3: When you actually review the data, you find that the cost of tuition has risen more than 1100% since 1978 and what's even more food for thought is that the linked article was published four years ago, in 2012.
column4: Comparatively, the median American family income has risen only 269% in nominal dollars - a not-quite three fold increase over that same 1978 - 2012 timespan.
column5: Factor in the disproportionate rise in the cost of healthcare by 601% over the same period and acknowledge the fact that more of the burden of these same costs are now borne by the American family than in 1978 and you begin to understand why it's become such a hot-button issue.

column1: But costs don't rise in such a fashion because they just levitate like so many feathers carried in the wind.
column2: There are reasons for this and the reasons are multi-fold and interconnected, one playing out upon another over the course of decades, unnoticed by the mass of people because they're engrossed in the very short-term necessities of either raising a family and living a life, or just binging on Netflix.&nbsp
column3: From this perspective, there are five factors that have contributed to our present situation:

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: First, the effects of globalization and the shift to a ""knowledge-based"" economy.&nbsp
column7: It used to be that entry into the fabled American middle class was predicated upon a sustainable, living wage job that could be had with just a high-school degree.&nbsp
column8: That it was in a factory was acceptable since the employee could raise a family in a standard that was undreamed of during the Great Depression years, and it didn't require additional education unless the employee wanted it.&nbsp
column9: But starting in the 1980s, companies and Wall Street began touting globalization, a principle whereby American corporations maximized their their profit for shareholders by shifting the lower-rung manufacturing overseas and retaining the higher-end positions here.
column10: In this model, Americans would design and engineer the goods that the world needed while the little brown and yellow people elsewhere would have to contend with the workplace drudgery and pollution that came with manufacturing.&nbsp
column11: That you didn't need to provide a sustainable living wage and could get a 'tween-ager to manufacture a high-end pair of sneakers for pennies?&nbsp

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: Second, there was a purposeful effort by companies in the late 20th century to alter their job requirements so that the baseline for hiring in a wide variety of positions was now a college degree instead of a high school diploma.&nbsp
column7: That these same positions were now already successfully filled by capable high school graduates was irrelevant, a degree replaced the diploma as the baseline.&nbsp
column8: There's certainly an argument for some of that being the result of a desire to move beyond what was perceived to be a failing public education system incapable of turning out satisfactory candidates.&nbsp
column9: But I can speak from experience that there were other factors as well.&nbsp
column10: The predominant reason was that as businesses made this move to a degree the hiring baseline, it created a ripple effect as their competitors felt compelled to do so in order to maintain the semblance of competitiveness, particularly in the eyes of their customers.&nbsp

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: Third, the effects of shifts in the funding paradigm for higher education.&nbsp
column7: Where a significant support previously was provided by the government, the burden of educating young people has shifted first to the family and within the last decade, to the student.&nbsp
column8: I don't believe that people truly understand the impact of the state and federal governments in the middle of the Twentieth Century upon higher education.&nbsp
column9: On the one side of the house, the Servicemen's Readjustment Act of 1944 - aka The GI Bill - made significant educational funding available to millions of servicemen who returned home from the Second World War and literally provided higher education for an entire generation of young adults.
column10: On the other side of the house, state governments boosted spending for their state institutions through the next several decades until the amount spent per student climaxed and then began to decline in the 1980s.&nbsp
column11: The ebbing has occurred in that while there are still educational benefits for veterans, we now have a volunteer military and the numbers of available recipients is far less than in the decade immediately following the end of World War Two.&nbsp
column12: Likewise, purposeful budgetary funding per student by most, if not all, state legislatures has declined in the three decades since the Reagan Administration.&nbsp

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: Fourth, the shift to self funding by first the family and then the student was greased by years of low interest rates and the easy availability of credit.&nbsp
column7: What's occurred with the funding of higher education is a microcosm of what's occurred within public society as well.&nbsp
column8: As the Congress and Executive began two decades of vicious sniping and attack, it has devolved into a farcical situation in which there is no longer an agreed upon budget but instead a lengthy trail of continuing spending authorizations and debt limit increases.&nbsp
column9: Because decisions can't be made and the debt continues to rise, the Federal Reserve has - and I hate to say it, but it's true - stepped into the breach to delay a day of reckoning by maintaining artificially low interest rates.&nbsp
column10: So the financial role of government in higher education has shifted from fiscal policy laid out in conscious budgetary decisions to monetary policy as shown by the low cost of borrowing money.
column11: Here's the difference between fiscal and monetary policy:&nbsp
column12: fiscal policy is made by consensus, which is often messy and combative as issues are threshed through.&nbsp
column13: Monetary policy however, simply acts to delay any decisions because there is no perceived cost to borrowing and hence, no need to actually make a decision
column14: can't make a decision because it's too unpleasant to hash through?&nbsp
column15: Don't worry, we can hold off because it won't cost much.&nbsp
column16: On the micro-level of the student and family, the story line for years was that borrowing to finance your education was wise because it was investing in yourself and would pay off in the long-run.

column2: &nbsp
column3: &nbsp
column4: &nbsp
column5: &nbsp
column6: Fifth, all of the preceding factors braided together neatly to create an entitlement sense amongst higher education that it simply now had a captive market.&nbsp
column7: And based upon the ways in which some of the institutions have spent their money, their perception has seemed to be that the market was in the French Quarter as college presidents and administrators strolled down the Rue amidst a shower of cash screaming out laissez les bon temps rouler!
column8: There was no perceived need to keep the spending down - apart from paying for pesky things like permanent faculty - since the money flowed and the steady flow of students continued.&nbsp
column9: Money was spent on increasing administration, extraneous and honestly unnecessary programs of study and physical plant and student options that are high-end accessories as many of the institutions competed with one another.&nbsp
column10: And yes, when your brochures are showing photos of climbing walls and Mongolian Grills as student dining options, then that would arguably qualify as high-end.&nbsp

column2: Like much else in America, we've gotten use to having plenty of options and choices without remembering that these options come with a price tag.&nbsp
column3: As my father used to comment from time to time:&nbsp
column4: champagne taste, beer budget.
column5: Over the next several weeks, I'll expand upon these factors individually because honestly, there's some fascinating stuff out there.","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

A short while back, my middle child and eldest son - aka ""Middle"" - asked me how college costs managed to rise so disproportionately over the past several decades.
column2: The <a href=""http://www.practicaldad.com/index.php/article/783"" title=""The High Cost of Higher Education:  &quot
column3: How in the hell did this happen?&quot
column4: >resulting article was a response to his question and looked at five different factors, each of which contributed to the present mess in the cost of a college degree.
column5: The first of these factors was Globalization and this article is the first of a series examining the factors in greater detail.

column1: Globalization wouldn't be the first thing that springs to mind when you think about why the cost of higher education has risen so dramatically in the past three decades.
column2: It frankly wouldn't be the second or third thing either, since the effect upon the cost of a college degree isn't primary.&nbsp
column3: The impact is derivative instead, yet it's still important because it helped to pave the road for the persistent annual tuition increases as the institutions of higher education realized that there was now a massive and sustained rise in demand for their product:&nbsp
column4: a college degree.

column1: Globalization is the economic principle that economic progress and advancement is improved for everyone when there is a free-flow of capital, technology, resources and labor across the globe and unhampered by national borders.
column2: It is supposed to be a sort of rising tide lifts all boats effect as the aforementioned inputs flow to that global region best able to utilize them to produce in the most efficient and effective manner.
column3: It is the linchpin concept behind the fiercely debated North American Free Trade Agreement of 1994 and the World Trade Organization, which was instituted by treaty in 1995.
column4: It's actually a reasonable concept and one that I didn't oppose when the debates occurred two decades ago.&nbsp
column5: But where the issue had an impact on higher education was a subsidiary concept:&nbsp
column6: the Knowledge-Based Economy.

column1: The Knowledge-Based Economy is of more amorphous origin, but the principle is predicated upon the notion that global resources are allocated where they can be most efficiently used until they can be brought to market as a final good or product.
column2: Since one of the basic variable costs in production is labor, it makes intellectual sense to shift lower-end manufacturing - requiring little education and training - to third world locations where a peasant can be paid a small fraction of what's earned by an American laborer.&nbsp
column3: This would continue and the First World nations would be left to utilize their own resources in the conceptual, design and engineering aspects of the production.&nbsp
column4: Higher-end and technical manufacturing would stay in the First World, at least until such time as the tides had lifted the other nations enough that they also had the intellectual and technical capabilities to support the design and engineering components.&nbsp
column5: Corollary to the Knowledge-Based Economy was the Service Economy, where American workers would be spending their time providing higher end services to run and support the now-displaced production aspects elsewhere across the globe.&nbsp
column6: I expect that some corporate visionaries envisioned a society in which the great mass of Americans became mandarin-like technocrats in a great machine that churned out profits enriching the lives of all privileged enough to participate.&nbsp
column7: But I also now expect that there was another group of corporate visionaries who saw this as the opportunity to offshore all manner of labor costs so that unions could be undercut and profits grown.&nbsp
column8: Understand one small yet highly significant fact from the early and mid-1980s:&nbsp
column9: there was a shift in how corporate senior executives were paid and stock packages and options now became even more potentially lucrative than salaries authorized by a Board of Directors.

column1: So now start to think of higher education in terms of supply and demand and this is probably where these principles began to have an impact upon the cost of a college degree.
column2: Preceding generations of young Americans had other alternatives to higher education so that there was less demand for it.&nbsp
column3: Young males could be drawn off into the military via the demands of the draft and the Cold War.&nbsp
column4: They also had options in sustainable, living-wage manufacturing and trades that did not require a degree.&nbsp
column5: Fewer women pursued a college degree since there were fewer, then-socially acceptable career paths available to them.&nbsp
column6: All of these factors meant that there was lesser demand for college, even though the GI Bill of 1944 had opened the spigot to higher education.&nbsp
column7: But then changes began.&nbsp
column8: The draft ended and the military shifted to an all-volunteer basis, followed two decades later by the end of the Cold War.&nbsp
column9: Women began to achieve greater opportunities for careers and there was a decided societal push for women to obtain an education and then a career.&nbsp
column10: And through the last three or more decades, the trickling shift of American jobs began and then became a torrent.

column1: It was now here, at the end of the 20th century, that Globalization and the Knowledge-Based Economy became fully enunciated as guiding principles and the offshoring of American manufacturing began wholesale.
column2: The resultant demand for a college degree turned the college marketing and admission process into a literal cattle chute and the colleges and universities realized that they had become - for many Americans hopeful for a future - the only game in town.&nbsp
column3: Even before this point, parents and guidance counselors pushed their kids to go to college so that they could have a better, more fulfilling future.
column4: Mike Rowe, of Dirty Jobs fame, wrote about this in Popular Mechanics in August, 2013.
column5: He described a conversation with his high school guidance counselor in which the counselor touted the value of a college degree, even to a kid who wasn't certain of what he wanted except for the understanding that his own skill set might be more technical and practical than intellectual.&nbsp
column6: I can attest to this type of conversation as well in my own experience.&nbsp
column7: So there was already a presumptuous mindset about the value of college: &nbsp
column8: but the increased demand that came from social change and the simple removal of other viable options simply drove everybody to the chutes.

column1: But here's the thing about cattle chutes.
column2:
Some of them lead to slaughter pens.

785,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The pricing for the February 2016 edition of the PracticalDad Price Index is in with deflation in the 47 item grocery market-basket continuing.
column2: As I sat there researching background information to understand something, it occurred that what we're watching in the retail economy is best described as bare knuckled price fighting.
column3: There was a time when grocery stores were adding upscale coffee kiosks and organic produce sections to entice customers, but that's now in the past as stores are finding new ways to fight for the disappearing consumer dollar and it's creating a feedback loop for deflation.&nbsp
column4: But first, the numbers from this most recent monthly pricing and then some comments both about what I'm seeing on the shelves and how this is impacting the Index.

column1: The Total Index reading on the 47 item PracticalDad Price Index for February 2016 came in at 103.86 (November 2010 = 100), down from January's 104.54.
column2: The 37 food-stuff components sub-index for February was 104.27 (November 2010 = 100), likewise down almost a full basis point from January's result of 105.25.&nbsp
column3: For the Food-only Subindex, this most recent result of 104.27 is fully 70% less than the high-point of that sub-index
column4: it reached a maximum of 115.13 in December 2014 and has declined since that time.&nbsp

column2: More than a half decade of artificially low rates pushing the zero-rate boundary to spur inflation and all of those trillions of dollars of additional liquidity wiped away in the fourteen months since that peak.&nbsp
column3: Fourteen months and the aggregate pricing is now back at a level unseen since the summer of 2011.&nbsp
column4: A pound of hamburger and a package of hot dogs are still more expensive than at the outset of the survey in November 2010, as are some other food items, but it's what has occurred with other items that provide a good explanation of deflation and what's occurring within the greater economy.

column2: Simply put, the grocers are doing everything that they can to fight for the average family's disappearing dollar - understand that one in seven Americans is now receiving government food assistance - and this consists principally of rolling out new products that cost less to produce, the lowest common denominator approach.&nbsp
column3: I've noticed this within the past year as two of the three surveyed grocers - each part of a separate grocery chain - established new pricing policies that moved towards low prices on store-brand products.&nbsp
column4: The third grocer is an independent whose store-brand within the past year has been completely replaced by another supplier with an across-the-board reduction in the price of each item surveyed.&nbsp
column5: But what has happened within the past several months is that one of the grocery chains is now in the process of supplementing its store-brand product line with another line of products that are offered by a grocery industry GPO (Group Purchasing Organization).&nbsp
column6: The savings on the products are significant
column7: in the case of a can of vegetables, by a full 40% (from $.79/can to $.47/can) and this is being played out among other products within the basket.&nbsp
column8: It's also led to a mental debate on whether and how to account for this shifting in the PracticalDad Index.

column1: When the concept for the Index arose in 2010, the pricing was based whenever possible upon the lowest prices for the items and these were, in all instances, the store-brand (generic) lines of products.
column2: Name-brand items were only used when the lower-cost store-brands weren't available in all of the stores.&nbsp
column3: These lower priced alternatives to the store-brands simply didn't exist in the products and it's only within the past few months that this has fed into multiple products.&nbsp
column4: Should I account for them or not?&nbsp
column5: Given that the baseline premise for the survey was a marketbasket of grocery items being purchased by a family with children living within an alloted monthly food budget, I opted to account for the product shift as these items would be purchased by the budget-conscious family in lieu of the now more-expensive store-brand items.&nbsp
column6: These products aren't going away and the question that I have, based upon what I've seen in one of the chain's stores, is whether it will actually be the store-brand items going away instead.

column1: I mentioned the term GPO in a previous paragraph and it's useful to explain what that is.
column2: A Group Purchasing Organization is actually an old concept now brought to the grocery industry.&nbsp
column3: The first GPO was started in 1910 by the New York Bureau of Hospitals and centralized purchasing of medical items for a number of hospitals in order to maximize buying power and gain price concessions from manufacturers.&nbsp
column4: This has long since caught on amongst other industries and holds true for the grocery industry as well.&nbsp
column5: What the Index now reflects is that one of the surveyed grocers now offers the low-end brand created and marketed by a GPO named Topco Associates, LLC.
column6: This GPO is a privately held concern consisting of more than 50 separate grocery retail chains across the country with aggregate revenues in the billions of dollars and the organization uses this buying heft akin to that used by Walmart to gain concessions from food producers.&nbsp
column7: As I researched the concept of GPO for this article, I came across an online ad touting Do you want to be like Walmart?
column8: The Walmartization of the American economy continues and I wonder where it will end.
column9: As I write this, to my left is an orange can of low-cost coffee now offered by the other grocery chain as a supplemental choice to it's own store-brand coffee and I surmise that it's from yet another GPO (as yet to be determined).&nbsp
column10: And as you'd expect, it's not good.

column1: And now for the past six months of results.

786,"1","1",,"xhtml","

The question about the upcoming presidential primaries for the 2016 nominees has arisen on both end of the spectrums, from one of the kids as well as from my mother, who popped it during a lunch the other day.
column2: So, who do you like?

column1: While it would be a beautiful thing to be able to spit out a response in favor of a singular candidate - because it's just time for a woman president, that's why - I find that it's difficult.
column2: The reality is that the issue overshadowing all else is the control that the uber-wealthy and corporations now have over the legislative and electoral process.&nbsp
column3: And by uber-wealthy, I mean those who have .01% of the nation's wealth...welcome back to the age of the Robber Barons.

column1: So the question arose again the other night where two of the three kids were gathered with us awaiting Middle's event.
column2: Both my wife and I looked at one another and the statements were identical and concise:&nbsp
column3: <em>It doesn't matter.&nbsp
column4: Taxes will go up regardless of who's in office and Sanders is the only one with the guts to acknowledge that that's going to happen.&nbsp
column5: But if Trump makes his way into office, don't be surprised if they increase there either since it's a mathematical certainty that the revenue will only flow if the taxes go up...because God knows we can't control our spending.
column6: We both elaborated further, knowing that the problems are wholly systemic and metastasized throughout the governmental body.&nbsp
column7: <em>If you want to know the truth, the ideal candidate is already resigned to the notion that it will be a single term presidency and he/she will lose, if even willing to run for a second term.&nbsp
column8: Because the system will have to be shaken to the core and if successful, that President will be hated and derided and probably for a generation.
column9: To call it a sobering commentary would be an understatement.

column2: Twain wrote that while history doesn't repeat itself, it does rhyme and we're now in a literal nursery rhyme with Andrew Jackson's clash with Nicholas Biddle's Second Bank of the United States.
column3: In that instance, Biddle put the screws to the country by betraying its role as the ostensible central bank and withholding funds from smaller banks in order to pressure the Congress to renew their original charter.&nbsp
column4: This resulted in multiple small bank runs with the resultant ruin of thousands of depositors who lost all of their savings
column5: but it also dramatized the threat that one or a few exceptionally wealthy and powerful individuals could pose to the body politic.&nbsp
column6: In that instance, Jackson's response - combative and populist - was to withdraw the government's deposits from Biddle's bank, which served as the capital base for all that that bank was supposed to do.&nbsp
column7: In essence, Jackson allowed the financial system to collapse in order to save the promise of the still very young Constitution.&nbsp
column8: To do otherwise would have been to allow a single individual to use the power of the pre-eminent financial institution to gain control over the mechanism of government.&nbsp
column9: If Jackson folded and Biddle won, what else would have happened - or not happened - if it displeased the banker.

column1: And with the Supreme Court's 2010 Citizens United decision that effectively quashed any campaign finance reform, please feel free to explain to me how this is any different from 180 years ago?
Some years ago, I used to spend considerable time on a wonderful financial/economics site and in the course of an evening's ongoing commentary with other members of that community, I commented this:
column2: My hope is that when all of this is said and done, we come through everything with some semblance of an intact Constitution.
column3: It sounds melodramatic, which I hate, but it's not at all far-fetched.&nbsp
column4: The levers of power have been grabbed by the very wealthiest few and the corporations and they are actively solidifying their hold on said levers.&nbsp
column5: President Obama's response in his first term should have been Jacksonian, moving to reform and re-institute meaningful regulation of the financial sector and he failed to do this.&nbsp
column6: That an Assistant Attorney General was canned and his then-Attorney General later acknowledged that the fear of financial damage to the economy affects decisions on prosecutions indicates the level of power of that sector and the fear that it engenders.
column7: And now that the heads of JPM Chase and Goldman Sachs have both become certifiable billionaires under this arrangement, the financial sector is wholly part and parcel of the cabal.

column1: The threat to the country is no longer economic but now, for all intents and purposes, both Constitutional and existential.
column2: My thinking had been that the key factor to my choice of candidate would be what kind of person they'd likely nominate to the Supreme Court and how that individual would vote on such a decision as Citizens United.
column3: That decision was reached by the narrowest margin of 5 - 4 and the dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens - eminently worthy of the read here - is a good distillation of the ultimate controversy:
column4: with whom does the power reside?&nbsp
column5: I have become convinced that the trade and monetary policies of the past three decades have been purposefully passed with the understanding that they will ultimately benefit only a relative very few and that, at the cost of the great majority of Americans.&nbsp
column6: The hemorrhaging of the median family income isn't a sudden event, but instead only the damage arising from the effects of three decades of cumulative muggings upon the American Middle Class.&nbsp
column7: Such is the effect of power moving to the control of a very self-interested few.&nbsp

column1: My thinking about the candidate that I'd support went to the type of individual that would be nominated to the Supreme Court.
column2: What would be the political persuasion and most importantly, their attitudes about the Constitution?&nbsp
column3: Strict constructionist?&nbsp
column4: Liberal?&nbsp
column5: It does matter because as much as I can appreciate the constructionist viewpoint, the reality is that we have issues today that would make our Founding Fathers' eyes bleed.&nbsp
column6: Some things are the same, yet some are simply not.

column1: At the end of the evening, we found out that Justice Antonin Scalia had passed away earlier that day and the narrow majority that ruled in favor of the Citizens United decision was now moot.
column2: I was unaware of Scalia's age and believed that the decision to nominate a new Supreme Court Justice would wait until the next president but that assumption is now moot.&nbsp
column3: It is the purview of any sitting President to nominate a person for the Supreme Court and for either side to cry for a delay is politics at its most venal.&nbsp
column4: But make no mistake, with the average age of the Supreme Court north of 70 years of age, it's likely that the next President will also have the privilege of nominating a candidate.&nbsp
column5: If President Obama does nominate someone who would shift that 5 - 4 margin in the direction favorable to overturning the Citizens United decision, it would still be only a razor thin majority.
column6: So that's what I'm considering as both sides of the political spectrum continue to throw the middle finger at the political class.&nbsp
column7: Do I have a list of candidates for the Court should Trump, Sanders, Hillary or anybody else take office?&nbsp
column8: No.&nbsp
column9: But I'm not stupid either, and what they say - and how much money that they take - is a solid indication of where they'll go.&nbsp
column10: And that's likely to be where I'll head, too.

column1:
787,"1","1",,"xhtml","

Teen and young adult dystopian literature has been around for a while but it's darkly fascinating to see how the notion that something's just not quite right is percolating through society.
column2: So it was when I was chatting with Youngest one evening about his school day and found that he had an essay due along with the rest of his middle school English class.&nbsp
column3: The topic was both surprising and more than a little disturbing:&nbsp
column4: each student was to describe the one skill that they'd most prize should the economy collapse and things go to hell (my term, not his).&nbsp

column1: We've known for a while that teens are feeling stress as acutely as adults and that their stress is timed to the school year.
column2: The push for good grades and to ascertain what their career goals - not to mention getting into and funding the right school - make their teen years significantly more tense than it probably was two or three generations ago.
column3: But throw in the refrain that a college degree has now supplanted the high school diploma as the baseline paper for some degree of financial success and the understanding that they're likely to graduate with the equivalent car loan around their neck for a barista's position, and they get it.&nbsp
column4: The question that it begs afterwards is how long this condition can last
column5: more importantly, what happens to society afterwards?&nbsp
column6: So their literature has come to mirror adult literature with authors tapping into the zeitgeist to work through the issues.
column7: Teens have seen their fictional societies ravaged by despotic regimes (Suzanne Collins' The Hunger Games), aliens (Rick Yancey's The Fifth Wave), nuclear post-apocolyptic societies (Veronica Roth's Divergent series), and zombies (James Dashner's Maze Runner and Charlie Higson's The Enemy series).
column8: Having seen each of these series come through the household with one child or another, I can only ask myself what else could possibly go wrong?&nbsp

column1: But this particular essay assignment doesn't have the Shakespearean suspend your disbelief quality that all of the previously mentioned series share.
column2: This has an immediacy that touches them deeply.&nbsp
column3: Youngest's generation is a group that has seen parents downsized and has seen a suburban school district host clothing drives each year, an event that didn't exist until just a few years ago.&nbsp
column4: A nearby city school district has a Friday power-pack program that hands out hundreds of food-filled backpacks to students so that they have food for the weekend and don't return to school the following Monday suffering from hunger.
column5: This isn't fiction and this isn't unbelievable.&nbsp
column6: For them, this is real.&nbsp
column7: I don't know what the teacher's thought process was behind the assignment and I don't know if that individual is a closet doomer or just looking to spur thought
column8: I frankly don't plan to bother finding out.&nbsp
column9: But it's still an eye-opening assignment.

column1: So as Youngest and I spoke, I inquired as to what his response was and after sharing it with me, we talked further about it.
column2: My own comments afterwards were to what I myself would consider the most important skill set and not surprisingly, it had to do with the ability to determine what holds value for people and then knowing how to negotiate and barter.&nbsp
column3: Because if the s*&^ hits the fan as the phrase goes, money will rapidly disappear and we'll be working on a barter basis.
column4: The conversation ranged to the highly practical - and cynical - view of human nature and that perhaps the family's stash of alcohol could be divvied into smaller containers for trade or supplemented with airline bottles.&nbsp
column5: It might even be of benefit to further supplement the stash with a supply of cartons of cigarettes for trade.&nbsp
column6: Is it an optimal outlook?&nbsp
column7: No.&nbsp
column8: But this type of scenario is going to require a pragmatic and clear view of the world around us, very different from what out youngsters have come to expect in their politically correct school cocoons.&nbsp

column1: It's been an interesting thought experiment in the days since that conversation.
column2: If there is an economic collapse - and the constant 24/7 newscycle feeds that fear - what should you expect?&nbsp
column3: What do you believe that would resemble and more importantly, what is your plan?&nbsp
column4: How would you plan to handle the first several weeks if there's a Greek/Cypriot style clampdown on bank ATMs or even a wholesale bank holiday?&nbsp
column5: Who is in your network of close friends upon whom you rely and in turn rely upon you?&nbsp
column6: Most importantly, what and how do you teach your children so that they can make their way as self-reliant and capable adults in such a world?&nbsp
column7: It's not a theoretical question but goes to the heart of being a parent since our primary job is to raise the children to become self-reliant, productive and moral adults capable of making their way in the world.

column1: I doubt that my conversation about bartering booze and smokes necessarily fits into the category of moral, but it can help get through the immediate crisis period while we work on the other skills that would serve them better in the long-haul.
column2: And it's also part of our parental purview to help them determine what those skills are and how to foster them along.&nbsp
column3: So make an effort to prompt them on their days and their assignments.&nbsp
column4: The results can be more revealing than another piece of classwork designed solely to get them through the next standardized test.&nbsp
column5: And a note to myself - get a final copy of Youngest's essay from his teacher.&nbsp
column6:
It's going to be an interesting read.

","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL

column2: It's just not fair!

column1: Almost all of us with kids have heard this phrase from their mouths at one time or another, especially if the child has a sibling.
column2: It's been a chronic complaint for generations of parents as the egocentric kids worry that Sib is getting more than they are, whether it's a smartphone, an Easy-Bake oven, a Hula hoop or a Dick Tracy detective kit.&nbsp
column3: And the response of most parents is a sigh or groan and an explanation that the Sib is really not being treated preferentially.&nbsp
column4: But does this age-old situation taken on a new face?&nbsp
column5: Has the technology curve changed how we handle the concept of fairness and equity with the kids and how do we manage it?

column1: From talking with my peers over the years, the common recollection was that most parents tried to maintain an almost mechanistic even-handedness in dealing with the kids.
column2: Like my own parents, if one child got a real desk at 10 years of age, then the next child received the same item at the same age.&nbsp
column3: It was a realistic defense in dealing with the kvetching that comes from kids sensitive to anything that threatens their own perceived place in the world.&nbsp
column4: And if anything can drive a parent batshit crazy, it's the constant grousing from one or more of the kids who chronically attempt to prove their point, as pointless as it may be.&nbsp
column5: My own history was one of the mechanistic even-handed sort.&nbsp
column6: My older sister got some milestone item at a specific age and when I reached that same age a few years later, I received a like milestone item.&nbsp
column7: Desk?&nbsp
column8: check.
column11: With many of my peers, it was a similar situation because typically, a kid didn't need a specific item until there was actually a perceptible need for it.&nbsp

column1: While my wife and I worked with this process through the early years of our children's lives, it has taken a decidedly different turn in the past several months because of technology, specifically laptops and smartphones.
column2: Until a few years ago, the family line was that there would be one family computer for the kids to share and that device was located in a common area of the house.&nbsp
column3: None of the kids had laptops that could be removed to bedrooms and there were no smartphones
column4: the word on mobile phones was that when circumstance dictated it, then a child got a cellphone.&nbsp
column5: When Eldest was fifteen years of age and traveling to a distant city for a week-long event, we got her a cellphone.&nbsp
column6: As her high school graduation gift, we footed a nice, high-end laptop that would last through college.&nbsp
column7: Several years after Eldest blazed the way, Middle got a cellphone just before he was eligible to drive.&nbsp
column8: His laptop however, was earlier since the school decreed that all students would receive free laptops for use and lo and behold, a laptop appeared years before we had planned to foot for one and household guidelines had to be revised accordingly.
column9: When the school district redrew boundary lines for the various schools to rebalance the size of their respective student bodies, we found that Youngest would be attending middle school at the school that was the further away so he got a simple cellphone for use in case or emergency
column10: this was at an age several years younger than his siblings.

column1: But the push has been on for months about upgrading to a better phone and by better, I mean a smartphone.
column2: The repeated requests have been at Youngest's behest because his simple phone is incapable of handling the communications now used by his peers, all of whom possess one manner of smartphone or another.&nbsp
column3: As one of his buddies commented, Dude, you should get an Apple...we're an Apple family!
column4: We've found that some of his friends will text with him simply because they're friends but he's the only one with whom they text and all else is handled via Instagram
column5: this means that in oversight, there have been multiple events and get-togethers from which he's been excluded and despite subsequent apologies from his buddies, it still hurts.&nbsp
column6: This realization has led to more discussion in the household.&nbsp
column7: <em>Should we let the fact that he's the only one without the latest and greatest drive a family decision?&nbsp
column8: What are the new family guidelines on smartphone use?&nbsp
column9: How fair is it to the older siblings that he's received earlier access to technology and in some instances, by years?
column10: Because Eldest was home visiting from college over a recent weekend, she responded that it was really irrelevant now.&nbsp
column11: The communication platforms favored by the youngsters - even younger than the college crowd - has changed significantly from when she was that age less than a decade before and if it was interfering with his capability to have a healthy and active social life with his peers, then it was worth the upgrade.&nbsp
column12: To be fully equitable however, we also upgraded Middle to a smartphone and as a favor to me, my wife also got me one as well.

column1: So technological change has altered the question of maintaining a degree of fairness amongst the children.
column2: What we've seen is that the other factor which makes it more pertinent is the age differential between the various children.&nbsp
column3: If you have only a few years between the children, then the matter won't be a potential booby-trap.&nbsp
column4: But if you're talking anywhere around the vicinity of five or more years between the kids, then it's liable to be more of a concern.&nbsp
column5: There are no right or wrong answers here.&nbsp
column6:
But it's worthwhile to be aware of the trip hazards as you negotiate the debate.

column9: - Sign in the crypt of the Capuchin Order, Rome, Italy

column1: You see some odd things as you travel and one of the oddest is the crypt of the Capuchin Friars in Rome.
column2: It is a multi-room collection of the bones - some still full skeletons - of more than 3700 Capuchin Friars and others, assembled in various displays that in some ways are morbidly artistic.&nbsp
column3: The captioned quote is on a sign in one of the rooms and serves as a graphic reminder to the tourist of the fleeting nature of life.&nbsp
column4: I saw the sign during a family vacation several years ago and noticing it served as the cherry on a thoroughly bizarre day.
column5: But the full import was lost on me until I became sandwiched between the youngsters and an elderly parent.

column1: For most people, life is a Bell Curve and the plateau for the total person - mental, physical, emotional - is typically reached during middle age.
column2: When you have kids, you're at or near the top of your game and can focus on raising them, bringing them along and preparing them for their own adulthood.&nbsp
column3: It is hard work, as the Wall Street Journal noted in a groundbreaking article some years ago - seriously, when I first read the article years ago, I actually looked at the title and exclaimed ""well, duh"" - and when you have more than one young child, the work explodes on a seemingly exponential level.
column4: But that work is also played out against a backdrop of anticipation, hope, love and at times, pure joy.&nbsp
column5: But there will come a time when the Bell Curve starts to slope downwards and while you are still approaching, at, or near the plateau, your own parents will start to descend that slope.&nbsp
column6: The parent's decline can be gradual and it certainly doesn't occur across all the phases - mental, emotional, physical - of the person.&nbsp
column7: But there can and probably will come a time when there's a break in the elder parent's descent and it goes beyond the capacity of one or both parents to manage it in the moment.&nbsp
column8: Falls that once would have left a bruise now leave a break and if the parent is sufficiently elderly, the break can create a cascade effect flowing further to the downside.&nbsp
column9: Middle-aged moments of forgetting what you needed from upstairs become senior moments of forgetting to turn off a gas range or even where you live when you take a walk.&nbsp
column10: These are the situations that bring the phone calls soliciting help from the elders and lead to an entirely new dimension of adulthood:&nbsp

column1: The slang term for the situation is being sandwiched because of the pressure that's felt from being responsible for both sides.
column2: While it makes sense on one level, it's also deceptive.&nbsp
column3: What's really happening is that you're simultaneously being stretched as the demands of each surrounding generation pull you in one direction and then in another.&nbsp
column4: If you've waited to have children until you're older, then the stretch is even more pronounced as you might find yourself visiting both pediatrician and geriatrician in the same week.&nbsp
column5: Trying to juggle making an appointment for the kid with the work schedule?&nbsp
column6: Now toss in having to make an appointment for your infirm father and the tension from the stretch becomes palpable.&nbsp
column7: As the American family has gone nuclear and mobile, creating physical distance between the adult generations, the response has been a budding growth industry for assisting the elderly when the adult children are absent.&nbsp
column8: The elderly with sufficient assets can enter full-spectrum retirement communities able to meet their needs as they age
column9: the parents can purchase a cottage and if and when the need arises, they can then shift to an apartment and later, be assured of a bed in assisted-living or skilled care.&nbsp
column11: Purchase a chairlift for the stairs or modify the bathtub to account for increasing issues with balance.&nbsp
column12: Hire a person to come visit for periods of time to combat the cumulative effects of isolation upon the mental faculties.&nbsp

column1: There's a downside to this however and my wife noted it, in of all places, a commercial for Priceline.com.
column2: The gist of the commercial was that another market segment for discount travel was for those who needed to get to elderly relatives quickly and inexpensively, because emergencies don't allow the luxury of planning six months ahead for the best rates.&nbsp
column3: In the commercial, an elderly woman was hiring someone to do repair work and the contractor was then coaxing her out of her social security number.&nbsp
column4: That came on the heels of a recent phone conversation between my wife and her own mother, who'd related how an upset elderly neighbor had visited, frustrated that she had allowed herself to divulge her bank account information and number to an unknown person on the phone.&nbsp
column5: This isn't to necessarily imply that all businesses oriented towards the elder market are shady, because they aren't.&nbsp
column6: But it is a real and added concern for the adult children because they don't want to see their parents manipulated and gulled.

column1: There is a common factor amongst the previous two paragraphs and it's one of which I am highly mindful as I look ahead:
column2: assets.
column3: We've predicated our family structure and society upon a model that requires assets for optimal performance.&nbsp
column4: Americans are living longer and encountering aging issues that didn't exist before simply because people died before they could reach the point at which the issues became relevant in the aggregate.&nbsp
column5: But the American family isn't in the same situation as it was during our grandparent's generation.&nbsp
column6: The costs of healthcare and higher education are disproportionately higher relative to family income than two decades ago, yet the family and individual now must bear a greater burden than before...and on a family income that is, in the aggregate, declining.&nbsp
column7: The private assets simply aren't there to support such a model for more than another generation and it's already leading to generational warfare between the likes of AARP and the Millenials as squabbling begins for the allocation of public assets.&nbsp
column8: While raising children can bring the emotions of anticipation, hope and joy, what I honestly feel as I look forward isn't tension, but foreboding.&nbsp
column9: On a personal level, is this something I can expect?&nbsp
column11: Frustration and fear because I might be increasingly incapable of navigating a technological system that's opaque to an elder American for its complexity?&nbsp
column12: Hell, I have difficulty figuring out the new smartphone already...what's going to happen when I'm three-quarters deaf and expected to walk through an automated phone registration system for some program or another?
column13: As my late grandmother used to say, being old ain't for sissies.

column1: That leads to the last aspect of being stretched.
column2: The model for aging in America will have to change and as we grope our way forward to whatever that new model is going to be, it's incumbent upon me to figure out how to model an appropriate behavior upon which my own children can draw as they move into adulthood.&nbsp
column3: My own parents dealt with their parents from a nuclear family's distance of 225 miles, although one parent had a sibling nearby to her mother.&nbsp
column4: Until the bitter end, it was managed via phone calls and the occasional visit to handle business and it's not terribly far removed from the way that many of their peers managed as well.&nbsp
column5: But the stresses of American society are such that it's not so operative anymore and it will be better for all involved if the kids are more closely attuned to their parents' situation, even if they aren't necessarily living down the street.&nbsp
column6: How often can I make medical appointments?&nbsp
column7: How do I honor a parent's desire for independence and yet assure safety for the parent and others?&nbsp
column8: What arrangements must I make if I'm responsible yet want to take a week vacation with the family?&nbsp
column9: How do I manage my own frustrations as ancient issues resurface after decades of living on my own as an adult?&nbsp
column10: What must I do to prepare so that I can be on good relations and make their own way easier as they eventually move into this role?

column2: I don't believe that there's any one perfect way of addressing any situation.&nbsp
column3: You determine the parameters within which you have to work and then figure out a mechanism that's best for the given set of parameters and even then, it's not going to be perfect.&nbsp
column4: But I'm mindful that the parameters within which our country has operated are changing and doing so rapidly and that simply is creating additional pressure because we're now in the position of not just being sandwiched between generations, but being sandwiched between systems.

The data is collected and calculated for the March 2016 edition of the PracticalDad Price Index and once again, the Index has declined as deflation now roars through the grocery stores.
column2: The PracticalDad Index marketbasket consists of 47 items from a standard grocery store that are commonly purchased by a family on a budget.
column3: These items compose the Total Index and for March 2016, the Total Index for this marketbasket was 102.86 (November 2010 = 100.00) and was down a full basis point from February's level of 103.86.&nbsp
column4: The Food-Only Subindex is composed of the 37 foodstuff items within the basket and in March was actually less, at 102.85 (November 2010 = 100.00) and declined by a considerable 1.42 basis points from February's Subindex reading of 104.27.&nbsp

column2: The PracticalDad Price Index began in November 2010 as a kitchen-table project to ascertain what was actually happening to food prices on a family level.&nbsp
column3: The Federal Reserve had commenced the first of three efforts at Quantitative Easing, an untried and novel approach to kickstart economic activity by flooding the financial system with liquidity.&nbsp
column4: The QE programs were the brainchild of the then-chairman Ben Bernanke, an economics professor whose academic expertise lay in the errors of his Great Depression era predecessors in the effort to fend off the deflation that laid waste to the global economy.&nbsp
column5: It was only natural that such an untried policy approach gave rise to immense debate over it's ultimate impact and whether it would fail, create the unicorn-like moderated inflation of 2% or tear the economy a new one that spewed a raging storm of inflation.&nbsp
column6: Yeah, good times...&nbsp
column7: But for all of the conversation about isolated items rising or falling in price, or the closely followed CPI, how would this play out in the marketbasket composed of items purchased by the common American family?&nbsp
column8: And so the PracticalDad Price Index was born.&nbsp

column1: So in five years and trillions of dollars created and injected into the Financial system by the Federal Reserve via three separate QE programs, what has been the result?
column2: From the period of November 2010 to November 2015, the Federal Reserve more than doubled the asset holdings on its balance sheet, seeing an increase from approximately $3 Trillion to $7 Trillion while the DJIA during the period of November 2010 to March 2016 rose by 60%, from 11124 to 17829.
column3: The gap between the uber-wealthy and the average American increased in terms of amount of assets owned by the top .1% - that's top one-tenth - now equals that owned by the bottom 90%.
column4: So Ferrari and other luxury car firms sold more, and the prices taken by collector's artwork at auction increased as well.&nbsp
column5: But that's on the upper end of the spectrum.

column1: What's happened on the lower end of the spectrum is a far, far different thing.
column2: By 2014, the most recent year for which Census Bureau figures for median household income are available, the median household income was 6.5% lower than the same category in 2007 ($53,657 vs $57,357), the last year prior to the Financial Crisis.
column3: The number of Americans receiving SNAP benefits rose from 44 Million in December, 2010 to 45.4 Million in November, 2015.&nbsp
column4: This is the human face of deflation:&nbsp
column5: deflation isn't just prices mechanistically declining on a grocery-basket basis, it's the result of thousands of grocers and suppliers working to maintain sales and profitability in the face of lower incomes, competing demands and increased hunger amongst millions.&nbsp
column6: Deflation occurs by substituting lower priced brands of food from cheaper suppliers across a broad range of foodstuffs.&nbsp
column7: And if the quality has to suffer, so be it.&nbsp
column8: Deflation is not a sudden event but instead a steady grind as economic pressures sand down incomes with the result that the suppliers and producers have no choice but to lower their prices so as to maintain sales and hopefully, profitability.

column1: When economists talk about inflation and deflation, it's treated much as any other abstract principal and the essential humanity behind them is lost.
column2: When I finally saw The Big Short with Middle the other week, I noted the scene in which two young hedge fund managers are in Las Vegas and break into celebration when they find that their mentor, Ben Rickert (Brad Pitt), has been able to secure the credit default swaps that will - hopefully - pay off massively when the housing market breaks.
column3: But Rickert simply stares at them and reminds them that for all of the statistics, there are people who will suffer.&nbsp
column4: Lost homes and bankruptcies, broken families and dislocation, and the two become more grave at the reality.&nbsp
column5: And so it is with deflation.&nbsp
column6: Prices will fall, but there is a cost to it.&nbsp
column7: The human face of deflation within the PracticalDad Price Index is one of hunger and quiet desperation.&nbsp
column8: It is the face of millions of Americans requiring government assistance to put food on their tables.&nbsp
column9: It is the face of the Food Bank manager who has to once again search out donors to help replenish the shelves for those in need.&nbsp
column10: It is the face of the elementary school student who receives a backpack each Friday afternoon during the school year, filled with enough food to sustain her through the course of the weekend until she returns to school and a free lunch the following Monday.&nbsp
column11: It is in the face of the elder who has to choose whether to spend precious funds on food or medication.&nbsp
column12: It is the face of the Boy Scout who participates in an annual national food drive to replenish food banks, and whose family is possibly going to have to utilize that food in another week.

column1: This project began out of an intellectual interest in what was occurring on a policy level.
column2: But maintaining it for the past five years - following the same 47 items - has become more than an intellectual exercise.&nbsp
column3: It has brought an awareness of the faces within those stores and with that, a frank anger at the hubris and detachment of so many of the political and financial elite.&nbsp
column4: Listen to what is being said and the manner in which it is presented.&nbsp
column5: But most importantly, try to move beyond the language and see the effects upon the humanity which will ultimately feel the impact of the proposals.&nbsp
column6: This affects our neighbors, co-workers and classmates.&nbsp
column7: This affects us and most importantly, it affects our children.&nbsp
column8:
Because God forbid that the face of the youngster looking at the stark choice is our own child.

Before he departed for his freshman year in college, Middle and I were talking about student debt and the high cost of a college degree.
column2: He looked at me and asked ""How in the hell did this happen?""
column3: This article is the third in a series that tries to make sense of what in the hell did happen to so disproportionately ratchet up the costs of higher education.

column1: The cost of a degree didn't just skyrocket willy-nilly over the course of decades, much as the shuttle Challenger didn't just explode and the Titanic didn't just sink.
column2: In each instance, there were a variety of reasons that came together to set the stage for the events in question by guaranteeing that higher education now had a far more massive demand for its services than ever existed previously in American history.&nbsp
column3: In terms of the demand for higher education, the first factor was globalization and the knowledge-based economy.
column4: The theory was that the lower-end and unpleasant manufacturing would be farmed out overseas and the Americans would, in their wisdom and foresight (and for those with Asperger's, this is sarcasm), keep the higher-end technical manufacturing, administrative and service functions here.&nbsp
column5: The second factor - and the one that we'll explore here - is also business-related:&nbsp
column6: starting in the 1970s and afterwards, the business community shifted the educational baseline for employment from the high school diploma to the college degree.

column1: A reasonable part of the shift during the last quarter of the twentieth century was objective.
column2: The baseline for academic performance - rightly or wrongly - is the SAT and since the the Golden Era of the 1960s, the average SAT scores on both the verbal and math components had dropped consistently.
column3: There was also continuing criticism of the public school system and its apparent inability to prepare young people to compete in the workplace.&nbsp
column4: No, folks, what we discuss today has been around in one form or another for decades.&nbsp
column5: American business through the 1970s and 1980s was in the process of having its lunch eaten by the Japanese and Germans and entire industries were simply being destroyed.&nbsp
column6: Remember the textile industry?&nbsp
column7: Foreign competition was hungrier and the sense was that the former Axis powers had lost the Second World War but were well into the process of winning the peace.&nbsp
column8: Given these factors, the push was on in the business world to recruit more and more college graduates to work instead of those with potentially suspect high school diplomas.&nbsp
column9: Hey, our high schoolers might be idiots but the good ones go through the still-respected college system and are ready to roll in the workforce was the attitude.
column10: If you are old enough to recall the stories about Ford Pintos catching fire and Chrysler employees sending cars out the factory doors with empty bottles rattling around inside the car doors, it actually made sense.&nbsp
column11: This gave the kids another four years to mature and gain a better education in preparation for the world.

column1: But increasing global competitiveness wasn't the only reason that businesses shifted their baselines upwards.
column2: The other reason was simply a question of cosmetics and I was privileged to be intimately acquainted with two separate instances of cosmetic baseline changes.&nbsp
column3: The first instance was cosmetic in terms of appearance to other businesses.&nbsp
column4: My first real job was when an employer hired me as part of its first group of college-educated ""professional"" hires for a particular operational area.&nbsp
column5: It was the job that actually paid me enough money to allow myself to move out of the family household, where I'd lived for a year after my own college graduation and it pertained to ceded reinsurance.
column6: You can certainly refer back to the link, but the best real-world example is that of a bookie laying off bets with other bookies so that he isn't wiped out should that million-to-one shot actually pay off.&nbsp
column7: Many insurance policies were written with reinsurance provisions that allowed a company with a large loss to be reimbursed by other companies and it was my job, along with the others, to review all of these losses and first ascertain if a reinsurance provision existed, then determine the amount to be billed and finally to get the money back from them.&nbsp
column8: It is an arcane, technical arena of insurance and the hubs for such work are all in major cities such as New York, Los Angeles, Munich, Atlanta and London.&nbsp
column9: My hire came about because the operations director for my new employer had looked around and noticed that everyone with whom his department interacted to retrieve the monies had, at the minimum, a bachelor's degree and in his mind, they'd be more willing to pay if they had faith in the competence of the people doing the billing.&nbsp
column11: But the reality was that with adequate training, the job didn't actually require a college degree as much as the capacity to focus and a simple willingness to learn and this was something that the majority of the existing non-college staff had in abundance.&nbsp
column12: We new hires did have to undergo two full weeks of classroom training before the director even allowed us onto the floor to shadow our non-degreed trainers and to say that it was uncomfortable was an understatement.&nbsp
column13: The demand for a degree was further fueled when these same staffers were told that if they wanted to go anywhere else within the company at or above their pay-grade, they would now require a college degree.

column1: The second instance of a cosmetic baseline change was to demonstrate perceived competence to prospective customers, even if the job again didn't require a college degree.
column2: <em>Hey, we're better!&nbsp
column3: Our people have college degrees!
column4: I left the reinsurance position to move to a smaller city where my better half was in school.&nbsp
column5: There was no hope of another reinsurance job but I managed to swing another hire as a commercial claims adjuster for a regional insurance carrier.&nbsp
column6: It is a mystery greater than the disappearance of Amelia Earhart that the claims manager and supervisor actually hired me since I had no actual experience doing this and simply had to learn on the spot, absorbing information and settling claims across a spectrum of insurance lines - workers' compensation, commercial and auto liability.&nbsp
column7: But it was also another uncomfortable situation since that company had instituted a college-degree requirement for all claims adjusters.&nbsp
column8: That meant that any future hires into adjusting positions had to be college graduates and that any future promotion for an adjuster was predicated upon the completion of a degree
column9: another increase in the aggregate demand for a degree.&nbsp
column10: Because I didn't receive the home office training received by new hires with a degree, I was literally dependent upon the goodwill of those around me, most especially those non-degreed adjusters now locked into a position.&nbsp
column11: When one of these adjusters - Bette - asked me to help clarify her purported confusion about a liability case, I agreed to do so and then smuggled the file out of the office to study it that evening to find the appropriate response.&nbsp
column12: When I gave her my response the following morning, I passed her test.

column1: Bette was the perfect microcosm for the debate on whether a degree was truly necessary.
column2: A claims adjuster is the person who proverbially walks behind cleaning up after the elephant parade
column3: the adjuster is dealing with those who have had a loss and it's not uncommon to take undeserved heat arising from misplaced anger.&nbsp
column4: The questions that arise also beg answers that don't come from calculators:&nbsp
column5: <em>How do you compensate someone for damage to an arm or leg?&nbsp
column6: Does a person who is considered ugly deserve less for a scar than someone who isn't considered ugly?&nbsp
column7: How much does someone deserve for pain and suffering?
column8: It was Bette's handling of a particular case that taught me a life lesson in assessing value, detail and negotiation.&nbsp
column9: Our insured store's security had publicly and wrongly detained an African-American educator in a neighborhood store for alleged shoplifting, immediately afterwards releasing him when the manager realized his innocence.&nbsp
column10: A claim was filed for wrongful detention and the insured wanted to see it negotiated promptly so as to avoid a publicly humiliating trial.&nbsp
column11: The case was assigned to Bette and she visited the educator and his wife, departing their home with the skeleton of what became a mutually satisfactory settlement after only the first visit.&nbsp
column12: What she noticed on the visit was a variety of travel magazines on the coffee and end tables and she used that as a departure point for cordial conversation.&nbsp
column13: After they began to discuss their claim, it became the segue to a settlement when she tied a potential amount to the cost of a vacation in their dream locale.&nbsp
column14: The upshot was that the couple happily had a two week vacation for considerably less than a possible jury verdict.&nbsp
column15: This case demonstrated more than anything that the college degree was utterly irrelevant to performance of the job at hand.&nbsp
column16: There was nothing about 120 credits of academia that could have successfully concluded this case, or almost any other for that matter.&nbsp
column17: What was required for a successful career was simply native intelligence, good people skills and an acute ability to observe.

column1: There is a time and a place for higher education.
column2: I want my bridge-builder and aircraft designer to have a good basis in engineering, which can only come from concentrated study.&nbsp
column3: I want my Family Practitioner and medical researcher to likewise have skills that only arise from concentrated study.&nbsp
column4:
But the simple reality is that we've allowed ourselves to be told that the only route to financial success is via a college degree and business hiring has now cast that into cement and again, the only winner is the institution of higher education.

The conversation occurred one evening when Middle was home from college on break.
column2: Given the political primaries occurring shortly, it naturally pertained to politics and where we stood on the issues.&nbsp
column3: But as the time passed, the discussion widened from specific issues and candidates to one of more general political leanings and it was here that I learned that Middle was now classifying himself as a Democratic Socialist cut from the European mold.&nbsp
column4: He likewise noted that many of his peers and friends now were leaning in that general direction and it was certainly in sync with the recent article that ","none",,"xhtml",,NULL,,NULL
